title: When a Rock God Meets Some of His Mortal Fans
description: In popular music, as in algebra, certain formulas apply. For example, inspiration equals romance. Sex churns in the rhythmic bottom of pop and the spirit emanates in its upmost harmonies. God and libido meet in the middle.

title: LOSS WIDENS AT GENUITY
description: Genuity Inc., an Internet-services provider that first sold shares to the public in June, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss widened because it spent more on marketing and set aside money in case customers fail to pay their bills. The loss widened to $284.1 million, or 29 cents a share, from $182.8 million, or 23 cents, a year earlier. The per-share results assume conversion of class B stock. Revenue rose 55 percent to $312.8 million. Genuity, whose network transmits Internet data, expects sales to rise 40 percent this year, missing forecasts for growth of 55 percent to 65 percent, its chief financial officer said.

title: Metro Matters; The Senator Doth Protest Too Little
description: LET us accept Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's contention that she was completely uninvolved in the presidential pardon of Marc Rich, a fugitive commodities trader accused of tax evasion. Ditto the former president's decision to reduce the sentences of four Hasidic men from New Square, N.Y., who were convicted of defrauding the government.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Tuesday about an acknowledgment by the chief executive of Cisco Systems that the company's business was slow in January carried an erroneous credit. It was by Bloomberg News, not Reuters.

title: Corrections

He was Krzysztof Jassem, not Krzystof.

title: Labelers That Whir Rather Than Click
description: FOR a time during the late 1960's and early 1970's, every family seemed to have one member, usually male, who left his mark in thin strips of embossed plastic. He branded his name on prized possessions with 3/8-inch-high, self-adhesive plastic tapes, fastidiously labeled every workshop drawer and posted critical instructions about the fuse box.

title: Medicine for the Economy
description: It has been a rough few weeks economically. Americans have been receiving their sobering year-end 401(k) statements in the mail and reading about energy crises and layoffs at companies ranging from DaimlerChrysler to Amazon.com. Somber-looking politicians have taken to the airwaves to worry about a potential recession, a malady that the much-hyped ''new economy'' had supposedly rendered obsolete. It is no wonder that the index tracking consumer confidence in the economy's future has taken its steepest single-month nosedive in a decade.

title: Weekend at Bernie's III: He's Dead but the Party's Not
description: Ossama Fawzi's ghoulish satire, ''Fallen Angels Paradise,'' goes where few films have gone before by suggesting that life in society's lower depths can be a loathsome kind of utopia. That doesn't mean the movie's portrayal of Cairo's grubby street life is at all sanitized.

title: Boarders Will Leave the Slopes For a Battle of the Thumbs
description: When some of the best snowboard athletes meet next week for the ESPN Winter X Games, they will have to share their arena with snowboarders who are masters of a smaller domain: the PlayStation 2 video game console. For the first time, video gamers will be an official part of a flesh-and-blood athletic competition, which is scheduled for Feb. 3 in Mount Snow, Vt. Some professional snowboarders are expected to take on video gamers on the digital slopes of Snowboarding, a game by Konami of America. Besides bragging rights, the winner will be given a gold medal. The video game finals will be broadcast on Monday evening on ESPN. MICHEL MARRIOTT

title: An English Bookshop Branches Out
description: Potterton Books, at the Old Rectory, Sessay, Thirsk, North Yorkshire, England, has opened its first American shop on the ground floor of the D&D Building, 979 Third Avenue. The shop, which specializes in interior design and decorative arts, sells new and old books as well as reproductions of antique catalogs and books. It also searches for rare out-of-print items. The owner, Clare Jameson, ships anywhere. Open to the public weekdays from 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; (212) 644-2292.

title: New President Inherits a Paralyzed Congo
description: When Congo's new president, Joseph Kabila, delivered his much anticipated first address to the nation on state television last Friday, he seldom raised his eyes from the 17-page speech on the desk before him.

title: ADOBE FALLS AFTER SALES WARNING
description: Shares of Adobe Systems Inc. tumbled more than 17 percent yesterday, a day after the software publisher warned that the weakening economy could bite into its quarterly sales. In a statement released late Tuesday, Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., said business had slowed in some markets, particularly in the United States, and that the softness in the United States could affect its revenue outlook for the quarter. After dropping as low as $42.38 yesterday, Adobe shares rebounded slightly to close at $43.69, down $9.06 from Tuesday. The company said it will spend cautiously in an effort to achieve its earnings goals for the quarter, which ends March 2. The consensus Wall Street forecast calls for a profit of 30 cents a share. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: ANGLOGOLD POSTS LOSS
description: Anglogold, the world's biggest gold miner, announced a $16.9 million loss for the fourth quarter, after the company's decision to write down the value of some of its struggling mines. Anglogold is trying to reposition itself in the gold industry by unloading its least profitable ventures, and the write-down, which totaled nearly $93 million, is a reminder of the reasons behind that strategy. With its huge global operation and its high overhead costs, Anglo is poorly suited to manage some of the low-margin mines in its stable, especially with the gold price stagnant and showing little promise of an upswing. The write-down offset a 9 percent rise in operating profit to $114 million.

title: ALCATEL SEES LOWER GROWTH
description: The French telecommunications equipment maker Alcatel, reported that net profit more than doubled in 2000 but reduced its forecast for sales growth this year because of a slowdown in the United States. The chief executive, Serge Tchuruk, said Alcatel had reduced its expected sales growth figure to the lower end of 20 to 25 percent. Alcatel had earlier predicted growth of 25 percent. Net profit for 2000 was 1.32 billion euros ($1.21 billion), down from 644 million euros ($597 million) in 1999. Alcatel's shares were up 6 percent in Paris.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNER, STANLEY ''BUZZ''
description: BRAUNER-Stanley ''Buzz'', 70, musician, of Emerson, NJ, formerly of Paramus, beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Seltzer), devoted father of Stephen and Jeffrey and the ''girls they brought us'': Shari and Jennifer, loving grandfather of Matthew, Melissa, Ryan, Adam and Michael. Buzz played every woodwind instrument in his profession. He started his career at age 15 with Art Mooney's band, and was the jazz tenor saxophone soloist with Tommy and Jimmy Dorsey until their demise. He served in the U.S. Army from 1954-1956 appearing on TV with Arlene Francis on Soldier Parade. He played on Broadway in Hello Dolly, 1776, and A Chorus Line as well as many others, on records with Harry Chapin, Nat King Cole, and Barbara Streisand and on many radio and TV commercials. Buzz retired in 1983 due to Parkinson's disease but remained active with hobbies such as photography. Donations to any Parkinson's Disease Research Foundation would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYMUDES, VICTOR THE ''VILLAGE''
description: MAYMUDES-Victor the ''Village''. Philosopher who as mentor, manager and friend guided Bob Dylan down the road from obscurity to icon in the early sixties, died peacefully on January 26th 2001 in UCLA Hospital, Santa Monica, California. On that journey he was protected and comforted by the presence and courage of his children Aerie Victoria and Jacob. He was sixty-five. Victor was the son of the respected liberal left-wing Los Angeles activists, Golda and Abraham Maymudes and the brother of August and Zicel; growing up the music and rhetoric of humanism, anti-fascism and civil rights was the food on their table. Late-sixties Victor stepped off the music stage to homestead in Northern New Mexico, his hands turned to chopping wood and carpentry, his heart to loving his family. 1986 until 1996 he returned to Dylan's side as a personal manager. The last years of his life were spent traveling and writing his memoirs. The product of that effort, ''The Joker and the Thief'' was scheduled for publication by Saint Martins Press in 2002. Above all, Victor appreciated the value of music, the poetry in a well-turned phrase. ''Song is the ultimate repository of human civilization,'' he maintained, ''it's a resting place for one heart and translates the soul of culture for all.''

title: Allowing Tchaikovsky To Mean What He Wanted
description: The title of the New Jersey Symphony's recent three-week festival, ''Meanings of Tchaikovsky,'' seemed to imply an attempt to make a weighty case for the deeper seriousness of a composer who is probably most familiar to a large segment of the audience as a writer of high-calorie ballets. But judging by its final program, heard Saturday night at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the festival didn't make the mistake of trying to force Tchaikovsky's music to prove some larger point; it simply presented the composer, in the words of the festival consultant, Joseph Horowitz, at ''his most autobiographical and programmatic.'' And the result, thanks not least to the symphony's fine playing under Zdenek Macal, was well worth hearing.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Unsteady Start

title: I.B.M. FORMING LINUX UNIT
description: Linux, the free computer operating system, got another boost with an announcement yesterday by I.B.M. that it will spend $300 million to develop Linux consulting services over the next three years. Irving Wladawsky-Berger, left, an I.B.M. vice president, said this would help Linux, which is an open-source version of the Unix operating system, ''move into the mainstream'' by assuring corporate customers of its reliability and the availability of support services. The computer maker said it will pursue a strategy of selling bundles of hardware, software and services for Linux to its clients. The new Linux consulting services will include building e-business environments, educating users about open-source computing, and designing Linux networks. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Grab Your Goggles: The Vespa Vrooms Back
description: Americans first met the Vespa, the jaunty Italian motor scooter, in 1953 when Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck rode one in ''Roman Holiday,'' above right. For several decades it was the cool means of transportation for American college students, academics and artists. Then in the 80's, poof, the Vespa disappeared from American roadways, having run up against stringent emissions regulations. Now? Jerry Seinfeld has one, and so does Christie Brinkley. And they are legal, because the new Vespas fully satisfy American emissions requirements. Available in eight fashion colors (including iridescent pearl, pearlized green and pearlized blue), the Vespa will be the way to get to the beach this summer. The 50-cc model ($2,950, above left) requires only a driver's license; you will need a motorcycle license for the 150-cc ($3,950). From Vespa at www.vespa.com or (800) 631-1101, or at Manhattan Motorcars, 270 11th Avenue (27th Street).

Surviving are her deeply loving husband, Max, her adoring children, Ellen and Ronald Murphy and Donald and Diane Cohen; her four adoring grandchildren, Emily and Jared Cohen and Alexandra and Joanna Murphy; and by her brother and sister-in-law, Alan and Bobby Mirken. She will be fondly remembered by her many very close friends. Services Thursday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau No. Chapels,'' 55 No. Station Plaza (opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Connecticut Dreaming: Skateboard Parks
description: It's hard growing up a skateboarder in leafy Greenwich, Conn. Signs posted on public property say, ''Skateboarding and Inline Skating Prohibited.'' The best nearby skate park is in Ridgefield, 30 miles away. The Junior League of Greenwich was aware of the problem and asked a local architect, Vincent Colangelo, at left in the photograph, to come up with a pro bono solution. He turned to his crack advisers, his son, Gian Colangelo, 12, center, and his son's friends Alex Jones, 13, right, and Luke Bace, 12, not pictured. If the Junior League and the town's Parks and Recreation Department can find a 10,000-square-foot site, preferably paved, something like a big parking lot, their skateboard park (computer rendering top) might be built. It would have curvy semicircular walls called half-pipes and shorter ones called quarter-pipes, as well as pyramids and rails, and possibly even a street spine, a ramp shaped like a pagoda roof. The design team visited the Ridgefield park, and went on the Internet to sites like www.skatepark.org for inspiration. ''The kids hand-drew 16 different ramps they liked -- an 11-foot half-pipe, pipe rails, street spines, boxes and pyramids,'' said Mr. Colangelo, who incorporated their ideas into the computer model. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW YORK ECONOMY SLOWS
description: The New York City economy slowed a little this month, but remained relatively strong, according to a monthly business survey that serves as a barometer of local business conditions. The report from the New York division of the National Association of Purchasing Management, a trade group, suggests that while the economy has been contracting since November, business managers recently became more optimistic about the outlook for the rest of the year. Leslie Eaton

title: TENNECO AUTOMOTIVE TO TRIM AN ADDITIONAL 405 POSITIONS
description: Tenneco Automotive said yesterday that it planned to eliminate up to an additional 405 salaried positions worldwide, because of increasingly difficult industry conditions in the automotive supply market. The job cuts follow 700 layoffs announced in October. The latest cost-reduction plan is expected to be fully completed by the end of the first quarter in 2002, Tenneco said, adding that the two rounds of job reductions will pare the company's salaried staff by 22 percent. Tenneco, which is based in Lake Forest, Ill., expects about $27 million in annual savings from the latest reduction. and about $45 million in annual savings from the earlier program. Charges related to the latest job cuts are expected to total up to $14 million in 2001.

title: Fans Lead The Taunts In Another Collapse
description: The Nets had been battered and booed, yet had hung around with seemingly little reason into the final minutes of tonight's game against the Detroit Pistons. Having cut the deficit to 3 points, the Nets forced Jerome Williams to lose the ball as he drove the lane. But just as they had all night, the Nets watched as the Pistons chased down the loose ball, with Williams grabbing it along the baseline and passing it to Ben Wallace, who flipped it to Jerry Stackhouse beyond the 3-point line. And then the Nets had nothing left.

title: Why the Classics Are Retranslated
description: I confess that it's been years since I thought about rereading ''Beowulf'' or ''The Inferno,'' but now I have new translations of each before me so it seems the moment to re-examine them, both as a reader and as a columnist. I remember them from high school as rousing tales in their own ways, with blood and guts and dragons, beasts and passion and lust. Both very different from ''Silas Marner,'' for instance, which was the literary castor oil that generations of high school students were also forced to choke down.

title: Chime Communications Agrees to Purchase LNS
description: Chime Communications in London, which owns agencies like Howell Henry Chaldecott Lury & Partners and Harvard Public Relations, agreed yesterday to buy LNS Communication in Cambridge, Mass. It is Chime's first acquisition in the United States.

title: Bush Calls Putin, Who Brings Up Kremlin Figure Held in U.S.
description: In what appears to be the longest and most substantive of his conversations with foreign leaders, President Bush initiated a 15-minute telephone call to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today. Mr. Putin raised the case of a former Kremlin aide now under arrest in New York on charges of money laundering, Russian officials said.

title: Evil Stalks These All-Too-Familiar Streets
description: RESIDENT EVIL 3: NEMESIS, from Capcom, raises the question, How many times can you release the same game and get away with it? Wandering the same streets of the same burning city killing the same flesh-eating zombies, it is difficult to distinguish Nemesis from the predecessors Resident Evil 2 and Resident Evil: Code Veronica. And while I never played the original Resident Evil, I suspect that it would not seem unfamiliar.

title: Amazon Offer Links Profit To Share Price
description: Amazon.com announced today that it was offering to lower the price of existing employee options, making it subject to an accounting rule that will directly tie its financial results to fluctuations in its shares.

description: YANGSHUO, China -- WHEN Li You picks up a pen, he finds that with increasing frequency he can't remember how to write the Chinese characters he learned to write as a child. The delicate strokes scramble themselves in the hazy recesses of his memory, eluding his brain's insistent summons to order.

Devoted sister of Janice and Harold Orbuch & adoring grandmother of Joshua, Rachel, Michael and Rebecca. Elaine's integrity, generosity, compassion in addition to her wonderful charm, sense of humor and personal friendship will be cherished memories by all who she touch. Funeral services today at 12PM at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: The Cole Investigation Proves Frustrating
description: Nearly four months after the bombing of the United States destroyer Cole in Aden harbor, early breakthroughs in the inquiry into the attack appear to have petered out, leaving American investigators with only circumstantial evidence, but no proof, of who was ultimately responsible for ordering the attack that killed 17 American sailors, and exactly how it was planned and carried out.

title: LECTRABEL PLANS LAYOFFS
description: The Belgian utilities group lectrabel said it planned to eliminate 1,700 jobs by 2003 as part of a revamping intended to refocus the company on its four core operations: electricity production, trading, network management and sales. Some employees in the noncore positions will be retrained and reassigned to the core operations, others will retire. The company expects to have to lay off about 800 employees of a total of 15,235. Paul Meller (NYT)

He was Sheik Hamad bin Jassim bin Jabr al-Thani, foreign minister of Qatar, not Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani, the emir.

title: The Lockerbie Verdict
description: The bombing that blew Pan Am Flight 103 out of the skies over Lockerbie, Scotland, more than a decade ago is impossible to forget. Just days before Christmas, 270 innocent people were killed, most of them Americans. Pictures of the plane's crumpled cockpit section are a haunting symbol of terrorism's random brutality. Yesterday a measure of justice caught up with one of the Libyan perpetrators. After a long-delayed trial, a panel of three Scottish judges unanimously convicted Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi of arranging the bombing. Another Libyan, Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, was acquitted.

title: WATCH SALES INCREASE
description: The Swiss watchmaker, the Swatch Group, said sales of its more expensive watches rose 30 percent last year, contributing to an 18 percent increase in sales to a record $2.58 billion. Swatch said it expected profit to grow at a higher rate than sales would. For 2001 sales, Swatch projected a rise of between 10 and 15 percent, lower than the 2000 figures. Swatch has not yet released its profit figures, but it is expcted to have earned more than $380 million. Swatch owns the Breguet, Blancpain, Omega and Longines brands as well as the Swatch and Flik Flak brands. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Ikea Cancels Plans for Store In Westchester
description: The city of New Rochelle and Ikea, the Swedish furniture company, said today that they were scrapping a proposal for a superstore that had elicited howls of outrage from Westchester County residents and had come to symbolize the growing fears of many in suburbia that development was eroding the quality of their lives.

title: McDONALD'S TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN SANDWICH STORE CHAIN
description: McDonald's said it will acquire a 33 percent stake in Pret A Manger, an up-market British sandwich-store chain seeking to expand in the United States. Financial terms were not disclosed. Pret A Manger's founders and shareholders will keep majority ownership and management control of the privately held company, which has $:100 million ($146 million)(pounds) in annual sales. Pret A Manger, founded in London in 1986, opened its first international outlet in New York last year.

title: A male sex symbol enjoys the company of larger women in a new campaign for Lane Bryant.
description: WOMEN don't have to be a size 6 or smaller for rich, powerful, handsome single men to find them desirable.

title: AVAYA EARNINGS DROP
description: Avaya Inc., a provider of communications systems for business and government agencies, said yesterday that its net income in the quarter ended Dec. 31 slid by 77 percent, to $16 million, or 3 cents a share, from $69 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Avaya, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J., attributed the decline to expenses related to its spinoff last year from Lucent Technologies. Excluding these expenses, the company met analysts' expectations for the quarter with net income of $51 million, or 16 cents a share, a decline of 24 percent. Avaya's revenue in the quarter fell 3.5 percent, to $1.79 billion, despite large contracts from customers like AmeriNet Inc., a health care group purchasing company, and the French central bank. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: CREDIT FOR DAEWOO MOTOR

The Korea Development Bank and other bank creditors agreed yesterday to provide the loans after they approved Daewoo's plan to cut 997.3 billion won ($789.3 million) in costs.

description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 1  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi today turned his personal welcome for the Libyan released in the Lockerbie bombing trial into a rambling tirade, both against the guilty verdict pronounced against the other defendant and the entire handling of the affair.

Her survivors include a son, William B. Chappell, Jr. of Pawling, NY, a daughter, Lydia Chappell of Cos Cob, CT, two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Friday, February 2, at 11AM at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mt. Kisco, NY. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mount Kisco, New York 10549, or a charity of your choice.

title: One Year After Alaska Airlines Crash, Relatives Visit Ocean Site in Mourning
description: At Port Hueneme on the Southern California coast, relatives of those who died on Alaska Airlines Flight 261 were taken aboard boats today to visit the spot where the jet plunged into the Pacific Ocean exactly one year ago.

description: The Lloyds TSB Group made a third bid today to acquire Abbey National, a major mortgage lender, for $:19.8 billion ($29 billion) in cash and stock.

description: All the fears of a letdown against a lowly team one night after a victory over an elite team surfaced for the Devils tonight at Nassau Coliseum. New Jersey took a two-goal lead, then allowed the Islanders to come back with two goals in a 16-second span of the second period to tie it.

description: In a sign that problems are deepening in California's overburdened energy market, a division of the Enron Corporation that sells power directly to large industrial and commercial concerns has decided to halt such service to dozens of its clients because of the potential for mounting losses.

title: DIGITAL ISLAND AIMS TO SPEED PROFITABILITY
description: Digital Island Inc., a San Francisco-based Internet infrastructure company, said yesterday that it expects to break even by June 2002, two quarters earlier than expected. With $439 million in cash and marketable securities, the company said it was fully funded until then. In the quarter ending June 2002, the company expects its revenues to match expenditures on a cash-flow basis. For the current year, the company lowered its annual revenue expectations by $20 million, to between $170 million and $175 million. It said it would cut capital outlays by $75 million, to $225 million, and predicted that its annual loss would beat Wall Street's estimates of $7.51 a share by 6 cents. For the quarter that ended Dec. 31, the company said it lost $142.5 million, or $1.82 a share, matching analysts' expectations. T. L. Thompson, chief financial officer, said Digital Island had gained only 10 customers during the last quarter, bringing its roster to 959, partly because of its decision to shed smaller customers. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: CURRENTS: EXHIBITIONS; The Blob and Other Shapes That Loom on the Landscape
description: In addition to mussels and frites, one of the Belgo chain's restaurants in London, above, serves up considerable drama. Wooden bands appear to loosen from the ceiling and flutter overhead. The techno-hipsters at Foreign Office Architects, based in London, used digital modeling to map the shapes. A show, ''Folds, Blobs and Boxes: Architecture in the Digital Era,'' at the Heinz Architectural Center of the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh, examines those geometric shapes pre- and postcomputer. The 56-page catalog ($14.95) is by Joseph Rosa, the show's curator. Saturday to May 27; (412) 622-3131 or www.cmoa.org. MICKEY O'CONNOR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, REV. EDWARD P.
description: HOGAN-Rev. Edward P. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of a retired priest of the Diocese on January 29. Reposing in Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr., Rockaway Beach, Friday, February 2 from 1-5 PM. Mass of Transferral at St. Thomas More-St. Edmund Church, 204-25 Rockaway Point Blvd., Rockaway Point, Friday, February 2 at 7:30 PM. Funeral mass at St. Thomas More-St. Edmund Church Saturday, February 3 at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of The Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily, Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Mother Accused of Abusing Young Sons During Journey
description: The cross-country search for two little boys and their mother began on New Year's Day in Brooklyn with reports of abuse that caused child protection authorities to fear for the children's lives.

title: Article 2001020190536060952 -- No Title
description: STATE OF THE ART

title: Economy Grew at Slowest Rate in 5 Years in 4th Quarter
description: The United States economy grew at its slowest rate in more than five years during the final quarter of 2000, as businesses abruptly cut their spending on new equipment, the government said yesterday.

title: FED CUTS KEY RATE BY HALF A POINT, CITING SLOWDOWN
description: The Federal Reserve today cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point for the second time this month, making clear that it intends to wage an aggressive battle against the growing possibility of a recession.

title: New Cell Phone Batteries Harness the Power of the Sun
description: Cell phone users can extend their talking time with a little help from the sun. Canoga California-based Sunpower Systems Inc., has wedded a cell phone lithium-ion battery to a small array of solar cells that fit in a phone's regular battery slot. On a bright day, a 15-minute charge will support about one minute of talking time. In five hours it can fully charge a battery, says the Sunpower president, Henry Adams. ''You can charge the battery in the car, in the woods or at the beach,'' he said, ''so it's always ready if you need to make an emergency call.''

title: A Look at American Diversity, From Sea to Shining Sea
description: Call it ''This O-l-l-l-d House.'' ''Save Our History: Frontier Homes,'' a one-hour special on the History Channel on Feb. 9 at 10 p.m., shows the techniques involved in building the Pilgrims' post-and-beam homes, the log cabins put up in the Appalachians, the sod homes of the Great Plains and the adobe buildings of the Southwest, which got their European looks from Spanish settlers (below). A free online study guide to the program will be available at www.historychannel.com/classroom on Monday.

title: Times Promotes Executive
description: Alexis Buryk, a vice president for advertising at The New York Times, has been promoted to group vice president for advertising sales. Her appointment was announced yesterday by Jyll F. Holzman, senior vice president for advertising.

title: With 76ers Returning, Knicks Look for Big Lift
description: They stormed Madison Square Garden on Halloween, planted their red, white and blue flag at midcourt and beat the Knicks so badly that those sitting near the rafters showered the home team with derisive chants of ''PA-TRICK EW-ING.''

title: DiFrancesco Sworn In as Acting Governor
description: After 25 years in New Jersey government and 7 years in the shadow of a political celebrity, Donald T. DiFrancesco, a middle-of-the-road Republican from Scotch Plains, humbly took possession of one of the nation's most powerful governor's offices today as he was sworn in to fill out Christie Whitman's remaining 11 months in office.

title: Women's Health Resources: Sexually Transmitted Diseases

title: PAPER MERGER BLOCKED
description: The European Commission, the European Union's executive body, blocked a takeover of the Finnish paper producer Metsa Tissue by its Swedish competitor SCA Molnlycke. The deal would have stifled competition in the Scandinavian toilet-paper and paper-towel markets, the regulator said. With a combined market share as high as 90 percent in some markets, the commissioner for competition, Mario Monti, said he had no choice. It was the 14th merger or takeover to be blocked by the commission in more than 10 years, out of more than 1,500 cases it has examined.

title: Modestly Making the Trains Run on Time
description: E. VIRGIL CONWAY clearly would rather be doing a dozen other things than talking about himself. He is in constant motion. He leans back, then pulls up abruptly in the black leather chair in his Madison Avenue office. He takes off his glasses. He glances at his watch, as if he has a train to catch.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: HUMAN NATURE/Anne Raver; An Intrepid Voyager Broadens America's Garden Repertory
description: ON a gray day with sleet falling over the frozen fields of his farm in central Pennsylvania, Barry Yinger was telling the story of his search for a hardy camellia 20 years ago on an island off the coast of Korea. This veteran plant explorer, fluent in Japanese and Chinese, is transforming American gardens with hundreds of the exotic plants he finds in Asia. But pursuing a hardy camellia seemed like a quest for the Holy Grail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, DOROTHY (SACHS)
description: MARX-Dorothy (Sachs), 79, peacefully on January 30, 2001. after a courageous, high-spirited struggle with illness for five years. She was the flowing center and the welcoming heart for all who knew and loved her. We grieve her loss as we are inspired by her all-caring love, her exquisite taste and style, and her insistence on recognizing the goodness in everyone she knew: Herbert L. Marx, Jr., husband; Tedra Schneider, daughter; Michael Levine, son; Ellen Levine, daughterin-law; Violet Lapides and Eva Marcus, Timothy and Nan Marx, and Alison Marx; grandchildren and step-grandchildren Gregory, Andrew and Hilary Schneider; Benjamin and Samuel Levine; Victoria and Robert Frank; Alyssa, Ariel, Benjamin and Sophie Marx; and three generations of nieces and nephews who adored their ''Auntie Mame''. Dorothy was a graduate of New York University. She served as Personnel Director of Nytronics, Inc. and Personnel Manager for the natinal office of Hadassah. Later, she became the active proprietor of Dorothy Marx Art and Antiques Acquisitions. She was formerly married to Maurice Levine. For those who wish to make a contribution, please do so to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or to a charity or organization of the donor's choice. Funeral service will take place on Friday, February 2, at 11 AM at Temple Shaaray Tefila, Second Avenue and 79th Street, New York City. The family will receive visitors at the Temple beginning at 10 AM.

title: Sports of The Times; Branca Knew '51 Giants Stole Signs
description: FOR nearly half a century since Bobby Thomson hit the home run that won the 1951 National League pennant for the New York Giants, Ralph Branca, the Brooklyn Dodgers right-hander who threw that fastball, has known that the Giants were using a high-powered telescope and a buzzer system late that season at the Polo Grounds to alert their batters to the next pitch.

title: New From a Famous Name in Hand Embroidery
description: For 200 years, the House of Lesage has produced hand-embroidered fabric for the Paris couture. Recently, Jean Franois Lesage, the 35-year-old son of the company's owner, set up workshops in Madras, India, where 70 men are now hand-embroidering silk, linen and cotton for the home. A 24-inch silk pillow with a coral motif, above, is $395; a 16-inch square with a center design is $250. Both are at Bergdorf Goodman, 754 Fifth Avenue. Embroidered fabric is $90 to $580 a yard from the House of Lesage, 207 Rue St. Honor, Paris; 011-33-1-44-50-01-01.

title: When the Answer to 'Call Me' Is 'On Which Phone?'
description: Some people seem physically attached to their cell phones, and it's easy to see why. Having one makes it simple to stay in touch with friends and colleagues. But the reverse isn't always true: friends and colleagues are not always sure which phone -- cell, office or home -- to call. So they often have to dial more than one number to track down their peripatetic friends.

title: Blake's Tygers (And Much More) Burning Bright at the Tate
description: The poet, printmaker and painter William Blake (1757-1827) attracted only a narrow coterie of admirers during his lifetime, but in death he became a patron saint of a broad and eclectic range of followers: artists, composers, writers, rock singers, hippies, believers in the occult, student poster enthusiasts, designers of CD covers.

title: ORGANIC GROCER IN DISARRAY
description: The Iceland Group, a British supermarket chain that sought to capitalize on scares about genetically modified food by switching to organic products, was in disarray after its stock slumped and its chairman quit in the wake of a regulator's inquiry into a big sale of shares. Iceland said its full-year pretax profit would be just over half analysts' forecasts of about $:110 million ($160.9 million). Its shares fell 38.5 pence (56 cents), or 21 percent, to 149 pence ($2.18), a three-year low. Compounding the company's woes, Malcolm Walker, the chairman, resigned over a $:13.5 million ($19.8 million) stock sale before the company released poor year-end sales, prompting an inquiry by Britain's Financial Services Authority. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, CONSTANCE MYERS
description: ANDERSON-Constance Myers. On January 31st, 2001, at Crosslands, Kennett Square, PA, at the age of 102. Wife of the late Dr. Arthur Forrest Anderson of NY and Wilton, CT, she was the mother of Constance A. Tate of Wilton and the late Forrest G. Anderson. She leaves three grandsons: the Very Reverend Robert L. Tate of Chestnut Hill, PA, Gerald A. Tate of Olivenhain, CA, and John R. Tate of Trumbull, CT; also, seven greatgrandchildren. A graduate of Vassar College in 1919, she was a longtime volunteer leader of the YWCA, serving as Chairman and Board member of the NYC YWCA for many years; as President of the National YWCA from 1946-52 and Honorary Board member since then; and as a past member of the World YWCA Executive Council and lifelong member of the World Service Council. Mrs. Anderson was a founding member of the USO and a Vice President and Board member of the US Committee for UNICEF. During the sixties, she was a member of the Committee of Correspondence, which helped to train leaders from around the world. She was a member of the Riverside Church Board of Deacons and the Riverside Orchestra during her years in the city. A service will be held at Crosslands on February 25 at 3 P.M. with a later memorial service in Wilton. Donations in her memory may be made to the YWCA of the City of NY, 610 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10022.

title: Metro Business Briefing; BUFFALO UNEMPLOYMENT
description: The Buffalo-Niagara Falls area has tied with Miami as having the highest big-city unemployment rate in the country, according to data released yesterday by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The jobless rate in both areas in December was 4.9 percent; the New York City area ranked third at 4.8 percent. It could be worse: in Yuma, Ariz., a small city on the border with Mexico, the unemployment rate is 15.8 percent. Connecticut continued to dominate the list of places with low unemployment. Danbury and the Stamford-Norwalk area registered jobless rates in December of just 1 percent, the lowest of all metropolitan areas; Hartford, at 1.6 percent, was second-lowest among big cities, after San Jose, Calif. Leslie Eaton

title: AOL USERS ARE WARNED ON VIRUS
description: A rogue computer program that affects users of America Online has been making its way around the World Wide Web, the antivirus company McAfee.com announced yesterday. The program, known as a Trojan horse, arrives in the form of a file that is attached to an e-mail message with the subject line ''hey you''; the message suggests that the attachment, ''mine.zip,'' is a collection of pictures. When the user clicks on the icon for the file, the program infects the machine. The next time the user turns the machine on and connects to AOL, the program sends the user's online name and password to a number of foreign e-mail addresses, and it sends copies of itself to every person on the victim's ''buddy list.'' McAfee's chief information officer, Doug Cavit, said nearly 200,000 infected files had already been detected on the company's Web site. (Because computers might have three or more infected files, the estimated number of machines infected so far is 60,000.) The program has proliferated quickly, with the number of infected files doubling in the last three weeks, Mr. Cavit said. He added that the program represented a new breed of ''identity theft'' attacks that try to steal information instead of damaging files or computers. John Schwartz

title: A Desire Soaked in Pain, Confusion and Great Need
description: ''In the Mood for Love'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Elvis Mitchell's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 30. The film -- in Cantonese and Shanghainese, with English subtitles -- opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 62nd Street.

title: Monitoring New York's Police
description: In some ways, the most powerful voice for a reform can be the one that has long resisted it. When Mayor Rudolph Giuliani roared into office seven years ago, the city's new independent board monitoring complaints about the police was one of his primary targets. He cut its budget and squabbled about its makeup and mandate. Now, in the twilight of his mayoralty and with federal investigators in Brooklyn threatening an outside monitor for the police, Mr. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Bernard Kerik have unveiled a proposal to allow the Civilian Complaint Review Board to gain more control over prosecuting complaints against police officers. If the mayor carries through with sufficient budget and authority, he will have made a major swing toward ensuring a police force that could be more responsive to citizens' complaints.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: REPORT HURTS NETWORK APPLIANCE
description: Shares of Network Appliance Inc. fell $7.06, or 13 percent, to $46.56 after a Credit Suisse First Boston analyst cut his rating on the maker of network data-storage devices, saying it may lose sales to rivals. Network Appliance may lose sales to a rival, the EMC Corporation, which is selling new data storage-related products, the analyst, Amit Chopra, wrote in an advisory to clients. A spending slowdown by Internet-related companies also could hurt earnings at Network Appliance. He cut his rating on the shares to ''hold'' from ''buy.''

description: With his cabinet ministers under attack for what is widely seen as a sluggish and flustered response to last Friday's devastating earthquake, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee today defended the Indian government's efforts.

description: JAFFE-Edda. Time can never diminish our memories of you, vivid and cherished forever. Your loving children Susanne and Brett

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELFER, IRA M.
description: BELFER-Ira M. January 31, 2001. Attorney-at-law, Manhattan, at age 89. Beloved husband of Jean Belfer, to whom he was married for 62 years; devoted father of Myron and Peter and adored grandfather of Russell and Philip, and father-in-law of Sandra Belfer. Loving brother of the late Geraldine, and uncle of Natalie. His love of the law provided sustenance and joy. A graduate of CCNY and Brooklyn Law School, his was a story of success from immigrant roots. He valued and lived the ethic of hard work. He maintained his law practice into his 89th year-a practice of over 65 years. He was known as a lawyer's lawyer for his expertise in negotiation. His diverse practice included movie producers, fashion designers, real estate interests, corporate clients and families. A great raconteur, his storytelling captivated friends and acquaintances. His philanthropy supported the establishment of the Peter Belfer Laboratory at the Johns Hopkins University Medical School and Hospital in honor of Peter, his son, an attorney with the SEC, who died at 25 from congenital heart disease. He was a Trustee of the Brooklyn Law School and President of the Alumni Association. He was Trustee and President of the Congregation of Temple Israel of the City of New York. He founded and led the North Shore Arts Center. Service will be held at Temple Israel of the City of New York, 112 East 75 St., Friday, February 2, 2001 at 11:00 AM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Peter Belfer Laboratory, Department of Cardiology, Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD.

title: Honoring Graham, Not Imitating Her
description: Buglisi/Foreman Dance thinks artistically on a grand scale. As modern-dance troupes go, it's a large one, with 17 dancers. And Jacqulyn Buglisi and Donlin Foreman, its directors, are admirably high-minded.

title: The World Invades, and Chinese Art Surrenders? Look Again.
description: The arrival of the modern age, the age of newness and neurosis, shook everyone up, and nobody more than the Chinese. Until that point China had envisioned itself as the center of the world, around which all else revolved. It was an aged, superior, sovereign being, sustained by its habits and history and demanding to be let alone.

description: A former investment banking associate at Merrill Lynch & Company has settled accusations that he had engaged in illegal insider trading in the stock of one of the firm's clients, IWL Communications.

description: Americans snapped up new cars and sport utility vehicles last month as though the economy were booming and layoffs were far from their minds, surprising and even mystifying auto executives worried about plunging consumer confidence and an economy that has slowed almost to a standstill.

description: Nick Hysong and Lawrence Johnson want to get higher. Each wants to capture the world record in the pole vault. It doesn't matter that Hysong became the first American to win an Olympic gold medal in the event since Bob Seagren did so in 1968, or that Johnson very nearly claimed that distinction.

description: Two witnesses testified yesterday that they saw the protg of the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs holding a gun during a chaotic shooting in a Manhattan night club that left three people injured.

title: French Car Parts Concern to Eliminate 1,000 Jobs
description: Valeo of France, one of Europe's biggest auto parts makers, said today that it would eliminate about 1,000 jobs in the next six months at factories in North America because its forecasts for the global automobile market predicted a slowdown in the European market. It also expects a drop in volumes in the North America and Asian markets.

title: In Test of Troubled Waters, Powell Rebuffs Montenegrin
description: Delving into Balkan diplomacy for the first time since he assumed office, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has refused to see Milo Djukanovic, the president of Montenegro, sending a firm signal that the Bush administration opposes independence for his republic, Serbia's last partner in the Yugoslav federation.

title: Well, That's What You Get For Spying on the Neighbors
description: In the romantic comedy supermodel thriller ''Head Over Heels,'' Monica Potter plays Amanda Pierce, an art restorer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art who goes weak in the knees -- literally and with annoying frequency -- in the presence of two artists whose work dominates the consciousness of their respective eras: Titian and Freddie Prinze Jr.

title: Caught in the Electrical Fallout
description: If pragmatic action isn't taken soon to fix the broken electricity market threatening the economy of the West, our national prosperity could be seriously harmed. And the federal government -- not just California and the neighboring states now finding themselves forced to share its problems -- must be involved in the solution.

title: CNN Election Coverage Called Debacle
description: In a report commissioned by CNN, three journalism experts excoriated television coverage of the presidential race on election night as a "news disaster," and blamed the networks for creating a climate of "rancor and bitterness."

title: City Prodigy Dazzles In His Small Town Debut
description: It took Lenny Cooke five seconds to give his new friends and fans what they had been waiting for these last few months. After winning the opening tap, he swooped to the basket from the right side, caught a lob thrown to the rim by Johnny Buldo and slammed his way into the Bergen County scoring column.

title: Chattering Objects That Need No Word for Art
description: ''African Forms'' at the Museum for African Art in SoHo is another outstanding exhibition from an institution that has made a habit of them since its founding 17 years ago. It hasn't hurt that the art of Africa is one of sustained and multifaceted excellence, or that research in this field has expanded exponentially over the last three decades.

description: The United States appealed a World Trade Organization decision today that held that its restrictions on imports of lamb from Australia and New Zealand were illegal.

description: New Yorkers still smarting over being trounced by Maryland now face another blow to their battered pride: evidence that other states are beating out New York on a host of nonfootball measures, economic and social.

description: Results of standardized tests for fourth and eighth graders in New Jersey's public schools show a wide gap in achievement between minority and white students, officials said yesterday -- an area of continued concern among educators nationwide.

title: Factory Index Shows Output At Its Lowest In a Decade
description: American manufacturers cut production sharply in January, sending an index of their activity to a level not reached since the recession of a decade ago, a trade group reported yesterday.

description: Jorge Pardo

title: Metro Business Briefing; SUIT SEEKS TO BLOCK POWER PLANT
description: The owners of Silvercup Studios sued yesterday to stop a state power agency from building a temporary generator on Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens. Justice Joseph G. Golia of State Supreme Court in Queens issued a temporary restraining order blocking work on the generator until Feb. 9, if Silvercup posts a $5 million bond, according to Mitchell Kaufman, the judge's law clerk. Justice Golia also ordered the New York Power Authority and the city's Environmental Control Board to explain why the construction should be allowed, Mr. Kaufman said. Silvercup, which owns property near the generator site, says it has plans to build studios, offices and apartments on that property. In the lawsuit, Silvercup said that environmental and other requirements for the generator have not been met and that alternative sites had not been explored. State officials said that the project has the needed approvals and that other sites could not be ready in time to provide power needed this summer. Dean Murphy

title: WASHINGTON POST UNIT IS BUYING 10 PAPERS IN MARYLAND
description: The Washington Post Company, publisher of The Washington Post and Newsweek magazine, said yesterday that its Gazette unit had agreed to buy 10 Maryland newspapers and a printing operation from the closely held Chesapeake Publishing Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Washington Post said it was buying The Maryland Independent in Charles County, The Lexington Park Enterprise in St. Mary's County and other newspapers that would complement the company's papers in Maryland.

title: Weyerhaeuser Extends an Offer
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company will extend a $5.4 billion tender offer for Willamette Industries until the end of March as part of its hostile takeover bid.

title: Choice Films For All Seasons
description: No one recommends movies quite as invitingly as Facets Video, the mail-order arm of a movie-loving organization in Chicago that runs two theaters and a copiously stocked rental library in addition to its mail-order catalog of 50,000 titles.

title: Notes Show Justice Official Knew of Pardon Application
description: With two Congressional investigations into the pardon of Marc Rich looming next week, his lawyer today released 60 pages of documents that he said proved he had notified the No. 2 official at the Justice Department about the case going to the White House.

title: Proselytizing for Modernism
description: AS the messiah of modernism, Alfred Stieglitz had two essential gifts. He read his moment, or at least he listened to others like Edward Steichen who read the moment, which not many people ever manage and precious few Americans in Stieglitz's era did.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: SHAREHOLDERS ORDER GAZPROM AUDIT
description: Minority shareholders in Russia's gas company, Gazprom, have ordered an independent audit of the company's finances. Shareholders say management has failed to run the company effectively. The investors have expressed concern that executives may be stripping assets from Gazprom, the world's largest producer of gas. Investors representing about 10 percent of Gazprom shares have hired Deloitte & Touche, the international auditing company, to review Gazprom's books, including its relations with a company, Itera, which is thought to have special access to Gazprom's reserves and pipeline. Itera is based in Jacksonville, Fla. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Energy Secretary Rejects Request for Price Caps on Electricity Costs
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 2  Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham listened intently today as Western governors warned that "out-of-control" electricity costs were spreading economic havoc across their region. But he stoutly rejected a plea from several of the state leaders that the federal government impose temporary price caps on wholesale electricity as a means of getting a grip on the problem.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: SWISSAIR PARENT TURNS DOWN INVESTMENT
description: The parent company of Swissair, SAirGroup, said it had decided against taking a 34 percent stake in TAP Air Portugal. SAirGroup, which is based in Zurich, did, however, agreed with the Lisbon government to guarantee the short-term financial needs of TAP Air, which is being privatized. Swissair and TAP will continue cooperating commercially, said a spokesman, Jean-Claude Donzel. Elizabeth Olson

title: Schwab Revises Days-Off Plan
description: Trying to avoid legal problems, the Charles Schwab Corporation told employees today that they would not be required to take unpaid time off to help the broker cut expenses.

title: Excerpts From Remarks in the Senate Debate on the Ashcroft Nomination
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate yesterday on the nomination of John Ashcroft for attorney general, as recorded by The Federal News Service Inc. Where the speakers -- Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York; Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas; John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina; and Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi -- refer to ''Mr. President,'' they are addressing the president of the Senate.

title: I.B.M. PACT VALUED AT $1.7 BILLION
description: An agreement under which I.B.M. would take over AstraZeneca's information technology operations would bring I.B.M. $1.7 billion in revenue over seven years. The outsourcing plan, which was announced last fall, before financial terms had been settled, provides for I.B.M. to hire the 1,200 permanent and contract employees that had been running the computer systems of AstraZeneca, a British drug company. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Tuesday about ''Fast Food Nation'' gave an incorrect location from the book for Hamburger University, McDonald's management training center. It is in Oak Brook, Ill., not Oak Park.

title: Residential Real Estate; 2 Rental Projects Near South Orange Train Hub
description: The first two upscale rental developments in a dozen years are under construction near the heart of this compact suburb's reviving downtown and a block from its New Jersey Transit train station.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about the Security Council's extension of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in southern Lebanon misstated its duration so far. It has been nearly 23 years, not 13.

title: The Neediest Cases; He Plays the Role, and Lands the Job
description: During many rehearsals last spring, Nathaniel Ebanks played the role of a potential employee and Mfon Ukpe, who wrote the script, played the role of a prospective employer.

title: DiPietro Excels Again But Can't Help Islanders
description: Rick DiPietro sank to his knees and stayed there for a while. He had seen the shot. He had even had enough time to lift his glove to catch the puck. DiPietro will soon learn that veteran hockey players have special ways to make shots dance. DiPietro had missed the save.

title: SABENA'S SURVIVAL IN DOUBT
description: Belgium's national airline, Sabena, is about to run out of cash, its chief executive, Christophe Mller, has told his staff. The airline's two shareholders, the Belgian government, with 50.5 percent, and the SAirGroup, with 49.5 percent, are to meet on Monday to decide whether to dissolve the company. Auditors have confirmed that Sabena is confronted with significant losses for 2000 and 2001, and that the company will run out of cash by the end of February if nothing is done, Mr. Mller said yesterday. The airline has proposed a revamping plan with 700 job cuts, but its pilots have said the plan is unacceptable. Paul Meller

title: Firgi Journal; Winds of Militant Islam Disrupt Fragile Frontiers
description: Veering off the main road to the official border crossing, a dirt path winds its way for two miles up and down rocky hills before arriving in Firgi, home to a couple of hundred villagers whose daily lives long moved to the slow rhythms of the farming seasons.

title: PT's Here And There, But Where?
description: LAST July, Brian and Lynn McKenna placed an order for a 2001 Chrysler PT Cruiser. In December, their dealer, Landmark Chrysler Jeep in Florissant, Mo., called with bad news. The vehicle they wanted would not be built.

description: DDB Worldwide Gets Amex Account

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about cattle feed that violated safeguards against mad cow disease misstated the ownership of Purina Mills, operator of the feed plant. It is an independent company, not a unit of Koch Industries.

title: Album of the Week
description: ELIZA CARTHY: "Angels and Cigarettes" (Warner Brothers). As the daughter of two leading English folk singers, Martin Carthy and Norma Waterson, Eliza Carthy grew up hearing age-old songs about love and betrayal. She also learned to play the fiddle and to sing with the mournful, subtle inflections of traditional balladeers. Now with "Angels and Cigarettes," her fourth album and American debut, she applies that heritage in her own songs. The contexts and attitudes are modern, but the heartache endures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUENER, REV. HARRY H.
description: KRUENER-Rev. Harry H. Died January 23, 2001 at the age of 85 in Camden, Maine. Rev. Kruener was the Senior Minister at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims from 1960-1984. He was a marvelous preacher who touched many with a spiritual message and taught many about faith. Rev. Kruener is survived by two sons, John and Philip along with his second wife Cheryl. Memorial Service will be held at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims located in Brooklyn Heights, on Orange Street between Hicks and Henry at 5 PM on February 15, 2001.

title: MGM AGREES TO BUY STAKE IN 4 CABLE CHANNELS
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. agreed yesterday to buy 20 percent of four cable television channels owned by a unit of Cablevision Systems, the New York area's biggest cable operator, for $825 million. MGM will pay cash for a stake in American Movie Classics, Bravo, the Independent Film Channel and We: Women's Entertainment, Cablevision said. MGM, based in Santa Monica, Calif., owns one of the world's largest film libraries. Cablevision, based in Bethpage, N.Y., had been considering the sale of all or part of Rainbow Media Group, its programming unit, or issuing a stock to track its performance. Cablevision owns about 74 percent of Rainbow, and NBC, a unit of General Electric, owns the rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARMIN, DR. LEO R.
description: KARMIN-Dr. Leo R. Beloved husband of Roslyn. Cherished father of Andrew and Ann, and Heather and Harvey Melniker. Much loved & loving grandfather of Deborah and Robert, Sarah, Douglas and Carly. Services are today at I.J. Morris, Hempstead, at 10:30 AM.

title: Metro Business Briefing; DOT.COM DAILY GOES TRADITIONAL
description: What does it say about the Internet industry in New York when the Silicon Alley Daily stops covering Silicon Alley? It seems the staff is tired of writing about layoffs. In a letter to subscribers of the Silicon Alley Daily, an e-mail newsletter produced by Rising Tide Studios, the newsletter's editor, Jason McCabe Calacanis, said that the publication had begun to expand its coverage of ''the media, finance and technology firms that are leveraging the Net.'' He said the focus on more traditional companies stems from the takeover of so many dot.coms by such concerns. Jayson Blair

title: Beyond Pizza Pies and French Fries, Teaching Children How to Ski
description: The ski instructor was yelling at her in a good-natured way: ''Keep your tips together in a pizza pie! O.K., listen to me. Stop crying for a minute. A pizza pie! A pizza pie!''

title: CBS Gains a Ratings Victory as Survivor Beats Friends
description: In one of the strongest nights for network television in recent history, the CBS reality series "Survivor: The Australian Outback" scored a huge ratings success Thursday night, bringing in almost 30 million people and leading CBS to the best performance by any network against NBC on its stronghold night in more than 15 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, DAPHNE (PAT)
description: WALLACE-Daphne (Pat). On January 28, 2001 in Philadelphia, PA. Her husband Harold, her children, grandchildren, extended family and many friends, will eternally miss her strength, character and devotion. Services Monday, February 5, 1:00 PM, at St. Phillips Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, ROBERT L.
description: WILLIAMS-Robert L. Broadcaster, died January 28, 2001. Survived by three children, Robert L. III, John and Maura, and four grandchildren. Memorial service February 3, 2001. John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, NY.

title: PEPSI BOTTLING SAYS IT IS BUYING CALIFORNIA BOTTLER
description: The Pepsi Bottling Group, the No. 1 bottler of Pepsi beverages, said yesterday that it planned to buy Pepsi-Cola Bottling of Northern California to expand its business in the state. Terms were not disclosed. Pepsi-Cola Bottling, which is closely held, serves 13 California counties, and its territory is adjacent to Pepsi Bottling Group's. Pepsi Bottling, based in Somers, N.Y., distributes Pepsi drinks in the United States, Canada, Greece, Spain and Russia. PepsiCo owns about 40 percent of the company.

title: With Conciliatory Gestures, Bush Reaches Out in Reprise of Successful Clinton Tactic
description: President Bush reached out today to moderates by declaring that in offering more aid to religious groups, ''I'm interested in what is constitutional and I'm interested in what works,'' and by announcing a new program to extend more government help to the disabled.

title: Death Penalty Is Upheld in 'Megan' Case
description: For the second time, the New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld the death penalty for a man whose rape and murder of a 7-year-old girl gave rise to a nationwide wave of laws named for his victim that require public notification about sex offenders.

title: Wary, Once Again, Over the Clintons
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOSEVELT, ANNE MASON BABCOCK
description: ROOSEVELT-Anne Mason Babcock. Of Beaumont at Bryn Mawr, PA, died on Monday January 29, 2001. Beloved wife of Theodore Roosevelt, III, she is also survived by her son Theodore Roosevelt, IV, daughter-in-law Constance Rogers Roosevelt and a grandson, Theodore Roosevelt, V. Service and interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Wilderness Society, 1615 M Street North West, Washington, DC 20036

title: Kafkaesque? Big Brother? Finding the Right Literary Metaphor for Net Privacy
description: It's customary these days for many legal thinkers, journalists and just plain civilians to use the phrase "Big Brother" when bemoaning the loss of privacy created by the rise of computerized databases which track an individual's every move in cyberspace.
