title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRO, HELEN
description: SPIRO-Helen. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Helen Ganz Spiro. Helen and her late husband, Manny, had been members of Fairview since 1946. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest condolences to her daughters. Bernard Steinweg, President Leonard Golub, Secretary

title: Invigorated Lieberman Claiming New Role
description: Hours after President Bush introduced his ambitious proposal to remake federal education policy, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman stepped before the cameras on Capitol Hill and announced a similar plan by moderate Democrats.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Wednesday about ''Time and Again,'' at the Manhattan Theater Club, misspelled the given name of the actor in the leading role. He is Lewis Cleale, as shown in the credit listing, not Louis.

title: A Passion for Food, Now Served Monthly
description: HERE we are, eating in the hottest new eating place in town, and Ruth Reichl, arguably the hottest eater in town, is talking about eating and waving her hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, HAROLD J.
description: SCHECHTER-Harold J., on February 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Francine. Dear father of Barbi (Kenneth) Zakin and Joe (Angela) Schechter. Adored grandfather of Carly, Peter and Sam. Cherished friend of Peter Wiener. Services today.

title: Russian Wants Dialogue With U.S. on Limited Missile Defenses
description: Russia's foreign minister said today in Geneva that his country and the United States should undertake an ''active and meaningful'' dialogue as soon as possible to develop defenses against ballistic missiles in troubled parts of the world.

title: It's Always Saturday On TV
description: WHEN I was a child, the longest hours of the week were on Saturday morning, between 7, when I popped out of bed, and 10:30, when I was allowed to wake my older (adored) sister to watch cartoons together. ''Your shows,'' our mother called them dismissively, adding the spice of parental scorn to the special, subversive pleasures of Saturday morning television.

title: PITTSTON POSTS $220 MILLION LOSS AND CUTS 350 JOBS
description: The Pittston Company, which owns Brink's security and the BAX freight business, said yesterday that it had cut about 350 jobs and that it lost $220.4 million in the fourth quarter as demand for its transportation and management services slowed. A year earlier, the company lost $17.9 million. The company said that it cut the jobs at its BAX unit as part of a revamping to reduce capacity and costs at its air transportation business. Shares of the company, based in Richmond, Va., fell $2.41, to $18.40, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPOFF, MARY L.
description: SHAPOFF-Mary L. On January 31, 2001 of Albertson, NY. Beloved wife of the late Stanley ''Skip''. Loving mother of Dr. Cary & Carol Shapoff and Edward & Joanne Shapoff. Dear grandmother of Stephanie, Amy, Edward A. and Christopher. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12 St, Garden City, NY Saturday 7-9PM and Sunday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Service at the Fairchild Chapel, Sunday 8PM. Interment Monday Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Donations to St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, New York, and St. LukesRoosevelt Hospital Center, New York, New York, appreciated.

title: Unsold At Auction
description: Last week's old master paintings sales in New York followed what has become a familiar pattern this season. While Sotheby's and Christie's were able to sell some works for exceedingly high prices, a large percentage of material in each auction remained unsold.

title: Chief Resigns At Terra Lycos After Dispute With Owners
description: Robert J. Davis, the tenacious Internet pioneer who took Lycos from a university project to the fifth-most-popular Web site in the country, resigned yesterday as chief executive of Terra Lycos after a dispute with its Spanish owners.

title: Videotapes Expose Misdeeds of Perus Most Powerful
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 2  They were the most closely guarded secrets of President Alberto K. Fujimori's rule, thousands of videotapes documenting the corruption and sexual high jinks of Peru's most powerful people that he and his spy chief used to blackmail and control virtually the entire political establishment.

title: LOSS WIDENS AT DIGEX
description: Digex Inc., which runs Web sites for companies like the UAL Corporation's United Airlines and Fannie Mae, said its fourth-quarter loss widened to $41.4 million, or 65 cents a share, from $22.4 million, or 36 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose to $57.9 million from $21.7 million.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Article 2001020293385427947 -- No Title
description: We have only one candidate  me.

title: Recalling Old Russia, Wistfully
description: Life is awful. If you doubt it, just listen to anyone around the Ranevskaya estate. Everything is changing, and for the worse, but no one has the energy to do anything about it. Fortunes have been squandered on Champagne and toffee and the peasants have breached the kitchen. There's even a railway clerk drinking vodka and dancing with the chambermaid in the ballroom.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PAPERMAKER TO LAY OFF 58
description: Lydall Inc., will lay off 58 employees as it closes the 121-year-old Lydall & Foulds cardboard-making factory in Manchester, Conn., to focus on higher-profit products. Lydall is shutting the plant at its Manchester, Conn., headquarters because of increased costs and competition in the cardboard industry, a spokeswoman, Carole Butenas, said. The plant will close immediately, but employees will be paid through next month. Lydall plans to concentrate on businesses like filtration paper and thermal insulation products used in the automotive industry.

title: Article 2001020293854265808 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: My Student Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Condominium Rentals
description: For stays of a week or more, condominium rentals sometimes are better values than hotel stays. Leisure Link International features such rentals in popular destinations like Orlando, Hawaii, Las Vegas, Vail, Branson, Hilton Head and Myrtle Beach at its Web site, www.leisurelinkintl.com . A two-bedroom condo in Orlando starts at $79 a night, based on a one-week stay. On Hawaiis Big Island, a two-bedroom unit starts at $109 a night. The Web site also includes last-minute prices on cruises, and five-night packages at Mexican resorts. Offers are subject to change, and Leisure Links packages generally do not include air fare. Visit the Web site or call (305) 827-1220.

title: Verizon's Earnings Rise 1.3%; Sprint's Profit Is Down 11%
description: Verizon Communications said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 1.3 percent, while Sprint reported an 11 percent decline in profit.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose on expectations that colder weather in the Midwest will increase demand. In New York, natural gas for March delivery rose 67.3 cents, or 11.8 percent, to $6.38 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: U.S. Said to Approve Anti-Hussein Funding
description: An Iraqi opposition group said today that it had been given permission by the Bush administration to begin American-funded activities within Iraq in an effort to undermine the government of President Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, CONSTANCE MYERS
description: ANDERSON-Constance Myers. On January 31st, 2001, at Crosslands, Kennett Square, PA, at the age of 102. Wife of the late Dr. Arthur Forrest Anderson of NY and Wilton, CT, she was the mother of Constance A. Tate of Wilton and the late Forrest G. Anderson. She leaves three grandsons: the Very Reverend Robert L. Tate, Gerald A. Tate, and John R. Tate; also seven great-grandchildren. A longtime leader of the YWCA in New York City and as a national president, she was also a leader with the USO and the US Committee for UNICEF. A service will be held at Crosslands on February 25th at 3 pm. Donations in her memory may be made to the YWCA of the City of New York, 610 Lexington Ave, New York, NY 10022.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the bibliographic note yesterday with the book review of ''Bing Crosby: A Pocketful of Dreams, The Early Years 1903-1940'' misspelled the surname of the author. He is Gary Giddins, as the review said, not Giddens.

title: People
description: * Durk Barnhill, an account director at the San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe, was named to the new post of general manager. He assumes the duties for overseeing operations day to day from Julie Bauer, president and chief executive of the office, who is moving to New York to assume new tasks as a managing partner overseeing offices in Canada and New York as well as San Francisco.

title: Johnson Memorial Service
description: A tribute to Beverley Peck Johnson, a voice teacher and faculty member at the Juilliard School of Music, will take place on Monday at 5 p.m. at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, Manhattan. Ms. Johnson died on Jan. 20 at 96.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: SUIT SEEKS TO BLOCK POWER PLANT

title: Albee Laughing Dourly Ever After
description: Sorry, Mayor Giuliani. Recent developments have conclusively shown that you are not the most powerful man in New York City. That distinction belongs to a fellow known only as -- wouldn't you know it? -- the Man.

title: National Black Fine Art Show
description: The Puck Building

title: General Powell Engages Africa
description: In the weeks before he took office as secretary of state, Colin Powell made clear he was determined to devote American attention to the problems of Africa, a continent that was barely mentioned during George W. Bush's campaign. General Powell seems to be making good on that commitment. He met this week with two of the leading antagonists in one of Africa's most destructive and intractable wars, the conflict in Congo. His involvement sends a welcome signal that the new administration understands the gravity of Africa's multiple crises and intends to play a role in trying to solve them.

title: Walls That Talk to You About Talking to Walls
description: Leonardo Drew is an artist with one theatrical theme: a powerful one, to be sure, that repetition has not yet killed. The theme is a massive gridded wall made of distressed wood, stacked boxes and various other materials, and coated with rust to simulate the encroachments of time and nature.

title: NEW PRODUCTS HELP COLGATE POST 10% INCREASE IN PROFIT
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 10 percent as new products increased sales in North America. Net income rose to $286.7 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $260.6 million, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier, Colgate said. Sales rose 2.9 percent, to $2.41 billion from $2.34 billion. Analysts had expected the company to earn 45 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. The company said earnings in the first quarter would rise at least 10 percent. Oral-care products and lower costs lifted Colgate's results even though falling currencies in Europe and Asia hurt its competitors. Shares of Colgate-Palmolive rose $1, to $61.08.

title: Jorge Pardo
description: Dia Center for the Arts

title: Tripping Through Europe On a Quest for Lost Time
description: The 1960's were a confusing time. Phoebe O'Connor (Jordana Brewster), a Bay Area teenager whose older sister, Faith (Cameron Diaz), was swallowed up in the madness of the era, is a confused young woman. Unfortunately, ''The Invisible Circus,'' which follows Phoebe as she retraces her dead sibling's steps from Paris to Berlin to the coast of Portugal, doesn't so much illuminate Phoebe's confusion as share it.

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about the Security Council's extension of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in southern Lebanon misstated its duration so far. It has been nearly 23 years, not 13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, MARCY
description: SCHREIBER-Marcy. Beloved wife of Israel, devoted mother of Ilene Zanchelli and Jan Schreiber, loving grandmother and cherished sister of R. Kamen. Service today 2PM ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Bklyn, NY (opposite Kings Plaza Mall).

title: 2 Bets, but Just 1 Payoff
description: ONE vehicle has a ground-breaking design rooted in the past. The other blazed a trail into what its designers saw as the future. Both are vanlike cars (or carlike vans) with a bit of S.U.V. attitude, and both are built in Mexico. Both were gambles, expected to appeal to the young drivers that automakers covet. And now, after months on the market, both are having problems -- of a very different sort.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Fast Eat the Slow
description: There's an interesting new trend in the Arab world that is easily detectable from here in Qatar, the small Persian Gulf emirate off the east coast of Saudi Arabia. It's this: Almost all the innovation happening in the Arab world today -- politically, economically and technologically -- is happening in the small states on the periphery, while the least innovation is happening in the big traditional Arab powers -- Iraq, Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia -- that always dominated this region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTTING, KATHRYN TERZIN
description: CUTTING-Kathryn Terzin. Of Westbrook, CT. Beloved wife of the late Earle Cutting. Requiem Mass at St. Mark's Church, Westbrook, Tuesday, February 6, 2001, at 10 AM. For information contact The Swan Funeral Home, 1224 Boston Post Road, Old Saybrook.

title: New Jersey's Acting Governor Is the Star on a Southbound Train
description: Technically speaking, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco ceased to be the acting governor of New Jersey sometime around 1 p.m. today, his first full day on the job, when the Jersey Special, an 18-car-long, beer-soaked, jam-packed political schmoozefest on wheels, trundled across a railroad trestle from Trenton into Pennsylvania.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOR, JOSEPH
description: CONNOR-Joseph. The Medical Staff, Board of Directors, and Administration of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center mourn the passing of Joseph Connor, father of Sally Rose. Mrs. Rose is a member of the Advisory Council and longtime friend and supporter of the Medical Center. The Hospital and all affiliated with it extend their sincerest condolences to the Rose family. Henry P. Read, Chairman, Board of Directors Thomas Ockers, President/CEO Seth O. Mankes, M.D., President, Medical Staff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNS, LIVINGSTON
description: JOHNS-Livingston. Died January 25, 2001. Survived by wife Connie and three children. Services Saturday, February 3, at 7 PM, Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave, NYC, between 20 and 21 St; 212-475-2024. Burial February 6, with full honors at Arlington National Cemetery, VA. Livingston served thirty years in the US Navy.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The blocks around New York University offer a few bright spots, like Tomoe Sushi, Lupa and Blue Hill, but overall the neighborhood feels like a cheap-eats mall dominated by cut-rate sushi, big burritos and pizza by the slice. Bringing promise of relief, Cafe Alyss arrives in this barren land like a breath of fresh air.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TITAN CORP., San Diego, a satellite-communications and information-technology company, said it intended to sell two consulting and network-monitoring software businesses. The units provide monitoring, protection and security services for networks like e-mail systems.

title: Blues to Ballads, All Sung With Optimism
description: The pop-blues singer Carol Woods, who spent much of the last three years playing Mama Morton in the national touring company of ''Chicago,'' is one of the more dependable theatrical troupers to mine a blustery rhythm-and-blues tradition that embraces large women with big, rugged voices.

title: Amazing Amazon: Losses Grow as They Seem to Shrink
description: AMAZON.COM says it will be profitable in the fourth quarter of this year. But what does that mean?

title: EATING OUT
description: Going Solo

title: Joan Nelson
description: Robert Miller

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIPPENBERG, JACK J.
description: KNIPPENBERG-Jack J. Age 59 years of Hawthorne, NJ. On Thursday, February 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Karin (nee Hoock). Loving father of Susan Knippenberg of Hoboken, NJ and Christine MacDougall of Langhorn, PA. Dear grandfather of Devon and Casey MacDougall. Brother of Sigi Sauthoff in Germany. Jack was a graduate of Pace University, valedictorian of his class. He was also an instructor at Pace. Jack began his career in banking at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York City, working his way from Junior positions to the Management Team. He served as the Senior Chase Officer in Istanbul, Turkey. He retired in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia as CEO of the Saudi Investment Bank. Visting hours Saturday, February 3, 2001 from 12 noon to 1:30 PM with a funeral service to follow at 1:30 PM at the Browning-Forshay Funeral Home, 557 Lafayette Avenue, Hawthorn, New Jersey. The family requests flowers be omitted and memorial donations be made to the North Shore Animal League, 25 Davis Avenue, Port Washington, New York 11050 in his memory.

title: Bjork Goes Back To Her Music
description: Bjork, the Icelandic pop singer whose performance in Lars von Trier's ''Dancer in the Dark'' earned her a Golden Globe nomination, was quietly working her way through a frothy cappuccino on the outdoor patio at the Chateau Marmont Hotel, above the Sunset Strip.

title: Talk to the Hand
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Giuliani, Thinking of the Future, Celebrates a Book Deal That Has City Hall Abuzz
description: Edward I. Koch landed a $100,000 advance for a book he wrote while still mayor. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo drew less than $20,000 for a collection of his best-received speeches. But when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went to the literary market, he set a City Hall record, drawing an advance of nearly $3 million for a memoir and a less juicy how-to guide on managing an unmanageable city.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAR, LEON D., M.D.
description: STAR-Leon D., M.D. Fourteen long years since you left us, but your love and dynamic spirit will live with us always. Your family

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the appointment of Joel I. Klein as United States liaison officer at the Bertelsmann media company misstated the name and location of a restaurant in Washington where he had breakfast with Thomas Middelhoff, the company's chief executive. It is the Seasons restaurant at the Four Seasons Hotel, not the Four Seasons restaurant. And it is in Georgetown, not downtown.

title: Quake's Victims: Rich and Homeless, Poor and Homeless
description: The earthquake last Friday knocked down the big concrete houses of this rich village with the same murderous fury with which it demolished the mud dwellings of farm laborers in Dagara.

title: Wary, Once Again, Over the Clintons
description: To the Editor:

title: Qaddafi Rants Against the U.S. In a Welcoming After Bomb Trial
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi today turned his personal welcome for the Libyan released in the Lockerbie bombing trial into a rambling tirade, both against the guilty verdict pronounced against the other defendant and the entire handling of the affair.

title: New Video Releases
description: Dr. T and the Women

title: Marc Rich and Pollard
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Incident at Indiana: Other Side of the Story
description: In some of his strongest comments yet regarding an incident with a fan in Indianapolis last Sunday, Allen Iverson reiterated last night that racial epithets were directed at him during the nationally televised game against the Indiana Pacers.

title: Disentangling A Worldwide Web of Riches
description: Anglo American P.L.C., the world's largest mining company, said today that it was in talks to buy out its sister company, De Beers, the global diamond giant, for $16 billion.

title: David Heneker, 94, Lyricist For Catchy Musical Comedies
description: David Heneker, who wrote the score for the musical ''Half a Sixpence'' and collaborated on the English adaptation of the book and lyrics for ''Irma la Douce,'' died on Tuesday in a residential home in Wales. He was 94.

title: Verizon Starts Office to Serve Silicon Alley
description: Verizon Communications is to announce today that it has created a Silicon Alley advocate's office to address complaints and improve high-speed Internet service for New York technology companies, according to officials involved with an agreement brokered by the city comptroller's office.

title: INSIDE
description: McCall Becomes Candidate

title: Lawmakers in Indonesia Accept Finding That President Lied
description: The Indonesian Parliament took the first step today toward impeaching President Abdurrahman Wahid when it overwhelmingly approved the findings of an inquiry implicating him in two corruption scandals, which have shaken this country's young democracy.

title: SPEEDY DRIVE HITS MARKET
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it would begin shipments this quarter of a new 15,000 revolutions-a-minute disk drive that performs some tasks as much as 25 percent faster than the industry's current leader, a device from Seagate Technology. The high-speed disks are used in e-commerce servers and data storage. I.B.M. is scrambling to recover after trailing Seagate by nearly a year in reaching the 15,000 r.p.m. threshold. Analysts expect announcements of similar products from Japanese companies in the next few months. And Seagate said it planned to introduce a drive that will top I.B.M.'s performance before the end of this quarter. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMANN, FRANK
description: ZIMMERMANN-Frank. Age 93. Beloved husband of Betty and the late Rebecca, dear father of Judy and Warren Axelrod and the late David Zimmermann, cherished grandfather of David and Elisabeth Axelrod, Rachel, Michael, Barry and David Levin, stepfather of Joshua, Daniel and Carol Levin and Jonathan Levin. Graduate of City College, Dropsie College and the Jewish Theological Seminary. Renowned biblical scholar, rabbi, professor emeritus and chair Department of Bible at Dropsie College, Philadelphia. Author of six books and numerous monographs. Services on Friday, 1 PM, February 2, Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, NY.

title: AFTER LONG CLIMB, PRISON POPULATION FALLS IN NEW YORK
description: The number of state prisoners in New York is declining for the first time in 27 years, according to officials of the State Department of Correctional Services.

title: Power Supplier Shifts Its Clients
description: Enron Energy Services officially notified many large business customers today that, as reported, it would no longer supply them with low-cost power because of the turmoil in California's electricity market.

title: Higher Ad Sales Help Primedia Narrow Losses
description: Primedia, the publisher of more than 220 magazines like Seventeen, New York and Shotgun News, said its fourth-quarter loss narrowed on higher sales for its specialty publications.

title: Fox and Lewis Left in Cold; Bills Select Titans' Williams
description: Two weeks ago, the defensive coordinators of the two Super Bowl teams -- the Giants' John Fox and the Baltimore Ravens' Marvin Lewis -- were hot head-coaching candidates. And with the Cleveland Browns and the Buffalo Bills each searching for a new head coach, Fox and Lewis were widely expected to be welcomed into the National Football League's coaching elite. It seemed only a matter of who went where.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, GLORIA W.
description: APPEL-Gloria W. Suddenly on January 31. Remembered with love and joy by her children: Carley Broder, Michael Broder and Rita Rubin, Charles Broder and Celeste Hoppey-Broder, and Betsy Broder and David Wentworth. Proud grandmother of Elexa, Ethan, Hannah and Aliza Broder and Ariel and Caroline Wentworth. Widow of Ed Appel, she was devoted to Eddie's children: Marianne Berson, Michaele and Thad Keyes, and Diane and John McCann; their children Deborah Parnes, Brad Berson, Rachel and Gabe Keyes, and Kevin and Ian McCann. President of the Louis and Harold Price Foundation and the Price Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies, which she served for over 20 years, a trustee of Babson College and Medical Development for Israel and advisor to Ewing and Marion Kauffman Foundation. Gloria also leaves countless cherished and loyal friends. Services Sunday, 1:15 Temple Shaaray Tefila, 79th and 2nd. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Price-Babson Fellows Program at Babson College or Medical Development for Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, ARTHUR H.
description: KAHN-Arthur H. The lawyers and staff of Schnader Harrison Segal & Lewis LLP mourn the passing of Arthur H. Kahn, former Chairman, colleague and friend.

title: Barak Stays in the Running for Next Tuesday, Pitting Him Against Sharon, the Favorite
description: The deadline for political parties to change candidates expired quietly at midnight on Thursday, and Prime Minister Ehud Barak finally put to rest the speculation that he would step aside and let former Prime Minister Shimon Peres run in his place in Tuesday's election.

title: Sports of The Times; A Superstar, Iverson Isn't A Role Model
description: SITTING in the Philadelphia 76ers' locker room in Madison Square Garden last night, fiddling with a new, bright red pair of sneakers, Allen Iverson said, No, he wasn't talking before the game. After all, it was implied, he needed all his energy to contemplate the game in about an hour against the Knicks.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, DOROTHY (SACHS)
description: MARX-Dorothy (Sachs), 79, peacefully on January 30, 2001. after a courageous, high-spirited struggle with illness for five years. She was the glowing center and the welcoming heart for all who knew and loved her. We grieve her loss as we are inspired by her all-caring love, her exquisite taste and style, and her insistence on recognizing the goodness in everyone she knew: Herbert L. Marx, Jr., husband; Tedra Schneider, daughter; Michael Levine, son; Ellen Levine, daughter-in-law; Violet Lapides and Eva Marcus, sisters. She is also survived by step-children Jonathan Marx, Timothy and Nan Marx, and Alison Marx; grandchildren and step-grandchildren Gregory, Andrew and Hilary Schneider; Benjamin and Samuel Levine; Victoria and Robert Frank; Alyssa, Ariel, Benjamin and Sophie Marx; and three generations of nieces and nephews who adored their ''Auntie Mame''. Dorothy was a graduate of New York University. She served as Personnel Director of Nytronics, Inc. and Personnel Manager for the national office of Hadassah. Later, she became the active proprietor of Dorothy Marx Art and Antiques Acquisitions. She was formerly married to Maurice Levine. For those who wish to make a contribution, please do so to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or to a charity or organization of the donor's choice. Funeral service will take place on Friday, February 2, at 11 AM at Temple Shaaray Tefila, Second Avenue and 79th Street, New York City. The family will receive visitors at the Temple beginning at 10 AM.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE SPEEDY DRIVE HITS MARKET I.B.M. said yesterday that it would begin shipments this quarter of a new 15,000 revolutions-a-minute disk drive that performs some tasks as much as 25 percent faster than the industry's current leader, a device from Seagate Technology . The high-speed disks are used in e-commerce servers and data storage. I.B.M. is scrambling to recover after trailing Seagate by nearly a year in reaching the 15,000 r.p.m. threshold. Analysts expect announcements of similar products from Japanese companies in the next few months. And Seagate said it planned to introduce a drive that will top I.B.M.'s performance before the end of this quarter. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Flames Consume the Dead, but Not the Anguish of India
description: BHUJ, India, Feb. 2  Corpse No. 686 was Chandra Kant Joshi's wife. They had been married for 36 years, and had he imagined her funeral, it would have been a traditional rite, with her body having been cleansed and scented and then dressed in the same red sari she had worn to their wedding. Hundreds would have walked in a procession to the pyre. Prayers would have been chanted. Mourners would have sat for hours as the flames expired.

title: Gaining, and Losing, Too
description: Throughout the battle over John Ashcroft's nomination as attorney general, President Bush said he had chosen Mr. Ashcroft for only one reason. He was, in Mr. Bush's stated view, the best person for the job.

title: SENATE CONFIRMS ASHCROFT AS ATTORNEY GENERAL, 58-42, CLOSING A FIVE-WEEK BATTLE
description: The Senate confirmed John Ashcroft as attorney general today, capping a five-week struggle that turned into the most bitter battle over a cabinet nominee in more than a decade.

title: After Year, Scope of Teacher Cheating Scandal Is Diminished
description: Thirteen months ago, 52 New York City teachers, principals and other educators were accused of helping students ratchet up scores on standardized tests in what was described as one of the biggest cheating scandals in American public schools.

title: Article 2001020290400566932 -- No Title
description: February 2, 2001

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, ARTHUR A.
description: GOULD-Arthur A. Age 93, of Floral Park. Preceded in death by wife Louise. Survived by sons James (Jayne) of Maine, Robert (Dawn) of California, granddaughters, Danielle Stevenson of FL., Suzanne Gould Berg of Washington, greatgranddaughter, Rachel Lynn Stevenson. Funeral services will be held Monday, February 5 in Minneapolis, MN. Memorials preferred to the donor's choice. For more information call Hodroff & Sons Funeral Chapel 612-871-1234

title: Corrections
description: A picture on the Public Lives page yesterday with a report about the Shubert Organization's donation of a police horse to the city was published in error. It showed Philip J. Smith, the president of Shubert, not Gerald Schoenfeld, the chairman, whose comment was quoted.

title: Starting Race for Governor, McCall Focuses on Pataki
description: Accusing Gov. George E. Pataki of ''aimless lethargy'' and ''detachment'' in office, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, announced last night that he will run for governor in 2002, kicking off what promises to be one of the longest and most bitterly contested races the state has seen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAK, MARIE A.
description: RAK-Marie A. On January 31, 2001. Beloved friend of Leonard G. Bisco and family, Peter M. Messer and family. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Saturday, February 3 at St. John the Martyr, 259 East 71 St, 10 A.M. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a sexual abuse investigation misstated the location of a swimming pool where the police said the suspect befriended boys. It is south of the Bronx Zoo, not on the zoo grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, HENRY C.
description: MARSHALL-Henry C. Of Williamsburg, VA. on January 31, 2001. Beloved husband of Margaret S. Father of Fred and Henry, Jr. Adored grandfather and great grandfather. You will be greatly missed by many.

title: Another Anachronism
description: To the Editor:

title: XEROX SAYS ACCOUNTING PROBLEM WAS LIMITED TO MEXICO
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that an independent investigation had found that accounting irregularities in its Mexican subsidiary were limited to that country. The problems of unpaid debt, which resulted in a $120 million charge, prompted a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation. Xerox said the unpaid debts were the result of several managers who made questionable business decisions and used questionable practices. The actions were ''conducted by a small group of senior Xerox Mexico and Latin American group executives in collusion to circumvent our policies and practices,'' Xerox's chairman, Paul A. Allaire, said. ''We can say with confidence that the appropriate corrective actions were taken and that those who were responsible were removed.''

title: O. Winston Link, Photographer, Dies at 86
description: O. Winston Link, a photographer whose requiem for steam railroading portrayed it as a spectacularly alive and often surreal presence in 1950's small-town America, died on Tuesday in South Salem, N.Y. He was 86.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: German Bank Posts Drop In Income
description: Deutsche Bank, which has spent billions of dollars competing with Wall Street's biggest investment banks, reported today that its net income declined slightly during the fourth quarter and acknowledged that last year's huge growth from investment banking was unlikely to be repeated in the year ahead.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: U.S. Is Optimistic After Powell's Meeting With Congo President
description: The new, young leader of the war-shattered Congo, Joseph Kabila, did the rounds of Washington today, a face among many at a Congressional prayer breakfast, a supplicant at the headquarters of the World Bank and the guest of corporate investors disappointed at the ruin of his country.

title: Musical Mysteries
description: One of the most famous missing treasures in the world of antiques is a beautiful harpsichord that Catherine the Great, empress of Russia from 1762 to 1796, commissioned in 1774 from England. It was designed by Robert Adam (1728-1792), the renowned neo-Classical British architect who created everything from palaces to furniture.

title: Reebok's Quarterly Profit Surges
description: Reebok International said today that its fourth-quarter profit surged as the company paid down debt, cut costs and increased domestic sales.

title: A Mel Gibson Action Adventure, Taken at a Stroll
description: ''I figured I could learn a lot from him,'' Tom Tom (Jeremy Davies), the central figure and narrator of Wim Wenders's almost new movie, ''Million Dollar Hotel,'' says of the F.B.I. agent, Skinner (Mel Gibson). The admiring and loony Tom Tom is tailing Skinner while Skinner investigates a murder in a Los Angeles flophouse. With a military brush cut and stiff suits that must be made from corrugated pinstripe, Skinner looks like an automaton parody of Mr. Gibson's action characters.

title: Wary, Once Again, Over the Clintons
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economic Mood Brightens In Europe as It Sours in U.S.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASS, ELAINE, M.D.
description: KASS-Elaine, M.D. Dr. Frank Ross, Director of Medicine, Dr. Joseph Masci, Associate Director of Medicine, and the staff of the Department of Medicine at Elmhurst Hospital Center, express profound sorrow at the passing of our esteemed colleague and cherished friend Dr. Elaine Kass, Associate Director of Pediatrics. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family.

title: National News Briefs
description: Judge Rules Mistrial in Suit Against Liddy

title: To Uphold the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Bearing Gift of Skill, Doctor Takes a Team to India
description: Dr. Butchi Babu Paidipaty has no family in the state of Gujarat in western India. He doesn't know anyone who lives there. But when he heard about the earthquake last Friday, he felt compelled to help.

title: KLM HAS UNEXPECTED PROFIT
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines posted an unexpected profit in its traditionally weak third quarter after it raised ticket prices and said its profit this year would be better than a previous forecast for it to double. It said strong demand, cost-cutting measures and falling fuel prices would improve its results. KLM said it earned 4 million euros ($3.77 million), compared with a loss, excluding exceptional items, of 18 million euros ($16.85 million) a year earlier.

title: Energy, in the Arctic and California
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIP MAKER WARNS SALES MAY FALL
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, a top maker of chips for cellular phones, said sales in the third quarter of its fiscal year might fall from the second quarter's as manufacturers of personal computers and mobile phones reduce inventories. Sales for the period ending Feb. 25 will be $475 million to $480 million, the company said. Sales of $558.4 million had been expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIBLE, FRANCES
description: BIBLE-Frances. New York City Opera deeply mourns the passing of one of its most revered and beloved company members. She passed away on January 29 in Hemet, CA., at the age of eightytwo after a brief illness. As a leading artist with NYCO from 1948-1977, she created some of the most vibrantly acted, beautifully sung, and memorable characters in our company's history, including Octavian, Dorabella, Lucretia, Cenerentola, Amneris, Ottavia, Hansel, Jocasta, Herodias, and Oberon, as well as Elizabeth Proctor in the world premier of ''The Crucible'' and Frade in the world premier of ''The Dybbuk''. She is perhaps best remembered as Augusta Tabor in NYCO's ''Ballad of Baby Doe'', a performance immortalized in a telecast and recently reissued recording. She was a preeminent figure in twentiethcentury American opera, performing with virtually every major opera company and symphony orchestra around the world. Her support of her fellow artists was exemplary, whether as a singing colleague or as a teacher at Rice University, where she served as Artist-in-Residence for fourteen years until her retirement in 1991. We will always remember her with great affection and respect. The music world has lost one of its greatest lights. Contributions in her memory may be sent to North Shore Animal League America, Lewyt Street, Port Washington, NY 11050. A memorial service is being planned for the spring. Paul Kellogg, General Director

title: Steel Maker Will Cut Jobs And Production in Britain
description: Britain's beleaguered heavy-industrial sector took a severe knock today when the Corus Group, a leading European steel maker, said it would cut 6,050 jobs, a fifth of its work force, mostly in regions of Britain already economically depressed by long declines in the coal, steel and shipbuilding businesses.

title: Public Interests; Power Politics
description: The Senate Energy Committee held a hearing about the California energy crisis this week. The most sympathetic remark about California was made by a senator from North Dakota who said, at one point, ''I think they're still part of the union.''

description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The dollar fell on concern that two interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve will not be enough to halt the economic slowdown. In New York, the dollar settled at 115.67 yen, down from 116.34 yen on Wednesday.

title: Article 2001020294202158186 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: BARRICK HURT BY CHARGE
description: With a $1.1 billion write-down of the value of its assets to reflect lower gold prices, the Barrick Gold Corporation of Toronto reported a fourth-quarter loss of $996 million, in contrast to a profit of $81 million a year earlier. Randall Oliphant, Barrick's chief executive, said investors had already reassessed assets acquired before 1997, ''and our books will now reflect this external reality.'' Without the noncash charge, the company said, fourth-quarter profit would have been a record $104 million, 28 percent higher than a year earlier. Timothy Pritchard

title: This Time, America Kept Its Hands Out of the Crisis in Philippines
description: MANILA  During 400 years of colonial rule and a half century of postwar independence, politics in the Philippines has been consistently influenced by foreign intervention  either overt military action of the Spanish and American armies or behind-the-scenes work by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NETBURN, AARON
description: NETBURN-Aaron. On February 1, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Father of Gail Bridger, Stephen, Malcolm and Mitchell Netburn. Grandfather of Margot, Perry and Jonathan Bridger, Sarah, Joshua, Oliver, Deborah, Laura, Amanda and Jennie Netburn. Great grandfather to Naomi and Rose Bridger. Beloved companion of Loretta Eisner. Brother of Frances Netburn, Ruth Gilwood and the late Bernie Netburn. Services Friday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: 3,000-Mile Trip for 2 Boys And a Nightmare of Abuse
description: The cross-country search for two little boys and their mother began on New Year's Day in Brooklyn with reports of abuse that caused child protection authorities to fear for the children's lives.

title: Mets Sign Leyritz and Matt Franco to Minor League Deals
description: The last time Jim Leyritz spent a full season with one team, he burst into Yankee lore by shifting the momentum of the 1996 World Series with a three-run homer in Game 4. Leyritz became a legend, but he soon became a nomad. He has been traded six times since then, and yesterday he signed with the Mets as a minor league free agent.

title: Some Black Pastors See New Aid Under Bush
description: While his party protested the new presidency, Bishop Charles E. Blake saw a field of opportunities. Bishop Blake, pastor of the West Angeles Church of God in Christ in Los Angeles, is a lifelong Democrat and civil rights activist.

title: A Biblically Inspired Tale About Dying and Surviving
description: ''How do you describe both a beginning and an end?'' a narrator intones portentously over the opening credits of Vic Sarin's film ''Left Behind: The Movie.'' ''We should have known better, but we didn't.''

title: Sprewell an Exuberant All-Star
description: Latrell Sprewell had a surprise visitor Wednesday afternoon. Shortly after the league informed the Knicks that Commissioner David Stern had made Sprewell an All-Star, Jeff Van Gundy arrived at Sprewell's house bearing the good news.

title: Metro Business Briefing; MANNEQUINS COMING TO NASSAU
description: A mannequin manufacturer is moving to Long Island. Leo D. Bernstein & Sons Inc. of Astoria, Queens and Pasadena, Calif., better known as Bernstein Display, will bring 175 employees to Port Washington. The employees in Astoria will move to the new plant about May 1, and about 40 employees from the Pasadena branch will also work there. The company, which also makes display fixtures and papier-mch bust forms, moved in order to expand, said Roger Friedman, its chief executive and a member of the fourth generation of the family-run business. Mr. Friedman said a tax-free bond issue sponsored by the Nassau County Industrial Development Agency helped attract the 84-year-old firm to Long Island. Tina Kelley

title: PENTAIR CUTS 400 JOBS AT TOOL UNIT AND HEADQUARTERS
description: Pentair Inc., a maker of power tools and electrical equipment, said yesterday that it had cut 400 jobs since the end of the third quarter and that its first-quarter earnings would be better than estimates. The company said 340 of the jobs came from its tools unit, where it closed production the last two weeks of December and the first two weeks of January. Pentair employs 13,000 people. The company also said it cut half the staff at its headquarters, closed executive offices in Minneapolis and moved the operations to its offices in St. Paul. Pentair said its actions would save about $20 million a year.

title: Rule of Thumb, For Starters
description: Aristotle called it the instrument of instruments. He said that it ''is for the body as the intellect is for the soul,'' and he saw it as ideal for grasping in senses both actual and figurative. Quintilian believed that the gestures it made were almost as expressive as words. The great Greek physician Galen found the intricate relationships among its muscles, bones and ligaments ''amazing and indescribable.''

title: Home Video: Choice Films for All Seasons
description: No one recommends movies quite as invitingly as Facets Video , the mail-order arm of a movie-loving organization in Chicago that runs two theaters and a copiously stocked rental library in addition to its mail- order catalog of 50,000 titles.

title: California Lawmakers Pass Energy Plan
description: With deadlines looming and electricity at dangerously low levels for a 17th straight day, the California State Legislature narrowly approved a $10 billion plan today to let the state buy power through long-term contracts, a first step toward stabilizing its troubled utilities and keeping the lights on while officials seek solutions to the state's energy crisis.

title: Energy, in the Arctic and California
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton, on Israeli Television, Sticks Up for the Underdog
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 2  In the Middle East, former President Clinton has not yet exited stage left. Four days before the Israeli election, he appeared tonight in a long interview on Israeli television and indirectly endorsed the underdog, Prime Minister Ehud Barak, by praising his courage in peacemaking.

title: Article 2001020291087155647 -- No Title
description: STATE OF THE ART

title: Lincoln Goes Into Playoffs With a Victory Over Grady
description: Sam Mielnik scored 25 points, 15 of them in the fourth quarter, to lead Lincoln past Grady, 81-67, yesterday in the regular-season finale for both schools in the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn I-A Division at the Louis Armstrong Recreation Center in Queens.

title: The Ashcroft Message
description: The Senate finally approved President Bush's attorney general, John Ashcroft. But the Democrats did so with great reluctance, producing a narrow enough margin to send two strong messages, to Mr. Bush and to Mr. Ashcroft. The message to Mr. Bush is that he should think twice before sending up any more right-wing nominees, especially for the Supreme Court. The message to Mr. Ashcroft is that he would be well advised to name moderates to key positions in the Justice Department that are subject to Senate approval.

description: Leslie Tonkonow

title: Davidson Sommers -- Insurance Executive, 95
description: Davidson Sommers, a former chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society and World Bank official who had a keen interest in philanthropy, died on Dec. 17 at his home in Washington. He was 95.

title: Griffin Struggles And Hall Stumbles
description: Seventeen National Basketball Association scouts, the former Nets coach Chuck Daly and the Hall of Famer Billy Cunningham showed up at Miami Arena tonight, in large part to watch Seton Hall's heralded freshman, Eddie Griffin.

title: 'Sea Gull' Among the Birds
description: If you're a Chekhov fan -- or a Meryl Streep fan or a Christopher Walken fan or a John Goodman fan -- you may want to start lining up now.

title: Brooks Campaigns to Drop 2002 N.H.L. All-Star Game
description: When the National Hockey League's best players and top executives gather in Denver this weekend for the annual All-Star Game, there will be little debate about this season's scheduling or format. The North American team will play the World team on Sunday, the third day of a four-day recess from the regular schedule, which will resume on Tuesday.

Magovern, John C. Magovern, Dr. George Magovern, Jr., Dr. James Magovern, Mary Scott, Susan Magovern, Frances O'Connor and Sr. Ann Magovern. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9.

title: For Some, Uncertainty Replaces Relief Over Ikea's Exit
description: Wednesday was for celebrating. Today there was just apprehension, and lingering suspicion, that the struggle to save an aging neighborhood here from large-scale commercial development was far from over.

title: Using Shock To Peddle The Goods
description: Talk about shock advertising.

title: Japan Banks Are Told Not to Rely on Aid
description: Hakuo Yanagisawa, the head of Japan's Financial Services Agency, said today that banks and their corporate customers should reform themselves to improve the country's financial system and should not expect additional government aid.

title: Energy, in the Arctic and California
description: To the Editor:

title: DDB Worldwide Gets Amex Account
description: The American Stock Exchange, owned by the National Association of Securities Dealers in New York, said yesterday that it had named the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account, which had been handled by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $20 million.

title: Internet Media Company Buys 2 Rivals for $128 Million
description: SonicBlue, an Internet media company, said today that it would buy ReplayTV, a troubled competitor in the business of digital video recorders, for about $120 million in stock.

title: AFTER 4TH-QUARTER LOSS, AIR CANADA PLANS JOB CUTS
description: High fuel prices, harsh weather and the cost of taking over its main rival combined to give Air Canada a fourth-quarter loss of 274 million Canadian dollars ($183 million), the company said yesterday. Excluding one-time costs of merging with Canadian Airlines, the quarterly loss was 174 million Canadian dollars ($116 million), slightly less than indicated in a warning to investors in December. To trim costs, the carrier, based in Montreal, is cutting 3,500 jobs, 8 percent of its work force, and grounding older aircraft. Timothy Pritchard

title: As American Economy Slows, Europeans Suddenly Feel Flush
description: Even as the economic mood of Americans has shifted almost overnight from exuberance to anxiety, Europe has emerged as an oasis of tranquillity and prosperity.

title: Energy, in the Arctic and California
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA PENSION FUND TO BUY STAKE IN CARLYLE GROUP
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's biggest public pension fund, agreed yesterday to buy a stake in the Carlyle Group, part of an agreement to invest up to $850 million with the group, a private equity firm whose advisers include former President George Bush. Calpers, as the fund is known, will pay $175 million for a 5 percent stake in the firm, which is based in Washington. The investment would be the second this week by Calpers in a firm focused on buyouts and venture capital. On Tuesday, it agreed to buy a stake in a new unit of David Bonderman's Texas Pacific Group for $60 million.

title: County in New York Gets New Jersey Help in Opposing Power Plant
description: Bergen County officials today joined the opposition of New York's Rockland County to plans for a 1,100-megawatt electrical generating plant in Suffern, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINK, JOSEPH
description: MINK-Joseph. On January 31, 2001, in his 93rd year. Survived by his loving wife and best friend, Florence, loving father of Marilyn Mundus and the late Phyllis Krain, adored grandfather and greatgrandfather. Service Friday, February 2, 2001, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Center for Special Studies at New York Hospital, c/o of Dr. Jonathan Jacobs, 449 East 68th Street, New York City 10021.

title: PACEMAKER DEVELOPERS HONORED
description: The inventors who developed two early models of pacemakers are to be the first recipients of an engineering award created to rival the Nobel Prize, the National Academy of Engineering said yesterday. Earl Bakken and Wilson Greatbatch will receive the Fritz J. and Dolores H. Russ Prize in a ceremony on Feb. 20. Mr. Russ established the $500,000 award with an $8 million endowment through Ohio University. The Nobel Prize is not awarded for engineering. Mr. Bakken developed a battery-powered, transistorized pacemaker in 1957, and Mr. Greatbatch, building on Mr. Bakken's work on components and materials, developed an implantable device three years later.

title: My Germ Is Yours
description: It all started out so innocently. One lousy night out, one crummy evening away from my husband and children with a couple of my girlfriends, one of whom happened to be recovering from a cold -- and this is what I get?

title: Houston Journal; Honky-Tonk Love Gets Its Day in Probate Court
description: The spectacle of rich people fighting over money ranks just below football as a favorite spectator sport in Texas, so it seemed fitting that Anna Nicole Smith took the stand in the lawsuit over her billionaire husband's estate on the day after the Super Bowl.

description: What kind of children's films rarely feature superheroes, may not end happily and aren't even long enough to get you through a bag of popcorn?

Adored uncle of Eric and Justine, Nicole, Jodi, Ethan and Torre. Viewing February 3, White-Love Funeral Home, Chesterton, IN.

title: His Friend Is Sweet 17, But Alas, Unavailable
description: As embarrassingly inept as they may seem in retrospect, our fumbling adolescent initiations into sex often turn out to be as momentous as any events in our lives, at least in memory. But how do you make a credible movie about such a tender subject in which tumultuous inner drama is often absurdly at odds with behavior that looks foolishly gawky?

description: MUCH of this job consists of dodging pitches from press agents, but once in a lifetime something different comes along. Your pulse races. You suddenly remember why you got into the business. You cannot believe the words you have just heard:

description: YELLEN-Charles John. Beloved husband for 70 years, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He is survived by his wife, Sadie; Lloyd, Sunny and Rita, his five grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. His warm sense of humor will be greatly missed.

title: Hearing on an Airline Merger Raises Wider Concerns
description: The proposed purchase of Trans World Airlines by American Airlines was supposed to be the subject of a Senate committee hearing today, but it strayed into a discussion about frustrations over high air fares, industry consolidation and airline delays. Several lawmakers raised the idea of blocking the merger legislatively, or retaliating with a passenger-rights bill.

title: Tossed Into a Tempest Over a Pardon; Friends See Navet, Critics a Payoff in a Clinton Fund-Raiser's Acts
description: A central question in the always interesting life of Denise Rich, the pop songwriter and fabulous Fifth Avenue party girl who has given more than $1 million to the Clintons and Democratic causes, is this: Was her largess in the interest of buying a presidential pardon for her ex-husband and the father of her children, the fugitive billionaire Marc Rich? Or were her motives more subtle and complex?

description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

title: WEBMETHODS ACHIEVES PROFITABILITY
description: WebMethods Inc., a software maker specializing in application integration, said third-quarter revenues had risen by 237 percent to $59.4 million or 5 cents a share, beating Wall Street forecasts of a penny a share. The company said on Wednesday that it had added more than 85 new clients during the quarter, bringing its total customer base to more than 550. Unlike many other companies in the beleaguered business-to-business e-commerce sector, WebMethods has reached profitability in its first year as a public company. Andrew Zipern

title: Separate Quarters on Good Ship Lollipop
description: Stories of Hollywood perfidy have always been seductive. The cruelties of the business have been mined for melodrama in movies like ''Sunset Boulevard'' and for satire in pictures like ''The Player.'' Audiences especially crave stories that emphasize the terrible price one pays for success. It's no accident that ''A Star Is Born'' was made three times.

title: En Route to the Bridal Path After Stumbles and Tumbles
description: The Wedding Planner

title: First, a Murder, and Then Everything Goes Downhill
description: Alex Winter's ''Fever,'' a somber, paranoid thriller set in New York's outer-borough bohemia, tracks the psychological unraveling of a young artist and drawing instructor named Nick Parker (Henry Thomas), who lives in a run-down tenement in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The murder of his landlord sets off a chain of troubling events, some of which seem to take place in Nick's imagination.

title: Verdict's Reasoning
description: When the defense in the Lockerbie bombing trial was making its 21-hour-long summation speeches last month, the prosecution's case was described as a cable made of frayed fibers, each a line of circumstantial evidence that could not support the conclusions suspended from it.

description: After the 52 Americans who were held hostage in the United States embassy in Tehran were released on Jan. 20, 1981, they were shown an hourlong video that summarized the world events they had missed during their 444 days in captivity.

title: Iverson Takes Blows, Then Deals Knicks One
description: Allen Iverson fought all night, against Knicks who tried to neutralize his blazing speed by clutching and bumping, against referees who often watched the brawling without blowing their whistles, and against his own shot, which more often than not bounced off the rim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, LONA B.
description: WOLF-Lona B. Born June 15, 1910, died peacefully at home on January 31, 2001. Beloved sister of Emma C. Lynaugh, Frances M. Deegan and Harry J. Wolf. Devoted sister-in-law of Marie Giblin Wolf, Marie Frey Wolf and Agnes Morr Wolf. Adored ''Auntie'' to her many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grand-nephews that survive her. Loyal friend to all. We will greatly miss this generous and selfless lady who gave so much to others throughout her lifetime. Reposing at Thomas C. Montera Funeral Home, 1848 Westchester Ave., Bronx, NY, Saturday and Sunday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10:00 AM, Blessed Sacrament Church, Bronx, NY. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Cathedral High School Scholarship Fund, 350 E. 56 St., New York, NY 10022-4199.

Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, corner of 81st, on Monday, February 5, 2:00-4:00 PM and 7:00-9:00 PM; Mass on Tuesday, February 6, at 10:30 AM at Saint Patrick's Cathedral. Private interment in Southampton. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund (William Goodloe or Helen Lowe, 212753-8583) and the Family Academy (Nancy McDonnell, 212749-3558).

description: DILLOFF-Jerome. Died suddenly on Feb. 1, 2001 of Boca Raton, Florida formerly of Lawrence, LI, NY. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Slifka) devoted father of Leni (Robert) Newman, Jr. and Nancy (Andrew) Schlesinger, brother of Morton, loving grandfather of Meg (David) Bitton and Rachel Schlesinger. Services private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity in Jerome's memory.

title: Jets Filling Out Their Staff
description: The Jets hired an assistant coach and a director for player development and retained another assistant yesterday.

title: Will Aid Make Churches Docile?
description: President Bush's decision to expand partnerships between religious organizations and federally financed social services has sparked a raging controversy about the separation of church and state.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Last Chance section of the Art Guide in Weekend yesterday misstated the closing date for ''A Century of Design, Part 3: 1950-75,'' at the Metropolitan Museum. It is May 27, not tomorrow.

title: Dragila Stays Up Late For Pole-Vault Record
description: Until 11:40 p.m., the Millrose Games belonged to the senior citizens. There was Johnny Gray, pounding the boards and winning the Millrose 800 meters for the fifth time in his career. There was Regina Jacobs, who pulled out of the 2000 Olympics with a respiratory infection, showing the world what it had missed, winning the mile for the third consecutive year.

title: Violets Use Late Jumper To Shock Washington
description: New York University knew it. So did its fans. If the Violets, who won the 1997 N.C.A.A. Division III title, were to win their second national championship, they would have to beat Washington University.

title: Mexico to Extradite an Argentine Accused of Genocide to Spain
description: Mexico decided today to extradite a former Argentine Navy officer, accused of abuses committed under Argentina's dictatorship 20 years ago, to face charges in Madrid.

title: 24-Hour Record For Distance Broken
description: Innovation Explorer, the 110-foot catamaran skippered by Loick Peyron of France, shattered the record for distance covered in 24 hours by a boat yesterday in The Race, a fully-crewed round-the-world competition.

title: BP Amoco Will Sell Stake in Caspian Sea Oil Field
description: BP Amoco said it had agreed in principle to sell its stake in the huge Kashagan oil field in the Caspian Sea to TotalFinaElf, advancing TotalFinaElf's campaign to gain management control of what many in the industry believe will prove to be the world's largest oil development project.

title: A Winter Garden Changes Bleak to Bright
description: Ten years ago, two brothers in my central New Jersey town, both seasoned gardeners, decided to create a colorful winter garden on their street. They wanted to provide both neighbors and passers-by with a refreshing, festive display at a bleak time of year.

title: At Donn Handicap, Jockeying Begins Before It's Post Time
description: The veteran jockey Pat Day changed horses to improve his chances of winning Saturday's $500,000 Donn Handicap, the year's first major handicap race in the East. The race favorite, Captain Steve, completed his final days of preparation in the care of a competitor. And the trainer Nick Zito has a good feeling about winning his second straight Donn.

title: Knicks at Home Beating the Nets Across the River
description: It was another humiliation in what has seemed to be an endless string of them for the Nets. The fans who filled Continental Arena tonight were decked out in blue and orange. In the Nets' first sellout of the season, many of the 20,049 fans came to cheer for the visitors from across the river.

title: Clinton Offers Help
description: Former President Bill Clinton has called the Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, to offer help after the earthquake in Gujarat State.

title: EL SITIO, AN INTERNET PROVIDER, IS CUTTING STAFF
description: El Sitio, an Internet provider in Latin America, said yesterday that it planned to cut 125 jobs as it tried to trim costs before its acquisition by the Cisneros Group, the Venezuelan media giant, and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the private equity firm. El Sitio, which has about 500 workers, said it expected to save $8 million and $9 million a year. The company, based in Buenos Aires, did not say when the cuts -- in marketing, advertising, sales and administration -- would be completed. In October, Cisneros and Hicks, Muse agreed to take over El Sitio to form Claxson Interactive Group.

title: Critical Path Suspends 2 Executives and Starts Financial Inquiry
description: Two weeks after it shocked Wall Street with dreary quarterly earnings, Critical Path, a once highflying provider of corporate e-mail systems, announced today that it had suspended two top executives and started an internal investigation into its financial practices.

title: A Different Campaign Trail
description: Four days before Israelis vote, Bill Clinton appeared on television and indirectly endorsed the underdog, Prime Minister Ehud Barak, by praising his peacemaking. Page A3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURLEY, MIRIAM
description: HURLEY-Miriam. Of Boston and Chilmark, Marthas Vineyard (formerly of Weston) on Thursday, February 1, 2001. Miriam Greene Hurley, age 90. Wife of the late Donald J. Hurley. Mother of Cornelia Hurley McPeek of Chestnut Hill, Donald Hurley, Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, NY, Stephen Nash Hurley of Boston and Rosamond Page Shugrue of Boston. Grandmother of several grandchildren. There will be a private family Mass. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, March 9, 2001 at the Memorial Church of Harvard University, Harvard Yard, Cambridge at 3:00 P.M. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Miriam Greene Hurley Memorial Fund at the Martha's Vineyard Garden Club, RFD 319X, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568. For information please contact J.S. WatermanEastman-Waring Funeral Services, Boston, MA. (617)536-4110.

title: BAER's PROFIT INCREASES
description: Julius Baer Holding, Switzerland's largest private bank, said second-half profit rose 45 percent, as the family-controlled company benefited from lagging investment performance at Zurich-based rivals. Net income at the 111-year-old bank increased to 183 million Swiss francs ($111 million) from 126.1 million, a spokesman, Jan Bielinski, said. The company, which has a market value of 9.3 billion ($5.7 billion) francs, also plans to split its shares 10 for 1.

title: Energy Secretary Rejects Request to Cap Electricity Price
description: Spencer Abraham, the federal energy secretary, rejected a plea from several Western governors today for the federal government to impose temporary price caps on wholesale electricity, after listening to their concerns that ''exorbitant'' and ''out-of-control'' electricity costs were spreading economic havoc across the region.

title: Agency Approves Sale of Stores In Bankrupt Grand Union Chain
description: Ending a three-month competition for the supermarkets owned by Grand Union, the Federal Trade Commission yesterday approved a piecemeal sale of nearly all the bankrupt grocery chain's stores.

title: In the Wake of Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Accepts Sotheby's Guilty Plea in Price Fixing
description: A federal judge accepted a guilty plea yesterday by Sotheby's to price fixing and collusion with its competitor Christie's and approved a $45 million fine that the auction house had agreed to pay in a plea agreement with prosecutors.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index
