description: BELFER-Ira M. Dear friend, counselor, and brother-in-law for over 60 years. A man of high intellect, dignity and professionalism who we will miss greatly. Our heartfelt condolences to Jean, Myron, Sandy, Russell and Philip. Jack and Marjorie Schleifer

title: Illinois Governor Dogged By Inquiry Into Corruption
description: At the start of Gov. George Ryan's State of the State address on Wednesday, he proudly introduced his six children and, by name, the dozen or more grandchildren who were sitting in the balcony of the Illinois General Assembly.

title: Energy Costs Catapult Idaho Regulator Into Public Eye
description: THEY have had it good, the residents of Idaho. Energy crisis, what energy crisis? In Idaho, electricity users have been paying about a nickel a kilowatt hour, the cheapest rate in the country and half what Californians pay.

title: CONFIDENCE SLIPS IN EUROPE
description: Confidence among executives and consumers in the euro region fell to the lowest level in 15 months in January amid concern an economic slowdown in the United States will spill across the Atlantic. A European Commission index, based on a survey of 25,000 consumers and 50,000 companies, fell to 103, the lowest since October 1999, from 103.3 in December. Manufacturers' orders weakened, and their outlook for future production worsened.

title: Who Is 'Civilized'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Journal; A Church Sells Its Silver, And Finds a Silver Lining
description: Events that occurred across hundreds of years at one American church may sound more like a parable than actual fact.

title: Clinton, Out, Says What Little He Can to Keep Barak In
description: In the Middle East, former President Bill Clinton has not yet exited stage left. Four days before the Israeli election, he appeared tonight in a long Israeli television interview and indirectly endorsed the underdog, Prime Minister Ehud Barak, by praising his courage in peacemaking.

title: Expert Says Car Weight Was Key in Tire Failures
description: Firestone tires have been failing on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles because of a combination of factors, especially the vehicle's weight, according to a report issued today by a professor retained by Bridgestone/Firestone Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, ERNESTINE
description: ALTMAN-Ernestine. On January 31, 2001. Beloved mother of Joan Schmulson. Mother-in-law of Barry. Devoted grandmother of Louis and Robin. Her memory will be cherished forever. Funeral services on Sunday, February 4, at 12:30 PM from ''Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel'' 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY.

title: Bright Lights, Big Thinkers
description: New York is the capital of commerce, finance and art, ground zero for the bagel and home to the Yankees and the Mets. So why not the center of philosophy, too?

title: Ertl Races To Victory On a Tender Right Knee
description: It has been a frustrating world championships for the host nation. After three events, the Wunderteam has been well short of wonderful and is still waiting for its first skiing victory.

title: INSIDE
description: Decline in Illegal Migration

title: TRADE PANEL TO EXAMINE BRAZILIAN LAW
description: The World Trade Organization has agreed to examine a United States complaint that Brazil's 1997 patent law discriminates against imported products. At issue is whether Brazilian companies can engage in so-called patent theft -- manufacturing patented items when they are not made in Brazil. Companies must wait three years in Brazil to win the legal right to manufacture a patented product. Urging the United States to drop its complaint, Doctors Without Borders said it could handicap Brazil's AIDS program by limiting the production of antiretroviral drugs now made generically by local companies. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, LONA B.
description: WOLF-Lona B. Born June 15, 1910, died peacefully at home on January 31, 2001. Beloved sister of Emma C. Lynaugh, Frances M. Deegan and Harry J. Wolf. Devoted sister-in-law of Marie Giblin Wolf, Marie Frey Wolf and Agnes Morr Wolf. Adored ''Auntie'' to her many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grand-nephews that survive her. Loyal friend to all. We will greatly miss this generous and selfless lady who gave so much to others throughout her lifetime. Reposing at Thomas C. Montera Funeral Home, 1848 Westchester Ave., Bronx, NY, Saturday and Sunday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10:00 AM, Blessed Sacrament Church, Bronx, NY. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Cathedral High School Scholarship Fund, 350 E. 56 St., New York, NY 10022-4199.

title: Boston Is Said to Broach Conductor's Job to Levine
description: James Levine, artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera, has been talking to Boston Symphony Orchestra members and officials about succeeding Seiji Ozawa as music director, people familiar with the discussions said this week.

title: Airports Fighting Long Expansion Delays Find a Top Ally
description: One tool for reducing air traffic delays is concrete mixers pouring new runways, the secretary of transportation said today, and he pledged to look for ways to reduce the time needed for airport operators to win construction approval from the government.

title: Corrections
description: Anews analysis article yesterday about the trial of the men accused of having blown up Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, misstated the given name of a former prosecutor with experience in terrorism cases who commented on the issue of witnesses' credibility. He is Richard Davis, not Robert.

title: American Bankers Invade Europe
description: In the summer of 1998, the United States was in the midst of its first trillion-dollar year of mergers and acquisitions. The value of all takeovers was outpacing the record from the previous year of $922 billion, and Michael Klein wanted to be where the action was.

title: Sports of The Times; Ready or Not, Fans Get Hit With XFL
description: WHEN Rusty Tillman was interviewed by Vince McMahon, impresario for the XFL, to be coach of the league's New York/New Jersey entry called the Hitmen, he wondered: when a guy scores a touchdown, does an opposing player hit him over the head with a chair?

title: Article 2001020390467722466 -- No Title
description: February 3, 2001

title: Border Agents Reporting Fewer Illegal Mexican Immigrants
description: The number of seizures of illegal immigrants crossing from Mexico into the United States has ebbed in recent months, according to law enforcement agents along the border.

title: Constance M. Anderson -- Volunteer Worker, 102
description: Constance Myers Anderson, a former head of both the New York City and national Young Women's Christian Association, died Jan. 31 at her retirement home in Kennett Square, Penn. Mrs. Anderson, a former resident of New York City and of Wilton, Conn., was 102.

title: Editorial Observer; How George W. Bush Can Reach Black Voters
description: The White House is spinning this week's meeting between President Bush and the Congressional Black Caucus as proof that Mr. Bush is mending fences with a black electorate that is still seething over the election irregularities in Florida. But even as he posed for photographs with the Black Caucus this week, the Senate was closing out a bitter confirmation debate on his choice as attorney general, John Ashcroft, known for his fervent opposition to court-ordered busing and especially for the racially tinged rhetoric he used to defeat the nomination to the federal bench of the respected black Missouri Supreme Court justice Ronnie White.

title: A Debunker? Just Call Me A Schlemiel
description: IT was quite a kick in the head to learn this week that the Shot Heard Round the World was not what we'd thought.

title: Article 2001020391197312757 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Congo's New Leader, at the U.N., Pledges Talks With War Foes
description: Congo's new president, Joseph Kabila, came before the Security Council today and pledged to open an unreserved dialogue with his opponents at home in hope of ending the nation's long civil war.

title: Civil War Brews in City Council Over Bill to Overturn Term Limits
description: In a darkened corner of the gilded ceiling that hangs over the City Council chambers in City Hall, there is an inscription that quotes Ulysses S. Grant: Let us have peace. It is a timely appeal even today, considering that another civil war is about to break out in these chambers -- one that threatens to turn local government upside down.

title: Edmund Fuller, 86, Novelist and Historian
description: Edmund Fuller, a novelist, historian and literary critic, died on Monday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 86.

title: A Relationship Sealed
description: Diane Von Furstenberg and Barry Diller married yesterday at City Hall.

title: Article 2001020390341729373 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Yet More Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Ashcroft and the Divided Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: Testimony About a Gun In Combs Case Is Softened
description: The only witness to testify so far that Sean Combs, the hip-hop mogul, had a gun in a crowded nightclub during a shooting in 1999 softened her statements yesterday under cross-examination. She said that her initial account to the police was influenced by her friends' recollections.

title: What Good Is Math? An Answer for Jocks
description: Here's the scheduling problem that faced the XFL, the new smack-in-the-mouth, kick-in-the-groin professional football league that has its premiere tonight.

title: Federal Leftovers? I'll Take My Check Now
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOK DEALER'S ACQUISITION
description: Approval from Canada's Competition Bureau is all that stands in the way of a merger between Canada's largest book retailer, Chapters Inc., and No. 2 Indigo Books Music and More. A proposal to merge the two, which control more than 40 percent of Canada's $1.3 billion book market, will follow the successful takeover of Chapters by the husband and wife team behind Indigo. Gerald Schwartz, Canada's best-known leveraged buyout specialist, and his wife, Heather Reisman, who controls Indigo, won over Chapters' largest shareholders on Thursday after a three-month battle. After initially offering 64 million Canadian dollars ($43 million) for 50.1 percent of Chapters, the couple eventually agreed to pay 122 million Canadian dollars ($82 million) for 70 percent. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, ANITA S. (NEE SAMUELS)
description: GREENBLATT-Anita S. (nee Samuels), on Thursday, February 1, 2001. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Fair Lawn, Wyckoff and Hackensack, NJ. Beloved wife of Nathan E. Greenblatt. Devoted mother of Jane Greenblatt-Di Fede and her husband, Michael, and Samuel D. Greenblatt and his wife, Barbara. Proud grandmother of Elizabeth Greenblatt, Rebecca Di Fede & David Di Fede. Services 1PM Monday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Rte. 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ. Memorial donations in memory of Anita S. Greenblatt may be made to American Heart Association, American Cancer Society, or Temple Emanuel, 151 East 33rd Street, Paterson, NJ 07514.

title: Jury Deliberating East Village Eviction Case
description: Another chapter in a five-year legal fight over an East Village community organization neared an end yesterday as lawyers for the organization, Charas/El Bohio, and the landlord who is trying to evict it gave closing arguments in a trial that had lasted more than two weeks.

title: Gretzky Supports Playing All-Star Game in Olympic Year
description: Like Herb Brooks, the coach of the United States hockey team for next year's Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, Wayne Gretzky, the general manager of the Canadian team, would like each competing nation to have sufficient time to practice before the Olympics. But, Gretzky said today, not at the expense of next season's National Hockey League All-Star Game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWLICHT, MARTIN
description: LOWLICHT-Martin. Of Manhasset, NY. On Feb. 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Claire. Loving father of Nan and Ben Hall of Tiverton, RI., and Dr. Roger and Dr. Kay of Pine Orchard, CT. Dearest grandfather to Elizabeth and Caroline Hall and Harrison and Spencer Lowlicht. Services on February 4, 1:00 PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', Great Neck, NY.

title: Bush, the Conciliator, Meets With Democrats
description: President Bush ventured into enemy territory today, meeting with Senate Democrats to outline his hopes for his first year in office.

title: BRAZIL'S TELECOM AUCTION DELAYED
description: he Brazilian government yesterday called off the first round of a $3.4 billion auction for cellular licenses that had been scheduled for Tuesday after the only bidder was disqualified. Serranby Participaes S.A., a venture between the Brazilian fixed-line operator Brasil Telecom Participaes S.A. and Opportunity Asset Management, was disqualified from the sale of the three wireless licenses. Brazil plans to sell six other licenses in two additional rounds the next two months. Seven local telecommunications companies have expressed an interest in the coming sales. Jennifer Rich (NYT)

title: Rice Is Considering Options For Dealing With Foot Pain
description: Glen Rice plunged his left foot into a bucket of ice to alleviate some of the pain. Rice never knows until he is on the court how long he will be able to play, if at all. While tonight was a good night for him -- 16 points in the Knicks' 95-71 victory over the Nets -- he admitted that the nagging pain could push him to the sideline for an extended period.

title: Murray Edelman, 81, Professor And Pioneer in Political Science
description: Murray Edelman, who in the 1960's and 70's helped pioneer a new approach to political science by arguing that the true importance of many political acts and institutions is often very different from what it seems, died on Jan. 26 in Madison, Wis. He was 81.

title: NEW JERSEY AGREES TO PAY $13 MILLION IN PROFILING SUIT
description: New Jersey's attorney general today agreed to pay nearly $13 million to settle a lawsuit arising from the state's most explosive racial profiling incident, in which several young minority men were shot and wounded by state troopers in a 1998 traffic stop.

title: Technology Dampens Stocks as Job News Sends Mixed Signals
description: A sharp drop in technology shares pulled the stock market lower yesterday as investors got mixed signals from the January employment report. Bond prices also fell, pushing yields higher.

title: The Making of a Suspect: The Case of Wen Ho Lee
description: The crime sounded alarming: China had stolen the design of America's most advanced nuclear weapon. The suspect seemed suspicious enough: Wen Ho Lee, a Taiwanese-born scientist at Los Alamos nuclear laboratory, had a history of contact with Chinese scientists and a record of deceiving the authorities on security matters.

title: Article 2001020392447519606 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: Gifts Properly Returned
description: Former President Bill Clinton and his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, have made an ethically correct and politically necessary decision to pay for the gifts showered on them by supporters as they left the White House. The move was especially important for Mrs. Clinton, since her political standing had eroded seriously in her first weeks in office. It was not just Republicans accusing her of mimicking her husband's grasping approach to money and political favors. Democrats who voted for her to continue the state's progressive senatorial tradition were speaking openly of their sense of betrayal.

title: Money Can't Measure Jeter's Value to Yanks
description: Tom Hicks, an experienced entrepreneur, found love at first sight and paid handsomely for it. Hicks, the owner of the Texas Rangers, gave Alex Rodriguez $252 million for 10 years, more than any athlete had ever secured in a contract.

title: Estate Tax Folly
description: It has been more than 100 years since Andrew Carnegie wrote that ''great sums'' bequeathed to the children of the wealthy ''work more for the injury than for the good of the recipients.'' Today Carnegie's sentiment favoring the diversion of inherited wealth to the public good seems almost quaint. But the debate over the fairness of the estate tax continues to rage, with President Bush advocating full repeal over time and the Democrats favoring adjustments that would retain the tax on the wealthiest Americans. In this debate, it is worth remembering a few first principles that would argue against throwing out the tax.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Jan. 25 about contacts among graffiti writers over the Internet misidentified the group with which one Norwegian works. The writer -- identified only by his graffiti signature, or tag, Card/Hovs -- is a member of the BEA group, not the Back Alley Bombers. BEA's Web site is bea .graffiti.dk.

title: Editing the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSTON, ELBERT
description: JOHNSTON-Elbert. 5/25/63-2/3/78. A child full of life. So long as we remember-you live. Love, Buni and Mom

title: Former Prosecutor Sentenced for Fraud
description: NEWARK, Feb. 3  A former federal prosecutor and securities industry regulator who became a conspirator in an $80 million telemarketing fraud and then helped law enforcement agencies mount a sting operation was sentenced today to two years in prison.

title: Acing the College Boards
description: The postseason history of Stanford's men's basketball team fits neatly on 13 lines stenciled on a small wall by the team's locker room in Maples Pavilion. The list begins in 1942, skips the post-World War II generation, bypasses the 1970's and jumps to 1988.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the trial of the men accused of having blown up Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, misstated the given name of a former prosecutor with experience in terrorism cases who commented on the issue of witnesses' credibility. He is Richard Davis, not Robert.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Keep courage. I've lost my wife. I've lost my daughter. I've lost my granddaughter. But I have courage.''

title: Article 2001020392163215456 -- No Title
description: By SUSAN STELLIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKELMAN, RABBI A. JOSEPH
description: HECKELMAN-Rabbi A. Joseph. We record with profound sadness the passing of our beloved colleague. After ordination he made aliyah and became the founding rabbi of the Conservative/Masorti community in Safed, a position he held until his death and also served as president of the Rabbinical Assembly in Israel. He was a pioneer on behalf of our movement in Israel and dedicated his life to our rabbis and our movement there. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Tzipora, children, Joshua and Sara and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Executive Vice President The Rabbinical Assembly

title: 1 Hurt in Steam Blast
description: A steam tank exploded in a maintenance area at Pennsylvania Station last evening, injuring a worker, causing the basement ceiling of a nearby Kmart to collapse and making dozens of shoppers flee.

title: Teenagers at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, LILLIAN P.
description: KAUFMAN-Lillian P. On Thursday, February 1, 2001. Devoted mother of Marilyn E. Merlob. Cherished grandmother of Lauren and Darren. ''Gigi'' of Jake and Sydney. Dear sister of Dr. Irving Price. Services 1:30PM Sunday at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Ashcroft Gets Acquainted on First Day of New Job
description: On his first day in office, Attorney General John Ashcroft toured the Justice Department's headquarters, met with heads of the agency's principal divisions and took a drug test that is required of all new department employees.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about city parks officials' surprise that a great blue heron was spending the winter near the Turtle Pond in Central Park omitted a dissenting view about the rarity of such behavior in the city's busiest park. ''The Birds of Central Park: An Annotated Checklist'' (Central Park Conservancy, 1996) lists great blue herons as year-round visitors to the park. Bird-watchers who compile that list and ornithologists at the American Museum of Natural History say it is not unusual for the birds to spend the winter in Central Park if there is open water.

title: Chester Rapkin, 82, Urban Planning Theorist
description: Chester A. Rapkin, an influential theorist of urban planning who came up with the novel designation SoHo for the rapidly changing community south of Houston Street in Manhattan, died on Sunday at a hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 82 and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Rebel to Meet Colombian President
description: The leader of Colombia's largest rebel group today accepted President Andrs Pastrana's offer of a face-to-face meeting aimed at thawing frozen peace talks.

title: Poll Reveals Higher Marks For the Police
description: Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik's efforts to mend the Police Department's frayed relationship with minorities appear to be making progress, according to the results of a recent Quinnipiac University poll, which indicates that the bitterness many black and Hispanic New Yorkers feel toward the police has softened.

title: How Do I Kill Thee? Let Me Count the Ways
description: ''Valentine'' is in the tradition of heartwarming holiday classics like ''Black Christmas,'' ''Friday the 13th'' and ''Halloween.'' Years ago Jay Leno had a joke about the ultimate film along these lines, an angry Thanksgiving picture called ''Turkey: This Time, It's His Turn to Do the Carving!'' ''Valentine'' could have been part of that routine, since it feels like both a joke and a turkey.

title: CHENEY ASSEMBLES FORMIDABLE TEAM
description: Vice President Dick Cheney is assembling a powerful parallel White House staff, including a mini-National Security Council and domestic policy team, to support his formidable role in shaping the Bush agenda and brokering it on Capitol Hill.

title: Successes of Reality TV Put Networks in 'Survivor' Mode
description: The CBS reality series ''Survivor: The Australian Outback'' scored a huge ratings success Thursday night, bringing in almost 30 million viewers and a particularly strong rating among young people.

title: Strouds Bankruptcy Sale
description: CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif., Feb. 2  Strouds Inc., a seller of bed and bath linens, has asked a bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del., to approve its plan to sell 50 stores and most of its remaining assets to iHome Inc. for about $38 million. IHome, which sells linens and furniture over the Internet, agreed to buy all but six of Strouds's stores, all its trademarks and copyrights, two distribution centers and a Web site, Strouds said. Strouds filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in September.

title: Landlocked Berth for Boat Lovers; New York Yacht Club Spruces Up Its Grand Home And Finds It Can Thrive Without America's Cup
description: They do not have the fabulous trophy anymore, that pitcher-shaped chunk of silver with the curly-topped handle -- the America's Cup. But they still have the fabulous building, the landlocked monument to the damn-the-torpedoes determination of J. Pierpont Morgan and his turn-of-the-century seafaring chums.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the court case in Chile against Gen. Augusto Pinochet misidentified the ocean into which the military apparently dumped the father of Viviana Daz, a woman who leads a group of surviving family members. It was the Pacific, not the Atlantic.

title: For Jeter, the Magic Number May Be $189 Million
description: Mike Piazza rejected an $80 million offer in his last days with the Los Angeles Dodgers and a young Yankees shortstop was aghast at the financial enormity.

title: Sky Watch: How Many Stars Are There?
description: Those who are involved in popularizing astronomy are asked certain questions time and again. One of these is, How many stars are there? Only when one is blessed with a rare glimpse of a star-spangled sky with its myriad luminaries can we understand why this question occurs. Special computer analysis can readily answer the question. Most people probably want to know how many stars they can see with their unaided eyes.

title: No Longer Alone: The Scientist Who Dared to Say Animals Think
description: Donald Griffin was at the Central Park Zoo last month watching the polar bears nuzzle a synthetic log smeared with Skippy. ''They really like that peanut butter,'' Dr. Griffin observed as Gus, 800 pounds, tried to fit his nose into an enticingly sticky knothole.

title: Stanford Researcher Convicted And Sentenced Again in China
description: A Chinese-born researcher at Stanford University who was arrested here three years ago on charges of revealing state secrets has been convicted for a second time and given a 10-year sentence, according to relatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOELLER, ALICE
description: MOELLER-Alice. Wife of the late William J. Reilly and the late Frederick E. Moeller, of Weston, CT, died February 1, 2001. Mother of Patricia Reilly Giff of Weston, CT, and Anne Reilly Eisele. Services Monday, 10 AM, at Notre Dame Church, Easton, CT. Visiting Sunday, 3-7, at Shaughnessey Funeral Home, 50 Reef Road, Fairfield.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an exhibition of William Blake's verse, painting and illustration at the Tate Britain museum in London misstated the dates for a modified version coming to the Metropolitan in New York. They are March 29 through June 24, not March 8 through May 27.

title: Report Calls Networks' Election Night Coverage a Disaster
description: In a report commissioned by CNN, three journalism experts excoriated television coverage of the presidential race on election night as a ''news disaster,'' and blamed the networks for creating a political climate of ''rancor and bitterness.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERLINICH, ELIZABETH MCKEE
description: WERLINICH-Elizabeth McKee. 52, of New York City and Southampton, NY, succumbed to cancer on Dec. 19, 2000, ending a courageous seven-year battle. She is survived by her loving husband of 25 years Douglas, her mother Elinor H. McKee of Corvallis, Oregon and Larchmont, NY, her brothers Richard and Donald, her stepson Gregory, her grandchildren Nola, Lily and Ezra, and her beloved cats Isabelle and Cedric. Mrs. Werlinich, a graduate of Sweet Briar College, was Vice President-International Field Marketing for Estee Lauder International, where she was employed for 21 years following an initial career with Chase Manhattan Bank. Friends and relatives will gather to commemorate Elizabeth's inspiring life at 4pm on February 19th at the Brick Presbyterian Church on Park Avenue at 91st Street in New York City, followed by a reception at The House of the Redeemer at 7 East 95th Street. In lieu of flowers or other expressions of remembrance, friends may wish to make a donation in Elizabeth's name to the Pain and Palliative Care Service fo the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. This would help to further the privately funded work of this extraordinary group of professionals who were so helpful to Elizabeth and her family during the last two years of her life. Checks should be made payable to order of the Pain and Palliative Care Service, MSKCC and addressed to: Mrs Freya Wigler, Pain & Palliative Care Service, MSKCC, Department of Neurology, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: U.S. and Microsoft Agree On Procedure for Appeal
description: Microsoft and the government filed an agreement with the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit today laying out the structure for their oral arguments later this month in the appeal of the antitrust ruling against the company.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Two Rare Plays in One Deal: All in an Expert Day's Work
description: To do something unusual in defense is always satisfying. To do two unusual things in one deal is rare indeed and worthy of note. The hero was Mike Passell of Dallas, a former world champion and one of the greats of the game. He recently acquired his 50,000th master point, the second player in history to reach that level.

title: Tapes Spy Chief Left Behind Scandalize Peru
description: They were the most closely guarded secrets of President Alberto K. Fujimori's rule, thousands of videotapes documenting the corruption and sexual high jinks of Peru's most powerful people that his spy chief used to blackmail and control virtually the entire political establishment.

title: Federal Leftovers? Ill Take My Check Now
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Family Fare column of Weekend yesterday about the New York Academy of Sciences' 2001 Science and Technology Expo and Family Science Day at City College misstated the date. It is tomorrow, not today.

title: Jet Loses a Panel Moments After Takeoff
description: A small metal panel flew off a Continental Airlines jet after it took off from Newark International Airport yesterday, prompting the pilot to return there, the airline said.

title: $2 Million for a Seat
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold yesterday for $2 million, a $300,000 increase from the last seat sale. The previous sale, on Dec. 15 for $1.7 million, had marked the first drop in the price of a Big Board seat in about six months. The stock exchange does not disclose the names of people who buy or sell seats. Three seats sold at $2 million each in September and November, down from a record $2.65 million set in August 1999. Another seat is now being offered at $2.5 million, and the highest bid is $1.9 million, the N.Y.S.E. said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIPSNER, JESSIE
description: LEIPSNER-Jessie. Beloved wife of Samuel. Devoted mother of Dr. George Leipsner and Judith Davis. Cherished mother-in-law of Sheila Leipsner. Dear sister of Murray and Isador Salwen and the late Lilly Liebenson and Goldie Steckelman. Loving grandmother of Joyce, Alan, Lisa and Michelle and great-grandmother of Eliza and Lauren. Services ''GuttermanMusicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ Sunday 10:30 AM.

title: Fugitive in French Corruption Scandal Is Arrested in Philippines
description: A French oil executive who once bragged that he had enough information about corrupt officials ''to bring down the Republic 20 times'' was arrested today in the Philippines after four years on the run.

title: A Biblical Theme Park in Florida Begets Ill Will
description: In a city that has a theme park to satisfy just about every taste, the latest addition can truly be called an original, or a sin, depending upon whom you ask.

title: For Diller and Von Furstenberg, a Merger
description: After 26 years as New York society's most notoriously unattached couple, Diane Von Furstenberg and Barry Diller, the chairman of USA Networks, officially sealed their relationship with a City Hall wedding yesterday followed by a party for 350 guests at Ms. Von Furstenberg's Greenwich Village carriage house.

title: Loyalty and Distrust of System Helped Keep Abuse Hidden
description: There was the time when one of the aunts called the boys' father, tormented by bad dreams that the boys' mother, Linda A. Harley, was going to harm them.

title: A DESIRE TO DUPLICATE
description: A grieving family hopes to replace a lost child. A genetics-obsessed sect dreams of achieving immortality. Is this how human cloning begins? A report by Margaret Talbot in The Times Magazine.

title: At Home Abroad; Bush And AIDS
description: The most profound and immediate threat to life on earth is the AIDS epidemic. According to the National Institutes of Health, more than 36 million people in the world now have H.I.V. or full-blown AIDS. Every day about 15,000 are newly infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: A Village Still Stands By Its Nuclear Plant
description: Even as it returned to full power this week, the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant was being reviled by environmentalists as a sloppily run menace to Westchester County and scrutinized by public officials who had recently called for its closing.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS AGREES TO BUY CARGO FURNITURE
description: Pier 1 Imports said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Cargo Furniture, a children's and casual furniture retailer. Financial terms of the deal, which is expected to close within 30 days, were not revealed. Pier 1 said the addition of the Cargo chain, which has 21 stores and is a unit of the consumer products manufacturer Tandycrafts, would allow it to enter the children's furniture and accessories market. Pier 1 and Cargo are based in Fort Worth. Cargo's stores are concentrated in Atlanta, Dallas, Fort Worth, Houston and Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, ETHEL V.
description: BLAKE-Ethel V. On January 30, 2001. Beloved mother of Robert H. Blake III. Devoted mother-in-law of Joanne. Adoring grandmother of Timothy, Schuyler and Cameron Rose. Memorial Mass on Monday, 10 AM, St. Monica's Church, 413 E. 79th St., NYC.

title: St. John's Has a Goal; Providence Is in the Way
description: Before the season, Omar Cook, the St. John's point guard, pointed to the Final Four as the team's goal. Upsets have muted those aspirations, but still on track is the team's short-term objective: qualifying for the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: In the Auction Race, Little-Noticed Gems
description: NEW YORK  A strange art scene is emerging as auction after auction send prices rising irresistibly in every category in the market. The race for the top intensifies, and so does the promotion of substitutes. Curiously, in the same sales, sudden fits of blindness allow here and there marvelous works to sell for a pittance, and sometimes to go unsold.

title: Gogel Sets Poppy Hills Mark and Leaves Past Behind
description: Matt Gogel has taken center stage again, at a tournament where he has played tremendous golf but where he also has terrible memories.

title: Carol Anne Letheren, 58, Member Of International Olympic Panel
description: Carol Anne Letheren, a member of the International Olympic Committee from Canada, died yesterday, two days after collapsing while giving a speech in Toronto. She was 58.

title: In Embattled California, Another Power Struggle
description: On the surface, it looks like a typical midwinter here. The camellias outside the Capitol are in brilliant bloom, the thick tule fog comes rolling up the Great Central Valley on cold mornings, and Frank Fat's, the illustrious Chinese restaurant and bar downtown, fills nightly with lobbyists and legislators looking for deals.

title: Rebellion Poses Quandary for G.I.'s in Kosovo

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about public reaction to toll and fare increases by the Port Authority misstated the title of a critic and misspelled his surname. He is Steve Carrellas (not Carellas), and he is coordinator (not executive director) of the New Jersey chapter of the National Motorist Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, MAXINE
description: BENJAMIN-Maxine. Died January 31, 2001. Beloved mother of Cindy and Scott, and of daughter-inlaw Cindy. Cherished best friend and former wife of Donald Benajamin. Dear sister of Sandy Smith and Earlene Beile. Memorial service at 12 noon, Temple Beth El, Great Neck, February 4th, 2001.

title: Gill to Have Knee Surgery
description: Kendall Gill, the Nets' shooting guard, will have surgery Tuesday to determine the cause of the pain in his right knee.

title: Dare Wright -- Children's Author, 86
description: Dare Wright, a photographer and children's book author whose best-known work is ''The Lonely Doll,'' died on Jan. 25. She was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Unemployment Grew to 4.2% During January
description: Responding to a slowing of the economy, the unemployment rate rose in January to 4.2 percent -- the highest level in 15 months -- as the number of jobs in manufacturing continued to shrink, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Ashcroft and the Divided Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: INDONESIA'S TRADE SURPLUS GROWS
description: Indonesia's trade surplus swelled 15.4 percent in 2000, to $28.47 billion, the government said, reflecting higher oil prices and strong demand for electrical goods. Indonesia is Asia's only member of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. A slowing economy in the United States is beginning to crimp Indonesian exports, however. The country's trade surplus for December declined compared with the similar month a year earlier. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Lesser Charges for Nassau Officer Named in Rape Case
description: A former Nassau County police officer charged with raping a woman after a traffic stop in October was indicted on lesser charges today after a grand jury found insufficient evidence for more serious charges.

title: The Empress of the Blues Comes Back to Life
description: As drama, it's a little thin, but the 75 minutes of ''The Devil's Music: the Life and Blues of Bessie Smith'' contain everything you look for in a celebratory wake, including the palpable spirit of the deceased.

title: Article 2001020391709546516 -- No Title
description: STATE OF THE ART

title: UNITED AIRLINES PARENT EXPECTS TO BREAK EVEN IN 2001
description: The parent of United Airlines, the UAL Corporation, said yesterday that it expected to break even this year if its acquisition of US Airways was completed by midyear. The company also forecast an unspecified rise in profit for 2002 with a larger gain in 2003. UAL told analysts that the combined revenue of the carriers would total about $26 billion this year with costs of about $25.3 billion if the acquisition was completed by midyear. The meeting with analysts in New York came as the company was pushing for the Justice Department's approval of its planned $11.6 billion purchase of US Airways by April 2.

title: The Power to Pardon, the Power to Gain
description: The flurry of debate surrounding President Clinton's final pardons has focused on two things. One is whether the recipients actually deserved leniency. The other is the president's own personal, political and economic gain. Both perspectives overlook the essence of executive clemency: it has little to do with justice, and everything to do with politics.

title: Flames Consume Dead but Not the Anguish
description: Corpse No. 686 was Chandra Kant Joshi's wife. They had been married for 36 years, and had he imagined her funeral, it would have been a traditional rite, with her body having been cleansed and scented and then dressed in the same red sari she had worn to their wedding. Hundreds would have walked in a procession to the pyre. Prayers would have been chanted. Mourners would have sat for hours as the flames expired.

title: National News Briefs
description: Judge Dismisses Suit Against G. Gordon Liddy

title: Mahler and the Boston in Levine's Knowing Hands
description: It's an open secret in the classical music world: talks are under way that could result in James Levine's becoming the next music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. If Mr. Levine took the post he would almost certainly remain artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera as well. Whether an arrangement can be worked out will depend a great deal on the flexibility of two men named Volpe: Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Met, and Mark Volpe (no relation), the managing director of the Boston Symphony.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's return to the Senate misidentified the country whose new president he planned to meet yesterday. It was Yugoslavia; Serbia is one of its components.

title: Eyes on Alaska, Where the Oil Is
description: To the Editor:

title: Baku Journal; How the Nobels Made a Prize of Baku
description: Mention the name Nobel and most people think of the prestigious prizes and maybe the invention of dynamite. But here the famous Swedish Nobels are synonymous with oil, the once and future lifeblood of Azerbaijan's economy.

title: REALNETWORKS PLANS TO LET WORKERS SWAP OPTIONS
description: RealNetworks, a software maker whose shares have fallen 89 percent the last year, said yesterday that employees would be allowed to exchange existing stock options for new ones because many were trading below the strike price. The new strike price will be based on the share value at the end of August, said Erika Shaffer, a spokeswoman for RealNetworks. Employees could lose if shares rose above the strike price of current options by the end of August and gain if the shares continued to trade at lower levels. The exchange will not require RealNetworks to take a charge against earnings. RealNetworks, which makes software to play audio and video files from the Internet, said employees held about 24 million options with an exercise price above $10. RealNetworks shares fell 50 cents to $8.94.

description: DIAMOND-Betty Lou. February 3, 1931-November 13, 1988. To live in hearts we leave behind is not to die. Mom, we love and miss you very much. Love, Your Family

title: Nicholas C. Forstmann, 54, Buyout Firm Partner, Dies
description: Nicholas C. Forstmann, an investment banker and a philanthropist who was a founding partner of Forstmann Little & Company, the leveraged-buyout firm, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 54.

title: Order Barring Union Protests At the Met Is Overturned
description: The United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan yesterday overturned a lower court's far-reaching injunction that barred a union from criticizing the Metropolitan Opera as part of its effort to organize 95 restaurant workers at the Met.

description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, GLORIA W.
description: APPEL-Gloria W. Suddenly on January 31. Remembered with love and joy by her children: Carley Broder, Michael Broder and Rita Rubin, Charles Broder and Celeste Hoppey-Broder, and Betsy Broder and David Wentworth. Proud grandmother of Elexa, Ethan, Hannah and Aliza Broder and Ariel and Caroline Wentworth. Widow of Ed Appel, she was devoted to Eddie's children: Marianne Berson, Michaele and Thad Keyes, and Diane and John McCann; their children Deborah Parnes, Brad Berson, Rachel and Gabe Keyes, and Kevin and Ian McCann. President of the Louis and Harold Price Foundation and the Price Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies, which she served for over 20 years, a trustee of Babson College and Medical Development for Israel and advisor to Ewing and Marion Kauffman Foundation. Gloria also leaves countless cherished and loyal friends. Services Sunday, 1:15 Temple Shaaray Tefila, 79th and 2nd. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Price-Babson Fellows Program at Babson College or Medical Development for Israel.

title: Journal; Charm School Graduate in Chief
description: The Ladies' Man is dead -- or at least in temporary exile in Chappaqua. Long live the Man's Man!

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOST MARRIOTT CORP., -- Bethesda, Md., owner of 122 hotels, said that the Blackstone Group, New York, an investment bank, had converted 12.5 million of its Host Marriott partnership units into shares and sold them. The shares had a market value of $166.6 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMANN, RABBI FRANK
description: ZIMMERMANN-Rabbi Frank. We record with profound sadness the passing of our beloved colleague. He served several pulpits in the New York area, after which he became chair of the department and professor of Bible at Dropsie college in Philadelphia. He was the author of many books including ''The Aramaic Origin of the Four Gospels'', and translations of apocryphal works from the Aramaic. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Betty, daughter, Judy Axelrod and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Executive Vice President The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Bookkeeper Is Sentenced
description: A Manhattan bookkeeper was sentenced to 6 to 18 years in prison yesterday for stealing over $8 million from the publishing company she worked for.

description: Christopher E., a 12-year-old from a Harlem housing project with just a hint of a stutter, wants to be either an architect, a video game designer, a chef or an archaeologist. Or perhaps all four.

description: GRAYBACK-George J. Of Lincoln Park, NJ on February 1, 2001. Survived by his loving wife Nola, his adoring children Gail and Fred, cherished grandchildren and stepchildren. Services are Sunday, 10:30 AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

description: The copier giant Xerox has begun discussions with several leveraged-buyout firms about selling certain assets, or perhaps even the entire company, according to executives involved in the negotiations.

description: After days of widespread criticism, former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that they would pay for $86,000 in gifts they received last year and that Mr. Clinton's presidential foundation would share the cost of his new office space in Midtown Manhattan.

description: A scouting report on the teams in the new XFL, which opens its season tonight. By JOHN TEMPLE

description: A man who is in prison for kidnapping a Staten Island girl in 1987 has been indicted for kidnapping another girl from the same borough in 1981, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Peeling the Layers of History in Berlin
description: MY plane landed smoothly at Tegel Airport in Berlin, but I didn't. Emerging from the gate with the other passengers, I soon found myself in the airport's main terminal. But what about immigration? I walked on, a bit nervously, eyes peeled for the official checkpoint I must have missed. Surely some security guard would notice me and steer me in the right direction before I did something illegal.

title: Medea, Witch and Woman, Takes Paris and London
description: MEDEA, it is generally agreed, is a mother from hell, a sorceress who kills her own children to avenge her husband's betrayal. But the Medea of Euripides' tragedy is also one of the great roles of classical theater. And now, by chance, two acclaimed actresses, each accompanied by a respected director, are simultaneously taking on the challenge: in London, Fiona Shaw is directed by Deborah Warner; in Paris, Isabelle Huppert by Jacques Lassalle. Suddenly, ''Medea'' is the talk of theatergoers on both sides of the Channel.

title: SOAPBOX; Waiting for That Thick Envelope
description: WELCOME to the dreaded waiting period: the time when unseen college admissions officers pore through applications and decide the fates of millions of high school students across the country who opted out of early decision.

title: Romania, Under Europes Scrutiny, Grasps at Stability
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  In the view of its new prime minister and many Western officials and investors who spent the last 10 years watching Romania slide deeper into poverty and despair, the country has one last chance to catch up with Europe and reverse the huge popular frustration that fed a sizable vote for neofascism in last December's elections.

description: ASSESSING ACELA

title: Libyans Stab Themselves To Protest Bomb Verdict
description: Four Libyan students stabbed themselves in the abdomen outside the United Nations mission here today, symbolically proclaiming that they would rather die than accept the split verdict this week from a Scottish court over the Lockerbie bombing.

title: Rate of Some Crimes Rises in Suffolk
description: The incidence of forcible rape, bank robbery and aggravated assault increased in Suffolk County last year after hitting a 30-year low in 1999, but the incidence of other major crimes in the county remained relatively the same, according to figures released by the Suffolk County Police Department.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOFFE, HELEN GEWERTZ
description: JOFFE-Helen Gewertz. June 4, 1930 to February 7, 1997. Beloved sister, may her memory be a blessing.

title: Zone Defense Would Add Zest to N.B.A.
description: If I had started watching National Basketball Association games this season instead of in 1983, I might never have become a fan. As talented and athletic as today's players are, the game is slower than it has been in decades. At times, it is downright ugly.

title: Workers in Silicon Alley Feel Underpaid and Fear Losing Jobs, Survey Finds
description: If the dawn of the new media world was supposed to mark the beginning of a fun and egalitarian workplace, Silicon Alley appears to have missed the target, according to a report released last week.

title: Hedging Your Bets? Look Homeward, Investor
description: WHEN David Bowers arrived in New York from London early last year as the new chief global investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, he set about to shake up the firm's view of the world. But he was not prepared for the change he would usher in after months of crunching numbers and examining the interplay of Wall Street and foreign stock markets.

title: Carolynne Taylor, Robert Peters
description: Carolynne Marie Taylor and Robert Joseph Peters were married in Las Vegas on Friday. The Rev. Michelina Taylor Foster of the Free Church of Antioch, a Christian denomination, officiated in the Legacy Chapel at the MGM Grand Hotel.

title: Betraying John Hancock
description: PAVEL P. BORODIN, a Russian official accused of accepting millions of dollars of kickbacks from Swiss companies, is sitting in jail in New York awaiting an extradition hearing. He might have avoided the messy predicament if he had stayed in Moscow, but he could not resist a signed invitation to the inauguration of George W. Bush.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Food Fight For High Stakes
description: LAST year, with five million people in Kenya facing starvation because of a severe drought, opponents of agricultural biotechnology urged the Kenyan government to reject corn donated by the United States and Canada because some of it was genetically modified. And when the United States sent corn and soy meal to India after a 1999 cyclone that killed 10,000 people, a prominent biotech critic in that country accused Washington of using the cyclone victims as ''guinea pigs'' for bio-engineered food.

title: Mickelson Savors Sunshine and a Share of the Lead
description: Phil Mickelson could argue that since the beginning of last year, he has been the best player in the world other than Tiger Woods.

title: Geneva Museum
description: To the Editor: Corinne LaBalme's ''What's Doing in Geneva'' (Dec. 24) did not mention an outstanding attraction of that lovely city, its Muse Ariana, one of Europe's top ceramic museums.

title: Mary Had Only One Lamb? This Woman's Expecting 25
description: It's lambing time for many sheep farms around the state. One of them is Nicky Wilson's 10-acre farm in Mannington in Salem County. She sells her sheep for meat, hides and fleece. She also spins, weaves and knits and is president of the Third Star Fibre Guild, which promotes the use of natural fibers in clothing and art. Ms. Wilson recently talked about breeding sheep.

title: BENEFITS
description: Whirl Awhile

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, DR. MARGARET M.
description: MULLIN-Dr. Margaret M. On February 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Matthew Kabriski who preceded her in death January 1, 2000. Dr. Mullin was born August 12, 1910, in NYC. She enjoyed a long career of teaching and guidance, influencing the lives of thousands of students for nearly 50 years. She began her work as a teacher of high school mathematics and then as Dean at Fort Hamilton High School. She was a faculty member of the School of Education of NYU and did post-doctoral study in Europe. She was a member of the Founding Faculty of Bronx Community College. Teachers inevitably have the opportunity to influence the lives of their students. This is a privilege which Dr. Mullin sensed instinctively and with sensitivity throughout her entire professional and post-professional life. Her work was deeply appreciated by her family and her many students and colleagues. Friends may call at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY, Monday, February 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass at 9:30 AM, Tuesday, February 6, at St. Michael's Church, 136-58 41st Ave., Flushing. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the William and Sylvia Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research Center of the NYU Medical Center; 212-263-5700.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLAS, FREDERICK S.
description: NICHOLAS-Frederick S. Died peacefully January 30, 2001 in Bryn Mawr, PA, aged 90. Born in Syosset, NY, the son of Dorothy and Harry Nicholas. Educated at St. Paul's School, Concord, NH and Harvard University. Mr. Nicholas's career was in the textile industry. In 1942, he joined the Navy and was a Lieutenant Commander. His wife of 62 years, Martha Milliken Nicholas, died in 1995. He is survived by four children: Frederick S. Nicholas, Jr., of Stonington, CT; Mrs. Douglas G. Lovell of Newtown Square, PA; Mrs. Charles J. Hatfield of Princeton, NJ; and Anthony P. Nicholas, also of Princeton, 11 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. Mr. Nicholas, who was President and Master of Fox Hounds for the Radnor Hunt Club will be remembered for his storytelling and sense of humor. Memorial Service will be held at 12 noon on Wednesday, February 14 at St. Francis-in-theFields, Sugartown Road, Malvern, PA. Please send any contributions to The Animal Hospital of Chester Co., 1353 Pottstown Pike, West Chester, PA. 19382.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You can't have Wyoming be a pristine, untouched area and still be a major natural gas producer. You have to decide what you want.''

description: LINCOLN CENTER Misguided Spending

title: W.'s World
description: Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, has spoken of having no time for ''recreation, family, introspection, 'life crises.''' Indeed, this seems evident in her comment that the importance of the mission in Bosnia and Kosovo was limited to ''escorting kids to kindergarten.'' This is frightening, given her enormous influence in America's involvement internationally.

title: The Devil and an Angel Envision a Revolution in College Sports
description: My favorite devil was calling from somewhere near Malibu, chortling over the follies of those mortals involved in college sports.

title: Lemieux Will Return for Another Season
description: Some stars will always shine brighter than others. And one of the brightest in National Hockey League history said today that he would be back for at least another season, maybe more.

title: Company Offers Apartments With Perks for Commuters
description: In legend, King Arthur flees to Avalon after having fought, and lost, his last battle. In New Rochelle, a Virginia-based company hopes renters, confronting high real estate prices in New York City, will flee to its version of Avalon.

title: Assessing Acela
description: To the Editor: I am an Amtrak traveler. I encourage friends to ride the train. Of course, I have not had any luck getting them on a train. Not even my husband! I ride the train to vacation destinations and he flies. That means I have left days earlier to meet him.

title: They Dislike a Tract's Weeds, But Oppose Shops Even More
description: If there's one thing everyone agrees on, it's that the tract isn't pretty. But what should be done with the patch of ugly weeds and scattered trees at the intersection of the Belt Parkway and Flatbush Avenue?

title: 'Sopranos' Stereotyping
description: To the Editor:

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Lox Lovers' Landmark Tries Recipe for Survival

title: In Lieu of Manners
description: In the new Fox series ''Boston Public,'' students have been forced to take random drug tests, teachers have been fingerprinted because the school board was worried about child molestation and the parents of the star football player have sued the principal because their son wasn't allowed to play after he failed two courses. It is a lot of litigiousness in one hour, particularly in a show that is not about law. Oddly enough, though, the idea that teachers and students live in fear of lawsuits doesn't feel like sensationalism. Instead, it seems that prime time is finally catching up with the reality of American life. As trust in traditional authorities declines, we are increasingly turning to law to regulate the kinds of behavior that used to be governed by manners and mores. In schools, in workplaces, in churches and in politics, our interactions are increasingly conducted in the shadow of legalese. We are becoming a nation of separate, resentful, legalized selves.

title: A Feud Brewing Over Family Leave
description: The usual marriage of convenience in which Republicans and business interests are joined in a common purpose -- is showing signs of strain.

title: Sale Of Coyotes Is Still In Works
description: The proposed sale of the Phoenix Coyotes to a group headed by Steve Ellman and Wayne Gretzky, according to National Hockey League Commissioner Gary Bettman, ''remains a work in progress.''

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Ashcroft Confirmed, 58-42
description: John Ashcroft was confirmed as attorney general, but only after a bitter Senate debate that may be a mere prologue to other battles. The 58-42 vote was a victory for President Bush but also a show of strength by Democrats, a signal of enough unity to mount a filibuster against the nomination of a similar conservative to the Supreme Court. Senator Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat, called the vote ''a shot across the bow'' of the president. But two other nominees easily won confirmation: Gale A. Norton as interior secretary and Christie Whitman as environmental protection administrator. Alison Mitchell

title: The Option as Shield In a Shaky Market
description: INTEREST rate cuts are generally good news for stocks. And, in fact, the market did rally last month in response to a surprise cut by the Federal Reserve on Jan. 3 and in anticipation of a second cut that came last week.

title: Being Mayor Is Just Another Job
description: LEO JACKSON was the first black mayor of New London, indeed the first black mayor in all of Connecticut, when he took office in 1980. For one year, a full term in that city, he worked to improve the local beach and encourage minorities in city government. He stayed on the city council until 1993 and still finds time to volunteer on regional committees -- when he's not driving a bus at a nearby casino.

title: Babe 3: Road Hog
description: Perhaps it began with the wishbone suspension and feather-touch power steering. Perhaps it will end with the drumstick gear shifter. In any case, bonds between the auto-assembly plant and the slaughterhouse are getting closer. Hormel Foods will supply pork and turkey byproducts that can be used in manufacturing car parts.

title: Style; Season of The Witch
description: Witches lead a charmed life. One wave of the wand and every problem is solved. But of course, it's not that easy. I brought three witches together -- Glinda, Samantha and Sabrina -- to discuss the many difficulties facing Wiccan-Americans. We were going to meet in Salem, Mass., until we realized we all lived in California. That struck me as strange.

title: Dealing With Control Issues
description: Why diet when you can, um, compress? This month, two additions to the ever-booming ''body contour'' market (i.e., girdles and such) are offering some new flab-obscuring options. At Saks Fifth Avenue, Spanx, a line of footless natural-colored control-top pantyhose promises to slim and smooth while offering wide comfortable ankle bands, no panty lines, and support all the way down to mid-thigh ($20). According to the manufacturers, the idea sprang from what they say is a common practice among women: cutting off the feet of their own control-top hose, securing the ankles with rubber bands and wearing their homemade contraption as a foundation garment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, ELLA (BERNARD)
description: SCHER-Ella (Bernard). At age 91, passed away peacefully in her sleep on February 1, 2001, at her home in Palm Beach, Florida. She was a true Aishes Chayil (woman of valor). She was the widow of Doctor Samuel Scher, who passed away six weeks ago. Ella was the first woman criminal lawyer in New York. She and Doctor Scher, a prominent plastic surgeon, were active at the New York Medical College, and the Westchester Jewish Center. She is survived by her son, Dr. Charles Scher (Donna) of Ocean Township, NJ, and daughter, Susan (Dr. Marvin Shuster) of Bal Harbour, FL., five grandchildren, Rabbi Yitzchok Shuster, Tova Greenbaum, Dr. Bernard Shuster, Libby Scher and Mia Scher. She had seven great grandchildren. Interment was at Menorah Gardens in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Shiva is private for the family. Donations can be made to The SHUL of Bal Harbour, 9450 Collins Avenue, Surfside, FL. 33154.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, ETHEL V.
description: BLAKE-Ethel V., on January 30, 2001. Beloved mother of Robert H. Blake III. Devoted mother-in-law of Joanne. Adoring grandmother of Timothy, Schuyler and Cameron Rose. Memorial Mass on Monday, 10 AM, St. Monica's Church, 413 E. 79th St., NYC.

title: The Content Isn't New, But the Processes Are
description: THE exhibition of abstract drawings at Kenise Barnes Fine Art here is a satisfying ''new wine in old bottles'' kind of show. The originality isn't in the style or even the content; rather what's innovative is the process used to achieve the work. If Ms. Barnes didn't expressly intend ''Re: Drawing'' to be a show of eight artists who work with unusual mediums, that's what she has achieved.

title: The A List
description: BIRTH OF THE COOL

title: That's Right, It's Afro-Semitic
description: THE jazz bassist David Chevan and the pianist Warren Byrd know that audiences coming to see their show of sacred music, called the Afro-Semitic Experience, may expect solemnity. These expectations, however, are usually quick to vanish.

title: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON: PAINTING STILL IN DISPUTE
description: The tug-of-war over a million-dollar painting by the 19th century Hastings artist Jasper F. Cropsey goes on, despite a court ruling last month that it is the property of the Hastings school district. In an appeal filed by the Hastings Historical Society, the society's lawyer, Paul Edelman, argued that Sherman Thursby, the painting's original owner, had never intended that the painting, ''View at Hastings-on-Hudson,'' be given to the school board. ''It was not given to the school board to own and sell,'' Mr. Edelman said. ''Essentially, the people of the village were the real owners of the painting. It was delivered to the school for the benefit of the people. We're only interested that it not be sold.'' The painting, on display at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, will be the subject of a Feb. 12 school board meeting. ''The board is nowhere near a decision,'' said Schools Superintendent John J. Russell. Merri Rosenberg

description: THREE weeks ago, The New York Times invited children from the public schools to submit essays on problems in their schools and how to correct them. Hundreds of essays were received; here are some excerpts:

title: Corrections

title: SHIPBOARD SPAS ARE THE NEW WAVE
description: THROUGHOUT the 1990's, new cruise ships attracted attention for adding features like simulated golf ranges, ice-skating rinks and rock-climbing walls. But since the mid-90's, another amenity has quietly outdistanced any other: the shipboard spa. Cruise lines have added or expanded spas in greater numbers than all those other features combined. At least 115 cruise ships now have spas, and passengers are flocking to them; procrastinators are often unable to schedule appointments when they want them, and sometimes not at all, especially when ships are at sea.

This location has long housed a string of restaurants: Tumbledown Dick's for many years, and Cafe Sunrise, James Bay and Ipanema Grill thereafter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDING, JUDGE ELIZABETH BASS
description: GOLDING-Judge Elizabeth Bass. The Board of Directors, staff, parents and students of the The Hebrew Academy of Nassau County (HANC) mourn the loss on Tuesday, January 30, of longtime friend, supporter, benefactor and honorary member of the HANC Board of Directors, Judge Elizabeth Bass Golding-LEYAH BAT VELVL. A longtime judge in Nassau County, Judge Elizabeth Bass Golding was one of the first women admitted to practice law in New York State in the early 1920's. A leading jurist, and confidante of Eleanor and Franklin Roosevelt, Judge Golding was head of the Democratic ticket in Nassau County in 1940. Judge Elizabeth Bass Golding was a full partner with her late husband, Samuel Golding in supporting the educational needs of tens of thousands of students at the Hebrew Academy of Nassau County. Their generous support helped bring to fruition the dream of a HANC elementary and nursery school in the West Hempstead community-the ''Samuel and Elizabeth Bass Golding Elementary School'' and the ''Samuel and Elizabeth Bass Golding Early Childhood Center''. The blessed memory of Judge Elizabeth Bass Golding will forever remain in the hearts of us all and will be carried on through the children of the Hebrew Academy of Nassau County. Contributions in her memory can be made to HANC, 240 Hempstead Ave., West Hempstead, NY 11552. Rabbi Moshe Gottesman, Dean Miriam Lieber, Administrator Warren Feierstein, Director of Development Harvey Liebman, President Isaac Blachor, Chairman, Board of Directors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORTZ, BERNARD J.
description: BORTZ-Bernard J. Devoted son of the late Fanny Bortz. Loving husband of the late Phyllis Elkin Bortz. Beloved father of Joyce G. Fiedler and John G. and Jean G. Bortz. Loving father-in-law of Jeffrey Fiedler and Laurie Kaplan. Devoted grandfather of Jessica and Candra Fiedler and Rebeccah and Jacob Bortz. A professional engineer with Ford, Bacon and Davis for many years and a private consultant in his later years. He was a member of Temple Israel, the Mid-Westchester Y and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. He was an active board member of the co-op at 240 Garth Road where he resided until his death. Bernie was a caring and selfless friend, a pillar of strength to his family and a helping hand to those less fortunate. He will be sorely missed, but not forgotten. Services will be held Sunday, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside'', 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon. Interment Beth Israel Memorial Park, Woodbridge, NJ. Shiva will be held at the Fiedler residence through Tuesday and the Bortz residence on Tuesday only. Donations may be made to the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, NY NY 10021. (646) 227-3546.

description: BAYLES-Virginia C. February 1, 1995. In ever loving memory. Sister Marilyn

title: Winter Break Refills Empty Nests
description: THEY haunt the hallways of their former high schools. They occupy your favorite booth at the local coffee shop. They use the best equipment at the fitness center. They camp out in the coziest chairs at Barnes & Noble or prowl The Westchester en masse. Some even work at the jobs they held during high school.

title: The Mayor's Book Deal
description: It is disappointing that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has become the second New York politician in little more than a month to enter into a compromising book deal. Although the mayor's hefty $3 million advance from Talk Miramax Books, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company, does not match Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's recent $8 million contract with a publishing subsidiary of Viacom to write her memoir, it raises similar concerns. Both authors should have declined to accept large up-front payments while still in office, as such payments can too easily be seen as bids for favorable treatment. Instead, they should have limited themselves to royalties on books actually sold, a better indication that they are being paid what their books have earned.

title: Novelty Upstages Game On the XFL's First Night
description: What began as a novelty act became a situation comedy tonight for the New York/ New Jersey Hitmen. They lost to the Las Vegas Outlaws, 19-0, marking the arrival of the XFL, a pro league that in its debut proved to be more reality television than quality football.

After receiving the dubious distinction of becoming the third Connecticut school to be put on probation by an accreditation organization, students here are talking about the East Side school closing down for good, diplomas becoming worthless and college being an impossibility.

title: Assessing Acela
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's glowing account of the new Amtrak Acela service reminded me of how far Amtrak's service had fallen on the New York-Boston corridor. When I regularly used the New Haven Railroad's service over 40 years ago, the fastest New York-Boston trains were scheduled for about four hours. This is an hour faster than many of Amtrak's current Northeast Direct trains, and the same as Amtrak's new Acela Regional trains. Locomotive changes in New Haven took only 5 minutes or less, not the 20 minutes Ms. Wade quotes from recent schedules.

title: So It's Come to This: Rats Riding the Rails
description: NO one could take his eyes off him. As he boarded the C train at 42nd Street, every head in the car turned. He was sleek and mysterious, lithe and enigmatic, a presence at once galvanizing and repellent.

description: IN one of the largest conservation gift donations in Long Island history, a Wall Street financier has permanently removed more than 500 acres in Southampton from the real estate market. The move has pleased Long Island government officials and residents worried about the loss of open space on the East End.

title: There's a Method to This 'Choral Miracle'
description: AN icy December wind chills Sweden's temporarily sunless capital. But inside the torchlit portals of Berwaldhallen, a 1979 concert hall carved into a granite hillside in Stockholm's green Djurgarden district, the 34 members of the Swedish Radio Choir are working up a sweat. They bray incantations from ''Curse Upon Iron'' by the Estonian composer Veljo Tormis: ''You flesh eater, gnawer of bones, spiller of innocent blood!'' Tonu Kaljuste, their departing music director, jerks about, smacking a tambourine against his flank like a mad shaman. Is this any way for good Lutherans to behave?

description: Re ''Giving It the Old College Try'' [Jan. 28]: There are three institutions on Long Island that successfully attract high-achieving students: the honors colleges at SUNY-Stony Brook, C. W. Post and Adelphi.

title: New Liaison to Gay Residents: From Rabble Rouser to Bureaucrat
description: UNTIL last month, Joseph DeFilippis had spent his adult life as a rabble-rousing advocate for gays and lesbians, lobbying government officials and writing angry letters. Now he has switched sides.

title: Micheaux Film at Newark Museum
description: Just a few years after D. W. Griffith made ''Birth of a Nation'' in 1915, the African-American filmmaker Oscar Micheaux, a former coal miner and Pullman porter, started making films. In them, African-Americans are portrayed with dignity in roles of authority in contrast to the typical stock characters of the day. Micheaux's genres included drama, musicals and films about social themes, and he directed over 40 films between 1918 and 1948. On Saturday Feb. 10 at 2 p.m. the Newark Museum will screen, one of Micheaux's silent films, ''The Symbol of the Unconquered'' (1920). The drummer Max Roach will provide the percussive accompaniment to the film he performed once before on television. Pearl Bowser, co-author of a book about Micheaux published last fall, ''Writing Himself Into History: Oscar Micheaux, His Silent Films, and His Audience,'' (Rutgers University Press) will also be there to discuss Micheaux and sign copies of her book. In her book, Ms. Bowser wrote that ''The Symbol of the Unconquered'' reveals the economic underpinnings of the Ku Klux Klan. Michele Parchment, manager of public programs, who also coordinates the Newark Black Film Festival, said of Micheaux, ''He is one of our silent heroes when we are dealing with African-American history.'' Margo Nash

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Little Neck, Queens, misspelled the name of a high school in Bayside. It is Benjamin N. Cardozo, not Cardoza. The article also misstated the designation of a school that offers gifted programs in Grades 6 though 9. It is Middle School 67, not Junior High School 67.

title: Japanese Spot That's Not Run of the Mill
description: THERE is a sameness about Japanese restaurants. Diners expect and usually find bustling sushi bars and a modern dcor that features blond wood and rice paper partitions. At Kiss'o in New Hyde Park there are some attractive additions: a brightly colored mural behind the sushi bar and a dramatic ceiling made of painted fabric highlighted with gold leaf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, SYLVIA G.
description: GOLDBERG-Sylvia G. Passed away in San Antonio, Texas, January 30, 2001, after a brief illness. She was born on August 31, 1909, in Hartford, Connecticut to Frances and Julius Ginewsky. Mrs. Goldberg and her husband, Jay Goldberg, an internationally renowned textile engineer, first lived in Worcester, Massachusetts, and later, for many years, in Riverdale, New York. Following the loss of her husband, she moved to San Antonio in 1995 to be with her sister, the late Marion G. Fish. A passionate devotee of the arts, she was a longtime patron of music, ballet and opera groups, as well as museums of fine art. In New York, she taught English to members of the Japanese U.N. diplomatic community for many years and was active in various charitable institutions. Mrs. Goldberg is survived by her brother, Alfred Ginewsky of Longboat Key, Florida, nieces and nephews and their children and many dear friends in both New York and San Antonio. Porter Loring, 1101 McCullough Avenue, San Antonio, TX 78212.

title: The Enforcer; As Mrs. Whitman Begins Her New Job, There Is Debate Over Her Commitment to the Environment in the Past
description: THERE was Christie Whitman, canoeing down a pristine stream in the interior of New Jersey. This was not a tourism advertisement, but rather a back-to-nature touch strategically inserted into the governor's State of the State address several weeks ago.

title: A Winter Garden Changes Bleak to Bright
description: TEN years ago, two brothers in my central New Jersey town, both seasoned gardeners, decided to create a colorful winter garden on their street. They wanted to provide both neighbors and passers-by with a refreshing, festive display at a bleak time of year.

title: Fun With Chicks
description: ''The class becomes the mother hen,'' said Nancy Caswell, describing the learning experience of raising chicks. Ms. Caswell is a program educator at the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Westchester County, which supplies eggs and trains teachers who want to raise chicks in the classroom.

title: Crime
description: Of all the wonders of nature evoked in Nevada Barr's national-parks mysteries (forest fires, cave-ins and feral pigs come to mind), none stirs the imagination quite like Ursus horribilis -- the grizzly bear. Four hundred pounds or more of muscle. Saw-toothed canines. Four-inch claws. Nasty temper. ''Walt Disney lied,'' Barr tells us in BLOOD LURE (Putnam, $24.95). ''It was the Brothers Grimm who had the right idea: witches baked little girls, stepmothers poisoned them, bears ate them.'' Even Anna Pigeon, the district park ranger who strides fearlessly through this invigorating series, is forced to re-examine her ''spiritual connection'' to all of God's creatures when she is assigned to work on a scientific project that has her hanging out lures of blood and guts (''so stinky'' that they have to be packed in glass jars) to attract the big grizzlies in Glacier National Park.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Keeping an Ear on Bush
description: Everybody's reading George W. Bush's lips.

title: Marvin Lewis's Agent Accuses Bills of Bias
description: It has been a hectic few weeks for one of the most powerful men in the National Football League. On the telephone, his voice sounds weary, but anyone who has met the agent Ray Anderson, famous for his relentless work ethic, knows that although Anderson's cell-phone battery might become drained, he rarely does. Instead, he is exasperated, having experienced a series of highs and lows with two of his clients, Herman Edwards and Marvin Lewis, both N.F.L. coaches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELFER, IRA M.
description: BELFER-Ira M. January 31, 2001. Attorney-at-law, Manhattan, at age 89. Beloved husband of Jean Belfer, to whom he was married for 62 years; devoted father of Myron and Peter and adored grandfather of Russell and Philip, and father-in-law of Sandra Belfer. Loving brother of the late Geraldine, and uncle of Natalie. His love of the law provided sustenance and joy. A graduate of CCNY and Brooklyn Law School, his was a story of success from immigrant roots. He valued and lived the ethic of hard work. He maintained his law practice into his 89th year-a practice of over 65 years. He was known as a lawyer's lawyer for his expertise in negotiation. His diverse practice included movie producers, fashion designers, real estate interests, corporate clients and families. A great raconteur, his storytelling captivated friends and acquaintances. His philanthropy supported the establishment of the Peter Belfer Laboratory at the Johns Hopkins University Medical School and Hospital in honor of Peter, his son, an attorney with the SEC, who died at 25 from congenital heart disease. He was a Trustee of the Brooklyn Law School and President of the Alumni Association. He was Trustee and President of the Congregation of Temple Israel of the City of New York. He founded and led the North Shore Arts Center. Memorial contributions may be made to the Peter Belfer Laboratory, Department of Cardiology, Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD.

title: Dragila's World Record: Better Late Than Never
description: A rose was clenched in her teeth as Stacy Dragila leaned back into the crowd, made up mostly of little girls, who stayed up well past midnight in Madison Square Garden to share in the celebration of a world record. The pioneer pole-vaulter Dragila signed autographs and posed for photographs; the youngsters marveled at the hero of a frontier sport.
