title: Indian Country Sends A Stronger Signal
description: THE opening day in December of KUYI-FM had a singular flavor, a contemporary American Indian mix of traditional songs and prayers with 21st-century technology and plenty of hospitality. As Hopi women filled a table with trays of cookies, dozens of Indian and white well-wishers, including teenage volunteers from the nearby high school, spilled out of the small reception room into the broadcast studio and the dirt yard outside.

title: Linda Scribner, David Paskin
description: Linda Christine Scribner and Dr. David Louis Paskin are to be married today by Judge Walter K. Stapleton of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia. The Very Rev. Robert L. Tate, an Episcopal priest, will also participate in the ceremony, to be held in Bryn Mawr, Pa., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Orleans, friends of the couple.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Pope Packs 'Em In
description: John Paul II, who recently named a record 37 new cardinals, added seven more, a surprising move that brought the number eligible to vote for the next pope to 135. Three are from countries that were once part of the Soviet bloc; two had been selected secretly in 1998, perhaps because the pope had not wanted to antagonize the Eastern Orthodox church. Ukraine will have two cardinals, one a Ukrainian Greek Catholic. Two Germans, a Bolivian and a South African will also be among the 44 receiving red hats on Feb. 21. Alessandra Stanley

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, WILLIAM, D.D.S.
description: GREENFIELD-William, D.D.S. On February 1, 2001. Cherished husband of Elyse nee Bloom. Loving father of Linda Plotnick of Merrick N.Y. and David Greenfield, M.D. of Boca Raton, FL. Devoted fatherin-law of Nina and Steven. Adoring grandfather of Jason and Joshua. A leader in dental anesthesiology and pain control, he served for 21 years as Associate Dean for Hospital Extramural and International Affairs at the NYU College of Dentistry, where his wisdom, creativity and brilliance advanced the programs of the College on a global level. He was a former President of the New York Society of Dental Anesthesiology, New York Society of Acupuncture, Association of Military Surgeons (N.Y. Chapter), and of virtually every organization he joined. At the time of his death, he was President of the American College of Acupuncture. A legendary storyteller, his humor, gentleness, sweetness and charm captivated everyone he met. He was perfect and everyone loved him. He will be with us always in our hearts. Services Sunday, February 4th, 1PM, United Hebrew Community of New York, 201 E Broadway NY (212-674-3580). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the NYU College of Dentistry.

title: Walking In a Hoofer's Fancy Footsteps
description: BILL ROBINSON was the epitome of tap-dancing fame, a consummate entertainer who earned more during his heyday than any other black performer of his time and whose birth date Congress has designated National Tap-Dancing Day. A star of vaudeville, stage musicals and films, he is revered today, a half-century after his death, as the greatest of all tappers. His steps and the sounds he made were said to be simple. He bowed his head, watching his feet sometimes as he danced, for a look of bulk and diffidence that vanished when one caught sight of that gleaming face and savored his extraordinary lightness and precision.

title: Confessions of a Lonely Atheist
description: I was pleased to read Angier's article. But she gives organized religion a free pass. As a cultural construct, it has a great deal to answer for -- from the carnage of the Crusades to the unending bloodletting in the Middle East to the zealotry of Christian Scientists who would deny their children medical care. If this is the moral behavior that is ''inextricably linked'' to religion, I'll take my chances in a universe governed by quarks and black holes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENGLER, SILAS
description: SPENGLER-Silas. A retired New York City lawyer and a former resident of Bronxville, N.Y. died January 31 at his home in Middleton, WI. Beloved husband of Anna M. (Sandy) and loving father of Silas of Nassau, Bahamas and Harry of Dover, N.H., proud grandfather of Silas William Spengler of Nassau, Bahamas, stepfather of Sam Barker and Peter Barker, both of Chicago, Il. Dear brother of William of Colorado Springs, CO., David of Madison, Wi. and Susan Lundberg of Wausau, WI. Silas was a co-founder of the law firm Roth Carlson Kwit & Spengler in 1964 which firm was known as Spengler, Carlson Gubar Brodsky & Frischling when in 1993 it combined with the firm of Reid & Priest. Born in Neenah, WI, he graduated from Phillips Academy, Andover 1949, Yale University in 1953 and in 1960 from the University of Pennsylvania Law School, where he served as Articles Editor of its Law Review. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Silas and Margaret Spengler Memorial Scholastic Fund, Phillips Academy, Andover, MA 01810-4161 or Hospice Care of Madison, 5395 East Cheryl Parkway, Madison, WI 53711.

title: The Titan of Toondom
description: CHUCK JONES may not necessarily be a household name, but his creations, including Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck and Elmer Fudd, certainly are. His short animated films pay homage to Twain, Chaplin and Keaton, and like them, Mr. Jones, 88, is an original in American comedy.

title: The Way We Live Now: 02-04-01: Documents; Movie Madness
description: Three years ago, Christian Leigh Curry couldn't get potential employers to return his calls. Nude photographs of him had appeared in Playguy. He had been fired by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company (on the never-substantiated claims of expense-account abuse). Now his fortunes are changed. Since the resulting suits were settled last fall, the 26-year-old former analyst has been barraged with pitches for business deals and companionship. In the last half year, Curry has bought The Black Star News, invested in TriBeCa real estate and opened a private equity fund. Here are excerpts from a letter received by Curry, who says he is still considering the project; J.R. Hill, the sender, says he is still looking for backers.

As the article said, there is one community called the Strand in which houses sell for $11 million to $25 million. description: On a recent sunny afternoon, customers marched purposefully into Peter's Ice Cream Parlor. But it was not ice cream they were after so much as solace.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Congo's New Leader in D.C.
description: Congo's Joseph Kabila, 29, was among the world leaders who flocked to Washington ostensibly for a Congressional prayer breakfast but in reality to make contacts. Mr. Kabila met with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who has vowed to put Africa high on his agenda. Washington wants the five nations fighting within Congo to leave, and took some encouragement from the young, untried leader's call for reconciliation in his first public address after his father's assassination. Jane Perlez

Greasy hamburgers, onion rings bogged down with soggy breading, lumpy mashed potatoes and limp French fries are nowhere to be found at the new Coppertop Pub and Eatery, at 149 Glen Street, Glen Cove (516-676-4343). That's because this as-yet-undiscovered little gem is in the classy, historic Coles House, where David Lake, the executive chef, and his high-powered kitchen crew preside.

title: The Future Is Foggy On Fisherman's Wharf
description: FOR much of last year, the question of what to do about Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco, a major tourist attraction and home to the city's fishing industry, was a cause for dispute. The best-known proposal, for a $30 million, 71,000-square-foot interactive history museum, was ridiculed after it became known that it would be enlivened by periodic blasts from a fog machine, a simulated earthquake, a miniature Golden Gate Bridge and a ride through a Haight-Ashbury exhibit aboard a Volkswagen convertible tram.

title: Cesare Maltoni, 70, Dies; Cut Workplace Cancer Risks
description: Dr. Cesare Maltoni, an Italian oncologist who identified cancer risks in the workplace and campaigned for stricter factory health codes, died on Jan. 22 at his home in Bologna, Italy. He was 70.

title: She's 'Margarita,' and 12,000 Latinos Call Her Yearly
description: Ask New Yorkers who watch Spanish-language television where to find a personal-injury lawyer, and chances are they will say, ''Pregunte por Margarita'' (''Ask for Margarita''). The catch phrase comes from more than 20 years of television, radio and subway ads for Trolman, Glaser & Lichtman, a law firm. Call Margarita, the ads imply, for help in your own language.

title: A New Identity Ahead for a Long-Troubled High School
description: After two years of discussions, School District 15 and Brooklyn and Staten Island Schools, a division of the Board of Education, announced Wednesday that they would revamp Park Slope's troubled John Jay High School.

title: Confessions of a Lonely Atheist
description: As a Roman Catholic, I loved every word of Angier's article. Anyone who declares, ''What a gift it is to be alive now,'' deserves applause, no matter how she arrived there.

title: I Felt Like I Was Hit In the Plexes
description: I SPENT Christmas in West Palm Beach, and while I didn't find any dimpled-chad T-shirts to bring home, I did discover a new movie chain called Muvico.

title: Marshall Crenshaw at Stone Pony
description: The singer and songwriter Marshall Crenshaw, who was hailed by rock critics as a master lyricist when he made his debut in the early 1980's, has since made 11 albums innovatively combining Memphis rockabilly, 70's rhythm and blues and soul.

title: In Technology, Caution Is Still the Better Part of Wisdom
description: NOW that technology stocks are humming again, investors are settling back into their comfort zone. The tech wreck of 2000 is receding into the mists of distant memory as investors focus on earnings in the second half of 2001 rather than the gloomy here and now.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Keeping the Lights On
description: In an air of partisan recrimination and consumer cries of ''bailout,'' California's governor signed a bill authorizing the state to negotiate long-term contracts for power that will be passed on to the state's financially troubled utilities. The plan will be financed by state revenue bonds, but allows for rate increases for consumers who use 30 percent more than a base amount of electricity set by region and climate. Todd S. Purdum

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 21 about ''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD, LP and Cassette'' misstated the nationality of an author, Brian Morton. He is Scottish, not English.

title: TUNNEL PLAN DRAWS INTEREST
description: In Tarrytown, there are plenty of opponents to a larger Tappan Zee Bridge. So when a Garrison man, Sandy Saunders, unveiled an alternative last week -- a tunnel under the Hudson River -- residents, officials and the media showed up. Mr. Saunders has outlined his plan before. But now, with the Thruway Authority considering building a new $2.5 billion bridge, there has been more interest. Mr. Saunders said the project would cost $850 million for a tunnel with two tubes, each holding four lanes of traffic and railroad tracks, 90 feet below the river bottom. Drew Fixell, a member of Tarrytown's Board of Trustees, who opposes a new bridge, said the idea has become the buzz around town. ''I'm already hearing jokes about the Big Dig and the Chunnel,'' he said. ''It's clearly possible, but is it cost-effective?'' Corey Kilgannon

title: Immigrants Provide Employee Answer for Long Island Mailing Company
description: There is a one-story building in the back of an industrial park here with a roof the size of eight football fields. There, companies' financial statements are prepared and shipped to investors across the country by Investor Communication Services, the nation's largest provider of such services, which expects to send a billion pieces of mail this year.

title: Set the Alarm for 2011
description: WHILE AMERICA SLEEPS

title: A Fairy Tale, Act 3: The Duchess in the New World
description: I'M not standing here because I'm paid to,'' declared Sarah, the Duchess of York, last week at a Weight Watchers meeting in Bethpage, N.Y. ''I know what it's like to look at myself in the mirror and say, 'I can't go out today.' ''

title: Dina Perlmutter, Stuart Berrin
description: Dina Beth Perlmutter and Stuart Edward Berrin are to be married today by Rabbi Daniel Cohen at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Article 2001020493789999676 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: A Soprano Who Stands Time's Test
description: FOR sheer sensationalism, maybe only opera can compare with childhood. The Ukrainian soprano Maria Guleghina, the reigning Tosca of the last decade, tells a story from her sixth year that would have raised a shudder in Puccini himself, that master torturer of heroines.

title: Race Takes Back Seat as States Prepare to Redistrict
description: State officials say that recent court decisions on voting rights have created confusion, uncertainty and immense new difficulties as they prepare to redraw the boundaries of Congressional districts and state legislative districts.

title: Michelle Hyver, Michael Oakes
description: Michelle Jon Hyver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Donnelly Hyver of New Orleans, was married last evening to Michael Thomas Oakes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Marvin Oakes of South Boston, Va. Msgr. Francis G. Boeshans performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Jesuit Church in New Orleans.

title: Confessions of a Lonely Atheist
description: Angier's brave ''confession'' reminded me of my own peevish response to organized religion, which claims a franchise on goodness. I wonder how many nasty letters and how many supportive ones you will get. Of course the results may be biased. Your readership has many gentle souls who may prefer Sunday mornings with The New York Times to a painful hour in church.

title: St. John's Loses Its Composure and Then the Game
description: The St. John's players could not believe what they saw. What resembled the entire student body of Providence College appeared to be descending on the visiting team as soon as the final buzzer sounded.

title: Article 2001020493209434794 -- No Title
description: February 3, 2001

title: Get Out the Pruners
description: Tackle pruning on days when trees and shrubs are not wet. Many trees, except bleeders, like maple and birch, are best pruned in late winter. Summer-blooming shrubs that flower on new wood need renewal in late winter to early spring. Maintain form and open the center of plants by removing crossing branches, suckers and dead wood. Removing too many healthy branches at once can weaken a tree. For best production, prune bush fruit like high bush blueberry annually. Cut up to a quarter of the oldest branches close to the ground, leaving the shoots and wood with the best fruit-bud formation. PATRICIA JONAS

title: RUNNING AWAY TO TAHITI
description: WELCOME to Tahiti,'' the captain of our Air Tahiti Nui Airbus droned in French-accented English. We were landing at Faaa Airport, just south of Papeete. ''The local time is 7:35 p.m., and the temperature is 86 degrees.''

title: Out for a Swirl
description: Spring is still more than a month away, so flower embroideries are a welcome sight now. The knitted flower skirt, bottom row, from Azzedine Alaa, is boiled wool and chenille. Its garlands of flowers are popular for day and evening. The short pleated version is in a lighter-weight wool knit. Other designers have embroidered flowers on jacket cuffs, left, or appliqud them on coats, right. Fendi has embroidered them on bags, far left. It all suggests a nostalgia for embellishment.

title: Decentralize
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, MAXINE
description: BENJAMIN-Maxine. Died January 31, 2001. Beloved mother of Cindy and Scott, and of daughter-inlaw Cindy. Cherished best friend and former wife of Donald Benajamin. Dear sister of Sandy Smith and Earlene Beile. Memorial service at 12 noon, Temple Beth El, Great Neck, February 4th, 2001.

title: Hong Kong to Monitor Falun Gong More Closely, Official Says
description: As the Chinese government's war against the Falun Gong spiritual movement grows ever more thunderous, its echoes are sounding in Hong Kong, the group's only refuge in China.

title: White House Mess
description: As a former member of Vice President Quayle's staff, I was mystified by your Ethicist's (Jan. 14) publication of a letter from an anonymous, ''soon-to-be-former member of Vice President Gore's staff,'' who says he was ''told'' that, in the transition, the Quayle team intentionally left a mess and performed various kinds of malicious mischief.

title: 1066 and All That
description: A History of Britain At the Edge of the World? 3000 BC-AD 1603. By Simon Schama. Illustrated. 415 pp. New York: Talk Miramax Books/Hyperion. $40.

title: Robert Lee, Only Chief of Chiefs of Mardi Gras Indians, Is Dead at 85
description: Robert Lee, the first and only chief of chiefs of New Orleans Mardi Gras Indian tribes, died on Jan. 19 at a New Orleans hospital. He was 85.

title: The 'St. Louis Blues' Saved His Life at Auschwitz
description: AS you walk through the second floor of the Museum of Jewish Heritage (A Living Memorial to the Holocaust) in Battery Park City in Lower Manhattan, past the ragged camp uniforms and photographs of faces framed in barbed wire, an unusual sight awaits. In a corner, inside a glass case, sits a tarnished old trumpet. A card says it belonged to man named Louis Bannet, who was known as ''The Dutch Louis Armstrong.''

title: Richmond Has the Little Point Guard Who Could
description: Michele Koclanes, the junior point guard for the University of Richmond, had American University right where she wanted it last week: on the defensive, trailing by 3 points with less than one minute to play. The ball and ultimately the game were in her hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ROSLYN
description: GREENBERG-Roslyn. Died on Feb 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Donald. Devoted mother of Sue Lebow and Debbie and Bruce Schneeman. Loving grandmother of Jaime, Allison and Kasey. Dearest sister of Irwin Wolfe. Graveside services Sunday 11am at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Mystery Solved
description: Ever since the atheist leader Madalyn Murray O'Hair disappeared in 1995, the mill of speculation surrounding her whereabouts covered the gamut. She was dead, she had fled the country; there were countless other scenarios. It now appears that she is dead. Investigators unearthed the decapitated remains of three bodies -- including one with an artificial hip, as Ms. O'Hair had. The suspect who led them to the bodies on a Texas ranch admitted that he did ''physical violence'' to Ms. O'Hair. Lab tests confirming the identities of the bodies are pending. Jim Yardley

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASE, ELEANOR
description: KASE-Eleanor. Loving wife of the late Jules. Devoted mother of Nina and Peter. Cherished grandmother of Jordan, Deborah, Jessie, Erica and Gregory. Services Sunday, 12 noon, Parkside Chapel, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: The Last Great Art Of the 20th Century
description: THE last great work of 20th-century American art has just been finished in this cattle town, a tumbleweed-tossed speck in the high desert plain near the Mexican border known here as ''el despoblado,'' the uninhabited place, 200 miles southeast of El Paso.

title: When Sands Give Up Maritime Treasures
description: GLIMPSES of Long Island's history abound in the old shops, houses, museums and plaques that dot the region. But there is plenty of history buried under the water and sand, and it only takes a strong storm to uncover more of the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, BETTY
description: OWEN-Betty. Of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Eastchester, NY, died Feb. 1, 2001 at age 93. Survived by her daughter Phyllis Elbe (Peter), three grandchildren, Michael Owen Elbe, Barbara Elbe Reiter (Barry) and Susan Elbe Lowy (Lloyd), and six greatgrandchildren, Parker Owen Elbe; Matthew, Kate, & Timothy Reiter; Alexander and Evan Lowy. Donations may be made to White Plains Hospital, White Plains, New York 10601 or The Docent Fund, attn: J. Dobrick, The Norton Museum of Art, 1451 S. Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL. 33401. Memorial services private.

title: MUSIC; The Show Stealer Is Now the Show
description: EUROPE. Mid-1980's. Filthy train. No taxis. Local dialect. Hot little hall. To hear a singer. She made her entrance, followed by a vision in red socks and a rainbow waistcoat. Her pianist. He was sporting a puffed-up do. And -- no, it couldn't be -- was that a touch of eye shadow?

title: Jody Goldfarb, Owen Samuels
description: Jody Anne Goldfarb and Owen Bruce Samuels were married last evening by Rabbi Michael Berenbaum at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Islamic Fervor From Iran Puts Azerbaijan on Alert for Unrest
description: Internal security authorities here are keeping a watchful eye on the activities of mullahs from neighboring Iran, nervous that the religious presence could translate into political instability.

title: Indian Ocean
description: CRYSTAL CRUISES

title: Suit Challenges Buyout That Won Fed Approval
description: Has the Federal Reserve, which administers consumer protection rules in addition to conducting the nation's monetary policy, approved a plan that victimizes minority shareholders in a buyout? At least one lawsuit contends just that.

title: Full Speed Ahead
description: JEFF JOHNSON once loved playing football or softball with friends. Then his neck was fractured in a motorcycle accident four years ago, leaving him paralyzed from the armpits down.

title: A Precision Jewel For LVMH's Crown
description: IT is not unusual to see the name LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton and the word ''acquisition'' in the same sentence. After all, LVMH, the luxury goods company, has been amassing an armada of brands in fashion, leather and cosmetics for years.

title: The Governor Doesn't Need Any Adjectives
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomson's Home Run
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Savings at Sea
description: Shopping on the Web can lead to savings on the water. Cruise Direct Online.Com posts regular discounted fares for cruises to various ports around the world. Five-day Caribbean cruises on the Holland America Westerdam, for example, start at $449 a person, double occupancy. A 15-day Renaissance Cruise of the Mediterranean out of Barcelona starts at $799, plus air fare. All offers on Cruise Direct Online are capacity controlled and available for short periods, so check frequently at www.cruisedirectonline.com . Call (800) 365-1445.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 4, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Taking Health Care Into Their Own Hands
description: MARY WOODS was fed up. After waiting all day to get a checkup for one of her four children at the county hospital in Valhalla, she had missed the last bus home to Peekskill.

title: U.S. TRIES DEFUSING ALLIES' OPPOSITION TO MISSILE DEFENSE
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, the first senior Bush administration official to visit Europe, tried today to defuse opposition to the administration's antimissile plans by offering to help European nations and other allies to deploy missile defenses.

title: Fans Hope It Isn't the End For a Shop Selling Donated Books
description: To the detriment of avid readers, used book dealers, college-bound girls and people with lots of old paperbacks to get rid off, the Bryn Mawr Book Shop closed in December when its basement home, at East 79th Street and York Avenue, became a nightmare of bursting pipes.

title: Technique for Mounting a Towel Bar
description: THE typical towel bar consists of a single bar running between two escutcheons that project from the wall surface. Usually, the escutcheons are not bolted directly to the wall surface but are attached to anchor plates. The anchor plates are bolted to the wall and the escutcheons are fastened to them with hidden set screws. This mounting technique conceals the large screw heads that hold the unit in place.

title: Helping Hand, at Arm's Length, for Crab
description: THE EFFORT to save the horseshoe crab might be one of New Jersey's most successful preservation programs. It has certainly been one of the strangest.

title: Harry H. Kruener; Minister, 85
description: The Rev. Harry H. Kruener, former senior minister of Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights, died on Jan. 23 at a nursing home in Camden, Me. He was 85 and lived in nearby South Thomaston.

title: SEVEN DAYS ON A FLOATING COLOSSUS
description: THIS is what you see when you stroll along the fifth-deck Royal Promenade, forward to aft. On the starboard side: Cafe Promenade, the Games Arcade, the Weekend Warrior sports bar, the entrance to the casino, the Fashion Boutique (designer labels), Tommy Hilfiger, and the tours and customer relations desk. Then, reversing direction, on the port side: the Champagne Bar, the General Store (with snacks and liquor and suntan products), the ship's logo souvenir shop, the Crown and Bottle Pub, the jewelry store and the perfume shop. The cafe and bars have outdoor tables, and the shops occasionally hold special sales on the street, for it is as a street that one must consider it. Three decks of cabins overlook the bustle from picture windows that can be cleaned only by cherry-picker.

title: Streetscapes/Luther Harris and Greenwich Village; A Man With a Passion About Washington Square
description: HE had to leave 2,500 photographs out, but Luther S. Harris, a telecommunications consultant, has finally finished his illustrated history of the area around Washington Square. His book, with 350 photographs, hasn't been published yet. But Mr. Harris is in no particular hurry, since he took 20 years to write it.

title: A Realist Stirs The Imagination
description: ENCOURAGING thoughts about the future of realist painting can arise while viewing the recent work of Steven DiGiovanni at Gallery Thirteen in Danbury. Though there are only 10 paintings on display, nothing in them is negligible and clues to possible meaning can pop up anywhere on the canvas.

title: Iverson And Fans: Love-Hate Embrace
description: Allen Iverson was about to skip off the floor quietly after a satisfying victory on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. But then Iverson, the Philadelphia 76ers' All-Star guard, caught the glance of one of his detractors, a Knicks fan who had been riding him throughout the game.

title: Program for Gifted Students in Jeopardy
description: FORTUNE was smiling on the Three Village school district last month when 12 of its high school seniors were named semifinalists in this year's Intel Talent Search, the most prestigious science contest in the nation. But no one here thinks it an accident of geography that its high school, Ward Melville, has the third highest number of Intel semifinalists in the country. Rather, it results from a commitment to academic excellence by the district and its taxpayers.

title: Senior Coupons
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to read in ''Airline Coupons Cut Senior Fares'' (Dec. 10) that Continental Airlines will not have any blackout days for 2001 and 2002. This was not my experience.

title: Amateur Pool Team Banking on Playoffs
description: AFTER a week of writing about government food service, military clubs and on-campus hospitality, Lenny Klie, an editor at EBM Publications in Westbury, is ready to wind down. Every Thursday, he leaves work at 5:30 p.m. and heads for a bar. But it is not the cold beer that he is anticipating -- it's getting the eight ball in the corner pocket.

title: Waiting at the Gate For Trade With Cuba
description: THE Havana harbor has been a forbidden port of call for American ships since the United States imposed its economic embargo on Cuba in the early 1960's, and not much was expected to change after Congress enacted a law last fall lifting the embargo just enough to allow the first sales of food and medicine. The new law imposed such severe restrictions on financing that nobody expected any deals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, HOWARD L.
description: CLARK-Howard L. On February 2, 2001, in Greenwich, CT, at the age of 84. Retired Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of American Express Company. Loving husbnd of Jean, father of four, Howard, Pamela, Stuart, Steve; step-father of five, Susan, Albert, Lynde, Paul, and Patty. Memorial service at 10:30 AM, on Wednesday, February 7, at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Museum of Natural History (NY) or the Columbia Presbyterian Hospital (NY).

title: Q and A
description: 'Home Swapping' in Geneva

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; So Much, From So Little
description: More than 12 years after the pieces of Pan Am 103 rained flaming down on the tiny town of Lockerbie, Scotland, someone was finally found guilty of the crime.

title: The Nation; In God We Trust. In Government We Hope for the Best
description: ON his radio show last week, Jay Sekulow said he was swamped with calls from listeners around the country eager to talk about President Bush's new initiative to funnel government dollars and support to religious social service programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREKKA, THOMAS THORWALD
description: BREKKA - Thomas Thorwald. 1928-2001. Tom Brekka died the evening of January 25th doing what he loved best, taking one of his twice-daily strolls around the neighborhood. He loved looking up into the mountains to see if there was snow on top and looking in the sky to see the airplanes he knew so well. He walked religiously so that he would stay healthy and have many years to come to spend with his wife, his 10 children and his 13 grandchildren (with two more on the way). If anything, Tom Brekka was a man who cherished children. And every child who knew him knew what it meant to be cherished. Even the neighborhood children couldn't pass him by without singing out, ''Hi Tom! Hi Tom! Bye Tom! Bye Tom!'' Tom Brekka was a Second Lieutenant in the United States Air Force during the Korean War, but thankfully was kept out of action so he could train other navigators at the Air Force Academy. In 1952 he married the love of his life, Patricia Flynn, and together they raised 10 children: four boys and six girls. Tom was perhaps most proud of having put all 10 children through college-he'd get a special gleam in his eye when he'd tell people ''we have 10 undergraduate degrees and four graduate degrees''-five including his own recent MBA from UC Irvine. Tom had received his Bachelor's Degree in Business, and his Doctorate of Law from Fordham University, shortly after retiring from the Air Force. Yet he always wished he had gotten his MBA. So, in 1997 he fulfilled that dream, at 70 years of age, when he graduated from UC Irvine's 21 month Executive MBA Program. He will be remembered and missed for his tremendous love and affection for all people-but especially for his own family. He always had a kind word, or a silly joke, a tickle, a smile, a hand to lend. He loved to make people laugh, and best of all, he loved to jump out at you when you least expected it. We have been so blessed to have had him as a husband, father, brother and grandfather. I love you Tom. We love you Dad. Thank you for your undying love and affection, your wisdom, your integrity, and your strength. Your belief in God and in each of us as individuals has emboldened us. You gave us the tools to live fruitful lives and we each carry a part of you in our hearts. We know a lot more about Heaven because we know you are there. His spirit lives on in the hearts of many: his wife of 48 years, Patricia Brekka, of Mission Viejo, CA; his brother, Larry Brekka of McClean, VA; his children: Patty, Tom, Rosemary, Cassie, Michael, Christine, Richard, Kevin, Maureen and Susan; and his grandchildren: Allison, Kimmie, Kyle, Candace, Marshall, baby Brekka, Aaron, Michael, Natalie, Julia, Emily, Michael, Adam, Maggie, Dylan, baby Heironimus, and all the future Brekkas. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The C.H.O.C. Foundation (Children's Hospital of Orange County), 455 South Main Street, Orange, CA 92868. Please include a brief note indicating: ''donation in memory of Thomas Brekka for children's cancer research, please notify Mrs. Brekka'' and a note will be sent to Patricia Brekka by the hospital.

title: The Nation: The Democrats; Will the Democrats Decide to Get Mad Or Get Even?
description: IT is no accident that the first lapel buttons to sell out at a gathering here this weekend of Democratic officials from around the country proclaimed: ''Re-elect Al Gore in 2004.'' Or that Terry McAuliffe, in his pitch to party members to crown him the new Democratic chairman, declared that he was driven to run because ''I'm a little outraged about the last election. I'm a little angry.''

title: Pardon in U.S. For Marc Rich Creates Storm In Switzerland
description: Prominent Swiss citizens who wrote to President Clinton to urge a pardon for Marc Rich have become the focus of an outcry here over whether the former fugitive trader bought their support for his pardon through charitable contributions.

title: Johanna Azoulay and Marshall Kiev
description: WHEN she was 20, Johanna Simone Azoulay left Le Raincy, France, her hometown near Paris, for New York, where she knew no one. She was thrilled, rather than terrified, by the prospect. ''I landed, moved into my room, started walking along the streets, got lost, and found my way home,'' she said. ''It was completely exciting.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDRE, OLIVIA DULANY WHEELER POST
description: ALEXANDRE - Olivia Dulany Wheeler Post. Died quietly at home on Saturday, January 21st. She was born in 1903, was twice widowed and leaves three stepchildren: Nancy Post Magro, George B. Post and L. Jerome Alexandre. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church Saturday, February 17 at 11 A.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Church at 865 Madison Avenue, NY, NY, 10021.

title: Buyer Beware On Domain Names
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALLEN, JARED DAVID
description: ALLEN-Jared David. We will love you forever. We will miss you for always. Grandma Fay, Grandpa Allen, Aunt Sheila, Uncle Jeff, Greg & Greer

title: PROPERTY TAX INCREASES
description: Property taxes in New Jersey rose an average of 4.8 percent last year, according to the Department of Community Affairs, which said the increase was mainly due to school taxes, which were 5.4 percent higher on average. Municipal taxes rose an average of 4.16 percent and county taxes an average of 1.83 percent. Abhi Raghunathan

title: For an Olds Family, the End of the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Sit and Read Quietly? Not at This Library
description: ANTHONY WOODEN bellows a command to samba, and instantly 20 or so students of African dance spring into action. Bounding forward, sliding sideways, the students, some young, some not so young, try desperately to keep up with the crescendo of an African drum and the elastic movements of their teacher.

title: Free-Tuition Program Transforms a University
description: In about eight weeks, the calls from furious parents will start to accumulate on the desk of Michael F. Adams, the president of the University of Georgia, in what has recently become a painful annual ritual. Doesn't he know they are alumni, Bulldog boosters, season ticket holders, prodigious writers of checks? How could he possibly refuse to admit their child to their alma mater?

title: Famous Long Ago
description: IT'S Saturday night, and on the stage at the Bowery Ballroom, the downtown rock club, the man in the pink vinyl pants is spinning like a dervish.

title: A Holy River Runs Through It
description: SISTER INDIA

title: Corrections
description: The Market Insight column on Jan. 21, an interview with Ivy Zelman, a building and building products analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, about the prospects for housing-related stocks, referred incorrectly to the sales practices of Ethan Allen, the furniture maker. Ms. Zelman said after publication that she had misspoken and that the company sells its merchandise through its own network of stores; it does not sell to independent stores.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Earthquake's Toll Grows
description: To salve its pain, India focused on the miracles: the 102-year-old woman resurrected from the rubble; the young man who survived by drinking the water trickling from a broken freezer; the mother and baby sustained in an air pocket in a mound of concrete. But these were rare. Most commonly, the Jan. 26 earthquake was about deaths: 25,000 of them. And hundreds of thousands of the homeless -- now hungry, thirsty and cold -- awaited help from a confused relief operation that left supplies stacked up on airport runways. Barry Bearak

title: Dominican Resort
description: To the Editor: I was very put off by the tone of Scott Norvell's ''From the Scrub Comes a Behemoth'' (Jan. 7). An all-inclusive vacation is what many of us seek, particularly in the winter. If not having to worry for five days about pickpockets, unsanitary food, poor infrastructure and substandard living conditions is considered by the author to be ''all exclusive,'' so be it.

title: The Dividend Check Isn't in the Mail
description: FOR the past 20 years, the dividends that corporate America doles out to its shareholders have won little respect. Most investors do not give much thought to these quarterly dollops of cash, which seem to dribble in haphazardly in amounts too small to notice, especially when automatically added to a brokerage statement.

title: Israel's 'Confused Dialectic': Peace, Sure, but Many Conflicting Definitions
description: Eighteen years ago, Avraham Burg was a peacenik demonstrating outside the Israeli prime minister's office to demand the resignation of Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. A right-wing fanatic hurled a grenade into the demonstration, killing another protester and injuring Mr. Burg. Israel was in tumult, and Mr. Sharon resigned.

title: From the Roof of a Shed, Tradition Soars
description: LOOMING above a small clearing in the woods about a half-mile from the center of the town of Salisbury is a formidable anachronism covered with snow.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Congreve's Comedy

title: Our Towns; After Eight Years, Unable to Walk Out of Prison, but Free
description: TERRENCE STEVENS is not your run-of-the-mill criminal given a break by a powerful politician. He may have looked every bit the coddled convict as he rode away from the Green Haven Correctional Facility on Wednesday morning in a stretch Navigator S.U.V. that felt a few luxurious feet longer than the arm of the law. But Terrence Stevens is no Marc Rich.

title: Beep! Beep! Classic Cars at Shore
description: The name auto auction is sometimes a little misleading because in the case of some classic car events it is as interesting to look at the cars as it is to bid on them. This fact is not lost on G. Potter King Inc., which will hold its 28th annual Atlantic City Classic Car Event and Auction at the Convention Center next weekend (Friday, Saturday and Sunday). Among the cars on view and on sale are a 1947 Invicta Convertible ''Black Knight,'' one of only 28 ever produced; a 1960 Henny Electric Car; two 1953 Cadillac Eldorado Convertibles; a 1942 Lincoln Continental Coupe; and a 1959 Mercedes Benz 220 SE Ponton Cabriolet. Karen DeMasters

title: What's doing in Rio
description: Rio de Janeiro is always alluring and exhilarating, but never more so than in the weeks leading up to Carnaval. As the annual bacchanal draws closer, the easygoing, relaxed rhythms of a Southern Hemisphere summer -- lying on the beach, quaffing ice-cold beer and chatting at a seafront cafe -- begin to wane and the city pulses with anticipation.

title: Up From the Slush Pile
description: BOOK BUSINESS Publishing Past Present and Future. By Jason Epstein. 188 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $21.95.

title: Assessing Acela
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade reported without comment that she overheard fellow passengers using their cell phones to admonish contractors and to gossip. Until peace and quiet are included among the amenities of this new service, I'll take the bus.

title: Toronto Museum Adds to Asian Collection
description: Aficionados of Eastern art and culture have another reason to visit the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto. The museum, known for its suite of Chinese, Korean and East Asian Galleries, has opened a permanent gallery dedicated to the art and culture of South Asia.

title: Blown Away The Wrong Way By Paradise
description: WE were lying awake on the first night of our Christmas beach vacation, listening to the wind caterwauling outside our windows, when my wife rolled over in bed to face me and ask, ''Did you notice that nobody has a tan?'' I had to admit the thought had already occurred to me. Now we had to figure out how to keep the truth from our children, blissfully asleep, expecting a full week of warming sun and gentle surf.

title: Correction Captain Kills Suspected Robber
description: A Department of Correction captain fatally shot one of two men who were robbing a Chinese restaurant in Queens at gunpoint Friday night, the police said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLOFF, JEROME
description: DILLOFF-Jerome. Died suddenly on Feb. 1, 2001 of Boca Raton, Florida formerly of Lawrence, LI, NY. Beloved husband of Evelyn (nee Slifka) devoted father of Leni (Robert) Newman, Jr. and Nancy (Andrew) Schlesinger, brother of Morton, loving grandfather of Meg (David) Bitton and Rachel Schlesinger. Services private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity in Jerome's memory.

title: Remember When Books Mattered?
description: FOR seven years, until I quit last winter, I worked as the weekly book reviewer at New York magazine. Other than a college English degree and a lifelong book-a-day reading habit, I had no qualifications as a critic. What's worse, at the time I was offered the job, I believed that this question of qualifications mattered. Because I also wrote novels and short stories, and because I'd felt the pleasure and the pain of having my own work reviewed, it troubled me that a mere civilian, an amateur, could turn on his word processor, pour a cup of coffee and -- on no other basis than his own prejudices -- render a public judgment on a book that might affect its sales, its reputation and its author's prospects, not to mention his or her emotional balance.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A DAY LATE AND A DOLLAR SHORT By Terry McMillan. Viking, $25.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Honoring The Good In Sport
description: AND now, a Sunday timeout from the grim tales of mayhem and murder and misogyny, as we consider the possibility of a sickly sports world someday rehabilitating itself.

title: A Brand of Tap Springing From Europe's Streets
description: ONE of Herbin Van Cayseele's first major appearances as a tap dancer in New York City occurred in 1994 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. The stage, set for that week's Shakespeare production, was covered with turf hillocks and slatted wood. Mr. Van Cayseele (pronounced Cazelle) appeared suddenly, a lean, dark-skinned zephyr with a mysteriously inward quality, his feet seeming barely to touch the bumpy terrain. His number was discursive but brief. The impression it left was of indelible magic.

title: Who's Got the Button?
description: This season's bombshell look of Swarovski crystal embellishments will be taking a teeny-bopper turn for spring, with 70's-style pin-on buttons studding everything from denim to T-shirts to camouflage pocketbooks.

title: BUCHANAN: PLANT IN FULL SWING
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant in Buchanan is running at full power for the first time since it closed last February after a small radioactive leak. County Executive Andrew J. Spano and several other officials had opposed the plant's restart, which began on Jan. 3, citing concerns about recent equipment failures. Some environmentalists continue to question the plant's safety and the adequacy of its emergency evacuation plan, which has not been tested since June 1998. But last week Mr. Spano, Senator Charles E. Schumer, and Representative Sue W. Kelly withdrew their calls to have the plant closed again, saying they had been reassured about its safety by the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Robert Worth

title: The Doctor Who Came In From the Cold
description: Ice Bound

title: Seeking Work. Over 40.
description: To the Editor:

title: Confessions of a Lonely Atheist
description: I was amazed by Angier's characterization of atheists as some kind of oppressed minority. Oppressed by whom? As she herself declares, atheism skews indisputably toward the well-educated elite, who tend to harbor deep antagonism toward organized religion.

title: Sales and Marketing in Demand
description: The economy may be slowing, but not the demand for sales and marketing professionals.

title: A Book on Fantome's Loss to Hurricane Mitch
description: Anchored off Key West, Fla., in the fall of 1998, Jim Carrier was living his dream. After 13 years roaming across the West and writing as the Rocky Mountain Ranger columnist for The Denver Post, Carrier purchased a 35-foot yawl, moved aboard and was embarking on fresh adventures and assignments.

title: Clay Lancaster, Helped Save Historic Districts, Dies at 83
description: Clay Lancaster, whose trained eye and playful imagination illuminated the history of architecture, and whose 1961 book documenting the historic houses of Brooklyn Heights proved to be one of the earliest and loudest shots in the historic preservation struggle in New York City, died on Dec. 25 in Harrodsburg, Ky. He was 83.

title: Gathered Vestiges of a Covered-Wagon Diaspora
description: ALMOST everyone is familiar with the entrance of Jews to America through Ellis Island, but few people have heard of a smaller but nevertheless important Jewish migration westward to New Mexico by wagon train along the Santa Fe Trail. Their number was not great -- by 1917, fewer than 1,000 called New Mexico home -- but these Jews helped shape the economy, culture and political landscape of the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLMAN, NORMAN S.
description: WOLMAN-Norman S. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Norman S. Wolman, associated with The Times from 1970 until 1976.

description: Best Bet

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 16 about the release of Mazen Al-Najjar, a Palestinian immigrant who was held in a Florida jail on the basis of secret evidence, referred incorrectly to the area in Gaza where he was born on June 4, 1957. At that time Egypt controlled the territory; it was not occupied by Israel. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Assessing Acela
description: To the Editor: As a Boston native, I am, of course, delighted that the new Acela Express train reduces the time between New York and Boston to three and a half hours. And yet even the new service, by European standards, is a joke.

title: Toasting Cheney's Victory With Coke? This Is Loyalty?
description: In the cultic world of soda mythology, it has long been said that Democrats are devoted to Coca-Cola, while Republicans bear a tireless loyalty to Pepsi.

title: Is That Al Gore On My $300 Bill?
description: Try this pop quiz: Name the people who appear on the $100,000, the $10,000 and the $200 bills.

title: The Quake's Silent Ally: A Hidebound Bureaucracy
description: He is a ''babu'' himself, Jagdish G. Pandiya an official of no small standing, with a stately Ambassador car and a driver, a brisk manner and a title, ''additional collector,'' that goes back to 250 years of British rule in India, when the basic administrative systems for ruling this vast, chaotic country were laid down.

title: Produce Politics
description: A label-reading walk through the grocery store reveals why so many Americans are undernourished and overfed with hydrogenated, fat-laden foods. Pollan speaks briefly about the ''citizen'' in all of us. The current spread of eco-labeling is a welcome sign. Let's lobby for more disclosure and keep some control in the hands of the consumer.

description: Earlier this week, the rookie defenseman Dale Purinton declined the Rangers' request that he return to Hartford of the American Hockey League during the All-Star Game break, Hartford Coach John Paddock confirmed.

title: Zimbabwe's Judges Are Feeling Mugabe's Wrath
description: President Robert Mugabe, the aging guerrilla who has led this country's long struggle against white domination, has rallied for a fresh fight, this time declaring war on the black and white judges of the highest court of the land.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 21 about new interest in original recordings of ragtime referred incorrectly to the absence of a spoken song title with a racial epithet from the recent compact disc compilation ''Popular Band and Instrumental.'' The epithet is in the original title of a cylinder recording by Maurice Levi and his band, but that recording was made after Columbia stopped announcing title and performer at the beginnings of its cylinders. On the CD, the song is called ''A Band Contest,'' but it was not ''shorn of its announcement'' by the reissue producers.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: The news in astronomy is often old -- billions of years old -- but it comes from farther away than any other kind, and there has been a lot of it in the last decade or so. John Noble Wilford, who has written about the universe for this paper since 1965, is the editor of a collection of recent Times news articles on astronomy and cosmology, COSMIC DISPATCHES: The New York Times Reports on Astronomy and Cosmology (Norton, $26.95). The reports describe amazing things: planets orbiting other suns than ours, stars born and stars dying, greedy black holes wolfing down whatever ventures close enough, the long, cliffhanging search for the missing mass of the universe. Heroes are profiled as well, distinguished discoverers like Allan R. Sandage, the present proprietor of the Hubble constant, and Stephen Hawking, the Delphic cosmologist of Cambridge University. The book even tells us the practical benefits of such knowledge, quoting Enrico Fermi on the value of basic research to the national defense: ''It gives us something worth defending.''

title: In Review: Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: Ashcroft Confirmed, 58-42

title: Price of Propane Making It Harder to Keep Warm
description: INDIANOLA, Iowa, Feb. 2  White is the color of cold in Iowa this winter, with perennially white skies folding into silent white pastures and fields of corn stubble. Behind white clapboard farmhouses, only the white tanks, shaped like snub-nosed submarines, offer protection from a winter that began as the coldest recorded around here and has almost two months to go.

title: A Person With a Plan to Shake Up the Schools
description: THE Camden educational establishment may be reeling with the number of initiatives the new school superintendent has put on the table in her first month, but Annette D. Knox says this is just the beginning.

title: Minorities Learning More Than Science At Museum
description: SEVENTEEN-year-old Alana Graham used to be afraid of snakes. Now she feels perfectly comfortable holding one end of a six-foot boa constrictor. She knows what to feed the boa (dead mice) and what to feed ferrets (fruit and vegetables) and how to make a tree frog comfortable (a little spritz so it won't get dry) and how to make a box turtle feel better (lower the tank humidity). She learned these things from animal keepers at the Newark Museum, where Ms. Graham has worked as an intern for three years in the Science Explorers program.

title: Assessing Acela
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''The New Acela: An Assessment (Practical Traveler, Jan. 21): What a disappointment the Acela Express has been for those of us who commute weekly and who were hoping to have a faster train at a reasonable price.

title: There Is Something New Under the Sun
description: PEOPLE who think that there is nothing new under the sun obviously do not receive garden catalogs. Each year the catalogs arrive, borne on wings of hyperbole, trumpeting the improvements that have invaded the world of plant merchandising since last year at this time.

title: QUICK BITE/Princeton; Paper or Plastic (Plate)?
description: Walk into the the Wegman's supermarket in Princeton and the first thing you'll spot is a sign: ''Discover the Orient with Sushi.'' A few feet away is a Happy New Year sign in Chinese. Walk a little farther and there in the cases are fancy hors d'oeuvres, spare ribs, potato pancakes, fish, pizza, grilled portobello mushroom sandwiches and more, all prepared by an executive chef and 15 to 20 assistants, including bakers who turn out 30 varieties of breads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURLEY, MIRIAM GREENE
description: HURLEY-Miriam Greene. Age 90, of Boston and Chilmark, Martha's Vineyard (formerly of Weston), on Thursday, February 1, 2001. Wife of the late Donald J. Hurley. Mother of Cornelia Hurley McPeek of Chestnut Hill, Donald Hurley, Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, NY, Stephen Nash Hurley of Boston and Rosamond Page Hurley Shugrue of Boston. Gandmother of several grandchildren. There will be a private family Mass. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial service on Friday, March 9, 2001, at 3 PM, at the Memorial Church at Harvard University, Harvard Yard, Cambridge. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Miriam Greene Hurley Memorial Fund at the Martha's Vineyard Garden Club, RFD 319X, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: THE PRICE YOU PAY

title: Not So Long Ago, 'a New Zealand Film' Didn't Even Exist
description: IN their 1996 film ''Forgotten Silver,'' the directors Peter Jackson and Costa Botes tell the story of Colin McKenzie, a plucky New Zealander who, as a young man in the early years of the 20th century, built a bicycle-powered movie camera, with which he captured history's first tracking shot and made his own film stock out of flax leaves.

title: Democrats Choose Close Friend of Clinton to Lead Party
description: The Democratic National Committee elected Terry McAuliffe as its new chairman today, and he vowed to take on President Bush as fiercely as Republicans went after the man Mr. McAuliffe calls his best friend, Bill Clinton.

title: Rio Yushin, Jonas Slaven
description: Rio Yushin, the daughter of Lidiya Yushin of Boston and the late Yuri Yushin, was married last evening to Jonas Drew Slaven, a son of Margaret Slaven of Demarest, N.J., and the late John J. Slaven. Theodore R. Kupferman, a retired New York State Appellate Court judge and former United States congressman, officiated at the Harold Pratt House in New York.

description: PLAYS in progress are everywhere. But the New Jersey Repertory Company here is a case of theaters in progress.

title: $330 Million Plan to Save Peconic Estuary
description: IN a striking advance for protecting the Peconic estuary, a 231,000-acre expanse of water and land between the North and South Forks, a group established by the federal government has formally adopted a comprehensive conservation and management plan calling for $330 million in spending for water and natural resource initiatives.

title: Article 2001020491906151937 -- No Title
description: By SUSAN STELLIN

title: SUN, ICE AND EXPLORERS' GRAVES
description: HIGH in the Canadian Arctic archipelago, some 560 miles north of the Arctic Circle, our rubber Zodiac raft scudded across a bay vivid and still as blue seaglass, nosing toward forlorn Beechey Island, a mass of gray cliffs and brown earth too small to appear on most maps. To the right of the forbidding cliffs, a rocky slope tumbled past ice-clogged clefts to a harsh gravel shoreline. And there on the beach, four bone-white specks caught my eye, their forms growing larger and sharper, until at last they resolved themselves into something I could recognize: simple wooden burial markers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUER, JACOB
description: BAUER-Jacob. Died January 25, 2001. Of East Moriches, NY at age 91. Captain U.S. Army WW II. Retired executive of Bristol Myers. Beloved husband of Marjorie of 64 years. Father of Peter & Wendy. Grandfather of Scott, Jenn & Brian. Memorial Service, First Presbyterian Church, E. Moriches, Saturday, February 10, 11 AM.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Learning the Hard Way in Camden
description: ONE indication that Annette D. Knox was the right choice for superintendent of schools here is that on the day after her first school board meeting, which went on until 2:30 in the morning, she was able to describe the event as ''mild.''

title: A Technique for Mounting a Towel Bar
description: THE typical towel bar consists of a single bar running between two escutcheons that project from the wall surface. Usually, the escutcheons are not bolted directly to the wall surface but are attached to anchor plates. The anchor plates are bolted to the wall and the escutcheons are fastened to them with hidden set screws. This mounting technique conceals the large screw heads that hold the unit in place.

title: What Is 'Black Dance'? A Cultural Melting Pot
description: IF things had gone according to plan, Salia Sanou would be earning a decent living these days as a police inspector in Burkina Faso, the tropical West African country where he was born and reared. After passing the police exam, Mr. Sanou was on the verge of getting his badge in 1991. Then, in a final fling with dance, which he had studied since childhood, he went to an audition that turned his world upside down.

title: More of the Same With Postal Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Fund Inflows Set Record
description: It's official. Last year was a record for money flows into stock funds. They took in $309.3 billion, versus $187.7 billion in 1999. The previous record, $227.1 billion, was in 1997. The Investment Company Institute, a trade group, published the tallies last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, JOSEPH F. SR.
description: LANE-Joseph F. Sr. Retired Police Commissioner of Long Beach, NY on February 2, 2001 in Mesa, Arizona. He was 82 and had been in ailing health since his move to Arizona three years ago. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Clark). Loving father of Joseph F. (Martha), Thomas P., Kevin P. (Malissa), Robert (Susan) and Patricia Lane (Luis J. Briones). Dear brother of Eileen E. Lane and Marie Lane Caufield. Cherished grandfather of Katherine Elizabeth Lane, Sandra Patricia Lane, Ryan Andrew Lane, Ligita Irene Lane, Megan Kema Lane, Nicole Marie Briones and Joseph Luis Briones. His extended family of sister-in-law Bernadette McCann, Veronica Inch and brotherin-law Joseph McCann and his 27 nephews and nieces. Reposing at Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY. Wednesday and Thursday 2-4, 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30 AM St. Ignatius Martyr RC Church, Long Beach, New York. Interment in Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower St., Phoenix, AZ 85014.

title: Field Guide? Check. Binoculars? Check. Lobbyists? Soon.
description: The golden-crowned kinglet alighted only briefly in the riverfront scrub of the Potomac River's western shore. But it arrived like a feathery punctuation mark for some fascinated bird watchers who had ducked out of the capital city across the river to take a midday break from their determined new task of building what amounts to a political lobby for birds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSTMANN, NICHOLAS C.
description: FORSTMANN-Nicholas C. On February 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Lana (nee Wolkonsky); adoring father of three children; dearest son of Dorothy Sammis; loving brother of Anthony, Theodore, John, Marina and Elissa; You will be forever missed and we will cherish your memory always. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, corner of 81st, on Monday, February 5, 2:00-4:00 PM and 7:00-9:00 PM; Mass on Tuesday, February 6, at 10:30 AM at Saint Patrick's Cathedral. title: POSTINGS: $9 Million Project at New York Botanical Garden Designed by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates; Amid the Flowers, a Visitor Center
description: The New York Botanical Garden, whose floral displays throughout its 250 acres in the Bronx attract about 630,000 visitors a year, has scheduled a $9 million facelift for the area that first greets visitors, with groundbreaking scheduled for this fall and completion in the spring of 2003. The result will be a 23,700-square-foot visitor center, designed by Hugh Hardy of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates of Manhattan.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Miranda Has Its Limits
description: A federal judge in the terrorism trial of four men in the 1998 bombings of the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania ruled that Miranda warnings, which advise defendants of the right to counsel and the appointment of a lawyer if they cannot afford one, may not be feasible when American officials question suspects on foreign soil. The ruling, by Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan, allows prosecutors to use statements made by three of the men who were questioned, without lawyers, in Africa. The ruling could have a major impact on future interrogations of terrorism suspects outside the United States. Benjamin Weiser

title: Ideas & Trends: Short Circuit; Deregulation: A Movement Groping in the Dark
description: THIS bit of gallows humor has been making the rounds of the electricity industry: The British decide to switch drivers from the left to the right side of the road, just like the rest of Europe. But the queen worries that making the changeover all at once will be too complicated.

title: Going on Trial: U.S. Accusations Of a Global Plot; In Embassy Bombings Case, The Specter of a Mastermind
description: Courtroom 318 in Old Federal Courthouse in Manhattan is where the United States brings terrorism to trial.

title: The Rare Producer Honored for His Art
description: IT'S very interesting,'' says the filmmaker James Toback. ''I have known Ed Pressman since school. We were at Ethical Culture and Fieldston together. We grew up in the same building, the Majestic, on Central Park West. He's like my oldest friend. He's always been there. And now he's become really very important and very powerful. And I don't see any change. As a kid he always had the best toys, and he'd share them. And now he's involved on maybe half -- or more -- of the best films. But it's still Ed -- quiet, shy, bookish Ed -- trying to help and please the wilder kids, the ones who try to make movies.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMAN, JENNIFER RACHEL
description: PERLMAN-Jennifer Rachel, 34. Died quietly at her home in San Francisco on January 24th, 2001, following a seven month battle with cancer. She was surrounded by family and friends, who loved her dearly. She embraced life and brought incredible warmth and joy to many. She leaves her beloved husand, Karl Horton; her parents, Jane and Larry; brother, Robert; and numerous friends. She trained at the Joffrey School of Ballet, and was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School, Brown University and Temple University, where she received her Ph.D. in clinical psychology. A memorial service will be held at Barge Music, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, New York on Tuesday, Feb. 6th at 4PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in Jennifer Rachel Perlman's memory to ''UCSF Foundation'', Cancer Center Fund, Box 0246, UCSF, San Francisco, CA. 94143-0248.

title: IN THE LAB WITH/Dr. Robert Pavlica; Formula for Turning Out Winners
description: FOR years, prestigious scientific competitions like the Intel Science Talent Search (more familiar by its former name, the Westinghouse program) were dominated by high school students from such science powerhouses as Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, Brooklyn Tech and some Long Island schools.

Cherished brother of the late Norman Krug and the late Ann Trachtenberg. Loving grandfather of Dana and Steve Lichtenstein, Nora, Aaron and Tracey Krug. description: Q: What does it feel like to run that fast? Is it the same kind of rush you get when you're going really fast in a car?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDEN, VICKI GREENE
description: GOLDEN-Vicki Greene. Of Minturn, CO, and Washington, DC, on February 3, 2001. Remembered with love and pride by her husband, Chuck Wiester, her children, Eric and Megan Golden, her grandchildren Anna, Eliza and Jonathan, and brothers Lee and Michael Greene. Memorial service will be held at 3:30 PM, Sunday, February 4 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation.

title: The Cloning Mission; A Desire to Duplicate
description: Last year, a 10-month-old baby boy died in the hospital after a minor operation went wrong. The baby's parents, an American couple, had two other children and probably could have had another if they wished; neither parent was infertile, and both were healthy and in their 30's. But they did not want another child. They wanted this child. And before long, they began to believe that the longing they felt was telling them something quite specific -- that their dead baby's genes were crying out, as a ghost might, to express themselves again in this world. The idea preoccupied them that their little son's genotype deserved another chance, that it had disappeared by mistake and could be brought back by intention.

description: How do you start a speech if you're president?

description: Among the problems faced by the Florida Panthers' Scott Mellanby, captain of the third-worst team in the National Hockey League, is language.

description: The 230 young athletes in the 27th annual Colgate Women's Games yesterday at Madison Square Garden jumped around the track as if they could still feel the heat generated by the elite athletes in Friday night's Millrose Games.

title: Father Who Killed His Two Sons Finds Way to Deepen Their Mother's Grief
description: First, the killer took her two children and now, prosecutors say, he teases her with the hope that she could have one back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUSTIN, MIRIAM
description: JUSTIN-Miriam. Died peacefully at age 94 on February 3, 2001. Beloved mother of Barbara Handler and her husband Mark, Jane Justin and her long time partner Les Suchman. Grandma Mim to Jody and Neal Cooper, Jonathan Handler and Penni Sibun. Great-grandmother for the first time on January 17, 2001 to Lorien Katharine Sibun-Handler. She will also be missed by her long time caregiver Gloria Avellana. Her feisty demeanor and firm maternal presence touched all those she knew. She was a woman of great style and sophisticated taste. She started and ran her own successful business ''Just-In-Case'' for more than 20 years. Her life was long and fruitful and may she rest in peace. Services will be private.

title: Talking Back Is Good Medicine
description: TWO years ago, Esther Weiss traveled from her home in Encino, Calif., to her hometown of Kansas City, Mo., to help celebrate her sister's 90th birthday. Upon arriving, she found that her older sister was suffering from painful, and untreated, gastric distress after eating.

title: The Witches of Eastwick: The Next Generation
description: Returning to our story: Sukie, Alexandra and Jane have inherited their namesakes' supernatural powers, not to mention their exaggerated lust and phenomenal 80's fashion sense.

title: By the Way; Stolen Moments
description: Five years ago Helene Stapinski visited the Jersey City Public Library to find the newspaper article documenting her Uncle Sonny's death: at age 14, he fell off a truck after stealing shingles for a clubhouse he was building. The text had been ripped out of the newspaper. She knew right off that the culprit was her Grandpa Beansie, who worked as the library's security guard and thought little of ''borrowing'' books, coins and artifacts from the premises. That gave Ms. Stapinski the idea to put together the tales of Grandpa Beansie ''going away,'' and of assorted numbers runners, armed robbers and other perpetrators in her family. The result is ''Five Finger Discount: A Crooked Family History,'' which arrives in bookstores next month. The book, published by Random House Trade Publishing, costs $23.95, if you pay for it. Adrienne Bell

title: Word for Word/Of Little Brain; Ritalin to the Rescue: A Children's Story for Our Time
description: THE the overdiagnosis of learning and behavioral disorders in ever-younger children has gone so far that even psychologists now joke that Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer, were they alive today, would be on Ritalin and in special education for hyperactivity. Similarly, the DSM-IV, the pyschiatrist's diagnostic bible, now includes something called Oppositional Defiant Disorder. Does that mean the Terrible Twos is an illness?
