title: Inspiring a New Generation of News Enthusiasts
description: Linda Ellerbee, host and executive producer of ''Nick News,'' likes to treat her viewers like adults. ''I have always believed that the audience has at least as much sense as I do, if not more, and that it doesn't matter if somebody is 60 or 10,'' said Ms. Ellerbee (right, on the ''Nick News'' set).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERRAKOS, DR. JOHN CONSTANTINE
description: PIERRAKOS-Dr. John Constantine. Of New York City, left this world for the next on February 1, 2001, seven days before his 80th birthday. He is survived by his daughter Magdalen Pierrakos.

title: In Albany, Ally of Insurers Profits From Them
description: Few industries are more closely regulated than New York's $90 billion insurance business, and in Albany, it shows. When the Legislature meets, scores of lobbyists retained by insurers descend upon the Statehouse.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Restoring an Old House? A Support Group May Help
description: IF Mr. Blandings were buying his dream house today, he might not be as likely to tear it down and build anew. These days, old house buyers tend to be dedicated and willing to tolerate the financial and emotional toll of restoration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN EES, DONALD
description: VAN EES-Donald. 80, on January 26, 2001, after a prolonged and agonizing illness endured with equanimity and great courage. Requiescat in Pace. Remembered always by his wife, Evelyn and his son, Van.

title: No-Cell-Phone Cars Would Ease the Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Warning on Military Spending Challenges Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  With his vow to keep Pentagon spending lean in the coming year, President Bush issued a stern and unexpected challenge to members of Congress and the military who believe that America's armed forces need a rapid and large infusion of money if the nation is to remain a global superpower.

title: Alfred Koeppel, 68; Headed Real Estate Concern
description: Alfred J. Koeppel, an executive in one of the oldest real estate families in New York and a former board chairman at Trinity College, died of cancer on Jan. 19 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was 68.

title: The Noble Two-Season Mission of 'Space: 1999'
description: ON the moon they have a problem: atomic waste shipped from earth and stored on the dark side is about to blow. ''We have magnetic energy of unprecedented violence,'' reports an officer in Moonbase Alpha, a sleekly modular outpost for 300 people on the lunar surface. One idea is to spread the stuff out, diffusing the explosive central mass. Nice try, but futile. ''The greatest step for mankind is about to look like a stumble in the dark,'' says Commander John Koenig, portrayed with furrow-browed intensity by Martin Landau.

title: King of the Gadflies
description: GEORGE N. SPITZ, public gadfly and perennial candidate, is seeking office again. But this time it's different. He says he's running to win.

title: Business Diary: Is That Al Gore on My $300 Bill?
description: Try this pop quiz: Name the people who appear on the $100,000, the $10,000 and the $200 bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINEMANN, HELEN LILLIAN
description: HEINEMANN-Helen Lillian. Died February 1, 2001, after a long battle with cancer. Helen was the beloved wife of Harry and the devoted mother of David and Tammy, Richard, and Cindy and Kevin Gold. Proud grandmother of Eric, Max and Aaron. Loving sister to Ruth Daub and Sidney Stern. She loved her family and friends. We will miss her very much. Funeral will be held at Sinai Chapels in Queens, 11 AM, February 4, 2001.

title: Now a Triple Threat, With Her Tale of Love and Class
description: ONE night in a small French city, a gloomy, middle-aged, provincial businessman who has no interest in culture is dragged to the local theater by his brittle wife. The tycoon finds himself falling head-over-heels for the star of the production, a 40-year-old struggling actress who can't comprehend his sudden attentions, let alone return them.

title: Defending English From Assault on the Job
description: PITY the linguistic purists. An Apple Computer advertisement exhorts, ''Think different'' when it means ''differently.'' A health insurer writes to a policy holder, without humor, to say, ''Thank you for your patients.'' The trouble even reaches inside the Oval Office to President Bush, who has said, ''Reading is the basics for all learning'' and has vowed not to let terrorists ''hold this nation hostile.''

title: To a Fan's Ear, the Times Changed, Not the Music
description: TWO English singer-songwriters of the 1970's are having their turn at the wheel of revival this year. Both died young, in different ways.

title: A Quieter Mason Finds Himself an All-Star at 34
description: Anthony Mason received the news while preparing to shoot a free throw during practice last Wednesday in Dallas. He does not remember everything Pat Riley said, yet something about Mason having to postpone his vacation in about 10 days while his coach went deep-sea fishing made him tilt his head and listen.

title: Here, Boy. Come to The Toy Store. Please!
description: INSIDE a cavernous New York sound stage, seven hours into an advertising shoot, a small robotic dog decides that it has had enough.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a fatal attack by a dog on a San Francisco woman misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the California Corrections Department, who said the animal came from an attack-dog business run by two prisoners. He is Russ Heimerich, not Heimrich.

title: European Waters
description: CELEBRITY CRUISES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATERFINO, DOUGLAS
description: CATERFINO-Douglas. On Friday, February 2, 2001, of Short Hills, NJ. Beloved husband of Elissa Caterfino (nee Shaw). Loving father of Andrew and Brian Caterfino. Cherished son of Sam and Mary Caterfino. Devoted brother of John Caterfino and Nancy McDermott. Adored grandson of Louise Thompson and Eleanor Caterfino. Dear son-in-law of Norman and Gail Shaw. Services will be held at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Rd., Union, NJ, on Sunday, February 4, 2001, at 2:15 PM. Interment at the B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Community Funds Inc., Douglas Caterfino Fund for Brain Tumor Research, New York Community Trust, 2 Park Ave, NYC 10016.

title: The Way We Live Now: 02-04-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Albert Hubbard, Thorndike, Me., Oct. 28, 2000

title: Children, See a Land of Gentler TV
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Mess
description: The Ethicist's wry (but, surely, political) reply to ''Anonymous'' that he should ''take the high road'' rather than resorting to the ''petty vindictiveness'' of the Quayle staff seems a bit, hmmm, unethical to me!

title: World Wrestling Federation Looking for Space in County
description: Last week, mere days after Texaco confirmed that it would leave its corporate headquarters in Harrison if its merger with Chevron went through, rumors began flying that the World Wrestling Federation could replace it at the large corporate campus. For now, the rumors are apparently about as real as a W.W.F. match, but the federation is indeed looking for space in Westchester.

title: SCARSDALE: CUT CLASS SIZE SUGGESTED
description: Scarsdale should reduce the size of classes in its elementary schools, a committee of teachers and school administrators has recommended. The report suggested that the limit for kindergarten through third grade be no more than 22 students, compared with 24 currently in kindergarten through second grade, and a maximum of 24 students for fourth and fifth grades, where the ceiling is now 26 in third through fifth grades. Merri Rosenberg

title: Deals and Discounts
description: LEASING WHEELS IN EUROPE -- Renault's Eurodrive program gets around car-rental taxes by offering factory-new cars on short-term leases (minimum 17 days, maximum 6 months). For example: a 17-day lease on a subcompact Renault Twingo is $499 (about $30 a day), with unlimited mileage, complete insurance and a factory warranty. There are 33 pickup and dropoff points in Europe; lessors must have permanent addresses outside the European Union. And through Oct. 31, holders of the American Express Senior Member Card receive a 10 percent discount on leases of a compact or larger model; Amex Student Card holders get three to five days added to leases. Information: (800) 221-1052; www .renaultusa.com.

title: The 9-Year-Old Poet With the Big Advance
description: Sahara Sunday Spain began writing poems before she knew how to spell. She'd wake up with an idea in her head, race to the telephone, dial her mother's voicemail and let fly. ''It was fun,'' she says of the poems she began dictating when she was 4 or 5. ''The words just kind of came tumbling out.''

title: How New Campaign Laws Would Help the Economy
description: TOO many comedians are making fun of George W. Bush's brainpower without any basis for their jibes. Why not give him a little quiz instead? O.K., Mr. President, which of the following would help the economy most?

title: Rabbi Found Not Guilty Of Menacing a Neighbor
description: A LOCAL rabbi who was charged with threatening a neighbor with a knife was acquitted last week in a trial that drew dozens of his congregants and other supporters to an evening court session here.

title: Resurrectionism
description: Gob's Grief

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Lori

title: A Shrine for Trout May Change Forever
description: In the days when trout fishermen wore fedoras, cast silk lines with split-bamboo rods, and thoughtfully smoked their pipes between mayfly hatches, the Letort Spring Run in the Cumberland Valley in Pennsylvania stood as the crown jewel of American dry fly fishing.

title: AIRPORT DELAYS
description: Newark International Airport last year was no longer the airport with the highest percentage of delayed takeoffs and landings in the nation, losing that distinction to La Guardia Airport, although the percentages of delays at both airports increased from 1999, with delays at LaGuardia nearly doubling, according to numbers released last week by the Federal Aviation Administration. At Newark, 8.1 percent of the flights were delayed in 2000 compared with 15.5 percent at La Guardia, making those two airports the top two for delays. In 1999, Newark had the most delays with 7.9 percent and La Guardia was second with 7.7 percent. Karen DeMasters

title: Forum's 'Rappaport' Stimulates Smiles
description: DON'T be surprised if, just a few minutes into ''I'm Not Rappaport'' at the Forum Theater in Metuchen, you find yourself smiling inwardly and reminding yourself of that old truth: nothing beats good writing.

title: Learning to Accessorize Those Chinny-Chin-Chins
description: IF Al Gore had a beard, maybe he would have been president.'' His assertion might be a stretch, but Salvatore Fodera is going to stand by it. Mr. Fodera, who has tended the hair of merchants and moguls at the salon that bears his name in the St. Regis hotel in Manhattan, is not suggesting that a fuzzy face alone can make a man electable. But pruned to perfection and worn with flair, ''a beard can create a strong impression,'' he said. And an impression of strength.

title: Improvement Districts Balk At City Plan For New Fee
description: A proposal by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to charge business improvement districts a fee for services they have not had to pay for previously has rekindled tensions between City Hall and the public-private partnerships.

title: Taking Pride In Island's Colleges
description: I was astounded to read the article about local universities and see no mention of the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University. In addition to C. W. Post having 8,100 undergraduate and graduate students and a vital College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, we have professional schools (Education, Health Professions, Visual and Performing Arts, Library and Information Science, Public Service, Accountancy and Management) that bring uniqueness and vibrancy to this beautiful 308-acre campus. The School of Health Professions, for example, has Long Island's only fully accredited baccalaureate programs in Health Information Management, Radiologic Technology and Clinical Laboratory Science, and one of only two R.N.-only baccalaureate degrees on Long Island. Graduates of our Cardiovascular Perfusion and Biomedical Sciences' master's degrees are widely coveted. Of great significance is the well-educated cadre of health professions who provide support to the health care industry on Long Island.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Unstuffed
description: What would you do if you lost, at one fell swoop, every one of your possessions? What if a thief were to come in and take not only your television and your jewelry but your dirty dishes, your underwear, your light bulbs, even your toilet paper? This is what happens to Mr. and Mrs. Ransome, the bourgeois, habit-bound couple in Alan Bennett's sharp new novella, THE CLOTHES THEY STOOD UP IN (Random House, $14.95). It comes as quite a shock to them to discover just how much their lives have been controlled and defined by their objects, and when they are suddenly relieved of them the couple's reactions expose the irreconcilable differences in their characters: Mr. Ransome rigidly carries on as though nothing has changed, while his wife begins to feel rebellious twinges of -- dare she admit it? -- freedom and adventure. But then their paraphernalia is restored to them as mysteriously as it was taken away, and ''life returned to what Mrs. Ransome used to think of as normal but didn't now, quite.'' Their marriage, and they themselves, have subtly changed. ''The Clothes They Stood Up In'' was a best seller in Britain, where Bennett, the author of the plays ''Habeas Corpus,'' ''Forty Years On,'' ''The Madness of George III'' and countless other films and television shows, is rightly thought of as a national treasure. The book will probably not do quite so well here, for the traits personified by the Ransomes -- emotional constipation on the husband's part, an almost pathological diffidence on the wife's -- are English vices and not American ones. (Our own run on quite different lines.) But it is a witty, dark piece of work, a happy evening's read and a tantalizing mental challenge to those of us who, like the Ransomes, find their lives encumbered and their senses blunted by too much stuff. Brooke Allen

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WHITESTONE; A Community Breathes Easier as a Planned Bus Route Is Killed
description: When New York City Transit announced Thursday that it had canceled a strongly opposed plan to extend the Q14 bus route into the quiet streets of Whitestone, residents were so overjoyed that they spent their afternoon going door to door spreading the news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUCE, EILEEN MILWARD
description: BRUCE-Eileen Milward. Wife of the late James Bruce, Jr., died February 2, 2001 in Fairfield, CT. Mother of James Bruce, III of San Francisco, CA and Dana Bruce of Milford, CT, grandmother of Kingston Fallon of Stamford, CT and Bruce Fallon of Boston, MA. Funeral services are private. Donations in her memory to United Home Care Hospice, 40 Lindeman Dr., Trumbull, CT 06611.

title: Easy on the Eyes and Fresh on the Palate
description: JUDGING by the packed houses on our visits to Esteva, the handsome new cafe facing Guilford's expansive green, the town has been waiting for such a place, one that is both good-looking and capable of serving fresh, inventive food at reasonable prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENNERT, WILLIAM J.
description: RENNERT-William J. On February 2, 2001, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Gloria Spamer Rennert. Loving father of Sherry Rennert Kreek of Bronxville and Brooks Rennert Wright of Rye. Cherished grandfather of Carolyn and Katherine Kreek and Christian Wright, and his favorite dog, Belle. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, on Sunday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Monday, 11 AM, at Christ Episcopal Church, Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice Care of Long Island or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

title: DAM REPAIRS
description: At least 14 dams in the state are considered unsafe and in need of immediate repair, the State Department of Environmental Protection said last week. Because of flood damage caused by Hurricane Floyd in 1999 and by the torrential rains in northern New Jersey last summer that collapsed several dams, the department has required the owners of all 720 dams in the state to inspect them. Karen DeMasters

title: Lewis Frozen Out
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lives; A Soggy Protest
description: On Jan. 19, after a day's work driving school buses in Boston, Robert Traynham, 63, boarded a 10:30 p.m. chartered bus headed for Washington to join thousands of other protesters at George W. Bush's inauguration. Some were demonstrating for the first time. Other activists like Traynham, who attended Martin Luther King Jr.'s march on Washington in 1963, shared a long history. This time, Trayhnam says, ''the main issue that got me down there was the black vote, the fact that our vote was thrown away. I would have walked to Washington if I had needed to.''

title: Sanctions' Ledger: Benefit or Harm?
description: To the Editor:

title: ABROSIMOVA OUT AT LEAST 2 WEEKS
description: A sprained left foot will keep Connecticut's Svetlana Abrosimova, an all-American forward, out of action for at least two weeks.

title: South Beach
description: To the Editor: I was surprised and disheartened that ''What's Doing in South Beach'' (Jan. 14) by Pamela Robin Brandt made no mention of SoBe's large and vibrant gay community. Gays were in large part responsible for its renovation, and are an integral and visible part of the energetic social scene.

title: Save the Open Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Bari Bloom, Neil Goldmacher
description: Bari Lauren Bloom, the daughter of Frieda and Howard Bloom of New York, was married last evening to Neil Jeffrey Goldmacher, the son of Seena Stein of Rumson, N.J., and Joel Goldmacher of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Alder officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: POSTINGS: 14th Annual Co-op and Condo Expo; A Day Full Of Advice
description: How to comply with recent fire code regulations that require residential buildings to prepare fire safety plans and how to safeguard buildings from corrupt vendors are among the subjects to be tackled on Thursday at the New York Hilton at the 14th annual Co-op and Condo Expo, sponsored by The Cooperator, a monthly publication.

title: Sequels of War
description: THE IRRITABLE HEART The Medical Mystery of the Gulf War. By Jeff Wheelwright. 427 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $26.95.

title: Airline Tickets Come With Health Advice
description: British Airways has begun including health information with its tickets, with an emphasis on avoiding blood-circulation problems on long flights.

title: Taking Pride In Island's Colleges
description: Everyone who lives on Long Island should be deeply concerned that so many of our best and brightest students not only go away for college but stay away. This major crisis was well addressed in your Jan. 28 article.

title: Did She Say Primate or Prime Rate?
description: Visitors observing the daily scrum on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange might be moved to mutter: ''What a zoo.'' This week, they may get an expert opinion on the subject.

title: INVESTING WITH/Peter I. Higgins -- Dreyfus MidCap Value Fund
description: MANY managers of value mutual funds will not touch technology stocks with a 10-foot pole. Peter I. Higgins, who runs the $400 million Dreyfus MidCap Value fund, is an exception. His fund has a 30 percent-plus stake in technology.

title: A Brutish Invasion
description: The Powerpuff Girls, those crayone-carrying crime fighters, look defeat in the eye when Townsville's most evil villains -- Mojo, Him, Princess and Fuzzy -- band together to form the ultimate criminal group on ''Meet the Beat Alls,'' a tribute to the Fab Four on at 9 p.m. on Friday, the anniversary of the Beatles' appearence on ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' in 1964.

title: Presidential Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: Sky Watch: How Many Stars Are There?
description: Those who are involved in popularizing astronomy are asked certain questions time and again. One of these is, How many stars are there? Only when one is blessed with a rare glimpse of a star-spangled sky with its myriad luminaries can we understand why this question occurs. Special computer analysis can readily answer the question. Most people probably want to know how many stars they can see with their unaided eyes.

title: VLASIC BANKRUPTCY
description: Vlasic International, based in Cherry Hill, declared bankruptcy last week and said it planned to sell its pickle and barbecue sauce lines to Heinz for $195 million. Vlasic is the largest pickle-maker in the United States, with 24 percent of the market, but has had financial difficulties since being spun off from the Campbell Soup Company, based in Camden, in 1998. Vlasic also makes Open Pit barbecue sauce and Swanson frozen dinners, which is not part of the proposed sale. Mr. Lowery said the company was still exploring either selling the Swanson line or making a cash-for-equity swap with creditors for Vlasic to continue making the dinners. Robert Strauss

title: More Ships Mean More Ports
description: EVEN though three cruise lines -- Premier, Commodore and Crown -- have suspended service since last September, the cruise industry last year experienced an 11 percent increase in capacity and a 16 percent growth in passengers from North America. Some 6.9 million North Americans took cruises last year, compared with 3.6 million in 1990, according to Cruise Lines International Association.

title: Tom Lea; Artist and Author, 93
description: Tom Lea, a West Texas artist and writer whose work was called inspirational by President Bush, then governor of Texas, in his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention in August, died on Monday in El Paso. He was 93.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Forbes, Ex-Congressman, Joins Ronkonkoma Firm

title: Skiers and Joggers Vie For Primacy Along the River
description: With snowfall comes the Hudson River Park cross-country ski race, pitting skiers not against one another but against the plows that remove snow from the park for the benefit of runners and bikers.

title: The Thwarted Promise of the 13 Days
description: Those participating in or witnessing turning points in world history are generally displeased by the way such crises are depicted in films and plays. So, it was only reluctantly that I went to see the film ''Thirteen Days,'' about President John F. Kennedy and the Cuban missile crisis that brought the world to the brink of nuclear catastrophe in 1962. But I was pleasantly surprised.

title: Votes In Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: The Way We Live Now: 02-04-01; Here Comes The Sun
description: When I was a kid in upstate New York, I wanted to be a weatherman. I suppose I liked the idea of controlling the elements. Sure, predicting the weather wasn't the same as changing it, but at least I'd know before my friends did when we were going to have a snow day. Also, I liked our local weatherman, a young guy named Al Roker. I liked that his name was my name and that if I joined Big Al's Fan Club (he was big back then too), I'd get a free Celsius-Fahrenheit conversion chart. The way Al presented it, the weather was an anodyne, a salve for the self-inflicted wounds of crime and football.

title: St. Francis Girls Win Sectional Title
description: St. Francis Prep of Queens won five events and Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn won six, but St. Francis earned the team trophy yesterday in the Brooklyn Queens girls' Catholic High Schools Athletic Association sectional indoor championships at the Armory Track and Field Center. St. Francis outscored Loughlin, 78-62.

title: Conquering Czechs Rule With Creativity
description: In the neutral corridor between dressing rooms at Madison Square Garden there stood a middle-aged man in a dark suit, dark shirt and dark necktie. He had the sturdy physique of a former athlete and silver hair trimmed in a brush cut. This was Frantisek Cernik, general manager of the national hockey team of the Czech Republic.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a fatal attack by a dog on a San Francisco woman misspelled the surname of a spokesman for the California Corrections Department, who said the animal came from an attack-dog business run by two prisoners. He is Russ Heimerich, not Heimrich.

title: W.'s World
description: What the foreign-policy pundits, in James Traub's article (Jan. 14), really mean when they refer to George W. Bush as an ''all-American boob'' is that they fear he will give United States national interests -- and the lives of American servicemen and women -- serious consideration before deciding whether to commit our troops to action. They should spend less time posturing and more time reflecting, at places like Belleau Wood, Omaha Beach and the Vietnam War Memorial. A visit to a Veterans Administration hospital wouldn't hurt, either. Your writer should lead the tour.

title: Children, See a Land of Gentler TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Written on Wall (And in Windows)
description: PEOPLE who know Hermann Zapf, the type designer, describe his work in terms usually reserved for fresco painters and classical composers. A legend in calligraphy and book design, Mr. Zapf, who uses passages from the writers Goethe and Hesse in his lettering samples, is equally renowned as an innovator in desktop publishing and word processing.

title: Three Valentine Confections
description: Two's company, three's a crowd, except on St. Valentine's Day, when three can be charming company.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Protests Roil Indonesia
description: It was not the best week for Indonesia's president, Abdurrahman Wahid, who faces possible impeachment after being censured by Parliament. Lawmakers voted to accept the findings of a disputed inquiry that implicated Mr. Wahid in two multi-million dollar schemes. Tens of thousands of protesters, mainly students, rallied across the country, demanding that he step down. But Mr. Wahid, who denies any wrongdoing, vowed to serve out his term, which ends in 2004. Calvin Sims

title: New Home for Delaware's Noted Chancery Court
description: WHEN the corporate raider T. Boone Pickens made a hostile bid for the Newmont Mining Corporation during the takeover frenzy of the late 1980's, the battle ended up in Delaware's Dickensian-sounding Court of Chancery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLISTER, LEO E., M.D.
description: HOLLISTER-Leo E., M.D. 80, Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry and Pharmacology at the University of Texas Medical School at Houston, passed away December 19, 2000. He was also a professor Emeritus of Medicine, Psychiatry and Pharmacology at Stanford University School of Medicine. Notes and remembrances may be sent to Harris County Psychiatric Center, 2800 South MacGregor Way, Rm 3A31, Houston, TX 77021.

title: Dear Diary: I've Made It to Sundance. Yes, Sundance!
description: The novelist and director Bruce Wagner's second movie, ''Women in Film,'' starring Beverly D'Angelo, Portia de Rossi and Marianne Jean-Baptiste, is a fictional portrait of three Hollywood hopefuls. It was accepted by this year's Sundance Film Festival, which ended last Saturday. Following are excerpts from the diary Mr. Wagner kept during his week at the festival, in Park City, Utah.

title: First Cruise? A Primer
description: A FIRST cruise is much like the first day at school, the first day at camp or starting a new job. You never know quite what to expect, you can only guess what the norms are, and you are eager not to make gaffes and appear a greenhorn in a situation where you will be among the same people for a while.

title: Boston University Is the Team to Beat in Beanpot
description: BOSTON  Bruce Crowder wants it to lend credibility to his hockey program. Mark Mazzoleni wants it to cement his team's standing as an up- and-coming team. Brian Gionta wants it before time runs out on his brilliant career.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Shadowing Hannah

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Jan. 21 about the new Mandarin Oriental Miami hotel misstated its total number of units. The total of 329 rooms includes the 31 suites; they are not additional.

title: Golden Boy to Visit Middle Kingdom
description: China is no stranger to prodigies -- its last emperor, Pu Yi, took the throne at the age of 3. But this Friday, it will play host to a different prodigy, from the West -- Keith Peiris, a 12-year-old Canadian boy who founded and runs a highly successful Web site company, Cyberteks Design. Keith, who lives in London, Ontario, is the youngest of a 500-member trade delegation led by Prime Minister Jean Chretien that will visit Beijing, Shanghai and Hong Kong.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG; It's a Small Wig After All: Many Faces Under One Lid
description: It's one wig, but many faces, all part of Ken Solomon's Wig Project, in which Mr. Solomon, a Williamsburg artist, hopes to photograph more than 1,000 people wearing the same wig. The project was inspired by a $35 wig he bought for Halloween four years ago and then wore for his Massachusetts driver's license photograph. He became fascinated with how wearing a wig can transform a person's identity.

title: Confessions of a Lonely Atheist
description: I have long admired Natalie Angier's (Jan. 14) science writing, but secular hallelujahs are now due for her ''pagan peevishness,'' shared by many who risk wearing the Scarlet A (for atheist). A cell in blastula division, a spiral galaxy, a crocus bulb, the 50,000 dancing atoms that make up a single period on this page -- such commonplace miracles are wondrously sufficient for my experience of metaphysical awe.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: NOBODY'S WIFE

title: A Buyer's Market: The Dot-Com Liquidation Sale
description: WHEN it comes to shopping, Lorie Tuma knows her way around the Internet, using its vast breadth of information on products and prices to get the best deals. But recently, she found something that took her bargain-hunting prowess to a new level.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRUNO, ANN
description: BRUNO-Ann. Resting comfortably in Heaven. Born July 10, 1905, deceased April 4, 1982. From your loving family here on earth, your daughter Eleanor, your grandchildren, the twins Thomas and Tullis, and Teddy, your great grandchildren Byron and Elaine, and two special people Steve Lundquist and Greg Minaya.

title: A Playwright Who's Unafraid to Admit She's Political
description: ONE of the boldest things about the playwright Kia Corthron is her willingness to embrace an identity that most American writers would consider a professional liability. ''I consider myself a political writer with a political point of view,'' she said recently. ''I don't write agit-prop because I think the point gets across much stronger if the audience feels something rather than being told something intellectually. But every play of mine starts from a socio political issue.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, GLORIA W.
description: APPEL-Gloria W. The members, trustees, directors, officers and employees of the Louis and Harold Price Foundation and The Price Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies mourn the passing of the beloved President of both Organizations, Gloria Appel. She played a major role for more than 20 years in the development of entrepreneurial education throughout the United States. Her dedication, kindness, spirit, intelligence and integrity will be remembered and missed by everyone who knew her. We express our deep condolences to all of the members of the family.

title: A Messy Construction Project Grows Even More Tangled
description: When renovation of the subway station at 72nd Street and Broadway began in June, the city assigned five traffic officers to help pedestrians and motorists navigate a confusing knot of street and sidewalk closings caused by the project. But last month, trying to save money, the Metropolitan Transit Authority took away three officers, raising concerns among residents about safety.

title: Confessions of a Lonely Atheist
description: Angier's article is evidence of one trait, at least, common to both believers and nonbelievers -- the tendency to see oneself as the underdog. Atheism may be unpopular in some circles, but would she like to try it from the other side? Despite the current vague political appeals to ''people of faith,'' personal, specific religious expression is, in my own experience, about as welcome in today's public schools, workplaces and universities as a case of the chicken pox.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; What's Both Up and Down?
description: Evidence mounted that the American economy is flagging. That led the Federal Reserve Board to cut key interest rates by another half a percentage point. Even so, the Congressional Budget Office predicted that the economy would grow faster than expected in the next 10 years and that the budget surplus would be $5.6 trillion, about $1 trillion more than its last forecast. ''The dip in the economy is expected to be short-lived,'' said Barry B. Anderson, deputy director of the budget office, telling Congress not to let cyclical weakness obscure long-term strength. David E. Rosenbaum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINEN, EDWIN K.
description: LINEN-Edwin K. 86. Of Rye, NY on February 2, after a long battle with emphysema. Mr. Linen was a former Officer and Director of Todd Shipyards Corporation, from which he retired in 1982 after 50 years of service. He is survived by three daughters: Sr. Barbara Linen, SHCJ of Rye, NY; Adrienne May, also of Rye; and Judith Linen of Provincetown, MA; and two sons: E. Kevin, of Sleepy Hollow, NY; and Robert, of Rye, as well as four grandchildren: Christine Castagna of Rye, Robert May of New York City; Michael May of Rye; and Nathan Linen of Indianapolis, IN. He is also survived by his former wife, Camille, of Port Chester, three stepdaughters and five stepgrandchildren. The family will welcome visitors at the William Graham Funeral Home, from 3 to 8 PM on Monday, February 5. There will be a service at the home on Tuesday morning, February 6 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Hospice of Westchester, 95 S. Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: DRUG ARRESTS BY TROOPERS
description: The New Jersey State Police said last week that the number of drug arrests on the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike fell last year, after the department came under scrutiny for racial profiling. The number of drug charges resulting from stops on the turnpike were 370 last year, compared with 494 drug charges in 1999. There were 1,269 charges filed in 1998. On the parkway, troopers reported 350 drug charges last year compared with 783 in 1999 and 1,279 in 1998. John Holl

title: The World: Losing by Winning; A Crackdown Burns Itself
description: MS. LU, a 40-year-old owner of a small beauty parlor, had a typical response to the gruesome television special last Wednesday night. ''Before, I didn't really understand Falun Gong, and I wondered how Li Hongzhi had attracted so many followers,'' she said as she closed up shop. ''But what I just saw made me really angry,'' she said. ''It's a phony religion that aims to hurt people.''

title: Drip Drop! Drip Drop! Square One Opens
description: WHEN Jim Bozzi, who plays the con man Starbuck in ''The Rainmaker,'' calls to the heavens to let it pour, the director and the producer of the play at Stratford's Square One Theater cross their fingers and say: ''Don't take him seriously.''

title: Defining Beauty in Swanky American Terms
description: THE password is . . . swanky. The music to remember it by is sung by Shirley Bassey. The fleeting image is a tan young man in a white bathing suit plunging off the high board, somersaulting out of the deep blue sky into the water of a sky blue pool. Cut to shot of Sean Connery wearing a light blue terry cloth playsuit. Anyone else would look ridiculous in such a get-up, but not James Bond. He looks . . . swanky.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A DESERT IN BOHEMIA

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Thumbs Down on Super Bowl
description: It may be sport's greatest spectacle of excess, but this year's Super Bowl set a record in only one major category: most punts. It is a fittingly exasperating hallmark: with each of the soaring, boring 21 punts, television ratings drooped and advertisers cringed. The Giants lost Super Bowl XXXV and the Baltimore Ravens, ne the Cleveland Browns, won, 34-7. The M.V.P. was the Ravens' Ray Lewis, who a year ago was jailed in connection with a double murder. (And the National Football League cringed.) The MTV-produced halftime show featured 'N Sync and Aerosmith. The best part? No punts. Bill Pennington

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANE, MARGERY ATWATER
description: CRANE-Margery Atwater. On February 3, 2001. Widow of Ralph T. Crane. Survived by her children Tom, Margaret and Phil. Loved and admired by many. Memorial service to be held in early summer in Quogue, NY.

title: The World; Looking Like War to Keep the Peace
description: YOU don't have to look at the flag on their shoulders to tell the American soldiers from the rest of the polyglot peacekeeping force in Kosovo.

title: New Move in the Ruy Lopez Retains Xie's Grip on a Title
description: Last year's International Chess Federation Women's World Championship, played for the first time under the knockout system, was won by Xie Jun of China with a 2 1/2-1 1/2 score against her countrywoman Qin Kanying. Xie won the first game and then stonewalled three draws to take the victory.

title: The Mystery of Economic Recessions
description: A great embarrassment for modern macroeconomic theory is that it has never achieved any consensus on the basic questions of what makes the stock market rise or fall and what ultimately causes recessions.

title: If Only Advice Were Taxes, Donnie Could Show a Surplus
description: Dear Donnie:

title: Misplaced Humor In Food Drawings
description: To the Editor:

title: Sundance, the Mall
description: Maybe they ought to change the name of the Sundance Film Festival's hometown to Perk City. The two-week festival in Park City, Utah, has become as much a destination for marketing products as for selling independent films. ''Sundance is no longer just about movies,'' said Marty Staff, the chief executive of Hugo Boss. ''It's about lifestyle. Our customers go to Sundance, so we're there, too. It's the best place for people to see cool people wearing our clothes.'' At the Hugo Boss house, an 8,000-square-foot public relations palace, which Mr. Staff rented in order to give three film-premiere parties, actors like David Hyde Pierce and Janeane Garofalo, left, and Donovan Leitch departed with glow-in-the-dark down coats and red wool hats emblazoned with the ''HUGO'' logo.

title: PROBATION REQUEST
description: State court officials last week requested $6.75 million for 150 more probation officers and a program that would team probation officers with police in high-crime areas, plus $5 million to expand drug treatment programs. The requests were made by Judge Richard J. Williams, the administrative director of the Courts, in a hearing before the State Senate Judiciary Committee. Abhi Raghunathan

title: High-Tech Solutions For Visually Impaired
description: JUDITH BRON picks up the phone and pitches a story to a newspaper editor about her client's cantorial concert. She turns to her computer and enters the response. She sends a press release by e-mail, clicks into a program and retrieves the next phone number on her list.

title: U.S. Panel Seeks Changes In Treatment Of AIDS Virus
description: Altering a long-held policy, federal health officials are now recommending that treatment for the AIDS virus be delayed as long as possible for people without symptoms because of increased concerns over toxic effects of the therapies.

title: Reckonings; Guns And Bitterness
description: What do Medicare and the military have in common? Both are about to be betrayed in the name of tax cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, DAPHNE (PAT)
description: WALLACE-Daphne (Pat). On January 28, 2001 in Philadelphia, PA. Her husband Harold, her children, grandchildren, extended family and many friends, will eternally miss her strength, character and devotion. Services Monday, February 5, 10AM, at St. Phillips Church.

title: To Ease Student Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Investing Diary: Suit Challenges Buyout That Won Fed Approval
description: Has the Federal Reserve, which administers consumer protection rules in addition to conducting the nation's monetary policy, approved a plan that victimizes minority shareholders in a buyout? At least one lawsuit contends just that.

title: Through the Looking Glass, Darkly
description: Last week provided ample proof that the markets have more in common with ''Alice in Wonderland'' than the real world.

title: Food; Fish Out of Water
description: My uncle Frank Remick -- who was nicknamed Bus till middle age, when his second wife, Margaret, said, ''That's enough; that's a kid's name,'' and got us all to call him Frank -- came to my rescue psychologically, socially, financially and legally more than once. With my father out West wedded to moguldom and uninterested in children, it was Uncle Frank, an elegant man, simultaneously masculine and aesthetic, who introduced me to pheasant under glass, wine and jazz, as well as to the proper perspective -- humor -- toward ''North by Northwest.'' I was 13 when this education began.

title: One Less Hour Isn't a Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 02-04-01: The Ethicist; Cult Objects
description: I have some old books published by a cult group I was involved with many years ago. These books are in demand and can bring a pretty penny through online auctions. Neither the group nor the books advocate anything illegal, though the practices of the group are (to borrow a phrase) 'spiritually abusive.' Is it morally defensible to sell books that were props for an oppressive group? Chris Taylor, New Jersey

title: Super Bowl Snooping
description: Although few spectators at last Sunday's Super Bowl were aware of it, surveillance cameras photographed their faces as they filed into Raymond James Stadium. Those images were then relayed instantly by cable to computers that scanned and compared them with images in a police database of criminals and criminal suspects. A Tampa Bay police spokesman described the system as a potentially ''priceless'' tool for detecting dangerous individuals and preventing terrorist acts. The American Civil Liberties Union has criticized the system as an invasion of privacy that could have serious consequences for a free society.

title: McHunter
description: CANDYLAND A Novel in Two Parts. By Evan Hunter and Ed McBain. 302 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Sleep Easy, Mr. Vallone
The Unexpected Cost Of Paying Bills Late
description: An attitude of ''better late than never'' will not fly with most creditors when it comes to paying bills. Yet many people do not fully understand the consequences of sending their payments late, a recent survey says.

title: Caroline Arfa, Morris Massel
description: Caroline Paulette Arfa, the daughter of Barbara and Harvey Arfa of New York, is to be married this evening to Morris Jacob Massel, a son of Matilda and Elihu Massel of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jacob Rubenstein will officiate at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Will Doctors Make Your Credit Sick?
description: KATHLEEN McNALLY knows a thing or two about bad credit. She is vice president for financial literacy at the National Foundation for Credit Counseling, an association of 1,500 agencies that help people with financial problems.

title: Entrepreneur Sees Room for Many More Cafes
description: AT seven-something in the morning, Main Street in Southampton is covered with snow and silence. What action there is takes place at the east end of town, over at the Golden Pear Cafe. Behind windows that steam up now that the temperature is down, several wholesome-looking employees serve up the usual coffee, bagels and muffins, plus a few upscale items like eggs and cheddar in a croissant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, GEORGE J.
description: AMES-George J. Financier and philanthropist, died on Friday, February 2, 2001, at his home in Rye, NY. He was 83 years old. Mr. Ames was a Limited Managing Director of Lazard Freres and Company, LLC. Surviving are his wife Bess R. Ames of Rye, NY, four daughters, Ruth A. Solie of Northampton, MA, Joan A. Berkowitz of Guilford, CT, Margery E. Ames of NYC, and Dorothy A. Cummings of Skillman, NJ, his step-children Paula S. Butler and Charles David Sammons of Rye, NY, a sister Dorothy Demers of Austin, TX, and seven grandchildren, John Solie, Jonathan and Rachel Berkowitz, and Michael, Kristin, Dillon and Quinlan Cummings. He was predeceased by his first wife Marion Patterson Ames and his brother Raymond Ames. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY, on Wednesday, February 7, at 10 AM. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY, on Monday, February 5, from 7-9 PM, Tuesday, February 6, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Burial will be at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be sent to the Hartley House with which he was associated since childhood; Hartley House, 413 W. 46th St., NYC 10036.

title: Debate Over Prepaying On Mortgage
description: JUST about everyone who has a mortgage wonders at some point whether it makes sense to prepay part of the loan.

title: Dilemmas, Dilemmas: What to Do With a Presidential Check
description: So you've given a gift to the president and his wife, something you hoped would make them comfortable in their post-White House years. A television. Some fine china. A chandelier, perhaps?

description: KAYE-Miriam. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Helene and Dr. Howard Blum, Marilyn and Leonard Rashkin. Loving sister of Ida Gordon. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside services Sunday, 2 PM, at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Libations for Lovers
description: Two's company, three's a crowd, except on Valentine's Day, when three can be charming company. Especially if your gift consists of three related confections from Quady, a masterly dessert-wine specialist.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: BEOWULF: A New Verse Translation, by Seamus Heaney. (Norton, $13.95.) The Irish poet and Nobel laureate breathes new life into the first great English epic, infusing this tale of triumph over inhuman threats to hearth and home with an intimate awareness of Ireland's struggles. His translation, which was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2000, captures both the work's celebration of the heroic and the current of melancholy running below its surface. Our reviewer, James Shapiro, said Heaney ''manages to accomplish what before now had seemed impossible: a faithful rendering that is simultaneously an original and gripping poem in its own right.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SORRENTI, DAVIDE
description: SORRENTI-Davide. Safe in our hearts forever. Love, Mom, Family and Friends

title: Gladly Taking Criticism, Instead Of Obscurity
description: IT does not bother Steve H. Hanke that he has been called a hustler, a charlatan and a snake-oil salesman. But being referred to as obscure -- that has the power to sting.

title: Produce Politics
description: Michael Pollan (The Way We Live Now, Jan. 14) documents a growing interest in the food we consume. The essay was marred, however, by his constant use of the word ''story,'' a term in vogue among academics in the field of cultural studies. The stories we tell about ourselves (in this case, ''the stories we tell about our food'') are supposed to be revealing of individual and social attitudes. Fair enough. But Pollan's repeated use of this term grows irritating as it becomes clear that what consumers demand from corporations are not semifictional ''stories'' but factual accounts of the origin of the foods they buy and the paths they take to supermarket shelves.

title: There's No Room For Smiling Pigs
description: Re the cartoon of a smiling pig bathing in a tureen accompanying the Food column on Jan. 14 [''Brining Pork Chops Makes for Tenderness'']:

title: Families' Tax Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOW, ARON, MD.
description: ARNOW-Aron, MD. Died December 31. A surgeon during WWII, after the death of his wife and child, Leah and Salomea, he emigrated from Poland to the U.S. He married Tessa Winkler and they lived together for 50 years until her death in 1999. He was a respected psychiatrist, practicing in Syracuse, N.Y. until his retirement to Highland Beach, FL. He leaves his sons Jonathan and David, his daughter-in-laws, four grandchildren and many people whose lives he touched and cared for. Donations in his memory can be sent to The Weizmann Institute of Science (10 fl), 130 East 59 St, NY 10022.

title: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; Whitman's Goodbye Present
description: Brinksmanship and threats of leaving town are the usual tactics used by sports team owners seeking taxpayer help in building new arenas or stadiums. But there was little of that in talks between the former New Jersey governor Christie Whitman and the owners of the New Jersey Devils hockey team and the Nets basketball team, about a $325 million arena in Newark to replace the suburban isolation of the teams' current home at the Meadowlands. So as Mrs. Whitman was leaving to head the Environmental Protection Agency, she left something for the Legislature to chew on: a proposal for a novel package of state grants and loans for the arena that could be repaid from capturing an expected stream of the taxes on its property, parking, advertising, payroll and sales. Ronald Smothers

title: Heel, Sit, Cheers!
description: Diva doggies who travel around town in Gucci handbags no longer have to suffer the indignity of drinking from a foil pan at a cafe when they get thirsty away from home. Now there is Dog Water, purified water packaged in a disposable plastic bowl with a bright red lid that doubles as a Frisbee for the athletically inclined pet.

title: Liberties; Fork It Over
description: It was much more than a tempest over teapots, a debate about demitasse spoons and sauce boats.

title: For Starters, Rockies Alter Plans
description: For Part 2 of the toughest task in baseball, Dan O'Dowd turned to free agency. In an effort to build a good starting rotation for an environment where that phrase is an oxymoron, the Colorado Rockies general manager spent a Denver mint full of money to lure Mike Hampton and Denny Neagle to Coors Field.

title: Tenley Bininger, James Phillips
description: Tenley Drew Bininger, the daughter of Sondra Jaques of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., and John Bininger II of Chester, Conn., was married yesterday to James Richard Phillips, the son of Kathleen and Richard Phillips of Newark, Del. The Rev. Dr. Craig D. Townsend, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James' Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, LESTER I.
description: LEVIN-Lester I. Husband of Dottie. Father of Bram, Michael and Dina. Survived also by Evelyn Gibian and Stanley Levin. Service Monday, 12:30 PM, Westchester Reform Temple.

title: The Deal With Jeter: Details, Details
description: Sometime before the start of spring training, the Yankees are expected to hold a news conference to announce a 10-year, $189 million deal with the 26-year-old star Derek Jeter, and Jeter will probably talk in thrilled tones about playing his entire career with one team. But before that moment occurs, there are still the last, laborious details of contract language to be hammered out.

title: Making a Case for Staying Together
description: DR. PAULINA KERNBERG was poring over a series of self-portraits drawn by a 6-year-old girl during the year her parents went through a fairly civil divorce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, EDWARD J.
description: McLAUGHLIN-Edward J. On February 2, 2001, of Forest Hills, NY. Recipient two Purple Hearts, WWII. Director of NY State Divison of Veteran Affairs, longtime Assistant NYC Corp Counsel, Chair NY State Liquor Authority, past Commander Queens County American Legion, Church Eucharistic Minister. Husband of the late Elaine Conway. Loving father of Edward J., Irene Sheehy, Gregory P., Kathryn C., Joseph P., Marian O'Connor and Mark M. Proud grandfather of 13. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., Ascan Ave., corner Metropolitan Ave., Forest Hills, NY, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9. Funeral Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Ascan Ave, at Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY, Tuesday, February 6, at 10:15 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Cage Was Not Only All Ears, He Was All Eyes, Too
description: JOHN CAGE left an exceptional trail as a composer, yet many of his richest and most significant friendships were with visual artists; this was significant not only for Cage but for the American arts. The revolution he helped foment forms the inspiration for a three-year concert, film and lecture series that begins this weekend at Weill Recital Hall, with music by Cage, his friends Morton Feldman, Earle Brown and Christian Wolff, and panel discussions and tours centered on the artists -- chief among them Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns -- who were their fellow travelers and co-conspirators.

title: Nicole Itkin, Benjamin Sawyer
description: Nicole Tracy Itkin, a daughter of Cheryl and Lawrence Itkin of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last evening to Benjamin Sawyer, the son of Miriam and Bernard Sawyer of Leonia, N.J. Rabbi Amil Wohl officiated at Pier 60 at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan.

title: It's Lilac Time
description: If you have a lilac in your yard, brave the elements and take a good look at it. Was it lightly pruned last spring or summer after it bloomed? If pruning has not been a priority for the last few years, late winter is a good time for a little shrub rejuvenation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODYEAR, LAURENCE RUMSEY, JR.
description: GOODYEAR-Laurence Rumsey, Jr. Rummy died suddenly on February 2, 2001. He leaves behind his wife, Lorraine Gallard, his children, Lauren Goodyear Schramm, Laurence (Jake) Goodyear, Cameron Goodyear, Dana Goodyear and Solomon Kuckelman; his son-in-law J.B. Schramm; his sister Wendy Griswold; and his brother Daniel M. Goodyear; his brother-in-law Ben Griswold and sister-in-law Dale Goodyear. He gave his love unstintingly and was adored in turn. We cannot imagine life without him. Memorial service to be arranged.

title: Bush Aides Debate Ways To Press China Over Rights
description: The Bush administration is debating how hard to press China on human rights, and may be tempted to drop condemnation of China at an annual human rights meeting next month in preference for what some see as a more pragmatic approach to extracting reforms from the Chinese.

title: For Busy Basements, There's No Day of Rest
description: WHEN the Rev. Mary Korte looks out the window of the nursery school of Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston, she can see her parishioners on their way to worship. She can only see their feet, however, because the nursery school is in the church basement.

title: Wintering at the Shore, Seals by the Thousands
description: THE seals are here on spring break,'' Chris Buchman said. ''From November through May, seal haul-out sites can be found all around Long Island. Their numbers are increasing, possibly due to the elimination of seal hunting in the United States and Canada.''

title: The alternative routes: river and canal cruises
description: The building boom continues for riverboats as well as oceangoing vessels. This spring at least four large river cruisers will be introduced in Europe: the 140-passenger River Princess and the 120-passenger Rhone Princess, for trips on the Rhine, the Danube and the Rhone; the 94-passenger Casanova, being built for Peter Deilmann Cruises for trips from Venice to Cremona on the Po River; and the 88-passenger River Cloud II, being built for Sea Cloud Cruises, also for cruises on the Po.

title: Verdi Proposes, God Disposes And Peace Breaks Out in Queens
description: THE SETTING -- God came to Queens last Thursday, and spent the afternoon with about 70 elderly people at the Kew Gardens Community Center. There he struck down a Babylonian despot, cleared the way for the Jews to rebuild on Temple Mount and made peace in the Middle East.

description: SHAPOFF-Mary. The leadership of Continuum Health Partners joins with the physicians and staff of its member hospitals in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Mary Shapoff, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague, Edward Shapoff, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer for Continuum. To Ed, his family and all of his mother's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Peter A. Kelly, President and CEO

title: Susanne Connolly Brian Kanaga
description: For many couples, choosing an elopement over a big, splashy wedding offers certain pluses. For instance, there's no need for a cake or to emulate the stiffly dressed plastic couple perched atop it. Elopements also promise a certain simplicity -- a simplicity that nonetheless managed to elude this couple.

title: Introduction
description: The response to Natalie Angier's ''Lonely Atheist'' was overwhelmingly enthusiastic: hundreds said she has plenty of company. A former Quayle staff member took issue with allegations of deliberately leaving a mess at the White House. And shoppers demanded just the facts, ma'am, about their food.

title: Here Come the Kids: Gen Y Invades the Workplace
description: THE other night, I went to a party with a 22-year-old colleague. We were covering the celebrity-happy event for our online news service, Fashion Wire Daily. After surveying the crowd, my co-worker asked what she should do next.

title: Anything except billiards
description: In the competition for passengers, major cruise lines are constantly adding features to their ships. But last year's luxury option (the Internet cafe, for example) has a way of becoming this year's standard equipment. Nevertheless, that hasn't discouraged ship operators from trying to come up with new gimmicks and features.

title: Mr. Bush's Smooth Start
description: Many Washington Democrats acknowledge with grudging admiration that the word ''honeymoon'' does not really capture the atmosphere of the first two weeks of the Bush presidency. Despite the understandably bitter reaction to John Ashcroft and to President Bush's anti-abortion stance on foreign aid, Democrats in Washington admit to being impressed by the new president's charm offensive, nicknames and all, and by the tactical dexterity of the White House's presentation of its agenda of issues. Mr. Bush's use of soothing words and symbolic acts has not been matched since Ronald Reagan's first days. In addition, the new president has surpassed both Mr. Reagan, his own father and Bill Clinton in making Congressional diplomacy an opening priority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRATH, STELLA A.
description: McGRATH-Stella A. A memorial service was held on February 3. She is survived by three daughters, Mrs. Barbara Sullivan, Mrs. Nancy Johns and Mrs. Suzanne Dunn, and nine grandchildren, and nine great grandchildren.

description: CHESSLER-Gertrude (nee Bieber). 88, February 1, 2001, peacefully, in Roslyn, NY, formerly of Hollywood, FL. Now again as one with her late, beloved husband George. Dearest mother of Ronald Chessler, Dolly and Andrew Weisinger. Loving grandmother of Joy (Steven), Michael, Debra (Jeff), Amy (Chris). Adoring greatgrandmother of six. Dear sister of the late Cora Katz. Services today, at the Mount Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY.

title: Corrections
description: An art review on Jan. 28 about works on display at Gallery North in Setauket misstated the given name of the artist who created the video projection ''Forever Is Over.'' She is Nancy Goldenberg. Her sister Suzanne Goldenberg also exhibited at the show.

title: Diane Michaels, Kevin Brown
description: Diane Faith Michaels, a harpist, and Kevin Eliot Brown, a bassist, are to be married today in Basking Ridge, N.J. The couple play for the Orchestra of St. Peter by the Sea, which is based in Bay Head, N.J. Rabbi Nathaniel Benjamin is to officiate at the Basking Ridge Country Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APOLET, HENOCH ''HENRY.''

title: Tiananmen's Shadow
description: Throughout the spring of 1989, Tiananmen Square, the political heart of Beijing, was engulfed in protests. By June, many of the people filling the square and surrounding streets were spectators with only the vaguest political motives. It was into these crowds that the People's Liberation Army opened fire in the early hours of June 4, killing hundreds or even thousands of civilians. No one outside the inner councils of the Chinese government knows for certain how many people died or why.

The crosscurrent of music and visual art chafing at boundaries is again on display, in an exhibition of photographs inspired by John Cage's pioneering music of chance operations.

title: On Their Toes
Confessions of a Lonely Atheist

My education as a skeptic began early: I remember my mother's raised eyebrows when the words ''under God'' were inserted in the Pledge of Allegiance shortly before I began kindergarten in the mid-1950's. In her day, she told me, we made do with ''one nation, indivisible.''

title: When time is no object, how about a freighter?
description: Travelers with lots of time to spend at sea can go by freighter to either the east or west coast of South America. Among vessels making a round trip from New York to Buenos Aires are the Brasilia of the NSB line and the Sea Cheetah and the Cap Castillo of the Hermann Buss line, both companies based in Germany. The Brasilia carries five passengers in two double cabins and a single cabin, and the Sea Cheetah and the Cap Castillo carry four passengers each in a double cabin and two single cabins. On all three freighters, the round trip takes about 42 days, but the stops vary. Among them are Norfolk, Charleston, Jacksonville, Miami, Puerto Cabello (Venezuela) and, in Brazil, Suape, Santos, Paranagua and Rio Grande.

title: Faith Base; As American As Second Acts And Apple Pie
description: THE stories a people tell and retell reveal a lot about who they are and who they want to be, and there is no public narrative more potent today -- or throughout American history -- than the one about redemption. In recent years, the old religious belief in hard-won salvation, based on prayer and good works, has begun to morph with the therapeutic language and formulas of the recovery movement. The dark night of the soul has increasingly given way to public confessions on Oprah and Sally Jessy Raphael; the arduous process of genuine contrition, to mechanical avowals of regret -- and equally automated dispensations of forgiveness (or forgetfulness).

title: The World: Let Them Eat Horse!; Epidemic Errors
description: STRICTLY speaking, there is no connection between AIDS and mad cow disease. The first is caused by a retrovirus, which overpowers the genetic material of cells, forcing them to create duplicates. The second is caused by a prion, an infectious protein that seems to ''persuade'' other proteins to imitate its abnormal folds. Whales and mosquitoes have more in common.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Riefenstahl Anthology
description: Is it possible to look at the work of Leni Riefenstahl and not see only Nazi propaganda? If there is a chance for her pictures to stand relatively unfiltered, it is presented in LENI RIEFENSTAHL: Five Lives (Taschen, $39.99), a collection of stunning photographs of and by one of the 20th century's defining image makers. Riefenstahl was born in Berlin in 1902, and she gained early fame as a ballet dancer, then as a movie actress. She created her own film company before she was 30, and had a hit directing herself in ''The Blue Light'' in 1932 -- the same year she wrote a fan letter to Hitler. Her collaboration with Hitler got her on the cover of Newsweek and produced ''Triumph of the Will'' (1935). Once Germany was defeated and the Fhrer dead, Riefenstahl was arrested and her archives seized. Amazingly, after winning her legal battles she somewhat overcame the Nazi stigma with new work, particularly photographs of the Nuba tribe in Sudan. Of all her work, the stills from her documentary about the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin stand out for their dynamism and epic compositions. Though this is intended as a picture book, it contains a year-by-year chronology that is essential to comprehend the constant boldness of Riefenstahl's transformations. She was at work as recently as 1999, which may make her own will the most triumphant of all. Ted Loos

title: IN THE DANCE STUDIO WITH/Mimi Wallace; Over 40, Still Dancing and Part of a Study of Movement

While special cameras transformed her muscle activity into a 3-D computer image, the 59-year-old dancer watched it all on the screen, amazed that the glowing stick figure bending, twirling and leaping was actually her.

title: LAKELAND: USE OF POLICE DOGS OPPOSED

The superintendent, Dr. Barnett Sturm, said dogs have been used at the alternative high school for years. He wants to use dogs in several schools, including Lakeland High and Walter Panas High. But board members opposed the plan, referring it to a committee. Opponents said that the schools do not have a drug problem, but that allowing such searches would create a reputation that one existed. Corey Kilgannon

title: A Sip of Hoboken
description: Tea lovers, arguably, feel prouder about Sir Thomas Lipton's storied affiliation with Hoboken than they do about that of a certain native-born crooner. A patch of the city's shoreline became home to Lipton's first American warehouse and headquarters in 1893 when Sir Thomas, the multimillionaire Irish-born grocer, came to town. Ships bearing tea from his overseas plantations docked next to the factory where workers packaged the leaves for nearly seven decades. Sir Thomas, whose boat Shamrock lost the America's Cup five times, used to drive straight into the building's freight elevator and park his car on its roof. Though the company pulled up stakes in 1962 and headed to Englewood Cliffs, its legacy endures. The factory has been renovated into apartments and tea consumption in this country has doubled in the past seven years, thanks largely to ''ready to drink'' brews. Peter Goggi, a Lipton expert on tea, presents ''All the Tea in Hoboken,'' a historical look at the leaves and the potion it produces next Sunday at the Hoboken Historical Museum. The discussion includes a tasting of Darjeeling and Earl Grey, and is part of the museum's ongoing series, ''Made in Hoboken.'' Reservations are required (201) 656-2240. Sara Ivry

title: Raising the Syrah Stakes

The bank also noted that it is advisable to hold on to the form until I am ready to sell the apartment, at which time I should file it ''to have the secured parties removed.'' Since I have no plans for selling my co-op in the near future, should I file it now, or is it advisable to hold on to it and wait until the co-op unit is sold to file it? . . . title: CLARIDGE ACQUISITION
description: The state Casino Control Commission ruled last week that adding the Claridge casino hotel to its Atlantic City empire will not give Park Place Entertainment, owner of the Caesar's, Park Place and Hilton casinos, an ''undue economic concentration.'' The ruling requires Park Place to limit its casino development to the Boardwalk if it should acquire the Claridge, which has remained open despite declaring bankruptcy. Both Park Place and the Sands, owned by the financier Carl Icahn, have offered buy-out plans to the Claridge's creditors. Bill Kent

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WINONA RYDER plays the central character in James Mangold's GIRL, INTERRUPTED (1999), based on Susanna Kaysen's 1993 memoir, but Angelina Jolie took home the blindingly glowing reviews (and the Oscar, for best supporting actress). Ms. Ryder plays a whiny upper-middle-class high school graduate with no ambition who makes a halfhearted suicide attempt and is promptly locked up in a mental institution for two years. Ms. Jolie is the seductively charming socio-path who becomes her best friend there. And she sizzles, even if her best scene (in which she misidentifies the location of the aorta while threatening suicide by ballpoint pen) was in all the commercials -- Sunday and Wednesday at 10 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: Updating Computer Software With Little Pain to Users

''If your car were as unreliable as your computer, you would never get to work,'' said Dov Goldman, the founder of Cognet Corporation. But it doesn't have to be that way, Mr. Goldman said. In a talk titled ''Making Obsolescence Obsolete: Managing the Lifecycle of Intelligent Devices,'' to be delivered at the Westchester Information Technology Cluster's monthly meeting on Feb. 13, Mr. Goldman will discuss Cognet's efforts to make computers, and their software, more dependable.

description: LYON-Rosalind Kaufmann. Died peacefully at her home on February 3, 2001, at the age of 90, following a long illness. She lived all her life in Manhattan. She was a graduate of the Ethical Culture School and Wellesley College, and was a noted amateur golfer. During WWII, she assisted the war effort by taking officers of the United States Armed Services between posts throughout the greater New York area, drving them in her family's car. She was the widow of Ludwig S. Lyon, who died in 1988. She is survived by a stepdaughter, Frances Lyon Rosenthal of South Londonderry, VT, and Scottsdale, AZ; a niece, Ellen Eiseman Hersh of Bradford, NH, and St. Petersburg, FL; a nephew, James Eiseman Jr., of Philadelphia; two granddaughters, five great-grandchildren, a grandnephew and grandnice, and a greatgrandniece.
