description: The New York author Darryl Pinckney is a man with literary pedigree.

title: The Prosecution Unravels: The Case of Wen Ho Lee
description: In a secure warren of the Los Alamos weapons laboratory, investigators mined the office of Wen Ho Lee. Books, reports, notes written in Chinese -- everything was handled with latex gloves to preserve the evidence. Just days before, laboratory officials had fired the computer scientist for security violations, and investigators suspected he was a spy, but the search was yielding little. Then agents discovered the list.

title: Trailing Now, but Plugging Away Anyway
description: The long road is not always the best one to take if your idea of a Sunday drive is to see the sights. The long road is one chosen because opportunities will occur at unexpected times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVENDA, GEORGE
description: LAVENDA-George. November 10, 1911, to February 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Violet, devoted father of Robert (and Emily Schultz) and Richard (and Cynthia), cherished grandfather of Daniel, Rachel, Miriam, and Ruth, and dear brother to Nathan Lavenda and Helen Rosenberg. A teacher, lover of the arts and ideas who influenced many generations. Donations to Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: I'm a Student, a Worker and a Kid
description: To the Editor:

title: Gritty Portrayal Of the Abyss From a Survivor; The Screenwriter for 'Traffic' Says He Drew on His Past
description: There was the Christmas morning in 1996 that he spent, pretty much at the end of his rope, awkwardly trying to steal crack cocaine from a curbside dealer who pulled a gun on him. But that was not enough to get him out of the junkie's life. Nor was the time a dealer working out of an abandoned elevator shaft on the Lower East Side of Manhattan put a knife to his throat. Not even when a 300-pound fellow inmate strung out on PCP chased him around a Manhattan holding pen singing the theme from ''I Love Lucy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, K. MARGARET
description: GROSSMAN-k. Margaret. Loving mother and wife, fabulous writer, and friend to many, passed away on February 3. Memorial services are being held on Wednesday, February 7, at Chelsea Commons at 8 PM, West 24th Street and 10th Avenue.

title: INSIDE
description: Second Killing at Campus

title: Iannis Xenakis, Composer Who Built Music on Mathematics, Is Dead at 78
description: Iannis Xenakis, the Greek-French composer who often used highly sophisticated scientific and mathematical theories to arrive at music of primitive power, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 78.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: A Market for Flotsam and Jetsam as Performance Art
description: Trong Nguyen sold a bottle of designer perfume last week through the online auction service eBay. Normally such a sale would not be considered a work of art. But Mr. Nguyen is an artist, and the $11.45 deal he made is part of a yearlong, untitled art project.

title: Brutish Rivalry Aside, the Knicks Win a Beauty
description: All the familiar aspects of the rivalry were there: pandemonium in the stands, ferocious banging of bodies, intense chest-to-chest defense and a near brawl that kept 20,058 fans and a national television audience in suspense until the last possession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, CASIMIR
description: MASON-Casimir. 91. February 3, 2001. Beloved husband of Evelyn and father of Marc, Peter and Ellen Mason; loving grandfather of Katherine Horowitz and Jonathan Mason and great-grandfather of Eric and Jennifer Horowitz. Private funeral services held at the Dapson-Chestney Funeral Home, Rhinebeck, NY (845)-876-6000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, EDWARD J.
description: McLAUGHLIN-Edward J. On February 2, 2001, of Forest Hills, NY. Recipient two Purple Hearts, WWII. Director of NY State Divison of Veteran Affairs, longtime Assistant NYC Corp Counsel, Chair NY State Liquor Authority, past Commander Queens County American Legion, Church Eucharistic Minister. Husband of the late Elaine Conway. Loving father of Edward J., Irene Sheehy, Gregory P., Kathryn C., Joseph P., Marian O'Connor and Mark M. Proud grandfather of 13. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., Ascan Ave., corner Metropolitan Ave., Forest Hills, NY, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9. Funeral Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Ascan Ave, at Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY, Tuesday, February 6, at 10:15 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Thursday about Donald T. DiFrancesco's installation as acting governor of New Jersey referred incorrectly to former Gov. Christie Whitman's new job. As administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency she will not be a member of the cabinet, although President Bush favors upgrading the post to cabinet rank.

title: First Leader to Visit Bush Is Canadian
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  After spending two weeks getting to know world leaders on the telephone, President Bush experienced his first taste of face-to-face diplomacy today with a White House visit by Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada.

title: The Neediest Cases; Fighting a Disease by Keeping Busy After School
description: More than anything else, Lorell Smith, 12, wants to be a dancer. But dance rehearsals are harder for the Bronx girl than they are for other children, because she has lupus.

title: New Ideas Sought to Help AIDS Orphans
description: AIDS has orphaned 12 million children in Africa, nearly triple the number of political refugees and displaced persons there, and millions more are expected to be orphaned in coming years, a leading epidemiologist told the opening session of an AIDS meeting here tonight.

title: MetroStars Trade Goalkeeper Ammann
description: The MetroStars traded their No. 1 goalkeeper from last season, Mike Ammann, to D.C. United yesterday for midfielder Richie Williams.

title: Im a Student, a Worker and a Kid
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, JACOB
description: BASS-Jacob. Died on February 3, 2001. Devoted husband of Virginia. Loving father of Lawrence and Marie Chen, Douglas. Grandfather of Kathryn. Services Tuesday morning, February 6, at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of your choice in Jacob's memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELLENBERGER, DONALD J.
description: SHELLENBERGER - Donald J. Age 75, of Brewster, MA, in Hyannis, MA, on Friday, February 2, 2001. Husband of Jeanne (Klein) Shellenberger. Father of David E. Shellenberger of NYC, and Susan G. S. Bowers of NYC. Brother of Jack Shellenberger of Virginia and Rolfe Shellenberger of Palm Desert, CA. A memorial service will be held in Dennis Union Church, Saturday, February 10, 2001, at 2 PM. Donations in his memory may be made to Dennis Union Church, 713 Rte. 6A, Dennis, MA 02638; or Cape Museum of Fine Arts, 60 Hope Lane, Dennis, MA 02638; or Camps Becket & Chimney Corners YMCA, Hamilton Rd., Becket, MA 01223. For information, Doane, Beal & Ames, South Dennis, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENGLER, SILAS
description: SPENGLER-Silas. The Yale College Class of 1953 mourns the loss of our most esteemed and beloved classmate. Si was our leader and class secretary for almost 40 years. His wisdom, humanity, good humor, and gentlemanly kindness were the hallmarks of a man of rare character. We extend our sympathy and support to his wife Sandy, and to his family.

title: Color on the Canal
description: Stephanie Wilson used to live in Park Slope, up the hill from her current apartment. When it came time to move, she appealed to a broker after seeing a number of dismaying apartments through "no broker" classified ads. "It never occurred to me, for instance, that I'd have to ask about whether or not an apartment had floors," she says, recalling one place where she found bare cement and exposed wires, which weren't as glamorous as, for instance, exposed brick. The broker she found said the magic words at last: "I think I might have something." He took her to the three-story, family-owned building she lives in now, and as soon as she walked in, she decided to take it. Tallying the view of the World Trade Center towers out the kitchen window with the magically low rent for a four-room apartment, she asked the broker about the safety of the neighborhood. "Uh," he said. "Well, very safe. It's, you know, a Mafia neighborhood. No one's going to touch your car." She was charmed and convinced and signed the lease.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Amtrak Proposes to Triple Capital Spending
description: Executives at Amtrak, focused for much of the last few years on the railroad's short-term survival, have caught their breath sufficiently to produce a new long-term capital plan. It calls for almost tripling the rate of investment for the next 20 years to build a rail alternative to crowded skies and highways around the country.

title: Bush Faces Group of Harsh Critics: House Democrats
description: It was as if President Bush returned to the campaign trail today and found himself before a skeptical small-town crowd. The questions were pointed. The follow-ups, more ferocious still. Mr. Bush, relying more on personality than policy, seemed to successfully work the room.

title: Price of Propane Making It Harder to Keep Warm
description: White is the color of cold in Iowa this winter, with perennially white skies folding into silent white pastures and fields of corn stubble. Behind white clapboard farmhouses, only the white tanks, shaped like snub-nosed submarines, offer protection from a winter that began as the coldest recorded around here and has almost two months to go.

title: The Chinese Professor Who Started a Ruckus
description: In the spring of 1999, Professor He Zuoxiu, an elderly theoretical physicist whose avocation is debunking pseudoscience, hoped to provoke some debate with a short article warning about the ''deceitful lies'' of certain ''qigong'' meditation sects. One called Falun Gong, he charged, led a student into mental illness.

title: Samuel H. Day Jr., Champion of Free Speech, Dies at 74
description: Samuel H. Day Jr., a journalist and opponent of nuclear weapons who led a leftist magazine in a landmark First Amendment court battle over the publication of an article on the hydrogen bomb, died on Jan. 26 of a stroke. He was 74 and lived in Madison, Wis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, LOUIS J.
description: GROSS-Louis J. Beloved husband of Dorothy Elkin Gross. Devoted father of Jane and Donald Linker, Michael Gross, Hedy and Donald Kaminsky and John and Robin Gross. Loving grandfather of Tom, Billy, Katie, Alex, Milo, Noah, Robert and Andrew. Services Monday at noon, The Riverside in Mount Vernon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBLATT, ANITA
description: GREENBLATT-Anita. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed ex-member, Anita Greenblatt, and extend to her beloved husband Nathan and family its deepest sympathy. Arthur I. Frankel, President Brian J. Strum, Secretary

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The days of somebody saying, 'Shut up and play' are over.''

title: More Money Sought to Fight Jumps in Infant Death Rates
description: Citing rising infant mortality rates in Harlem and the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, two City Council members and the Manhattan borough president called yesterday for the immediate restoration of funding for a maternal- and infant-health program that had helped reduce the death rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKENBERG, ALBERT
description: FINKENBERG-Albert. On January 31, 2001. Beloved father of Margery, Frank and Susan. Loving grandfather of Lea, David, Chandra and Jared. Great-grandfather of Yosef, Orly and Rita.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about President Bush's appearance at a closed-door meeting with Senate Democrats included an erroneous phrase from a pool news report of the event. A spokesman for the White House said afterward that the Democrats had been ''attentive and silent,'' not ''tentative and silent.''

title: Razorfish Sets Second Round of Cutbacks, Laying Off 400
description: Razorfish Inc., one of the oldest and most established Internet consulting companies in Manhattan's Silicon Alley, announced today that it was laying off about 400 employees because of slowing revenues.

title: Sun Taking New Step Toward Computing Outside the Box
description: For years Sun Microsystems, even as it staked a leader's claim to many facets of contemporary computing, has described a future in which the network, not the device, would rule.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 11, Dies in Apartment Fire Caused by Faulty Wiring
description: A boy who neighbors said had cerebral palsy and used a wheelchair was killed early yesterday when a fire broke out in his apartment in New Lots, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Barge Cruises on the Loire
description: Spring in Burgundy, Champagne and the Upper Loire Valley has an added attraction this year: French Country Waterways has cut prices on April departures of its barge cruises by $1,400 a couple. This rate combines an April discount of $600 a stateroom ($300 for single occupancy) with a value-season discount of $400 a person. With the discounts, the rates for Sunday departures April 1 to 29 are $2,895 to $4,095 a person, double occupancy. French Country Waterways has a fleet of five barges that carry 8 to 18 passengers on six-night cruises that include all meals, wine, a dinner at a Michelin two  or three-star restaurant, wine tastings and daily sightseeing trips. Rates include transfers to and from Paris, but air fare to Paris is extra. Contact French Country Waterways, (800) 222-1236; www.fcwl.com .

title: Barak Speaks Stoically Of Tomorrow's Showdown
description: No amount of pancake makeup could cover up just how weary Prime Minister Ehud Barak looked today as he enjoyed his last puffs of a cigar before an interview began.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSING, ANDREW
description: MESSING - Andrew. Age 52, passed away peacefully on Saturday, February 3, at his home in Lake Worth, FL. Born in Short Hills, NJ, Andy was the founder and operator of National Groundcover, Inc., a company with an innovative and trend setting approach to the installation of landscaping applications. His philanthropic activities through the Messing Family Foundation were always appreciated nationwide. As an avid golfer, Andy was a member of both Banyan Golf Club and Mayacoo Lakes Country Club in Florida, where he served on numerous committees and board member positions. Andy is survived by his beloved wife Erin, his brother Gilbert, and his sister Madeline Levy. Services will be held at Quattlebaum-HollemanBurse Funeral Home in West Palm Beach, FL, on Monday, February 5, at 10 AM. Interment will occur at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ, on Tuesday, February 6.

title: Report Says Money Launderers Exploit Banks
description: A report to be formally released today by Democrats on the staff of a Senate investigating panel says that money launderers have exploited the international system by which banks handle accounts for one another's customers, according to a copy provided in advance. The investigation was led by Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the Governmental Affairs Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, RALPH S.
description: GOODMAN-Ralph S. A former prosecuting attorney for the US Department of Justice at the Nuremberg Trials in 1946. He is survived by his daughter Clara Connor and his son Berk Goodman, six grandchildren and 15 great-grandchildren. Visitation 2-6 PM, Tuesday, at the Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Inc., Mt. Kisco, NY, 914-666-4840.

title: Buildings Should Last
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Phillips Plans to Buy Tosco In $7 Billion Stock Deal

title: Stepping Aside and Stepping Up; New Job Has Nita Lowey's Political Fortunes Rising
description: Hard as it may be for her to accept, Nita M. Lowey became famous for what she didn't do.

title: Knicks-Heat Game Worthy of Special Rivalry
description: MIAMI -- Because of the building, insatiable interest, a pool reporter was sent in to talk to one of the referees officiating yesterday's game between the Knicks and the Miami Heat. This man's job was not to ask about a controversial call or a rule interpretation that cost one team the game.

title: The Perils of High-Tech Voting
description: Perhaps the only unchallenged result of the Florida election has been a surge of interest in better voting technology. The punch card, introduced for tabulating the 1890 census as the ultimate in electric-age objectivity, is now revealed as an ambiguous lattice of wavering flaps. Former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald Ford agreed last week to serve as honorary chairmen of a National Commission on Federal Election Reform. Senators Charles Schumer and Sam Brownback have proposed spending $2.5 billion for equipment upgrades over five years in matching grants to states and localities. Senators Mitch McConnell and Robert G. Torricelli are sponsoring legislation to provide $500 million in federal matching grants in one year, and $100 million in each subsequent year, indefinitely.

title: Graham's Three Victories Power Seton Hall to Met Title
description: As a 16-year-old senior in 1998, Nolle Graham won three events at the Armory Track and Field Center to lead Taft High School to its first Public Schools Athletic League championship. Last night in the same arena, Graham, now a 19-year-old college junior, led Seton Hall to the women's team title in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Indoor Championships with another three victories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADOLF, ROSALIE K.
description: ADOLF-Rosalie K. Gentle, generous and gracious lady. Devoted wife of the late Norman L. Adolf. Caring mother of Benine Adolf and Sally Laurent (Neil). Grandmother of Nate and Ben. Longtime active member of National Council of Jewish Women; volunteer at LIJ Hospital; graduate and benefactor of Hunter College; devotee of art, music and theater. Graveside services Monday, 1:30 PM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions to National Council of Jewish Women or your favorite charity in lieu of flowers.

title: Article 2001020591682212574 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Before Vote, Israel Sees 'Day After'
description: Two days before a potentially fateful election for prime minister, the presumption of a victory by Ariel Sharon, the right-wing leader, has made for a lackluster campaign climax. Most Israelis are already peering beyond Election Day to the diplomatic and political repercussions of what news programs call ''The Day After.''

title: A Lesson in Degradation and Inhumanity
description: ''Hymn to the Rising Sun,'' a grim prison drama from the 1930's, takes place in the barracks of a rural Southern work camp in the early morning on the Fourth of July, and the idea of the cruelly incarcerated waking to Independence Day is the irony that thrums loudly throughout the play. Written by Paul Green, a playwright celebrated in the 1920's and 30's for his harsh, realistic depictions of social ills, often on racial themes, ''Hymn'' is marked by the unblinking indignation that made it courageous and powerful in its day but now comes across as thunderously unsubtle.

title: Can't Anybody Here Play This Game?
description: During a break in the first game of the XFL, the new made-for-television football league that promises titillating sex, bone-crushing violence and access to the team members' innermost thoughts, a reporter ran onto the field. He grabbed a player for the Las Vegas Outlaws, who had ''He Hate Me,'' on the back of his jersey. ''Why?'' the reporter wondered, looking for those intimate details.

title: Article 2001020592287781526 -- No Title
description: February 5, 2001

title: Bush Looks for Support on Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  President Bush tried today to inject a new note of urgency into his tax-cut proposals, saying that he wanted them enacted soon and made retroactive to Jan. 1.

title: Here's to Bad Times
description: Consumer confidence is plummeting and companies are cutting back, but I, for one, am not mourning. The 90's boom left me both financially battered and psychically troubled, and I don't think I'm alone. As the economy has slowed, I'll confess that my main reaction has been relief.

title: Message From the Lakers: Don't Count Us Out Yet
description: Midway through the final quarter today, the Shaq-less Los Angeles Lakers seemed destined to fold. A 14-point lead had evaporated. The Sacramento Kings, poised to supplant the Lakers, the defending National Basketball Association champions, as the marquee team in the Western Conference, pushed the ball down the floor, ready at last to seize command.

title: In God We Trust; All Others Pay Cash
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Steps for Ballot Reform
description: As Congress and state legislatures gather themselves for the task of modernizing the nation's antiquated voting systems and addressing the other flaws in the electoral process, there will be a strong temptation to settle for quick and ineffective remedies. The impulse should be resisted. The balloting breakdowns the country witnessed in November demonstrated that a complete overhaul is needed in the way Americans vote. The federal government and the states will have to work together to get the job done, with Washington providing standards and money and the states installing new equipment.

title: Canada Determined to Be First Neighbor to Bush
description: Worried that American attention is shifting south to Mexico, Canada's prime minister, Jean Chrtien, visits the White House on Monday, capping a campaign of diplomatic elbowing to become the first foreign leader to meet President Bush.

title: A Band That Has Learned To Take It a Little Easier
description: About four years ago Abraham Burton was an alto saxophonist and led a band that was almost a caricature of overheated New York-style jazz playing. His drummer, Eric McPherson, seemed only truly comfortable with fast tempos, and his pianist, James Hurt, hammered out gut-punching, relentlessly rhythmic solos.

title: Can ABC Kick the Regis Habit?; Too Much 'Millionaire' Has Let the Network Grow Flabby in Prime Time
description: Last February, the ABC television network was riding toward weekly prime-time supremacy and record profits on a totally unexpected rocket called ''Who Wants to be a Millionaire.''

title: Katherine Harris Redux: No Longer Larger Than Life
description: FOR someone who loomed so large in the public consciousness during last fall's election melodrama, Katherine Harris is strikingly small.

title: XFL Declares Victory in Round 1
description: Amid postgame perceptions of success and failure Saturday night, Vince McMahon, the XFL's founder, taunted his critics with a few more defiant stares. In the background, the roar of Jesse Ventura's motorcycle could be heard as the Minnesota governor and XFL commentator rode into the neon sunset after the debut of a professional league that may splash unfamiliar hues across the sports landscape.

title: E-Commerce Report; Comparison-shopping sites have felt the shakeout but hope that a diversified source of revenues may serve as a buffer.
description: BACK in 1999, when people believed the e-tailing shakeout would leave a few Internet merchants standing in every category to compete with the Web sites of traditional companies, the idea of comparison-shopping sites sounded -- like so many things dot-com -- brilliant.

title: When the Author Is Still in Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Are a Way of Belonging
description: As most everyone knows, the PGA has fought the request by Casey Martin, a professional golfer who has a circulatory disorder that impairs his ability to walk, to use a cart on the course during PGA Tour events. The Supreme Court is currently considering the PGA's appeal. This case involves a couple of things close to my heart. One is golf. The other is the belief that competitive sports should be as inclusive as possible.

title: Ecuador's Use of Dollars Brings Dollars' Problems
description: A year ago, the government announced that it was abandoning the sucre as the national currency and adopting the American dollar as the solution to its chronic economic problems. While the promised benefits have been slow to arrive for ordinary Ecuadoreans, the move has proved an unexpected boon to two very dangerous groups: drug traffickers and counterfeiters in neighboring Colombia.

title: In Surprise Move, the Chairman of Texaco Resigns
description: The chairman and chief executive of Texaco Inc., Peter I. Bijur, unexpectedly resigned yesterday in a move that analysts said might point to the rocky progress of the company's acquisition by the Chevron Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATKINS, ROSE (NEE STRUMEYER)
description: WATKINS-Rose (nee Strumeyer). On February 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Albert H. Watkins, loving mother of Arline and son-inlaw David Rosenfeld. Caring grandmother of Marc Lax and the late Roger Lax. Graveside service at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing N.Y. on February 5, 2001, at 1:30 PM. For further information, call Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel at 718-263-7600.

title: In a World of Zany Antics That Defy the Impossible
description: ''Momix in Orbit'' began with what looked like an ambling skyscraper jauntily crossing the stage. The program, presented on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, closed with antic, ingenious shadow play. Clearly this is not for those who savor the perfect arch of a foot or who grow breathless at a well-executed arabesque or pirouette.

title: Convention Town
description: To the Editor:

title: North American Stars Show That the World Is Not Enough
description: Mario Lemieux has often said that the National Hockey League's commitment to offense helped prompt him to make a comeback this season.

title: MediaTalk; NBC Election Star Accepts Offer From ABC
description: Every giant news story has its big television stars. The Iranian hostage crisis had Ted Koppel of ABC. The Persian Gulf war had Peter Arnett of CNN. The Wall Street boom, and the attending national obsession with stocks, had Maria Bartiromo of CNBC.

title: The Power to Pardon
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. M. Powell Lawton, 77, Expert on the Elderly
description: Dr. M. Powell Lawton, a leading researcher on aging and the physical and psychological needs of the elderly, died on Jan. 29 at a retirement community in Haverford, Pa. He was 77 and a former resident of nearby Collegeville.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, DR. MARGARET M.
description: MULLIN-Dr. Margaret M. On February 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Matthew Kabriski who preceded her in death January 1, 2000. Dr. Mullin was born August 12, 1910, in NYC. She enjoyed a long career of teaching and guidance, influencing the lives of thousands of students for nearly 50 years. She began her work as a teacher of high school mathematics and then as Dean at Fort Hamilton High School. She was a faculty member of the School of Education of NYU and did post-doctoral study in Europe. She was a member of the Founding Faculty of Bronx Community College. Teachers inevitably have the opportunity to influence the lives of their students. This is a privilege which Dr. Mullin sensed instinctively and with sensitivity throughout her entire professional and post-professional life. Her work was deeply appreciated by her family and her many students and colleagues. Friends may call at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY, Monday, February 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass at 9:30 AM, Tuesday, February 6, at St. Michael's Church, 136-58 41st Ave., Flushing. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the William and Sylvia Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research Center of the NYU Medical Center; 212-263-5700.

title: Stalking New Hot Trends Along the Lycos Trail
description: There may be such a thing as a crystal ball, at least for pop-culture trends: just track what millions of people search for on the Internet each day. That is what Aaron Schatz does at Lycos, an Internet search portal.

title: What if Beethoven Had Been Dozing Quietly at the Y?
description: Zoltan Kocsis at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday night seemed to be two personalities sharing the same pair of hands. This Hungarian pianist has that rare ear for the phrase as a whole: the talent to see from the beginning of a line to its end and to exploit the tension points along the way. In moments of repose -- the quieter episodes of Mozart's C-minor Fantasia, the eerie concluding variations of Beethoven's Sonata Op. 111 and even Liszt's uncharacteristically grim Hungarian Rhapsody No. 5 -- Mr. Kocsis exercised the continuous melodic reach that eludes other musicians who may be brilliant in matters of detail but short of breath in longer musical sentences.

title: Hallmark's 99-cent cards, for those who don't care quite enough to send the very best, sell well.
description: MARITA WESELY-CLOUGH of Hallmark Cards Inc. knew she was onto something when she saw garage sales proliferating in affluent suburbs and heard teenagers bragging about great deals at discount stores.

title: It's Hard Work Being a Hedonist in Cuba
description: DIRTY HAVANA TRILOGY

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 23 about Justice Department prosecutions of health care fraud misidentified the defendants who agreed to a $486 million plea settlement in Massachusetts in January 2000. They were NMC Homecare Inc., LifeChem Inc. and NMC Medical Products Inc. -- not Fresenius Medical Care North America. The three defendants were subsidiaries of National Medical Care Inc., which was purchased by Fresenius during the investigation.

title: The Stock Market Has Made Inmate 90T1282 a Rich Man
description: ELMIRA, N.Y.  On his tax returns, Michael Mathie writes "investor" in the blank reserved for occupation. He claims to have traded upward of $8 million in securities since 1998. In 1999 his adjusted gross income was $899,969, all but a sliver in capital gains. He has also invested in a house for his family on Long Island and bought four cars, including a $97,000 Dodge Viper. Plus a garage to keep it in.

title: Bloomberg Hint of Aid to Bridge
description: Michael Bloomberg announced to his staff on Friday that he was prepared to help out Bridge Information Systems, a struggling rival, but stopped short of saying what that help might entail.

title: Brutish Rivalry Aside, the Knicks Win a Beauty
description: MIAMI, Feb. 4  All the familiar aspects of the rivalry were there: pandemonium in the stands, ferocious banging of bodies, intense chest-to-chest defense and a near brawl that kept 20,058 fans and a national television audience in suspense until the last possession.

title: MediaTalk; Heartbreak, Angst, Soul-Searching. Really.
description: ''Temptation Island,'' Fox's hit reality program in which four ''committed couples'' are tempted by sexy, modern-day sirens to stray, has drawn large audiences with all of its heartache and angst.

title: Wayward Police
description: Recent weeks have brought an alarming series of incidents in which rogue police officers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties have been accused of abusing their authority by asking women drivers to strip or perform sex. These harrowing accusations have emerged just as state investigators are looking at wayward police operations in other suburban and rural counties. Clearly it is time for responsible authorities at the highest level -- Gov. George Pataki, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer and the leaders of the Legislature -- to take a searching look at how New York's 500 separate police operations conduct their business.

title: Phillips Petroleum to Acquire Refiner in $7 Billion Deal
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company reached an agreement yesterday to acquire the Tosco Corporation, an oil refiner and retailer that markets gasoline under the 76 and Circle K brands, for $7 billion in stock.

title: Patents; Many companies will forgo patents in an effort to safeguard their trade secrets.
description: A COUPLE who bought their house nearly 30 years ago from Harland Sanders, founder of Kentucky Fried Chicken, learned last week that a handwritten note they discovered in their basement in 1999 did not reveal Mr. Sanders's famous secret recipe.

title: Anger With Leadership Style Fed Indonesian Censure Vote
description: Behind the Indonesian Parliament's decision to censure President Abdurrahman Wahid for misconduct in two financial schemes last week, setting the stage for his impeachment, was widespread frustration with his erratic stewardship of the world's fourth-largest population, which has been floundering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MARJORIE WARREN
description: BROWN-Marjorie Warren. Died on February 1, 2001. Our beloved mother, wife of the late Courtney C. Brown, is survived by three children, five grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Services at Scarsdale Congregational Church, February 7, 2001, at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Hospice of Westchester.

title: Bush Wants Tax Cut Sooner To Aid Economy This Year
description: In an effort to help get the faltering economy back on track, President Bush will try to speed up his tax cut, to put money into people's pockets this year, the White House's chief economic adviser said today.

title: California's Energy Plan Promises Market Stability, and Big Risks
description: You could almost hear a collective sigh of relief ripple across California last week as the governor signed the first of what are likely to be several monumental pieces of legislation to stabilize the volatile power market.

title: A New Trick Gives Snoops Easy Access To E-Mail
description: For those still harboring the illusion that e-mail exchanges are private, a watchdog group has uncovered a new trick that enables someone to essentially bug an e-mail message so that the spy would be privy to any comments that a recipient might add as the message is forwarded to others or sent back and forth.

title: A Changed Israel Heads to the Polls
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 5  The Israel that will go to the polls on Tuesday is not the same hopeful Israel that overwhelmingly elected Prime Minister Ehud Barak in 1999 with faith in his supreme confidence that he could bring peace to the land.

title: Nonsense Bows to Sweetness and Pain
description: The Metropolitan Opera has disinterred ''L'Italiana in Algeri,'' offering a run of this Rossini opera that began on Friday night. The Jean-Pierre Ponnelle production carries its 28 years with a kind of wan dignity, even though it has had 15 years to rest up from its last appearances here. The Met's motive, aside from Rossini's obvious charms, may have to do with its principal singers. Samuel Ramey (Mustaf) and Jennifer Larmore (Isabella) have exposed and elaborate parts, each with enough meat to keep them happy and nourished.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 17 about programs that give secondhand computers to public school students for home use referred imprecisely to one finding of a survey conducted by a donor organization, Computers for Youth. It found that 46 percent of those surveyed used their computers often to play games -- not occasionally. The article also referred imprecisely to one student whose printer ran out of ink. Computers for Youth does not arrange donations of printers.

title: Russian Forces in Chechnya Free New York Aid Official
description: After more than three weeks in captivity in Chechnya, Kenneth Gluck, a New Yorker who is the director of relief operations for the aid group Doctors Without Borders, was freed Saturday night in an operation conducted by Russia's security services.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NETTER, KIMBERLY LAWRENCE
description: NETTER - Kimberly Lawrence. Beloved wife of Donald T. Netter, and devoted mother of her labradors Paloma (10), De Neiges (8), Cricket (5) and Scout (six months), and her horse, Justice, passed away Friday evening, February 2, 2001, at the age of 44, after a courageous 11 year battle with breast cancer. She was the beloved granddaughter of the late Eleanor Humphrey, the adored daughter of Edith and Richard Lawrence, brother Craig, sister Wendy Probert and loving aunt of Lars (8) and Lily (2). Kimberly graduated from Mamaroneck High School and Berkley College, was raised in Rye Brook, NY, and was a resident of Greenwich, CT, for the past 20 years. Prior to her marriage in 1989, she was a valued long-term associate of Geneve Corporaton, a Stamford, CT, diversified investment concern. Despite her protracted battle with cancer, she always exhibited grace, humor, vigor and compassion. As a woman with a great zest for life, she was an enthusiastic event rider, trainer of field dogs and excelled in a wide array of outdoor and athletic activities. As a gifted photographer with an adventuresome spirit, she was a frequent world traveler. As a Partner in the American Ballet Theatre, she expressed a great passion for the arts. Possessing a generous heart, she will be deeply missed by children of all ages and the many people she uniquely connected with. In lieu of flowers, donations will be gratefully accepted by Pegasus Therapeutic Riding of Greenwich, Adopt - a - Dog of Greenwich, NABCO, the Patient Advocate Foundation and the Rockefeller University's Cancer Research programs. A celebration of Kim's joyous and extraordinary life will be held at the First Church of Round Hill Road (464 Round Hill Road, at the corner of John Street), in Greenwich, CT, on Wednesday, February 7, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YACCARINO, JOSEPH J.
description: YACCARINO-Joseph J. Fifth birthday away. They say it gets easier,...I'm waiting. Happy Birthday, dear friend. Ton

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUSTIN, MIRIAM

Grandma Mim to Jody and Neal Cooper, Jonathan Handler and Penni Sibun. Great-grandmother for the first time on January 17, 2001 to Lorien Katharine Sibun-Handler. She will also be missed by her long time caregiver Gloria Avellana. Her feisty demeanor and firm maternal presence touched all those she knew. She was a woman of great style and sophisticated taste. She started and ran her own successful business ''Just-In-Case'' for more than 20 years. Her life was long and fruitful and may she rest in peace. Services will be private.

title: Gujarat's 'Normality' Still Reeks of Death and Loss
description: Perhaps half the dead have now been found. The rest lie under pile after pile of huge concrete ruins, their bodies hidden from the eye but not the nose. There is nothing sweet along the way of all flesh. Workers picking at the debris must tie handkerchiefs over their faces, like outlaws in a Western.

title: Trying to End Haiti's Impasse, Aristide Meets His Opponents
description: A coalition of opposition leaders who had steadfastly refused to recognize Jean-Bertrand Aristide as Haiti's president-elect said they were willing to compromise after meeting with him and his Lavalas party this weekend to try to resolve the nation's political crisis.

title: Rutgers Erases 17-Point Deficit to Stun Seton Hall for First Big East Victory
description: Todd Billet kept his nose in Seton Hall guard Darius Lane's chest as Lane squared for a 22-foot jump shot. When Lane's shot skipped off the rim with 5 minutes 33 seconds remaining, Billet barked to no one in particular: ''They're tightening up.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICKETTS, JAMES
description: RICKETTS-James. Actor, songwriter and environmentalist, born May 11, 1948, raised in Weston, CT; died January 27, 2001, in his NYC home. Mr. Ricketts attended the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in NYC. He was a U.S. Army veteran who interrupted his performing career to serve his country in Alaska in the late 1960s. He is most well known as the lead in the musical ''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown.'' As a songwriter, he is represented on several recordings by Barbara Cook. He wrote the song ''Adam'' for Ms. Cook as a tribute to her son. In addition, his works are sung by many top cabaret performers. Mr. Ricketts was executive assistant at Environmental Defense since 1988. He is survived by his life partner Christopher Kennedy and beloved brother William of Weston, CT. Memorial services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: ''The Shandelee Music Festival, Jim Ricketts Scholarship Fund'' and mailed to: 36 East 74th St., NY, NY 10021

description: On one of golf's most famous holes, Davis Love III made the day's most important birdie, while Phil Mickelson made the biggest mistake.

title: City Begins Its Last Phase In Closing Out Fresh Kills Site
description: Truck traffic on New York City's bridges and tunnels will be a bit heavier starting today, as the city begins the final step in its four-year effort to send residential trash from throughout the five boroughs to mostly out-of-state landfills and incinerators rather than to the huge Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.

title: Italian Festival Asks Clinton to Appear
description: Bill Clinton has not formally rejected an invitation to appear at the annual San Remo song festival on the Italian Riviera in three weeks, but an appearance there is ''highly unlikely,'' an aide, Jake Siewert, said yesterday.

title: Progress on Money Laundering
description: In its final week, the Clinton administration, after lengthy discussions with leading banks, announced new measures that banks may take to deter corrupt foreign leaders and their business associates from hiding stolen wealth in the United States. The voluntary guidelines, if followed, will represent a welcome recognition of the central role that official corruption plays in the impoverishment of much of the world and in the proliferation of criminal syndicates in today's global economy. But they fall short of providing the legal tools that prosecutors need to combat the problem effectively.

title: Emotions Soar at Vigil on 2nd Anniversary of Diallo Killing
description: Hundreds gathered yesterday on the street in front of the Bronx building where Amadou Diallo was killed by four police officers in a hail of 41 gunshots two years ago to commemorate the second anniversary of his death.

title: TRACK AND FIELD; Millrose Runners Win N.J. Titles
description: Erin Donohue of Haddonfield and Brian Boyett of Parsippany Hills came off strong performances at the Millrose Games on Friday to dominate the 33rd annual New Jersey high school all-group championships today at Jadwin Gym.

title: Accounts
description: * Symantec,indep Cupertino, Calif., which makes the Norton line of computer security software, to the Los Angeles office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group,indep to handle its consumer account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million. The creative part had been handled in-house and the media part had been handled by Carat Freeman, Newton, Mass., and San Francisco, part of the Carat North America unit of the Aegis Group. indep Ogilvy Los Angeles also handles business-to-business advertising for Symantec.

title: Iran's Dubious Reformers and the Politics of Freedom of the Press
description: LONDON  Geneive Abdo, who has reported for the International Herald Tribune from Iran since 1999, fled Tehran on Friday after warnings that she faced almost certain punishment for an interview she conducted with a political dissident. Ms. Abdo escaped with her husband, the Reuters correspondent Jonathan Lyons, who has been told that he may not return to Iran.

title: E-Commerce Report: Comparison Sites Struggling as Well
description: Back in 1999, when people believed the e-tailing shakeout would leave a few Internet merchants standing in every category to compete with the Web sites of traditional companies, the idea of comparison-shopping sites sounded  like so many things dot-com  brilliant.

title: Dispute Over Authorship Of Prizewinning Memoir
description: ''Notes From the Hyena's Belly: An Ethiopian Boyhood,'' by Nega Mezlekia, an Ethiopian civil engineer living in Toronto, is a piercing memoir of his youth in his war-wracked native land. As a child, he dodged ravening hyenas and scrounged for scraps of food. He was a teenage soldier fighting for the Somali rebels, weighed down by heavy weapons as bombs exploded around him. His father was executed during the war, and his mother also died.

title: Sotheby's Guilty Plea Brings Collusion Case Closer to End
description: With a federal judge's acceptance on Friday of a plea deal in which the auction house Sotheby's admitted its guilt in a price-fixing conspiracy and agreed to pay a $45 million fine, the Justice Department investigation and the civil suits that have stemmed from the case are ending.

title: Practical Questions Greet Bush Plan to Aid Religious Groups
description: On the other side of the Anacostia River from where the federal government reigns, in a neighborhood awash with drugs and poverty, the Rev. Herbert B. Chambers is open for business.

title: Corcoran Gallery Given $30 Million for Expansion
description: Two America Online executives and their wives have given $30 million to the Corcoran Gallery of Art toward construction of a planned addition that is being designed by Frank O. Gehry.

title: Disc Machines Gaining on VCR's
description: DVD players, which reached the market four years ago this month, are fast gaining on the VCR as the preferred way for Americans to watch movies at home. Sales of the machines more than doubled last year, with 6.4 million sold in the United States. By contrast, sales of VCR's grew only 6.2 percent.

Schramm; his sister Wendy Griswold; and his brother Daniel M. Goodyear; his brother-in-law Ben Griswold and sister-in-law Dale Goodyear. He gave his love unstintingly and was adored in turn. title: The Postal Service is going right along with the trend of putting ads on everything in sight.
description: THE United States Postal Service is accelerating plans to offer marketers advertising space to peddle private goods and services in places where paid pitches had never appeared until last year, including on the sides of mail trucks and collection boxes, in post office lobbies and on the service's Web site.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Sunday about the dissatisfaction of Manhattan waiters with tips during New York Winter Restaurant Week misstated the name of a restaurant in the base of the Queensboro Bridge. It is Guastavino, not Gustavino.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DROPS. Natural gas fell as forecasts called for milder weather in the northern and central United States. In New York, natural gas for March delivery fell $1.037, or 15.4 percent, to $5.706 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: CANON PROJECTS PROFIT GROWTH
description: Canon Inc., a leading maker of office automation equipment, said its earnings would rise this year on brisk sales of laser printers, digital cameras and machines used to make semiconductor chips. The Tokyo-based company said its group net income would rise 34 percent to 180 billion yen ($1.55 billion) this year, from 134 billion yen ($1.16 billion) last year. Canon aims for sales of 3.12 trillion yen in the year ending December 2001, up 12 percent from 2.78 trillion yen in 2000. Canon shares fell 90 yen, or 2.2 percent, to 4,050 yen.

title: TYCO AGREES TO BUY SCOTT TECHNOLOGIES
description: Tyco International Ltd., the world's biggest maker of fire-protection and security systems, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Scott Technologies for about $376 million in stock to add respiratory equipment and services. Scott shareholders will get $23 worth of Tyco shares for each Scott share, Tyco said in a statement. The price is about 1.6 percent less than Scott's closing price Friday. Scott makes respiratory products for the firefighting, aviation and other markets. In an unrelated deal, Tyco's Raychem unit agreed to buy the Pyrotenax unit, a maker of cables used to insulate pipes, from the General Cable Corporation, for $60 million, according to General Cable. Raychem makes electronic components.

title: In the Mysterious Microscopic World, Noise Begets Silence
description: Physicists have a history of finding natural laws that fit elegantly into the language of mathematics but that become seeming paradoxes when expressed with ordinary words. Now, along with particles that behave as waves and vice versa, they have a new paradox to entertain them: noise that makes certain systems in nature quieter.

DiFrancesco today told New Jersey residents that he would fight to lower property taxes, end racial profiling and improve children's health, all in his first few months in office, while he assured state lawmakers that he would work closely with them, a break from the practice of his predecessor, Christie Whitman.

description: Eyes closed, speaking as slowly as the teardrops crawling down her cheeks, Natividad H. went back there again, back to the farm in Santo Domingo, a little girl picking fruit, playing tag and frolicking through the fields beneath a bright sun, hand in hand with her brothers and sisters.

He is also mourned by his best friend, Lilly Leonardis. He was a loving father, a devoted friend, and a sharp observer of the world and its foibles. We will miss him, his humor and his deep sense of loyalty. Donations may be made in his memory to the Groton School, Groton, MA 01450-0991, or the Roy Waters Scholarship Fund (jschneider@I-55.com). A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church, Princeton, on February 12, at 11:00 AM.

description: When it comes to making deals, the stock market usually voices an opinion, but companies don't always pay heed.

title: CHIP SALES GROW, BUT SO DO INVENTORIES
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association, an influential trade group in San Jose, Calif., said worldwide chip sales last year grew 37 percent over 1999, reaching a record high of $204 billion. But George Scalise, the association president, warned in an interview that a high supply of chips waiting to be sold might drive growth down to as low as 10 percent in 2001, half the association's earlier prediction of 22 percent. Sales declined 2.1 percent between November and December, to $17.9 billion, which the association attributed to typical seasonal patterns. Mr. Scalise said he expected the sales channels to be cleared of inventory by midyear, offering hope for a stronger second half. The association will revise its annual prediction in June. After several Wall Street analysts issued reports echoing Mr. Scalise's predictions, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's Semiconductor Index, a composite of chip maker stocks, dropped $28.74 cents, or 4.2 percent, as Intel, Micron and Applied Materials lost ground. Chris Gaither

description: Two advertisers have made decisions on accounts.

It came with a sheaf of papers attesting to its pedigree; it was in mint condition.

description: Two giant Spanish electric utilities, Endesa and Iberdrola, today called off their planned $13 billion merger, citing conditions imposed by Spanish regulators to shield consumers, which the companies said were too stringent.

But the ache he felt today was a good one, each bruise reminding him of the 20 points and 11 rebounds he had accumulated to help his team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, HOWARD L.
description: CLARK-Howard L. It is with deep sorrow that the Directors, Managers and employees of American Express company mourn the passing of Howard L. Clark on February 2 at the age of 84. Mr. Clark was Chief Executive Officer of American Express from 1960 to 1977, a time of great expansion and success for the company. He was the beloved husband of Jean Beavan Clark and father of Howard L. Jr., Pamela, Stuart and Stephen. Mr. Clark's leadership and contributions had a lasting impact on building the American Express brand. He played a central role in the birth and growth of the American Express Card. He also oversaw the development of the company's travel and financial services businesses, and steady growth in the company's earnings, assets and shareholders' equity. During his tenure, the number of travel service offices increased fourfold to 650 locations in 108 countries; cardmembers totaled eight million; and charge volume exceeded $10 billion. Mr. Clark continued as a member of the American Express Board of Directors until 1983, and served as an Advisor to the Board from 1983 to 1993. He began his business career in 1937 with Price, Waterhouse & Company and left that firm to attend Harvard Law School from 1939 through 1942. After service in the Navy between 1942 and 1945, he joined American Express in 1945. After holding various positions in the company, he became Senior Vice President and Director in 1952, Executive Vice President in 1956, and President and Chief Executive Officer in 1960.

description: Nobody knows how many tens of thousands died in the earthquake that devastated India's Kutch peninsula 11 days ago, but this much is certain: Many were children, and many boys and girls who survived were left as orphans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, DR. MARGARET M.
description: MULLIN-Dr. Margaret M. On February 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Matthew Kabriski who preceded her in death January 1, 2000. Dr. Mullin was born August 12, 1910, in NYC. She enjoyed a long career of teaching and guidance, influencing the lives of thousands of students for nearly 50 years. She began her work as a teacher of high school mathematics and then as Dean at Fort Hamilton High School. She was a faculty member of the School of Education of NYU and did post-doctoral study in Europe. She was a member of the Founding Faculty of Bronx Community College. Teachers inevitably have the opportunity to influence the lives of their students. This is a privilege which Dr. Mullin sensed instinctively and with sensitivity throughout her entire professional and post-professional life. Her work was deeply appreciated by her family and her many students and colleagues. Friends may call at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY, Monday, February 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass at 9:30 AM, Tuesday, February 6, at St. Michael's Church, 136-58 41st Ave., Flushing. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the William and Sylvia Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research Center of the NYU Medical Center; 212-263-5700.

title: Freud and Einstein On Swiss Bank List
description: Einstein and Freud were among the holders of 21,000 dormant Swiss bank accounts posted on the Internet today in an effort to identify accounts that belonged to Holocaust victims. Holders of the accounts, or their heirs, can claim part of the $1.25 billion settlement from Swiss banks.

title: For Parks Commissioner, a Day of Defense and Theatrics
description: Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern found himself under siege yesterday as he defended himself in an impromptu, chaotic news conference in the City Hall rotunda against federal charges of racial discrimination in his department.

title: Surgery Heals Scars Both Physical and Emotional
description: During MonaLou Callery's marriage, there were nights when her husband would knock her to the floor and then kick her and choke her until she passed out, or slam her face into the wall, his hand at the back of her head, she later recalled in divorce proceedings against him. In 1983, after six and a half years of abuse, she left him. She found a job, fought for custody of her children and started rebuilding her life. Yet every time she combed her hair or brushed her teeth, the mirror showed a constant reminder of the brutality.

title: Metro Business Briefing; HARLEM CENTER TO RISE
description: Construction is about to begin on the Harlem Center, a retail, office and hotel complex on 125th Street next to the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building. A groundbreaking ceremony is scheduled for Thursday to mark the beginning of the project's first phase, a retail component with 130,000 square feet of space. Tenants are to include Gap, Bally's Total Fitness Center, CVS and Circuit City. The project, which will be between Malcolm X and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevards, is being jointly developed by the Abyssinian Development Corporation, the development arm of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, and Forest City Ratner.

Lifetime, the mold-making network for women, wanted her to be its first female president. Hello? How could she say no?

A brilliant cantor with a magnificent voice, he quietly and gently served the spiritual needs of his congregation, Beth Yeshurun of Houston, Texas, for over 47 years with dignity, warmth and care. His kindness, his humanity and his caring inspired us all. We extend our sympathy to his family and loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Chaim Najman, President Hazzan Stephen J. Great grandfather to Chelsea and Samantha. Abe was loved and revered by friends and family. His charity and good works will be remembered by all. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Riverdale Temple at 4545 Independence Ave, Riverdale, New York 10471 or a charity of your choice. Services are to be held at the Riverdale Temple Wednesday, February 7 at 11:30 A.M.

title: A New Look At Estrogen And Stroke
description: For women trying to decide whether to take hormone replacement after menopause, a study being published today offers new information about strokes. In one group of women, those who already have heart disease, researchers have found that hormone therapy has no effect at all on the risk of stroke. But it is not yet known whether the new findings apply to women who do not have heart disease.

title: AT&T OFFERING NEW $7 SERVICE
description: AT&T said it would begin offering residential customers combined Internet access and telephone service for a $7 monthly fee. The service, called AT&T 7/7, will give consumers unlimited access to the Web and a round-the-clock rate of 7 cents a minute on state-to-state long-distance calls made from home, the company said. Internet access will be through AT&T's WorldNet service, which will display advertisements to subsidize the cost. AT&T and other phone companies were slow to embrace the Internet and have struggled to sign up customers for their online services. AT&T said last week that WorldNet had more than 1.4 million residential customers at the end of 2000.

title: British Airways Posts a Profit; Will Continue Cutting Fleet
description: British Airways returned to profitability in its third fiscal quarter, helped by a strategy of raising prices for premium services like seats that convert into beds on long-haul flights, while trimming overall capacity.

title: The Stock Market Has Made Inmate 90T1282 a Rich Man
description: On his tax returns, Michael Mathie writes ''investor'' in the blank reserved for occupation. He claims to have traded more than $8 million in securities since 1998. In 1999, his adjusted gross income was $899,969, all but a sliver in capital gains. He has also invested in a house for his family on Long Island and bought four cars, including a $97,000 Dodge Viper. Plus a garage to keep it in.

title: Previn Drops In on Mozart, Then Visits Ravel's Sensuality
description: Andr Previn began his two-week visit to the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall with a program that looked in on two very different musical worlds. Before the intermission Mr. Previn, presiding from the keyboard, led a reduced ensemble in two works by Mozart. After the intermission, with the orchestra's proportions expanded, he stepped up to the podium for two of Ravel's essays in timbral lushness. The mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager sang on both halves of the program and made enlivening contributions to a performance that was otherwise surprisingly low on energy.

One of mine was a cold February night in 1970, when I ventured into a brave new neighborhood called SoHo and sat on cushions on the floor in a dark room to watch the dozens of video screens that constituted a theater production called ''Global Village.'' (It included a nude sex scene, which was pretty shocking, and shocking was good.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NETTER, KIMBERLY LAWRENCE

Her life story is deeply inspiring. We will always remember her enormous courage and amazing spirit in the face of her struggle with breast cancer, and her tireless advocacy on behalf of others afflicted with this terrible disease. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Donald, to our friend Richard Netter and to the entire Lawrence and Netter families. Arnold J. Levine, President Richard B. Fisher, Chairman Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus and R.U. Council Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman

title: COMMERZBANK POSTS LOSS
description: Commerzbank of, of Germany, recorded a loss in the fourth quarter as the retiring chief executive, Martin Kohlhaussen, took charges to slim down the bank, hoping his successor will reap the benefits. The Frankfurt-based company said it had lost 98 million euros ($92 million) in the quarter after setting aside 100 million euros ($93.64 million) for losses at its Korea Exchange Bank unit. Commerzbank also increased provisions for bad loans and raised reserves by 800 million euros ($749.12 million) as it reorganizes to increase earnings. Mr. Kohlhaussen, 65, is preparing to hand control to board member Klaus-Peter Mller, above, in May. (Bloomberg News)
