description: Still upset that Al Gore lost despite labor's big campaign push, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said yesterday that unions hoped to work with President Bush on issues like a patients' bill of rights.

title: World Business Briefs
description: EUROPE COMMERZBANK POSTS LOSS Commerzbank of, of Germany, recorded a loss in the fourth quarter as the retiring chief executive, Martin Kohlhaussen, took charges to slim down the bank, hoping his successor will reap the benefits. The Frankfurt-based company said it had lost 98 million euros ($92 million) in the quarter after setting aside 100 million euros ($93.64 million) for losses at its Korea Exchange Bank unit. Commerzbank also increased provisions for bad loans and raised reserves by 800 million euros ($749.12 million) as it reorganizes to increase earnings. Mr. Kohlhaussen, 65, is preparing to hand control to board member Klaus-Peter Muller, above, in May. (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Attorney General John Ashcroft's first day in office misstated the Senate's 1999 action on the nomination of Ronnie White, Missouri's first black state supreme court judge, for a seat on the federal bench -- a nomination that Democrats were now urging Mr. Ashcroft to revive. The 1999 appointment indeed reached the Senate floor, where it was rejected, 54 to 45.

title: Lax Standards in Albany
description: State Senator Guy Velella, a Republican from the Bronx, served as chairman of the Insurance Committee for a decade and retains a powerful hold on insurance matters in New York's State Legislature. Thus it is unconscionable that he has used a loophole in the state's notoriously weak ethics laws to accept large fees from the very insurance industry whose activities he is supposed to be overseeing on behalf of the public.

title: Collectors Steal a March on the Runway Hut-Two-Three
description: By the time the fall 2001 men's shows ended in Milan a few weeks ago, editors and buyers had witnessed more leather lace-up boots, Eisenhower jackets and belted trench coats than if they had stayed home and spent five days with the History Channel. Over the years, fashion has embraced military style with a frequency roughly equal to that of the naming of national security advisers. The look appeared on runways a number of times during the 1990's, and it is bubbling up again as a prevailing theme in women's lines this spring -- Comme des Garons, Miguel Adrover and Christian Dior all include it. A recent cover of Elle featured Sharon Stone in a $1,600 Dior camouflage jacket, and matching bikini, an item coveted by fashion editors and an avowal of female sexual aggression matched in its bluntness only by certain lyrics in the Foxy Brown canon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOW, PEARL
description: SOLOW-Pearl. Loving wife of Sam for sixty-six years, devoted mother of Ted (Ronnie) and Robert (Marsha), grandmother of Marc, Laurie (Eddie), Ryan and Kim, great-grandmother of Jared. Funeral services at 11 A.M., Wednesday, February 7 at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Rapper Fired Gun, Witness Says
description: A woman who was shot and wounded during a scuffle in a Times Square nightclub in late 1999 testified yesterday that she saw the hip-hop impresario Sean Combs fire a pistol into the air just before a bullet hit her in the face.

title: Article 2001020690793718644 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: December-May Romance, Postmarked
description: Prazak String Quartet

title: Murphy's Law at Work: St. John's Falls Apart
description: For nearly 30 minutes tonight, St. John's became the talented, hard-playing team that usually shows up at home. Then it disintegrated, as usual, on the road.

title: Shots Are Reported Fired Outside the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Shots were fired outside the White House today after a potential intruder approached the southwest gate before noon and was challenged by security guards.

title: A Ford Heir Struggles For Control
description: William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, has been frustrated in recent months at being left out of decisions at the company that bears his family's name, people close to Ford's leadership said.

title: Article 2001020692628830564 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: A New Revolution: Libert! galit! Sororit!
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORTZ, BERNARD
description: BORTZ-Bernard. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and its Men's Division record with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved father of Joyce Fiedler and extend our heartfelt sympathy to her; to her husband, Jeffrey; and to their entire family. Yeshiva University Dr. Norman Lamm, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean David H. Schwartz, Chairman Men's Division

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: White House Seeks Ways To Speed Up Tax-Cut Plan

title: Facing Drop in Revenue, Razorfish Is Planning More Cuts
description: Razorfish Inc., one of the oldest and most established Internet consulting and design companies in Manhattan's Silicon Alley, announced yesterday that it was laying off about 400 employees because of slowing revenues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HARRY
description: SCHWARTZ-Harry. With his keen intelligence and humor he was a treasure to his family and friends. He served in the Marine Corps during World War II and was a graduate of NYU and a recipient of a Yale University Fellowship. He was the youngest and first Jewish president of the National Housewares Household Association and was well respected and admired in the industry. A very sensitive, deeply caring man with grace, vigor and compassion, he leaves an unfillable void in the lives of his beloved wife Frances, daughter Deborah, son-in-law Roger, and adoring grandchildren James, Abigail and her husband Mark. A truly remarkable man, he will be sorely missed by all whose lives he touched.

title: Prudential Adds a Bank Analyst
description: Michael Mayo, a prominent banking stock analyst, has finally found a home. Dismissed from Credit Suisse First Boston after its merger with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette last fall, Mr. Mayo is going to Prudential Securities, according to an executive at the firm.

title: Lockerbie Verdict Tainted By Politics, Qaddafi Says
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi held a marathon news conference today to deliver a sometimes sharp, sometimes bizarre analysis of the Lockerbie bombing case, emphasizing that even a verdict he considered flawed should lead to removing economic sanctions and better ties with Washington.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about ''Hymn to the Rising Sun'' at La MaMa E.T.C. used a misspelled surname at two points for the actor playing the Captain. He is Charley Hayward, as noted elsewhere in the review, not Heyward.

title: DeFrantz Announces Long-Shot I.O.C. Bid
description: Undaunted by her position as an outsider, Anita DeFrantz has become the first woman and the first African-American to declare her candidacy for the most powerful job in international sports.

title: Pardon for Subject of Inquiry Worries Prosecutors
description: One of the 140 people pardoned last month by President Clinton was a businessman being investigated for new potential felonies. Now, some Justice Department officials arequestioning whether the president's broadly worded order could hamper their inquiry.

title: LOSSES INCREASE AT WILLIAMS
description: Williams Communications said its losses deepened in the fourth quarter as it sought to complete a huge fiber-optic communications network. The loss from continuing operations at Williams, which is controlled by Williams Companies, the gas-pipeline operator, based in Tulsa, Okla., widened to $55.7 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $50 million, or 11 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Operating costs, including those related to Williams recently completed fiber-optic network, rose to $402.3 million from $229.4 million, while revenue climbed 80 percent, to $287 million. The company's overall loss in the quarter ballooned to $542.2 million, or $1.18 a share, from $74 million, or 16 cents, because of costs related to the sale of a business unit that sells communications networks to businesses. Simon Romero

title: Metro Business Briefing; OFFICE DEAL SIGNED
description: PaineWebber, the securities firm, has signed a lease with the Lefrak Organization for a 32-story, 1.2 million-square-foot tower to be built at the Newport office complex in Jersey City. Designed by Kohn Pederson Fox Associates, the PaineWebber tower will be the seventh office building at Newport, where the Lefrak Organization has leased three million square feet in the last two years alone. In July, J. P. Morgan Chase & Company signed an agreement to occupy two office buildings at Newport. While many of the companies have come from Manhattan, PaineWebber is expected to move employees from its office in Weehawken, N.J., to the Jersey City tower when it is completed in 2002. PaineWebber, a division of UBS AG, is also looking to consolidate its offices in Manhattan. Charles V. Bagli

title: Jury Award Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANSONE, FRANK
description: SANSONE-Frank. Born February 19, 1917, died on January 26, 2001. ''He has slipped the surly bonds of earth, to touch the face of God.''

title: Hypocrisy Has Its Virtues
description: We need to be careful, or we will drive our best hypocrites out of public life.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SAFETY; What Drug Researchers Do Not Report
description: Researchers reporting on the effectiveness of new drugs tend to skimp on providing information on their safety and side effects, according to a study published Jan. 24 in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Washington's Other Mr. Powell
description: George W. Bush has named Michael Powell to be the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, making the Powells one of Washington's most powerful father-son teams in a long time. The powers held by the secretary of state are well known. Less obvious is the importance of the F.C.C., the traffic cop to the nation's information technologies. The agency was created seven decades ago to insure an orderly allocation of the airwaves, and its power and responsibilities have increased greatly with the explosive growth of the Internet, wireless communications and cable and broadcast television. Not knowing what will come next, or even how today's technologies will intersect tomorrow, is what makes the F.C.C.'s regulatory work so conceptually challenging.

title: LTV TO RESTART BLAST FURNACE AND RECALL 400 WORKERS
description: The LTV Corporation, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in December, said it was restarting a blast furnace at its Cleveland plant and recalling 400 workers because orders had increased. The Cleveland furnace, taken off line in November, is being restarted because it uses oil that is now less expensive than the natural gas used at other plants, LTV said. The recalled workers began returning to the plant Sunday. About 200 employees remain laid off, the company said.

title: J. J. Johnson, Jazz Trombonist, Is Dead at 77
description: J. J. Johnson, the most influential trombonist in postwar jazz, died on Sunday at his home in Indianapolis. He was 77.

title: Empty Aisles and Empty Stores; What Happens When Anchor Stores Weigh Anchor?
description: Bradlees was the first to give up the fight. Then Montgomery Ward's, the long-troubled retailer, declared bankruptcy in late December, concluding that consumer spending was too soft to prop it up through the upcoming year. Soon after retailers like J. C. Penney, Sears, ShopKo, and OfficeMax all announced store closings.

title: Statehouse Stalemate Delays Relief from Tax on Heating Fuel
description: The State Senate and the Assembly both passed bills today authorizing the New York City Council to suspend the city's 4 percent sales tax on heating oil and natural gas this winter, but the two measures differ slightly, leaving it unclear when consumers might see an actual tax reduction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERSHATSKY, CHARLES
description: BERSHATSKY-Charles. Father of Evelyn and Eugene. Grandfather of seven, great grandfather of two. Brother of Sidney and Bell.

title: BUSH TO PROPOSE MAKING A TAX CUT EFFECTIVE IN 2001
description: President Bush said today that he wanted substantial parts of his tax-cut plan to apply retroactively to the beginning of this year -- a full year ahead of what he proposed during the campaign -- as a means of shoring up the faltering economy.

title: Clintons Will Return Any Gifts Found to Belong to White House
description: Former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton received authorization to take certain household furnishings to their new homes as gifts but will return any items that are found to be White House property, a spokesman said today.

title: A Jury Rules in Favor of a Latino East Village Group Battling Eviction
description: A jury in Manhattan Civil Court gave the Charas/El Bohio Cultural and Community Center a significant victory yesterday in its fight to stay in the East Village building that it has occupied since 1979.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAGO, RICHARD
description: DRAGO-Richard. On February 4th, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Loving father of Richard W., Diane, Linda Drago-Keedy and Robert. Dear grandfather of Christopher Robert and Jennifer Michelle Keedy. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at M.J. Smith Sons Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:15 AM, at Holy Name R.C. Church.

title: Foreign Affairs; The War Saddam Won
description: The Bush team has a full-fledged public relations disaster on its hands in the Arab world.

title: Profit Declines 66% At Oxford Health
description: Oxford Health Plans, one of the New York area's biggest health insurers, said its fourth-quarter profit fell 66 percent after charges related to a recapitalization, though it added customers and cut costs.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose on expectations that reports this week will show that economic growth in Europe is outpacing that of the United States. In New York, the euro settled at 93.87 cents, up from 93.48 cents on Friday.

title: Rumors Fly After January Surge in Toyota Shares
description: A report by a newspaper here that the Tokyo Stock Exchange was investigating a sudden surge in Toyota Motor shares in mid-January has bolstered suspicions that insider trading may have been involved.

title: Super Bowl XXXV Archive
description: This is a selected archive of Times coverage of the Giants' postseason road to Super Bowl XXXV.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ROSLYN
description: WOLF-Roslyn. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Roslyn Wolf, and extends sincere sympathy to her family and friends. David S. Mack, President Marshall L. Hess, Secretary

title: SINGAPORE'S ELECTRONICS SECTOR GROWS
description: Singapore's Economic Development Board said the island-state's electronics industry posted 19.7 percent growth in 2000 to 82.3 billion Singapore dollars ($47.4 billion). Economists have said that Singapore's dependence on technology exports, especially semiconductors and hard disks, makes it more vulnerable than many Asian economies to the current global economic slowdown. Singapore's production of semiconductors soared by 73.4 percent last year, thanks in part to the board's success in attracting new investments from abroad. Wayne Arnold

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the equity and debt calendar of Business Day yesterday for an initial public offering by Williams Energy Partners misidentified the underwriter. It is Lehman Brothers, not Merrill Lynch.

title: Gilbert Trigano, a Developer of Club Med, Is Dead at 80
description: Gilbert Trigano, who in the 1950's developed the concept of vacation clubs that later made Club Med synonymous with fake Polynesian villages and organized fun, died on Saturday after a long illness, his family said. He was 80.

title: Of Cleaner Cutting Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEREN, ARTHUR TEWES STIEREN
description: STIEREN-Arthur Tewes Stieren, Jr. passed away on Sunday, February 4, 2001 at the age of 71. The cause of death was lung cancer. He was born in San Antonio, Texas on October 24, 1929 to Arthur Tewes Stieren and Elizabeth Huth. He attended Alamo Heights schools and graduated from Culver Military Academy in 1946 and from Yale University in 1950. He entered the Harvard Business School in 1950, but his education was delayed by serving in the U.S. Army Field Artillery for two years. He served in this country and in Korea. He was honorably discharged a First Lieutenant in 1953. After returning to the Harvard Business School, he was awarded a Masters of Business Administration in 1954. He is survived by his wife, Jane and daughters, Lisa Cox, Wendy Wirth, Kelly Daniell, Amy Burgess, by his son, George L. Stieren, and numerous grandchildren. He is survived also by a sister, Betty Kelso. He was a Trustee of Trinity University, San Antonio, and was active in the McNay Art Museum, the Santa Fe Opera and the Metropolitan Opera. A Memorial Service at Parker Chapel, Trinity University, is planned for Monday, February 12, 2001 at 4:00 P.M. Contributions are welcome to the institutions named above, as well as to the charity of choice. Services with Porter Loring Mortuary, 1101 McCullough, San Antonio, Texas, 210-227-8221.

title: Mirra Ginsberg -- Translator, 91
description: Mirra Ginsberg, a noted translator of works by Dostoyevsky, Mikhail Bulgakov and Isaac Bashevis Singer, died on Dec. 26 on Long Island. She was 91.

title: 2000 Final Four Archive
description: Here is a selected archive of Times coverage of the 2000 National Collegiate Athletic Association's Final Four for both men and women.

title: McCain Joining Democrats To Offer Health Rights Bill
description: Senator John McCain, the maverick Republican who irritated many leaders of his own party in his quest for the presidency, will join Democrats this week in proposing legislation intended to break a three-year impasse over patients' rights.

title: 30-Year Treasuries Rise a Bit On Speculation Sales Will End
description: Treasury bonds prices were mixed yesterday with the 30-year bond rising on speculation the government's sale of 30-year debt this week may be one of the last.

title: It Takes Training and Genes To Make a Mean Dog Mean
description: The fatal mauling of a San Francisco woman by her neighbors' dog on Jan. 26 revives the question of whether some dog breeds are more inherently violent than others and should be banned as pets.

title: Beatings and Other Abuses Cited at Samoan Apparel Plant That Supplied U.S. Retailers
description: Workers at a factory in American Samoa that made apparel for the J. C. Penney Company and other retailers were often beaten and were provided food so inadequate that some were ''walking skeletons,'' a Labor Department investigation has found.

title: Gestures by Bush, To All Americans
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JERONIMO, DOLORES
description: JERONIMO-Dolores. Died on February 3rd, 2001 in Anna Maria, FL. Wife of the late Armand Jeronimo. Mother of Bob and Corky and grandmother of Matthew, Alexandra and Nicholas. She will be deeply missed. No services. Donations in her memory to Hospice of Southwest Florida, 3355 26th Street W., Bradenton, FL. 34205.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSETTI, ANDREW JOSEPH
description: ROSSETTI-Andrew Joseph. Student and dear friend to many, on February 3, 2001. On behalf of the students and faculty of Hopkins School, we wish to offer our deepest condolences to his family, especially his sister Paige, our schoolmate. Andrew was a guiding light to all who had the privilege of knowing him. His confident voice and steady hand will be missed dearly. It is with great and heartfelt sorrow that we say farewell to one of own.

title: The Clintons and the Gift Givers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARACCHI, OLIVA
description: VARACCHI-Oliva. On February 4, 2001. Devoted mother of Patricia Tutrone, Gregory and Camille. Cherished grandmother of Michelle, Peter, Christopher, Stephanie, and great-grandchildren, Olivia and Carmine. Loving sister of Rose Barbieri and Eugene Rossi. Mass Thursday, 10:15 AM, St. Francis Xavier Church. Reposing at the chapel of Joseph G. Duffy Inc., 9th St. between 4th and 5th Aves., Brooklyn. Call Henry McCaddin & Son Funeral Directors for information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERWAGER, KARL
description: OBERWAGER-Karl. Beloved husband, left us on Feb. 4, one month after his hundredth birthday. Survived by his loving and devoted wife, Susie; his family in Israel and Mexico, and numerous friends who all loved him. My life is diminished without him. Yours always, Susie and his poodle, Giselle. Funeral service on Wednesday, February 7, 10 AM, at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. & 76 St.

title: The Week in Science: One Dread or Another
description: Infectious disease, of one dread kind or another, was the theme of this week's news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENGLER, SILAS
description: SPENGLER-Silas. His devotion to clients, attention to legal draftsmanship and high ethical standards were examples followed by all who had the privilege to work with him. A graduate of Andover, Yale College, and University of Pennsylvania Law School, Mr. Spengler began his practice at Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, and in 1964, co-founded Roth, Carlson, Kwit & Spengler, which grew to some 75 attorneys over the next 28 years. In 1992, his firm, then known as Spengler, Carlson, Gubar, Frischling & Brodsky, combined with the firm now known at Thelen Reid & Priest, where he remained until his retirement from the practice of law in 1994. Mr. Spengler was in every sense, a gentleman, and he will be missed by his friends and colleagues.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OLD DOMINION FREIGHT LINE INC., High Point, N.C., a transporter of freight, said it would buy selected assets of Carter & Sons Freightways Inc., Tex., which is a regional carrier, to strengthen its service in the south-central United States. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Wait a Minute, Mr. Postman, Please. Keep Still!
description: In the spring of 1888, having recently moved to the town of Arles in the south of France, Vincent van Gogh decided to make portraits of some of the natives. One of his first subjects, a postal worker named Joseph Roulin, became a deeply important friend to the lonely and troubled artist. Now five of the six pictures that van Gogh painted of him and two drawings have been reunited at the Museum of Modern Art in a revelatory micro-exhibition organized by Kirk Varnedoe, the museum's chief curator of painting and sculpture.

title: The Clintons and the Gift Givers
description: To the Editor:

title: WEB SERVER SHIPMENTS REMAIN STRONG
description: Worldwide shipments of servers -- powerful computers used for commercial Internet operations and other business -- rose to 1.1 million in the fourth quarter, Dataquest reported yesterday. The figure, an increase of 21 percent over the same quarter a year ago, suggests growth in server shipments remains strong, despite slower growth in the personal computer market. During all of 2000, 3.9 million servers were shipped worldwide, an increase of 14 percent over shipments in 1999, according to Dataquest, a unit of Gartner Group. Domestically, Dataquest estimated from preliminary data that shipments of servers in the United States in the fourth quarter of 2000 rose 32 percent over the same period a year earlier. Matt Richtel

title: Knicks Fall Victim to Another Rockets Comeback
description: The method was different but the outcome was just as ghastly.

title: A Snowfall That Means Business
description: The third significant snowfall of the winter -- and the first on a weekday -- blanketed the region yesterday with a torrent of white flakes as big as cocktail napkins, making a quick mess of the northern and western suburbs, where schools closed, businesses shuttered early and highways were littered with spun-out cars and flipped vans.

title: In Big Bang's Echoes, Clues to the Cosmos
description: A dappled glow from the explosive birth of the universe is teasing astronomers with its mysteries and apparent contradictions, as it has again and again since two scientists at Bell Laboratories in Holmdel, N.J., discovered it accidentally in 1965.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Attorney General John Ashcroft's first day in office misstated the Senate's 1999 action on the nomination of Ronnie White, Missouri's first black state supreme court judge, for a seat on the federal bench  a nomination that Democrats were now urging Mr. Ashcroft to revive. The 1999 appointment indeed reached the Senate floor, where it was rejected, 54 to 45.

title: U.S. Men Are Happy Despite Loss
description: Despite a mediocre performance against Colombia in its last preparatory match before playing Mexico in a World Cup qualifier later this month, the United States men say they have made progress.

title: Term Limits Bill Draws a Sharp Response From Those Who Would Run
description: The introduction of a bill in the City Council to rescind the city's term limits law for members of the Council has created a firestorm of reaction from a wide spectrum within New York City's political landscape, with many officials and politicians outside of the Council denouncing the legislation.

title: Workers Say They Hit a Job Ceiling
description: Paula Loving went to work for the city's Department of Parks and Recreation in 1987. She rose to become citywide coordinator in the Work Experience Program -- and then saw her rise cut short. Ms. Loving, a black woman, watched, twice, as much-younger white women were promoted to director of work-experience operations, a position she believed entailed more responsibility. To her knowledge, the job was never posted and no interviews were held for it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, PHILIP
description: WEINSTEIN - Philip. Respected lawyer and counselor, beloved husband of the late Molly, brother to Nancy, father to Elaine and David, grandfather to Matthew, uncle and patriarch to many, friend and neighbor. He passed peacefully in his sleep on February 5, 2001. Phil served his country proudly as a decorated infantryman during World War II. He worked for four decades as an attorney with the firm Bernstein, Weiss, Parter, Coplan, Weinstein & Lake specializing in maritime law and always strongly advocating for his clients' interests. A man of principle, conviction and ideals, Phil was keenly interested in world affairs and the continuity of Jewish tradition. A graveside service will be held at Mount Golda Cemetery/Huntington Hebrew Congregation located in Huntington, Long Island on Old Country Road off Exit 41 on the Northern State Parkway at 11 AM on Thursday, February 8th. The family will receive visitors at Phil's former residence Thursday afternoon and Friday, February 8th and 9th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the: Weinstein Family Fund, c/o Fidelity Charitable Gift Fund, 82 Devonshire Street, Boston, MA 02109.

title: Article 2001020690368841092 -- No Title
description: Whatever she says it will be, it will be bigger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIER, SIDNEY
description: SCHNEIER-Sidney. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, and great grandfather. Father of Eileen Lauer, our outstanding nursery teacher and director of our day camp. Grandfather of Neil Lauer and Rachel Lauer Verbov, alumni of our yeshiva. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Manhattan Day School/ Yeshiva Ohr Torah Rabbi Mordechai Besser, Principal George Karasick, President Elliot Gibber, Chairman of the Board

title: At the Game, Big Brother Is Watching You
description: To the Editor:

title: DAVITA REPORTS FEDERAL INQUIRY, AND SHARES PLUNGE
description: DaVita shares fell 17 percent after the company, which runs kidney dialysis centers, said federal prosecutors had asked for information on its billing practices and financial relationships with doctors. DaVita said it was cooperating and had not been accused of any wrong doing or been subpoenaed. Its shares fell $3.25, to $15.50. The government is investigating whether DaVita, which changed its name from Total Renal Care Holdings in October, offered financial incentives for doctors to refer patients, its chief executive, Kent Thiry, told investors.

title: American Communists Come Home, on Microfilm
description: In 1993, John Haynes, a historian at the Library of Congress, was in Russia meeting with the head of that nation's archives when he was startled by a sudden remark.

title: In the Basie Tradition, Jokes and All
description: Carnegie Hall Jazz Band

title: SPRINT EXPANDING FOREIGN WEB NETWORK
description: As part of its new international strategy, the Sprint Corporation plans to announce today that it will expand its Internet network to 15 European and Asian cities by the end of the year. By the end of 2003, Sprint intends to expand the network to a total of 35 overseas cities. With the collapse of Sprint's international Global One venture with Deutsche Telekom of Germany and France Tlcom, Sprint has been searching for a way to reinvigorate its overseas operations. Sprint currently delivers Internet services to more than two dozen foreign countries, but mostly uses other companies' networks to deliver those products. The company also plans to announce that its Internet operation in London is open for business. Seth Schiesel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, JOSEPH F. SR.
description: LANE-Joseph F. Sr. Retired Police Commissioner of Long Beach, NY on February 2, 2001 in Mesa, Arizona. He was 82 and had been in ailing health since his move to Arizona three years ago. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Clark). Loving father of Joseph F. (Martha), Thomas P., Kevin P. (Malissa), Robert (Susan) and Patricia Lane (Luis J. Briones). Dear brother of Eileen E. Lane and Marie Lane Caufield. Cherished grandfather of Katherine Elizabeth Lane, Sandra Patricia Lane, Ryan Andrew Lane, Ligita Irene Lane, Megan Kema Lane, Nicole Marie Briones and Joseph Luis Briones. His extended family of sister-in-law Bernadette McCann, Veronica Inch and brotherin-law Joseph McCann and his 27 nephews and nieces. Reposing at Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY. Wednesday and Thursday 2-4, 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30 AM St. Ignatius Martyr RC Church, Long Beach, New York. Interment in Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower St., Phoenix, AZ 85014.

title: Ex-Worker Opens Fire at Illinois Plant; 5 Are Killed
description: A man forced his way into a Navistar engine factory in this western Chicago suburb this morning and opened fire, killing four people and wounding four others, before taking his own life.

title: The Culprits, When Good Food Goes Bad
description: Rick awakened at 2 a.m. with severe gastrointestinal distress, passed out on the way to the bathroom and spent the next two days in bed. The problem, he surmised, was food poisoning from the dozen raw oysters he had eaten that evening at a three-star restaurant. But because he never saw a doctor and did not obtain a stool or blood culture, the case and the causative organism never made it into the record books. And because the restaurant was neither informed nor investigated, chances are Rick was not the only victim of a presumed slip in its food buying and preparation procedures.

title: The Clintons and the Gift Givers
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Cast of Creatures At Steinbeck's Monterey Bay
description: In his novel ''Cannery Row,'' John Steinbeck describes ''the parklike property'' of the Hopkins Marine Station, the research center Stanford University has operated for more than 100 years at the edge of Monterey Bay.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: This Second Lady Is Keeping Her Day Job
description: In the back seat, Lynne Cheney whispered that she was trying to refrain from telling the Secret Service agent behind the wheel which route to take.

title: Big Oil and the Arctic
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; In Matters of the Heart, Family Counts
description: Researchers who examined the arteries of people whose parents or siblings had heart disease found that half showed early signs of arteriosclerosis, according to a study published last week in the journal Circulation.

title: Remedies: Herbal Relief for Premenstrual Syndrome
description: An herbal compound made from the fruit of the chasteberry tree was effective in reducing most of the symptoms of premenstrual syndrome, German researchers reported last month in The British Medical Journal.

title: Eastman Chemical Announces Plan to Split Itself Into 2 Companies
description: The Eastman Chemical Company said today that it planned to split into two companies to protect its fast-growing specialty chemicals business from the ups and downs of prices for commodity plastics and fibers.

title: Who's Defending Rockefeller Drug Laws? The Prosecutors
description: As the push to ease New York State's mandatory drug-sentencing laws has drawn the once-improbable support of leading Republican lawmakers lately, one influential interest group has refused to join the chorus: prosecutors across the state, who regard the so-called Rockefeller drug laws as their most powerful weapon against drug dealers.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Whatever she says it will be, it will be bigger.''

title: Herman Liveright -- Activist, 89
description: Herman Liveright, who was dismissed in 1956 as program director for the New Orleans television station WDSU after refusing to tell a Senate panel whether he was a Communist, died on Jan. 19 in a hospital in Corpus Christi, Tex. He was 89, lived in Lenox, Mass., and spent winters in Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDRE, OLIVIA DULANY WHEELER POST
description: ALEXANDRE - Olivia Dulany Wheeler Post. Died quietly at home on Saturday, January 21st. She was born in 1903, was twice widowed and leaves three stepchildren: Nancy Post Magro, George B. Post and L. Jerome Alexandre. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church Saturday, February 17 at 11 A.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Church at 865 Madison Avenue, NY, NY, 10021.

title: What, Geeks at M.I.T.? Not With This Class
description: In the men's room on the third floor of the M.I.T. student center on Friday, Dr. Travis Merritt, a professor of literature at M.I.T. and former dean of undergraduate academic affairs, was teaching 20 students how to clear their throats.

title: A Tilt to India
description: To the Editor:

title: From Guyana to Brooklyn, This Fighter Aims High
description: The boxer living in Brooklyn dialed the number in Georgetown, Guyana.

title: Rodolfo Morales, 75, Painter Of Peasant Life in Mexico
description: Rodolfo Morales, whose surreal paintings of rural Mexican culture won acclaim around the world, died last Tuesday in Oaxaca. He was 75.

title: Russia Says U.S. Antimissile Plan Means an Arms Race
description: Two days after American officials told their European counterparts that the United States intended to go ahead and develop a national missile shield -- but only after extensive consultations -- Russia responded today with a sober warning that it is ready to resort to a new arms race to ensure that its strategic rocket forces will not be undermined.

title: Technology Briefings
description: DIGITALHACKERS STEAL DATA FROM ECONOMIC FORUM Officials of the World Economic Forum, host last week to international leaders in Davos, Switzerland, said computer hackers had gained access to a database from a previous event held last year containing, among other personal details, the credit card numbers of 1,400 participants. Calling the security breach a serious crime, the forum's managing board said it had asked the Swiss authorities to help find the responsible hackers and had taken legal action to prevent the spread of any illegally procured information. This year's participants include Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader, Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general and William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman. The theft was first reported by a Swiss newspaper, Sonntags Zeitung, after hackers approached the publication with credit card details, mobile phone numbers and private addresses of some forum participants. The annual forum has been aimed at by anti-globalization protestors; the forum would not say whether it suspected those forces in the theft.

title: Missing Fugitive Delays French Corruption Trial
description: The multimillion-dollar corruption trial of a former French foreign minister was postponed again today to await the extradition of a fugitive oil executive involved in the case, a man who once bragged he knew enough secrets ''to bring down the Republic 20 times.''

title: Ex-Contestant On 'Survivor' Files Lawsuit
description: Stacey E. Stillman, a contestant in the original version of the hit CBS reality series ''Survivor,'' sued the network and the show's producer Mark Burnett yesterday, saying they had manipulated a vote that eliminated her from the chance to win the $1 million prize.

title: TRICON TO OPEN 100 MORE KFC FRANCHISES IN CHINA
description: Tricon Global Restaurants Inc. plans to add about 100 new franchises in China for its Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants to match the growth of its rival, McDonalds, a company official said. Tricon invested $200 million to open 400 KFC outlets in China since 1987, of which 10 were franchises, said Xu Zhen, a Tricon China spokeswoman. The company wants to expand to smaller cities in China.

title: 2 Web Sites For Women Announce Their Merger
description: IVillage and Women.com, start-ups that competed to attract female Web surfers and the advertisers to cater to them, said yesterday that they would join forces, with iVillage paying $27 million to acquire its former rival.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about the Walt Disney Company's plan to close Go.com, an Internet portal site, included an asset incorrectly among those to be sold. They do not include a user list.

title: Thomas Finds Himself Out of Playing Shape
description: Drenched with sweat and breathing heavily, Kurt Thomas walked off the court and into the visitor's locker room tonight with the gait of a man who was ready to bang with the Houston Rockets. There was no sign of the sprained right ankle that had kept him out of the previous four games and there was no question that he was eager to play.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKENTHALER, BERNICE
description: FRANKENTHALER - Bernice. Feb. 5, 2001. Loving wife of the late Norman, beloved mother of Judy Mydans of Denver Co., and Robert Frankenthaler of Boston Ma. Devoted grandmother of Dan, Lindsay, Amy, Jill, and Scott. A dedicated educator in the New York City school system for 32 years. Her career culminated as Principal of Robert Wagner Junior High School in New York City. She also served as a volunteer in many city-wide agencies. A woman full of life & energy, who gave to many, who will be missed by all. Services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, 81st Street, on Wednesday, February 7, 4 PM.

title: Bertelsmann to Take Over Broadcaster for $9 Billion
description: In a move that may eventually transform one of the world's biggest and most privately controlled media empires, Bertelsmann of Germany agreed today to take control of Europe's biggest television broadcaster, the RTL Group, in a stock transaction worth roughly $9 billion.

title: WASHINGTON TRIES NEW STRATEGY
description: Picking a new approach for dealing with Japan, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill suggested he would try to work directly with executives there. Business Day, Page C1.

title: AS ISRAELIS VOTE, DREAMS OF PEACE SEEM TO BE FADING
description: The Israel that votes on Tuesday is not the same hopeful Israel that overwhelmingly elected Prime Minister Ehud Barak in 1999 with confidence in his supreme confidence that he could bring peace to the land.

title: Climbing High, but Feeling Low
description: For many years Janet Shown, a hiker and cross-country skier, suffered odd symptoms whenever she ventured beyond 9,000 feet.

title: From Brainwash to Carwash: Creating a National Passion
description: The shaping of consumer demand for cars, and especially the idea of introducing newly designed models every year, is not only a classic American story but also one of advertising's historical triumphs.

title: Vivendi to Acquire Uproar for $140 Million in Cash
description: Uproar Inc., the Silicon Alley online games company, said today that it had agreed to be acquired for about $140 million in cash by Vivendi Universal, the French water utility that turned itself into a telecommunications and entertainment giant.

title: A New Revolution: Libert! galit! Sororit!
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Vigil and Waiting for Marshal to Lock the Door
description: The watchmen inside the Indianapolis Baptist Temple slapped cards into the night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, STEPHEN M.
description: ROBERTS-Stephen M. Dear Stevie, you are with us always, your loving memories, our strength and guidance. Everything as you predicted, you're always right. Saving every Tuesday, our love, Susan, Bubba, Blondie, Mom, Lisi, Jason, and your family.

title: Summa Cum Laude in Math, With a Taste for Messiaen
description: You have to have intelligence to be a concert pianist. But the depth of Christopher Taylor's intelligence is intimidating. Before a rapt audience at the Miller Theater on Saturday night, Mr. Taylor, a lanky 31-year-old pianist who graduated summa cum laude in mathematics from Harvard, gave an astonishing performance of Messiaen's complete ''Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant-Jsus,'' more than two hours of some of the most complex and difficult music ever written for the piano. And he played the 176-page score from memory.

title: The Big City; If It Ain't Broke, Investigate It
description: NEW YORK'S parks were famously decrepit not long ago, but they've become one of the city's great success stories. Dust bowls have become lush green landscapes; gardens have sprung up; paths and playgrounds have been rebuilt; children are playing where drug dealers used to operate.

title: Green Favors Police Pay Rise And Tuition to Build Morale
description: Mark Green, the public advocate and a Democratic candidate for mayor, called yesterday for New York City police officers to get raises and two years of free college tuition as ways of improving deterioriating police morale. He also said the city should spend money on repairing dilapidated police station houses across New York.

title: HALIFAX TO BUY EQUITABLE
description: The Halifax Group agreed to buy the assets of Equitable Life Assurance Society for 1 billion ($1.5 billion), beating a competing offer from GE Capital. Equitable Life put itself up for sale in July after the House of Lords decided that the 239-year-old company had illegally slashed bonus payments to some customers. Equitable said in December, after efforts to sell the business outright had failed, that it would close to new business and seek a buyer. Halifax said it would pay 500 million ($734.7 million) for Equitable's assets and rename the concern Halifax Equitable, with another 500 million payment contingent upon a settlement with Equitable policyholders. Suzanne Kapner

title: CINAR POSTS LOSS
description: The Cinar Corporation, a producer of children's television programs such as Arthur, reported a loss of almost 203 million Canadian dollars ($136 million) for the 18 months ended May 31, 2000. Cinar has not issued a financial report since the end of fiscal 1998, and Ernst & Young resigned as its auditor last month. The loss includes a write-down of assets and unrecovered offshore investments of 63 million Canadian dollars ($42.1 million). The company is suing Micheline Charest and Ronal Weinberg, the husband and wife team that founded the company and still own 63 percent of its shares, for misappropriating funds. The couple has denied all allegations. Timothy Pritchard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMASHEFSKY, WILLIAM
description: TOMASHEFSKY-William. Former President of the Thomas Button Company, Inc., died Saturday, February 3. Survived by his beloved wife Rena, loving brother Lawrence. Adored uncle to his many nieces, nephews and grandnieces and grandnephews. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery in New Jersey.

description: Managing Athletes and Fashion Shows

description: To the Editor:

title: Global Warming Poses Threat
description: ST. ANTON, Austria -- In the valley here, the snow is melting in the middle of winter: Saturday's massive drifts turning into yesterday's muddy rivulets and another day of delays and frustration at the world championships. But what if it all melted? And not just this week, but for all time? What if the snow in well-established, world-renowned winter resorts like St. Anton became a casualty of global warming?

title: Reagan Will Celebrate His 90th in a Quiet World
description: He will not have much of a celebration in the secluded house on St. Cloud Road, just a quiet dinner with his wife, some chocolate cake, maybe some physical therapy. Chasen's, his favorite restaurant and the scene of birthdays past, is only a shell, with what is left of its green-shuttered, white-brick facade wrapped around a new upscale grocery store, and his favorite Tuesday special, boiled beef Belmont with matzo ball soup, is not even a memory now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADOLF, ROSALIE K.
description: ADOLF-Rosalie K. Gentle, generous and gracious lady. Devoted wife of the late Norman L. Adolf. Caring mother of Benine Adolf and Sally Laurent (Neil). Grandmother of Nate and Ben. Longtime active member of National Council of Jewish Women; volunteer at LIJ Hospital; graduate and benefactor of Hunter College; devotee of art, music and theater. Graveside services were held Monday 1:30 PM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions to National Council of Jewish Women or your favorite charity in lieu of flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARASH, ERNEST S., M.D.
description: BARASH-Ernest S., M.D. On February 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Lee (Fenichel). Devoted father of Peter, Anne, James and father-inlaw of Eric Holzwarth. Cherished grandfather to Michael Holzwarth and Steven Barash. Services Tuesday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDING, ELIZABETH BASS
description: GOLDING-Elizabeth Bass. The trustees, faculty, staff, alumni and students of New York University Law School are deeply saddened by the loss of Judge Elizabeth Bass Golding, Class of 1921. Judge Golding was a pioneer at a time when few women took up the challenge of the legal profession. Judge Golding met her husband and classmate, the late Samuel Golding, at NYU Law. He graduated first in his class and Judge Golding graduated second. We are very proud to have counted her as one of our own. Her lifelong commitment to NYU Law School is commemorated by the Golding Media Center and the Judge Elizabeth Bass Golding and Samuel Golding Student Lounge. In 1988, Judge Golding was awarded the Law School's highest honor, the Arthur T. Vanderbilt Medal. Our community is grateful for Judge Golding's years of service and her devotion to NYU. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. John Sexton, Dean NYU School of Law Lester Pollack, President NYU School of Law Foundation

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANCTUARY OF ABRAHAM AND SARAH
description: Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah Above ground Jewish burial. Affordable indoor mausoleum spaces and prime family rooms. Free brochure, call 800-526-4600.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORMAN, ETHEL
description: GORMAN-Ethel. Lovingly remembered by her children and grandchildren. Linda, Doug, Abby and Richard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, LARRY
description: FISHER-Larry. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the death of Larry Fisher, a dear friend who was greatly admired for his extraordinary generosity. A dynamic real estate magnate and beloved philanthropist, he left a legacy that will be felt for generations to come. Mr. Fisher shared his family's deep commitment to Jewish causes. He will always be remembered for his dedication to Israel and to endangered Jewish communities around the world. Through his compassion and philanthropic leadership, he helped sustain UJA-Federation's diverse network of health and human service agencies. His selfless dedicated serves as an inspiration to us all. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Kathleen; his son, Arnold; his grandchildren, Kenneth, Steven, and Karen; his great-grandchildren; and his entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSOW, ROSALYN (RAYE)
description: ROSOW-Rosalyn (Raye). On February 5, 2001. Raye is survived by her husband, Jerome, her sons, Michael and Joel, her sister, Sorrell Caplan, and five grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for 12 noon, Thursday, at the Ballard - Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. The family will greet relatives and friends before the service and at their home, 117 Fox Meadow Rd., Scarsdale, NY after the burial. Those who wish may make memorial donations to the Westchester Alzheimer's Association.

title: HACKERS STEAL DATA FROM ECONOMIC FORUM
description: Officials of the World Economic Forum, host last week to international leaders in Davos, Switzerland, said computer hackers had gained access to a database from a previous event held last year containing, among other personal details, the credit card numbers of 1,400 participants. Calling the security breach a serious crime, the forum's managing board said it had asked the Swiss authorities to help find the responsible hackers and had taken legal action to prevent the spread of any illegally procured information. This year's participants include Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader, Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general and William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman. The theft was first reported by a Swiss newspaper, Sonntags Zeitung, after hackers approached the publication with credit card details, mobile phone numbers and private addresses of some forum participants. The annual forum has been aimed at by anti-globalization protestors; the forum would not say whether it suspected those forces in the theft. Chris Gaither

description: This is a selected archive of Times coverage of the Giants' postseason road to Super Bowl XXXV.

description: JONTRY-Esther, Chadds Ford, PA, born November 16, 1913, Brooklyn; died February 5, 2001. Widow of Henry. Survived by son Richard, daughter Bonnie.

description: SWIGER-Reverend Msgr. Charles W. Pastor of St. Kilian R.C. Church, Farmingdale, on February 4, 2001. Beloved son of Elizabeth C. Swiger and the late Charles W. Swiger, Sr. Dear brother of Susan Swiger Munch and Terrence C. Swiger and brother-in-law of Roger Munch and Mary Swiger. Loving nephew of Miriam Burrowes and cherished uncle of Terrence, Erich, Siobhan and Claire Swiger. Monsignor Swiger will be reposed Tuesday, from 5-10 PM, and Wednesday, 1-5 PM, in the St. Benedict Chapel of St. Kilian's Rectory, 485 Conklin Street, Farmingdale. Mass of Transferral will be celebrated at 8 PM, Wednesday, in St. Kilian R.C. Church. Celebration of Mass of Christian Burial will be on Thursday at 11 AM. Interment will follow in Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, Queens. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to St. Kilian's Centenary Capital Campaign, appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWERSKY, DAVID, GRAND RABBI
description: TWERSKY-David, Grand Rabbi. A distinguished and respected Hasidic leader who has guided thousands with counsel and referrals on matters of medical health and domestic affairs. A scion of the royal family of Tzchernobel, he was affectionately called the Skwere Rebbe of Boro Park. He is survived by his Rebbetzin, five sons and two daughters. In keeping with sacred tradition, a funeral was held Friday, February 2 with thousands of mourners. Interment was at Beth David Cemetery just hours after death. Shiva is being observed until early Thursday morning at Congregation Khal Skwere, 1336 47 St. Brooklyn, NY.

title: In the Twilight of His Career, Messier Is Starting to Fray
description: Will Mark Messier be rested and energetic tonight against the Buffalo Sabres at Madison Square Garden? Like most of his Rangers teammates, Messier got six days off for the All-Star Game break. Only Brian Leetch and Theo Fleury represented the team in the game.

title: Q & A
description: Sense of Smell

title: Haiti's Opposition Proposes 3-Member Presidency
description: The Haitian opposition has proposed to President-elect Jean Bertrand Aristide that he be part of a three-member presidency that would lead the country to new elections in two years, diplomats and mediators involved in talks to break the nation's political impasse said today.

title: Income Down At Computer Sciences
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, the No. 3 computer-services company in the nation, said today that its profit fell because of acquisition costs in its most recent quarter.

title: WESTPOINT STEVENS LAYING OFF 125 AT 3 PLANTS
description: WestPoint Stevens, a leading maker of bedding and towels, said yesterday that it was laying off 125 people at three North Carolina sites as part of a previously announced reorganization. The layoffs will occur at two plants and a distribution center in Roanoke Rapids, N.C., The sites will still employ about 500 people, a spokeswoman, Toni Cauble, said. WestPoint Stevens, whose brands include Martex, Utica and Lady Pepperell, announced the restructuring plan in June. The company said last week that it would close a plant in Seneca, S.C., and cut 468 jobs. WestPoint Stevens has about 16,800 employees.

title: O'Neill Offers a New Approach to Japan
description: President Bush's treasury secretary described a new approach today for dealing with Japan as the world's largest and second-largest economies appear headed into decline, suggesting he would abandon Washington's constant stream of advice to the government in Tokyo and try working directly with Japanese executives he came to know while running Alcoa.

title: Contralto Perks Up A Baroque Program
description: During the cold war, when Russian ensembles were tantalizingly out of reach except through recordings and occasional tours, the Moscow Chamber Orchestra enjoyed something of a cult status among record collectors. In recordings conducted by Rudolph Barshai, who founded it in 1956, the orchestra had a rich, focused sound with a particularly Russian edge that made it ideal for Shostakovich and appealingly exotic in the Germanic classics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREAMER, MARGARET
description: CREAMER-Margaret. Of Tuckahoe, NY, seventy-five, February 5, 2001. Dear wife of Robert W. Creamer. Beloved mother of James, Thomas, John, Ellen Sitron and Robert. For funeral information phone Fred H. McGrath & Son, Bronxville, NY, 914-337-6770.

title: Injury Ends Abrosimova's UConn Career
description: In a blow to third-ranked Connecticut's hopes of repeating as the women's national champion, Svetlana Abrosimova, the Huskies' all-American forward and best player, has been lost for the remainder of her senior season because of a torn ligament in her left foot.

title: Tunnel Vision; A Die-Hard Few Cling to Those Tokens
description: They are creatures of habit. They remember better days gone by. They don't trust technology. They frustrate economic theorists, refusing to change their behavior in exchange for a bargain.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Giants Sure of Keeping Stars
description: In the next two weeks, the Giants will probably give Coach Jim Fassel a four-year contract extension and sign their two most prominent and valuable free agents, running back Tiki Barber and cornerback Jason Sehorn. As significant as these transactions are to the team, it is a measure of how harmonious the negotiations are expected to be that there appears to be little urgency to rush into the talks.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Venture
description: Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. plans to form a venture with two former J. P. Morgan & Company executives that will help companies, government agencies and individuals use derivatives.

title: Europe Is One -- Until Disaster Strikes
description: There are two versions of what is happening in Europe. One asserts that things couldn't be going better for the European Union. The Germans are in the driver's seat, confidently leading everyone else (including the reluctant French) toward a larger, more integrated community. The German foreign minister is bursting with ambitious projects for a European presidency and a European constitution. Productivity is up, unemployment down. Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, can hardly contain his satisfaction at the prospect of a recession in the United States and the resurgence of the euro. The hour of Europe has struck. We are the masters now!

title: HARMONIC TO CUT 100 JOBS
description: Harmonic, a maker of equipment used to provide Internet service over cable television lines, said it would cut 100 jobs, or about 10 percent of its work force, to reduce costs. The company, in a press release distributed by the Business Wire service, said it expected the cuts to result in an $800,000 charge in the first quarter. Company officials could not immediately be reached for comment. The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company said in the statement that it was cutting costs because some of its major customers had slowed spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, MURIEL (DOTTIE) MEISELMAN
description: HANDLER - Muriel (Dottie) Meiselman, 81, of Boca Raton, FL. Passed away Sunday, February 4, 2001. Predeceased by her first husband, Sanford Meiselman. Beloved wife of Abraham Handler, cherished mother of Jay and Kenneth Meiselman and Mark Phillips, loving grandmother of six, dear sister of Florence Weinrib. Services were held in Florida. Contributions may be made to Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton or the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, BERTHA
description: HARTMAN-Bertha. Formerly of New York City, died peacefully in her sleep in Vancouver, Canada on January 31, 2001 at age 85. Bertha balanced her joy and involvement with her family with an active dedication to social progress. All who knew her through her many years of teaching and political activism were touched by her astute intellect and deep humanity. She is survived by her children: Matt Hartman, Neil Hartman, and Joanne Bullington; by her grandsons Eric Hartman, Sven Hartman, and Thomas Hartman, and by her great grandson Elias Hartman.

title: Metro Business Briefing; VICE DEAN LEAVING
description: Avijit Ghosh, vice dean for professional programs at the Stern School of Business at New York University, has agreed to become dean at the University of Illinois College of Commerce and Business Administration. The appointment will be reviewed by the University of Illinois' board of trustees in March. If he is approved, Dr. Ghosh will assume his new duties Aug. 21. Dr. Ghosh, one of four vice deans at Stern, joined Stern as a professor in the department of marketing in 1980. He joined the dean's office in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLARUSSO, PAULINE E. (NEE OCHNER)
description: COLARUSSO-Pauline E. (nee Ochner). On Sunday, Feb. 4, 2001. Of Short Hills NJ. Wife of the late Sam A. Colarusso. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Friends may attend the Funeral Mass at St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, Wednesday, February 7 at 10AM. Visitation at Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Avenue, Summit, 2-4 and 7-9PM on Tuesday. Entombment in Gate of Heaven Chapel Mausoleum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, GEORGE J.
description: AMES-George J. Financier and philanthropist, died on Friday, February 2, 2001, at his home in Rye, NY. He was 83 years old. Mr. Ames was a Limited Managing Director of Lazard Freres and Company, LLC. Surviving are his wife Bess R. Ames of Rye, NY, four daughters, Ruth A. Solie of Northampton, MA, Joan A. Berkowitz of Guilford, CT, Margery E. Ames of NYC, and Dorothy A. Cummings of Skillman, NJ, his step-children Paula S. Butler and Charles David Sammons of Rye, NY, a sister Dorothy Demers of Austin, TX, and seven grandchildren, John Solie, Jonathan and Rachel Berkowitz, and Michael, Kristin, Dillon and Quinlan Cummings. He was predeceased by his first wife Marion Patterson Ames and his brother Raymond Ames. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY, on Wednesday, February 7, at 10 AM. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY, on Monday, February 5, from 7-9 PM, Tuesday, February 6, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Burial will be at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be sent to the Hartley House with which he was associated since childhood; Hartley House, 413 W. 46th St., NYC 10036.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSTER, HARRY D. III
description: FORSTER-Harry D. III. Died on Friday, February 2nd, at age 42. Beloved son of Bette of Tamarac, FL, and Harry D. II of North Miami. Husband of Grace (Simonetti) of NYC. Brother of Gregg of Belmar, NJ, and uncle of Kylie. Memorial service at the Chapel at St. George's, 16th St. and Rutherford Pl., Tuesday, February 6, noon.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Wants To Stay With the Isles
description: Goaltender John Vanbiesbrouck has told General Manager Mike Milbury that he would like to stay with the Islanders through at least the rest of this season, the team announced yesterday.

title: Shots Are Reported Fired Outside the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Shots were fired outside the White House today after a potential intruder approached the southwest gate before noon and was challenged by security guards.

Quality of the game? In a league that encourages a player to run onto the field with He Hate Me on the back of his jersey instead of a name?

title: Suspect Admits Helping Make Embassy Bomb
description: A lawyer for a defendant who could face execution in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Tanzania acknowledged yesterday for the first time that his client was involved in making the bomb.

title: Norwegian Cruise Line Sale
description: Look past the bad pun, and Norwegian Cruise Line's Sale of All Sails makes sense. Book before March 31 and receive a two-category upgrade on any cruise. Seven-day Alaska cruises start at $799 a person, double occupancy; three-day Caribbean jaunts start at $269, and 12-day European voyages start at $1,899; all fares are without air fare and are subject to availability. Also, on selected sailings, added bonuses will include savings of 50 percent or more, four-category upgrades and a $400 credit toward shipboard purchases per stateroom. Details: (800) 327-7030 or www.ncl.com .

title: At Risk: In Matters of the Heart, Family Counts
description: Researchers who examined the arteries of people whose parents or siblings had heart disease found that half showed early signs of arteriosclerosis, according to a study published last week in the journal Circulation.

title: J. BAKER MOVES TO CHANGE NAME TO CASUAL MALE
description: J. Baker Inc. said yesterday that it was asking shareholders to vote to change the company's name after completing the sale of its footwear business to Footstar for $59 million. Shareholders will vote whether to change the company's name to the Casual Male Corporation at a meeting on Feb. 26, said J. Baker's chief financial officer, Elizabeth White. The sale of the shoe business was completed Feb. 3. Footstar, based in Mahwah, N.J., bought J. Baker's 1,163 footwear departments in stores run by retailers. The company, based in Canton, Mass., will now sell only apparel at its stores.

title: Victims' Relatives Remember and Wait
description: Wind whistled through the Old Federal Courthouse in Lower Manhattan yesterday. There was a driving winter storm outside, and the plaintive howl it made was eerie accompaniment to the start of the embassy bombings trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSTMANN, NICHOLAS C.
description: FORSTMANN-Nicholas C. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the untimely passing of a courageous and loving man. We were blessed to have been touched by his dignity, wisdom and playful charm. A caring mentor and true friend who met life with optimism, kindness and generosity. Our prayers are with Lana and the entire family. The beauty of Nick's memory and legacy live within everyone touched by his love. Dolores, Curtis, and Sydney Hofhine

description: CHERNICK-Hannah. Daughter of the late Morris & Pauline. Sister of the late Nathaniel. Beloved cousin of the Bandel & Chernick families. Treasured friend. Graveside services were held February 4, 2001. For more details contact Plaza Memorial Chapel 212-769-4400.

title: Corrections

Ms. Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, is a political science professor and a former provost at Stanford but not an alumna; she graduated from the University of Denver.

description: RABINOF-Sylvia. Concert pianist, composer specializing in classical improvisation, teacher (pre college division at Juilliard, Brevard Music Center, Round Top, and Converse College), 87, died on January 20 in Florida. Beloved wife of the late Benno Rabinof, a concert violinist with whom Sylvia toured the world for over thirty years performing works for violin and piano, and the late Charles Rothenberg. New York memorial service at a later date-to be announced.

title: The Embassy Bombings Trial
description: The terrorism trial that opened yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan presents an extraordinary challenge to the impartial administration of justice in the United States. The four defendants are accused of participating in a homicidal conspiracy of terror against the United States during much of the last decade, including the 1998 bombing of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. Because the attacks were so repugnant, and the defendants are foreign-born, the prosecutors and the court bear a special obligation to insure that the case is handled fairly and in full compliance with the rights that must be accorded to every defendant in a criminal case.

title: Disney Earnings Slump Amid Internet Group Losses
description: Burdened by mounting losses from its Internet division, which it decided last month to scale back sharply, the Walt Disney Company said today that its net income fell sharply in its first fiscal quarter.

title: Biotech Food
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Set to Deliver Station's Scientific Core
description: One of the most critical chapters in the young history of the International Space Station begins on Wednesday, when the space shuttle Atlantis is to lift off bearing the station's scientific centerpiece.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLAR, ANITA E.
description: SKLAR-Anita E. Beloved wife of Bernard. Devoted mother of Diane & Steven. Dear sister of Dr. Norman Lichtenstein. Cherished grandmother of Darci, Benjamin and David. Services today 1 PM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Patterns: A Sex Difference for Asthma Patients
description: Among high-risk asthma patients, women were admitted to the hospital twice as often as men and stayed longer, even though blood tests indicated that their attacks were actually less severe, according to a new Yale study.

title: Man in the News: Ariel Sharon: Hawk, Commander and Finally, Prime Minister
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 - Throughout his long military and political career, Ariel Sharon has been nothing if not tenacious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASCHKIN, BERNARD BORIS
description: BASCHKIN-Bernard Boris. Of Rye, died February 5, 2001. Age 73. Born December 31, 1927 in Berlin, Germany to Esay and Anna Poliakoff Baschkin. Immigrated to New York in Spring 1939. Graduated Syracuse University 1952. On August 7, 1955 he married his beloved and adored Millicent (nee d. Auerbach). Served the U.S. Coast Guard, member Rotary Club of Harrison, past President of the Scarsdale Synagogue/Tremont Temple, founder and President of InterDok Corp. In addition to his wife Millicent he is survived by his daughter Karen-Anne Paul, son Laurance, son-in-law Stephen W. Paul, cherished granddaughter Hannah Suzanne, loving sister Sophie Stein. Funeral service Thursday 11:30 AM at the Scarsdale Synagogue/Tremont Temple, 2 Ogden Road in Scarsdale. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Scarsdale Synagogue/Tremont Temple, Mount Sinai Hospital Renal Department CAPD Unit (Attn: Dr. Jamie Uribarri or Mt. Sinai Cardiac Research Department (Attn: Dr. Jonathan Halperin).

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Bush Stalling Bipartisan Bill On Rights Of Patients
description: President Bush, who campaigned on a promise to bring Republicans and Democrats together on legislation defining patients' rights, raised objections today to the major bipartisan bill addressing the issue in Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENGLER, SILAS
description: SPENGLER-Silas. We note with sadness the passing of Silas Spengler, a true gentleman, a superb lawyer, and a devoted and loyal partner and friend. Leonard Gubar, Gregory Katz, William McSherry, Howard Jacobs, Thomas Sear, Richard Swanson, Mary Fleur, and Steven Wasserman on behalf of the partners, assoccates and staff of the former Spengler Carlson law firm

title: After Election, Clinton and Gore Had Tense Discussion on Blame
description: Days after Al Gore conceded on Dec. 13, he and Bill Clinton had what aides described today as a tense and forthright White House conversation about what went wrong in the presidential campaign and who was to blame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFEN, LOUIS
description: GEFFEN-Louis. U.S. Army Honor Guard carried the flag draped coffin of Louis Geffen, WWII prosecutor of Japanese war criminals, to his grave next to his parents, Rabbi and Mrs. Tobias Geffen. Three volleys fired and taps sounded. Died on January 23, 2001 at 96 in Atlanta, Georgia; devoted husband of Anna Birshtein for 66 years; father of Rita and David; grandfather of Avie, Elissa and Chemi, Keren and Tuvia Jeremy, great-grandfather of Ori, Lyron, Eden and Daniel. B.A. Emory with honors, 1923; description of his college experience in ''Jewish American Family Album.'' J.D. Columbia University Law School 1927. In 1967 he translated the important responsum written by Rabbi Tobias Geffen ''Is Coca-Cola kosher and kosher for Passover?''. Translation appears in ''Lev Tuviah.'' The Geffen Family Papers, donated by Louis and Anna Geffen, are in Special Collections, Woodruff Library, Emory University, and number over 15,000 items and objects. A devoted son, knowledgeable and observant Jew, excellent attorney, American Patriot and a true Southern gentleman.

title: Metro Business Briefing; STATE'S CREDIT RATING RAISED
description: Moody's Investors Service has raised the credit rating on $16.8 billion worth of debt sold by New York State agencies to finance transportation, student housing and environmental projects. Moody's raised its rating to A3 from Baa1 on almost half of the $38 billion of debt the state has outstanding. The credit rating company cited the state's financial strength for its decision to raise the rating one notch. Robert Kurtter, a senior vice president at Moody's, said New York is the latest state to benefit from Moody's decision to award higher ratings for state agencies' debt.

title: On Campus, Free Fast Internet Access Is No Longer a Given
description: When today's high-school graduates arrive on college campuses, they expect that their new dorm rooms will come with ultra-fast Internet connections. And they expect to be able to use that access as they please, even if that means clogging the campus network with pirated music files.

title: Music and the Macabre With Spellbinding Power
description: The New York City Ballet offered two mysteriously beautiful ballets by George Balanchine on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDBERG, ANN
description: FREEDBERG-Ann. A remarkable woman who indelibly touched the lives of those she met. Loved by her children, David and Karen, and her grandchildren, Andrew and Elissa. Gifts in her memory may be made to The Mount Sinai Visiting Doctors Program, in care of Dr. David Muller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, RUTH
description: WAGNER-Ruth. Beloved mother of Barbara Ordover, Aileen Nathan, Joan Smith. Honored friend and mother-in-law of Buddy Ordover, and Jack Nathan. Loving grandmother of Mark Ordover, Susan and Peter Weiss, Susan and Ed Vidal, Richard and Dana Smith, John Smith. Great-grandmother of Melissa, Loren, Emily, Matthew, Joshua, Noah, Joshua and Errin. 98 years old. Feisty, alive, on her game to the end. Graveside service on Thursday, February 8, 11 AM at Knollwood Park Cemetery, 57-80 Cooper Ave, Ridgewood, N.Y. Donations to William Breman Jewish Home, 3150 Howell Mill Road, Atlanta, GA. 30327.

title: A New Leader for Israel
description: Ariel Sharon's decisive electoral victory yesterday marks a sharp turn in Israeli policies. Just 21 months after voting in Ehud Barak, who promised to accelerate peace negotiations with the Palestinians and Syria, Israeli voters have chosen one of the country's most unyielding politicians as prime minister. Mr. Sharon will now need to show that he can combine his customary toughness with enough flexibility to avoid aggravating an already combustible situation in Israel and across the Middle East. In a conciliatory move last night, Mr. Sharon renewed his invitation to Mr. Barak's Labor party to join him in a broad national unity government. Labor should accept.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about the opening of Tamarind, a Manhattan restaurant owned by Avtar Walia, misstated his role in another restaurant, Dawat. He is a partner with Sushil Malhotra, not the sole owner.

title: Once a Wendy's, Now a Desolate Reminder of a Massacre
description: ''UR 2 Good 2B 4gotten,'' someone has scribbled on the plywood stripped across the front door. Another message promises, ''I'll never forget you guys.'' There is also a drawing of a small heart with the inscription, ''Rest in peace.''

title: Bucking U.S. Officialdom To Shelter Wartime Jews
description: Television series about the Holocaust have been rare. The handful of acclaimed ones, like ''Holocaust'' and ''War and Remembrance,'' have dealt only marginally with what some historians call the United States' wartime indifference to the slaughter of millions of Jews. ''Haven'' does not shy away from the issue.

title: SHARON EASILY OUSTS BARAK TO BECOME ISRAEL'S PREMIER; CALLS FOR A RECONCILIATION
description: Ariel Sharon, a burly 72-year-old hawk who heads a newly reinvigorated right wing, rode a wave of national anxiety to an overwhelming electoral victory on Tuesday as Israel's fifth prime minister in more than five years.

title: Barnesandnoble.com to Cut 350 Jobs as Its Loss Widens
description: Barnesandnoble.com Inc., the No. 2 Web-based bookseller after Amazon.com, announced today that it would eliminate about 350 jobs in an effort to cut costs.

description: Adapted from "The L. L. Bean Book of New New England Cookery" by Judith and Evan Jones (Random House, 1987)

Bisconti. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 24 and 7-9PM Wednesday and Thursday. description: Larry Fisher, the last of the founding Fisher Brothers, a real estate dynasty that did much to reshape the Manhattan skyline, died on Sunday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 93 and also lived in Manhattan.
