title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about changes in the ecology of Monterey Bay in California misspelled the name of the author of ''Between Pacific Tides.'' He was Joel W. Hedgpeth, not Redpath.

title: White House Reaches Out To Both Sides In Peace Talks
description: The Bush administration, which had been expecting the victory of Ariel Sharon, dispatched immediate messages today calling for calm in the Middle East and reassuring Israel that its relationship with the United States remained ''rock solid.''

title: VERIZON PLANS NETWORK EXPANSION
description: Verizon Communications Inc. intends to announce a $1 billion plan today to expand its international communications network in Asia, Europe and Latin America. Verizon, the nation's biggest local phone carrier and the dominant local communications company in the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic region, wants to expand its overseas presence mainly to serve the communications needs of multinational corporations. To expand its network, Verizon intends to announce that it will work with partners including FLAG Telecom Ltd. and Metromedia Fiber Network Inc. A Verizon spokesman said the company would spend $1 billion over the next five years on the new plan. Seth Schiesel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, GEORGE
description: AMES-George. The Camp Rising Sun community mourns the passing of a cherished friend. George was our first camper and went on to serve as music counselor, camp director, and then Director, President and Chairman of the Louis August Jonas Foundation. We will miss his guiding spirit, wise counsel, and generous heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, LAURENCE WARNER, JR.
description: CLARKE-Laurence Warner, Jr. Age 77, of Greenwich, CT and Ocean Ridge, FL, died peacefully on February 3, 2001. He was a graduate of Philips Exeter Academy and Yale University. He was a former member of the New York Stock Exchange. He is survived by his wife, Helen, 2 sons Langdon and Laurence III, 2 daughters Frances Rourke and Helen Gonzalez, and 8 grandchildren. A private service will be held on Saturday, February 10th. Donations in his memory to Nathaniel Witherell Nursing Home, 70 Parsonage Rd., Greenwich, CT. 06830, would be greatly appreciated by his family to honor this gentle, loving man.

title: Business Travel; Sales on online corporate booking systems are seen growing eightfold, to $33 billion, by 2005.
description: VIRTUALLY unknown a few years ago, online corporate booking systems have suddenly become the fastest-growing segment of the Internet commerce travel market.

title: Productivity Growth Slows to 2.4% Rate
description: Earning higher wages but putting in fewer hours, American workers increased their productivity at a higher-than-expected annual rate of 2.4 percent in the last three months of 2000, the government reported today.

description: MARKS-Sondra Dorothy Kahan. Died on February 5, 2001. She is survived by her loving friends and family; her daughter Leslie, her sister Alice, and her brothers Leo and David. ''The dead will always be with us.'' Services Thursday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76 Street.

description: BRANDES-Joseph. On February 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Norma; adoring father of Frieda, Adine, Wendy, Joel and John; adored Papa of Sam, Steven, Max and Emma; devoted uncle of Gary, Brad, Ricki and Steven; beloved brother-in-law of Dorothy; and beloved brother of Malvina and Irwin. description: A huge trove of photographs that depict half a century of black American life is about to go on view here, giving a vivid face to communities seldom explored by outsiders.

title: Bush Administration Holds to Clinton Budget for Pentagon Spending in 2002
description: President Bush has told top military officials that he plans to propose a Pentagon budget for the coming fiscal year that is essentially unchanged from the long-term spending plan outlined last year by his Democratic predecessor, Bill Clinton, senior Pentagon officials said today.

description: AS a gin drinker, I always thought all vodkas were essentially the same. I was wrong.

title: Lands Without Plenty: Images of Asia
description: IF a Big Mac tells only part of the story of eating in America -- where hunting, gathering and cultivating food means logging on to the Internet, ordering overpriced takeout or strolling through the neighborhood singles' supermarket -- the food of India, China, Vietnam and Nepal tells a more complicated tale. When there are 3.6 billion fellow Asians clamoring for lunch, everyone had better work.

title: New F.C.C. Chief Would Curb Agency Reach
description: Signaling a marked departure from his Clinton administration predecessors, the new Republican-appointed chairman of the Federal Communications Commission voiced skepticism today about a wide array of regulations affecting broadcasters, telephone companies, cable operators and Internet service providers.

title: German Company Bolsters Offer for a Spanish Utility
description: A lengthy battle for the Spanish utility company Hidroelctrico del Cantbrico appears to be drawing to a close as Germany's biggest power company trumped two rival offers today with a sweetened $2.7 billion offer.

title: Graduation Rule Adjusted for Vocational Students
description: The New York State Board of Regents yesterday gently modified its graduation requirements for vocational students by giving them more flexibility in the kind of courses they may take to meet the state's higher academic standards.

title: Wachovia Bank Weighs Sale Of Its Credit Card Business
description: The Wachovia Corporation said yesterday that it might join a growing list of banks getting out of the credit card business, rather than compete with companies spending heavily to woo fickle consumers with promotions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERTZER, FLORENCE
description: SCHERTZER-Florence. On February 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Bert Hart. Adoring mother of Elaine and Joel Burzin, and Diane Susan and Craig Sim. Devoted grandmother to Brandon, Stephanie, Beth and Jill. A courageous, warm and gracious woman. A good friend to all who knew her. She will always be remembered and sorely missed by everyone. Funeral services at 1PM today at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Nets Not About to Pick Apart Victory
description: Stephon Marbury was positively jovial in the locker room after tonight's game. He was joking with teammates as he dressed and explaining which rap artists were the best even to reporters generations removed from the music. But the words evaporated to a precious few when he was asked to describe what had happened in the just completed game.

title: HCA Net Income Drops 77%
description: HCA-The Healthcare Company, the nation's largest hospital chain, posted a sharp drop in fourth-quarter net income today because of the effects of a federal inquiry into Medicare fraud.

description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that net income fell in its fiscal first quarter but operating income rose as profits from hit films and theme parks more than offset soft advertising revenue at its ABC and cable television networks and weaker sales at Disney stores.

title: Fighting Sleep on the Job? Join the Crowd
description: One-third of adults got less than six and a half hours of sleep a day during the workweek last year, far below the eight hours recommended by experts, according to the National Sleep Foundation. And --surprise -- one-third of adults suffered from significant daytime drowsiness.

title: DABHOL, ENRON UNIT IN INDIA, INVOKES PAYMENT GUARANTEE
description: The Dabhol Power Company, the Indian subsidiary of the Enron Corporation, said yesterday that it was invoking an Indian government guarantee to cover bills for electricity totaling $50 million. Dabhol made the request after the Maharashtra State Electricity Board failed to make the payments. The bills include electricity provided in November and December. Under an agreement with Enron, the governments of the Maharashtra state and India have guaranteed they will pay Enron if the state utility defaults. P. J. Anthony

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: An Opportunity Knocks for Trump

title: HAVAS BUYING CIRCLE.COM
description: Havas Advertising in Paris agreed yesterday to buy the 83 percent of the tracking stock of Circle.com that it did not already own for stock worth about $28.4 million. The purchase values Circle.com. at about $1.27 a share, compared with the Circle.com price of 66 cents a share before the deal was announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANHEIM, JEAN (NEE LITIN)
description: MANHEIM-Jean (nee Litin). Of Margate, FL, formerly of Hillside, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Isidore. Devoted mother of Rhoda Pauley, Michael and the late Marvin Manheim. Also survived by five granddaughters. Funeral services at Temple Neve Shalom, 250 Grove Ave., Metuchen, NJ on Wednesday, February 7 at 10:00 AM. Interment JEC Cemetery, McClellan Street, Newark, NJ. Information: Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, NJ.

title: Executive Changes At 3 Agencies
description: There are changes involving top executives at three agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, LOUIS M.
description: BARNETT-Louis M. Beloved husband of the late Estelle. Devoted father of Barbara Barnett and the late Ruth Barnett Petrakos. Loving grandfather of Avra and Marina and other friends close to his heart. Service will be held privately.

title: MORE CASH FOR LETSBUYIT
description: LetsBuyIt.com N.V., an unprofitable Internet retailer, said it raised 52 million euros, allowing it to stay in business. In December, the company averted bankruptcy when it raised 4 million euros from Kimvestor A.G., a German company. Now, unidentified investors have provided an additional 48 million euros, including 20 million immediately and the balance over a year. Suzanne Kapner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSTMANN, NICHOLAS C.
description: FORSTMANN-Nicholas C. The Cancer Research Fund expresses its profound sorrow to the Forstmann family. Nicholas Forstmann was not only a brilliant businessman, but an important philanthropist. His impact was great on the field of cancer research and his legacy will help the lives of future generations. Dale F. Frey, Chairman Cancer Research Fund of the Damon Runyon-Walter Winchell Foundation

title: Democrats' Anger, And Its Causes
description: To the Editor:

title: Thruway Authority Pledges to Seek Public Opinion on Tappan Zee Bridge's Fate
description: Promising a Web site, e-mail bulletins and dozens of public hearings, the New York State Thruway Authority vowed today to aggressively seek public opinion before deciding whether to rebuild the aging Tappan Zee Bridge or construct another bridge across the Hudson River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEREN, ARTHUR TEWES STIEREN
description: STIEREN-Arthur Tewes Stieren, Jr. passed away on Sunday, February 4, 2001 at the age of 71. The cause of death was lung cancer. He was born in San Antonio, Texas on October 24, 1929 to Arthur Tewes Stieren and Elizabeth Huth. He attended Alamo Heights schools and graduated from Culver Military Academy in 1946 and from Yale University in 1950. He entered the Harvard Business School in 1950, but his education was delayed by serving in the U.S. Army Field Artillery for two years. He served in this country and in Korea. He was honorably discharged a First Lieutenant in 1953. After returning to the Harvard Business School, he was awarded a Masters of Business Administration in 1954. He is survived by his wife, Jane and daughters, Lisa Cox, Wendy Wirth, Kelly Daniell, Amy Burgess, by his son, George L. Stieren, and numerous grandchildren. He is survived also by a sister, Betty Kelso. He was a Trustee of Trinity University, San Antonio, and was active in the McNay Art Museum, the Santa Fe Opera and the Metropolitan Opera. A Memorial Service at Parker Chapel, Trinity University, is planned for Monday, February 12, 2001 at 4:00 P.M. Contributions are welcome to the institutions named above, as well as to the charity of choice. Services with Porter Loring Mortuary, 1101 McCullough, San Antonio, Texas, 210-227-8221.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSH, EVA M., DR.
description: HIRSH-Eva M., Dr. Of Norwalk, CT. Born Freiburg, Germany, in 1928, married Dr. Joseph Hirsh in 1962. BA, from Bryn Mawr College, MA, Ph.D., from New York University. Professor of physiology & pharmacology at New York Medical College from 1975 to 1994. Lecturer, Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine, antique collector and dealer, a Member of The American Ceramic Circle, National American Glass Club, Westchester Glass Club, Connecticut Ceramic Circle, died February 1, 2001, at home. Survived by Lisa Hirsh, of Boston, MA, and Donna Hirsh Geller, of London. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday February 10, 2001 at 11 A.M. at The Collins Funeral Home, Norwalk, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to: Connecticut Hospice Inc, 30 Stevens St, Suite D, Norwalk, CT 06850.

title: YankeeNets in a Soccer Deal
description: The Yankees and Manchester United are sports kin. Each is a storied and wealthy franchise. The Yankees have won three of the last four World Series, Manchester United six of the past eight English Premier League soccer titles.

title: Article 2001020791150942418 -- No Title
description: STATE OF THE ART

title: Taliban Seem to Be Making Good on Opium Ban, U.N. Says
description: Initial results from a survey of opium-growing areas of Afghanistan in recent days indicate that the Taliban may have succeeded in sharply reducing the annual poppy crop, astonished United Nations narcotics-control officials say.

title: Metro Business Briefing; BUILDING BOUGHT ON EXCHANGE SITE
description: City and state officials signed an agreement with the Rockrose Development Corporation on Friday to buy a 28-story apartment house at 45 Wall Street, one of five buildings on the development site for a new billion-dollar trading complex for the New York Stock Exchange. The city will pay Rockrose about $160 million, according to real estate executives, and provide a relocation package for the residents living in the building's 435 apartments. The tenants were notified Monday night that they could obtain stipends worth as much as $15,000 to cover moving expenses and broker fees. City officials are continuing to negotiate with J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, which controls four other buildings on the site bounded by Exchange Place and Broad, Wall and William Streets. The total land costs for the project are expected to be more than $400 million. City and state officials have also agreed to give the exchange $480 million in cash and $160 million in tax breaks for the new 10-story trading complex. Charles V. Bagli

title: California Narrowly Averts Power Cutoff
description: A federal judge in Sacramento ordered a major electricity supplier tonight to keep selling power to California, despite the scheduled midnight expiration of a federal order requiring suppliers to do so. The judge's ruling averted a possible cutoff of current that power officials feared might have led to another round of rolling blackouts on Wednesday.

title: Coming of Age, Noisily, in Greenwich Village
description: I REGRETTED the loss of Indigo, the unpretentious neighborhood restaurant in Greenwich Village that offered an unusual combination of sophisticated food at moderate prices in a calm, grown-up atmosphere. It closed last summer, when Scott Bryan, its executive chef, who was also an owner, decided to concentrate on Veritas, his high-end restaurant farther uptown.

title: Glover's Vanished Game Reflects St. John's Struggles
description: Anthony Glover has been a mainstay at St. John's for two seasons. He had started 52 straight games at forward until this week, and he had overseen the Red Storm's transition from a veteran team built around point guard Erick Barkley last season to a team revolving around freshmen this season.

title: Warrior Who Confounds -- Ariel Sharon
description: When Ariel Sharon was appointed foreign minister by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu two and a half years ago, the promotion was viewed as a last hurrah for a military and political veteran whose career had been declared dead.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Support Mixed With Concern Among U.S. Jewish Groups
description: American Jewish groups applauded the victory of Ariel Sharon yesterday, and his brand of rough realism, but some expressed the fear that he might extend his reputation as one of the region's harshest men.

title: His Rear-View Mirror Reflects Big Business
description: Lloyd D. Ward, the former chief executive of the Maytag Corporation, is sitting in a cramped office here, talking about how he is going to make a household name out of a company most people have never heard of.

title: Slowing Economy Forces Governors to Trim Budgets
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 7  With a swiftness that has taken many governors by surprise, the slowing economy has sharply reduced state tax revenues in the last few weeks, forcing a growing number of states around the South and Midwest to cut their budgets for the first time in a decade.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about frustrations in the investigation of the bombing of the destroyer Cole in Yemen misstated the date of a comment from Barbara K. Bodine, the American ambassador, to the Yemeni Army's newspaper that ''it will take a long time to find the local people behind the attack.'' The comment was made recently, not on Sept. 26. (Sept. 26 is the newspaper name, in tribute to the date of the 1962 revolution that overthrew the monarchy.)

title: Yes, 28 Homers Are Nice; A Healthy Son Is Better
description: Jorge Posada ambled into the Yankee clubhouse every day last summer, a place that some players have described as a sanctuary. Leave your problems at home. Come here, play baseball, do what you do best and, for a few hours, troubles disappear. But there were no sanctuaries for Posada last season. How do you find a moment of solitude when your son has a brain ailment that is seven syllables long?

title: Japanese Slim Vs. the German Heavyweights
description: NO matter how deeply and wildly American chefs have delved into fusion cooking, they have kept a strong grip on knives rooted in European traditions. Heavy, sturdy German knives from makers like Wsthof-Trident and F. Dick, the kind they learned to slice and dice with in cooking school, are what they tended to reach for no matter how their cooking has evolved.

title: California Energy Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Armed Man Shot and Wounded Outside White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- An armed man was shot and wounded near a fence around the White House today after a tense standoff in which he waved a handgun and refused to surrender.

title: VOTER.COM FOLDS ITS TENT
description: Voter.com, an all-politics Web site that achieved some prominence during the 2000 presidential campaign, is shutting down. The site featured discussions of political issues, links to sites with information on campaign spending and opinion columns. Voter.com was started in 1999, and interest in the site spiked during the political conventions last year.

title: The Taxes Before Death, and After
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILIP, PATRICIA A. (NEE JARIS)
description: FILIP-Patricia A. (nee Jaris) of Cockeysville, MD on February 3, 2001. Beloved daughter of Ann and Joseph Jaris. Sister of Richard and William Jaris. Cherished aunt to Hannah, Lisa, Maggie, Liam and Danny. Niece of Lillian Lipchuck. Family will receive friends at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Thursday, 7-9PM, Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10AM, at the Immaculate Conception Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Maryland Chapter of the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 8600 LaSalle Road, Suite 314, Chester Building, Towson, MD. 21286.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOCK, SARA MARGARET KURR
description: ZOCK-Sara Margaret Kurr (private philanthropist), died in her Sea Girt, New Jersey home on January 31, 2001 after a very brief illness. She had celebrated her 97th birthday on January 19th. She was born in Bethel, Pennsylvania in 1904. She taught first to third grades in a one-room schoolhouse in Berks County, PA. After graduating from Teachers College at Columbia University, NY in 1928, she taught in the Pelham and Geneseo, NY school districts. After her marriage to Joseph A. Zock, an investment banker, she moved to New York City where she worked with her husband for many years. She became a permanent resident of Sea Girt, NJ in 1965. She and her husband were two of the oldest members of the New York Stock Exchange. She was an active member of the Sea Girt Women's Club. During her fifty plus years of marriage, she and her late husband were very private donors to a wide variety of charitable causes and community betterment projects. She and her husband traveled the world extensively, whenever possible by ocean liner. They enjoyed many round the world cruises. She became an accomplished artist in her 70's. She read her beloved Wall Street Journal every day until three weeks before her death. After Joseph A. Zock's death in 1986, she increased her private philanthropic activities. She was the driving force and principal, but anonymous, benefactor in establishing the Sea Girt Public Library in 1991. It was not until her 95th birthday in 1999 that she allowed the town to honor her generosity. She has quietly and anonymously assisted the Tulpehocken, PA area school districts in educating many deserving students and contributed to school improvement projects. She also privately helped many less fortunate individuals throughout Monmouth County, NJ. Through the charitable trusts and private foundations created by Mrs. Zock and her late husband, significant annual contributions have been made to many and varied charities, educational institutions and local government projects. Besides her husband, Joseph A. Zock, she is predeceased by her sister, Mary Kurr Roberge. She is survived by a nephew, Dr. James K. Roberge, Lexington, MA, a grand-niece, Dr. Ann Roberge Cheal and grand-nephew, James D. Roberge and five great-grand nephews. She is also survived by her longtime friend, advisor and confidant, John H. Rogicki of Holmdel, NJ. A memorial service will be held at 11:30AM on February 21, 2001 at O'Brien's Funeral Home, Route 35, Wall, New Jersey with a luncheon to follow at her favorite restaurant, The Old Mill Inn. An additional memorial service will be held in Bethel, PA on a date and time to be announced shortly. Mrs. Zock's three favorite public charities were: American Cancer Society (Monmouth County Chapter, 801 Broad St., Shrewsbury, NJ); the American Heart Association (New Jersey Chapter, 2550 US Route 1, N. Brunswick, NJ); and the Salvation Army (Asbury Park Chapter, 605 Asbury Ave., Asbury Park, NJ). Donations in her memory can be made to the local chapters listed above. O'Brien Funeral Home, Wall, New Jersey, for further information

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Gold prices dropped after Harmony Gold Mining said it might join other South African producers in selling borrowed gold. In New York, gold for April delivery fell $2, or 0.7 percent, to $265.40.

title: Devils Score in a Flurry And Now Lead the East
description: The break for the All-Star Game apparently did the Devils a lot of good. After losing to the Islanders in a lackadaisical performance in the final game before the break, they left nothing to chance against the Montreal Canadiens tonight at the Molson Center.

title: Electrician Awarded $50 Million for Injuries in Switch Explosion
description: An electrician was finishing work on an electrical switchboard at William Paterson University in 1996 when two live wires connected and the device exploded into a ball of flames, lifting him off his feet, throwing him across the room and leaving him near death.

title: The Taxes Before Death, and After
description: To the Editor:

title: DaimlerChrysler Pledges to Pay Dividend Despite Mounting Losses
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 7  Although huge losses at its Chrysler division have brought its net cash position to virtually zero, DaimlerChrysler A.G. said today that it would nevertheless pay its fairly generous dividend this year at a cost of more than $2 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERWAGER, KARL
description: OBERWAGER-Karl. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and Benefactor Karl Oberwager on February 4, 2001, shortly after his 100th birthday. Together with Susie, his beloved wife of 53 years, the Oberwagers established the Philipp Rothbart and Helene Gottheil Rothbart Endowment Fund in honor of Susie's parents, to provide scholarships and student aid at the Hebrew University. In May 2000 they traveled to Jerusalem to participate in the Benefactors dedication ceremony on the Mount Scopus Campus where their generous commitment was recognized. It was Karl's 20th visit to Israel and a true highpoint in an extraordinary life that began with his birth in Austria. Karl barely survived six years in the coalmines of Siberia during WW II. He met and married Susie in Romania and the couple eventually immigrated to the United States, where Karl rose from busboy to popular restaurant owner of the Parkway in New York City. The couple worked together until Karl's retirement in 1980. Karl will be remembered as a gracious human being and a true gentleman. He will be mourned and missed by all who knew him. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Susie and the entire family. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menachem Magidor, President Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, Rector Yigal Arnon, Chairman of the Board of Governors Ambassador Moshe Arad, Vice President for External Relations American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan Executive Vice President

title: Tharp Meets Beethoven, And Ballerinas Bustle
description: A big ballet to Beethoven and a little one to Chopin were among the works the New York City Ballet danced on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Gill's Surgery Seen as Success
description: Kendall Gill underwent exploratory arthroscopic surgery on his right knee today. The surgery was deemed a success, and it left open the possibility that he would return to the Nets this season.

title: The Taxes Before Death, and After
description: To the Editor:

title: Alaskan Cruise
description: For travelers who want to take their chances sailing to Alaska in May, Crystal Harmony's first Alaska cruise of the season, leaving San Francisco on May 21, has been discounted 45 percent from its original prices, with fares now starting at $2,660 a person, double occupancy for the 12-day voyage. Those who wait a little longer (namely, the departures June 2 through Aug. 13) will save about 40 percent, with fares starting at $2,890 a person, double. The Crystal Harmony carries 940 passengers, and it calls at Sitka, Skagway, Juneau and Ketchican in Alaska, and Victoria and Vancouver in British Columbia. The ship goes through the Inside Passage and, depending on the itinerary, Glacier Bay or Hubbard Glacier. These fares do not include air fare to San Francisco. Crystal Cruises are booked through a travel agent. For information, contact (800) 820-6663; www.crystalcruises.com .

title: Software Maker Reports Counterfeit Shares
description: A small Internet software company said yesterday that more than one million shares -- or 10 percent of the shares outstanding -- had been counterfeited by a stock transfer agent. It added that the founders of the company had agreed to donate $5 million of their own shares to cover the counterfeiting.

title: Bush to Open Country to Mexican Truckers
description: The Bush administration indicated yesterday that it would reverse a Clinton administration policy and begin allowing Mexican trucks to haul goods throughout the United States, notwithstanding concerns about the trucks' safety problems.

title: Yankees Land Reynoso, a Pitcher With Promise
description: Unless you are a baseball scout, you have probably never heard of Edwin Reynoso. But if the right-hander pitches as well as the Yankees believe he can, he will be a force by summer's end, perhaps as the replacement for the departed reliever Jeff Nelson.

title: Despite Recovery Efforts, Sunbeam Files for Chapter 11
description: The Sunbeam Corporation filed yesterday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the latest step in a nearly three-year effort to recover from an accounting scandal and a series of acquisitions that left it with $2.6 billion in debt.

title: Israel's Vote for a Safe Peace
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak's overwhelming defeat by Ariel Sharon at the polls represents not a rejection of peace but a rejection of a failed political process that brought Israel the worst collapse of security in years. Yesterday was the culmination of a political free fall that began seven months ago at Camp David. There, Mr. Barak was willing to make far-reaching concessions to the Palestinians that were unacceptable to both the parliament and the people of Israel and that broke the explicit promises he had made to the electorate when running for office 20 months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNOFF, DORIS
description: CHARNOFF-Doris. The Physicians and Staff at Cross County Medical PC mourn the loss of Doris Charnoff, beloved mother of our friend and colleague Dr. Judah A. Charnoff. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Charnoff family. May G-D comfort them among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Daniel Zanger, MD Howard C. Eisenstein, MD Susan Berman

title: The Taxes Before Death, and After
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-President in Philippines Sues to Reclaim at Least His Dignity
description: In his first direct legal challenge to the woman who helped oust him, the former president Joseph E. Estrada filed a lawsuit on Tuesday challenging the legal basis of her presidency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIN, DR. MARGARET M.
description: MULLIN-Dr. Margaret M. On February 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Matthew Kabriski who preceded her in death January 1, 2000. Dr. Mullin was born August 12, 1910, in NYC. She enjoyed a long career of teaching and guidance, influencing the lives of thousands of students for nearly 50 years. She began her work as a teacher of high school mathematics and then as Dean at Fort Hamilton High School. She was a faculty member of the School of Education of NYU and did post-doctoral study in Europe. She was a member of the Founding Faculty of Bronx Community College. Teachers inevitably have the opportunity to influence the lives of their students. This is a privilege which Dr. Mullin sensed instinctively and with sensitivity throughout her entire professional and post-professional life. Her work was deeply appreciated by her family and her many students and colleagues. Friends may call at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside, NY, Monday, February 5, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass at 9:30 AM, Tuesday, February 6, at St. Michael's Church, 136-58 41st Ave., Flushing. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the William and Sylvia Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research Center of the NYU Medical Center; 212-263-5700.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DANIEL
description: RYAN-Daniel. At age 70. Retired Paper Handler for the New York Times from 1977 to 1997. Of Wayne, New Jersey. Formerly of Tournafulla, County Limerick, Ireland. Husband of Mary K. Ryan of Wayne. Loving father of Daniel J.A., John J. and Gina M. Daniel is predeceased by his daughter Regina, 1968. Dear brother of Michael, Sean, Timothy and the late Patrick, 1972. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10AM St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Oradell. Interment is at Mary Rest Cemetery in Mahwah, N.J. Family will receive friends at Beaugard Funeral Home, 869 Kinderkamack Road, River Edge, New Jersey, Wednesday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9. In lieu of flowers, donations in Daniel's memory are requested to the Hospice of New Jersey, 400 Broad Acres, Bloomfield, N.J. 07003.

title: Bush Brings Tax Plan to Center Stage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  President Bush used the White House as theater today, trying to enlist the support of middle-class Americans  and the lawmakers who represent them  for his tax-cut package just one day before he sends it to Capitol Hill.

description: Adapted from Alan Wong's, Honolulu

title: REGULATORS CLEAR JDS DEAL
description: JDS Uniphase, the world's largest maker of fiber optic equipment, gained regulatory approval yesterday for its $18 billion purchase of SDL Inc. after its agreement last month to sell a laser manufacturing plant in Zurich to Nortel Networks. The merger now awaits only shareholders' approval. The deal between JDS Uniphase and SDL -- the No. 2 supplier of optical networking components -- had raised concerns at the Justice Department that the market for optical lasers would become overly concentrated. ''We are pleased that the agreement with Nortel Networks permits us to complete our merger with SDL,'' Jozef Straus, above, chief executive of JDS Uniphase, said. Andrew Zipern

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, IRA
description: SUSSMAN-Ira. Beloved husband of Ronna Sussman, loving son of Estelle Sussman, adored father of Joanne and Rob Stone, Amy and Neil Katz, David & Audry Eppner, Allison and Robert Bauer, Jeremy and Becky Sussman and cherished poppy of Jason & Jennifer, Jaclyn and David, Jacob, Harris & Phin and Niall and Sammy. He knew what it meant to be a good friend to many. Ira took great pride in his Jewish heritage, loved life and took good care of the lives of all around him. Funeral Services will be held at Temple Sholom, Greenwich, CT. Wednesday 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich Library or a charity of choice. For information Leo P. Gallagher & Son F.H., Greenwich, CT.

title: Gingered Almonds
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Homegrown or Store-Bought? No Contest
description: GROWING ginger commercially takes at least nine warm months, which makes it a crop for the tropics. But a personal crop can be grown just about anywhere, if it's started in a little pot indoors during the cold months. And now is the time to plant.

title: Of Schools and Crimes, And Gross Exaggeration
description: WHEN President Bush introduced his education program two weeks ago, he included proposals on school safety. Children in dangerous schools should transfer to safe ones, he said. States should get federal money for enforcing tough disciplinary rules. And there should be funds for character education.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Mexico's decision to extradite to Spain a former Argentine Navy officer accused of genocide and torture of Spaniards misstated the year in which a Spanish judge first asked Britain to extradite Gen. Augusto Pinochet in a similar case. In was 1998, not last year.

title: Life Lesson: Yearning That Leads To Wisdom
description: Like a good marriage, a perfect fit between a singer and a particular songwriter bespeaks a chemistry that is often based on kindred sensibilities. (Think of Barbra Streisand and the lyrics of Alan and Marilyn Bergman.) But in rare instances it suggests a meeting of opposites, or at least partial opposites. The lyric soprano Barbara Cook and the composer Stephen Sondheim, who recently turned 70, are such a pair. When Ms. Cook, 73, a no-nonsense interpreter who eschews fussy line readings, applies herself to Mr. Sondheim's complicated ballads, the result isn't just a lesson in how to read a lyric clearly and with feeling, but a master class in life itself too.

title: Article 2001020791576177053 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASPER, RAPHAEL
description: KASPER-Raphael. Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life, extends its deepest condolences to the Granoff and Kasper families on the passing of their beloved Raphael Kasper. Mr. Kasper was the husband of Sheila Kasper, father of Perry Granoff, father-inlaw of Hillel Board of Governors member Martin Granoff, grandfather of Hillel Board of Governors member Michael Granoff, and of Hillel professional Gillian Granoff. May the Granoff and Kasper families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Edgar M. Bronfman, Chairman Lynn Schusterman, Co-Chair Michael Steinhardt, Co-Chair Richard M. Joel, President

title: Farewell to the King, Resigned and Sad, in Many-Towered Camelot
description: Sunday afternoon's concert at Avery Fisher Hall must have been one of the best Leon Botstein and the American Symphony have given together. On the program was the biggest work of Ernest Chausson: his opera ''Le Roi Arthus,'' or ''King Arthur,'' a score that is full of glowing beauty and that occasionally rises to an impassioned nobility all its own. This rare performance would have been welcome in any event, but Mr. Botstein and his team, catching the music's special tone, made the occasion magnificent and even thrilling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARASH, ERNEST S., M.D.
description: BARASH-Ernest S., M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague and friend. Dr. Barash began his residency in Orthopedics at Mount Sinai in 1954. He dedicated his life to teaching and to the care of his patients. He will be remembered for his commitment to the elderly in the nursing home population and for his outstanding efforts in Geriatric Orthopedics. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Anthony Squire, M.D., President Vicki Lopachin, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZMAN, STANLEY
description: HERZMAN-Stanley. On February 3, 2001, at age 94. Beloved husband of the late Gladys and the late Adele. Loving father of Carol Fishman and stepfather of Lucia Scott and Guy Thomas. Grandfather of four and great grandfather of three. Devoted brother of Ruth Abel. Interment private. Memorial service Wednesday, February 7th, 3 PM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65 Street. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Educational Alliance or the New York Philharmonic.

title: City Council Worker Killed In Robbery Attempt at Home
description: A Brooklyn man who had worked for the City Council for more than a decade was fatally shot by a group of men trying to rob his apartment late Monday afternoon, the police said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He said to me, 'No one would have believed then that I would be president and you would be prime minister.'''

title: CIENA RAISES $1.5 BILLION
description: Ciena, a leading provider of electronically controlled optical networks for telecommunications companies, raised $1.52 billion by selling 11 million shares of stock at $83.50 a share and $600 million in convertible bonds. Strong demand for both the securities allowed Ciena to raise $500 million more than first planned. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Thompson Will Quit Education Board to Run for Comptroller
description: William C. Thompson Jr., the president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that he would resign from the board within two months to comply with an ethics ruling that bars him from raising money for his campaign for city comptroller.

description: At first, I had separation anxiety.

description: Time: 4 hours 20 minutes

title: A Youthful Fantasy of Love Turned Tragically Inside Out
description: The early scenes of Jean-Pierre Amris's ''Bad Company'' (''Mauvaises Frquentations'') resemble nothing so much as a French adaptation of the television series ''My So-Called Life.'' Like Angela Chase, Delphine (Maud Forget) is the bored, uncommunicative daughter of distracted middle-class parents (Delphine Rich and Franois Berland) who is drawn into friendship with a wilder schoolmate and conceives an irrational passion for a brooding, hollow-cheeked, vaguely dangerous boy. (The film even has an analog for Brian Krakow, the nerdy boy whose desperate love for the heroine is requited with sisterly affection.)

title: A Biography, Abridgment By the F.B.I.
description: MARIE RUNYON said to come on up to her place on Morningside Drive, near Columbia University. It had to do with the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: For Impatient Port Drinkers, While They Wait
description: FEW passions require as much discipline as vintage port. This sweet fortified wine is produced only in the best years, made with grapes from the best sites and bottled within two years of the vintage.

title: A 'Good Soldier,' Loyal in a Time of Turmoil
description: WHEN James E. McCabe walked into his parents' colonial-style house in Bellerose, Queens, in 1988, he announced to his father, who had spent 42 years in the New York City Police Department, that he was marrying a cop.

title: Format for Microsoft Appeal
description: The United States Court of Appeals set a format today for oral arguments in the appeal of the antitrust ruling against the Microsoft Corporation and made changes in the format the litigants had agreed to previously -- changes that seem to favor Microsoft.

title: Sports of The Times; Why Woods Hasn't Won: His Putting
description: OF all the dazzling golf shots Tiger Woods hit last year, the most memorable for most people occurred on the final hole of the Bell Canadian Open. Hitting out of a fairway bunker from 213 yards, he faded a 6-iron over a pond to within 15 feet of the cup to assure a birdie 4 for a 65 and a one-stroke victory.

title: The XFL Files As Extreme Hit
description: After only one week, the XFL has become the X-factor in this season's competition.

title: INDUSTRIAL GROWTH IN BRAZIL
description: The pace of Brazil's industrial output growth unexpectedly surged to a four-month high in December. Output grew 7.5 percent from the period a year earlier, after growing a revised 5 percent in November.

title: Leslie Is Winner Of Hyman Award
description: Lisa Leslie, a two-time Olympic gold medalist and one of the top players in the W.N.B.A., has been named the winner of the Flo Hyman Memorial Award from the Women's Sports Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RUTH
description: MILLER-Ruth. Beloved wife of Emanuel, mother of Lynn Towers, Henry Miller, and Marjorie Rotman, loving Nana of Amanda, Kelly, Holly, Michael, and Brett, survived by brother Paul Marcus. Interment private in Boynton Beach, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, LARRY
description: FISHER-Larry. The Simon Wiesenthal Center and its Board of Trustees extend their sincerest condolences to Kathleen and the entire Fisher family on the death of Larry. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know of no further sorrow for a long time. Rabbi Marvin Hier, Dean and Founder Nelson Peltz, Co-Chairman, Rhonda Barad, Eastern Director

title: Sharon Wastes Little Time In Building Coalition Base
description: JERUSALEM, February 7  Wasting little time, Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon spent the day after his landslide victory trying to put together a broad-based government with his vanquished rivals from the Labor party, a coalition that he said would pursue a new interim peace pact with the Palestinians.

title: In a Society of Their Own, Children Are Learning
description: Jorge Tirado had the skills. ''I am a good writer, so I can write tickets,'' he told the chief of police during his job interview.

title: Hughes Nears Deal to Create Giant Satellite TV Network
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation, the satellite television unit of General Motors that owns DirecTV, has moved closer to reaching a deal with the News Corporation that would create a global satellite network worth as much as $70 billion, according to executives close to the negotiations.

title: Pardoned Fugitive Said to Be in Talks on Russian Deal
description: In what appears to be the culmination of a long history of business dealings in Russia, Marc Rich, the billionaire fugitive pardoned by President Bill Clinton before he left office, may sell his global commodity trading empire to a Russian group.

title: Frances Bible, 82; Starred in City Opera
description: Frances Bible, a mezzo-soprano who performed in the New York City Opera for nearly 30 years and created roles in several contemporary works, died on Jan. 29 in Hemet, Calif., where she lived. She was 82.

title: COMPASS BUYS COMPANY TO BUILD HOSPITAL FOOD BUSINESS
description: The Compass Group said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Morrison Management Specialists for $563 million to strengthen its worldwide business supplying food to hospitals and nursing homes. Compass will pay $40 a share, 21 percent more than Morrison's $33.10 closing price on Monday, and will assume $63 million in debt. The purchase will allow Compass to add hospitals to its client list in the United States, where the market for health care food services is valued at more than $16 billion. Compass currently provides catering to retirement and nursing homes in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the use of tobacco as an ingredient in restaurant dishes misidentified the pastry chef at Patria, who does not use it. He is Alex Astenza. Alex Garcia was formerly a chef at the restaurant, but he no longer works there.

title: That Old Caramel Magic Is All in the Color
description: ALL the textbooks say the same thing: cooking granulated sugar until it turns into caramel involves complex chemistry. And I'm sure they are right. But I'm just as sure that what turns sugar into caramel is magic.

title: I See Your Pets as Your Children
description: I was always interested in animals. I remember coming home on the school bus one day and noticing an injured squirrel on the side of the road. I hooked a wagon to the back of my bike and rode over to where I had seen the squirrel. Although I found a mother squirrel dead, one of the babies was still alive so I picked it up, brought it home, put it in an incubator, nursed it back to health until it bit me, and I let it go.

title: Howard L. Clark Dead at 84; Ex-Chief at American Express
description: Howard L. Clark, a visionary executive who helped transform the American Express Company into a modern corporate giant, died on Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 84.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FEDEX CORP., Memphis, has added 85 United States cities to its FedEx Home Delivery system as part of an accelerated expansion to meet demand for shipping goods ordered by consumers on the Internet. FedEx said the terminals opened expand Home Delivery coverage to 70 percent of American households.

title: Senate Votes to Release Dues to U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Ending a bitter dispute with the United Nations, the Senate voted today to immediately release $582 million the United States owes in back dues, in effect agreeing that the international organization had made significant strides toward reform.

title: A Nice Confit Like You in a Place Like This?
description: PAPILLON is the garage band of Manhattan bistros. From the outside it looks like a neighborhood saloon. It looks that way from the inside, too, even after you walk past the bleached-out ''Papillon'' movie posters and the bar that takes up half the restaurant. The dining room has some uncomfortable banquettes, a lot of dark wood and a few small tables. It feels as if it should also have a jukebox and a dartboard. But then a waitress swings by, with a strong French accent, and the food arrives, with an even stronger French accent, and the anti-dcor begins to seem, if not charming, at least bearable.

title: Agencies Expand Via Two New Units
description: Two agencies are expanding operations.

title: Roasted Pork Tenderloin with Ginger and Golden Raisins
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Disabled Achieve Victory in Taking Standard Exams Who Get Accommoda
description: In a major victory for disability rights groups, the Educational Testing Service announced yesterday that on many of its standardized exams it would stop flagging the results of students with physical or learning disabilities who receive special accommodations, like extra time, for the tests.

title: Democrats' Anger, And Its Causes
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILIPPINES COKE BOTTLER BOUGHT
description: Coke's bottling operation in the Philippines has fallen back into local hands with the acquisition of Coca-Cola Bottlers Philippines by the San Miguel Corporation and the Coca-Cola Company. Coke and San Miguel, the country's largest food and beverage company, agreed to buy the bottler from Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd. of Australia for $1.24 billion. The deal will give San Miguel 65 percent of the bottler, as well as management control. Coke will own the rest. San Miguel had owned Coke's Philippine franchise since 1927 but gave up control in 1997 for shares in Amatil. Mark Landler

title: Allstate Talks On Dispute With Agents Abruptly End
description: Talks aimed at resolving a discrimination dispute involving Allstate and more than 6,500 agents and former agents have broken off, both sides said yesterday, and specialists in employment law say they think it is now likely that the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will take the insurer to court.

title: Homeless Shelters in New York Fill to Highest Levels Since 80's
description: The number of homeless people lodging nightly in the New York City shelter system this winter has risen above 25,000, the most since the late 1980's, city figures show, with the largest increases coming among women and children over the last few years.

title: Democrats' Anger, And Its Causes
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BOSS; Many Think of Me as Lucky
description: My father was my first boss who never wanted to go into the Manhattan market. He said, ''Why would you pay 100 times more per square foot when you can have it for much less in Queens and Brooklyn?'' I always looked to the towers under construction on the other side of the river and said to myself, ''Someday I'll take Manhattan.''

title: Survey Shows Job Cuts at an 8-Year High
description: American businesses announced the most job cuts in January for any month since a placement firm started tracking such reports eight years ago.

title: A Mother's Struggle to 'Fix Things' for a Child With Down Syndrome
description: For a native Texan, Farrah Fawcett seems awfully ill at ease with the rhythms of a rural Southern accent. But then, as the title character in ''Jewel,'' a CBS movie that has its premiere tonight, she is fighting an uphill battle.

title: Mutation That Slows H.I.V. May Play a Role in Hepatitis C
description: Five years ago, scientists discovered that some people had a genetic mutation in their cells that could either protect them against infection from the AIDS virus or significantly slow the course of AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSINI, JULIUS
description: ROSSINI-Julius. 72, Deceased February 6. Adoring husband of Margaret, loving father to Kim, Ralph, & son-in-law Joel, faithful brother to Lou and Delia, and phenomenal grandfather to Michael and Daniel. Jules, known throughout the publishing world as a marketing guru, began his successful career in the 1960's at Western Publishing where he created The Betty Crocker Recipe Card collection, and Wonderful World of Walt Disney Library. His string of successes continued through the 1960's at Random House and Simon & Schuster. In the 80's, he founded Rossini Publishing, creating supermarket-continuity programs for Bantam books including the Walt Disney Fun-To-Learn & Fun-to Read series, Mickey's Young Readers Series, and Sesame Street Early-Learning Card Series. Working with Lynx Publication, he conceived Raggdy Ann & Andy's Grow-and-Learn Library. One or more of these series has been, or still can be found in one out of every five homes in America. He will be dearly missed by family and friends, especially for his unique way of viewing the world. We have lost a truly creative spirit, an honorable man, and the core of our family. May he rest forever in heavenly peace.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Decisions Made On Accounts
description: Two large advertisers have made decisions on accounts.

title: Bill Seeks to Ban Use of Mercury In a Variety of Common Products
description: Lawmakers from both major parties have introduced legislation in the Assembly and State Senate that would ban thermometers, fluorescent lights and other products that contain mercury, in order to cut the amount of it entering sewers, landfills and incinerators.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: EXECUTIVE IS PROMOTED TO CHAIRMAN AND CHIEF AT CNBC
description: General Electric said yesterday that it had promoted the president of its CNBC financial news channel to the newly created position of chairman and chief executive of the unit. The executive, Bill Bolster, 57, had been president of CNBC since January 1996. Previously, Mr. Bolster was president and general manager of WNBC-TV, NBC's flagship TV station in New York. General Electric also announced the promotion of Pamela Thomas-Graham to president and chief operating officer of CNBC.

title: Language Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Crisis, Bay Area Is Calm But Cranky
description: Just another perfect morning in the ''most beautiful city on earth,'' and Sandy Strauss was relaxing in front of the always-packed Peet's Coffee in Pacific Heights, sipping a caff latte, ready to take on the world.

title: Corrections
description: A list in the special Working section on Jan. 30 with an article about education programs jointly sponsored by companies and labor unions referred incompletely to the sponsorship of the Alliance for Employee Growth and Development, a program for communications and electrical workers. Along with those cited in the list -- the Communications Workers of America, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and Lucent Technologies -- the sponsors include AT&T and Avaya Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PTASHEK, BERTHA
description: PTASHEK-Bertha, died February 6, 2001 in San Francisco, CA. Formerly of Jamaica Estates, NY, and North Miami Beach, FL. Devoted wife of the late Murray Ptashek, beloved mother of Sheila Adelberg (Gerald) and the late Phyllis Samuels, sister of seven, loving grandmother of four and proud great grandmother of seven. Graveside service on Friday, February 9, 2001 at 11AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: The Truth About Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: Get ready for an outpouring of Gatorade spots on the Disney sports media outlets.
description: LIKE coaches who are drenched by players as they near the end of a game, the offline and online sports media owned by the Walt Disney Company are about to be doused with a flood of Gatorade advertising.

title: Barnesandnoble.com to Cut 350 Jobs as Its Loss Widens
description: Barnesandnoble.com Inc., the No. 2 Web-based bookseller after Amazon.com, announced today that it would eliminate about 350 jobs in an effort to cut costs.

title: The Boss: Many Think of Me as Lucky
description: My father was my first boss who never wanted to go into the Manhattan market. He said, "Why would you pay 100 times more per square foot when you can have it for much less in Queens and Brooklyn?" I always looked to the towers under construction on the other side of the river and said to myself, "Someday I'll take Manhattan."

title: At a 200-Year-Old Inn, Wine Prices From Another Era
description: Dining at the Old Tavern at Grafton, in southeastern Vermont, is like stepping back in time. And not just because the gracious inn has been operating for 200 years. What caught this diner's eye on a recent visit were the wine prices, which seemed from a previous era.

title: Where Spam Ruled, a Cuisine Thrives
description: HAWAIIANS are the world's champion consumers of Spam. It's made from pork, which they like, it's cheap, and it never spoils. Mold Japanese rice into a rectangular block, slap a slice of Spam on top, wrap that with a strip of nori (seaweed) to hold it all together, and you have musubi, the island's favorite takeout food.

title: Trade Feud On Bananas Not as Clear As It Looks
description: In the simmering eight-year trade feud over bananas, the two sides have publicly staked out simple positions: the European Union maintains import quotas to protect the fragile economies of former colonies where bananas are grown, while the United States is foursquare for unfettered trade. Likewise with the position of the war's biggest apparent casualty, Chiquita Brands, which said last month that it was near bankruptcy, and that it was suing the European Commission over the quotas.

title: A Trek to See if Only Memories Survived Quake
description: She is old, very old, and the years have pinched her face tightly until it has become almost all nose and chin. Devai Ben Bura, age 83, was coming up the dusty village lane alone, with only a walking stick at her side.

title: Deconstructing Gale Norton
description: As at her confirmation hearings, Gale Norton, the new secretary of the interior, delivered a polished public- relations performance on NBC's "Today" show Tuesday morning. Once again she asserted that she would enforce the various laws protecting endangered species, and would do nothing to threaten "our wildlife and our national treasures." Yet before anyone gets too dewy- eyed, it should be remembered where she is coming from and where she is headed.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Reckonings; Bums and Rushes
description: ''Hurry up!'' say the Bush people. ''We need tax cuts now! In fact, we need them yesterday!''

title: Back to Square None For Struggling Rangers
description: After five days off for the All-Star Game break, the Rangers played last night and picked up right where they left off, which means they failed to pick up any ground.

title: 54 Million Watched XFL
description: The XFL's debut on NBC Saturday night produced a 9.5 national Nielsen rating, an 86 percent improvement upon the movies that have aired in that time period this season, and was watched by an estimated 54 million viewers.

title: Thousands March in Kiev Over Political Crisis
description: Thousands of protesters waving Ukrainian flags and chanting, ''Ukraine without Kuchma,'' streamed into Kiev today in a mostly peaceful protest march demanding the resignation of President Leonid D. Kuchma, who is struggling to overcome a deepening political crisis.

title: Study Says Disabled Would Lose Benefits Under Plan to Revamp Social Security
description: People with disabilities would lose income and benefits under the major proposals to revamp Social Security by creating individual investment accounts, a new government study said today.

title: President Reagan at 90
description: Better than almost anyone, Ronald Reagan understood the boundary between public and private life. He knew what happens to the inner core of a person whose vocation is acted out, as his was, before the cameras in Hollywood and under the intense scrutiny of the world at large.

title: Traveler Who Had a Stopover In Newark Is Tested for Ebola
description: A woman who traveled from Congo to Toronto last weekend, with a stopover at Newark International Airport, became seriously ill on Sunday and is being tested for several contagious diseases, including meningitis and the deadly hemorrhagic fever caused by the Ebola virus.

title: Metro Business Briefing; VIVENDI TO BUY GAMES COMPANY
description: Up roar Inc., a Silicon Alley online games company, announced that it had agreed to be acquired for about $140 million in cash by the Flipside unit of Vivendi Universal, the French water utility that turned itself into a telecommunications and entertainment giant. Uproar's shares jumped 46 percent, or 93 cents, to $2.94, after news of the agreement, which was signed yesterday and calls for Vivendi to pay $3 a share. The shares are down 92 percent from their high of $35 in March, when Uproar made an initial public offering. The resulting company, which will carry the Flipside name, will be based in Manhattan and will be led by Uproar's chief executive, Kenneth D. Cron. The company will offer some of the top titles in online games, including ''Family Feud'' and ''You Don't Know Jack.'' Uproar and Flipside have a total of 350 employees. But executives said in a statement that cuts after the merger would reduce the combined company's operating expenses later this year. The transaction is expected to close in March. Jayson Blair

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HARRY
description: SCHWARTZ-Harry. On February 4th, 2001. Services today, February 7th, at 12 noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. 516-487-9600 The complete notice ran yesterday in The New York Times.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Planned Office Complex: Big and Easy to Get To
description: After sitting fallow for 15 years, a 35-acre property that lies south of Black Rock Turnpike and east of Kings Highway East in Fairfield, Conn., is now the proposed site for a $250 million, eight-building office-and-retail complex. Real estate executives say it would be the largest commercial development ever in the town and one of the largest in the state.

title: In Prison, and Innocent
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Disaster' to Some Palestinians But Others See Little Change
description: The election of Ariel Sharon as Israel's prime minister makes no difference at all, many Palestinians here contended tonight as they dispiritedly followed the news of the right-wing former general's overwhelming victory.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, MAX
description: FUCHS-Max, 94. Loving father of Selma Schwartzburg and the late Dr. Seymour Fuchs. Devoted husband of 70 years to the late Fannie Fuchs. Proprietor of Nathin & Max Clothing Store at 47 Bayard St., NYC, for 63 years. Survived additionally by daughter-in-law Ruth Fuchs and grandchildren Lisa, Steve, Peggy, Danny, Bob and Gary. Great grandfather of 11. Graveside ceremony Thursday, February 8 at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Selma will be receiving Thursday evening at 7020 108 Street, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUBERT, IRWIN J.
description: SHUBERT-Irwin J. On February 6, 2001. Beloved husband of Carolee. Dear father of Brenda, Andrew, Peter, Michelle, John and Philip. Father-in-law to Deborah and Catherine. Adored grandfather of Justin, Raychel, Ilana, Jacob and Tyler. Dear brother of Florence (Sidney) Grossman, Thelma (Fred) Cohen, Miriam (Murray) Cutler and Herman Shubert. Memorial Service February 7th, 5:30pm Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Av and W. 76 St. Interment to be at Sunnyside Cemetery in Coupeville, Washington. In lieu of flowers please send donations in the name of Irwin J. Shubert to the charity of your choice.

title: Oprah's Oxygen
description: Oxygen, the women's cable network, turned one last week.

title: Council Panel Backs Hospitals' Security Workers
description: A City Council committee, responding to pressure from organized labor, voted yesterday to prohibit the Health and Hospitals Corporation from replacing its 837-member police force with lower-wage private security guards at its hospitals and nursing homes.

title: Words Versus Deeds
description: Put President Bush anywhere near a gaggle of Democrats and he cannot pat their backs warmly enough, smile at them widely enough or proceed with more alacrity in assigning them their own nicknames. In the realm of gestures and imagery, Mr. Bush is a bipartisan love machine.

title: Article 2001020793015274019 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET VOTER.COM FOLDS ITS TENT Voter.com , an all- politics Web site that achieved some prominence during the 2000 presidential campaign, is shutting down. The site featured discussions of political issues, links to sites with information on campaign spending and opinion columns. Voter.com was started in 1999, and interest in the site spiked during the political conventions last year. (NYT)

title: One Lie, Then Another, Then Only One Way Out
description: THE ADVERSARY

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Mexico's decision to extradite to Spain a former Argentine Navy officer accused of genocide and torture of Spaniards misstated the year in which a Spanish judge first asked Britain to extradite Gen. Augusto Pinochet in a similar case. In was 1998, not last year.

title: RIO TINTO TO STEP UP SPENDING
description: The Rio Tinto mining group said it would increase capital spending by at least half, investing $1.25 billion to $1.5 billion in each of 2001 and 2002, to expand output of coal, diamonds and other commodities. The company said it earned $1.51 billion in 2000, up 18 percent from 1999 and at the top of analysts' range of forecasts. Becky Gaylord

title: Better Mousetrap? No, Peeler, From Finland via Japan
description: Petri Piirainen, a Finnish student at the University of Lapland, found a way to improve the vegetable peeler and won a design contest for it sponsored by the Seki Cutlery Association of Japan. His plastic peeler, called the Shell, has a double-edge cutting blade and neatly collects peels in its container, which opens easily to empty. It is $12 in clear, green or orange at Gallery 91, 91 Grand Street (Greene Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: TOSHIBA CUTS PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The Toshiba Corporation warned that its group net profit for the year ending in March will be 30 percent lower than had been previously forecast because of falling sales and prices of chips and PC's caused by the slowing economy in the United States. Toshiba, a leading Japanese chip maker, lowered its profit forecast to 96 billion yen ($837 million) from 137 billion yen. The company lowered its revenue forecast 3.9 percent, to 5.98 trillion yen ($52 billion). Toshiba also said its American unit would lay off 500 assembly line workers and engineers at its computer-making plant in Irvine, Calif., and shift much of the work to Asia.

title: Who's Afraid of Being a Bird Watcher?
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind Voters' Backs
description: The best way to oust politicians from office is to vote them out on Election Day, not to remove them through term limits like those imposed in New York City. But New Yorkers voted twice to limit the terms of all city officials, in referendums in 1993 and 1996. Now, in a craven effort to overturn those votes and retain the option to run again for their $90,000-a-year jobs, at least 22 members of the New York City Council have signed on to a bill to eliminate term limits for Council seats (but not for other city offices), just as they are about to take effect.

title: Cisco Results Come In Short Of Forecast
description: Raising fears of a deepening economic slowdown in the United States, the Silicon Valley bellwether Cisco Systems Inc. fell short of Wall Street's already lowered expectations today, reporting revenue of $6.75 billion for the second quarter of its 2001 fiscal year.

title: Basmati Rice with Coconut Milk and Ginger
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: Advertising: Addenda
description: Decisions Made on Accounts

title: After Kathie Lee
description: After Kathie Lee Gifford resigned from ''Live With Regis and Kathie Lee'' last summer, this morning show's ratings rose as Regis Philbin tested his chemistry with potential co-hosts.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The euro fell as a weaker-than-expected German labor report raised concern that Europe would outpace the United States by less than thought. In New York, the euro settled at 93.03 cents, down from 93.87 cents.

title: Apple Almond Tart with Gingered Streusel Topping
description: Time: 1 hour 10 minutes

title: Straphangers Says Subways Are Growing Cleaner
description: It might not seem like it -- especially with the brown, soggy aftereffects of so many snowstorms this winter -- but your subway car is probably cleaner now than it was last year.

title: A Thin-Skinned Cucumber With Identity Issues
description: They are green and a little confused. They're identified as Persian cucumbers, but the ones being sold in New York are actually grown in Israel, Mexico and California. They resemble a seedless English cucumber, and are comparable in size to a medium zucchini -- but are more deeply ridged, like a Chinese bitter melon. Other small cucumbers, including the Japanese, are related to them.

title: An Arranged Marriage: Jewish Cultural Center Merges With 92nd Street Y
description: A businessman-turned-philanthropist has donated a Jewish cultural center's building near Lincoln Center to the 92nd Street Y, the largest individual gift in the Y's history.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Lehman Bond Analyst Paints a No-Nonsense Portrait of Amazon
description: When executives at Amazon.com announced the company's fourth-quarter results last week, they said that this would be the year that the Internet retailer would finally turn the corner toward profitability. But yesterday, Ravi Suria, an influential convertible bond analyst at Lehman Brothers, published a report arguing that this may be the year in which both time and money run out for Amazon.

title: Austria Regains Dominance In Alpine Championships
description: Order was restored to the Alps yesterday in St. Anton, Austria.

title: Congressional Republicans See Bush's Big Tax Cut, and Think Bigger
description: A day after President Bush began his drive for an ambitious $1.6 trillion tax cut over 10 years, Republican Congressional leaders opened the door today to even larger cuts, including a reduction in the capital gains tax and new breaks for retirement savings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOPF, ROBERT FULTON. DDS
description: KNOPF-Robert Fulton. DDS, of Northport (formerly of Roslyn and Roads End Farm, Brookville). On February 4, 2001. Golfer, fisherman, racehorse owner and avid Yankees and Knicks fan. Robert served as a Captain in the Army with the 76th Infantry Division in World War II. He participated in the liberation of Buckenwald and Auschwitz. Robert practiced dentistry in Manhattan and Roslyn for 56 years. He is survived by his son and daughter-in-law Michael and Janice Knopf of Northport and his daughter and son-in-law Melissa and Ian Berrenge-Browde of Santa Cruz, Calif. Dear brother of Murray. Also survived by his four grandchildren, Joshua, Hayley, Tristan, and Carrie. His wit and unique sense of humor will be missed. Private cremation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VENTI, (ALESSI) PHILIP J.
description: VENTI-(Alessi) Philip J., 75, of East Marion, NY (formerly of Dix Hills, NY), on February 6, 2001. Beloved husband of Antoinette. Loving father of Russell Venti and Nancy Lohneiss. Dear father-inlaw of Barbara Venti and Michael Lohneiss. Cherished grandfather of Daniel and Victoria Venti. Friends may visit Thursday and Friday, 2:00-4:30 and 7:00-9:30 PM at the Claude R. Boyd-Spencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main St., Babylon, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 AM, at St. Matthew's RC Church, Dix Hills. Entombment following at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, NY.

title: ROYAL AHOLD WILL ADD OVER 1,000 FOOD CLIENTS IN FLORIDA
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the largest supermarket retailer on the East Coast, said it bought Parkway Food Service to add more than 1,000 restaurants, schools and other clients in Florida. Financial details were not disclosed, though an Ahold spokesman, Jan Hol, said the price was ''several tens of millions'' of dollars. Parkway, based in Clearwater, Fla., has annual sales of about $85 million. Ahold, which is based in Amsterdam, bought U.S. Foodservice last year for $3.6 billion and has added related companies in an effort to expand in the food-distribution business. Parkway operates primarily in western Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKENTHALER, BERNICE
description: FRANKENTHALER - Bernice. Feb. 5, 2001. Loving wife of the late Norman, beloved mother of Judy Mydans of Denver Co., and Robert Frankenthaler of Boston Ma. Devoted grandmother of Dan, Lindsay, Amy, Jill, and Scott. A dedicated educator in the New York City school system for 32 years. Her career culminated as Principal of Robert Wagner Junior High School in New York City. She also served as a volunteer in many city-wide agencies. A woman full of life & energy, who gave to many, who will be missed by all. Services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, 81st Street, on Wednesday, February 7, 4 PM.

title: Article 2001020790595064837 -- No Title
description: February 7, 2001

title: Gunman's Life Came Undone In Years Before the Shootings
description: Something began to come apart in Willie Dan Baker's life six years ago.

title: Break Out The Walnuts
description: I FIRST encountered a walnut-based sauce for pasta in Liguria, on the Italian Riviera, also the home of pesto. There the sauce is made with cream or a creamy cheese and usually covers the local ravioli, which are stuffed with greens. I've since discovered a similar sauce made with olive oil that could pass for winter pesto, with parsley filling in for the usual basil.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about reactions to the appointment of Lorin Maazel as the next music director of the New York Philharmonic misstated the name of the first American orchestra he directed. It is the Cleveland Orchestra, not the Cleveland Symphony.

title: Miss Manners Would Be Appalled
description: One would think he would have had more sense. The chief executive of a Fortune 500 company, posing for a photo with executives of a Japanese corporation at the end of arduous negotiations in Tokyo to seal a business deal, stuck his hand behind one of his colleagues' heads and made rabbit ears.

title: The King of Nostalgia Enters a New Realm; Joe Franklin Now Holds Court In a Restaurant That Bears His Name
description: If anyone embodies the seedy charm of the old Times Square, it is Joe Franklin, whose television talk show was once a showcase for celebrities, has-beens and those never to be, and whose 42nd Street office was so pathologically disheveled that William Whitworth once wrote of it in The New Yorker: ''If it were a person, it would be a bum.''

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR BUYING INNOCOMM
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it agreed to buy the closely held InnoComm Wireless, whose chips connect electronic devices like desktop and laptop computers and telephones to one another without wires, for about $130 million.

title: Article 2001020790796742972 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESTER, ABRAHAM J.
description: LESTER-Abraham J. Died in New York City on February 5, 2001 in his 95th year. Loving husband to Yetta, beloved father of Ann Stone and the late Elaine Isenberg, father-in-law of Leon Stone, grandfather to Julie, Hal, Susan, Tom, Stephanie, Marc and Paul. Great grandfather to Chelsea and Samantha. Abe was loved and revered by friends and family. His charity and good works will be remembered by all. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Riverdale Temple at 4545 Independence Ave, Riverdale, New York 10471 or a charity of your choice. Services are to be held at the Riverdale Temple Wednesday, February 7 at 11:30 A.M.

title: Ex-Aide to bin Laden Describes Terror Campaign Aimed at U.S.
description: A secret government witness emerged yesterday to tell a hushed federal courtroom in Manhattan how he helped the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden move money and arms to terrorist groups in Africa and the Middle East as part of a conspiracy aimed at the United States.

title: Capturing the Light
description: I was astonished to learn a few weeks ago that physicists at Harvard and at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, using specially prepared gases, had succeeded in slowing light down to a crawl, and finally a dead stop. I am filled with admiration for this accomplishment. At the same time, I feel something grand has been lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARACCHI, OLIVA
description: VARACCHI-Oliva. On February 4, 2001. Devoted mother of Patricia Tutrone, Gregory and Camille. Cherished grandmother of Michele Datello, Peter, Christopher, Stephanie, and great-grandchildren, Olivia and Carmine. Loving sister of Rose Barbieri and Eugene Rossi. Mass Thursday, 10:15 AM, St. Francis Xavier Church. Reposing at the chapel of Joseph G. Duffy Inc., 9th St. between 4th and 5th Aves., Brooklyn. Call Henry McCaddin & Son Funeral Directors for information.

title: The Lamp They Use And Use and Use
description: The accommodating light being shed in many restaurants comes from hanging fixtures that are hardly fanciful yet increasingly familiar. The style of lamp -- drum-shaped and swathed in neutral-colored linen or silk, or sometimes metal or paper -- is made, with variations, by several manufacturers and can be seen all over town.

title: Haitian Opposition Says It Will Form Alternative Government
description: On the eve of Jean-Bertrand Aristide's second presidential inauguration, a coalition of political opponents announced today that it was forming an alternative government after talks aimed at resolving Haiti's political crisis collapsed.

title: The Neediest Cases; Ex-Drug Dealer Gets Help In Keeping a Legal Job
description: David Harris's drug-dealing friends knew they had a winner when he told them he had never been arrested. They asked him to help them sell drugs and assured him that if the police ever caught him, he would not go to jail. ''My friends said, 'David, you have no record,' '' he recalled. '' 'How would you like to make some quick money and get high?' ''

title: Lucent Closes Silicon Valley Laboratory
description: The Bell Laboratories unit of Lucent Technologies laid off 18 researchers at its Palo Alto research center today, quietly ending a one and a half year effort to create a Silicon Valley beachhead.

title: To Believe or Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands Are Still Waiting for Power After Snowstorm
description: Thousands of residents of western Connecticut, northern New Jersey and upstate New York were still without power yesterday after Monday's storm dumped from 5 inches to more than 2 feet of snow in a matter of hours.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Debt-Laden Sunbeam Files For Bankruptcy Protection

title: That's One Way to Respond If a Man Decides to Leave
description: There is little reverence in the Target Margin Theater Company's production of Christopher Marlowe's ''Dido, Queen of Carthage,'' but when Dido sinks into the funeral pyre she builds after Aeneas abandons her it delivers a real emotional punch. Marlowe's text invites much of the comic irreverence the company brings to some of these scenes; this is Marlowe before he was Marlowe.

title: IRISH MOBILE PHONE PURCHASE
