description: British Telecommunications agreed to buy the 49.5 percent of Esat Digifone, Ireland's No. 2 mobile operator, that it did not already own from Telenor for $1.24 billion. The deal was part of a broader agreement that gave British Telecommunications control of the Esat Telecom Group, Digifone's parent, last January. Under terms negotiated at that time, Telenor, based in Norway, received the right to exercise an option to sell its stake at a preset price. The deal is the second in two months in which British Telecommunications has had to buy out its Norwegian partner Suzanne Kapner

title: Indian Company Offers to Supply AIDS Drugs at Low Cost in Africa
description: In a move that could force big drug multinationals to cut the prices of their AIDS drugs in poor countries, an Indian company offered today to supply triple-therapy drug ''cocktails'' for $350 a year per patient to a doctors' group working in Africa.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Knicks Considering Trade Options
description: With the trading deadline just two weeks away, Knicks General Manager Scott Layden is busy on the phones, seeing if there are any available deals that could transform the Knicks from an Eastern Conference contender into an Eastern Conference favorite.

title: Onaga Baked in Thyme and Rosemary Rock Salt Crust
description: Adapted from Chef Mavro, Honolulu

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, PHILLIP
description: PARKER-Phillip. On February 5, 2001. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their esteemed member Phillip, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to his wife Rose. Board of Governors, Lowell Kwiat, President

title: Chengdu Journal; Man of a Thousand Faces Planning to Share a Few
description: By some accounts here, Peng Denghuai is a self-promoting scoundrel bent on disclosing to outsiders one of the town's most closely guarded secrets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUER, RAYMOND W.
description: BAUER-Raymond W. Of Hightstown, N.J. formerly of Westfield, N.J. on Thursday, February 1, 2001. Husband of Mary Hall Bauer. Father of Eugene Bauer, Patricia Ruud and Victoria Myers. Brother of Grant and Robert Bauer and Dorothy Fedor. Also survived by four grandchildren and three great grandchildren. A private funeral service was held at the Westfield Presbyterian Church. Memorial donations may be sent to Junior Achievement of Union County, 1101 Bristol Road, Mountainside, N.J. 07092 or the YMCA of Eastern Union County, 135 Madison Avenue, Elizabeth, N.J. 07201.

title: Women's Health Is No Longer a Man's World
description: When Dr. David Garfinkel joined a New Jersey ob-gyn practice in 1996, his contract provided for a $65,000 raise his second year and a share in the practice the third year. But Dr. Garfinkel received no raise -- and in January 1998, he was told that he would not become a shareholder in the practice, Morristown Obstetrics & Gynecology Associates.

title: Cosmopolitan Ingredients From the Web
description: Rarities like ground vanilla beans or Tastic rice from South Africa are the stock in trade of www.chefshop.com, a Web site with more than 40 categories of foods. Some items are cross-referenced by region, like that African rice, an extra-plump long-grain variety ($3.69 for 1.1 pounds) that makes a lovely pudding. Baking ingredients include the ground vanilla ($20 for two ounces) and fine-textured baking sugar ($10.99 for three pounds). Superb Portuguese canned solid white tuna in olive oil ($5.79 for 7.5 ounces) and rustic Italian spaghetti made from farro ($5.29 for 8.8 ounces) are also standouts.

title: For Likud Party, Sharon Is the 'King of Israel'
description: At 10 o'clock tonight, when the numbers showing Ariel Sharon's stunning victory flashed on a giant television screen, a thunderous roar went up from Pavilion 27 at the Tel Aviv fairgrounds.

title: RYANAIR POSTS HIGHER PROFIT
description: The Irish budget airline Ryanair Holdings reported a 42 percent increase in third-quarter profit, helped by an increase in passengers and greater use of its Web site. Its profit increased to 21.3 million euros ($20 million) from 15 million euros in the period a year ago. The airline said passenger traffic had increased 39 percent and its Web site, Ryanair.com, handled 65 percent of its reservations. Brian Lavery

title: Smart Start on Defense Budgeting
description: President Bush is right to defer any major increases in military spending until his administration has a chance to review America's real defense needs. By declining to load new weapons programs into the coming year's budget, Mr. Bush creates the opportunity for a wiser, more cost-effective use of future defense dollars.

title: U.S. SAID TO FOCUS CAMPAIGN INQUIRY ON TORRICELLI ROLE
description: A federal investigation that began by looking into illegal contributions to Robert G. Torricelli's Senate campaign in 1996 is now focused in large part on Mr. Torricelli himself, lawyers and others familiar with the case said.

title: THE CHEF
description: TO me, a vegetable menu is a success if you eat it and then it dawns on you that it's only vegetables. You don't miss anything.

title: Homegrown or Store-Bought? No Contest
description: GROWING ginger commercially takes at least nine warm months, which makes it a crop for the tropics. But a personal crop can be grown just about anywhere, if it's started in a little pot indoors during the cold months. And now is the time to plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, LILLIAN (NEE STRAUSS)
description: LEVINSON-Lillian (nee Strauss). Age 94. On February 6. Formerly of Manhattan. Widow of Julius Levinson, devoted mother of the late Louise Adolph. Survived by a good friend, Jane Adolph of Sudbury, Massachusetts. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan Adolph of Amherst Ma., Janis Jordan of Northboro, Ma., Allison Kaplan of Bedford N.Y. and Daniel Kopelman of Los Angeles & 8 great grandchildren. Graveside services 12:30 PM on Friday, February 9, at New Town Cemetery in Sudbury, MA. Perlman Funeral Home, Worcester, MA., for further information.

title: Article 2001020790527821569 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Staff Still Incomplete, Jets Plan Next Season
description: The Jets will lay the groundwork for the off-season today when the new coaching staff, which is still incomplete, meets to map out a plan for free agency and the college draft.

title: How an Anti-Mafia Film Struck an Italian Chord
description: Giuseppe Impastato had a doubly unfortunate death. He was killed on May 9, 1978, the day that the body of Aldo Moro, the kidnapped former prime minister, was found in Rome in a terrorist assassination that shook Italy and the world. The Moro case eclipsed the passing of Impastato, a 30-year-old anti-Mafia crusader in Cinisi, Sicily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEIFER, ALVIN H. (BUD)
description: SCHLEIFER-Alvin H. (Bud), on February 2. Beloved husband of Fleur. Devoted father of Nicola, Tracy and Kerry. Dear brother of James Sheldon.

title: Metro Business Briefs
description: VIVENDI TO BUY GAMES COMPANY Up roar Inc., a Silicon Alley online games company, announced that it had agreed to be acquired for about $140 million in cash by the Flipside unit of Vivendi Universal , the French water utility that turned itself into a telecommunications and entertainment giant. Uproar's shares jumped 46 percent, or 93 cents, to $2.94, after news of the agreement, which was signed yesterday and calls for Vivendi to pay $3 a share. The shares are down 92 percent from their high of $35 in March, when Uproar made an initial public offering. The resulting company, which will carry the Flipside name, will be based in Manhattan and will be led by Uproar's chief executive, Kenneth D. Cron. The company will offer some of the top titles in online games, including "Family Feud" and "You Don't Know Jack." Uproar and Flipside have a total of 350 employees. But executives said in a statement that cuts after the merger would reduce the combined company's operating expenses later this year. The transaction is expected to close in March. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Norbert V. Osterland -- Former Green Stamps Executive, 81
description: Norbert V. Osterland, the former president of Sperry & Hutchinson, the company that distributed S&H green stamps, died on Jan. 20 at his home in Souderton, Pa. He was 81.

title: Washington Talk; Celebrating the Birthday And Legacy of Reagan
description: It sometimes seems as if he never left.

title: The Americanization of Dirk Nowitzki
description: On one of his first road trips with the Dallas Mavericks in 1998, the young, shy German Dirk Nowitzki had to ask somebody to explain the term shoot-around, the routine, game-day preparation for all N.B.A. teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUSSO, DAVID E.
description: ROUSSO-David E. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Loving father of Eli and Judith, Sandra and Eli and Harilyn and Gene. Cherished grandfather of Suzanne, Linda, Evelyn, David, Terry-Ann, and Joseph. Devoted great-grandfather of Jessica, Jennifer, Charles, Nicole, Evan, Gabrielle, Kimberly and David. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 1:30 P.M. Wednesday.

title: China Steps Up War on Sect, but Some Denounce Attacks
description: China's already shrill campaign to discredit the Falun Gong spiritual group reached a new pitch today, with the strongest accusations yet that the group is colluding with Western forces seeking to vilify and destroy the nation.

title: Proposed Law Stirs Concern on Europe E-Commerce
description: Advertisers, publishers and online commerce companies are warning that a proposed European Union law would erect barriers to communicating across borders in the union.

title: BID FOR WINEMAKER
description: Allied Domecq, the world's No. 2 liquor company, offered 945 million New Zealand dollars ($418 million) for the Montana Group N.Z., New Zealand's biggest winemaker, to gain labels including Brancott Vineyards and Church Road. Allied said it would pay 4.40 New Zealand dollars a share, 9 percent more than Montana's closing price Wednesday. Montana said it intended to recommend the offer. Montana's independent directors in December rejected separate bids from Lion Nathan and Masfen Holdings, a company owned by Montana's chairman, Peter Masfen.

title: Libyan Wants Lockerbie Appeal
description: The Libyan intelligence agent convicted of 270 counts of murder for blowing up a Pan American jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 told the Scottish courts today that he wished to appeal.

title: Machines Let Resorts Please Skiers When Nature Won't
description: IN the past, when dry weather lingered in the Northeast in mid-February, that would have meant the cancellation of many a ski trip. But later this month, even if there is no hint of snow in the forecast, thousands of skiers will make their way to mountain resorts, comforted by ski reports on the radio announcing that all the trails are open.

title: Rutgers Is Finally Reaping Talent Grown in New Jersey
description: Last December, soon before he announced that Greg Schiano would be Rutgers's next football coach, Athletic Director Bob Mulcahy gathered together a group of New Jersey high school coaches to tell them what they wanted to hear. But with a catch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROBERT W.
description: WHITE-Robert W. The Musicians, Trustees and Staff of the Marlboro Music School and Festival join in celebrating the life of Dr. White, and extend their affection and sympathy to his son, David, and other family members. A devoted Marlboro Board member, Chairman of the Board (1970-73) and Trustee Emeritus, Dr. White made an inestimable contribution during formative years of the School and was a valued friend to the entire Marlboro community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANTON, DR. ARNOLD
description: STANTON-Dr. Arnold, on February 5, in Hollywood, Fl, loving husband to Jean, father to Paul and Roy, father-in-law of Harriette, grandfather of Evan and Marc, and Heidi and Glenn, great-grandfather of Jamie. Services at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, today 10:30AM.

title: XFL Promotes W.W.F. Announcer
description: In a move that offers a clear signal about the XFL's direction, NBC Sports has replaced its lead announcer, Matt Vasgersian, with Jim Ross, the World Wrestling Federation announcer who called the network's backup game last Saturday.

title: QUANTUM UNIT BUYING BRITISH DATA STORAGE COMPANY
description: The Quantum Corporation, a maker of computer disk drives, said yesterday that a unit, DLT and Storage Systems, would buy the closely held M4 Data Holdings for about $56 million to add data storage products. DLT will pay $13.4 million in cash, with the rest split between debt and stock. The purchase, which will add to earnings in 2002, is expected to close by the end of March. The price could change if performance goals are met, Quantum said. M4 Data Holdings makes products that back up and protect data, said a Quantum spokesman, Emory Epperson. The company, based in Wells, England, has 130 employees and operations in Germany and Melbourne, Fla.

title: A New Way to Chill Out: Last Guy In, Shut the Door
description: From ultracold to ultracool: walk-in refrigerators that belonged to a former restaurant have been turned into V.I.P. rooms at Deep, a new Hollywood nightclub on the same site. The stainless-steel fridge rooms can hold 25 people each. ''We did nothing but disconnect the freezer and clean it up and decorate it,'' said Ivan Kane, the owner. He and the designer, Fred Sutherland, have decked out the V.I.P. room shown below with a shiny thrift-store table, a video monitor with four screens offering views of what's happening in the rest of the club and, just out of sight, a strippers' pole. The aim of the club is ''to push the envelope in terms of sexuality, decadence and voyeurism,'' said Mr. Kane, who also owns a dance club called Kane on Melrose Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of restaurant closings in the Off the Menu column of the Dining section yesterday included one restaurant by mistake. Gubbio, an Umbrian restaurant at 223 West Broadway (White Street), is open; its lease is being renegotiated.

title: Treasury Head Queries Wall St. on Tax Cut
description: On his one-day listening tour of Manhattan, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill did not hear much dissent from Wall Street officials about the new administration's plans for stimulating the slowing economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, DONALD, HAZZAN DR.
description: FISCHER-Donald, Hazzan Dr. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the tragic passing of a revered colleague. A brilliant cantor, he quietly and gently served the spiritual needs of Congregation Netivot Shalom of Berkeley, Calif., for more than a decade. His kindness, his humanity and his caring inspired us all. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Jan, his children and his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Chaim Najman, President Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Exec. VP Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro Exec. Administrator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENAGH, DONALD F.
description: MENAGH-Donald F. Feb. 7, 2001. Age 85. Beloved husband of Claire. Devoted father of Diane Menagh, and Douglas Menagh and his wife Lucille Falcone Menagh. Cherished grandfather of Douglas and Nancy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Friday, February 9, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, February 10, at 10AM,, Saint John the Evangelist Church, 1st Avenue at East 55 St.

title: Nonpartisan, Maybe
description: To the Editor:

title: YankeeNets Makes a Deal With Manchester United
description: In four of the past five seasons, the Yankees found no one to beat them in the World Series. But they freely admit that one faraway team is superior, at least in the art of marketing itself: Manchester United, the storied soccer team that has won six of the past eight English Premier League championships.

title: First Cutback By Archbishop: High School In Ulster County
description: After eight months of quietly studying the sprawling Archdiocese of New York, Archbishop Edward M. Egan announced his first major cost-cutting measure today, a decision to close a financially failing high school with a dwindling student population here in Ulster County.

title: Tempers Afire, Council Members and Opponents Argue Over Term Limits
description: The bid by nearly two dozen City Council members to repeal a term limits law exploded yesterday into an angry ground war at City Hall, with supporters and opponents engaging in face-to-face shouting matches even before the bill was formally introduced.

title: Her Biggest Fixer-Upper
description: The stucco fixer-upper on the south slope of Camelback Mountain on the outskirts of Phoenix was an outdated 60's contemporary, with avocado-colored appliances, Brady Bunch dcor and a $400,000 price tag.

title: Meeting Today With Rebels Crucial for Colombia's Leader
description: With the hopes of a war-weary nation on his shoulders, Andrs Pastrana won the presidency in June 1998. He was the candidate for peace who Colombians believed would bring Latin America's largest and oldest rebel group to the peace table.

title: Mental Decline Is Linked To Heart Bypass Surgery
description: Five years after heart bypass surgery, 42 percent of patients show a significant decline on tests of mental ability, probably from brain damage caused by the surgery, doctors from Duke University say in a new study.

title: Sharon in Power: The New Mideast Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing; MORTGAGE LENDER CHARGED
description: The New York State Banking Department has charged that a mortgage lending company ''routinely engaged in deceptive acts and practices'' and said it was considering whether to revoke the company's license. The department said yesterday that the lender, Anvil Mortgage Banking Ltd. of Orangeburg, N.Y., had, among other things, accepted $500 application fees from 7,633 mortgage seekers last year -- a total of nearly $4 million -- but ''could not reasonably expect to be able to fund any significant portion of the applications'' because it had only $5 million available. The company made fewer than 300 loans in the state last year, the state agency said. Eric Kotch, Anvil's president, said the company had acted lawfully and had ''helped hundreds of first-time buyers'' purchase homes. Joseph P. Fried

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, SHELDON R.
description: LEVINE-Sheldon R. We mourn the passing our beloved uncle, Sheldon R. Levine, Uncle Shelly. While saddened by his far too early passing, we are honored to have shared in his life. Never to be forgotten, always to be remembered with love and a smile. From his loving nephews and nieces, David, Janice, Andrew and Philip Sloves and Judi, Stephen and Joshua Zimmerman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETROVICH, WILLIAM
description: PETROVICH-William. A gentle caring man, died on February 1, 2001 at the age of 80, after a long battle with heart disease. Husband to Addie, father to Neva and Len and grandfather to Alex, he will be remembered for his good humor and courage.

title: The Other Drudge Report Has Fans in High Places
description: IF Colin Powell starts throwing books around in his new job as secretary of state, it is not necessarily because of looming chemical weapons threats or infighting with the secretary of defense.

title: Bush Takes First Step to Shrink Arsenal of Nuclear Warheads
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  President Bush will order a comprehensive review of the nation's nuclear arsenal, a first step toward the unilateral cuts in warheads and missiles that he promised during last year's campaign, senior military and administration officials said today.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Names Marketing Official as Chief Executive
description: Peter R. Dolan first made his mark by getting consumers to buy more Jello at General Foods. Now, after 13 years at Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceutical company, he has been named chief executive, becoming the latest marketing executive to run a major drug company.

title: Gateway Splits With McCann-Erickson
description: Gateway, the personal computer maker, said yesterday that it had parted ways with its creative agency since April 1998, McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $250 million.

title: Four A's Nominates Slate of New Officers
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York has nominated executives to serve as top officers for the 2001-2 year.

title: Ex-Fugitive Appears at French Corruption Trial
description: A former oil executive who is expected to be a crucial defendant in a multimillion-dollar corruption case made a brief appearance in court today as France's justice minister urged him to tell all he knows about high-level bribery and fraud.

title: Cash or Not, Daimler to Pay Its Dividend
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., where huge losses at Chrysler have sharply reduced its net cash position, said today that it would nevertheless pay its fairly generous dividend this year at a cost of more than $2 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEREN, ARTHUR
description: STIEREN-Arthur. The Metropolitan Opera Association mourns the death of our good friend Arthur Stieren, a member of our official family for twenty years. His commitment to our company was invaluable, and we remember in particular his enthusiasm for the Wagner repertory. We extend our condolences to his wife Jane and his family. Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Chairman Emeritus Bruce Crawford, Honorary Chairman James W. Kinnear, Chairman Paul M. Montrone, President

title: A New Music Player Marries MP3's With CD's
description: Rio, a pioneer in the development of the first portable MP3 player, which came out in 1998, recently introduced its first portable compact disc player -- but with a twist. The player, the Rio Volt, joins the ranks of a new class of CD players that play not only standard music CD's but also custom CD's, which listeners can make themselves with increasingly popular CD recorders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATTIE, WILLIAM S.
description: BEATTIE-William S. Of New York died February 5, 2001. Friends may call Thursday 7-9PM Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, Inc. 262 Main St, Mt. Kisco, NY 914-666-5891 Funeral Services Friday, 11AM at the St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, NY, interment to follow, Middle Patent Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, C/O Pain Clinic, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10022.

title: Compaq Cuts Frills and Price On iPAQ Personal Organizer
description: In an effort to distinguish their devices, the makers of hand-held computers using Microsoft's Pocket PC operating system often portray them as mini home-entertainment centers, with vivid color displays and the ability to play music.

title: Connecticut Budget Proposal Calls for Modest Increases
description: Warning about a cooling economy, Gov. John G. Rowland today proposed a budget for the next two fiscal years that he said would impose fiscal restraint while allowing modest new spending for education, mental health and drug rehabilitation programs.

title: Economic Scene: Comparing Nasdaq and Tulips Unfair to Flowers
description: WAS the Nasdaq bubble yet another example of tulipmania?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, WILLIAM
description: FINK-William. On February 7, 2001, of New York City and Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Anne. Dear father of Arnold and the late Eugene Fink, fatherin-law of Roberta and Sheila, adored grandfather of Jill, Andrew, Zachary, Jason and greatgrandfather of Emma and Nathaniel. Loving brother of Ruth Cogut. Services on Friday, February 9, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: SLOWING ECONOMY FORCES GOVERNORS TO TRIM BUDGETS
description: With a swiftness that has taken many governors by surprise, the slowing economy has sharply reduced state tax revenues in the last few weeks, forcing a growing number of states around the South and Midwest to cut their budgets for the first time in a decade.

title: Taking Video Games Seriously, as Art and Product
description: TRIGGER HAPPY: VIDEO GAMES AND THE ENTERTAINMENT REVOLUTION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, SHIRLEY
description: HAHN-Shirley. On February 6, 2001. Beloved wife to Stanley. Loving mother of Steven and Robert. Cherished grandmother of Declan and Saiorse. Services Thursday, 2:30 at Menorah Gardens and Funeral Chapel, 9321 Memorial Park Rd., W. Palm Beach, FL, 561627-2277. Donations may be made to the American Lung Assoc. of South Florida in her memory.

title: Hall's Griffin Is a Question, Not an Answer
description: With the exception of an infamous punch, Eddie Griffin is the king of cool. He rarely shows emotion on the court, and that makes him look uninterested at times.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SOROS GETS CONTROL OF BLUEFLY
description: George Soros, the billionaire investor, has taken control of Bluefly, a Silicon Alley online retailer, Bluefly executives announced yesterday. Bluefly will now officially be controlled by Soros Private Equity Partners L.L.C. as a result of Soros's $15 million loan to Bluefly in November. On Jan. 16, Bluefly announced that it had received a letter from Nasdaq officials advising it that the company's tangible assets were too low for it to qualify for continued inclusion in the index. Bluefly's stock dropped 19 percent, or 34 cents, to $1.43 per share yesterday on the Nasdaq composite index. Jayson Blair

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRUCKER, ELLA
description: DRUCKER-Ella. 2/8/89. Forever loved. Forever missed. V.

title: LAWYERS WANT DATA ON BRIDGESTONE TIRES MADE IN JAPAN
description: The Bridgestone Corporation produced Firestone ATX steel-belted radial tires in Japan with a design different from ATX tires that have been recalled in the United States, lawyers representing people injured in tire-related crashes said yesterday. The Japanese-made tires used an extra wire in each of the steel cords that made up the steel belts and used thicker rubber, said the lawyers, who contended that this produced a stronger tire. Jill Bratina, a spokeswoman for Bridgestone's American subsidiary, said the tires made in Japan met the same performance specifications as in the United States but had been manufactured differently because of the type of resources available in Japan. Ms. Bratina would not elaborate or provide statistics on tires by place of manufacture, something the lawyers have requested. Keith Bradsher

title: What $50 Million Buys In the Hamptons
description: THOSE waiting for bargains in the Hamptons may have to wait a little longer: a property was listed this week that could, if sold, break the price record of $32 million for a house in the Hamptons set last year by Jerry Seinfeld's purchase of Billy Joel's 11-acre spread in Amagansett, N.Y.

title: Locks Issued by Gun Group Are Being Recalled
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced a recall of 400,000 gun locks today after a government study found that they could be easily opened without a key.

title: ARTS ABROAD: A Camera-Shy Legend, Exposed and Indignant; Cartier-Bresson Chafes Over a Book Of Photographs of His Well-Guarded Face
description: Henri Cartier-Bresson is arguably the most famous photographer alive, a tall, elegant Frenchman who at 92 still accepts the occasional portrait assignment. Among colleagues, however, the master of the intimate ''decisive moment,'' as his photographic signature became known, is also famous for hating to be photographed himself. ''I spent all my life trying to be unknown, to disappear, to be able to observe,'' he explained some years ago.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: An Actor Tries Hand at Editing

title: An Unbreakable Way To See The Pottery of Mexico
description: Who doesn't come back from Mexico with pieces of pottery? A new book, ''Cermica: Mexican Pottery of the 20th Century,'' written by Amanda Thompson (Schiffer, $49.95), divides Mexican ceramics into regions and catalogs some of the 1,200 pieces shown last year at the California Heritage Museum in Santa Monica. At far right is a charger made in Jalisco from the 1950's to the 60's; on the book jacket, 1930's to 40's Fantasia vessels from the Jalisco region.

title: Machines Let Resorts Please Skiers When Nature Won't
description: IN the past, when dry weather lingered in the Northeast in mid-February, that would have meant the cancellation of many a ski trip. But later this month, even if there is no hint of snow in the forecast, thousands of skiers will make their way to mountain resorts, comforted by ski reports on the radio announcing that all the trails are open.

title: Chip Maker In Korea Posts Loss for Year
description: Hyundai Electronics Industries, the South Korean semiconductor manufacturer, said yesterday that it lost 2.4 trillion won ($1.9 billion) in 2000 despite rapid sales growth. Huge write-downs on failed investments and the sale of unprofitable assets were mainly responsible.

title: LOSS AT SKY BROADCASTING
description: The British Sky Broadcasting Group said pretax first-half losses rose more than fourfold to $389 million as it continued to invest heavily in efforts to sell digital television to new clients and existing analog customers. Since 1999, the company has been giving away set-top digital boxes to draw customers to multichannel viewing and interactive services like shopping, banking and betting through their television sets. BSkyB said it beat its forecast of 5 million digital customers by the end of 2000 with 5.05 million direct customers. Its shares fell as much as 3.4 percent, to 1,063 pence. The company said it would return to profit by 2003 with seven million customers. BSkyB is owned 38 percent by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and 23 percent by Vivendi. Alan Cowell

title: Book Calling Holocaust a Shakedown Starts a German Storm
description: The publication of a book here today by an American historian declaring that the Holocaust has become an ''extortion racket'' through which some Jews blackmail Germany has ignited a stormy debate.

title: Stopping Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZMAN, STANLEY
description: HERZMAN-Stanley. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Stanley Herzman, a cherished friend to UJA-Federation and its affiliated agencies. His leadership and generosity have left an enduring mark on the Jewish community that will be felt by generations to come. To his daughter, Carol Fishman; to his stepchildren Lucia Scott and Guy Thomas; to his grandchildren and great grandchildren; and to the entire family, we extend our deepest sympathies. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Internet Age Becomes the Dark Age
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  When David Drake, an engineering manager in Escondido, Calif., saw his monthly electric bill climb to more than $600 recently, he took action. He turned off 7 of the 10 computers he had been running constantly in his house and cut back on operating his pool filter. He and his wife, Ginny, replaced their 13-year-old water heater with a more energy-efficient one, and they ordered double-paned windows with a special energy-efficient coating. Mr. Drake estimates that they cut their energy consumption by nearly 20 percent.

title: Leon Beer Schachter, Union Organizer, Dies at 91
description: Leon Beer Schachter, a union organizer, negotiator and former head of the Washington office of the Amalgamated Meatcutters and Butcher Workmen, died on Jan. 25 at a nursing home near Philadelphia. He was 91.

title: Rockefeller Drug Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Tales of Lost Homes Surface in Queens
description: They were churchgoing people with modest incomes -- among them, a service attendant for a car rental company, a Wonderbread packer, a data processor, a retired phone company representative. They were also homeowners in Jamaica, St. Albans and other Queens neighborhoods who were having a tough time keeping up with their mortgage payments.

title: Utah, in Census War, Fights North Carolina for House Seat
description: When American workers abroad were counted for the 2000 census, only federal employees were considered, a rule leaving out a large group that included more than 11,000 Mormon missionaries from Utah.

title: British City Defines Diversity and Tolerance
description: Jitendra Vaitha, a jeweler, leaned across a glittering display of gold necklaces and sought to describe how life had changed for the large Asian population in this traditional city with its Victorian clocktower, medieval timbered buildings and Roman ruins.

title: One Woman's Viewpoint; Message Begins to Reach Small-Town America
description: The gentle warning from the pediatrician came during a recent check-up. Holton is tall for his age, the doctor observed of the 4-year-old boy. Is he going to kindergarten in the fall?

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Wyckoff School Board Sues, Accusing Two of Embezzling
description: Officials of the Wyckoff Board of Education in New Jersey, after taking the unusual step of suing the board's business administrator and a Bergen County businessman, accusing them of embezzling $2.5 million from the district, said they were reviewing their procedures to make sure nothing similar happens again.

title: Officials Say Investigation Will Go On Despite Pardon
description: Federal prosecutors in Los Angeles said yesterday that they planned to push ahead with their criminal investigation of a businessman pardoned last month by President Bill Clinton, assured that the clemency applied only to crimes he committed two decades ago.

title: Search Engine Hunts for Gold Beneath the Surface of the Web
description: Specialized search engines have been lifesavers for many Web users, primarily because they make it easier to dig into the ''invisible Web,'' the online content that is not usually found by general search tools like Yahoo or Excite. But specialization comes with a price. Instead of being able to check many sources with just one search, Web searchers looking for the unusual browse directories of specialty engines and then run their searches on each engine, one after the other.

title: Transcript of Richard Sandomir's Visit to the Media and Business Forum
description: Richard Sandomir, who covers sports media and sports business for The Times, visited the forums on Feb. 7. Here is a transcript.

title: A Modest Quest: Garbage In And Garbage Out
description: WHEN the E.P.A. published its most recent list of Superfund sites, I was surprised that my kitchen trash can was not mentioned.

title: Familiar Objects Aglow With Wit
description: THERE was a time, not long ago, when almost every lamp had a base and a shade. Not anymore -- at least not at last month's Maison & Objets show in Paris or at the New York Gift Fair that followed it. Instead, there were whimsical lamps inspired by ordinary objects like a glowing dog made of soft resin and a lighted handbag with leather straps. And even though their light is demure, these lamps will never fade into the background.

title: WITNESS DESCRIBES BREAK WITH GROUP LED BY BIN LADEN
description: One day in mid-1996, a Sudanese man stood in the visa line at an American embassy abroad. When a clerk asked if he wanted an application, he replied, ''No, I don't want visa, but I have some information for your government.''

title: Philosophers' Habitats
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUSSO, DAVID E.
description: ROUSSO-David E. We deeply regret the passing of our esteemed colleague, an honorary past treasurer and honorary chairman of the Dedications Committee of the Sephardic Home. David E. Rousso and his family were staunch and dedicated benefactors of the Sephardic Home since its inception 53 years ago. He and his late wife, Evelyn, dedicated themselves to the care of the elderly of our community. Our sincerest condolences to Eli and Judith Rousso, Sandra and Eli Izhakoff, Harilyn and Gene Brown, and the entire family. Officers and Board of Directors of the Sephardic Home and LASHA Robert A. Cohen, President Ralph J. Kamhi Chairman of the Board Ira Rousso, Vice President Michael New, Executive Director Marion Crespi, President LASHA Reggie Goldberg Chairman of the Board, LASHA

title: Homeless Shelters in New York Fill to Highest Level Since 80's
description: The number of homeless people lodging nightly in the New York City shelter system this winter has risen above 25,000, the most since the late 1980's, city figures show, with the largest increases coming among women and children over the last few years.

title: South Florida Businessman Killed in Ambush on Street
description: Gus Boulis, a South Florida developer who made a fortune by assembling an empire of restaurants, hotels and floating casinos, was shot and killed on Tuesday night on a Fort Lauderdale street in what the police described as a well-orchestrated assault.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET FASHIONMALL QUITS MERGER TALKS The online retailer Fashionmall.com and GenesisIntermedia said yesterday that they had broken off merger talks after Fashionmall's board rejected the $7-a-share acquisition offer of Genesis. The offer was made on Dec. 29 after Genesis announced that it had obtained a 7 percent stake in Fashionmall. The companies said they would still consider a strategic alliance. "Naturally, we're disappointed," said Ramy El-Batrawi, the chief executive of Genesis. Fashionmall is best known for its purchase last year of the failed Internet fashion company Boo.com. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Old Soldier, New Battle
description: After a stubborn, lumbering climb over several decades to reach the Israeli political pinnacle, Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon must now move like a gazelle. He has little time to build a working coalition from an unruly Parliament, and the conflict with the Palestinians is not something that will go lightly to the back burner.

title: Sports of The Times; The 'Older' Generation Carries and Guards the Torch
description: The world-level athletes stared at the mass of energy that is a junior high school auditorium, and they thought it was only yesterday when they were out there, wriggling.

title: Controls Rely on the Twitch of a Muscle, Not the Twitch of a Mouse
description: COMPUTERS, cell phones and other gadgets continue to shrink, but the means of interacting with them, like keyboards and keypads, are either too large and cumbersome or too small for the human hand. That is the belief of a group of NASA scientists who have been working on more direct ways to control machines, starting with jets and spacecraft.

title: New Blow for Telecoms:French IPO Price Is Cut
description: LONDON  The outlook for Europe's heavily indebted telecommunications companies suffered a major new blow Wednesday when France Telecom was forced to slash the price of an initial public offering of shares in its Orange mobile unit by as much as 30 percent to attract buyers.

title: Cisco's Weak Earnings Report Nudges Equities Lower
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, as traders and investors sold shares after a disappointing earnings report from Cisco Systems, the maker of computer-networking equipment.

title: AUSTRALIA RATE CUT
description: The Australian central bank reduced a key rate, cutting the overnight cash rate to 5.75 percent from 6.25 percent. The bank cited slower world growth and restrained inflation. Analysts here foresaw a further easing of Australian monetary policy in coming months. In a statement announcing the rate reduction, the bank said domestic business confidence had slipped and the labor market had softened. Rory Robertson, interest rate strategist at Macquarie Equities, called the move ''a pre-emptive strike against weaker growth down the track.'' Becky Gaylord

title: RAYTHEON SHARES FALL ON NEWS OF JET-APPROVAL DELAY
description: The Raytheon Company, a leading military contractor, said yesterday that the federal government would not approve the design of its Premier business jet until the second quarter, later than investors had hoped. The Federal Aviation Administration held up certification because it was concerned that the wheels might burst under certain landing conditions. Testing has been scheduled, said Hansel Tookes, the aircraft division's chairman. He did not specify a date. Raytheon's Class B shares fell $1.58, to $33.81. It is based in Lexington, Mass.

title: When a Veil Is Lifted, Is the Magic Gone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivera's Agent Is Fired, Setting Back Negotiations
description: The Mariano Rivera salary arbitration hearing, scheduled for today, was postponed yesterday amid a corporate confrontation that resulted in the dismissal of the pitcher's agent. Rivera, the Yankees' premier reliever, is the player most immediately affected by the dispute, but it is a far-ranging conflict that touches the owner of the Texas Rangers and other agents.

title: Bronx Science Loses Acting Principal to L.I. School
description: The acting principal of the Bronx High School of Science, one of New York City's most prestigious schools, has taken a job in an affluent Long Island suburb, after a four-month struggle between his supporters and Chancellor Harold O. Levy over whether to promote him to principal.

title: Foreign Affairs; Sharon, Arafat and Mao
description: So I'm at the Davos World Economic Forum two weeks ago, and Shimon Peres walks by. One of the reporters with him asks me if I'm going to hear Mr. Peres and Yasir Arafat address the 1,000 global investors and ministers attending Davos. No, I tell him, I have a strict rule, I'm only interested in what Mr. Arafat says to his own people in Arabic. Too bad, says the reporter, because the fix is in. Mr. Peres is going to extend an olive branch to Mr. Arafat, Mr. Arafat is going to do the same back and the whole love fest will get beamed back to Israel to boost the peace process and Ehud Barak's re-election. Good, I'll catch it on TV, I said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a ''charm school'' program at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology misattributed the quotation ''I think this is something everyone in Boston could use. Charm isn't just for nerds.'' The sophomore who spoke was Lilian Chau, not Jenny Shu.

title: Gawking at Skylines Without Blocking Traffic
description: IMAGINE strolling through the great cities of the planet without leaving your desk. Of course, it would not be nearly as satisfying as actually being there, but it could be fun, enormously useful and perhaps even a good first step before traveling to the likes of Paris, Berlin and New York.

title: U.S. Judge Extends Order to Sell Energy
description: In a move that California's power managers said would spare millions of residents from blackouts on Thursday, a federal judge in Sacramento tonight extended an order forcing a supplier to continue selling energy to the state's nearly bankrupt utilities.

title: Former German Chancellor Agrees to Pay Fine
description: BERLIN, Feb. 8  Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed today to pay a stiff fine to end a criminal investigation into his illegal acceptance of $1 million in secret payments to the Christian Democratic party during the 1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DESOSA, COUNT MAXIM
description: DeSOSA-Count Maxim. 2/8/61-5/26/92. ''All is ephemeral, both what remembers and what is remembered.'' Marcus Aurelius Eric

title: The Neediest Cases; Wall St. Pitches In for Less Fortunate
description: In the 20th floor of a downtown skyscraper, Jonathan Hummel and a group of about 25 other young financial analysts came together to give new meaning to the word ''rally.'' During breaks from work, the analysts raised a company record for some of New York's neediest people.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about collecting African art misstated the prices of terra-cotta figures from the Nok region of Nigeria sold through Eric Robertson's gallery in Manhattan. They have sold from $800 to $15,000; they do not start at $15,000.

title: Knicks Dig In and Finally Hold Off the Mavericks
description: Latrell Sprewell stood beneath the Dallas Mavericks' basket, clutching the basketball and thinking the Knicks had stolen a game. But as the clock raced toward zero and chaos broke out around him, Sprewell stepped out of bounds, unwittingly setting in motion one of the wildest regular-season games ever at Madison Square Garden.

title: Are Democrats Ready on Taxes?
description: While campaigning against Al Gore last year, George W. Bush had such trouble getting broad support for his proposed tax cut that he stopped emphasizing the subject for a time. That was then. Now, with the economy stalling and Mr. Bush's popularity on the rise, Republicans in Congress say they want to expand a tax cut that is already too large and generous to the wealthy, adding bonuses for businesses and investors.

title: Sharon in Power: The New Mideast Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS TAKES STEPS TO CUT COSTS
description: Verizon Communications plans to cut some jobs, limit overtime and dismiss contractors in an effort to reduce costs, the company president, Lawrence T. Babbio Jr., said yesterday. Verizon will achieve 40 percent of the cuts by dropping contractors and reducing overtime, Mr. Babbio said. Much of the rest, the company said, will come through attrition, with some layoffs, although it declined to be more specific. Mr. Babbio said Verizon expected to have 6.4 million to 6.6 million long-distance customers nationwide by year-end, a rise of 31 percent to 35 percent from the 4.9 million at the end of 2000. Verizon started selling long-distance service in New York about a year ago and enrolled 1.4 million customers by December.

title: Insurers Push Rates Higher For Medigap
description: The rising costs of prescription drugs are driving up the premiums of insurance plans that supplement traditional Medicare and include drug coverage. The high costs of these so-called Medigap policies are forcing many elderly and disabled people out of the programs even as Medicare managed care plans and employers are retreating from providing drug coverage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DANIEL
description: RYAN-Daniel. Age 70 of Wayne, NJ on February 4th 2001. Retired New York Times Paperhandler, formerly of Touraafulla, County Limerick, Ireland. Beloved husband of Mary Ryan of Wayne. Loving father of Daniel J.A., John J. and Gina M. Daniel is predeceased by his daughter Regina (1968). Dear brother of Michael, Sean, Timothy and his late brother Patrick (1972). Funeral Mass Thursday, 10: AM at St. Joseph's R.C. Church in Oradell. Interment is at the Mary-Rest Cemetery in Mahwah, New Jersey. Family will receive friends at the Beaugard Funeral Home, 869 Kinderkamack Road, River-Edge, New Jersey, Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations in Daniel's memory are requested to the Hospice of New Jersey @ 400 Broad Acres, Bloomfield, N.J. 07003.

title: National News Briefs
description: Raids in Kentucky Aim at Deadly New Drug

title: Minimum-Wage Option
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Big Makers Scale Back At Toy Fair; So the Little Guys Have More Room To Show Their Stuff
description: The nation's three largest toy makers are pulling back from the American International Toy Fair, one of New York City's most venerable and lucrative trade shows.

title: EIRCOM IN TALKS TO SELL ASSETS
description: The former Irish state telecommunications company Eircom confirmed yesterday that it was discussing the sale of its fixed-line and Internet assets to the entrepreneur Denis O'Brien, left. Any such deal will have to wait for the completion of the sale of Eircom's wireless subsidiary, Eircell, to the Vodafone Group. Mr. O'Brien had offered to buy Eircom's fixed-line business, excluding its Internet interests, for one euro, or 93 cents, a share, or 2.25 billion euros ($2.1 billion), in October, but the offer was rejected as too low. The current all-cash offer values the company at 1.10 euros, or $1.02, a share. Brian Lavery

title: SCHERING'S PROFIT FALLS
description: Schering, a German drug maker, said fourth-quarter profit fell 5 percent, but, excluding a one-time charge, its operating profit almost doubled, helped by sales of the multiple sclerosis medicine Betaferon. The company predicted sales and earnings growth of 10 percent or more in 2001. Net income excluding a one-time charge rose to 116 million euros ($108 million) from 60 million in the year-earlier period, as sales rose 16 percent.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: New York Team Announces Schedule
description: The New York Power, located on Long Island, will open its season in the newly formed Women's United Soccer Association in Atlanta on April 21 and play its first home game eight days later, April 29, at Mitchel Field in Uniondale. The opponent is San Diego.

title: Dale Evans, the Queen of the West, Is Dead at 88
description: Dale Evans, who won the hearts of millions of Americans as she rode alongside her husband, Roy Rogers, in western films and on ''The Roy Rogers Show'' in the early years of television, died yesterday at her home in Apple Valley, Calif., east of Los Angeles. She was 88.

title: 1 BR, Lower Rent
description: To the Editor:

title: An Adviser To the Stars Is Sentenced To Prison
description: A former money manager once known as the investment adviser to the stars was sentenced yesterday to nearly five years in prison for stealing about $10 million from clients.

title: Photos Go Beyond the Inkjet
description: BEHIND every person who extols the virtues of a digital camera, there's a traditional film-camera owner listening with a baffled expression. Sure, it's fun to preview your photos on a digital camera's built-in screen, but getting them onto paper is usually a clunky and imperfect process, a far cry from simply dropping off a roll of film at the mall. You have to transfer images from the camera to a Mac or PC and perhaps fiddle with them for a while. Then you either upload them to a photo- developing Web site and wait for next week's mail or, if you're like most people, print them on a color inkjet printer.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Willie Dan Baker, the former employee who went on a shooting rampage on Monday at the Navistar engine factory in Melrose Park, Ill., misstated the number of those he shot before killing himself. Four, not three, were killed; four others, not three, were wounded.

title: Watching Grass Grow and Men Fight
description: A PAINTED HOUSE

title: Serbs May Arrest Milosevic Shortly for a Local Trial
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Feb. 8  Slobodan Milosevic, who led Serbs into four wars and 13 years of impoverishment and isolation, could be arrested very soon and tried for multiple crimes ranging from embezzlement and election fraud to discrimination against minorities and perhaps treason, the new Serbian justice minister said this week.

title: REVIEW; Taking Video Games Seriously, as Art and Product
description: TRIGGER HAPPY: VIDEO GAMES AND THE ENTERTAINMENT REVOLUTIONBy Steven Poole (Arcade Publishing, $25.95)

title: C.I.A. Chief Sees Russia Trying to Revive Its Challenge to U.S.
description: Russia is using international trade in weapons and technology to improve relations with China, India and Iran while trying to revive its status as a great power and challenge United States influence, the director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, EVA S.
description: MARCUS-Eva S. On February 6, 2001. Loving wife of the late Dr. Jacob T. Marcus. Beloved mother of the late Dr. Robert L. Marcus, Judith and Bernard. Fond sister of Perry and Silfen. Cherished grandmother of David and Barbara Marcus, Deborah and Gary Blyn, Eileen and David Cohan and Sharon and Mitchell Konichowsky. Adoring great-grandmother of Jared and Ethan Blyn, Matthew Cohan and Elana Konichowsky. Services were held Wednesday, February 7, at I.J. Morris.

title: Accounts
description: * Ruth's Chris Steak House, New Orleans, to the Bethesda, Md., office of Earle Palmer Brown, part of Panoramic Communications, to handle its account, which had been at Duke Creative Marketing Solutions, New Orleans. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $10 million.

title: More Storage in Your Pocket For the Computer on Your Lap
description: I.B.M. threw its hat into the ring of new PC offerings this week with revisions to its ThinkPad and NetVista lines.

title: To the Arabs, It's Bad News. Or It's Good. And So What?
description: Reaction in the Arab world to the election of Ariel Sharon was a mixture of indifference, predictions of dire consequences for any agreement with the Palestinians and occasional relief among Arabs hostile to Israel that the notorious general would be the one to abort the idea of coexistence.

title: Two Opposition Leaders Are Arrested in Zimbabwe Crackdown
description: In a widening government crackdown on independent voices in Zimbabwe, the police in that country arrested two political opposition leaders this week on charges of inciting violence during speeches at weekend rallies.

title: Stop Them Before They Overspend Again
description: The table has been set. The Congressional Budget Office has projected that budget surpluses over the next 10 years will amount to $5.6 trillion. Alan Greenspan has offered his blessing for tax cuts. The president and Congress are poised to binge, not only on tax cuts, but on things like defense spending, prescription drugs for Medicare beneficiaries and education initiatives.

title: The Basket That Lets You Shop Until You Scoot
description: Say you go everywhere on your Razor scooter. Since you need both hands to steer, what happens when you want to buy a paper and a quart of milk? The Trottibasket from France is the Razor answer to a glove compartment and trunk. Made of sturdy translucent plastic, the attachment, around $20, fits all Razor models, and is, of course, perfect for carrying a loaf of French bread home. Stores that offer the basket in the United States can be found at the designers' Web site, www.stilicforce.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Bush Outlines His Principles For Protecting Patient Rights
description: President Bush laid out his criteria for patients' rights legislation today, saying patients should, as a last resort, be able to sue insurance companies that improperly denied medical care.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Aibo's Lack of Education

title: Searching For an Entre On a Menu of 8 Composers
description: Attending the Juilliard School's annual Focus! festival of 20th-century music is a bit like visiting a garden in early spring. There are a lot of eager buds ready to burst (plus some that are frost-nipped), but the shapes and colors of the summer can only be guessed at.

title: CITIGROUP UNIT AGREES TO BUY REST OF DELCO REMY
description: A venture capital unit of Citigroup has agreed to buy the 47 percent of the auto parts maker Delco Remy International that it does not already own. The Citicorp unit, Court Square Capital, will pay $109.3 million, or $9.50 each, for the remaining 11.5 million shares of Delco Remy after raising an earlier offer by about 19 percent. Delco Remy said its board would recommend that shareholders accept the offer. The board last month urged shareholders to take no action on Court Square's offer of $8 a share, or about $92 million. Delco Remy, a maker of starter motors and alternators based in Anderson, Ind., was spun off by General Motors in 1994.

title: Sharon in Power: The New Mideast Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: Africans Ask if Washington's Sun Will Shine on Them
description: Expectations for Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the new Bush administration have never been high in Africa. Most of the worry flowed from a single comment made by George W. Bush during the presidential campaign: ''While Africa may be important, it doesn't fit into the national strategic interests, as far as I can see them.''

title: Don't Glorify Graffiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Sather Won't Give Up on Rangers
description: Glen Sather awoke yesterday with the frustrating realization that eight months into his job as the Rangers' president and general manager, he has yet to have any real impact on the team, which seems almost certain to miss the playoffs for the fourth consecutive season.

title: Sharon in Power: The New Mideast Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: CORNING PLANS OPTICAL FIBER PLANT IN OKLAHOMA
description: Corning, the world's largest maker of fiber optic cable, said yesterday that it planned to invest about $400 million to build an optical fiber plant in Oklahoma City. The plant will open in 2004 and will employ several hundred people, the company said. Corning, based in Corning, N.Y., said it planned to increase its fiber manufacturing capacity by about 25 percent a year from 2002 to 2004. The company said in December that it would spend $450 million to expand its plant in Concord, N.C. Corning's shares fell $3.25, to $46.50.

title: The Quiet Beatle Makes Playful Noise Online
description: George Harrison, the ''quiet Beatle,'' is making a lot of noise online. AllThingsMustPass.com, a Web site promoting the reissue of his 1970 solo album, is filled with weeping guitars, chirping birds, giggling gnomes and other playful audio elements. Beatle buffs will enjoy the handwritten lyrics for ''My Sweet Lord,'' but the highly animated site is also stocked with goodies like a blue mushroom linked to a short cartoon for ''Let It Down.'' Employees of @radical.media, a New York design firm, moved into Harrison's home to build the site. ''For him, the lack of sound was clearly disturbing,'' said Jon Kamen, @radical's chairman. MATTHEW MIRAPAUL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the effects of the merit-based Hope Scholarships on enrollment and minority recruitment at the University of Georgia misstated the given name of the former editor of the student newspaper, who said he sensed less diversity on campus. He is Mark Anthony Thomas, not Michael.

title: MORE CUTS AT ONLINE POSTAGE SERVICE
description: Stamps.com, a company that permits users to buy postage online and print electronic stamps directly onto envelopes, labels or business documents, said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by 50 percent. The company laid off 150 employees in Santa Monica, Calif., and Bellevue, Wash., in what company officials said was a continuing effort to streamline operations and to achieve profitability. Bruce Coleman, chief executive of Stamps.com, said the company was trying to get ''back to the basics, operating on the most efficient levels.'' Last fall, Stamps.com laid off 240 employees. Mr. Coleman, who said the company's Internet postage service had 300,000 active customers, called the latest job cuts ''a new start for a company with a strong market opportunity, significant resources and a growing customer base.''

title: New Yale Venture Fund To Use Student Volunteers
description: Students at Yale University's School of Management will have an opportunity to start giving back to their alma mater even before they graduate, thanks to the creation of a venture capital fund supported by the university and private investors.

title: Deal on Citigroup Tower Puts Buyer in the Real Estate Big Leagues
description: Two weeks ago, Eric Hadar's deal to buy the 59-story Citigroup tower for $725 million and carve his family's name into the New York skyline hit a major snag and nearly fell apart.

title: New Increases in Worker Output
description: Despite the slowing economy, American workers increased their productivity at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the last three months of 2000, a gain that was higher than expected, the government reported yesterday.

title: Officer Shoots Armed Man Near White House Fence
description: An accountant who worked for the Internal Revenue Service years ago and has been engaged in disputes with the agency fired shots outside the White House fence today and after a 10-minute standoff was shot in the knee by a Secret Service agent, officials said.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: INDEX TRADING VENTURE
description: Euronext, Europe's second- largest stock exchange, which groups the French, Dutch and Belgian bourses, said it had agreed to a joint venture with the American Stock Exchange to cross-list index funds. The American exchange, the third-biggest United States exchange, is the world's largest market for the funds, which enable investors to trade a portfolio of stocks as a single instrument. The two bourses said trading would begin later this year depending on regulatory approval. Alan Cowell

title: The Eurodrive Program: Lease for Less
description: For Americans thinking of a longer European driving vacation, Renault suggests a potentially less-expensive alternative to renting a car: leasing. Renaults Eurodrive program arranges short-term leases of 17 to 185 days, for anyone whose permanent address is outside a European Union country. The savings come from treating the deal as a purchase-repurchase transaction, which exempts it from car-rental taxes of almost 20 percent. For comparison purposes, a 17-day lease on a subcompact Renault Twingo is $499, or about $30 a day, with unlimited mileage. The leased cars are factory-fresh: no dents, scratches or smoking odors  you get to provide those. There are 33 pickup-dropoff sites in nine European countries, and the minimum age for leasing is 18. The price includes fire, theft, collision and liability coverage with no deductible. Call (800) 221-1052 or call up www.renaultusa.com .

title: Anne Morrow Lindbergh, 94, Dies; Champion of Flight and Women's Concerns
description: Anne Morrow Lindbergh, the lyrical author and aviator whose marriage to Charles A. Lindbergh brought her both joy and tragedy, died yesterday at her home in Passumpsic, Vt. She was 94.

title: Little Squares And Big Sales
description: Book publishing, like many entrancing enterprises, has its own quiet outskirts of charm and profitability that few think about amid the glamour of huge advances, mega-selling authors, celebrity agents and star publishers. But the fantastical obsession for filling up those small empty white squares with J's and I's and L's and S's until incrementally they become words is one of those inaudible amusements that generate sales in the many millions of what is really an esoteric genre, the crossword puzzle book.

title: 5 Drug Makers Use Material With Possible Mad Cow Link
description: For the last eight years, the Food and Drug Administration has repeatedly asked pharmaceutical companies not to use materials from cattle raised in countries where there is a risk of mad cow disease.

title: Essay; The 'New' Sharon?
description: Strange, how conservative hawks Churchill, de Gaulle, Nixon, now Ariel Sharon -- can survive years in the political wilderness until warlike circumstances impel their nations to turn to them.

title: Telmex Completes Spinoff Of 2 Big Parts of Business
description: Telfonos de Mxico, the country's dominant telephone company, spun off its cellular and international businesses throughout the Western Hemisphere to its shareholders today as a new company called Amrica Mvil. Its stock began trading in Mexico City and Madrid today; its American depository receipts begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANCTUARY OF ABRAHAM AND SARAH
description: Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah Above ground Jewish burial. Affordable indoor mausoleum spaces and prime family rooms. Free brochure, call 800-526-4600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIERRA, NATALIA MARIA
description: SIERRA-Natalia Maria, 92, a long time resident of Brooklyn, passed away in San Diego, February 3, 2001. She is survived by her daughter Elisa Gutierrez of San Diego, one brother Luis Diaz of Florida and one grandson, Miguel Gutierrez of San Diego. Funeral mass Thursday, February 8, 2001, St. Brigid Catholic Church, San Diego. Donations are suggested to the Marcelino F. Sierra Memorial Scholarship Fund. Checks can be sent to the New York City Branch of the ASM (American Society of Microbiology P.O. Box 736, Westbury, New York 11590.

title: Jets Add Coach For Receivers
description: The Jets continued to fill out their coaching staff yesterday, hiring Mose Rison as the wide receivers coach, a job he held for six years at Stanford. Rison, who is the cousin of Oakland Raiders receiver Andre Rison, coached Mark Harris and Troy Walker, both of whom are in the National Football League, while they were at Stanford. He also coached the 2001 draft prospect DeRonnie Pitts.

title: PERRY ELLIS BUYING BUGLE BOY NAME AND SOME OPERATIONS
description: Perry Ellis International Inc., a maker of men's clothing, said yesterday that it would acquire the name and wholesale clothing operations of Bugle Boy Industries to add to its line of sportswear. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Perry Ellis said the purchase of Bugle Boy, which is under bankruptcy court protection, is subject to the court's approval. Perry Ellis, based in Miami, said the purchase included Bugle Boy's licensing operations, other intellectual property and inventory.

title: Transcript of Richard Sandomir's Visit to the Media and Business Forum
description: Richard Sandomir, who covers sports media and sports business for The Times, visited the forums on Feb. 7. Here is a transcript.

title: A Swiss Army Knife on Wheels
description: BRAN FERREN missed the last great era of exploration by over a century. But more than a little of Sir Ernest Shackleton's adventuring spirit has found its way into the MaxiMog, a one-of-a-kind custom expedition vehicle that he and a team of dozens of experts built from the ground up over the last three years. He came up with the idea of a car -- he calls it the MaxiMog Global Expedition System -- that he could drive around the world while president for research and development, technology, at Walt Disney Imagineering, where he worked until last year overseeing more than 100 Imagineers, the term Disney coined for his designers 50 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a survey of Silicon Alley workers misstated the job held by Ned Rightor, who helped conduct it. He is president of MXCIX, an executive search and work-force research company in Boston. He is no longer a vice president of the Isaacson Miller executive search firm.

title: The Glow of the Footlights Beckons the Young and Free
description: There are no calla lilies in the Salt Theater production of ''Stage Door.'' The central character, Terry (played by Katharine Hepburn in the 1937 movie version), isn't rich or arrogant. And no one in the 27-member cast will remind anyone of Ginger Rogers, Eve Arden, Andrea Leeds or Lucille Ball. This is a revival of George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber's 1936 Broadway play, not the film loosely based on it, and it's a very different animal.

title: Critics of Power Generators Sue, Citing Threat to Environment
description: A coalition of neighborhood and environmental groups sued yesterday to block an emergency plan that would bolster New York City's electricity-generating capacity in time for the summer. The groups said the plan had been illegally and unnecessarily rushed into place.

title: Castanets and a Mazurka in Paris's 'Paquita'
description: Curses, foiled again! A mustached Spanish villain in a 19th-century ballet orders the death of Lucien, a young French officer betrothed to the villain's sister but in love with a Gypsy. This heroine, Paquita, escapes with Lucien through a revolving panel in a fireplace.

title: Sharon in Power: The New Mideast Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: Wiretap Laws; The Legal Hurdles For Surveillance
description: THE number of court-approved wiretaps is higher than ever, but it is probably less than most people think. The most recent report by the Administrative Office of the United States Courts says 1,350 full-scale wiretaps were authorized by state and federal courts in 1999, a 2 percent increase over 1998.

title: Washington Memo; Tax Foes' Best of Times Equals Worst for Others
description: The last time federal taxes were reduced was 20 years ago. Not coincidentally, that was the last time a Republican took over the White House from a Democrat.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Murdoch's satellite TV goals raise doubts about the timing.
description: RUPERT MURDOCH finally seems close to obtaining a satellite television system in the United States, but investors are fretting that he might overpay for a slowing business.

title: The Debut of a Young Cellist With Energy to Spare
description: Some child prodigies are said to play beyond their years. Alisa Weilerstein, an 18-year-old cellist, came across in her debut Friday night at Weill Recital Hall as exactly her age -- in the best possible sense. She presented a difficult Romantic program calculated to make New York sit up and take notice, and she played it with an abundance of heightened emotion.

title: Economic Scene; Comparing the Nasdaq bubble to tulipmania is unfair to the flowers.
description: AS the Nasdaq bubble yet another example of tulipmania?

title: Metro Business Briefs
description: SOROS GETS CONTROL OF BLUEFLY

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sharecroppers' Promised Land
description: A jaunty newsreel from the 1940's describes a mechanical ''robot'' that could pick as much cotton in an hour as a family could pick in a day. The commentator suggests, enthusiastically, that perhaps sharecropper families could move to Chicago and work for International Harvester, the manufacturer whose invention had destroyed their livelihood. The farm family staring grimly at the camera does not seem to find the prospects ahead quite so cheerful.

title: Damage Control; How to Protect Your Computer Against Blackouts
description: THERE are blackouts, and then there are blackouts. Unlike unexpected power outages caused by bad weather, the rolling blackouts in California have been planned and last no longer than two hours.

title: First and Second Ladies
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon in Power: The New Mideast Landscape
description: To the Editor:

title: Johannesburg Journal; A Tour That Finds Poetry in a City's Grimy Walls
description: At birth it was a village of swinging pickaxes, groaning gold miners and swirling red dust that choked the ragged masses. Yet 13 years later, the South African writer and feminist Olive Schreiner was already mesmerized by the raw energy, power and wealth of Johannesburg.

title: Independent Counsel Set To Withdraw Into History
description: Robert W. Ray, the independent counsel, says he is beginning the process of closing his office over the next several months, shedding lawyers and staff members, gradually shrinking the office space and eventually turning off the lights on the longest criminal investigation of a president in history.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Approves U.N. Dues

title: Controls Rely on the Twitch of a Muscle, Not the Twitch of a Mouse
description: COMPUTERS, cell phones and other gadgets continue to shrink, but the means of interacting with them, like keyboards and keypads, are either too large and cumbersome or too small for the human hand. That is the belief of a group of NASA scientists who have been working on more direct ways to control machines, starting with jets and spacecraft.

title: An Electric Razor, And Maybe Even A Few Close Shaves
description: Isn't the Razor scooter's whole point that it's self-propelled? Hey, dude, that's so Year 2000. Razor USA is banking on electric scooters to be the hot item this year. Above is the Razor E (for electric), with a battery on the upright. With one charge, the E scooter can go 5 to 10 miles, depending on how heavy the rider is, and how steep the hills are. But isn't there a power crisis in California? Katherine Mahoney, Razor's marketing director, said the lead-acid battery recharges in less than an hour. Made of aircraft-grade aluminum, the E, a joint effort by Razor USA and JD Components in Taiwan, can zip along at 10 m.p.h., so it's not for young children. (In fact, Razor suggests that buyers check local regulations to see if a driver's license is required.) $329, in stores in March; www.razorusa.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, GEORGE J.
description: AMES-George J. New York Medical College is saddened by the passing of our colleague and friend, George J. Ames. A member of the Board of Trustees since 1990, he recently was awarded the William Cullen Bryant Medal, our most prestigious honor recognizing individuals who demonstrate national leadership in health care, science, education, business or the arts. We will miss his counsel and his genuine interest in our welfare. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman Board of Trustees Rev. Msgr. Harry C. Barrett President and CEO Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D., Provost and Dean, School of Medicine

title: The Nature Consevancy comes up with a campaign to acquaint the public with its goals.
description: FOUNDED in 1951, it has 1.1 million members and an annual budget of about $740 million. Its mission is to acquire and preserve ecologically fragile places around the world or to assist local groups in doing so, and millions of acres of land worldwide are under its protection, more than 12 million of them in the United States alone. (That's more than the combined area of Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Jersey and Delaware.)

There were the requisite speeches; the local mayor (Rudolph W. Giuliani) came up onstage to present a plaque; society gathered for a dinner afterward; and the familiar players of the home team strutted their stuff before a partisan audience.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Bernard Asbell, a writer on politics and government, a college professor and a folk singer, died on Feb. 1 in a hospital in State College, Pa., where he lived. He was 77.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline rose 4 percent after the American Petroleum Institute reported an unexpectedly large decline in inventories. In New York, gasoline for March delivery rose 3.55 cents, to 92.25 cents a gallon.

title: Forced Airline Mergers Said to Be Possible
description: The chief executives of two major airlines left out of the industry's recent takeovers told lawmakers here today that they, too, would be forced to merge with rivals if regulators approved deals proposed by United Airlines and American Airlines to divide up US Airways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, SYLVIA (NEE ZUCKERBORD)
description: SIMON-Sylvia (nee Zuckerbord) of Brooklyn. Beloved wife of the late Allan. Devoted mother of Howard and Robert. Dear sister of Lee Fishman, Esta Rosenberg and Marcia Silverstein. Loving grandmother of Robert, Jennifer Gale, Melissa Nickl, and Stefanie Simon. Cherished great grandmother of Katie Simon, Madeline Simon, Nicholas Gale and Harley Nickl. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' corner of Park and Passaic Sts, Hackensack, NJ Thursday 9:30AM. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to UJA.

title: White House Says Race and AIDS Efforts Will Be Adjusted, Not Abandoned
description: The Bush administration scrambled today to contain impressions that it planned to place less priority on AIDS and race relations after the president's chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., said in an interview that White House offices devoted to those issues would be closed.

title: Study Reports Drug-Resistant Strains Have Increased to 14 Percent Among New H.I.V. Cases
description: Drug-resistant strains of the AIDS virus have risen to a worrisome 14 percent among newly infected people, according to a study of nine cities in the United States and Canada.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TV ADS TO PROMOTE CITY
description: The Giuliani administration will spend $3 million on a television advertising campaign to promote the city as a vacation destination to people in other parts of the country. In announcing the campaign yesterday at the annual meeting of NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors' bureau, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Cristyne Lategano-Nicholas, the bureau's president, said that although leisure travelers had been coming to the city in record numbers in recent years, ''aggressive marketing efforts'' were needed to offset the possible travel-dampening effects of a slowing national economy. More than 38 million people visited the city last year, Mr. Giuliani said. A spokeswoman for the bureau, Nell Barrett, said that details of the campaign, including how many ads would appear, and in which television markets, had not yet been determined. Joseph P. Fried

title: In Tapping Net, F.B.I. Insists Privacy Is Not a Victim
description: QUANTICO, Va. -- AS long as there have been law enforcement agents, they have tried to listen in on what the bad guys are planning.

title: Conflict Rules Urged For Doctor Research
description: Several top medical schools are proposing stringent conflict-of-interest guidelines for doctor-researchers who have financial stakes in their work, the dean of Harvard Medical School said today.

Beloved husband of Esther, father of Marthe, Cathy, and Laurie, fatherin-law of Bob and Rob, grandfather of Darcy, Lindy, Sarah, and David, brother-in-law of Sarah Sturim. Mentor, friend, inspiration. Private services will be held on February 9th.

title: Topics of The Times; Al Gore, Off the Record
description: Defeated presidential candidates, especially Democrats, have a way of dropping off the radar screen. Michael Dukakis comes immediately to mind. But that fate is unlikely to befall Al Gore if he can keep finding innovative ways of generating headlines. What he may also want to find, however, is a way of generating those headlines without embarrassing himself in the process.
