title: Bush Sends Tax Plan to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  President Bush formally sent to Congress today the broadest and deepest proposal to cut taxes in two decades, touching off a debate that seems sure to produce a major cut in personal income taxes this year, even as Democrats jockey to limit its size and conservatives and business interests seek to expand it dramatically.

title: Clintons Return Household Gifts of Uncertain Ownership
description: Former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday returned 11 sets of gifts to the White House because the White House usher's office could not determine whether the gifts were the Clintons' personal property or belonged to the permanent White House collection, an aide to Mr. Clinton said.

title: H. Otto Hirschler, 87, Who Aided Space Program, Dies
description: H. Otto Hirschler, an electronics expert who helped build the complex controls of rockets to propel American astronauts to the moon, died on Friday at his home in Huntsville, Ala. He was 87.

title: Jury Questionnaire Fills in a Few Blanks
description: They are bank tellers, retired track workers, accountants, book editors, salesmen, construction workers and office clerks. They are black, white, Hispanic and Indian, and their homes are scattered through Manhattan, Westchester County and the Bronx.

title: Pulls and Pillowcases: It's a Man's World
description: THERE are two kinds of men. The kind that spend long hours lying on the couch in front of professional wrestling. And those of us who prefer to spend our spare time shopping for the perfect couch to lie on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARFIELD, LARRY
description: ARFIELD-Larry. Born July 19, 1949 Beaver Falls, PA. Died February 5, 2001, New York City. Son of Julius and Clarissa Arfield. Brother of John Arfield of Philadelphia and uncle of Joshua and Jeremy Arfield of NYC. Devoted friend to many. MFA in Painting, Carnegie-Mellon University, 1975. Worked in NYC as interior stylist and display designer. His specialty was flowers. Memorial will be held on Sunday, February 11, 2-5PM at Bodanna Gallery, 125 East 7 St, NYC, 10009. Contributions can be made to Bodanna, Inc., an urban youth ceramics program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FADER, BRUCE, M.D.
description: FADER-Bruce, M.D. On February 7, 2001, beloved husband of Kim, loving father of Alexander, Anna, Emily, Ben, and Sophie, cherished grandfather to Amelia, dear son of Beulah Rothman, and the late Sam Fader. Services Friday 12:45 P.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: To Blunt Criticism, Bush Reunites Working Families Backing His Tax Cut
description: President Bush today trotted out some of the working families that he used in the presidential campaign to put a human face on his tax-cut plan and counter Democratic suggestions that his proposal was overly skewed toward the rich.

title: World Business Briefing
description: NEW ZEALAND

title: 'V' for Victorious, Among Other Things
description: THIS is all about Eve and the v-word. The playwright, Eve Ensler, is talking about both subjects the other day. Wearing deep red lipstick, her dark hair in a blunt Louise Brooks bob, Ms. Ensler nestles into the corner of a hip little cafe near Union Square, chatting up her crusade to end violence against women. The bustling cafe, City Bakery, its tiny tables inches apart, is a terrific eavesdropping joint, and women, strangers, lean over to interrupt in ''you go, girl'' mode.

title: Burnett USA to Cut 9% of Its Work Force
description: Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group, is making the largest single job cut in its history, dismissing 9 percent, or 200, of its estimated 2,145 employees.

title: Barnesandnoble.com to Trim 350 Jobs in Cost-Cutting Move
description: Barnesandnoble.com Inc., the No. 2 Web-based bookseller in the United States, announced yesterday that it would eliminate about 350 jobs in an effort to cut costs.

title: Mount Kisco Agrees to Extend Ban on Bias Against Hispanics
description: A federal consent decree intended to prevent Mount Kisco village officials from discriminating against Hispanic day laborers has been extended another year, as part of a settlement of a complaint that charged the village had modified a housing ordinance to force workers out.

title: A Palm Springs Inn That Is 50-ish and Proud of It
description: Bubble-gum colors, linoleum floors, Sinatra music. California Modernism has been recreated as a themed experience at Ballantines Movie Colony, a refurbished hotel in Palm Springs originally designed by Albert Frey in 1935. The 16 rooms and three town houses have names like Wallpaper (for its 1950's wall coverings) and the Norma Jean Room (above left, decorated with a copy of an Andy Warhol ''Marilyn''). ''There was nothing retro-kitsch that celebrated Palm Springs's heyday,'' said Sarah Robarts, who owns the hotel with her husband, Fraser Robertson. Near Ballantines is their other hotel, the Original, designed in 1938. Room rates range from $139 to $395 at both hotels. Information: (800) 780-3464 or www.ballantineshotels.com.

title: Laurence R. Goodyear Jr., Investment Banker and Adviser, Dies at 65
description: Laurence R. Goodyear Jr., a former investment banker with Kidder Peabody and the Fiduciary Trust Company, died on Friday while on a hunting trip near Los Lunas, N.M., on the Rio Grande. Mr. Goodyear, a resident of Bethesda, Md., was 65.

title: Photos Go Beyond The Inkjet
description: BEHIND every person who extols the virtues of a digital camera, there's a traditional film-camera owner listening with a baffled expression. Sure, it's fun to preview your photos on a digital camera's built-in screen, but getting them onto paper is usually a clunky and imperfect process, a far cry from simply dropping off a roll of film at the mall. You have to transfer images from the camera to a Mac or PC and perhaps fiddle with them for a while. Then you either upload them to a photo-developing Web site and wait for next week's mail or, if you're like most people, print them on a color inkjet printer.

title: Electronic Data's Earnings Are Better Than Expected
description: Giving investors reason to smile after a dreary earnings season, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation announced quarterly earnings yesterday that beat Wall Street's expectations by 2 cents a share.

title: Disabled Win Halt to Notations Of Special Arrangements on Tests
description: In a major victory for disability rights groups, the Educational Testing Service announced yesterday that it would stop flagging the test scores of students with physical or learning disabilities who take its standardized exams with special accommodations, like extra time.

title: Traffic Jam: Harried Drivers, Seduced by Museum Come-Ons
description: Can advertising be public art? That is the tantalizing question facing motorists who pass the 61 billboards on display in Los Angeles, part of a provocative new advertising campaign for the Museum of Contemporary Art. Conceived by a writer, Maya Rao, and an art director, Moe Verbrugge, at TBWA/Chiat Day advertising, the campaign borrows from conceptual art to market the art museum. Ms. Rao and Ms. Verbrugge selected the billboard locations and then wrote site-specific ''labels'' like those for a museum exhibition, as in ''Red Glowing Lights,'' top, at the intersection of Interstates 110 and 10 downtown. ''Turning the ordinary into the extraordinary,'' Ms. Zerbrugge said, ''forces drivers to look differently at their environment.'' The $1 million campaign (180 billboards will be installed in all, over six months) is well suited to the city's car culture. ''To build an audience here one has to engage with the city in a different way than in Chicago or New York,'' said Jeremy Strick, director of the museum. Whether it will lure drivers into the museum and its satellites (MOCA at the Geffen Contemporary and the new MOCA Gallery at the Pacific Design Center) remains to be seen. But if people go, they can buy a conceptual coffee cup that says ''Habit, 2001: Coffee in glazed ceramic. On loan from the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles'' for $9.95. (213) 626-6222.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the settlement of a lawsuit by four men who were fired upon by two state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike in 1998 misstated the cost and form of the settlement, and the outlook for further court action.

title: Love Is Playing So Well, He Might as Well Play
description: Before his victory on Sunday, Davis Love III had planned to take this week off.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Treasury Secretary Seeks Support for Bush Tax Cut

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen dropped after a report showed Japanese business confidence declined in the fourth quarter. In New York, the dollar settled at 116.26 yen, up from 114.75 yen on Tuesday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is greater diversity in two or three square blocks here than anywhere I can think of in Europe.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNOFF, DORIS
description: CHARNOFF-Doris. Beloved wife of Dr. Stanley, cherished mother of Dr. Shelley Teronno, Dr. Nina Charnoff Berger, Dr. Judah and Adam, adored grandmother of eight. Interment took place February 7, 2001. Shiva at 1117 East 7th St., Brooklyn until February 13.

title: ABBEY REJECTS BID AGAIN
description: Abbey National rejected for a second time a 19.2 billion ($28 million) takeover offer from the Lloyds TSB Group. Like a previous offer made in December for the same amount, the valuation is inadequate, Abbey said. It also said it feared any such combination would draw fire from regulators. Britain's Office of Fair Trading is expected to decide whether to refer the potential merger to the Competition Commission for investigation by Feb. 23. In the meantime, regulators on Monday gave a green light to a proposed merger between Abbey National and its preferred partner, Bank of Scotland. Suzanne Kapner

title: Bank of England Cuts Rate
description: LONDON, Feb. 8  Following cautiously in the footsteps of the Federal Reserve, the Bank of England cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point today, to 5.75 percent. The reduction, the first interest-rate change here in a year, reflected concern that the slowdown in the United States economy may retard Britain's already sluggish growth.

title: Nets Try to Build On Two Victories And New Hope
description: After a seven-game slide, the Nets slapped one masterful victory onto a ragged one and called it a winning streak, pleased to have ducked out of the monsoon.

description: Q. What is a VCD?

title: Internet Age Becomes the Dark Age
description: WHEN David Drake, an engineering manager in Escondido, Calif., saw his monthly electric bill climb to more than $600 recently, he took action. He turned off 7 of the 10 computers he had been running constantly in his house and cut back on operating his pool filter. He and his wife, Ginny, replaced their 13-year-old water heater with a more energy-efficient one, and they ordered double-paned windows with a special energy-efficient coating. Mr. Drake estimates that they cut their energy consumption by nearly 20 percent.

title: MP3.COM PICKS WIRELESS STANDARD
description: The Internet music company MP3.com said yesterday that it would design technology using a software standard developed by Qualcomm to deliver music on wireless devices. MP3.com's decision represents a potentially important endorsement for Qualcomm, which is competing with companies like Sun Microsystems and Openwave Systems to promote a universal software standard as a basis for consumer services for the mobile Internet. Qualcomm's standard is known as BREW, for binary runtime environment for wireless. Simon Romero

title: Vowing Peace, Aristide Is Sworn In Again as President
description: Jean-Bertrand Aristide was sworn in today as president of this poor republic for the second time in a decade, promising not only to build a peaceful and viable future but also to reach out to the very opposition that defiantly installed its own alternative president this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, HOWARD L.
description: CLARK-Howard L. Philip Morris Companies, Inc., notes with sorrow the passing on February 2, 2001 of retired Philip Morris Board member, Howard L. Clark. Mr. Clark served as a member of the Philip Morris Board of Directors from 1986 until his retirement in 1990. His colleagues on the Board remember him as a highly dedicated and effective Board member who made significant contributions to the Board, its membership and to the Company. The Philip Morris Board and its employees extend their deepest sympathy to his devoted family.

title: Poll Watch: New Jersey Governor Candidates Looking for Attention
description: Candidates for governor of New Jersey are arranging their schedules to try to gather early attention from the voters this year.

title: Albany Moves To Help Curb Doctor Errors
description: The New York State Department of Health has issued recommendations for hospitals that seek to eliminate cases in which the wrong body part or area of a patient is operated on.

title: New Bidder for T.W.A. Emerges
description: The AMR Corporation's offer for Trans World Airlines Inc. will face a competing bid in a bankruptcy auction next month, officials of an investor group said today.

title: GS INDUSTRIES, A MAKER OF STEEL RODS, SEEKS PROTECTION
description: GS Industries, North America's largest producer of steel wire rod, said yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy court protection and would close its plant in Kansas City, Mo. The move will cut by about half the production of the closely held company, said its chief financial officer, Luis Leon. The filing was a result of increased competition and higher energy costs, the company said. Mr. Leon said the company, based in Charlotte, N.C., would dismiss the 760 workers at the Missouri plant, which produced about 800,000 tons of wire rod a year. GS Industries has revenue of $1 billion a year.

title: The White House Shooting
description: There can be nothing trivial about the appearance outside the White House of a person who is armed and prepared to endanger himself as well as the president of the United States. But the swift, appropriate response yesterday morning by the Secret Service and other law enforcement agencies made certain that Robert Pickett, who appeared along the South Lawn fence holding a five-shot revolver, never came close to breaching the White House grounds. After a brief standoff during which he threatened suicide, Mr. Pickett, a 47-year-old tax accountant from Indiana, was shot in the right knee, disarmed and taken to a nearby hospital for medical treatment and psychiatric evaluation.

title: The Wise Youth and the Impetuous Geezer
description: Half a century ago many top players were in the habit, when circumstances were favorable, of opening the bidding as dealer with worthless hands. They hoped to confuse the opponents, and their partners could usually judge what was happening. This sometimes led to trouble and occasionally to difficulties with directors and committees, so most experts gave up on these psychic bids except perhaps when desperate for a good result.

title: An Electric Bike and Its Just-As-Zippy Display
description: Energy crisis? Electric transportation is all the rage. The Electro Bike, one of several models by ZVO (Zero Emission Vehicle Operation), will appear in April and cost about $800. It was designed by Marcus Hays, an entrepreneur whose headquarters are in the Brewery loft complex for artists in downtown Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERBER, ABRAHAM DAVID
description: SPERBER-Abraham David. Born June 18, 1901, a resident of Hollywood, Florida, passed away at Memorial Regional Hospital on February 6, 2001, of natural causes. He is survived by his loving wife of over 41 years, Charlotte Delfiner; his daughter, Elizabeth Alland Sperber of Chico, CA, and his stepchildren, Joan Stanley of Bozeman, MT, Nancy Stanley of Carlsbad, CA, and Kenneth Brian Stanley of Wellsley, MA; his grandchildren, Melissa, Audrey, Scott, Jason, Ashley, and Adam; great-grandsons, Ryan, and Maxwell. Mr. Sperber, son of Hyman and Martha Alland Sperber of Boston, Massachusetts, was a graduate of Harvard College Class of 1921 and the Harvard School of Business Class of 1923. A former resident of New York City. He was Vice President of the Lerner Corporation until his retirement in 1973. Graveside service will be held 2:30 PM, Thursday, February 8, 2001, at Beth El Memorial Park, Ft Lauderdale. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Jewish Federation.

description: The desert has been kind to Moses Pendleton. It has made his choreography blossom. His new ''Opus Cactus,'' which Momix, his company, presented on Saturday afternoon at the Joyce Theater, is a suite abounding with desert flora, fauna and fantasies.

title: Onetime Illegal Immigrant Sheltered by Chavez Recalls Painful Past
description: The satellite television trucks that lined up outside her quiet suburban home here have left. The reporters who once vied for interviews have stopped calling. Life is slowly returning to normal for Marta Mercado.

title: Shuttle Atlantis Heads for Space Station Carrying Laboratory
description: The space shuttle Atlantis, carrying a giant American science laboratory that will anchor further expansion of the International Space Station, created a visual spectacular today as it rocketed into the twilight.

title: Architecture Books With the Heft of Blocks and Bricks
description: BEWARE when you browse through bookstores' architecture sections these days: you might trip over monographs too huge to shelve, books almost as large as architects' egos.

title: Witness Insists Hip-Hop Star Was Holding Gun Inside Club
description: A second witness testified yesterday that the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs was holding a gun during a Manhattan nightclub shooting, and, unlike previous witnesses, did not waver from this statement during more than two hours of vigorous cross-examination by Mr. Combs's lawyer, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, FLORENCE
description: GORDON-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Friedman, Murray Gordon and devoted companion of the late Allan Gitter. Devoted mother of Frederick and Susan Friedman, Neil and Dana Bieff, Anita and Harvey Friedman. Adored grandmother of Stephanie and Andrea Friedman, Gwyn and Atticus Bieff, Adam and Jonathan Friedman. A true woman of substance, she loved with sincerity, guided with wisdom and supported with strength. She was an inspiration to all who knew her. We will miss her each day, but will carry with us her wonderful joy of family and life. Services private. Contributions to Variety The Children's Charity, 350 5th Ave, Suite 1234, New York, NY 10118, would be appreciated.

title: France Tlcom Trims Price Of Shares in Orange Offering
description: France Tlcom said today that it had cut the price range again on the pending offering of shares in Orange, its wireless unit. The offering may now yield as little as 6.5 billion euros ($6.04 billion), less than half what France Tlcom originally expected.

title: Sharon Starts Out by Trying To Assemble a Coalition
description: Wasting little time, Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon spent the day after his landslide victory trying to put together a broad-based government with his vanquished rivals from the Labor Party. He said such a coalition would pursue a new interim peace pact with the Palestinians.

title: De La Hoya's Vacation Is Over
description: Oscar De La Hoya spoke of retiring last June after losing his World Boxing Council welterweight title to Sugar Shane Mosley. Yesterday, De La Hoya spoke with enthusiasm about his return to the ring on March 24 in a 12-round welterweight fight against Arturo Gatti, the former International Boxing Federation junior-lightweight champion, at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas.

title: Senate Ends Bitter Dispute With the U.N. On U.S. Dues
description: Ending a bitter dispute with the United Nations, the Senate voted today to immediately release $582 million the United States owes in back dues, a recognition that the world organization has made significant strides toward revamping its operations.

title: Innovative or Traditional? Why Not Both?
description: One of the problems with jazz in the last 30 years is that its most innovative ideas and its best musicianship don't always come in the same package. The masters of technique often see tinkering with the basic components of jazz history as aesthetically suspect, while the daring conceptualists see the pursuit of traditional form and technique as soulless.

title: Parliament Supports Putin's Plan to Regulate Political Parties
description: President Vladimir V. Putin won first-round passage today for a bill to finance and regulate political parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, GERTRUDE S.
description: PETERS-Gertrude S. At 82. Loving wife of the late Roland; adored and cherished mother of Jody; dear sister of the late Adeline; aunt to Caroline and Maddy; great aunt of Stephen, Stacey and Douglas.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES, Jerusalem, a generic drug maker, said it received American approval for a generic version of the Procardia XL hypertension and angina drug made by Pfizer Inc., New York.

title: Ambitious Plans At Chase Manhattan; Retail Banking Chief Aims For Big Gain in Consumer Business
description: For New Yorkers, the local Chase Manhattan branch is as familiar as Con Edison or Verizon. With more than 1,000 branches or A.T.M.'s around town, Chase controls one of every three New York banking dollars.

title: American Consultant Makes His Own Comeback in Israel
description: Ariel Sharon was not the only winner in the Israeli election on Tuesday. Arthur J. Finkelstein, the American political consultant whose clients have ranged from Alfonse M. D'Amato in New York to Jesse Helms in North Carolina to Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel, chalked up a much-needed victory as well, helping to engineer the campaign to drive Ehud Barak out of office and put the Likud Party back in power.

title: Bobby J. Jones and Padres Agree to Terms on Contract
description: When the Mets planned their off-season, they separated their nine free agents into three groups. They were sure they wanted to keep five players and let three others go. The only player with his own category was Bobby J. Jones.

title: GARDEN Q. & A.
description: Urn Planting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOND, BERTHA
description: MOND-Bertha. Young Israel of Flatbush mourns the passing of our beloved member and supporter, Bertha Mond. Kenneth Auman, Rabbi Mark Goldstein, President

title: Gadget Tries to Lengthen Young Attention Spans
description: CRITICS have often argued that children who spend too much time playing computer games have trouble staying focused on tasks when they are away from the computer and in the classroom. But a new computer game system is designed to teach children to improve their ability to pay attention.

title: Yes-Dearing Your Way to a Happy Marriage?
description: IF the title had been scrawled in broom smoke across the sky, it could not have sent chillier shivers down my spine: ''The Surrendered Wife: A Practical Guide to Finding Intimacy, Passion and Peace With a Man.''

title: FASHIONMALL QUITS MERGER TALKS
description: The online retailer Fashionmall.com and GenesisIntermedia said yesterday that they had broken off merger talks after Fashionmall's board rejected the $7-a-share acquisition offer of Genesis. The offer was made on Dec. 29 after Genesis announced that it had obtained a 7 percent stake in Fashionmall. The companies said they would still consider a strategic alliance. ''Naturally, we're disappointed,'' said Ramy El-Batrawi, the chief executive of Genesis. Fashionmall is best known for its purchase last year of the failed Internet fashion company Boo.com. Jayson Blair

title: In Unruly Colombia, a Mother's Hope
description: For Fanny Gidalgo, the last three years have been filled with protests, frustration and pain. She dedicated herself to winning freedom for her son, an army soldier held by rebels, but nothing seemed to work.

title: Attractions for Visiting Children
description: J. EDGAR HOOVER F.B.I. BUILDING, E Street, NW, between 9th and 10th Streets. Tours Mondays through Fridays, 8:45 a.m. to 4 p.m. Closed weekends and federal holidays. Admission free. During peak holiday seasons waits can be two hours or longer. Write or call your representative or senator's office to reserve spaces for parties of up to six people. Information: (202) 324-3447.

title: Pauline Koner Dies at 88; Dancer and Choreographer
description: Pauline Koner, one of the eclectic individualists of contemporary American dance, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Russia Vows to Start Destroying Chemical Arms
description: Russia pledged this week that it would finally begin destroying 40,000 tons of lethal chemical weapons -- the largest stockpile in the world -- this summer, Western officials said.

title: FLEXTRONICS BUYS COMPONENTS MAKERS
description: Underscoring the trend toward optical electronics in high-speed communications applications, Flextronics, an electronic manufacturing services company with headquarters in San Jose, Calif., and Singapore, plans to announce that it has acquired two privately held makers of advanced optical networking and optical electronics components. Wave Optics, based in Mountain View, Calif., is an independent design and manufacturing service provider focusing on the design, manufacturing and packaging of optical subcomponents and components for a variety of high-speed digital networking markets. Fico Fiber Optics, based in Westford, Mass., focuses on the manufacturing of advanced optical and electro-optical modules. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, EVA S.
description: MARCUS-Eva S. On February 6, 2001. Loving wife of the late Dr. Jacob T. Marcus. Beloved mother of the late Dr. Robert L. Marcus, Judith and Bernard. Fond sister of Perry Silfen. Cherished grandmother of David and Barbara Marcus, Deborah and Gary Blyn, Eileen and David Cohan and Sharon and Mitchell Konichowsky. Adoring great-grandmother of Jared and Ethan Blyn, Matthew Cohan and Elana Konichowsky. Services were held Wednesday, February 7, at I.J. Morris.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/9/94 Another great battle just lostwish both of you were still in there fighting and winning. Miss you so much. Vicki

title: Poor and Homeless: Seeking a Way Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rules That Sotheby's Handled '98 Auction Properly
description: A federal judge here rejected accusations today that Sotheby's botched the 1998 auction of a large collection of Spanish colonial antiques owned by an art dealer in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Sanctions That Misfire
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, LARRY
description: FISHER-Larry. The Officers, Directors and Staff of the USO of Metropolitan New York extend deepest sympathy to the family and friends of Larry Fisher, father of USO Board member Arnold Fisher. Myron J. Berman, Chairman Oliver M. Mendell, Chairman Emeritus

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an eviction proceeding against Charas/ El Bohio, a cultural and community center in the East Village, misidentified the subject of a sculpture there. It is Pedro Albizu Campos, who fought for Puerto Rican independence, not a folk singer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, RUTH
description: KANTOR-Ruth. Your courage, love of family, generous enthusiastic spirit will always be remembered. Anne & Bill Lichter

title: Thinking Aloud About Movement: All the Rest Is Talk
description: A great tradition of blending dance and words goes back to Renaissance spectacles that combined movement with music and poetry. And dancers still talk. That's being demonstrated in ''Talking Dance,'' a series of programs at the Kitchen. Both the dancing and the talking were good there last Friday night.

title: Governor Sees A Takeover In Waterbury
description: Increasing the pressure on his hometown, Waterbury, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut told reporters yesterday that a state takeover of the city's troubled finances seemed inevitable and that he supported the creation of a three-member oversight board.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Tuesday about ''Theater of Light,'' a light show by Rudi Stern at the Flamboyn Theater at 107 Suffolk Street on the Lower East Side, referred incorrectly to his role in ''Global Village,'' a 1970 theater production by a video center of the same name. Mr. Stern was the video center's co-founder and co-director with John Reilly; he was not its sole creator.

title: California Treasurer Won't Save Utilities
description: California's treasurer said today that if the state's two largest utilities, which have run out of cash and can no longer buy power, file for bankruptcy in the coming days, ''it is their choice.''

title: KPMG Consulting Rises 30% in Debut
description: KPMG Consulting Inc. provided a bit of positive excitement on the Nasdaq exchange yesterday as its offering of 112 million shares rose about 30 percent. It was the first high-profile initial public offering of the year and one of the largest since the offering by the AT&T Wireless Group last year.

title: Federated to Close Stern's And Rename or Shut Stores
description: A darkening retail environment claimed another once-venerable but now damaged shopping institution, as Federated Department Stores said it would close its New Jersey-based Stern's department store division.

title: Clay Lancaster Is Dead at 83; Historic Preservation Pioneer
description: Clay Lancaster, whose trained eye and playful imagination illuminated the history of architecture, and whose 1961 book documenting the historic houses of Brooklyn Heights proved to be one of the earliest and loudest shots in the historic preservation struggle in New York City, died on Dec. 25 in Harrodsburg, Ky. He was 83.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Levy, Citing Need to Debate, Delays Charter School Vote
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he would delay by two weeks a scheduled vote by parents of children at five low-performing New York City public schools on whether to allow the schools to be managed by a private company.

title: TISCALI CHIEF RESIGNS POST
description: Tiscali S.p.A. said its chief executive, James Kinsella, left, resigned after clashing with the chairman, Renato Soru. Mr. Kinsella, who was chairman of World Online International before it was acquired by Tiscali, resigned because of ''a difference of opinion with Soru'' over the chief executive's role, Tiscali said in a statement, giving no further details. Mr. Kinsella, 40, an American who had been chief executive of MSNBC.com, was brought into World Online to restore investor confidence after its founder resigned last May. He will remain a Tiscali director.

title: VODAFONE PURSUING OPTUS
description: The Vodafone Group agreed to transfer at least one million wireless customers to Hutchison Telecommunications (Australia) Ltd. if its bid for Cable and Wireless Optus Ltd. succeeds. The shift would be made to try to satisfy antitrust regulators. In a proposal to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, Vodafone said it would sell some of its customer phone contracts and reduce its market share, after acquiring Optus, to about 40 percent, behind the top-ranked Telstra Corporation's 46 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEIFER, ALVIN H. (BUD)
description: SCHLEIFER-Alvin H. (Bud), on February 2. Beloved husband of Fleur. Devoted father of Nicola, Tracy and Kerry. Dear brother of James Sheldon.

title: China Is Said to Abuse Promoter of Factory Union
description: A silk-factory worker who was forcibly placed in psychiatric care in December after he tried to organize an independent union has protested detention with a hunger strike, according to a human rights group abroad. As a result, he has been forcibly drugged and subjected to electroshock, the group said today.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Stern Faces Problems On and Off the Court
description: The day after his 17th anniversary as commissioner of the National Basketball Association, David Stern looked out over St. Patrick's Cathedral from his 15th-floor conference-room window, toward the bustle of Fifth Avenue and Rockefeller Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, JOSEPH A.
description: COLE-Joseph A. On February 6, 2001. Father of Gregory. Cherished employee of Canadian Pacific Railroad and 400 Madison Ave. New York's most dapper gentleman, loved by all. Reposing at Redden's, 325 West 14 Street, NYC Sun 2-5 & 7-9PM. Mass Monday 9:30AM, St. Bernard's Church.

title: Sports of The Times; Years Later, Jones Feels a Link to Owens
description: NO,'' said the slim young woman with the bright eyes and the generous smile, a smile, however, that began to fade. ''I have not had to race a horse.''

title: Dog Treats For Admiring Humans
description: Dogs rule at this time of year. The Westminster Kennel Club Show opens on Monday at Madison Square Garden, and the Manhattan art world has scheduled shows and sales meant to attract the dog fanciers in town.

title: Album of the Week
description: ELIZA CARTHY: ''Angels and Cigarettes'' (Warner Brothers). As the daughter of two leading English folk singers, Martin Carthy and Norma Waterson, Eliza Carthy grew up hearing age-old songs about love and betrayal. She also learned to play the fiddle and to sing with the mournful, subtle inflections of traditional balladeers. Now with ''Angels and Cigarettes,'' her fourth album and American debut, she applies that heritage in her own songs. The contexts and attitudes are modern, but the heartache endures.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRODSKY, MILTON
description: BRODSKY-Milton. Precious memories forever in our hearts. Love, Grace and Ruth

title: Davis Cup Captaincy Fits Patrick McEnroe
description: The telephone rang this week, and when the reporter answered with his name, the voice on the other end of the line responded with, ''McEnroe,'' followed by a slight pause and then, ''Patrick McEnroe.''

title: The Neediest Cases; Mother Finds Support For Girl's Medical Needs
description: More than 15 years ago, Migdalia Figueroa saw a commercial for a foster care agency while watching late-night television.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Journey Into Directing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOECHEL, PAUL F.
description: KOECHEL-Paul F. Of Allentown, PA, and formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died on February 5, 2001. Husband of Amanda L. Koechel. Father to Lesley Lojko, Joan Lemen and Janet Koechel, and grandfather of five. He was a trust officer at the former Chemical Bank in Manhattan. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 10, at 10:30 AM, at the funeral home, 17th and Hamilton Streets in Allentown, PA. Contributions should be made to the American Parkinson's Disease Association, 116 John St, Suite 417, NYC 10038. For information call Bachman Kulik and Reinsmith Funeral Home, Allentown; 610-432-4128.

title: Article 2001020992206424148 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: INSIDE ART
description: Whitney's '02 Biennial

title: The Big City; Term Limits: The Promise And the Perils
description: DURING a tumultuous news conference Wednesday, City Councilman Stanley E. Michels imagined what would happen if the new term limits law prevented most members of Council from running for re-election this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEFFEN, LOUIS
description: GEFFEN-Louis. Dedicated brother, brother-in-law: Lottie and Abe Simon, Sylvia and Rabbi Joel Geffen, Rabbi Samuel Geffen, Bessie and Dr. Carl Wilensky, Annette and Ralph Raskas, Helen and Sam Ziff, Ethel and Dr. Abraham Geffen, Bess and S. Joseph, M.I., Frances and Oscar Birshtein. Contributions: Temple Israel, Scranton, Pa.

title: Houston School Chief To Test Hispanic Will
description: The confirmation of Roderick R. Paige as President Bush's education secretary last month was fast and flattering. It lasted less than two weeks. If only finding Mr. Paige's successor as Houston's superintendent of schools could be so easy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FADER, BRUCE, M.D.
description: FADER-Bruce, M.D. On February 7, 2001, beloved husband of Kim, loving father of Alexander, Anna, Emily, Ben, and Sophie, cherished grandfather to Amelia and Ester, dear son of Beulah Rothman, and the late Sam Fader. Services Friday 12:45 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Adultery in Athens, and the Heartaches It Causes
description: ''Signs and Wonders'' is a doleful romantic melodrama: ''Fatal Attraction'' shot with a camcorder. This digital video transfer, directed by Jonathan Nossiter, stars Stellan Skarsgard and Charlotte Rampling as married Americans, though it doesn't bother to explain their foreign accents. Perhaps they can get away with them because they're living in Greece. But the Greek landscape is overrun with American brand-name logos; Pizza Hut, Domino's and Tide are inescapable, indicators of the American drive toward commercial colonization, regardless of the consequences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, FLORENCE
description: GORDON-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Friedman, Murray Gordon and devoted companion of the late Allan Gitter. Devoted mother of Frederick and Susan Friedman, Neil and Dana Bieff, Anita and Harvey Friedman. Adored grandmother of Stephanie and Andrea Friedman, Gwyn and Atticus Bieff, Adam and Jonathan Friedman. A true woman of substance, she loved with sincerity, guided with wisdom and supported with strength. She was an inspiration to all who knew her. We will miss her each day, but will carry with us her wonderful joy of family and life. Services private. Contributions to Variety The Children's Charity, 350 5th Ave, Suite 1234, New York, NY 10118, would be appreciated.

title: BUSH IN FIRST STEP TO SHRINK ARSENAL OF U.S. WARHEADS
description: President Bush will order a comprehensive review of the nation's nuclear arsenal, a first step toward the unilateral cuts in warheads and missiles that he promised during last year's campaign, senior military and administration officials said today.

title: The Story of the Interned Jewish Refugees
description: The first half of ''Haven'' ends with a visceral jolt. In 1944 nearly 1,000 Jewish refugees who have been brought to America are arriving at their new home in upstate New York. As their train pulls up to an abandoned military barracks in the darkest night they are greeted by searchlights, fences, soldiers pointing guns at them -- all the terrifying signs of the death camps they thought they had left behind. Ruth Gruber, the American who had accompanied them from Europe, reassures the refugees that they will be safe here, even though their names are written on tags around their necks that read ''casual baggage.''

title: Article 2001020990211428588 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: Bowe Charged With Beating Wife
description: Riddick Bowe, the former undisputed heavyweight boxing champion whose private life has been marred by violence, was arrested yesterday on charges that he beat his wife during an argument at their home in Old Brookville, N.Y., the Nassau County police said.

title: Do the Poor Have a Right To Cheap Medicine?
description: GENEVA -- For years now, the Other War on Drugs has been fought from the thatch-roofed hospitals of rural Africa to the travertine-clad corridors of the United Nations' Palace of Nations here. It is a war over the sale of life-saving medicines to developing countries. At issue are not only prices but also implications for free trade and intellectual property rights.

title: Unit of BellSouth Accused of Bias
description: The BellSouth Corporation's telecommunications subsidiary is being sued by a government agency over suspected racial bias against black workers at the company's office in Mobile, Ala.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A warning light is flashing on the dashboard of our economy. We need tax relief now. In fact, we need tax relief yesterday. And I will work with Congress to provide it.''

title: Sports of The Times; It's More Program Than Pro
description: THREE weeks ago, the Giants, about to go to Super Bowl XXXV, were practicing in the plastic bubble here outside Giants Stadium, but yesterday, using a red-striped black football, the Hitmen were rehearsing.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Happily in the Middle
description: During the presidential campaign, Al Gore portrayed George W. Bush's tax-cut proposal as way out on the fiscal fringe, a risky scheme that would send the healthy economy into a downward spiral. Even Republicans saw his tax plan more as a wish list than a program that could be enacted.

title: Bipartisanship on Patients' Rights
description: George W. Bush pledged on the campaign trail to bring Democrats and Republicans together on behalf of a patients' bill of rights. But his failure now to back the sensible bipartisan bill being sponsored by John McCain, John Edwards and others in Congress calls into question the sincerity of his pledge. The legislation, which sponsors say is supported by solid majorities in both chambers, would make it easier for Americans to resolve disputes with their health maintenance organizations and other insurance providers and to seek redress when they have been wrongly denied needed treatment. The House passed a similar bill in the last session, but the effort died in the Senate, strongly opposed by the insurance industry.

title: Social Detectives for Life's Confusions
description: The pieces of data fly furiously, like the contents of a bulging overturned briefcase in a windstorm. Statistics, case histories, newspaper headlines, a set of rules from a guidebook: the characters in Kia Corthron's ''Force Continuum'' recite such things with the fervor of desperate souls in prayer.

title: Hong Kong Will Check on Falun Gong
description: Echoing the position of the Chinese government, Hong Kong's top official said today that he was shocked by television images of what Beijing says were members of the Falun Gong spiritual group setting themselves on fire in Tiananmen Square.

title: Xerox Facing New Pressures Over Auditing
description: The Xerox Corporation, which has been struggling for months to maintain credibility with investors and customers, is now coming under sharp criticism from analysts and management experts for not doing more to address accusations of faulty accounting practices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEYER, MARTHA CARROLL RAKOW
description: BEYER-Martha Carroll Rakow. July 12, 1890-February 9, 1951. Remembered for her love and generosity.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Stepping In For the Stars

title: Long-Distance Competition Drags WorldCom Profit Down
description: WorldCom Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings fell 44 percent in the fourth quarter, hurt as were its top rivals, AT&T and Sprint, by a consumer long-distance pricing battle.

title: SOUTH KOREAN RATE CUT
description: South Korea's central bank lowered its key interest rate a quarter-point, to 5 percent, as falling exports and weak domestic spending threaten to cut economic growth by half this year. The cut in the Bank of Korea's call rate, which is charged to commercial lenders for overnight loans, was the first since April 1999 and came just four months after the bank raised rates to fight inflation.

title: Motorola to Cut 4,000 Jobs
description: With computer chip orders falling and two rounds of job cuts already ordered in its wireless phone manufacturing operations, Motorola Inc. said today that it would reduce its semiconductor division's work force by up to 4,000 employees, or nearly 12 percent of the unit's work force, through layoffs and attrition.

title: Foreign Media Role Cited in Beijing Immolation
description: At least two official newspapers have carried articles saying that Western news agencies knew in advance about plans by apparent Falun Gong believers to set themselves on fire last month, and that some foreign journalists could face homicide charges for helping in a suicide.

title: Cancer Painkillers Pose New Abuse Threat
description: Harried police detectives in dozens of rural areas in Eastern states are combating what they say is a growing wave of drug abuse involving a potent painkiller prescribed for terminal cancer patients and other people with severe pain.

title: Layoffs Galore in Silicon Alley, but Many Find a Traditional Net
description: For Silicon Alley, the week started with Razorfish announcing that it would lay off 400 workers. On Wednesday, Barnesandnoble.com cut 350 jobs, Bluefly said it had agreed to be taken over by the billionaire investor George Soros, and GoRefer.com, an online marketing concern, said it was going out of business.

title: REUTERS WILL SELL SHARES IN ITS INSTINET GROUP
description: The Reuters Group, a news agency and leading provider of financial information, said yesterday that it planned to raise as much as $450 million by selling shares in the Instinet Group, its electronic securities trading unit. Instinet, which is based in New York, allows investors to trade stocks directly with one another. The plan was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The total number of shares and their price will be determined later, the plan said. Instinet hopes to complete the sale in the middle of this year. It will use some of the proceeds from the initial public offering to repay about $200 million owed to Reuters and may use some cash for acquisitions.

title: Struggling British Telecom Works to Chart Clear Path
description: Its stock has sagged 59 percent from its peak. Interest costs are eroding its profits. A sour, erratic market mood casts doubt on its plans to raise money. No wonder British Telecommunications finds itself on the defensive once again, battling critics who say it dithered away valuable opportunities.

title: Mediation and the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Beach Club in Bermuda
description: The Pink Beach Club in Bermuda reopens for the season on March 1, two weeks earlier than usual. To attract some early birds, low-season rates will be in effect through April 11, with prices from $330 a night for a double-occupancy room, with daily full breakfast and five-course dinner. After April 11, rates begin at $410. Weather in Bermuda during this time is not good for swimming, but amenable to most other activities (golf, sightseeing, tennis). And air fares are usually not at their highest, either. Pink Beach Club and Cottages is on the island's south shore. Contact Pink Beach Club, (800) 355-6161; www.pinkbeach.com .

title: Residential Real Estate; Setback for Bill on Disclosing a Home's Defects
description: Despite its unanimous approval by the State Senate and Assembly, Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed a bill that would have required sellers of private homes to disclose to potential buyers the physical and environmental condition of their properties.

title: A Tiny Force Of Nature Is Stronger Than Thought
description: A new experiment involving a tiny ball and seesaw has demonstrated that what was thought to be a mere curiosity of quantum mechanics could yield a force powerful enough to be harnessed for use in future microscopic devices.

title: Bush Tax Plan Sent to Congress, Starting the Jostling for Position
description: President Bush formally sent Congress his proposal today for the broadest and deepest tax cuts in two decades, touching off a debate that seemed sure to produce a major cut in personal income taxes this year.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, DAVID A.
description: LESSER-David A. On February 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Adrienne. Devoted father of Jonathan, Tina, Tony, Jamie and Jennifer. Adoring grandfather of six. Dear brother of Joan. Loving friend. Services today 2PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUENSTEIN, THERESE (TEDDY) ORKIN
description: GRUENSTEIN-Therese (Teddy) Orkin. A shining reflection of God's love, your spirit forever lives on in those who loved you so dearly and whom you so dearly loved. Susi, John, Michael, Carolyn, Cassie, Alex and Elizabeth. Reposing Sat. evening 6 to 9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (corner 81 St). Funeral services Sunday at 11 AM at funeral home. Donations can be made in her name to the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter, 237 E. 77 St, NYC 10021.

title: Glickman Provides Reminder Of How Good Sports Can Be
description: As the XFL's sewage pollutes NBC Sports, it is valuable to find a bridge to quality in sports television.

title: Bush Officials Pronounce Clinton Mideast Plan Dead
description: The Bush administration formally abandoned the Middle East peace proposals of President Clinton today, saying they belonged to the former president and did not apply now that Ariel Sharon has been elected prime minister of Israel.

title: Head of Internet Board Defends Selection of Domain Names
description: The head of the board that oversees the Internet's addressing system appeared before a Congressional panel today and defended the process the board used to select new suffixes to compete with the popular .com. But he said that the system could be better.

title: Resurrecting a Treasured Classic, Step by Step
description: THE curtain goes up on Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering'' at 9:53 tonight at the New York State Theater. The audience settles into its seats, cell phones and beepers obediently turned off for the most part and baby sitters checked during intermission. Backstage, New York City Ballet dancers are warming up in dim light in the wings at barres ranged across the scarred floor. One dancer has sought out the solitude of a nearby rehearsal studio.

title: Acquisition of VoiceStream Wireless Delayed
description: Deutsche Telekom's planned acquisition of the upstart American wireless operator VoiceStream Wireless has been delayed by a complex clause that was quietly added to the terms of the deal earlier this week, executives close to the companies said yesterday.

title: Seeing DVD, Seeing the Light
description: When its livelihood suddenly disappeared, Image Entertainment had one thing to do. ''Reinvent ourselves very quickly,'' said Martin Greenwald, Image's president. For years the distributor, based in Chatsworth, Calif., released laser discs for studios including Warner, Disney, MGM and Fox. Then, in 1997, came DVD.

title: Two Agencies Fill Top Creative Posts
description: Two agencies have filled top creative posts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPHSON, ESTHER (ESSIE)
description: JOSEPHSON-Esther (Essie). On January 31, 2001. Beloved mother of Robert, Terry and Stephen. Cherished grandmother of Lauren, Howard, Jonathan, Amy, Matthew, David and Michael, and cherished great-grandmother of Elijah. Born November 2, 1915. Services were held on February 2 at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer and burial at Mount Hebron in Forest Hills, New York. We will all truly miss this wonderful queen of a lady. May she rest in peace. Amen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSCHING, RONALD
description: MARSCHING-Ronald. Of Woodbury, CT. A 1950 graduate of Princeton University and Harvard Law, Class of '53, died February 7. He was an attorney with the law firm of White & Case before becoming General Counsel and Secretary of the Timex Corporation. He retired in 1986 as Vice Chairman. He leaves his wife Marjory and daughters Christine of Paris and Jane of Boston.

title: Moving the Renaissance Forward
description: Correggio's ''Annunciation,'' below, is among the 129 drawings in ''Correggio and Parmigianino: Master Draftsmen of the Renaissance'' at the Met. They faced the challenge of following in the footsteps of Leonardo, Michelangelo and Raphael.

title: Parks Dept. Recruiting Program: A Great Idea or Example of Bias?
description: Cas Holloway, a 23-year-old graduate of Harvard, arrived at the New York City Parks and Recreation Department in July 1996. A government major, he was interested in public service, and the parks department, not unlike Fortune 500 companies, had recruited him on campus to come join a special new program at the department.

title: The High Price of Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon Offers Barak and Peres Senior Ministry Jobs
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9  Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon offered the post of defense minister today to outgoing Prime Minister Ehud Barak, who is weighing the offer three days after announcing his retirement from politics, Israeli radio and television reported.

title: Six Degrees of Oscar
description: Six degrees of separation may link the actor Kevin Bacon to most any film ever made, but gather a flock of DVD's and one finds that, with a stretch or two, Academy Awards aren't bad links either.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIFFUNI, JOSEPH L.
description: GIFFUNI-Joseph L. Of Plandome, NY on February 7, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Marie. Devoted father of Louis. Loving grandfather of Katie. Dear brother of Vincent. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 7-9 pm at Weigand Brothers Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Avenue, Williston Park, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30AM at Saint Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Manhasset. Interment to follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Home Video: Seeing DVD, Seeing the Light
description: When its livelihood suddenly disappeared, Image Entertainment had one thing to do. "Reinvent ourselves very quickly," said Martin Greenwald, Image's president. For years the distributor, based in Chatsworth, Calif., released laser discs for studios including Warner, Disney, MGM and Fox. Then, in 1997, came DVD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENAGH, DONALD F.
description: MENAGH-Donald F. Feb. 7, 2001. Age 85. Beloved husband of Claire. Devoted father of Diane Menagh, and Douglas Menagh and his wife Lucille Falcone Menagh. Cherished grandfather of Douglas and Nancy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Friday, February 9, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, February 10, at 10AM,, Saint John the Evangelist Church, 1st Avenue at East 55 St.

title: Saks Inc. Says It Won't Split Up, for Now
description: In a retail union that is turning out to have almost as many ups and downs as a Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor marriage, Saks Inc. said yesterday that contrary to an announcement it made last July, the company would not be spinning off its Saks Fifth Avenue division into a separate company.

title: Article 2001020992456278951 -- No Title
description: February 9, 2001

title: Ex-Wife of Pardoned Financier Pledged Money to Clinton Library
description: The Congressional committee looking into former President Bill Clinton's last-minute pardon of the financier Marc Rich was told today that Mr. Rich's former wife, Denise, had pledged ''an enormous sum of money'' for Mr. Clinton's presidential library.

title: Geiberger's 64 Good for Lead By One Stroke
description: Brent Geiberger was surprised to be the first-round leader, but Davis Love III was not surprised to be in contention.

title: Unilever Says Buying Spree Contributed to Quarter Loss
description: Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch consumer products behemoth whose brands range from soup to soap, said today that its ambitious $5 billion overhaul was producing its first results, as the company concentrates on big-name global brands like Lipton tea, Dove soap and Hellman's mayonnaise while shedding hundreds of smaller, less profitable product lines.

title: S.E.C. Opens Investigation of Lucent's Accounting
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has started a formal investigation of accounting practices at Lucent Technologies Inc. after the company stunned investors by reducing its reported revenue by hundreds of millions of dollars late last year.

title: George J. Ames, 83, Financier Who Spent 60 Years at Lazard
description: George J. Ames, a philanthropist and investment banker whose career at Lazard Frres & Company spanned more than 60 years, died on Feb. 2 at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 83.

title: The Stubborn Knicks Have Same Old Success
description: The way the season started was harrowing: a 29-point drubbing at the hands of the Philadelphia 76ers that suggested the Knicks, without Patrick Ewing, would be nothing more than a kickball for the league's elite.

title: With Three In a Row, Momentum For the Nets
description: Stephon Marbury did not wait for this weekend's national showcase. This was where he earned his first All-Star nod, defying gravity above the Continental Arena court.

title: A Refreshed Torre Wants To Manage Past 2001
description: Joe Torre leaves Maui every winter and takes his emotional pulse as he prepares for spring training, asking himself if he is still excited about being the manager of the Yankees. The answer this year, again, is yes, so much so that Torre wants to continue managing beyond the coming season, after his current contract expires.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTS, PATRICIA MCSHANE
description: POTTS-Patricia McShane. On February 7, 2001 of Chevy Chase, MD. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Gerli Potts; mother of Joseph McShane of Arlington, VA, Maureen McGlynn of Baton Rouge, LA, Colleen Danos of Virginia Beach, VA, Brian of Ashburn, VA, Dennis and Colin of Chevy Chase, MD and the late Kevin and Sheila Potts; sister of Marianne Doyle of Hilton Head, SC. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Ave at Harrison St., NW, on Sunday, February 11 from 3-6 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Matthew's Cathedral, 1725 Rhode Island Ave., NW, Washington, DC on Monday, February 12 at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to Catholic Charities, 924 G Street, NW Washington, DC 20001.

title: Whetting That Large Appetite for Second Helpings
description: ''He's a very dangerous man,'' the F.B.I. agent Clarice Starling (Julianne Moore) says of Dr. Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins), and she's right. Lecter is the world's wiliest cannibal at large, as his two previous filmed adventures, ''Manhunter'' and ''The Silence of the Lambs,'' clearly established. So he's definitely the type to be handled with kid gloves.

title: A Tasty B.L.T., With Mayo, For a Meditator Writ Large
description: Lawrence Goldhuber called his evening of dance ''When the World Smells Like Bacon.'' He also made and began to eat a bacon, lettuce and tomato sandwich on the stage in the title piece, a meditation on families, Judaism and being fat, in a program presented on Sunday night at P. S. 122.

title: Peace, One Very Small Step at a Time
description: Today, many Arabs and Israelis are ready to proclaim that the election of Ariel Sharon as Israel's next prime minister means the end of the peace process. Don't believe them. Whatever else Ariel Sharon is, he is not a man who ignores realities.

title: Article 2001020990794237807 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, JOHN JOSEPH
description: MILLS-John Joseph. On February 1, 2001. Beloved husband of Karin Landgren, father of Emily, Elinor and Benedict. Memorial Mass on Friday, February 9, at 6PM at the Oratory, St. Boniface, Duffield St., downtown Brooklyn.

title: Union Chief Has Issues On Eve of N.B.A. Talks
description: Billy Hunter and a dozen prominent players will walk into a conference room today at a Washington hotel and engage in a forthright discussion with Commissioner David Stern and several owners about the state of the National Basketball Association.

title: MILOSEVIC FACING ARREST BY SERBS FOR A LOCAL TRIAL
description: Slobodan Milosevic, who led Serbs into four wars and 13 years of impoverishment and isolation, could be arrested very soon and tried for multiple crimes ranging from embezzlement and election fraud to discrimination against minorities and perhaps treason, the new Serbian justice minister said this week.

title: National News Briefs
description: Report Faults Oversight in National Lab Studies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROUDY, REGINA
description: BROUDY-Regina. Our Kentucky belle and classy lady who sparkled with wit and salty humor, 93, of the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, NY, and formerly of North Miami, FL, and the Bronx, NY, on February 8, 2001. She was loved, admired and respected for her thoughtfulness and vivid stories of growing up in Lexington, KY. She is survived by her loving family; Leanore and Alfred Loeb, Bobbi and Harvey Chertok, Larry Loeb and Dr. Linda Silberstein, Wendy Katz, Michael Chertok, Pamela and Paul Caine, Douglas Chertok and her great-grandchildren; Jonathan Silberstein-Loeb, Mark and Lauren Katz; and Samantha Mallory, Ryan Grant and Gavin Kyle Caine.

title: ICEBOX CALLING IT QUITS
description: Icebox, the Los Angelesbased Internet company that produced some of the most popular animated entertainment distributed on the Web, is shutting down today. Company officials said the venture was unable to raise the $10 million it needed to reach profitability, which they had believed would be possible within 18 months. The year-old concern, which had 106 employees at its height and spent about $15 million of its investors' money, is one of a string of Internet entertainment companies that have gone under in recent months. Icebox was counting on revenue from licensing deals with traditional media, but was unable to generate sufficient advertising or merchandising revenue to stay afloat until such deals could be negotiated. The company plans to sell off its library of shows like the cartoon series ''Zombie College,'' whose characters include Zelda, above, and Mr. Wong. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: CALPINE TO BUY CANADIAN NATURAL GAS PRODUCER
description: An independent California electricity supplier, the Calpine Corporation of San Jose, said yesterday that it was buying Encal Energy Ltd., a Canadian natural gas producer, for $1.2 billion, including an assumption of debt. The acquisition, Calpine's third in Canada in the last nine months, will increase its gas supply by 70 percent. Last year, Calpine bought TriGas Exploration and Quintana Mineral Canada, both of Calgary, Alberta, for a total of $192 million. Shares of Calpine rose $3.43, or 8.2 percent, to $45.50. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Visiting May Be Hazardous. . .

title: Court Blocks A Water Plant In Bronx Park
description: New York City cannot build a water treatment plant in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx without approval from the State Legislature, the state's highest court ruled today, raising questions about how the city will comply with a federal mandate to clean its drinking water.

title: Trolling and Scavenging To Fill Empty Bellies
description: In 1998, concerned about crucial problems in Asia of food production, population explosion and environmental destruction, the Japanese photojournalist Hiroji Kubota went to various Asian countries to bring their troubles to the eyes of the Western world.

title: Congress Plans Study of Voting Processes and TV Coverage
description: Television network presidents are scheduled to testify before Congress next week about their election night coverage. The hearings could lead to new agreements about how television projected winners and new legislation about how Americans vote.

title: F.C.C.'s New Intentions
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Jets Name Harris As Backfield Coach
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards completed his offensive staff yesterday, hiring Bishop Harris as the running backs coach. Harris will replace Maurice Carthon, who interviewed for the Jets' head-coaching job but declined to return to the staff when he was not selected for the top job.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER SELLING PLANT IN TEXAS
description: The American Electric Power Company, which owns utilities in 11 states and Europe, agreed to sell a 500-megawatt power plant in Texas to Teco Energy Inc. for $265 million. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission required A.E.P., which is based in Columbus, Ohio, to sell the plant as part of its $12.2 billion purchase of the Central and South West Corporation, the Dallas-based utility company. Teco owns or has interests in 21 plants in eight states and Guatemala, Costa Rica and the Czech Republic. The natural-gas-powered plant being sold is outside Mission, Tex., near the border with Mexico.

title: The Battle Over a Tax Cut Is Joined
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REITMAN, EDWARD
description: REITMAN-Edward. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Thinking of you, missing you, loving you. Remembered always by your family

title: Seat of Government, Seat of the Pants
description: We had a great time, but a child-friendly introduction to government it was not.

title: Officers Describe Encounter With Combs
description: The police officers who stopped a sport utility vehicle speeding through red lights on Eighth Avenue in the small hours of Dec. 27, 1999, found themselves facing a remarkable carload of suspects, six officers testified yesterday in the trial of the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW JERSEY

title: BID FOR INSURER WITHDRAWN
description: GE Capital withdrew its offer for Equitable Life after the British life insurer said the proposal was inferior to a competing bid from the Halifax Group. Although G.E.'s offer of 1.5 billion ($2.2 billion) was higher than Halifax's bid of 1 billion, Equitable said the G.E. proposal included more uncertainties, including 400 million in loans and several conditional payments over five years.

title: MicroStrategy Chief Faces Huge Losses
description: Like many a high-tech executive, Michael J. Saylor, chief executive of MicroStrategy, a Virginia software company, has seen his fortune soar and swoon in recent months.

title: The Battle Over a Tax Cut Is Joined
description: To the Editor:

title: Annie's Got Her Gun Again, And Hits the Clay Pigeons
description: And boy, does it come naturally.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Marika, by the sound of it, could be Swedish or Hungarian or perhaps even Japanese. The cryptic name belongs to one of the owners, Marika Somerstein, and it sheds no light on the food, which is American.

title: Washington Opera Gets Gift for Training Program
description: The Washington Opera announced today that the philanthropist Alberto W. Vilar had donated $8 million to establish a training program for new artists and for the production of an opera and underwriting the performance of another opera and a vocal work.

title: Bernard Asbell, 77, Professor, Prolific Writer and Folk Singer
description: Bernard Asbell, a writer on politics and government, a college professor and a folk singer, died on Feb. 1 in a hospital in State College, Pa., where he lived. He was 77.

title: One Hurt as Car Bomb Goes Off In Orthodox District of Jerusalem
description: A car bomb exploded today in a strictly Orthodox Jewish neighborhood of Jerusalem, shaking buildings and sending chunks of metal hurtling through the air, but only one person was wounded.

title: With an Eye on U.S., Britain Cuts a Key Interest Rate
description: Following cautiously in the footsteps of the Federal Reserve, the Bank of England cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point today, to 5.75 percent.

title: Feick Rejoins the Nets, None Too Soon
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 8  Byron Scott walked into the Nets' practice gym late last summer and saw the likeness of Dennis Rodman  minus the Technicolor hair, stud earrings and otherworldly personality. It was Jamie Feick, with tattoos, from Lexington, Ohio, the Nets' leading rebounder from last season.

title: 2 Plead Guilty in Multimillion-Dollar Investment Scheme
description: Two men accused of involvement in a scheme to fleece millions of dollars from investors through stock manipulation, violence and fraud, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges of racketeering and racketeering conspiracy.

title: Despite Their Changes, Rangers Still Languish
description: The record is so absymal, the playoffs so distant, the performances so lackluster, that Rangers Coach Ron Low is simply looking for an honest effort from his players.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: The Battle Over a Tax Cut Is Joined
description: To the Editor:
