description: EUROPE

title: The Battle Over a Tax Cut Is Joined
description: To the Editor:

title: Kohl Agrees to a Stiff Fine but Still Faces Parliamentary Inquiry
description: Former Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed today to pay a stiff fine to end a criminal investigation into his illegal acceptance of $1 million in secret payments to the Christian Democratic Party during the 1990's.

title: People
description: Lance Mald was named to the new position of managing partner and chief creative officer at Earle Palmer Brown, New York, part of Panoramic Communications. He had been executive vice president and executive creative director at the Los Angeles office of Campbell-Ewald, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Finding Turmoil in Istanbul, Above and Underground
description: ''Journey to the Sun'' was shown as part of the New Directors/New Films series last year. Following are excerpts from Elvis Mitchell's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 29. The film -- in Turkish, with English subtitles -- opens today at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, ARLENE
description: EISENBERG-Arlene. Congregation Ansche Chesed mourns the loss of our beloved friend, past president and illustrious member, Arlene Eisenberg. She was a vital force in the life and revitalization of our community, and her wisdom and generosity of spirit directly touched so many of us. A generation of families learned what to expect from her skillful and caring writing. A light has gone out from our midst. Sincere condolences to her dear husband Howard, her children and the entire family. Funeral services at Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100 Street, February 9, 11 A.M.

title: Picture Perfect
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paris Journal; Gastronomes Have a Beef With a Renouncing Chef
description: When life in the French kitchen was still normal, before mad cow disease appeared, the chef at Arpge would singe the choicest T-bones and bathe his fattened goose livers in a mixture of caramel and raspberry.

title: The Battle Over a Tax Cut Is Joined
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001020993912166848 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Escaping an Evil Woman: One Who (Gasp!) Reads
description: Dennis Dugan's ''Saving Silverman'' is about two hapless losers, Wayne (Steve Zahn) and J. D. (Jack Black), who conspire to prevent their best buddy, the title character, from marrying the wrong woman. Almost as soon as Judith (Amanda Peet) appears on screen, the movie signals that she's trouble. Not only is she reading a book -- what, does she think she's better than everyone else? -- but she also summarily rebuffs the advances of a goofball in a silver sequined shirt and a Neil Diamond wig.

title: Nan Goldin -- 'Memory Lost!!'
description: Matthew Marks

title: Products of a Modern Dreamscape To Keep Noses to the Cybergrindstone
description: WORKSPHERES,'' the new design show at the Museum of Modern Art, is a bright basket of carrots without the sticks. It's no secret that Americans, in particular, are working themselves to death. To which ''Workspheres'' offers a bonny riposte: yes, but what a way to go!

title: Tests Keep Airport's Monorail Closed
description: When it comes to predictions about when service will resume, the monorail at Newark International Airport can seem more like a roller coaster.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NO-FAULT RULING UPHELD
description: The Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court yesterday upheld a lower court ruling that overturned stricter no-fault auto insurance regulations adopted a year ago by the Pataki administration. The New York State Trial Lawyers Association and the New York Public Interest Research Group had sued the state, claiming that the regulations were unfair to accident victims. The State Insurance Department appealed the lower court ruling, made last June by State Supreme Court in Manhattan, arguing that the stricter regulations eliminated opportunities for fraud. ''We are currently reviewing the merits and assessing what our next steps will be,'' said Joanna Rose, a spokeswoman for the department. Aaron Donovan

title: Metro Business Briefing; ECONOMIST NAMED
description: North Fork Bancorporation in Melville, N.Y., has named Irwin Kellner, the chief economist for CBS MarketWatch.com and the Weller professor of economics at Hofstra University, to the new post of chief economist. Dr. Kellner, who will continue with his duties at MarketWatch.com and Hofstra, had previously held the same post at Chase Manhattan's regional bank and the predecessor banking organizations Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover. North Fork plans to use Dr. Kellner's views on economic results and trends in formulating overall business strategy and direction. Allison Fass

title: Metro Business Briefs
description: NO-FAULT RULING UPHELD The Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court yesterday upheld a lower court ruling that overturned stricter no-fault auto insurance regulations adopted a year ago by the Pataki administration. The New York State Trial Lawyers Association and the New York Public Interest Research Group had sued the state, claiming that the regulations were unfair to accident victims. The State Insurance Department appealed the lower court ruling, made last June by State Supreme Court in Manhattan, arguing that the stricter regulations eliminated opportunities for fraud. "We are currently reviewing the merits and assessing what our next steps will be," said Joanna Rose, a spokeswoman for the department.

title: The Battle Over a Tax Cut Is Joined
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANES, MATHEW
description: MANES-Mathew. Respected lawyer and counselor, died February 7, 2001, in his 94th year. Beloved husband of Esther, father of Marthe, Cathy, and Laurie, fatherin-law of Bob and Rob, grandfather of Darcy, Lindy, Sarah, and David, brother-in-law of Sarah Sturim. Mentor, friend, inspiration. Private services will be held on February 9th.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Woman Against Mountain: Reaching Her Peak in New Hampshire
description: A half-mile from the summit, I stepped onto a boulder and was blown off again into deep snow. Struggling out of the drift took energy I couldn't afford to waste. Down below the tree line, protected from the wind and the killing cold, I had assumed that the summit was a given; now I'd lost all interest in getting there. For the first time, I wondered if this climb might be too hard for me. The answer came in the next blast of wind: it had better not be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, MURIEL
description: EPSTEIN-Muriel. On Februrary 7, 2001 in Stamford, Ct. Beloved wife of Louis. Loving step-mother of Gene and Mel Epstein. Cherished grandmother of Jim, Kate and Eric Epstein. Dear sister of Florence Silver and Alice Spilken.

title: Article 2001020993596992574 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: MORE HOUSEHOLDS GET BROADBAND ACCESS
description: High-speed Internet access among homeowners rose 148 percent in December 2000, compared with a year earlier, Nielsen/NetRatings said in a study released yesterday. Almost 12 million people had such connections in December, compared with 5 million in 1999. Not surprisingly, however, the audience measurement service found that more people still use conventional dial-up connections operating at 56,000 bits a second. ''Despite the current attention focused on broadband, nearly two-thirds of the home Web audience log online via a 56K-b.p.s. modem,'' said T. S. Kelly, director of Internet media strategies at Nielsen/NetRatings. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Another Master Designer Departs
description: TOM GALE is not the only member of the Chrysler design team to move on. Also retiring is John E. Herlitz, the senior vice president for product design. Mr. Herlitz, 58, directly supervised the design staff in recent years as Mr. Gale took on new corporate responsibilities.

title: Adelphi Looks Beyond Perfect Season
description: In the afterglow of Adelphi University's 78-58 victory over Queens College on Wednesday night, guard Ryan McCormack played down the Panthers' 21-game winning streak.

title: Jennifer Reeves
description: Max Protetch Gallery

title: Hip and Nihilistic, the Gangster Movie Reinvented as Part Musical and All Farce
description: ''Love, Honour and Obey'' may be the only movie you'll ever see in which a London mob boss takes the stage of a karaoke bar to belt out a cheery version of Jimmy Cliff's reggae anthem, ''The Harder They Come.'' This terminally scatterbrained gangster farce, however, turns into a musical only when the thought occurs, which isn't often. But at such times, it seems to imagine itself as a sort of facetious, bottom-feeding ''Threepenny Opera'' whose songs are cheesy production numbers that allow one or another character to sock out an obscure pop nugget with a canned accompaniment. Welcome to lowlife millennial London, where the karaoke bar has replaced the music hall as an entertainment hub and everybody's in show biz.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the reaction of American Jewish groups to the election of Ariel Sharon as prime minister of Israel misstated the name of a group that favors negotiation with the Palestinians. It is Americans for Peace Now, not Americans for Peace.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the shooting of an armed man outside the White House fence mislabeled a neighboring building. It is the Department of the Treasury -- not a museum, though it includes one.

title: City Unlikely to Change Voting Gear by November
description: When officials sat down in City Hall yesterday to review New York City's antiquated voting system, they had visions of dimpled chads, lawsuits and the near-panic that set in during the presidential recounts in Florida last year.

title: Leon Beer Schachter, 91, Union Organizer
description: Leon Beer Schachter, a union organizer, negotiator and former head of the Washington office of the Amalgamated Meatcutters and Butcher Workmen, died on Jan. 25 at a nursing home near Philadelphia. He was 91.

title: Kevin Garnett of the Minnesota Timberwolves is the focus of a campaign for And 1 sneakers.
description: FIRST, Kevin Garnett got game, in the parlance of his sport, basketball. Then, the upstart maker of basketball sneakers known as And 1 got Garnett. Now, the New York office of Fallon Worldwide got And 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARFIELD, LARRY
description: ARFIELD-Larry. Born July 19, 1949 Beaver Falls, PA. Died February 5, 2001, New York City. Son of Julius and Clarissa Arfield. Brother of John Arfield of Philadelphia and uncle of Joshua and Jeremy Arfield of NYC. Devoted friend to many. MFA in Painting, Carnegie-Mellon University, 1975. Worked in NYC as interior stylist and display designer. His specialty was flowers. Memorial will be held on Sunday, February 11, 2-5PM at Bodanna Gallery, 125 East 7 St, NYC, 10009. Contributions can be made to Bodanna, Inc., an urban youth ceramics program.

title: The Wraps Come Off Prof. Gore's Seminar
description: On Tuesday, former Vice President Al Gore's debut as a lecturer at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism was officially ''off the record,'' which meant, in the standard journalistic interpretation, that his remarks could never be reported.

title: Hungry for More?
description: In Ridley Scott's ''Hannibal,'' Anthony Hopkins (below) takes a second helping of the role that won him an Oscar in ''The Silence of the Lambs.'' This time, the chianti should be ever so much more accessible, since Dr. Lecter has moved to Florence, Italy. Can the F.B.I. agent Clarice Starling (Julianne Moore) be far behind?

title: FREEMARKETS BUYING ADEXA
description: FreeMarkets, a Pittsburgh-based business-to-business electronic commerce company, said it would buy Adexa, a manufacturer of e-commerce software. In a deal that is structured as a stock-for-stock merger, FreeMarkets will issue 17.25 million shares and options valued at $340 million (based on FreeMarkets' closing share price on Wednesday) in exchange for all outstanding shares and options of Adexa. Glen Meakem, chairman and chief executive of FreeMarkets, said the acquisition of Adexa would allow the company to expand its business-to-business services. ''Now we're able to not only help people source and find the best prices, we'll help them optimize, collaborate and synchronize the supply chain with the solutions Adexa brings,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Monday about Eddie Parker, a billiards player, referred incompletely to his claim of having inspired the book and movie ''The Hustler'' and a sequel, ''The Color of Money.'' Although Mr. Parker said the writer Walter Tevis had modeled the main character on him, the writer's widow, Eleanora, has told The A.P. that her husband denied this.

title: U.N. Drug Chief, Under Attack, Says He's Cast as the Outsider
description: The head of the United Nations drug-control and crime-prevention programs has come under attack from a former senior aide and an assortment of diplomats who say he has mismanaged his agency and is destroying its morale.

title: Four in Bangkok Charged in New Jersey Heroin Seizure
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that they had seized 126 pounds of heroin hidden in bales of cotton towels on a container ship docked in Elizabeth, N.J., and announced charges in the case against four people tied to a Burmese warlord who has long been a dominant force in the Southeast Asian heroin trade.

title: BARCLAYS PROFIT INCREASES
description: Barclays P.L.C. said second-half profit increased 8.5 percent as the bank, one of the largest in Britain, held back cost increases and bolstered lending to consumers after buying Woolwich P.L.C. Net income rose to 1.15 billion ($1.68 billion), or 74.4 pence a share, from 1.06 billion, or 71.3 pence a share, in the second half of 1999. The chief executive, Matthew Barrett, who took over in October 1999, is trying to cut costs by 1 billion by 2003.

title: Fix Up School Buildings
description: To the Editor:

title: Vito Acconci -- 'Performance Documentation and Photoworks, 1969-1973'
description: Ubu Gallery

title: Chevron Plans to Join Project to Build Turkish Oil Pipeline
description: ISTANBUL, Feb. 9  In a potentially significant boost for a proposed pipeline to carry Caspian Sea oil to Western markets via Turkey, the Chevron Corporation said today that it planned to take part in the engineering and construction of the project.

title: A Shimmering Beauty From Modern Masters (No Oddballs, Please)
description: Permanent collection shows have been taking up major chunks of New York museum space in the last two years. ''The Global Guggenheim: Selections From the Extended Collection,'' which opens today, is the latest of them. It's also the coolest, the prettiest, the least programmatic and, in some ways, the most conservative.

title: Berkshire Cuts Its Disney Stake
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Warren E. Buffett's investment vehicle, has reported selling more than 80 percent of its stake in the Walt Disney Company during the last quarter of 1999 and the first quarter of 2000.

title: The Pardons Look More Sordid
description: The hearing yesterday before the House Committee on Government Reform made it clearer than ever that President Clinton's decision to pardon Marc Rich, the fugitive commodities trader, was an inexcusable abuse of the president's absolute clemency power. The hearings produced information -- unproven but disturbing -- suggesting that Mr. Clinton may have discussed the pardon with a Democratic fund-raiser and was aware of objections to the pardon by White House lawyers. More Congressional inquiries lie ahead. Based on the testimony yesterday they are warranted, but Congress should avoid the temptation for endless inquiry and reach an expeditious account of the interplay between fund-raising and the pardons.

title: At the Philharmonic, Maestro Knows Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcome to J.F.K., Now With Service To Rochester; An International Airport Looks Homeward
description: When Kennedy International Airport -- then known as New York International -- was dedicated in the summer of 1948, President Harry S. Truman announced that the airport would become nothing less than the ''front door for the United Nations.''

title: RADIO ONE BUYING RIVAL BLUE CHIP BROADCASTING
description: Radio One Inc., the nation's leading radio broadcaster serving black listeners, agreed yesterday to buy a closely held rival, Blue Chip Broadcasting Inc. for about $135 million in stock, and cash to expand in urban markets. Radio One will pay $45 million in cash and the remainder in stock, the chief financial officer, Scott R. Royster, said. Radio One will also spend $55 million to refinance Blue Chip's debt. The purchase includes 15 radio stations owned or operated by the Cincinnati-based Blue Chip in Ohio, Minnesota and Kentucky. Radio One, which is based in Lanham, Md., said on Monday that it had completed the $52.5 million purchase of a radio station in Dallas. Including that transaction, it now owns 63 stations in 22 of the largest markets.

title: Cracking Down in Zimbabwe
description: Zimbabwe's spiral into lawlessness has taken a turn for the worse in recent days. President Robert Mugabe, who is struggling for political survival after two decades in power, seems to be shedding whatever pretense of democratic legitimacy he once maintained, cracking down on three vital checks on his otherwise autocratic power -- the press, the courts and the political opposition.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the reaction of American Jewish groups to the election of Ariel Sharon as prime minister of Israel misstated the name of a group that favors negotiation with the Palestinians. It is Americans for Peace Now, not Americans for Peace.

title: Loss in Technology Stocks Drags Major Indexes Down
description: Another slide in technology stocks dragged all three leading stock indexes lower today, leaving them all flat for the year despite interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve and a big rally in technology stocks in January.

title: A Telescopic Lens on a Baseball Legend
description: THE baseball career of Sal Yvars is a footnote in the sport's history. Just 12 unremarkable lines in the Baseball Encyclopedia.

title: Authorities Plan Charges Against Man Shot by Agent
description: The 47-year-old former Internal Revenue Service employee who was shot outside the White House after a standoff with police faces the possibility of local and federal charges, officials said today.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Public Interests; Elba on the Hudson
description: New York's greatest resource has always been the waves of refugees who come here, fleeing disaster and seeking to build a new life. We've had Irish, Jews, Asians, Africans, Latin Americans. Now we've got Washington Democrats.

title: Al Gore at Columbia
description: To the Editor:

title: When Even Semi-Opposites Attract
description: ''The Taste of Others'' was shown as part of the New York Film Festival last year. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6. The film -- in French, with English subtitles -- opens today in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Acquisition of VoiceStream Delayed by Changing Terms

title: Tough Life Lessons From the Deathless Diva
description: Opera connoisseurs may debate the merits of beautiful voices, but for people who believe in opera as theater, as characters in vocal action, the German soprano Anja Silja has to count among the supreme performers. What she does, she does fiercely. Starting on Sunday, New York audiences have a chance to see her onstage -- which is where she belongs, by right and determination -- in one of her great roles: Emilia Marty in Janacek's ''Makropulos Case,'' which she sings at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in a fine production by Nikolaus Lehnhoff originally mounted six years ago at Glyndebourne.

title: INTEL GETS $2 BILLION ORDER
description: Intel said yesterday that it had won a $2 billion order to supply the No. 4 cell phone maker, Siemens of Germany, with flash-memory chips over the next three years. Siemens had problems meeting demand last year because chip suppliers could not deliver enough of the flash memory chips, which store information when mobile phones are turned off.

title: As Ex-Theorist on Young 'Superpredators,' Bush Aide Has Regrets
description: From his perch as the director of the new White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, which he believes will help uplift many needy people but particularly the most troubled teenagers, John J. DiIulio Jr. conceded today that he wished he had never become the 1990's intellectual pillar for putting violent juveniles in prison and condemning them as ''superpredators.''

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 9.

Caring grandmother of Larry Eichler, Ellen Graball, Sharon Ingber, Jonathan and Daniel Linden, Ida and Jesse Bastiaens. Devoted sister of Alan Sverdlow. Great grandmother of 9. Funeral today 12 PM, EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY.

description: FORSTMANN-Nicholas C. The kindest of men. Loving wishes to Ted and the Forstmann family. Shivaun Manley

description: A Suffolk County resident has come forward as the first man to report that a county highway patrolman forced him to undress during a traffic stop, a charge that comes shortly after several women made similar accusations.

A memorial service is to be held at 11AM on Sunday, February 11, 2001 at University Heights Presbyterian Church, 2167 University Avenue, Bronx, New York 10453.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 31 about the future of the Menil Collection, a private museum in Houston, misstated the age and display status of some Byzantine frescoes there. They are from the 13th century, not the 12th. Stolen from a cathedral on Cyprus, they were in effect ransomed by Dominique de Menil, a founder of the museum. In exchange for her help, Cyprus agreed to let the works remain in Houston for 20 years, until 2012, not indefinitely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUMGARTEN, MYRA
description: BAUMGARTEN-Myra. On February 6, 2001. In Lauderhill, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of Neil and Sondra. Sister of Ruth and Martin Lindeman. Loving grandmother of Jay (Carol) and Marc (Stephanie). Great grandmother of Aaron and Ray. Graveside services were held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont on Thursday.

title: Children of the Renaissance, With a Hard Act to Follow
description: Correggio and Parmigianino, as the 16th-century painters Antonio Allegri and Francesco Mazzola are known, just missed the glory days. Born on either side of 1500, they were still incipient geniuses when the High Renaissance peaked in the decade before 1520. As such they belonged to the first wave of Italian artists to face working beyond the galvanizing yet daunting fusion of religious faith, classical form and empirical observation achieved by Leonardo, Michelangelo and Raphael.

title: Attractions for Visiting Children
description: J. EDGAR HOOVER F.B.I. BUILDING, E Street, NW, between 9th and 10th Streets. Tours Mondays through Fridays, 8:45 a.m. to 4 p.m. Closed weekends and federal holidays. Admission free. During peak holiday seasons waits can be two hours or longer. Write or call your representative or senator's office to reserve spaces for parties of up to six people. Information: (202) 324-3447.

title: Church's Window on the Past, and the Future
description: A slave ship rises in the east, a testament frozen in time and sun-washed stained glass.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; He Put a New Face on Chrysler
description: WITH Chrysler on the ropes, German managers displacing Americans and 26,000 workers losing their jobs, there has been relatively little fanfare over the retirement of Thomas C. Gale, one of the last remaining members of the executive team that engineered Chrysler's last rust-to-riches revival in the 1990's.

title: W.T.O. SETS DATE FOR MEETING
description: The World Trade Organization sets Nov. 9-13 as the dates for its next top-level meeting, to be held in Doha, the capital of the Persian Gulf state of Qatar. Human rights advocates protested the setting on the ground that Qatar curbs political expression, but no other country formally offered to be host to the biennial gathering. The European Union, among other members of 140-country organization, are pushing to revive a new round of global trade talks. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Laurence R. Goodyear Jr. -- Investment Banker and Adviser, 65
description: Laurence R. Goodyear Jr., a former investment banker with Kidder Peabody and the Fiduciary Trust Company, died last Friday while on a hunting trip near Los Lunas, N.M., on the Rio Grande. Mr. Goodyear, a resident of Bethesda, Md., was 65.

title: New Video Releases
description: Woman on Top

title: BHP SHARE BUYBACK
description: Taking advantage of an increase in profits, high mineral prices and a weak Australian dollar, BHP Ltd., the largest resources company in Australia, said it planned to buy back up to 90 million shares, or about 5 percent of those outstanding. BHP said it earned 1.4 billion Australian dollars ($773 million), a jump of 18 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: For Romance
description: Valentine's Day is less than a week away, and if you've been procrastinating about making plans, you might try one of the 12 romantic restaurants below. If you find they're already booked, don't despair; just save this list for another romantic and less crowded evening. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Cosmetic Saves a Cure for Sleeping Sickness
description: A cure for sleeping sickness, a disease devastating parts of central Africa, may soon be available cheaply because it has a second, profitable use: it eliminates facial hair in women.

title: In College in Georgia
description: To the Editor:

title: McCall Faults Pataki's Record On Cleanup of Toxic Waste
description: The state comptroller criticized the Pataki administration today for its handling of toxic waste sites, issuing an audit that said, among other things, that the cleanup of at least 30 sites did not meet the standards for protecting public health.

title: Gannett's Quarterly Profit Increases 3.8%
description: The Gannett Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 3.8 percent on higher advertising sales at its papers and purchases of publications in the United States and Britain.

title: Metro Business Briefing; LAYOFFS DESPITE TAX BREAKS
description: New York City has given millions of dollars in tax breaks to companies that nevertheless laid off workers in the city, according to a new report issued by the Center for an Urban Future, a nonpartisan policy group. Of the 80 or so companies that since 1988 have received at least a half-million dollars to keep workers in New York, 16 have recently announced layoffs, the report said. The report does not suggest that most of these companies have deliberately broken their agreements with the city. Rather, it said, they have usually been caught up by changes in their industries, like consolidation in the banking and brokerage sector, or the drought of financing for Internet companies. The New York City Economic Development Corporation, which administers the city's corporate retention efforts, did not respond to a request for comment on the report. Leslie Eaton

title: Animal Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: Powell to Visit Middle East at End of Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  Demonstrating the Bush administration's broad regional approach to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that he will travel later this month to Egypt, Saudia Arabia, Jordan and Kuwait, as well as Israel and the Palestinian territories.

title: No Longer All Rosy, Mayor's Report Card Finds Some Services Are Slipping
description: Departing from his traditional rosy portrait of the quality of life in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday acknowledged several areas of recent slippage in city services that he said demanded immediate attention, including slowing police response times and unkempt streets and parks.

title: Two Devils Injured In Tie With Senators
description: It was remarkable that Scott Stevens had the strength to talk minutes after the Devils and the Ottawa Senators played to a 4-4 tie tonight at the Corel Center.

title: When All Were Young And So Very Earnest
description: Near the end of Betsy Blankenbaker's documentary scrapbook, ''New York in the 50's,'' the author Dan Wakefield relates a personal horror story in which romantic disappointment combined with too much liquor triggered a halfhearted suicide attempt the night before he was to be interviewed for a Nieman fellowship in journalism. Patched up by a friend, the bandages on his wrists concealed, Mr. Wakefield staggered to the interview and to his own amazement triumphed.

title: Merrill Unit Makes Leadership Change
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that it had named Sam Chapin to replace Daniel Bayly as co-head of investment banking.

title: Tiniest of Particles Pokes Big Hole in Physics Theory
description: New observations of subatomic particles do not appear to fit into the standard theories explaining the matter and forces that shape the universe, scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory reported today.

title: Metricom, in Financial Trouble, Warns of Shutdown
description: Wall Street knocked off nearly half the market capitalization of Metricom today, after the company, a provider of high-speed wireless networks, announced disappointing subscription rates and said it would shut down in the second half of the year if it failed to secure more financing.

title: Don Celender

title: As Countdown Kicks Off, Bribery Trial Looks Likely
description: Just minutes before Mitt Romney was scheduled to set off a 365-day countdown to the 2002 Winter Olympics with a fireworks display tonight, and only a block from where revelers gathered to celebrate in a downtown plaza, Thomas K. Welch and David Johnson quietly exited a federal courthouse.

description: Mississippi's two Republican senators have asked President Bush to retain William R. Ferris as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities even though he was named to the post by President Bill Clinton in 1997.

description: THERE'S life in debt land.

title: Tom Gale's Legacy
description: UNDER Tom Gale, Chrysler designs went from yawn-inducing (K-cars of various lengths) to trend-setting (today's PT Cruiser). In the 1990's, Chrysler's theatrical concept car introductions were the most-awaited events at auto shows.

title: In Philippines, The Economy As Casualty; The President Ousted, a Credibility Repair Job
description: In the topsy-turvy hours before Joseph Estrada was drummed out of the Philippine presidency on Jan. 20, Alberto Romulo waited anxiously at the Edsa shrine. Famous as the rallying place for the revolt that overthrew Ferdinand E. Marcos in 1986, Edsa was again a locus of ''people power.''

title: Woman Against Mountain: Reaching Her Peak in New Hampshire
description: Ahalf-mile from the summit, I stepped onto a boulder and was blown off again into deep snow. Struggling out of the drift took energy I couldn't afford to waste. Down below the tree line, protected from the wind and the killing cold, I had assumed that the summit was a given; now I'd lost all interest in getting there. For the first time, I wondered if this climb might be too hard for me. The answer came in the next blast of wind: it had better not be.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COINSTAR INC., -- Bellevue, Wash., the maker of coin-counting machines, said it hired J. P. Morgan Chase & Co. as it considers the possible merger or sale of the company or its units.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Missa Solemnis That Mines the Past and Future
description: Simple, strong and sure, Beethoven's Missa Solemnis on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall was touched also with the sublime. The strength and the sureness were there throughout in the singing of the Westminster Symphonic Choir and the soloists, and in the playing of the Philadelphia Orchestra, warmly attentive to both the singers and the conductor, the estimable Wolfgang Sawallisch. The performance that resulted was full of astounding and generous moments, not least when it pointed up details springing from either the ancient past or the century ahead, and yet -- here was the simplicity -- the work came across as one soaring thing.

title: INSIDE
description: New Mideast Line for U.S.

title: H. Otto Hirschler, 87, Aided Space Program
description: H. Otto Hirschler, an electronics expert who helped build the complex controls of rockets to propel American astronauts to the moon, died on Feb. 2 at his home in Huntsville, Ala. He was 87.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE INTEL GETS $2 BILLION ORDER Intel said yesterday that it had won a $2 billion order to supply the No. 4 cell phone maker, Siemens of Germany, with flash-memory chips over the next three years. Siemens had problems meeting demand last year because chip suppliers could not deliver enough of the flash memory chips, which store information when mobile phones are turned off. (Bloomberg News)

description: Researchers expressed hope today, at the end of a major AIDS meeting, that a recently discovered molecule might eventually lead to new ways to prevent the infection.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Hearing the Voices of Hip-Hop
description: A dozen years ago, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences announced that it would offer a Grammy award for best rap performance. The rapper nominees were delighted, until they learned that the award was to be presented off-camera. In response, three of the five nominated acts stayed home -- including D.J. Jazzy Jeff and the Fresh Prince (featuring the future superstar Will Smith), which won anyway.

title: CANADA'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE IS UP
description: Canada's unemployment rate rose slightly, to 6.9 percent, in January, from 6.8 percent in December, but economists were surprised by the small increase in the number of new jobs and the sharp drop in full-time work. Marc Lvesque, senior economist at the TD Bank Financial Group in Toronto, said the latest report contains ''ominous signs that the economic slowdown that is under way in the United States is starting to make its way across the border.'' Almost 20,000 full-time jobs were eliminated last month, half of them in manufacturing. Only a marginally bigger increase in part-time employment produced a net gain of 700 jobs, ending a string of increases averaging 38,000 new jobs a month since August. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: State's Poorest Facing Loss Of U.S. Aid
description: Nearly a third of New York State's poorest families risk losing their federal welfare benefits at the end of this year, when the first batch of welfare recipients hits the new lifetime limit for receiving public assistance, new state figures show. Their cash benefits will be replaced by a system of state and local aid, but the details are far from worked out.

title: HONG KONG DEBT RATING
description: Standard & Poor's raised Hong Kong's sovereign credit rating, citing the territory's autonomy within China and its rapid rebound from the Asian financial crisis of 1997-1998. The credit rating agency raised Hong Kong's long-term foreign-currency credit rating to A+ from A, putting the territory's rating three notches above its sovereign, China.

title: A Referendum for Term Limits
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who normally has little difficulty deciding what he thinks on any issue, is remaining firmly undecided on term limits -- a matter of such passion that it nearly brought politicians to blows outside Wednesday's New York City Council meeting. With more than 150 candidates lining up to run for 35 open Council seats, the mayor's neutrality is not helpful. He should end the confusion by explaining that the voters have spoken twice on term limits and that he will veto any backdoor attempts by the Council to lift them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDASSARE, JOSEPH

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GARDEN BOTANIKA INC., Redmond, Wash., a personal-care products company, said it would close all of its 109 stores, lay off 65 workers and seek to sell its trademarks, Web site and other assets to an undisclosed party. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April 1999.

description: All Hallows, behind 19 points by the junior guard Marvin McCullough, defeated Rice, 61-48, yesterday to clinch the regular-season championship of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association New York Division.

title: THE MAYOR'S SCORECARD
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani will leave behind a city where the left is dead, capitalism is embraced and residents have made their peace with bourgeois values. But his agenda, as his second and final term is drawing to a close, has turned out to be radically incomplete. A report by James Traub in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE MAH, STEVEN,
description: GEE MAH-Steven, on February 7, 2001. Beloved husband of 53 years to Wai Lin. Loving father of Shirley, Rita, Evelyn, Betty, Steven, and Robert. Adoring grandfather of eleven. He immigrated to the US at age 12, attended Brooklyn Polytechnic University. He was an Electrical Engineer at ATT Western Electric, now Lucent, for 33 years. Following retirement, he energetically devoted himself to community service. A cherished leader of The First Chinese Baptist Church and a supporter of numerous community organizations. He will be deeply missed by his family and everyone he has helped over his fruitful, accomplished life of 78 years. Private service on Sunday. In lieu of flowers, a scholarship fund will be set up in the name Steven Gee Mah Memorial Foundation Inc.

title: Knee Surgery Takes Niedermayer Out of Play for Devils

Loved Nanna of Robin, John, Steve, Beth, Nancy, Jesse, Tamar, Kayla, Harlan, David, Deborah, Andrew, Susan, Marcie, Stephanie and Warren. title: So sue me, suggests the chief of the White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives.

title: In Government and, Incidentally, Gay
description: You may not know me, but until last week I was the highest-ranking member of the Bush administration who is openly gay. That wasn't my official title, of course. As a holdover appointee from the previous administration, I served for two weeks as President Bush's acting administrator of the Small Business Administration. I left office as a matter of protocol, to clear the decks for the new president's choice.

title: As Children Help Test Medicines, Profits and Questions Are Raised
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  Children and adolescents, who were once routinely left out of pharmaceutical research, are now being enrolled by the thousands into drug company experiments, a trend that is both transforming the care of sick children and generating qualms among pediatricians, ethicists and parents.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The Bank of Japan lowered its discount rate, bolstering speculation the economy will have to stumble more before the bank cuts the overnight rate. In New York, the dollar settled at 117.67 yen, up from 116.62.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about a Congressional hearing into the pardon of Marc Rich misstated the amount that a Democratic fund- raiser said Mr. Rich's ex-wife, Denise, had pledged to the Clinton presidential library. The fund-raiser, who was not identified in the article, said the amount was less than $1 million, not nearly $1 million, in four installments. In an interview yesterday, the fund-raiser put the amount at $450,000, in three payments from July 1998 to May 2000. An article about further developments in the pardons investigation appears today.

title: Colombia and Rebels Agree on Restarting Peace Talks
description: President Andrs Pastrana and the leader of the country's largest rebel group announced today a broad agreement aimed at restarting formal peace talks that have been suspended since November.

title: Some Roosevelt Relatives Join Effort to Save Heirlooms From Auction
description: One of the largest private hoards of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt's papers, books and heirlooms will be auctioned at Christie's next Wednesday and Thursday, despite pleas from National Park Service officials, historians and some members of the Roosevelt family that the items be preserved for the public.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 1 about Johnnie Johnson, a British fighter pilot in World War II, referred incorrectly to his ranking as an Allied air ace, as well as that of Richard Bong, of the United States Army Air Forces in the Pacific. While Mr. Johnson's record -- he shot down 38 planes in Europe -- was exceeded by that of Mr. Bong, who shot down 40 in the Pacific and was the leading ace there, both records were eclipsed by Ivan Kozhedub of the Soviet Union, who downed 62 planes.

Loving great-grandmother of Erica, Samantha, Emma, Alex, Cassidy, Ian, Jake, Reed and Ryan. Services Sunday, 9:45AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: POWELL WILL VISIT MIDEAST, SETTING A WIDE ITINERARY
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that he would travel later this month to Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Kuwait, as well as Israel and the Palestinian territories, in another sign of the Bush administration's broad regional approach to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Rising Numbers of Investors Make Social Goals a Priority
description: For years, John Rempel struggled to find investments that did not make him feel guilty.

title: An Unlikely Trio With Music at the Core
description: ''Fearful Symmetries,'' ''Robert Schumann's 'Davidsbndlertnze' '' and ''Brandenburg.'' No three ballets could be more dissimilar than this trio presented by New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. Yet music was the springboard for the choreography in each case.

title: Charges in Shooting At the White House
description: Federal prosecutors today filed charges of assaulting an officer against Robert W. Pickett, the former Internal Revenue Service employee who was shot after he brandished a gun outside the White House this week.

title: The Best Possible Investment in Africa
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Africa, with tens of millions of lives at stake, needs around $5 billion to $10 billion a year from the rich countries in the next decade to battle AIDS. This may sound like a huge amount, but it is a remarkable bargain. Not only is it tiny compared with the great annual income of the well-off nations, but spending it could save the rich countries greater costs down the road: in response to military upheavals, humanitarian disasters and the worldwide spread of infectious diseases given a new foothold by AIDS. Secretary of State Colin Powell wisely said this week that Africa's AIDS epidemic is a national security issue for the United States.

title: The Storm Over Clinton's Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: ALCATEL AND MARCONI RAISE FUNDS
description: Alcatel S.A. and Marconi P.L.C. said that they sold shares in Alstom S.A. worth 1.8 billion euros ($1.7 billion), representing 33 percent of the shares of Alstom, a French industrial group. The two companies sold an equal portion of the 71 million shares in the offering and will receive 900 million euros ($833 million) each in cash. Demand for the shares far outstripped the supply. Alstom makes components for the energy distribution industry.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a Congressional hearing into the pardon of Marc Rich misstated the amount that a Democratic fund-raiser said Mr. Rich's ex-wife, Denise, had pledged to the Clinton presidential library. The fund-raiser, who was not identified in the article, said the amount was less than $1 million, not nearly $1 million, in four installments. In an interview yesterday, the fund-raiser put the amount at $450,000, in three payments from July 1998 to May 2000. An article about further developments in the pardons investigation appears today on Page A11.

title: Arlene Eisenberg, 66, Author Of 'What to Expect' Guides
description: Arlene Eisenberg, who with her two daughters wrote ''What to Expect When You're Expecting,'' which became known as the pregnancy bible, died on Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 66.

title: It's Not Too Late to Save the Token, Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Storm Over Clinton's Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: Touted Guards Waiting and Wishing
description: New York City point guards begin their college basketball careers bearing the same burden beauty pageant contestants from Texas do when they enter national competitions. Both have a reputation for polish, both exude entitlement and the public expects them to win.

title: Sharon Asks Barak and Peres To Join a Unity Government
description: Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon today offered the post of defense minister to departing Prime Minister Ehud Barak, who is weighing the offer three days after announcing his retirement from politics, Israeli radio and television reported.

title: 2 Rabbis Plead Guilty in Conspiracy to Divert Federal Money
description: Two Brooklyn rabbis who were given a $2.5 million federal grant to help Holocaust survivors pleaded guilty yesterday to a felony conspiracy charge for defrauding the program by using hundreds of thousands of dollars for themselves and others.

title: Hartford's Sassy Time Traveler, Still Wandering
description: ''Say, how long can you stay fresh in that can?'' says the man in evening clothes to the man in armor. That's how the 20th century meets the sixth century in ''A Connecticut Yankee,'' the Rodgers and Hart show inspired by Mark Twain's novel of colliding cultures and the opening production in the new season of the Encores! series of American musicals in concert.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: The Storm Over Clinton's Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: Tilling History With Biology's Tools; The Field Opens Up (a Bit) to Darwinist Explanations
description: Evolutionary biology has become the scholarly equivalent of Starbucks or the Gap. Neo-Darwinist explanations for everything from artistic creativity to morality and rape spill off the presses. Every academic department, it seems, has its biology-enamored theorist. Every department, that is, except history.

title: The Happiest All-Star Of Them All
description: Stephon Marbury's eyes flashed complete surprise and the words spilled from his smile. ''Thank you! Thank you! Thank you, God!'' Marbury yelled into the cell phone. ''I can't believe it! Thank you!''

title: 21 Indicted in South Jersey
description: Twenty-one people, including a borough councilman from Runnemede in Camden County, were indicted in South Jersey yesterday on racketeering charges, the State Division of Criminal Justice announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANES, MATHEW
description: MANES-Mathew. Respected lawyer and counselor, died February 7, 2001, in his 94th year. Beloved husband of Esther, father of Marthe, Cathy, and Laurie, fatherin-law of Bob and Rob, grandfather of Darcy, Lindy, Sarah, and David, brother-in-law of Sarah Sturim. Mentor, friend, inspiration. Private services will be held on February 9th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURCHLAG, E. NELSON DR.
description: DURCHLAG-E. Nelson Dr. At the age of 90. On February 7, 2001 in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Kreielsheimer Durchlag. Adored father of Barbara (Theodore Reff) Divver and Ronnie (Roger) Brooks. Loving grandfather of Kirsten (Tom Selinger) Brooks and Russell Brooks. Physician and surgeon in practice in Irvington, New Jersey for 50 years. Services private.

title: Starting Fresh in the Middle East
description: Political realities in the Middle East have changed substantially in recent weeks, most notably with the election of Ariel Sharon as Israel's prime minister, replacing the more dovish Ehud Barak. For that reason, the Bush administration was right to declare that the far-reaching peace proposals put forward by Bill Clinton last December are no longer on the table. At the same time, the new administration has wisely signaled that it is not abandoning the search for Mideast peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARRY, WILLIAM H.
description: PARRY - William H. Retired Professor of Law at New York's St. John's University School of Law and former senior partner at the old Brooklyn law firm of SM&DE Meeker. Died in the company of his wife on February 8, 2001 in Central Florida's Leesburg Regional Medical Center of congestive heart failure. His remains will be cremated, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at St. Timothy's Catholic Church, Lady Lake, FL, on Thursday, February 15th. After a memorial service at the SJU School of Law in midMarch celebrating his life, interment in Arlington National Cemetery will follow. He had served in the Pentagon's Office of the Judge Advocate General US Army in the late '50's. He is survived by his wife, three daughters, and a son, a son-in-law, two granddaughters, and two grandsons, a brother, a sister, two sisters-in-law, two nieces, three nephews, and other members of his family of-theheart. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorial contributions to CityMeals on Wheels or God's Love We Deliver or St. John's University School of Law. Beyers Funeral Home, Lady Lake, FL.

title: Article 2001021090979097826 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the film and television star Dale Evans on Thursday misstated the name of the Chicago supper club where she performed in the early 1940's. It was Chez Paree, not Gay Paree.

title: Mr. Hagel's Reform Ruse
description: Senator John McCain won a big victory two weeks ago when he got the Senate to schedule a full debate on campaign finance reform next month. At least for now the reform bill does not face the threat of a filibuster by Trent Lott and the Republican leadership. Recently, however, a new danger has emerged for campaign reform in the guise of a Senate bill that poses as a more realistic alternative. Sponsored by Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican, and Mary Landrieu, a Louisiana Democrat, this substitute would open more loopholes than it attempts to close and would do nothing to stop the flow of corrupt money into the system. Reformers should not be lulled into supporting it.

title: Chevron Talks to Azerbaijanis About Pipeline
description: In a potentially significant boost for a proposed pipeline to carry Caspian Sea oil to Western markets via Turkey, Chevron said today that it planned to take part in the engineering and construction phases of the project.

title: Europe's Shifting Role Poses Challenge to U.S.
description: BERLIN, Feb. 10  A little phrase from Rudolf Scharping, the German defense minister, recently caused American military commanders to shudder: "As the European Union develops its security and defense policy and becomes an independent actor, we must determine our security policy with Russia, our biggest neighbor."

title: Commission Sues Railroad To End Genetic Testing In Work Injury Cases
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission yesterday filed its first court action challenging genetic testing by an employer, the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIMLER, MOE
description: RIMLER-Moe. Of Manhattan. On February 8, 2001. Peacefully at age 80, after a long and happy life. Proprietor of Moe & Phil Clothiers, on New York's vanishing Lower East Side. Loved and beloved husband of Ruth for 60 years. Extraordinary father to George, Marsha and Phyllis. Outstanding father-inlaw to Anita and Howard. Cherished and loving Grandpa to Lee, Melanie and her husband Gary, and Nina. Devoted brother to the late Albert. He was one-of-a-kind and will truly be missed. Services 10AM Sunday, Gramercy Chapel, 2nd Ave and 9th Street, New York. Donations to Simon Wisenthal Center, 9760 West Pico Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA. 90035.

title: Nassau County District Attorney to Dismiss Charge Against Officer in Sexual Assault
description: The Nassau County district attorney confirmed tonight that he would move to dismiss a criminal charge that a county police officer forced a woman to have oral sex a year ago while the officer was on duty. The decision was disclosed earlier at a news conference here called by the officer's lawyer, who said his client had a consensual relationship with the woman.

title: Vintage Performance by Richter Leads Rangers
description: The Rangers, who entered tonight's game against the Florida Panthers as losers of five of their previous six games, received a game from goaltender Mike Richter that was reminiscent of his All-Star past.

title: Another Round of Notoriety for Miami, and Thanks Again to the Mayor
description: Things were just starting to get back to normal in South Florida. Most people had stopped talking about Elin Gonzlez, and all the attention paid to butterfly ballots, chads and the fate of the American electoral system seemed to have faded.

title: DiFrancesco Pledges to Give More Details About Finances
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco said today that he would soon reveal more detailed information about his finances than he has before, including his 2000 tax return.

title: Ukrainian President Says Growing Opposition Threatens Security
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma of Ukraine said today that the growing opposition movement on the streets of Kiev and in the Parliament posed ''a threat to the national security.''

title: Staten Island Cottages Used by Dorothy Day Are Demolished
description: Several cottages that were used by Dorothy Day, a founder of the Catholic Worker movement, were bulldozed yesterday on Staten Island, despite the opposition of preservationists who had fought a developer's plans to knock them down.

title: Russian Defector Was Spy, Not Diplomat, U.S. Officials Say
description: A Russian intelligence officer working under cover as a diplomat at the United Nations has defected to the United States, say several American officials familiar with the case.

title: TWO KEY OFFICERS RESIGN FROM POSTS AT CRITICAL PATH
description: Critical Path Inc., which is investigating its own accounting practices after finding possible sales misstatements, said its chief executive, Douglas T. Hickey, and its president, David Thatcher, have left. Their duties will be filled, in part, by David C. Hayden, founder and chairman, who was named executive chairman, and Diana Whitehead, senior vice president, who was promoted to president. The company, a San Francisco-based provider of e-mail systems, also hired an executive search firm to recruit a new chief executive. Critical Path, which sells e-mail systems and software for businesses, said last week that it might have ''materially misstated'' fourth-quarter financial results and discovered ''a number of'' questionable transactions.

title: Webber's Comments Put Him in Spotlight
description: A television reporter in Sacramento recently asked the owner of a downtown soul-food restaurant if he was offended by Chris Webber's comments -- the ones in which Webber, the Kings' All-Star forward, said he could not find a decent soul-food restaurant in the capital of California.

title: CREDENCE SYSTEMS REDUCES ITS WORK FORCE BY 14%
description: The Credence Systems Corporation, a maker of equipment used to test semiconductors based in Fremont, Calif., said yesterday that it laid off about 200 people, or 14 percent of its 1,450 workers, because of lower-than-expected first-quarter revenue. Remaining employees will be required to take one week of accrued vacation each quarter, a move that reduces accounting expenses, said John Detwiler, the corporate controller. The job cuts were effective yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIGATNER, HERMAN
description: FIGATNER-Herman. Born on October 27, 1916, died February 7, 2001 in New Rochelle, New York. Beloved husband of Betsy. Father of Steven and Nancy. Grandfather of Julia, Jamal, Sarah and Dustin. Executive for 45 years at George Braziller Publishers. Concerned community member, he showed the world grace, integrity and compassion, always with a smile. Private memorial planned.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WATSON, ELSIE AMENCIA
description: WATSON-Elsie Amencia. Beloved wife and mother. Four years of never-ending sadness and a broken heart that still beats. We love and miss you more than words can say. You are a shining light forever in our hearts. Love, Wes, Denise, David, Relatives and Friend

title: Herbert A. Simon Dies at 84; Won a Nobel for Economics
description: Herbert A. Simon, an American polymath who won the Nobel in economics in 1978 with a new theory of decision making and who helped pioneer the idea that computers can exhibit artificial intelligence that mirrors human thinking, died yesterday. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GAIR, HARRY A.
description: GAIR-Harry A. Always in memory, a preeminent barrister amongst preeminent barristers. Herbert

title: DOW CHEMICAL MAKES DEAL FOR UNIT OF ENICHEM OF ITALY
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the chemical maker that bought its rival the Union Carbide Corporation, for $10 billion on Tuesday, agreed yesterday to buy a polyurethane unit from Enichem of Italy for 400 million euros, or about $370 million, Enichem said. As part of the deal, Dow agreed to sell a 50 percent stake in Polimeri Europa, which belongs to Union Carbide, to Enichem to comply with a European Union antitrust requirement for approval of Dow's acquisition of Union Carbide. The Enichem business, which manufactures the material used to make polyurethane, has annual sales of about $500 million. Polimeri makes polyethylene.

title: It's Not Too Late to Save the Token, Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombia and Rebels Agree to Talk Peace
description: President Andrs Pastrana and the leader of Colombia's largest rebel group reached broad agreement on restarting formal peace talks, which had been at a standstill since November.

title: Owner Backs Milbury As Islanders Lose Again
description: The Philadelphia Flyers got two goals from the video-replay judge tonight, then handed the Islanders a 5-2 loss. An Islanders loss is old news; it was their 32nd of the season.

title: Gays in the British Military: Ask, Tell and Then Move On
description: For the last year it has been perfectly legal for Chief Petty Officer Rob Nunn, who is openly gay, to serve in the Royal Navy. But there have inevitably been awkward moments, like the time someone jokingly asked, using slang for homosexual, why he was ''standing around like a poof.''

title: MCKESSON HBOC SIGNS CONTRACT VALUED AT $33 BILLION
description: McKesson HBOC Inc., a leading drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it signed a contract valued at $33 billion with the closely held pharmacy buying group ServAll Health Alliance to provide drugs and other services. The contract lasts through March 2010 and replaces a $10 billion five-year agreement set to expire in 2004, the president of ServAll, Ian Flynn, said. McKesson, which has provided drugs to ServAll pharmacies since 1994, will continue to be the primary supplier of generic and brand-name drugs to ServAll's more than 3,000 members. McKesson will also provide management software and financial consulting services. ServAll is based in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Mbeki Strongly Urges Racial Reconciliation in South Africa
description: Moving to allay the fears of whites and jittery investors, President Thabo Mbeki today issued his strongest call to South Africans for racial reconciliation, urging citizens of all colors to work together to reinvigorate the slow-growing economy and to reduce poverty and racial inequality.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about ABC's prime-time schedule misstated the setting for a series, ''Wonderland,'' which was shown last year. Although the psychiatric facilities on the show were modeled on those at Bellevue Hospital Center in New York City, the setting was a fictional hospital called Riverview, not Bellevue.

title: Orchestras Still Preserve the Myths, but Who Cares Now?
description: There was a time not long ago when the selection of a new music director of the New York Philharmonic was a subject of considerable anticipation. When Leonard Bernstein was chosen in 1958 and when Pierre Boulez took over in 1969, there was talk of new eras and expansive possibilities. Now hardly anybody cares. The recent announcement that Lorin Maazel will succeed Kurt Masur in that post may have stirred some gossip, but otherwise it simply doesn't matter. And this is no reflection on Mr. Maazel. Never in the history of the Philharmonic have orchestras been so marginal in American culture; never has the devotion of their audiences been more in question; never has the status of their repertory been so diminished.

title: Article 2001021092189264860 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Art of Moving the Mouth Along With Those Feet
description: The fusion of movement and spoken text was the subject of ''Talking Dance,'' a two-part series at the Kitchen. The big guns were fired in the first part. What followed, in a performance devoted to younger or newer groups and individuals on Thursday night, was for the most part a series of dismal misfirings.

title: Tainted Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRASCO, JOSEPHINE
description: BRASCO-Josephine. January 29, 2001. We thank the members of our extended families, our friends, our neighbors and our colleagues for their wonderful outpouring of love, sympathy, kindness, generosity and respect upon the untimely death of our beloved wife, mother and grandmother. May God bless and keep you and those dear to you every day of your lives. Ralph and Anthony Brasco Toni, Vincent, Vito, Ralph and Albertina Pitta

title: I.R.S. Is Going After Businesses on Withholding Tax
description: The Internal Revenue Service plans to announce next week that it is actively pursuing small-business owners who are bragging on the Internet and in seminars that they do not withhold taxes from their employees' paychecks, arguing that the tax laws do not apply to them.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial yesterday on pardons erred in saying that Michael Milken's pardon application did not go through the usual Justice Department channels. His lawyers filed the application with the department's Office of the Pardon Attorney.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Cuttings: The Indoor Takeover Artists
description: THIS is the time of year when I need a little jungle in my life. In summer, vining houseplants are superfluous. During the growing season, I avoid additional tangle, doing all I can to keep indoor vines alive, healthy and watered, but concentrating on outdoor chores.

title: For Jeter, Being Part of Yanks' History Is Priceless
description: When it became apparent several days ago that Derek Jeter's 10-year, $189 million deal was going to become official, he talked by phone with the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner. Not many players get this type of contract, Steinbrenner said, and Jeter understood the subtle message in the owner's words: we believe in you, and we expect you to lead.

title: Article 2001021093149319116 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: U.S. Salvages First-Round Split in Davis Cup
description: Even if Todd Martin had been at his healthiest today, it would have been a daunting task to beat the Swiss teenager Roger Federer.

title: Robert E. Garis -- Dance Writer, 75
description: Robert E. Garis, a writer on dance, literature, music and film, died on Jan. 26 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 75.

title: Article 2001021093110544548 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STRAUSS, LAURI
description: STRAUSS-Lauri. Your love and laughter are always with us. Lentch Bentch. Mom, Dad, Julie, David, Gregory and Emily.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My private life has never been embroiled in my working life. If I'm asked, I'll answer, but I don't walk around with a big flag saying, 'I'm gay.' ''

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday, on Monday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect. In Connecticut and New Jersey, state offices and courts will be closed.

title: Inquiry Said to Point To a Torricelli Aide
description: Federal investigators have uncovered evidence that the chief fund-raiser for Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, solicited illegal campaign contributions from two fugitive businessmen who were involved in investment frauds, lawyers and others involved in the case said.

title: Times Picks Designer For Tower's Interior
description: The architectural firm Gensler will design the interiors of the new New York Times headquarters planned for Eighth Avenue between 40th and 41st Streets, Michael Golden, vice chairman of The New York Times Company, said yesterday.

title: It's Not Too Late to Save the Token, Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chasing Mexico's Dream Takes a Toll
description: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico  Often looking as if he had slept in his clothes, Salvador Duron does not cut the most distinguished figure. But even with his gray stubble and grease-stained fingers, he is welcomed like a king into the shantytowns at the edge of this teeming city on the border with the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, LOUIS
description: LERNER-Louis. On February 9, 2001. Beloved husband of Shirley. Cherished father of Fredda Fuchs and Marlene Robins. Loving grandfather of Mitchell, Jason and Jessica. Graveside services on Sunday at 11 A.M., Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

title: Creditors Said To Be Seeking Loews Theaters
description: An investor group that holds much of the debt of the Loews Cineplex Entertainment Corporation is negotiating to acquire the cinema company after it makes a bankruptcy filing, executives involved in the talks have said.

title: Evidence Said to Show Torricelli Aide Sought Illegal Gifts
description: Federal investigators have uncovered evidence that the chief fund-raiser for Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat, solicited illegal campaign contributions from two fugitive businessmen who were linked to investment frauds in the United States and Europe, lawyers and others involved in the case said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURWITZ, HERBERT
description: HURWITZ-Herbert. Of the Music Exchange, on Friday, February 9, 2001; beloved husband of the late Edith (nee Kierstein); devoted father of Nancy and Gerry, and Sandy and Len; loving grandfather of Shana, Marin, Chad, Haley, Ethan and the late Zachary. Graveside service on Sunday, February 11, at 11 A.M. in the Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: INDONESIAN GAS CONTRACT
description: Indonesia is scheduled to sign a contract on Monday worth as much as $14 billion to supply natural gas to Singapore. The gas, which will began flowing in 2003, will be transported over a $1.1 billion, 300-mile pipeline from fields in the island of Sumatra operated by subsidiaries of Gulf Canada Resources and Santa Fe Energy Resources. Singapore began receiving the city-state's first shipments of natural gas from Indonesia last month via a separate, 400-mile pipeline from gas fields to the west in the South China Sea. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Lesson on Syllables
description: Researchers from the Learning Therapy Program at Southern Methodist University have written a curriculum to help teachers at a Head Start center in Dallas prepare 3- and 4-year-olds for reading. President Bush is seeking to adapt the curriculum for all Head Start centers. Following are excerpts from a scripted lesson developed to teach the concept of syllables:

title: Can't We at Least Lose the Face Masks?
description: To: Dick Ebersol, NBC Sports

title: Mickelson and Love Are Tied for Lead
description: For the past week, Davis Love III and Phil Mickelson have been connected, two golfers battling for pride, bragging rights and a bundle of money.

title: The Last Superpower Ponders Its Next Move
description: President George W. Bush's order for a sweeping review of American military strategy was the first signal that the White House is serious about re-evaluating the fundamental assumptions behind the nation's role in the world.

title: Scrounging To Feather A New Nest
description: DEAR NYC:

title: 9 Victims of Collision at Sea Still Missing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  Navy and Coast Guard ships and planes searched the waters off Hawaii through the night, but as dawn broke today rescuers had not found nine people missing from a Japanese boat that sank after a collision with a United States Navy submarine.

title: The Storm Over Clinton's Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a tiny force in quantum mechanics that could be used in future microscopic devices referred incorrectly in some copies to the size of the force measured when two metal plates were placed within one 40-thousandth of an inch of each other. It was one 300-millionth of an ounce, not one 300-thousandth.

title: Where Did You Go, Raggedy Ann?; Toys in the Age of Electronics
description: Nostalgic parents looking for Erector sets for their children were hard pressed to find any during the last Christmas season.

title: Parks Chief Defends Fee for Felling Street Trees
description: Parks Commissioner Henry Stern, already under fire for soliciting donations in exchange for the use of city parks by private groups, came under fresh criticism yesterday for a policy of charging homeowners to cut down trees on their sidewalks.

title: KODAK TO BUY HICKS EQUIPMENT CO. FOR UNDISCLOSED SUM
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Hicks Equipment Company of Flint, MIch., for an undisclosed price to increase sales of photo-processing services to wedding and portrait photographers. Kodak, based in Rochester, will integrate the optical and digital photo-processing systems of Hicks with the digital systems it bought last month from Bremson Inc. The transaction is expected to be completed within 30 to 60 days. The acquisitions are part of Kodak's strategy to develop an Internet-based photo-processing and editing system to let customers of professional photographers select and order prints on line, Kodak said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Public Lives column yesterday about ''Workspheres,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, described the cover of its catalog incorrectly. It bears a raised picture of a stain from a coffee mug, not simply a picture of a mug.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL FALLS. Heating oil fell on expectations that cold weather forecast for the Northeast would come too late to lead to inventory shortfalls. In New York, heating oil for March delivery fell 1.94 cents, to 82.24 cents a gallon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARVEY, DR. MEGAN
description: GARVEY-Dr. Megan. On February 8, 2001, Dr. Megan Garvey of Mt. Kisco, New York went to her reward in heaven. She is survived by her brother and sister-in-law, Jack and Mary Ann Garvey of Dallas, Texas, and her sister Mary Lane of Champaign, Illinois. Megan also loved and was very much loved by her nieces, Kerry Vyverberg, Kristen Schulz, Amy Garvey, Ana Garvey and Katie Garvey and her nephew Kevin Garvey. In January 2001, she became the proud great aunt of Jack Min-u Schulz and Benjamin Patrick Vyverberg. Megan struggled in her battle with cancer for almost 17 years. She loved life and shared many wonderful times with her lifelong friends. Included among Megan's many friends who will miss her are Marlene Spaeth who went to St. Mary's Grammar School with Megan, Melitta Bucciero, Terry Ritchie, Louise Galleshaw and Mary McGarry from St. Vincent Ferrer High School, Sr. Janis Klein and Diana Capps Keller from Loyola University, Dr. Eli Mayer, Dr. Sandy Rainbow and Dr. Alice Weisko from Yeshiva University and her co-workers at Westchester County Health Clinic especially Nancy Badding and Sheila Boylan where Megan ministered to people seeking help in their lives. Megan was a Dominican Sister of Columbus, Ohio for 25 years and also had many friends from her time as a Dominican Sister including Jane Litzinger, Sr. Margaret Ormond, Sr. Mary Elizabeth Donoghue, Sr. Nancy McAlroy and Thadine Coyne. In lieu of flowers donations to The Dominican Sisters of Columbus, Ohio, 2320 Airport Dr., Columbus, Ohio, 43219, or the American Cancer Society would be appreciated. Funeral Mass will be held Saturday (today) at 1:30PM at St. John's and St. Mary's Church in Chappaqua, NY. Interment will be private.

title: 'Periscope' Shows an Expert What Defenders' Cards Are
description: Beginners sometimes say admiringly of an expert friend: ''So-and-so knows every card in everyone's hand before the play starts.'' Unless so-and-so regularly employs a periscope, the statement is in principle false, but there are some rare hands on which it is valid.

title: White House Memo; Presidency Takes Shape With No Fuss, No Sweat
description: His public comments tend toward the epigrammatic, and he makes little effort to conceal his appetite for restorative breaks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERT, LILY
description: ALBERT-Lily. Of Great Neck, NY, on February 8th at the age of 88. Beloved wife of the late Bernard H. Albert. Cherished and devoted mother of Sondra, Sigmund, Edward (Brenda). In lieu of flowers, donations to the Women's American ORT. Services Sunday, February 11, 12:00 PM at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The Ski Report column on Jan. 25 about the Bretton Woods area in New Hampshire referred incorrectly to nearby Mount Washington. At 6,288 feet, it is not the highest peak in the eastern United States. That is Mount Mitchell in North Carolina (6,684 feet).

title: A Foolish Drug War
description: Secretary of State Colin Powell recently affirmed the Bush administration's support for Plan Colombia -- the plan inherited from the Clinton White House that pledged $1.3 billion to fight drugs in Colombia. But this plan -- based almost entirely on military strategies -- could well lead to America's next proxy war in Latin America.

title: Going the Way of the Victrola
description: THE home computer revolution may soon chalk up another casualty: the recording studio  that shrine where many a music legend has been born. The old legends relied on their talent but also on record companies to cover the expense of the studios. In exchange, the labels had a say in the aesthetic direction and distribution of the final product. New talent won't need this help. The personal computer is freeing it from the need of both a recording studio and a record company  and, maybe, from traditional musicianship altogether.

title: Tokyo Makes a Mostly Symbolic Rate Cut
description: Faced with mounting evidence that Japan's economy is stalling and with growing pressure to do something about it, the Bank of Japan announced an interest rate reduction today that was almost purely symbolic, while leaving most other aspects of its monetary policy unchanged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONER, PAULINE
description: KONER-Pauline. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Pauline Koner, dance faculty member from 1986 to 1999. She was an extraordinarily powerful performer who could hold the stage with both bold movement and subtle gesture. Although her stage career ended many years ago, she generously shared her profound understanding of the elements of dance performance with her students. She will be deeply missed. Mary Rodgers Guettel, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President Benjamin Harkarvy, Director, Dance Division

title: Nothing but Net in Marlboro
description: On Tuesday night in the Marlboro High School gymnasium, Brina Pollack, a point guard on the Marlboro basketball team, raced downcourt with the ball. Facing a Howell opponent, she whipped a behind-the-back pass to Chakhia Cole on her left. Without hesitation, Cole flipped the ball back to Sharnee Zoll, who leapt to the basket for a layup, giving Marlboro a 58-16 halftime lead.

title: Abraham Beame, Mayor During 70's Fiscal Crisis, Is Dead at 94
description: Abraham D. Beame, an accountant and clubhouse Democrat who climbed the gray ranks of municipal bookkeeping and confounded oddsmakers to become mayor of New York in the mid-1970's, only to spend his term struggling with the worst fiscal calamity in the city's history, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRELSIN, DOROTHY STRELSIN
description: STRELSIN-Dorothy Strelsin. Died at her California home on February 8th. She was 87. A philanthropist and very good friend, she is mourned by her nephew Walter Ehmer of Atlanta and his family and her many friends in this country and in Europe.

title: Sky Watch: Rich With Tiny Stars
description: Near the center of the sky chart is the bright constellation Auriga. Its highlights include the yellow star Capella, second brightest star now above the horizon, and a row of three clusters of stars that are readily visible with only the slightest optical aid. M36, M37 and M38 look quite similar in binoculars: hazy gray glows lurking in a field rich with tiny stars.

title: Article 2001021093541825920 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Stocks Drop Broadly, Wiping Out Gains of 2001 Rally
description: Despite two Federal Reserve rate cuts and a big technology stock rally in January, the three major stock indexes have now given up all their gains for the year.
