title: New Drug Is Determined To Cut Death Rate of Sepsis
description: Researchers reported strong results yesterday for the first drug ever to reduce the death rate from severe sepsis, an illness usually caused by infection, which kills about 225,000 Americans a year.

title: Deutsche Telekom Will Delay Deal to Buy VoiceStream
description: Deutsche Telekom confirmed yesterday that it had added a clause to the terms of its acquisition of VoiceStream Wireless that would delay the completion of the deal and pay its new shareholders a special stock dividend.

title: In Quake, Unity Overcame Diversity
description: When this village awoke on a bright winter's morning two weeks ago, all the talk was of the village cricket championship to be played that afternoon on a dusty stretch of open ground beyond the main Hindu temple and the mosque and the tiny, cramped houses that are home to the village's poorest people, the dalits, traditionally known as untouchables.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTS, PATRICIA MCSHANE
description: POTTS-Patricia McShane. On February 7, 2001 of Chevy Chase, MD. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Gerli Potts; mother of Joseph McShane of Arlington, VA, Maureen McGlynn of Baton Rouge, LA, Colleen Danos of Virginia Beach, VA, Brian of Ashburn, VA, Dennis and Colin of Chevy Chase, MD and the late Kevin and Sheila Potts; sister of Marianne Doyle of Hilton Head, SC. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Ave at Harrison St., NW, on Sunday, February 11 from 3-6 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Matthew's Cathedral, 1725 Rhode Island Ave., NW, Washington, DC on Monday, February 12 at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to Catholic Charities, 924 G Street, NW Washington, DC 20001.

title: Nicol Handles Top Rival And Passing Distractions
description: Some of the world's best squash players gathered last night for a major tournament amid the hubbub of Grand Central Terminal. But they are used to distraction.

title: A Foolish Drug War
description: TOLIMA, Colombia -- Secretary of State Colin Powell recently affirmed the Bush administration's support for Plan Colombia  the plan inherited from the Clinton White House that pledged $1.3 billion to fight drugs in Colombia. But this plan  based almost entirely on military strategies  could well lead to America's next proxy war in Latin America.

title: Arthur Hummel, Ambassador to China '81-85, Dies at 80
description: Arthur W. Hummel Jr., who as ambassador to China from 1981 to 1985 negotiated an agreement on United States arms sales to Taiwan, died on Feb. 6 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 80.

title: Through the Voters' Eyes, Senator Clinton's Missteps
description: There is some gentle needling going on in the Harrison household in Amsterdam, N.Y., these days as a couple who canceled each other out in the voting booth last November watch with dismay the untidy start of Hillary Rodham Clinton's career in the United States Senate.

title: John Prebble, 85, Writer and Historian
description: John Prebble, a writer and historian who specialized in the bloody battles that marked Scotland's past, died on Jan. 30 in London. He was 85.

title: Report to Back Forests to Fight Warming
description: An influential panel of scientists is preparing to endorse two strategies for curtailing global warming that have been major points of contention between the United States and Europe in efforts to complete a climate treaty.

title: How Power Sellers Profited on California's Panic
description: FOLSOM, Calif., Feb. 9  The largest planned blackout of electricity in California since World War II came in the midst of a heat wave last June, when the mercury hit 103 in San Francisco, and air-conditioners roared. Electricity supplies fell to dangerous levels, and utilities cut power to more than 100,000 homes.

title: HEINZ SELLS BUDGET GOURMET FROZEN LINES TO LUIGINO'S
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that it had sold the All American Gourmet Company frozen-food business to the closely held Luigino's Inc. for undisclosed terms. The transaction will cut 2 cents a share from earnings for the year ending in April and 4 cents from next year because of lost sales, Heinz said. It will take a one-time charge this year of about $65 million. All American Gourmet makes the Budget Gourmet and Budget Gourmet Value Classics low-priced frozen entrees. Luigino's makes frozen entrees and snacks under the Michelina's brand.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: A Proud and Unwavering Believer in the Death Penalty
description: AT a time when even some prominent supporters of the death penalty are raising concerns about the system's fairness and the risk of executing an innocent person, Robert H. Macy remains a true believer.

title: Baseball's Back: Team Workout Dates
description: Here are the dates for the first spring training workouts for pitchers and catchers and for the first workouts of full squads.

title: Citing a Failed Bid to Change, Lechters Will Close 166 Stores
description: Lechters -- a well-known but ailing purveyor of spatulas, cheese graters and dish towels -- plans to close 166 of its 490 stores in the next three months, including several of its 126 stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the company said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Clay Lancaster, an architectural historian whose 1961 book documented the houses of Brooklyn Heights, misstated the position of Kent Barwick, who spoke about Mr. Lancaster's influence on the historic preservation movement. Mr. Barwick, the president of the Municipal Art Society, is a former chairman of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission; the current chairwoman is Jennifer Raab.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Despite Ruling, E.P.A. Insists That City Must Filter Water
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that it would not reconsider its order requiring New York City to build a plant to filter water from the Croton watershed.

title: Students, Mindful of Columbine, Break Silence to Report Threats
description: For weeks two teenage girls in Fort Collins, Colo., listened at lunch or in the hallways at school as two male classmates described how they planned to re-enact the shooting at Columbine High School on its second anniversary in April. The girls said that they heard the boys tell of guns and a propane tank to be used as a bomb, and that they saw drawings of how the boys would block the exits to keep students from escaping.

title: The Best Possible Investment in Africa
description: Africa, with tens of millions of lives at stake, needs around $5 billion to $10 billion a year from the rich countries in the next decade to battle AIDS. This may sound like a huge amount, but it is a remarkable bargain. Not only is it tiny compared with the great annual income of the well-off nations, but spending it could save the rich countries greater costs down the road: in response to military upheavals, humanitarian disasters and the worldwide spread of infectious diseases given a new foothold by AIDS. Secretary of State Colin Powell wisely said this week that Africa's AIDS epidemic is a national security issue for the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, ROSE
description: HIRSCHHORN-Rose. The beautiful and radiant memories of times together in yesteryear, sustain and hearten me as I continue into longevity. Herbert

title: Of Prints and Process: The Science Behind Art
description: If you want to learn how to tell a salt print from a platinum one or a carbro print from a chromogenic one, the small but ambitious exhibition called ''Photography: Processes, Preservation and Conservation'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art may not be your best bet. That's too bad, because museums rarely delve into the science behind their art.

title: BENITEZ'S EX-FIANCEE URGES END OF CASE
description: Mets closer Armando Benitez's former fiancee, who filed a domestic assault complaint against him last month in Flushing, said she wanted the police and the Queens district attorney's office to close their investigation of the incident.

title: PERNOD SALES INCREASE
description: Pernod Ricard S.A., a leading distiller, said that its fourth-quarter sales rose 17 percent, with the drinks division lagging units that are being sold to pay for the purchase of several Seagram liquor brands. Sales rose to 1.24 billion euros ($1.1 billion) in the period from 1.06 billion euros a year earlier. Full-year sales rose 22 percent, with Havana Club rum, Jacob's Creek wines and other drinks increasing only 12 percent. The company is selling a fruit preparation unit, a British-Irish wholesaler and other divisions to help pay for Glenlivet whiskey, Martell cognac, and other Seagram brands to be added after completing the joint $8.15 billion purchase with Diageo P.L.C.

title: Net Drops 11%, But Electrolux Sees Good Year
description: Electrolux A.B., the maker of Frigidaire refrigerators and other appliance brands, said today that a streamlining program, including the elimination of 2,000 jobs, would buoy its profits this year despite a looming slowdown in the United States economy.

title: CREDITORS JOIN FORCES IN ELECTRICITY CRISIS
description: Stepping up the pressure in the California electricity crisis, three of the state's largest electric-power generators said yesterday that they had formed a creditors committee to share proprietary information and explore ways to get money owed them by the state's two largest utilities. Reliant Energy and Dynegy Inc., both based in Houston, and the Mirant Corporation, based in Atlanta, said they formed the committee because they were ''troubled over the pace of progress toward a comprehensive solution'' of the crisis. Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison have been pushed close to bankruptcy because of soaring prices for wholesale electricity.The independent generators that sell to the utilities say they are already owed hundreds of millions of dollars for power. Richard Oppel (NYT)

title: Motorola Cuts 3% of Its Jobs As Chip Demand Cools Off
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it would eliminate 4,000 of its semiconductor jobs, or about 3 percent of its global work force, because of slowing demand for its products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, DAVID
description: LESSER-David. Sincerest condolences to Dr. Jonathan Lesser on the passing of his father, David Lesser. Dr. Cohen, Dr. Digiacento, Dr. Perin, Dr. Sen, Dr. Williams Dept of Neurosurgery at SLRHC

title: LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS ADDS TO EXECUTIVE'S PAY
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. paid its chairman and chief executive, Richard Fuld, $28.3 million last year, up 68 percent from 1999, after the firm's profit rose to a record and its market value almost doubled. Mr. Fuld received a salary of $750,000, a cash bonus of $8.75 million and restricted stock valued at $13.6 million. He also got options to buy 800,000 shares now worth $5.2 million, according to a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Last year, Mr. Fuld's compensation totaled $16.8 million, including a $4.5 million bonus and restricted stock valued at $7.5 million. The pay increase came as net income at Lehman climbed 57 percent to $1.78 billion in 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROBERT W.
description: WHITE-Robert W. Of Weston formerly of Brookline, MA and Concord, MA., Marlborough, NH and Marboro, VT. February 6, 2001. Father of David W. White of Cambridge and Marlboro, VT. Uncle of Barbara and Sally Baker of Needham, MA., and Donald V. Baker of Beverly, MA. Many cousins and friends. Mr. White is predeceased by his wife Margaret Ley (Bazeley) White, a son Timothy White, a brother Henry D. White, and a sister Katharine H. White. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 17th at 2:00 PM in First Church in Chestnut Hill, 26 Suffolk Rd, Chestnut Hill (Newton). Organ prelude to commence at 1:30 PM. Donations may be made to either High Mowing School, PO Box 850, Abbott Hill Rd, Wilton, NH 03086 or Marlboro College, Marlboro, VT 05344 or Marlboro School of Music Inc. Box K, Marlboro, VT 05344 or Walker Home and School, 1968 Central Ave., Needham, MA 02492.

title: Broadcast of Rape Angers Women's Groups in Israel
description: Israeli state television this week showed a home video of a rape that was taped by the rapist himself, generating outrage from women's groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARASH, ERNEST, MD.
description: BARASH-Ernest, MD. The Jewish Home and Hospital medical department and entire staff mourn the loss of Ernest Barash, MD, Chief of Orthopedics for more than 30 years. ''Ernie'' was a friend to many, an outstanding surgeon and clinician, a favorite teacher of the more than 2,000 students and fellowship physicians in training at Jewish Home and a person who shared his positiveness with all.

title: A Ferry Loop Plan To Connect the Dots For New York Bay
description: From Boston to Seattle to San Diego, maritime cities across the country have embraced ferries as an inexpensive and people-pleasing way to ease congestion, spur waterfront revitalization and stitch together far-flung communities snubbed by other forms of mass transit.

title: Documents Show a Complex Campaign to Win a Pardon
description: Lawyers and advisers to the financier Marc Rich joined his former wife in choreographing a complex legal and political campaign to win a last-minute pardon from President Bill Clinton, whose own legal advisers opposed the pardon, newly released documents and interviews show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, CORINNE
description: MEYERS-Corinne. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our devoted longtime member Corinne Meyers. Corinne and her beloved late husband, Archie, had been members of Rodeph Sholom for over 50 years. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her daughters, Sherri and Carole, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Senior Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: The Storm Over Clinton's Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: Previn's Stab at Simplicity, With Beethoven Alongside
description: Some principal players were missing on Thursday night when the New York Philharmonic opened its second program this season with Andr Previn, and their absence may have been partly to blame for the lackluster nature of the proceedings.

title: The Climate Is Changing In the N.F.L.
description: Dick Vermeil's first hiatus from pro football lasted 14 years, and when he returned to coaching in 1997 he found a jarringly new landscape: a leaguewide salary cap was in place, the West Coast offense was en vogue and the cornerstone on which to build a championship team began with luring a franchise quarterback.

title: 9 Are Missing Off Pearl Harbor After U.S. Submarine Collides With Japanese Vessel
description: A Navy submarine collided with a Japanese vessel near Pearl Harbor this afternoon and sank it, leaving nine people unaccounted for, a Navy spokesman said.

title: The Last Superpower Ponders Its Next Move
description: President George W. Bush's order for a sweeping review of American military strategy was the first signal that the White House is serious about re-evaluating the fundamental assumptions behind the nation's role in the world.

title: National News Briefs
description: Antidrug Official's Son Is Guilty in Heroin Case

title: A Bush Aide Faults Plan To Repeal Estate Tax
description: The man who heads President Bush's program to encourage more social services involvement by religious and charitable groups has come out against the president's proposal to repeal the estate tax.

title: Prosecutors in Skakel Case Seek To Move the Trial to Bridgeport
description: Prosecutors preparing to try Michael C. Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy, in the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley have asked a judge to shift the case to a courthouse here, filing the first motion in what is expected to be a long period of wrangling over procedural matters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KROUWER, HENRI
description: KROUWER-Henri. You will always be the shining light of my life. In love, Nadia

title: Evening Steeped in the Essence of Everything French
description: Refinement and restraint are thought to be basic to French style, to French everything, really: culture, cuisine, fashion, music. At least that's the stereotype. And, true, we all should be wary of trading in stereotypes.

title: Israelis and Arabs: The Art of Bending
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Tactics on Global Warming

title: Article 2001021092725888395 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: The Storm Over Clinton's Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: Strike the Band: Pop Music Without Musicians
description: IN the 1950's and 60's, the recording studio became an instrument. From its humble origins documenting live performances, the studio turned into a music-maker itself, retooling raw material  the work of musicians  into a finished product. Once mere "records" of musical events, recordings were now something much more exotic and autonomous, painstakingly layered confections. But even after multitrack recording had severed music making from real time, somebody still had to play that guitar.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Motorola Plans to Eliminate 4,000 Chip-Making Jobs

title: Divided Over Public Spending and Private Savings
description: The nation's economists are deeply divided over whether President Bush's tax-cut plan would hurt the economy over the long run or make it stronger and more efficient.

title: The Neediest Cases; Son Fulfills Promise To Be Brothers' Keeper
description: Shortly before his mother died in 1998, Ludwik L. promised her that as long as he lived, he would take care of his two disabled brothers.

title: National News Briefs
description: Cosby Son's Killer Drops Appeal and Admits Guilt

title: Alexandra Schley, Gregory Landegger
description: Alexandra Schley, a daughter of Stephanie Schley and Dr. W. Shain Schley of New York, was married yesterday to Gregory Maximilian Landegger, the son of Rene and Carl C. Landegger, also of New York. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James' Church in New York, with the Rev. Leo J. O'Donovan, a Jesuit priest, taking part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, ARLENE
description: EISENBERG-Arlene. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Arlene Eisenberg, a cherished friend who inspired the community's efforts to revitalize Jewish life on the Upper West Side. As a respected author, her renowned series of child-rearing books touched the lives of a generation of families. She will always be remembered for her generosity, leadership, and wisdom. We extend our sincerest condolences to her beloved husband, Howard; her children; and her entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Dr. Robert Pavlica, who started a program that has helped students compete in the Intel Science Talent Search, omitted the name of a finalist from Westchester. He is Vinod Nambudiri of Blind Brook High School.

title: Cleaning Up in Business, With a Mop
description: AS a teenager working part time at an animal hospital in Huntington, where she grew up, Joy Mangano came up with an idea for a fluorescent flea collar to keep cats and dogs from getting hit by cars at night. A year later, Hartz Mountain introduced a similar product.

title: And Now, Bonds for the Masses
description: The corporate bond market, long an unwelcoming place for ordinary investors, is looking a bit more friendly.

title: In Paris, a Dog's Vie en Rose
description: Man's best friend has no greater champion than a Frenchman. ''Vies de Chiens,'' an exhibition that runs until March 31 at the Muse de la Chasse et de la Nature in Paris, demonstrates this with panache. With artifacts and paintings, it traces the dog's place in humankind's affections from the 16th through the 19th century.

title: CITYPEOPLE; The Lone Ranger of Staten Island
description: TIM BYRNES seems a little out of place in New York City. Maybe it's his uniform. It's green. And it's made out of durable institutional fabric that nobody would ever wear unless it was required. And those boots: more military surplus than Madison Avenue.

title: Another Tick-Borne Ailment
description: AT least six people have been infected with chaffeensis, also known as human monocytic ehrlichiosis, the latest tick-borne disease detected in Connecticut. The disease, which can lead to hospitalization, is marked by high fever, severe headache, fatigue and incapacitating muscle and joint stiffness.

title: Women Away
description: To the Editor: ''The Old Bags,'' as my college friends and I call ourselves, have expanded our weekend getaway to an entire week on the Jersey Shore. Before the year we all turned 50, weekend getaways were at one another's homes, scattered from Philadelphia to Boston, Springfield and Worcester to Buffalo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERT, MIRIAM
description: HALPERT-Miriam. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, on February 10, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Devoted mother of Carol and Foster Schwartz, Janice and John Schwartz. Adored grandmother of Leonard, Bennett, Roy, Wendy and Adam. Cherished great-grandmother. Services today, 2:30 PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Children's Books
description: The Art of Keeping Cool

title: Paramus Journal; Almost Like a Death in the Family
description: Before the dawn of Dress Barn and Dollar Bill's, before Gap and Costco helped conquer the retail landscape of America, there were simple shopping pleasures like Stern's, an old-fashioned emporium that prided itself on solid merchandise, sagacious sales help and the kind of clientele that cherished continuity in this mall-eat-mall world.

title: Clean-Air Plants
description: ANYONE who has been through supermarket plant departments has seen gerbera daisies (Gerbera jamesonii). The daisylike flowers generally come in an array of sherbet colors: creams, yellows, oranges, pinks and roses, and the plants thrive indoors on sunny windowsills.

title: Putting the Brakes on the Soap Box Derby
description: THE Soap Box Derby gives off the nostalgic glow of a Norman Rockwell painting, evoking an idyllic American past fast fading from memory.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Jan. 28 about ''La Bte,'' in Manasquan, misstated the name of the theater company. It is Two River Theater Company, not Two Rivers.

title: Fighting for Change Through Music
description: THE intense gleam in Jos Jnior's eyes is a familiar one. He shares it with rock stars, world leaders and self-made millionaires who have risen to their positions through the sheer force of will, determination and an almost megalomaniacal immersion in their work. Jos Jnior, or just Jnior, as he is known, could have easily been a rock star, politician or millionaire if he had wanted. But instead, he runs a community center in the violent Vigario Geral favela, where he leads six different performing groups, most notably the 20-member drum, rap, funk and dance troupe Banda Afro Reggae.

title: Seton Hall Wonders After Loss To Syracuse
description: Eddie Griffin of Seton Hall wondered aloud when the losing would end. His teammate Darius Lane sat at the other end of the locker room in the Carrier Dome tonight and asked what might have happened had he defended Allen Griffin even tighter as the Syracuse guard launched his game-winning shot.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: THE BALKANS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, PHILLIP
description: PARKER-Phillip. Beloved father of Alan and Carole, grandfather of Sophie and Michael, widower of the late Sylvia Zimet Parker, husband to Rose Lerner Parker, died peacefully at his home in Florida on February 6. Interment occurred on February 8 in New York. His family and friends will mourn him and miss him. Contributions in his memory can be made to the American Cancer Society or the National Kidney Foundation.

title: Gotham, in Good Times and Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Knowledge Literally At Their Fingertips
description: NO one knows exactly when people began to write on their hands, but the practice is probably as old as writing itself and continues to this day, especially among the Bedouins in Israel, the women in wedding parties in India and most anyone who needs to jot down a name or telephone number and doesn't have a matchbook or a hand-held digital organizer.

title: Travel Advisory
description: IN PARIS, A DOG'S VIE EN ROSE

title: Software Developer To Expand Tarrytown Offices
description: Framework Inc., a developer of software for the financial services and mortgage industries, will spend more than $35 million to improve its new offices in Tarrytown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNNELL, PTAH
description: BUNNELL-Ptah. January 2001. Was feared by some, but loved by many, especially his family Keith and Bobby. He was so perfect.

title: Universal H.I.V. Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Snow, the Grinch That Stole Recess
description: WHEN kids start wishing it won't snow, that's a bad sign. I think Nostradamus even mentioned it, somewhere between the village idiot getting elected president and the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

title: Article 2001021191250682240 -- No Title
description: In Tapping the Net, the F.B.I. Insists Privacy Is Not a Victim

title: Right on Target
description: To the Editor:

title: Southampton Limits On Building Up in Air
description: A moratorium on large residential subdivisions, imposed by the Southampton town board 10 months ago to allow time to enact building restrictions, expired last week with no action taken.

title: Kindred Spirits
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; French Twist: Parity, Thy Name Is Woman
description: THERE are some who trace the passage of France's new parity law, which obliges all political parties to put up an equal number of male and female candidates in almost all elections, to a day in 1995 that the press here dubbed Black Tuesday for Women. On that day, former Prime Minister Alain Jupp, slipping in the ratings, decided he needed a leaner, meaner cabinet. So he dismissed 8 of the 12 women ministers he had ostentatiously hired six months earlier, giving each roughly five minutes of his time to say goodbye.

title: AN APPRECIATION; Chronicling the End of the Industrial Age
description: I THINK that O. Winston Link is one of nature's noble/men, and a legitimate American genius and nut. I like him and his work very much, and have asked to buy five of his prints for our collection. Among other things, Link is a demonstration of the fact that, for an artist, there is no substitute for a fixation.''

title: The Hall of Mirrors Meets the House of Wax
description: THE photographs in a recent project by the artist Hiroshi Sugimoto have a spooky, imposing presence that their immediate subjects do not. Take Mr. Sugimoto's portrait of Henry VIII. Except for a slightly vacant expression on his beefy face, one would swear the king, in all his regal excess, had granted a studio sitting.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-11-01: Process; Ars Brevis
description: There are two things that are constant in my work. I'm always portraying things that represent other things. And I'm always representing things that exist just for a limited amount of time. I'm a photographer. If something is not ephemeral, why photograph it? If you want to see it, you just go there and see it.

title: Lisa Volpe, Andrew McCabe
description: Lisa Marie Volpe was married yesterday to Andrew Gregory McCabe by the Rev. George Simons, a Roman Catholic priest and cousin of the bride, at the Church of St. Dominic in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Style; Touchy-Feely
description: I was working on deadline, typing 50 words a minute, when I looked up to check what I had written -- H*&bv##[knzW% ,kw! -- gobbledygook, an illegible salad. Computer malfunction! Brain tumor! No, it was my new extended acrylic nails with palm trees and sunsets. I'd been seeing superlong nails in fashion magazines, and when Karl Lagerfeld sent talon-clawed models down the Chanel runway for couture, unable to resist any longer, I popped out to Brooklyn, where a woman from Vietnam turned me into Dragon Lady.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-11-01: Phenomenon; Yell Fever
description: This weekend, 314 high-school cheerleading squads from 31 states are flipping and tumbling at Universal Studios' Indiana Jones Epic Stunt Spectacular Theater and at Disney World in Orlando, Fla. It's fitting that the Universal Cheerleaders Association national championship will be held in venues tied to movie studios and be televised on ESPN (as it has been since 1983). Last year's ''Bring It On,'' about a San Diego cheer team vying for its sixth consecutive national championship, was a surprise box-office hit. Other recent fare includes an episode of the new television show ''Boston Public'' and the current cheerleading movie, ''Sugar and Spice,'' starring Mena Suvari, best known for her role in ''American Beauty'' -- as a cheerleader. Why are cheerleaders hot lately? ''Everyone has a point of view about cheerleaders,'' says Max Wong, an executive producer of ''Bring It On.'' ''You were one, you hated one, you wanted to go out with one.''

title: The Author as Impresario
description: IF you write a book and Oprah Winfrey never mentions it, does it make any noise? If Larry King, Rosie O'Donnell and Regis Philbin forget to invite you to appear on their shows to talk about your book, can you still make it to the best-seller lists?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGEN, ABE
description: DOLGEN-Abe. Died February 9, 2001. Born 1908. Retired Manager Cutter's Local #

title: Hamptons Home Prices Continue Their Surge
description: Fueled by a booming economy, the price of homes in the Hamptons soared 44 percent last year, and for the second straight year the sales of single-family homes topped 2,700 -- about 35 percent higher than normal, according to a survey by the East Hampton real estate brokerage firm Cook Pony Farm.

title: Jennifer Gaffney, Erik Oken
description: Jennifer Adelaide Gaffney, a daughter of Janet Gaffney and Philip Weed Gaffney of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday in an Episcopal ceremony in Beaver Creek, Colo., to Erik Richard Oken, the son of Judith Oken and Dr. Richard Leslie Oken of Piedmont, Calif. The Rev. Stuart Brooks Keith III officiated in the Chapel at Beaver Creek.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELLMAN, JEANETTE
description: ELLMAN-Jeanette-Although one year since we last were togetherwe are inextricably linked forever. Your loving family

title: Invitation a 'Mistake'
description: The chairman of Morgan Stanley, the investment firm, said the company ''clearly made a mistake'' by having former President Bill Clinton speak at its conference last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, SHIRLEY (NEE TANENBAUM)
description: ROSEN-Shirley (nee Tanenbaum). Died in her home in Fair Lawn, N.J. on February 7, 2001, age 81. Born in Brooklyn, she graduated in 1941 from the Long Island College Hospital School of Nursing. While there she met her husband, Albert P. Rosen, a medical student. They married in 1943. She worked for the American Red Cross and Planned Parenthood during WWII, and upon her husband's return from military service, moved to Providence, R.I. where she worked at the Chapin Hospital. Settling in Fair Lawn in 1949, she assisted her husband in the establishment of his pediatric practice, and remained active in his office until her recent illness. A prodigious seamstress and quilter, she was also a skilled tennis player and accomplished singer. Hiking, an avocation she shared with her husband, inspired travel to all 7 continents, and climbing expeditions that included the Rockies, the Andes and the Tien Shen mountains of Kazakhstan. She summitted the Grand Teton, Mt. Kilimanjaro and Mt. Ararat, among others. Her affiliations included the Appalachian Mountain Club, the Iowa Mountaineers, the Catskill 3500 Club and the AMC 4000-Footer Club. She is survived by her husband, Albert P. Rosen, M.D., her sister, Rhoda Tomashefsky, her daughter, Nancy Rosen Blackwood, her son, Jonathan M. Rosen, M.D. and two grandsons. Donations may be made to the LIC Hospital School of Nursing, 397 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201; the NY/NJ Trail Conference, 156 Ramapo Valley Road, Mahwah, N.J. 07430; or Brandeis University National Women's Committee, 13 Garwood Road, Fair Lawn, N.J. 07410.

title: Joseph Ransohoff, Pioneer in Neurosurgery, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Joseph Ransohoff, one of the country's foremost practitioners and teachers of neurosurgery, died on Jan. 30 at his home in Tampa, Fla., where he moved after retiring from New York University Medical Center. He was 85.

title: 'Holes in the Rain'
description: The Wooden Sea By Jonathan Carroll. 302 pp. New York: Tor/Tom Doherty Associates. $23.95.

title: BENEFITS
description: Teaching the Teachers

title: Chasing Mexico's Dream Into Squalor
description: Often looking as if he had slept in his clothes, Salvador Durn does not cut the most distinguished figure. But even with his gray stubble and grease-stained fingers, he is welcomed like a king into the shantytowns at the edge of this teeming city on the border with the United States.

title: VIEW; The Scoop on Professor Gore, An Insider's Story
description: WHEN the dean of the Columbia Journalism School sent a class-wide e-mail two weeks ago announcing Al Gore as a visiting faculty member, jealousy and high-fives spread quickly through the halls.

title: The Nation; Back to the Future: National Missile Defense
description: THE Bush administration's commitment to building a missile defense system has quickly reanimated the debate over whether it is advisable -- or even possible -- to reliably swat incoming warheads from the skies like so many pesky mosquitoes. On the political front, critics argue that the spirit and possibly the letter of international arms agreements might be violated if the United States proceeds with such a system. Cost too is a concern. No one yet knows exactly how much even a basic missile shield would cost, and estimates run as high as $100 billion. But most challenging will be the technological hurdles, which many experts say are beyond current capabilities. How to reliably find a warhead in a field of decoys? Can a laser be powerful and focused enough to kill from a safe distance? And what combination, if any, of ground-, sea-, air- and space-based defenses will sufficiently defend against all possible threats? Following is an overview of how a missile shield might work, why the idea appeals to so many, and a brief look at other threats that no shield can deter. TOM ZELLER

title: Sinatra's Bad Ear
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COMPTON, CAROLYN OLSEN
description: COMPTON-Carolyn Olsen. Cherished Mother, Sister, Friend Died February 11th, 1991 Remembered Every Day

title: Renewed Battle of Hastings Ends in a 2-Way Tie for First
description: The New Year's International Tournament in Hastings, England, is the longest-running chess competition ever. This edition, the 76th in the series, held at the new Horntye Park Sports Complex, Dec. 28 to Jan. 7, ended in a tie for first place between two grandmasters, Krishnan Sasikiran of India and Stuart Conquest of England. They each scored 6-3 in the 10-player invitational round-robin.

title: Children's Books
description: THE GIRL WHO LOST HER SMILE

title: Using Nature to Teach Varying Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: The Color of Money (In the Bank)
description: The New York fall 2001 fashion collections open today in the tents in Bryant Park. A recurring complaint of professionals for the last few years has been the cookie-cutter sameness of the collections and of department store selections. But one woman, Marilyn Kirschner, shown here in photos made in chance encounters over the last year or so, doesn't like to look like everyone else. Three years ago, Ms. Kirschner, editor in chief of The Look On-Line (www.lookonline .com), a fashion Web site, started dressing almost exclusively in the ''amazing things'' she discovered at unbelievable prices in New York's thrift shops and vintage sales (like the $200 Op Art-pattern mink coat, top left).

title: Letters
description: Kindred Spirits

title: Personal Business: Can't Buy Me Love? Maybe Just a Wedding?
description: Sure, you can't put a price on love. But there is a price for all the romantic trappings thereof.

title: February 4-10; A Killer Theory
description: A disgruntled former I.R.S. worker, Robert W. Pickett, fired a gun near the White House last Wednesday. Police officers and Secret Service agents quickly surrounded him and then subdued him with a bullet to the knee. Mr. Pickett was charged with assault.

title: West Lures Its Doctors; South Africa Fights Back
description: In his travels through the bustling towns and remote villages of North America, South Africa's ambassador to Canada discovered hundreds of South African doctors working in Canada's gleaming hospitals and clinics. And when he learned of Canada's plans to hire even more foreign doctors, he howled.

title: A New Coach and a New Star, But Haldane Keeps On Winning
description: THE torch was passed on the Haldane girls' basketball team this season. But not very far.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOT, MARILYN PARLETTA
description: ROOT-Marilyn Parletta. Marilyn Parletta Root, a mental health counselor specializing in the treatment of adolescents and adult survivors of childhood sexual abuse, died at her home on Mercer Island, WA February 6 after a long struggle with ALS. She was 61. In addition to her therapeutic practices in San Francisco and Seattle, she was also a skilled photographer of people and scenes throughout the U.S. and Europe. Born in New Jersey, she married Dr. Richard K. Root in 1960. Dr. Root's training and career in academic medicine brought them to multiple cities on the East and West Coasts and foreign travel. Each experience contributed to developing her counseling and photographic skills. She received a BA from Quinnipiac University in 1980 and a MA, MFCC from the University of San Francisco in 1987. She is survived by her husband, who is Professor and Vice-Chairman of the Department of Medicine at the University of Washington, her sons, Richard A. Root of Upland, CA, David L. Root of Seattle, WA and Dr. Daniel C. Root of White River Jct, VT, their wives and five grandchildren.

title: Political Briefing; Is Katherine Harris Considering Congress?
description: Whatever Florida Democrats might think of Katherine Harris, Florida Republicans dearly love her.

title: Elizabeth Golding, Judge and Activist for Children's Rights, Dies at 100
description: Elizabeth Bass Golding, a Nassau County Family Court judge and pioneer activist for children's rights who set up group homes to keep troubled youths out of mental hospitals, died on Jan. 6 in a nursing home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 100.

title: Incentives for Cleanup At Brookhaven Rejected
description: Brookhaven National Laboratory has ended plans to award financial incentives to Bechtel, the San Francisco-based engineering and construction giant, if it speeds up a federally required cleanup of chemical and radioactive contamination on the 5,300-acre laboratory property.

title: WATERSHED LAND, GLENVILLE WOODS PRESERVED
description: The state has announced the preservation of more than 1,100 acres, among them 58 acres in New York City's Croton Watershed near Turkey Mountain in Yorktown, to protect drinking water supplies. The state is using $579,000 from the state Environmental Protection Fund to acquire the wooded parcel. The state is also helping to preserve a 41-acre parcel in Greenburgh known as Glenville Woods, which will be bought by Greenburgh town and the Open Space Institute for about $2.5 million. The state will provide $400,000, with the institute and the town contributing $833,333 each. Westchester County will contribute $400,000, and the remaining $34,000 will be provided through private donations raised by the Glenville Community Association. Elsa Brenner

title: For Those Sweet On Impressionism
description: TWO months ago, the Meserve Coale Gallery opened in a refurbished chocolate store in Greenwich.

title: Susan Ferguson, Paul Atkinson
description: Susan Copeland Ferguson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan W. Ferguson of Richmond, Va., was married yesterday to Paul DeCarr Atkinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Atkinson of Princeton Junction, N.J. The Rev. Randolph L. C. Weber performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Footlights
description: From Others' Scenes to His Own

title: Soul-Searching As a Power Pursuit
description: It's not the wild, profane Salomon Brothers trading desk portrayed in Michael Lewis's 1989 book, ''Liar's Poker.'' The traders have been tamed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONER, PAULINE
description: KONER-Pauline. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Pauline Koner, dance faculty member from 1986 to 1999. She was an extraordinarily powerful performer who could hold the stage with both bold movement and subtle gesture. Although her stage career ended many years ago, she generously shared her profound understanding of the elements of dance performance with her students. She will be deeply missed. Mary Rodgers Guettel, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President Benjamin Harkarvy, Director, Dance Division

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMAN, LISA S.
description: HEYMAN-Lisa S. Beloved daughter of Helen and Alan Goodfield; adored sister of Suzanne Lynn, Nancy and Jeff Davis, and Karen. Loving aunt of Casey, Elena and Gaylen; cherished niece of Sheila Fischer; dear cousin of Susan Fischer-Diaz, Jill, Gary and Mariel Conway and Nico Diaz. Devoted relative and friend to many. Lisa was a marketing executive, having earned her MBA at the University of Texas at Austin. She was fluent in Spanish. She was a tireless advocate for anyone in distress. Dear Lisa, you will live in our hearts forever.

title: Coming to the Rescue of a Bored Nation
description: HER head thrown back, her platinum hair cascading into a sink behind her, Anna Nicole Smith was enjoying a shampoo last Monday morning, a procedure so pleasantly mindless it left her a moment to muse. ''I've been so busy lately, I haven't had time to have the luxuries I need,'' she said, affecting a put-upon Blanche DuBois drawl. ''All this has been really hard on me.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The simple fact is that a handful of people who were really smart figured out how to make a ton of money selling the same product in essentially the same market conditions as before at 10 times the price.''

title: INVESTING WITH/Douglas S. Foreman; TCW Galileo Aggressive Growth Equities Fund
description: THE dot-com shakeout does not faze Douglas S. Foreman, who manages the $250 million TCW Galileo Aggressive Growth Equities fund. It happens to have a 35 percent stake in technology.

title: Visit Your Vacation Home Before You Go
description: Last fall I asked a rather well-off acquaintance if he'd gotten away for a summer vacation. ''Yeah,'' he said casually. ''Got a villa near Florence. Took the wife and kids.''

title: An Underground Spa In North Carolina
description: For 88 years, the Grove Park Inn has welcomed visitors to Asheville, N.C., to be soothed and relaxed by the Blue Ridge Mountains. For the new century, the resort is adding an underground spa.

title: Gabriella Blanco, Adam Lawrence
description: Gabriella Elena Blanco, the executive director of the Concordia Orchestra in New York, and Adam Gunn Lawrence, a graduate student, were married yesterday at Gedney Farm, an inn in New Marlborough, Mass. Eva Sheridan, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Looking For Love
description: ASHA SEKHRI cannot recall the first time she felt Other. Perhaps it happened as a child at the family dinner table, when looking around, she saw faces that did not mirror her own.

title: ATTORNEYS GENERAL TO TESTIFY
description: Two former state attorneys general are legally free to testify at hearings of the Senate Judiciary Committee next month about their knowledge of racial profiling by the New Jersey State Police. Some lawmakers questioned whether Peter G. Verniero and Deborah T. Poritz, now both State Supreme Court justices, would be shielded by attorney-client privilege; they used to be legal counsel to the Division of State Police. But the state attorney general, John J. Farmer Jr., said he waived that privilege on behalf of the division in November when he released 91,000 pages of State Police records showing that officials were aware that troopers disproportionately searched minority motorists before the state admitted to the practice in April 1999.

title: A Book Of Love, A Chapter At a Time
description: READING through the admiring English-language reviews of Eric Rohmer's films that have accumulated over the years, one can't help but be struck by the frequent recurrence of words like ''perfect'' and ''flawless'' -- phrases dutifully reproduced, sometimes out of context, on lobby posters and VHS boxes. But acknowledging perfection in a work of art -- especially, perhaps, in a movie -- can sometimes be a form of faint praise, even of condescension. Flawlessness involves the mastery of small proportions and brief measures, a preference for concentration over risk. The appetite of critics and audiences is more often for size, scale and heroic ambition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, RICHARD C.
description: CLARK-Richard C. Prominent NYC architect, died of cancer January 22, 2001. Devoted husband to Dolores. Beloved father of Elizabeth and Barbara. Cherished grandfather of Tyler and Allan. Born in 1928 and raised during the Depression in Hell's Kitchen, Richard ''Dick'' Clark was a proud son of NYC. He attended P.S. 51, Stuyvesant High School and Columbia University School of Architecture. His passion for life took him from winning the Silver Skates in the Speed Skating Competition at Madison Square Garden in 1957, to being a volunteer fireman in Croton-on-Hudson, to flying planes and collecting antique cars. His love of architecture led him on a 54 year career that took him from Battalion Drafting Instructor in the U.S. Army in the early 1950's, to Head of NY's World's Fair Examination Department in the 1960's, to President of Taylor Clark Architects, Inc. from 1979. In 2000, TCA merged with the prestigious firm, Swanke Hayden Connell Architects, to create Swanke Hayden Connell Architects/Taylor Clark Healthcare Group, where Dick served as a principal until his death. Richard was a published and internationally recognized expert in the planning and design of medical facilities and academic medical campuses. Serving over 100 clients during his extensive career, he directed numerous major projects including the NY Presbyterian Hospital (expansion over the FDR Drive was done in association with HOK), the NY Hospital Medical Center of Queens, the Brooklyn Hospital Center, Long Island College Hospital, and North Shore University Hospital, to name a few. He was honored by the NY Hospital Medical Center of Queens by receiving their Pacesetter Award in 1998 at a gala event. Richard was also an active and enthusiastic participant on many boards and committees including the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, the American Institute of Architects, Chairman of the Ad Hoc Committee of American College of Radiology, American Association for Hospital Planning, Society of Architectural Historians, and the NY Association for Ambulatory Care. He also served as a member of the board for Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY and Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, NY. Richard died peacefully at his home in NYC. He will be sorely missed by a great number of people. There will be a memorial service on Friday, February 16th at the Church of the Transfiguration (1 East 29th St., NYC) at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in his name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 1275, York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

title: Verdi Meets Shakespeare
description: Commemorating the 100th anniversary of Giuseppe Verdi's death, the New Jersey State Opera opens its 2001 season with two performances of ''Macbeth.'' Verdi's chilling adaptation of Shakespeare's tale of ambition and murder is a brooding theatrical combination of psychological undoing and thrilling action, complete with haunting arias, a chorus of witches and a sword fight.

title: February 4-10; Canada Scrambles
description: Alarmed that President Bush's first foreign trip will be to Mexico, Canada sent its foreign minister, defense minister and head of government to meet Bush administration counterparts, becoming the first country to do so. Canadians worry about losing influence with the United States, their largest trading partner, as America's population and interests shift southward. Canada's Liberal prime minister, Jean Chrtien has another liability: the Bush clan's friendship with Brian Mulroney, the Conservative Canadian leader who forged free trade with the United States in the 90's. After Monday's visit, Mr. Bush said: 'I've got a preference for friends. And the Canadians are longstanding friends.'' The next day, administration officials announced plans to open highways to Mexican trucks. James Brooke

title: February 4-10; Rise in Homelessness
description: The average nightly census in New York City's homeless shelters rose above 25,000 this winter, more than at any time since the 1980's, with the increase led by women and children -- already the bulk of shelter seekers. The commissioner for homeless services called a 10 percent surge in families since last year a ''crisis'' that reflected national trends. Among the causes: fallout from the economic boom through rising rents, more warrants for eviction, cutbacks in subsidized housing and a city ad campaign that helps bring 950 refugees from domestic violence nightly to a program with 450 beds. Nina Bernstein

title: Eugene J. Casey, Marketing Designer, Dies at 83
description: Eugene J. Casey, a marketing designer who founded the firm that designed the logotype for the Merrill Lynch bull, died on Jan. 30 in Guilford, Conn., at the home of a son. He was 83.

title: A Short Drive to a Spot a World Away
description: ONE always wants to find some corner of the world pristine in its beauty, rich in its comforts and best yet, close to home. The three rarely go together, needless to say.

title: Ocean Yields Up a New Mystery: 3 Dead 'Greyhounds of the Sea'
description: Three finback whale carcasses have appeared in New York Harbor recently, surprising marine mammal researchers, conservationists and ship operators. Usually only one carcass from a large whale species like the finback is found locally each year.

title: Technology Wreckage: Yes, More To Come
description: IT was February 2000, and tulips were blooming in Tech Land.

title: OPINION; Boon Times and Their Waistlines
description: THERE is no question that Long Island is experiencing an obesity epidemic. A brief visit to any public place, especially the supermarket, will erase any doubt. Even as we are bombarded with diet plans, exercise regimens and medical warnings about the perils of being overweight, the reading on the collective bathroom scale continues to climb at an alarming rate.

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: There are many who, like Klam, have had positive, life-changing experiences with Ecstasy and related substances that some call sacred medicines. The use of ''psychedelic'' substances for healing and spiritual enlightenment has a 5,000-year history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIBACH, SOL
description: ZWEIBACH-Sol. Educator, loving husband and father died February 3rd, 2001. Survivors: wife Pearl; children, Stephen and Charles; eight grandchildren; sisters Faye Siegel, Hilda Stoller, Shirley Berger; nephew Charles Siegel. For information please contact the O'Connor Laguna Hills Mortuary Directors, 949-581-4300.

title: A Whistler, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: In describing the reactions of those who use Ecstasy, Klam employs words like ''euphoria,'' ''empathy,'' ''epiphany'' and ''enlightenment.'' Glamorizing Ecstasy in this manner sends an inaccurate message to America's youth.

title: Szczerbiak Schools Rookies
description: Like many of the weekend's other invited participants, Wally Szczerbiak nearly did not play this afternoon as the N.B.A.'s second-year players took on the league's rookies. But instead of staying home to rest his right knee, which is still painful after off-season surgery, Szczerbiak threw himself into the game and came out with a bloody scratch under his right cheekbone to prove it.

title: Can International Relief Do More Good Than Harm?
description: One soldier wanted to light a cigarette, so he walked off into the bush, found two sticks and started rubbing them together. I gave him a lighter. We had landed not long before on a ragged airstrip in the Nuba Mountains of Sudan, a place all but cut off from the outside world for the last decade. It is short of matches and most everything else. Even five years ago, many Nuba were naked, and they talk about it with great shame; their clothes simply eroded from their bodies, as if from scarecrows a few autumns on.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about changes in federal law governing trade with Cuba misstated the year that the U.S. Healthcare Exhibition, a show of American products, was held in Havana. It was January 2000, not 2001.

title: Yankees Entering Transitional Year As Old Guard Nears End of the Line
description: Paul O'Neill says he's going to retire at the end of this year, but as his Yankees teammate Mike Stanton tells it, O'Neill has seriously contemplated retirement every day for the past four years. ''I've heard it standing in the outfield with him,'' Stanton said, chuckling. ''I won't believe it until they rip the jersey off his back.''

title: Romania Seeks to Stay On the Track to Europe
description: The new prime minister, Adrian Nastase, knows that his government represents Romania's last, best chance of catching up with Europe and of reversing the huge popular frustration that fed a sizable vote for neofascism in last December's elections.

title: Political Briefing; From Washington, A Look Back at Texas
description: Only three months have passed since Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas won a second full term. But will she serve out all six years?

title: Confessions of a Lonely Atheist
description: As an observant Jew, I was moved by Angier's article. In contrast to much of the recent religious bombast, her beliefs are brilliantly articulated, and she deftly punctures the notion that institutional attendance and moral behavior follow a belief in God. Far from feeling threatened by her atheism, she challenges me to struggle with my own beliefs, even as I am strengthened by them.

title: Recalling the Actor
description: To the Editor:

title: February 4-10; . . . States Are Tax-Starved
description: More than 15 governors have spent the last month surprising their states with bad news: tax collections are way down, state spending will have to be cut as much as 15 percent and a decade of expansion is over. Last year almost every state was flush with surplus cash, but the nation's economic slowdown has lashed states in the South and Midwest that rely heavily on manufacturing and sales taxes. Many economists have warned that the downturn will eventually hurt those states that depend on income taxes, along with the federal government. David Firestone

title: Equipment Counts
description: To the Editor:

title: Faulty Labeling?
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: HORSESHOE CRAB BAN
description: The National Marine Fisheries Service last week issued a ban on commercial fishermen using horseshoe crabs as bait in a 1,500-square-mile area from Pecks Beach in Cape May County to just north of Ocean City, Md. Migratory birds, which have been diminishing in the area, eat the crab's eggs. The restricted fishing zone will be expanded from its current three-mile limit to 30 miles offshore.

title: Men Are Crazy for Women Who Are, Too
description: ''You're young, you're crazy, you're in bed and you've got knives.''

title: OUT THERE: San Francisco; The Joy of Joblessness In the Web Wipeout
description: KEVIN GEORGE, a freelance Internet producer who has been out of work for three months, just returned from a two-and-a-half-week vacation in North Africa, which included a rave-style trance music festival called ''Morocco 2001.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'Time for Mime'

title: Stuck on the Bench
description: FEW young lives are as charmed as those of the star high school athlete. They receive local renown, colleges look at them fawningly and if you find one without a prom date, you've found the very first. In the Social Register of high school, the star athlete is, quite simply, le grand fromage.

title: Genome Analysis Shows Humans Survive on Low Number of Genes
description: Opening a new era in human biology and medicine, two rival teams of scientists this week present their first interpretations of the human genome, the set of DNA-encoded instructions that specify a person.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HSU, JOHN J., M.D.
description: HSU-John J., M.D. February 7, 2001. Age 81. Beloved husband of Elizabeth for 55 years. Dear father of James Hsu (Mary Jane), Nancy Hsu (James Dumbrell), Timothy Hsu (Beth), Hwayling Hsu (Jeffrey Enzminger) and John Hsu (San). Loving grandfather of ten. Private service will be held at a later date. For further information call A.J. Desmond & Sons Funeral Home 800-294-5668.

title: Democrats Struggle to Find a Stance on Tax Cut
description: After years of confidence that Bill Clinton had ended the Democratic Party's vulnerability on fiscal issues, Congressional Democrats are once again on the defensive and searching for a tax-cutting plan of their own that will maintain party unity in the face of President Bush's tax-cutting juggernaut.

title: Wireless Giants Won F.C.C. Auction Unfairly, Critics Say
description: George D. Crowley Jr., a longtime telecommunications entrepreneur, recalls the day last fall when an old friend contacted him about an intriguing opportunity. The friend represented SBC Communications. As Mr. Crowley knew, the Federal Communications Commission was preparing to begin an auction in December of wireless airwave frequencies that the largest telephone companies desperately needed.

title: Joan Scarangello, Patrick McNeive
description: Joan Frances Scarangello and Patrick Thomas McNeive were married yesterday by the Rev. Richard Leonard at All Souls Unitarian Church in Manhattan.

title: Academic Warfare
description: Anthropology has never had a particularly good reason for existing. How could an enterprise that began as a Victorian gentleman's hobby -- the effort to catalog every facet of the savage mind -- remain respectable in a postcolonial world? Anthropologists deal with this problem in two ways. Some of them elevate anthropology to a science, an inquiry into the universal truths of man. (The great anthropologist Franz Boas defined his field as ''the biological history of mankind in all its varieties.'') Others scoff at such pretensions. In their view, anthropology is an applied branch of the humanities, an intellectual apprenticeship in the delicate art of getting to know other cultures without flattening them to the contours of your own.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ETTINGER, SIDNEY
description: ETTINGER-Sidney. 2/11/16-5/30/86 Celebrating your 85th birthday (alone). You're still my movie star. You're still the love of my life. Your Bride

title: Allen Is 3-Point Champion
description: Milwaukee's Ray Allen won the 3-point shooting contest, hitting 10 shots in a row and scoring 19 points in the final round. He edged out Sacramento's Peja Stojakovic, who had 17. The Knicks' Allan Houston, after scoring 11 points (the lowest total of the eight shooters) and failing to advance, heard boos from the crowd.

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: I want to add my voice to what I suspect is a deafening chorus of angry readers commenting on your article about Ecstasy.

title: The Nation; Smaller, Cheaper, Stealthier, Deadlier
description: The passionate debate over missile defense has obscured an important fact: today, a number of experts believe that long-range missiles are pass compared with other threats. Big missiles, the reasoning goes, are lumbering, fire-breathing monsters built more for prestige, intimidation and political symbolism than for firing at enemies half-way around the globe.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A HEART OF STONE

title: Still Pushing and Shoving
description: Twyla Tharp, the choreographer whose signature work is ''Push Comes to Shove,'' is still pushing and shoving dance boundaries. After 35 years, her fusions of classical ballet, modern dance, jazz and something of her own make her look like the new kid on the block.

title: Long Acela Trip
description: To the Editor: On Jan. 21, I had reservations on the 6:55 p.m. Acela Regional from Boston to New York. Five minutes out, all the lights went out and we stopped for 20 minutes. The conductor said the engine was being ''recycled.'' This occurred twice more.

title: Kim Steinburgh, Scott Sherman
description: Kim Elizabeth Steinburgh and Scott Leigh Sherman were married in New York last evening at the University Club. The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Tewell, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the ceremony, in which Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel took part.

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: I read Klam's article with interest -- and a sense of dej vu. Describing his transcendence of emotional barriers to empathy and connection, he writes, ''No other drug produces this kind of feeling.'' He is wrong. I had similar experiences taking LSD. Along with them went a conviction that the drug somehow allowed me access to a capacity for happiness long suppressed and forgotten. As with Klam, this effect waned after my first few trips. The question then became how to recover that lost capacity in a less-ephemeral way. The drug of the moment may change; the question does not.

A Web site, www.thetube.com, allows users to plan trips around the city and then print out itineraries showing the best route on the Underground. Users may enter a tube stop, a point of interest, a postal code or an address. (Tip: after the address, place a comma followed by London.) The results include the approximate time the trip will take and the fare. The site also includes system maps and schedules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAF, FREDERICK W.
description: GRAF-Frederick W. On November 24, 2000, peacefully at home, aged 86, in Bethlehem, PA. For 38 years he was organist and choirmaster of the Cathedral Church of the Nativity there, which had a noted choir of men and boys since 1886. He also directed the Cathedral Choral Society of Bethlehem, which had annually performed Handel's ''Messiah'', with orchestra, in the Lehigh University chapel for 29 years when he retired in 1992. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, the former Esther Kennedy, and a son, David, of Mt. Kisco, NY. Born in New York City, he earned bachelor's and master's degrees at New York University. He served for four years in the U.S. Army in World War II, with the 9th Evacuation Hospital, through the campaigns in North Africa, Italy, France, and Germany. Following the war, he was assistant organist and carillonneur at Saint Thomas Church, 5th Avenue, NYC, from 1946-1952. Several of his early compositions have been published. He was greatly loved by all who knew him, especially those who sang in his choirs or studied with him, some of whom went on to careers in music. Along with musical training, he instilled principles of character and discipline, all with a wit and humor for which he was famous. He was a member of the St. Wilfrid Club of NYC and of the American Guild of Organists.

Mishra's ''spare and reflective fiction . . . is a welcome antidote to the riotous magic realism so common in contemporary Indian writing,'' Akash Kapur wrote in the Book Review last year. That seems to be this year's retail message, with a cataract of petophilic products coming out in time for the big day. Old Navy's new pet line includes bright red bowls, leashes and bandannas in heart prints ($3.50 to $7.50). Oh, My Dog!, the popular fragrance designed for pets and owners to share, is introducing a shampoo for joint ablutions ($20 at Saks Fifth Avenue) as is Aesop, whose Animal shampoo for pets, ($30 at Barneys New York) is also safe ''for use on human fur.'' He will then have to gain the support of the United Nations Security Council for the revised approach.

But I wish she had pointed out that one's particular religious beliefs are almost always determined by one's parents, in a process of enculturation that has little to do with thought, choice or revelation.

Chris Trapper, lead singer-songwriter-guitarist, is the guiding force here. Expect a grittier live sound than the arrangements on record. They will perform songs from ''Opening Time,'' released this week, at 9 p.m. Wednesday at Maxwell's in Hoboken. Robbie Woliver

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Great Stone Face
description: Ernest Hebert, the author of five well-received novels about New Hampshire's rural underclass (the ''Darby'' series), departs from his earlier material and style in his new book, THE OLD AMERICAN (University Press of New England, $24.95). It's a historical novel inspired by the true story of Nathan Blake, a house builder in Keene, N.H., who was captured by an Indian raiding party and spirited off to Canada in 1746, during the French and Indian Wars. The rest is fiction, but the novel is always grounded in a fine historical sensibility and sympathetic imagination. Hebert's most notable invention in this book is Blake's captor, an aged Indian -- an ''old American'' -- named Caucus-Meteor. Caucus-Meteor takes Blake to his village of Conissadawaga, near Quebec city. Eventually the relationship between master and slave grows so close that the old chief makes Blake his godson and a member of the tribe. As a character, Blake is rather lifeless, perhaps because the author felt constrained by a respect for history. Caucus-Meteor, in contrast, is magnificently alive -- he is funny and brooding, by turns practical and maudlin; he thinks and plots constantly, peering into the future with the help of magic, and he is slyly disrespectful of all received wisdom and the hypocrisies of European civilization in America. He thinks he would be pleased to die, not out of depression but because he feels he's simply too old and tired to live. His face already looks like the Old Man of the Mountains, the rock formation in New Hampshire's Franconia Notch; toward the end of his life, when even his tribe thinks he's dead, Caucus-Meteor has a tattoo artist increase the resemblance (through the use of color, intentional scarring and a dislocated nose) and changes his name to Great Stone Face. There is little action in ''The Old American,'' but to share Caucus-Meteor's thoughts is itself an extraordinary adventure. William Ferguson

The top, with a leather strap and a silver buckle, is available alone for $1,400.

Downtown Washington is the heart of an astonishing amount of security activity, obvious to the public only at times like the morning last week when a distraught former federal employee appeared outside the White House fence with a gun. He was almost immediately confronted by teams of local and federal law enforcement officers, who ended the potential threat by shooting him in the knee.

description: By the end of the regular season, and certainly by Super Bowl XXXV, Giants defensive end Michael Strahan was playing on a level where he was arguably the second best defensive player in the league, behind only Baltimore linebacker Ray Lewis. Strahan was simply overwhelming.

description: CAFE MELMAR'S finale is its finest hour. A cascade of desserts lights up tables throughout the subdued dining room at this new East Hills spot. Sid Grabill, the executive chef, who prepares them, learned his pastry making in Belgium and France and it shows. The sweets at this spiffy Italian-skewed spot don't take the predictable cannoli, ricotta cheesecake, tiramis trail. There was ricotta on the dessert specials menu, but it is tucked into two warm, flaky, almost air-born apple strudel cylinders and escorted by a scoop of caramel gelato festooned with caramel syrup squiggles.

And so what if they were asked to sign confidentiality or noncompetition clauses? Jobs were plentiful, and in a tight labor market, it seemed that few employers were enforcing those agreements anyway.

Sandler and stepfather of Jonathan Feld of Boston, MA and David Feld of Fremont, CA. Calvin Butts, pastor of Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church, suggests the following: ''There was a fellow named Josiah that became king. And they were searching through some rubble, and they found the books of the law that had been lost. And Josiah said, 'Read them to me.' And then he said, 'That's what we're supposed to be doing?' And he went through the land. He pulled down all the temples of the foreign gods, and he killed off the priests who would not submit to the one god. It was a brutal, ugly thing, but he brought order, peace, the law back to the land. He went down in the annals of Second Kings as one of the great kings.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOESTER, KATHERINE RAUB RIDLEY
description: KOESTER-Katherine Raub Ridley. The Preservation League of New York State notes with great sadness the untimely passing of Katherine Raub Ridley Koester of Binghamton, New York. Counsel at the League for over 13 years, she will be missed by New York State's entire preservation community. Our sincerest sympathy is extended to her husband Norman and their children.

title: Hate the Service at Movies? You Can Buy Your Own

title: Smooth Sailing for Medals and Rolex Awards
description: For two pairs of United States Olympic sailors, it all came down to one final race. The Star-boat tandem of Mark Reynolds and Magnus Liljedahl had started last October's Olympic regatta in Sydney, Australia, in disappointing style, but over the course of the 11-race series they had clawed their way back into contention. On the last day of competition they were assured of a bronze medal, and still held an outside chance for a gold.
