DJ Marlboro, two cell phones in hand, moved through the crowd. A pregnant woman asked him to kiss her belly, beautiful dancers gave him their phone numbers and a 9-year-old begged him for a recording contract.

title: QUICK BITE/Jersey City; Meet Chickpea Patty
description: Sure, a rose by any other name would smell as sweet. But would we eat falafel if it were sold under the name of deep-fried chickpea patties? The answer is yes, if you're at Ibby's Falafel in Jersey City. Using a recipe created by his mother and perfected over the last 30 years by his uncle, a restaurateur in New York, Adnan Kwara is busy making converts to this Middle Eastern staple. But in the beginning, he wasn't so sure it would sell. ''When we first opened in '96, we served pizza, wings, and falafel,'' said Mr. Kwara. ''But people came just to eat the falafel.'' He took the hint and reopened the restaurant a few months later with a streamlined Middle Eastern menu. The star, of course, is the falafel sandwich ($2.50), topped with lettuce and onions and drizzled with tahini, a smoky dressing made from sesame seed paste. For a dollar more, it comes with hummus, baba gannouj or tabbouleh, and for $2 more, with all three plus fava beans and stuffed grape leaves. Shawarama, a 13-spiced Syrian version of the gyro, is an excellent choice for meat lovers, as are the chicken kebabs, which are marinated for 24 hours in garlic, olive oil, lemon juice, onions and paprika. Both are served as sandwiches for $4 or platters for $9. Pastries are made daily; the best choice is mabrouma ($1.50), a flaky nest of phyllo stacked high with walnuts, almonds and pistachios. At these prices, there's hardly a downside, unless you dislike garlic, which subtly infuses everything but the tahini. And why is this dressing garlic-free? ''We get a large lunch crowd,'' Mr. Kwara said. ''People are going back to work. We have to be considerate.'' Gretchen Kurtz

title: Writing a Show for Mom and Her Friends
description: THE framed photographs displayed on the grand piano in her Beverly Hills home tell the story: Elizabeth Taylor, Jimmy Stewart, Cary Grant, to name a few. Growing up in Los Angeles, Carrie Fisher, daughter of Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher, had a front-row seat for the behind-the-scenes doings in the entertainment industry. As a screenwriter and in her best-selling semiautobiographical novels, including ''Postcards From the Edge,'' which was made into a film starring Meryl Streep and Shirley MacLaine, Ms. Fisher has used her Hollywood insider's life as rich comic fodder.

title: HARRIS'S DOUBLE MARKS ARMORY MEET
description: I-Perfection Harris scored his third double victory of the season, Stacey Ann Livingston recorded her third nation-leading time, and Kedar Inico and Corey Thomas each won two events yesterday in the Evian Mayor's Trophy all-city high school championships at the Armory Track and Field Center.

title: Women Away
description: To the Editor: Our six-member group of former PTA-ers -- 19 children among us -- has been ''escaping'' spring and fall since 1973. We began in a tent, but after a later trip saw our lakeside tent blow into the water, we opted for cabins or campers. Like Ms. Benzel's group, we often shared a member's home serendipitously situated on Lake Hopatcong, complete with dock and boat.

title: February 4-10; Inquiry Shifts to Torricelli
description: An investigation of illegal contributions to Robert Torricelli's 1996 campaign is making the senator, a champion Democratic fund-raiser from New Jersey, increasingly uncomfortable. Recently, three of his former campaign aides learned they had become targets of a Justice Department inquiry now in its fourth year. Now, people familiar with the case say that Mr. Torricelli himself is the main focus. The senator says it is a fishing expedition. ''This is the ultimate example of attempting to find something -- anything -- on somebody of significance,'' he said. Andy Newman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETHEL, C. MARK
description: BETHEL-C. Mark. Sailor, sandhog, jeweler and entrepreneur, died on February 8, at the age of 72. Mark Bethel combined a lifelong love for reading with the grit of a compressed air worker, fine craftsmanship and the practical acumen of a successful businessman. His presence will be missed but his impression is indelible. A daughter, son, three sisters, two brothers and three grandchildren survive him.

title: February 4-10; AIDS Meeting in Chicago
description: Ten years ago, an international AIDS meeting was moved from Boston to Amsterdam, in part because of United States government restrictions on allowing people infected with H.I.V. into the country. But the United States also had restrictions on sending its scientists abroad to such meetings. So American scientists formed their own meeting, which emphasized science rather than the politics and advocacy efforts that often created a circus-like atmosphere at international AIDS meetings. The eighth American meeting, held in Chicago, however, took an unusually international focus. Among the reports about AIDS in other countries or by foreign scientists:

title: Corrections
description: The Strategies column last Sunday, about the Super Bowl Indicator, which holds that stocks will rise over the coming year if the winning team can trace its roots to the original National Football League, misstated the number of years in which both Super Bowl teams had such origins. It is seven, not one.

title: Hey, It's All in the Family
description: If politics makes strange bedfellows, try the mix of politics and corporate boards. William M. Daley, the former commerce secretary who served as chairman of Al Gore's close-but-not-close-enough run for the presidency, joined the board of Electronic Data Systems. But that is just the beginning of the story. E.D.S. was famously started by Ross Perot, who worked to defeat the North American Free Trade Agreement; the Clinton administration campaign to approve the treaty was coordinated by -- you guessed it -- Mr. Daley.

title: N.J. LAW; Here's My Number. Don't Use It.
description: Theresa Crusius hates telemarketers who wake her on Saturday mornings, who interrupt dinner at her home in Hackensack, who call when she is trying to whisk her children off to basketball, soccer or track practice.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Three Anti-Romantics; Black Hearts and Dead Flowers
description: ELEVEN years ago Marc Leonard was a skinny, disenfranchised 18-year-old wandering around the Rutgers campus in New Brunswick, N.J., grumbling about being unlucky in love. Things weren't clicking with his sort-of girlfriend, and as Valentine's Day approached, they decided to throw a party to share their unhappiness.

title: Holly Kurtz, Garth Yettick
description: Rachel Holly Kurtz, a daughter of Marilyn Kurtz of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Dr. Robert Kurtz of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Garth Conrad Yettick, a son of Carole and Keith Yettick of San Jose, Calif. The Rev. Susan Sealy, an aunt of the bridegroom and an assistant pastor at the Believers' Church in Tulsa, Okla., performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Don CeSar Beach Resort and Spa in St. Pete Beach, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYON, ROSALIND KAUFMANN
description: LYON-Rosalind Kaufmann. Died peacefully at her home on February 3, 2001, at the age of 90, following a long illness. She lived all her life in Manhattan. She was a graduate of the Ethical Culture School and Wellesley College, and was a noted amateur golfer. During WWII, she assisted the war effort by taking officers of the United States Armed Services between posts throughout the greater New York area, drving them in her family's car. She was the widow of Ludwig S. Lyon, who died in 1988. She is survived by a stepdaughter, Frances Lyon Rosenthal of South Londonderry, VT, and Scottsdale, AZ; a niece, Ellen Eiseman Hersh of Bradford, NH, and St. Petersburg, FL; a nephew, James Eiseman Jr., of Philadelphia; two granddaughters, five great-grandchildren, a grandnephew and grandnice, and a greatgrandniece. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., NY, NY, at 11 AM, on Monday, February 12. Interment private. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions to Lenox Hill Hospital or Wellesley College.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 11, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Subway Riders Rue a Loss
description: For years, hundreds of photographs of children, pets and wild animals decorated the subway elevators at the 181st Street and 190th Street A train stations. But last week, officials of the Metropolitan Transit Authority ordered the pictures removed, saying they violated the fire code. They also ordered the elevator operators to stop eating, drinking, playing music and reading during their shifts, except when on break.

title: A $100,000 Winner In E-Commerce Contest
description: For Jeff Mancini, e-commerce has certainly paid off. His Web site, www.eastcoastfisherman.com, won him $100,000 in the American Express ''E-magine With Blue for Business'' contest last week.

title: Kovalev's Hat Trick Stuns Devils
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins never forgot that the Devils scored nine goals against them here in the first month of the season, and they wanted to erase that memory. The Devils wanted to prove they could do just as well against the Penguins even with Mario Lemieux in the lineup.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-21

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Exuberance Is Rational
description: It is possible that Richard Thaler changed his mind about economic theory and went on to challenge what had become a hopelessly dry and out-of-touch discipline because, one day, when a few of his supposedly rational colleagues were over at his house, he noticed that they were unable to stop themselves from gorging on some cashew nuts he'd put out. Then again, it could have been because a friend admitted to Thaler that, although he mowed his own lawn to save $10, he would never agree to cut the lawn next door in return for the same $10 or even more. But the moment that sticks in Thaler's mind occurred back in the 1970's, when he and another friend, a computer maven named Jeff Lasky, decided to skip a basketball game in Rochester because of a swirling snowstorm.

title: Push-Button Books
description: Hotel guests can press a button on their room telephones and order meals, an extra blanket or fresh towels. But what about a good book, a magazine or a CD?

title: February 4-10; Bush Tax-Cut Plan Goes to Congress, but . . .
description: President Bush sent his $1.6 trillion tax-cut proposal to Capitol Hill, and it was denounced by Democrats as too big and by conservatives -- and business leaders -- as way, way too small. The debate is clearly no longer whether there will be a big tax cut, but rather how big it will be. The Democrats -- with an eye to the prevailing political wind -- have already given some ground, but point out that the Bush plan does little for the working poor, who pay almost nothing in income taxes but plenty in Social Security and medicare taxes. Mr. Bush says bigger child credits and the reduction of all tax rates will help everyone, and lift the economy.

title: When Barbie's Sick, They Make Dream House Calls
description: The symptom, as presented to the doctor, seemed dire. ''That door just fell off, without the dinosaur even ripping it off,'' said an exasperated Rob Meyer, indicating a yellow door on a sleek new toy: the foot-long Jurassic Park III sport utility vehicle (retail, $19.99). As if on cue, the door dropped off again. And not a Tyrannosaurus in sight.

title: Lessons Learned on the Streeet
description: IT WAS the summer of 1973 and the new parole officer was touring his beat, the mammoth public housing projects of Newark's Central Ward.

title: Hotel Discounts in New York and Philadelphia
description: New York hotel prices can be daunting, but older properties sometimes offer relief. Through the end of February, rates at the Hotel Belleclaire, 250 West 77th Street in Manhattan, start at $139 a night, with a Continental breakfast. The 189-room Art Nouveau hotel, which dates from the turn of the century, is near the Museum of Natural History and Lincoln Center. Rooms are done in an Art Deco style. Reservations: (877) 468-3522; information: www.hotelbelleclaire.com .

title: Gowns? What Gowns?
description: JACQUELINE KENNEDY took a pair of valuable antique tables. Millard Fillmore took a coach and six bay horses, then sold them after he left the presidency. Ronald and Nancy Reagan, after his two terms in office, left the White House with more than $1 million worth of dresses, jewelry, shoes and accessories.

title: Works From Jamaican Artists That Tell Their Own Stories
description: ONE of this season's finest exhibitions, ''Redemption Songs: The Self-Taught Artists of Jamaica,'' can be seen here at the Arts Alliance of Haverstraw. The show features works by 17 Jamaican artists selected largely from the collection of Wayne and Myrene Cox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, CORINNE R. (COREE)
description: MEYERS-Corinne R. (Coree). On February 7, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Archie Meyers. Dear mother of Sherri Goldsmith and Carole Davidson. Mother-in-law to Howard. Cherished grandmother of Allison. Adored sister of Phyllis Lasser and Morty Ryweck. Her consuming love for her family will be irreplaceable. Services today, February 11, 11:45 AM, ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: POSTINGS: Offices, Rentals and Condos at Broadway and Chambers St.; Putting 3 Buildings in One
description: The old Arthur Levitt State Office Building at Broadway and Chambers Street, where for seven decades state legislators and agencies hung their New York City hats -- and hundreds of aspiring real estate brokers took their state licensing exams -- is being converted into, in effect, three buildings stacked one atop another.

title: Corrections
description: A Bookend essay on Jan. 14, about the reading habits of American presidents, misstated the scope and original date of a book by Charles de Gaulle, ''The Edge of the Sword.'' It was published in France in 1932, not 1960, as ''Le Fil de l'epee''; a 1960 English translation nowhere mentions the earlier publication. It is not a memoir; it consists chiefly of lectures on war, edited for publication.

title: Sub in Collision Was Conducting Drill, Navy Says
description: The United States Navy submarine that struck and sank a Japanese fishing boat carrying 35 people on board near Hawaii on Friday was conducting a drill when it surfaced quickly, as if in an emergency, the Navy said today.

title: Baby, It's Cold Inside
description: A STUDENT

title: Accessory to Murder?
description: A People Betrayed

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESPOSITO, FRANCESCO
description: ESPOSITO-Francesco. Beloved husband of the late Carmela and son Patrick. Loving father of Josephine, Concetta, Anna, Salvatore and Vincent. Fond father-inlaw of Rocco, Joseph, Camille and Ali. Cherished grandfather of ten and 16 great-grandchildren. Funeral from Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th St., Brooklyn, NY, Monday, 8:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial Most Precious Blood Church, NYC, 10 AM. Interment Resurrection Cemetery, S.I., NY.

title: Shedding Light on Lincoln
description: HAROLD HOLZER first met Abraham Lincoln when, in the fifth grade, he pulled his name out of a hat. Lincoln became his assignment, and the boy borrowed a book from the school library, ''The Lincoln Nobody Knows'' by Richard Current, for his report.

title: Letters
description: BING CROSBY

title: Cook Doesn't Let an Elbow, or Hurricanes, Stop Him
description: When Omar Cook was helped to the locker room early in the second half today holding a towel to his face, St. John's chances against Miami appeared to go with him. Cook, the freshman point guard, has led the Red Storm this season in points and assists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREIER, LAURA
description: DREIER-Laura. 84. Of Phoenix. Formerly of New York City. Passed away on February 7, 2001 at home. She was a beloved and devoted wife to Fred, her husband of 57 years. Laura was deeply loved and will be missed by her husband, daughter Jill and son-inlaw Bert Alanko. Her dear son Jonathan passed away in 1986. Laura's two grandchildren, Lisa and Adam Goldring and her daughterin-law Tami, along with her three great-grandchildren, Alex, Jacob and Ashley will hold her forever in their hearts. Laura was a beauty both inside and out. She always embraced and encouraged her many friends. Her generous gifts of financial help including those through the Jonathan Dreier Foundation have and will continue to benefit many. Her talent and love for writing poetry leaves us with her private collection ''Through Love, Laughter and Tears'' to treasure always. We will miss her. Viewing and memorial services will be held at Green Acres Cemetery and Mortuary, 401 North Hayden Road, Scottsdale, AZ on Monday, February 12, 2001 at 12:00 noon and 1:00 PM respectively. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested to the Laura Dreier Breast Center at Good Samaritan Hospital, 1111 East McDowell Road, Phoenix, AZ 85006.

title: Judging Khrushchev, in History's Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Slick Routine Makes Way For Vitality
description: GOOD SHEPHERD PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH on West 66th Street stands in the shadow of Lincoln Center, dwarfed by the back side of the Juilliard School. Yet in the church's dusty old sanctuary you can hear some of the most meaningful music-making in the city: concerts by Jens Nygaard and the Jupiter Symphony.

title: Strike The Band: Pop Music Without Musicians
description: IN the 1950's and 60's, the recording studio became an instrument. From its humble origins documenting live performances, the studio turned into a music-maker itself, retooling raw material -- the work of musicians -- into a finished product. Once mere ''records'' of musical events, recordings were now something much more exotic and autonomous, painstakingly layered confections. But even after multitrack recording had severed music making from real time, somebody still had to play that guitar.

title: The World: Learning to Fly; Kosovo's Young Get By With a Little Help From the West
description: STANDING on a barren plaza, dressed in an Oakland Raiders parka and Nike sneakers, 16-year-old Luan Sherifi takes a drag on his Lucky Strike cigarette and assesses how Western culture has influenced his hometown, his native land and his generation.

title: Flights of Fancy for Books and Chairs
description: Not for Publication

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUSSENHOVEN, WALTER HOWARD
description: GUSSENHOVEN-Walter Howard. Former General Motors executive. Died at home in Charleston, S.C. on February 4, 2001. He was born December 16, 1910 in Chicago, IL. and attended The Choate School in Wallingford, CT. and Dartmouth College, from which he graduated in 1934 with a B.A. degree in Economics. Mr. Gussenhoven was an Executive Vice President of General Motors Overseas Corporation with responsibility for GM activities throughout different regions of the world, particularly South America, Africa and The Middle East. During his 41-year career with General Motors, he was also a General Manager in several coutries in Latin America, where there were large assembly and manufacturing operations. Upon retiring from General Motors in 1975, he and Mrs. Gussenhoven, the former Marie Aspinwall, moved from New York City to Charleston, S.C., where Mrs. Gussenhoven died in 1980. Later, in 1982, Mr. Gussenhoven married Marguerite Valk Reeves, who survives him along with other members of a large and extended family. He was a member of the Charleston Club, the Carolina Yacht Club and the Country Club of Charleston.

title: You've Got Nails
description: Even without these dazzling jewels, you've got your finger on the pulse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, MORTIMER V.
description: SCHWARTZ-Mortimer V., of San Francisco. On February 5, 2001. Bon vivant, epicure, entrepreneur and beloved father of Cathy, Peter, Alexandra, Pamela, Bart and Fredric. No services. For information about the Culinary Institute of America memorial scholarship, or to contribute to the family's book of memories, please call 415733-0734.

title: MY FIRST JOB; Enticing Enemies To Work Together
description: Daniel Ciporin is president and chief executive of DealTime.com, which provides online comparison-shopping services in the United States, Britain, Germany and Japan. Mr. Ciporin, who is based in New York, is a former executive of MasterCard.

title: Women's Work
description: THE PRICE OF MOTHERHOOD

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-11-01: Questions for AVERY DULLES; Divine Promotion
description: Q: Your name is deeply rooted in the American WASP establishment. Your grandfather was a liberal Presbyterian theologian. Your father, John Foster Dulles, was one of the architects of the postwar world. Your uncle, Allen Dulles, was the head of the C.I.A. And yet here you are, a Catholic cardinal. Was your family religious at home?

title: The Lead Is Love's, But Woods Is Nearby
description: The leader board at the Buick Invitational looked more crowded today than Tiger Woods's trophy case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANNER, SELMA
description: KANNER-Selma. Born October 5, 1910 passed away on the evening of February 9, 2001 in NYC. Dearest Selma, wife of the late Louis Kanner, brought joy and kindness to all of her friends and family. She will be lovingly remembered by her brothers Harold and Arthur; daughter Rita Diane Skyler; son-in-law Martin Skyler; grandchildren Edward, Tristine, Lisanne and her husband Kevin Black.

title: A New Wrinkle for the Morning Commute
description: FOR years, Tim Mortimer stood at the crowded south end of the Metro-North platform in Bronxville to board one of the first cars. Now he stands at the north end.

title: An Aversion to Economic Pain
description: Despite employee concerns about a weakening economy, most American workers are unwilling to sacrifice their quality of life if they lose their jobs, a recent survey shows. Nearly half of workers surveyed by Zogby International, an opinion research firm, said they would hold out for a job comparable to their current one if they were laid off, and nearly two thirds would take a pay cut over moving to a new city.

title: To Some All-Stars, It's Not About Image
description: Allen Iverson was trying to put the best spin on the issue. He and many of his peers have heard Karl Malone and Charles Oakley denounce the younger generation of players, railing about their attitudes toward the game and their actions off the court.

title: In Mall or Office, Growing Touches of Green
description: SOME plants just naturally make a splash. Poinsettias stand out, even amid the holiday glitter. Big blousy peonies practically insist on special attention. And those much-hyped ''dinner plate'' dahlias are the brazen hussies of the horticultural world.

title: A Few Words From Gregory Hines
description: Gregory Hines, the actor, singer and dancer, will be seen in three different television productions this month. For the Showtime movie ''Bojangles,'' Mr. Hines stars as Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, as well as serving as executive producer. He also stars as Ben Doucette on the sitcom ''Will and Grace'' and is the voice of Big Bill on Bill Cosby's animated series ''Little Bill.'' He recently made his directorial debut in ''The Red Sneakers'' for Showtime.

title: There'll Always Be an England in India
description: The Glass Palace

title: Words and Music for a Revolution
description: AGNES CUNNINGHAM and the late Gordon Friesen were living in a small apartment on the 11th floor of the Frederick Douglass housing project on West 104th Street when they founded Broadside, a ''topical'' song magazine, in 1962.

title: Passport Woes
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article, ''How to Avoid Passport Woes'' (Dec. 31) reminded me of how my husband avoided a potential passport problem. Between Kennedy International Airport and home, his shaving lotion spilled onto his passport, streaking some foreign stamps and obliterating others. The title page, with the picture, personal data and passport number, was not touched.

title: MONEY FOR SCHOOL BUILDINGS
description: Six of the state's poorest school districts received approval from the Department of Education last week for $2.7 billion in building improvements. Construction and renovation plans were approved for Paterson, Newark, Millville, Phillipsburg, Orange and Neptune. The department also approved $657 million in state money to help finance more than 400 construction projects in 172 non-Abbott districts.

title: Small Airlines Hit Hard By Fuel Prices
description: THE rise in crude oil prices is hurting some small regional and niche airlines, four of which sought refuge from creditors in United States Bankruptcy Court in December. All four cited the doubling of fuel prices in the last year as the prime cause of their problems, and while oil prices have come down a bit since last summer, they are still pinching all the airlines, none of which have rescinded the fuel surcharges that they began imposing last February.

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: Your writer's largely anecdotal article discounts a decade of scientific research showing that Ecstasy (MDMA) has serious short-term and long-term effects, including disrupting the brain's serotonin system and, as a result, interfering with a person's mood, emotions, learning, memory, sleep and perception of pain. In addition, the drug dramatically raises body temperature, heart rate and blood pressure -- with dire consequences for some people that can include heart and kidney failure.

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: As a psychotherapist with a specialty in substance use and addictions, I read Klam's article with a mixture of fascination and dread. It seemed clear from the outset that this gifted writer might inspire more curiosity than caution, although by the article's end I felt that he had made a fairly balanced presentation. I am also regularly reminded of the reality that often accompanies such pursuits. Three of my female clients, while under Ecstasy's influence, were raped in clubs by male ''friends'' or dealers who may or may not have been using the drug themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, LEONARD
description: DAVIS-Leonard. The arts have lost a dear friend and an extraordinary gentleman. Leonard Davis was one of the original members of the Kravis Center's Board of Directors. He, along with his beloved wife Sophie, who predeceased him four months ago, shared their love of the arts in guiding the Center in its growth as a world class performing arts center. His direction, guidance and pure humanity will be profoundly missed, but his impact on the cultural landscape will be felt for generations to come. Our heartfelt condolences to Alan, Michael and their families. Alexander W. Dreyfoos, Jr. Board Chairman Judith A. Mitchell Chief Executive Officer Kravis Center for the Performing Arts

title: Air Travel Difficulties Mount in Rural West
description: Sitting at Gate 59 on the B concourse Friday morning, waiting for a flight back to Casper, Wyo., Richard and Becky Osborne looked anything but happy. They had arrived at Denver International Airport on Wednesday night on a United Airlines flight from Las Vegas, but their connecting flight and five more on Thursday had been either canceled by the late-week snowstorm or overbooked.

title: Art Commission: Elitist Bastion or Aesthetic Boon?
description: IT seemed to be an open question at the end of the 20th century whether the New York City Art Commission, a product of the 19th, would survive into the 21st.

title: Exit, Plymouth Grocery; Enter, Plymouth Deli
description: A longtime greengrocer in Brooklyn Heights, Plymouth Grocery, is to reopen tomorrow as Plymouth Deli. Peter Hong, who has owned the business at 90 Henry Street, on the corner of Pineapple Street, for 15 years, said, ''I want to appear more professional, with hot food and a deli.'' Competition from other groceries and a large supermarket on the street also made business difficult, he said.

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

description: At Satchmo Museum, No One Can March In

title: Nothing to Scoff About
description: I plead guilty: I have tasted Mouton Cadet rouge. First, in 1984.

title: But Sometimes, Commuting Is Not the Solution
description: WHAT do you do when you have a long commute to New Jersey, but the the house of your dreams is in New York, Pennsylvania or some other state?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANSOHOFF, JOSEPH, MD.
description: RANSOHOFF-Joseph, MD. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of NYU School of Medicine mourn the passing of Joseph Ransohoff, MD, Professor and Chairman of the Department of Neurosurgery and Director of The Neurological Service at NYU Medical Center and Bellevue Hospital from 1961 to 1992. Dr. Ransohoff's distinguished career spanned more than 50 years. After receiving his BS at Harvard University in 1938 he earned his medical degree at the University of Chicago Medical School, completed residencies at Cincinnati General and Montefiore Hospitals, and was a neurological surgeon with the U.S. Army during the Second World War. Soon after joining the NYU faculty, he established the world's first neurosurgery ICU at Bellevue and trained more than 60 neurosurgeons, many of whom advanced to positions of leadership at medical schools all over the country. An avid fisherman, boater and jogger, Dr. Ransohoff moved to Tampa, Florida in 1992, but never truly retired. Since then, he served as Professor of Neurosurgery and Neurology at the University of South Florida School of Medicine and Director of Neurological Surgery at The Moffitt Cancer Center and Research Hospital. The entire Medical Center community extends its most heartfelt sympathy to Dr. Ransohoff's widow, children and grandchildren. Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff, President, NYU Hospitals Center Patrick J. Kelly, MD, Chairman, Department of Neurosurgery

title: Underworld Tales From India's Tarnished Screen
description: Bollywood's biggest financier of films an immensely wealthy diamond merchant named Bharat Shah -- is living for now in a small, dreary jail cell, far from the glamorous parties where he loved to mingle.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction; Finger Painting, Even
description: Heralded in his time as ''the only perfect landscape painter whom the world has ever seen,'' J. M. W. Turner (1775-1851) worked entirely within the system -- the Royal Academy in London, to whose school he was admitted in 1789, at the age of 14, and where he taught and exhibited until his death in 1851. Yet if his resume is not exactly iconoclastic, his working methods were; they are detailed by the art critic Eric Shanes in TURNER: The Great Watercolours (Royal Academy of Arts/Abrams, $55), a book of rigorous scholarship and beauty. Shanes looks at Turner's career through the focus of his work in watercolor, a medium in which he achieved a spontaneity he never quite matched in oil. Perfect for conveying subtle atmospheric changes, Turner's watercolors set new levels of sophistication. Not one to idly watch the paint dry, early on he set up production lines, working in one tone across multiple sheets before introducing another. This helps to explain his hefty output, demanded by aristocratic patrons who would order paintings just on the basis of thumbing through sketchbooks from Turner's travels. By the mid-1810's, Turner was creating his radiant skies and diaphanous colors with a whole bag of tricks: dumping entire drawings into buckets of water, dropping down wet colors that would diffuse on the page, using anything from stale breadcrumbs to scalpels to fingers to manipulate paint into ethereal approximations of nature. Turner had his detractors, who took him to task for such liberties and carped of his inability to depict the human figure accurately. Yet mainly he was a source of national pride. One critic swooned in 1819: ''The art itself is par excellence English, no continental pencil can come near the force, freedom, and nature of our professor's.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: Who Will Fix 3 Overpasses Sheathed in Ice?
description: Forty years ago, official plans for the Prospect Expressway did not include an ice rink. But in recent years that is what some of the expressway's pedestrian overpasses have become, say residents who describe being cut off from shopping, schools and churches after heavy snows.

title: Following the Money, but Also the Mind
description: IN the histories of economics still to be written, the spring of 1994 will almost certainly be flagged as momentous. That is when an ophthalmologist's son from Main Line Philadelphia -- David Laibson -- received his Ph.D. in economics, qualifying with a thesis about willpower and money that drew as much on psychology and quirky behavior as on standard economics. Harvard quickly hired him, becoming the first university to deliberately recruit an economics professor trained as a behavioral economist.

title: Europe's Banana Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Avery McConnell and Andrew Leider
description: DESCRIBING her life as a single woman in the United States Army, Maj. Avery McConnell said: ''Water, water everywhere and not a drop to drink. You're surrounded by men, all good-looking and healthy, in good physical condition and drug-free. That's a problem -- you can't date anybody unless they're in a different unit, far out of your chain of command. I thought I would perpetually be in a state of temptation. All around me were men, and if I became interested in them I'd lose my job.''

title: Deborah Lerner, Matthew Bieschke
description: Deborah Lynn Lerner, a daughter of Rina and Burton Lerner of Wayne, N.J., was married last evening to Matthew Simon Bieschke, a son of Gail and Richard Bieschke of Oak Park, Ill. Rabbi Randall Mark performed the ceremony at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: DEAL BETWEEN TAXI COMMISSIONS
description: Taxi drivers in Westchester will be able to take passengers to New York City without having to pay city licensing fees under a new agreement between the taxi and limousine commissions of Westchester and New York City. The agreement, which takes effect in June, will also allow cabs from Westchester to pick up passengers in the city, by pre-arrangement, if they are going to a destination outside the city. Elsa Brenner

title: Balancing Long-Term Wants And Needs
description: SORRY to spoil the party. But the euphoria about the growing federal budget surplus and the opportunities it creates for tax cuts, debt reduction and additional money for most everything from school lunches to cruise missiles, is obscuring a depressing reality.

title: The Nation; Please Do Not Disturb Us With Bombs
description: FOREIGN leaders who find themselves perplexed by the Bush administration's insistence on building a national missile defense might try reading what another American president wrote about national defense 200 years ago.

title: Arthur Hummel Jr. Dies at 80; Negotiated Taiwan Arms Pact
description: Arthur W. Hummel Jr., who as ambassador to China from 1981 to 1985 negotiated an agreement on United States arms sales to Taiwan, died on Feb. 6 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 80.

title: More to This Composer Than Meets the Eye
description: FOR legions of movie lovers, the composer Bernard Herrmann is a venerated figure. In the often awkward marriage of film and music, his scores are models of drama, atmosphere and unmistakable pathos. But film music is only part of Herrmann's story. A classically educated musician (as most composers were in the predigital age), Herrmann also wrote scores for the concert hall and the opera house. That this music never achieved real recognition pained the composer, who felt that his talent transcended commercial forms.

title: SOAPBOX; Meeting Victor Borge
description: THE premise was an article for a yachting magazine about interesting people who commute to work on their personal boats. Someone heard that Victor Borge lived on the water in Greenwich. Being Danish, he was born nautical and often avoided the traffic on I-95 by driving his 40-foot Magnum muscle boat to New York, New Jersey and even Boston.

title: Sneaking a Peek At 2 New Musicals
description: FIRST there's the snob factor, the thrill of being one up. That's the publicity strategy at the Stamford Center for the Arts, where ''Bells Are Ringing'' is to begin and end its pre-Broadway tryout later this month. ''See it at S.C.A. before it goes to N.Y.C. and be first to give it a rave review,'' the advertisements read.

title: How to Keep Radon Gas In Check
description: ACCORDING to scientists, radon is a colorless, odorless gas formed by the decay of naturally occurring radium that is found in basically every particle of soil on the planet. Under ordinary circumstances, they say, radon gas slowly dissipates into the atmosphere, where it becomes diluted to concentrations that are almost harmless to living creatures.

title: Hearty Stew: An Antidote to Cold Weather
description: ON a cold winter day, the chef David Waltuck says, a good homemade stew is the culinary equivalent of a down parka. He has just published ''Staff Meals'' (Workman), a cookbook of dishes from his TriBeCa restaurant, Chanterelle. But instead of the fancy food he serves his customers, the recipes are for dishes he has made for his employees. It's a compilation of the family fare -- stews, pastas and one-pot dinners -- that he has prepared for them over the last two decades.

title: Patricia McLaughlin, Devon Cheshire
description: Patricia Ann McLaughlin, a daughter of Helga and William K. McLaughlin of Rochester, was married yesterday to Devon Jon Cheshire, the son of Eva Neibauer of Old Lyme, Conn., and the late Jon Cheshire. The Rev. Stuart Brooks Keith III, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Chapel at Beaver Creek in Beaver Creek, Colo.

title: DANCE; Against the Odds, They Keep on Making Dance
description: EVERYONE who's aware of dance has heard how grueling it is, how intrepid dancers brave financial hardship, physical pain and lack of proper respect to pursue their passions. As our culture tumbles into the 21st century, concert dance is succumbing to the big business model: grow bigger or perish. But what happens to talented dance makers whose chamber-scale work will never fill the stages or auditoriums of City Center, the Brooklyn Academy of Music or even the Joyce Theater?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTWEIN, EUGENE, PH.D
description: ROTWEIN-Eugene, Ph.D on February 7, 2001. Beloved husband of Anneliese. Loving father of Lisa Axelrod and Geoffrey Rotwein and his wife Rachel. Devoted grandfather of Sara and Daniel Rotwein. Dear brother of Edith. Professor Emeritus of Economics Queens College, CUNY. Memorial service to be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory to the American Cancer Society.

title: Streetscapes/Brooklyn Historical Society; An 1881 Landmark in Red Brick and Terra Cotta
description: THE Brooklyn Historical Society closed its headquarters building in 1999, as part of an interior reconstruction project for the landmark 1881 structure at Pierrepont and Clinton Streets in Brooklyn Heights. The society plans to reopen completely next year, but only now, after a decade of testing and analysis, do restoration professionals feel they can repair the building's brick and terra cotta facade. Work is to begin next month.

title: Millions Who Want to Be Millionaires Prowl Cyberspace for Inheritances
description: There is hidden treasure here, millions of dollars floating around in cyberspace.

title: Kudos for Marsalis
description: To the Editor:

title: NO BOAT PARKING
description: Atlantic City has forbidden boat parking on its streets. The City Council last week unanimously passed an ordinance that forbids parking trailers of any size, with or without a boat, on the city's streets. Councilman Ernest Coursey sponsored the ordinance in response to boat owners from neighboring towns where boat-trailer parking is banned who ducked off-season marina fees by parking their boats on trailers in Atlantic City. ''If you can afford the boat,'' Mr. Coursey said, ''you can afford to find a place to park it.''

title: WHITE PLAINS: HOSPITAL SEEKS MEETING ON PLANS
description: New York Presbyterian Hospital has offered to meet with city officials to resolve a dispute over the development of 121 acres the hospital owns near the downtown area. Last summer the Common Council rejected two plans for the site, and the hospital filed suit challenging the decision. ''We view this as perhaps the last real opportunity to resolve our differences,'' Constance P. Hildesley, the hospital's vice president of real estate, wrote in a letter to council members. Mayor Joseph Delfino has said he believes the city lost an opportunity by rejecting the hospital's first proposal, which included 60 acres of parkland in addition to commercial development that would have generated millions of dollars a year in sales and property taxes. Robert Worth

title: Succeeding a Superstar Isn't Easy
description: Carlos Guillen will not so much replace Alex Rodriguez as he will take Rodriguez's place.

title: Hello Again, Clarice, But You've Changed
description: AS much as anybody, Julianne Moore knows that a part can live on. Especially after her experience on the daytime drama ''As the World Turns.'' In 1985 Ms. Moore played the dual role of the good girl Frannie and her mysterious, identical, British half-sister Sabrina, who, in true soap fashion, was selfish and evil. Ms. Moore was so adept at making her characters' melodramatic existences plausible that in 1988 she was awarded a daytime Emmy, although she wasn't present at the ceremony to pick up her statuette. By then, she had left the show and was rehearsing the role of Ophelia in ''Hamlet'' at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis.

title: Forget XFL; Real Revolution Is on Campus
description: This has been a stressful week, worrying that Derek Jeter will not be emotionally satisfied by $19 million a year, wishing that the XFL would get in touch with its inner animal, wondering if the radical teach-in at Tennessee will be the athletic equivalent of the Revolutions of 1848.

title: It's Spring Cleaning Time for Tools
description: DURING winter it is difficult or impossible to do outdoor chores and maintenance, but it is a good time to inspect your shop tools and garden tools and prepare them for spring and summer work. A little tender loving care now can restore your tools so they look almost new and at the same time condition them so they will work more efficiently when you need them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRELSIN, DOROTHY
description: STRELSIN-Dorothy. The Officers and Board of Directors of The American Theatre Wing note with sorrow the passing of Dorothy Strelsin, an esteemed member of the Wing's advisory committee and a loyal supporter of Wing activities. Her presence will be sadly missed. Isabelle Stevenson, Chairman of the Board Roy A. Somlyo, Presidnet

title: Children Test New Medicines Despite Doubts
description: Children and adolescents, who were once routinely left out of pharmaceutical research, are now being enrolled by the thousands into drug company experiments, a trend that is both transforming the care of sick children and generating qualms among pediatricians, ethicists and parents.

title: Gowns Galore
Long Island History, One Village at a Time
description: THE petite Cape Cod-style house here at 22 Shelter Lane has tan siding with brown shutters, a different look entirely from the stone facing on the Cape Cod at No. 20. Up the block, 32 Shelter Lane has wooden shingles and an unattached garage with a big ''32'' painted on the door, distinguishing it from No. 34, where a bay window was added to the otherwise flat facade. And for Sopranos-style grandeur, No. 16, with its Greek columns and raised roof line, stands out on the block.

title: The Swiss Force the United States to the Edge of an Abyss in the Davis Cup
description: Once good enough to win the boys' 12-and-under national championship, the American doubles team of Justin Gimelstob and Jan-Michael Gambill was not nearly good enough to win today in a higher age bracket.

title: Hilary Beall, Joseph Tesoriero
description: Hilary Alexis Beall, a banker, and Joseph James Tesoriero, a Manhattan assistant district attorney, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan, The Rev. Arthur Leone performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. David Herndon, a Unitarian Universalist minister and a cousin of the bride, took part.

title: Five Freshmen at Marlboro High School Put Girls' Basketball First
description: MARLBORO TOWNSHIP, N.J., Feb. 9  On Tuesday night in the Marlboro High School gymnasium, Brina Pollack, a point guard on the Marlboro basketball team, raced downcourt with the ball. Facing a Howell opponent, she whipped a behind-the-back pass to Chakhia Cole on her left. Without hesitation, Cole flipped the ball back to Sharnee Zoll, who leapt to the basket for a layup, giving Marlboro a 58-16 halftime lead.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, WILLIAM F. JR.
description: GORDON-William F. Jr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William F. Daniel Jr., associated with The Times from 1951 until 1976.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAW, SADIE
description: WARSHAW-Sadie. Passed away on February 3, 2001, lovingly cared for at Shalom Village in Hamilton, Ontario,in her 94th year. Predeceased by her husband, Monte, beloved mother of Susan Honig, and Stephen Warshaw, fabulous Bubbie to Meredith Honig, Michael and Claire Honig, Anne and John Nieland, and Michael P. Warshaw. Great Bubbie to Matthew Honig. Outstanding mother-in-law of Howard Honig and the late Harriet Warshaw. Survived by her sisters, Sophie Steinberg, Bess Rosenberg, and Dorothy Tuchman, also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Contributions in her memory may be made to Shalom Village, 70 Macklin Street North, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada L8S3S1, or the charity of your choice.

title: Every Inch Counts in a Toyota-Ford Space Race
description: JUST when you'd begun to forget about undervotes and butterfly ballots, two automakers are embroiled in their own counting dispute -- over technical specs, not dangling chads. Once again, the winner may depend on how one interprets the rules.

title: When Rangers Play Devils, The Outcome Is Predictable
description: Ken Daneyko of the Devils said he would not be looking for Manny Malhotra of the Rangers at Madison Square Garden this afternoon, even though Daneyko clearly remembers what happened the last time they met.

title: A Young Witness Struggles With the Aftermath of a Murder
description: IT has been four years since Kathleen Martyn was murdered in her home on Edgewood Avenue here in a bungled robbery attempt while her 18-month-old baby slept in the next room. Her husband, Jim, has long since moved away, as have several other people who lived on the street at the time.

title: An Eclectic Menu on the Saugatuck River
description: THE BRIDGE CAFE, a staple in Westport since 1994, changed hands several months ago. The current owners and chefs are Lauren Seideman and Jo Ann Plympton. They have introduced a completely new and compelling eclectic menu, which brings added verve to this country-style restaurant on the Saugatuck River.

title: Financing an Endurance Film Does Not a Survivor Make
description: In the mid-1970's, after he persuaded John J. Mack, then a bond trader at Morgan Stanley, to invest in a documentary film about Arnold Schwarzenegger, George Butler could have said, ''I'll be back.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIERSTEIN, BERNARD
description: FEIERSTEIN-Bernard. Formerly of Great Neck NY and of Heritage Village CT and Boca Raton FL, died January 31, 2001 after a prolonged illness. Husband of Shirley, father of Alan and Susan Tornheim, beloved grandfather.

title: Corrections
description: Ahighlight picture caption in the Television section on Jan. 21 about the A&E drama "Dalziel and Pascoe: The British Grenadier," shown on Jan. 27, misidentified the actor next to Colin Buchanan. He was David Royle, who plays Detective Sergeant Wield  not an extra.

title: POSTINGS: Report on New York City Hotels; Occupancy Up; Room Rates Too
description: New York City hotels recorded another banner year in 2000, setting records in occupancy and average room rates. This year, according to the forecast by PKF Consulting, the hospitality consulting firm, occupancy rates will weaken slightly, while room rates will increase at a slower pace than last year.

title: Dutch Museums
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Amsterdam in the Winter: Warmth in Unexpected Places,'' (Frugal Traveler, Jan. 7), mention should be made of the Museumjaarkaart (Year Card), which can be bought at major museums. The card, which costs about $12.50, can be used throughout the country for a year. All that is needed is to attach a small passport-sized photograph (although I have used mine for almost a year without a picture). Not only does this card save money; it also saves time at the entrance kiosk when visiting a busy museum.

title: VIDEO IMAGE COMPANY
description: Cablevision announced last week that it would invest $17.5 million in Princeton Video Image Inc., which designs technology that places images like a virtual first-down marker on football telecasts. Cablevision, the cable television operator, will gain a 24 percent share of the Princeton company and a seat on its board.

title: Roses Are Red, Violets Are Blue, Tattoos Are Any Color You Choose
description: ORIGINALITY, or old-fashioned hearts and flowers? Big bucks, or ''it's the thought that counts''? Whatever your Valentine choice, add personal touches, and present the gift lovingly -- you know, with wrapping and a card, not in a brown paper bag with a Post-it note.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Scenes From a Courtroom: Hip-Hop and Unhipness Collide at a Rap Star's Trial
description: Julius Jones, dressed in a leather suit, strolled into the popular ''Hot Chocolate Party'' at Club New York on Dec. 27, 1999, with his closest companions: Chutney, whom he calls his home girl and whose last name he does not know, and his friend of 25 years, whose occupation he does not know.

title: How California Fell Prey to Power Sellers
description: The largest planned blackout of electricity in California since World War II came in the midst of a heat wave last June, when the mercury hit 103 in San Francisco, and air-conditioners roared. Electricity supplies fell to dangerous levels, and utilities cut power to more than 100,000 homes.

title: Voting Accessible to All
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Says I.B.M. Aided The Nazis In Technology
description: Lawyers who have represented victims of Nazi oppression in lawsuits against European banks, insurers and manufacturing companies in the last five years have turned their sights to American executives of I.B.M.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Girlfriend 44

title: The Last Days of Fuling
description: RIVER TOWN

title: Article 2001021193212367246 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: Hundreds of Homes Rise at Ex-Air Base in Bay Area
description: THROUGHOUT the Hamilton housing development in this city 29 miles north of San Francisco are reminders that this new community was built on the bones of a former Air Force base.

title: Where the Earth Meets The Sky
description: WHEN I first heard of a Jeep safari in Himalayan India, I was puzzled. I had traveled in the Himalayas and knew that it was rare to be able to get anywhere in those mountains other than on foot. But the region of Spiti, in Himachal Pradesh, in India's north, is an exception: it offers Jeep travel as well as trekking possibilities.

title: Cod Fishing Tests Anglers' Midwinter Resolve
description: The true test of anyone who claims to be a dedicated angler is a willingness in midwinter to hunt for cod. Why winter? Because it is only at this time of year that codfish along the Northeast coast abandon the chilled depths of the Atlantic Ocean and move inshore to the chilled shoal waters in their constant hunt for food. Shoal waters is a relative phrase because cod always like their waters deep, and here deep means anything between 60 and 120 feet.

title: Article 2001021192022764810 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Jan. 28 outlining the history of St. Nicholas Antiochan Orthodox Cathedral in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, mislabeled the period in which Arabic-speaking Orthodox Christians formed an association and opened a church in Manhattan. It was the 1890's, not the 1980's.

title: The Nation; Let the Markets Rule, Sometimes
description: NO company in recent years has complained more loudly than Microsoft about Washington's regulatory power. From its perspective, the Justice Department's antitrust lawsuit, which threatens to split the company in two, is an example of that power run amok.

title: Bernstein Wants To Spin Off Restaurants
description: Jeffrey Bernstein, the turnaround specialist who in December combined the Arthur Treacher's and Pudgie's Famous chains into one restaurant offering both brands, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to spin off the restaurants from their corporate owner, Lake Success-based Digital Creative Development Corporation. The new restaurant would trade on the Nasdaq exchange.

title: Commercial Property/Westchester; After a Frenetic Year, the Market Eases a Bit
description: THE pace of Westchester County's commercial real-estate market seems to be slowing somewhat, and some building owners and managers actually seem relieved. Last year, the economic expansion led to a new annual high in the amount of office space occupied in the county -- 3.3 million square feet. And the overall availability rate countywide dipped to 11.6 percent -- its lowest level in at least the last 12 years -- from 14.7 percent in 1999.

title: A Wee Bit O' Imperialism
description: THE RISING SUN

title: Ideas & Trends; Will the Gipper Ever Get a Piece of the Rock?
description: AT the summit of presidential commemoration, there is, most would say, little room left at the inn. The Jefferson Memorial doesn't cry out for a statue of John Adams; the Lincoln Memorial would look peculiar with, say, Andrew Johnson brooding alongside the elbow of the Great Emancipator; and the Washington Monument, for all its majesty, doesn't even have George Washington in it.

title: February 4-10; Peace Gambit in Colombia
description: A politically risky move seems to have paid off for Colombia's president, Andrs Pastrana: after he met in rebel-held territory with the leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the country's largest rebel group, the two announced an agreement designed to restart formal peace talks, which stalled in November.

title: 'Not to Say This Is a Better Movie' Than Beatty's . . .
description: A FEW years ago, soon after the premiere of his first comedy special on HBO -- the special that in short order would get him an Emmy and a book deal and propel him into his Emmy-winning talk show -- Chris Rock was offered the chance to star in a movie about a busload of touring rappers. It would have paid him a pile of money, he recalls, but he said no.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Karl Lagerfeld let his claws show last month as these baby blue nails (a) paraded down Chanel's couture runway, the handiwork of a Paris manicure star named Christina Conrad. It is nearly impossible to get an appointment with Conrad at her Left Bank salon, Artistic Nails, but once admitted, you can opt for any number of wild tips (b), including the Eiffel Tower, stiletto boots and designer logos. Conrad, who works regularly with Chanel, is also responsible for the talons of another fashion icon -- Catherine Deneuve.

title: Mediation as an Aid In Dealing With Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: The Brothers Viertel, a Theatrical Tag Team
description: ONE prefers the late-night pulse of city life, the other the lights-out peace of the suburbs. One is a Mets fan, the other is devoted to the Yankees. One can't stand caviar, the other abhors clams.

title: A Norman-Style Castle With a River View
description: ELEGANT table appointments, candlelight, tapestries, burnished timbers, carved stone embellishments and mullioned windows -- Equus at The Castle projects medieval romance and a grand lifestyle that most of us have only read about.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: A Church's Tax Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: February 4-10; Bombing Trial Opens
description: The trial of four men in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in Africa began in New York with prosecutors calling as their first witness a Sudanese man who served as a close aide to Osama bin Laden and described the inner workings of his group, Al Qaeda. Mr. bin Laden, the Saudi exile who has been indicted in the case, is believed to be hiding in Afghanistan, but his presence is likely to be felt constantly during the trial, as prosecutors build a case that he led a broad terrorist conspiracy to kill Americans, which included the embassy attacks. Benjamin Weiser

title: Abraham Beame Is Dead at 94; Mayor During 70's Fiscal Crisis
description: Abraham D. Beame, an accountant and clubhouse Democrat who climbed the gray ranks of municipal bookkeeping and confounded oddsmakers to become mayor of New York in the mid-1970's, only to spend his term struggling with the worst fiscal calamity in the city's history, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Emergency Exits in a Wired World
description: THIS capital city offers vacationers engaging sites, stimulating culture and sumptuous food. Sadly, it is sorely lacking a chapter of E-Mailers Anonymous.

title: When the Author Insists on Directing the Play, Too
description: THERE are no extant first-night programs to tell us who, if anyone, directed ancient Greek dramas. But from Shakespeare and Molire to Brecht and Ludlam, there is a long and respected tradition of authors staging their own work. Contemporary playwrights who would make the short list include Edward Albee, Harold Pinter, David Hare, Maria Irene Fornes, David Mamet and Sam Shepard.

title: A Cart for Casey Martin
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; My Blue Heaven
description: Making almost any cheese is about promoting, and then controlling, decay. The process is most obvious in blue cheeses. As it wends through the ivory-colored curd, Penicillium roqueforti leaves a trail of gray, blue or green in its wake. Blue cheese is an example of the malignant begetting something close to the divine. It is particularly satisfying after a bad day. It is a fatty cheese, but its sharp, salty flavor belies its richness. A blue cheese is the perfect counterpoint to heavy meat, bitter greens and big red wines.

title: PRIZE WINNER
description: James E. Hansen, a NASA scientist credited with alerting the public to global warming, has been named a winner of of the Heinz Award, which honors people who enhance the lives of others. Mr. Hansen, 59, lives in Ridgewood and is director of the NASA's Goddard Institute of Space Studies in Manhattan. He gave the first warnings about how industrial pollution is changing the climate in testimony before a Congressional panel in 1988. The $250,000 award will be presented in Washington March 5. George James

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Upscale 25-Store Retail Strip Set for Woodcliff Lake
description: GENERATIONS of families came to Tice Farms on Chestnut Ridge Road in the Bergen County borough of Woodcliff Lake to shop for produce or trinkets and to pick pumpkins during the fall. That tradition ended in 1999 when the farm's barnlike roadside stand and minimall were razed to make way for a different kind of shopping outlet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCH, BERTHA
description: KIRSCH-Bertha. At age 91, died peacefully on February 7, 2001. Beloved wife for 60 years of the late Morris Kirsch. Dearest mother of Lee and Flo Kirsch, David and Paula Kirsch and Sara (Dixie) Lampert and sister of Samuel I. Cohen and the late Harry and Cecile Cohen. Loved Nanna of Robin, John, Steve, Beth, Nancy, Jesse, Tamar, Kayla, Harlan, David, Deborah, Andrew, Susan, Marcie, Stephanie and Warren. Adoring Nanna Nanna of Sari, Alex, Jason, Stacy, Ross, Kira, Jordan, Alexandra, Olivia, Jared, Alex, Julia, Kiron, Jenya, Danielle and Noah. Active in numerous philanthropic activities in Greater New York and Miami Beach, Florida, she had a beautiful voice and sang at many charitable affairs. Services Sunday, February 11, at 1PM at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations in her name to a charity of your choice.

title: A Marriage of Business and Businesswoman
description: THERE is something inherently self-laudatory in the notion of businesspeople offering their wisdom in books about their own successes. Chief executives, after all, are seldom wallflowers in a world that runs to the rules of the jungle.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-11-01: The Ethicist; Goodfella's Good Works
description: I am on the board of a health facility raising funds for a necessary extension. A local businessman with known ties to organized crime has offered a substantial donation. Should we take the money? -- S. Wagner, Stamford, Conn.

title: Undeterred by a Monster; Secrecy and Stigma Keep AIDS Risk High for Gay Black Men
description: They can't really say they didn't see ''the monster'' coming.

title: In Review: Feb.4-10
description: Bush Tax-Cut Plan Goes to Congress, but . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANVEY, PHILIP
description: JANVEY-Philip. In loving memory of Philip Janvey. Father of Marjorie Zimmerman, grandfather of Anne Zimmerman, brother of Abe Janvey and Siddell Wagenstein.

title: Children's Books
description: ALL THE BLUE MOONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVRUTICK, FRANCES
description: AVRUTICK-Frances. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its affiliates mourn the passing of the beloved mother of their devoted member, Naomi Goldstein. We extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: Striking A Blow For the Little Guy
description: IT has been almost two years since the Wall Street brokerage firms that clear securities trades for customers of smaller firms were put on notice by securities regulators and prosecutors. No longer could they escape responsibility if fraud occurred inside the smaller shops for which they provided capital.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Stars Put Their All Into Helping the Afflicted
description: How could Dikembe Mutombo refuse his good friend and former college teammate Alonzo Mourning when he stood up among his peers to bare his soul in the interests of others? Mutombo handed him a check for $50,000 here Friday afternoon. Fortunate as Mutombo may be, it couldn't have been easy with his own charity clock ticking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE MAH, STEVEN
description: GEE MAH-Steven, on February 7, 2001. Beloved husband of 53 years to Wai Lin. Loving father of Shirley, Rita, Evelyn, Betty, Steven, and Robert. Adoring grandfather of eleven. He immigrated to the US at age 12, attended Brooklyn Polytechnic University. He was an Electrical Engineer at AT&T Western Electric, now Lucent, for 33 years. Following retirement, he energetically devoted himself to community service. A cherished deacon of The First Chinese Baptist Church and a supporter of numerous community organizations. He will be deeply missed by his family and everyone he has helped over his fruitful, accomplished life of 78 years. Private service on Sunday. In lieu of flowers, a scholarship fund will be set up in the name Steven Gee Mah Memorial Foundation Inc.

title: In a High School, 'Criminal Acts'
description: IN any given high school, you've got your smart students, your rich students and your egocentrically manipulative students. They're often different animals -- the rich ones are not necessarily the smart ones; the smart ones can also be the most altruistic.

title: The View From/Hartford; Women's Group Set to Study Infant Mortality Among Blacks
description: IT is no secret that infant mortality is disproportionately high among blacks in the United States. But to researchers monitoring the problem in Hartford, another disparity has become apparent -- within the black population.

title: At Casino, Pavarotti Comes Back
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI'S reappearance at the Trump Taj Mahal here may have been the most prolonged encore of his career. Too ill at his November concert to sing his signature high notes and encores, the tenor invited the audience back to the casino's 5,000-seat Mark Etess Arena last weekend for what was, in essence, a do-over.

title: Recession Committee Is Still in Recess
description: Concern that the economy may be tipping into recession -- or perhaps has already landed there -- is on many minds. The people officially responsible for making such a call, however, have yet to stir.

title: A Wing and a Prayer
description: LONG ago, when most people remembered the days when Roosevelt Field meant airplanes, not shopping, a young man set out from the land where Charles A. Lindbergh took off for Paris and buckled up for his first long-distance airplane ride.

title: A Park Adults Can Love
description: ENTERING Disneyland's brand new California Adventure theme park in Anaheim is a little like walking into one of those old hand-tinted ''Wish You Were Here'' postcards. Two vivid murals present iconic pop images of northern and southern California, like an overspiced cultural bouillabaisse cooked up by the Beach Boys and the Mamas and the Papas. There's a mini Golden Gate Bridge, a fountain that produces curling waves, an oppressively bright sun sculpture and a shiny, ultra streamlined postwar-style train where you can buy cookies.

title: Sorting Out Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plan For 97 Riverfront Acres
description: AFTER General Motors shut down its minivan assembly plant here in 1996 and leveled 97 acres on the Hudson River, developers and dreamers began floating plans: a gambling casino, a golf course, a virtual reality theme park, a film sound stage, a Donald Trump high-rise.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: FOR Rabbit, With Love

title: Sachets Last Forever
description: For would-be suitors with writer's block, L'Artisan's Love Letters sachets may be a good out. Introduced for Valentine's Day, the set of four taffeta sachets, shaped like envelopes and in brilliant hues, come in a silk box ($70). Barneys New York has already had to restock. There's no message -- the envelopes don't even open -- but with a subtly spicy scent, they release the right note. Postage not included.

title: Teodolinda Barolini, James Valentini
description: Dr. Teodolinda Barolini, the chairwoman of the Italian department at Columbia University, and Dr. James J. Valentini, a Columbia chemistry professor, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. H. Gaylord Hitchcock, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius of Antioch Church.

title: 80 Percent Nudity
description: The Funeral Party

title: Island Colleges Overlooked Because They're Pragmatic
description: ''Giving It the Old College Try'' [Jan. 28] gives rise to a possible explanation as to why Long Island universities and colleges have not attained a comparable status with more well-known and desirable mainland institutions. Perhaps the answer lies in the fact that much of Long Island's curricular emphasis has an overly pragmatic bent. Certainly it is a viable approach to prepare people for actual careers -- as nurses, computer programmers, technicians of various kinds, etc. -- but this should not be done at the expense of traditional learning. I would urge a major return to the liberal arts with emphasis given to the humanities, social and natural sciences. It is only through building core curriculums of in-depth substance that they will attract the higher-quality students.

title: Enticing Brasserie That Needs Signposts
description: SOME restaurants are hard to find but worth finding. Brasserie 345 is just such a place. Would-be diners checking out the address at 345 Main Street in Huntington Village will see no sign of a restaurant. It faces the back parking lot and is visible only from Gerard Street.

title: A Few Bad Cops, or a Problem With the System?
description: LAW enforcement experts count three milestones in the recent history of the Nassau and Suffolk police departments. The mid-1980's brought changes to the police entrance examinations. In the early 1990's came the first in a spiraling series of wage increases that attracted a flood of former New York City officers to the Long Island departments. In the mid-1990's, rotating work schedules were changed to fixed hours on the day or night shifts.

title: NPD Goes Online to Draw Portrait of Consumers
description: For nearly 50 years, Port Washington-based NPD Group has tracked what America buys when it goes shopping.

title: LAND PURCHASE FOR AFFORDABLE HOUSING
description: The county will spend $125,000 for a vacant 5,000-square-foot lot in Mount Vernon so that it can be transformed into 11 affordable housing condominium units. The land will be transferred to P. Forest Development and its nonprofit sponsor, Local Development Corporation of Mount Vernon. The project will cost $1.7 million and will be paid for with state and local grants and loans. Elsa Brenner

title: He Said Surfboard, Not Stanford
description: Lawrence J. Ellison didn't need a college degree to achieve success. Neither did William H. Gates, whom he describes as his former friend, nor Steven P. Jobs, whom he describes as a best friend now.

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: Thanks for demystifying this drug and its culture. Living in New York, I have participated in the club scene, but I have never tried Ecstasy. I still do not feel a need to do a hit of X. Not even after reading Klam's feature.

title: Ideals, Trying to Soar, Are Talked to Death
description: BEWARE of a play that begins with a pedagogue trying to calm two out-of-order students by telling them what a debate means.

title: God Was Not His Co-Pilot
description: Cassada By James Salter. 208 pp. Washington: Counterpoint. $25.

title: Jackson Hole
description: Jackson Hole, Wyo., is nearly a year-round destination now; its proximity to some of the nation's great natural wonders, preserved within the national park system, makes it a place to be enjoyed whether the landscape is sagebrush green or snow-mantled white.

title: The Indoor Takeover Artists
description: THIS is the time of year when I need a little jungle in my life. In summer, vining houseplants are superfluous. During the growing season, I avoid additional tangle, doing all I can to keep indoor vines alive, healthy and watered, but concentrating on outdoor chores.

title: Putting Wings on Web Access
description: IN 1948, Pan American World Airways ushered in what was apparently the first in-flight movie when it set up a projector and screen in the aisle and showed ''Stagecoach'' with John Wayne.

title: February 4-10; How Much Is That Picture . . . ?
description: The Clintons obviously love Buddy, the chocolate Labrador retriever Bill Clinton acquired in 1997. Not only did the family forsake their cat, Socks, when they moved out of the White House because the two pets didn't get along, the Clintons also included a $300 painting of Buddy among the gifts they received last year and now promise to pay for.

title: Benched by a Dating Coach
description: FIRST, I dated the moody musician with the Tori Spelling fetish. Next there was the dashing daredevil who loved his skateboard more than me. Then I met the 25-year-old bartender who came complete with 6-year-old son, ex-wife and the live-in girlfriend he referred to as his ''roommate.''

title: Dr. Marshall Raymond Urist, Found Substance to Mend Bones, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Marshall Raymond Urist, the orthopedic surgeon who identified the substance that mends broken bones, died last Sunday at his home in Los Angeles, where for 46 years he practiced, taught and did research at the U.C.L.A. medical school. He was 85.

title: A Vineyard's Debut Ros
description: When Chilean and American investors acquired Laurel Lake Vineyards in 1999, in effect they bought a theater. When marketing the wines that came with the purchase, they staged a long dress rehearsal. And when they released their own 2000 Lake Ros the other day, they finally made their debut.

title: A Stickler for Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: There's No Free Lunch in London, But Prix Fixe Eases the Sting
description: LONDON is on almost everyone's favorite destination list, yet Britain is one of the few European countries where the dollar is not almighty. Although the current exchange rate is slightly improved, travelers on a budget -- even a large budget -- feel squeezed by prices that would seem reasonable only if the pound and the dollar were roughly equivalent.

title: Some Big Dreams, A Lot of Hard Work And Who Knows . . .
description: THE passion that drives young performers to sing on their school buses or practice piano chords until their hands cramp may eventually propel some of them to fame.

title: GURU/Saundra Parks; She Makes The Flowers Go Hip-Hop
description: LAST Thursday, Saundra Parks was crossing the dance floor of a party named ''Aerodynamic'' at Club Cheetah. It was a V.I.P.'s only night, and as a soul singer wailed onstage, Ms. Parks paused to greet hip-hop luminaries like Jay-Z and Damon Dash, his Roc-a-Fella Records partner, comfortably ensconced in cheetah-skin-print booths with their Champagne buckets and platinum jewelry.

title: A Long Way From Tacoma
description: Bing Crosby

title: February 4-10; 5 Die in Workplace Rampage
description: A man went on a shooting rampage in a Navistar truck engine factory in Melrose Park, Ill., killing four people and himself, and wounding four others. The carnage was gruesome, yet the crowd of journalists was relatively modest and so were the national headlines. Perhaps it was because the crime, though senseless, seemed to be somehow explicable: the man, Willie Dan Baker, had been fired in 1995 by Navistar for stealing engine parts; his federal prison sentence was to begin the next day. Or perhaps there was a sense that workplace shootings with multiple deaths are becoming common. Indeed, both the police chief and the mayor of Melrose Park expressed relief that even more blood had not been shed. Pam Belluck

title: Between Two Eras
description: We are cautious on this newspaper about using the word unprecedented, so let it suffice to say that strain as we might we cannot come up with an exact historic parallel to the current political drama. In Washington, a president who entered office with a shaky mandate is performing above expectations. New York, meanwhile, has become home to a former president who seemed to make a redoubled effort in the last moments of his presidency to plunge further and further beneath the already low expectations of his most cynical critics and most world-weary friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, DANIEL
description: RYAN-Daniel. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Daniel Ryan, associated with The Times from 1976 until 1997.

title: Gotham, in Good Times and Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REVILLE, FRANCES WASSERVOGEL
description: REVILLE-Frances Wasservogel. 94, on January 31, 2001. Beloved wife of the late James F. Loving mother of Susan Bernstein, James Jr. and Georgia. Adored grandmother of Dennis, James, Elizabeth, Frances, James and Jeremiah. Great-grandmother. She was a unique and gracious lady of courage, intelligence, honesty, loyalty and dedication, a leader and advocate in business and public service. Recipient of 1990 NYSARC Volunteer Award. She served as: president and treasurer of Welfare League, member NYSARC Board of Governors; NYS DD Council; Treasurer of NYSARC; member Board of Visitors of Letchworth Village and Manhattan DC; appointed by Governor Carey to the NYS Advisory Council on MR/DD. Responsible for improvements in the lives of many mentally retarded persons. She has left a golden memory for her many descendants and friends.

title: An Adult Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: Donnie Can't Hide If He Wants to Run
description: Minutes after taking the oath of office on Feb. 1, Acting Governor DiFrancesco announced that he would have vetoed the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's sharp increase in tolls and fares, which will take effect next month, if he had had the chance.

title: The Future Comes to a Place That Hasn't Always Had One
description: THE SETTING -- Welcome to Cyber Casa, the Bronx's first and only Internet cafe, which opened last month to small crowds and long speeches about bridging the digital divide.

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: On one level, Matthew Klam's article about Ecstasy (Jan. 21) was a skillfully crafted coming-of-age odyssey, appropriately self-deprecating and entertaining. But on another, it was a worrying description of adolescent anxiety and dislocation magnified through illicit drug use. Careful readers would have found, amid the detailed descriptions of Ecstasy's life-enhancing qualities, some sober warnings about serious side effects. As one who treats adolescent drug abusers, I was glad to see them. I was also relieved that Klam saved himself by coming to the realization that drug-induced good times are fleeting and unsustainable.

title: Culinary Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: When Jailing Batterers Won't Save Families
description: SHE'S a black woman who refuses to call the police when her husband hits her because she believes the legal system is racist.

title: February 4-10; Aristide Returns as President
description: Ten years after he first took the office, Jean-Bertrand Aristide was again sworn in as Haiti's president. But the crowds at the presidential palace were diminished, as was the patience of the international community. Diplomats blame Mr. Aristide and his Family Lavalas party for refusing to reach an accord with the opposition. Angered by electoral irregularities, the opposition, in a largely symbolic gesture, installed its own president. Mr. Aristide will now have to prove he is able to compromise if he hopes to get hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign aid and loans that he needs in order to deliver on his promises of jobs and stability. David Gonzalez

title: Guide Helps Disabled Enjoy Philadelphia Arts
