description: An 80-page guide to museums, theaters and other cultural institutions in the Philadelphia area that are accessible to people with disabilities has been published by Art reach, a nonprofit group.

title: Cautious U.S. Hope on Report of Lower Afghan Opium Crop
description: A top narcotics expert in the United States Drug Enforcement Administration said this week that American agencies were receiving reports similar to those received by United Nations agencies of a sharply reduced opium crop in Taliban-controlled areas of Afghanistan, but he cautioned that it was too soon to confirm the trend or to explain the cause.

title: It's the Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: ROBBING BANKS

title: Russia in Winter: Bleak, Desperate, Beautiful
description: IN the winter of 1998, the French photographer Luc Delahaye traveled across Russia, knocking on people's doors, asking to see how they lived. For four months he journeyed by train from Moscow to Vladivostok, stopping in several cities along the way. The previous summer the ruble had crashed. Many people's lives, already miserable, were now hopeless. Mr. Delahaye recorded their suffering, and the result is a powerful book of nearly 100 photographs called ''Winterreise'' (''Winter Journey'').

title: Looking for Love in All the Right Places
description: AND now, a bit of advice for the unattached from Robin Gorman Newman, a love coach. Valentine's Day is high season for Ms. Gorman Newman, who, while dispensing advice to lonely hearts, has still penciled in dinner that evening with her husband, Marc Newman, an accountant.

title: A Poll of One City Reveals A Tale of Two Cities
description: The people and what they think has been the central question of New York politics for generations. Last week, Hunter College offered an early look at the results of their second Big Apple Poll, the only multilingual poll in the city devoted to the public's perceptions of the quality of life.

title: Our Towns; To the Locals, He's Just Bill, the First Suburbanite
description: A SMALL crowd gathered on the sidewalk outside Starbucks one day last week, drawn by a television camera.

title: A New Flag for a New Mississippi
description: After a bruising and impassioned debate, the Georgia State Legislature last month approved a new state flag, one not dominated by the Confederate Southern Cross. On April 17, Mississippi will hold a referendum on changing its own flag. By putting the flag change to a popular vote, Mississippi has raised the stakes a great deal. Some observers expect white Mississippians, in the anonymity of the voting booth, to choose to keep the Southern Cross in the flag's upper left quadrant. Mississippi is the only state to retain the Confederate symbol prominently in its flag; it also has a higher percentage of black residents than any other state. Symbolically, at least, the vote will have enormous significance.

title: Reviving Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001021191732673462 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Shifts in Europe Pose Prickly Challenge to U.S.
description: A little phrase from Rudolf Scharping, the German defense minister, recently caused American military commanders to shudder: ''As the European Union develops its security and defense policy and becomes an independent actor, we must determine our security policy with Russia, our biggest neighbor.''

title: Good Will From Stern, And Aggressive Defense
description: Pledging renewed cooperation with the players association and firing back at his game's detractors, an edgy and passionate David Stern issued his state of the National Basketball Association address tonight at the MCI Center.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Jan. 14 about vandalism by the Earth Liberation Front misstated the slogan spray-painted on a garage door in a Mount Sinai housing development. It was: ''If You Build It We Will Burn It. E.L.F.'' (''Stop Urban Sprawl'' had been painted on another facade of the house.)

title: Can't Buy Me Love? Maybe Just a Wedding?
description: Sure, you can't put a price on love. But there is a price for all the romantic trappings thereof.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Domestic Ferment
description: American Vintage

title: Love Is on the Air
description: How better to learn about life's little romances than by following in the footsteps of fictional friends whose heartthrobs and heartaches can be turned on or off with the click of a button? Here's a sampling of Valentine's Day shows to count your cards by.

title: William D. Krimer, Interpreter, Dies at 86
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  William D. Krimer, the chief English-Russian interpreter for the State Department for nearly two decades, died last Sunday in Fairfax, Va. He was 86 and lived in Reston, Va.

title: 'Constantine's Sword'
description: To the Editor:

title: What Were They Thinking?
description: THE DREAM OF REASON A History of Western Philosophy From the Greeks to the Renaissance. By Anthony Gottlieb. Illustrated. 469 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $27.95.

title: A Show Where Many Share in the Limelight
description: GRIEF counseling won't be necessary. Despite concerns over digital technology, the darkroom has not yet become obsolete. In its 20th season, the juried exhibition here at the Perkins Center for the Arts celebrates the aesthetic vitality of film-based photography and the talented community of artists from the greater Delaware Valley.

title: Gay Couples Head North To Make Their Unions Official
description: Dozens of gay couples in New York will celebrate their first Valentine's Day on Wednesday as legal spouses, thanks to a new Vermont law that allows same-sex couples to enter into civil unions.

title: A Lack of Sublety
description: To the Editor:

title: Dclass? No Way
description: I plead guilty: I have tasted Mouton Cadet rouge. First, in 1984.

title: Breast Cancer Link To Abortion Exists
description: I teach my students to spot emotional verbiage and to separate fact from fiction in regard to any scientific claims. A case in point was a Jan. 28 letter to the editor dismissing a Jan. 4 letter-writer's remarks about a connection between abortion and breast cancer. Saying that to assert such a connection ''saddened,'' ''angered and disgusted'' her, the Jan. 28 writer supports her opinion with vague reference to the secondhand opinions of unnamed ''scientists of note.''

title: Kitty Buck, New York City's Cakemaker to the Stars, Dies at 93
description: Kitty Buck, who with her husband, Otto, ran Cake Masters Bakery, an institution on the Upper West Side of Manhattan that made cakes for Liberace, President Kennedy and Elizabeth Taylor  and for less famous families' celebrations for more than half a century  died on Jan. 9 in Oceanside, N.Y.

title: Lives; Night Swimming
description: With the fall of Saigon on April 30, 1975, my childhood came to a halt. I was 7 years old. Because of my mother's wealth and the fact that my brother and I had American fathers, both of whom left after having brief liaisons with my mother, our lives became difficult. My mother, brother, sister, grandparents and I moved into a crowded, uncomfortable compound with my aunt and her 14 children, even though my aunt openly resented my mother's capitalist past. In 1981, after my grandmother's passing and so many years of gradually selling our furniture and jewelry to subsist, our resources and spirits were exhausted. I became obsessed with the idea of leaving. America was a distant dream, but it burned in my imagination, an irresistible beacon to a world of possibilities.

title: Defaults Sound Alarm About Money Funds
description: INVESTORS in money market funds had yet another scare in mid-January, when Pacific Gas & Electric and Southern California Edison defaulted on commercial paper -- unsecured short-term corporate borrowings -- held by money funds.

title: A Vanished Century in Black and White
description: BACK in 1943, there were about 50 Horn & Hardart Automats in New York City, serving more than 350,000 customers a day. The last one closed in April 1991. The 1943 photograph of Horn & Hardart customers shown above is part of an exhibit titled ''New York for All Seasons,'' opening on Thursday at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-11-01: On Language; Mushy
description: With Valentine's Day bearing down on us, you need to know the difference between the pronunciation mooshy (with the first syllable rhyming with whoosh) and mushy (with the first syllable rhyming with hush).

title: Experiencing Ecstasy
description: Klam disparages a good school. (''I went to U.N.H., a crummy state school in the middle of some cow fields.'') I went to the University of New Hampshire too, and it's way better than that. And during the course of my excellent education there, I learned that it is not particularly cool to make your mark as a writer at the smart-aleck expense of others.

title: A Prosperity Easy to Destroy
description: I had not intended to get involved in the public debate on fiscal policy at this point, but I feel so strongly that a tax cut of the magnitude proposed is a serious error in economic policy that I felt a need to speak.

title: Article 2001021194229368954 -- No Title
description: February 11, 2001

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KACHATURIAN, ARMEN
description: KACHATURIAN-Armen. Suddenly, on February 7, 2001. Freelance photographer and professor of photography. Husband of Kritina Lee Knief Kachaturian. Loving father of Zachary Armen and Ezra Lee Kachaturian. Fond brother of Zoya Kachadurian. Funeral service will be held Monday, February 12 at 11 AM at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Mt. Kisco, NY. Interment to follow at Oakwood Cemetery. For information contact the Oelker & Cox Funeral Home, 914-666-5891.

title: Major Battle Looms Over Medicare
description: How rough can the debate over health policy get? Ask the survivors of the last great effort to overhaul the Medicare program -- the National Bipartisan Commission on the Future of Medicare, which lasted 14 months before expiring in deadlock in March 1999.

title: Brush Up Your Shakespeare
description: Lectures on Shakespeare By W. H. Auden. Edited by Arthur Kirsch. 398 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $29.95.

title: Dominican Republic Gets a New Airport
description: Casa de Campo, the upscale resort in the Dominican Republic, is growing, and it now has an airport to match. The 7,000-acre resort's new attractions include a 200-slip marina, a yacht club to open later this year, and a third golf course, the first nine holes of which are scheduled to open late next winter.

title: Missing Lawyer's Body Found In a Field Near Coney Island
description: The body of a 73-year-old Borough Park lawyer who disappeared from his office six days ago was found yesterday in a field of tall weeds along a creek in Brooklyn, where it had apparently been dumped. There was a plastic bag over his head and his hands had been bound, the authorities said.

title: Children's Books; A Tropical Rumpelstiltskin
description: The prolific and celebrated author Virginia Hamilton is a master storyteller, expert at offering a new spin on an old folk or fairy tale. She did so most notably with the multiple-award-winning ''Her Stories: African American Folktales, Fairy Tales and True Tales.'' Now, in THE GIRL WHO SPUN GOLD (Blue Sky/Scholastic, $16.95; ages 5 to 9), Hamilton and her frequent collaborators, the illustrators Leo Dillon and Diane Dillon, take on ''Rumpelstiltskin,'' giving that oft-told German fairy tale a clever multicultural update.

title: Board Helps 12,000 Crime Victims a Year
description: TO many people, the notion that the state should compensate crime victims for school costs may seem like a stretch.

title: In a Loveless Marriage, Where Do Children Turn?
description: To The Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALLOUF, ALICE STOLOFF
description: ALLOUF-Alice Stoloff. 2/11/98. Gone but not forgotten. Not a day goes by when we don't think of you...a cherished memory always in our minds and hearts. Mike and Joe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURNIT, SHEPARD
description: KURNIT-Shepard. Beloved husband of Jean. Father of Paul, Rick and Scott. Brother of Hal, Vic and Norman. Father-in-law of Susan Kurnit, Diane Katzin and Abbe Heller, and grandfather of Ara, Jesse and Catrina. Died peacefully on February 10. In lieu of flowers donations to Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 2247, NYC 10116. A memorial reception will be held on February 16.

title: Introduction
description: The cover article on Ecstasy generated much mail, which was notable for its especially strong opinions, both pro and con. Many parents, doctors and public officials accused the article of glorifying Ecstasy use and said we did not sufficiently describe the drug's risks. A nearly equal number of readers praised our attempt to detail what attracts users to the drug and our description of its deadening effect over time. Overall, its numbers were dwarfed by those for the previous week's article defending atheism, which continues to draw hundreds of readers' thanks.

title: February 4-10; More Heart Problems
description: While saving the heart, bypass surgery may also injure the brain. Researchers at Duke University reported that five years after bypass surgery, 42 percent of patients showed a drop in mental sharpness, as measured by tests of memory, spatial ability and other skills. Mental declines had been reported before, but were thought temporary. Suspected culprits include the stress of surgery and anesthesia, diminished blood flow to the brain during heart surgery and widespread vascular disease that may affect blood vessels in the brain. Denise Grady

title: Loved Ones Lost, Then Found Online
description: WHO has not wondered whatever happened to a childhood sweetheart, college crush or even a long-lost family member? To find them, people often had to contact old friends for information or even hire a private investigator to track the loved ones down. Now, the Internet has made missing persons much easier to find.

title: Give Youth a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: From Black Monday to Black Gold
description: CONSIDER Thomas O'Malley's career an ode to the principle of buy low, sell high.

title: 'Which Track For the High Line?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, RUTH (NEE KASTENBAUM)
description: GOLD-Ruth (nee Kastenbaum). Died on February 3 in Forest Hills. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Seth (Cindy), Leon and Toni (Nick) Gordon. Loving grandmother of Daniel and Michael Gordon and Perel Pnina, Moshe and Rassie Gold. Dear sister of Jack and Marvin. Devoted aunt. Her family and friends will greatly miss her.

title: A Retro Trip Down Kitchen Lane
description: IF Janet Foster and Carol Siegel are nostalgic for a time when a woman's place was believed to be in the kitchen, it's not because they agree with the adage. On the contrary, the two women from Mount Kisco have turned the kitchens of the 1940's and 50's into a thriving 21st-century business.

title: If x Teachers Are Overpaid by $y, How Much Confusion Results?
description: The Camden Education Association bargained long and hard on its latest contract with the Board of Education. Finally, nearly a year after its old contract had run out, the union signed what both sides believed to be an equitable three-year agreement in May 2000.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Jan. 14, about two thrillers, ''Code to Zero,'' by Ken Follett, and ''Protect and Defend,'' by Richard North Patterson, misstated the given name of the writer from whom the Follett book takes its epigraph. He is Thomas Powers (not John), the biographer of the former director of central intelligence Richard Helms.

title: Keep Up the Pruning
description: Continue annual pruning chores. Up to a quarter of a mature peach tree's wood should be removed every year before growth begins. The idea is to keep the tree growing in bounds and to encourage new shoots that will bear fruit next year (peaches flower and fruit on one-year-old shoots). Remove old unproductive wood, and head back branches to pointed growth buds, not plump flower buds.

title: Reaching A Goal In Nepal
description: ON a trek, there are good starts and there are bad starts to a day. The fact that my guide was cursing from the doorway of our room undoubtedly meant the latter.

title: The Precedents Exist
description: To the Editor:

title: February 4-10; Not So Standard Anymore
description: Happy experimental physicists are all happy in the same way: they delight in proving a theory wrong. That is close to what happened at Brookhaven National Laboratory, where the wobbling of subatomic particles called muons could not be explained by the Standard Model, a colossus of a theory whose predictions have correctly accounted for 30 years of experimental data. The rate at which the muons wobbled like tops may have been affected by the ghostly presence of a new form of matter. Theorists point out that the Standard Model may yet survive, perhaps as part of a grander mathematical structure called supersymmetry. James Glanz

title: From Infamous Pitch to Saving Lives
description: RALPH BRANCA, 75, and a lifetime Westchester resident, has known adversity. Perhaps that's why his life has been spent helping others prepare for and deal with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROIDA, MARK
description: BROIDA-Mark. Of San Diego, CA, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ and Westbury, NY, on January 30, 2001. Beloved husband of Karen (nee Harten). Loving son of Arline and Irwin, cherished grandson of Edna Braverman and the late Theodore Braverman, and the late Rose and Sidney Broida. Devoted brother of Lisa and brotherin-law of Michael Josephson. Adored uncle of Teddi and David. Graveside services are today, February 11, 2001 at 1PM, Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: White Plains Lawyer Wins Bar Association Award
description: When the State Bar Association considers a candidate for its attorney professionalism award, it's not looking for a David Boies. Frank Ciervo, an association spokesman, said the recipients are of a more modest ilk: ''They don't make headlines, but they put their clients first,'' he said.

title: Twyla Tharp Looks To Brooklyn and Beyond
description: In April, Twyla Tharp Dance will move into its first permanent home, a converted Civil War-era church near the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Harvey Lichtenstein, chairman of the academy's Local Development Corporation, is overseeing a 10-year, $560 million plan to create a cultural district in Brooklyn near the academy, and Ms. Tharp is the first major artist to move into the community. One recent evening Mr. Lichtenstein, who was the head of BAM for 32 years, and Ms. Tharp, one of the most talked about choreographers working today, met at her Upper West Side apartment to discuss her coming season at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan and her hopes for the new space in Brooklyn. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

title: Murphy's Law, Strictly Applied
description: CALL me Bfstplk.

title: Subcontinental Cuisine
description: GRIPPING news accounts of the recent earthquake and its aftermath in western India always include addresses and phone numbers for those who want to help. But the connection is particularly compelling when your evening plans include dinner at an Indian place and inside the door is a cardboard donations box covered with a photograph of a beautiful Indian woman with haunted eyes.

title: One Dot-Com's Story: No Boom, but No Bust
description: At a staff meeting a year ago, George Cigale tried to galvanize the young crew of Tutor.com, an Internet start-up that matches tutors and students online. Mr. Cigale, the chairman and chief executive and a co-founder, spoke with the charismatic candor that had served him well in talking to venture capitalists; he told the staff that the next three months could mean $100,000 or so for each of them, in newly issued stock.

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: Because of Lincoln's Birthday tomorrow, alternate-side parking regulations for street cleaning will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect. In Connecticut and New Jersey, state offices and courts will be closed.

title: Around the Island
description: A slowdown in the national economy caused a first-quarter sales drop-off for Hauppauge-based Vicon Industries (Amex: VII), said its chief executive, Ken Darby. Net sales for the quarter were $17.4 million, down from $19.5 million in the period in the previous fiscal year. Net income for the quarter increased more than twenty-fold, to $1.72 million from $85,000 last year, primarily because Vicon sold its interest in a South Korean manufacturing and distribution enterprise. After that transaction, Vicon paid 37 cents a share, compared with 2 cents a share last year. Vicon produces industrial surveillance systems and components. . . . Net sales for the second quarter increased 43 percent, said Huntington Station-based American Technical Ceramics Corporation (Amex: AMK). Sales for the quarter were $21.3 million, up from $14.9 million. Net income amounted to $2.4 million, or 31 cents a share, compared with $1.66 million, or 22 cents a share, last year. Management said it expected to see continued sales and profitability growth as new products reached international markets. The company makes packaging components for the microwave and telecommunication industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLIGEL, KENNETH
description: FLIGEL-Kenneth. Age 51. Cherished son of Esta and the late Marshall. Beloved brother and best friend of Craig. After a long and terrible ordeal, needing a liver transplant that never came, his body could fight no longer. Memorial Services at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, 1 PM, Sunday.

title: Next-Day Delivery For 'Grocery-Store Starved'
description: Though some online delivery services have been struggling, NEDexpress.com has jumped into the market, delivering groceries in TriBeCa, SoHo, the financial district, Battery Park City and South Street Seaport.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: TWO days until the Academy Award nominations are announced, and already Steven Soderbergh's ERIN BROCKOVICH (2000), a film generating serious Oscar talk for its star, Julia Roberts, is on premium cable. Ms. Roberts plays the title character, a financially desperate single mother who wangles a job as a legal assistant for an ambulance chaser in a cheap toupee (Albert Finney) and finds herself saving the world. Well, at least one town, where toxic chemicals are in the water supply. The film, based on the life of a real person (who has been turning up on talk and awards shows herself), deteriorates into a do-gooder soap opera, but Ms. Roberts, memorable in micro-mini hemlines, deep cleavage and cheap jewelry, keeps things lively -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:20 a.m. on Starz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOT, GERALD
description: ROOT-Gerald. On February 9. Beloved husband of Rhoda. Loving brother of Laura Rosenblum and Milton Root and adoring uncle of many nieces and nephews. Lifetime fighter of progressive causes. Service to be held Sunday, February 11, 11:45 AM, at I.J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE DRIFTING OF SPIRITS

title: Word for Word/Who's Asking?; Everything Researchers Ever Wanted to Know About Sex
description: POETS, lyricists and lovers are not alone in their fascination with sex. Researchers have long sought to shed light on its mysteries, bringing scientific techniques to bear on the varieties of human sexual behavior.

title: Children's Books
description: THE HINDENBURG

title: Going the Way Of the Victrola
description: THE home computer revolution may soon chalk up another casualty: the recording studio -- that shrine where many a music legend has been born. The old legends relied on their talent but also on record companies to cover the expense of the studios. In exchange, the labels had a say in the aesthetic direction and distribution of the final product. New talent won't need this help. The personal computer is freeing it from the need of both a recording studio and a record company -- and, maybe, from traditional musicianship altogether.

title: Power Lines Build New Rift in East End
description: A UESTION of whether new power lines should be put underground has sharpened more than purely geographic divisions between the North and South Forks.

title: A Public Viewing
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Couples With Staying Power
description: It's the antithesis of ''Temptation Island.'' ''Couples: A Celebration of Commitment,'' a book of portraits by M. I. Hamburg and essays by Catherine Whitney (Andrews McMeel Publishing, $27.95), profiles the marriages of 35 prominent pairs and shares their secrets for staying together.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 11, 2001
description: Weeks

title: The Rights and Wrongs for the Yankees
description: Three Things That Must Go Right

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELCH, HELEN L.
description: WELCH-Helen L. Widow of Clifford F. Welch. Ever a fighter for justice, and for peace and freedom. Loved by Beatrice Olsen, Clara and David Sack and all their children and the Kastner family.

title: In Future, Gnus Won't Rip Owls
description: THEY haven't dodged trolleys outside Washington Park in decades, so we won't see a team name like the Brooklyn Trolley Dodgers -- shortened to you know what -- anytime soon. Instead, for the next wave of team names, consider the XFL, the new football league created by the World Wrestling Federation. The eight-team league offers an innovation in monikers: none of the teams are named after animals. No Cubs or Bears, no Ravens or Timberwolves.

title: Remains of a 'Farm' Where the Glamorous Once Vacationed
description: In its heyday, the Ocean Township area of Monmouth County, including Asbury Park and Long Branch, was one of the most prestigious and popular vacation spots in the nation. The Ross Fenton Farm in the Wanamassa section of Ocean Township was indeed a working farm with large greenhouses but also included a large lakeside hotel, several guest cottages and two casinos. Ron Gorsky is restoring the house he grew up in, which was once part of the estate. A teacher in Asbury Park and a founder of the Ocean Township Historical Society, Mr. Gorsky is trying to find out as much as possible about the Ross Fenton estate and its history. He talked recently about what he has learned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOURNIER, JOSEPH E. MD.
description: FOURNIER-Joseph E. MD. The Faculty and Staff of NYU Medical Center note with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Joseph E. Fournier. Dr. Fournier completed his residency in anesthesiology and a fellowship in cardiac anesthesia at NYU School of Medicine before joining the Department of Anesthesiology in 1998. He quickly became an essential part of the life of our institution and will be sorely missed. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his family and loved ones. Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff, President, NYU Hospitals Center Charles Fermon, MD, Chairman, Department of Anesthesiology

title: Critics Call Creedmoor Idea Penny-Wise and Child-Foolish
description: A proposal to save money by moving the Queens Children's Psychiatric Center into a nearby treatment center for adults has angered parents and local elected officials, who say the shift will be harmful for the children.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Ukrainian soprano Maria Guleghina, who made her American solo recital debut at Alice Tully Hall that afternoon, misidentified the composer of the opera ''Andrea Chnier,'' in which she has sung the role of Maddalena de Coigny. He was Umberto Giordano, not Francesco Cilea.

title: Crime by the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Union City, N.J.; Manhattan Views At Blue-Collar Price
description: BISECTED by the approach road of the Lincoln Tunnel, Union City, N.J., has waited more than a quarter-century for a boom like the ones that have revitalized the neighboring communities of Hoboken and Secaucus.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBS, IRENE OSTREICHER
description: JACOBS-Irene Ostreicher. 2/2/21-7/30/81. 80th Birthday. We love and miss you and remember you always. Julie, Nancy, Kare

description: HOLLYWOOD V. HARD CORE

title: 15 Minutes of Fame Where Black Is the Color
description: ''Who is that?''

title: Renewal Looms for a Grand School Just Saved from the Wrecking Ball
description: Nearly two years after Public School 109 was saved from demolition, the century-old neo-Gothic building may be on a slow road to renovation.

title: Where Everyone's Salome
description: The strains of Middle Eastern melodies drifted through a Hastings-on-Hudson home on a wintry night as 10 women, clad in loose pants, scarves and shawls, undulated in the rhythmic motions of belly dancing.

title: Darkness Visible
Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LARRY
description: NEWMAN-Larry. On February 9, 2001. Loving father of Remi and Claire. Beloved son of Ann and Max. Devoted brother of Peter. Dear companion. Larry died doing what he loved most-playing tennis in a tournament. He will be missed by a multitude of wonderful friends. Graveside service Sunday, 1:30 PM, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ.

title: Stankowski Struggling to Regain Top Form
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 10  In 1997, Paul Stankowski finished 21st on the PGA Tour money list, captured his second career victory and was being touted as one of golf's most promising young players.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota Sequoia; Having Sampled the Local Cuisine, Toyota Bulks Up
description: WHEN Toyota declared 2000 ''the year of the truck and S.U.V.,'' it wasn't kidding. In 12 months, it has added four pickups and sport utilities to the four it already offered, plus the two utilities from its Lexus division. It is now mounting a full-scale assault on Detroit's stronghold -- the truck market -- on 10 fronts.

title: Fashion Isn't for the Meek
description: LAZARO HERNANDEZ, a fashion student in his junior year at the Parsons School of Design, was saying goodbye to his mother at the Miami airport last summer when his heart almost stopped. Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, was getting on his flight.

title: NEW AGENCY HEAD
description: Alison Greene, formerly a top official in the federal Department of Health and Human Services, is the new executive director of the Westchester Human Rights Commission. The agency investigates discrimination complaints and promotes education programs to combat bigotry. Ms. Greene is a native of New Rochelle and a longtime resident of White Plains. She will be paid $121,035 a year. She worked for four years as the attorney in charge of the civil division of the Legal Aid Society of Westchester. Elsa Brenner

title: An Earlier Drug Saga, With No Easy Answers
description: BEFORE ''Traffic,'' Steven Soderbergh's widely praised film about the heroin network stretching from Mexico into America, there was ''Traffik.'' This five-and-a-half-hour miniseries, produced by Britain's Channel Four in 1989, is being shown at the Museum of Television and Radio beginning Thursday, and viewers of it will be able to recognize the source of each of the subplots deftly juggled in Mr. Soderbergh's movie; what they won't find is the film's glossy, melodramatic style or its preachy, social-problem-picture tone.

title: Skills Seminar Aimed At Building Better Busineses
description: How to build better businesses by enhancing professional and personal skills is a topic on the agenda of the Winter Breakfast Seminar Series sponsored by the Westchester County Association and Aetna U.S. Healthcare. Sessions will be held on four consecutive Tuesdays, starting Feb. 20, at 8 a.m. at MBIA Insurance headquarters in Armonk. The cost per seminar is $40 for association members and $50 for nonmembers. The fee for all four sessions is $125. Reservations and information:(914) 948-6444. Penny Singer

title: New Town Service: Baby-Sitting
description: SATURDAY night is usually parents' night out. Now their children can have a night out too.

title: Cancer Support Group Moves In
description: BEFORE she died of ovarian cancer in 1989, the comedian Gilda Radner said, ''Having cancer has given me membership in an elite club I'd rather not belong to.'' Six years later, her husband, the actor Gene Wilder, and others close to her formed Gilda's Club, a national, nonprofit group for people with the disease and their families and friends. Three months ago, a clubhouse, as the centers are called, opened on Maple Avenue here.

title: Investors Gaze Forlornly at Earnings
description: With fresh economic data scarce last week, Wall Street focused on other influences on stocks, notably news about quarterly earnings, corporate layoffs and retail sales. For the most part, investors did not like what they saw.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: MY AMERICA: A Poetry Atlas of the United States. Selected by Lee Bennett Hopkins. Illustrated by Stephen Alcorn. Simon & Schuster. $19.95. (Ages 8 to 12) Here's a reference book and poetry anthology combined in one handsome volume. There are 50 poems reflecting the regions of the nation, many by well-loved writers like Carl Sandburg and Langston Hughes. In addition there's the kind of data you find in an atlas: maps, capitals, state mottoes and curious facts. The muted illustrations are sometimes abstract, sometimes specific. A treat for those confronting that inescapable curriculum unit: learning the 50 states.

title: Young Pen
description: ''Yo, Alejandro'' is not a greeting. ''Yo'' is Spanish for ''I,'' and it is part of the title of what the back cover says is ''Alejandro Gac-Artigas's first book.'' The author, an eighth grader from Fair Haven, is 12, young for even a first-time author. The book is an autobiography, subtitled ''The Story of a Young Latino Boy Struggling Through Life.'' The struggles mainly consist of things like the attempts by his parents -- his mother is a professor of Spanish-American literature at Monmouth University and his father is a Chilean-born writer -- to get him into kindergarten though he was born after the cut-off date and an unresponsive teacher and soccer coach. This is conveyed in sometime sesquipedalian prose that demonstrates his precocity (he got 1100 on the SAT's at age 11). In fact, the book, published by Ediciones Nuevo Espacio ($11.95), is on a reading list for participants in a Johns Hopkins program for talented youngsters.

title: SOAPBOX; Welcoming Affordable Rentals
description: NEW JERSEY consistently ranks near the top of the list in national surveys of housing costs. Affordable rentals are needed throughout the state. Yet a troubling policy conflict limits the effectiveness of the only program that develops affordable rental housing in New Jersey. As a result, such housing is being excluded from communities where there is a pressing need and is being concentrated in a relatively small number of municipalities willing to accommodate the necessary requirements.

title: Judging Khrushchev, In History's Eyes
description: To the Editor:

description: SNUG HARBOR

description: ARFIELD-Larry. Sunday, February 11, 2001, 2-5P.M. Bodanna Gallery, 125 East 7th Street, NYC, 10009. In lieu of flowers please consider contributions to Bodanna Inc., an urban youth ceramics program.

title: Questions Linger For Crossroads
description: The Crossroads Theater Company bought some time last week, but two crucial questions remain: Did it buy enough time? Did it get enough money?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, SYLVIA
description: SNYDER-Sylvia. 91, on February 6, 2001. President of NY Photoindustrial Union-Local 401 from 1942 to 1972. Beloved mother of Amy Snyder of Silver Spring, MD. Cherished sister of Dorothy Boyle. Dear aunt and Godmother of Dr. Richard Snyder of Los Angeles, CA. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, and friends including Joann and Anthony Raimondi, and Alicia Boyle, all of Staten Island and (author) Linda Nevins of Boston, MA.

title: Youth Movement
description: The Nets' Kenyon Martin, the league's No. 1 draft pick, was feeling a little giddy in preparation for the Rookie Challenge later today against last season's rookies, almost predicting victory. ''We have a better chance of winning than the rookies of last year,'' Martin said. Why? ''Because I'm on the team,'' he added.

title: Business Class as if You Belonged
description: I JUST flew business class from Tokyo to San Francisco, and boy are my thumbs tired.

title: Siobhan Hammer, Jake Dolce
description: Siobhan Virginia Hammer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Hammer of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Coakley Dolce, a son of Mrs. John E. Dolce of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Mr. Dolce. The ceremony was performed at the Fordham University Church in the Bronx by the Rev. Joseph Currie, the director of campus ministry at Fordham.

title: Political Briefing; From Arizona, Talk Of a Bid by Quayle
description: Former Vice President Dan Quayle made a few headlines in 1999 when he briefly considered running for president. But the money wasn't there, not to mention the poll numbers, and so by first frost, a good four months before the spring 2000 caucuses and primaries, he was gone, saying as he departed, ''There's a time to stay and a time to fold.''

title: Infused in the Industry
description: DAVID C. BIGELOW remembers sitting with his father in the kitchen of their New York City brownstone one evening in the late 1940's. He was watching his father hand paint labels for Ruth C. Bigelow's flavored teas, then new to the market.

title: Looking Beyond Mergers In Global Antitrust Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Away
description: To the Editor: When I read ''What Women Want: Not Much, Really'' (Jan. 21) my first thought was that someone had been eavesdropping on my mind. Congratulations to Jan Benzel for capturing so accurately and expressing so evocatively the thoughts and feelings associated with the women's weekend away.

title: Buff and Ready
description: Looking Good

title: Investing Diary: Soul-Searching as a Power Pursuit
description: It's not the wild, profane Salomon Brothers trading desk portrayed in Michael Lewis's 1989 book, "Liar's Poker." The traders have been tamed.

title: Fears of Mad Cow Disease Reach Bullfighting Rings
description: To the sound of trumpets and the applause of an expectant crowd, the three imperious matadors stalked into the damp ring, manfully ignoring the bitter chill of a freezing Sunday to take part in what promoters billed as the first great bullfight of the new century.

title: Nearing Endgame in the Violin Trade?
description: FOR about 150 years, the upper-end violin trade has not only connected the rich and famous with old, mostly Italian instruments, by such iconic makers as Antonio Stradivari and Giuseppe Guarneri. It has also issued and controlled the certificates of authenticity that ultimately establish their market value. The business is rich in story lines, including power, sex, even murder. But at most times and places -- including Court 51 of the High Court of Justice in London only last week -- the prime mover has been money.

title: Judith Jankowski, Charles Lyons Jr.
description: Judith Marie Jankowski, a daughter of Sally and Gene F. Jankowski of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Edward Lyons Jr., the son of Mary Claire and Mr. Lyons Sr. of Penfield, N.Y. The Rev. William Byron performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Liberties; Get Rich Quick
description: Oh, heck, let's just impeach him again.

title: At a Bakery, Vivid Scars of a Fire and a Brother's Despair
description: A brick wall on the outside of Shane's Bakery on 61st Street is stained black from a fire in May that leveled six adjoining stores and almost destroyed the bakery. It is the color of near ruin, of danger that drew near and left a scar.

title: Laughter, or Lawsuit? You Judge
description: Warning: Shin pads cannot protect any part of the body they do not cover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, JESSE
description: MARCUS-Jesse. Husband of the late Rosalind. Survived by son Michael and daughters Carol Singer and Cheri Lee.

title: New Insights Into the Novel? Try Reading 300
description: When Neil Baldwin of the National Book Foundation called to inquire if I would agree to be one of the fiction judges for the 2000 National Book Awards, I responded with an immediate and enthusiastic yes. It was a great honor. An opportunity to influence the course of American letters and uphold the standard of art. Under the enthusiasm a certain trepidation gnawed at me: Would I be able to do the job, and do it well? And what about the novel I was halfway through writing? But I blithely shrugged it off.

title: 3 Workers Accuse Apparel Maker of Forcing Unpaid Overtime
description: Two apparel factories in Brooklyn are being accused of forcing three employees to work 100 to 140 hours a week -- and illegally failing to pay them overtime.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Feb. 1 about the efforts of Fred Shapiro, a Yale librarian, to create a new dictionary of quotations referred incorrectly to HeinOnline, a source he uses. It is a database of articles in legal periodicals, not of legal quotations.

title: Long-Held Beliefs Are Challenged By New Human Genome Analysis
description: The publication of the first interpretations of the human genome sequence this week overturns some long-held beliefs about human biology.

title: Action! When Arf Imitates Life
description: Backstage at the Mayflower Dog Show, the overwrought yuppie dog owner Hamilton Swan exhorts his neurotic Weimaraner, Beatrice: ''You see a blue ribbon. Grab it! Get it!'' When her attention wanders, he shouts: ''Look at me! Don't look at those loser dogs. Look at me!''

title: Hieroglyphic Script Fights for Life
description: LIJIANG, China  At his simple wooden desk in a room along the shores of the Black Dragon pool high in the Chinese Himalayas, the brush in He Kai-xian's steady hand marks a series of distinctive symbols, the meaning of which almost nobody else can fully decipher.

title: Schlumberger Is Reported in Negotiations to Buy Sema
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the American energy services company that has begun branching out into technology, is negotiating to buy Sema, a European information technology company, in a deal valued around 3.5 billion, or a little more than $5 billion, people involved in the talks said today.

title: Metro Matters; Abe Beame, Mugged By History
description: AFTER the memorial service for John V. Lindsay last month, a group of mourners found themselves waiting on a crowded West Side subway platform for the next No. 1 train, and soon the station had turned into an old clubhouse, without smoke. There was talk of Mayors Wagner and Lindsay, of Forest Hills and Al Shanker, and of Mr. Lindsay's successor, Abe Beame.

title: Talk Is Still Waiting to Catch Fire
description: Last week, as Tina Brown discussed the challenges she faced starting Talk magazine and its parent company, Talk Media, she related a tale about David Geffen, the DreamWorks SKG executive, reading an article about Geffen Records.

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: How One Man's Pride Helped Inspire His People
description: While the broadcast networks crow about their big ratings for ''Survivor'' and ''Temptation Island,'' public television has been doing its duty admirably, celebrating Black History Month with serious programs about real struggles for survival.

title: Reality Shows Set Off Fight Over Awards
description: The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences is the leading trade group in the television industry. It is a society of writers, producers, artists, actors and crafts people that for the last year has been trying to deal with a relatively simple issue: How should its annual showcase, the Emmy Awards ceremonies, handle the latest television craze, reality TV?

title: A Dream Made Concrete
description: For idealistic young architects, overbuilt New York City usually offers only demanding clients and renovation jobs, not empty plots of land and a free rein. But Upper West Side native Jim Harwood lucked into a fateful combination -- a parking lot in Park Slope and an owner who couldn't pay his back taxes. After the taxman came calling, Harwood got a chance to design what was literally his dream building: a modern concrete-and-glass residence, nestled among traditional row houses, built for the most demanding client of all: himself.

title: Flare-Up of Mideast Violence Continues
description: In a housewarming present for Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon, Palestinian gunmen fired tonight toward the Israeli neighborhood of Gilo, on the outskirts of Jerusalem, for the first time in more than a month. Israeli troops responded with a barrage against the source of the gunfire in the Palestinian town of Beit Jala.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEECHER, LAWRENCE J.
description: BEECHER-Lawrence J. On February 10, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Margery. Devoted father of Andrew and Ronnie, Robert and Megan Beecher. Loving grandfather of Amy and Owen. Private service was held.

title: E-Commerce Report; Internet retailers find that the ancient business method of bartering helps them cope with a variety of transactions.
description: IN refining their approach to the world's newest profession, Internet retailers have made plenty of highly public blunders. Late shipments of Christmas goods brought the wrath of the federal government. Security breaches jeopardized the credit of hundreds of thousands of customers. Pricing errors attracted swarms of bargain hunters.

title: Ukraine Rally Calls on Chief To Step Down
description: Thousands of demonstrators marched through the capital of Ukraine today, the second such outpouring in a week, demanding the resignation of President Leonid D. Kuchma and calling for new presidential elections.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A friend of mine said this was like the Cincinnati Bengals playing the San Diego Chargers at Hooters.''

title: China's Long  but Uneven  March to Literacy
description: BEIJING  Hua Lijun owns a most decidedly unfashionable pair of thick black reading glasses, and when she puts them on she has no trouble at all threading a needle. Still, she mutters constantly about her poor eyesight.

title: In the Bronx, Ethnic Mix Breeds Tensions at School
description: At lunchtime, the Albanian students at Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx gather in front of the diner across East Tremont Avenue. Other students, many of them black and Hispanic, head the other way, toward the White Castle.

title: Marbury's Dreams Can't Match Reality
description: Stephon Marbury, who came from 31st Street in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn all the way to the N.B.A., never dreamed of this moment. But now he has a videotape to prove it really happened.

title: Review/Fashion; Talking Revolution and Showing Suits
description: Thirteen years ago this month, Nike offered television viewers the controversial advertising campaign in which the Beatles' ''Revolution,'' that anthem of 1960's dissent, was sampled to hawk sneakers that cost as much as some airline tickets. As readers of op-ed pages may remember, many Americans -- baby boomers, to be exact -- did not take warmly to the use of a sacrosanct pop cultural product to sell a less mythologized synthetic-soled consumer one.

title: Article 2001021290241659901 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Compressed Data; Brazilians Think Basic to Bridge the Digital Divide

title: Returning to the Action as Bush's Lobbyist to Congress
description: ON paper, at least, it made little sense.

title: Court Orders Modified Napster Injunction
description: By swapping music files online, the 61 million clients of Napster Inc. are making unfair use of copyrighted material, a federal appeals court ruled today, in a decision that could allow a judge to shut down the service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, LEO P. JR.
description: LARKIN-Leo P. Jr. A veteran litigator and corporate lawyer, passed away Thursday, February 8, 2001, at his Manhattan home at the age of 75. The cause of death was cardiopulmonary arrest. Born and raised in Ithaca, NY, Mr. Larkin, after Army service, graduated from Cornell University in 1948 with a B.A., and received his LL.B. in 1950 from Cornell Law School, where he was an editor of the Law Review. His college honors included Phi Beta Kappa and Phi Kappa Phi. He was a founding Trustee of The Cornell Delta Phi Educational Fund, which grants scholarships to Cornell students. A partner in Rogers and Wells (now Clifford Chance Rogers and Wells) since 1962. Mr. Larkin acted in general and business matters. His assignments ranged from representing foreign corporations in real estate litigation to acting as the outside legal representative of Newsweek. He handled in First Ammendment and libel litigation for various publications, among them participation in The Washington Post's involvement in the Pentagon Papers case. Mr. Larkin served as a director or trustee of several institutions and was a member of the American, New York State, and City of New York Bar Associations and The Federal Bar Council. A musician and actor, Mr. Larkin acted in off-Broadway plays during the 1950's, most notably as the lead in ''The Man Who Came To Dinner.'' He was an active member of The Society of American Magicians. Mr. Larkin is survived by his longtime friend, Gabriel M. Rivera of Manhattan, his sister, Dorothy Vagts of Cambridge, MA, and his nieces, Lydia Vagts also of Cambridge and Karen Vagts of Arlington Heights, MA. A private funeral service was held at Frank E. Campbell. Plans will be announced for forthcoming memorial service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTOSOFSKY, CANTOR IRVING
description: ANTOSOFSKY-Cantor Irving. February 10, 2001, age 93. Loving husband of Gussie for 70 years. Beloved father of Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky and Loretta, Barbara Kasower and Irving, Marcia Christie and Roy, eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. A cantor for over 65 years in synagogues in Brooklyn, Bronx and Manhattan. Recognized for his beautiful operatic tenor voice and consummate knowledge of ritual. His life was devoted to family and music demonstrating integrity, care and professionalism in everything he did. He lived fully and joyously with humor and an appreciation for all that life had to offer. Services at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Fuel-Short Region in Russia Is Now Freezing in the Dark
description: A bitter wind grasping at his pants legs, Nikolai A. Yudin raised one arm outside the boiler room at the O.A.O. Razdolnoye Building Materials Factory, a red-brick husk aged well beyond its 42 years, and pointed emphatically at -- nothing.

title: Our Influence in Belize
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Two efforts to prevent disease: one purifies blood; the other reminds people to wash their hands.
description: MILLIONS of people receive blood transfusions in this country every year, and many more samples of potentially diseased blood are handled by clinical workers in laboratories. Because blood banks, health care workers and patients fear the spread of disease from unhealthy blood, every donated pint is routinely screened for pathogens.

title: Corrections

title: Court Rules Napster Users Infringe on Copyrights
description: Napster Inc. was dealt a serious legal setback today, as a federal appeals court ruled that the millions of people who exchange music on its online service were infringing on copyrights and that the company needed to stop this infringement.

title: Letting the Music Sing for Itself
description: Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's production of ''Manon'' at the Metropolitan Opera is nearly as old as the work's 16-year-old protagonist -- middle-aged in production years -- but it seemed as fresh and youthful as its heroine in its revival on Saturday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, THOMAS W.
description: THOMPSON-Thomas W. A memorial service will be held for Thomas W. Thompson, of Rhinebeck, NY, at 11 AM, on Thursday, February 15, Chapel of the Brick Church, Park and 92 St. A Senior VP at Columbia Artists, over 45 years Thompson managed artists such as Yehudi Menuhin, Robert McDuffie, Birgit Nilsson, Andras Schiff and Charles Rosen, and produced regular U.S. tours for many orchestras including the RPO, the Czech Philharmonic, and the Stuttgart, Franz Liszt and Prague Chamber Orchestras. Born in Cedartown, GA, ''Tommy'' Thompson was a true southern gentleman and his passing represents the end of an era in the music industry.

title: Americans' Davis Cup Hopes Ended by a Swiss Teenager
description: It could have been quite an ending: 18-year-old Andy Roddick making his Davis Cup debut for the United States in the fifth and final match of this tie against Switzerland, and winning it in straight sets.

title: China Youth Take Names From West: Hi Medusa!

''It's too easy to have the same name with someone else with the common names,'' said Ms. Zhou, 24, who has used Satan for the last six years with English-speaking foreigners. ''I have yet to meet another person named Satan,'' she says.

Their report is a major step toward final court approval of the antitrust lawsuit brought last year by more than 130,000 auction house customers who said they were cheated in a price-fixing scheme dating from 1992.

title: The Finest Football February Can Offer
description: The upstart XFL arrived on a bitter wind at Giants Stadium today, and in its attempt to distance itself from the National Football League, it did at least retain the celebratory ritual of tailgating. Two hours before the home opener for the New York/New Jersey Hitmen, the parking lot was buzzing with the usual foaming beers and smoking grills. The one noticeable difference was that fans were tossing around footballs the color of a loaf of pumpernickel.

title: Nikodinov Trying to Prove Her Turnaround Will Last

title: In Playoff, a Double-Bogey Beats a Triple-Bogey
description: The ending was bizarre, not brilliant. How many sudden-death playoffs on the PGA Tour have been won with a double-bogey? Phil Mickelson did not know, and he did not care. His double-bogey on the third hole of sudden death today won the Buick Invitational when Frank Lickliter three-putted for triple-bogey, missing a 5-foot putt to end a three-man playoff that also included Davis Love III.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Jean the Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76th St, Thursday, 11 AM. title: Rewards of Changing Partners
description: Half a century ago, when bidding methods were relatively unsophisticated, the top players regularly switched partnerships. Nowadays most experts have one partner with whom they can play very efficiently, often relying on many pages of notes dealing with a large array of situations. Within a team, therefore, breaking up a partnership is rarely done unless sickness or another emergency dictates.

title: Two on Tuesday
description: Working weekends is a drag, but it can have advantages when vacation time comes around. Anyone who can begin and end a one-week European vacation on Tuesdays can use the Two on Tuesday package from IMTC/Pegasus. Through March, a couple can fly from Boston, New York, Washington, Atlanta or Miami to Amsterdam, Brussels, Paris, Vienna, Prague, Budapest, Madrid, Barcelona, Zurich or Athens for $1,198. That includes their economy-class air fare as well as two nights accommodations in a three-star hotel in the center of the arrival city and one week's car rental with collision and theft coverage. Payment is due 14 days before departure. Details: (800) 790-4682 or www.intc-travel.com .

description: Eleanor Lawrence, a flutist who played frequently in chamber music performances and with several orchestras in New York and who is credited with transforming a newsletter into an important resource for flutists, died on Jan. 16 at her home in Manhattan. She was 64.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, SHEILA LONDON
description: ABRAMS-Sheila London. On February 10. Loving and beautiful wife of Fred. Beloved mother of Philip, Roberta, Gary and Cliff. Adored grandmother of Matthew and Lonn. Daughter of the late Lena and Morris London. Dear sister of Andrew London and the late Helen Heymann. Loving aunt, cousin and devoted friend to many. She lived a full life as a most caring woman. She was a tireless educator and counselor to people with epilepsy and people with heart disease. Sheila was an Officer and Director of the Epilepsy Foundation of America, the Epilepsy Foundation of Long Island, and a volunteer at St. Francis Hospital. Her cheerful and giving spirit will always be with us and with those whose lives she touched. Services today, at 1 PM, Riverside-Nassau North, Great Neck Station.

description: Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Prize winner whose name has been mentioned in relation to the Marc Rich pardon case, said yesterday that he understood why the team trying to secure a pardon for Mr. Rich sought his help, as documents released last week by a Congressional committee showed. But, contrary to the documents' assertions that he had weighed in with the White House, Mr. Wiesel said, ''I didn't do anything.''

title: The Mayoralty of Abraham Beame
description: It was Abraham Beame's misfortune to have been elected mayor of New York City in 1973 at least in part because of his expertise on municipal finances and then become overwhelmed by the worst financial crisis in the city's history. Mr. Beame, who died Saturday at the age of 94, fought tenaciously to save the city from bankruptcy, cutting back services while striving to preserve New York's traditional approach to social welfare. But ultimately the city had to be bailed out by the state and federal governments. Mr. Beame paid a huge political price. He surrendered his budget powers to a state control board, and was defeated in the Democratic primary election in 1977.

title: Mexico's New President Faces Pesky States' Rights Revolt
description: The new president of Mexico, Vicente Fox, is a little busy right now. President Bush is coming for lunch on Friday. The Zapatista rebels start marching to Mexico City to demand Indian rights next week. And Mr. Fox is trying to turn this country into a working democracy while attracting billions in foreign investment in his spare time.

Services Tuesday, February 13, 2001, at 11:45 AM, at Park East Synagogue, 163 E. 67th St. In lieu of flowers or other gifts please make contributions to the Abe and Mary Beame Scholarship Fund at Baruch College of City University of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEVAT, ISIDORE
description: CHEVAT-Isidore. 79, died at home of a heart attack on February 11, 2001. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. A lifelong fighter for social justice, peace and democracy. A graduate of New Utrecht High School and Brooklyn College, he was a veteran of many struggles, including serving with the U.S. Army in Kunming, China, during WWII, where he trained Kuomintang Troops. He was part of the line that protected Paul Robeson at Peekskill, NY, in 1949, and last month marched against the innauguration of George W. Bush. He was also proud to have been the faculty advisor for the first African American History Club at Woodrow Wilson Vocational High School, Queens, and was chosen to represent the school at the funeral of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. During his career as a teacher and guidance counselor he touched the lives of hundreds of young people and continued to work as a counselor for foster children at the Little Flower Agency in Brooklyn. He was also president of the New York Chapter of the U.S./China Peoples Friendship Association. He is survived by Edith, his loving wife of 53 years, his children, Alan, Richie, Cary and Ben, his daughters-inlaw, Ruth, Debbie, Beth and Sherri and his grandchildren Zoe, Lani, Caroline, Michael, Rachel, Amanda and Rebecca. He will be sorely missed. Services today, at 12:45, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. The family will be sitting Shiva at 395 Southend Ave, Manhattan.

title: Meddling With the News
description: Despite a national election that was an international embarrassment, Republicans in Washington have been moving sluggishly, at best, toward electoral reform. But that has not stopped some Congressional leaders from using the election as an excuse for tampering with the most basic constitutional protections for a free press. Representative Billy Tauzin, a Louisiana Republican, has scheduled a hearing Wednesday with five network executives as part of a Congressional investigation into how television anchors projected winners on election night. Although Mr. Tauzin has repeatedly said he does not want to threaten the First Amendment with this investigation and hearing, he is doing exactly that. In a free society, the government should not try to intimidate or pressure the media into changing the way they go about reporting the news.

description: Big advertisers are making decisions on accounts.

title: Rangers Outplay the Devils But Still Can't Defeat Them
description: If they keep playing this well against the Devils, the Rangers are going to beat them -- one of these days, some kind of way. They played well enough to win yesterday at Madison Square Garden in a grueling 1-1 tie. The Rangers outshot the visitors and outhit them, too, while blocking more shots before they reached the goal crease.

title: Time-Tested Defense Expected as Terrorism Witness Returns
description: The testimony given by the first witness in the embassy bombings trial last week riveted the courtroom.

title: Phillips Talks About A Winter Defensive
description: From the desk in his second-floor office at Shea Stadium, Steve Phillips faces a wall with three framed Mets jerseys, Nos. 98, 99 and 00. They represent the three full seasons Phillips has been the general manager, and each one is covered with the autographs of the players on the opening day roster in those years.

title: As Assisted Living Centers Boom, Calls for Regulation Are Growing
description: If John Anselmo, 82, had entered a nursing home instead of Senior Quarters, odds are he would not have enjoyed the private room, sumptuous meals and rambling chats with nurses' aides that $3,500 a month bought him at the Great Neck, N.Y., residence for the elderly.

title: Adventure Gone Awry Divides Close Cousins
description: Katsuya Nomoto and Choichiro Yokoyama were not just cousins. They had been inseparable friends since childhood, playing the same sports, living as neighbors, sharing buddies and pursuing the same careers.

title: For the Microscopic Genome, It's a Big Moment in Biology
description: In keeping with the current fashionableness of all things Extreme -- Extreme Football, Extreme Wrestling and Extremely Large Tax Cuts -- scientists now present the Extreme Genome.

title: Software Start-Up Is Using Phone Message Technology
description: The NotifyMe Networks Corporation, a start-up software company with prominent investors, today will formally begin its effort to use the telephone and computerized voice messages to send alerts to users.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; By One Measure, Nasdaq Stocks Are Pricey Despite Drop
description: As the red ink flows -- in a somewhat hidden manner -- the Nasdaq 100 is setting new standards for a price-earnings ratio by a major index. The index is now trading at 811 times the combined earnings of the companies in the index.

title: New Political Field Challenges Labor Leaders
description: The nation's labor leaders gathering in Los Angeles tomorrow for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s winter meeting will devote much of their time to trying to figure out how to respond to the change in the political winds in Washington that has put them on the defensive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, IRENE
description: SEGAL-Irene. Devoted mother of Judge Marvin and Carole. Devoted sister of Mary Lawrence. Cherished grandmother of Joel Segal and Lisa and Evan Poczik. Loving great-grandmother of Jenna and Carly. With intelligence, humility, charm and kindness, she always put the well-being of others before herself. She will be profoundly missed and lovingly remembered. Services private.

title: First Line of Defense; Chief Privacy Officers Forge Evolving Corporate Roles
description: Jules Polonetsky has the power of life and death. Over contracts, anyway.

title: When the Luster Dims and the Hollywood Stars Fade
description: The last time we saw Elizabeth Taylor on television, as a presenter at the Golden Globe awards last month, she was so addled that viewers could only wonder what was wrong. Shirley MacLaine recently directed and appeared in a charming film, ''Bruno,'' that went straight to cable; she is more visible mocking her past lives in television commercials for Visa.

title: Essay; Sharon The Unifier
description: ''The Israeli nation needs unity,'' said Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon, continuing our phone conversation, ''to try to overcome all the hatred and the unbelievable splits. Arguments have always been part of political life here, but never as bad as this.

title: Kitty Buck, 93, Who Founded Cake Masters Bakery Chain
description: Kitty Buck, who with her husband, Otto, ran Cake Masters Bakery, an institution on the Upper West Side of Manhattan that made cakes for Liberace, President Kennedy and Elizabeth Taylor -- and for less famous families' celebrations -- for more than half a century, died on Jan. 9 in Oceanside, N.Y.

title: Online Tour of the Human Genome Is Just a Few Clicks Away
description: All humans with Internet access can treat themselves to an astounding tour of their species' genome, courtesy of the web browser written by James Kent for the University of California at Santa Cruz. If the human genome sequence is the terrain, the browser lets the viewer fly above it with enough perspective to see major features like the gene-coding regions. You can also zoom down to the level of DNA and see the mind-numbing data stream that biologists are trying to interpret.

title: Clients clip their budgets, the dot-coms atomize and Madison Avenue retrenches.
description: AS concern mounts about the slowing economy's impact on advertising, widespread layoffs are becoming commonplace on Madison Avenue for the first time since the mid-1990's, when the industry emerged from a severe downturn.

title: A Bit of Hypocrisy Makes the Politician
description: To the Editor:
