description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001021392096987065 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: The Unglamorous Mad Dash of It All
description: Of the Glazed if Discriminating Eye

title: Icy Pluto's Fall From the Planetary Ranks: A Conversation
description: News that astrophysicists at the American Museum of Natural History do not consider Pluto a planet spurred more than 100 e-mail messages, some critical, some supportive, to Dr. Neil de Grasse Tyson, director of the museum's Hayden Planetarium. The museum is now considering changing its exhibits slightly to explain its views to confused visitors.

title: Scams Point the Desperate To Nonexistent Assistance
description: Pete Cooper, president of the Community Foundation of Greater Chattanooga, makes grants to nonprofit groups in his southern Tennessee county.

title: For Silence, Just Add Noise
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUMHOLZ, MARVIN
description: KRUMHOLZ - Marvin. Dearest husband of the late Shirley. Beloved father of Drs. Ellen and David Mandel and Dr. Martin and Susan Shulman. Adored grandpa of Leigh, Susannah, Lawrence, Dina and Andrew. Much loved uncle of many nieces and nephews. Services on Wednesday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Top Marine Clears Osprey's Design in Crash
description: The Marine Corps has conclusively determined that the Dec. 11 crash of a V-22 Osprey that killed four marines was a result of hydraulic and computer failures, not the aircraft's hybrid tilt-rotor design, the commandant of the corps said today.

title: Manners as a Harbinger
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: For Silence, Just Add Noise
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Killer Is Transferred To Camden
description: One of New Jersey's most notorious inmates, Thomas Trantino, the convicted killer of two police officers, was moved to a halfway house in Camden late Sunday night after spending 37 years in state prisons.

title: Abusers Go Unpunished
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Care Is Theme of Senator Clinton's First Floor Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  In her first address from the floor of the United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton today offered a broad agenda of health care initiatives, casting herself as a moderate on the very issue that resulted in one of her most embarrassing defeats as first lady.

title: Named for Both Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Bench Needs a Raise, Bar Groups Say in Report
description: Salaries of federal judges may get a boost as a result of efforts by lawyers and judges to focus attention on the disparity between judges' wages and the compensation that lawyers in private practice receive.

title: Israel Hunts Down and Kills a Top Arafat Security Officer
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 13  Two Israeli helicopter gunships swooped over northern Gaza this morning and dropped four missiles on the car of a senior Palestinian security officer, instantly killing a man whom Israel considered a terrorist in a uniform and a beret.

title: Bush, in Break With Pentagon, Urges New Weapons Systems
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 13  President Bush said today that he planned to break with Pentagon orthodoxy and create "a new architecture for defense of our people," investing in new technologies and weapons systems, rather than make what he called "marginal improvements" in systems in which America's arms industry has already invested billions of dollars.

title: Like a Genie, So Elusive And Loose
description: You can see the genie but not the bottle in the tap dancing of Tamango, previously known as Herbin Van Cayseele. Like all great dancers, he has a signature style but never ceases to surprise. Don't miss him.

title: Clinton's Pardons, Bush's Giveaways
description: To the Editor:

title: Surveys to Gauge Public's Perception of Police
description: Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik offered a detailed picture yesterday of the ''neighborhood satisfaction surveys'' the Police Department will conduct as part of his efforts to improve relations with New Yorkers, who he said should be treated like ''customers.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, EDWARD E.
description: FITZGERALD-Edward E., 81. Of Eastchester, died on February 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Libuse Ostruk Fitzgerald. Devoted father of Eileen Fitzgerald and her husband Paul Rosenblum, and Kevin and his wife Linda Fitzgerald. Cherished grandfather of Leona Rosenblum. He was a noted writer, editor and former president of the Book of the Month Club. The family will receive friends at the Westchester Funeral Home, Inc. Eastchester, Tuesday 2-4 & 7-9PM. Service at the funeral home, Wednesday, February 14 at 11 AM.

title: Searching for an Inner Self From a Bronx Perspective
description: Toward the very end of her one-woman show Annie Korzen portrays an elderly Danish widow reading from a letter to Ms. Korzen's husband, a Jew whom the woman, a Christian, helped shelter from the Nazis in Denmark when he was a boy during World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, PHYLLIS SARI
description: LEVY-Phyllis Sari. A wonderful woman in all respects. Peaceful now, after a long illness. Survived by her adored mother, Ruth Jaffe, her dear sister, Susan, and brother-in-law, Paul. Services private.

title: Top Shelf Is Good And Bad For Richter
description: Mike Richter is playing so well, he might be playing his way right out of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNEO, GLORIA F. (NEE BRITTING)
description: CUNEO-Gloria F. (nee Britting). Of Westbury, L.I., formerly of The Bronx, N.Y. on Feburary 11, 2001. Beloved wife of John A. Cuneo, Jr. Devoted mother of Richard A. Cuneo. She was a Co-Founder and General Secretary of the Catholic Traditionalist Movement (CTM). Reposing at Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave, Westbury, L.I. Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30PM. Traditional Latin Roman Catholic Requiem Funeral Mass Thursday, 10AM, Ave Maria Chapel, 210 Maple Ave, Westbury, L.I. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Absence of Urgency: A Deadly Problem When Strokes Occur
description: Of the estimated 730,000 Americans who have strokes each year, nearly 160,000 die and another 400,000 suffer varying degrees of disability. Yet, when stroke patients arrive at emergency rooms, medical experts say, they are not usually treated with the urgency required.

title: Health Care Is Theme of Senator Clinton's First Floor Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  In her first address from the floor of the United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton today offered a broad agenda of health care initiatives, casting herself as a moderate on the very issue that resulted in one of her most embarrassing defeats as first lady.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, JANE
description: ALTMAN-Jane. On February 11, 2001. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Service 10AM today, Schwartz Bros, Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Music as Medicine and Minstrel as Therapist
description: She does not start IV's or check vital signs, but she is a new key member of the Infusion Room staff at Creticos Cancer Center in Chicago. And for a stethoscope slung over her shoulders, she has substituted a guitar.

title: A Big Night for a Little Schnauzer
description: The first night of the 125th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show began with class: a dog sang ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' The tuneful howls of Shasta, an Alaskan malamute, properly known as Ch. Snowlion's King of the Pride, demonstrated a keen mastery of pitch.

title: Nets' Marbury Alights From Cloud Nine
description: With two shots on Sunday, Stephon Marbury seemingly rocketed to the rafters, floating in euphoria.

title: Los Angeles Cardinal Regrets Role in Pardon
description: Cardinal Roger Mahoney of Los Angeles said today that he regretted having written a letter to President Bill Clinton on behalf of a man who had been convicted of involvement in a drug-dealing operation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUDSON, PAUL
description: JUDSON-Paul. Died February 9, 2001 in Pinehurst, NC. He attended Pascedina Playhouse, had a long and outstanding career both as singer and actor. Toured with Spike Jones Band. Later years he became a teaching golf pro in Manhattan. He sang in many night clubs in the US and he was seen in many television commercials. Survived by daughter Terri Milligan of Oakdale, NY; sister Genevieve Chorba, and two grandchildren. Memorials may be made to a favorite charity. For information Powell in Southern Pines, N.C., call 1-800-765-0630.

title: Take That, Giuliani: Bratton Endorses Green
description: William J. Bratton, the former New York City police commissioner, endorsed Mark Green's campaign for mayor yesterday, coming to Mr. Green's aid as he sought for the second time in a week to burnish his anticrime credentials in his campaign to succeed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about tensions between young Albanian immigrants and other ethnic groups in the Bronx gave a misspelled surname in some copies for a 15-year-old Albanian student who was suspended after a brawl. He is Ylli Mujaj, not Mujai.

title: Q & A
description: Clearing the Air

title: Harlem's Executive Perks? Park View, Golden Arches
description: On 125th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues, you can pawn jewelry, get advice from a spiritual healer and choose among any number of hair braiding salons and 99-cent novelty stores. On the same strip, you can listen to jazz, have a Starbucks latte or dine on ethnic cuisine in newly opened, votive-lighted restaurants and cafes.

title: Public Interests; Fly the Lonely Skies
description: The great thing about the airline industry is that politicians take it so personally.

title: Clinton's Pardons, Bush's Giveaways
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NESS, ARTHUR GRAHAM
description: NESS-Arthur Graham. Age 82, Saturday, February 10, in Montclair, NJ. Vice President of Chemical Bank. Survived by his wife of 53 years, Laurel, and daughters Francine, Carolyn and Lorna. Memorial service Friday, February 16, 10:30 AM, Union Congregational Church, 176 Cooper Ave., Upper Montclair. Donations may be made to the Montclair Volunteer Ambulance Unit, 86 Valley Road, Montclair, New Jersey 07042.

title: Criticized on Office Rent, Clinton Looks to Harlem
description: Faced with a barrage of criticism for his decision to rent lavish office space in Manhattan, former President Bill Clinton yesterday abandoned his plans to move into the 56th floor of a Midtown skyscraper. He is now looking uptown, at more modest space on Harlem's main shopping boulevard, with equally panoramic views.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, IRVING SAMUEL
description: ELIAS-Irving Samuel. Cherished and beloved husband of Charlotte, devoted loving father of Gale (Ken), Shari (Mitchell) and Sam; adored grandfather of Colby, Harry, Samara, Chloe and Brant; passed on Sunday, February 11, 2001. His kindness, inner beauty, wisdom, sense of humor and strength were an inspiration to all who knew him. It is with deepest sorrow that we mourn him. He will be in our hearts forever. Funeral service Wednesday, February 14, 11:45 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUPPUCH, WINFIELD II
description: HUPPUCH-Winfield II in Wenham, MA., February 8, 2001, former Tax Attorney and formerly of Salem, N.Y. Husband of Helen E. (McMahan) Huppuch. Son of the late Frank and Helen (Packer) Huppuch. Father of Winfield III, William, Frank, & Thomas Huppuch, Helen Mulry, Alice Gallasch and Katherine Holland. As requested there are no visiting hours, and a memorial service will be held at a later date. For information C.R. Lyons & Sons, Funeral Directors, Danvers, MA.

title: It May Be Now or Never for a Mission to Pluto
description: Depending on what NASA decides at the end of the summer, scientists hoping for a close-up look at Pluto may have to wait another 10 to 20 years -- or they may have to wait a very, very long time.

title: Both Sides Courting Sharpton On School Privatization Plan
description: Supporters and opponents of a plan to privatize five New York City schools have begun courting the Rev. Al Sharpton, who they believe could sway many of the parents who will be deciding the fate of the project next month.

title: Keenan Returns, Still Flinty and Still a Winner
description: The conga line of coaches and general managers in the National Hockey League undulates like a column of children playing crack-the-whip on the neighborhood skating rink. Sometimes, the ones in the back are snapped off by centrifugal force.

title: To Combat the Wily H.I.V., Newer and Safer Drugs Are Necessary
description: An arsenal of 15 drugs would seem ample to treat a disease successfully. But not AIDS.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Napster Suffers Setback In Appeals Court Ruling

description: To the Editor:

title: Text of the Ruling by the 9th Circuit Court
description: The following text is from the decision by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in the recording industry's case against Napster. The opinion was written by Senior Judge Robert R. Beezer, who was joined by Judges Mary M. Schroeder and Richard A. Paez.

description: The Pittsburgh Penguins aren't worried about Mario Lemieux's sore back -- yet.

title: In Speech, Bush Charts New Course for Military
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 13  President Bush said today that he planned to break with Pentagon orthodoxy and create "a new architecture for the defense of America and our allies," investing in new technologies and weapons systems rather than making "marginal improvements" for systems in which America's arms industry has invested billions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAKE, JOHN B.
description: LEAKE-John B. On February 10, 2001 of Villanova, PA. Husband of Jane (Whitridge), father of Alexandra and Joan. Also survived by a granddaughter, two step granddaughters, his brother Eugene and numerous nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 3, 2001 at 11AM at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church, 226 Righters Mill Road, Gladwyne. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Philadelphia Orchestra, 250 South Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19102. For further information call Stuard Funeral Home at 610-649-0243.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, PEARL
description: SOBEL-Pearl. On February 12, 2001, after a long and blessed life, Pearl Orloff Sobel passed away peacefully after a brief illness. She is survived by her husband of sixty-two years, Gerson, her children, James, Judith, and Thomas, and her grandchildren, Paul, Eric, Lisa, David, and Daniel. Energetic and vigorous to the end, Pearl loved her family and friends. She held records as a Master Swimmer in the 100 Medley and 50 Butterfly, a feat made even more remarkable by the fact that she did not even begin to swim until she was over sixty-five. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, February 14th, 2:30 P.M. at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, RVC.

title: SCHLUMBERGER TO ACQUIRE SEMA
description: Schlumberger, the American energy services company that has begun branching into technology services, confirmed that it had reached an agreement to acquire Sema, the British-French information technology company, for 3.6 billion ($5.3 billion), or 560 pence a share. With the acquisition, Schlumberger makes perhaps its largest expansion into technology services, which include smart-card operations in Europe. Schlumberger said it expected to increase revenue by selling some of its products to Sema's customers. It also said the value of the deal represented a 42 percent premium to the closing price of Sema shares on Feb. 2, the last day of trading before Sema said it had been approached by bidders. Shares of Sema surged 13 percent. Suzanne Kapner

title: APPELLATE JUDGES BACK LIMITATIONS ON COPYING MUSIC
description: A Federal appeals court dealt a major setback today to Napster, the start-up that has shaken the record industry by allowing millions of people to copy music free over the Internet, by largely affirming a lower-court ruling that the company encourages and abets the wholesale infringement of copyrights.

title: Nathan Cohen, 91; Helped Reshape Social Work
description: Nathan Edward Cohen, who helped shape professional social work in the United States, died on Jan. 27 at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 91.

title: Second Quake in One Month Kills More Than 100 in El Salvador
description: SAN SALVADOR, Feb. 13  A powerful earthquake struck El Salvador this morning.

title: CLAIMING THEIR SHARE: A special report.; Women in Sports Cultivating New Playing Fields
description: Kirsten McKnight, once a guard on the University of Oregon women's basketball team, is now an assistant coach with the Ducks. She is also studying for a graduate degree at Oregon, with the goal of someday working as an executive in a professional league.

title: Music as Medicine and Minstrel as Therapist
description: She does not start IV's or check vital signs, but she is a new key member of the Infusion Room staff at Creticos Cancer Center in Chicago. And for a stethoscope slung over her shoulders, she has substituted a guitar.

title: Dozens of Afghans Are Dying in the Cold, U.N. Says
description: Dozens of Afghan children, exhausted from long journeys with their families to seek food and shelter, have frozen to death at makeshift refugee camps in recent weeks, United Nations and private aid officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday and in some late editions on Sunday about the first analysis of the human genome compared the number of genes in humans and roundworms incorrectly. Humans have about 50 percent more genes, not just one-third more.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURNIT, SHEPARD
description: KURNIT-Shepard. Memorial service will be at the W New York Hotel, 541 Lexington Ave. (50th St.), on February 16 at 10:30 AM.

title: A Carnegie Connection, Then and Now
description: It was only after the artistic directors of Carnegie Hall had begun to plan a weekend festival devoted to the music of John Cage and Morton Feldman that they discovered something almost too good to be true: these two experimental composers first met at Carnegie Hall.

title: M.I.T. Professor Reconsiders Children's Online Lives
description: There are few neighborhoods left where children can meet their pals after school for a friendly game of kickball in a vacant lot. Parents should accept this reality of contemporary life and understand that the virtual world can be a boon to today's latchkey child.

title: A Wise Plan for 'Head Start'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Elsa Klensch, Still in Style, but Out of a Job
description: THE out-of-work icon of television fashion journalism tucks her legs up beneath her and assumes a comfy pose on the living room sofa. Evidently, feet-on-the-furniture etiquette is not frowned upon in Elsa Klensch's Orient-inspired domain overlooking the Museum of Modern Art's unsightly construction site. ''Everything's higgledy-pig gledy,'' she apologizes.

title: Music and Science Meet on a Piano Bench
description: After reverently shaking hands with the great pianists Josef Hofmann and Leopold Godowsky at a party, a fan was struck that the men's hands were rather small. ''How can you great artists play the piano so magnificently with such small hands?'' the woman asked. Godowsky replied, ''Where in the world did you get the idea that we play the piano with our hands?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, ALAYNE
description: SCHORR-Alayne. Beloved mother of Carla Rose and Lisa. Devoted companion of Charles Nurse. Dear sister of Cynthia Feiner. Loving grandmother of Jasper Rose, adored cousin of Lenore Safier. Services Tuesday, 11:30AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: Headache May Lurk Inside a Sandwich
description: For some people who suffer from recurring headaches, the culprit could be as close as the sandwich in their hands or the pasta on their plates.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''While you're serving us well, America is not serving you well.''

title: 'Gladiator' Captures 12 Oscar Nominations
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13  Exceeding the nominations reaped by "American Beauty" last year, "Gladiator," another DreamWorks release, captured 12 nominations today for the 2001 Academy Awards, including best picture, best original screenplay and best director for Ridley Scott.

title: Shares of Emulex Plunge On Warning of Slowdown
description: Shares of the Emulex Corporation fell 48 percent, dragging down other computer data storage companies, after the company said a slump in demand might cause its third-quarter profit to come in below forecasts.

title: A Longtime Friend of Powell Is Tapped to Be His Deputy
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell once said of his friend, Richard L. Armitage, ''I would trust him with my life, my children, my reputation, everything I have.''

title: Jets' Staff Signals Intention To Build Through the Draft
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards repairs to his nearby hotel room for only about five hours a day, spending the rest of his time hunkered down in meetings that will soon give shape to the future of the team. There is little time for sleep and none for house hunting.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MUNIAUCTION, Pittsburgh, which handled the first municipal bond auction over the Internet in November 1997, said it had changed its name to the Grant Street Group to emphasize its move beyond selling municipal bonds on the Internet.

title: On Africa's Caravan Trail
description: In a corner of Niger that was once a vast sea, dozens of families mine salt, and are the inheritors of a caravan trade that brought life to the Sahara for centuries. Page A12.

title: An Online Tour of the Human Genome Is Just a Few Clicks Away
description: People who have Internet connections can treat themselves to an astounding tour of their species' genome, courtesy of the U.C.S.C. Web browser written by James Kent. If the human genome sequence is the terrain, the browser lets the viewer fly above it with enough perspective to see major features like the gene-coding regions. You can also zoom down the level of DNA and see the mind-numbing data stream that biologists are trying to interpret.

title: It's All Up in the Air As Second Act Starts
description: When everyone is bemoaning what's wrong with professional basketball, Allen Iverson weaves his way through mounds of muscle to show what is still special about the National Basketball Association: a phenomenal athlete turning a dead-quiet arena into Smackdown 2001.

title: METLIFE RECEIVES FED APPROVAL TO BUY GRAND BANK
description: MetLife has received the Federal Reserve Board's approval to buy Grand Bank of Kingston, N.J., the federal agency said yesterday. MetLife, based in New York, plans to use the bank to offer banking and investment services to its customers, especially those who receive insurance payouts. Grand Bank, which opened in February 1999, provides banking services to individuals and small businesses in Princeton, N.J., and the surrounding area. It has assets of $83.8 million, according to the Federal Reserve's bank order.

title: FOSTER'S POSTS PROFIT
description: The Foster's Brewing Group has reported operating profit of 293.1 million Australian dollars ($158 million), a 20.5 percent rise for the six months ended Dec. 31. Sales rose 21.6 percent to 2 billion Australian dollars. Growth in the wine division, powered by its $1.6 billion acquisition in October of Beringer Wine Estates, underpinned the result. Wine group profit rose 89 percent. Beringer's contribution to earnings, which began in October, was 63.7 million Australian dollars ($34.4 million), and beat forecasts. Becky Gaylord

title: Foreign Affairs; Space Rangers
description: It's only a month into the Bush administration and I'm already tired of listening to its foreign policy. Because it seems to be focused on only one idea, which, so far, doesn't work -- building a ''Star Wars'' missile shield -- against an enemy that, so far, doesn't exist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISLES, JULIE
description: ISLES-Julie. On February 10, 2001 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of Herb Pomerantz, dear sister of Rebecca Bakunin, loving aunt of Debra, Jane and Nancy. Retired sportswear designer for Christian Dior. Services today, 11:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Jagged Figures in 9 Minutes, Then a Warm Collective Tone for the Titans
description: In assembling the program it performed at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, the Emerson String Quartet set the bar typically high. Its curtain raiser was Gyorgy Kurtag's ''Hommage  Mihaly Andras,'' a short, densely concentrated work that, at nine minutes, was overshadowed by the two titanic scores that shared the bill: 10 of the fugues and canons from Bach's ''Art of the Fugue'' and Beethoven's Quartet in B flat (Op. 130), with the ''Grosse Fuge'' (Op. 133) restored to its original place as the quartet's finale.

title: Canadian Cable TV Deal
description: Alliance Atlantis Communications agreed today to buy Salter Street Films for about 71.1 million Canadian dollars ($46.7 million) in cash and stock to gain comedy programs and specialty cable television channels. Alliance offered 3.33 Canadian dollars in cash plus 0.31 of a Class B share for every Salter Street share, valuing Salter Street at about 8.63 Canadian dollars a share. That's a 31 percent premium to Friday's close. Shareholders can opt to take 0.465 of an Alliance share for every Salter Street share. Salter Street had about 8.24 million shares outstanding in its most recent quarter. Salter Street, based in Halifax, Nova Scotia, produces the popular Canadian television satire show ''This Hour Has 22 Minutes.'' Alliance, which is based in Toronto, is a film producer and distributor.

title: A Wise Plan for 'Head Start'?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUCKING COMPANY LAYS OFF ANOTHER 160 EMPLOYEES
description: The Yellow Corporation, a trucking company, said yesterday that it had laid off 160 managers, or about 4 percent of its executive work force, because demand had slowed with the economy. Yellow said it might recall the managers, 100 at field locations and 60 at its Overland Park, Kan., headquarters, in 90 days if economic conditions improve. The company also laid off 75 managers on Jan. 12. And 1,000 Teamsters, or 5 percent of Yellow's union work force, remain on a furlough that began late last year.

title: AMAZON TO OFFER DOWNLOADS
description: Amazon.com has decided that even overnight delivery is not fast enough for some people. The online retailer began offering a software downloading service yesterday that allows customers to buy some software online and then to start using the products almost immediately. The announcement of the new service, which is called the Software Downloads Store, is timed to take advantage of tax-filing season, when many people are seeking fast access to software that is used in tax preparation. The company is also selling several other kinds of programs electronically. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, HARRY S.
description: REISMAN-Harry S. Of Riverdale, NY. Husband of Rita. Loving father of Mona Favreau (Larry Sashin) and Arlene Reisman. Cherished grandfather of Matthew and Josh. Funeral services Tuesday 11:30AM at the Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Yonkers, New York.

title: Man Killed in Fall at Metropolitan Museum
description: A 23-year-old air-conditioning maintenance worker fell to his death from the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday morning while performing a regular weekly inspection, the police said.

title: China Begins to Shine Light on Use of Torture
description: Soon after his arrest on trumped-up charges, Li Kuisheng was beaten to a bloody mess.

title: Dogs' Potential for Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Microscopic Genome, It's a Big Moment in Biology
description: In keeping with the current fashionableness of all things Extreme  Extreme Football, Extreme Wrestling and Extremely Large Tax Cuts  scientists now present the Extreme Genome.

title: Airlines Fail to Ease the Distress of Flight Delays, Report Says
description: Despite promises by airlines to treat passengers better, they do a poor job of making delays more tolerable by keeping customers informed and setting policies to put them up in hotels overnight and meet their basic needs, a report ordered by Congress and released today said.

title: Pardon Investigators to Issue Subpoenas
description: Congressional investigators said tonight that they would issue several subpoenas in their investigation of President Bill Clinton's last-minute pardon of Marc Rich to determine whether there had been any connection between the pardon and money being raised for Mr. Clinton's presidential library in Little Rock, Ark.

title: New Governor Faces Questions About Bailout on Defaulted Loan
description: Less than two weeks after being sworn in, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco is already discovering how hot it can feel under the spotlight.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Honoring the Man In White, Fully

title: E.A.B. Purchase Lets Citibank Expand Long Island Presence
description: In a transaction that greatly expands its presence on Long Island, Citibank said yesterday that it had agreed to buy European American Bank from ABN Amro Bank for $1.6 billion in cash, and that it would assume responsibility for $350 million in European American preferred stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTONE, ZELDA
description: BLUESTONE-Zelda. Died Feb. 10, 2001 in Boston, MA. Cherished wife & best friend of Irving for over sixty years. Beloved mother of Barry, Maura and Karen. Precious mother-in-law of Mary Ellen Colten, Robert Greifinger & Bruce Cohen. Adored Nana of Joshua, Rena, Liza & Alex. Zelda was a sparkling, compasssionate, loving woman. We are all the lucky beneficiaries of her wisdom and endless humor. She will be forever missed by her family and wide circle of loving firends. Donations in her memory may be made to Recording for the Blind, 5600 Rochester Road, Troy, MI. 48098.

title: Former Brokerage Officers Convicted of Fraud
description: A federal jury convicted Michael S. DeVegter, a former vice president of Stephens Inc., a Little Rock, Ark., brokerage firm, and Richard P. Poirier, a former vice president of Lazard Frres & Company, of fraud charges related to a $163 million bond deal in Fulton County, Ga.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, BERTHA
description: TAUB-Bertha. At age 93. Formerly of Merrick, LI, and Bay Harbor Island, FL. Wife of 57 years of the late Murray. Mother of Judy Dworken and the late Natalie Keyser. Grandmother of Chris Keyser, Stephanie Keyser, Jonathan Dworken, Sara Dworken. Great-grandmother of Madeline, Benjamin, Michael, David, Aaron and Simon. Rest in peace, Mom.

title: Grad Student Becomes Gene Effort's Unlikely Hero
description: A surprising hero helped the consortium of academic scientists decoding the human genome to avoid a drubbing by its rival, the Celera Genomics company. Scientists throughout the world are now beating an electronic path to his Web site, where they can analyze and download the human genome sequence. He is a graduate student at the University of California at Santa Cruz, and his name is not Clark but James Kent.

title: High School Girl Sets Meet Record
description: Tawana Watkins, a 17-year-old junior at Kennedy High School in Paterson, N.J., made her first effort last night in the 800 meters at the Varsity Classic a memorable one. She registered the fastest time in the nation this year when she won in 2 minutes 9.6 seconds, breaking the meet record by more than eight seconds.

title: Pardoning in Secret
description: As Congress continues to investigate Bill Clinton's pardon of Marc Rich, the fugitive financier, it might be worth asking how such a controversy can be avoided in the future.

title: Osaka Journal; Japanese Date Clubs Take the Muss Out of Mating
description: With its blue tobacco haze, mellow jazz and slick decor, the Tu-Ba Cafe looks, at first glance, like any singles bar anywhere.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Debt Rating For Lucent Is Cut Again
description: The news continues to worsen for Lucent Technologies, which has been effectively shut out of the short-term financing market.

title: Four Nights in Bangkok
description: It's a long way to go, and for a relatively short stay, but the price looks good. Singapore Airlines Exotic Bangkok package includes round-trip air fare to Bangkok, four nights at the Peninsula Bangkok or Royal Orchard Sheraton, daily breakfast and a half-day tour of the Grand Palace. The price: from $988 with departures from Los Angeles, $1,060 from San Francisco and $1,080 out of Newark or Kennedy. Those are per person, based on double occupancy, and do not include departure taxes. Black-out dates and other restrictions apply. See a travel agent or contact Asian Affair Holidays at (800) 742-3133.

title: Eagles Take Home Beanpot Trophy
description: Propelled by its underclassmen, Boston College proved tonight that the adage that wisdom comes from experience was not entirely accurate by defeating Boston University, 5-3, to win the 49th Beanpot Tournament and end the Terriers' run of six straight titles.

title: An Irrational Case of Dread
description: President Bush is concerned about the state of the United States economy, and so is Alan Greenspan. With such prominent voices expressing worry, it may seem heretical to dispute the idea that the economy is in trouble. But before Americans get too gloomy, they should step back and examine the situation carefully. I think they will find that while being alert is fine, panicking is ill-advised.

title: Work Out at 80? Experts See the Gains
description: Exercise, even late in life, has repeatedly been found to improve people's health in a number of ways, including reducing the risk of heart disease and broken bones.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Tuesday about a translator of works by Dostoyevsky, Mikhail Bulgakov and Isaac Ba shevis Singer misspelled her surname. She was Mirra Ginsburg, not Ginsberg.

title: N.B.A. Joins the Trend Of All-Star Ratings Fall
description: Despite the Eastern Conference's stirring comeback to win the National Basketball Association All-Star Game on NBC Sunday night, the overnight Nielsen rating fell 17 percent, to a 6.9 from an 8.3 last year.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The euro rose after finance ministers said economic growth in Europe would not slow as much as in the United States. In New York, the euro settled at 93.09 cents, up from 92.58 cents on Friday.

title: Tunnel Vision; Leisurely Rush Hour on City's Other Subway
description: It was rush hour yesterday, just after 9 a.m. This is what the subway looked like:

title: ANADARKO MAKES BERKLEY BID
description: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation has agreed to buy the Berkley Petroleum Corporation of Calgary, Alberta, for 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($777 million), or 11.40 Canadian dollars a share, topping by 9 percent a hostile bid by the Hunt Petroleum Corporation. Berkley will become part of Anadarko Canada, also based in Calgary. Jim Emme, president of the Canadian unit, said the deal ''accelerates our long-term strategy by about three years.'' Timothy Pritchard

title: Article 2001021391708983549 -- No Title
description: February 12, 2001

title: Devil Is in the Details: A Stageful of Ballerinas
description: George Balanchine was choreographically impish in one of the works the New York City Ballet performed on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. And he was angelic in another.

title: AGIP of Italy Picked to Manage Big Kazakh Oil Field
description: After weeks of jockeying for position by its members, the consortium preparing to undertake a huge oil field development in the Caspian Sea made the surprising choice of AGIP S.p.A. of Italy, the smallest of four candidates, as the company that will manage the project.

title: From Handel to 'Circus Orchestra,' at Lincoln Center
description: For its 2001-2 season, Lincoln Center's Great Performers series will present some 115 events, including series on the music of Rachmaninoff, Handel and Shostakovich, and the interdisciplinary New Visions series.

title: Runyan to Try for Record In 5,000 at the Armory
description: Marla Runyan no longer feels challenged by the 1,500 meters.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern and charges of discrimination in his department gave a misspelled surname in some copies for a lawyer and former Central Park Conservancy chairman who defended Mr. Stern. He is Ira Millstein, not Milstein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARLES, L. ROBERT
description: CHARLES-L. Robert. On February 10, 2001, at age 72. Beloved husband of Barbara Charles. Loving father of Frederick Charles and grandfather of Ian Robert and Clara Mary Charles. Devoted son of Helena and the late Leon Cieciuch. Dear brother of Sr. Jorene Cieciuch, O.P., and Richard Cieciuch. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Jean the Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76th St, Thursday, 11 AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 6931 Arlington Rd, Bethesda, MD 20814.

title: A Wise Plan for 'Head Start'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Gunship Missiles Kill Palestinian Security Officer
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 13  Two Israeli helicopter gunships swooped over northern Gaza this morning and dropped four missiles on the car of a senior Palestinian security officer, killing instantly a man that Israel considered a terrorist in a colonel's uniform.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Sahara Salt Mine, Life's Not Too Grim
description: The sun was setting on this ancient oasis in the Sahara the other day, as the villagers trudged across the sand to their mud homes. But on Bilma's edge, away from the date palms that cast long shadows and thwart the great desert's advance, a husband and wife were toiling together in a salt pit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, DINA P. (NEE PERINI)
description: NOLAN-Dina P. (nee Perini). Beloved wife of the late Thomas. Devoted sister of the late Aldo, Lino and Lydia DeMartino. Devoted mother of Debra Pocci and Kevin. Loving grandmother of Leslie, Kathryn and Melissa. Reposing at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NY Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9:30PM. Funeral Mass Thursday 10AM at Our Lady of Pompei Church, NYC. Entombment Ferncliff Mausoleum.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Friday showing how President Bush's proposed tax cut would affect 14 hypothetical households misstated the figures for a married couple with two children and a gross income of $20,000 a year before deductions. Correcting its model yesterday, the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche said that such a couple, claiming the dependent child care credit, would realize no tax saving -- not $33 in the first year and $168 when the tax plan was fully phased in.

title: Decisions About Sonar Use Are at Issue in Investigation of Submarine Accident
description: The Navy submarine that abruptly surfaced on Friday and sank a Japanese fishing boat off Hawaii was following standard procedures and did not use highly accurate active sonar devices that might have better detected that the vessel was near, Navy officials said today.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: EDGAR, BOTH FREE AND FEE FreeEdgar will no longer be free. Sort of. Executives at FreeEdgar's parent company, Edgar Online, said yesterday that users seeking e-mail alerts on the filing of Securities and Exchange Commission documents on more than five companies will now have to pay $9.95 per month. Users who list fewer companies will still receive the alerts free, company officials said. The move was made in an attempt to cover costs. Nearly 100,000 people have signed up for the so-called watch lists, according to officials at Edgar Online, which is based in South Norwalk, Conn. On Feb. 1, Edgar Online, which also runs the sites www.ipo-express.com, www.inside-trader.com and www.compensation-express.com, reported a net loss of $15.1 million on gross revenues of $10.4 million last year. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: The Week in Science: Fewer Than We Thought
description: This past week's big news - which would have dropped on Monday, February 12 if the London Observer had been able to resist breaking the embargo - was the first look at the human genome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, SHEILA
description: FREEMAN-Sheila. Loving and beautiful wife of Harvey. Beloved mother of Valerie and Eric. Daughter of Frances. Dear sister of Arnold and Anne. Adored aunt and devoted friend to many. She touched everyone with her extraordinary intelligence, kindness, humility and warmth. Her generous and relentless spirit will always be with us through the sensitive and beautiful poems she wrote. In lieu of flowers, donations to the animal charity of your choice. Services to be held Wednesday at 2PM at Menorah Chapels, Inc., 2145 Richmond Avenue, Staten Island.

title: Bush Seeks $5.7 Billion Increase For Military Salaries and Benefits
description: Even as conservatives in Congress pressed for more money for the military, President Bush today proposed shifting $5.7 billion in Pentagon spending for increased pay, improved health care and better housing, warning that substandard benefits and aging barracks were taxing soldiers and their families.

title: British Company Reports Option to Costly Genzyme Drug
description: One of the most expensive drugs in the world, Cerezyme, made by the Genzyme Corporation, could soon face competition. Oxford GlycoSciences, a British biotechnology company, announced yesterday that patients taking its experimental drug for Gaucher disease were able to remain off Cerezyme, the only approved treatment, for the six-month duration of a clinical trial.

title: Terror Exports Are the Business Of Jihad Inc.
description: When the business was just a start-up, the boss had the first office on the left as you entered the eight- or nine-room headquarters on McNimr Street in downtown Khartoum, Sudan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVY, ROBERT
description: NOVY-Robert. Beloved husband of Tina (Nee Gelson), son of Dot and Ray, brother of Mickey, uncle of Donna and Tim, son-in-law of Nellie Gelson, died on February 11, 2001 in Staten Island, New York. Bob was a Police Officer for over 27 years. Presently the Vice-President Northern Region of the Metropolitan Transporation Authority PBA, formerly President of the Metro North PBA, member of the PCNY, Metropolitan Police Conf., FOP, Affiliated Police Assoc. of Westchester Co., and IPA. His presence will be missed but his impression will be indelible. Reposing at Colonial Funeral Home, 2819 Hylan Blvd, SI, NY, Wed and Thurs 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 10:30 AM Holy Rosary Church. Interment Resurrection Cemetery.

title: Accounts
description: HomePortfolio, Newton, Mass., which operates a home design Web site, to Ideate, Watertown, Mass., to handle its account, which had been at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: It's No Fun if You've Outlived Them All
description: The Glyndebourne Festival Opera in England operates in near-ideal summer festival conditions that would seem hard to transfer elsewhere. So when the production of Janacek's ''Makropulos Case'' that opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday night is billed as the Glyndebourne's first United States engagement, this must be taken in context.

title: U.S. Coach In England To Scout
description: BRUCE ARENA, coach of the United States men's team, was in England last weekend scouting a handful of American players who could be on the roster for World Cup qualifying matches.

description: A chart with the Baseball Notebook article on Sunday showing the reporting dates for spring training was printed in error. It gave last year's dates. A corrected version appears today, on Page D7.

title: Precision In Presenting The Funky And the Lush
description: The Dallas Symphony Orchestra's Carnegie Hall concert on Friday night made a convincing case for the unusual position that an entire evening of 20th-century music, some of it completely unfamiliar, can truly entertain an audience. There were two New York premieres of American works -- Cindy McTee's ''Timepiece,'' commissioned for the orchestra's centenary last year, and the Second Piano Concerto of Lowell Liebermann, the orchestra's composer-in-residence -- as well as Shostakovich's Sixth Symphony and Stravinsky's ''Firebird'' Suite in the 1945 version.

title: Russia Offers a Motherly Embrace for Ukraine Industry
description: The presidents of Russia and Ukraine signed agreements today to expand their cooperation in civilian space research and aviation, in a meeting that reaffirmed the political and industrial ties between the two former Soviet republics.

title: INSIDE
description: Translating the Book of Life

description: In Tapping the Net, the F.B.I. Insists Privacy Is Not a Victim

title: Leonard Mandel, 73, Revealer Of Light's Weirdness, Is Dead
description: Dr. Leonard Mandel, a physicist whose experiments with light vividly demonstrated the strange, Alice-in-Wonderland quality of reality at the microscopic level, died Friday at his home in Pittsford, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester. He was 73 and an emeritus professor of physics and optics at the University of Rochester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERRITY, JOSEPH WARREN, III.
description: GERRITY-Joseph Warren, III. On Thursday, February 8, 2001. Joseph Warren Gerrity, III of Niskayuna, N.Y. Survived by his wife Anna Gerrity, his children, JoJo Gerrity and Andrea Grable, his son-in-law Dave Grable, his father Joe W. Gerrity, Jr. of Loudonville, N.Y., three brothers and three sisters. Private memorial service will be held this summer. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts in Joe's name may be made to the American Cancer Society, 260 Osborne Road, Loudonville, New York 12211. Inquiries Daly Funeral Home, 518-374-1600.

title: For Bob Kerrey, A Blind Date In Academia; New School University Basks In the Glow of Its President
description: Bob Kerrey, the just-retired senator who lost part of his right leg in a grenade attack in Vietnam, served as governor of Nebraska and got rich as an owner of restaurants and health clubs, may have arrived in New York only last month to assume the presidency of New School University in Greenwich Village. But he has already made it into the city's gossip columns (and wants you to know that the reports, which said that he and Bill Clinton were telling lesbian jokes at a popular Village restaurant, were false).

title: Napster Suffers Setback in Appeals Court Ruling
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12  A Federal appeals court dealt a major setback today to Napster , the start-up that has shaken the record industry by allowing millions of people to copy music free over the Internet, by largely affirming a lower-court ruling that the company encourages and abets the wholesale infringement of copyrights.

title: David Twersky, 79, Grand Rabbi Of a Borough Park Hasidic Sect
description: David Twersky, grand rabbi of a branch of the Skverer dynasty of Hasidic Judaism, died on Feb. 2 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMBRIA, DOROTHY (NEE MCCORMACK)
description: CAMBRIA-Dorothy (nee McCormack). Of Brookville. Widow of Frank. Mother of Nancy (Duncan) Armstrong and Cathy Cambria. Grandmother of Kathryn and Christopher. Reposing Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington. Mass Thursday, 9:45AM St. Patrick's Church, Main Street, Huntington.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC TO BUY DELAWARE UTILITY
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company has agreed to buy Conectiv, a utility based in Delaware, for about $5.4 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt, the companies said yesterday. The deal will double the number of Potomac's customers and will create the largest electric delivery company in the mid-Atlantic region. Potomac, based in Washington, will pay $2.2 billion, or $25 a share, in cash or stock. The offer is worth 31 percent more than Conectiv's closing price on Wednesday, before reports of the takeover talks sent the shares up. Potomac will also assume $3.2 billion in Conectiv debt and preferred stock. After the acquisition, Potomac will have a transmission system that runs between Washington and Wilmington, Del.

title: Metro Business Briefing; EDGAR, BOTH FREE AND FEE
description: FreeEdgar will no longer be free. Sort of. Executives at FreeEdgar's parent company, Edgar Online, said yesterday that users seeking e-mail alerts on the filing of Securities and Exchange Commission documents on more than five companies will now have to pay $9.95 per month. Users who list fewer companies will still receive the alerts free, company officials said. The move was made in an attempt to cover costs. Nearly 100,000 people have signed up for the so-called watch lists, according to officials at Edgar Online, which is based in South Norwalk, Conn. On Feb. 1, Edgar Online, which also runs the sites www.ipo-express.com, www.inside-trader.com and www.compensation-express.com, reported a net loss of $15.1 million on gross revenues of $10.4 million last year. Jayson Blair

title: Mayor Hints at Willingness To End Some Term Limits
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani opened the door yesterday for a deal with the City Council members trying to repeal the law that limits their terms, hinting he might consider signing such a repeal if Council members agreed in exchange to revise a campaign finance program the mayor has argued is too generous.

title: Housing the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenspan Says Downturn Hasn't Become a Recession
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 - While warning that the economy still faces substantial risks, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the United States is not in a recession and that the current downturn could prove to be as short as it is sharp.

title: When a Steady Buzz Spells Steady Stress
description: There may be no bellowing at your workplace or no heavy equipment rumbling back and forth, but don't equate the relative quiet with a lack of stress.

title: Hospitals in City Faulted by State For Failing to Report Many Errors
description: Hospitals in New York City are the state's worst when it comes to informing the state of mistakes and unexpected harm suffered by patients, state officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURNIT, SHEPARD
description: KURNIT-Shepard. Beloved husband of Jean. Father of Paul, Rick and Scott. Brother of Hal, Vic and Norman. Father-in-law of Susan Kurnit, Diane Katzin and Abbe Heller, and grandfather of Ara, Jesse and Katrina. Died peacefully on February 10. In lieu of flowers donations to Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 2247, NYC 10116. A memorial service will be held on February 16 at the W New York Hotel, 541 Lexington Ave. (50th St.) at 10:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELFAND, BOBBIE
description: GELFAND-Bobbie. Beloved wife of the late Joseph, loving mother Mark, Robin, Howard and Janet. Beloved grandmother of Melanie and Emily. Services Wednesday, 12 Noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Trnpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ANITA
description: LERNER-Anita, 53. On February 12th in Los Angeles. Beloved and devoted daughter of Ruth Leaf and Hershey Lerner. Loving sister of Karen Casino. Dear aunt of Mia Casino, Becky Waitz and Alexis Simone Casino. She will be lovingly remembered by many cherished friends. Memorial service to be announced. Donations to any cancer charity will be appreciated.

title: Article 2001021392989669177 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: INSURER'S REVENUE GROWS
description: AXA S.A., France's biggest insurer, said its revenue rose 20 percent last year as government pension changes forced Europeans to save for their retirements. Revenue increased to 80.1 billion euros ($74.4 billion) from 66.5 billion in 1999 with almost three-fifths tied to the sale of life insurance and other savings products, said Christophe Dufraux, a company spokesman. European regulators are pushing to overhaul the pension system to help ease the strain of higher payouts to retirees as life expectancy increases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAND, DR. LEONARD
description: BRAND-Dr. Leonard. Of Englewood Cliffs. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Thomashow). Devoted father of Dana, Jennifer and Stefanie. Dear brother of George. Loving grandfather of Sonia, Sarah and Samuel. Services will be held at ''Wien & Wien'' 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ on Wednesday at 12 noon. Should friends desire contributions may be made to the Dr. Leonard Brand Memorial Fund, Dept. of Anesthesia, Columbia University, 630 West 168 St., New York, New York 10032.

title: Buddy Tate, 87, Saxophonist for Basie's Band
description: Buddy Tate, a broad-toned saxophonist who was a vital part of the widely admired Count Basie band of the 1940's, died on Saturday in Chandler, Ariz. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLENGER, RUTH (NEE WARNER)
description: SCHLENGER-Ruth (nee Warner), 102. Of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of South Orange and East Orange, NJ. Died on February 11, 2001, after a long, beautiful life. Beloved wife of the late Herman Schlenger for 67 years. Devoted mother of Donald, Judith Heyman and Marjorie Weil and dear mother-in-law of Linda Schlenger, Martin Weil and the late Kenneth Heyman. Adored grandmother of Nancy Doernberg (Richard), Carol Schlenger, John Heyman (Nita), Kenneth Heyman Jr. (Mimi), Patricia Heyman, Peter Weil (Pamela) and David Weil (Nancy). Also survived by 13 great-grandchildren and one great-great-grandchild. As the last survivor of the large Warner family of Newark, NJ, she will be missed by countless nieces and nephews. Funeral services private. Contributions in her memory to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Rd., Boca Raton, FL, would be appreciated.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CHURCH & DWIGHT, Princeton, N.J., named Robert A. Davies III, chief executive, to the added post of chairman, succeeding Dwight C. Minton, who becomes chairman emeritus. Mr. Davies relinquishes his president position to Jon L. Finley, who also takes on the chief operating officer position, effective April 1.

title: Genome's Riddle: Few Genes, Much Complexity
description: The human genome is the most precious body of information imaginable. Yet the biologists who yesterday reported their first analysis of the decoded sequence have found as much perplexity as enlightenment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, SHEILA
description: ABRAMS-Sheila. We have lost a dear and treasured friend. A beautiful woman with a constant smile and compassion for everyone. Our hearts go out to Fred, his children and grandchildren. We shall miss her and love her for all time. Phyllis and Herb

title: Bouncing Along With a Zany Classicism
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet bears about the same relationship to New York City dance as Canada does to the United States. This Philadelphia-based troupe is a worthy longtime neighbor that has attracted little attention from New York dance audiences in recent years.

title: XFL Game Intrusion on 'Saturday Night Live' Roils NBC Executives
description: The second Saturday night broadcast of the XFL football league turned into a disaster for NBC as ratings for the show plunged and the game ran late, severely damaging the ratings performance of one of the network's franchise programs, ''Saturday Night Live,'' which did not go on the air until almost 45 minutes after its scheduled starting time.

title: Market and Government Are Sapping Murmansk
description: The fresh fish have vanished. This city of 400,000 on Russia's bleak Arctic coast worries about doing the same.

title: DEL MONTE FOODS IS LOOKING FOR A BUYER OR A MERGER
description: The Del Monte Foods Company is seeking a buyer or a merger partner, the company says. In a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Del Monte says it is seeking a deal to increase the value of its stock. Del Monte, with $1.5 billion in annual revenue, 14,000 employees and 65 production centers, leads the markets in canned fruit, canned vegetables and canned tomatoes. But the company's sales have grown slowly in recent months as many retailers have reduced inventory.

title: Aftermaths Of Three Flirtations With Fame
description: If fame, as a poet once wrote, is but a slow decay, then near-fame must be a kind of arrested development. The entertainment industry requires countless momentary stars to fill the gaps between icons, and for such artists, the aftermath of hype can be bewildering. A sold-out triple bill at the Village Underground over the weekend was a hopeful show of determination to survive celebrity.

title: Camp/Arbues Principal Is Leaving Agency
description: Roger Camp, principal and creative director at Camp/Arbues in San Francisco, is leaving as of March 1 to become one of two creative directors on the important Diet Coke account at Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore.

title: The Neediest Cases; In a Sea of Need, Casting for the Most Desperate
description: The phone in Judith Milone's office at the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies rang continually one day last week with people in desperate situations who were looking for financial help.

title: U.N. Plans Fewer Troops For Congo
description: Hoping to seize the opportunity provided by the change in leadership in Congo, the United Nations peacekeeping department is working out a plan to send fewer troops there than originally planned, but to send them sooner, the head of the department said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a Critic's Notebook article about ''House'' and ''Garden,'' interlocking plays by Alan Ayckbourn at the new Goodman Theater in Chicago, misidentified the actor at the right in the top picture. He was Donald Brearley (who plays the character Giles Mace), not B. J. Jones (who plays Gavin Ryng-Mayne).

title: Fighting Free Music, Europeans Take Aim at Personal Computers
description: FRANKFURT, Feb. 13  While American music producers pursue their marathon court battle against Napster and other free-music sites on the Internet, European composers and record companies are opening an entirely different front in the war against unauthorized copying: the personal computers that do the actual work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANDARD, JOHN EDWARD, MD.
description: STANDARD-John Edward, MD. of Southbury, Connecticut, formerly of Naugatuck and Middlebury, Connecticut, and Saltaire, New York, died Sunday, Feb. 11, 2001 of complications due to Alzheimer's disease. Besides his wife Gloria, he is survived by his sister, ten children, 14 grandchildren. Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, February 17th, 11AM, St. Paul's Church, Woodbury, CT.

title: Three's Still a Crowd, But the Knicks Manage
description: Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy spent the All-Star Game break wearing his thinking cap, pondering ways to get Latrell Sprewell, Allan Houston and Glen Rice more court time together. But after four days of analysis, Van Gundy came up with nothing more than a greater appreciation for the problem created by the three-man logjam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOPER, BAYARD
description: HOOPER-Bayard. Age 72. Of Sag Harbor, N.Y. and Bonita Springs, FL., where he died February 9, 2001. A graduate of Groton School and Harvard College, his professional life was largely spent as writer and editor of ''Time'', ''Life'' and ''Discover'' Magazines. He leaves his widow Nancy and four children by previous marriages, David, Carolyn, Robert and Elizabeth, a brother Roger, a sister Justine Milliken, and four grandchildren. All his family mourn his loss and will miss him greatly. Funeral plans pending. Memorial donations may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 St, N.Y., N.Y. 10032.

title: Genome Shows Evolution Has an Eye for Hyperbole
description: In keeping with the current fashionableness of all things Extreme -- Extreme Football, Extreme Wrestling and Extremely Large Tax Cuts -- scientists now present the Extreme Genome.

title: Clinton's Pardons, Bush's Giveaways
description: To the Editor:

title: Double Helix With a Twist; Do Fewer Genes Translate Into Fewer Dollars?
description: Incyte Genomics advertises access to 120,000 human genes, including 60,000 not available from any other source. Human Genome Sciences says it has identified 100,000 human genes, and DoubleTwist 65,000 to 105,000. Affymetrix sells DNA analysis chips containing 60,000 genes.

title: Napster Users Make Plans for the Day the Free Music Dies
description: Most music fans congregating in Napster's chat rooms yesterday afternoon were seeking an answer to a simple question. As ''AnonGirl'' put it succinctly: ''How long do we have???''

title: Sports of The Times; Two Stars Are Rising To Occasions
description: I WAS tipped to this story: Allen Iverson was out somewhere one night and didn't remember where he had parked his Bentley. Couldn't find it. So he abandoned it, wherever it was, and went to a Bentley dealer and bought another one.

title: Rivera Hearing Is Postponed
description: Mariano Rivera's arbitration hearing was postponed until next week, a change that offers two clues about the pitcher's talks for a long-term contract. On one hand, there has been enough progress in the discussions that the two sides want more time. On the other hand, the talks are not so far along that an agreement is imminent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIFF, SYLVIA
description: ZIFF-Sylvia. On Feb. 12, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Devoted mother of Richard & Gilbert. Dear mother-in-law of Lenore and Sara. Loving sister of Rose Langroth and Elaine Wolstein. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Services on Thursday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  METZ, HAROLD
description: METZ-Harold. Feb. 13, 1997. Years pass but your memory never fades. We love & miss you. Barbara and Morri

title: 3 Agencies Announce Expansion Moves
description: Three acquisitions are being made for undisclosed terms.

title: Particle Physics Gets Modern-Day 'Eureka!'
description: Archimedes shouted ''Eureka!'' when he discovered how to tell what an apparently gold crown was really made of without tearing it apart. Last week, particle physicists at Brookhaven National Laboratory said they had found hints of a new form of matter using a remarkably similar trick.

title: Berlin's Film Festival, in Transition and in Search of an Identity
description: To the German movie industry's frequent complaints of mistreatment by the Berlin film festival, Moritz de Hadeln, the festival's director since 1979, likes to respond that searching for a good German film these days is ''like looking for a diamond in a haystack.'' Mr. de Hadeln did use a German movie to open this year's Berlinale -- his last before his involuntary retirement -- but it is unclear whether it was a conciliatory gesture or a parting shot.

title: Houston Journal; Legal Fight Stalls a City's Plan for Light-Rail Relief
description: Of all the major cities in the nation without a light rail system, Houston would seem the most obvious candidate for one. It has serious traffic problems, which contribute to even more serious air pollution problems, as countless thousands of automobiles chug along the city's ever-expanding maze of highways.

title: On Kicking Up Heels To the Tune of Chopin
description: Spring came to the New York State Theater on Friday night. The New York City Ballet presented the season's first performance of ''Dances at a Gathering.''

title: A Flawed Wireless Auction
description: The Federal Communications Commission's recent auction of wireless airwave frequencies raised $17 billion for the Treasury but failed almost completely to encourage the entry of small companies that could foster price competition and technological innovation. The commission set aside some licenses for smaller companies but then allowed those bidders to be financed by the industry's leading players, as reported yesterday in The Times by Stephen Labaton and Simon Romero. The F.C.C. and Congress ought to rethink their approach to these auctions to determine if there is some way to develop genuine set-aside programs. If not, the pretense should be dropped before it erodes public confidence in the regulatory system.

title: Marines Defend Osprey
description: The commandant of the Marine Corps said hydraulic and computer problems, not the design of the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft, caused a fatal Dec. 11 crash. Page A20.

title: JDS Completes SDL Takeover and Projects Future Earnings
description: JDS Uniphase, the world's largest maker of fiber optic equipment for telecommunications and cable television systems, completed its merger today with SDL Inc., a rival component maker specializing in lasers, and gave Wall Street some guidance on its expected earnings.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/The Genome; The Silence Is Broken and the Genome Speaks
description: After yesterday's news conference at which Dr. Francis S. Collins and Dr. J. Craig Venter described the human genome, a reporter for a radio talk show inserted a miniature microphone into the nucleus of a skin cell left on the lectern where they had been standing and managed to record the following interview:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIESES, CHARLOTTE
description: MIESES - Charlotte. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member, Harry Goodrich, upon the loss of his sister. We express profound condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: President Of Newspaper Is Promoted By Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company has appointed Janet L. Robinson, president and general manager of The Times, to a new post in which she will oversee all of the company's newspapers.

title: Corrections
description: Achart on Friday showing how President Bush's proposed tax cut would affect 14 hypothetical households misstated the figures for a married couple with two children and a gross income of $20,000 a year before deductions. Correcting its model yesterday, the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche said that such a couple, claiming the dependent child care credit, would realize no tax saving  not $33 in the first year and $168 when the tax plan was fully phased in.

title: Jurors Find Mitsubishi Guilty Of Aiding a Price-Fixing Scheme
description: A federal jury found the Mitsubishi Corporation guilty today of aiding an international price-fixing cartel for graphite electrodes used to make steel.

title: Cindy Crawford, no longer a fixture for Revlon, is hired to give Ellen Tracy apparel youthful appeal.
description: ARDENT fans of Cindy Crawford who may be distraught at the loss of her high-profile endorsement deal with Revlon can now find a compensatory campaign to help provide their minimum daily requirement of supermodel chic.

title: It's True: Rutgers Holds the Key In the Big East
description: The Big East tournament begins three weeks from tomorrow and Rutgers -- yes, Rutgers -- could determine which teams use it to vault into the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Technology Briefing
description: E-COMMERCEPLANETRX TO HALT RETAIL BUSINESS A troubled online drugstore, PlanetRx , plans to exit the retail health and beauty products business and focus on fulfilling specialty prescriptions. The company said it had signed a letter of intent to buy a specialty pharmacy business and that it would give details of that deal on Feb. 21. The company said customers would be able to transfer their accounts to a former rival, Drugstore .com . PlanetRx cited industry estimates showing the specialty pharmacy business had faster growth rates than the overall pharmacy market. (Reuters)

title: Excerpts From Ruling By the 9th Circuit Court
description: Following are excerpts from the decision yesterday by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in the recording industry's case against Napster. The opinion was written by Senior Judge Robert R. Beezer, who was joined by Judges Mary M. Schroeder and Richard A. Paez.

title: People
description: Rob Slosberg was named to the new post of executive vice president and group creative director at Bates USA, New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of the Cordiant Communications Group. Mr. Slosberg, who joins three other executives with that title, had been creative director at DeVito/Verdi, New York.

title: Review/Fashion; When the Spotlight's Smile Turns to a Glare
description: Those 15 minutes of fame that Andy Warhol promised everyone now seem like an eternity in an age gone stale with hype and mediocrity. Does anyone outside the myopic fashion world -- the editors, photographers and stylists gathering this week for the New York fall 2001 collections -- really know who Miguel Adrover is? And if they don't know about Mr. Adrover, who tested the patience of even his most ardent fans on Sunday night with a show reeking of incense and exoticism, what chance do they have of knowing Alice Roi or Elisa Jiminez?

title: With a Skip and a Bounce, Spacecraft Lands on Asteroid
description: A NASA spacecraft ended its yearlong mission orbiting the asteroid Eros today by defying the odds and becoming the first man-made instrument to land on such a body.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, EDWARD
description: KING-Edward. We mourn the passing of Edward King, father of our esteemed trustee, John King, and extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire King family. Roy J. Zuckerberg, Chairman, Board of Trustees John S.T. Gallagher, CEO North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Vegetarian Wardrobe
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing; MICROSOFT TO THE RESCUE
description: Audible .com, a Silicon Alley company that develops and uses technology to place audio books, newspapers and lectures on the Internet, said in a call with investors on Friday that it had received an additional $10 million investment from Microsoft. Microsoft already owned a 7 percent stake in the company. Audible shares rose on the news Friday, but then dropped today. The shares, which are traded on the Nasdaq composite index, fell 28 percent, or 56 cents, to close at $1.46 yesterday in regular trading. Jayson Blair

title: Basketball's Troubles
description: One of the press reports from the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game last weekend included this astonishing quotation from Karl Malone, an aging superstar who was making perhaps his last appearance at the game: ''I think the product and the perception we have out to the public right now, people don't want it.'' Smoothed out a bit, what Malone was saying was that the public does not much like the way basketball is being played on the court or the way the players are behaving off the court.

title: As Violence Erupts, Barak and Sharon Agree on Unity Guidelines
description: As another spasm of deadly violence gripped the West Bank and Gaza Strip today, Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon moved close to a deal on forming a national unity government with the vanquished Labor Party.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Bulletin Board column of the Education page on Wednesday about a program to have pop musicians record historical songs for classroom use misstated its fund-raising progress. The sponsor, a group of music and education professionals known as Song masters, is trying to raise $19.2 million in addition to a $200,000 planning grant it received from the Ford Foundation; it has not yet raised the $19.2 million.

title: `Sopranos' May Be Heading Toward Its Final Season Soon
description: he Sopranos" will return to HBO on March 4 for its third season of new episodes, ending a long and excruciating wait for a horde of fervent fans. But those fans are well advised to savor every moment of every episode this season.

title: GOOGLE GETS DEJA.COM's USENET
description: The Internet search engine Google said that it had acquired Deja.com's Usenet discussion service, as well as related software, domain names, trademarks and other intellectual property. Financial terms were not released. The service, which allows users to post and read messages organized by topic, includes an archive of more than 500 million postings dating back to 1995. It is among the final assets to be sold by Deja.com, which sold its consumer product review service to eBay's Half .com in December. For a while, Google said, only part of the Usenet archive would be available for browsing, while the company improves Usenet's search technology. Susan Stellin

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday showing the minute-by-minute change in the Dow Jones industrial average was published in error. It showed activity for Feb. 5 rather than last Tuesday. Readers wishing a corrected chart may write to Business Day Tables, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959, or telephone (212) 556-7648. E-mail: tables @nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Reaching Out to Japan
description: The sinking of a Japanese fishing vessel by an American Navy submarine off Hawaii last Friday has prompted apologies from Washington, a promise to investigate and a moment of silent prayer yesterday from President Bush. These actions reflected appropriate sensitivity by the new administration as it moves to renew ties with Japan at a difficult time. Indeed, the submarine episode could force the administration to make some quick decisions on how to handle an apparently growing uneasiness over the presence of American troops in Japan, most of them on Okinawa. The administration also needs to decide how to address Japan's suddenly worsening economic problems.

title: O'Neill Urges Quick Passage of Key Parts of Bush Tax Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill urged Congress today to quickly pass key elements of President Bush's proposal for a 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut as a way to help stave off any further downturn in the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, GARY
description: REED-Gary. Age 89, passed away after a long illness on February 10. Of Great Neck. Beloved husband of Vera, father of Kenny (Kathleen). Dear grandfather of Scott, Amanda and Gregory.

title: Lastminute.com Loss Doubles, But Sales Increase Fourfold
description: Lastminute.com, the British online travel site, said today that its first-quarter loss doubled from a year ago, even as sales more than quadrupled.

title: Sounds of Silence on Hospice Options
description: Despite recent growth of the hospice field, intended to help the terminally ill die as peacefully as possible, most Americans still die in hospitals. Other studies had found that doctors often failed to tell patients' families about their options; now, a new report suggests that nurses, too, may play a role.

title: Article 2001021392527441069 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: Drug Was Rightfully Pulled
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving Your Skin When Winter Attacks
description: For residents of colder climes, this is not a happy time of year for body surfaces that depend upon moisture to remain pliable, comfortable and intact.

title: Genome's Riddle: Few Genes, Much Complexity
description: The human genome is the most precious body of information imaginable. Yet the biologists who yesterday reported their first analysis of the decoded sequence have found as much perplexity as enlightenment.

title: Eugene J. Casey -- Designer, 83
description: Eugene J. Casey, a marketing designer who founded the firm that designed the logo for the Merrill Lynch bull, died on Jan. 30 in Guilford, Conn., at the home of a son. He was 83.

title: Judge Refuses to Allow a California Utility to Raise Rates
description: A federal judge today denied a request by a California utility that would have allowed it to raise electric rates immediately and pass along its $5 billion debt to the state's consumers.

title: Dozens of the Wealthy Join to Fight Estate Tax Repeal
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 13  Some 120 wealthy Americans, including Warren E. Buffett, George Soros and the father of William H. Gates, are urging Congress not to repeal taxes on estates and gifts.

title: Unwrapping a New Era; Erykah Badu Gets On With the Business of Creating Herself
description: The most famous unseen hair in popular music belongs, without question, to Erykah Badu. When her first album, ''Baduizm,'' appeared in 1997, she wrapped her hair in tall cylinders of African-patterned fabric, turning concealment into a crown. Now, stepping on to the shiny set of the Black Entertainment Television cable network's Top 10 countdown show, ''106 and Park,'' Ms. Badu reveals a new invisible hairdo: she has recently shaved her head. With her almond eyes, high forehead, long cheekbones and broad lips, she looks more than ever like a Benin mask.

title: Insurer Plans A Large Rise In Auto Rates
description: The American International Group said yesterday that it was seeking increases of 10 percent or more in its auto insurance rates, continuing a trend begun a year ago in the industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZICKERMAN, RUTH B.
description: ZICKERMAN-Ruth B. Died February 9, 2001, age 95. Widow of Dr. Julius Zickerman. Retired NYC schoolteacher of 40 years. Resident of North Miami Beach, Fla. since the 1970's. She will be remembered with love by her sons Stuart and Martin of Hollis, N.Y. and her many friends. She was a tireless fundraiser and organizer for Hadassah in New York and Florida for almost 50 years. ''The Hostess with the Mostest''. A Memorial Service will be held at Sinai Chapel, Fresh Meadows, N.Y. February 13th, 10:15am. Memorial donations should be sent to HMO at National Hadassah Fundraising, attn Bella/Susie, 50 West 58 Street, New York, New York 10019.

title: Bush Names Acting Chairwoman for S.E.C.
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission member, Laura S. Unger, the panel's only Republican, has been appointed acting chairwoman of the agency by President Bush, according to a White House announcement.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP HIRES 2ND TOP EXECUTIVE FROM NABISCO
description: The Campbell Soup Company, the world's largest soup maker, has named Robert Schiffner, the treasurer at the Nabisco Holdings Corporation, its new chief financial officer, effective Feb. 26. Mr. Schiffner, 51, will succeed Basil Anderson, 56, who announced his retirement earlier this month, the company said.
