Mr. Schiffner's appointment comes less than two months after Campbell named the Nabisco Foods Company's president, Douglas Conant, its chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAME, ABRAHAM D.
description: BEAME-Abraham D. The Board, staff and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City sadly acknowledge the passing of Abraham D. Beame, former Mayor of New York City. Mr. Beame was a staunch supporter of people with cerebral palsy and related disabilities during his tenure as mayor. In the '70's Mayor Beame responded to UCP/NYC's request for transportation services for people with disabilities by creating a transportation system which provided accommodation to meet their special needs. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Leo Hausman, Chairman Martin C. Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews, Exec. Dir. UCP/NYC

title: BUSH DUE TO VISIT MEXICO TO DISCUSS OBTAINING ENERGY
description: President Bush comes to Mexico on Friday, and at the top of his agenda, alongside trade, immigration and drugs, is his vision of an across-the-border bargain to allow billions of dollars of energy to flow to the United States.

title: White House Is Not Ruling Out Airline Strikes
description: A senior White House official said yesterday that President Bush's decision to prevent mechanics at Northwest Airlines from going on strike did not necessarily mean that the Bush administration would intervene to head off potential strikes at three other major airlines.

title: Mixed Grades For First Year Of New Classes
description: As it begins gearing up for a second year of large-scale summer school, New York City has found that children in elementary school benefited markedly from extra classes last summer, with more than half of all fifth graders moving to a higher level in reading.

title: For Diabetics' Hearts, Aspirin Therapy
description: Only about one in five diabetics takes regular doses of aspirin to help prevent heart disease, even though people with diabetes are at much greater risk of developing it, a new study has found.

title: Genetic Sequence of Mouse Is Also Decoded
description: At a news conference convened yesterday to present the first analysis of the human genome, Celera Genomics said it had assembled the genome sequence of another favorite subject of study, the mouse.

title: Safety Board Tells of Fight to Survive Sinking of Fishing Vessel Hit by Submarine
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 12  In their first interviews with American government officials, the captain and some of the students from a Japanese fishing vessel that was sunk near here on Friday by a United States Navy submarine said that they had heard two loud noises and found themselves ankle deep in rapidly rising oil and water and that within five minutes their ship had slipped beneath the choppy seas.

title: Oxfam Joins Campaign to Cut Drug Prices for Poor Nations
description: Oxfam, the influential charity, began a campaign today to force multinational drug companies to cut the prices of their live-saving drugs to poor nations.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Don't Touch That Plant!

title: Farmers Favor Genetically Altered Crops, Producers Say
description: Despite growing concerns over the use of biotechnology in agriculture, and the recent controversy over Starlink, an unapproved variety of bioengineered corn that accidentally entered the food supply, American farmers continue to favor planting genetically altered crops, according to surveys conducted by the nation's biggest seed companies.

title: Information About Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Before the Big Bang
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS DECLINES. Natural gas fell as forecasts for milder weather in the Midwest signaled that demand would weaken. In New York, natural gas for March delivery fell 38.9 cents, or 6.3 percent, to $5.821 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Safety Board Tells of Fight to Survive Sinking of Fishing Vessel Hit by Submarine
description: In their first interviews with American government officials, the captain and some of the students from a Japanese fishing vessel that was sunk near here on Friday by a United States Navy submarine said that they had heard two loud noises and found themselves ankle deep in rapidly rising oil and water and that within five minutes their ship had slipped beneath the choppy seas.

title: A Marriage of Convenience
description: IT started showing up in cookbooks a few years ago. A separate chapter devoted to stocking your kitchen. The idea is simple and cloyingly romantic: keep your pantry and refrigerator well stocked and at any time you can piece together a delicious meal. After toiling for hours at the office. After a Saturday afternoon running around doing errands. After the winds kick up and you don't feel like leaving the house.

title: Defense Grills Terror Witness On bin Laden
description: A former close aide to the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden testified yesterday under cross-examination in the embassy bombings trial that he worked proudly for Mr. bin Laden in his war against the United States, but later acknowledged telling American agents that Mr. bin Laden ''misinterprets certain portions of the Koran to justify violent action.''

title: A Special Kind of Officemate
description: MY husband is about to lose his best buddy at work. Bob is leaving, off to great new adventures, and when he leaves, an important beat in the rhythm of Bruce's day will leave, too. Workplace friendships are a crossbreed of the species, sturdy yet fragile at the same time. They start out as lunch and evolve into loyalty. As Laura Senturia, an account executive with Schwartz Communications in Waltham, Mass., says about her colleague, Marybeth McLean Roberts: ''Somewhere along the way, 'Marybeth from work' became simply 'Marybeth.' ''

title: F.D.A. Action Could Change Food Marketing on the Web
description: In a move that could change the way food is marketed on the Internet, the Food and Drug Administration has warned Ocean Spray Cranberries to stop making unapproved health claims about its juices on the company World Wide Web site.

title: Senate Power-Sharing Pact Strained by Intelligence Committee
description: The historic power-sharing pact between Senate Republicans and Democrats has suffered one of its first and most visible setbacks, on the secretive intelligence committee that has broad oversight and investigative authority over the Central Intelligence Agency and the rest of the United States intelligence community, officials said.

title: Israel Hunts Down and Kills a Top Arafat Security Officer
description: Two Israeli helicopter gunships swooped over northern Gaza this morning and dropped four missiles on the car of a senior Palestinian security officer, instantly killing a man whom Israel considered a terrorist in a uniform and a beret.

title: Teatime Enters International Zone
description: HOTEL teas are going global. In addition to the usual scones and Spode, some are taking on Asian and even Russian accents.

title: PRUDENTIAL TO CUT JOBS
description: Prudential P.L.C., one of Britain's largest insurers, said it would eliminate 2,000 sales jobs over the next year to trim expenses. Prudential said it would have restructuring charges of 110 million ($159.8 million), but said it expected annual gross cost savings of about 135 million ($196.2 million) by 2002. Suzanne Kapner

title: Dozens of Rich Americans Join In Fight to Retain the Estate Tax
description: Some 120 wealthy Americans, including Warren E. Buffett, George Soros and the father of William H. Gates, are urging Congress not to repeal taxes on estates and gifts.

title: THE BOSS; No 2nd Chances on Live TV
description: My father was in the movie camera and equipment business, so my most memorable childhood moments involved playing with his Super-8-millimeter gadgets. In junior high, I took a course in filmmaking and immediately started shooting Claymation scenes on the house patio. My first subjects were a cross between Gumby and the Blob.

title: Rapper Goes to Court, but This Time as Plaintiff
description: The law has not been a friend these days to the rap star Sean Combs. But that is where he turned yesterday -- specifically, to Federal District Court in Manhattan -- to try to end a collaboration with a journalist who was hired to help write his autobiography.

title: Chief Executive Compensation Rose 16% Last Year Over '99
description: The annual pay packages of chief executives continue to soar and now exceed $10 million among the nation's very largest public companies, according to a new survey.

title: JDS UNIPHASE COMPLETES ACQUISITION
description: The big fiber optic equipment maker, JDS Uniphase, completed its takeover of SDL Inc., a rival. JDS Uniphase told analysts that it now expects revenue of $3.9 billion and earnings of 74 cents a share this year. For its third fiscal quarter, ending March 31, it projected revenue of slightly more than $1 billion and earnings of about 17 cents a share. Dave Kang, an analyst for ABN Amro, said the company's new guidance showed the takeover was diluting earnings more than he had expected. ''They overpaid,'' Mr. Kang said. ''But you had to overpay for somebody like SDL'' because stock prices were much higher in the summer. When the all-stock deal was announced in July, it was valued at $41 billion, or $441.51 per SDL share, a premium of almost 50 percent. Since then, JDS Uniphase stock has fallen 64 percent, reducing the value of the shares that SDL shareholders received to $147.96. Michael Brick

title: Cupid, Get Out of the Kitchen
description: IT'S Feb. 14. Time to eat.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an apology by the archbishop of Los Angeles for having written to President Clinton on behalf of a drug dealer whose sentence was later commuted by Mr. Clinton misspelled the archbishop's surname. He is Cardinal Roger Mahony, not Mahoney.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about former President Bill Clinton's decision to negotiate for office space in a Harlem building misstated the name of the California city where former President Gerald Ford has an office. It is Rancho Mirage, not simply Mirage.

title: Excerpts From Greenspan's Testimony
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his semiannual report on the economy to the Senate Banking Committee today. Following are excerpts from his testimony and from an exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, in a question-and-answer session after the testimony, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: The Neediest Cases; Defying Labels and Low Expectations
description: On work breaks this past football season, Henry Farrell would give his tongs a rest, part company with his apron and hop the counter of the concession stand he manned at Giants Stadium.

title: Rangers' Mind Games Are Over for Malhotra
description: All we are saying, Rangers' fans have been pleading for almost two years, is give Malhotra a chance.

title: Greenspan Says Slowdown Could Be Brief but Acknowledges Risks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  While warning that the economy still faces substantial risks, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the United States was not in a recession and that the slowdown it was experiencing could prove to be as short as it is sharp.

title: Russia Reviving Dreaded Practice of Anonymous Complaints
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14  Reviving a practice that was hated, feared and ultimately banned in Soviet times, the domestic successor to the K.G.B. has served notice that it once again is investigating anonymous accusations of crimes against Russian citizens.

title: Marbury and the Nets Make the Lakers Work for It
description: For four quarters and an overtime tonight, Marbury and the Nets danced with the defending champion Los Angeles Lakers in a zone where three All-Stars matched one another, shot for shot.

title: Justice Thomas Raises Issue Of Cultural Intimidation
description: Speaking to a large and generally conservative gathering, Justice Clarence Thomas said tonight that the nation was engaged in a cultural war in which people who stood for their beliefs were often intimidated into silence.

title: European Allocation: 7 Sent to N.F.L. Europe
description: The Jets allocated seven players to N.F.L. Europe yesterday. The league is designed to give promising prospects game experience in the hope that they will return to compete for a roster spot or practice-squad position on a National Football League team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, IRVING S.
description: ELIAS-Irving S. In memory of our esteemed colleague, Honorary President, Irving S. Elias, who devoted his life to generously supporting the Sephardic Home for the Aged. A proud Sephardic philanthropist who was a charter member of the Home, as were his parents, Sam and Sophie Elias. We extend sincere condolences to his wife, Charlotte; children, Gale Sitomer, Shari Cherne, Sam I. Elias and grandchildren; and brother Jack Elias and sister Lillian Handwerger. Officers and Board of Directors of the Sephardic Home and LASHA Robert A. Cohen, President Ralph J. Kamhi, Chairman of the Board Michael New, Exec. Dir. Marion Crespi, Pres. LASHA Reggie Goldberg, Chairman of the Board LASHA

title: Newsday Gathers Itself for Another Try at the City
description: In the second-floor warren of press offices at New York City's Police Headquarters, Newsday has squeezed in a fourth desk. In City Hall, the chaotic pressroom, Room 9, is so full that Newsday's new man on the beat -- its third -- has had to go to the overflow basement pressroom. And Stephanie Saul, who won a Pulitzer Prize investigating police disability-pension abuses on Long Island, has started to cover Queens.

title: BUSH DETAILS PLAN TO FOCUS MILITARY ON NEW WEAPONRY
description: President Bush said today that he planned to break with Pentagon orthodoxy and create ''a new architecture for the defense of America and our allies,'' investing in new technologies and weapons systems rather than making ''marginal improvements'' for systems in which America's arms industry has invested billions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTLEMAN, BETTE JOBLIN
description: MITTLEMAN-Bette Joblin. On Sunday, February 11, 2001. Dearest and loving mother of Brad Joblin and mother-in-law of Barbara Joblin. Cherished grandmother of Blake Joblin. Beloved wife of the late Budd Mittleman. Devoted stepmother of Michael and Peter Mittleman and Kate Arens. Former Professor of Finance and an MBA Graduate of Columbia University. A memorial service will be held at a later date. She had beauty and elegance and was a woman of achievement ahead of her time.

title: Buffalo Steak Frites With Barnaise? Well, Yes
description: MORE and more, I have replaced beef, the little I still eat, with buffalo. Juicy, medium-rare buffalo burgers have become a regular part of my weekly dinner repertory and not just because they have far fewer calories and saturated fat than ones made with beef. I also like the way buffalo is raised: either completely on grass or on grass with a little grain.

title: Article 2001021490341546626 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Glad to Be A Laker, O'Neal Returns
description: In a season in which divisive controversy and bruised egos have threatened to damage the Los Angeles Lakers' chances of successfully defending their title, at least Shaquille O'Neal's strained right arch has healed.

title: Senate Panel Opens Hearing on Rich Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  Democrats as well as Republicans harshly criticized former President Clinton's pardon of the fugitive financier, Marc Rich, as the Senate Judiciary Committee today began its inquiry into the affair.

title: Barnes & Noble.com Wins Round in Amazon.com Patent Dispute
description: Afederal appeals court in Washington freed Barnes & Noble.com today to allow its customers to buy books on its Web site with one mouse click, at least until a trial is completed on Amazon.com's contention that such buying infringes on one of its patents.

title: Helping New Teachers Survive the Hardest Years
description: A few weeks into Pamela Nathan's first year as an eighth-grade science teacher at Honiss Elementary School, Linda Merschtina asked how she was doing.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA CUTS 300 JOBS AS FEWER ORDERS COME IN
description: Kulicke & Soffa Industries, a leading maker of semiconductor-assembly equipment, said yesterday that it was cutting about 300 jobs, or 7 percent of its work force, because it had received fewer orders. The company, based in Willow Grove, Pa., will make most of the cuts in its second quarter, which ends in March, a spokesman said. A slowing economy and lower demand for personal computers have hurt the semiconductor industry, prompting chip makers to order less equipment.

title: Morgan Stanley 'Mistake'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURNIT, SHEPARD
description: KURNIT-Shepard. Memorial service will be at the W New York Hotel, 541 Lexington Ave. (50th St.), on February 16 at 10:30 AM.

title: Excerpts From Greenspan's Testimony
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his semiannual report on the economy to the Senate Banking Committee today. Following are excerpts from his testimony and from an exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, in a question-and-answer session after the testimony, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: New Hotel Bars

title: German Sees Russia Bending on Missiles
description: President Vladimir V. Putin and Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, discussed the proposed American missile defense at a Kremlin meeting today, ending two days of talks that Mr. Fischer said pointed to new Russian flexibility on the notion of a shield against rogue missiles.

title: People
description: * Stephen Whyte, managing director at the London office of Leo Burnett Worldwide, part of the Bcom3 Group, was named chief executive, succeeding Nick Brien, who is moving to Chicago to take the new post of president for United States corporate business development at a sibling, the Starcom MediaVest Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDNICH, JEAN KOELLHOFFER
description: MINDNICH-Jean Koellhoffer. Of Basking Ridge, N.J., formerly of Short Hills, N.J. on Tuesday, February 13, 2001. Wife of the late John David Mindnich. Mother of John D., Jr., Peter A. and Michael G. Mindnich, and Mrs. Lisa Benson. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Funeral Mass Saint Rose of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Ave, Short Hills, Friday, February 16th, at 10 A.M. Entombment Somerset Hills Mausoleum, Basking Ridge. Friends may call at Smith and Smith (Suburban), 415 Morris Ave, Springfield, New Jersey, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Familial Alzheimers Disease Fund, Attn Dr. Susan Bassett, Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, 600 North Wolfe Street, Meyer 3-166, Baltimore, MD 21287.

title: St. John's Jessie Hopes to Save His Best for Last
description: As St. John's season progressed into December, Reggie Jessie quickly became an interloper in a young man's game. A veteran who played behind four eventual National Basketball Association draft picks, Jessie was ready to assume control. Then, Jessie lost playing time to freshmen and ended up on the bench.

title: Napster Charts A New Course After Ruling
description: A day after Napster suffered a crippling legal blow, officials within the company scrambled to chart a legal and business future, while skeptical industry analysts said Napster might never become profitable, and might eventually fade away.

title: 'Avant-Garde' Artists Come In From the Cold (War)
description: Although the 1950's are often described as somnolent years in the United States, they were also a time of artistic ferment, when dissonant music and abstract painting burst into the public consciousness.

title: Review/Fashion; At Marc Jacobs, Dressing for Life as a Perpetual Child
description: Last week, anyone who turned on a television set would probably have come up against NBC's promotion for a special sweeps-month episode of ''Friends'' that promised to have the charmingly rudderless, commitment-averse sextet collectively turn 30. Given that the series is now seven years old and that the actors looked as though they had been inaugurated into life's third decade by the time the series began, the friends should really be sitting around trying to secure six places in an assisted living community.

title: A'Lelia Nelson, 82, President Of a Black Cosmetics Company
description: A'Lelia Nelson, a librarian who was a former president of a famous early black enterprise, the Madame C. J. Walker Manufacturing Company, died Jan. 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 82. The cause was pancreatic cancer.

title: HEWLETT OFFERS INTERNET SOFTWARE
description: Hewlett-Packard introduced two Internet-based software suites that help business clients streamline their Web operations. One of the new software packages, Netaction, uses technology Hewlett acquired with the purchase of Bluestone Software last month. Hewlett also upgraded its popular OpenView suite, which helps manage large portfolios of software across computer systems. ''H. P. predicted that intelligent, useful e-services would drive the next wave of business development opportunities,'' said Bill Russell, a vice president for software. ''As that vision takes root in the world economy, businesses increasingly require a strong, flexible software foundation.'' The products underscore Hewlett's increased focus on software, particularly applications that are paid for by subscription, a blueprint the company calls service-centric computing. Andrew Zipern

title: The Boss: No 2nd Chances on Live TV
description: My father was in the movie camera and equipment business, so my most memorable childhood moments involved playing with his Super-8-millimeter gadgets. In junior high, I took a course in filmmaking and immediately started shooting Claymation scenes on the house patio. My first subjects were a cross between Gumby and the Blob.

title: Puntarelle: The Hot New Green on New York's Plate
description: I FIRST fell for puntarelle a few years ago, when I had a job cooking in Tuscany at a farmhouse bed-and-breakfast. It was a green unlike anything I had tasted back in the land of romaine lettuce. It had a little pepperiness like arugula in the leaves, a hint of fennel in the stalks and an underlying flavor that was a cross between chicory and endive. It even had the crisp, satisfying crunch of celery in top form.

title: Civilians in Sub Sat at 2 Controls When Ships Hit
description: Civilian visitors were at the controls of two important stations aboard the American nuclear attack submarine on Friday when it surfaced and sank a Japanese fishing vessel near here, the Navy said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNER, WILLIAM J., SR.
description: DONNER-William J., Sr. Age 63. Of East Brunswick, New Jersey. On February 8, 2001. Senior Staff Member of MCI-WorldCom's Americas Engineering Team. Husband of Ann Drohan Donner. Father of William J. Donner, Jr., Janet (Matthew) Bauer, Veronica and Maureen Donner, and Ann (Paul) Fischbach. Brother of Joseph Donner, Joanne Arcidiacono and the late Dorothy Donner. Grandfather of Eileen, Matthew, Craig and Abigail. Funeral 9:15AM Friday, The Brunswick Memorial Home, 454 Cranbury Road, East Brunswick, 10 A.M. Mass Saint Bartholomew Church, East Brunswick. Interment Holy Cross Burial Park, South Brunswick, N.J. Visitation 2-4 and 7-9PM Thursday. Memorials to Oratory of Saint Philip Neri, C/O Rev. Thomas Walsh, POB 6078, Somerset, NJ 08873.

title: Fewer Genes, but No Less Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: ABB HAS DISAPPOINTING RESULTS
description: ABB Ltd., a leading maker of electrical equipment, said profit unexpectedly stagnated in the fourth quarter, as demand in the United States and Europe fell. ABB also lowered its growth forecast. Its stock dropped 8.5 percent, its biggest decline in two years. Net income was steady at $219 million, or 74 cents a share. Analysts had expected a 6.7 percent increase. Fourth-quarter sales fell 2.1 percent, to $6.75 billion. For the year, revenue dropped 6 percent.

title: Pride of New Zealand: Nick Willis
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand  Nick Willis is the most promising high school miler in New Zealand since John Walker and Rod Dixon. And, from all indications, his best races are yet to come.

title: The Language of Love
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Palestinian's Hit-and-Run Bus Kills 8 Israelis and Injures 20
description: AZOR, Israel, Feb. 14 -- The day began here with a typical morning rush hour as scores of young Israeli soldiers waited at a junction near Tel Aviv for a ride to their military bases. Pvt. Moshe Saroussi, 19, his black hair spiky and his eyes sleepy, saw an empty bus approaching and stretched, letting the others rush ahead of him.

title: Fewer Genes, but No Less Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNEO, GLORIA
description: CUNEO-Gloria. The Catholic Traditionalist Movement (CTM) mourns the passing into Heaven of its co-founder and, for the past thirty-seven years, General Secretary. While traditionalist Catholics the world over will gratefully remember her behind-the-scenes self-effacing dignity and grace that made the traditional Roman Catholic Mass in Latin available to them via weekly shortwave radio and daily internet, she will be even more deeply missed at the CTM headquarters' Ave Maria Chapel in Westbury, Long Island, where her loving and caring ways in so many different capacities made her the community's leading traditionalist lay person, especially endearing herself to the children of two generations. With lasting gratitude, I will personally offer the traditional Latin Roman Catholic Requiem Funeral Mass for at our Ave Maria Chapel, 210 Maple Avenue, Webtbury, Long Island, N.Y. at 10 A.M. this Thursday. Rev. Dr. Gommar A. De Pauw Founder-President Catholic Traditionalist Movement

title: Fed Changes Procedures On Securities
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said yesterday that the central bank had made changes in procedure and was considering others to ensure that the shrinking of the nation's Treasury market would not inhibit the Fed's ability to move interest rates when it wants.

title: Governor Is Urged to Reopen Inquiry on Inspection Contract
description: The ranking Democrat in the State Senate urged Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco today to reopen a long-dormant legislative inquiry into a $500 million contract for the overhaul of New Jersey's auto inspection stations, a day after reports that an engineer involved in the contract had lent Mr. DiFrancesco $150,000 to bail him out of a defaulted bank loan four years before the contract was awarded.

title: Beauty Is Truth, and Sometimes Betrayal
description: THE BEAUTY OF THE HUSBAND

title: Microsoft Names a President and Confirms a New Inquiry
description: Since the Microsoft Corporation introduced its .NET initiative last year with much fanfare, analysts and investors have pressed the giant software company to define its amorphous and loosely defined plan.

title: Corrections
description: A children's activity listing in the Connecticut section on Sunday misstated the date of a concert by the violinist Vadim Gluzman and the pianist Angela Yoffe at the Pequot Library in Southport. It is 2 p.m. on Saturday; it was not last Sunday.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Levy Hires an Aide to Senator Clinton

title: Little Hen, Big Flavor
description: THIS recipe looks like an ordinary weeknight sort of dish -- after all, it's just Cornish hens, salt and pepper. But it is elevated far beyond that by two simple tricks: a broiling technique that quickly browns the birds and leaves them juicy, and a peppercorn that adds an elusive, almost floral spice.

title: In First Day of Trading, Orange Stock Starts Slow and Falls Flat
description: Even after being marked down sharply, the stock of Orange, the wireless unit of France Tlcom, fell flat in its first day of trading in London and Paris, and closed below its offering price.

title: Yanks Agree to Terms With Defector
description: Andy Morales, whose three-run home run capped the Cuban national team's 12-6 victory over the host Baltimore Orioles in 1999, has agreed to terms with the Yankees. And he is expected to play a utility role this season for the three-time defending World Series champions.

title: Fewer Genes, but No Less Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: EPSTEIN-William. Of the United Nations. On Friday, February 9th. Survived by his wife Edna of Portland, OR., and his son Mark of Washington, DC. Services are on Wednesday, at 12 Noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center would be appreciated.

title: Politics and Traditions Propel the Search Effort
description: Four days after a collision off Hawaii between an American nuclear submarine and a Japanese fishing vessel carrying high school students, the United States Coast Guard has maintained an incessant search for the nine missing Japanese, even though experts say that no one could survive at sea this long.

title: Rewriting the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILOVE, ROBERT
description: TILOVE-Robert. On February 9, 2001, at age 86 in Mitchellville, Md. He was a beloved colleague from 1949 to his retirement in 1979, and then as a consultant to our company. Bob's creativity in pension plan design and his analysis of the economic effects of private and public pension funds broke new ground in a highly complex field. We were most fortunate to have been associated with him and send our deepest sympathy to his family. Martin E. Segal, Founder and Chairman Emeritus Robert D. Krinsky, Chairman Howard Fluhr, President, The Segal Company

title: Metro Business Briefing; FIGHTING CON ED-N.U. MERGER
description: Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut asked a state court yesterday to block a merger of Consolidated Edison and Northeast Utilities that the State Department of Public Utility Control had recently approved. Mr. Blumenthal, who had strongly lobbied the department to deny the merger on grounds that it would cost customers more for electricity and harm the environment, among other reasons, asked Superior Court in New Britain to delay the merger until resolution of his appeal of a court's decision not to block the merger. The power companies said they expected the merger to proceed despite the legal challenges. Paul Zielbauer

title: Fewer Genes, but No Less Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Fewer Genes, but No Less Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Freddy Wittop, Costume Designer, Dies at 89
description: Freddy Wittop, a Tony Award-winning costume designer who dressed hordes of Broadway actors, Latin Quarter nightclub dancers and Parisian showgirls, died on Feb. 2 in Atlantis, Fla. He was 89.

title: A Money-Market Millionaire Bids to Be Nassau's Executive
description: For months the Nassau County Republican Party has been unable to find a candidate willing to challenge County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, the well-financed but increasingly isolated Republican incumbent.

title: Prospect of Pardon Inquiry Sets Off Sparks, but Little Zeal
description: Federal prosecutors are deliberating whether to open a criminal inquiry into former President Bill Clinton's pardon of Marc Rich, although some senior Justice Department officials have expressed little enthusiasm for such an investigation, government officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the expansion of Russian-Ukrainian cooperation in civilian space research and aviation misstated the given name of the secretary of Ukraine's national security council, who denied that the two countries would jointly make intercontinental ballistic missiles. He is Yevhen Marchuk, not Oleksandr.

title: A Sandwich Salute to India
description: A FRENCH friend of mine criticizes Americans for not respecting the culinary traditions of other cultures. I wonder what he would make of the Hampton Chutney Company, a cafe and takeout shop that opened two weeks ago in SoHo.

title: A Rebuilding Year For a Reputation
description: Tim Welsh gathered his Providence College basketball team for an important meeting on the first day of school last September. Normally, Welsh would wait a few days before addressing his players so they could get acclimated to the intricacies of a new semester. But Welsh did not wait this time. He could not waste one day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GWATHMEY, ROSALIE
description: GWATHMEY-Rosalie died on February 12 at her home in Amagansett, NY, age 92. Wife of the late artist, Robert Gwathmey, cherished and devoted mother of Charles, adored mother-in-law of Bette-Ann, beloved grandmother of Annie and Eric Steel. Artist, photographer, founding member of The Photo League, patron and political activist. Born in Charlotte, N.C., Rosalie was a passionate observer of social inequities as documented through her photographs of Southern Black culture. Her charm, perceptive wit, honesty and sensitivity, as well as her unique personal style will be remembered by all who loved and knew her. A memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: He'll Play Bush
description: Comedy Central has cast the lead for its new series based on George W. Bush's White House, ''That's My Bush!'' by Matt Parker and Trey Stone, the creators of ''South Park.''

title: Sports of The Times; Marbury Has Another Great Game
description: HONK!''

title: Eminem and His Lyrics
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's plan to combat racial profiling referred incorrectly in some copies to the New York Police Department's Street Crime Unit, which federal prosecutors in Manhattan have concluded engaged in profiling. The unit was decentralized in 1999; it is not defunct.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Fund Giants to Introduce Self-Directed Portfolios for Investors
description: Almost a year after an Internet start-up began offering investors a way to create their own stock funds, two of the biggest companies in the $7 trillion mutual fund industry are gearing up to introduce do-it-yourself investment portfolios.

title: Article 2001021493029602894 -- No Title
description: This is business, it's not personal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORREY, OWEN CATES JR,
description: TORREY-Owen Cates Jr, at Norwalk, CT., on February 13, 2001. Born October 31, 1925, in New York, NY, son of Owen Cates Torrey and Emily Gertrude McChesney Torrey. Graduate of St. Paul's School 1943, Harvard University AB 1947 and Columbia University Law School JD, 1951. Admiralty lawyer and sailmaker. Served in the U.S. Army, 63rd Armored Infantry Batallion, 1944-1945 in the Ardennnes and Rhineland campaigns. Winner of the Bronze Medal (Yachting-Swallow Class) in the 1948 Olympic Games (XIVth Olympiad), London, 1948. Member of American Yacht Club, New York Yacht Club, Storm Trysail Club, and life member of ISCYRA; President of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound 1992-1994. Lifelong involvement in yacht racing as a competitor (including two America's Cup campaigns), racing handicapper, race committee member and U.S. sailing judge. Survived by his wife Allegra Mertz Torrey, South Norwalk, CT. and four children of a previous marriage: Emily Southard Torrey, Jackson, WY; Ellen McChesney Torrey, Elkton, MD.; Margery Torrey Godwin, Pine Mountain, GA.; and Owen Cates Torrey III, Houston, TX. Funeral service to be held at the American Yacht Club, Milton Point, Rye, NY, on Friday, February 16, 2001, at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, donation to New York's Aquarium (Wildlife Conservation Society) 2300 Southern Blvd, Bronx, NY 10460-1099.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, HENRIETTA
description: MEYER - Henrietta. Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to our member, Judy Freudenstein, upon the loss of her sister. We express profound condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Business Travel; Rosenbluth is cutting back its late-flight guarantees as more delays and problems loom.
description: IT'S barely remembered now, but last May, after more than a year of steadily worsening conditions, airline flight delays abruptly dropped 7 percent from the year before.

title: Prize-Winning Filmmaker on the First Try
description: THERE is something delightfully refreshing about Edet Belzberg, a recent Columbia University graduate student and, now, award-winning first-time filmmaker. She is waiting -- on time and standing politely -- in an Upper West Side diner. And she has no people with her, those aggravating publicists who hover around like gnats.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Is Not in a Recession, Greenspan Tells Senators

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: M.I.T. Professor Reconsiders Children's Online Lives
description: There are few neighborhoods left where children can meet their pals after school for a friendly game of kickball in a vacant lot. Parents should accept this reality of contemporary life and understand that the virtual world can be a boon to today's latchkey child.

title: National News Briefs
description: Police Arrest a Student in Killings at Gallaudet

title: Civil Suit Over Azerbaijan Oil Deal Gains Plaintiffs in London
description: Columbia University and a Wall Street investment firm have joined a civil suit in London against a Czech promoter accused of fraud in a $450 million deal to acquire control of Azerbaijan's state-owned oil company.

title: Fewer Genes, but No Less Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: New Market Concentrates On Organic Food
description: THE Whole Foods supermarket chain will open its first store in New York City tomorrow, in a 31,000-square-foot space at 250 Seventh Avenue (24th Street) in Chelsea.

title: A Company Backtracks On a Speech By Clinton
description: A major financial company has canceled negotiations with former President Bill Clinton over hiring him for a speech, fearing it would be drawn into controversies swirling around Mr. Clinton since his departure from the White House, people involved in the negotiations said today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is business, it's not personal.''

title: Beautiful People and a Menu That Glows
description: THERE'S a difference between style and taste, and it's on view at Aleutia, a restaurant with a lot of style and not quite enough taste. The style starts at the door, where two futuristic L.C.D. panels seductively flash the menu in a slow, throbbing pulse of light. There's a lot more of it in the retro lounge opposite the bar, already a social nerve center for a young, good-looking crowd, and there's still more atop the steel and glass staircase, which leads to a soothingly decorated dining room suspended over the main floor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHNER, DANIEL B., M.D.
description: KUSHNER-Daniel B., M.D. Physician and former councilman of Alpine, NJ (1984-1990), on February 13, 2001. Beloved husband of 36 years of Zina, loving father of Dr. Adam, Jonathan and Lesley and Jennifer. Medical director of the Boulevard Health Center, Bronx, NY. Private practice of Internal Medicine and Cardiology East 60th St, NYC. Attending physician Mt. Sinai Hospital. Instructor Mt. Sinai School of Medicine. A graduate of Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine-1951. Internship George Washington University Hospital, 1951-52. Residency Kings County Hospital Center, 1952-53, and Bellevue Hospital Center, 1953-54. Fellow Cornell University Medical School Department of Pharmacology, 1954-55. Board certified in internal medicine. Services Friday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions in his name to Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America.

title: Rewriting the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Upsets No. 35 Voltchkov
description: Wayne Black of Zimbabwe upset second-seeded Vladimir Voltchkov of Belarus yesterday in the first round of the Copenhagen Open, scoring a 6-4, 6-2 victory. Voltchkov, ranked No. 35, created a sensation last year when he won eight matches in a row at Wimbledon, becoming only the second player after John McEnroe in 1977 to make it to the semifinals after starting as a qualifier. Top-seeded Tim Henman of Britain beat Slava Dosedel of the Czech Republic, 6-4, 2-6, 6-1. (Agence France-Presse)

title: A Win for Intellectual Property
description: The federal Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has upheld a trial court's preliminary injunction against Napster's online exchange of copyrighted music -- and issued a convincing rebuttal of the company's arguments that its members engage in a fair use of copyrighted material. The decision is a major victory for the music record industry, and more broadly for all creators of original material.

title: Article 2001021491384435531 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Channel 5 Gets 50 Yankees Games
description: WNYW-TV and Madison Square Garden Network reached an agreement yesterday that grants Channel 5 in New York exclusive television rights to 50 Yankees games for the 2001 season. Cablevision Systems' MSG Network will oversee production of the broadcasts. About 100 Yankees games will be broadcast in the New York market on MSG Network, which has owned the team's television rights since 1989.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The dollar rose after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the economic slowdown would most likely be limited. In New York, the euro settled at 92.03 cents, down from 93.09 cents.

title: INSIDE
description: Call for Swift Tax Cut

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Migrants Plant Pine Trees but Often Pocket Peanuts
description: Outside the Pine Tree Motel, under the reddish glow of a neon sign, Rubn and 10 other Mexican workers pile into a van at 5:30 a.m. and head to a warehouse an hour away, where they load thousands of pine seedlings into a trailer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSSMAN, LOUIS
description: GROSSMAN-Louis. What's good about goodbye? What's fair about farewell? We love and miss you. Your Loving Family

title: Article 2001021490347703964 -- No Title
description: In Tapping the Net, the F.B.I. Insists Privacy Is Not a Victim

title: McCain to Offer Bill to Help Air Travelers
description: Having blocked a passenger rights bill for air travelers in 1999, Senator John McCain, chairman of the Commerce Committee, said today that he would soon introduce his own measure, and he quickly drew support from other committee members who had already planned similar legislation.

title: Kingmaker in Brazil Has Built a Castle of His Own
description: From the moment of arrival, there is no doubt who controls the reins of power here. Visitors land at an airport named for a member of the Magalhes clan, whose names also adorn the main highway into town and assorted monuments, schools and buildings.

title: Census Makes Gains in Reducing Number of People Not Counted
description: The number of people overlooked in the census may have dropped for the nation as a whole in 2000 and plummeted sharply for many minorities compared with 10 years ago, people familiar with the yet-to-be published census data said yesterday.

title: Article 2001021493004661255 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: A Voice on Term Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIALLER, JOSEPH
description: BIALLER-Joseph. Of Teaneck, NJ, on Feb. 13. Beloved husband of the late Florence, devoted father of Leslie and Nancy. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' Hackensack on Wednesday, Feb. 14, at 1 PM. Should friends desire contributions to the Imus Childrens Center c/o Hackensack Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the business implications of the first analysis of the human genome compared the number of genes in humans and roundworms incorrectly. Humans have about 50 percent more genes, not just one-third more.

title: I Want to Read
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany Weighs Overhaul of 'Consensus' Capitalism
description: The debate may sound tedious and even trivial. But behind a fog of discourse over arcane rules, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder is about to decide an issue at the heart of efforts to overhaul and modernize Germany's ''consensus'' approach to capitalism.

title: LOSS AT INTERNET AUCTIONEER
description: QXL Ricardo, a British Internet auctioneer, reported a wider third-quarter loss related to acquisition costs. For the three months ended Dec. 31, QXL Ricardo lost 41.3 million ($60 million), including good will for acquisitions, compared with 38 million ($55.2 million at current exchange rates) a year ago. QXL said it had 2.6 million members at the end of the period, a sevenfold increase from last year. Shares declined 10 percent, to 11 pence (16 cents). Suzanne Kapner

title: Looks Like Winter, Tastes Like Summer
description: A CHILLED, minty drink sounds like a summer cooler. But one look at Serendipity 3's new frozen white chocolate and you think winter. It's a snowy confection, icy cold (though the restaurant playfully calls it ''hot chocolate'') and piled high like a snowbank in its ice cream bowl. Look closely and you'll see tiny flecks of green. A harbinger of spring? No. It's the fresh mint that adds to the refreshment.

title: Phyllis Levy; Editor, 69
description: Phyllis S. Levy, a prominent Good Housekeeping book editor who in her early publishing career helped discover Ken Kesey, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 69.

title: Handlers Size Up Judges Before Dogs Enter the Ring
description: Awaiting her turn to show an Afghan hound yesterday at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, Bobbi Kinley-Blewett felt that she knew what to expect of the judge, Carol A. Reisman. Kinley-Blewett believed that the black Afghan she handles, Ch. Xandali Isabeau of Boanne, or Izzy, was the type of dark-colored dog with the classic sort of movement that Reisman favored.

title: Don't Pull Up a Chair: Plump Up a Pillow
description: A YOUNG woman in pigtails, a short baby-doll dress and frilly white bloomers kneeled over the mattress and offered me a jar of beluga caviar with the relevant fixings. I lunged for it, but she pulled it away, carefully placing the platter on the mattress between us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRIAT, ILANA
description: KIRIAT-Ilana. On February 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Dr. George Kiriat. Devoted mother of Dr. Raffi Kiriat and his wife Joan, & Gideon Kiriat and his wife Nita. Cherished grandmother of Sheera, Jessica, Oren and Leigh. Funeral service is today at 10:00 A.M., Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Military Budget Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSBERG, EZEKIEL (OSCAR)
description: KOSBERG-Ezekiel (Oscar), 92. Passed away on February 13, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Minnie. Devoted father of David and Larry. Special father-in-law of Helen and Frida. Service to be held at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ on February 15, 2001 at 1 PM.

title: When Rage And Pride Illuminate The Genius
description: In the very entertaining first act of ''Cellini,'' John Patrick Shanley's new play about the grandeur of the artistic temperament, the hubris of Benvenuto Cellini, the great Florentine sculptor and goldsmith of the Renaissance, is presented as a lively, emotional struggle against self-immolation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: The Best Ever Is Forever Down the Road
description: IT can happen when you arrive. Sometimes it doesn't happen until you are putting on your coat and getting ready to leave. It may happen in the middle of the dinner, the party, the meeting. One thing is certain: if you are involved in wine in any way, it is going to happen.

title: A Spunky Bichon Fris Prances to a Big Championship at Westminster
description: In the end, cute, fluffy and friendly won.

title: BMW picks a shop to introduce its Mini car to the United States.
description: A MINICAR is giving a maxiboost to a smallish agency with big ambitions.

title: Mayors Make Overtures as China Holds Baton
description: The mayor of Taipei and his opposite number from Hong Kong met for a more than an hour today, holding a chat that spoke volumes about the political gamesmanship in relations between Taiwan and China.

title: Ambivalent Writer Turns His Memoir Upside Down; Denouncing Profits and Publishers While Profiting From Publication
description: Most first-time authors whose books become best sellers are simply delighted, but not Dave Eggers. The experience was brutal, he writes in an additional section for the paperback version of his memoir, ''A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius.'' He dreaded returning to it, he writes, ''like one dreads seeing a bad-smelling distant elderly relative lying prone in a rank and wrong nursing home.'' Just weeks before the paperback's publication yesterday, he half seriously asked his editors at Vintage Books if they could call the whole thing off.

title: Snag in Clinton's Office Plan: Giuliani Stakes Claim to Space
description: For Bill Clinton, yesterday was yet another New York moment -- one minute he was up, the next he was down, this time tangled in a real estate dispute with one of his wife's former rivals.

title: Political Memo; Clinton Out of Office, Diminished in Power and Caught Unawares
description: When Bill Clinton left the White House three weeks ago, he had, by most accounts, given little thought to the mundane details of the life that awaited him at the end of his Air Force flight out of Washington. That became quite clear on his first Sunday morning in Chappaqua, N.Y.: the former president had to enlist his wife's campaign spokesman to drive up from New York City to deal with the reporters on his driveway.

title: Arab Drives Bus Into Crowd, Killing 8 Israelis
description: AZUR, Israel, Feb. 14  After years of shuttling Gazan laborers into Israel without incident, a Palestinian bus driver who passed a strict Israeli security clearance just two weeks ago veered wildly off course today with deadly consequences.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Colombian Military Officers Convicted in '97 Village Killings
description: An army general and a colonel were convicted late Monday for allowing right-wing paramilitary gunmen to kill dozens of villagers in 1997, the first such conviction of high-ranking military officers in a human rights case.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Monday about ''These Old Broads,'' a drama on ABC, referred incorrectly to Debbie Reynolds's appearance. It was not her television debut; she has long acted on television and appeared recently in ''Will and Grace'' on NBC.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON NAMES 2 TO NEW VICE CHAIRMAN POSTS
description: Johnson & Johnson named two top executives to newly created positions of vice chairmen yesterday, a move seen as preparing for new leadership at the company, one of the world's top makers of medical devices and drugs. James Lenehan, head of the medical device and diagnostics business, and William Weldon, who leads the pharmaceuticals business, will become part of the office of the chairman, joining Johnson & Johnson's chief executive, Ralph Larsen, 62, and its senior vice chairman, Robert Wilson, 60. Johnson & Johnson declined to comment on the reasons for the appointment.

title: TV Notes: Just One Year for `Sopranos'?
description: Just One Year For `Sopranos'?

title: KOREA TELECOM SALE FAILS
description: South Korea failed to sell much of the stake it offered in Korea Telecom, setting back the government's efforts to sell off its 59 percent stake in the nation's biggest phone company by next year. Local investors agreed to buy 3.3 million shares at an average price of 66,967 won ($53.20) a share, the company said. That was about 4.5 percent below the market price, and represents 1.1 percent of the company. The government wanted to sell 14.7 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEYERS, BONNIE LYNN
description: MEYERS-Bonnie Lynn. On your 35th birthday, and always, many loving thoughts bring you back. Mom, Mark, Jud & Grandparents

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: What New York Schools Get in Aid Often Has Little Connection to Needs
description: Last month, a state court judge threw out the formula by which New York State distributes money to its schools, ruling that New York City does not receive enough to offer a ''sound, basic education.'''

title: Go Ahead, Laugh. It Works at Work.
description: At her 7 a.m. staff meeting one Thursday last month, Bobbe White passed out an agenda that contained a cryptic item called ''stress reduction technique'' right after her marketing update. Her 45 bleary-eyed co-workers thought nothing of it until Ms. White, a business development officer at State Street Bank and Trust Company in Quincy, Ill., showed a two-minute ABC news feature on laughter clubs in India.

title: A Canadian Rail Pioneer Plans Split-Up
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., which built the railroad that linked Canada's prairies to the west coast in the 1880's and later expanded into a conglomerate, announced plans today to split itself into five publicly traded companies, a move intended to mollify holders of the company's lagging stock.

title: Mr. Clinton's Next Move
description: Former President Clinton has taken a step to clear up one of the many problems he created for himself just before and after he left the White House. He abandoned the pricey Manhattan office suite he had hoped to occupy on West 57th Street for less expensive and symbolically more appropriate quarters on 125th Street in Harlem. The move reflected Mr. Clinton's well-honed instincts for damage control, but was at least a commendable break from the recent pattern of Clinton outrages.

title: 'Gladiator,' 'Crouching Tiger' and Soderbergh Are Oscar Nominees
description: Ang Lee, the director of ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' was at the front desk of his New York hotel, checking in after a long night of shooting in New Jersey, when his publicist reached him with the news. Joan Allen, star of ''The Contender,'' had just taken a shower with her pet parrot and was watching the Oscar nominations in her Upper West Side apartment while blow-drying the bird. (''You're not supposed to let them get a chill.'') Javier Bardem, a star of ''Before Night Falls,'' was alone at home in Madrid, having a beer, when the news came across Spanish television. And Jeff Bridges, best supporting actor nominee for ''The Contender,'' was being worked on by the makeup artist Edouard Henriques, nominated for ''The Cell,'' while nearby the cinematographer John Mathieson, nominated for ''Gladiator,'' was preparing for a shot.

title: Sofitel's Winter Sale
description: Agood deal sometimes means paying less than usual for deluxe accommodations, even if the price seems steep by roadside-motel standards. Take, for instance, the Winter Sale at 70 Sofitel hotels worldwide. Through March 11, the rate for a double room with breakfast and service charges (there may be value-added tax and city tax in some places) will fall into one of six categories: $129, $149, $169, $219, $269 and $369. At the lowest price, guests can choose from the Sofitel at the Brussels airport (normally $250), Lille Metropole in France (versus $135 regularly), Nice ($160) and Houston ($209). Skipping to the $169 level, the hotels include the Sofitels in Bologna (regularly $212), Amsterdam ($195) and Los Angeles ($349). The $269 rate applies to the Sofitel New York (regularly $449) and Rome ($480), among others. And for $369, you can get a suite or junior suite in Paris at the Le Faubourg (normally $430) and Hotel Scribe ($660). Rates are subject to availability. Contact (800) 763-4835 or www.sofitel.com .

title: Article 2001021493238811394 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Alfonseca Gets 2-Year Contract
description: The Florida Marlins signed their closer, Antonio Alfonseca, to a two-year contract today, thereby avoiding salary arbitration.

title: A School District Refuses To Worship Scores Alone
description: IN 1997, four school board members in this upper-middle-class Chicago suburb ran for re-election against challengers who said that test scores were high, but not high enough.

title: Feed the Economy, And Watch It Grow
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001021492254001623 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Liberties; Black And White
description: There is nothing like stealing a presidential election to put a little wind in a guy's sails.

title: Crichton Signs With HarperCollins After 3 Decades With Knopf
description: The best-selling author Michael Crichton has agreed to publish his next two books with the HarperCollins Publishers division of the News Corporation, a disappointment for his longtime publisher, the Knopf Publishing Group of Bertelsmann.

title: INSURERS PLAN ONLINE MARKET
description: Here is a new twist in selling insurance on the Internet: Instead of one company hawking its wares or a broker offering coverage from a handful of companies, three insurance companies are joining forces to form a marketplace site. The American International Group, the Kemper Insurance Companies and the Prudential Insurance Company of America expect to start before the end of the year with auto insurance. They say the new site, to be known as Fusura -- coined from the words future and insurance -- will let customers compare coverage offered by the three and immediately close a deal using a credit card. Until now, customers have had to hop from one company's site to another or go to brokers' sites where many companies' prices were quoted. Then they often had to contact the company they selected. The new site promises to take much of the frustration out of insurance shopping on the Web. Joseph B. Treaster

title: Pain Relief for Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Shepard Kurnit; Advertising Executive, 76
description: Shepard Kurnit, a longtime advertising executive, died on Saturday. He was 76 and lived in Manhattan and Boca Raton, Fla. The cause was a brain tumor, said his son Rick.

title: Lendl, With 8 Grand Slams, and Rose Gain Hall
description: Ivan Lendl, whose baseline style and relentless preparation and fitness lifted him to eight Grand Slam singles titles between 1984 and 1990, and Mervyn Rose, the left-handed anchor of the Australian Davis Cup team from 1951 to 1957, were announced today as the 2001 inductees into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: Figures Show Redskins Spent Most
description: Success in the National Football League is not always the result of big spending. Simply look at the Giants and the Washington Redskins.

title: Europe Approves New Genetically Modified Food Control
description: PARIS, Feb. 14 -- The European Union Parliament passed a measure today that establishes strict rules on genetically modified organisms, preparing to end Europe's unofficial moratorium on bioengineered seeds and food.

title: In Quick Recovery, Brazil Sells Three Wireless Licenses
description: Rebounding from the failure of its auction two weeks ago, when no valid bids were received, the Brazilian government succeeded in selling three wireless telephone licenses for a total of $1.32 billion in an auction at the Rio de Janeiro stock market.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: ROGERS LOSS NARROWS
description: Rogers Communications, Canada's No. 1 cable television company, said its fourth-quarter loss narrowed as it attracted more cable television subscribers and sold more advertising at its radio stations. The loss narrowed to 21.1 million Canadian dollars ($13.8 million), or 20 cents a share, from 27.2 million dollars ($17.9 million), or 19 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 9.9 percent to 947.2 million dollars ($662.7 million). Rogers Communications, based in Toronto, competes with BCE, Canada's No. 1 telecommunications company, for digital television, wireless phone and fast-Internet customers.

title: BP Amoco Posts Rise In Earnings For Quarter
description: BP Amoco said today that fourth-quarter profit from operations nearly doubled, fattened by higher oil and gas prices, and cost savings from acquisitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, LEO P., JR.
description: LARKIN-Leo P., Jr. Cornell Delta Phi Association, The Cornell Delta Phi Educational Fund and Llenroc Foundation record with deepest sorrow the passing of its distinguished member, trustee and officer, Leo P. Larkin, Jr. He shall be missed.

title: Bats Crack and Balls Arc; The Yanks' Spring Nears
description: A few more familiar faces arrive here each day, to shake hands and to join the last informal workouts before spring training begins later this week. They come to the Yankees' minor league complex on North Himes Avenue: the pitchers stretch and throw, the hitters hit and then take groundballs.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CITY ECONOMY KEEPS GROWING
description: New York City's economy ended 2000 on a strong note and continues to outpace the nation's, according to a report issued yesterday by Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller. In the last three months of last year, economic growth in the city, as measured by the value of goods and services produced, hit 3.6 percent, versus the national rate of 1.4 percent. At the same time, the number of jobs in the city soared and the unemployment rate fell. ''But if the national slowdown continues, it is bound to affect the city,'' Mr. Hevesi said in a statement. ''The Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts should help, but the impact may not be felt for a few months.'' Leslie Eaton

title: Investigator For Prosecutor Kills Himself In His Office
description: A senior investigator for the Queens district attorney's office who was known for his compassionate work with the victims of violent crimes shot himself to death in his office yesterday morning, the authorities said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CALPINE CORP., San Jose, Calif., an independent power producer, said it would build a power plant near Beloit, Wis., for $350 million. Construction is scheduled to begin in the third quarter of 2001, and Calpine expects the plant to be operating by the third quarter of 2003.

title: Jersey City Mayor Begins Race for Governor
description: Declaring that New Jersey cannot solve its property tax problem without reforming its education system, Bret D. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City, began his campaign for the Republican nomination for governor today by promising his conservative programs would lower tax rates for homeowners and offer more school choice for parents.

title: $50 Million Given to Pay for Kirov Performances
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13  Alberto W. Vilar, who has made large donations to performing arts institutions in the United States and in Europe in the last year, is about to do it again with a gift of $50 million to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Lawyer's Killing Puzzles Investigators
description: The days of Sanford Silver's life were simple and ordered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHEZ, HELEN JULIETTE
description: MATHEZ-Helen Juliette. Died at home on February 12, 2001. Funeral service at 10:30AM Thursday, February 15 at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. James' would be appreciated.

title: Just One Year For 'Sopranos'?
description: On March 4, ''The Sopranos'' will return to HBO for its third season of brand-new episodes, ending a long and excruciating wait for a horde of fervent fans. But they are well advised to take in every moment of every episode this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTSON, LAWRENCE T.
description: MATTSON-Lawrence T. On February 12, 2001 at Trumbull, Ct. Formerly of Sunnyside, N.Y. Beloved husband of Rose (nee McNulty), loving father of Lawrence, Charles, Maureen Gartlan, and Ann Feldmann. Cherished grandfather to eight grandchildren. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd, Sunnyside, N.Y. Funeral Mass Queen of Angels R.C. Church, Thursday, 9:45 AM. Interment St John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St Joseph's Manor, Trumbull, Ct. 203-268-6204.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIN, STEPHEN
description: SCHEIN-Stephen. Beloved husband of Ethel, loving father of Bette and Richard Pesikoff and Jonah and Carla Schein and dear brother of Edith Kohl. Adoring grandfather & great grandfather. Funeral Service Wednesday, February 14, 1PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNETBUY.COM CHIEF RESIGNS Hoping that a change of management will help turn the company around, the Internet retailer Buy .com said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Gregory Hawkins, left, and its chief financial officer, Mitch Hill, had resigned. It said James B. Roszak, a board member since 1998, would serve as interim chief executive. Another board member, Donald Kendall, retired chief executive of PepsiCo, was appointed as the new chairman. The management changes follow Buy.com's announcement earlier this month that its sales this year would be $580 million to $600 million, 43 percent to 45 percent below analysts' forecasts. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: BUY.COM CHIEF RESIGNS
description: Hoping that a change of management will help turn the company around, the Internet retailer Buy .com said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Gregory Hawkins, left, and its chief financial officer, Mitch Hill, had resigned. It said James B. Roszak, a board member since 1998, would serve as interim chief executive. Another board member, Donald Kendall, retired chief executive of PepsiCo, was appointed as the new chairman. The management changes follow Buy.com's announcement earlier this month that its sales this year would be $580 million to $600 million, 43 percent to 45 percent below analysts' forecasts. Susan Stellin

title: Palestinian Officer Is Killed by Israelis
description: Two Israeli helicopter gunships swooped over northern Gaza yesterday and fired four missiles at the car of a senior Palestinian security officer, instantly killing him. Israel holds him responsible for a failed mortar attack on a Jewish settlement in Gaza and for unrealized plans to kidnap senior Israeli military officials.

title: Islanders Seeing the Future, and He Is 19
description: Rick DiPietro had been thinking about what he would do with the puck after he made the save. There was one hitch in his plan: He did not make the save.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURNIT, SHEPARD
description: KURNIT-Shepard. Beloved husband of Jean. Father of Paul, Rick and Scott. Brother of Hal, Vic and Norman. Father-in-law of Susan Kurnit, Diane Katzin and Abbe Heller, and grandfather of Ara, Jesse and Katrina. Died peacefully on February 10. In lieu of flowers donations to Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 2247, NYC 10116. A memorial service will be held on February 16 at the W New York Hotel, 541 Lexington Ave. (50th St.) at 10:30 AM.

title: Health Care Is Mrs. Clinton's First Item on Senate Floor
description: In her first address from the floor of the United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton offered an agenda of health care initiatives today, casting herself as a moderate on the very issue that resulted in one of her most embarrassing defeats as first lady.

title: After People Power
description: In 1997, as an American official invited to Serbia to address a conference on economic reform, I described Belgrade as ''the Pyongyang of Europe.'' The speech was, of course, condemned by Slobodan Milosevic. Now that Belgrade is free from his rule, the question is what kind of place it will choose to be. Despite the peaceful triumph of ''people power'' last October, there are lingering doubts about Serbia's future direction.

title: O'Neill Presses Case for Swift Action on Taxes
description: Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill urged Congress today to give swift passage to key elements of President Bush's proposal for a 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut as a way to help stave off any further downturn in the economy.

title: Review/Fashion; Creating a Fantasy Life Beyond the Seams
description: Sometimes a fashion show provides such an exquisite keyhole into a certain kind of life -- specifically, the status life of New York -- that automatically your mind starts reeling off all these little scenes, very Upper East Side, very Mario Buatta, with the pillows creased just so and all these blond divorces ready to carve each other up while they slowly pick their way through their rare hamburgers at Swifty's and wonder what became of Mr. Right in St. Bart's.

title: Libya Under Qaddafi: Disarray Is the Norm
description: Life can be so unpredictable here that people are not even sure what year it is.

title: 4 Police Officers Hurt Chasing an Assault Suspect
description: Four police officers were injured yesterday in a frenzied chase in which the police pursued a suspect in an assault along crowded streets and over backyard fences in the Bronx before they caught up with him, officials said.

title: Article 2001021494091301565 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, GEORGIA (GORJA)
description: MILLS-Georgia (Gorja). 1919-2001 Queens, NY (former longtime resident of Perris). Services were held Monday, February 12, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISEMAN, JANE GENTRY SHELTON
description: WISEMAN-Jane Gentry Shelton. 67, in San Francisco on January 28, of cancer. Born in St. Louis, MO; attended The Master's School, Dobbs Ferry, NY and Smith College. Daughter of William Gentry Shelton and granddaughter of Frank Overton Watts. President, First National Bank of St. Louis. Pursued career as a stockbroker, entrepreneur and restaurateur in New York City, Shelter Island, New York, and San Francisco. Survived by her three loving children, Sayre and John, of Los Angeles and Shelley, of New York, and a grandson, Liam. A celebration of her life will be held this summer in New York: contact Shelley Wiseman at swshellbell@aol.com. Donations in her memory may be made to the Shelter Island Public Library, P.O. Box #

title: Testing His Love, She Jumps Into $1,500 Worth of Milk
description: In the production notes for ''The Price of Milk,'' a terminally whimsical contemporary fairy tale set in New Zealand farming country, its director, Harry Sinclair, calls the film ''my dream about New Zealand, this make-believe country that seems almost empty of people, where love stories are played out in silence and loneliness.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARCOVE, RALPH C., M.D.
description: MARCOVE-Ralph C., M.D. Memorial service Thursday, February 22, 2001, 5PM at the Chapel at Presbyterian Hospital, 622 West 168 Street, New York City.

title: Nickelodeon's Tweens
description: Almost since its inception, Nickelodeon, the No. 1 children's network, has faced a problem inherent to its programming.

title: Youths Held In Eco-Terror Are Reported Nearing Plea
description: Lawyers for two young suspects in an underground campaign of arson and destruction in Suffolk County are in negotiations with federal prosecutors that could result in guilty pleas in Federal District Court as soon as Wednesday, a law enforcement official said today.

title: Rewriting the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: MANAGEMENT: Business Students Do an About-Face; Recruiters for Banks and Consultants Have Regained the Upper Hand
description: Ask business school students what ''B2B'' and ''B2C'' stand for these days, and you will probably not hear the same answer you would have a year ago. Then, the dot-com craze was in full throttle, and it seemed everybody wanted to join a ''business to business'' or ''business to consumer'' Internet start-up.

title: Dutch Police Arrest Suspect After Computer Virus Spreads
description: The Dutch police arrested a 20-year-old man today who confessed to having released a malicious software program that arrived in e-mail boxes disguised as a picture of the tennis star Anna Kournikova.

title: In Brooklyn, a Bistro Comes Into Its Own
description: AMONG the French bistros that dominate the Smith Street restaurant row in Brooklyn, Smith Street Kitchen alone specializes in seafood. And perhaps best of all, the restaurant offers excellent value, especially now, when prices have risen and few fish restaurants are accessible to diners on a moderate budget.

title: COMPETITION IN WIRELESS MARKET
description: The Matsushita Communication Industrial Company plans to ship 10 million lower-priced handsets to Europe next year, hoping to take market share from Nokia and other rivals. Matsushita, which is Japan's largest maker of mobile phones but is better known for its Panasonic brand, will begin shipping the new models in March, said Yoshihisa Tatsumi, general manager for overseas marketing.

title: Bush Says He'll Be Judicious in His Use of Troops
description: YEAGER FIELD, W. Va., Feb. 14  President Bush said today that he would be judicious in sending American forces overseas, warning that "over-deployments" can strain troops, their families and, in the case of members of the National Guard and Reserves, their civilian employers.

title: Shares Fall After Greenspan Hedges Odds of a Rate Cut
description: Stock prices moved lower yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested in Senate testimony that economic conditions did not warrant aggressive cuts in interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAME, HON. ABRAHAM D.
description: BEAME-Hon. Abraham D. The City College of New York mourns the passing of the Hon. Abraham D. Beame, former Mayor of New York City and a 1928 alumnus of CCNY. Mayor Beame provided long and distinguished service to the people of our city. He was devoted to his Alma Mater and served with distinction on the Board of The City College Fund. On behalf of CCNY's faculty, students and alumni I wish to extend my deepest sympathy to his family. Stanford A. Roman, Jr., Interim President The City College of New York/ CUNY

title: Ussuriysk Journal; A Tipple That a Tiger, It Seems, Finds Toothsome
description: Galina Savostyanova cupped her hands as if holding a delicate crystal snifter and lowered her eyelids to half-mast. All but purring, she proffered her personal advice on imbibing one of the finest beverages in all Russia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, ROBERT
description: SIMON-Robert. Loving husband of the late Pearl. Beloved father of Roberta Simon and father-in-law of Herbert Leiman. Cherished grandfather of Peter Leiman, fond brother of Marvin and dear friend of Jane Faggen. Services today at 12 noon, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, New York, New York.

title: Quake in El Salvador
description: A powerful earthquake struck El Salvador, leaving 170 dead and 1,500 injured. The quake, with a preliminary magnitude of 6.6, struck one month after a quake with a 7.6 magnitude killed at least 844 people and left thousands homeless. The tremor was felt in neighboring Honduras and Guatemala.

title: Amtrak Chooses A New Agency
description: Amtrak said yesterday that it had selected the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, as the agency for its account, which had been handled for more than 25 years by the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at more than $35 million.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the expansion of Russian-Ukrainian cooperation in civilian space research and aviation misstated the given name of the secretary of Ukraine's national security council, who denied that the two countries would jointly make intercontinental ballistic missiles. He is Yevhen Marchuk, not Oleksandr.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa climbed on speculation that a shortage of workers on Ivory Coast farms had reduced available supplies for export. In New York, cocoa for May delivery rose $38, or 3.6 percent, to $1,093 a metric ton.

title: Advertising: Addenda
description: Amtrak Chooses a New Agency

title: Article 2001021491026233760 -- No Title
description: February 12, 2001

title: Reckonings; Doing the Wrong Thing
description: Three weeks ago Alan Greenspan, in his now-famous testimony to the Senate Budget Committee, gave decisive aid and comfort to the advocates of huge, irresponsible tax cuts. Rumor has it that Mr. Greenspan himself was taken aback by the feeding frenzy unleashed by that testimony, and that he is now engaged in a backdoor campaign to limit the damage. (Damage to the nation, or to himself? Good question.) The Medley Report, a newsletter on economic affairs, says that ''many Congressional Democrats have heard Mr. Greenspan -- or his aides -- tell them that he actually favors something like $1 trillion in total tax cuts rather than $1.6 trillion.''

title: Peace Talks in Colombia
description: The resumption of peace talks today between the Colombian government and the country's largest guerrilla group is a welcome development. There can be no purely military solution to this 37-year-old conflict, and without some kind of negotiated settlement with the guerrillas there is a significant risk that Washington's $1.3 billion anti-narcotics aid package to Colombia could draw Americans into the fighting. Most of that assistance is for military training and equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, RUTH J.,
description: ROSENBERG-Ruth J., 89. Of Deerfield Beach. Died February 12, 2001. Wife of the late Edward. Survived by her son Dr. Stephen (Barbara), daughter Barbara Guter (Dr. Marvin), and 4 grandchildren, Jordana, Amanda (Finance Kevin Hall), Lev & Avi. Services will be held Thursday, 1 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St., New York, NY. Donations may be made to Hadassah.

title: Questionable Performance Leaves the Knicks Stumped
description: The Knicks could see Nick Van Exel pushing the ball up the floor with the speed of a getaway car, but couldn't find the energy to keep pace with him.

title: The Hot New Green On New York's Plate
description: I FIRST fell for puntarelle a few years ago, when I had a job cooking in Tuscany at a farmhouse bed-and-breakfast. It was a green unlike anything I had tasted back in the land of romaine lettuce.
