It had a little pepperiness like arugula in the leaves, a hint of fennel in the stalks and an underlying flavor that was a cross between chicory and endive. It even had the crisp, satisfying crunch of celery in top form.

title: Piano Pieces From a Luminous and Fantastical World
description: After five years in which Gyorgy Ligeti has produced only odd piano pieces in his continuing series of tudes, suddenly he has come out with two larger works: a set of songs for mezzo-soprano and percussion quartet, and a long-awaited horn concerto. Both were performed Sunday night in the Queen Elizabeth Hall here by the London Sinfonietta. Both are brilliant, funny and strange, highly sophisticated yet immediately apparent to the ear and delightful.

title: From Alsace, a Lively White That Goes with Everything
description: FOR many wine drinkers, the holy grail is an unpretentious, versatile wine that can be enjoyed with dinner any night of the week.

title: TRACK AND FIELD; New Zealand Has Its Best Young Miler Yet
description: Nick Willis is the most promising high school miler in New Zealand since John Walker and Rod Dixon. And, from all indications, his best races are yet to come.

title: Will the Real Voters Please Stand Up?
description: Last week the final ballots were submitted by the 17,000 recording business professionals who vote on the Grammys. More so than in the recent past, voting this year became a moral and political decision because Eminem's outrage-igniting ''The Marshall Mathers LP'' (Interscope) is a nominee for the night's most prestigious award: album of the year. Throughout the voting, members of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (which produces the Grammys) received pressure from both pro- and anti-Eminem factions.

title: National News Briefs; Police Arrest a Student In Killings at Gallaudet
description: The police tonght announced the arrest of a man in the killing of two students at Gallaudet University here and said robbery had apparently been the motive.

title: Time Revamps Business Titles
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that it had reorganized its business magazines into a new unit to be led by John Huey, the managing editor of Fortune. Mr. Huey was named to the new position of editor of Fortune and will be succeeded by Richard Kirkland, the magazine's deputy managing editor.

title: Fighting Free Music, Europeans Take Aim at Personal Computers
description: While American music producers pursue their marathon court battle against Napster and other free-music sites on the Internet, European composers and record companies are opening an entirely different front in the war against unauthorized copying: the personal computers that do the actual work.

title: Puntarelle with Lemons, Olives and Feta
description: Time: 35 minutes

title: Statehouse Journal; Governor's Drug Efforts Show Fruit in Santa Fe
description: When he first proposed radical changes to his state's drug laws almost 18 months ago, Gov. Gary E. Johnson of New Mexico was viewed by many New Mexicans as something of an oddity.

title: Thursday Night Logjam
description: The impact of moving the CBS reality show ''Survivor'' to Thursday has created one of the most unusual logjams of popular programs in television history. Last week, the 18-to-49-year-old viewers that networks covet -- mainly because advertisers do -- turned up on Thursday night in remarkable numbers: enough so that of 7 of the top 10 shows in that age category were seen that night. No other night had more than one show.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Touches of Poetry, Stages of Dying,

title: Hail Chiefs With a Day For Each One
description: FOR starters, there is the floating apostrophe. It's a bit of a pain.

title: High Fatality Rate Found in Cars That Crash With Explorers
description: A new federal study of how vehicles interact in crashes has found that Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles seem to be especially deadly to the occupants of cars they hit, even compared with other midsize sport utility vehicles.

title: THE CHEF
description: WINE is important to all my tasting menus, but most vegetables have a hard time with wine, red wine in particular, because they're chalky and starchy. If you're not using mushrooms, which go well with reds, it can be difficult to come up with an entree. And since you can't tweak the wine, you have to tweak the food.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANCTUARY OF ABRAHAM AND SARAH ABOVE GROUND JEWISH BURIAL
description: Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah Above ground Jewish burial. Affordable indoor mausoleum spaces and prime family rooms. Free brochure, call 800-526-4600.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SESAME STREET-TIME INC. DEAL
description: He may laugh. He may let you tickle him. But yesterday it became clear that not even something as cute as Elmo is safe from economic change. Employees had a hard time not making Oscar the Grouch jokes yesterday, as the Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit education organization that created the ''Sesame Street'' television show, laid off 60 workers and said it would turn over the production and marketing of its Sesame Street Magazine, which is geared to children, to Time Inc., and close its other magazine, Sesame Street Parents. The financial details of the 10-year agreement were not disclosed yesterday. Sesame Workshop changed its name from the Children's Television Workshop last year. The magazines are bundled together and have an estimated 1.1 million readers. Beginning in October, Sesame Street Magazine will be packaged with Parenting, which is published by the Parenting Group, a division of Time Inc. Sesame Workshop will continue to provide the editorial content for Sesame Street Magazine. Jayson Blair

title: Op-Art; Love Found
Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, PHYLLIS SARI
description: LEVY-Phyllis Sari. A wonderful woman in all respects. Peaceful now, after a long illness. Survived by her adored mother, Ruth Jaffe, her dear sister, Susan, and brother-in-law, Paul. Services private.

title: Microsoft Introduces New Windows System
description: Stung by slowing personal computer sales and continuing antitrust battles, Microsoft introduced a new version of its Windows software today, one that it hopes will help restore the company to its glory days of the 1990's.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Remodeled Tavern For a New Century
description: Don't expect squirrel pie.

title: CHICAGO BRIDGE SAYS IT LAID OFF 130 TO REDUCE ITS COSTS
description: The Chicago Bridge and Iron Company, an engineering and construction company, said yesterday that it cut 130 jobs during the fourth quarter to trim costs after acquiring Howe-Baker International Inc. and two units of Pitt-Des Moines Inc. The company also trimmed other costs at five operations worldwide, it said. In December, Chicago Bridge completed the purchase of Howe-Baker for $130.4 million to add the ability to construct natural gas processing plants. This month, it completed the purchase of the Pitt-Des Moines engineered construction and water storage units for $84 million in cash and stock.

title: GREENSPAN UPBEAT ON THE ECONOMY
description: While warning that the economy still faces substantial risks, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the United States was not in a recession and that the slowdown it was experiencing could prove to be as short as it is sharp.

title: Families Win Cuban Money In Pilots' Case
description: The Treasury Department has authorized the release of $96.7 million in frozen Cuban funds to the families of three Miami-based pilots shot down by Cuban fighter jets in 1996, lawyers for the families said today.

title: Levy Names Panel to Help Reduce Bureaucracy of School System
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has enlisted nine high-powered corporate executives for a panel that will help him further reduce the Board of Education bureaucracy and apply more private-sector practices to the school system.

title: Puntarelle with Anchovies
description: Adapted from Sandro's

title: City Opera Plans Rarities And 8 New Productions
description: The New York City Opera will present eight new productions as part of its 2001-2 season, including the world stage premiere of Deborah Drattell's ''Lilith'' and rarities by Handel, Bellini and Sousa. The company's fall season opens with a new production of Wagner's ''Fliegende Hollnder'' on Sept. 11 and runs through Nov. 18; its spring season runs from March 1 through April 28.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about stroke prevention misidentified a group that is alerting women to the dangers. It is the National Stroke Association, a national nonprofit organization. (The National Stroke Foundation is a local organization in Nebraska.)

title: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on the Military
description: Following are excerpts from remarks yesterday by President Bush at the Joint Forces Command headquarters in Norfolk, Va., as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.:

title: Envisaging The Industry As the Loser On Napster
description: On Monday an appeals court panel decided that Napster, the free music-sharing Internet service, had to stop letting users copy recordings that copyright holders didn't want shared, as soon as those copyright holders could provide a list, and assuming that Napster could figure out the technological means to do so. The decision gave recording companies a brief reprieve from the inevitable.

title: Profits Raise Pressures on U.S.-Owned Factories in Mexican Border Zone
description: CIUDAD ACUNA, Mexico  Juan Tovar Santos, an assembly- line worker in this border city, will not forget the time he traveled to Alcoa's annual shareholders meeting in Pittsburgh and confronted the chief executive about working conditions in Alcoa factories here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAMATO, JOSEPH E.
description: DAMATO-Joseph E., on February 12, 2001. Retired Captain FDNY. Beloved husband of the late Irma (nee Panaro) and Annette (nee Carmelitano). Loving father of Janet Batterberry, Edward and Stephen. Also survived by five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Reposing C. Johann & Sons, 21-04 College Pt. Blvd., College Pt., Wed. 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral Mass St. Fidelis Church, Thursday,10:15 AM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROHS, POLLY HART
description: GROHS-Polly Hart. Of Sarasota Fla. formerly of Cleveland, Ohio and Scarsdale, NY. Died February 12, 2001 at age 87. Beloved wife of Edward M. for 59 years. Dear sister of Elaine H. Neuburger and the late Louis M. Hart. Remembered with love by her nephew and niece, Frederic Neuburger and Joan N. Savitt. She will be missed.

title: A City Remembers Abraham Beame
description: New York City yesterday quietly remembered an immigrant accountant who rose to become its gentleman mayor in the bleak days of the 1970's fiscal crisis, a calamity that turned him out of City Hall but endeared him to those who said he saved the city from financial embarrassment.

title: Study Hints That Alzheimers May Have Nongenetic Cause
description: Poor residents of Ibadan, Nigeria, are much less likely to develop Alzheimer's disease than blacks living in Indianapolis, researchers are reporting. And that, they say, may mean that some factor other than genetics -- high blood pressure, for example, or diet -- may determine whether susceptible people develop the devastating brain disease.

title: New Jersey Trying to Send Police Killer Out of State
description: New Jersey's acting governor, Donald T. DiFrancesco, interjected himself yesterday into the uproar surrounding Thomas Trantino, the paroled killer of two police officers, directing state officials ''to take every possible action'' to transfer Mr. Trantino to another state.

title: Hey, New York. Nice Map. Care to Give It a Try?; The City in Exquisite Detail, Soon to Be Online
description: New York, the city that never tires of looking at itself, has an extraordinary new mirror.

title: I.B.F. Supervision Ends; Founder Gets 22 Months
description: Robert W. Lee Sr., the founder and former president of the International Boxing Federation, who was found guilty of money laundering and tax evasion last August, was sentenced to 22 months in prison today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROBERT W.
description: WHITE-Robert W. Of Weston formerly of Brookline, MA and Concord, MA., Marlborough, NH and Marboro, VT. February 6, 2001. Father of David W. White of Cambridge and Marlboro, VT. Uncle of Barbara and Sally Baker of Needham, MA., and Donald V. Baker of Beverly, MA. Many cousins and friends. Mr. White is predeceased by his wife Margaret Ley (Bazeley) White, a son Timothy White, a brother Henry D. White, and a sister Katharine H. White. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 17th at 2:00 PM in First Church in Chestnut Hill, 26 Suffolk Rd, Chestnut Hill (Newton). Organ prelude to commence at 1:30 PM. Donations may be made to either High Mowing School, PO Box 850, Abbott Hill Rd, Wilton, NH 03086 or Marlboro College, Marlboro, VT 05344 or Marlboro School of Music Inc. Box K, Marlboro, VT 05344 or Walker Home and School, 1968 Central Ave., Needham, MA 02492.

title: Paying the Troops
description: Defense has been this week's theme at the Bush White House, with three successive speeches dwelling on different aspects of the administration's ambitious national security agenda. The latter two speeches dealt with the important and contentious subjects of reforming the way the Pentagon buys weapons systems and a more restrictive approach to foreign peacekeeping missions. We want to dwell today, however, on the subject with which Mr. Bush quite properly began -- the pay, housing and morale of American troops.

title: EUROPE APPROVES STRICT FOOD RULES
description: The European Union Parliament passed a measure today that establishes strict rules on genetically modified organisms, preparing to end Europe's unofficial moratorium on bioengineered seeds and food.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: AIDS and the Global Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Senators Show They Pose a Real Threat to the Devils
description: If the Devils are to be dethroned as Stanley Cup champions this spring, the Ottawa Senators are the type of team to do it. Playing with skill, discipline and an unmistakable lan -- even their redesigned uniforms look classy -- the Senators took over first place in the Eastern Conference tonight with a 3-2 victory over the injury-plagued and schedule-weary Devils in the Meadowlands.

title: Longtime Enemies, Armenia and Turkey Softly Broach Dtente
description: The governments of Armenia and Turkey have initiated quiet diplomatic contacts in recent weeks to evaluate prospects for cooperation and opening the border between them, said people outside the governments who have been briefed on the talks.

title: Transcript of Ambassador Alon Pinkas's Visit to the Middle East Forum
description: Ambassador Alon Pinkas, the consulate general of Israel in New York, answered questions about the Mideast peace process on Wednesday in a forum on The New York Times on the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, BLANCHE
description: BERMAN-Blanche. Wife of the late Jack, mother of Kenny and Ronni and Froma. Sister of Henrietta and the late Nusie. Grandmother of Melissa and Billy Gildin, Neil and Beth Berman, Jamie and Hera Berman, Jennifer and Marc Bernstein. Great grandmother of Ashley, Tyler, Hunter, Mackenzie, Harper, Reese, Nathan and Adam. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside Chapel'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 11:30AM Friday.

title: Bush Discusses Relations With Mexico and Canada
description: President George W. Bush, on the eve of flying to Mexico on his first foreign trip as president, stressed today that his administration considered its relationships with Canada and Latin America as "fundamental" to United States foreign policy.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Feb. 8 about a marketing agreement between the Yankees and the Manchester United soccer team misstated the last time the English club played in the United States. It was 1982, not 1960.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SASS, SHERMAN G.
description: SASS-Sherman G. On February 14, 2001, in Boston, MA. He was a beloved colleague from 1955 to his retirement in 1991, and then as a consultant to our company. Sherman served as mentor to many of our staff members during his long tenure as head of our Boston office and regional manager for New England. His deep knowledge of our field was publically recognized when he received the Cushing-Gavin Award for his contributions to the field of labor relations. We were most fortunate to have been associated with him and send our deepest sympathy to his family. Funeral services will be held at 10 AM Friday, February 16, at the Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, Brookline, MA, 617-232-9300. Martin E. Segal, Founder and Chairman Emeritus Robert D. Krinsky, Chairman Howard Fluhr, President The Segal Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORROW, ROBERT
description: MORROW-Robert. Died February 12th in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. In loving memory of a father, mentor, friend and psychologist from those whose lives you touched. You will never be forgotten. J. Mardi and Chelsea

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURAK, BETTE H.
description: BURAK-Bette H. On February 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Paul, Michael and the late George. Adored mother-in-law to Edna and Lois. Cherished grandmother of Hally, Eliot, Jason and Emily. Contributions may be made to the Women's Division American Technion Society. Funeral services will be held Friday, 9:30AM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: TELEPHONE JOBS CREATED
description: A British company specializing in the construction of telephone networks said it would offer jobs to some of the 6,000 steel workers facing dismissal by Corus, Britain's biggest steel maker. EXi Telecoms said its proposal was part of a plan it had devised with a labor union and the government to create 4,000 jobs in the telecommunications industry. EXi said it would establish training sites in steel plants threatened with closing. Alan Cowell

title: Clinton's Pardons, Put in Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Nintendo Moves Up Release Of Game Boy's Big Brother
description: Nintendo is expecting again. It's a Game Boy.

title: Review/Fashion; For Kors and Lauren, a Fondness for the Paddock
description: By now, it should be clear that Ralph Lauren is a small man with a big gift for dreaming. He turned a tie business into the new American empire -- the lifestyle brand. That he has a tendency to compare himself to Alain Delon, Cary Grant and Gary Cooper, as he did in a recent article in Vogue (in which he memorably stated, ''I never wear makeup in photos -- Cary Grant said he never did either''), seems at best curious in a man whose achievements are his own. It is a weakness, in any case, that doesn't let light into the dream.

title: Americans Positive on Bush, but Mixed on Tax Cuts
description: Public approval of the new Bush administration is fairly strong, but Americans have mixed views on the large tax cut that is one of the administration's first initiatives, according to several opinion polls out this week.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From Caribbean hotels to London attractions, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: In Settlement, Welfare Offices Will Become City Job Centers
description: The Giuliani administration has scored a victory in its long-running battle to transform welfare offices into so-called job centers, after advocates for the poor unexpectedly agreed to the lifting of a two-year-old court order blocking the switch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, PHYLLIS SARI
description: LEVY-Phyllis Sari. An individual who was a major influence on American culture will be missed by all. The members of Rosenzweig & Maffia LLP and R&M Royalty Review LLC express their condolences to Ruth, Susan and the rest of the family. John R. Lieberman, CPA/PFS Partner

title: Indications Of New Vision At Microsoft
description: Since Microsoft introduced its ambitious Internet initiative last year, analysts and investors have pressed the company to articulate its amorphous and loosely defined vision.

title: Union Drive Collides With Korean Grocers
description: Kum Lee, a Korean immigrant who was eager to open his own business, hired two Mexican clerks and opened a 24-hour greengrocery in Manhattan last March. Two months later, there was a picket line outside Mr. Lee's store, the Olympic Deli on First Avenue, over the low wages he paid his workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWNES, SAUL
description: DOWNES-Saul, age 79, of Forest Hills. Loving husband of Shirley of 52 years. Loving father of Burt, Ellen and Kim. Graduate of Wayne State University and Wayne State University Law School. Lawyer, Teacher, Civil Libertarian. Friend of all Persons. Grandfather, brother, uncle. Service Friday, Feb 16, 9am, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a demonstration in Ukraine misidentified one of two top intelligence officials dismissed on Saturday. Along with Leonid Derkach, the ousted official was Volodymyr Schepel. (Valeriy Strogov was his successor.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, IRVING
description: ELIAS-Irving. Our hearts are filled with the deepest sympathy for our dear friend Gale and her family, Charlotte, Shari and Sam. Iggy's passion, love and admiration for friends & family will be cherished & missed forever. With Love, Candice and Steven Stark Andrea and John Stark

description: Two agencies are making senior executive changes.

title: Thanking Web Sites, With Cash
description: CALL me stingy, but I can't think of a single time I suddenly got the urge to pay for something I had been getting free and could continue to get free.

title: Sprewell Comes Up Limping, and So Do the Knicks
description: A night after Latrell Sprewell played as if he needed a good whiff of smelling salts, he was alert, driven and desperately spinning into the paint to keep the Knicks alive against the Utah Jazz.

title: Article 2001021591450462118 -- No Title
description: Teenagers Try Online Learning

title: Mrs. Clinton's Chief Worrywart Moves On
description: HOWARD WOLFSON was strolling outside the Capitol, beneath an unusually bright and clear winter sky, when the answer suddenly came to him.

title: A Secret, Not Too Secret
description: This week that old demon ''embargo'' has risen once again from the belly of a book publisher, resurrecting, as always, the questions of why a publisher would bother to hide a book's content and what, if anything, is gained by the effort. The answers are usually robustly fuzzy, which means that they are nearly always, finally, about book sales and marketing. Whatever, every year publishers try to smuggle a few books into bookstores without aggressive prepublication publicity about their content.

title: Article 2001021590593967061 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HATHAWAY, FRIEDA
description: HATHAWAY-Frieda. Wife of the late George. Sister of the late Sidney Rosenberg and Rose Shaw and of Ellen Rosenberg Tilman (cantor David Tilman) and Jane Rosenberg. Funeral Services on Thursday at 1 P.M. at Mount Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, New York.

title: Dutchman, 20, Admits E-Mail Virus
description: The Dutch police arrested a 20-year-old man yesterday who confessed to having released a malicious software program that arrived in e-mail boxes disguised as a picture of the tennis pro Anna Kournikova.

title: Ravens Hire Mike Nolan
description: The Super Bowl champion Baltimore Ravens hired the former Jets defensive coordinator Mike Nolan as their wide receivers coach yesterday, hoping he can help invigorate a passing attack that struggled last season.

title: Essay; Question Time
description: Suppose a reporter rose in the East Room to ask: ''Mr. President, you said about the investigation into the Marc Rich pardon that 'it's time to move on.' Was this your directive to the U.S. attorney in New York to drop her criminal investigation into the influence of money on the pardon decision?''

title: High-Definition TV: All or Nothing at All
description: I LOVE high-definition television. I have been enamored of the technology, now the highest quality of digital television, since I saw an early version demonstrated by CBS in 1982. Even in its earliest incarnations, the difference in image quality between it and regular TV was startling. I figured we would all have HDTV by the end of the 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOGAN, ELSIE
description: MOGAN-Elsie. On February 14, 2001. Beloved wife of Harry. Loving mother of James, Glen and Lynn. Dear sister of Robert Beck. Adoring grandmother of Jacqueline, Jeffrey, Grant, Craig, Bradley, Caroline, Douglas and Jessie. Service Friday 11:15 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In Mid-Crisis, Ukraine President Lashes Out at Opposition
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma has sharply warned the political forces arrayed against him that he will use the formidable powers of his office to protect himself in an unfolding crisis over corruption and the murder of a prominent journalist, Western officials said after the arrest this week of Yulia V. Timoshenko, a leading opposition figure.

title: Your Worst Nightmare Gets Worse, With an Audience
description: Henry Selick, the director of ''Monkeybone,'' which opens next week, offers a cinematic vision of purgatory. Brendan Fraser, his protagonist, plays a cartoonist in a coma whose imagination carries him to Hyp's Hideaway, above, where Hypnos (Giancarlo Esposito) broadcasts nightmares -- live. Visuals in the eye-popping film include a black-and-white-striped Op Art hallway and a carnival-like downtown. ''It's a rundown Disneyland, with rickety roller coasters, and kind of a combination of L.A. space age architecture and earlier 60's Op Art,'' said Mr. Selick, who previously directed ''The Nightmare Before Christmas.'' ELAINE LOUIE

title: Sports of The Times; Young Stars Shoot Down Old Notion
description: FOR most of the second half Tuesday night, from an opening leading onto the court at Continental Arena, Rory Sparrow and I watched the Nets and the Lakers battle. We carried on a friendly debate centering on the idea that the caliber of play in the National Basketball Association is not what it once was. My position was that the level is absolutely not the same. Indeed, the level of play is better now than at any time in the history of the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHEZ, HELEN JULIETTE
description: MATHEZ-Helen Juliette. Died at home on February 12, 2001. Funeral service at 10:30AM Thursday, February 15 at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. James' would be appreciated.

title: Powell Pledges Strong Support for Wide Spectrum of U.N. Activities
description: Stepping into the heart of an organization grown wary of Republicans, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell sought today to assure Secretary General Kofi Annan that he could count on the Bush administration's strong support across a wide spectrum of United Nations activities.

title: GAZPROM BATTLE GROWS
description: The struggle between management and minority shareholders at the Russian gas company Gazprom intensified after Boris Fyodorov, a board member who represents minority shareholders, said he had received an unsigned letter accusing him of harming Gazprom's reputation. Mr. Fyodorov has led a campaign to increase openness in the company. Minority shareholders who accuse management of stealing assets have requested an additional audit of the company s books. Managers, however, are fighting the proposal, saying it violates Russian law. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Easing Up at the Border
description: Both President Bush and Vicente Fox, the president of Mexico, are saying that Mexican migration to the United States will be on their agenda when they meet tomorrow at Mr. Fox's ranch. Most Americans understand what a big issue this is for domestic politics in the United States. Fewer may realize that it is also a subject of great internal interest in Mexico.

title: New Directors for Mexico Oil Monopoly
description: Determined to transform Pemex, the state-owned oil company, from a bloated and antiquated monopoly into something more like an efficient multinational corporation, Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, has announced a new slate of directors for the Pemex board that bristles with successful business leaders. Past directors were generally bureaucrats and political functionaries and were often accused of mismanagement and corruption.

title: Mission Extended for Surprisingly Sturdy Little Spacecraft
description: The first spacecraft to land on an asteroid got a reprieve from a scheduled communications shutdown today and will stay in contact with Earth a little longer.

title: MIXED GROWTH FOR BRAZIL
description: The pace of Brazil's economic growth slowed in the fourth quarter from a revised four-year high in the previous quarter. But growth remained strong enough to make the full-year expansion the biggest since 1995. Gross domestic product grew 4.38 percent from the period the year before after growing 5.08 percent in the third quarter. The revised third-quarter growth rate, up from a previous estimate of 4.2 percent, was the highest since the third quarter of 1996.

title: Longest Delays Are Abundant At La Guardia
description: Want to fly from La Guardia to O'Hare? Avoid American Airlines Flight 357, scheduled to leave at 8 p.m. and arrive at 9:33. Last year it was the flight most likely to be delayed by at least an hour or canceled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAGOLNITZER, EDITH
description: YAGOLNITZER-Edith. On February 14, 2001. Beloved mother of Bobby and Phil Yarnell, Suzanne and Marvin Yarnell. Cherished grandmother of Madge, Gail, Barbra and Steven, Laurie and Gary, Lisa and David, Elisa and Brian, Vicki and David. Adored greatgrandmother of Chase, Brent, Leslie, Danae, Adam, Nikki, Matthew, Jason, Steven, Geoffrey and Alex. Special aunt of Sheila, Philip, Ann, Lee, Rochelle, Randy, Paul, Linda, Chris, Sheila, Philip, Barbara, Alan, Denise, Andrew and Debi. Special cousin of Bernice, Sol and Dotty. Graveside services.

title: Vicente and Jorge W. Will Get Along Just Fine
description: Both presidents are new to their offices, and both are personable, plain-spoken business types who favor cowboy boots and feel most at home on their ranches. So naturally, Vicente Fox of Mexico and George W. Bush are expected to get along when the American president visits Mr. Fox's ranch tomorrow.

title: 2 New Jobs for Massachusetts Official: Acting Governor and Mother of Twins
description: Jane Swift, the lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, first drew national attention in 1998 for campaigning while pregnant. Then, last year, she faced fire for ethical lapses that included asking aides to baby-sit for her little daughter. Now, she takes on an even greater challenge:

title: Corrections
description: A report on the Public Lives page on Tuesday about the award of a medal of honor by the National Arts Club to the author Tom Wolfe misspelled the surname of the painter who unveiled a portrait of him and misidentified the club in which it will hang. The painter was Everett Raymond Kinstler, not Kintsler. The painting will hang temporarily at the Lotos, the private club at 5 East 66th Street -- not Lotus, a nightclub on West 14th Street.

title: Advertising: Addenda
description: Executive Changes at 2 Agencies

title: A Trompe l'Oeil Supported by Grand Allusions
description: IN November 1997, Dr. Michael Tanner, director of the primary care clinic at Bellevue Hospital Center, asked Rick Jordan, an artist, to create a mural for his living room. Dr. Tanner expected the job to take a few weeks and cost about $2,000. Three years and $30,000 later, Dr. Tanner has walls that would have suited the Medicis. He also enjoys what is surely one of the most personal interiors in New York City.

title: Online, in School; Web Courses in the Classroom
description: WHILE debates may be brewing over the prospect of students' going to high school entirely online, thousands of students around the country are experiencing a less radical version of Internet-based education. They are taking online courses to supplement their regular high school experience, not replace it.

title: Article 2001021593263583925 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about four people arrested in Thailand and indicted in Brooklyn on charges that they had smuggled heroin to New Jersey misidentified one country in the opium-producing area known as the Golden Triangle. With Myanmar and Thailand, the third country is Laos, not China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, ATTORNEY EDWIN M.
description: FREEMAN-Attorney Edwin M. of Cambridge, Ma. and Scarsdale, NY on February 13, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Sheila M. (Precker). Devoted father of Douglas M. Freeman of Newton, Ma., Kenneth M. Freeman of San Francisco, Ca. and Clifford M. Freeman of Needham, Ma. Brother of Bernice Levine of White Plains, NY. Also survived by five grandchildren. Devoted grandmother of Hillary, April and Levitt. Adored friend who deeply loved life lived to the fullest, and was and will always be an inspiration to us all. Services today 10AM ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: School Time, Minus the Face Time; Some Teenagers Forsake High School for Online Learning, but Educators Have Doubts
description: IT is 12:12 p.m. at a pink-stucco public school near Orlando, and a shrill bell is echoing under the metal roofs of covered walkways. The lunch break has come to an end, and ninth graders who just seconds before were standing in giggling groups or playing basketball are now shuffling toward the school's open doors and heading to class.

title: Filming the Beckett Canon, Stage Directions Included
description: On a recent afternoon at the Irish Film Center, a crowd poured out of a movie and headed for the bar while another rushed to down pints before the next screening started. Alan Moloney managed to squeeze through the throngs and sit down, just for a minute, with his cigarette. His youthful look -- a tight black T-shirt and spiky hair -- couldn't hide his exhaustion, which he said was from excessive celebration.

title: J. C. PENNEY TO CARRY DISNEY MERCHANDISE
description: J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it would begin selling children's clothes based on Walt Disney Company characters and theme-park attractions to compete with rivals that have similar merchandising agreements. Terms were not disclosed. Penney will start selling the sportswear and pajamas in the fourth quarter, the companies said. The apparel will feature characters like Winnie the Pooh and Mickey Mouse, and images related to the ''It's a Small World'' ride at Disney theme parks.

title: From the Radio to the Stage, Playing All the Way
description: The idea of the radio orchestra is not entirely foreign to the American cultural consciousness; Toscanini, after all, led the NBC Symphony back in the days when live classical music was a staple of American radio. But that was a half-century ago.

Spending was estimated at $10 million.

description: Reviving a practice hated, feared and ultimately banned in Soviet times, the domestic successor to the K.G.B. has served notice that it is again investigating anonymous accusations of crimes against Russian citizens.

description: Alumni Hall has been good to St. John's, but even it alone can't guarantee victory. With at least one Red Storm player looking past surging Providence and with the squad as a whole suffering another second-half stumble, the Friars easily pulled away for a 64-53 victory last night.

title: Look Like the Innocent Flower, but Be the Serpent
description: Opera in concert can be like reading the book rather than seeing the movie: one is free to imagine the course of events without the interference of a director's interpretation. This was certainly true of the Collegiate Chorale's vivid presentation of Verdi's ''Macbeth'' with the Orchestra of St. Luke's on Monday night at Carnegie Hall, not least because Maria Guleghina needed no sets or costumes to bring Lady Macbeth to life.

title: Germany Expands Workers' Councils
description: Germany's center-left coalition agreed on a plan today to strengthen the power of workers' representatives in corporate management decisions. Business groups angrily argued that the move would lead to higher costs and greater inflexibility.

title: President Bush Wants Horse Breeder as Envoy in London
description: William S. Farish, a multimillionaire horse breeder who is a longtime friend of the Bush family, is expected to be nominated to the plum assignment of United States ambassador to Britain, administration officials said today.

title: HARRIS BUYS YANKELOVICH UNIT
description: Harris Interactive, an Internet-based market research firm, acquired the custom-research division of Yankelovich Partners for an undisclosed sum. The Yankelovich unit offers research and consulting services including product forecasting, public opinion polling, brand equity studies and corporate reputation measurement. The division, which conducts most of its research over the telephone, is expected to have revenue of $15 million in 2001. Harris Interactive hired 65 Yankelovich employees -- mostly research analysts and data processing staff -- as part of the agreement. Andrew Zipern

In lieu of flowers donations to Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 2247, NYC 10116. A memorial service will be held on February 16 at the W New York Hotel, 541 Lexington Ave. (50th St.) at 10:30 AM.

description: For the first time since the ''I Love New York'' tourism promotions began in the 1970's, one of its the seasonal campaigns will focus solely on the state's cultural and historical tourist destinations, the Empire State Development Corporation, which runs the program, said yesterday.

description: On the day four decades ago when Riza Pahlevi was born, crowds took to the streets throughout Iran to chant: ''It's a boy! God is great!''

description: Joe Orseno waited yesterday for the van that would transport his 3-year-old colt, Macho Uno, from Hallandale, Fla., to a Kentucky-bound plane so the horse could be examined for a rear left ankle problem. Orseno, a trainer, tried to think beyond a lost Kentucky Derby chance.

title: Doctors Sue Health Plans Over Coverage
description: Two groups representing 7,000 Connecticut doctors filed a battery of lawsuits today against six large health maintenance organizations, claiming that the companies ''systematically harmed'' patients by arbitrarily denying crucial medical treatment and illegally withholding millions of dollars in payments they owe doctors.

title: Ugo Fano Is Dead at 88; Physicist Linked to Fermi
description: Dr. Ugo Fano, an atomic theorist who was a pioneer in the study of radiation's effects on matter, including living tissue, died on Tuesday in Chicago, where he was an emeritus professor of physics at the University of Chicago. He was 88.

description: February 12, 2001

title: Bias Charges at the Parks Department
description: The report from the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission accusing New York City's Parks Department of discriminating against its employees based on race deserves to be taken seriously both at the Parks Department and at City Hall. Disputes between the Parks Department and specific employees will require investigation and perhaps even a trial to sort out. But employment statistics supplied by the department itself show a work force that is 49.7 percent minorities and a senior management structure that has been dominated by whites for years. The parks commissioner, Henry Stern, argues that other city agencies have problems with imbalance and have less diverse work forces, but that is not a reason for failing to address problems in his department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, SAMUEL M.
description: SOLOMON-Samuel M. Died at home on February 13, 2001. Following his WWII service in the South Pacific, he dedicated his professional life to supporting the economic development of Israel. He had served as: National Director of Institutional Sales of Israel Bond Drives; Director of the Eastern Region of the Israel Bond Organization; and as Executive Vice President of the American Friends of Tel Aviv University. In 1984 the State of Israel Bond Organization presented him with the Gates of Jerusalem Award in appreciation of 30 years of dedicated service on behalf of Israel's economic growth. He is survived by his devoted wife Alexandra, daughter Valery Luce Cristol, brothers Herbert and Adrian, nieces nephews and their families. Services Friday 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his name to Jacob Perlow Hospice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEAHAN, KATHLEEN
description: SHEAHAN-Kathleen. On Feb. 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Daniel Sheahan. Loving mother of Elizabeth. Caring sister of Margaret Maier. Family will receive friends at the Bennett F.H., Scarsdale, NY, today 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be Friday, 10 A.M. at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale, NY. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery.

title: Herbert Robbins, 86, Statistician Who Fueled Interest in Math
description: Dr. Herbert E. Robbins, who developed several widely used statistical techniques and wrote a popular book that inspired many students to enter the mathematics profession, died Monday at Princeton Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 86.

title: ADVANCED MICRO OUTLINES SUCCESSION
description: W. J. Sanders III, who founded Advanced Micro Devices in 1969 and led its fight against Intel for a share of the computer processor market, will relinquish control of daily operations next year, the company said. Advanced Micro, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said Mr. Sanders, 64, would continue to serve as chief executive until the annual shareholder meeting in April 2002. The company said it expected his successor to be Hector de J. Ruiz, the president and chief operating officer, who was hired from Motorola in January 2000 as Mr. Sanders's heir apparent. An Advanced Micro spokesman said Mr. Sanders would continue his term as chairman until 2003, when he plans to step down. Chris Gaither

title: People's Publisher / Marcos Foe Returns to Fray : Wily Media Maverick Who Helped Topple Estrada
description: MANILA  Two years ago Eugenia Apostol, 75, was doing what she says a woman of her age should be doing: taking long trips on cruise ships to exotic places, brushing up on her ballroom dancing and throwing parties for her elite group of friends.

title: Injunction Against Barnesandnoble.com Is Overturned
description: A federal appeals court in Washington freed Barnesandnoble.com yesterday to allow customers to buy books on its Web site with one mouse click, at least until a trial considers an assertion by Amazon.com that such transactions infringe its patent.

title: VULCAN DROPS PRICELINE
description: Priceline.com, the name-your-price airline ticket company has lost one of its key backers. The Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen and his venture capital company, Vulcan Ventures, reported holding no shares in an filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In March 2000, Priceline's proxy filing stated that Mr. Allen held about 9.1 million shares in the company, or about 5.3 percent of its common stock. A Priceline spokesman said he had learned only recently that Vulcan Ventures had sold its interest. Priceline.com, which is to announce fourth-quarter earnings at the close of business today, fell 9 cents, to $2.56, yesterday. ''This is bad news on top of bad news for Priceline,'' Mike May, an analyst at Jupiter Media Metrix, said. Catherine Greenman

title: U.S. IS BEGINNING CRIMINAL INQUIRY IN PARDON OF RICH
description: The United States attorney in New York has started a preliminary criminal investigation into the circumstances of President Bill Clinton's pardon of Marc Rich, the fugitive commodities trader, senior government officials said today.

For Eloy Ybarra and Patricia Martinez, together for five years with two children, ''it was time.'' For Shawn Mendoza and Jennifer Schere, engaged for a year and pregnant for eight months, time was running out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMYTH, JOSEPH PERCY
description: SMYTH-Joseph Percy. On February 14, 2001. Born May 24, 1907 in Brooklyn, NY to Katharine Stoothoff Eldert Smyth and the Rev. Joseph Percy Smyth, an Episcopal minister. His maternal grandfather was Cornelius Eldert, president of the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York 1919-1930. In 1926 Joseph graduated from St. Paul's School, Garden City, NY. He entered Columbia College where he was a member of the Columbia College Glee Club. In 1934 he was awarded an LL.B. from Brooklyn Law School, Brooklyn, NY. 1935-1937 he worked for Cullen and Dyckman, attorneys Brooklyn, NY. He then went into private legal practice in Manhattan with John P. Smith. December 7, 1938 he married Virginia Sandford Gibbs at St. Bartholomew's Church. (His marriage ended in divorce in 1967). Classified 1A during WWII he closed his legal practice and waited to be called while working for Todd Shipyards in Hoboken, NJ. Passing the eligible age for the draft, he was released from military service. In 1944, he joined the legal department of Sacony Vacuum, now called Mobil Oil Company. He later went into private practice in Manhattan. He served for 15 years on the associate vestry at St. Bartholomew's Church and was president of the St. Paul's School Alumni Association. In 1965, he was awarded the Lion Award for distinguished leadership as class chairman Columbia College Fund. He was a member of St. Bartholomew's Church, New York from 1935, a member of the University Club, New York from 1954, a member of the St. Nicholas Society, president of the Society of Colonial Wars and a member of the New York Social Register. He is survived by a son, Joseph Philip Smyth of New York, daughters, Mary Katharine Smyth Basquin of New York, and Virginia Sandford Smyth Low of London, England, and five grandchildren: Philip Hughes Smyth, Susan Virginia Basquin, Peter Lee Basquin, William Clark Basquin and Ciannait Tamsin Low. Grandson Stuart Tristan Low predeceased him. A memorial service will be held on Monday, February 26, 4:30 PM at St. Bartholomew's Church, 50th St and Park Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 East 50 Street NYC, N.Y. 10022

title: China Delays Natural Gas Pipeline Project
description: China's biggest offshore oil company, which has attracted great attention from overseas investors, has been told by the government to forget about supplying natural gas to Shanghai, the nation's fastest-growing market, for at least two years.

title: Playing to Learn
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Copley Plaza
description: The Fairmont Copley Plaza, in the Back Bay of Boston, is offering rooms on weekends for $189 a night through March 31. But for those who like a challenge in figuring out how big a bargain a deal is, the hotel also sells several weekend packages. The Family Winter Weekend package, for example, includes a room with two double beds, breakfast for two adults and two children, a welcoming serving of milk and cookies, a guidebook to seeing Boston with children, a disposable camera and skate rentals at the Boston Common Frog Pond; prices start at $259 a night. A Romance Weekend, with a deluxe room, bottle of chilled champagne and room-service breakfast, is $285. All rates are subject to availability and do not include taxes or tips. Call (800) 441-1414 or go to www.fairmont.com .

title: NEC TO CUT SPENDING
description: The NEC Corporation, one of the world's largest chip makers, said it would cut spending at its semiconductor business by 20 percent the next fiscal year, citing a slump in chip prices. NEC will cut capital expenditures starting April 1 by outsourcing chip-packaging operations to other companies. It will spend less on basic production while focusing on operations like printing circuits onto silicon wafers. The spot price of a 64-megabit D-RAM chip, the main memory in computers, has fallen to less than $3 from a high near $9 in July.

title: XILINX BULKING UP IN IRELAND
description: Xilinx Inc., a San Jose, Calif.-based manufacturer of reprogrammable chips, said that it would invest 41 million Irish pounds ($47.8 million) in its Irish operations, with financial support from the Irish government. Xilinx will build a 128,000-square-foot plant at its Dublin location and hire 500 employees, basing more than a quarter of its work force in Ireland. Wim Roelandts, the chief executive, said the six-year-old Dublin operation accounted for 30 percent of revenue from programmable logic chips, which incorporate Xilinx's core technology. Investors responded favorably, pushing Xilinx's shares up $3.50, or 7.3 percent, to $51.25, in trading on the Nasdaq stock market. Brian Lavery

title: Barak May Join Sharon's Cabinet as Israeli Defense Chief
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15  Ehud Barak, the caretaker prime minister, conditionally agreed tonight to serve as defense minister under Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon, the right-wing leader who crushed him at the polls last week, Israeli news reports said.

title: Defying Conventional Wisdom Sometimes Has Its Advantages
description: The usual policy for the defense is to attack a suit in which the declaring side is weak. But if there is no such suit, it can be right to lead a suit in which the declarer is overwhelmingly strong. Such a lead cannot give away a trick and may be advantageous for other reasons.

title: Corrections

description: Audits of tax returns by the Internal Revenue Service, already at a record low in 1999, fell almost 50 percent last year.

description: As if news executives had not been humiliated enough by their networks' haywire projections of winners on election night, they had the chance today to relive those golden moments in a hearing room on Capitol Hill.

title: They Line Up to Be Flashed, Splashed and 'Extorted'
description: ''I hate it, I just hate it,'' a young woman was telling her date Tuesday night in the lobby of the Beekman Theater, where the compulsively hip design team Imitation of Christ was staging its fall 2001 show. What troubled the woman was not the fact that she was being mashed against the theater doors by the usual fashion-mad mob, and it was not that she was being filmed as she entered the lobby on East 66th Street only to find her image relayed live and 40 feet high to the movie screen inside.

title: Sonia Arova, 74, a Ballerina Who Danced With Nureyev
description: Sonia Arova, a Bulgarian-born ballerina who became an international star and was an early partner of such great male dancers as Erik Bruhn and Rudolf Nureyev, died on Sunday in San Diego. She was 74.

But when the grandiose claims were stripped away, he turned out to be the son of a plumber from Waukesha, Wis., with a disarming manner and a prison record.

Loving and supportive mother of Christopher and Jason. Loving grandmother of Christos, Gregory, Nicholas and Matthew. Her strength, courage and determination were unyielding and her great love of family, friends and life will always be cherished. We all love her and will miss her dearly. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, the Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 E. 74 St., Saturday, 12 PM.

description: PARIS, Feb. 15  The French government today announced plans to slaughter up to 10,000 cattle a week in order to support beef prices forced down by the mad cow disease crisis.

title: Metro Business Briefing; DELISTING AVERTED
description: Bluefly, an online fashion retailer, announced yesterday that Nasdaq officials have said the company is no longer in danger of being removed from the Nasdaq composite index. A hearing had been scheduled because the company did not meet the net tangible assets requirement of the index. Bluefly officials said the Nasdaq ruling came after the company closed the second phase of its investment agreement with affiliates of Soros Private Equity Partners. The deal, which gave Soros control of Bluefly, was announced on Feb. 7. Jayson Blair

title: A Bassist Turns to the Piano and Shares the Spotlight
description: Last year the bassist Avishai Cohen, who tours almost constantly with Chick Corea when he's not playing with his own groups around New York, was stuck in Jerusalem with visa problems. To keep himself busy, he played the piano with a trio in a jazz club.

title: Ferrer Gets Backing for Mayor by McCall and Others

And today, Mr. Ferrer plans to announce the backing of H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller.

title: INTERNET-NAMES GROUP QUESTIONED
description: The head of a Senate subcommittee on communications said yesterday that the operations of the organization in charge of creating and distributing Internet domain names were ''shrouded in mystery'' even though the group, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, is supposed to function in an open and transparent way. ''My greatest fear is that the administration of the Internet will be changed in foolish, even disastrous, ways while very few people are watching,'' Senator Conrad Burns, above, the Montana Republican who is chairman of the committee, said at a hearing to examine Icann's system for selecting new Web suffixes. Icann chose seven new domain names last fall along with the companies and groups that will sell new names within the domains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE BOUTILLIER, MARTIN
description: LE BOUTILLIER-Martin, died Tuesday, February 13, 2001. He graduated Hotchkiss class of '40, and Yale '44. He then served in the South Pacific as a PT boat captain during W.W. II. Martin returned to NY and in a career in investment banking, ultimately serving as President and Chief Operating Officer of Paine Webber. Martin was an avid tennis player, fly fisherman, hunter and yachtsman. Throughout his life, Martin faced adversity with bravery and celebrated the joys of life with gusto. Survived by wife Janet, sister Cornelia, brother Charles, daughter Clelia, sons Martin and John, stepchildren Duncan and Sarah and nine grandchildren. Memorial service will be held at 11 o'clock AM, Saturday, February 17 at Grace Episcopal Church in Old Saybrook, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hotchkiss Scholarship Fund, POB 800, Lakeville, CT. 06039, or Memorial Fund, Grace Episcopal Church, 336 Main Street, Old Saybrook, CT 06475.
