For the last year, Ms. Garrigues (whose main shop, Jennifer Garrigues, is in the Worth Avenue shopping district in Palm Beach) has had a second shop, Dixie Monkey, on South Dixie Highway in Antiques Row; (561) 805-9599.

title: Excerpt of Testimony From a Lawyer for Marc Rich
description: Following is an excerpt from the testimony of Jack Quinn, a lawyer for Marc Rich, before the Senate Judiciary Committee yesterday as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc. Mr. Quinn testified about the role Mr. Rich's former wife, Denise, and Beth Dozoretz, a Democratic fund-raiser, had played in seeking the presidential pardon for Mr. Rich.

title: Look What's Sheer and Soft And a Natural for Curtains
description: The newest and most unexpected sheer fabrics this season are soft, fuzzy and woven with mohair. At the Biennale des diteurs de la Dcoration, a show of new home textiles in Paris last month, Sahco Hesslein of Germany showed Donna, a fabric patterned with alternating wide stripes of sheer silk and fluffy mohair (above), in shades of brown and burgundy; 48 inches wide, $225 a yard at Bergamo, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street). Another sheer mohair, by Kravet Fabrics, called Zora, is a light gray blend of wool, polyester and silk, made in Italy (top); 53 inches wide, $235 a yard, 979 Third Avenue, or (888) 457-2838 or www.kravet.com for other showrooms. Both are to the trade only. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Disabled Test Takers
description: To the Editor:

title: CAE BUYING U.S. FLIGHT SIMULATOR BUSINESS
description: The Canadian manufacturer of flight simulators, CAE Inc., said yesterday that it would buy an American flight training unit of BAE Systems North America for $80 million to increase access to United States military business. CAE, based in Toronto, said it planned to work with BAE Systems of Britain, Europe's biggest military company. CAE has said it plans to expand its military flight and training business. BAE's flight training unit is in Tampa, Fla.

title: A Music Reference Goes Electric, Finally
description: IT took long enough. For at least a decade, musicians, musicologists, record collectors and just plain music fans who turn to the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians as a source and arbiter of musical information have been clamoring for an electronic, searchable version of this enormous reference work. Grove's last edition, published in 1980, offered some 20,000 articles in 20 thick volumes, and as reference works like the Encyclopedia Britannica and the Oxford English Dictionary went electronic, Grove was becoming a dinosaur.

title: Ignore the Label, It's Flextronics Inside; Outsourcing's New Cachet in Silicon Valley
description: Dot-coms are collapsing right and left, and e-businesses are vanishing by the dozens, but here in a nondescript industrial park in the heartland of Silicon Valley, business is booming.

title: Anguish That Pours From Spain's Very Soul
description: Two of Spain's most celebrated flamenco musicians, the guitarist Manolo Snlucar and the singer Carmen Linares, devoted most of their concert on Saturday night at Town Hall to Mr. Snlucar's cerebral extensions of the tradition. Introducing the program, he called flamenco ''music born of the soul's anguish'' and said it ''tries to reflect the invisible.'' It also reflected the impulses of a musician seeking new challenges.

title: China's War Against Itself
description: China's Liberation Army Daily recently condemned the Falun Gong movement and its leader, Li Hongzhi, as ''Western anti-Chinese forces'' -- a new wrinkle in a government campaign to group Falun Gong with the Branch Davidians and Aum Shinrikyo as apocalyptic doomsday cults, and which began by dismissing the spiritual movement as a trick played on the superstitious and the illiterate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAGLIANO, MICHAEL R.
description: STAGLIANO-Michael R. Of Mashpee, MA, Feb. 13, 2001. Husband of June A. (Mackey), father of Lisa A. Stagliano-Mackey, Susan M. Stagliano, Mark S., Michael R. and John E. Stagliano. Brother of Paul H. Stagliano and Catherine M. Fabiano. Also survived by 8 grandchildren. A funeral Mass will be celebrated in Christ the King Church, Mashpee, MA, on Friday, February 16 at 10 AM.

title: Panel Won't Take Up Bush's Medicare Plan
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Charles E. Grassley, said today that he would not act on President Bush's campaign proposal for a fundamental restructuring of Medicare but would try instead to forge a consensus this year on legislation quickly adding prescription drug benefits to the program.

title: Bush Condemns Attack and Calls for End to Mideast Violence
description: Calling for an end to the cycle of ''violent action and reaction'' in the Middle East, President Bush today condemned the latest attack there, in which a Palestinian drove a bus into a crowd of Israelis near Tel Aviv.

title: More Work but Worth It
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS and the Global Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001021591910973391 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: New Site Promises Access To Drivers You Meet on Street
description: Americans' love of the Internet is almost as intense as their obsession with cars, so perhaps a new Web site that links the two is not surprising. The site, PlateMatch.com, is a service designed to help drivers hook up with one another by using their car license plates as a method of introduction, no honking or waving required.

title: YANKEE CANDLE CUTTING 455 JOBS, OR 15% OF WORK FORCE
description: The Yankee Candle Company, a maker of scented candles, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 455 jobs, representing about 15 percent of its work force, to increase earnings this year. The company also said fourth-quarter net income rose 22 percent to $27.7 million, or 51 cents a share, from $22.7 million, or 42 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. That was less than the 55-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. The shares of Yankee Candle fell 61 cents, or 4 percent, to $14.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. The job cuts will save about $10 million annually and result in per-share earnings growth of at least 25 percent this year, the company said. Yankee Candle, based in Whately, Mass., will take a first-quarter pretax charge of $7 million for the reductions.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOKOLOW, MEL
description: SOKOLOW-Mel. We adore you, we miss you, and we are inspired by you. Love and hugs forever, Diane, Betsy, Alec & Sam

title: LENDER MEETS EXPECTATIONS
description: Abbey National, a leading British mortgage lender facing a takeover bid from the Lloyds TSB Group, said pretax profit rose 11 percent last year, to 1.96 billion ($2.8 billion), which was the high end of analysts' forecasts. Abbey National, which is in merger talks with the Bank of Scotland, is awaiting a ruling scheduled for Feb. 23 by Trade and Industry Minister Stephen Byers on whether antitrust regulators should scrutinize Lloyds's bid. Alan Cowell

title: Connoisseur of African-American Art Finds New Home for Collection
description: His eye ever on the prowl, Paul R. Jones has found a home in this unpretentious university town for his mighty portrait of John Henry by Charles White plus his eclectic trove of hundreds of other works by 20th-century African-American artists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWD, JANET
description: DOWD-Janet, 75, of Rome, NY. Died February 12, 2001. Her cousins, friends from the acting community and other friends will miss dear Janet and her amazing courage through her long illness.

title: Europe Gets A Guideline To Protecting Copyrights
description: The European Parliament gave the music industry everything it wanted in a vote on copyright law today, approving a directive that the 15 members of the European Union will use to write new national laws that would extend coverage to digital technology and the Internet.

title: Article 2001021590617130123 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: Paradise Recharged: Palm Beach Lightens Up
description: IN the 1890's Henry M. Flagler, an oil and railroad tycoon, developed the island community of Palm Beach as a luxury resort and drew America's moneyed aristocracy to this little slice of paradise.

title: Admiral Who Lost Job Set Up Civilians' Submarine Trip
description: The submarine trip for civilians that led to the sinking of a Japanese fishing vessel, leaving nine people missing, was arranged by a Navy admiral who was forced to retire in 1995 after he made an offensive remark about the rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan girl, government officials said yesterday.

title: SINGAPORE AIRLINES CHOOSES BOEING
description: Singapore Airlines said it would buy 10 Boeing 777-200 aircraft and an option to buy 10 more, an order worth $4 billion. The airline will use the aircraft largely to replace Airbus A310-300's on routes within Southeast Asia. The new Boeing planes are scheduled for delivery between 2003 and 2009 and will use engines from Rolls-Royce. Last year, Singapore Airlines gave a lift to Airbus Industrie and its plans to build the superjumbo A380 when it announced it would pay $8.6 billion for as many as 25 of the 555-passenger jets. Wayne Arnold

title: Mindless? Far From It. Violent? Just a Tad.
description: PHYSICUS

title: Israeli Town's Adieu to 4 'Finest Sons and Daughters'
description: ASHKELON, Israel, Feb. 15  Under leaden skies in a military cemetery at the edge of this coastal town, 18-year-old Yasmin Karissi was laid to rest today in the first of four freshly dug graves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESTLER, SAMUEL
description: RESTLER-Samuel. Age 97 of Roswell, Georgia. Passed away peacefully on Tuesday, February 13, 2001. Mr. Restler was born in New York City, April 29, 1903. He formerly resided in Rockville Centre, NY and Ocean Ridge, FL. His survivors include his wife of 66 years, Leah, his three sons and their wives, Richard, Donald, and Peter, eight grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Contributions may be made to Hospice Atlanta.

title: Economic Scene; Plans to cut taxes may be clever politics, but they're not wise fiscal policy.
description: IT'S a little ironic that George W. Bush chose to screen the movie ''Thirteen Days'' at the White House for members of the Kennedy family recently. In the film, a dramatized account of the Cuban missile crisis, President John F. Kennedy makes every effort to avoid frightening the American people into a panicky response to the threat of missiles just off the coast.

title: In the Shenandoah Valley, a Historic House Dreams on a Grand Scale
description: The new Museum of the Shenandoah Valley, formerly the Glen Burnie Historic House, in Winchester, Va., may just make Sunday outings a lot more ambitious. No more driving out to the countryside in hopes of finding an old house with a few roomfuls of furniture and a boxwood maze. This old house aspires to be a ''regional history complex'' in an area famous for its Skyline Drive and Civil War sites.

title: Union Seeks New Overseer For New Jersey Troopers
description: The head of the union representing New Jersey's state troopers is urging that the force no longer be supervised by the state attorney general, whom he criticized for dropping drug and weapons charges against 128 people who claimed they were victims of racial profiling.

title: The Neediest Cases; The Father of the Children, And Her Batterer, Is Back
description: The haunting memories are everywhere.

title: Rather Talk Than Type? Digital Dictation
description: IN the 1968 film ''The Producers,'' Zero Mostel played Max Bialystock, a crooked Broadway producer. When he's not bilking widows out of their fortunes, Max turns his attention to hiring Ulla (played by Lee Meredith), a secretary with no apparent understanding of English. When asked to perform stenography or any other work, Ulla responds by go-go dancing.

title: A Radio That Charges Its Own Batteries
description: Plug In, a rechargeable radio by Lexon in France, won the award for ''best discovery'' last month in the Now Design section of the Maison & Objets show in Paris. The brightly colored plastic radio's antenna is a three-inch circular wire halo that folds behind the unit when it is not in use. Plug In plays while plugged into a wall outlet but can run untethered for 15 hours once its batteries are charged.

title: Winning the Race Is All That Matters
description: ''I don't particularly love anything about the sport except winning,'' said the old pro on the eve of his 17th Daytona 500, which he has never won. ''Racing's not about speed for me. It's about being better than other people.''

title: Cable Channel CNBC Lays Off Workers
description: CNBC, the financial cable news network, alerted more than 40 of its workers today that their positions would be eliminated as part of a continuing work force reduction at NBC.

title: Arab Drives Bus Into Crowd, Killing 8 Israelis
description: After years of shuttling Gazan laborers into Israel without incident, a Palestinian bus driver who passed a strict Israeli security clearance just two weeks ago veered wildly off course today with deadly consequences.

title: Reliving War's Horror
description: To the Editor:

title: A Curator Will Now Provoke In the Netherlands
description: Aaron Betsky, a ubiquitous presence on the American architectural scene for 20 years, is headed for Europe. Mr. Betsky, 43, is the mastermind behind 35 exhibitions as the curator of architecture, design and digital products at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. He has been made director of the Netherlands Architecture Institute in Rotterdam, one of the world's largest architecture museums. Mr. Betsky is known as a friendly provocateur, with shows about the rebel designer Tibor Kalman and the sneaker. To him, things are ''cultural artifacts that help us construct our identity and envision the complexity of our everyday world.'' As for the Netherlands, he said, ''I can't think of any other place where new good design in every field is being supported and produced.'' JULIE V. IOVINE

title: Nurture the Symphony, That It May Live
description: To the Editor:

title: Nurture the Symphony, That It May Live
description: To the Editor:

title: N.A.S.D. Criminal Unit's Activities Face Legal Challenge
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, the group that serves as watchdog over the nation's brokerage firms, set up a unit three years ago to help federal prosecutors mount criminal securities fraud cases. Now the activities of this little-known criminal unit, the first of its kind inside a securities regulator, are being challenged.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Championing A Fabled Bandit; For Novelist, a Rogue Australian Sums Up His Underdog Culture
description: For the novelist Peter Carey, there are three great Australian stories: the battle at Gallipoli in World War I; the life and death of the champion racehorse Phar Lap, and, most tantalizingly, Ned Kelly.

title: Man in the News; Prize Job for a Bush Rescuer; Theodore Bevry Olson
description: Theodore B. Olson was little known outside Washington until the Republican Party called upon him to rescue George W. Bush's hopes of becoming president by arguing before the Supreme Court that ballot-recounting in Florida should stop.

title: New Boots Could Reduce Knee Injuries
description: They say you are safer skiing down the mountain than you are driving your car to get there. They say you are safer skiing than you are riding a bike. Some studies insist most team sports are more dangerous than skiing.

title: Bin Laden Pilot Says He Helped Buy Jet to Ship Missiles
description: An Egyptian-born flight instructor who worked freelance as Osama bin Laden's pilot said yesterday that he once helped the bin Laden organization buy a $200,000 decommissioned military jet in order to ship Stinger antiaircraft missiles from Pakistan to Sudan.

title: Best Buy-Motorola Deal
description: The Best Buy Company, a leading chain of electronics stores, and Motorola Inc. said today that they had agreed on a two-year partnership to increase sales of Motorola's wireless products and to attract customers to Best Buy's new wireless department. The terms were not disclosed. Motorola's wireless products, including phones and pagers, will be prominently displayed at most of Best Buy's 412 stores by midyear, the companies said in a statement. Motorola, the No. 2 maker of cellular phones in the world, will provide Best Buy's wireless department with educational videos and other materials. Best Buy has doubled the floor space it devotes to wireless products and is placing the department near the front in most of its stores, said the company, which is based in Eden Prairie.

title: Cash Flow Increases 17% At Viacom as Net Falls
description: Viacom reported strong quarterly performances yesterday for its two largest operations: cable networks and radio stations.

title: New Palms Will Use Bluetooth To Cast a Much Wider Net
description: Fans of Palm hand-held computers already enjoy the convenience of swapping programs and electronic business cards by beaming them through the air, thanks to the infrared transmitter built into every palmtop. But in a few months, they will not have to do so by standing 20 inches apart and pointing their palmtops at each other; they'll be able to send information wirelessly to up to seven other Palms, not to mention certain printers, cell phones, laptops and networks, within about 30 feet, without even aiming.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a demonstration in Ukraine misidentified one of two top intelligence officials dismissed on Saturday. Along with Leonid Derkach, the ousted official was Volodymyr Schepel. (Valeriy Strogov was his successor.)

title: In the City of Big Shoulders, Big Ideas and Modest Egos
description: Here's a Chicago acting story.

title: DECISION IN CZECH MEDIA FIGHT
description: An international arbitration court in Paris ruled that Vladimir Zelezny, left, must repay $23 million to his former employer, Central European Media Enterprises, which is owned by Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetics heir. Mr. Zelezny said he would appeal. A Media Enterprises subsidiary, CNTS, operated TV Nova with Mr. Zelezny until it fired him as the station's general director in April 1999. Mr. Zelezny, who owns the broadcast license for the station, started broadcasting without CNTS, depriving it of all income. The arbitration court ruled that Mr. Zelezny must repay Media Enterprises the $23 million it paid him to buy shares in CNTS in 1997 and annulled the sales contract. Katka Fronk

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Charges From Calling Cards Often More Than Expected

title: Oppenheimer Family to Take De Beers Private
description: LONDON, Feb. 15  The Oppenheimer family, which has controlled much of the world diamond trade for more than 70 years, has tightened its already powerful grip with a $17.6 billion agreement to turn De Beers into a private company in partnership with its sister corporation, Anglo American, and other close allies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSYNOWITZ, JUDITH
description: NUSYNOWITZ-Judith. Died on February 14, 2001 of Peekskill, New York formerly of the Bronx, New York. Loving mother of Michelle, Nina and Lisa. Beloved grandmother of Jessica & Zachary. She was predeceased by her husband Irving. The funeral service will be at the Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY on Thursday, February 15 at 10:00 AM. Interment will be at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: AIDS and the Global Conscience
description: AIDS and the Global Conscience

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Nets Go Quietly on Tired Legs Against the Pistons
description: A day after they were soaring with the N.B.A. elite, one shot away from knocking off the defending champion Los Angeles Lakers, the Nets plummeted to earth tonight in a 105-86 loss to the lowly Detroit Pistons.

title: Mansion Bobs Up And Moves In
description: AT most beaches, incoming tides bring dead jellyfish and errant litter. In this south Florida resort, however, the roiling Atlantic recently deposited flotsam more fitting to the island's century-old status as a haven for the rich and famous: a Jazz Age mansion.

title: Sale of Coyotes Finally Finished
description: The Wayne Gretzky era began Thursday for the Phoenix Coyotes when the league's career scoring champion and a developer, Steve Ellman, acquired the team for $90 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARDIAC SCIENCE INC., Irvine, Calif., a maker of defibrillators, agreed to buy the closely held Survivalink Corp., Minneapolis, also a maker of defibrillators, for $71 million in cash and stock.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Tennis Hall of Fame reversed the numbers of times Ivan Lendl won the Australian Open and the United States Open. It was three times at the Open here (1985-87) and twice for the Australian (1989-90).

title: Onstage, Digital Hits And Misses
description: IN 1990, Stewart Alsop, the technology analyst, noticed that the real fun of computer conventions wasn't in the marketing mania at the booths on the show floor. Instead, he was far more intrigued by the one-on-one demonstrations of coming technologies conducted in hallways and hotel rooms during the off hours. Imagine how exciting it would be, he thought, to attend a computer show consisting exclusively of those sneak peeks at the near future of computing.

title: Happy No Trash Day
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: White Rosemary?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITTLEMAN, BETTE
description: MITTLEMAN-Bette. Your passing on 11 February 2001-A shock, a tragedy. May your soul rest in peace. Gloria Smith and many friends at the fitness center

title: AT&T SELLING WIRELESS STOCK TO REDUCE DEBT
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would sell about $3 billion of AT&T Wireless stock, instead of distributing it to investors, and that it would use the proceeds to repay its debt. AT&T also said it would delay by a month the exchange of its shares for wireless stock that is part of a plan to split into three companies and create tracking shares for its consumer long-distance unit. It cited ''an undetected electronic file transfer error'' that caused financial data to be omitted from a regulatory filing it made in March.

title: Giants from Unilever to DoubleClick to Pfizer make decisions on big accounts.
description: LARGE advertisers in major categories from packaged goods to automotive products to drugs have been as busy as a certain naked arrow-wielding cherub, making decisions affecting accounts with billings estimated at $1.1 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELFOND, NORMA
description: GELFOND-Norma. On December 8, 2000 at the age of 93. Beloved wife of the late Sol Gelfond. Cherished mother of Geri and the late Seymour Zeff, and Joyce and Arnold Swartz. Adored grandmother and great grandmother. Now at peace. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Documentary Subjects Find Their Own Voices
description: Sound Portraits Productions, a nonprofit organization, has collected a series of its radio documentaries at www.soundportraits.org. The documentaries, most of which were produced for National Public Radio, can be explored through audio excerpts, transcripts, images and links.

title: Google Search Engine Reaches Into Usenet
description: IN the early days of the Internet, newsgroups, otherwise known as electronic bulletin boards, were a place where researchers, academics and others could post messages on subjects that interested them. They could also read the responses to their messages, as well as other postings on similar topics.

title: New Player Makes Room For More Digital Music
description: If your MP3 player holds only enough music to get you halfway to work, you could either get a new job or Intel's Pocket Concert MP3 player, which holds up to four hours of music.

title: Clinton's Pardons, Put in Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget Folding Chairs: Pull Up a Stool
description: Never underestimate the versatility of the humble stool. Especially not when so many people are trying to carve out space for a home office in cramped apartments. Nomadic stools move effortlessly from room to room and can be placed around a desk to create a dining table when guests arrive. Many do double-duty as tables; some even make themselves useful in the bathroom as a resting place for towels, magazines or other bath essentials. Though some stools can be stowed under a table, or folded and stored in a closet, others are so decorative and sculptural you might not want them out of sight. Stools come in materials as diverse as rough-hewn wood, shiny metal, cardboard, even ceramic. No wonder so many were on display at the home design shows in Paris and New York last month.

title: Toys Unto Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Fans the Size of a Grain of Sand May One Day Cool Computers
description: AS processors on personal computers grow more powerful, they grow hotter, too. Now an alternative to the large, noisy fans needed to dissipate that heat may be in sight.

title: Berkshire Buys 3 Stakes
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the holding company run by the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, reported stakes in Mueller Industries, H&R Block Inc. and the Sealed Air Corporation in filings today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: AIDS and the Global Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: William Epstein, 88, U.N. Disarmament Official
description: William Epstein, a United Nations official involved in promoting disarmament for more than 20 years, died on Friday in New York. He was 88.

title: City Proceeds With Moving Fulton Fish Market to Bronx
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city would proceed this year with a long-planned relocation of the 167-year-old Fulton Fish Market to the Bronx, saying that the proposed new $81 million fish distribution center in Hunts Point would benefit the city's fish merchants.

title: For Campaign Disclosure
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Appointments
description: The News Services division of The New York Times has appointed Gloria Anderson, president and editor in chief of its Syndication Sales division, to a new post in which she will work to expand the presence of The Times outside the United States.

title: Goodyear Announces Loss And Plan to Cut 7,200 Jobs
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, grappling with persistently high raw materials costs and a weak euro, reported a fourth-quarter loss yesterday and said that it would reduce its 105,000-employee work force by almost 7 percent.

title: In School Aid Blame Game, Fingers Also Point Back at City
description: For years, New York City has complained that its schools have been shortchanged by the aid the state provides, leaving it unable to keep up with the maintenance of rundown schools, hire enough certified teachers and relieve overcrowded classrooms.

title: Kansas Puts Evolution Back Into Public Schools
description: In the beginning, there was the theory of evolution. That was until the Kansas State Board of Education voted two years ago to remove it as the sole explanation of the origin of man from the state's public school curriculum.

title: Nurture the Symphony, That It May Live
description: Nurture the Symphony, That It May Live

title: To Break Impasse, Taiwan Leader Confirms Reactor Go-Ahead
description: Desperate to break a political impasse that has all but paralyzed Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian's government confirmed today that it would resume construction of a partly built nuclear power plant.

title: REGAL CINEMAS MAY CLOSE MORE THEATERS
description: Regal Cinemas Inc. said yesterday that it was considering closing up to 30 percent of its theaters as it struggles to repay almost $2 billion of debt. Regal, owned by the buyout firms Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, has already shut 61, or 14 percent, of its theaters and could close 26 to 69 more, said Dick Westerling, a spokesman for Regal, based in Knoxville, Tenn. ''We don't have a target number, but we continue to evaluate each individual theater'' for profitability, Mr. Westerling said. Last June, Regal operated 430 theaters with 4,485 screens. The company now has 375 with 4,219 screens, including some new theaters. Last week, theaters closed in Sarasota, Fla., and Greensboro, N.C.

title: Thus Spake, With Prescience, Arthur C. Clarke
description: NO black monolith has turned up yet, but then, extraterrestrial artifacts may not be discovered according to a timetable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, RUTH J.
description: ROSENBERG-Ruth J., 89, of Deerfield Beach, died February 12, 2001. Wife of the late Edward. Survived by her son Dr. Stephen (Barbara), daughter Barbara Guter (Dr. Marvin), and 4 grandchildren, Jordana, Amanda (fiance Kevin Hall), Lev and Avi. Services will be held today at 1 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St., New York, NY. Donations may be made to Hadassah.

title: Stottlemyre Has That Rookie Grin
description: Mel Stottlemyre feels like a rookie going to a big league camp for the first time, his excitement raw. Never mind that he has been through more than 30 spring trainings. This is the first time he has begun spring training as a survivor of cancer. ''It feels great,'' he said today.

title: Romanian Past, Interrupted
description: JACQUELINE WALDMAN had glimpsed her father's house once, in 1996, from the sidewalk on a street called Mircea the Old in a beautiful quarter of the old Romanian port city of Constanta.

title: The Scam of Free Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Warns Against 'Overdeployment'
description: President Bush said today that he would send American forces overseas more judiciously, warning that ''overdeployments'' strained troops, their families and, in the case of members of the National Guard and Reserves, their civilian employers.

title: ANTIDRUG PROGRAM SAYS IT WILL ADOPT A NEW STRATEGY
description: In a striking shift, leaders of the nation's most widely used program to discourage drug use among schoolchildren have acknowledged that their strategy has not had sufficient impact and say they are developing a new approach to spreading their message.

title: AMERITRADE, IN ACQUISITION, SEEKS INSTITUTIONAL CLIENTS
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, an online brokerage firm, said yesterday that it would buy TradeCast Ltd., for $67.3 million in stock, to increase its business with institutional investors. TradeCast, based in Houston, provides trade-order routing and management services to about 60 money management and broker-dealer firms. Users typically are among the most active traders. Ameritrade, based in Omaha, has been losing business recently as individual investors have cut back on stock trading

title: Mets Avoid Arbitration By Settling With Rusch
description: The Mets avoided an arbitration hearing for the ninth year in a row by signing the left-handed pitcher Glendon Rusch to a one-year, $1.8 million contract yesterday. Rusch had requested $2.35 million, while the Mets had offered him $1.5 million.

title: How Does Your Garden Glow? With Globes to Squeeze and Toss
description: Forget candles. The newest way to light a garden table is with the Bubble, a rechargeable light by Aaron Rincover of California. Once charged (much like a cell phone) it will stay lighted for five hours. Available in orange, blue or green, the light is switched on and off by squeezing, and it can be used indoors or out. (Try tossing a few into the hedges.) The Bubble, produced by Mathmos in England, which makes the Lava lamp, will be available in April for $75 at the Terence Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Man in the News; Ashcroft's No. 2: A Black Conservative Lauded by Liberals; Larry Dean Thompson
description: In 1991, with a Supreme Court nomination on the line, Larry D. Thompson went before the Senate Judiciary Committee to testify to the intellect and character of his longtime friend Clarence Thomas.

title: Paris as Tomorrowland
description: ALL things weird are normal in this whore of cities,'' says the detective Lemmy Caution, the crater-faced antihero of Jean-Luc Godard's 1965 ''Alphaville,'' in a voice like a police radio. Godard's new wave, sci-fi film noir is set in Paris in an unspecified future.

title: U.S. May Not Need to Borrow, but It May Still Need to Be in Debt
description: As government surpluses grow and the government comes closer to the possibility of closing down the Treasury securities market, the Bush Administration Treasury says it is considering ways to keep the market alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, EVELYN
description: GREENSTEIN-Evelyn. In Burlington, VT. on February 3, 2001. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of Carol and Barry Stone, Martin and Gloria Greenstein, and Kenneth Greenstein. Loving grandmother of Jennifer and Teddy Greenstein and Judith Mallory, and great grandmother of Mark and Andrew Mallory. Pre-deceased by her devoted husband Leo Greenstein and her dear grandson Jeffrey Stone. Also survived by her brother Philip Kraus and her sister Helen Karp, and their families. Memorial service to be held in April. Interment private.

Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. Funeral from the Chas. Peter Nagel, Inc. Funeral Home, 352 E. 87 St, Friday, 12PM. Interment, Ferncliff Cemetery. Visiting hours Friday 10AM-12PM.

title: Americans Positive on Bush, but Mixed on Tax Cuts
description: Public approval of the new Bush administration is fairly strong, but Americans have mixed views on the large tax cut that is one of the administration's first initiatives, according to several opinion polls out this week.

title: For Some Who Use Calling Cards, The Number Is 1-800-BEWARE
description: Janet E. Oseroff of Manhattan signed up for her new calling card from the local phone company, Verizon Communications, in December, and the plan seemed quite clear.

title: From Vilar's Deep Well, a Wish for the Kennedy Center
description: Alberto W. Vilar, an investor who in recent years has become the most generous donor to opera and ballet companies around the world, describes his latest gift, $50 million to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, as ''a project that kills two birds with one stone.''

title: A Shelf Wide Enough For Horizontal Pepperoni
description: When was the last time someone asked ''What's wrong with your refrigerator?'' Maytag did in 1999, asking customers in particular about side-by-side refrigerator-freezers. In response, people complained that the freezer space was too narrow for a frozen pizza to lie flat. ''If you stand it on its edge, the ingredients fall down -- and they struggle with loading bulk items like turkeys,'' said Steve Benton, general manager of refrigeration at Maytag Appliances in Newton, Iowa. The new Maytag Wide-by-Side refrigerator-freezer has the same total width as standard side-by-sides, but a jog gives half the refrigerator a width of 21 inches, and half the freezer a width of 14 inches (instead of the standard 12). In white, bisque or black, $1,649. At the end of the year, a stainless steel model will sell for $1,949. Information: (888) 462-9824. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Critics Try to Turn Whitman Against Her Emissions Plan
description: New Jersey environmentalists, joined by a group of anonymous employees of the Environmental Protection Agency, today called on the agency's new administrator, Christie Whitman, to reject an emissions-credit trading program that she herself had introduced as governor.

title: Silver Aide Is Accused Of Assault
description: In an internal complaint filed with the Assembly, a Republican legislative aide has accused a top aide to Speaker Sheldon Silver of sexual assault, but no criminal charges have been filed, officials said.

title: Hundreds Implore Archdiocese Not to Close Failing School
description: More than 500 parents, students and local residents filled the gymnasium at John A. Coleman Catholic High School tonight to implore top officials of the Archdiocese of New York not to close the financially failing school, pledging to increase enrollment and develop a business plan that would reduce the school's huge deficits.

title: LONDON'S DOME NOW IN LIMBO
description: The Millennium Dome in London suffered another setback as the British government broke off talks with Legacy, a group led by the property developer Robert Bourne, left, and reopened the process to other bidders, said Stewart Todd, a Cabinet Office spokesman. Legacy's 125 million proposal ($182 million) to turn the Dome into a high-tech office park failed to muster enough support by a deadline on Wednesday. The group, which won favored bidder status in November, planned to meet to decide whether to resubmit a bid. The Japanese bank Nomura also submitted a proposal and is considering its options, said a spokesman, Andrew Dowler. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: FAMILY FARE
description: From Books To Ballet

title: Threat of Vouchers Motivates Schools to Improve, Study Says
description: A new study of Florida's efforts to turn around failing schools has found that the threat that children would receive vouchers to attend private schools spurred the worst performing schools to make significant academic strides.

title: Rosalie Gwathmey, 92, a Photographer of Southern Black Life
description: Rosalie Gwathmey, a photographer who was noted for the warmth and artful simplicity of her pictures of black Southern communities, and who threw away all her negatives in 1955 after donating most of her prints to the New York Public Library, died on Monday at her home in Amagansett, N.Y., said her son, the architect Charles Gwathmey. She was 92.

title: Stake Sale Averts Collapse Of German Media Company
description: EM.TV and Merchandising A.G., the German media company that bought the Muppets and half the Formula One racing organization, escaped collapse today. But the prospects are much less clear for its chairman and founder, Thomas Haffa.

title: Nortel Plans to Cut 10,000 Jobs as It Lowers Earnings Outlook
description: Sharply cutting its projections for both sales and profits, Nortel Networks, the Canadian maker of communications equipment, said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 10,000 jobs, adding to the toll that a slowing economy in the United States is taking on the communications industry.

title: Driver Says Rapper Offered Him Bribe to Beat Gun Charge
description: In unflinching detail, a former driver for the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs testified yesterday that the rapper had repeatedly offered him money to claim ownership of a gun that the police found in Mr. Combs's vehicle shortly after a nightclub shooting in December 1999.

title: Halting Marbury Looms Next For Fading Knicks' Defense
description: It was difficult enough for Charlie Ward and Chris Childs to watch Denver's Nick Van Exel swoop, dip and dart around them with the carefree flight of a paper airplane Tuesday night.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NO VERIZON INCREASES
description: In what consumer advocates hailed as a victory yesterday, Verizon New Jersey said it would not seek an increase in its basic service rate of $8.19 a month for local phone service or for add-on services like caller ID. Across the board, there will be no increases, said Dennis Bone, president of the company, which is based in Newark. In December, Verizon withdrew an application to the State Board of Public Utilities that if approved would have forced most residential callers to accept bundled service packages starting at $15 per month. Verizon did ask the utilities board yesterday to deregulate rates charged to businesses with more than one phone line, asserting that dozens of companies had expressed interest in providing such service and therefore the market was competitive. But Michael Schweder, president of AT&T New Jersey, said that only a handful of companies, including his own, actually provide business phone service in New Jersey, meaning that Verizon could raise rates significantly. Verizon also said yesterday that it would contribute $20 million to provide Internet access to schools and libraries. Steve Strunsky

title: Paying the Price Pays Off for Franco
description: It was a batting practice fly ball this past August, like thousands he has seen, and John Franco was in the outfield to track it down. As the ball climbed above him, Franco flipped his glove in the air to try to stop its flight. It is a casual move; players do it every day. Franco will never do it again.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARTH, EDITH
description: BARTH-Edith. February 16, 1997. Forever mourned, forever missed, forever loved and always in our thoughts. Your Family

title: Goin' His Own Sweet Way, From Bluegrass to Swing
description: Depending on the song, the gently entrancing music of the Howard Fishman Quartet might be labeled anything from bluegrass-Dixieland to folk-swing. Such stylistic hybrids reflect the philosophy of the group's leader and namesake, who plays guitar, banjo and piano. In the first of three successive Sunday evening shows at Joe's Pub, Mr. Fishman declared his distaste for the compartmentalization of musical genres, which he blamed on the record industry, and held up early American music as an ideal.

Memorial service to be held on Sunday, February 18, at 11:00 AM at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, 516-487-9600. Contributions may be sent to Carcinoid Foundation, 1751 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

description: After watching the rookie forward Jeff Ulmer score two goals in his first five National Hockey League games, most Rangers fans could be excused for wondering, ''Where has this kid been all season?''

description: WILSON-Jerry Gordon. December 3, 1914-February 16, 1991. Dearly loved. Dearly missed.

title: Dell Computer to Cut Work Force by 4%
description: The softening market for personal computers finally struck home with Dell Computer's work force yesterday. The company said it would eliminate 1,700 jobs, or about 4 percent of its employees, in the first large-scale layoff in its 16-year history.

description: Thorspring Iceland, Heidmork, Iceland, owned by companies including the Coca-Cola bottler for Iceland, to the Sloan Group, New York, part of the Draft Worldwide unit of Interpublic, to handle the introduction of its Iceland Spring water brand in the United States. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: SILICON VALLEY LAW FIRM TO OPEN NEW YORK CITY BRANCH
description: Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati, the Palo Alto, Calif., law firm whose rapid growth in recent years has paralleled that of its Silicon Valley clients, said yesterday that it would open a branch office in New York City to serve Silicon Alley. Initially, the office will have a staff of two partners, Alexander D. Lynch and Babak Yaghmaie, and about eight junior lawyers. Wilson Sonsini hired the two partners away from the New York office of a rival, Gunderson Dettmer Stough Villeneuve Franklin & Hachigian. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, IRVING
description: MILLER-Irving, 82. May 6, 1918February 14, 2001, of White Plains, NY. Professor Emeritus Columbia University School of Social Work, taught 38 years. Survived by his wife Helen, children and their partners Josh and Davina, Abby and Melanie, brother Sidney and sister-in-law Janet, six grandchildren, and many family, friends and colleagues. A wise, lively, provocative spirit whose presence was always felt and will continue to be. We loved him dearly. Services Sunday, Feb. 18th at 10AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broadway, Mount Vernon, NY. Contributions may be made to Retinitis Pigmentosa International 1800-344-4877.

title: More Than a Slice
description: Almost everyone loves pizza. There are so many pizzerias in New York City that they have their own category in the Yellow Pages. And you don't have to confine yourself to takeout; many full-service restaurants, including these 12, offer pizzas in many forms along with other dishes. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

A newcomer to the company would have been hard-pressed to locate its avant-garde profile amid the mush: no hard-edged complex ballets in leotards to Stravinsky, no erotica in the abstract.

description: On the day before pitchers and catchers report to the Mets' training camp, closer Armando Benitez learned today that the district attorney's office in Queens had decided not to prosecute him on domestic assault allegations brought by his former fiance.

title: As Seen on TV: Making the World Safe for Vacations
description: Parents, get ready for the slogan ''only in theaters'' once again. ''Recess,'' the smart-alecky animated television series in which T. J. Detweiler and his schoolyard pals fight a never-ending battle against teacher-imposed doldrums at the Third Street School, comes to the big screen with ''Recess: School's Out,'' probably a momentary stopover on its trip to Blockbuster. Here, T. J., a prepubescent Hawkeye Pierce, is apprehended in one of his schemes by the authoritarian enemy, Principal Prickly, who bellows ''This time, I'm really gonna throw the book at you.'' But Prickly is checked in midtoss, since school is letting out for the summer.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEZAHLER, HANNAH
description: BEZAHLER-Hannah. Died February 14, 2001 in her 93rd year, in Miami, Florida. Widow of Joel Bezahler, mother of Arline Schwartz and Donald J. Bezahler. Her sonin-law Mac, her daughter-in-law Suzanne, her brother and sister-inlaw George and Mindy, her sister Syd, her grandchildren Ellen, Renee, David and Amber, and her great grandchildren Ryan and Adam all mourn her passing. To the end, Hannah was tough. She succumbed only after a bitter fight against illness and advanced age. She loved everyone in her own way, and is finally at peace with herself and with those whom she loved. The last eight months established an entirely new bond between her and her children, and, for that, we are eternally grateful. Interment at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY, Sunday, February 18th at 10:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers, please donate to your favorite charity.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about the practice of ''embargoing'' a new book -- controlling disclosure of the contents through the distribution of advance copies -- referred incorrectly to an article in The Daily News on Saturday about ''I.B.M. and the Holocaust'' by Edwin Black, issued by Crown Publishers. Editors at The Daily News deny that they ''broke the embargo.'' They say that they did not have an advance copy and that their article was based on information from others familiar with the book.

title: HONDA'S PROFIT FALLS
description: The Honda Motor Company said its group net profit fell 25 percent from the year-earlier quarter to 47 billion yen ($404 million) for the quarter ended Dec. 31. Increased sales in Japan and North America were overshadowed by the weak euro, which hurt sales in Europe, and by higher costs, the company said. Sales grew 9 percent. Auto sales increased 59 percent in North America and 29 percent in Japan. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Redeploy the Dollars
description: One of President Bush's campaign promises was a top-to-bottom review of American military strategy, missions, forces and weapons. His will not be the first sweeping review of the Pentagon's post-cold-war plans. Similar reviews in 1991, 1993 and 1997 all set out to restructure the military -- and all failed. They did result in smaller forces and reductions in major weapons purchases. Yet the forces and weapons themselves changed surprisingly little. Across the services and within them, the structure of our military is virtually the same as during the cold war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEEKS, P. SHELTON, JR.
description: WEEKS-P. Shelton, Jr. Aged 85. Born in Oyster Bay, L.I., died February 14, 2001 in Bonita Springs, FL. Previously a resident of Greenwich, CT. He retired after 45 years in advertising and marketing. He was Chairman of the Board of Kelly, Nason Advertising, prior to which he was Senior V.P. of Cunningham and Walsh Advertising. An amateur architect in CT and VT. An avid skier and sailor, founder of the New York 40' Class Boat. Former Commodore of Indian Harbor Yacht Club, one of the oldest living members of the New York Yacht Club, The Cruising Club of America, Storm Trysail Club and Mystic Seaport. He graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and served in the Navy. Survived by his wife, Anne, after 58 years of marriage, his sons, Peter and Nicholas, and daughters, Barrett Betschart and Perry Betteridge, five grandchildren, a sister, Mrs. William H. Peck. His eldest son, Mitchell, predeceased him. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant St., Concord, NH 03301 or Mystic Seaport, Greenmanville Ave., Mystic, CT 06355. A memorial service will be announced later in the Spring.

title: Xerox Debt Is Worrisome To Traders
description: The Xerox Corporation's stock has recently been popular with investors, but traders of its bank debt are a lot more skeptical about the company's prospects.

Cherished grandmother of Morgan, Ashley and Courtney Brokaw. Dear, devoted sister to Jean and Sid Kaufman, Barbara Schwartz and the late Gene Schwartz. Daughter of the late Henrietta and Oscar Baer. Survived by loving nieces and nephews Toni Schwartz, Doug Schwartz, Terri Kaufman and Jill and Rick Kaufman. Gloria will be remembered for her lively spirit, style and wit and her nurturing and loving nature. She was deeply loved and admired by all. She will be sadly missed. Services Sunday, February 18, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. The family will receive guests at the home of Gloria Kalender on Sunday from 3:307:30PM.

title: U.S. Seeks Bank Records in Pardon Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors in New York have prepared subpoenas demanding the bank records of Denise Rich, the former wife of Marc Rich, in an effort to determine the source of her contributions to Democratic causes in recent years, including $450,000 to Mr. Clinton's presidential library, government officials said today.

title: People

She had been senior vice president and United States corporate practice director at Manning, Selvage & Lee, New York, part of Bcom3.

title: Rooted in the Cajun Idiom, But Roaming More Widely
description: Beausoleil, the band from Louisiana led by Michael Doucet, started out as a crusade and then, sometime in the last 25 years, expanded into a party. Before Mr. Doucet founded the group in the mid-1970's, he sought out and studied with the Cajun and Creole fiddlers on the bayou. He was determined to keep their idiosyncratic styles alive and to rescue the image of Acadian culture from Cajun caricatures. But he didn't confine the band to purism, so Beausoleil has also linked the bayou to country music, Celtic music, jazz, swamp-pop and New Orleans rhythm and blues. Years ago Mr. Doucet realized that the best way to spread the music was to keep its good-time spirit.

title: A Cold and Hesitant Van Horn Is Torn Between Two Positions
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott said today that he is now worried about a hesitant Keith Van Horn. And Van Horn, the Nets' No. 2 go-to player, said he is not yet comfortable, feeling caught between positions.

title: Love Means Not Ever Having to Make a Bit of Sense

So says Sara Deever (Charlize Theron), a free-spirited San Francisco bohemian, to her beau, Nelson Moss (Keanu Reeves), a career-obsessed advertising executive, in ''Sweet November,'' a new romantic weepy remade from an old one that starred Sandy Dennis and Anthony Newley. Her words might well have served as an advertising tag line for the movie, which defies all comprehension.

He's the director of orthopedics and sports rehabilitation at Beth Israel Medical Center, but he's a serial moonlighter, hiding a spiffy gold tie inside his on-duty laboratory coat (as NBC's sports medicine consultant, he tends to be TV-ready).

title: Review/Fashion; When the Message Swamps the Medium

Beasley, Jr. of Reston, VA; Sayde Gray of Atlanta, GA; Winnie C. Beasley of Leominster, Mass.; brother of Jean Briston of CA. He also leaves eight grandchildren. Anderson & Son Funeral Home, 46 Washington St., Ayer. Memorial contributions may be made to the Rev. Louis J. Scott Nicholls, Jr., Treasurer Guy N. Robinson, Secretary Robert W. Radsch, Assistant Secretary

title: Puerto Vallarta Wedding
description: Two-for-ones are a staple of travel bargains. Here's a twist on that idea from the Club Viva Vallarta in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico: a deal that combines a wedding with a honeymoon. The resort's wedding package, $690 on top of the regular all-inclusive rates, includes a civil judge and legal expenses, bridal bouquet, decorations, wedding cake, private bar for 10 people, 10 color photos and music. Club Viva Vallarta overlooks Vallarta Bay on Mexico's Pacific Coast. Rates for its 355 rooms start at $130 a person, double occupancy, through April 14, and the price includes all meals, alcoholic beverages, fitness programs, nightly entertainment and all taxes and tips. Couples who wish to be married in Mexico do not have to reside there, but there are some requirements, which can be found at www.vivaresorts.com . Contact the hotel at (800) 898-9968.

title: Nihilists Beware: A Swath of Black Life, 'Family of Man' Style
description: You don't have to consult a calendar. If there's a major new museum show of African-American art in town, it must be February. Such is the jaded reaction of more than a few black artists to the predictable swell of mainstream attention that comes their way during Black History Month, then quietly dies down.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Mill Closes, and a Hamlet Fades to Black
description: An aching stillness has settled over this company town. All that can be heard now are the whispers of the Adirondack winds spinning whirls of snow in empty streets.

title: Defending the Estate Tax
description: From the time that opponents started calling it the ''death tax,'' momentum has been building in Congress to get rid of the federal tax on estates. Vetoed by President Clinton last year, the estate tax repeal is now a central element of President Bush's $1.6 trillion tax-cut package. Lately, however, Congress has begun entertaining second thoughts, and for good reason. Some of the strongest arguments against repeal are coming from a group of 120 wealthy Americans, including Warren Buffett, George Soros and William Gates Sr., the father of the founder of Microsoft. Their words are worth listening to as Congress takes on the entire tax-cut package.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESNOW, BERTHA (NEE EISENBERG)
description: LESNOW-Bertha (nee Eisenberg). In her 95th year. Beloved wife of Dr. Jack Lesnow for 69 years. Sister of Ruth Kramer and the late Joseph Eisenberg. Devoted mother of Judith (and Kal) Noselson. Adoring grandmother of Betsy (and Michael) Hockstein, Susie (and Rob) Koltun and the late Adam Noselson. Loving great grandmother of Katie, Max, Fannie and Moe. Graveside service on Friday, February 16, at 1:00 PM, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the charity of your choice.

title: U.S. and British Jets Strike Air-Defense Centers in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The United States and Britain staged air strikes against radar stations and air defense command centers in Iraq today, including targets around Baghdad, in what President Bush called a necessary response to Iraqi provocation.

title: Critic's Notebook; Making and Taking Offense, Elevated to Art Form
description: Again? Publicity and political gain having become ends in themselves in our sorry cultural wars, the bait is once more being dangled. Wouldn't it be nice to take a pass occasionally?

title: Imperfect Networks, Imperfect Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the sentencing of the International Boxing Federation founder, Robert W. Lee Sr., for money laundering and tax evasion, referred incorrectly to part of a related civil action. The civil agreement accepted by Judge John W. Bissell of the United States District Court in Newark included Mr. Lee's lifetime ban from boxing and a $50,000 payment to the federation; it did not lift court supervision of the organization.

title: George Simon, 88, a Jazz Critic Who Reviewed the Big Bands
description: George T. Simon, a jazz critic best known for his writing during the big-band era, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 88 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Raji Jallepalli-Reiss has established a big reputation with her Indian fusion cooking in an unlikely place, Memphis. Not many New Yorkers make the trip to eat at Restaurant Raji. But they can get a taste of the Raji style at Surya in Greenwich Village, where she was menu consultant, and now at Tamarind, a new restaurant owned by Avtar Walia, formerly a partner in Dawat.

title: Breathless in Haifa (and Hungry, Too)
description: Amos Gitai's ''Yom Yom,'' completed in 1998 and opening today at Anthology Film Archives as part of a retrospective of Mr. Gitai's work, is the second of a trilogy of films about life in Israel's major cities. The first, ''Devarim,'' was set in the cosmopolitan bustle of Tel Aviv, and the third, ''Kadosh,'' which was shown at Film Forum last year, explored, from a decidedly secular perspective, the ultra-Orthodox neighborhoods in Jerusalem.

title: New York as Textbook For Art History 101
description: When my 15-year-old daughter was very young, I would muse that when she grew up we could have conversations about books and music and art. And that's what happened. They began much earlier than I had anticipated, and they were always wonderful.

title: Residential Real Estate; Downtown Office Tower Yields 115 Apartments
description: A 1920's office tower at 53 Park Place in Manhattan's financial district has been brought back to life as an apartment building, continuing the march of conversions downtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, IRVING SAMUEL
description: ELIAS-Irving Samuel. Daddy and Pop Pop, we love you. Gale, Shari, Sam, Colby, Harry, Samara, Chloe and Brant

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a subheading in Business Day yesterday with an article about the complexity of rates for long-distance calling cards and the tricky definition of ''no hidden charges'' misstated the given name of the dictionary maker who might have been baffled by it. He was Noah Webster; Daniel Webster was the statesman and orator.

description: To the Editor:

title: He May Be in Heaven, but He's Dying at the Apollo
description: In the May 1969 issue of Playboy (which I read just for the articles, incidentally), I came across an item that still stuck in the back of my head as I watched ''Down to Earth,'' the remake of ''Here Comes Mr. Jordan,'' starring Chris Rock. In an interview with Bill Cosby, Playboy mentioned, ''And in April of this year, Cosby began filming a remake of 'Here Comes Mr. Jordan,' '' saying the movie was due for release in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, HANNAH
description: STAHL-Hannah. On February 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Loving mother of Harvey, Robert & mother-in-law of Jackie. Dear sister of Lillian Rachleff and sister-in-law of Jack Rachleff. Adoring grandmother of Lori, Kevin and Allison. Most loving greatgrandmother of Jacob. Services Friday 12:45PM at Riverside-Parkwest, 76th & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Asia-Pacific Is Hot Spot For 3 Agency Deals
description: Agencies are making deals in the Asia-Pacific region, all for undisclosed terms.

title: Builders' Optimism Is Up, Survey Says
description: Home builders' optimism improved in February after falling a month earlier to the lowest level in four years, a construction industry survey said today.

title: Rate of All I.R.S. Audits Falls; Poor Face Particular Scrutiny
description: Audits of tax returns by the Internal Revenue Service, already at a record low in 1999, fell almost 50 percent last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERBIT, MARSHALL
description: BERBIT-Marshall. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Marshall Berbit, husband of Thea Berbit, our esteemed colleague. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, Nat'l President

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: No More Pluto, No More Taupe
description: Quietly, and apparently uniquely among major scientific institutions, the American Museum of Natural History cast Pluto out of the pantheon of planets.

title: New Georgetown President
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Georgetown University on Friday will announce the selection of John J. DeGioia as its next president, the first in its history who is not a Jesuit priest, school officials said.

title: Bush Team Under Attack on Emissions Talks
description: The Bush administration is only slowly turning to climate issues and so is being left on the sidelines in international talks that could shape a treaty curtailing global warming, say government officials and executives involved in the discussions.

title: 4 Nominations: 'It's Cool'
description: Cameron Crowe was on the set of ''Vanilla Sky,'' a new thriller he is shooting with Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz, when he received word that his previous film, ''Almost Famous,'' had been nominated for four Academy Awards. He looked around and realized that many of the cast and crew members had worked with him on both films.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, HERBERT ELLIS
description: ROBBINS-Herbert Ellis, died on February 12. Beloved husband of Carol; adored brother of Francie; esteemed father of Mark, David and Emily, Susannah and Marcia, and grandfather of Alice and Michael Borden. An incredible character in all of our lives, he shall never be forgotten. His Loving Family

title: Recreating Pollock, Gingerly
description: One hundred miles seems to have been Jackson Pollock's ideal distance from Manhattan. Pollock, whose spontaneous paint pouring produced abstract masterpieces, was an emotionally fragile man whose drinking problem and mood swings were at odds with his creative drive. In New York City, where he went to study art in 1930, he found the stimulus his ambition demanded. As he began to achieve recognition, however, he was increasingly overwhelmed by the social and professional pressures of the art world.

title: Aetna Executive Named
description: Aetna Inc. the nation's leading health insurer, named Dr. William C. Popik as its chief medical officer as it struggles to control costs and change the way it deals with customers and doctors. Dr. Popik, 55, will start March 5 and report to Aetna's chief executive, John Rowe, the company, which is based in Hartford, said. Dr. Popik had been senior vice president and national medical director at Cigna HealthCare, a unit of the Cigna Corporation, the health insurer. Dr. Popik will be at the center of Aetna's efforts to manage medical costs.

title: Congo Leader Offers Talks To the Rebels; Tensions Ease
description: Parties warring in Congo, meeting for the first time since the assassination last month of the president, Laurent Kabila, moved closer to peace today with unexpected agreements on a handful of crucial issues.

title: Big Woman on Campus Leads Irish
description: Growing up in Macy, Ind., about 70 miles south of here, basketball was a natural fit for Ruth Riley. Since fourth grade, she has played the game that can seem like a birthright in this state.

title: PEDIATRIX MEDICAL IS BUYING MAGELLA FOR $141 MILLION
description: The Pediatrix Medical Group said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Magella Healthcare Corporation for $141 million in stock. The acquisition will add doctors to Pediatrix management practices in hospital neonatal intensive care units. Pediatrix, based in Sunrise, Fla., will issue 6.8 million shares of stock in exchange for the outstanding stock and warrants of the closely held Magella, the company said. Pediatrix will also assume about $48.5 million in Magella debt and subordinated notes. The acquisition will create a $322.5 million company that employs 550 physicians in 27 states and Puerto Rico, the company said. Magella is based in Dallas.

title: Bankrupt Daewoo Cuts 1,750 as Angry Workers Protest
description: SEOUL, Feb. 16  Beginning a long-threatened corporate bloodletting over the bitter protests of its union, the Daewoo Motor Company sent dismissal notices to 1,750 employees today. Several hundred workers responded by marching outside a big Daewoo plant in Pupyong, 20 miles west of Seoul, shouting "We will fight to the end," as their families cheered them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, DOUGLASS
description: CAMPBELL-Douglass. On February 14, 2001, in his 82nd years, while traveling in Australia. His late wife, Marion Danielson Campbell, died in November 1998. Survived by two (step) sons, Richard Strachan of Hood River, OR., and Stephen Strachan of Denver, CO, his brother Stafford Campbell of Jacksonville, FL and one grandson, Kammer Douglass Strachan also of Denver. Formerly Vice President New York Central Railroad; Chairman and President, Bowater Paper Company; Founder and President Argyle Research Corporation; Vice President Hambro America, Inc.; Senior Vice President Resource Holdings Ltd. US Army 1942-1946, Major, serving as Adjutant, Port of Bombay, India. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Yale University, Class of 1941, New Haven, CT 06521, would be appreciated.

title: Bush Gives Mexico Backing on Drive Against Narcotics
description: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LOS RANCHOS, Mexico, Feb. 16  Acknowledging that Americans' demand feeds drug traffic, President Bush signaled today that he would support Mexico in its efforts to end the annual ritual in which Congress requires the Mexican government to prove its commitment to the war against narcotics or face economic sanctions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROBERT W., PH.D
description: WHITE-Robert W., Ph.D of Weston, formerly of Brookline and Concord, MA, Marlborough, NH and Marlboro, VT, February 6, 2001, Father of David W. White of Cambridge and Marlborough. Uncle of Barbara and Sally Baker of Needham and Donald V. Baker of Beverly. Many cousins and friends. Mr. White is predeceased by his wife, Margaret Ley (Bazeley) White, a son Timothy White, a brother Henry D. White, and a sister Katharine H. White. Memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 17th at 2pm in First Church in Chestnut Hill, 26 Suffolk Road, Chestnut Hill (Newton), MA. Organ prelude to commence at 1:20 pm. Donations may be made to either: High Mowing School, P.O. Box 850 Abbott Hill Rd., Wilton NH 03086 or Marlboro College, Marlboro, VT 05344 or Marlboro School of Music, Inc., Box K, Marlboro, VT 05344 or Walker Home & School, 1968 Central Ave., Needham, MA 02492. J.S. Waterman & Sons Eastman - Waring 617 536-4110

title: Fountain Favorite Gets Bailey
description: After Jerry Bailey won the $100,000 Shirley Jones Handicap atop Hidden Assets on Wednesday at Gulfstream Park, he winked at the trainer Steve Flint and said: ''That was the tough one. The easy one is Saturday.''

title: Nasdaq Drops Sharply Amid Economy Worries
description: Already jolted by the latest round of profit warnings from technology companies, Wall Street was further unnerved today by an unexpectedly big rise in producer prices, which it saw as an omen that inflation might be rising and further interest rate cuts were less likely despite the economic slowdown.

title: Gordon R. Dickson -- Science Fiction Writer, 77
description: Gordon R. Dickson, a science fiction author best known for his Dorsai books, died on Jan. 31 at his home in Minneapolis. He was 77.

title: U.S. and British Forces Attack Air Defense Installations in Iraq
description: Two dozen American and British warplanes blasted Iraqi air defense targets around Baghdad today in response to what military officials said were heightened and more accurate attacks on the planes patrolling a "no flight" zone over the southern part of the country.

title: COVAD SUED OVER INTERRUPTED SERVICE
description: DSLnetworks, a high-speed Internet access provider, has filed a lawsuit against Covad Communications of Santa Clara, Calif., after Covad cut off service to DSLnetworks' 3,500 customers. The suit, filed in California County Superior Court in Santa Clara, accuses Covad of cutting service with the intent of converting DSLnetworks' customers to Covad's high-speed service. A spokesman for DSLnetworks, based in San Francisco, said high-ranking Covad executives even telephoned several of DSLnetworks' largest corporate customers directly. Covad says it disrupted the company's service for nonpayment of millions of dollars in past-due bills. Covad also cut off service to Internet Express, another service provider, for what it said was nonpayment of past-due bills. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: INSIDE ART
description: Whitney Again Looks for Space

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Beauty? Brains? Place Your Orders
description: I WOULDN'T be surprised if in another 30 years,'' Francis S. Collins, director of the National Human Genome Research Institute, said the other day, ''that some people will begin to argue, as Stephen Hawking already is, that we ought to take charge of our own evolution and should not be satisfied with our current biological status and should as a species try to improve ourselves.''

title: Why Napster Is Music to My Ears
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: I.B.M. AND ERICSSON TO SELL BANK PRODUCTS JOINTLY
description: International Business Machines and Ericsson A.B. of Sweden agreed yesterday to sell products jointly to help banks provide advanced wireless services, including mobile trading and payments. Financial terms were not disclosed. I.B.M. and Ericsson, the top builder of cellular-phone networks, said they would integrate software products this year so that financial services companies could offer broader and more secure trading and banking services. The Ericsson alliance is part of an effort by I.B.M. to spend $1 billion this year developing European wireless initiatives. Separately, I.B.M. said it had won a $200 million contract from Kmart, Troy, Mich., to supply Kmart's stores with computer-based checkout devices.

title: 2 Moderate Republicans Oppose Bush Tax Plan as Democrats Offer Their Own
description: Showing the challenges ahead for President Bush, two Republican senators have come out against his proposal for a 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut and Democratic Congressional leaders today began a drive for a tax cut less than half the size of the president's plan.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Best of Enemies
description: History does indeed work in funny ways. Two men who nearly 20 years ago tried to kill each other in Beirut are about to discover that the only way they can save themselves politically is if they now save each other. Ladies and gentlemen, I introduce Ariel Sharon and Yasir Arafat, surely history's oddest couple.

title: WATCHING MOVIES WITH/Steven Soderbergh; Follow the Muse: Inspiration To Balance Lofty and Light
description: THIS is one of the great openings of all time,'' Steven Soderbergh said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an investigation of the pardon of Marc Rich conducted by the United States attorney in New York in coordination with the Justice Department misspelled the surname of the head of the department's public integrity section. He is Lee Radek, not Radick.

title: A Ramble Through Louisiana's Roots Music
description: To describe the recent films of the documentarian Robert Mugge as cultural reference books doesn't mean to imply that these explorations of the musical byways of Southern rural America are lacking in pungent musical sap. It's the careful balance between music and scholarship that lends Mr. Mugge's films a foundation of academic seriousness that flirts with dryness without becoming mired in trivia. Documents of a flourishing below-the-radar culture, often involving older musicians who won't be around much longer, they are archival records as well as entertainments.

title: Waco Pins Its Hopes for Image on Bush Ranch
description: Several hours into Day 1 of the 51-day standoff between federal law enforcement officers and the Branch Davidians, Sammy Citrano decided the officers must be hungry. He loaded his truck with hot coffee and beef fajitas, drove outside town to the siege site, and soon he was feeding guys carrying machine guns. He admits now that he was terrified.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WHIRLPOOL, Benton Harbor, Mich., the appliance maker, said it had acquired a stake in the closely held ZBox Co., San Francisco, a maker of secure home-delivery boxes. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Power Plant Idea Has Few Friends at Hearing
description: A proposed 1,100-megawatt electrical generating plant in a craggy little valley in western Rockland County was roundly criticized today as New York State started public hearings on the plan.

title: RATES STEADY IN EUROPE
description: The European Central Bank's council decided to keep interest rates unchanged yesterday, leaving the key minimum bid rate at 4.75 percent. In contrast to the United States Federal Reserve's fears about American growth, the council has remained confident about the euro zone. But a rate cut is expected within the next several months. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Experienced Lawyer Picked for Antitrust Chief
description: President Bush said today that he would nominate Charles A. James, an experienced and respected antitrust lawyer in Washington, to be the new assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division of the Justice Department.

title: TELECOM SWAP IN INDONESIA
description: Indonesia's two state-owned telecommunications companies announced a $1.5 billion deal yesterday to swap shares in the other's subsidiaries, including stakes in the country's two largest cellular operators. The government has ordered the deregulation of Indonesia's telecommunications industry by 2003, ending a monopoly on domestic fixed-line services held by Telekomunikasi Indonesia and one on international calls held by Indonesia Satellite. Wayne Arnold

title: Sports of The Times; Midwinter Nightmare Almost Over
description: PITCHERS and catchers are here. We shall soon be cured by Dr. Selig's Magic Elixir.

title: France to Kill 10,000 Head of Cattle a Week to Help Beef Prices
description: The French government announced plans today to slaughter up to 10,000 head of cattle a week to support beef prices forced down by the mad cow crisis.

title: Vito Acconci and Ana Mendieta -- 'A Relationship Study, 1969-1976'
description: Galerie Lelong

title: Three 19th-Century Minds, One Vision of Nature
description: In the annals of male bonding, the friendship of three celebrated 19th-century Americans -- the poet and journalist William Cullen Bryant and the painters Asher B. Durand and Thomas Cole -- should rank high. It lasted from young adulthood until their deaths, although Cole (1801-1848) departed early and Durand (1796-1886) and Bryant (1794-1878) lived to ripe old ages.

description: The Bear Stearns Companies is increasing its involvement in trading at the New York Stock Exchange through a partnership with a firm managed by John A. Mulheren Jr., a trader who once threatened to kill Ivan F. Boesky, his onetime associate.

title: Priceline Reports Losses and Slow Sales
description: Priceline.com said yesterday that its losses widened and its sales plunged in the fourth quarter, throwing the company's viability further in doubt.

title: Public Interests; Massachusetts Delivers
description: The governor of Massachusetts, Paul Cellucci, has been nominated to become ambassador to Canada. This seems to have pleased the Canadians, who noted that Mr. Cellucci's daughter is dating a hockey player.

description: THEY were haikus of victimization scrawled on scraps of cardboard that peered timidly from car windows.

title: F.T.C. INTERVENES IN DOMAIN-NAME CASE
description: The Federal Trade Commission has asked a judge in the United States District Court in Atlanta to stop an Internet domain name operation that it said had tricked as many as 27,000 people into needlessly registering variations of existing domain names by suggesting that another party, acting in bad faith, was preparing to claim it. According to the commission, a company known as Electronic Domain Name Monitoring or Corporate Domain Name Monitoring sent faxes to Web site owners indicating that someone had registered domain names that were nearly identical to those of the recipients' sites. For example, the government agency said, an owner of the site www.sobi-sky.org might have been told that an application had been submitted for the domain name www.sobi-sky.net. The fax solicitations offered to block the application for a $70 fee. The F.T.C. asked the court to prohibit the practice and to shut Web sites used to promote it.

title: Town's Adieu to 4 'Finest Sons and Daughters'
description: Under leaden skies in a military cemetery at the edge of this coastal town, 18-year-old Yasmin Karissi was laid to rest today in the first of four freshly dug graves.

title: A Deep Slumber For Seton Hall In Another Loss
description: There were few boos for Seton Hall at Continental Arena tonight, but there were plenty of sighs. Sighs of frustration and exasperation. Everyone can see that Seton Hall has immense talent, but everyone also sees that the Pirates do not always play as if they care. Too often, Seton Hall is lethargic.
