description: February 15, 2001

title: Governor and Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Suffolk's Lazio Weighs Run for Nassau County Executive
description: Rick A. Lazio, who repeatedly dismissed Hillary Rodham Clinton as a carpetbagger during his failed Senate race against her, is now weighing a run for county executive in Nassau County, where he has never lived.

title: York Coach Will Miss Part of Game
description: For the first half of this season, the York College team had only six players; fouls were a luxury that this team could not afford.

title: Preserving History
description: To the Editor:

title: Khallid Abdul Muhammad, Former Nation of Islam Official, Dies at 53
description: Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the former Nation of Islam official who was a leader of the next generation of radical black civil rights leaders to some and a racist hatemonger to others, died late Thursday in a hospital in Marietta, a suburb of Atlanta. He was 53.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ALICE L.
description: WILSON-Alice L., a lifelong volunteer, activist, friend to the Arts, and former academic development officer, died on February 5, in Guilford, Conn. at the home of her daughter. Mrs. Wilson was 75. The cause of death was sudden heart failure. Mrs. Wilson's enthusiasm and warm personality attracted a great array of faithful friends in Nantucket, Ohio, and New York. She is survived by her husband, David; her brother, Charles F. Lehmann of Ann Arbor, Michigan; three daughters, Suzanne Stark of Maui, Hawaii, Karen Stark of New York City and Guilford, Conn., and Amy Tercek of Irvington, New York, and four grandchildren.

title: An Official's Empathy
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLTEL SAYS IT WILL CUT 1,000 JOBS TO REDUCE EXPENSES
description: The Alltel Corporation, a provider of wireless, local and long-distance telephone services, said yesterday that it would cut 1,000 jobs, or 3.7 percent of its work force, as part of a plan to reduce expenses. Alltel, which expects to add 500,000 to 550,000 wireless customers this year, also forecast per-share profit from current businesses of $2.85 to $3 in 2001. Analysts had expected profit of $2.98. The company, based in Little Rock, Ark., said the job cuts would be accomplished partly through early retirements. Alltel shares rose 18 cents, to $53.29.

title: Key Executives Are on the Move
description: Senior executives are making moves at four agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORIN, MARGARET
description: GORIN-Margaret. 10/31/11-2/16/97. Beloved sister to Irene and Leo and aunt of Kathy and Mark, great aunt of Alex and Destiny Rose. We miss you always.

description: Stefan Stux

title: Questions About Rush in Nortel Trading
description: The announcement of disappointing results by Nortel Networks yesterday was preceded by heavy trading and a sudden decline in the company's stock price as well as by a rapid increase in options trading that could indicate that word of the bad news had leaked out.

title: IONA AND NETFISH TO MERGE
description: Iona Technologies agreed to buy the closely held software integration company Netfish Technologies for $270 million in stock. Under the agreement, Iona, based in Dublin, which provides products to operate Internet portals and e-commerce sites, will exchange 5.5 million common shares for Netfish, based in Santa Clara, Calif. Shares of Iona jumped $9.06, or 18.5 percent, to $58.13.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Bill Clinton Lends a Hand

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAFFE, BEVERLY
description: YAFFE-Beverly. Age 64. February 13, 2001. Beloved wife of Bob. Loving mother of Alan, David and Rick. Loving mother-in-law of Kathie, Claire and Anna. Devoted grandmother of Hillary, April and Levitt. Adored friend who deeply loved life lived to the fullest, and was and will always be an inspiration to us all. Services were held Thursday, 10AM ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Pentagon Bars Civilians From Submarine Controls
description: The Navy has tightened its rules on allowing civilians to participate in training exercises aboard submarines, at least until the investigation into the sinking of a Japanese fishing trawler off Hawaii is completed, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Teachers Upset by Play's Treatment of the Holocaust
description: A children's play about African-American history that is being performed for thousands of students in Brooklyn for Black History Month has angered several public school teachers, who complained that the first scene belittles the Holocaust.

title: Legal Expert Sees Light Focused on Napster Users
description: It's no secret that Napster suffered a major and perhaps fatal blow Monday when the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, issued its long-awaited decision. Boiled down, the federal appeals court found it likely that the popular online music-swapping service illegally aided others in violating copyright law.

title: States' Pardons Now Looked At In Starker Light
description: In Wisconsin, just before he left office to become President Bush's secretary of health and human services, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson pardoned a Republican state senator's son who had been convicted of cocaine possession.

title: Talk Is of Beanballs, and Thoughts Turn to Clemens
description: Roger Clemens was not mentioned in a memorandum distributed to umpires this week, a letter that reinforced their discretion to eject a pitcher who throws at or near the head of a batter. But after hearing about the memo's contents today, Yankees Manager Joe Torre saw between the lines, and fretted.

title: YAHOO EUROPEAN HEAD QUITS
description: Yahoo said that Fabiola Arredondo, the chief of its European operations, resigned to pursue other business interests. A replacement was not named. Mr. Arredondo, whose title was Yahoo Europe managing director, will leave before the end of this quarter, after helping with the transition, a spokeswoman said. Yahoo's president, Jeffrey Mallett, will take a greater role in Yahoo Europe until a replacement for Mr. Arredondo is named.

title: Affronted by Nude 'Last Supper,' Giuliani Calls for Decency Panel
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art that includes a color photograph of a nude woman in Christ's place at the Last Supper was ''disgusting,'' ''outrageous'' and ''anti-Catholic.'' Then he declared that he would appoint a commission to set ''decency standards'' to keep such work out of museums that receive public money.

title: BANNER ADS FOR GOOD CAUSES
description: Recent skepticism about the effectiveness of banner advertisements on Web sites does not seem to have discouraged a specific advertising segment -- banner ads that are placed pro bono. The Advertising Council said yesterday that Web-banner public service announcements for its almost 40 campaigns received more than 11 billion impressions, which it valued at $400 million in donated advertising space, last year -- an increase of more than nine billion impressions and $300 million over 1999. Among the ads that were placed by the council, those for the organization Environmental Defense received the most impressions, followed by ads for the National 4-H Council and for the Benton Foundation's Connect for Kids site.

title: A New Aide Prompts Talk of Beijing's Strength in Hong Kong
description: A month after the No. 2 official here resigned amid signs she was in disfavor with Beijing, Hong Kong shuffled its government today, appointing a bureaucrat with a British knighthood to head its civil service and a onetime pro-Beijing student leader to keep its books.

title: An Auction of Roosevelt Items Brings $2.7 Million at Christie's
description: A private collection of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt's papers, books and heirlooms fetched $2.7 million from the National Park Service, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library and hundreds of other bidders during a two-day auction at Christie's that ended yesterday.

title: A New Front in the Pardon Investigation
description: The United States attorney in New York, Mary Jo White, has now added the authority and investigative resources of her office to the widening inquiry into President Clinton's 11th-hour pardon of Marc Rich, the fugitive commodities trader. Although we have expressed reservations about a prolonged round of investigations, Ms. White's intervention is throughly justified. Indeed she would not be doing her duty if she ignored the direct lobbying of Mr. Clinton by Mr. Rich's former wife, Denise Rich, and the money trail linking Ms. Rich to Democratic campaigns and the Clinton library.

title: Greg Colson
description: Sperone Westwater

title: Stern Agrees to City Legislation Lowering Fees for Tree Work
description: Facing criticism because his department had sought to charge $42,000 to cut down a homeowner's tree, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern agreed yesterday to a compromise under which homeowners would be charged less.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 6 about a group investment in the 18th-century instrument played by the violinist Robert McDuffie misstated the birth and death years of its maker, Giuseppe Guarneri, known as Ges. He lived from 1698 to 1744 -- not 1699 to 1774.

title: Opposition to Bush Tax Plan
description: Two Republican senators have come out against President Bush's tax-cut plan, and Congressional Democrats are pushing for a cut less than half its size. Page A16.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: A bipartisan group of lawmakers mounted a drive in the House and Senate today to overturn the new Bush administration policy on international family planning assistance, which they argue is counterproductive and cruel.

description: RICHARDSON-Adele. Age 79. Beloved wife of the late H. Smith Richardson, Jr. died on February 15 following a brief illness. A service of remembrance will be held on Sunday, February 18, 2001 at 3:00 PM at the First Presbyterian Church, Greensboro, N.C. Mrs. Richardson was born in Newport, R.I. and was a longtime resident of Wilmington, N.C. Mrs. Richardson is survived by three daughters, Adele Richardson Ray of Pittsboro, N.C., Page Richardson of Chapel Hill, N.C. and Cary Paynter of Wilmington, N.C.; three sons, Stuart Richardson of Easton, CT, Peter Richardson of Riverside, CT and H. Smith Richardson III of Santa Barbara, CA. Also surviving is a brother, Pickett Greig of Washington, D.C.; twelve grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. The Hanes-Lineberry Funeral Home, 515 North Elm St., Greensboro, N.C. is assisting the family.

title: Times Fax Service Expands
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that it was renaming and redesigning TimesFax, its compilation of news articles distributed to hotels, resorts, cruise ships, corporations and Navy ships and bases in more than 60 countries.

title: It's Not Just AT&T: How Telecom Became a Black Hole
description: THOSE whom the Wall Street gods would destroy, they first make glamorous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, BEATRICE JEAN
description: BENNETT-Beatrice Jean. Only child of Robert Russell Bennett, famous orchestrator and composer, and Louise Bennett, died on February 14th, 2001 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She was an artist. She is survived by her son, Kean K. McDonald, and three grandchildren.

title: Bush Is Moving to Reduce Labor's Political Coffers
description: The administration has told union leaders that President Bush will soon issue an executive order effectively reducing the amount of money that goes to organized labor's political campaign coffers, union officials said today.

title: DISAPPOINTING TELECOM PROFIT
description: The Telecom Corporation of New Zealand posted a lower-than-expected second-quarter profit of 139 million New Zealand dollars ($60 million), a 29 percent drop from a year earlier. Domestic competition and the cost of financing the acquisition of the Australian telecommunications company AAPT Ltd. eroded earnings in the quarter, which ended Dec. 31. Debt swelled last year because of the AAPT purchase. Customers grew, but revenue growth was hurt by competition, forcing Telecom New Zealand to trim prices, the chairman, Roderick Deane, said.

title: The Big City; Distress From a Zipper Out of Season
description: FASHION WEEK is ending none too soon for my taste. Whatever triumphs others have enjoyed in the tent at Bryant Park, for me it has been a week that began with anxiety and concluded in cruel disillusionment.

title: Europe and South Korea Fail To End Shipbuilding Dispute
description: Top trade officials of the European Union and South Korea confronted one another here today in a bitter dispute over whether South Korean shipbuilding companies are unfairly ''dumping'' their goods on world markets.

description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Leader of Harlem Youth Rallies Is Reported Gravely Ill in Georgia
description: Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the former Nation of Islam official who clashed with the Giuliani administration over several rallies in Harlem, is gravely ill in a suburban Atlanta hospital after having suffered a brain hemorrhage, friends and associates said yesterday.

title: Selig Unlikely To Void Trade
description: Barring unexpected disclosures, Commissioner Bud Selig will not void the trade of David Wells to the Chicago White Sox because of Mike Sirotka's shoulder ailment, a baseball official said yesterday. Furthermore, another official said, the Toronto Blue Jays do not want Wells back.

title: $17.6 Billion Deal to Make De Beers Private Company
description: The Oppenheimer family, which has controlled much of the world diamond trade for more than 70 years, has tightened its already powerful grip with a $17.6 billion agreement to turn De Beers into a private company in partnership with its sister corporation, Anglo American, and other close allies.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The dollar rose on expectations the economy will avoid a recession and investors will continue to favor the United States. In New York, the euro settled at 90.42 cents, down from 91.76 cents on Wednesday.

title: Home Video: Award Buzz at Home
description: ward buzz will send winning rock era autobio up the video charts," reads the recommendation for "Almost Famous" in The Movie Monitor, a tip sheet for video dealers. Cameron Crowe's reminiscence about his youthful days as a rock writer, with Oscar nominations as best supporting actress for Kate Hudson and Frances McDormand, is due on March 13.

title: Stolen-Car Odyssey: A Crash, A Sleeping Boy and an Arrest
description: Like thousands of couples, Patricia Carrington, 30, and her husband, Kenmore, 28, decided to go out on Valentine's Day, and left the children with a relative so they could celebrate alone. First it was dinner at Red Lobster in Darien, Conn., then out for a couple of drinks and then a quick stop at home in Stamford before relieving Mrs. Carrington's mother of her baby-sitting duties.

title: Steinbrenner Broaches Subject of a New Contract With Torre
description: George Steinbrenner ambled into the Yankees' clubhouse today, stepped into the office of Manager Joe Torre and shut the door.

XP is scheduled for the second half of the year, after OS X, not before.

description: Adirondack Park in upstate New York, which covers six million acres of public and private land, has numerous ski-touring centers and countless ski trails.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTIS, JOSEPHINE
description: BASTIS-Josephine. The Cycladic Art Foundation is deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and benefactor, Jo Bastis. Her respect for family and community is well known. Her keen knowledge in the field of ancient Greek art, coupled with her generosity, serve as a respected and enviable example. We shall miss her kindness and graciousness. Dolly Goulandris, Honorary Dir. Shelby White, Chairman

title: Democrats See a Party Adrift As Presidential Loss Sinks In
description: Democrats didn't think it could get any worse than Florida. They were wrong.

In lieu of flowers donations to Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 2247, NYC 10116. A memorial service will be held on February 16 at the W New York Hotel, 541 Lexington Ave. (50th St.) at 10:30 AM.

title: Directive Says Rice, Bush Aide, Won't Be Upstaged by Cheney
description: President Bush has given his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, the traditional powers of her post and rejected suggestions that Vice President Cheney head important meetings of the National Security Council, according to a presidential directive distributed today.

She was previously director of epidemiology and prevention research at the National Institute on Drug Abuse; she was not its director.

description: Oakland Athletics Manager Art Howe agreed yesterday to a one-year contract extension through the 2002 season.

title: Racial Slurs and Intrigue on City I.

title: Let Forests Grow Old
description: To the Editor:

title: Amateur Physicists, Gliding Across Snow
description: I've come to think that winter is the season of physics. Classical mechanics, actually. Not if you stay inside, of course. Then it can be the season of old Kirk Douglas movies, or hearty stews, or naps. But if you venture outdoors to indulge in winter sports, you enter the realm of velocity, mass, speed and friction -- above all friction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, JAMES A.
description: LEE-James A. The American Civil Liberties Union and The New York Civil Liberties Union mourn the sudden passing of James A. Lee, who as a Board member, donor and valuable member of the Union's budget and investment committees, was, for nearly four decades, one of the ACLU's most devoted supporters. His passionate concern for access to justice, especially for those with relatively few resources to brave the legal system, will leave a lasting imprint on the ACLU's programs in this area. We will miss him, but we will not forget him. Ira Glasser, Exec Dir, American Civil Liberties Union

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell after OPEC's president said he did not see a need for an output cut when the group meets next month. In New York, crude oil for March delivery fell 91 cents, or 3.1 percent, to $28.80 a barrel.

title: WESTFIELD AMERICA TRUST TO BUY REST OF U.S. AFFILIATE
description: Westfield America Trust Ltd. of Australia said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the part of its United States shopping mall affiliate it did not already own for $268 million in cash. The trust will pay $16.25 a share, or $268 million, for the shares in the affiliate, Westfield America Inc., a 12 percent premium to their closing price of $14.45 on Wednesday. It will also assume about $452 million of debt. Westfield America Trust's sole asset is a 57 percent stake in Westfield America Inc. Shares of Westfield America Inc. were at a 16 percent discount to the value of its real estate, according to analysts. Westfield America Inc. owns or has a stake in 39 shopping malls.

title: The Devils Try to Shape Up For Lemieux and Penguins
description: Mario Lemieux has been slowed by a chronic sore back, but Devils Coach Larry Robinson does not care.

title: The Mayor and the Arts, Round 2
description: Like others who have seen the series of photographs now at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is perfectly within his rights as an individual to express his opinion on the depiction of Jesus as a nude black woman. He described the work as ''disgusting,'' ''outrageous'' and ''anti-Catholic.'' Others disagree with his judgment about ''Yo Mama's Last Supper,'' a group of large photos by Renee Cox in a show that officially opens today featuring the works of contemporary black photographers. But as the mayor of New York City, which advertises itself as an arts capital, Mr. Giuliani stepped far out of bounds when he announced plans to create a commission to set decency standards for art museums, such as the Brooklyn Museum, that receive city funds. The City Council speaker, Peter Vallone, said it best yesterday when he argued that no matter how little he or the mayor may think of the photographs, it is not up to the city to play ''culture cop.''

title: Carlos Garaicoa -- 'The Ruins, The Utopia'
description: Bronx Museum of the Arts

title: Collectors See a Flurry Of Folk Art
description: People who collect American folk art, including the Rockefellers, who remain the first family of American folk art, aren't like other collectors. ''We don't collect for the money or the prestige or for the 'wrong' reasons,'' said Peter Brams, a New Jersey jewelry designer and devotee of contemporary art and folk art for 20 years. ''Folk art collectors are simply mad about the work. They are like family. They share expertise. They collect for the sheer joy of it.''

description: HALPERN-Sylvia Maisler. Devoted wife and partner of Simon, caring mother of Seth, loyal sister of Sabina, dutiful child of Thomas and Rose, died February 12, 2001 after 90 difficult years.

title: CANADIAN INFLATION FALLS
description: Canada's annual rate of inflation dipped to 3 percent in January from 3.2 percent in December, mainly because of lower prices for new vehicles and smaller increases for natural gas and heating oil. Although energy prices were 10.4 percent higher than in January 2000, the gain was the smallest in 18 months. Core inflation, excluding energy, was 2.3 percent. The Bank of Canada is expected to ease interest rates next month. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

description: After being beamed up to an alien spaceship, a family pet takes off his dog suit to reveal that he is an alien creature himself. ''What have you learned?'' his leader asks. The creature pauses to think, then responds ''Whassup?'' with his tongue lolling out of his mouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, SAMUEL
description: WALLACH-Samuel. Died February 14, 2001, age 91. Dedicated teacher, courageous activist. Former President of the N.Y. Teacher's Union. Advocate for developmentally disabled children. Loving husband of the late Lottie Tanenbaum, proud father of Joan Scott and Ruth Frankel. Adoring grandfather and great grandfather. Caring brother of Shirley Auerbach, Eli Wallach and the late Sylvia Grant. ''Don't Mourn, Organize.'' Memorial Services this Spring. In lieu of flowers send contributions to the Samuel Wallach Scholarship Fund, Center for Worker Education, CUNY, 99 Hudson Street, NY, New York 10013.

title: Jury Acquits 6 Who Sought Vote For Washington in Congress
description: A Superior Court jury today acquitted six advocates of Congressional voting rights for the District of Columbia who had been charged with disrupting Congress.

title: A Shrine to Power: Is Berlin Ready?
description: Anyone searching for what Christopher Isherwood called ''the flash of that hysteria which flickers always in Berlin'' need look no further than the new federal Chancellery, a colossal building now near completion that sits on the banks of the Spree like a marooned ocean liner.

title: A Dreamer Qualifies For a Drive At Daytona
description: Kenny Wallace lingered atop his conspicuously plain trailer this afternoon in the infield at Daytona International Speedway, but he was all business. He suddenly had congratulatory telephone calls to take and details to sweat, like where to take his driver's suit for dry-cleaning. Soon he scurried through the noisy garages, a man very happy to be in a hurry.

description: For 29 years, the Popular Women's Organization in Barrancabermeja has run soup kitchens, offered programs for children and provided social services to the poor -- work that has little to do with this country's civil conflict.

title: Free-Speech Ruling Voids School District's Harassment Policy
description: In a decision with potentially wide reverberations for school districts, a federal appeals court in Pennsylvania has ruled that a district's anti-harassment policy violated the First Amendment right of free speech.

title: In the Former East Bloc, Abortion Remains Norm
description: FRANKFURT  An entrenched "abortion culture" in Russia and Eastern Europe has outlived the collapse of communism by more than a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEPKOWITZ, SAMUEL, MD
description: SEPKOWITZ-Samuel, MD, age 78, died on February 7, 2001, at his home in Oklahoma City. Born in Wichita Falls, TX, Dr. Sepkowitz attended medical school at the University of Texas, Galveston. He completed his training in pediatrics at Lincoln, Willard Parker, and Bellevue hospitals, each in New York City. After serving as a U.S. Army Captain in Hot Springs, Arkansas, he settled in Oklahoma City and established a pediatric practice that continued until 1999. He was a Clinical Professor of Pediatrics at the University of Oklahoma College of Medicine, where he taught several generations of young physicians, and he contributed numerous reports to the medical literature. He was an avid farmer, reader, Anglophile, and fan of American show tunes. He is survived by his wife, Joanna, of Oklahoma City; five children, Julie, Douglas and Kent, all of New York City, Warren of Charlotte, NC and Sara Rosinsky of Boston; three step-children, Mark, Jonathan, and Susan Harris, and sixteen grandchildren. He learned to pray for rain under the Dust Bowl skies of Texas and is considered by many to have grown the best ear of corn in the state of Oklahoma.

title: No Choice But To Strike
description: Yesterday's air strikes against Iraq were a necessary, if not vital, part of United States strategy in dealing with Iraq and the Persian Gulf. It was not American saber rattling. It was Saddam Hussein who had stepped up Iraqi air defense activity, and who had tried to create a new kind of trap for American and British aircraft. President Bush may have chosen to react with an unambiguous message, but it was Mr. Hussein who provoked the strikes.

title: SABENA SEEKS COST CUTS
description: Unions representing pilots and ground staff met with management of the Belgian airline Sabena yesterday trying to find ways of cutting 52 million euros ($47.5 million) from its labor costs. The cuts have been ordered by the airline's two shareholders, the Belgian government and the Swiss aviation group SAirGroup, who have said they would not rescue the airline from bankruptcy if the cuts are not made. The management board must present the cost-cutting plans to the owners next Friday. Paul Meller

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about fears of mad cow disease that are affecting Spain's bullfighting industry referred incorrectly in some editions to the worth of the meat from the 40,000 bulls slaughtered each year. Sales total $10 million, not $10 billion.

description: Lost Bearings in Israel

title: Lost Bearings in Israel: Some Expectations Defied
description: There was a great blurring of bedrock distinctions here this week, the kind of distinctions that many Israelis have relied on to make sense of their stressful world.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Feb. 9 about the soprano Anja Silja and her appearance in the Janacek opera ''The Makropulos Case'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music misstated the year of the death of Wieland Wagner, her companion and the grandson of Richard Wagner. He died in 1966, not 1967.

title: Freud, Influential Yet Unloved
description: Jared Diamond, a professor of physiology at the U.C.L.A. School of Medicine, argues that only two scientists in the last 200 years can justifiably be called irreplaceable: Freud and Darwin. In an essay in the February issue of Natural History magazine, he tries to explain why Darwin is so revered and Freud so often reviled. Here are excerpts:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAVIN, JOHN J., JR.
description: NAVIN-John J., Jr. The New York Law School community is saddened by the death of John J. Navin, Jr., a member of its Board of Trustees from 1975-1994. Mr. Navin was a wonderful ally of the school during times of great challenges. He was an early supporter of the Second Century Campaign and helped set the pace for others. We will miss his leadership and his friendship. Our condolences to his wife Joan and his children John, III, Cara Moxley and Stacey NavinWeinstein.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS HAS AGREED TO A BUYOUT
description: Vicorp Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by an investor group for $174 million. Vicorp, which is based in Denver, owns and franchises the Bakers Square and Village Inn family-style restaurants. It announced the acquisition late Thursday and yesterday its stock rose $6.13, or 33 percent, to $24.63. Vicorp said it would be acquired for $25.65 a share in cash. The investor group includes BancBoston Capital, the private equity investment arm of the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, and Goldner Hawn Johnson & Morrison Inc., an investment firm based in Minneapolis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, RICHARD C.
description: CLARK-Richard C. The Lincoln Hall Board of Managers notes with deep regret the passing of Richard C. Clark who faithfully served on the Board from 1983 to 1991. Mr. Clark served as Chairman of the Audit and Insurance Committee and was a member of the Buildings and Grounds Committee. The Board extends sincere condolences to the family of Mr. Clark. James G. Nugent, President Douglas W. Wyatt, Vice President And The Lincoln Hall Board of Managers

title: VOLVO PLANS TO CUT 400 MORE JOBS IN NORTH AMERICA
description: Volvo, the heavy-truck maker, said yesterday that it planned to cut 400 more jobs from North American truck operations and reduce production again as it reported that January sales fell 20 percent. Volvo sold 1,244 units in North America in January, down from 1,552 in the period a year earlier. Volvo cut 1,000 temporary workers in North America and scaled back production in the first half of 2000. It cut production three times in 2000 as North American demand fell.

title: Again: The Mayor And the Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: A Composer For Movies, Finally Heard On His Own
description: In 1941, his first year as a composer for Hollywood films, Bernard Herrmann wrote the brilliant music for ''Citizen Kane.'' By 1960, with his amazing score for ''Psycho,'' he must have known that he was stuck in the field, that he would probably die a film composer, which is exactly what happened: Herrmann had just finished the recording of ''Taxi Driver'' when he died in Los Angeles in 1975 at age 64.

title: Buzzing Through Idioms With a Growl and a Click
description: You generally don't go to jazz clubs to hear breadth of style. Usually what you get is a narrowly focused view of a bandleader's direction, a chunk of a discourse. Dave Douglas's new quintet, at the Village Vanguard this week, breaks that mold. The music leaps around freely between jazz idioms and draws energy from them, so much that the music kept threatening to explode.

title: Lawyer Tries to Discredit Key Witness in Case Against Rapper
description: A defense lawyer yesterday tried to discredit the testimony of a key witness in the bribery and gun possession case against the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs, but the witness, a limousine driver, gave little ground.

title: CREDIT SUISSE SELLS UNIT
description: The Credit Suisse Group, a leading European financial services company, said it would sell an international property and casualty insurance unit that serves large businesses to XL Capital Ltd. of Bermuda for $600 million and that it would use the proceeds to bolster its European business. The unit, Winterthur International, has annual premiums of 2.3 billion Swiss francs ($1.4 billion) and 1,300 employees, Credit Suisse said. Credit Suisse will retain the rest of the unit, including Winterthur Insurance, and will try to enlarge its nonlife business with private clients as well as companies.

title: In Self-Storage Units, Art Market Thrives; For African Dealers, a Place to Trade
description: The Chelsea Mini-Storage, a grimy, seven-story brick building with a loading dock at 615 West 27th Street, may well be the nation's largest transit point for wholesale African art.

title: Sports of The Times; Years Later, A Statement Still Has Bite
description: WHENEVER the Nets and Knicks have played in the last couple of seasons, there is this sense of a game being played in the wilderness: the Nets are going nowhere, again, and who knows where the Knicks are going.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: U.S. Diplomats Turned Aside Israeli Push on Rich's Behalf
description: Senior diplomats in the Clinton administration initially blocked Israeli lobbying efforts on behalf of the fugitive Marc Rich but were bypassed in the final decision-making when the president granted Mr. Rich a pardon on his last day in office, current and former United States officials said.

title: Inflation at Wholesale Level Up a Steep 1.1% in January
description: Prices paid to manufacturers and other producers for their goods climbed 1.1 percent in January in the steepest monthly gain in more than a decade, the government reported today.

title: Newest Mets Playing Getting to Know You
description: They wandered in throughout the day, some with foreign equipment bags and slightly bewildered expressions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Who Chose Clinton To Give Speech Quits Firm
description: The Morgan Stanley Dean Witter executive who selected former President Bill Clinton to give a speech that later set off a controversy said yesterday that he had resigned.

title: Article 2001021792744682653 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: AGUILERA IS RETIRING
description: Rick Aguilera, who is eighth among relief pitchers with 318 career saves, is retiring after 16 major league seasons, his agent, Tom Selakovich, said.

title: To Keep the Estate Tax, or Kill It?
description: To the Editor:

title: City Administrators Assume Supervision of Bronx Science
description: Two weeks after the Bronx High School of Science lost a cherished candidate for principal to the suburbs, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has taken the prestigious appointment out of the hands of the superintendent for Bronx high schools.

title: U.S. AND BRITISH JETS STRIKE AIR-DEFENSE CENTERS IN IRAQ
description: The United States and Britain staged air strikes against radar stations and air defense command centers in Iraq today, including targets around Baghdad, in what President Bush called a necessary response to Iraqi provocation.

title: Another Falun Gong Member Reportedly Burns Himself in China
description: Another member of the banned Falun Gong spiritual group committed suicide by setting himself on fire today, according to Chinese state media. It was the second time in less than a month that group members were reported to have resorted to self-immolation to bring attention to their cause.

title: DURACELL REDESIGNS ITS MAIN LINE OF BATTERIES
description: The Gillette Company's Duracell unit, the nation's leading battery maker, said yesterday that it had redesigned its main line of batteries for the first time in nine years to try to reverse declining sales with a longer-lasting product. Gillette just started selling the new line, called Duracell Plus, in Europe, and sales in the United States will begin by June, a spokeswoman, Ann Davin, said. Though Duracell regularly makes small improvements, the more powerful Duracell Plus is the first overhaul since 1992, when mercury was eliminated, Ms. Davin said. Gillette's profit the last two years has been hurt by lower-than-expected sales of Duracell batteries, Braun appliances and toiletries.

title: Article 2001021793217805290 -- No Title
description: Teenagers Try Online Learning

title: Again: The Mayor And the Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADA AND BRAZIL DISPUTE SUBSIDIES
description: The World Trade Organization agreed to examine Canada's challenge to Brazil's Proex export-subsidies program to the aircraft manufacturer Embraer. Earlier rulings at the W.T.O, based in Geneva, went against Brazil, which has said that its program complies with world trade rules. Canada, however, has asked for a panel of experts to investigate compliance. In a sharp exchange, Brazil suggested that Canada's recent ban on its beef imports was linked to the five-year-old aircraft-subsidies dispute. Canada denied the accusation. Elizabeth Olson

title: Again: The Mayor And the Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Confidence Is Wild Card in the Nation's Economy
description: American consumers, shaken by a rash of layoff announcements and a weakening stock market, are losing confidence in the economy at the fastest pace since the last recession.

title: Memorial for Verdon
description: Broadway colleagues will speak and perform at a tribute to the dancer Gwen Verdon on Tuesday at 11 a.m. at the Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street, Manhattan. Ms. Verdon died in October at 75.

title: Ad Campaign To Recruit Teachers Draws Fire
description: The president of the union representing New York City teachers criticized Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy yesterday for spending $8 million on an advertising campaign to recruit new classroom teachers, saying that he should first use the money for generous raises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANAHAN, ANNE ROSE (NEE BURKE)
description: SHANAHAN-Anne Rose (nee Burke). Beloved wife of the late Thomas J. Shanahan. Loving mother of Anne, Clare Shanahan Lynch, Thomas J. Shanahan, Jr., James J. Shanahan and Ellen Shanahan Cosman. Dear motherin-law of Edward F. Lynch, Sarina and Alice; sweet grandmother to Anne Lynch Kaufman, Clare Lynch Shannon, Edward T. Lynch, Thomas J. Lynch, Robert Lynch, Christin Shanahan Brecher, Mark T. Shanahan, Anne Rita Shanahan, James J. Shanahan, Jr., Kevin Shanahan, Gregory Shanahan, Sarah Anne Cosman, Clare Cosman and fifteen great-grandchildren. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 St., Friday 7:00-9:00 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89 St., Saturday 11:00 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SASSOWER, REBECCA
description: SASSOWER-Rebecca. The Birch Wathen Lenox School mourns the loss of Rebecca Sassower, mother of our Board Chairman, Philip Sassower, and grandmother of three Birch alumni, Mark Sassower, Caroline Sassower Sack and Robert Sassower. We share in the family's bereavement and will remember Mrs. Sassower in our prayers. Frank J. Carnabuci Headmaster The Birch Wathen Lenox School New York City

title: Amid Strong Debate, Mild Curiosity at the Exhibition
description: At the entrance of ''Committed to the Image,'' a new photography exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, a makeshift altar of roses, lilies and tulips appeared yesterday. They were in memory of Mfon Essien, a Nigerian-born photographer whose naked self-portraits taken after she had a mastectomy are among 188 photographs by black photographers in the exhibition. Ms. Essien, 35, died of cancer on Tuesday.

title: To Keep the Estate Tax, or Kill It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBB, VANCE T.
description: WEBB-Vance T. A New York Times employee killed on February 11, 2001. He is survived by his loving wife Leora and son, Martin Vance. Wake will be on Monday, February 19, 5-8PM at Miles Funeral Home, 136 Decatur Street, Brooklyn, Between Throop and Sumner Avenue. Services, on Tuesday, February 20, 10AM at Concord Baptist Church of Christ, 833 Gardner Taylor Boulevard, between Madison and Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn. Interment will follow at the Veteran's Cemetery, Calverton, Long Island.

title: LLOYDS PROFIT GROWS
description: Lloyds TSB Group said pretax profit increased 7 percent last year to 3.62 billion ($5.24 billion). The results were driven by strong operating profit from insurance and investments that offset slower growth in retail banking and a decline in mortgages, placing renewed pressure on Lloyds to secure a deal with Abbey National, the British mortgage lender, to revive growth in those areas. Abbey National has spurned Lloyds's advances in favor of a deal with its preferred partner, the Bank of Scotland, a combination that has already been approved by British regulators. Officials are expected to rule on Lloyds's offer for Abbey National by next Friday. Suzanne Kapner

title: Excerpt From Speech On New SAT Policy
description: Following is an excerpt from remarks by Richard C. Atkinson, president of the University of California, prepared for delivery on Sunday at the annual meeting of the American Council on Education in Washington:

description: GOLDENBERG-Laura. Beloved mother of Michael, Gene and Hazzan Devin Goldenberg, Karen Shapiro and Idy Lanier. Cherished grandmother of Cara, Alex, David, Emily, Seth and Joshua Goldenberg, Elena and Max Shapiro, Daniel and Alison Lanier. Dear sister of William Whitehorn. Service Sunday, 1:00 PM, Temple Israel Center of White Plains, 280 Old Mamaroneck Rd., White Plains, N.Y. 10605. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisades Ave., Bronx, NY 10471 or Temple Israel Center of White Plains.

title: In Spy Hunt, Peru Wants U.S. to Make A Better Effort
description: The Peruvian government called on the Bush administration today to step up its efforts to apprehend Vladimiro Montesinos, the fugitive former Peruvian spy chief, who has long ties to the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Lemieux Effect on the Penguins Takes Hold
description: In the Pittsburgh dressing room after morning practice yesterday, Mario Lemieux crossed the floor wearing only a big, blue pack on his aching back. One level above, in the lobby of Continental Arena, a box-office worker reported a Devils rarity: only scattered singles remained for the game between the Stanley Cup champion Devils and the visiting Penguins.

title: 'Yo Mama' Artist's Past as Superhero
description: Until the current fuss, Rene Cox, the 43-year-old artist of ''Yo Mama's Last Supper,'' occupied a modest spot in the art world a notch below Andres Serrano's position before he was catapulted to fame in a similar fiasco.

title: Senate Democrats Stall Bankruptcy Bill
description: Democrats have blocked a Republican effort to rush through the Senate a bill that would overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system and make it far more difficult for people to wipe out their debts. The action was an early test of their influence in a Senate split 50-50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILNE, JAMES TONER, SR.
description: MILNE-James Toner, Sr. February 15, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted and loving father of Marcia and her husband Edward Kloos, James T. Milne Jr. and his wife Judith, Mark Milne and his wife Claire and Christopher Milne and his wife Deborah. Cherished grandfather of Gregory, Rebekah, Owen, Gavin, Curran, Heather, Vanessa, Andrew and James. Loving brother of John and the late Jerome. A paratrooper of the 101st Airborne Division ''Screaming Eagles'' who served in the liberation of Holland and the invasion of Normandy. A prisoner of war and recipient of both the Silver Star and the Purple Heart. In his later years he served as a member of many executive boards in the tri-state area. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, February 19, 2001, 10:30AM at St. Joseph's Church, East 87th Street (between York and 1st Avenue). Contributions in his memory may be made to Catholic Charities.

title: Dreary Reports On Layoffs And Earnings Afflict Markets
description: Investors were served up another unappetizing plate of earnings and economic news yesterday and left the table in a hurry.

description: SHEA-Robert S. The Veteran Corps of Artillery, State of New York records with sorrow the passing of our friend and comrade Colonel Robert S. Shea on February 15, 2001. MG John E. Connelly, III Commandant

title: Deal Allows Clinton to Lease Space He Wants in Harlem
description: After three days of dangling the keys to the penthouse in front of Bill Clinton, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani finally handed them over yesterday when he announced a deal that makes it possible for the former president to move his offices to a building in Harlem.

title: Sub Incident Erodes Trust in Japan Chief and the U.S.
description: TOKYO, Feb. 17  Tempers have flared with the news that civilian visitors were at the controls of the nuclear submarine that caused a Japanese boat to sink last week off Hawaii, leaving nine people missing and presumed dead.

description: EUROPE

title: U.S. Is Set to Assail China on Rights at U.N.
description: In its first major policy decision regarding China, the Bush administration plans to sponsor a United Nations resolution next month condemning Beijing's record on human rights, officials said today. But it was unclear how vigorously it would seek the international support necessary to make the resolution a diplomatic success.

title: Surfing in the Sewage
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 7 about Norbert V. Osterland, a former business executive, misidentified the company of which he was president from 1974 to 1977. It was S&H Green Stamps, not Sperry & Hutchinson, the parent company.

title: Evolving Passion, of All Kinds
description: ''Passion,'' a mixed-media New Age ''Fantasia'' by Moses Pendleton, stands up remarkably well 10 years after its premiere. It has all the unfettered imagination and irreverence that made Mr. Pendleton so distinctive as co-founder of Pilobolus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANO, EMANUEL T.

In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Sunday and Monday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday 10AM St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Again: The Mayor And the Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STARBASE CORP., Santa Ana, Calif., a developer of Internet software, said it would acquire Technology Builders Inc., Atlanta, a software provider, for about $36.9 million in stock. Earlier this week, the company also said that it would buy Worldweb.net Inc. for $26 million in stock and cash.

title: Traces of Plutonium Found in NATO Arms
description: GENEVA  Two laboratories have confirmed finding "very low" traces of plutonium in rounds of depleted uranium weapons fired by NATO warplanes over Kosovo two years ago, the UN environment agency said Friday.

title: A Champion Who Continues to Not Give Up
description: The wrestler Rulon Gardner, in his first Olympics, was waiting to meet Aleksandr Karelin of Russia for a gold medal in Sydney last September, but he already knew about the move.

title: SAMSUNG SHRINKS BOARD
description: The Samsung Electronics Company said it would reduce its board by one-third, cutting the number of members to 14 from 21 and including as many as 7 from outside the Samsung group. The company said it was reducing the size of the board to accelerate decision-making by directors and in response to claims by foreign shareholders' that a large board was inefficient. Don Kirk

title: Nextel Says Spending May Hurt Results
description: Nextel Communications Inc., the wireless telephone company, said today that higher spending may hurt first-quarter results, and its stock fell 14 percent.

title: Motive Is Everything in the Marc Rich Pardon
description: Bill Clinton may have had good reasons to pardon Marc Rich and ignore customary pardon procedures. Maybe Mr. Clinton decided that Mr. Rich, the fugitive financier, was innocent or that he was the victim of an overzealous Reagan Justice Department. Or maybe he just wanted to do a favor for Jack Quinn, Mr. Rich's lawyer, who coincidentally was once White House counsel, too.

title: Terrorism on Another Continent Takes Its Toll on a Small Oregon City
description: It has been more than four months now, and Gold Hill is still waiting for some good news from Ecuador.

title: Yanks and Rivera Agree on $39.99 Million Deal
description: Now that closer Mariano Rivera has agreed to a multiyear deal, the Yankees can make a rare claim in the era of free agency: roster stability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, ALVIN L. JR.
description: MOSS-Alvin L. Jr., 88, died on February 16, 2001. Beloved husband of Rose K. Moss. Cherished father of Mark Chanko. Adored grandfather of David, Kenneth, Todd, Rick and Pamela. Proud greatgrandfather of Daniel, Ariel, Nora, Nicky, Samantha, Gillian & Sasha.

description: New York University defeated Case Western Reserve University, 86-58, in a University Athletic Association game last night at the Coles Sports Center.

title: Andrew Cuomo Joins Law Practice in New York
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, the United States secretary of housing and urban development under President Bill Clinton, said yesterday that he had joined the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Newsday's strategy in New York City referred incorrectly to the ranking of its affilate WPIX-TV in the local television market. According to Nielsen ratings, the rank is third, not fifth, for the full day. For overall news audiences, the rank is fifth of six stations.

title: Rose Freedman, Last Survivor of Triangle Fire, Dies at 107
description: Rose Freedman, the last survivor of the Triangle Shirtwaist fire in which 146 of her co-workers perished in 1911, died on Thursday in her apartment in Beverly Hills, Calif., her daughter said. She was 107.

description: Henry B. Schacht, the chief executive of Lucent Technologies, made personal pleas with bankers during negotiations yesterday in an effort to secure $6.5 billion in financing, people close to the talks said.

description: EURO RISES. The dollar fell after reports showed a drop in United States consumer confidence and faster inflation in January. In New York, the euro settled at 91.40 cents, up from 90.42 on Thursday.

title: Specter of Armed Attack at School Shakes Elmira
description: He helped other students with their homework and waved politely to his neighbors, but there was still something about Jeremy Getman that unsettled more than a few of them.

title: Van Horn Falls Flat In Bid to End Slump
description: Keith Van Horn heard the piercing whistles all night. He kept shaking his head in disbelief and shuffling helplessly to the bench, head down, muttering in frustration.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about fears of mad cow disease that are affecting Spain's bullfighting industry referred incorrectly in some editions to the worth of the meat from the 40,000 bulls slaughtered each year. Sales total $10 million, not $10 billion.

title: Civilian Says Submarine Took Precautions
description: A Texas oilman who was aboard the submarine Greeneville said yesterday that its officers made six sweeps with the periscope at two slightly different depths but saw no other ships less than 10 minutes before it surfaced and slammed into a Japanese fishing trawler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ESTHER MAYER
description: GREEN-Esther Mayer. Died peacefully at home on February 15, 2001. Loving wife of Hubert, devoted mother of Robert and Nancy, and grandmother of Jonathan, Elizabeth, Andrew and Adam. Caring mother-in-law of Jane Green and Jerome Katz. A dedicated professional social worker. Memorial service to be held on Sunday, February 18, at 11:00 AM at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, 516-487-9600. Contributions may be sent to Carcinoid Foundation, 1751 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

title: Police Arrest Suspect In Killing of 2 in '96
description: The police said today that they had solved a double killing that rocked the quiet town of Eastchester, N.Y., four years ago, when a 79-year-old man and his home health aide were stabbed and bludgeoned to death in his elegant house.

title: Devils Get a Tie on Late Goal But Their Injured List Grows
description: Before tonight's ragged but entertaining 4-4 tie between two good teams at Continental Arena, one great French-Canadian star discussed another. It was Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh center, talking about Martin Brodeur, the Devils' goalie. ''I always like to play against him,'' Lemieux said of Brodeur. ''Obviously, he's one of the top goalies in the world. I like the challenge.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCREARY, RUTH CHANDLER
description: McCREARY-Ruth Chandler. Born March 23, 1921. Died February 14, 2001, Hanover, NH. Accomplished artist/watercolorist. Sadly missed by family and friends. A memorial service will be conducted at Kendal at Hanover, Hanover, NH, at a time to be determined. Contributions to The Cadbury Fund, Kendal at Hanover, 80 Lyme Road, Hanover, NH 03755 or The Union of Concerned Scientists, 2 Brattle Square, Cambridge, MA 02238-9105 would be appreciated.

title: Singing Labor's Song to Immigrants, Legal or Not
description: AS organized labor's chief advocate for immigrant workers, Linda Chavez-Thompson often harks back to her grueling childhood in West Texas, where her Mexican-American father was a $30-a-week farmhand.

title: Judge Extends Legal Rights Beyond U.S.
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled that foreign suspects who are interrogated abroad by American law enforcement officials are entitled to the same Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination as suspects who are questioned in the United States.

title: A Ruff West Couldn't Refuse Lets South Make His Game
description: Distance to be traveled does not discourage top players in search of action. Experts taking part in the annual NEC team tournament, which ended Sunday in Yokohama, Japan, came from Argentina, Australia, Austria, England, Indonesia, Poland, Sweden, Taiwan and the United States.

title: The World Stage, Act I
description: On the first four days of what President Bush designated ''national security week,'' he promised troops in Georgia a pay raise, visited a NATO outpost to describe his long-range plans for the military and went to West Virginia to sympathize with the troubles facing reservists -- all visits intended to show how seriously he took and understood his role as commander in chief.

description: In religious traditions, symbols play a powerful role, identifying for people elements that lie at the heart of their faith. To illustrate, one can cite some very obvious examples, like the cross for Christians and Jerusalem's Western Wall for Jews.

description: The Daewoo Motor Company sent dismissal notices to 1,750 employees today, beginning a long-threatened downsizing.

description: LEIKIND-Sally, 90. On February 16, 2001, in Boca Raton, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Leikind. Loving and devoted mother of Honey and Seymour. Adored mother-in-law to Mike and Simone. Admired sister to Beatrice and brother-in-law, Phil. Cherished and esteemed grandmother of Jeffrey, Ellen, Andrew, Bonnie and Sharon. Great-grandmother of Stewart, Samantha, Hannah, Jared, Casey and Kylie. We will love and miss her dearly, her devotion, spirit and leadership.

title: A Calmer Way of Moving Around This Universe
description: Mo-Trans Dancing presented seven dances that seriously addressed well-conceived themes in a program presented Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. The performers are skillful and charming, with a nice diversity in size and age. Clearly a good deal of thought and taste has gone into the creation of this eight-year-old troupe, which is also known as the Montana Transport Co. and is based at the University of Montana in Missoula.
