description: WAYNE - Gloria (Lebowitz). Passed away at Boca Raton, Florida on February 15, 2001. Loving wife. Dear mother of Judge Jeffrey D. and Richard, sister of Robert, grandmother of Shana, Alexa, Jay and James. Services Sunday 9:30AM at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: A Property Rights Case Tests Wetland Curbs
description: In a little over a week, Anthony Palazzolo a former auto wrecker, 80-year-old father of six and the kind of outspoken, tenacious guy a lot of people around here call a character -- is finally getting his day in the big court. And depending on how the United States Supreme Court rules, experts say, Mr. Palazzolo could enter the pantheon of plaintiffs whose cases have changed property rights law in America.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KENNER, MORTON
description: KENNER-Morton. February 17, 1999. Loving you and missing you. Love, Edyth

title: A French Troupe Tests Baroque's Boundaries
description: Human passions adapt to their surroundings. How else do we so easily recognize the intensities and ardors of ''Acton,'' product of a culture and a sensibility so far from ours? Charpentier was writing for a French Baroque stage at the end of the 17th century, an art tempered by a rigid decorum and almost ritual allegiance to classical mythology.

title: Hartford Museum Chooses a Novel Architect
description: Following its tradition of recruiting innovators, the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford has selected relatively unknown experimental architects from the Netherlands for an expansion and renovation of the institution, the oldest public art museum in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNTING, JAMES
description: BUNTING-James. Of Westport, CT. Former engineer with Farrand Controls, Valhalla, NY. Father of Mary Karr; William, Robert, John and Charles Bunting. Predeceased by two wives, Michaela Bunting and Martha Wollman Bunting. Memorial Services, Sunday, 2 PM, Saugatuck Congregational Church, Westport.

title: Long Island Utility Will Seek Surcharge to Cover Fuel Costs
description: The chairman of the Long Island Power Authority called today for a temporary 5.8 percent surcharge on the electric bills of its 1.06 million customers to help offset the rising costs of oil and natural gas.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Freddy Wittop, a costume designer whose work was sometimes compared to that of Cecil Beaton, misstated the Broadway opening year for ''My Fair Lady,'' a musical costumed by Beaton. It was 1956, not 1957.

title: In the President's Words on the Bombing: 'It's a Routine Mission'
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference with President Bush and President Vicente Fox of Mexico, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. Mr. Fox spoke in Spanish, and an interpreter translated.

title: RATE CUT IN INDIA
description: India's central bank said it had cut the interest rate that it charges banks by half a percentage point, to 7.5 percent, citing recent developments in the international and local financial markets. The central bank said it also reduced the proportion of deposits that banks must keep as cash with the central bank to 8 percent from 8.5 percent.

title: Rookie Starts at Summit, Daytona
description: Jason Leffler was back in his car bright and early this morning, trying to coax a little more speed out of his black Dodge. His next Nascar Winston Cup race will also be his first, but Leffler was not thinking much about the immensity of the task ahead. He had no time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IRENE (NEE LIBERMAN)
description: COHEN-Irene (nee Liberman). The nephew and niece of the much beloved and admired Irene Cohen, Barnet and Phyllis Liberman and her grand-nieces and nephew, Ava, Zoe, Stella, Leah and Aaron, are saddened by her loss. Her bold and joyful spirit touched and changed everyone's life, and she was an inspiration to us all. Our sympathy and love to her husband Aaron and her daughter Barbara.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL CLIMBS. Crude oil rose on speculation that Saudi Arabia will support a pricing plan for OPEC oil that would encourage an output cut. In New York, crude oil for March delivery rose 36 cents, to $29.16 a barrel.

title: Air Strikes in Iraq
description: The first American military operation authorized by George W. Bush unfolded yesterday in the skies near Baghdad, the same arena where his father's last actions as commander in chief took place eight years ago. Yesterday's attack by two dozen American and British warplanes on five air defense installations near the Iraqi capital was justified as a response to intensified targeting of allied planes patrolling the ''no-flight'' zone over southern Iraq.

title: In Japan, Waiting for the Captain to Appear
description: Before I began writing this piece, I asked a friend of mine in the United States to send me information about how the collision between an American submarine and a training ship chartered by a Japanese high school was being reported. Based on what my friend sent, I have to admit to a strange feeling. I noticed references to the collision as occurring ''off Pearl Harbor.'' In Japan, the news media described the site as ''off Hawaii.''

title: Truly Honest Abe
description: To the Editor:

title: Poof! You're a Skeptic: The Amazing Randi's Vanishing Humbug
description: James Randi was standing at the front of Florida Atlantic University's sloping auditorium here before his lecture when a couple walked over to ask for an autograph. In turn, he had a favor to ask. Would they run down the street to the Eckerd drugstore and buy him a box of sleeping pills? He gave the man $5 and a slip of paper on which he'd drawn a picture of the box.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Conrad Bagne, an officer of Alaska Native Wireless, with an article on Monday about the federal auction of airwave frequencies, carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Al Grillo (not Grill), for The New York Times.

title: By the Book: Individuality Vs. Franchising; Trading Spark of Creativity For the Safety of Numbers
description: Stephen Gurwitz is proud that his Hilltop Farms convenience store has long been a fixture here in this small town on the Rhode Island border.

title: K.A. Muhammad, Ex-Official of Nation of Islam, Dies at 53
description: Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the former Nation of Islam official who was seen as a leader of the next generation of radical civil rights leaders by some and as a racist hatemonger by others, died yesterday in a hospital in Marietta, Ga., a suburb of Atlanta. He was 53.

title: Harlem Hopes Move Spurs a Revival
description: When the 15-story C.A.V. Building on 125th Street near Lenox Avenue opened in 1973, 600 people went to a dinner marking the occasion. The developer, Charles A. Vincent, predicted that the speckled-brown-brick and glass structure -- said to be the largest office tower in the nation built and owned by blacks -- would spur a commercial revival in Harlem.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE APPROVES SOTHEBY'S SETTLEMENT
description: A federal judge gave final approval yesterday to a $70 million class action settlement between Sotheby's and shareholders who sued the auction house claiming that antitrust violations still under federal investigation damaged the company and depressed its stock price. The judge, Denise Cote of the Southern District of New York, approved the agreement, which awards shareholders $30 million in cash, paid by A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's former chairman and controlling shareholder, and $40 million in company-issued Class A stock. The settlement will become final in 30 days if no appeal is filed. Judge Cote also reduced the fee of the plaintiff's lawyer, Berger & Montague of Philadelphia, to $1.25 million, from $10.5 million. Ralph Blumenthal

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, EDWARD M.
description: SIMMONS-Edward M. On February 15th at age 96. Beloved husband of Marjorie Michaels. Loving father of Wendy and Lynn Simmons, Nancy Steiger (Norman) and Marion Benedek. Beloved grandfather of Deborah Schnur (Daniel), Elizabeth Newman (Steven), Sue Ellen Gerber (Steven), Michael Benedek (Karen), and Elizabeth Kaye (Alan). Adored great grandfather of nine. Services February 18th at The Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey, at 1 P.M.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Jarrett Gets Help in Victory
description: Dale Jarrett won the first International Race of Champions race of the season today, but not without a generous and unpopular nudge from Eddie Cheever Jr.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Saddam Hussein has got to understand that we expect him to conform to the agreement that he signed after Desert Storm.''

title: Germany Examines Perjury Allegations Against Foreign Minister
description: State prosecutors have begun an investigation into whether Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer committed perjury in testimony last month at the murder trial of a former revolutionary comrade from the 1970's.

title: EM.TV CHAIRMAN QUITS
description: The chairman of the supervisory board of EM.TV and Merchandising, the struggling German media company that owns the rights to the Muppets, resigned over a rescue deal with the Kirch Group, also a German media company. The EM.TV chairman, Nickolaus Becker, is the third executive to leave the company recently. His departure leaves it up to Thomas Haffa, the founder and chief executive of EM.TV, to dig the company out from under a mountain of debt. In its deal with Kirch, signed Thursday, EM.TV will get $550 million and give up 16 percent of its equity, 25 percent of its voting rights and half of its 50 percent stake in the Formula One racing organization. Mr. Becker had been exploring alternative offers.

title: For an Ex-President in New York, No Hair Shirt Required
description: Relax, Mr. Former President. It seems a lot of people in New York are willing to let things slide. Yet again.

title: Navy Stonewalling
description: More than a week after an American nuclear attack submarine accidentally sank a Japanese fishing boat near Hawaii, the Navy is still suppressing information about the incident. That is a misguided strategy that ill serves the American people and the Navy itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZER, KATHRYN
description: SALTZER-Kathryn. On February 16, 2001 after a long illness. Loving wife of the late Daniel M. Saltzer. Dear mother of Joseph. Beloved grandmother of Rebecca W. and Amanda A. Saltzer.

title: Article 2001021790146249085 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Bomb Kills 7 Serbs In Kosovo Convoy Guarded by NATO
description: Seven Serbs were killed and more than 40 were injured today when a roadside bomb blew apart their bus in northeastern Kosovo in one of the boldest and bloodiest attacks NATO troops have seen in 20 months of peacekeeping.

title: Mysteries of the Genes
description: The Kansas State Board of Education came to its senses this week and officially voted to restore evolution to the state science standards as an explanation of the origin of species. It was not a moment too soon. Just days earlier, two rival scientific teams had unveiled their first interpretations of the human genome, the set of genetic instructions that specify how humans are made. One of the most interesting findings was how closely the human genome correlates with the genomes of other creatures, not just the apes whose kinship with humans seems to appall many creationists, but mice and even lowly bacteria as well.

title: Office Deal for Clinton
description: Mayor Giuliani agreed to release the city's claim on office space that the former president wants to rent on the top floor of a building in Harlem. Article, Page B6.

title: Conflict in Forest Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman has disqualified herself from acting on a conservation plan for the Sierra Nevada in California because she once did legal work for a coalition that opposes the proposal.

title: Article 2001021793697588474 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Ousted Loft Residents Allowed to Return
description: Seven weeks after city officials ousted about 60 people from illegally converted lofts in a Brooklyn factory building because of fire safety hazards, most of the residents were allowed to return yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Democrats Block Attempt To Rush a Bankruptcy Bill

title: Compassionate Fashion
description: To the Editor:

title: Reward for Faithful Service
description: In his four decades as a Roman Catholic theologian, the Rev. Avery Dulles has served as an adviser to Vatican officials and American bishops and was a leading figure in forging the momentous declaration of understanding between Catholics and Lutherans in 1999.

title: Head of U. of California Seeks To End SAT Use in Admissions
description: Contending that standardized college tests have distorted the way young people learn and worsened educational inequities, the president of the University of California is proposing an end to the use of SAT's as a requirement for admission to the state university system he oversees, one of the largest and most prestigious.

title: Census Power Is Returned To Secretary Of Commerce
description: The Bush administration today transferred the power to adjust population figures produced by the 2000 Census to the secretary of commerce from the Census Bureau, setting up what was bound to be an intense legal and political fight.

title: Talks Are Under Way for Big European Steel Merger
description: Usinor, the giant French steel manufacturer, said today that it was in talks to merge with two European rivals, Arbed of Luxembourg and Aceralia Corporacin Siderrgica of Spain. The deal would create the world's largest steel maker.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERBER, STEVEN
description: FERBER-Steven. 2/17/61-9/27/97 Happy 40th Birthday. We love you and miss you. Mom, family and friends

title: Pardon Puts New Spotlight On a Clinton Fund-Raiser
description: Until recently, Beth Dozoretz seemed to be in a competition with her fellow Clinton friend and fund-raiser Terry McAuliffe over who deserved the greater share of credit for bringing in serial donations from Denise Rich, two senior party officials said.

title: BUSH GIVES MEXICO BACKING  ON  DRIVE AGAINST NARCOTICS
description: Acknowledging that Americans' demand feeds drug traffic, President Bush signaled today that he would support Mexico in its efforts to end the annual ritual in which Congress requires the Mexican government to prove its commitment to the war against narcotics or face economic sanctions.

title: Plan to Stabilize Utilities Is Outlined in California
description: Gov. Gray Davis sketched the broad outlines today of a multibillion-dollar plan to stabilize California's nearly bankrupt electric utilities by buying their transmission lines and letting the utilities set aside part of consumers' monthly payments to finance bonds to pay the rest of their debts.

title: Cuttings: Where Hotbeds Get a Jump
description: WEST NYACK, N.Y.  People sort of stumble on Bumps & Company, the little nursery that takes its name from the nickname for Gertrude Jekyll, the prickly Victorian gardener. Even if you're looking for the little sign, "Honey for Sale," you're likely to miss it.

title: Sky Watch: Advance Notice
description: Many readers of this weekly column might have wished at one time or another to have more than just a week's notice on some upcoming celestial event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURAK, BETTE
description: BURAK-Bette. The Partners of Rosenman & Colin LLP express their sincere condolences to the family and friends of Bette Burak, mother of our partner and colleague, H. Paul Burak. May you find comfort in her memory and the love and times she shared with you.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about governors' clemency decisions misstated the action taken by Gov. Gray Davis of California in the case of a battered woman who had killed a former boyfriend. The governor approved, with additional restrictions, a state board's decision to grant parole. The action allowed her release after her minimum sentence of 15 years. Mr. Davis did not give her a pardon, which would have restored her political and civil rights.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Will Oppose Some Limits In Finance Bill
description: For the first time in years, the A.F.L.-C.I.O has entered the Congressional debate over political fund-raising, opposing several provisions of bipartisan legislation to overhaul the campaign finance system.

title: COVAD COMMUNICATIONS TO CLOSE 60 MORE OFFICES
description: The Covad Communications Group, a provider of fast Internet service over telephone lines, said yesterday that it would shut 60 more offices as it reviewed its accounts. Covad shares fell 88 cents, or 31 percent, to $2, before trading was halted yesterday morning by the Nasdaq. The exchange said trading would not resume until the company provided more information. Covad sales for 2000 may not reach its expectations because Internet providers, some of which have filed for bankruptcy, cannot pay their bills, said a spokeswoman, Martha Sessums. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., may take additional actions to further trim expenses. It expects to have a charge for the cost cuts larger than the $20 million it had expected.

title: 'Head Start' History
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Candidates At the Walls Of Academe
description: THE mini-movement to get Bill Clinton to run for mayor seems to have lost all its steam, not that it had much to begin with. Can't imagine why, begging his pardon.

title: Benitez Is Hoping Fans Will Move On
description: On the day he reported to spring training last year, Armando Benitez and his agent, Mike Powers, held a news conference to announce the signing of a four-year, $22 million contract. For Benitez, it was a joyous day.

title: Internet Company Pleads Guilty to Enabling Others to Distribute Child Pornography
description: An Internet service provider has pleaded guilty to enabling others to transmit child pornography in a case that the New York attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, characterized as a breakthrough.

title: Selig Asked to Intervene In Wells-Sirotka Trade
description: The controversial trade involving David Wells and Mike Sirotka officially landed in the lap of Commissioner Bud Selig yesterday. The Toronto Blue Jays, who traded Wells to the Chicago White Sox on Jan. 14, asked Selig to look into the circumstances in which they received Sirotka, only to learn that he had an injured left shoulder that could force him to miss part or all of the coming season.

title: EBOLA'S NEMESIS
description: When an outbreak of the deadly disease threatened to overwhelm a northern Ugandan hospital last year and spread far beyond its walls, there was only one man to call: Matthew Lu kwiya, a local doctor who combined low-key geniality and a devotion to his work that bordered on recklessness. A report by Blaine Harden in The Times Magazine.

title: Donald C. Peirce -- Curator, 52
description: Donald C. Peirce, a specialist in American decorative art and a curator at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta, died on Feb. 5 at his home in Atlanta. He was 52.

title: Critic's Notebook; Fashion Week Fizzles Under the Tents
description: Fashion week in New York usually ends with murmurs and cries of ''Genius!'' But it ended yesterday on a different note, a profound sense of despondency. Those in the industry and on its fringes who typically influence what women will wear next fall found themselves questioning the relevance of the American shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, SUZANNE P.
description: JONES-Suzanne P. On Thursday, February 15, 2001. Miss. Jones was President and Owner of Cymru Inc., CT. Memorial service will be held February 26, 2001 at a location to be announced.

title: Senator Clinton's Book Deal
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is understandably pleased by the approval she received on Wednesday from the Senate Ethics Committee for her $8 million deal to sell her memoirs. In finding that the transaction passes muster under the Senate's rules governing book deals, the committee essentially supported Mrs. Clinton's contention that both her auction of the book to the highest bidder and the terms governing her advance payments conformed to ''usual and customary'' publishing practice, the Senate's standard for assessing members' book agreements.

title: Conquest Of Nets Is Not Sweet For Knicks
description: Larry Johnson had the control of a puppeteer. He would make a pump fake and watch the Nets rookie Kenyon Martin jerk back like a boxer being smashed with a jab. Or he would work a spin move that would leave Keith Van Horn stumbling as if he were on a sheet of ice.

title: Big Board Will Study Effects of Decimal Trading
description: The New York Stock Exchange, scrambling to deal with some institutional investors who are angry about the way markets are operating now that stocks are traded in cents rather than in fractions of dollars, said yesterday that it would set up a group to study changes in the system.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Washington's Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, THEODORE
description: JACOBSON-Theodore. Beloved husband of the late Muriel. Loving father of Louis (Leslie). Cherished grandfather of Rebecca and Rachel. Dear brother-in-law of Rosalind Greenberg, Mildred and Lola Geiger. Services Sunday 12 noon ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Clinton Did Not Consult C.I.A. Chief on Pardon, Official Says
description: George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, was not consulted by President Clinton on his decision to pardon the former director John M. Deutch on Mr. Clinton's final day in office, a United States intelligence official said today.

title: Journal; Smash-mouth 1, Civility 0
description: Rational -- and irrational -- people may differ over the merits of Bill Clinton's presidency, but few can dispute that he was without peer as our entertainer in chief. He turned the whole citizenry, regardless of ideology or demographic, into drama fiends. When he left office, the clich had it that late-night comics, after eight years of sure-fire punch lines, would miss him the most. Now it turns out we're all junkies for the fast-paced, round-the-clock theatrics that defined the Clinton years, and we're desperate for a fix, any fix, to fill the cultural vacuum he left behind.

title: INDOSAT EXPANDS HOLDINGS
description: Indonesia's main international telecommunications business, P T Indosat, said it would pay $260.4 million for a majority stake in a company that owns almost half of Satelindo, giving it control of the country's No. 2 mobile phone operator. P T Indosat said the purchase, a 70 percent stake in the telecommunications company P T Bimagraha Telekomindo, will effectively increase its stake in Satelindo, also known as P T Satelit Palapa Indonesia, to 61.5 percent. Bimagraha owns 45 percent of Satelindo.

title: Suddenly, the Stock Option Looks Just Like a Bad Penny
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- Like a proud father, David Van Wie watched in late 1999 as the Internet company he helped found went public and promised to spread its wealth among hundreds of employees. With the stock soaring, employees from executives on down to engineers expected to be millionaires because of their stock options.

title: National News Briefs
description: Study Finds 'Silent Strokes' Affect 11 Million

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, ANNA M.
description: McCABE-Anna M., 65, on February 14th. Former Insurance Broker. Beloved wife of Terrence M. McCabe, 5 children, 12 grandchildren and 1 great grandchild. A Mass of Christian Burial will be on Monday at 10 AM at St. John's Church in Piermont, NY with Burial to follow at Gethsemane Cemetery in Rockland Lake, NY. Viewing will be Sat. and Sun. 2-4, 7-9 at the Hannemann Funeral Home, Inc. in Nyack, NY. Donations in her memory can be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 180 Fort Washington Ave., Harkness Pavilion 744, New York, N.Y. 10032.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts to improve the image of Waco, Tex., misspelled the surname of a journalist in the 1890's who criticized the city's major university, Baylor. He was William Cowper Brann, not Brand.

title: The Nation; Getting More Bang for the Armed Forces Buck
description: AFTER a decade of post-cold-war downsizing, there is broad agreement in Washington that the Pentagon needs more money. Some say a few billion dollars, others $100 billion more a year. Details aside, defense spending seems headed up.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-18-01: On Language; Proteomics
description: Remember the word urgently whispered into Dustin Hoffman's ear in the 1967 movie ''The Graduate'' -- the secret that would lead him on to great fortune? Of course you do: ''plastics!''

title: Films Saved From Ravages of Time
description: It's that time of year again, when spotlights cascade over Hollywood and Las Vegas bookies give odds on Oscar winners. Oldies like ''Touch of Evil'' and ''On the Waterfront'' would surely give this year's contenders a run for their money.

title: Creating Contracts With Corporate America
description: Plastics.

title: CHILD CAR SAFETY
description: New Jersey ranked the worst of all 50 states and the District of Columbia for protecting children riding in automobiles, according to a study conducted by the National Safe Kids Campaign. New Jersey law allows children 18 months and older to ride unrestrained in the back seat and allows adults to hold children on their laps when a car is crowded. The National Safe Kids Campaign advocates that children up to the age of 15 be required to use restraints.

title: Smart Cookies
description: Molly O'Neill (Jan. 28) may think that black-and-white cookies are ''frumpy,'' but I'll bet if she were away from New York for any length of time she would miss them the way I do. It may be spectacularly beautiful out here in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, 26 miles from Lake Tahoe, but survival is difficult without black-and-whites and egg creams (although they are almost extinct, even in New York).

title: Abigail Ehrlich, Mark Lyons
description: Abigail Mary Ehrlich, a daughter of Phyllis A. Ehrlich and Simon B. Ehrlich of Norwalk, Conn., was married there last evening to Mark Edmond Lyons, the son of Eda Jane Lyons and Howard Lyons of Rockaway, Queens. Frank N. Zullo, a Connecticut justice of the peace and the former mayor of Norwalk, officiated at Silvermine Tavern.

title: LIPA Outlines Plans For Power Demands
description: The Long Island Power Authority outlined a plan last week to cope with strained power supplies and possible blackouts this summer in an effort to avert an energy crisis like the one in California.

title: Article 2001021894163984735 -- No Title
description: Teenagers Try Online Learning

title: Dr. Matthew's Passion
description: In the last few hours before he died, Simon Ajok seemed to explode -- first in blood, then in aggravation.

title: Safer Alternatives To Hitchhiking
description: To the Editor:

title: The Road to a Roadster
description: Inside the General Motors advanced design studios in Warren, Mich. -- past the security guards, past the sign reading ''no cameras or image-capturing devices,'' through two sets of locked doors -- designers sketch cars on computers and race them in three-dimensional form, silent as phantoms, around the room. But the studios still have an earthy, elementary-school smell: wet clay, that primitive image-capturing device. It is a reminder that for all the lasers and digital power, something artistic and intuitive, even atavistic, happens there.

title: Nets See A Rerun Of Knicks' Dominance
description: About two weeks ago, the Nets sat in the dark video room at their practice site and watched what the Knicks' defense had done to them at the Meadowlands.

title: Film or Digital? Don't Fight. Coexist.
description: THE ninth-floor screening room of DuArt Lab, on West 55th Street in Manhattan, is a home away from home for many exhausted filmmakers. They collapse into its chairs late at night to munch pizza while watching the ''dailies'' of their current production. I know it well. I have photographed a dozen feature films in New York in the last 15 years. So what was I doing a few weeks ago arriving in broad daylight carrying a roll of 35-millimeter film that had just arrived from a lab in Los Angeles?

title: Dealers Striking a Note of Caution
description: With five days left before the National Basketball Association's trading deadline, the megadeal thus far features this: Othella Harrington for Erick Strickland and a couple of draft choices.

title: A Life of Change, A Long Way to Go
description: IN their lifetimes, they have been called colored, Negro, black and African-American. If you want to talk about history, if you want to talk about change, then talk to these women at the Elmcor Senior Center in East Elmhurst, Queens.

title: More Than Just Notes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Town That Gags Its Writers
description: RECENTLY one of my students at the University of Florida wrote a story about a young writer who lives at 895 NE 107th Street in New York City. It goes without saying that this student had never been to New York. In her story, the hero, an aspiring novelist, rents a charmingly rundown flat in Manhattan, has an interesting if low-paying job and spends much of his time sitting in coffeehouses with his friends, talking about literature and philosophy.

title: Hearts, and Flowers
description: If you received a florist's cyclamen (C. persicum) for Valentine's Day, give it full light in winter (bright light in other seasons) and cool temperatures. If it is too warm, buds will not continue to develop properly and the plant will be susceptible to insects. When watering, avoid soaking the crown (the top of the tuber should be just above the surface of the soil), and let soil dry out slightly between waterings. Apply a dilute low-nitrogen fertilizer every three weeks while in bloom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEDDIE, VEDA RAMONA
description: CHEDDIE-Veda Ramona. Beloved wife of Jack Garrett. Daughter of George (deceased) and Kelly Cheddie. Her sisters Elizabeth and Geeta and her brother Keith, and her brothers-in-law Gregor Wiget and John Musall will always deeply mourn the passing of our bright flame. She will be remembered for her lively spirit, style and wit, and her nurturing and loving nature. She will be sadly missed. Funeral services will be held at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St, NYC, on Tuesday, February 20, at 10:30 AM.

title: Weekend Worriers
description: According to David Levin, a six-day school week helps kids feel that ''school is a place that's meeting all their needs.'' Is the next step cots in the classroom and 24-hour day care? Hey, school can't do it all. We're not even doing the three R's, in five days, effectively. As a retired teacher (after 40 years), I have to agree with David Elkind: ''It's too much.''

title: A Date, Not a Marriage, for 2 PBS Stations
description: WHETHER it's ''Doo Wop 50'' or ''The Three Tenors,'' Bill Moyers discussing death in America or countless other Public Broadcasting Service television specials on scientific, cultural, educational and historical subjects, Long Islanders have access to an unusually rich menu of programs, thanks to Channel 21, WLIW in Plainview, and to Channel 13, WNET in Manhattan.

title: It's a Bird, It's a Plane, It's a Cloud in the Sky
description: FOUR times in six days beginning on Tuesday, a crop-dusting plane that has been reworked for skywriting will draw a series of clouds over the Manhattan skyline from outlines designed by Vik Muniz, a Brazilian artist. At left is an image taken in Herald Square from a test flight on Jan. 13.

title: Ideas & Trends: The Story of Us; The Other Secrets of the Genome
description: BIOLOGISTS have taken their first look at the human genome and report that its 30,000 genes, though fewer than expected, will help decipher the genetic basis of many diseases and in time revolutionize medicine. But what will the genome tell us about human nature?

title: Sex Ed
description: To the Editor:

title: Mila Atmosudirdjo, Thomas Tuttle
description: Sharmila Hainum Atmosudirdjo, the daughter of Ruhul Aflah Kuhn-Osius of New York and Judiwantoro Atmosudirdjo of Batu Malang in the Indonesian province of East Java, was married last evening to Thomas Louis Tuttle, a son of Nora and F. James Tuttle of Kinderhook, N.Y. The Rev. S. Park Bodie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York.

title: Preserving the Work of the Artful Tagger
description: PETER ROSENSTEIN, mild-mannered periodontist, has a habit of shimmying up fences and fire escapes. Dressed usually in white sneakers and a blue parka that matches his eyes, he has been spotted squeezing past locked gates, clinging to roofs and occasionally bribing a security guard or two. But for all his brazen subterfuge, the only thing he takes is photographs of graffiti murals.

title: Nobody's Perfect: Rutgers Stuns Notre Dame
description: When Ruth Riley of Notre Dame sat down with foul trouble in the first half tonight, a Rutgers upset of the unbeaten and top-ranked Fighting Irish seemed possible. When Riley, the all-American center, left the game with her fifth foul in the final minute, it was after Tammy Sutton-Brown had beaten her for the tying layup. And when Sutton-Brown made the ensuing free throw, it gave Rutgers a stunning 54-53 upset of Notre Dame, the last remaining unbeaten men's or women's team in Division I.

title: All? All?
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane's tale reminded me of the time I was being pushed in a wheelchair through the far reaches of Frankfurt airport by an airport attendant. Wanting to make contact with this helpful but bored person, I searched through my German phrase book. There I found the perfect opening: ''Help! There is a man following me everywhere.'' He burst out laughing and we ended up with a rather jolly journey.

title: Article 2001021893755235731 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Rivera Aiming to Be Unpredictable
description: The results are seamless when Mariano Rivera pitches in October: he enters the game, he shuts out the other team, the Yankees win. But within the span of a few hitters last fall, Rivera made an adjustment that should benefit him this season.

title: A Clinton Fund-Raiser Is Said to Be Behind Gifts in Rich Case
description: Donations to the Clinton presidential library from Denise Rich, the former wife of the fugitive financier Marc Rich, were solicited by Beth Dozoretz, a prominent Democratic Party fund-raiser, two individuals knowledgeable about the library's funding said today.

title: Praised by Bush, A Church Center From the Streets
description: When George W. Bush was campaigning for president, he stopped in downtown Los Angeles at the Dream Center and praised it as the kind of religious antipoverty program he wanted his administration to support. Now that Mr. Bush is president, a close look at the Dream Center suggests how such charities might use public money in their work.

title: A Medical Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: For Schundler, the Question Is Not Why, but Just WHY?
description: Say what you will about Bret T. Schundler, the quixotic mayor of Jersey City, no one can accuse him of shying away from a fight.

title: Shame on NBC
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLERSON, ALAN DONALD
description: HILLERSON-Alan Donald. On Wednesday, February 14, 2001, died in Scottsdale, Arizona. Born October 30, 1947 in Washington, DC, Mr. Hillerson grew up in the Washington, D.C. area. After serving in the U.S. Army, he worked for Sears, Roebuck & Co. at an entry level job, and advanced through the ranks to department manager. He was promoted to corporate level in New York City, where he bought textiles for Sears. He then worked for Shirley Fabrics, a New York converter and importer of textiles, where he eventually bought the company and became its CEO. While living in Salt Lake City, he was an account executive with Prudential Insurance. In 1988, Mr. Hillerson required heart transplant surgery that was performed in Salt Lake City, Utah. He made his home in Salt Lake City until 1999, when he retired to Scottsdale, Arizona. He was instrumental in bringing the Transplant Olympics to Salt Lake City in the 1990's. He was a member of the Exchange Club in Salt Lake City, and was a Board Member of the Intermountain Donor Recovery System. He is survived by his wife, Jane Schwacke Hillerson, his mother, Fannie Hillerson Salzer, and his brother, Robert Paul Hillerson. We will all miss Alan who had a special ability to touch each person with whom he came into contact. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the American Heart Assocn. or the National Kidney Foundation.

title: LAKELAND-PANAS: A PERFECT SEASON
description: The record has been claimed and the streak lives on. The Lakeland-Panas girls' gymnastics team has spent the last week in divisional and sectional competition, but 10 days ago it wrapped up another perfect season by rallying past Mahopac in a battle of unbeatens. It extended the team's national-record dual-meet winning streak to 74. The girls had moved out of a tie for the record at 70 by winning three individual meets in a four-team competition just days before. Brooke Hamilton, Nancy Patterson, Courtney Collins, Lauren Gim and Liz Washburn thus finished their high school careers without losing. ''For Mahopac,'' Patterson said, ''we were telling ourselves 'just one more.' '' Chuck Slater

Every one has a similar array of vegetarian appetizers (always including ''shepherd's salad''), the same assortment of grilled meats and kebabs, the same sweet, sweet desserts.

The changes were prompted in part by new Department of Education rules allowing schools to use drug prevention grants only on scientifically proven programs. The new DARE, which will be tested in six cities in the fall, will focus on seventh and ninth grade instead of fifth and include some strategies that DARE's critics have advocated. Kate Zernike

Minor Trips, a newsletter and booklet published annually by Bob and Sue Carson, contains travel hints for trips to minor-league baseball parks. These stadiums, more intimate than major league parks, capture the charm of the game's bygone days (with ticket prices to match). The 46-page booklet has schedules for over 200 teams in 17 North American leagues. Send $8 to Minor Trips, Post Office Box 360105, Strongsville, Ohio 44136; e-mail: minortrips@aol.com. JOSEPH SIANO

Even if you prefer to have a professional do the return, a basic knowledge of how the tax laws work can help you improve your financial planning.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Last Samba in Sao Paulo
description: The Brazilian writer Caio Fernando Abreu's allegorical novel WHATEVER HAPPENED TO DULCE VEIGA? (University of Texas, cloth, $35; paper, $15.95) follows a has-been journalist as he tracks down the story of a popular lounge singer who vanished 20 years earlier. An engaging and sometimes brilliant pastiche of detective fiction, urban soap opera and spiritual questing tale, ''Dulce Veiga'' unfolds over the course of a week as the unnamed hero navigates the social jungle that is Sao Paulo in the 1990's, with its beggars, junkies, transvestites, shattered revolutionaries, fortunetellers and social climbers. As he struggles to find the truth beneath layers of confusing signs, his journey slowly draws him away from decadent blight into a healthier, earthier life. Among the pleasures here are the author's international cultural references, his integration of Afro-Brazilian religions and their orixs, or gods, into the plot, and the felicitous, loose-limbed translation by Adria Frizzi, which maintains a lively balance between suspense and comedy. In particular, the author uses the orixs to structure the novel in an almost Joyce-like fashion, interweaving symbolic and human manifestations of the gods into the story. Dulce Veiga herself is one of these; she appears to the narrator in dreamlike visions. (The uninitiated will appreciate the glossary that Frizzi provides of some of the more unusual religious words.) Abreu, a journalist, novelist, short-story writer and playwright who died of AIDS in 1996, has created a work at once satirical and tender, silly and serene; it begins in darkness and ends advancing toward light. Jana Giles

title: With New York, Good Boundaries Make Good Neighbors

Positioned at one-mile intervals from the Hudson to the Delaware, they measure the distance from the Hudson. In 1882, more were added as replacements and at roads and railway crossings. Originally there were 168 markers, but some sank into the ground and were lost or were destroyed by construction or stolen. William Graff, supervising topographic engineer of the New Jersey Geological Survey, talked about the markers.

title: Crime
description: How far back in time do you have to go to pinpoint the moment when a friendship, a marriage, a family, a neighborhood, a person's life loses its purity and begins to decay? In his powerhouse of a crime novel, MYSTIC RIVER (Morrow, $25), Dennis Lehane identifies that turning point in the life and spiritual death of a working-class Boston neighborhood as the day in 1975 when 11-year-old Dave Boyle climbed into a car with two strange men -- and his best friends, Sean Devine and Jimmy Marcus, did not. A quarter-century later, when the murder of Jimmy's 19-year-old daughter forces the three of them into a heart-scorching reunion, they still carry the scars of that childhood trauma. ''Maybe they had gotten in that car. All three of them,'' Sean thinks. ''And what they now thought of as their life was just a dream state.''

This casual but still classy room, with sculptured, stuffed and carved giraffes, diverse bright china and exceptional three-course, $19.95 fixed-price dinner from Sunday through Friday ($25.95 on Saturdays), is less stuffy and far more economical than its predecessors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAY, DR. ROBERT P.
description: SHAY-Dr. Robert P., Professor Emeritus at Columbia University, and a leading scholar of the economics of consumer finance, died on January 21 in Ellsworth, Maine. He was 78. The cause was cardiac arrest after a 12 year battle with Parkinson's disease. Dr. Shay's work on the impact of interest rate regulation on consumer demand and credit availability contributed to the easing of interest rate regulation in the United States. Born in Belmont, Mass on March 27, 1922, he earned his Bachelor of Science, Master's and Doctorate in Economics at the University of Virginia, finishing in 1951. He joined the faculty at the University of Maine in 1950, where he became a full professor and head of the departments of Economics and Sociology in 1957, and founded the School of Business in 1958. In 1959, Dr. Shay joined the staff of the National Bureau of Economic Research, and was appointed Professor of Banking and Finance at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business in 1964, where he was an admired teacher and active faculty member until his retirement in 1989. Dr. Shay was also very active in the communities in which he lived. During his tenure at the University of Maine he was elected Selectman in the Town of Orono. After moving to Scarsdale, N.Y. in 1959, he served on the School Board and numerous other town committees. In 1994 he was named recipient of the Scarsdale Bowl, jointly with his wife Esther, in recognition of their contribution to the civic life of Scarsdale. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Esther Cunningham Shay, their three sons, Robert Shay, Jr. of Watertown, Mass, Warren of Skowhegan, Maine and Stephen Shay, of Sharon, Mass, grandchildren Elliott, Anthony, Keith, Laura, Rebecca, David and Rachel Shay, and his sister, Laura Hogan of Palm Beach, Florida. The funeral was held on Wednesday, January 24, in Blue Hill, Maine. The family asks that instead of flowers, contributions be made in Dr. Shay's name to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Inc. at Columbia University, 710 W. 168 Street, New York, N.Y. 10032-9982.

title: Solving AIDS: Look at Brazil

title: In Dance, Preserving A Precarious Legacy Begins Onstage

Maybe it's a sign of the flagging energy of contemporary dance, or a case of millennial self-consciousness about the past and future, or the result of conservative funding priorities, but preservation now occupies a top spot on the field's agenda. Organizations like the Dance Heritage Coalition, the National Initiative to Preserve America's Dance and the George Balanchine Foundation have succeeded in raising consciousness about the critical and immediate need to safeguard the notoriously precarious legacy of American dance.

The two New Jersey Democrats made the announcement in Orange, near the site where a man with an illegally purchased handgun shot two police detectives last month before he was killed. The man had bought the gun from someone who had bought 22 guns in a single purchase in West Virginia and brought them to New Jersey. Anne Ruderman

''There was a lot of snuffing and handkerchiefs being surreptitiously used,'' Mr. Thaw said on the telephone from his home in Wiltshire, England. ''Not least of all by me.''

title: Solving AIDS: Look at Brazil
description: Rosenberg was accurate: we must urgently assist poor countries to confront AIDS. She focuses on Brazil, which has the seventh-largest economy in the world and a tax base that allows its government to spend $444 million a year on AIDS drugs. As she notes in the article, sub-Saharan African countries are not in the same economic position and, more tragically, are facing an epidemic that is more severe. The situation there will not change, even if antiretrovirals are provided free of charge. Yes, drug prices and international trade law are large parts of the problem. More significant, though, is the provision of basic medical care.

title: Quebec on the Inside: Deliciously Welcoming
description: EVEN in winter, Quebec is an outdoor city: winding, narrow streets beckon, outdoor rinks draw skaters and parks offer trails for cross-country skiers. But sooner or later, frigid temperatures and chill winds propel everyone inside, an eventuality that only serves to make dining out a more intense pleasure. Visitors are likely to be warmed by both the food and the welcome.

title: Global Goal Is Modernization
description: Gian-Franco Kasper, a native of the Swiss ski resort of St. Moritz, has been president of the International Ski Federation, known by its French acronym FIS, since 1998. He claims to grow uncomfortable as soon as the temperature rises above 55 degrees. The FIS is the governing body for several Olympic winter sports, including cross-country skiing, ski jumping and Alpine skiing, and Kasper is convinced that a proactive approach is necessary if those sports are to remain attractive and commercially viable. Kasper shared his views on the future with Christopher Clarey during the Alpine world championships in St. Anton, Austria, earlier this month.

title: Perspective; At Daytona, a Sunday Drive With the Right Feel and Fervor
description: He was a car-crazy kid who raced dragsters, but he couldn't find anyone willing to bet a million dollars that he could really drive. That's a basic story line off pit road; every tire changer was once a ride away from becoming a contender. But Bill Davis did find a woman who could organize his ambitions, manage his dreams and chat up a sponsor. ''I never had a passion for something the way he did,'' said Gail Davis, his wife of 19 years, ''but I was willing to follow his and work hard.''

title: Deaths Spur Laws Against Drivers on Cell Phones
description: Mardy Burns learned the blessings of the cell phone when a stranger called for emergency help from the roadside in Kansas where her 18-year-old daughter, Sara, was in a car wreck.

title: Fear! Dread! Torment! Why Poe's Fans Are Obsessive
description: AS surely as ravens speak English and perch indoors, the reader of an Edgar Allan Poe poem or story may expect to encounter characters in the grip of extreme experience. Murder is common, as is madness, and life itself at times can seem a horror.

title: Corrections

title: Habitats/Willow Street, Brooklyn Heights; Turning an Apartment Into a Dolls' House
description: ANDREA LEVITT had always wanted a window seat and a chaise lounge, and so when she renovated her new apartment she made sure to include both in the bedroom. But she has never sat on them, and although she has two sofas in her living room, she rarely stretches out on them either.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Glenville Area of Greenwich, Conn.; Prestige Address and Schools at Discount
description: WHEN Andrea and Lawrence Levine wanted to move from their Stamford apartment into a house last winter, they had a plan. ''We figured it would be a wise investment to buy a home in a town like Greenwich because it is so well known for its schools, among other things,'' said Mrs. Levine, a lawyer at Katz & Katz in White Plains. ''We were going to look there and see if there was something we could afford. If not, we would move on.''

title: A Searcher for Wonder In a World Overturned

There was a family collection, the student, Anna-Elizabeth Arneberg, explained; her grandfather, Arnstein Arneberg, had been a prominent architect, the designer of Oslo's city hall and Munch's good friend. Her father, Per Arneberg, a shipping magnate, was an important collector and authority on the artist.

title: The World: Entanglements; A New View of Where America Fits in the World
description: PRESIDENTIAL campaigns are a notoriously bad environment for debating how America will approach the world. During the cold war, every candidate sought to prove he would be tough on the Communists, and his opponent a wimp. In this murkier age of global markets, globe-trotting terrorists, disintegrating superpowers and distended peacekeeping missions, George W. Bush made realists happy by assuring them he would protect America's ''national interests,'' while assuring allies that America would stop lecturing and conduct a ''more humble foreign policy.''

title: Article 2001021890692785338 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: The Bush Plan
description: The tax-cut proposal that President Bush sent to Congress this month is the starting point for debate: How big should a tax reduction be, and what should it include at a time when the projected federal budget surplus could reach $5.6 trillion over the next decade?

title: Wading In at Aquariums
description: IF the idea of swimming with dolphins is becoming a bit routine, wading with whales may be the next logical step. An adventure camp being offered to adults for the first time this summer at SeaWorld San Antonio will give participants a chance to don wet suits and join a trainer in the belugas' pool to learn about the animals' behavior. The camp is one of several ways that marine parks and aquariums are giving visitors a chance to get their feet wet.

title: Finding the Private Heart of a Public Hero
description: IF you saw Jeffrey Wright's hilarious and volcanic performance as the Salvadoran drug lord Peoples Hernandez in last summer's ''Shaft,'' his portrayal of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the HBO film ''Boycott'' may confound you. It's a platitude to call an actor who switches gears from role to role a chameleon, but Mr. Wright doesn't just scramble identities in moving from Peoples to King -- he turns himself into an entirely different style of performer. The outsize theatricality of his work in ''Shaft,'' which suggests a hybrid of vaudeville and opera, gives way to a cerebral approach to playing the young King. He offers a contemplative performance that's centered in his wide, watchful eyes, and he holds the camera with the hushed intensity of his presence.

title: A Different Kind of Urb
description: The Regional City Planning for the End of Sprawl. By Peter Calthorpe and William Fulton. Illustrated. 304 pp. Washington: Island Press. Cloth, $55. Paper, $35.

title: Lounging at the Palace
description: You won't find sculptural topiaries or wheat grass in aluminum planters in the New York Palace Hotel's Villard Bar and Lounge. Billed as Manhattan's version of the Baroque-modern Htel Costes in Paris, it's an over-the-top homage to historic fashionistas: Napoleon, Queen Victoria and Louis XIV. But that's not why the Vanity Fair gossip columnist George Wayne gave his annual 100 People in Fashion party on the bar's opening night on Tuesday. ''It's 'cause it's new,'' said Mr. Wayne, who was wearing a vintage Pierre Cardin tuxedo jacket and Levi's as he leaned on a long mahogany bar embedded with brass lion heads. ''And I just love mahogany. It always works, you know?''

title: Some Furniture Shopping How-To's
description: BUYING quality furniture requires looking carefully at construction details and evaluating the materials used.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 18, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Chinatown to Boston On a $15 Van Ride
description: It started with van service between Sunset Park, Brooklyn, and Chinatown. Now it has branched out to Boston: a van ride from Chinatown can cost as little as $15.

title: Bosnian War Trial Focuses on Sex Crimes
description: Witness No. 50 was just 15 when the soldiers picked her out at the detention center. Her mother and her grandmother watched her leave, still nurturing their dream that one day their girl would wear her veil, just as they had done, for a Muslim wedding in the village, with everyone dancing to Bosnian music under the trees.

title: February 11-17; Touchdown
description: While NASA astronauts installed a modular laboratory at the International Space Station, another little spacecraft that could -- did. NEAR Shoemaker, the first craft to orbit an asteroid, also became the first to land on one when it touched down on Eros after circling it for a year. Somewhat to the surprise of its builders at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, the NASA robot craft survived a landing it was not designed to make and was awarded extra time to transmit bonus scientific data to Earth. The first in a series of faster, cheaper and less complicated space missions for NASA, the $223 million NEAR project shows that simpler solutions can be good ones. Warren E. Leary

title: Stronger Than Steel
description: I read Stephen J. Dubner's elegy for Three Rivers Stadium (Jan. 28) with my heart in my throat. I was 7 when the Steelers won their first Super Bowl. My classmates and I used to file into school assemblies for Steeler highlight films. But like many others, I grew up and moved away. Sixteen Sundays a year, Steeler fans gather around televisions in our new hometowns, rooting for our old one.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Sir Anthony Hopkins; The Man Who Still Isn't Hannibal Lecter
description: ''Really,'' Sir Anthony Hopkins protested with the fatigued patience that comes when a line must be repeated hundreds and hundreds of times. ''I'm almost a vegetarian. I don't like meat. I like a bit of fish. Fish and pasta.''

title: Pennsylvania Studies New Jersey
description: While students at Columbia battled for seats to soak up Al Gore's alleged media savvy, hundreds of students at the University of Pennsylvania, an Ivy League rival 100 miles down the road, vied for the nine spots in a seminar on probabilities in Atlantic City taught by a humble statistics professor.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: NEW YORK

title: The Neediest Cases; Three Lives Go Forward After Their Painful Loss
description: Manilo Muoz has five large portraits of his loved ones displayed in his living room: his parents, his children, and in the center, the position of greatest honor, his late wife, Gloria, smiling and beautiful. Next to her picture Mr. Muoz keeps a dozen red tulips.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; New Housing for Reviving South Amboy Waterfront
description: A RESIDENTIAL enclave rising along Raritan Bay in South Amboy is the latest sign that this Middlesex County city's two-mile-long waterfront is undergoing a revival after sitting dormant for nearly 50 years.

title: February 11-17; War and Peace and Air Travel
description: The airlines have found they can reduce delays by lengthening projected flight times; since 1988 they have added time to 83 percent of their major routes, up to 26 minutes. Still, a substantial number of flights are more than an hour late or are canceled. The Transportation Department says half of the most-delayed flights begin or end at La Guardia. Maybe the solution is to replace the magazines handed out near the cabin door with Russian novels. Matthew L. Wald

title: Trade Wheels Start to Turn as Gretzky Takes the Helm
description: The wait is over for the general managers in the National Hockey League. With Wayne Gretzky ensconced in his decision-making duties just two days into his new role as the managing partner of the Phoenix Coyotes, a flurry of deals before the March 13 trading deadline could be set in motion.

title: A True Nonbeliever
description: LILI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAF, FREDERICH W.
description: GRAF-Frederich W. The St. Wilfrid Club of New York acknowledges with deep regret the death of our esteemed member and colleague.

title: A Fan Is Born
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: INVESTING WITH/Michael A. Prober; CRM Mid Cap Value Fund
description: MICHAEL A. PROBER, who runs the $40 million CRM Mid Cap Value fund, has two polestars: neglect and confusion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANSHOFF, JOSEPH, MD.
description: RANSHOFF-Joseph, MD. With personal grief the loss of a personal friend and esteemed colleague. J. Lawrence Pool, MD. Emeritus Professor Neurosurgery Columbia University

title: Giuliani, Art Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Runway, Colors and Styles to Fit Any Size
description: FASHION is an unfriendly business, never more so than during the toxic-chic kiss-and-hiss days of Fashion Week. Beauty, however, is arguably the friendliest of style industries. Whereas fashion excludes, beauty includes. Fashion is affordable to a privileged few (although free to celebrities); beauty comes in all price brackets (and throws in free samples, to boot). Fashion seeks people who aspire to be so superior, they don't even allow themselves to eat; beauty welcomes all shapes and sizes. Fashion spits on the fat kid. Beauty cleans her off and gives her the name of a good lipstick.

title: The Music Is Worshipful, the Creators Aren't
description: WHEN I was young in the 1940's and 50's -- music was expected to be heard, not seen, much less told. If there were messages to God, they took indirect channels: string quartets, piano sonatas or newly minted instrumental combinations. Opera houses, with storytelling on their minds, had the 19th century to fall back on. Within the church, journeymen turned out the notes necessary to nudge liturgical texts into song.

title: Hedge Funds That Excel (And Avoid The Exotic)
description: RUNNING his fingers over a stock chart, Arthur C. Spinner was telling a common story, but from an uncommon point of view. The stock of a British company called Bookham Technologies, he said, went public in April at $15.83 and, riding a wave of enthusiasm for fiber optics stocks, floated to a high of $84.63 by July.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: PASSIONATE MINDS: Women Rewriting the World, by Claudia Roth Pierpont. (Vintage, $13.) These brief profiles of women writers like Gertrude Stein, Ayn Rand, Eudora Welty and Doris Lessing, all originally published in The New Yorker, are unified by their subjects' intense need to transcend the limitations of their own lives through language and storytelling. The book is an ''adroit melding of biography and criticism'' that ''sparkles with intelligence, wit and human interest,'' Morris Dickstein wrote in the Book Review last year.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, GERTRUDE
description: GROSS-Gertrude. We love you and miss you very much. Ruby, Joan, Ken, Donald, Jonathan, Kim, Jack and William

title: Defending the New Park Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEIGER, ELLA
description: GEIGER-Ella. Died suddenly in her home in New York, on February 16th, 2001. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Peggy Ellis and mother-in-law of Mark Ellis. Adoring grandmother of Elizabeth. Dear sister of Helena Spelman and Gisella Eisenstark. Cherished aunt of Agnes Bruce, Joelle Kent, Jay and Blanche Eisenstark and their children. Services Tuesday, February 20th, 10 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to the Brearley School, 610 East 83rd Street, New York, New York 10028, attention: Development Office. May she rest in peace.

title: F.C.C. Auction Worked
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about the national high-school cheerleading championships referred incorrectly to their location. It was a single place -- the Indiana Jones Epic Stunt Spectacular at Disney-MGM Studios at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla.; there is not also a Universal Studios Indiana Jones Epic Stunt Spectacular Theater.

title: Defending the New Park Slope; More Legend Than History In Account of Rabbits Gang
description: To the Editor:

title: Spoleto Festival Celebrates Its 25th Edition
description: The Spoleto Festival USA in Charleston, S.C., celebrates its 25th season this spring with a number of new productions, as well as the return of the choreographer Bill T. Jones.

title: Slow Mail, No Mail, Wrong Mail: Patrons Want More for Their 34 cents
description: Sometimes Nona Petioni doesn't get her mail until late into the evening. There is misdelivered mail, too, including a dismal two-week period a few years ago when she got no fewer than 18 pieces of misdirected mail. She sent a record of those mistakes to the Bronx postmaster.

title: Acknowledging Work Of Public Relations Firms
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Long, and Longing for Wit
description: IF one is to allow that guile, deceit, treachery, lechery and greed are the ways of the world, then the stratagems and counter-stratagems of betrayal according to William Congreve are the ways to go. In a society, where the individual withholding truth is as prevalent as the government withholding tax, it is important to master the art of the insult and the variety of invective instead of indulging in the same old tiresome put-downs.

title: If You Wow Them, They Will Come
description: ONE Saturday last fall at the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea, a security guard was positioned at the door, a clicker in hand, counting heads. A solo show by Damien Hirst, his first in four years, had opened to great fanfare, drawing throngs of visitors. The crowd, a mix of uptowners, downtowners and suburban day-trippers, was a record for the gallery -- some 7,000 people passed through its glass doors that day. This was on a par with blockbuster museum shows like the Museum of Modern Art's 1998 Pollock retrospective, which drew just under 8,000 visitors on the day of peak attendance, the 1999 Brooklyn Museum of Art's ''Sensation'' show, which drew 9,000 to 10,000 people on opening day, and the Armani retrospective last year at the Guggenheim, where about 6,000 visitors showed up on Saturdays.

title: Another Roadside Attraction
description: Even in the best of seasons, the Admiral Wilson Boulevard, the main drag in and out of the city -- mostly out -- is a tough place to do business. In the middle of winter, the stretch of road looks particularly forlorn.

title: Nassau College Faculty Agree to New Contract
description: In what some Nassau County legislators called a model for future labor negotiations, full-time faculty members at Nassau County Community College have agreed to a new contract that would raise pay almost 8 percent over five years.

title: Trolleys Making Comeback in Auto Land
description: OVERSHADOWED by the leading roles played by ships, trains, cars and planes, trolleys have had nothing but cameo appearances in Long Island's transportation history. The few trolley systems that operated on the Island -- in Northport, Huntington and Patchogue -- are long defunct.

title: Defending the New Park Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: Setting Up Shop Amid the Action
description: DAN EDWARDS, a sculptor based in the eastern Connecticut town of Moosup, succeeds at doing what few in his field even try to do. Instead of having his subjects pose in his studio, Mr. Edwards travels to them and works on location.

title: If You Go
description: GETTING THERE

title: Islip Takes Off
description: THERE was time for talk but not much tension on a recent weekday morning inside the control tower at Long Island MacArthur Airport, where the morning rush, such as it was, had subsided by 9 a.m.

title: Inquisitive Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page 22 of the Book Review today, with a review of ''Primetime Blues: African Americans on Network Television,'' misstates the surname of the actress who played Sapphire on ''Amos 'n' Andy.'' She was Ernestine Wade, not Wood.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Busy in the Legal Arena; Soon to Be in Theaters

title: Finding a Place for the Cash
description: The good news for money market fund managers is that total assets just reached $2 trillion. The bad news is that deteriorating credit quality is making it harder for managers to find good investments.

title: Welcome to the New World of Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Out With the Tide
description: ISLAND

title: The Past Is Inaccurate
description: MILOSZ'S ABC'S

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN RUDERFER, LISA BETH
description: FISHMAN RUDERFER - Lisa Beth, on February 16, 2001. Wife, partner, lover of Stuart-lil'd to his Big D. Adoring, sweet sister of Debra. Devoted daughter of Susan Warren and Lee and Wendy Fishman. Beloved granddaughter of Evelyn Saklad. Special daughterin-law of Jill and Irwin Ruderfer, and sister-in-law of Amy and Brett. Step-sister of Robert, Brian and Fara. Doctoral candidate in clinical psychology. Wonderful, fun friend. An elegant and gentle lady. Extraordinary. Service Sunday, 11:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: In Berlin, a Road With an Identity Crisis
description: YOU can find almost everything on the Berlin Turnpike in Berlin, from live lobsters to live adult entertainment. One thing you can't find, however, is a road sign that reads ''Berlin Turnpike.'' They all bear the road's official name, Wilbur Cross Highway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ELLEN
description: GOLD-Ellen. Words can't express our sorrow upon your leaving us so early in the prime of your life. Your presence will be missed forever, in our most pleasaurable memories. You'll remain in our hearts forever. Marilyn and Lou Ostrer

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: SOAPBOX; At Rest, but Where?
description: TO paraphrase the tag line from an old television show, there are thousands of poignant stories of the American Civil War and its aftermath in New Jersey; this is just one of them.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 4 about Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, misstated her earnings as a special correspondent for the ''Today'' show on NBC. She does not earn ''an estimated $600,000 a year.'' Between September 1999 and September 2000, when the duchess had an annual contract with the network, her salary was $36,000; currently, she is paid by assignment and is expected to earn less than that figure.

title: Commercial Property/The Building at 75 Varick Street, Now 1 Hudson Square; A Landlord's Subtractions Lead to an Addition
description: NEW YORK CITY'S zoning rules limit the size of buildings that can be constructed on a given site. But a close reading of those rules can sometimes produce an unexpected benefit for landlords, particularly when an older building is being renovated for a more modern use.

title: Conquistadors, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cheyenne in Algonquin Country
description: JOSEPH FIRECROW'S first thought was that the news was not good.

title: February 11-17; Napster Reined In
description: No matter that every teenager you know is doing it: trading copyrighted music with other anonymous Internet users is illegal, according to a ruling by a panel of judges on the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals. That's bad news for Napster, which has attracted 58 million registered users by facilitating digital music swapping. But the Napster saga is not over. The major record labels that sued the company could come to a settlement that lets Napster be Napster, with the addition of a small fee. Or Napster users could craft new ways to evade detection so as to retain the unlimited access to free music that so many have come to enjoy -- and to feel they deserve. Amy Harmon

title: Despite Fear, Deregulation Leaves Nuclear Reactors Working Harder, Longer and Safer
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass.  Last year, technicians at the Pilgrim Nuclear Power Station here found a problem they could not repair in a part of the electrical generator. They called General Electric, which built the part, but were told that that company's expert was moose hunting in Maine. In the old days, Pilgrim's managers would have notified their corporate parent, a Boston utility that did not operate any other reactors, and waited. But now Pilgrim is owned by the Entergy Corporation, a large power company with seven other nuclear plants, which is more eager  and able  to keep Pilgrim running.

title: Touch of Complexity
description: To the Editor:

title: February 11-17; Afghan Refugees Dying
description: A new round of fighting erupted in Afghanistan, sending more people into flight in a country already parched by drought and frozen by an unusually harsh winter. Of the more than 600,000 Afghans now displaced from their homes, nearly 200 have been confirmed dead of exposure in recent weeks, most of them children. Francesc Vendrell, the United Nations special envoy for Afghanistan, blames new Security Council sanctions backed by Russia and the United States for encouraging the all-but-defeated opposition to the Taliban. The sanctions allow the rump Northern Alliance to buy arms but not the Taliban. Barbara Crossette

title: Nassau Lament: The Grant That Got Away
description: SINCE 1976, Donald E. Fahey has helped corral millions of dollars for Suffolk County, from Washington and from Albany, for maintaining courthouses and for improving health care.

title: A Federal Case in Suffolk: Eco-Terrorism or Adolescence in Bloom?
description: Over the last two months, a rash of destruction in Suffolk County -- fires set in newly built subdivisions, anti-meat graffiti, torched construction equipment -- posed a puzzle: Was it the work of a smart, devoted band of eco-terrorists or young vandals merely blowing off adolescent steam?

title: Article 2001021892578114389 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Terrence Howard Is a Player
description: If I was white,'' says Terrence Howard, the best actor you've never heard of, ''I would be huge. No question. But if you're black, you're going to struggle. It doesn't matter how much good work you do. You will struggle.'' Howard, who is calling from Philadelphia, where he lives near his estranged wife and three children, laughs softly. ''I'm going to Prague in four days to do this movie with Bruce Willis and this other guy named Colin Ferrell. He's new. He's made only a couple of movies, and he's getting $2 million for this film. I'm still fighting to get half a million dollars after making a dozen movies. So I want to see what this kid's about. I'm like: Let's get in the ring and box. We'll see who wins.''

title: A Risk of Offense
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMOND, GERTRUDE R. (NEE REICH)
description: DIMOND-Gertrude R. (nee Reich) on February 16, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Dimond, M.D. Devoted mother to Arthur and Patricia Dimond, the late Alexander Dimond, M.D. and Elayne Dimond. Loving grandmother to Anna and Samuel and to Jessica, Paul and Marielos. Sister of Nathaniel Reich, M.D. Service on Sunday, February 18th at 10:00 AM at Weinstein, Garlick, Kirschenbaum Chapel, 1153 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to National Counsel of Jewish Women-Brooklyn Chapter. 1001 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, New York 11223.

title: Gail Fisher, Emmy Winner for Her Role in `Mannix' Series, Dies at 65
description: Gail Fisher, who won an Emmy Award in 1970 for her portrayal of Peggy Fair, secretary to the gumshoe played by Mike Connors on the CBS television series "Mannix," died on Dec. 2 at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 65.

title: King of the Ghosts
description: FLASHING BEFORE MY EYES

title: Ticket Fees, Taxes Add Up
description: THE cost of flying is going up, especially for those who need to change their tickets. And when the increases are flat fees, not percentages, which has been the case lately, cheaper trips take a proportionately bigger hit, as do children's tickets, senior tickets and other discounted categories.

title: In Mother's Closet: Sequins and Secrets
description: JUST before Christmas, my 18-year-old daughter, Anna Sussman, a vintage-clothing devotee, was offered a dream gift.

title: TEACHER FIRED
description: Joanne Latorre, a teacher at Mahopac High School since 1999, has been fired for changing scores on 61 of the 62 chemistry Regents exams she administered last year. The problem was discovered when several students told their physics teacher this year that they were surprised that they had passed the chemistry Regents, Dr. Joseph P. Sabatella, superintendent of schools, said. The exams were rescored. One student of the 16 who failed the exam has retaken it and passed. Another will take it in June. The others do not need the chemistry Regents for graduation and will not take the exam again, Dr. Sabatella said. Elsa Brenner

title: Fashion Week Becomes Fashion Telethon
description: A RAVISHING teenage model in the Marc Jacobs show was driving Andr Leon Talley batty. It wasn't the clothes: goodness no, he adored the clothes. It was her toes. As she traversed the runway, hips rocking, eyes as frozen as a doll's, the toes, one gathered, were pointing absolutely in the wrong direction.

title: Gauguin Revealed From Myth to Muse
description: PAUL GAUGUIN is a magnetic artist, not least because of his well-known life story -- or at least the outlines of that story.

title: Some How-To's for Furniture Shopping
description: BUYING quality furniture requires looking carefully at construction details and evaluating the materials used.

title: A Stone Mason Who Flowers Into Pop Diva In the Evening
description: TOMMI MISCHELL is a pop diva the kind that sings in stadiums and signs autographs on the street. Her flowing red mane and sultry smile are splashed across the covers of magazines regularly. What sets her apart is her day job.

title: Reagan's Writings
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits of Walking Are Not Just for Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: February 11-17; Algerian Fingerpointing
description: Less than two years ago, Abdelaziz Bouteflika was elected president of Algeria on a promise to end years of violence between Islamic militants and government forces. But over the last six weeks, there have been daily reports of new deaths -- dozens in the last week alone.

title: All Cozy and Snug in Their Pajamas and Ready for . . . Exams
description: NANCY BOROWICK was as ready as she was ever going to be for her biology midterm. As the test was placed before her, Nancy's mind was swimming with definitions and formulas, her pencils were sharp, and her pajamas were keeping her cozy.

title: At 92, a Mentor for Entrepreneurs
description: WHEN Linda Stack decided to leave the corporate world and set up shop in Rye selling Mexican imports, she turned to Murray Maizner for advice.

title: Auckland
description: Auckland is defined by its geography, lying as it does on a narrow isthmus between two harbors, Waitemata, which spills into Hauraki Gulf on the east coast, and Manukau, opening out to the dramatic black- sand beaches of the west coast.

title: Sub Incident Erodes Trust In Japan Chief And the U.S.
description: Tempers have flared with the news that civilian visitors were at the controls of the nuclear submarine that caused a Japanese boat to sink last week off Hawaii, leaving nine people missing and presumed dead.

title: Women Still Seek Equality in Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Piazza Approves of Beanball Memo to Umpires
description: Mike Piazza knows it will happen, and probably soon. A fan will ask him to sign a broken bat or a photo of the incident in Game 2 of last season's World Series in which the Yankees' Roger Clemens threw a shattered bat in his direction. Piazza said he would never sign something like that, and he would not appreciate being asked to.

title: Daily Nonstop Flights, New York to Hong Kong
description: New polar routes through Russian airspace and technological improvements in aircraft will soon permit nonstop flights between New York and Hong Kong.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page introduction last Sunday to a conversation between the choreographer Twyla Tharp and Harvey Lichtenstein, former president and executive producer of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, referred incorrectly to the move of Ms. Tharp's company to a new cultural district near the academy. It is not the first by a major artist; the Mark Morris Dance Group announced a new headquarters in the area in 1998 and started construction last year.

title: NO-SALE FOR SAND
description: Though Atlantic City's is among the last free beaches on the shore (tags not required), its sand is not for the taking, according to the beach patrol, which blocked an attempt by Harry Mehlman of Brigantine to sell a pound of Atlantic City beach sand for 99 cents (plus $4 shipping and handling) through the Ebay Web site to a sand collector in Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Mehlman canceled the sale after eBay officials questioned the sale's legality and contacted the patrol. ''I take more than a pound of sand off the beaches in a month in the summer in my shoes and kayak,'' he said.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the investment prospects for railroad stocks misstated the titles held by John Schreiber, a fund manager who plans to concentrate on other issues instead. He is an assistant portfolio manager of the Janus Fund, not its portfolio manager; he is portfolio manager of the Janus Fund 2.

title: Gretchen Wolfe, Lee Hansen
