description: Gretchen Wolfe and Lee Christian Hansen are to be married today in San Francisco. The Rev. Michael E. Woodsmith performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-18-01: Questions for Joy Williams; Up a Tree
description: Q: Tell me about your book of essays, ''Ill Nature.'' It has a certain scorched-earth tone.

title: The City by the Bay? To Them, It's Oakland
description: WHEN John Protopappas started buying a few residential and office properties in this traditionally unfashionable blue-collar city in the early 1980's, ''not many people wanted to join me,'' he recalled. Through the years of the city's decline, his business grew slowly.

title: Playing Both Sides With Convertibles
description: WITH each interest rate cut, you can almost hear Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, asking investors, Dirty Harry style, ''So, are you feeling bullish today?''

title: A Thorny Irish Rose
description: Nuala O'Faolain is making up for lost time. It has been a meteoric five years since the 60-year-old journalist banged out her tentatively titled memoir, ''Are You Somebody?'' in an inspired two months spent sitting at a wooden table in her one-bedroom cottage in County Clare. The book, which had an initial print run of 1,500 copies, remained on the Irish best-seller list for six months before it was bought for a pittance, presumably without great expectations, and became a best seller on this side of the Atlantic as well.

title: Brief Blackout in Queens
description: Nearly 10,000 households in Queens were engulfed in a half-hour blackout last night, a spokeswoman for Consolidated Edison said.

title: February 11-17; Criminal Inquiry Into Pardon
description: The furor over former President Bill Clinton's pardon of the fugitive commodities trader Marc Rich turned more serious with the opening of a preliminary criminal investigation by Mary Jo White, the top federal prosecutor in New York. She is trying to determine whether Denise Rich, Mr. Rich's ex-wife, was part of a scheme to buy executive clemency for her former husband in return for large campaign contributions to Democratic causes, including $450,000 that Ms. Rich donated to Mr. Clinton's presidential library foundation. David Johnston

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, ANNA M.
description: McCABE-Anna M., 65, on February 14th. Former Insurance Broker. Beloved wife of Terrence M. McCabe, 5 children, 12 grandchildren and 1 great grandchild. A Mass of Christian Burial will be on Monday at 10 AM at St. John's Church in Piermont, NY with Burial to follow at Gethsemane Cemetery in Rockland Lake, NY. Viewing will be Sat. and Sun. 2-4, 7-9 at the Hannemann Funeral Home, Inc. in Nyack, NY. Donations in her memory can be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 180 Fort Washington Ave., Harkness Pavilion 744, New York, N.Y. 10032.

title: February 11-17; For a Potus Who Has Everything
description: This year, more than 14,000 Americans have made donations to charity in the name of George W. Bush. But this is one gift horse the president may be looking in the mouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIU, F.T.
description: LIU-F.T. The Board and Staff of the International Peace Academy mourn the loss of our friend and colleague F.T. Liu. After a distinguished career in the United Nations, he shared with us his experience and insights in the realm of peacekeeping and the search for peaceful resolution of conflicts. We will miss him greatly.

title: New Roc City Developer Takes Over Biggest Tenant
description: Louis Cappelli, the owner of the New Roc City entertainment complex in New Rochelle, was never entirely happy with his principal tenant, Sports Plus, which includes a video arcade and skating rink, among other attractions.

title: Style; The Great Gianni
description: The last swimmers have come in from the beach now and are dressing upstairs; the cars from New York are parked five deep in the drive, and already the halls and salons and verandas are gaudy with primary colors and hair shorn in strange new ways and shawls beyond the dreams of Castile. The bar is in full swing, and floating rounds of cocktails permeate the garden outside, until the air is alive with chatter and laughter and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other's names.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, BETTY GRUBER
description: SOBEL-Betty Gruber. In loving memory of my beloved ''Madam,'' queen of 631. Mother of Michael, Stevie and Dava. She nurtured, educated & loved me. She is with me now & forever. Mimi

title: Q & A
description: Euganean Hills of Italy

title: A Sushi Baron Expands
description: JAY KIM admits that supermarket sushi has a bad reputation. But Mr. Kim, who opened his first sushi bar in a Dobbs Ferry convenience store eight years ago, is determined to change people's perceptions.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Gems in the Rough

title: Loans Help Couples Afford Adoption
description: WHEN Gus and Maria Teixeira brought a baby girl from South Korea to their Newark home in October, they faced adoption costs totaling $14,000. Although that is roughly half the price of some international adoptions, it rivaled the bill for the couple's Nissan Altima. So they turned to a familiar source for financing -- a bank, namely MBNA.

title: The Next Wave
description: Last year Bed Head (as in Jennifer Aniston's messy dreadlocks at the Academy Awards) was all the rage; the year before, Cher Hair (as in, um, Cher) reigned supreme. This year, the style is Lake Waves (as in Veronica). Seen on such celebrity heads as Sarah Jessica, Gwyneth, Julia, Cate and Kate, Lake Waves combines the high-texture ballast of Bed Head with the smooth, shiny control of Cher Hair. ''The key is no volume,'' said Steven Berg, a stylist at Pierre Michel, (212) 593-1460.

title: A Questionable Crutch for a Limping Economy
description: HAVE investors lost faith in Alan Greenspan's magic?

title: For Nose and Tongue
description: Although Extra Dry Vya's label announces a ''preferred California vermouth,'' its enchanting bouquet resembles perfume or an aroma therapist's elixir.

title: Yesterday's Junk Food Is Today's Party Food
description: WHEN David Holmes, an MTV video jockey, recently learned that his roommate was moving to Europe, he sought inspiration for a going-away party. In Aisle 5 of Key Food, it struck him with the force of a produce sprayer: he would glorify the American treats so scarce, and so reviled, on the other side of the Atlantic.

title: All? All?
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane skillfully recounts the joys, struggles and rewards in store for those who try to learn the languages of the places they visit, in ''A Language Fan Loves to Get Lost in Translations'' (Frugal Traveler, Jan. 28). In addition to earning a warmer reception from local people, one also often gains insights into the culture that just don't translate. Finally, the feeling of accomplishment can be wonderful; some of my proudest memories are of foreign-language moments -- like a 20-minute back and forth I had with a woman in a remote Guatemalan village, as my sister and I tried to get ourselves unlost. Although I have no aptitude for languages, I always make the effort.

title: Orpheus and Purchase Part Over Fees
description: The Orpheus Chamber Ensemble became a staple at the Performing Arts Center in Purchase more than 15 years ago, lending stature and stability to a concert series that has since grown in both size and diversity. Orpheus will be missing from next season's lineup, however, and the 27-member ensemble, known for playing without a conductor, is sadly asking why.

title: February 11-17; Auditing the Poor
description: The overall chances of an audit by the Internal Revenue Service fell last year to 1 in 200, half the rate two years earlier, Commissioner Charles O. Rossotti said. But the working poor were almost five times as likely to be audited as everyone else. For the 20 million or so Americans who applied for the Earned Income Tax Credit, a form of negative income tax for the working poor, the chance of being audited was about 1 in 75, compared to 1 in 370 for everyone else. David Cay Johnston

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Citigroup Buys E.A.B. For $1.6 Billion in Cash

title: Death Toll in the Kosovo Bomb Attack on Serbs Rises to 11
description: British peacekeepers and the United Nations police said today that 11 people including a baby had died in the bomb blast that destroyed a bus full of Serbs escorted into Kosovo by Swedish peacekeepers on Friday.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS; For Now, the Bells Toll for No One
description: The bells of Riverside Church have long furnished a pleasant backdrop to life in Morningside Heights. But tonal flaws in the 74-bell carillon have marred their ringing for nearly half a century and, to the disappointment of many local residents, they will be silent, probably until 2002, to undergo repair.

title: The Boss Might Prefer A Tie With the Khakis
description: Whatever happened to dressing for success? An increasing number of corporate executives would like to know.

title: Solving AIDS: Look at Brazil
description: This was a gutsy article, for which I am sure you will receive flak from the pharmaceutical industry. Wear the flak as a gold star for having the courage to publish it.

title: Political Briefing; Bush Looks Early To New Hampshire
description: Back in 1992 when President George Bush was running for re-election, he was blindsided in New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation primary. He and his advisers failed to pay enough attention to the state's Republicans, and when all the votes were in, Mr. Bush was only 10 points ahead of Patrick J. Buchanan. It was all downhill after that for Mr. Bush.

title: February 11-17; Gallaudet Student Confesses
description: A sense of tragedy and unthinkable violation swept over the campus of Gallaudet University in Washington after first one student was murdered, and then, four months later, another. ''It's unreal,'' the provost said after the second killing. ''I couldn't have imagined this.'' Not in the insular world of the nation's top educational institution for the deaf. But the most prosaic of motives, it turns out, was apparently behind the shattering of that world: a 20-year-old student, Joseph M. Mesa Jr. of Guam, admitted to murdering his classmates in robberies. Hubert B. Herring

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: WEST FARMS

title: More Runaway Than Runway
description: The peacock revolution of the 60's fanned its feathers on a few men at the fall 2001 designer shows in the tents in Bryant Park. Fur coats, one sable-lined, and fur scarves abounded, as did coordinated couples. The 1950's were represented by the gray-suited man in his homburg. Classics included a Yorkie in a plaid bag, bottom far left, and rakishly tilted hats. But the week's standout was Shail Upadhya, a Nepalese diplomat, right and left. He wore different black and white ensembles on each of the nine days of the shows, which ended Friday.

title: Ideas & Trends; 'Los Simpsons': Don't Have a Vaca, Man
description: NONE of its characters are Hispanic; in fact, they're not even human. But that hasn't stopped ''The Simpsons'' -- or in this case ''Los Simpsons'' -- from becoming the most popular English-language show on television among the almost nine million Hispanic households in the United States.

title: A Landmark's Luster May Not Be Restored
description: Preservationists rejoiced last summer when a movie studio bought the abandoned building that once housed the New York Architectural Terra Cotta Company in Long Island City, and promised to restore the structure. But a decision by the New York Power Authority to put a two-turbine generating plant next door may jeopardize the building's future.

title: For the Not-So-Retired, Freedom and Flexibility
description: IN 1999, Sam Chororos turned 65 and decided to find out when he could start collecting Social Security.

title: Buying on Margin: Not for the Faint of Heart
description: CONSIDER it yet more evidence that bullish sentiment, if not quite as rampant as it was a year ago, nevertheless remains widespread. Several readers have asked me to elaborate on a passing reference I made in a column last month to making borrowed money, or margin, part of a long-term investment strategy.

title: Article 2001021893617945221 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: At Least There's No Wind Chill
description: IT was 2:32 a.m., and my nose was cold, very cold. Bundled in an Arctic-grade sleeping bag, on a bedding of deer pelts, I had scrupulously followed all the directions for sleeping in North America's first ice hotel. At the ice bar, I imbibed sparingly from ice cubes filled with vodka. I had exercised, walking back and forth -- boots crunching and clouds of breath rising -- down vaulted ice halls, admiring ghostlike sculptures of Inuit spearing seals and building igloos.

title: All? All?
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane ran into trouble in Tamil Nadu because, as in many parts of the world, the written language there differs, sometimes significantly, from the language spoken by the people. For example, in the Tamil book Ms. McLane was using (''Learn Tamil Through English''), the word for the number two is listed as eranndu (the written form). In the spoken language it is rendu.

title: For Rent: Office Space In Central Hackensack
description: John DeNoy stood at the window of his restaurant near the Bergen County courthouse and looked out at the falling snow. Normally at this hour of the morning, the place would be filled with people bantering with him over bacon and eggs or just coming in for coffee and a muffin to go. Today, John's Restaurant was as empty as a freeholders meeting.

title: A Singer-Songwriter Is Finding Her Groove
description: THE singer-songwriter KJ Denhert, who characterizes herself as an ''urban folk and jazz artist,'' can attest to the value of good fortune and even divine encouragement in her music career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADANES, ELLIOTT B.
description: BADANES-Elliott B. Died February 7, 2001 in Oakland, CA. Pre-deceased, in 1997, by Mildred (Millie), nee Rosenberg, his wife for fiftyeight years. He is survived by his sons Steve, John and Tom and by John's wife Ellabaff. Elliott received a B.A. from City College, New York, in 1938 and an M.B.A. with Distinction from Harvard in 1940. After graduation from the Industrial College of the Armed Services in 1941, he served in the Army Air Forces, achieving the rank of Lt. Col., and returned to civilian life in 1946. A home-builder and developer in New Jersey, he was President of Elliott Construction Company until 1969 and retired to California in 1983 after holding managerial positions with Boise Cascade, J.H. Snyder Company and Larry Mayer & Company in Chicago. Elliott had long been an active advocate for the mentally ill and, with his late wife, was a co-founding member of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill (NAMI) in 1979. He served two terms as President of the California Alliance for the Mentally Ill (CAMI) and received the organization's Lifetime Achievement Award in 1997. As Elliott desired, no formal funeral services will be held, but the family would appreciate donations in his memory to either the California Alliance for the Mentally Ill (CAMI), 1111 Howe Ave, Suite 475, Sacramento, CA 95825, or The Alameda County Mental Health Association, (ACMHA), 1801 Adeline St., Oakland, CA 94607.

title: Prowling Suffolk, the Gray Panthers of Bingo
description: THE sun wasn't over the horizon yet but Helen Kolody didn't want to be late. Up at 5:30 a.m., she was having coffee and a roll in her car in the parking lot by the Wal-Mart in Middle Island by 6:20 on a recent Wednesday morning. And when the store's outer doors opened at 6:45, Ms. Kolody, 73, was the first inside the vestibule, waiting for the inner doors to be unlocked.

title: Some Lights, Some Action, and Suddenly, Who's Acting?
description: SSSHHH -- you talk too much during sex,'' Jessica reprimanded, grazing my lips hurriedly. Asking permission to kiss her neck, as I had just done, was apparently a faux pas. So I awkwardly grabbed hold of the chaise longue's armrests and lunged forward. Then I stopped, worried I might be moving too fast.

title: By Listening, 3 Economists Show Slums Hurt the Poor
description: HOUSING vouchers have been a ticket out of the slums for thousands of poor families since the 1980's. But only recently have researchers begun to pin down the benefits of moving to better neighborhoods. And three economists may have stumbled on the most important benefit of all -- by engaging in some unconventional economics.

title: My Brother's Guilt Became My Own
description: Your Jan. 14 Lives column brought back a wave of terrible memories for me. Leah Schendel, the 78-year-old victim in this case, was my grandmother. Bill Babbitt feels guilty for turning in his brother all those years ago, but he must know that there was simply nothing else he could have done. Through 18 long years of appeals, the courts never bought into the post-traumatic-stress-disorder defense sought by his brother's supporters. Manuel Babbitt had a long history of violent crime. It didn't start with my grandmother. Nor did it start with Vietnam. In the end, it is not Bill Babbitt who bears the responsibility for his brother's plight. It is not the judicial system or the victim's family who demanded justice. And it is not Vietnam. Manuel Babbitt alone bore the responsibility for what happened to him.

title: Rights Groups Fear Implications in Egypt's Trial of a Sociologist
description: Prosecutors in the Supreme Security Court began their arguments today in the case against Saad Eddin Ibrahim, a prominent sociologist whose trial on charges of defaming Egypt is being closely watched for its chilling effect on the work of human rights groups and other independent research organizations here.

title: An Intricate Bond; New Haven's Past and Future Are So Tied to Yale, but It Took 300 Years for the Two to Get Along
description: FROM behind the wheel of his silver Lincoln Town Car, Bruce Alexander turned left onto Winchester Avenue, a humble pockmarked strip that is something of a crossroad for the city of New Haven.

title: My Reasons for the Pardons
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Boris Goldovsky, 92, Musician And Opera's Avid Evangelist
description: Boris Goldovsky, the conductor, pianist, lecturer and opera impresario best known to millions of radio listeners for his intermission commentaries during nearly 50 years of Saturday matinee broadcasts from the Metropolitan Opera, died on Thursday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 92.

title: Craftsmanship Intact
description: To the Editor:

title: Courage and Thought
description: To the Editor:

title: NAVY TO CONVENE A PUBLIC INQUIRY ON SUB ACCIDENT
description: A senior naval commander said today that he would convene a formal court of inquiry to investigate the collision of the submarine Greeneville and a Japanese training vessel off Hawaii, setting the stage for what amounts to a public trial of the submarine's captain and crew.

title: Car Dealers' Lament: Take My Incentive, Please
description: GERALD SMITH was impressed with the latest version of the Oldsmobile Aurora, redesigned for 2001, when he first saw it last fall, but he was put off by its $30,000-plus price tag. Then General Motors announced in December that it planned to phase out the Olds brand, and Mr. Smith began strategizing.

title: With Classy Ambience and Preparation
description: FROM the string of tiny blue lights outlining the building to the teal walls, the brilliant blue shell-like wall sconces and the flickering candles in blue glass containers illuminating the bar, Nel Blu lives up to its name. Too much? Not at all. This restaurant is a stunner.

title: Defending the New Park Slope; A Way to Let The Buyer Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROCKWELL, DENNIS J.
description: ROCKWELL-Dennis J. Greatly missed by Denise, Kirsten, Amber and Rashawn. June 21, 1916 to February 18, 2000

title: Dismissing a Dozen, Hiring One
description: The New York law firm of Dewey Ballantine was in the news twice for its arithmetic last week -- once for subtracting some associates, and again for adding a bankruptcy lawyer from a rival New York firm, Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Feb. 4 with an article about Dan Flavin's installation ''Untitled (Marfa Project)'' in Marfa, Tex., referred incorrectly to the source of light in the work. It is fluorescent tubes, as stated in the article, not neon.

title: What Is Making Long Islanders Overweight?
description: Re ''Boon Times and Their Waistlines'' : I have been a physician for more than 30 years and I have seen the myriad health problems that come from ''unconscious'' eating. The food industry in America has been hugely successful in promoting increased intake of tasty and inexpensive foods. People, for the most part, have lost control of their discipline in food matters.

title: Livingston In Form At P.S.A.L. Meet
description: Stacey Ann Livingston led Boys and Girls High School to its first Public Schools Athletic League girls' indoor track and field title yesterday. The Brooklyn school scored a record 103 points, almost doubling the 55 posted by the runner-up, A.P. Randolph, in the 93rd edition of the city indoor high school championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.

title: Just a New Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: Beating the Odds (and the Offensive Ends)
description: His mother named him Sirr because she wanted him to be treated with respect. And that's what Sirr Parker received after beating the odds to become an honor-roll student, an all-star athlete and, at the age of 12, a parent to his younger brother.

title: An Adventurous Spirit at the Helm of San Francisco Symphony
description: ALL first-rate artists can walk the walk, which is their largest measure of success. So if some can't talk the talk, it usually doesn't matter. M.T.T., as the music director Michael Tilson Thomas is known, brings excitement to the San Francisco Symphony because he can do both. Not only he is a gifted conductor and pianist, but he is a quick-witted and eloquent speaker, particularly in setting out reasons for the musical choices on each program.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-18-01: Salient Facts; Mercury Rising
description: THE GOOD, THE BAD AND THE UNEXPECTED

title: When to Go Along, and When to Walk Away
description: AS the new attorney general, John Ashcroft is working for an organization that has some laws he finds disagreeable. His new job, in fact, makes him the chief enforcer of those laws. Yet in his confirmation hearings, he said, ''I understand that being attorney general means enforcing the laws as they are written, not enforcing my personal preferences.''

title: Without Mulder (Most of the Time), 'The X-Files' Thrives
description: MULDER has a brain tumor? One that he neglected to mention to Scully, his longtime partner in F.B.I. investigations and unresolved sexual tension? And this was preying on his mind for a full year before he was abducted by space aliens last May?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 4 about New Zealand filmmakers misstated the given name of the director of ''Scarfies,'' shown at the 62nd & Broadway Cinema. He is Robert Sarkies, not Richard.

title: A More Competitive Daytona 500 Is Expected
description: The stock cars were still flying at a blur around the track, but Dale Earnhardt could see that those delicious moments of paint-swapping and name-calling and villain-making, the stuff that made driving fun, had all but disappeared.

title: White Plains Aiming For State Championship
description: IT'S impossible to say where the journey will end for the White Plains basketball team, which is top-seeded among the Class A schools in the Section 1 tournament. But where it began seems pretty clear.

title: Footlights
description: Story Quilt-Making From the Heart

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SASSOWER, REBECCA NEWMAN
description: SASSOWER-Rebecca Newman. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved mother of Philip (and Susan) Sassower-dear friends of YU who are Founders of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine and supporters of our Sy Syms School of Business. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren, greatgrandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman, Board of Trustees Yeshiva University

title: N.J. VINES/Asbury; The Fruit of the Bush
description: Like a genie that materialized from an opened bottle, ready to do one's bidding, a delicious raspberry aroma filled the dining room at dinner and then lingered until morning.

title: A Softer Way to Fight Drug Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Bonds
description: Almost Home

title: 'Chocolat' Is Only Icing on Her Cake
description: TWO years ago, Juliette Binoche came to New York with the script for ''Chocolat'' in hand, and the starring role for herself in mind. She sat down with Harvey Weinstein, the larger-than-life power behind Miramax Films, whom she already knew was planning to produce the film, and told him how much she loved the part.

title: Pedaling With A Revolutionary Spirit
description: I KNEW we were in for some serious fun when our Cuban guide mispronounced ''cycle tourists'' as ''psycho tourists.'' You don't have to be crazy to spend two weeks bicycling through Cuba's eastern provinces -- the Oriente that hatched three major revolutions, sheltered Fidel Castro in cloud-covered mountains, and gave birth to the hip-shaking rhythms of Afro-Cuban music -- but it helps to have an attitude of cheerfully accepting whatever is thrown your way.

title: Week in Review: Feb. 12-17
description: Napster Reined In

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-18-01: Map; A Trail of Refuse
description: Philadelphia's so-called Ash Boat, or at least its ash, finally found a home a few weeks ago -- only to be cast out again. In 1986, the City of Philadelphia loaded 15,000 tons of incinerated trash onto a ship, the Khian Sea. Fifteen years and many unsuccessful ports of call later, the ship's captain, Arturo Fuentes, and his crew have disappeared, and the ship's whereabouts are unknown. ''That's the million-dollar question,'' says Kenny Bruno, a former Greenpeace employee who is considered the national expert on the Khian Sea. With 4,000 tons of the original cargo abandoned in Haiti in 1988 once again at sea, the odyssey is not over yet. Here are some of the highlights.

title: A Message in Eroding Glacial Ice: Humans Are Turning Up the Heat
description: The icecap atop Mount Kilimanjaro, which for thousands of years has floated like a cool beacon over the shimmering plain of Tanzania, is retreating at such a pace that it will disappear in less than 15 years, according to new studies.

title: February 11-17; Submarine Investigation
description: News that civilians were at two controls of the American submarine Greeneville when it smashed into a Japanese fishing trawler enraged many in Japan and created diplomatic tensions. Nine people missing from the trawler, including four students, are presumed dead. Navy officials said that the civilians, on an outing to build public relations, were closely monitored during an emergency surfacing drill and did not cause the accident. But the Navy also decided to stop letting civilians near controls. And investigators focused on the biggest mystery: how the submarine's crew could have failed to spot the 190-foot trawler. Christopher Drew

title: Liberties; Dj Dubya
description: Nothing personal, Saddam. Just bidness. Bush family bidness.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE LONDON MONSTER

title: How a Costly Conversion Can Be Undone
description: AFTER last year's stock market slide, many people saving for retirement thought they had the bad news when they saw their brokerage or mutual fund statements. But at tax time, the situation gets worse.

title: Limiting Liabilities for 2000 and Beyond
description: DEPENDING on their personal circumstances, taxpayers may yet be able to pare their tax liabilities on their 2000 returns, as well to plan ahead for reducing what they owe a year from now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAVIN, JOHN J., JR.
description: NAVIN-John J., Jr. Of Short Hills, NJ on Wednesday, February 14, 2001. Husband of Joan Gannon Navin. Father of John J. Navin, III, Mrs. Cara Moxley and Mrs. Stacey Navin-Weinstein. Brother of Sister Catherine Navin and Dennis Navin. Also survived by three grandchildren. Funeral from Smith and Smith (Suburban) 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ on Tuesday, February 20 at 10 AM. Funeral mass in St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, NJ at 11 AM. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. Entombment St. Rose of Lima Mausoleum. Friends may call Monday 2-4, 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, Millburn-Short Hills Volunteer First Aid Squad, PO Box 226, or Millburn Township Beautification League, Inc., PO Box 46, Millburn, NJ 07041

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-18-01: Design; Being a Pill
description: The fact that a new antidepressant, Organon's Remeron SolTab, came to market several weeks ago probably isn't as remarkable as the fact that it's the first one that disintegrates orally: the pill dissolves within 30 seconds on the tongue, which makes it easier to take and should improve patient compliance. Because virtually all medication tastes bad (one reason the majority of oral dosages are meant to be swallowed whole), taste thus became a design element in this drug's creation. Lots of considerations determine a pill's form, in fact, as some samples from the major drug makers show.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT'S hard to imagine anyone but Tom Hanks playing the prison-guard protagonist of THE GREEN MILE (1999). Even death row was a gentler, more humane place during the Depression in this film, written and directed by Frank Darabont and based on the serial novel by Stephen King. Michael Clarke Duncan is heart-wrenching as the gentle giant of prisoner who calls all the guards ''boss,'' is afraid of the dark, protects even the tiniest of god's creatures and yet has been convicted of the rape and murder of two little girls. Gradually the men around the prisoner come to believe in his literally miraculous healing powers and his innocence. Mr. Hanks, as is his gift, comes across as decency personified -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

title: Burmese Junta in Talks With Democracy Leader
description: The first sign that something unusual was going on was the disappearance of editorial cartoons pillorying Myanmar's pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, as a ''democracy princess,'' a ''political stunt actress'' and a ''Satan of destruction.''

title: Martin LeBoutillier; Brokerage Firm President, 79
description: Martin LeBoutillier, a former president of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, the brokerage house, died Tuesday at a hospital in Old Lyme, Conn. He was 79.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: MY FATHER'S DAUGHTER

title: How Cherry Hill Schools Try to Attract Employees
description: IN more than two decades as a school administrator, Dr. Morton Sherman was always the one making demands of job applicants. Not anymore.

title: In East London, A New Thames Park
description: London's first riverside park in recent years has opened eight miles east of the center of London on the north bank of the Thames alongside the Thames Barrier, the steel and concrete movable flood barrier that was completed in 1982.

title: Still Tussling With Worms
description: Cromwell Recreation Center is the only city parks center sitting on a New York harbor pier. This makes for nice views from the second-floor weight room, but it made for bad news last July when it was discovered that borer worms had chewed away most of the wood pilings under the building.

title: Article 2001021892627735636 -- No Title
description: February 15, 2001

title: Finally, a Shop to Buy Pulverized Rubies
description: The store has no name. But it has rules.

title: Linoleum Taken From Floor to the Wall
description: BILL MILLER'S artwork can be appreciated on two levels. The first is its visual appeal -- original, colorful expressionistic portraits and landscapes. The second is that it just might evoke happy memories of Grandma's kitchen floor.

title: Vanishing Act
description: MAPPING THE EDGE

title: Sex and Innocence in Argentina
description: A PRIZE-WINNING play by a writer from Buenos Aires has been running there for more than two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ROSE
description: FREEDMAN-Rose. Age 107. Passed away February 15. Beloved mother of Arlene March, Robert and Herbert. Loving grandmother of Daniel and Keira March, Dana Walden, Robyn, Kristi, Laura, Pamela and Douglas Freedman. Dear great-grandmother of Aliza Walden. Services today at 11 AM at K.T.I. Synagogue, 575 King St., Port Chester, New York.

title: BENEFITS
description: Art Show 2001

title: The Mets Play Wait and See With Escobar
description: It is the kind of tale that precedes Alex Escobar, who promises to make more such stories this spring.

title: Another View of Power Of P.R. Companies
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLATZER, DR. HENRIETTE T.
description: GLATZER-Dr. Henriette T. Died February 16, 2001. Survived by her son John Z., grandson Ollie, and daughter-in-law Joan Goodman; predeceased by her husband William and her son Stephen. Services at Campbell's, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 11:30 AM, Tuesday, February 20. Donations to charity of your choice.

title: In Baltimore's West Side, Preservation Story Unfolds
description: TWO and half years ago a development plan that would have demolished hundreds of buildings in Baltimore and filled the cleared area with retail stores, parking garages and residential projects, seemed inevitable.

title: An English Playwright With Very Mixed Notices
description: NO British dramatist polarizes his countrymen as much as Edward Bond.

title: Huge Welcome For Solo Sail In Record Time
description: From the deck of her racing boat, Kingfisher, England's new prodigal daughter returned home last Thursday, and even via a crackling trans-Atlantic cell-phone connection, the glee in Ellen MacArthur's voice was clear and audible. So too was the shrill blast of a ship's horn in proximity.

title: Ideas & Trends; In Oscar Race, Family Prevails
description: AT first blush, the two main contenders for this year's Oscar for best picture, ''Gladiator,'' which received 12 nominations last week, and ''Traffic,'' which received five, could hardly be less similar. The first is a costume drama, the second contemporary. The first is stately, the second kinetic, almost documentary in style; the first narratively conventional, the second kaleidoscopic.

title: Corrections
description: The L.I.@Work column last Sunday, about the Port Washington-based market research company NPD, referred imprecisely to the ownership of a proposed spinoff of the company's custom research unit. It would be owned by Ipsos, a French company, not by NPD.

title: Unvented Dryer In a Condo
description: Q: We recently bought a condominium that has no outside venting for the dryer. Now the builder is telling us we have to purchase a different dryer that does not require outside ventilation. He wants us to pay for half the cost of this dryer. How is it possible that this contractor got a certificate of occupancy for this building with the dryer situation as it was? The same problem exists in all the condominium units in the development. We were not made aware of this problem until 10 months after we had already moved in. . . . Kathie M. Sapienza, Piermont, N.Y.

title: Nhu An Tran, Noah Zaring
description: Nhu An Tran and Noah Samuel Zaring, who received master's degrees in international economics and international relations from the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, where they met, were married yesterday in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. Shay Auerbach, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. On Friday, the couple held a traditional Vietnamese ceremony, in which their families were formally introduced, at the home of the bride's parents, Le thi My Nhan and Tran van Kien of Fairfax, Va.

title: Reagan's Writings
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockefeller Offers Plan for Farm
description: AN 80-acre cattle farm owned by the Rockefeller family would become an environmental and agricultural education center, complete with a restaurant, cafe and commercial offices, under a plan presented by David Rockefeller last week.

title: Winter's Tales
Facing a Detour, Riders Want a Shorter, Free One
description: Rerouted subways and service disruptions are a familiar problems for commuters. Later this month, for example, many people who ride the West Side No. 1 and No. 9 trains at night will be forced to switch between uptown and downtown lines before reaching their destination.

title: Longer School Days for Kindergartners
description: THE traditional half-day kindergarten program most adults are familiar with is going the way of classroom nap time.

title: Facing Challenges of Greatness and Mortality
description: SINCE Beethoven, a composer's ninth symphony has been a big occasion, and in disturbingly many cases -- those of Schubert, Dvorak, Bruckner and Mahler besides Beethoven himself -- a final one. Any composer now might want to pause before this point, but Hans Werner Henze, who celebrates his 75th birthday this year, boldly took on the challenges of greatness and mortality in his Ninth Symphony, which has its American premiere beginning on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall, with Kurt Masur conducting the New York Philharmonic. (And happily, Mr. Henze, unlike those other composers, has completed a 10th Symphony, with its premiere to be conducted by Simon Rattle at the Lucerne Festival in 2002.)

title: Egg Hatches, and Mystic Has a Brand-New Bird
description: AT just 12 ounces, SD0101 may be the one of the smallest animals at Mystic Aquarium, but it may soon be one of the most popular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACH, SAMUEL
description: WALLACH-Samuel. Died February 14, 2001, age 91. Dedicated teacher, courageous activist. Former President of the N.Y. Teacher's Union. Advocate for developmentally disabled children. Loving husband of the late Lottie Tanenbaum, proud father of Joan Scott and Ruth Frankel. Adoring grandfather and great grandfather. Caring brother of Shirley Auerbach, Eli Wallach and the late Sylvia Grant. ''Don't Mourn, Organize.'' Memorial Services this Spring. In lieu of flowers send contributions to the Samuel Wallach Scholarship Fund, Center for Worker Education, CUNY, 99 Hudson Street, NY, New York 10013.

title: Weekend Worriers
description: I sincerely hope that the six-day school week (The Way We Live Now, Jan. 28) does not emerge as a national policy aimed at getting ''more'' out of already overworked teachers. The teacher's workday by no means begins at 8 and ends at 2:30. And the work year extends far beyond the limits of the academic calendar. Perhaps we should consider the effects of increased teaching time on those we trust with our nation's future.

title: Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: The Nation; High-Stakes Politics: The Race to Rule the Nation
description: REMEMBER the Reagan years? Republicans couldn't stop predicting they were on the verge of becoming the new majority party.

title: Plenty of Students, Not Enough Staff
description: LAST winter, school administrators in Hopewell began a search for someone to teach physics and chemistry. After months of digging through files, advertising in newspapers and magazines and even holding a job fair, they finally got lucky.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARPENTER, KEVIN L.
description: CARPENTER-Kevin L. January 27, 1947-February 18, 2000. ''But Love, this love has not ended, just as it never had a birth, it has no death.'' Valerie.

title: Appliances And Music: Best Buy's Prospects
description: VALUE investors who bet on the Best Buy Company late last year were richly rewarded: after dropping to $22.31 on Dec. 8, the stock doubled in less than six weeks.

title: Shane Battier Mixes Common Sense With Court Sense
description: There was a conference call with Cedric Dempsey, the president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, sandwiched between some reading for school: Pope John Paul II's statement on evolution and, for leisure, ''Shrub: The Short but Happy Political Life of George W. Bush.'' There were also noisy practice bouts with a trumpet that he is trying to master again after abandoning it as a grade schooler.

title: Helen Shepherd, Timothy Johnson
description: Helen Stevenson Shepherd, a lawyer in the market oversight and enforcement office of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in Washington, and Timothy William Johnson, a tennis professional at the Regency Sport and Health Club in McLean, Va., are to be married today on the Prince's Court, which is the Regency's court tennis facility. The Rev. Derek Ching, an Anglican priest, is to officiate.

title: A Toy Company That Caters to the Disabled
description: Dr. Steven Kanor, the founder of Enabling Devices, doesn't worry much about competition. That's because his Hastings-on-Hudson-based toy company is one of the few that cater to disabled children.

title: Sex Ed
description: To the Editor:

title: Bacon, Frise or Pesto for Salads With Summer Envy
description: SALAD in winter can take imagination. It's not the moment for that wonderful bunch of freshly picked arugula and ripe tomatoes that shine with but a splash of good extra-virgin olive oil. The greens, when they're not limp, may be sturdier, and the tomatoes are either dismal or require a bank loan to buy them.

title: Reckonings; The Unreal Thing
description: ''Treason doth never prosper: what's the reason?'' asked Sir John Harrington. ''Why, if it prosper, none dare call it treason.'' Fortunately, the stakes are lower these days. A modern version might read: ''Deregulation never fails: what's the deal? That when it fails, they say it wasn't real.''

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ON BROKEN GLASS

title: Lives; A Father's Secret Stash
description: Karen and Jerry Kuehn's father abandoned them when they were kids. ''He basically high-tailed it to Oregon and avoided all responsibility,'' Karen recalls. A lifelong alcoholic, Ron Kuehn lived on 440 acres of land at the end of a canyon with hardly any company but his drinking buddies and his wife of the moment. (He had eight in all, three of whom Jerry and Karen found out about only after he died.) Over the years, their mother allowed them to see him occasionally. ''It wasn't as if we really even knew him,'' Karen says.

title: FIGHTING POLLUTION
description: The county plans to install catch basines with metal gratings that carry messages about protecting the area's water. ''We are trying to raise the public's awareness to a simple fact: that what is thrown down a storm drain can be the source of contamination for the water we drink or the fish we eat,'' County Executive Andrew C. Spano said. The basins will be made by a New Jersey Foundry and will cost about $20 more than a traditional basin.

title: A Moore Retrospective At Dallas Museum
description: The Dallas Museum of Art is presenting the first major retrospective of Henry Moore's work in the United States in almost 20 years. ''Henry Moore, Sculpting the 20th Century'' includes 109 works ranging in size from an almost 40-foot-wide bronze to palm-size maquettes (models of planned sculptures), as well as 98 drawings from his earliest portraits to studies of Londoners under the blitz made while he was Britain's official war artist.

title: Jennifer Flaherty, Joseph Schultz Jr.
description: Jennifer Jane Flaherty, a daughter of Helen and John Flaherty of Kennebunkport, Me., was married yesterday to Joseph Michael Schultz Jr., a son of Virginia Schultz and Mr. Schultz Sr. of Brick, N.J. The Rev. Paul O'Connell performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Shrewsbury, Mass.

title: A Softer Way to Fight Drug Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A music listing on Page 37 of Arts & Leisure today about a Carnegie Hall recital on Tuesday by Cecilia Bartoli refers incorrectly to her singing voice. She is a mezzo-soprano, not a soprano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, IRVING
description: MILLER-Irving. Our teacher, colleague, dearest friend. We will miss your wisdom, your wit, your generosity of spirit, your humanity. Thank you for this legacy. Memorial service being planned, call 212-854-5064 for details. Alex, Naomi, Jackie, Renee, Richard, George, Toby, Steve, Anita, Dede, Shelley

title: Dr Pepper Hospital? Perhaps, for a Price; Company Names Are Busting Out All Over
description: CHILDREN visiting the expanded St. Louis Zoo can pet animals at the Emerson Electric Children's Zoo, watch a show at the Bank of America Amphitheater, study bugs at the Monsanto Insectarium and, starting this summer, view the underwater antics of hippopotamuses at the Anheuser-Busch Hippo Harbor.

title: Technology vs. Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: Showy Shrubs
description: THIS is the time of year when garden pundits tell their disciples to bring in branches of forsythia, pussy willow or flowering quince for indoor bloom.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Interest in Historic Preservation Is on the Rise
description: WITH the Great South Bay at one end and picturesque South Country Road at the other, Bellport Lane, a tree-shaded street of white colonial houses bordered by white picket fences, is a vivid portrait of American history. With that in mind, the Village of Bellport, a one-and-a-half-square-mile community on the South Shore, has passed a local landmark ordinance that would preserve the street's historic ambience forever.

title: Slab City Journal; For Thousands, a Town of Concrete Slabs Is a Winter Retreat
description: Every winter, when the Winnebagos and pickups shake the desert off Beal Road like a small earthquake, Ben Morofsky gets wistful for the 120-degree days of summer, and the peace of living with just a few hearty slabbers like himself.

title: Journeys That Lead to Musical Destinations
description: IT has been a roller coaster career for Alice Leon, a singer-songwriter from South Brunswick. Although she has been performing since the 1980's and has fronted several bands bearing her name, it has not been since the release of her new CD, ''Travels With Lady Berlin,'' that she feels she has come into her own.

title: Valerie Lichman, Andrew Krieger
description: Valerie Anne Lichman and Andrew J. Krieger are to be married today by Dr. Jonathan L. Seidel, a rabbinical student, at the Enchantment Resort in Sedona, Ariz. Uqualla, a Native American spiritual medicine man, will also participate in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, HOWARD A.
description: ALLEN-Howard A., died peacefully at his home in his 92nd year on February 13, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruth Singer Allen, brother-in-law of Julie Shimmerlik, uncle of Warren, Sel, Susan, Don, Eve, Anette, Susie, great-uncle of Tanya, Rachel, Lauren and Brian. Interment private.

title: The Day My Free Computer Music Died
description: AS a noncomputer person over 23, I came late to the Napster party -- way after most of the 58 million people who have used the free music site since it began from a college dormitory in 1999. After last week's federal court ruling that Napster abets copyright infringement, I was hit with a desperate, last-days-of-disco feeling. I, like many others who stampeded to the site, wanted to squeeze as much fun as I could from the free-for-all before Napster became a respectable subscriber service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, IRVING
description: FARBER-Irving. At age 88. A loving husband (Mimi), a loving father (Howard and Pat), grandfather (Lori and Jon McLelland, Abbey Wendorf), and great-grandfather (Leah Morgan). Heaven has a terrific piano man. Private service. Contributions to Cancer Care, Queens Chapter.

title: O. J. Simpson Finds Fame and Infamy Blur Together in Florida Haze
description: From a distance, he is just another retiree limping on arthritic knees along the sun-splashed sidewalks, another man with a small paunch and a solid pension, trying to decide whether to play 18 holes or only 9.

title: Leenane Inmates Return to Complete McDonagh's Trilogy
description: FOR audiences already familiar with Martin McDonagh's fictional residents of Leenane, County Galway, the opening on Thursday of ''A Skull in Connemara'' at the Gramercy Theater will afford an opportunity to meet some characters they have only heard about in passing in previous plays. Those encountering Leenaneans for the first time may be in for a shock.

title: Homegrown Art
description: METROMEDIA Fiber Network, a company that develops technology for sending information over the Internet, has recently occupied three floors of the office building at 360 Hamilton Avenue here. To crown its corporate headquarters, Metromedia turned to the Westchester Arts Council, also based in White Plains, to help it build an art collection -- one consisting of contemporary art made in Westchester County.

title: POLICE KILLER TO MOVE
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco last week instructed corrections officials to transfer Thomas Trantino, the recently paroled killer of two police officers, to a halfway house in another state. Mr. Trantino, 63, was moved from a state prison to a halfway house in Camden last Sunday after serving 37 years for the murder of two police officers in 1963; he is scheduled to be released in a year. The Department of Corrections is working with the office of the Attorney General to find a state willing to accept Mr. Trantino. A spokesman for the Department said the process would probably take more than a month.

title: Defending the New Park Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Haven, Growing Plans for Biotech
description: IN a gleaming lab at Genaissance Pharmaceuticals in New Haven's Science Park, across a dirt lot from the abandoned Winchester Rifle factory, a scientist peers at a tiny glass tube. Inside is a single unfurled strand of human DNA, barely visible, far thinner than a hair.

title: Stronger Than Steel
description: For anyone lucky enough to grow up in Pittsburgh in the 1970's, Three Rivers Stadium provided a lifetime of triumphant memories. Watching the last game played at Three Rivers was an experience.

title: Simplification, the Other Tax Goal
description: ALMOST overlooked in the controversy over the Bush administration's proposals to cut taxes by $1.6 trillion over 10 years are calls for simplifying the nation's tax laws.

title: Returning From a Self-Imposed Exile (of Sorts)
description: TWO years ago, at the age of 38, the jazz pianist Matthew Shipp announced that he was retiring from the studio. In interviews, Mr. Shipp described his decision as if it were one of those ''exemplary renunciations of a vocation'' that Susan Sontag talks about in her 1967 essay ''The Aesthetics of Silence.'' In case you didn't see the parallels with Rimbaud's repudiation of poetry and Glenn Gould's exit from the stage, Mr. Shipp suggested them for you.

title: Bring In the Noise
description: MAKING MUSIC MODERN New York in the 1920s. By Carol J. Oja. Illustrated. 493 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $39.95.

title: Met Museum Exhales Vapor, And Residents See an Assault
description: The sky above the Metropolitan Museum of Art seems moodier than most. During the winter months, especially, and on dank or humid days, great, white sighs of water vapor roll over the rooftop.

title: Defending the New Park Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: A College Of Art That Suffered Fools Gladly
description: CLOWNS are walking catalogs of human imperfection, and comedy is the chronicle of their struggle to survive. With oversize shoes and trousers to match their Rabelaisian appetites, these slapstick warriors battle relentlessly against cream pies and pomposity. Their pants fall down to reveal knock-knees and ridiculous underwear. Their bodies flop face first into dung-scented sawdust. But despite the humiliations, clowning is an art in which the well-timed collapse of dignity is rewarded by the audience's laughter, a soothing and addictive sound that provides incentive to persevere in a war that pits red noses against etiquette and common sense.

title: Pop Music's War of Words; Bumping and Grinding, but Who's Singing About Love?
description: SAY my name, say my name,'' chanted the women in Destiny's Child throughout last year's top-selling song of that title. The love cry signified neither erotic rapture nor fond sentiment. Instead, it was a battle tactic. The song's heroine catches her two-timing lover on the telephone while he is with his other girlfriend, and naming the singer would show his new conquest that he is not free. Tense rhythms, ominous strings, and the icy vocals of the group's lead singer, Beyonc Knowles, helped ''Say My Name'' make art of war, not love.

title: Travel Advisory
description: SPOLETO FESTIVAL CELEBRATES ITS 25TH EDITION

title: The Bush Defense Agenda
description: In his first weeks as president, George W. Bush has given every indication that he intends to challenge several cold-war customs that still shape American defense strategy nearly a decade after the disintegration of the Soviet Union. This reassessment is long overdue. If executed in an enlightened fashion, it could clear away Pentagon cobwebs and launch a new era in the management of nuclear weapons and the development of novel military technologies. If mishandled, especially by rushing to construct unproven missile defenses, the effort could lead the nation into a new arms race with Russia and China.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAMM, DOROTHY
description: STAMM-Dorothy. February 20, 1976. Lovingly remembered, missed always. Sheila Samalin & Famil

title: Real Food, Real People
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-18-01; Visible Man
description: Eminem, the rapper whose ''Marshall Mathers LP'' is up for Album of the Year at the Grammy Awards this week, is white. I would prefer not to mention that at all, let alone make it my subject, because it has little to do with the quality of his work, which is superb, as many critics have said. But it has everything to do with why he bothers people. On the simplest level, this is because, unlike many black rappers whose lyrics would outrage white America, if white America could understand them, Eminem's accent, enunciation, idiom and, to use the term of art, flow are clearly intelligible to pundits; to children, if they hear him; to everyone. On a less innocent level, it is because he comes from a world that is not supposed to exist, the world of the white underclass. On a very, very ugly level, it is because a white suburban kid identifying with Eminem is basically, as Eminem is regarded to have done, turning ''black,'' thereby muddying the pools of cultural and racial and class separation (a process that has actually been under way in popular music, with greater and lesser degrees of visibility and impact, for at least 50 years).

title: February 11-17; Greenspan's Reassurances
description: After warning last month that the economy seemed to have hit a wall, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave Congress a relatively optimistic update. The country has not slipped into recession, he said, suggesting that the economy is resilient enough to bounce back quickly from current difficulties.

title: Proposal for Fewer I-95 On-Ramps
description: INTERSTATE 95 in Connecticut, also called the Connecticut Turnpike, is not like turnpikes in other states, where exits might be 15 miles apart. Here, travelers can jump on and off every half-mile in some areas. Studies of driving habits prove that I-95 is used as a handy route across town as well as the main thoroughfare out of the state.

title: La Guardia Showing Early Gains From F.A.A. Cutbacks
description: A government-ordered reduction in flights at La Guardia that took effect about two weeks ago has slowly begun to ease severe backups at the airport, the most delay-prone in the country last year, federal aviation officials and airline operators say.

title: A Valentine's Story: Take Out Your Handkerchiefs
description: In a city notorious for broken hearts, this may be one of the saddest St. Valentine's Day stories of all: a massacre.

title: A Decade Beyond the Gulf War
description: Soon after the 1991 Persian Gulf war came to an end, senior aides to President George Bush predicted that Saddam Hussein would be overthrown within six months. A decade later, much of the old Bush national security team is back in power -- and still trying to fashion a plan to contain the ambitions of the Iraqi leader.

title: Rockin' Round the Camp
description: For soccer moms and dads, finding summer activities is a breeze: sports camps abound. But what if your child would rather spend the summer in the basement emulating Dylan, or in the garage playing Pearl Jam?

title: Authors' Queries
description: For a biography of the American poet Abbie Huston Evans (1881-1983), I would appreciate hearing from anyone who has personal recollections, letters or archival materials relating to her life.

title: Stock Option Blues: Slide Leaves Little But a Big Tax Bill
description: Like a proud father, David Van Wie watched in late 1999 as the Internet company he helped found went public and promised to spread its wealth among hundreds of employees. With the stock soaring, employees from executives on down to engineers expected to be millionaires because of their stock options.

title: Hurley's Long-Shot Horse Holds On to Beat Favorite
description: Bobby Hurley stood stoically today watching the television monitor as his horse, Songandaprayer, led 10 other touted 3-year-olds into the stretch of the $200,000 Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park. For Hurley, the former Duke basketball all-American, there was no reason to get excited yet; Songandaprayer had led in his previous race only to finish fifth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, HARRY
description: POLLACK-Harry. Dear, sweet Harry, we will miss you dear friend and your funny stories. The Elson & Greenberg Families

title: Food; Ostrich: The Movie
description: FADE IN ON EXT. U.S. POST OFFICE CARGO PLANE -- NIGHT

title: Sub Incident Erodes Trust
description: In Japan, anger has grown about the submarine accident. The outcry has added to the troubles of Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori. Page 15.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARPELS, MALOU
description: ARPELS-Malou. A year has passed without you, and yet your place in our hearts will never disappear. Your loving family

title: REGULATING DEVELOPMENT
description: In the wake of Ikea's decision to drop plans for a store in New Rochelle, James Maisano, a county legislator from that city, is drafting a bill to give the county's Planning Board more say over development projects, particularly when they involve conflicts between municipalities. Under Mr. Maisano's proposal, a municipality would need one vote more than a simple majority to approve a project that county planners oppose -- or to reject a change the planners recommend. The county Planning Board's recommendations are now only advisory. Elsa Brenner

title: Stock Car Star Killed on Last Lap of Daytona 500
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18  Stock car racing's greatest star, Dale Earnhardt, was killed today as he tried to block a car from catching the two front-runners on the last turn of the last lap of the sport's premier event, the Daytona 500.

title: The Art of Sisterhood
description: IMAGINE you are 18 years old with a caring, gifted sister you are getting to know all over again after being pulled apart for two years by your parents' divorce.

title: From Flower Children to Hulks
description: The Volkswagen New Beetle was designed and marketed to evoke memories of flower children. The hulking Hummer sport utility vehicle is basically a Persian Gulf war Humvee. What do they have in common? Well, General Motors, which bought the Hummer brand a year ago, has hired Elisabeth Vanzura, 36, the former director of advertising and marketing at Volkswagen of America and the woman responsible for the quirky award-winning ads that helped to revive Volkswagen's quirky counterculture image. (Remember the two drifters humming the German tune ''Da Da Da'' in the Volkswagen Golf ad? It started a nationwide craze.) Ms. Vanzura's task is to help G.M. turn Hummer, the automaker's first new division since Saturn, into a mass-market brand like BMW, increasing sales from 1,000 a year to more than 100,000. Ms. Vanzura says selling New Beetles is not that different than selling Hummers, because ''they're both very hip, very cool, edgy brands that are not for everyone.'' But a New Beetle slogan may have oddly foreshadowed Ms. Vanzura's move: ''Less flower, more power.'' Keith Bradsher

title: Shakespeare for the Young
description: Brevity is the soul of wit, Polonius pontificates in ''Hamlet.'' Yet he is often a witless windbag, and William Shakespeare, his creator and the wittiest of men, is not known for brevity; Hamlet uncut takes more than four hours. Abridged by the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's dynamic Shakespeare LIVE! troupe, however, the story of the melancholy Dane, from the visit of his father's ghost to the cracking of his noble heart, takes about 75 minutes. Suitable for middle-schoolers and up, today's 2 p.m. performance at the Community Theater at 100 South Street in Morristown includes an after-show discussion with the cast. Tickets are $12. The readiness is all: call the box office at (973) 539-8008. Claudia Kuehl

title: Erin King, John Sweeney
description: Erin Marie King, the daughter of Rosemary King and United States Representative Peter T. King of Seaford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Paul Sweeney, a son of Cyril Sweeney of Castleknock, Ireland, and the late Rene Sweeney. The Rev. John White performed the ceremony at St. William the Abbot Roman Catholic Church.

title: Letters on Travel
description: Allo? Allo?

title: Caribbean Bargain
description: Dollar-conscious travelers need to keep a sharp eye on the calendar. In this case, behold the ides of April, when prices in the Caribbean start dropping. Take, for instance, La Cabana, an all-suite resort on the beach in Aruba. Beginning April 16, a garden-view studio starts at $132 (the night before, it was $219); a garden-view one-bedroom suite suddenly drops to $176 (down from $260); superior suites are $174 ($281). All rooms include a kitchenette with microwave, full-size refrigerator, coffeemaker, blender and plates and utensils. The bathrooms have whirlpools. Activities include tennis (five lighted courts), racquetball, squash and watersports. A Robert Trent Jones Jr. golf course is nearby. Information: (800) 835-7193, www.lacabana.com/resort .

title: In 100 Years or So, It'll Be Worth Something
description: At the annual American International Toy Fair in New York last week, lost among Planet of the Apes dolls, Harry Potter games and Jurassic Park III dinosaurs, was a much smaller license: ''Antiques Roadshow.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUZIK, MILTON
description: GUZIK-Milton. On February 16, 2001. Of East Meadow. Beloved husband of Alice. Devoted father of Howard, Joan, Robin and David. Loving grandfather of Samuel, Benjamin, Jeremy and Ethan. Services Sunday, 12 Noon at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIN, JEANNE MICHAEL
description: ELLIN-Jeanne Michael. Wife of the late, internationally renowned author, Stanley Ellin, died on Tuesday, February 13. She leaves a daughter, Sue Ellin (Mrs. William L. Jacobsen), and a granddaughter, Tae Ellin. A fine artist, playwright, and community activist, her beauty, charm and brilliance will be greatly missed by her family and by all who knew her.

title: Political Satire's End
description: To the Editor:

title: Aurora Trout: One of Fishing's Best-Kept Secrets
description: In 50 years of fishing, probably the toughest challenge I ever faced was trying to catch a brook trout without spots. And if that wasn't difficult enough, the fish had been extinct for 30 years. So it was with some disbelief that I questioned Larry Sorochan of Timmins, Ontario, when he called and told me that aurora trout, believed by some to be the only subspecies of brook trout, were alive and well in a dozen small lakes around Timmins.

title: Reuters America Is Moving To White Plains Offices
description: Reuters America's information management group is leaving Stamford for White Plains. It has leased 42,541 square feet at 44 South Broadway, where it said it would get a better deal on its rent.

title: America's 'Culture War'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAHN, EMILY
description: HAHN-Emily 1/14/'05-2/18/'97. Forever loved and missed. Carola

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Busy Week Awaits a Grammy Winner
description: PHIL RAMONE has quite a week on tap.

title: The Madness Of Queen Pumpkin Et Al.
description: VIRTUALLY nothing is sacred in Yasuko Yokoshi and Gonnie Heggen's collaboration ''Royal Madness.'' In this evening-length work, the choreographers rule over a fictional region for which there is a profane name, a bawdy constitution and a national anthem that features lines like, ''Oh great taste of pork chop/ that drips with blood and grease/ our belly sticks out like a mountain top.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATE, HOWARD E.
description: BLATE-Howard E., 83, of Richmond, MA and Great Neck, NY. On February 8, 2001 in Sarasota, FL. Graduated Wharton School. President Brownlee Insurance Agency. Survived by his loving wife Mildred, daughter Barbara Levy and her husband Edward of Scottsdale, AZ; son Mark Blate and his wife Sharon of Sarasota, FL; a granddaughter Dara (Levy) Coope and her husband Robert of New Hyde Park, NY; two grandsons, Andrew and Micah Blate of Sarasota, FL.

title: Perspective; A Hockey Pilgrimage Worth Singing About
description: Looking back, the preparation for our trip to Quebec for a legendary youth hockey tournament probably started several years ago but, at the time, we didn't know it.

title: Soon, Fishermen May Take the A Train (as in Albacore)
description: Years of hearing commuters grumble about being packed into subways like sardines may have inspired a Metropolitan Transit Authority idea for disposing of 1,300 old cars: put them on the ocean floor to serve as reefs to shelter local sport fish.

title: Solving AIDS: Look at Brazil
description: Tina Rosenberg's article (Jan. 28) was an insightful and global perspective on the AIDS crisis. Brazil's success in addressing the spread and treatment of AIDS should be included in the notes of every publication that addresses the epidemiology of the disease. No one questions the need for economic incentives to develop better drugs to end this plague. But where does the profit motive of the pharmaceutical industry end and compassion for our fellow man begin?

title: After 30 Years Wearing the Same Shoes, A Surgeon Leaves the Operating Room
description: DR. LAWRENCE J. KADISH is retiring from surgery and, he says, no one can fill his shoes -- literally. The 59-year-old doctor, who has just taken on a full-time position as medical director and executive vice president of White Plains Hospital Center, wore the same shoes while operating for 30 years.

title: New Jersey Playwrights Stake a Claim Off Broadway
description: PLENTY of jokes have portrayed New Jersey as a place people should be eager to escape from, but two plays now running Off Broadway in New York, both by New Jersey writers, suggest the state's credentials as a place to escape to.

title: Roll Over, Verdi: Jungle Music in a Mini-Opera at P.S. 69
description: THE SETTING -- Thursday evening at the opera house, or rather Public School 69, where singing animals live in a cardboard jungle and fly to the North Pole on paper airplanes.

title: Going Back to the Mortgage Store
description: WHEN James and Maureen Fleming bought their 2,100-square-foot Cape on one and a quarter acres in Trumbull, Conn., last April for $227,000, they took out a $202,000 30-year mortgage at 7.75 percent interest. But as mortgage rates gradually fell in the months since then, the couple decided to refinance. Two weeks ago they decided to take out another 30-year mortgage, this one at a 7 percent interest rate, and they expect to wind up with a monthly mortgage payment of $120 less than before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANO, EMANUEL T.
description: SPANO-Emanuel T. On February 15, 2001 formerly of Whitestone and Roslyn. Beloved husband of the late Josephine. Loving father of Candida and Robert. Cherished grandfather of Elena and Stephen. Brother of Helen and Donna. Father-in-law of Howard. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Sunday and Monday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday 10AM St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: February 11-17; Partial Unity in Israel
description: The outgoing prime minister, Ehud Barak, tentatively agreed to serve under Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon as Israel's defense minister. With Shimon Peres as foreign minister, they face continuing violence. In the last week, one Israeli settler was shot dead on a West Bank road and eight Israelis were killed by a Palestinian bus driver. Five Palestinians were killed by Israeli troops, including one senior security officer who was assassinated. Two others were killed in disputed circumstances, and an elderly Palestinian reportedly suffered a heart attack when his ambulance was stopped at an Israeli roadblock. Deborah Sontag

title: New Dorm in Doubt For Five Towns College
description: The plans of Five Towns College in Dix Hills to open a 200-student dormitory in the fall are now in doubt as a result of a Feb. 2 court order to halt construction.

title: All? All?
description: To the Editor: I read Daisann McLane's article with much compassion as I reminisced about the many attempts I have made to be polite in other lands and at least learn ''thank you,'' ''please'' and greetings. It is a hobby for me as I am a language lover and teacher. I rely on a Berlitz CD-ROM ''Passport to 31 Languages,'' which I find very satisfactory and up to date whether it be Czech or Thai or German. It rates your speaking voice as well.

title: Conversation/Ralph Nader; A Party Crasher's Lone Regret: That He Didn't Get More Votes
description: RALPH NADER'S name used to be synonymous with consumer advocacy and corporate muckraking. But since running for president on the Green Party ticket, Mr. Nader, 67, has been more often described as a spoiler.

title: POSTINGS: 24 Condominiums for TriBeCa; Four Buildings Combined, Four Floors Added
description: The developers of the Keystone Building, a group of four commercial structures dating back to the early 20th century that is being converted to condominium lofts, say they have reaped the benefits of a fashionable TriBeCa location, but without the constraints of owning a landmark.

title: Article 2001021891336561715 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: Solving AIDS: Look at Brazil
description: The United States has led the world in developing AIDS drugs. But where it has failed in making them accessible, countries like Brazil will become the leaders in combating this devastating disease.

title: Editorial Observer; Where Lethargy Is a Way of Life
description: Ordinarily, this being mid-February, one might be forgiven for thinking that the problem in Albany is simply the season. Winter upstate is notably short on sunlight and long on hibernation. But this winter problem -- this lack of sunshine, this abundance of lethargy -- was also noticeable in New York's state capital last spring. Also last summer. So, for anyone who has the stomach to keep returning to Albany, the idea finally dawns that New York's state capital is some kind of stale legislative biosphere. It is a closed system that methodically saps political beings of energy, creativity and even, in very severe cases, their ambition.

title: The Road to Oprah
description: PRIMETIME BLUES

title: Caution: Men Working (From Paris South)
description: Train travelers heading south from Paris will notice major construction work in many stations as the ambitious TGV Mditerrane rail project nears its scheduled completion on June 10. This 12-year undertaking, which cost $3.5 billion, will cut transit times from Paris to Provence and the Riviera.

title: Will a Shuttered Subway Lead to Shuttered Shops?
description: A plan to suspend service on the B and D lines at the Grand Street subway station, a major hub serving Chinatown, has community leaders worried that the area's fragile economy will be devastated by the disruption. Specifically, they fear that some mom-and-pop shops will be forced to close if the many Chinese immigrants living in Brooklyn find it more difficult to travel to these stores.

title: CREDIT CARD COMPANY
description: MBNA, the world's largest independent credit card issuer, will expand its Newark office over the next three or four years to include 1,500 jobs. The Newark office, at Washington Street and University Avenue, which opened in 1999, now employs 200 people as customer service representatives and telemarketers. The company had originally planned to expand to only 500 employees, but decided that the city's location, available work force and underground fiber-optic cables suited MBNA's needs. If is expands, the company, which has its headquarters in Wilmington, Del., will be one of Newark's biggest employers, behind Continental Airlines, Prudential and IDT Corporation. Angela Starita

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about proposals for restricting telemarketers misstated the name of the magazine published by Consumers Union, where a manager said telemarketers could benefit by eliminating calls to people who had no intention of buying. It is Consumer Reports, not Consumers Report.

title: Sports of The Times; It Takes an Angel To Get Lost for Us
description: IN this rootless society, most of us are nomads. One day you are creating software for Bill Gates; the next day you are a barista at Starbucks. Or less often, vice versa.

title: Aiming to Survive In a Market Wilderness
description: Their $100,000 stakes are imaginary, but those who survive this investment competition could pocket a very real $500,000. And the losers face embarrassing ejection on network television, just as contestants do on the popular survival shows that spawned it.

title: 'The Bonesetter's Daughter'
description: For the past eight years, always starting on August twelfth, Ruth Young lost her voice.

title: Letters
description: WITHOUT MUSICIANS

title: What Is Making Long Islanders Overweight?
description: The opinion piece ''Boon Times and Their Waistlines'' [Feb. 11] places blame for the obesity epidemic on Long Island on several factors: television, computers, eating patterns and the overall lack of exercise. Although I agree that bad eating habits are a major factor in obesity, television is not the major culprit. It doesn't matter whether people are sitting at night in front of a TV or a computer because the activities people did before the advent of TV were just as sedentary: reading, playing cards or board games, playing music, etc.

title: Andrea Wilson, Joshua Reibel
description: Andrea Esther Wilson, the daughter of Judith and Leonard M. Wilson of Rye Brook, N.Y., is to be married today to Joshua Henry Reibel, a son of Judith Reibel and Dr. Stephen P. Reibel, both of Manhattan. Cantor Kerry Ben-David will officiate in the Garden Terrace Room at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: A Veteran Foe of Fakery With a Cattle-Prod Style
description: IF you were shocked and dismayed when Bambi was trampled in ''Bambi Meets Godzilla,'' wait until you see what happens to poor Heidi in Paul McCarthy's retelling of the Swiss maid's tale. Never one to leave a folk tale untwisted, Mr. McCarthy puts her in the care of an abusive, anal-fixated grandfather who engages the girl in unnatural, not to say unspeakable, rituals in his 1992 video collaboration with Mike Kelley, a fellow California artist. Titled ''Heidi, Midlife Crisis Trauma Center and Negative Media-Engram Abreaction Release,'' the video is a prime example of Mr. McCarthy's careerlong fascination with the underbelly of popular culture. In videos, media installations, sculptures, drawings and writings, this 55-year-old artist has persistently debunked the false idealism he regards as rampant in Hollywood films, advertising and folklore.

title: Streetscapes/Staple Street in TriBeCa; A Brief Walk Through Manhattan Old and New
description: STAPLE STREET? Where's Staple Street? Its two tiny blocks -- west of Hudson Street, from Duane to Jay to Harrison Streets -- are barely an eyelash on the face of Manhattan. But they're in the heart of TriBeCa, and a walk through them captures not only some of the oldest architecture in the district but some of the youngest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, BLANCHE
description: BERMAN-Blanche. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Blanche Berman. Blanche was the beloved mother of Dr. Kenneth Berman, a cherished friend, leader, major suporter of our mission, and chair of our Long Island South Shore Campaign. We extend our deepest sympathies to Kenny and his wife, Ronni, and their children, and to Kenny's sister, Froma Hisenberg, and Blanche's grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May her memory be a blessing. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect Arthur M. Katz, LI Cabinet Chair John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Simon S. Kaminetsky, LI Director

title: Police Seeking Two Teenagers Charged in Dartmouth Killings
description: Police officers continued searching today for two Vermont high school students they have charged with the stabbing deaths last month of a couple who taught at Dartmouth College.

title: Act Now, Save Later As the 1040 Changes
description: SO far, people looking to adjust their financial plans to save on taxes this year have been spared the anguish of muddling through an assortment of mind-numbing modifications to the 45,662-page tax code. Aside from the usual inflation-adjusted increases for certain deductions, the biggest change for 2001 has been a cut in the capital gains tax for lower-income people -- a change that is only now being phased in as part of a 1997 law.

title: Corrections
