description: An article last Sunday about an increase in the number of workers commuting to New Jersey from neighboring states misspelled the name of an electronics manufacturer in Dover. It is Casio, not Cassio.

title: Noted Names In TriBeCa
description: CITY HALL

title: K.A. Muhammad, 53, Dies; Ex-Official of Nation of Islam
description: Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the former Nation of Islam official who was seen as a leader of the next generation of radical civil rights leaders by some and as a racist hatemonger by others, died yesterday in a hospital in Marietta, Ga., a suburb of Atlanta. He was 53.

title: February 11-17; Modified Crops for Europe
description: If strict control of a new technology implies consent to its use, then the European Union Parliament has opened the way for genetically modified crops to be planted in European fields again. The body passed what were described as the ''toughest regulations in the world'' on biotech organisms. Fourteen are waiting for approval, including corn, tomatoes, cotton and beets. But whether farmers will plant them remains to be seen; European consumers are firmly against what newspapers call ''Frankenstein food.'' Donald G. McNeil Jr.

title: Look Homeward, Edith
description: WINTER JOURNEY

title: Bush Caught In the Middle On Research On Stem Cells
description: The Bush administration is at the uncomfortable center of an increasingly intense struggle over embryonic stem cell research.

title: An Audacious Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Bugging Him? Everything
description: Cardiologists and paramedics would do well to stay away from Bananas, the Hasbrouck Heights comedy club, next Saturday, because Lewis Black will be there, and his performances are generally nothing that anyone in the medical profession should watch.

title: A Tradition Seen in the Flesh, Then Across a Divide
description: AUDIENCES feel one kind of pleasure when artists seem to embody a tradition, letting us live fully in its past while being completely individual. They give us the history of their art in flesh and bone.

title: A Case for the Melodious and Poignant Stravinsky
description: THIRTY years after the death of Igor Stravinsky, the composer universally regarded as the central figure in 20th-century classical music, two questions still shadow his reputation: Will the majority of the works he composed after 1930 ever find a place in the standard repertory? Are we certain about the way to perform his music?

title: Changing the Balance of Power at City Hall; Term Limits May Weaken Next Council Speaker's Check on Mayor
description: In a city with a powerful mayor so self-assured that he seems to suck the oxygen out of Lower Manhattan whenever he approaches a City Hall lectern, residents may not always remember that New York City government has a legislature. It is called the City Council, and despite an occasionally anemic presence in the public debate, it does have some say in how the city runs.

title: In Harlem's Ravaged Heart, Revival
description: Burgers grilling, fruit punch staining baby faces, summer scenting the air. In a courtyard on 129th Street, the tenants are having a barbecue.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Welcome to the New World of Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tree's Convenience
description: A 75-foot-tall white oak tree has been standing in Millville for at least 253 years. An expansion of a Wawa convenience store isn't even built yet. Guess which one will give way to the other. The answer is not what cynics (or perhaps realists) probably think, though it almost was. The tree will stay. Among the heroes are members of the Millville Memorial High ecology class, who protested when they learned the expansion of a Wawa into a ''superstore'' with gasoline pumps and added tractor-trailer truck parking would mean the demise of the white oak, which is apparently pictured on some area survey maps dating back to 1748. Expansion plans, which already had been approved by the city planning board, are being redrawn to save the tree, a type of move the company, based in Wawa, Pa., says it has never made before. Wawa has agreed to give the tree a wrought-iron fence and a plaque. Karen DeMasters

title: Veteran Diplomat Is Bush's Pick for U.N. Post
description: Presi dent Bush has selected John D. Neg roponte a three-time ambassador who has served in some of America's most sensitive diplomatic posts -- to become the next ambassador to the United Nations, an administration official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, PAULINE
description: BROWN-Pauline. On February 17, 2001, at age 97. Loving mother of Marilyn Linder and the late Arlene Appelbaum. Beloved wife of the late Lewis Schwartz and Phillip Brown. Adored grandmother of Steven, Alan and Joan, and proud great-grandmother of Jessica, Stuart and Ben. Dear sister of Lottee and the late Abe, Hannah and Milton. Dear sister-in-law of Doris. Interment today, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 12:30 PM.

title: MY FIRST JOB; Hauling Trash, Confidentially
description: Mark A. Ernst, 42, is president and chief executive of H & R Block, the tax-preparation company based in Kansas City. He is a former senior vice president of American Express.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWSTER, MARION D.
description: BREWSTER-Marion D. On February 15, 2001 at age 100. Beloved wife of the late Warren. Mother of Isabel and Vance Van Dine, Thomas S. and Mary, Samuel D. and Eliza and Richard W. and Barbara Brewster. Grandmother of Sylvia and Dale Brewster-O'Connor, Scott, Maxwell, Sophia, Darrah Brewster and the late Rose Van Dine. Sister of the late Jean Thomas. Funeral service at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Avenue at 90th Street, on Tuesday at 12 Noon. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Ladies Christian Union, 118 West 13 Street, New York City 10011.

title: Remembering the Days Long Before Cineplexes
description: To the Editor:

title: Czech Line and Richter Enough Against Tampa
description: Night after night, Rangers Coach Ron Low implores his Czech line to take more shots. Tonight, the Czechs listened, shooting enough to score all five of the Rangers' goals.

title: OPINION; Take Tax Cut and Give, Give, Give
description: YOU probably don't want to hear this, but your tax break is coming.

title: The Nation: Shadow President; This Episode of 'The Clintons' Makes Bush the Star
description: IT'S a silly question, maybe, but one worth asking: What shape would President Bush be in if Bill Clinton had just skipped the last week of his presidency and left town quietly, without pardoning the fugitive commodities trader Marc Rich, without a carload of gifts and without casting a covetous eye on a plutocratic suite of offices in a Manhattan high-rise?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILNE, JAMES TONER, SR.
description: MILNE-James Toner, Sr. February 15, 2001. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted and loving father of Marcia and her husband Edward Kloos, James T. Milne Jr. and his wife Judith, Mark Milne and his wife Claire and Christopher Milne and his wife Deborah. Cherished grandfather of Gregory, Rebekah, Owen, Gavin, Curran, Heather, Vanessa, Andrew and James. Loving brother of John and the late Jerome. A paratrooper of the 101st Airborne Division ''Screaming Eagles'' who served in the liberation of Holland and the invasion of Normandy. A prisoner of war and recipient of both the Silver Star and the Purple Heart. In his later years he served as a member of many executive boards in the tri-state area. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, February 19, 2001, 10:30AM at St. Joseph's Church, East 87th Street (between York and 1st Avenue). Contributions in his memory may be made to Catholic Charities.

title: Brodeur Yanked From Net as Devils' Free Fall Continues
description: Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur shook his stick in frustration as he skated from the ice and shuffled along a carpeted hallway toward the locker room with more than a period left in the game.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Thonx!
description: Gouverneur Morris fights the new American government in vain to prevent a road from cutting though his large farm. Edgar Allan Poe takes refuge in the village of Fordham, which is so isolated it has no post office. Robert Moses drives the stake of the Cross Bronx Expressway through the heart of the neighborhood of Tremont. Clive Campbell and Joseph Saddler are reborn as the hip-hop artists Kool Herc and Grandmaster Flash. Through such moments Lloyd Ultan and Barbara Unger tell the history of the borough in BRONX ACCENT : A Literary and Pictorial History of the Borough (Rutgers University, $32). Ultan, a history professor at Fairleigh Dickinson University, and Unger, an English professor at Rockland Community College, are at their strongest when they do the least, juxtaposing excerpts from autobiographies and historical fiction; no historical description of the once thriving Jewish community can match the wit of Sholom Aleichem or the poetry of Abraham Liessen. The result is a vibrant mix of historical and contemporary voices; at one point, an excerpt from E. L. Doctorow's novel ''Billy Bathgate'' is followed by an account from Kate Simon's ''Bronx Primitive: Portraits in a Childhood.'' Matt Polazzo

title: Cheers! Using Nostalgia to Sell a Brooklyn Soda
description: NEXT month, residents of Los Angeles will learn exactly why pineapple doesn't belong on pizza. They will also find out why anyone named Lars shouldn't be selling slices in the first place.

title: Machu Picchu
description: To the Editor: It was great to read Ted Rose's article ''Good Morning in Peru's 'Lost City' '' (Jan. 7). The photographs were really wonderful as well. There is one point, however, that I would like to clarify regarding Hiram Bingham's initial perception of Machu Picchu.

title: Lack of Size Is Starting To Take Toll on Knicks
description: For more than three months, the Knicks have played big man's basketball without a big man. On offense, they have chosen a grinding, halfcourt style over a fluid, open-court game, and on defense, they have opted to battle and bang rather than trap and gamble.

title: Alisa Biran, Jeremy Ben-Ami
description: Alisa Biran, the daughter of Paula Biran and Cantor Ephraim Biran of New York, is to be married this evening to Jeremy Daniel Ben-Ami, the son of Eve Ben-Ami of New York and the late Yitshaq Ben-Ami. Rabbi Robert Levine is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York. Rabbi James Prosnit will take part in the service.

title: Julie Irwin, Steven Landis
description: Julie Elizabeth Irwin, a daughter of Mary Jane and John Irwin, both of Clay, N.Y., is to be married today to Steven Scott Landis, a son of Harriet Landis of Whitestone, Queens, and Raymond Landis of La Habra, Calif. Rabbi Samuel Weintraub will officiate at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Unusual Products for The Home
description: JIM SCHNEIDER spent the better part of last weekend standing on a wood-framed, trampolinelike contraption in front of thousands of strangers. It was all in a day's work for Mr. Schneider, one of scores of vendors and contractors who set up shop in the Garden State Convention and Exhibit Center in Somerset, N.J., for the Garden State Home Show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAME, ABRAHAM D.
description: BEAME - Abraham D. The trustees, administration, and faculty of Yeshiva University mourn the recent passing of Mayor Abraham D. Beame, highly esteemed public servant, friend, and 1972 honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree recipient of our University. He dedicated his life to public service. His philanthropic, religious, and community activities and his custodianship of our city were characterized by judicious fairness and trustworthiness in both word and deed. We extend our deepest condolences to his son Bernard, and to his entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman, Board of Trustees Yeshiva University

title: As Good as Their Word In Scrabble Competition
description: IN the late 1940's, just after World War II, a Connecticut couple would while away the hours on their living room floor, sitting before a square game board, competing to create clever combinations of words out of little lettered tiles.

title: Yanks' Owner Speaks His Mind
description: There might be only two Americans more heavily pursued by journalists than the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner -- one is President Bush and the other is Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. Steinbrenner waded into a crowd of reporters today, opened his mouth and made news.

title: Dry Vermouth That Stands On Its Own
description: Although Extra Dry Vya's label announces a ''preferred California vermouth,'' its enchanting bouquet resembles perfume or an aroma therapist's elixir.

title: U.N.L.V. Carries On
description: Surrounded by N.C.A.A. sanctions and speculation, Max Good has performed like a trapeze artist without a net since replacing the fired Bill Bayno as the Nevada-Las Vegas men's basketball coach.

title: New Owner Reuniting Indian Pt. 2 and 3
description: LIKE twins separated at birth, the Indian Point 2 and 3 nuclear power plants in Buchanan are nearly identical but have separate owners.

title: The Nation: Mother's Milk; Breast-Feeding: How Old Is Too Old?
description: SURE, breast-feeding gives babies some of their mother's immunities, protects them against childhood diabetes, leukemia, sudden infant death syndrome, allergies and high blood pressure.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Town Looks to 3 Commercial Projects for Revenue
description: AT the eastern end of Fairfield County's Gold Coast lies the affluent town of Fairfield. A quiet residential community, it was a bit too distant from New York and lower Fairfield County to attract the kind of intense office construction that occurred in Stamford and lower Fairfield County. Not that it cared, until now.

title: A Refuge For Film Buffs Makes Way For a Temple To Fitness
description: The lights have been permanently dimmed at the Art Greenwich Theater, a decades-old movie house at Greenwich Avenue and West 12th Street.

title: Pointing With Pride At Southampton College
description: We at Southampton College of Long Island University read with great interest your Jan. 28 article ''Giving it the Old College Try.'' Certainly many of Long Island's brightest students go elsewhere for college, but programs at many local colleges also attract students to Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANDAU, EVA J.
description: LANDAU-Eva J. February 18, 1982. Who found well deserved rest and peace 19 years ago today. Your loving son, Robert

title: Karen Gulkin, Ted Hirshfield
description: Karen Rene Gulkin, a daughter of Lianne and Stanley Gulkin of West Caldwell, N.J., was married last evening to Edward Robert Hirshfield, a son of Susanne and Stuart Hirshfield of New York. Rabbi Norman Patz officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Students' Pet
description: ''School's In,'' an hourlong Disney Channel special on Tuesday at 7 p.m., features documentary-style vignettes about six educators, including Ron Clark (first row center, with his sixth grade class), who works in Harlem. Andy Lawrence (second row center) is the host.

title: Using a Come-Hither Line To Seduce and Ruin a Foe
description: An effective strategy, when it works, is to feign weakness and lure the opponent to his destruction. This requires that you resuscitate a line of play long thought to be incorrect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATZA, SAM
description: MATZA-Sam, 86. Of Lauderdale Lakes, FL. on February 12, 2001. He was a loving husband, father, grandfather & great-grandfather. He is survived by his wife Kaye, his children Mrs. Florie and Ernie Rudnet of Tamarac, Dr. Barry and Sue Matza of Boca Raton, his grandchildren David and Colleen Rudnet, Vance, Brian, Jeremy and Josh & his great-grandchild, Tyler. Dad, you will be forever in our hearts and always remembered lovingly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ALVIN
description: COHEN-Alvin. 73, Formerly of New York City, currently residing in Scottsdale, Az., passed away February 8, 2001 after a 2 months illness with Valley Fever. He is survived by his wife Paula and three daughters Alisa, Shari and Ynid and two granddaughters Karla and Anika. Services were held in Scottsdale on February 9th.

title: From Grave to Cradle
description: MARY AND O'NEIL

title: Man Held in Subway Push
description: A woman was pushed onto subway tracks in the West Village last night by a homeless man, the police said.

title: Governor's Budget: Is It More Money, or Less?
description: GOV. JOHN G. ROWLAND'S speech on Feb. 7 outlined his $26 billion budget proposal with a series of numbers in the millions: exciting new initiatives, more money for popular causes. Of course, the speech didn't say where all that money was going to come from.

title: Machu Picchu
description: To the Editor: Ted Rose's article about Machu Picchu could easily discourage people from visiting this wonderful archaeological spot. I read his story as I was heading out the door on my way to Peru. Anticipation about Machu Picchu turned to consternation.

title: Authentic American
description: Would anyone believe it was still worth quarreling over who is more authentically American -- Mark Twain or Henry James? Move to other zones of identity, though, and critics are still battling over definition rights to authentic African-American (or Latino-American or Asian-American) literature; a queer sensibility; and writing by women. It isn't the questions I mind, it's certain flat-footed answers that just won't go away. Why are we still tempted to believe there is any one kind of authenticity, that we are the ones who can always recognize it, or that writing marked by one's sex isn't at least as varied and confounding as sex itself?

title: Plan for a Larger, Long-Awaited Library Faces a Crucial Vote
description: Years of effort to bring a larger central library to the Bronx could take a giant step closer to reality this week if the state Public Service Commission approves the sale of a Con Edison building, at 310 East Kingsbridge Road, to the New York Public Library. The commission meets on Thursday in Albany.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Brunelleschi's Dome

title: Pardon Is Trouble for Clinton Library
description: It seems fitting somehow. Bill Clinton's presidential library, which will be charged with telling the story of a presidency compromised by self-infliction, is now itself caught in a storm created by Mr. Clinton's own hand.

title: Juliette Bennett, Scott Greathead
description: Juliette Alden Bennett, a writer and consultant on international peace, and R. Scott Greathead, a lawyer and human-rights consultant, were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Park Bodie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Scene-Stealing Clothes
description: Toile, the scenic-patterned fabric popular for sofas and curtains, is finding a place in human upholstery this spring in hats, handbags, coats, skirts, pants and even suits, for both men and women. While it traditionally depicts people working (men tilling fields, women doing riverside washing), the new fashion toile is decidedly less . . . well, sweaty, with rustic village musicians and romantic balcony tableaux the favored scenes.

title: New Haven and Yale: A Couple With a History
description: FOR much of Yale's history, its significance was overshadowed by other concerns: shipping, then carriage-making, then weapons production.

title: Casa Grande
description: To the Editor: Your article ''Exploring the Wild Edges of Phoenix,'' by Suzanne Winckler (Jan. 14), omitted some useful driver information about the Casa Grande Ruins National Monument.

title: A Tried and True in Chester Only Gets Better
description: FIDDLERS SEAFOOD RESTAURANT in Chester is not a family name, but rather is named for fiddler crabs, a tip-off that seafood is a major player here. Fiddlers aren't on the menu, but seafood fans will find most other briny treats on a menu that changes daily, depending on the market.

title: HOME PRICES
description: The prices for existing homes in New Jersey rose 3.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2000 over the same period a year earlier, but the cost of housing in Bergen and Passaic Counties jumped by nearly 20 percent, the second-highest percentage increase in the nation after the San Francisco Bay Area, according to a survey made public last week by the National Association of Realtors. The median price of a home in Bergen and Passaic was $261,200, a 19.7 percent increase over a year ago. Essex, Somerset, Hudson, Union, and Middlesex counties also saw price increases of 10 percent or more. Karen DeMasters

title: Out With the Old
description: The letterhead says, in large type, Castello di Borghese and, in smaller type, Hargrave Vineyard. It displays the family crest, which is familiar in Italy. Marco and Ann Marie Borghese, who in October 1999 bought the Hargrave Vineyard, may introduce a redesigned label along the same lines this year.

title: The Real Naples
description: To the Editor: As a resident of Naples, Fla., I would like to comment on both the hyperbole and the omissions in Robert Plunket's otherwise well-written article (''In Naples Money Talks, Casually,'' Jan. 14). The real Naples lies somewhere between truck drivers eating grits ''out by the Interstate'' and dot-com millionaires with $25 million second homes.

title: A Spot for Casual Eating in Pawling
description: ONCE filled with quirky dcor and a great deal of noise, the modest dining room of McKinney & Doyle Fine Food has been given a new identity. Some whimsy remains -- the charming wooden bear, a clothesline pinned with dollar bills, brick walls (now hung with tasteful paintings) and a couple of country slogans -- but the room has become more mature, more sober.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-18-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Representative Jim Langevin, Democrat of Rhode Island, Washington, Jan. 3, 2001

title: Where Hotbeds Get a Jump
description: PEOPLE sort of stumble on Bumps & Company, the little nursery that takes its name from the nickname for Gertrude Jekyll, the prickly Victorian gardener. Even if you're looking for the little sign, ''Honey for Sale,'' you're likely to miss it.

title: Different Kind of Canned Excuse
description: Hormel has a reason for weak earnings in late 2000 that nobody else can claim: fewer sales of Spam. Hormel said last week that for its fiscal first quarter ended Jan. 27, earnings fell 5.3 percent from a year earlier, when buyers hoarded Spam, fearing Y2K chaos.

title: St. John's Tries to Avoid Reviewing Its Mistakes
description: After two classic games with Duke, St. John's should have every right to think it can play with the Blue Devils. But the last thing Coach Mike Jarvis wants today is for his players to think they must beat No. 3 Duke to salvage their season.

title: Introduction
description: Many readers praised Brazil's enterprise in coming to grips with AIDS, while others backed the rights of drug companies to protect their patents. Steelers fans bid a reluctant adieu to Three Rivers Stadium, realizing that it is better to lose the hallowed field than the whole team.

title: Running the Gamut at Birch Hill
description: This week the Birch Hill Entertainment Complex continues its eclectic booking policy with two bands, representing two completely different lifestyles, from two distinct parts of the country performing two contrasting styles of rock music.

title: Crouching but Not Hidden, Kung Fu Master in Hit Film
description: Call him Master, but please, do not call him a movie star.

title: Architect of Bush Presidency Still Builds Bridges of Power
description: Inside the White House Cabinet Room on Thursday evening, President Bush waited to receive Republican senators. But his guests were in no hurry. Just outside the door, there was something of a logjam because they wanted, first, to pay respects to the aide who is widely viewed as the principal architect of the Bush presidency: Karl Rove.

title: Glimpses of China Never Seen in China
description: BREAKING taboos and the furniture in a single gesture, a young man in Beijing slams a chair onto his father's head. With that, the shouting stops in Zhang Yuan's ''Sons,'' and silence opens like an abyss -- perhaps the only opening possible in the dim, cramped apartment where the film's characters rub one another raw.

title: When Artists Extend Invitations to Other Artists
description: 'Artists Invite Artists'

title: Political Briefing; The Political Boat Is Rocking in Illinois
description: An unwritten rule in politics is that freshman legislators should keep their ears and eyes open and their mouths shut. But Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald of Illinois, a Republican in office only two years, apparently thinks otherwise.

title: Welcome to the New World of Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Wardrobe Awaits
description: One measure of a hotel used to be how many towels, ashtrays and other items guests took home with them. Now, the Pan Pacific San Francisco near Union Square has come up with another yardstick: what guests leave behind. Repeat visitors can travel light by taking advantage of a deluxe locker service, leaving behind a change of clothes or a more extensive wardrobe. Clothes will be dry cleaned or washed and shoes will be shined, then locked in a cedar-lined closet. Toiletries for the return visit will be supplied as well. The storage is free, but cleaning and toiletries are not. Call (800) 533-6465 or visit www.panpac.com.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARKIN, MILTON
description: BARKIN-Milton. We celebrate the memory of our beloved father and grandfather, a builder and real estate visionary, who would have been 100 years old today. Nannette, Stephen, Sandra, Suzanne and Robert

title: A Softer Way to Fight Drug Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving Fools Gladly
description: The Rescue Season

title: A Walk in the Woods to Discover Trilliums
description: I JUST finished reading Ann Mohin's wonderful novel ''The Farm She Was'' (Bridgeworks Publishing Company, 1998). In it, the author uses the literary device of an elderly person reminiscing about an eventful life, and revitalizes it with lyrical prose passages. The book describes the narrator's rural home ground in central New York State, and when the 90-year-old Irene Leahy describes the woods and fields and the plants that grow there, she strikes a responsive chord with me.

title: First-Term Pardon
description: To the Editor:

title: To Stay Warm In Quebec, Play Outside
description: IN Quebec City, no sports are exclusive to summer, and winter is the most sporting season of all. At home in Toronto, my outdoor activities are limited to shoveling the walkway and negotiating the dirty ice and snow between the curb and my car. To experience a different side of winter, I flew to Quebec City for three days last month to skate, slide, ski and ride a dog sled in or near one of the most beautiful urban landscapes in North America.

title: An Easy, Sometimes Quiet Getaway
description: SLEEK white cruise ships glide down the Hudson River from April through October, carrying passengers some 770 miles miles away to sunny Bermuda. After months of watching them from our studio apartment, my husband, Davis, and I decided to climb aboard. With no planes, traffic jams, or rushed cab rides, it would turn out to be the easiest getaway we ever made.

title: The End of Orthodoxy
description: REFLECTIONS ON EXILE And Other Essays. By Edward W. Said. 617 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $35.

title: Signs of Civility
description: SOMETHING there is that loves a stop sign. At least it does in my village of Hastings-on-Hudson, where last spring's permanent installation of two stop signs in front of the middle and high school complex has given me and all my neighbors pause.

title: As Warnings Flash, Buyers Hit the Brakes
description: The markets lost ground last week, undermined by bad earnings news and troubling economic reports.

title: Pop Music's War of Words; While Eminem Is Attacked, Steely Dan Gets a Free Pass
description: IN the furor that has surrounded this year's Grammy contenders for Album of the Year, it may surprise no one to hear that one of the nominated albums includes a song whose narrator gloats over his affair with an underage girl and tries to pressure her into a threesome. Or that another tune from the album is about a man propositioning his young cousin.

title: COUNTY'S LIAISON TO ITALY
description: Sandy Auriti, a resident of Westchester and a native of Bruzzo, Italy, has been appointed by the county to strengthen Westchester's ties to Italy. In her new position, which pays $1 a year, Ms. Auriti is planning an Italian-American book fair and a film festival. Italian-Americans account for about 21 percent of Westchester's population. Ms. Auriti is vice president of Comites, an Italian Consulate-sponsored organization that promotes cultural events in the region, and works as a publications director for Mondadori, an Italian publishing company in Manhattan. She also teaches Italian at St. John's University. Elsa Brenner

title: Not in My Backyard? That Depends on the Payroll
description: THE Yukon and Northwest Territories, the beautiful but forlorn territories in Canada's distant northern corner near Alaska, have coexisted as peacefully as the caribou that crisscross their vast expanses of tundra and scrubby spruce forests. But the prospect of a multibillion-dollar Alaskan natural-gas pipeline snaking southeast to feed the lower 48 states has touched off a quiet struggle between the two territories to win the project, which could mean prosperity for just one of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, SUZANNE P.
description: JONES-Suzanne P. On Thursday, February 15, 2001. Miss. Jones was President and Owner of Cymru Inc., CT. Memorial service will be held February 26, 2001 at a location to be announced.

title: Corrections
description: Amusic listing on Page 37 of Arts & Leisure today about a Carnegie Hall recital on Tuesday by Cecilia Bartoli refers incorrectly to her singing voice. She is a mezzo-soprano, not a soprano.

title: The Theater in Chicago
description: To the Editor:

title: Muslim Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Lack of Interest in Henderson Endangers His Runs at Ruth and Cobb
description: Rickey Henderson has never been one to rush to get to spring training, but this is ridiculous. Henderson won't be reporting for spring training any time soon because he has nowhere to report to. After 21 years in the major leagues, 1,370 stolen bases, 2,178 runs scored, 2,914 hits and 10,331 at-bats, Henderson has been unable to find a job. No one wants him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFSCHULTZ, FLORENCE
description: LIFSCHULTZ-Florence. 93, beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Bobbie and Larry Rose, Lowell and Betsy Lifschultz. Cherished grandmother of Lynne Breslin and the late Geoff Brown; Curtis and Linda Breslin; Dr. Ken and Debbie Breslin; Laurie and Davy Thomas; Carey Lifschultz and David Stiepleman; Amanda Lifschultz and Julia Lifschultz, and great-grandmother of Adam, Ben and Rebecca Brown, Carly Breslin, Sarah, Zachary and Alex Breslin, and Emma and Noah Thomas. She was loved and admired by her extensive family and friends. Her spirit and celebration of life, and her indomitable will in the face of adversity were an inspiration to those who knew her. She took pure delight in the triumphs of her family and the good fortune of her friends. Wemiss her, but celebrate the richness she has brought to our lives. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Despite Fear, Deregulation Leaves Nuclear Reactors Working Harder, Longer and Safer
description: Last year, technicians at the Pilgrim Nuclear Power Station here found a problem they could not repair in a part of the electrical generator. They called General Electric, which built the part, but were told that that company's expert was moose hunting in Maine. In the old days, Pilgrim's managers would have notified their corporate parent, a Boston utility that did not operate any other reactors, and waited. But now Pilgrim is owned by the Entergy Corporation, a large power company with seven other nuclear plants, which is more eager -- and able -- to keep Pilgrim running.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Diary column on the Investing page last Sunday about the sale of corporate bonds to individual investors mistated the name of an investment bank in Chicago that is selling them. It is Incapital, not Intercapital.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Brazilian Champion as Hero In a Tale of Remarkable Play
description: Last year appears to have set a record for the number of bridge books published, and the quality was high. This department's favorite is ''Fit for a King,'' a collection of entries in the Bols Brilliancy competition organized by the International Bridge Press Association. The authors are Sally Brock and Barry Rigal, who have added considerable flavor by providing biographical sketches and photographs of most of the players and journalists who are featured. The reader is challenged with quizzes based on the problems the players solved or in some cases failed to solve. The book is available for $21.95, including mailing, from Baron Barclay Bridge Supplies, (800) 274-2221.

title: Hoop Dreams, and a Few Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: EVENTS

title: Let Voters Limit Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENSCHOWICZ, JOINE
description: RENSCHOWICZ-Joine. Cherished husband of the late Mania. Beloved father of Annette and Hyman. Loving brother of Helen Reiber. A Holocaust survivor. Services were held Sunday, February 18, 2001, at Parkside Memorial Chapel.

title: Pitching With the Enemy Is Fueling Cone's Fire
description: As David Cone slipped a Boston Red Sox jersey on for the first time today, he said the only thing that gnaws at him about his departure from the Yankees is the notion that he had been disloyal.

title: 400 Anti-Tax Leaders Meet to Plan Campaign
description: Nearly 400 leaders of a fractious, squabbling movement of people who call the tax laws a hoax set aside their differences here today and made plans to conduct a sustained national advertising campaign to expand their numbers.

title: A Latecomer to Web, The New Yorker Hopes to Be a Lasting Site
description: From one perspective, the start last Monday of a companion Web site to The New Yorker might be seen as a conspicuously late arrival to a party when many of the guests were making moves to leave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORI, MARVIN
description: DORI-Marvin. Beloved husband of Sheila. Loving father of Evan Dori, Susan Calise and Jeffrey Marks. Cherished grandfather of Keith and Eric. We will always miss you. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: William H. Masters, Expert on Sex, Dies
description: Dr. William H. Masters, who with his co-researcher, Virginia E. Johnson, revolutionized the way sex is studied, taught and enjoyed in America, died Friday at a hospice in Tucson. He was 85.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Like a market epicenter, Nortel Networks' decline jolts the shares of its suppliers as well.
description: LATE last year, Nortel Networks was confident enough of its standing in the communications equipment industry to rent a plane that circled over a factory operated by its troubled rival, Lucent Technologies, with a banner reading, ''Are your options losing altitude?''

title: Will Sales Prevail?
description: If album sales were the criterion, the rapper Eminem would be assured of winning the Album of the Year award at Wednesday's Grammy ceremony in Los Angeles. His ''Marshall Mathers LP'' has sold eight million copies, according to Soundscan, which monitors music sales. None of the other album nominees have even broken the one-million mark; Steely Dan's ''Two Against Nature'' was second among the best-album candidates with sales of 798,000 copies. But as the results of the last two years indicate, quantity is not always equated with quality. TIM RACE

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the United States and British air strikes in Iraq misspelled the surname of the junior senator from Texas, who called the action a signal that the Bush administration would stand up for America. She is Kay Bailey Hutchison, not Hutchinson.

title: Eddie Mathews, 69, in Hall of Fame With 512 Home Runs
description: Eddie Mathews, the Braves' Hall of Fame third baseman who hit 512 home runs and teamed with Hank Aaron to form the most productive power-hitting combination in baseball history, died yesterday at a hospital in San Diego. He was 69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAUGHAN, CONNIE
description: VAUGHAN-Connie. On February 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Anthony. Devoted mother of Honorable David B. and Dennis J. Cherished mother-in-law of Lorraine and Theresa. Loving grandmother of Dennis, Melissa, Stephen, Brian and Kenneth. Fond great-grandmother of nine. Reposing at Ralph Aievoli & Son Funeral Home, 1275 65 St., corner 13th Ave., Brooklyn, Sunday and Monday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 11:15 AM, St. Ephrem's Church.

title: Victory Is an Impostor at Daytona
description: Michael Waltrip told himself to squeeze out every tear of happiness today before he parked his car in victory lane for the first time at a Nascar Winston Cup race.

title: Hospital Errors
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note
description: An Op-Ed article by former President Bill Clinton yesterday about the pardons of Marc Rich and Pincus Green stated erroneously in some editions that ''the applications were reviewed and advocated'' by three prominent lawyers, Leonard Garment, William Bradford Reynolds and Lewis Libby. Mr. Clinton's office and the lawyers are in agreement that none of the three men, former lawyers for Mr. Rich, reviewed the pardon applications or advocated for the pardons. During the press run, Mr. Clinton's office asked that the reference to ''applications'' be changed to ''the case for the pardons'' to try to clarify Mr. Clinton's point. Even the revised wording, however, could be read as leaving the impression that the lawyers were involved in the pardon process, which Mr. Clinton's spokesmen said was not the intended meaning.

title: Analyze Gore's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Duke and Williams Too Hot For the Red Storm to Handle
description: If Duke is the standard for college basketball, St. John's previous two encounters with the Blue Devils provide affirmation that the Red Storm has been a strong team. Two years ago, St. John's lost in double overtime to Duke, then finished the season one victory short of the Final Four. Last season's team may not have been as talented, yet it produced a stunning victory at Durham, N.C.

title: A Girls' Guide to Renting and Decorating
description: roker" and "Ikea" are two words that often make New Yorkers cringe in a conversation about apartments. But not Dana Johnson. The 22-year-old from Davis, Calif., could not afford to be so picky last June when, two weeks after she graduated from the University of Chicago, she started work as a paralegal at the prestigious New York law firm Cravath, Swaine and Moore. On a recent Sunday afternoon, the curly haired brunette looks me in the eye and says, "This is the first complete weekend I've had off in the last four months." She says her 90-hour work weeks leave her time for little aside from feeding Kira, her cat, and sleeping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, BERNARD M.
description: EPSTEIN-Bernard M. On Saturday, February 17, at age 82, residing at Evergreen Woods, North Brandford, CT. Beloved husband of Ada M. (Bernstein), brother of Inda Goldfarb of Marlboro, NJ. Caring grandfather of eight splendid grandchildren. Services Tuesday, February 20, noon, at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Request no flowers. Donations may be rendered in his memory to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 W. 168th St, NYC 10032-9982.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, ALYCE M., M.D.
description: O'CONNELL-Alyce M., M.D. On February 17, 2001. Beloved wife of Daniel R. Adler. Loving daughter of John and the late Margaret. Dear sister of Ruth, Paula, John and James O'Connell. Reposing at the Urban Funeral Home, 42-17 69th St, Woodside, NY, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Friday about an agreement to take the De Beers diamond business private misstated the change in its stock price. It rose on Thursday by 8.8 rand, to close at 328.4 rand ($41.67); the increase was not 880 rand.

title: Signs of Uneasiness in Seoul Over Change at White House
description: As President Kim Dae Jung prepares to visit Washington early next month for a summit meeting with President Bush, signs of uneasiness have been multiplying here about a possible change in direction in Washington's policy toward the divided Korean Peninsula.

title: Article 2001021994119615312 -- No Title
description: February 15, 2001

title: A Moscow Pooh-Bah, Bearing Up in Brooklyn
description: If there were a translation of the dry bureaucratic job titles Pavel Pavlovich Borodin has held in Russia during the last decade, they would say Kremlin vizier, presidential sidekick, one of the truly powerful.

title: Essay; Lay Off Our Bill
description: I refuse to join the thundering herd of disgusted liberal columnists and irate Democratic politicians in their stampede to castigate our former president for appearing to sell a pardon to a fugitive billionaire.

title: City in a Mouse's Pocket Tries to Move Beyond Its Small World
description: Perhaps nowhere more than in this playground city has an economy so successfully been built on making people believe in make-believe. Now, however, it is the computer wizardry and engineering brainpower behind all those laser shows and thrill rides that the city wants to show off.

title: After Scott Loses Temper, Nets Find Motivation to Win
description: Perspiration and anger dripped from Nets Coach Byron Scott as he sprayed his players with an expletive-filled tirade during a second-quarter timeout today. The listless Nets were down by 19 points to the Los Angeles Clippers, the league's perennial punch line.

title: Mr. Nader's Thesis
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time, Magic Holds Its Ground Against Knicks
description: There would be no dramatic comeback and no heroic rescue by Marcus Camby, no devastating collapse by the Orlando Magic and no stress-relieving victory for the struggling Knicks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Canadian Concern Is Seen In Deal for Unilever Unit

title: CBS and NBC Going Into Overtime in Thursday Night Race
description: The Thursday night fights, already prime-time television's best programming slugfest, will become even more ferociously competitive starting on March 1 when CBS puts the first serious drama in five years into the ring against NBC's mighty ''ER.''

title: A Tchaikovsky Surprise From Russian Capitalists
description: The Russian National Orchestra is in some ways the quintessential post-Soviet ensemble. Formed in 1990 by Mikhail Pletnev, the pianist and conductor, it proudly asserted its status as the country's first orchestra not to be sponsored by the government.

title: Article 2001021991194095742 -- No Title
description: Teenagers Try Online Learning

title: Yo, Suburban B-Boys, Tear It Up; From Rec Rooms to Malls, Complex Break Dancing Is a Hit
description: It was a distinctly suburban scene. On a chilly Saturday night teenagers were smoking cigarettes against a wall in the sprawling Dunning Farm Mall in Middletown, N.Y., while families were making final purchases at T. J. Max and Staples, and youngsters were grabbing a slice at the local pizzeria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATT, RUTH
description: PLATT-Ruth. Beloved wife of Stanley, loving mother of Susan and Alan Finkelstein, and Ann and Jay Goldman. Cherished grandmother of David, Laurie, Andrew and Matthew. Graveside service Monday, 11 AM, at Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Compressed Data; Napster Is Stirring Debate on Art and Ethics
description: The legal issues may still be in play, and the technical outcome is anyone's guess. But in a forum on the Napster controversy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology last week, it was the ethical issues that took center stage.

title: Early Favorite For the Derby: None of the Above
description: You don't know who your Kentucky Derby horse is going to be come the first Saturday in May? Don't worry, you're in good company. Twenty-three 3-year-olds were listed in the future book pool that closed yesterday: Which one did horse players favor in the 28 states where the wager was available?

title: XFL's Audience Tumbles 25% From Earlier Ratings on NBC
description: The NBC television network said yesterday that its preliminary ratings for Saturday night's broadcast of the XFL fell 25.5 percent from the previous week.

title: A Daily Disaster for Children
description: In its ability to remove children from their parents, the state has extraordinary power. Because of the implications for the fundamental rights of families, New York State law requires that when a child is removed involuntarily, there must be an immediate review by a Family Court judge. Both parents and children must have legal representation, and if they are poor, the court must appoint lawyers for them. In the Family Court in New York City, most of these lawyers are drawn from the Assigned Counsel Panel, a group of lawyers that do this work as a major part of their practices.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   STEYER, MURRAY
description: STEYER-Murray. Not a day, Dad...not a day. We love you always. Betsy, Fred and Harr

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about teachers who were upset over the treatment of the Holocaust in a play for schoolchildren in Brooklyn misspelled the surname of a teacher at one point in some copies. She is Shari Fischberg, not Firschberg.

title: Sports of The Times; St. John's Runs Into a Pass-Fail Examination
description: WHEN they enroll in college, students do not expect seminars to be held Sunday at high noon.

title: Bush Speaks at Oklahoma City Museum Dedication
description: On a somber visit to the site of the Oklahoma City bombing, President Bush said today that "one act of malice" had taught lessons of courage and caring and love.

title: How Two Sites Plus Two Casts Equals One Musical
description: In the musical ''1776,'' John Adams attends the Continental Congress while his wife, Abigail, stays home in Braintree, Mass. Although these characters are separated by a great distance, the actors portraying them share the stage as they sing ''Yours, Yours, Yours.'' But what if the Internet allowed them to perform their duet from afar, with one really in Philadelphia, the other really in Massachusetts and an audience looking on from virtually anywhere?

title: One Fewer Place to Unstick a -inicky 'F' Key
description: After more than 66 years in the platen and paper-bail trade, the Tytell Typewriter Company, an iconic repair and rental store in Manhattan, is preparing to close its doors.

title: Compressed Data; Finding a Meaning for 'B2Q' is Quixotic
description: Last Monday, the New Economy column put forth suggestions of how the e-commerce universe might look once the marketers who came up with ''B2B'' (business to business), ''B2C'' (business to consumer) and ''B2G'' (business to government) finished staking claims to the rest of the alphabet. The column made proposals for all of the other letters -- except Q, for which we sought reader guidance. The plea brought scores of ''B2Q'' suggestions.

title: Hoop Dreams, and a Few Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONWAY, ADELYN C. (NEE ROSENFELD)
description: CONWAY-Adelyn C. (nee Rosenfeld). A lady of infinite wisdom and incredible devotion passed quietly on February 16. Beloved mother of Carol Jane Conway Castano. Cherished mother-in-law of Robert Castano. Adored grandmother of Caroline Aaron. Graduate of University of Pennsylvania, Yale Graduate School and Georgetown School of Foreign Service. She was very proud to be one of the first women to serve in the US Foreign Service, being stationed in Germany, England and Burma. In addition, she served here and abroad for the American Red Cross. She will be desperately missed in the lives of many. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to the Women in Military Service Memorial Foundation, Washington, DC, and the Janssen Memorial Hospice of Tuckahoe, NY. Services today, 3 PM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, HELENA (NEE EDEY)
description: JOHNSON-Helena (nee Edey). Age 89, of Far Hills, NJ, on Friday, February 16, 2001. Wife of the late Francis Edgar Johnson Jr. Mother of Dr. Cynthia Mackay of Brooklyn, NY, Helena Bienstock of Princeton, NJ, and Frank E. Johnson III of New York City. Grandmother of Robert L. Mackay, Jessica F. Koehler, Hope M. Crosier, Christina M. Johnson and the late Alison G. Fraker. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 3, at 11 AM, at Lamington Presbyterian Church, Lamington, NJ. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the Clarence Dillon Library, Lamington Rd, Bedminster, NJ 07921, or WNET Channel 13, 450 W 33rd St, NY, NY 10001.

title: The Cannibal Who Evolved Into a Stereotype
description: After the release and failure of ''Manhunter,'' the first film adaptation of a Thomas Harris novel (''Red Dragon'') featuring Hannibal (the Cannibal) Lecter, the serial killer with the on-the-nose nickname, few would have assumed that Lecter would turn out to be so important an archvillain that he would survive the shuttering of the studios, DEG and Orion, that released his first two adventures. Or that the character would go on to be the center of a film -- ''Hannibal,'' which sets Lecter (Anthony Hopkins) loose in a way that makes the rest of the human species his free-range smorgasbord -- that would have the largest box-office opening ever for an R-rated movie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWSTER, MARION D.
description: BREWSTER-Marion D. On February 15, 2001 at age 100. Beloved wife of the late Warren. Mother of Isabel and Vance Van Dine, Thomas S. and Mary, Samuel D. and Eliza and Richard W. and Barbara Brewster. Grandmother of Sylvia and Dale Brewster-O'Connor, Scott, Maxwell, Sophia, Darrah Brewster and the late Rose Van Dine. Sister of the late Jean Thomas. Funeral service at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Avenue at 90th Street, on Tuesday at 12 Noon. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Ladies Christian Union, 118 West 13 Street, New York City 10011.

title: Rights Group Tells of Taliban Massacres
description: Field commanders of the Taliban movement have been involved in the last year in the massacres of several hundred civilians in areas where fighting continues in northern Afghanistan, according to a report to be published today by Human Rights Watch.

title: Mr. Clinton's Explanation
description: In an article published on The Times's Op-Ed page yesterday, former President Bill Clinton made his case that the pardoning of Marc Rich was a legitimate exercise of a president's constitutional authority, based on sound principles of law and foreign policy. We found that case unconvincing as to the legal and constitutional issues involved and evasive in its failure to explain why Mr. Clinton was discussing Mr. Rich's case with major contributors to his party while he kept the Department of Justice in the dark about his consideration of a pardon for one of the nation's most famous tax fugitives.

title: Adapting 'Mormon' to Emphasize Christianity
description: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which has long been concerned that it be understood as a distinctively Christian institution, will step up efforts to discourage use of the term Mormon Church and instead emphasize the name Jesus Christ in references to the church, a leading Mormon official said in an interview on Thursday. It will urge that the church be called first by its full name and then, in subsequent references, the Church of Jesus Christ.

title: Legal Claws Bared Over a Pussycat; Josie's Artist Claims Ownership In Suit Against Archie Comics
description: If you're under the age of 60, you've almost certainly seen the work of an acclaimed artist named Dan DeCarlo. Chances are good you've even bought some of it.

title: Lincoln's Marriage Mirrored the Pain Of His Torn Nation
description: In the last months of the Civil War, unable to see victory despite an escalation of killing, Abraham Lincoln turned to Shakespeare and the Bible. He studied the Book of Job, the classic text on suffering, trying to comprehend the anguish around him.

title: Auditing the Poor
description: During his campaign, President Bush kept promising to remove the ''toll booth on the road to the middle class'' by easing taxes and other burdens on the poor. He could make a start on this pledge by asking Congress to do something about an inequity that Congress itself created -- the disproportionate attention that the Internal Revenue Service pays to the tax returns of the working poor, compared with those of the well-to-do.

title: Warming's Likely Victims
description: Global warming is expected to increase crop yields in temperate northern regions while harming agriculture in the tropics, further widening the gap between rich, industrialized countries and poor developing nations, according to a new analysis by an influential network of scientists.

title: And Again, Balanchine Provocatively Stirs the Pot
description: A pitiful speck of a body, more boy than man, twists, rolls and bounces on the ground to the sound of resonating pings. A femme fatale moves her limbs in hingelike angularity to the rhythm of repeated creaks until her huge cape billows over the entire stage and swallows her along with the crumpled male figure at her feet.

title: But Ministers Tell U.S. And Japan That They Must Stimulate Growth : G-7 Leaders Optimistic On Averting Recession
description: PALERMO, Sicily  The Group of Seven countries, seeking to soothe fears about the impact of the U.S. slowdown on the global economy, signaled cautious optimism that the world would avert recession this year, but they also made clear that the United States and Japan, the two biggest economies, needed to take steps to stimulate growth and recovery.

title: Beneath New Surface, an Undertow
description: Vivian Cabey stood on the stone porch of 60 West 129th Street, collecting her breath and her children after a bruising day at work. On this fall night, darkness had reached the block before she had, and ominous shadows played around her.

title: Labor Leader Sounds Do-or-Die Warning
description: John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., gave an unusual do-or-die warning at a meeting of labor leaders here, telling them that unless unions did far more to increase their ranks, organized labor could drift into irrelevance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, GEORGE
description: KLEIN-George. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of Randy and Robert Martin, Heidi and Jeffrey Quitman, and Hope and David Levy. Adored grandfather of Harrison, Deena and Darien. Dear brother of Flora Lubowsky and Larry Klein. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Tuesday, 12:30 PM.

title: William H. Masters, a Pioneer in Studying and Demystifying Sex, Dies at 85
description: Dr. William H. Masters, who with his co-researcher, Virginia E. Johnson, revolutionized the way sex is studied, taught and enjoyed in America, died Friday at a hospice in Tucson. He was 85 and had lived in retirement since 1994, first in St. Louis and then in Tucson.

title: Changes Made in Liberty Media Cable Deal
description: The Liberty Media Corporation and UnitedGlobalCom Inc. have made changes to their intended merger plan -- aimed at creating the largest cable television operator outside the United States -- after bondholders rejected the transaction.

title: New Economy; For many online companies, customer service is hardly a priority. Just try to find a phone number.
description: ANYONE who signs up to use PayPal, an Internet payment service that has become popular among users of auction sites, must provide it with a lot of personal data: name, telephone, address, e-mail and credit card or banking information.

title: Political Notebook; Back Home In Crawford And Having A Texas Ball
description: A Longhorn steer named Frito loitered outside the Crawford Community Center, tethered to a nearby tree and encircled by white Christmas lights.

title: Canada Company Expected To Buy Unilever's Bakeries
description: George Weston, the Canadian food conglomerate best known for making Girl Scout cookies, is expected to buy Unilever's bakery division for about $1.75 billion in cash, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Article 2001021991565258295 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LEO HARRY
description: BERMAN-Leo Harry. Died February 16, 2001, in his 85th year in Westport, CT. Husband of Dorothy Karg; father of Heather Lee Cantino, and Daniel Paul Berman, father-in-law to Philip and Mindy and sister-in-law to Gladys Berman and grandfather of his very special grandchildren Andrew, Julia, Shaina and Rachael. He married his first wife Jean Wertheimer in 1941. She died in 1985. He received his Bachelor's degree in 1936 from Long Island University, then Masters Degrees in Psychology and Social Work from Columbia University and his M.D. from Edinburgh University in 1949. He completed his training in Psychoanalysis at the New York Medical College in 1956. He was a psychiatrist for the past 50 years and still in practice. He had an incredible love for the world, for all people, for his friends, and professional associates as well as his patients, and his family. He was so very active and interested in the beauty and the complexities of the world. Our dad, husband, and friend surely will be greatly missed. Contributions can be made to either the American Academy of Psychoanalysis, POB 30, 1 Regency Drive, Bloomfield, CT 06002 or Physicians for Social Responsibility, Rockvillen, MD, 800-433-6853. A memorial service will be at 7 PM, on Friday, February 23 at the Unitarian Church of Westport, 10 Lyons Plains Road.

title: New Tapes Appear With Threats by Ukraine's President
description: A newly released secret recording of Ukraine's president, Leonid D. Kuchma, indicates that in the fall of 1999, he ordered his police and tax authorities to undertake a broad campaign of threats and intimidation to ensure that he would win election to a second term as president.

title: Old Ties Give Bush Aide Cachet; Job Gives Him Power
description: OTHER aides are higher on the White House totem pole than Clay Johnson. They spend more time at President Bush's side during the workday. But nobody in the administration has known the president longer.

title: Mount St. Michael Wins Championship
description: Mount St. Michael of the Bronx, with Ron Hussey winning two events, took its first Catholic High Schools Athletic Association boys' indoor team title in six years yesterday. Holy Trinity of Hicksville, N.Y., won its first girls' championship.

title: Media Marriage of Convenience Yields Best Seller
description: In 1966, the NBC television network broke new ground in the marketing of both recorded music and television programming with the appearance of ''The Monkees'' -- a made-for-TV band that also sold its own records. Now NBC and HarperCollins Publishers are trying something similar with a book, and it is working like a charm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVI, JOSEPH
description: LEVI-Joseph. Died peacefully on February 18, 2001, in his 95th year. Loving husband of the late Ruth. Adored and beloved father of Adina and Michael Levine and Haskel Levi. Cherished grandfather of Mindy and Michael Mervis, Joanne Levine and Noah Sabin, Robin Levi and John Hays. Greatgrandfather of Jake, Rebecca, Julia and Hannah. title: E-Commerce Report; After rushing Internet kiosks into their stores, retailers are trying to refine them, to make them useful and profitable.
description: IN 1999, when traditional retailers scrambled to build defensive positions against Internet competitors, the phrase ''clicks and mortar'' was their battle cry. For many merchants, that strategy -- to use both traditional and online stores to reach consumers -- was embodied by Internet kiosks, which sprang up in the aisles of Gap, Staples and Borders, among others.

title: Refugees in Kenya Tell of Shakedown by U.N. Agency
description: Dahir is too afraid to give his full name, and for good reason: he is a refugee. So far, at least three people with far more standing -- Western workers at the United Nations here -- have received death threats. For their safety, they were flown out of Kenya. No one will do that for Dahir.

title: The World Champs Go Global
description: The New York Yankees announced a marketing alliance earlier this month with Manchester United, the English soccer club. The deal between two of the world's most valuable sports teams signals their desire to become truly global franchises, and their inability to do so on their own. Baseball has an avid following in the Caribbean and in Japan, but it is not clear that America's pastime will catch on elsewhere. Nor is it clear whether soccer, the world's most popular game, will ever conquer America.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Saturday about the United States and British air strikes in Iraq misspelled the surname of the junior senator from Texas, who called the action a signal that the Bush administration would stand up for America. She is Kay Bailey Hutchison, not Hutchinson.

The new Friendly's down the street from Thomas J. White Stadium sells Mets ice cream cakes. New banners hailing the team decorate the town's main strip.

In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to the Brearley School, 610 East 83rd Street, New York, New York 10028, attention: Development Office. May she rest in peace.

But in many cases, only a fraction as many Americans will soon find themselves unemployed.

description: Balthasar Klossowski, the painter internationally known as Balthus, died yesterday at his chalet in La Rossinire, Switzerland, near Gstaad. He was 92.

title: A Mozart Work Stressing Togetherness
description: Mozart's ''Cos Fan Tutte'' is a true ensemble work. Performed without the arias, the opera would lose some sublime music but still make sense. Ensembles dominate the score and the stage action. So above all a good production requires the cast and the orchestra to work together. And collaboration was the strongest aspect of the Metropolitan Opera's ''Cos Fan Tutte,'' conducted by Patrick Summers, which opened on Saturday night.

title: MediaTalk; Morgan Stanley Wants Apology from Journal
description: Christian L. Curry has been gone from the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter investment bank longer than he worked there. But Mr. Curry, who was fired in 1998 after nude pictures of him appeared in a magazine aimed at gay men, is far from forgotten.

title: INSIDE
description: Balthus Dies

title: Humbled by the Genome's Mysteries
description: Two groups of researchers released the formal report of data for the human genome last Monday -- on the birthday of Charles Darwin, who jump-started our biological understanding of life's nature and evolution when he published ''The Origin of Species'' in 1859. On Tuesday, and for only the second time in 35 years of teaching, I dropped my intended schedule -- to discuss the importance of this work with my undergraduate course on the history of life. (The only other case, in a distant age of the late 60's, fell a half-hour after radical students had seized University Hall and physically ejected the deans; this time at least, I told my students, the reason for the change lay squarely within the subject matter of the course!)

title: Suit Accuses Federal Contractors of Mishandling Cleanup at Nuclear Lab
description: Buried in underground tanks and dumped into trenches at the Idaho National Engineering and Environmental Laboratory northwest of here is a witches' brew of deadly chemicals and radioactive waste left over from the cold war. It includes enough plutonium debris from the Rocky Flats weapons plant in Colorado to build hundreds of nuclear bombs.

title: Federal Panel Warns Bush Of Social Security Problems
description: The quality of service provided to the public by the Social Security Administration has deteriorated in recent years, and the problems are likely to grow as millions of baby boomers retire, a federal advisory panel has told the Bush administration.

title: Bush's Call to Church Groups Attracts the Untraditional
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13  After eight years in prison, Joseph Fabio now lives in a halfway house next to a funeral home here, where counselors have helped him steer clear of drugs, find a job in a gas station and contain the uncontrollable anger that earned him a murder sentence at age 18.

description: The icecap atop Mount Kilimanjaro, which for thousands of years has floated like a cool beacon over the shimmering plain of Tanzania, is retreating at such a pace that it will disappear in less than 15 years, according to new studies.

title: Two-For-One Cruise
description: The Radisson Diamond, a 350-passenger twin-hull ship, is selling four- and five-night cruises from San Juan, Puerto Rico, on a two-for-one basis in March and April. With the discount, rates start at $1,996 per cabin on the four-night trips, which stop at Virgin Gorda, in the British Virgin Islands, St. Barts and St. Martin. On the five-night sailings, which add a stop in St. Thomas, rates begin at $2,396 a cabin. Fares include tips and wine with dinner. Air fare to San Juan is extra. By securing a deposit with a credit card when booking, you will also get a $200 credit per cabin for purchases on the ship. All cabins have an ocean view. Call (800) 285-1835 or visit www.rssc.com .

title: Shades of 2000, Wilpon Has High Expectations
description: Fred Wilpon was having a very good day. His golden retriever, Lefty, was chasing a ball around a practice field. Judy, his wife, and Sandy Koufax, his best friend for the past 50 years, were here. His manager and general manager are locked into new contracts and his team is the National League champion.

description: Dale Earnhardt, the legendary stock car driver known as the Intimidator for his blunt demeanor, his push-broom mustache and his steely, unrelenting driving style, was killed today in an accident on the last lap of the Daytona 500. He was 49.

title: Runyan Beats Clock in the 5,000
description: Marla Runyan, running the last 14 laps by herself, set an American indoor record for 5,000 meters, 15 minutes 7.33 seconds, yesterday in a special New York Road Runners Club challenge race at the Armory Track and Field Center in Manhattan.

title: Clinton's Defense of Pardons Brings Even More Questions
description: Leaders of House and Senate committees examining former President Bill Clinton's decision to pardon a fugitive financier said today that Mr. Clinton's latest and most detailed defense of his decision raised fresh questions that needed to be investigated.

description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, strapped for cash and desperate to find new income, has begun charging a universal fee for prescription drugs at the pharmacies of all its public hospitals and community clinics.

title: Rice Feeling Deadline Pressure
description: Glen Rice has heard the rumors and read the newspapers, and he admits they have made him a bit testy. With the trade deadline approaching -- slowly, in Rice's judgment -- he is worried about being dealt to another team. He said before tonight's game against the Orlando Magic that his insecurity has made it hard to focus solely on basketball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ANITA J.
description: WEINSTEIN-Anita J. Born February 3, 1908, died early Sunday morning, February 18, 2001, of complications from lung cancer. Ms. Weinstein will always be loved and missed by her brother Walter Freed, grandchildren Wendy and Geoffrey Alexander, great-granddaughter Morgan Alexander, and her devoted friend Beverly Malcolm.

title: Stock Car Star Killed on Last Lap of Daytona 500
description: Stock car racing's greatest current star and one of its most popular and celebrated figures, Dale Earnhardt, crashed and was killed today after he made a characteristically bold lunge for better position on the last turn of the last lap of the sport's premier event, the Daytona 500.

title: Kurds, on Riviera, Recall Horrors of Week at Sea
description: The contrast could not have been starker: 908 Kurdish migrants, unfed and unwashed after seven days at sea, huddled on the glittering coast of the Riviera, where the masses normally arrive in summer sporting sunglasses, skimpy sunwear and well-toned tans.

title: Patents; In health emergencies, Brazil allows the copying of drugs, to the dismay of American companies.
description: COUNTLESS pharmacies serve the nearly 20 million people living in this enormous city, including a chain called Drogeria So Paulo that features 24-hour franchises nestled next to all-night gas stations. Inside one of those drug stores on Vincenzo Rao Street, a large red and white sign hanging from the ceiling declares: ''We have generics. Look at our list.'' An arrow points down to a six-page list printed from a Web site and propped on a counter display.

title: Earnhardt Dies in Crash
description: Dale Earnhardt Sr., stock car racing's greatest star, died yesterday in a crash on the last lap of the Daytona 500, Nascar's premier event and its season opener. Earnhardt, 49 years old, was locked in a battle for third place when his Chevrolet grazed another car and hit a concrete wall. He was cut from his battered car and pronounced dead of head injuries at a hospital. Earnhardt's teammate Michael Waltrip won the race, and his son, Dale Jr., was second. Obituary, SportsMonday, Page D3.

description: Philanthropy, one of the nation's most spectacular growth industries for the last decade, is feeling the pinch of the market turnaround, several indicators suggest.

title: Singing the Praises of Love, Romantic and Otherwise
description: It is difficult to believe that the King's Singers gave their first concert as long ago as 1968. None of the original members of this British vocal sextet remain, and several members of the current ensemble, which performed at St. Bartholomew's Church on Wednesday evening, were born in the 1970's. Even so, the group's style and characteristically flexible vocal blend remain largely intact, as does the eclecticism that has long driven its programming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LEONARD
description: LEVINE-Leonard. Age 81. We mourn the death, on February 18, of our beloved husband, loving father and grandfather.

description: Elisabeth Rosenthal, a New York Times correspondent in Beijing and a physician, visited North Korea Feb. 6-10 with AmeriCares, a private, United States-based relief organization that was inspecting the use of aid it had already provided to North Korea. Two days after Dr. Rosenthal arrived, North Korean authorities told her that she could not work as a reporter during the trip. She said she could not continue the visit under those circumstances, and later left the country.

title: The Key Vanishes: Scientist Outlines Unbreakable Code
description: A computer science professor at Harvard says he has found a way to send coded messages that cannot be deciphered, even by an all-powerful adversary with unlimited computing power. And, he says, he can prove it.

title: Air Traffic Paralysis
description: The nation's air traffic congestion can no longer be thought of as merely an annoyance, or a nettlesome transportation issue. It is a growing economic ill as well, and the Bush administration ought to address it as such. Instead of seeking to cut the Federal Aviation Administration's 2002 budget by some $568 million, as proposed by the Office of Management and Budget, President Bush should develop a comprehensive long-term strategy to meet the growing demand for air travel. Thinking of ways to speed up the development of new satellite navigation systems and the building of new runways at major airports would be a good start.

title: Corrections

It is the World Psychiatric Association, not the World Psychological Association.

''If they're going to take my money they should be a little faster about it before I change my mind,'' said Richard Turrin, a wry smile cutting across his chiseled face. Actually, Mr. Turrin, a ''blissfully unemployed'' investment banker, didn't give a hoot about waiting forever to buy merchandise at the first day of Barneys Warehouse Sale, a twice-a-year ''New York institution,'' as he put it.

title: Why a Job at a Record Club Isn't So Cool, After All
description: It's hard to fathom why a film as irritating as ''The Target Shoots First'' should also be so impossible to turn off. Somehow this documentary, in which a young man named Christopher Wilcha chronicles his two years of employment at a record club, manages to make the inconsequential very compelling. Maybe it's a Gen X thing.

title: Our Soldiers Didn't Volunteer for Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Moose Must Relearn Lessons in Survival
description: The reintroduction of large carnivores like bears and wolves to areas they used to populate is in vogue these days, and when such a reintroduction occurs, the result, initially at least, can be a field day for the predators and a rout for their prey.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Feb. 9 about ''Correggio and Parmigianino: Master Draftsmen of the Renaissance,'' at the Metropolitan Museum, misstated the year Parmigianino was born. It was 1503, not 1403.

title: Undaunted By the Legend; A Young Actress Finds the Spirit Of Anne Frank in a New Mini-Series
description: It was of course not her death in the Holocaust that distinguished Anne Frank, but her life, above all the writing talent and ebullient personality that shine from the pages of her ''Diary of a Young Girl.'' And yet, in the half-century since her journal was published, the image of Anne Frank the martyr has taken over, her wartime hideout in Amsterdam visited as a shrine even by those who have never read her words.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Feb. 12 and last Tuesday, Friday and Saturday, and in some copies on Sunday, about the Navy submarine collision that sank a Japanese training ship misstated the rank of Scott D. Waddle, the officer in charge of the submarine. He is a commander, not a lieutenant commander.

title: With Wit and Some Surprises, A Beast Emerges From Within
description: The French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj has one of the most fertile minds on the international dance scene. Yet his works, highly physical in their energy and innovative virtuosity, are not dry and cerebral.

title: Woman, 77, Is Pushed Off Terrace and Dies
description: A mentally disturbed man pushed his 77-year-old grandmother to her death from the 21st-floor terrace of her Harlem apartment yesterday afternoon, the police said. The man, Rashaan Lamb, 24, then held the police at bay for nearly two hours before he was grabbed while dangling his legs from the terrace, said Detective Edward Reuss.

title: Roger Caras, 72, Animal Welfare Advocate
description: Roger A. Caras, one of the most prominent public voices for animal welfare as a popular writer, broadcast personality, A.S.P.C.A. president and announcer for the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, died Sunday in Towson, Md. He was 72 and lived on a farm in Freeland, Md.

title: The Neediest Cases; On Wall and Other Streets, Hopes for Record Giving
description: As the amount of money recorded by The New York Times Neediest Cases fund steadily creeps closer to $8 million, the average daily amount declines. If donations continue to flow into the fund at the rate they have this month, the fund will fall short of that figure.

title: Wildlife and Derricks Coexist But the Question Is the Cost
description: At the mouth of the Mississippi, at Louisiana's far southern tip, a marsh that is home to alligators, herons, egrets, ospreys, spoonbills and more than 200 other species has since 1935 enjoyed protected status as the Delta National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Kraft Sues Big Pizza Rival Over Loss of Trade Secrets
description: In a case that brings the cloak-and-dagger world of corporate espionage to, of all places, the frozen pizza aisle, Kraft Foods, the nation's biggest food producer, has sued its biggest rival in the grocery pizza business, Schwan's Sales Enterprises, charging that Schwan's improperly obtained trade secrets.

description: Last week two rival teams reported their first glances at the human genome. Analysis of the genome continued to dominate this week's news as well.

title: Doubters Fault Theory Finding Earlier Puberty
description: A widespread belief about the onset of puberty in girls is coming under vigorous attack, led by a group of medical specialists who say that it is based on flawed science and that it can have dire medical consequences.

title: A Concert as Chocolate Box, Loaded With Sugar
description: Dianne Reeves's Valentine's Day show at Avery Fisher Hall, presented by Jazz at Lincoln Center, matched the holiday it celebrated perfectly: it stirred in liberal amounts of saccharine with the real thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTER, JAY
description: POSTER-Jay. On February 18, 2001. Beloved son of Murray and the late Natalie. Devoted and loving partner of Alan Krevis. Dear brother of Steven and the late Richard and brother of Joanne. Loving uncle of Stacey. Keep smiling. Services on Tuesday, at 1PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale.
