description: The On Horse Racing column yesterday, about this year's top 3-year-old horses, misstated the date of the Florida Derby. It is March 10, not May 11.

title: Barak Turns Down Sharon and Leaves Politics Again
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21  Ehud Barak quit politics for the second time in two weeks early today. He resigned as Labor Party chairman in the face of bitter internal opposition, and declined Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon's invitation to serve as defense minister.

title: Sleepy Boys and Double Trouble
description: Letting a toddler skip a nap can raise the odds of a trip to the emergency room, especially for boys, a new Italian study suggests.

title: Low-Tech Wins in Gauging Infant Health
description: In a victory for low technology, a study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine found that the Apgar test, which is a quick visual checklist applied to newborns, was a better predictor of distress than a newer method of testing the acidity of blood from the umbilical cord.

title: Reporter's Notebook; All Rise? Not So Fast
description: In some ways, the embassy bombings trial is like an Andrew Lloyd Webber musical: it takes a good long time for the stage to be set and the characters to take their appointed places before the curtain rises every day.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile and a picture caption yesterday about Clay Johnson, director of presidential personnel, misstated the name of the prep school attended by Mr. Johnson and President Bush. It is Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., not Andover Academy.

title: Bench Warmer
description: To the Editor:

title: Energy East Agrees to Buy RGS Energy in a $1.4 Billion Deal
description: The Energy East Corporation, the upstate New York concern that owns New York State Electric and Gas, plans to announce today that it has agreed to acquire the RGS Energy Group, a Rochester-based energy company, for $1.4 billion.

title: Some Caution Signals for Older Drivers
description: Last summer, as a 72-year-old friend exited from a strip mall in Connecticut, her car was struck broadside by an van she had not seen coming. She died three days later of complications related to her injuries.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Time Is No Fugitive Here
description: Thomas Hobbes, the 17th century British political thinker, once described human existence in nature as nasty, brutish and short. Paul W. Butler, one of the prosecutors in the bombings case, once described the terrorism trial as long, complicated and chilling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, LISA
description: FISHMAN-Lisa. Loving partner to Stuart and a bright light to so many, Lisa's ebullient spirit will forever reside in our hearts. Parke, Nina and Steven

title: Article 2001022090961157924 -- No Title
description: Teenagers Try Online Learning

title: Napster Offers Deal to Record Companies
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 - Outlining plans to transform into a fee-based service, Napster said today that it intends to start charging users this summer to exchange music files online. And the company said it has proposed giving $1 billion over 5 years to record companies, including the major record labels that sued Napster after accusing it of abetting copyright infringement.

title: Racer's Death Leaves Hole in Heart of His Hometown
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C., Feb. 20  His death brought a silence to the Wal-Mart.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Composite, Fix Thyself

title: Sports of The Times; Nascar Gets A Green Flag Amid Deaths
description: IT was exactly four years ago, during the stretch run of the Daytona 500, that I got my first close-up look at a freshly mangled racing car. It happened to belong to Dale Earnhardt, then 45 and still looking for his first victory in what is known as Nascar's Super Bowl.

title: Love Your Genuineness, Guys, and Matching Pants
description: The feat of filling Madison Square Garden can tie the tongues of the most loquacious musicians. The Barenaked Ladies expressed their joy at hitting this pinnacle late in their Thursday show. Suddenly the group's strapping drummer, Tyler Stewart, leapt forward and pirouetted across the stage as if he were Bambi blissfully chasing a butterfly. ''I guess some people can find ways to express it,'' quipped his bandmate Steven Page.

title: Giuliani, Meet Balthus: Trying to Root Out 'Pornography'
description: The painter Balthasar Klossowski, known as Balthus, who died Sunday, was born on Feb. 29, 1908, leap day. The poet Rainer Maria Rilke once told him that this was like slipping through a crack in time, which gave him access to a ''kingdom independent of all the changes we undergo.'' Balthus enjoyed that idea and adopted it as a kind of creed, living in an archaizing and exotic realm of his own devising in his enormous chalet in Switzerland, where he painted pictures that seemed out of time and, to a fickle, amnesiac American art world, out of touch.

title: We Should Witness the Death of McVeigh
description: After 30 years directing funerals, I've come to believe in open caskets. A service to which everybody but the deceased is invited, like a wedding without the bride or a baptism without the baby, denies the essential reality of the occasion, misses the focal point. It is why we comb wreckage, drag rivers and bring our war dead home. Knowing is better than not knowing, no matter how difficult the facts; and seeing, it turns out, is believing. That's what hurts, the heart-sore widow says of the body in the blue suit in the box. Births, deaths, marriages -- the fashions of these passages change, but the fundamental obligations of witness and remembrance remain. And whether we bear witness to the joy or sadness, the love or grief, the life or death, the sharing of it makes the bearing of it better.

title: Financier's Partner Remained Loyal Lieutenant Throughout
description: As lawyers and lobbyists for the fugitive financier Marc Rich hurried to orchestrate a pardon in the waning months of the Clinton administration, much attention was paid to getting the application just right.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Feb. 12 and last Tuesday, Friday and Saturday, and in some copies on Sunday, about the Navy submarine collision that sank a Japanese training ship misstated the rank of Scott D. Waddle, the officer in charge of the submarine. He is a commander, not a lieutenant commander.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: National Park Status Sought For Paterson Waterfall Site
description: New Jersey's two United States senators and one of its House members opened a campaign today to create a national park around the Great Falls, Paterson's landmark and the essence of its birth as a major manufacturing center after the Revolutionary War.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Testing the Limits of the Western Dream
description: As we write, we are sitting in paradise. To our west, the Front Range of the Rockies looks like a Bierstadt painting. If you want your soul to soar, this is the direction to look in. New snow has put the contours of the mountains in high relief. Once on the ground, Rocky Mountain snow almost always skips the familiar East Cost stage of blackened, sludgy heap, instead graciously melting under the bright sunlight. No wonder everyone wants to join us.

title: Tempers Flare and Losses Mount After Canada Bans Brazil Beef
description: The anti-Canadian displays were mild at first, starting with a local radio station's ban on music by Alanis Morissette, a native of Ottawa. Restaurateurs and bar owners publicly dumped out bottles of Molson beer. And demonstrators dressed as Mounties held a barbecue in front of the Canadian consulate.

title: 2 Companies Weigh Future Of Phone Deal
description: AT&T and British Telecommunications are in talks to make significant changes to their $7 billion joint venture, which provides communications services to large corporations, people close to the talks said.

title: PURCHASE OF BAKING UNIT CONFIRMED
description: The Canadian food producer and retailer George Weston Limited confirmed that it had agreed to buy the Bestfoods baking unit of Unilever for $1.76 billion. Weston was a surprise buyer for the unit, whose brands include Entenmann's, Thomas' and Arnold; it outbid the two companies widely expected to win, Sara Lee Corporation and Grupo Bimbo de Mexico. Weston, based in Toronto, said it would now focus on baked goods and will sell its dairy and fish processing operations in Canada.

title: Hunting bin Laden's Allies, U.S. Extends Net to Europe
description: Spurred by growing international alarm about Osama bin Laden's militant networks, the police in Britain and Germany have recently arrested more than a dozen Islamic radicals. American officials say some of those arrested were plotting terrorist attacks in Europe and elsewhere.

title: Emotions Escalate at Hearing on Killings of Israeli Arabs
description: An Israeli Arab couple lost control today as a border police officer suspected of fatally shooting their son took the witness stand a few feet from them.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about China's practice of committing members of the Falun Gong spiritual movement to psychiatric hospitals misstated the name of a medical organization that is being asked to bar China from its convention next year. It is the World Psychiatric Association, not the World Psychological Association.

title: A Woman Emerges to Offer Peru an Alternative
description: Elderly women jumped out of their rocking chairs and little girls tugged at their mothers' dresses in excitement as Lourdes Flores's presidential campaign caravan moved through the rutted streets of this northern jungle town.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIANO BUYERS FOR HYUNDAI LIFE

title: Tributes Are Expressed by Fans of All Ages
description: Bill Moormann called home this morning, just before he and his friends would begin the 16-hour drive back to New Jersey. His 11-year-old daughter, Michelle, had been waiting for his call.

title: Intel Limits Hiring, Defers Some Raises
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20  The Intel Corporation announced today a wide range of cost-saving measures, including delayed raises for employees but not layoffs, intended to counter a slowing economy.

title: Tripoli Journal; Behind Thick Walls, a Defiant Past
description: Winter winds gusting off the nearby Mediterranean Sea hurl sand into the broken windows of a long, mustard-colored stone building that squats outside the imposing walls of old Tripoli.

title: In the wake of a sales setback, Sprite's advertising is revised.
description: THE advertising for Sprite, the popular lemon-lime soft drink sold by the Coca-Cola Company, is being revised significantly for the first time in almost seven years, following a rare decline in the brand's sales and market share.

title: Mergers in Australia Stir A Debate Over Competition
description: Caught between the competing pressures of global consolidation and energetic antitrust enforcement, many Australian companies are coming to the uncomfortable realization that they may have become both too big to merge and too small not to.

description: To the Editor:

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

And the Nascar Winston Cup series will move on, too, heading to its next stop this weekend despite the death of Dale Earnhardt during the Daytona 500 on Sunday.

title: Fresh Dynasties Sprout in Post-Soviet Lands as Democratic Succession Withers
description: The demise of President Heydar A. Aliyev, 77 years old and a survivor of major heart surgery, is so nearly unthinkable in this former Soviet republic, which he has dominated for most of the last three decades, that the local press refers to it only as Event X.

title: Armenia and Azerbaijan Signal Progress in Talks on Enclave
description: After seven years of an uneasy truce and stalled peace talks, signs of progress have emerged in the dispute between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh.

description: The mere mention of the name made Latrell Sprewell perk up. Just moments after Sunday night's tough loss to the Orlando Magic, an animated Sprewell appeared energized enough to run through another 48-minute game. His fervor was all because of the Miami Heat.

description: Clara Miller's son-in-law drives her to school, carries her heavy book bag, steers her around patches of ice in the parking lot and runs interference in the stairwells where undergraduates push and shove.

title: Detroit's Answer to 'Hybrid' Cars; Cheaper Than Japan Models, But Far Less Fuel Efficient
description: Japanese automakers have led the way in selling ''hybrid'' cars, which have improved fuel economy and reduced tailpipe emissions by running on either gasoline or electricity. But the Toyota Prius and Honda Insight, on the American market for a year, are costly to produce and sold in limited numbers at a loss. So Detroit is trying a middle ground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, DOUGLASS
description: CAMPBELL-Douglass. We have known Douglass from the viewpoint of friends and office colleagues for many years and knew him as a person that belonged to another age; yet one who had a timeless, gentlemanly dignity. His love of life kept him buoyant. He was unique for his many passions ranging from opera and theater, to raising orchids and collecting the rare and beautiful. He had an exceptional engagement in both charitable causes and current events, and had an appreciation for an ardent conversation about politics. Although he was a steadfast Republican, his attitude to those few of us Democrats in the office was an amusing ''de gustibus non disputandum est''. Or, in plainer words, there is no accounting for bad taste. We will miss his presence in the office greatly. Alpha Finance Resource Holdings

title: In Winter Slumber, Visions of Brackets

Yes, it has been all year, but outside any fan's particular home team or conference, it has become increasingly difficult not to hit the snooze button and wait to take a wide view of college basketball. It's a long season, cable television offers almost nightly wall-to-wall coverage and, as in entertainment and politics, too many images make the truth hard to ascertain.

title: Burning to Be a Part Of That Yankee Magic

The conversation yesterday bounced from his new contract, worth nearly $40 million, to how he got food poisoning to the importance of having a healthy David Justice in the Yankees' lineup. No matter where the discussion swerved, Rivera kept chewing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, MARTHA PAULA RUPPANER KNOWN AS POPPI
description: THOMAS-Martha Paula Ruppaner known as Poppi. Died suddenly on February 18, 2001 at her vacation home at Tryall, Jamaica. She was 85. The widow of Joseph A. Thomas, she was the beloved stepmother of Michael M. Thomas of Brooklyn, N.Y. and Jeffrey F. Thomas of San Francisco, CA. She is survived by her stepsons and their families, by her cousin, Dr. Pedrin Tondury of Switzerland and by numerous loving friends. Among the latter must be counted the denizens of the Animal Kingdom, whose interests she tirelessly served as a longtime Board member of the Wildlife Conservation Society (formerly the New York Zoological Society) and the Animal Medical Center (of which she was Board Chair Emerita and recipient of its ''Top Dog'' and Brook Astor awards). Interment will be private. Memorial services will be scheduled in Old Brookville, L.I. and Jamaica at later dates. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Wildlife Conservation Society or the Animal Medical Center.

description: Robert Tilove, a pension expert who helped draft state and federal pension laws, died on Feb. 9 in Mitchellville, Md. He was 86 and was a former resident of Baldwin, N.Y. and Roosevelt, N.Y.

description: Improbably and imperfectly, the baseball lives of Al and Mark Leiter have finally intersected. Their lockers are side by side in the Mets' clubhouse at Thomas J. White Stadium, and the pitchers needle each other playfully, as brothers do.

description: Another typewriter store is going out of business; a few more of the shrinking qwerty minority shudder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, ROBERT SMITH
description: SHEA-Robert Smith. Colonel and Reverend. Died February 15, 2001 in his 79th year in New York, New York. The New York Society of Military and Naval Officers wishes to express its deepest sympathy for the loss of our Chaplain, Colonel Robert S. Shea, who served far and above the call of duty not only for the members of our Society, but for the soldiers, airmen, sailors and veterans with whom he came in contact both while on active service and in his retirement. Colonel Shea received his B.A. from St Bonaventure University in 1943, his Master's in Education from St. Bonaventure University in 1948, his M.A. from Tulane University in 1949, and his Doctorate in Education from Columbia University in 1967. In civilian life, he served as Dean of Marymount College in N.Y.C. His career in the U.S. Air Force earned him the Joint Services Commendation Medal, the U.S. Air Force Commendation Medal, the U.S. Air Force Reserve Medal, the World War II Victory Medal, the New York State Medal of Military Commendation, and numerous other federal and state military medals and awards. Those of us in the Society will miss his dedication and personal warmth as a Chaplain and as a dear friend. May he rest in peace. Viewing will be at Church of the Guardian Angels, 10th Ave between 22nd and 23 St, Manhattan on Tuesday, February 20, from 12:30-1:30 PM. The mass will be held at 1:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORI, MARVIN
description: DORI-Marvin. The residents of Round Dune, Quogue N.Y. note with deep sorrow the passing of our dear friend, Marvin Dori. Our sincere condolences to Sheila and family. Gale Spitalnik, Pres.

Your lifelong keen intellect, quick wit and indefatigable spirit were precious gifts that will enrich us for generations.

title: In the Best Wagner Scenario, Clarity Comes From the Pit
description: Something astonishing is happening at the Netherlands Opera this month: a production of ''Tristan und Isolde'' in which the orchestral performance is so beautiful, expressive and transparent that the score just glows. The playing elevates the singers, both by encouraging them to excel themselves and by giving them such immense, passionate inner lives. It also makes the staging a side issue -- especially to the bulk of the audience, which is sitting in balconies and therefore able to watch the music as it happens in the large pit in front of the proscenium.

title: Protection for Nurses
description: To the Editor:

title: NO BUYERS FOR HYUNDAI LIFE
description: The Hyundai Life Insurance Company and two other debt-ridden Korean insurers failed to attract buyers in a government auction, further stalling Korea's plan to clean up its financial industry. The government failed to attract bids for Hyundai, Hanil Life Insurance and Samshin Allstate Life Insurance by last Friday's deadline. The failed auction left the government without a backup plan for the three insurers, which have only 1.6 percent of the life insurance market. ''There were no bids for the insurers because whoever takes over these companies will only be assuming more debt,'' said Song Yoon Young, a banking analyst at the firm of Shinhan Securities in Seoul. ''Who would want to end up with more debt?''

title: CHANGE STIRS HOPE FOR LEGAL STATUS AMONG IMMIGRANTS
description: An obscure change in immigration law passed in the waning days of the Clinton administration could lead to legal status for as many as half-a-million illegal immigrants, but it could also lead to disappointment for millions more who have misinterpreted the change as a general amnesty.

title: As Diabetes Strikes Younger, Children Get Lessons in Defense
description: Every Tuesday after school, 9-year-old Ashley Moreno and a few classmates get together and play how-to-prevent-diabetes games -- not the sort of extracurricular activity that would thrill most fourth graders.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Wise Look At the Future

title: HOSTILE BID FOR SULZER
description: A Swiss venture capital firm, InCentive Capital of Zug, made an unsolicited $2.6 billion bid for Sulzer A.G., the Swiss machinery company. InCentive Capital, Sulzer's largest shareholder with 15 percent, said it wants to spin off the Sulzer Medica unit, which is Europe's biggest maker of orthopedic devices, and integrate the other units before selling them as well. The offer represents a premium of about 11 percent on Sulzer's market value. InCentive Capital led a successful shareholder revolt last year to block Sulzer's management from buying back the 26 percent of Medica's stock now in the hands of investors. Elizabeth Olson

title: Clinton and the Pardons: The Raging Storm
description: To the Editor:

title: Collapse of Health System Adds to North Korea's Crisis
description: In the dim light of their frigid ward at the South Pyongan Provincial Children's Hospital, Kim Yuk and Kwang Sun listlessly fingered the small colored blocks that had been placed on their bed. They were too weak to be interested and too cold to come out from under their thick red covers anyway. It was 10 below outside, and a pot-bellied stove provided the room's only heat.

title: Top Reality Producer May Help CBS to Revive 'Big Brother'
description: In an effort to revive the reality show that did not become a huge hit last summer, "Big Brother," CBS is in negotiations to bring back one of the reality genre's best-known producers, Arnold Shapiro, to serve as the executive producer of a second run of the show this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLERHAND, IDA
description: ALLERHAND-Ida. On February 19, 2001. Wife of 68 years of Irving Allerhand. Mother of Hershel, Ruth, Judy and Joseph.

title: Our Soldiers Didn't Volunteer for Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Trenet, French Pop Singer, Dies at 87
description: Charles Trenet, one of France's most beloved popular singers who was best known abroad as the composer of hits like ''La Mer'' (''Beyond the Sea''), ''Boum'' and ''Que Reste-t-il de Nos Amours'' (''I Wish You Love'') died on Sunday in Creteil, a suburb of Paris. He was 87 and lived in Paris.

title: Clinton and the Pardons: The Raging Storm
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Purposeful Strides
description: Adam Taliaferro is walking again with repaired electricity in his stride, his slight limp a hopeful shiver of circuits reconnected, pathways restored. The troubling dreams have stopped playing in his doctor's head, with Taliaferro lying on the football field, his eyes wide in fear and teenage panic in his voice: ''Doc, doc, I can't move. You've got to help me. I can't feel my legs. I can't move.''

title: The Big City; Standards Of Decency, Standardized
description: NOW that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants a new panel to establish ''decency standards'' for museums, you may be wondering how to apply for a job with the New York City Decency Commission. The first step is to take the Minnesota Multi-Phasic Propriety Exam.

title: Letters: The Genome's Riddle
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * The .tv Corporation, Los Angeles, which administers Web addresses ending in ''.tv,'' to Ant Farm Interactive, Atlanta, to handle its interactive account, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $2.5 million.

title: A Passion for Physical Realms, Minute and Massive
description: In gentler times, physicists like Niels Bohr and Werner Heisenberg liked to ramble through the countryside near Copenhagen arguing over the outrageous new things a fledgling theory called quantum mechanics said about the subatomic world.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TESTING; Low-Tech Wins in Gauging Infant Health
description: In a victory for low technology, a study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine found that the Apgar test, which is a quick visual checklist applied to newborns, was a better predictor of distress than a newer method of testing the acidity of blood from the umbilical cord.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLATZER, HENRIETTE T.
description: GLATZER-Henriette T. Your warm, provocative, intelligent embrace of mind and life will be with me always. You have been the best of teachers. Margaret Mandel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOPNICK, SANDRA
description: CHOPNICK-Sandra. On February 17th. Cherished sister of Charles Chopnick and Gertrude Whitaker. Loving aunt of Greta and Richard Greenfield. Private interment.

title: Two Worlds Collide In Dartmouth Deaths
description: The suspects and the victims inhabited different worlds, and the authorities are offering few clues about how they might have collided.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASSIN, WILLIAM F. JR.
description: CASSIN-William F. Jr. Daddy, after 12 years you are still truly missed. Love, Billy, Danny, Michelle, Brian and Laura

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINER, HYMAN L.
description: FEINER-Hyman L. Age 91. February 13, 2001. In Wynnewood, PA. Industrial engineer and consultant to the international needletrades industry. Avid athlete. Survived by Milly, beloved wife of 65 years, son Dick, daughter Victoria Roth, sister Helen Goldstein, and three grandsons.

title: Review/Fashion; He's Back: Klein Shows His Stuff, and It Struts
description: So often accused of resting on his laurels or falling under the influence of other designers, Calvin Klein closed a dismal New York fall season with an exceptional collection that represented a change not only for him but for fashion as well.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ABBOTT LABORATORIES, Abbott Park, Ill., named Thomas Freyman, vice president for hospital products, as chief financial officer, effective April 1. He will succeed Gary Coughlan, who is retiring.

title: F.B.I. Agent Charged With Espionage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  A veteran agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation spied for Moscow for some 15 years, selling secrets that endangered the country's security and caused the deaths of two Russian agents who were working for the United States, the Justice Department said today.

title: DDB Worldwide Wins Merck Account
description: Merck & Company has expanded its relationship with the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, by naming the agency to handle its Singulair anti-asthma drug, which had been handled by the New York office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications. Spending was estimated at $40 million.

title: For Cardinal-to-Be, a Busy Day in Rome
description: On his first day here, Archbishop Edward M. Egan encountered only one hitch today in his preparations to become one of 44 new cardinals on Wednesday. The red ceremonial robes that he had ordered turned out to be a few inches too long and had to be sent back to the tailor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, HANNAH
description: HERMAN-Hannah, 101. Widow of Irving. Mother of Richard and the late Louis. Grandmother of Jennifer, Nicholas, Melinda and Felton. Mother-in-law of Maureen. Sister of Celia, Edward, Miriam and the late Sally, Morrie, Sam and Marcy. Lovingly cared for by Bernadette, Monica, Pinky and Nevlin. Venerated by generations of relatives, friends and neighbors. Memorial gathering at home on Sunday, February 25, at 4 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: The Big City column on Friday, about the sparseness of influence of men's fashion shows on the way men dress, misspelled the given name of an editor for American Vogue, who was interviewed during Fashion Week at Bryant Park. He is Hamish Bowles, not Hamisch.

title: VITAL SIGNS: UPDATE; When Peanuts Are Palatable After All
description: Food allergies are common among infants, and they are usually quickly outgrown.

title: VITAL SIGNS: OUTCOMES; Vaccine Discounted as a Link to Autism
description: An analysis of vaccination data in Britain shows no support for the theory that the sharp increase in cases of autism is related to the vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella, according to an article published Saturday by The British Medical Journal.

title: Findings Boost Hope for Better Lyme Vaccine
description: Like a villain traveling incognito, the elusive germ that causes Lyme disease can disguise itself and evade vaccines by changing the chemistry of its outer coat with surprising complexity, scientists have found. This chemical virtuosity, they say, helps explain why the current Lyme vaccine has not been more protective.

title: Bush Dedicates Museum at Site of Oklahoma City Bombing
description: He stood silent in a room where a tape recording resurrected the horrific sound of the explosion and the screaming that shattered this city on April 19, 1995, forever changing it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENNIS, DR. CHARLES E.
description: ENNIS-Dr. Charles E. Music Professor Emeritus of Long Island University, former Organist and Choir Director of All Angels Episcopal Church, N.Y. and Peekskill Presbyterian Church. Died February 18, 2001 after a brief illness. He leaves his beloved wife Agnes, daughter Susan Compton, grandchildren Caitlin and Gavin, brother Fowler Ennis, family and friends. Services and burial in Vandalia, MO. Remember him for the joy of singing he brought to so many.

title: Article 2001022090034296934 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Tax-Cut News for Mr. Bush
description: For a while, President Bush's proposal for a $1.6 trillion tax cut seemed to be immune to the rules of legislative reality. Republicans who wanted to make it bigger seemed to outnumber Democrats wanting to cut it back. Last week, however, Mr. Bush got some sobering news from a leader of his own party, Senator Pete Domenici, chairman of the Budget Committee. He reported to the White House that critics of the tax cut had begun making headway even among Republicans with the argument that it is too big, unfair and unlikely to help the economy. We have been urging Democrats to stick together and fight the tax cuts. Today we urge moderate Republicans to listen to the tough appraisal of their own party colleagues.

title: Article 2001022091326881902 -- No Title
description: By DAVID F. GALLAGHER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLLY, PATRICIA
description: BERLLY-Patricia. Loving sister of Joel Berlly and sister-in-law of Joan. Aunt of Michael and Lauren Berlly. Beloved niece of Lillian Zucker. Pat fought a long and tough battle right to the end. She will be lovingly remembered by all her family and friends.

title: Public Interests; The Art of Rudy
description: Bill Clinton's defense of the Marc Rich pardon may be seen by many as a plea for understanding. But I prefer to think of it as a bid for a slot on the Rudy Giuliani Decency Commission.

title: U.S. Teams Are Training Worldwide
description: Eight of Major League Soccer's 12 teams are scattered around the world preparing for the 2001 season, with the Los Angeles Galaxy taking its traveling to extremes. The Galaxy left for China and Japan last week and will play its first exhibition game tomorrow against the Chinese national team near Beijing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, ETHEL (WARSHAVSKY)
description: EPSTEIN - Ethel (Warshavsky). Died peacefully at 91 on February 18, 2001. Beloved wife, for 54 years, of the late Stanley. Dear mother of Anne Epstein Newton. Cherished sister of Lee Greenberg, Ruth Dobkin, and the late Betty Rivkin and Molly Fleischer. Adored aunt of David Rivkin, Cynthia Greenberg Byer, John Dobkin, Bob Fleischer, Susan Fleischer Axelrod, Marjorie Dobkin. Also survived by lifelong best friend Fritzi Jacobs. Services Wednesday, February 21 Plaza Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91 Street at 12:30 P.M.

title: Infertility Affects All
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bodies in Panama
description: Two years ago, three former soldiers in Panama's military told their priests that human remains were buried on an old military base. The soldiers, apparently driven by conscience, said that the bodies were those of opposition activists murdered under the military dictatorship. The Catholic Church passed the information to the government, and so far four bodies have been uncovered, one of them with hands and feet bound.

title: TOTALFINAELF BREAKS OFF TALKS
description: The Franco-Belgian oil group TotalFinaElf said yesterday that it had broken off talks with the Polish oil company PKN Orlen over the possible sale of a 50 percent stake in the Mider G.m.b.H. oil refinery in Leuna, Germany. TotalFinaElf owns 100 percent of Mider. ''No agreement has been found and discussions with PKN Orlen have broken off,'' TotalFinaElf said in a news release.

title: A Loathsome Threesome In an Aristocrats' Minuet
description: AIDING AND ABETTING

title: X-Rays Reveal Star Inside the Cat's Eye
description: New data from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory reveal a bright central star surrounded by a glowing bubble of multimillion-degree gas within the planetary nebula known as the Cat's Eye. This image combines X-ray data from Chandra and optical views from the Hubble Space Telescope, with the central star appearing in X-rays. The new data provide insight into the ways that stars like the Sun end their lives. Material shed by the Cat's Eye is flying away at about 4 million miles per hour, and the star is expected to collapse and become a white dwarf in a few million years.

title: Rookie Additions Help Devils End Slump
description: In one smooth motion, Devils left wing Jiri Bicek swept his stick across the blue line, corralled the puck and skated hard toward Maple Leaf goaltender Curtis Joseph.

title: Rangers Lose Richter For Season
description: The Rangers should have felt good yesterday after a 4-2 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks extended their unbeaten streak to a season-high five games. Instead, the mood in their dressing room at Madison Square Garden was somber.

title: BUSH V. GORE: A special report.; Election Case a Test and a Trauma for Justices
description: The last time the justices of the Supreme Court appeared together in public was at the inauguration of President George W. Bush, their presence on the platform providing the starkest reminder possible of the court's extraordinary role in deciding the outcome of the 2000 election.

title: Major Utility Chief Set to Resign Post
description: After nearly six years as chief executive of the Southern Company, the largest power generator in the United States, A. W. Dahlberg, 60, said yesterday that he will retire on April 2, the scheduled day of completion for his signature project, the spinoff of the company's competitive energy businesses.

title: INSIDE
description: Emotional Edge in Israel

title: Rich's Trading Firm to Merge With Russian-Owned Company
description: GENEVA, Feb. 20 - The international commodities trading firm run by Marc Rich, the billionaire pardoned by President Clinton, will be merged with Crown Resources, a Swiss-based energy trading concern owned by the Alfa Group of Russia, the two firms said today. The merger is expected to be completed within two months; financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Revamping For Sabena Is Seen Near
description: The talk at Sabena, Belgium's cash-short national airline, is not about the restructuring plan that is about to be approved by the owners. It is about the rescue plan that might have to follow.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: VITAL SIGNS: PROGNOSIS; At Risk for a Stroke? Check the Map
description: A study presented last week at a conference of the American Stroke Association found wide racial and regional differences in stroke rates across America.

title: Clinton and the Pardons: The Raging Storm
description: To the Editor:

title: Gail Fisher, 65, TV Actress Who Won Emmy for 'Mannix'
description: Gail Fisher, who won an Emmy Award in 1970 for her portrayal of Peggy Fair, secretary to the gumshoe played by Mike Connors on the CBS television series ''Mannix,'' died on Dec. 2 at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 65.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's not enough to give food, if hospitals have no medicines and the water supply is contaminated.''

title: Under Icy Arctic Waters, A Fiery, Unexpected Find
description: By accident, scientists peering into icy waters far beneath the North Pole have found a hidden world of fire.

title: REORGANIZATION AT TELIA
description: Scandinavia's largest phone company by sales, Telia A.B. of Sweden, said it would restructure itself into six new divisions to allow managers to make deals and alliances. It also announced that its acting president and chief executive, Marianne Nivert, would keep those posts until she retires in September 2002, and called off a search for an immediate replacement. The moves increased speculation among analysts that a big Nordic telephone deal may be brewing. Telia's stock rose 5.6 percent to 56.5 kronor ($5.78) a share after the company announced pretax profits of 7.66 billion kronor ($780 million), exceeding forecasts. Alan Cowell

title: Tunnel Vision; Trying to Close Door on Stubbornness
description: As exercises in mass behavior modification go, the one that New York City Transit has been trying out on New Yorkers over the last five years is incredibly modest in its goals.

title: Confident and Racy, Mysterious 'Sisters' Hypnotize Japan
description: They don't dance. They don't sing. They're not movie stars. They aren't really even models in the traditional sense.

title: Shivering in New Jersey, and Shuddering at the Heating Bills
description: A single mother of three in New Brunswick, N.J., endured having her natural gas service cut off because she had fallen behind in her payments and owed the utility company more than $1,000. Her service was reconnected last week after a social service agency helped her with a small grant and negotiated a payment plan for her.

title: British Telecom May Cancel Public Offering for Wireless Unit
description: British Telecommunications confirmed today that contrary to assurances it gave just five days ago it may not proceed with an initial public offering for its wireless unit after all. Instead, it may spin off the unit to its existing shareholders.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: In Russian-Language TV, a Slice of Moscow-Style Turmoil
description: Most immigrants from the former Soviet Union may have thought they left its power struggles and intrigues behind them. Then came the television wars.

title: Times to Announce Deals With NewsStand, an Online Publisher
description: The New York Times Company and NewsStand Inc., an online publisher, will announce today a five-year agreement to provide daily Internet distribution of the print version of The New York Times. The distribution, which will begin this spring, will enable Times readers to see the newspaper on their computers in the same form as it appears on newsstands.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: British Telecommunications May Halt Wireless Offering

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LEONARD
description: LEVINE-Leonard. Cherished husband of our esteemed friend and colleague, Naomi. Our thoughts are with the Levine family at this sad time. Your friends share your grief over the loss of this beloved member of the NYU community. The NYU Office of Public Affairs

title: Frank Gilbreth Jr., 89, Author Of 'Cheaper by the Dozen'
description: Frank Bunker Gilbreth Jr., a journalist whose life-with-father memoir ''Cheaper by the Dozen'' became a best seller and a popular movie of the same title, died on Sunday in Charleston, S.C., where he had lived for the last 50 years. He was 89 and also had a home in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHER, MURRAY
description: RICHER-Murray. On February 18, 2001. Of Wantagh, Long Island. Beloved husband of Lillian. Devoted father of Robert, Eve, David and Mark. Loving father-in-law of Robin, Maria & Diane. Dear brother of Sylvia Wallin and the late Sol Richer. Cherished and adored grandfather of Seth, Michael, Steven, Daniel, Kevin, Madeline and Benjamin. Services today 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Clinton and the Pardons: The Raging Storm
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton and the Pardons: The Raging Storm
description: To the Editor:

title: BOND ISSUE TO BUILD WAR CHEST
description: Singapore Telecommunications said yesterday that it would sell one billion Singapore dollars ($574 million) in bonds, the biggest issue in memory denominated in Singapore's currency, to help finance acquisitions overseas. As deregulation and new competition eat into its profits at home, the company, Singapore's former telephone monopoly, has sought to expand overseas, but efforts to buy stakes in Hong Kong and Malaysia were thwarted for political reasons by SingTel's largest shareholder, the government. SingTel is now bidding for a 52 percent stake in Optus, the Australian wireless and data transmission subsidiary of Cable and Wireless. Wayne Arnold

title: A Playwright's Warning, Sounded From Berlin, 1933
description: There are quick moments when there isn't a trace of character in the handsome, apple-cheeked face of the actor Stephen Barker Turner, and they are more unsettling than any focused words or gestures. Mr. Turner plays a German medical student named Peter Karlanner in the Classic Stage Company's studious production of ''Race,'' Ferdinand Bruckner's anguished warning cry of a play from 1933.

title: Ruling Favors Public School in Hasidic Village
description: A state judge has given the upstate village of Kiryas Joel another chance to continue operating a separate public school district for its disabled children.

title: In Fox's First Daytona, It's Action, Elation, Then a Sense of Dread
description: Fox Sports was about to celebrate its production of the Daytona 500 in its rookie year of carrying Nascar. Fox's first foray at Daytona had produced a breathtaking race, a better-than-credible broadcast and an 8.4 overnight Nielsen rating, the highest in at least 15 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RELLES, GUSSIE
description: RELLES-Gussie. 93, of Lakewood, NJ, on February 18, 2001. She was the loving wife of the late Nathan. She leaves her beloved children Judith and Stephen Goodhue and Arleen and Richard Danford. She was the devoted grandmother of Tim Wiener (Janice Ono), Jill Berkman (Lawrence), Greg Danford (Erica), Laura Mandel (Paul) and Natalie Danford (Paolo Pierleoni). Dear Gigi of Jeremy and Sarah Berkman, Jake Danford and Benjamin Mandel. She was loved and admired by her nieces and nephews. She was an outstanding woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, PAULINE
description: WIENER-Pauline. 100 years young. Died Sunday, February 18, after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Adored mother of Madeline (Al), Walter (Marilyn) and Judy (Peter). Cherished grandmother of Bonnie, Shelley (Steven), Robin (Jerry), Rabbi Moshe (Mariasha), Lori (Gary), Michael, Ilene (Jeff) and 19 greatgrandchildren. Survived by five sisters and a brother. Funeral 11:30AM Tuesday, BoulevardRiverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. Rest in peace mom-we love you dearly.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Arguments in Bomb Trial, but With His Own Lawyer
description: Defense lawyers are supposed to fight hard for their clients. But sometimes the two see things differently.

title: What's in an Inkblot? Some Say, Not Much
description: Psychology has produced few more popular icons than the Rorschach inkblot test.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRTENSTEIN, DANIEL. DANIEL
description: HIRTENSTEIN-Daniel. Daniel, a man for all seasons, a man for all reasons, a many you could talk to, a man you could learn from, a man of charity and kindness, a man of love and laughter. His warmth, wisdom, compassion, unbelievable perseverance against all odds and his great, big smile will forever be felt in our hearts. Dan was not only a good friend, but a great listener and advisor. Our thoughts and prayers are with Audrey, Tracy, Andrew and their families. Dan, rest well as you are forever in our hearts. Robin and Jeff Michaels

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IACOVETTA, ASSUNTA
description: IACOVETTA-Assunta. Age 90. On February 18th, 2001. Bronxdale. Beloved wife of the late Alberto Iacovetta. Mother of Vincent (Yvonne) and Gene. The daughter of a naturalized American citizen, Assunta was born in Italy and raised her older son alone during and just after WWII, during which her husband was a prisoner of war. An avid church-goer and supporter, & deeply devoted mother and wife, Assunta will be sorely missed by many. Visitation will be at D'Bari Funeral Home, 605 East 188 Street, Bronx, N.Y. Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Services at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, 627 East 187 St, Thursday, 10:15AM. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartdale.

title: 'Splashy Discovery' Is Made on the Inner Edge of a Black Hole
description: Astronomers have discovered a black hole that they think may give them a clear and revealing view of something never before observed: the climactic plunge of matter as it disappears into one of these cosmic gravitational sinks.

title: GIANT STEEL DEAL MADE OFFICIAL
description: As expected, Usinor of France said it had agreed to buy rivals in Spain and Luxembourg for $3.12 billion in stock to create the world's biggest steelmaker with 110,000 workers, sales of $28 billion and control of one-quarter of Europe's steel output. Usinor expects to save millions of dollars by consolidating some operations, but the savings will be made ''through reasonable and progressive job cuts in agreement with the unions,'' Usinor's chief executive, Francis Mer, above, told a news conference. Close antitrust scrutiny by the European Union is likely. Investors in Aceralia Corporacion Siderurgica of Spain will receive a 56 percent premium on the value of their shares; those in Arbed of Luxembourg will get a 57 percent premium. Alan Cowell

title: Genome's Riddle
description: To the Editor:

title: Riot Police Dislodge Unionists Who Took Over Korean Plant
description: Acting against labor unionists at the Daewoo Motor Company, riot police officers stormed a large plant near Inchon today and dislodged most of the several hundred workers who had seized it over the weekend to protest layoffs.

title: Earnhardt's Death Turns Nascar Talk to Safety
description: In the moments after Dale Earnhardt hit the wall Sunday, a voice in his headset, crackling with static and rising concern, said: ''You O.K., Dale? Talk to us, talk to us.''

title: PROGRESS ON EUROTUNNEL DEBT
description: For the first time since the Channel Tunnel opened in 1994, cash flow exceeded debt payments in 2000, the operating company, Eurotunnel S.A., reported. Its operating losses narrowed 10.8 percent to 124 million ($179 million), it said, but lost money overall in 2000; it posted a profit in 1999. Eurotunnel raised freight and passenger car tolls to offset its loss of earnings from duty-free sales, which were abolished within Europe in mid-1999. The company said its chairman, Patrick Ponsolle, will leave the company in April. Alan Cowell

title: DNA Shows Malaria Helped Topple Rome
description: An analysis of the bones of a child buried in a Roman cemetery more than 1,500 years ago has yielded what British and American researchers say is the earliest genetic evidence of malaria infection to be identified so far.

title: Court Weighs Unreasonable Search Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Supreme Court wrestled today with how to apply the Fourth Amendment's ban on unreasonable searches to a technological development the Constitution's framers most likely did not have in mind: a thermal imaging device that the police can use from outside a home to detect patterns of heat being generated from inside.

title: Stock Offerings Schedule
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Blotting It from My Mind
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Vaccine Discounted as a Link to Autism
description: An analysis of vaccination data in Britain shows no support for the theory that the sharp increase in cases of autism is related to the vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella, according to an article published Saturday by The British Medical Journal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAMBURY, JOSEPH A., JR.
description: BAMBURY-Joseph A., Jr. Died on February 16, 2001 in Charlotte, N.C. Loving husband of Mary (nee Forde), father of Joseph, John, Jean, Justin and the late James. Loving father-in-law to Lynn Baldinger and grandfather to William Edward and James Henry. Brother to Jim Bambury, Margaret Mary Bambury and the late Frank Bambury. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 & 7-9PM Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, NYC. Funeral Mass on Thursday 11AM St. Francis Xavier Church, 30 West 16th Street, NYC.

title: Inflation Risks Are Still Seen for Euro Zone
description: A member of the European Central Bank council, Ernst Welteke, said today that inflationary risks in the 12-nation euro zone, though reduced, were still present, suggesting that he remained skeptical about lowering interest rates.

title: China on the Verge
description: To the Editor:

title: Gaps in Ames Case May Be Filled by F.B.I.'s Own Spy Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  When a Central Intelligence Agency officer, Aldrich H. Ames, was arrested as a spy for Moscow in 1994, critics questioned how the agency could have allowed his espionage to go undetected for nine years. Officials at the Federal Bureau of Investigation helped fuel the criticism with complaints that the C.I.A. had failed to share sensitive information, stifling the investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSLER, SARA
description: TESSLER-Sara. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member, Marcel Stern and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: Suspect in Harlem Death Was Deemed Sane
description: A 24-year-old man accused of pushing his grandmother from the terrace of her 21st-floor Harlem apartment on Monday, apparently after stabbing her several times, was discharged this month from a city hospital. Doctors had concluded that his previous reckless behavior on the same terrace likely resulted from a drug-abuse problem and not from mental illness, a city official said yesterday.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, ELSE (NEE KLEEMANN)
description: SILBERMAN-Else (nee Kleemann). Born in Wuerzburg, Germany. Came with her husband Curt Silberman to the United States in 1938 as victims of the Hitler regime. In her youth she studied medicine, a study which she was forced to discontinue due to the Nazi Laws. In the United States she was active in Jewish organizations such as Hadassah, United Jewish Appeal, N.J. Council of Jewish Women and was supportive of her husband's activities in leading positions in the Jewish community. She and her husband dedicated the Curt C. and Else Silberman chair in Jewish studies at Middlebury College, Vermont. Else leaves in addition to her husband, a niece in Melbourne, Australia and many cousins and friends. Funeral services will take place Thursday, February 22, 2001 at 11 A.M. At Bernheim-ApterGoldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey.

title: Court Says 2 Veterans Are Owed Lifetime Care
description: A federal appeals court has ruled that the government owes free lifetime medical care to certain veterans of World War II and the Korean War because recruiters promised them such care if they served in the armed forces for a minimum of 20 years.

title: Sports of The Times; Fans Spared Equalizer Ejections
description: IN the furious history of the Knicks and the Heat, this was a calm one: No fights, no last-second basket, no fans ejected from the front row.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Saturday reported the killing of an Israeli soldier by Hezbollah guerrillas in the disputed Shabaa Farms area, controlled by Israel. The headline and the picture caption said that the attack occurred in Lebanon.

title: Powder Keg: Truffle Flavor in Flour Form
description: IF the fragrant puddles of white truffle oil set loose on the soups and salads and pastas of New York have dulled your senses, a new product could wake them up again, with all the seductive, medulla-grabbing power of a 20-pound fungus.

title: CALENDER
description: Italy Comes to Town

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, ELAINE GRACE (NEE TEPPER)
description: LIPPMAN-Elaine Grace (nee Tepper), of Englewood, NJ, on February 20th, 2001. Beloved wife of Mac. Devoted mother of Barbara L. Siegel and Anne L. Finger. Loving grandmother of Dr. Shari Goldman, Howard Siegel, Jill Finger, Barrie Finger and greatgrandmother of Nicole Charlotte Goldman. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' Hackensack, NJ, on Wednesday, February 21st, at 2 PM.

title: Egypt and the Nile
description: Tourism to Egypt has been in a slump lately, but Americans generally need not fear to go there. And there's not much to cause apprehension in the price of an 11-day trip that combines a stay in Paris, a Nile cruise and a stop in Luxor. Starting at $1,299 a person, based on double occupancy, the Sunny Land Tours package includes round-trip air fare from the United States to Paris, two nights' accommodations in Paris, with continuing air fare to Egypt, a four-night Nile cruise on the Nile Carnival, three nights in a deluxe hotel in Luxor and 18 meals. That rate is good on departures March 15 through 29; from April 5 through May 3, it is $1,499 a person. These rates are subject to a 10 percent service charge, and there is a $20 visa fee and $35 for cruise tips. Call (800) 783-7839; Web site www.sunnylandtours.com .

title: ARNOTT'S M.R.I. IS NEGATIVE
description: The Devils got some good news yesterday on the status of Jason Arnott. The magnetic resonance imaging examination to determine whether his back spasms were related to a spinal disk problem was negative. Lou Lamoriello, the president and general manager of the Devils, said last night that the M.R.I. showed some inflammation and nothing more.

title: Barak, Angry With His Party and Sharon, Quits Politics Again
description: Ehud Barak quit politics early today for the second time since he was thrashed in national elections two weeks ago. He resigned as Labor Party chairman in the face of bitter internal opposition, quit his Parliament seat and declined Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon's invitation to be defense minister.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about Flextronics, a Silicon Valley manufacturer, misstated the timing and the level of its record high stock price. Adjusted for stock splits, the record was $44.91 a share in September 2000, not $85 in late 1988.

title: Folke Karl Skoog, 92; Helped Transform Understanding of Plants
description: Dr. Folke Karl Skoog, a biochemist who helped identify the hormonal forces that prompt plants to sprout and flourish, died on Thursday in Madison, Wis., where he was a professor emeritus at the University of Wisconsin. He was 92.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. -- Natural gas fell on expectations that milder weather in the Midwest and Northeast will reduce demand. In New York, natural gas for March delivery fell 29 cents, or 5.2 percent, to $5.278 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Barak, Under Fire, Again Quits Politics
description: Ehud Barak quit politics for the second time since he was badly defeated in national elections two weeks ago -- resigning as Labor Party chairman in the face of bitter internal opposition, quitting his seat in Parliament and declining an invitation by Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon to serve as defense minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKMAN, EVELYN
description: DRUCKMAN-Evelyn, age 61, died on February 17. She is mourned by her nephew Daniel Druckman, her niece Karen Jeanneret and her sister-in-law Muriel Topaz Druckman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Surprise in the Heavens as Energy Is Detected in a Brown Dwarf
description: A dim, fading object wandering alone through space, something between a large planet and a tiny star, turns out to be roiled by storms several times more powerful than the most energetic flares on the Sun, a team of radio astronomers has found.

title: Genders That Shift, but Friends Firm as Bedrock
description: If there was ever a movie that deserved the credit ''a film by,'' it is the documentary ''Southern Comfort,'' which was mostly made with a one-person crew, its director Kate Davis. Ms. Davis had brains enough not to wait for funds because she knew that she had a great story right in front of her: the tale of Robert Eads, a female-to-male transsexual who was dying of cervical and ovarian cancer and being neglected by doctors uncomfortable with treating him.

title: Safin Is Defeated In the First Round
description: Marat Safin, who tops the ATP ranking, lost to Max Mirnyi, 6-7 (7), 6-4, 6-3, in the first round of the $750,000 ABN AMRO indoor tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, yesterday.

title: Article 2001022191381262541 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Contrasts Come Together in a Sweet Bread Pudding
description: I ALWAYS want my desserts to have a connection to the food that comes before them, which is light, clean and flavorful, but I also want them to have a balance of taste, texture and temperature. As the last dish in my vegetable menu, the rich pudding here with candied kumquat rinds, hot caramel sauce and ice cream has it all.

title: THE BOSS; Persuasion and Persistence
description: When I was at Westminster College in New Wilmington, Pa., I noticed a theater there that played terrible movies, things like Abbott and Costello meet the monster. In my sophomore year, the theater closed. Who was going to see Abbott and Costello on a Saturday night?

title: Pirating Is Not New
description: To the Editor:

title: Vin and Sprit In Talks Over Vodka Rights
description: Vin and Sprit has begun final negotiations with Fortune Brands and Maxxium, a consortium of liquor companies, for the distribution rights to Absolut vodka, people involved in the talks said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, SIDNEY, DR.
description: GOODMAN-Sidney, Dr. Age 91. Beloved husband of Edna Palmer Goodman and father of Robert. Passed away February 19, 2001.

title: EBay Is Said To Be Close To Acquiring A French Site
description: EBay is close to acquiring the French online auctioneer the iBazar Group, people close to the negotiations said today.

title: Liberties; Your Fault. No, Yours. No, Yours.
description: You know what happened to New York's hottest couple.

title: Reality Producer Sought by CBS
description: In an effort to upgrade the reality show that didn't become a massive hit last summer, ''Big Brother,'' CBS and the Dutch company that created the series, Endemol, are in negotiations to bring back one of the reality genre's best-known producers, Arnold Shapiro, to serve as executive producer of a second edition of the show this summer.

title: Former Democratic Leader Admits a Bribery Attempt
description: The former chairman of the Rockland County Democratic Party, an active supporter of Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign, stood before a federal judge today and admitted that he had sought to bribe a town official for a vote on a development project and had evaded paying income taxes.

title: We Can Afford a Much Bigger Tax Cut
description: Circumstances have changed dramatically since President Bush first proposed his tax cut last year. The economy has slowed down, with recession a distinct possibility. But in the long term, official budget surplus projections have risen from $3 trillion to almost $6 trillion.

title: Britain Stops Animal Exports Because of Foot-and-Mouth Disease
description: LONDON, Feb. 21  Faced with its first outbreak in 20 years of foot-and-mouth disease, a virulent illness that spreads with relentless speed, Britain said today that it was suspending all exports of live animals, milk, meat and other animal products.

title: Fashion Tips
description: To the Editor:

title: Fassel's Life May Have Changed, but His Contract Hasn't
description: These days, Giants Coach Jim Fassel is an extremely popular man. Leading a team to the Super Bowl will do that. He is stopped on the street and told by fans how proud they are of him, and he has received thousands of congratulatory letters.

title: Court Curbs State Workers' Options With Disability Law
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  The Supreme Court continued its trend of limiting the power of the federal government over the states today as it curbed the effects of a law protecting people with disabilities.

title: A Flight Of Fancy Begins In Portugal
description: THE star dessert at Pico is a heaped plate of cinnamon-dusted puffs of dough. Each one fits neatly into the mouth, a single, blissful bite that moves into ecstasy territory after being dipped in molten bittersweet chocolate or warm raspberry jam. They're called sonhos, which the menu renders as ''beautiful little dreams,'' and it would be hard to think of a better way to end a meal at this little dream of a restaurant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHORR, DAVID
description: SHORR-David ''For those like us, our fate is to face the world as orphans, chasing through long years the shadows of vanished parents. There is nothing for it but to try and see through our missions to the end, as best we can, for until we do so, we will be permitted no calm.'' Love Barbara, Frank, Miriam & Grandchildre

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about secret recordings in which Ukraine's president, Leonid D. Kuchma, indicated that he had ordered a campaign of intimidation to win re-election misattributed a quotation. It was the former intelligence chief, Leonid Derkach -- not Mr. Kuchma -- who suggested additional powers for the prosecutor's office, saying, ''If we are the power, then that is an instrument of our power -- the prosecutor's office.''

title: Piggies Go to Market All the Way From Quebec
description: High-quality du Breton pork from Quebec -- rosy and framed with creamy fat -- comes from hogs raised without antibiotics or growth hormones (though the meat is not certified organic).

title: Lucent Investigates Record of Former High-Ranking Executive
description: Lucent Technologies is investigating the activities of a former high-ranking executive who was convicted of embezzlement when he was a high school principal and of forging information when he applied to become a schools superintendent before his employment at Lucent. It said it had discovered the criminal record of the executive, who died in September, only in the last few months, when it was conducting a separate investigation of his work.

description: North African Flavors

title: Consumer Prices Rose Sharply in January
description: Americans paid sharply higher prices for energy in January, causing inflation at the consumer level to rise at its quickest pace in 10 months, the government reported today.

title: Standing, A Last Time, For a Dancer
description: GWEN VERDON got her last standing ovation yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEKOFF, CHARLES, M.D.
description: PEKOFF - Charles, M.D. We mourn the loss of our dear associate, Dr. Charles Pekoff, who passed away after a short but valiant battle with illness. He loved his work and he loved the many children he cared for. Heartfelt condolences to his loving family and many friends. The doctors and staff of Wantagh Pediatric Assoc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LEONARD
description: LEVINE-Leonard. We offer our deepest sympathies to our cherished colleague and friend, Naomi, and her family over the passing of her husband, Leonard. We know how much she loved him, and through her we came to feel deep affection for him, too. We share her grief at the death of this longstanding member of our community, and pray that her pain may be eased. The Staff of the NYU Div. of External Affairs

title: Daewoo Motor's Fate Tied to Labor Strife
description: A day after the riot police dislodged hundreds of striking workers at a Daewoo Motor plant in Inchon, questions remained today about whether General Motors would now come to the rescue.

title: People
description: Rick Capps, chief executive at Capps Digital, Chicago, was named to the additional new post of executive vice president and director for print development worldwide at the Bcom3 Group, as Bcom3 increases its ownership of Capps to 100 percent from 75 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERIN, ANNE
description: HALPERIN-Anne. Widow of Alvin M. Halperin. Loving mother of Marsha Epstein of Newtonville, Mass., Richard E. Halperin of Harrison, NY and mother-in-law of Lucy Landesman Halperin and Martin Epstein. Fond sister of Lillian Marsh, Murray Beecher. Cherished grandmother of Peter and Robert Epstein; Ross, Robert, Kenneth and Steven Halperin. Services Wednesday 10 AM at The Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Avenue, Harrison NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to Hale House, attn: Lisbeth Jimenez, 152 West 122 Street, New York, NY 10027 www.halehouse.org

title: Pope Elevates New Cardinals
description: VATICAN CITY -- In a sunlit ceremony of ancient ritual in St. Peter's Square, Pope John Paul II on Wednesday installed a record number of cardinals -- 44 new princes of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Headhunters seek the 30-45 age group with a new campaign.
description: THEY are known universally as headhunters, and though it's a tag that executive recruiters dislike, it's not inapt. Sure, they don't slay their prey, but they are bounty hunters nonetheless, eager for trophies: not anyone's actual head, of course, but a fee often amounting to 30 percent or even 35 percent of the employee's annual salary, if not more, paid by grateful employers who hire the prospects the recruiter finds.

title: Extradition For Teenager In Killing Of Professors
description: A day after the arrest of two teenagers in the killing of two Dartmouth College professors, New Hampshire officials announced this afternoon that they would bring one of the young men back from Indiana on Wednesday but that they would have to wait at least a week for the return of the second.

title: Spicy Pan-Glazed Tofu
description: Time: 20 minutes 16 ounces firm or extra-firm tofu

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRTENSTEIN, DANIEL
description: HIRTENSTEIN-Daniel. The family and friends of Colel Chabad mourn the loss of our dear friend and integral supporter, Daniel Hirtenstein, and extend our sympathy to his dear wife Audrey, his daughter Traci and son Andrew, and their families. Danny's friendship and kind deeds for Chabad are his true legacy and will always be remembered. May the Hirtenstein family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sholom Duchman, Director, Colel Chabad

title: IMAX CUTTING 13% OF ITS JOBS AS ORDERS SLOW
description: The Imax Corporation, the maker of big-screen projection systems, said it is eliminating 130 jobs, about 13 percent of its work force, to cut costs as orders from customers slow and earnings decline. Imax will consolidate its sound and projection systems manufacturing at its headquarters in Mississauga, Ontario, the company said. It scaled back operations at its plant in Birmingham, Ala., that makes sound equipment. Imax said it would report a first-quarter charge related to the cuts. Last month, Imax said profit last year was less than expected before charges because bankruptcies at some big theater chains in the United States reduced demand for its products. Imax shares fell 25 cents, or 5.1 percent, to $4.63 on the Nasdaq stock market.

description: By BOB TEDESCHI
