description: In percent

title: Strawberry Up For Yanks Job
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, is looking into the possibility of giving the former slugger Darryl Strawberry a job with the team, perhaps as a counselor for younger players, someone who would speak to minor leaguers about the perils of drug use and drinking.

title: Beijing Is Given an Olympian Burnish
description: ''It's nice to meet you.''

title: Stanley Kramer, Filmmaker With Social Bent, Dies at 87
description: Stanley Kramer, the producer and director of socially groundbreaking films like ''The Defiant Ones'' and ''Judgment at Nuremberg'' and one of Hollywood's most respected filmmakers in the late 1950's and early 60's, died on Monday in Woodland Hills, a section of Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: Net Profits Rise 4.5% at Wal-Mart, but Crumble at Home Depot
description: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose the smallest amount in almost five years, while Home Depot said its earnings fell as the slowing economy prompted consumers to spend less.

title: Heat-Seeker's Ability to Pierce the Home Comes Under Supreme Court's Scrutiny
description: The Supreme Court wrestled today with how to apply the Fourth Amendment's ban on unreasonable searches to a technological development the Constitution's framers most likely did not have in mind: a thermal imaging device that the police can use from outside a home to detect patterns of heat being generated from inside.

title: Matsushita and NEC Steeply Cut Income Forecasts for Fiscal Year
description: Matsushita Electric Industrial, the world's largest consumer electronics company, and NEC, the world's third-largest chip maker and Japan's largest personal computer supplier, joined a crowd of high-technology companies today, announcing less rosy earnings outlooks.

title: Giuliani, Meet Wilde
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW LIFE FOR RCA BUILDING
description: Following the relighting two years ago of the stained-glass image of Nipper, the RCA dog, atop the abandoned Nipper Building in Camden, N.J., officials say the sprawling complex itself will be cleaned up and converted into 300 apartments. The Delaware River Port Authority, a bistate agency of New Jersey and Pennsylvania, is to vote this morning on whether to spend $6 million on an environmental cleanup plan that includes removing asbestos from the 500,000-square-foot building, said Joe Diemer, a port agency spokesman. The Nipper Building, which is actually several buildings combined, is considered a symbol of Camden, where the Radio Corporation of America and its predecessor, the Victor Talking Machine Company, were founded. This afternoon, the Coopers Ferry Development Association, which is financed by the port agency, is expected to award the $6 million cleanup contract to Dranoff Properties of Narberth, Pa., said Judy London, an association spokeswoman. Ms. London said the association was also negotiating a lease under which Dranoff would invest $50 million to convert the building into apartments. Steve Strunsky

title: Egan to Head to Albany to Fight Coverage of Contraceptives in Women's Health Bill
description: One of Archbishop Edward M. Egan's first acts as a newly named cardinal in New York City will be to lead a political offensive in Albany to thwart a bill that would require Catholic hospitals and schools to provide insurance coverage for contraceptives for their female employees.

title: Firm to Offer Cash for Stock Orders
description: The Tradescape Corporation, one of the nation's largest day-trading firms, said yesterday that it would pay its customers to place certain stock orders with MarketXT, the company's electronic trading network.

title: Chicago Journal; Broad-Shoulder Brotherhood, Forged in Steam
description: When the heat was on him, Jesse Jackson came here to sweat.

title: Fordham Student Is Elected To Father's Old Council Seat
description: Joel Rivera, a 22-year-old Fordham University student, was elected yesterday to a City Council seat that his father had held for more than a dozen years. The special election was more a battle between two warring political camps in the Bronx than an ideological contest between two candidates.

title: A Clinton In-Law Recieved $400,000 in 2 Pardon Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  Former President Bill Clinton's brother-in- law, Hugh Rodham, received nearly $400,000 in fees for successfully lobbying for a presidential pardon and a prison commutation for two wealthy felons, Mr. Rodham's lawyer and other officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENTHAL, HELEN (NEE GREEN)
description: LOWENTHAL - Helen (nee Green), February 18, 2001, of Philadelphia. Wife of the late Daniel, mother of Dana Ackerman, of New York City, and Ellen Goldstein, of Short Hills, N.J., motherin-law of Jack R. Ackerman, and Jonathan L. Goldstein, sister of Joel Green of Santa Rosa, CA. Also survived by three grandchildren, Adam, Andrew, and Kathryn Goldstein. Services are private. The family asks that contributions may be made to the Daniel Lowenthal Fund, C/O The University of Pennsylvania Law School, 3400 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19104. Joseph Levine and Son (www.levinefuneral.com)

title: WILLIAMS AND KINDER MORGAN IN POWER PLANT DEAL
description: The Williams Companies, a leading natural-gas pipeline operator, agreed to supply fuel for six natural gas-fired power plants being developed by Kinder Morgan Inc., and then sell the electricity that the plants produce. Terms were not disclosed. The plants are being built in the next four years by the power-company unit of Kinder Morgan, the operator of one of the largest fuel pipelines in the western United States. The plants will be built in the Midwest and Southeast and are expected to produce 3,300 megawatts of power, or enough to light 3.3 million homes.

title: Have Camera, Will Travel
description: One week I might be in Singapore on board the Eastern and Orient Express. The next, I could be doing a promotional video on resort spas in California. On some assignments, though, I feel more cursed than lucky. I've had severe altitude sickness in the Himalayas, food poisoning in Mexico and a close encounter with an aggressive sea lion in the Galpagos Islands.

title: Privacy Suit Over Student Survey Thrown Out
description: A federal judge has thrown out a lawsuit by three parents in this affluent suburb that accused the local school district of violating students' privacy rights by administering a survey that asked about their sexual behavior, drug and alcohol use and family relationships.

title: Reckonings; Fowl Play
description: One hears that George W. Bush likes to give people nicknames. So I hereby propose that he himself be known as Chicken Little. After all, he has been running around saying ''The sky is falling! Hurry up and pass my tax cut!'' And that of course means that we should dub Dick Cheney, who has been the administration's point man for economic pessimism, Chicken Big Time.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONSECO INC., Carmel, Ind., said its quarterly operating profits rose 5 percent, beating expectations, as the company, a life insurance and loan business, continued its efforts to shore up its finances.

title: Racer's Death Leaves Hole In Heart of His Hometown
description: His death brought a silence to the Wal-Mart.

title: Advertising: Addenda
description: Kellogg Consolidates Cereal Work at Burnett

title: Daytona 500 A Ratings Success
description: The Daytona 500 on Sunday, which ended in Dale Earnhardt's death, generated a 10.0 Nielsen rating on the Fox network, the best performance since a 10.5 in 1979 when the race was carried by CBS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ANITA J.
description: WEINSTEIN-Anita J. Fried. A woman of incomparable beauty, humor and grace. Scarlet has a Scrabble board ready. Forever in my heart. Janet Jacobs Fine

title: TURKEY'S MARKET CALMS DOWN
description: Turkey's stock market steadied yesterday after costly damage from an unprecedented clash between Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit and the president. Turkey's top economic officials sought to calm the markets after a row between Mr. Ecevit and President Ahmet Necdet Sezer over ways of fighting corruption. The economic officials said they would not devalue Turkey's currency and pledged to stick to financial reform plans. The nation's news media berated both leaders for causing a crisis that cost the country billions of dollars as foreign investors pulled out Turkey and the cost of government borrowing soared. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Hopkins Is Ready For His Payday
description: At 37, Bernard Hopkins, the International Boxing Federation middleweight champion, is finally where he always thought he should be: fighting a high-profile contender -- Keith Holmes, the World Boxing Council middleweight champion -- for big prize money, at least $1 million.

title: Rich Is Selling Trading Firm to Alfa Unit
description: The international commodities trading firm run by Marc Rich, the billionaire pardoned by President Clinton, will be merged with Crown Resources, a Swiss-based energy trading concern owned by the Alfa Group of Russia, the two firms said today. The merger is expected to be completed within two months; financial terms were not disclosed.

title: A Disturbing New Spy Case
description: The espionage charges filed against Robert Philip Hanssen yesterday portray him as a cunning practitioner of the very arts of espionage he was supposed to combat as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Instead of hunting Russian spies, prosecutors say, Mr. Hanssen became one. Using the skills he learned at the bureau, Mr. Hanssen not only deceived the F.B.I. but also shielded his true identity from Moscow even as he sold the Russians sensitive American secrets for the last 15 years in return for $1.4 million.

title: Pan-Glazed Tofu with Thai Red Curry Sauce
description: Time: 20 minutes 1 one-pound package firm or extra-firm tofu

title: New York Fall Fashion Week in Review
description: In this audio/visual presentation, the Times fashion critic Cathy Horyn reviews New York Fashion Week, which ended on Friday, by talking through photographs of the fall 2001 collections shown here.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Hotel Occupancy Rate Hit Record Level Last Year
description: Last year was a boom time for New York's hotel industry, with the occupancy rate at a record 84.6 percent, up 3.1 percent from the previous year, according to figures compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. The cost of a night in a hotel increased even more sharply, 7.3 percent, to an average of $220.86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDSKIN, DIANE
description: LIDSKIN-Diane. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the tragic passing of Diane Lidskin, beloved daughter of Roland and Sylvia Schaefer. Roland is an Honorary Vice Chair of ADL's National Commission and a member of the ADL Florida Regional Board. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Roland and Sylvia, sisters Bonnie and Marla, her children and the entire family. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Blair Seeking To Ease Tension On Iraq Strikes
description: As he prepared to become the first European leader to visit President Bush, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain offered today to revive his role in the Clinton administration as the bridge between the United States and Europe. It was not the easiest of times to send the message.

title: Secret Services
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Accounts
description: New Zealand Milk, Wellington, New Zealand, the consumer division of the New Zealand Dairy Board, expanded its relationship with FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, by naming the agency to handle its account in Africa, Asia and the Middle East, which had been handled by various local agencies. Billings were estimated at $50 million. FCB already handles the board's account in the Caribbean and Central and South America.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of restaurant closings in the Off the Menu column of the Dining section on Feb. 7 included one restaurant erroneously. And a correction in this space on Feb. 8 referred incorrectly to its lease. The restaurant, Gubbio, at 223 West Broadway (White Street), remains open, and its lease is not being renegotiated; it has 17 more years to run.

title: Metro Business Briefing; POWER PLANT APPROVAL
description: The New York Power Authority, which hopes to build 11 small electricity generators in New York City and on Long Island by this summer, received approval yesterday from state environmental regulators for the final piece of its emergency supply plan. The permit, for a 47-megawatt generating station on Staten Island, rounds out a list of sites in the Bronx, Queens, Brooklyn and Suffolk County. Both the authority and the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which issued the permit, were sued earlier this month by a coalition of neighborhood and environmental groups that say the approval process was illegally circumvented because of political pressures. Kirk Johnson

title: The Cheney Factor
description: Vice President Dick Cheney's name does not appear anywhere on the White House home page. But Mr. Cheney's ubiquity in the real White House has reached such heights that the president recently made news by deciding not to add to his portfolio. On top of all the vice president's other responsibilities, there were reports earlier this month suggesting that Mr. Cheney might be put in charge of the all-important ''principals' meetings'' of the National Security Council, supplanting the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. Last week President Bush designated Ms. Rice for that job, rightly affirming her place in the White House hierarchy. No one doubts, however, that when Mr. Cheney is in meetings on security issues, the budget or any other subject, he will have extraordinary authority. But there is still widespread uncertainty in Washington over the effects of this supercharged vice presidency, especially in relation to the cabinet officers Mr. Cheney helped select.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, JOHN (JOHNNY) J.
description: DWYER-John (Johnny) J. Of West Palm Beach, Florida, formerly of Manhattan, died on February 18, 2001. He was 85. Beloved husband of Mary Kinney Dwyer and the late Margaret ''Margie'' Cuddihy Dwyer, who passed away in 1974. Loving father of John and George. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Andrew, Margaret, Kathryn and Courtney. Retired union official of the Seafarers International Union. Served in Special U.S. Naval Battalion, Chief Bos'n, from December 1942-November 1945. Friends may call Thursday 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue (at RR Plaza), Floral Park. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10:30 AM at Our Lady of Victory R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Major Union May Stay Out Of Primary
description: One of the state's most powerful unions, the hospital workers' union, is leaning toward staying neutral in the New York Democratic mayoral primary, officials with the organization said yesterday, making it highly unlikely that the top three labor organizations will be able to unify behind a single Democratic candidate this year.

title: 'Yo Mama' Artist Takes On Catholic Critic
description: In a fractious debate yesterday, Rene Cox defended her iconoclastic depiction of Christ as a nude woman, squaring off against the man who is perhaps her most persistent critic: William Donohue, the president of the Catholic League for Religious and Civil Rights.

title: Opposition to Coalition Simmers in Israel's Labor Party
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21  Ehud Barak's sudden resignation from political life appears to have cleared the way for a unity government under Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon, but there are still bitter opponents to the coalition within the now leaderless Labor Party.

title: F.B.I. Agent Charged as Spy Who Aided Russia for 15 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  A senior F.B.I. agent who worked as a counterintelligence supervisor at the agency's headquarters was charged today as a spy who passed highly classified information to Russia for 15 years without being detected. Law enforcement officials described the case as an extremely grave breach of national security.

title: Teacher's Union Criticizes Method for Charter School Vote
description: The union representing New York City teachers yesterday stepped up its criticism of a plan to privatize five troubled schools, just three weeks before parents are to vote on the proposal.

title: Bill Rigney Is Dead at 83; New York Giants Manager
description: Bill Rigney, who played on the New York Giants' memorable pennant-winning team of 1951, then became the Giants' last manager at the Polo Grounds and first one in San Francisco, died yesterday in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 83.

title: 2 Giant Steps for Columbia
description: The Columbia men's basketball team has an overall record of 10-13 and will most likely miss the N.C.A.A. tournament for the 33rd straight season. But Lions Coach Armond Hill received so many calls of congratulations on Monday that his office sounded like a switchboard.

title: Corrections
description: Charts of holiday travel schedules last Friday through Monday for Washington's Birthday included an erroneous summary of New York City parking rules supplied by the Department of Transportation. Alternate-side regulations were suspended, but other normal regulations -- not Sunday rules -- remained in effect.

title: Payton Is Focus Of Trade Talks For Sheffield
description: When Jay Payton played in Japan during the off-season with a major league all-star team, he was teammates with Gary Sheffield and enjoyed the experience.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE CELESTICA BUYING AVAYA PLANTS The Canadian electronics subcontractor Celestica said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two manufacturing plants from Avaya of Basking Ridge, N.J., and to supply $4 billion of components over five years to the company, which makes communications networks. Avaya, which was spun off from Lucent Technologies in September, said the arrangement would reduce costs and inventories. It is selling the plants in Westminister, Colo., and Little Rock, Ark., for about $200 million, and is closing another plant in Shreveport, La. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DECLINES. -- The euro fell as Turkey's central bank moved to stem the slide of its currency, the lira, after a flight to euros. In New York, the euro settled at 91.17 cents, down from 91.40 cents on Friday.

title: Contours of Careers
description: To the Editor:

title: Submarine Made Sonar Contact With Boat Before Collision
description: Asailor assigned to plot sonar contacts aboard the United States Navy submarine that hit and sank a Japanese fishing vessel nearly two weeks ago has told American investigators that he had to briefly halt his task because of the distraction of civilian guests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLERHAND, IDA
description: ALLERHAND-Ida. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ida Allerhand, beloved mother of our board member, Joseph S. Allerhand, and mother-in-law of Randi Schatz. We extend our sincerest condolences to Joseph and Randi, both active leaders; to Irving, Ida's husband of 68 years; and to the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Vornado Realty Is Highest Bidder To Win Lease for the Twin Towers
description: Vornado Realty Trust has emerged as the high bidder for the largest commercial real estate complex of all: the 110-story Twin Towers and World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

title: HESS BUYING GULF COAST NATURAL GAS PROPERTIES
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation will buy substantially all of the exploration and production assets of the Llog Exploration Company for $750 million, after closing adjustments. In a news release yesterday, Amerada Hess said the properties were located on the Gulf of Mexico shelf and in South Louisiana. Amerada Hess expects the deal to close in the second quarter. Its stock rose $1.75, to $72.76.

title: The Kiss of the Buffalo: A Mozzarella That Weeps Joy
description: Burrata is the Cracker Jack of cheese: it comes with a prize inside. A specialty of Salerno, Italy, it is made from a sheet of fresh buffalo mozzarella wrapped and tied like a beggar's purse around a creamy center of even softer mozzarella floating in cream. When it is served at the proper temperature, the little bundle oozes richness as you slice it open.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Los Angeles Will Challenge Bush on Census
description: The City of Los Angeles will seek to block a Bush administration order revoking the Census Bureau's power to adjust the 2000 census to account for millions of people who were not counted, city officials said today.

title: Tofu, That Excellent, Underrated Entree
description: ASK someone ''What's the best way to cook tofu?'' and you are almost guaranteed to get a snide reply like ''Not at all.'' Why are most cooks, even adventurous ones, so negative about tofu? My theory is that we food writers are partly to blame. The preparation of tofu -- the high-protein, low-fat curds of soy milk -- has been clouded by countless unnecessary suggestions. I know, because I have tried them all.

title: Longing for the Past in a Changing Church
description: WHEN the city folds in on itself, when the lights blink off in office towers and commuters scurry home to spouses, children or silent rooms, when the work of the day is set aside, a Catholic priest climbs the 64 steps to the top floor of a Manhattan brownstone. He closes his door, leafs through a stack of vinyl records and allows the music to roll back time.

description: With sport utility vehicles becoming bigger and bigger, perhaps it was inevitable: Freightliner, the nation's biggest maker of 18-wheelers, plans to start selling a four-wheel-drive vehicle that dwarfs even the largest family vehicles on the road.

Daughter of the late Louis Goldberg and Anna Freund. Sister of the late C.M. and I. Harold Kellar. She is survived by her daughter Andrea, her nephews Raymond, Alan and Jeffrey, her grandnephew Michael and her sister-in-law Charlotte. Services Thursday, 9:45AM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Memorial contributions to Museum of Jewish Heritage, Battery Park City, New York.

title: SYBASE BUYING NEW ERA OF NETWORKS
description: Sybase Inc., a maker of database software, agreed to buy New Era of Networks Inc. for about $373 million in stock to acquire New Era's programs for linking incompatible computer systems. Each common share of New Era, known as Neon, will be converted into 0.3878 share of Sybase common stock. That is about $9.50 a share, based on Sybase's closing price of $24.50 today. Neon shareholders would get a premium of about 37 percent; Neon stock last traded today at $6.94, up $1.19, before it was halted on Nasdaq. The shares have fallen about 91 percent in the last year. Sybase, based in Emeryville, Calif., said Neon would broaden its products aimed at doing business over the Internet. Sybase said that it expects the acquisition to be completed in the second quarter and to add to its earnings next year.

title: Is It Time to Abolish the SAT?

title: Fernandez Hopes He Still Has Something Left
description: Sid Fernandez showed up at a reunion of the 1986 Mets last month in New Jersey and his former teammates were stunned by his girth. El Sid always battled his weight in his playing days, and yet at age 38, almost four years since his last pitch in the majors, El Sid looked pretty good. Gary Carter and a couple of others suggested he should try a comeback.

title: Exchange Hires Former Banking Official
description: The Chicago Board of Trade hired a former vice chairman of the Bank One Corporation, to be chief executive of the largest United States futures exchange.

title: Success, at a Price, at Nail Salons; Anxiety Tempers Good Times for Koreans in Business
description: Duk Su Noh, believing prosperity was close at hand, tried to do everything just right.

title: Counterintelligence Specialist Is Arrested in Virginia Woods : FBI Agent Accused Of Passing 'Grave' Secrets to Russians
description: WASHINGTON  A longtime FBI agent was charged Tuesday with having spied for Moscow since the 1980s, passing on highly sensitive data  including the names of agents working for the United States  and doing other damage that the FBI director described as "exceptionally grave."

title: A Little Corner of Spain, in Brooklyn Heights
description: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS would seem an obvious target for restaurateurs: beautiful buildings on thriving blocks, a diverse population with disposable income and few noteworthy eating places apart from the River Caf, Grimaldi's pizzeria and some spots on the Atlantic Avenue fringe. Yet the restaurant boom that has overtaken other neighborhoods has conspicuously bypassed Brooklyn Heights.

title: YAHOO EXPANDING WIRELESS SERVICE
description: The big search engine company Yahoo said yesterday that it had started to let users of Internet-enabled wireless telecommunications devices search for localized information. Yahoo Local Info allows users to search by street address, Zip code, city or state for information like concert and sports event listings, business directories and restaurant reviews, the company said.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  The Russians apparently never knew the name of their prized American spy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about secret recordings in which Ukraine's president, Leonid D. Kuchma, indicated that he had ordered a campaign of intimidation to win re-election misattributed a quotation. It was the former intelligence chief, Leonid Derkach  not Mr. Kuchma  who suggested additional powers for the prosecutor's office, saying, "If we are the power, then that is an instrument of our power  the prosecutor's office."

title: Are Rebounds Today Worth the Future?
description: Dikembe Mutombo is one of the best people in sports, a man who used the game as a tool to help others. Beyond his philanthropy, the Atlanta Hawks' center still has two good years left as a top-flight rebounder and shot-blocker.

title: Freshmen Blend In for Hoyas
description: Youth was supposed to be the theme in the Big East this season, with Seton Hall, St. John's and Connecticut each riding strong recruiting classes to remain among college basketball's elite teams. Instead, all three have struggled to incorporate the newcomers with upperclassmen, while Georgetown has used a pair of less-heralded freshmen to all but lock up an N.C.A.A. bid.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TOY STORE FOCUSES ON BABIES
description: F. A. O. Schwarz has renovated its flagship Fifth Avenue store and doubled the space dedicated to toys for preschool children. The toy retailer has renamed the entrance at Madison Avenue and 57th Street F. A. O. Baby, expanded its collection of Brio trains, stocked gifts for newborns and created extra-wide aisles to accommodate strollers. Since the $2 million renovation was completed Feb. 10, sales increased 137 percent from the same week last year, said David Niggli, the company's chief operating officer. The moves mirror a national trend. Fueled by a millennium baby boomlet, sales of infant and toddler toys increased 11.2 percent last year, even as overall toy sales fell 1.4 percent, according to the Toy Manufacturers of America.

title: Nassau Marks Surplus, but Leaders Warn Against Celebration
description: Nassau County, among the most famously mismanaged municipalities of recent times, has ended its second straight year with a multimillion-dollar surplus, the county comptroller said today.

title: TRENDS; Getting Fired Isn't What it Used to Be, and That's Good and Bad
description: Pink -- as in the pink slip -- is back in style. Preliminary figures released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that layoffs rose to 15,700 last year from 14,900 in 1999, with manufacturing and the high-technology industries especially hard hit. And the pace has picked up this year.

title: ENERGY EAST BUYING ROCHESTER UTILITY
description: The Energy East Corporation agreed to buy the RGS Energy Group Inc. for $1.4 billion in cash and stock to add power and natural-gas customers in New York state. Energy East, which owns New York State Electric & Gas and utilities in New England, will pay $39.50 a share in cash and stock for the owner of Rochester Gas & Electric. That is 19 percent more than Friday's closing price. Energy East will also assume about $1 billion in debt.

title: Airline Executive Is Named To Be Head of Burger King
description: Moving a step closer to its goal of leaving the burger business, Diageo, the British beer and spirits giant that owns Burger King, has hired a new chief executive to rejuvenate the fast-food chain and eventually take it public.

description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Tax Shelter Is Disallowed
description: A federal judge has ended a tax shelter that American Electric Power, an electric utility based in Columbus, Ohio, created using life insurance sold by the Hartford Group. American Electric said it would take a $317 million tax charge against 2000 earnings as a result of the decision yesterday by Judge James L. Graham of United States District Court in Columbus, Ohio. The charge covers taxes avoided, plus interest, from 1991 to 1999, said Pat D. Hemlepp, a spokesman for the company, which plans to appeal. The case is significant because American Electric obtained state approval for the shelter, only to be rejected by Judge Graham.

title: Driving With the Giants
description: DaimlerChrysler plans to market the Unimog in the United States. The vehicle weighs more than six tons, about the same as a Tyrannosaurus rex. It is twice the weight of, and three feet taller than, even the biggest sport utilities. Base price: $84,000. Bussiness Day, Page C1.

description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIEL, CAROLYN FORMAN
description: PIEL-Carolyn Forman. Died while snorkeling in the waters of Anguilla on February 13, 2001, at the age of 82. Professor emeritus of pediatric nephrology at the University of California at San Francisco, Dr. Piel, who published extensively in her field, was also a Past President of the American Board of Pediatrics, the first woman elected to that office. The wife of the late John Piel, M.D., she is survived by her brother, James Forman of Birmingham, Alabama and her four children, Dr. Mary Piel Hubbard of San Rafael, Elizabeth (Libby) Piel of San Francisco, John (Jock) Piel of Danville, and Scott Piel of Plantation, Florida. Also surviving are five grandchildren, Wil and Ross Hubbard, Jessica and John Joseph (Jake) Piel, III; and Taylor John Piel. On the seventh of March, a memorial service will be held at the St. Francis Yacht Club at 5PM. Contributions in memory of Dr. Piel should be sent to the UCSF Pediatric Nephrology Research at 533 Parnassus Avenue, SF, CA. 94143, or to the National Kidney Foundation, 553 Pilgrim Drive, Suite C, Foster City, CA 94404.

title: Looking Tough on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Investors May Get Access to Wider Market
description: In a move that is likely to benefit Chinese companies and foreign investors alike, China is planning to allow local investors to trade openly in the Class B shares of Chinese companies. That category of stock, traded here but denominated in foreign currency, has been reserved for foreigners.

title: Death at Daytona
description: Dale Earnhardt, the legendary Nascar driver who died after crashing in the final lap of Sunday's Daytona 500, left behind an extraordinary record of achievement -- 76 career wins over 26 years, 7 Winston Cup championships, more than $40 million in career earnings. His skill, competitive personality and rakish features made him one of the best-known drivers in America and an easily recognizable symbol of the boisterous, dangerous, expensive world of stock-car racing. But his ultimate legacy may be something that Earnhardt himself might not have anticipated -- a concerted effort to make Nascar racing a safer sport.

title: The Boss: Persuasion and Persistence
description: When I was at Westminster College in New Wilmington, Pa., I noticed a theater there that played terrible movies, things like Abbott and Costello meet the monster. In my sophomore year, the theater closed. Who was going to see Abbott and Costello on a Saturday night?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Leads Stocks Lower In a Technology Sell-Off

title: A Firmament Of All-Stars From All Over, All Glittering
description: An evening billed as ''Millennium International Ballet Gala, Stars of the 21st Century'' proved more routine than festive a year ago at the New York State Theater. But the opposite was true on Monday night as the same Canadian organizers presented another ''International Ballet Gala, Stars of the 21st Century.'' This time the dancing was better, and there were revelations. New Yorkers could see for the first time the perfection of Tamara Rojo, a young Spanish principal in Britain's Royal Ballet, and the brilliant Bournonville stylist, Johan Kobborg, a Dane with that company.

title: The Film of Taste: Just Add Soft Lighting and Close-Ups
description: Bogus good taste is not punished enough. It was a great pleasure last week to see the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences punish the infuriatingly bogus and tasteful ''House of Mirth'' by denying it any Oscar nominations. And this despite that aura of high aesthetic integrity that so often impresses -- or at least guilt-trips -- Hollywood. ''The House of Mirth'' is an art house success. But film art houses do business the same way art auction houses do: they have to sell what they can get and make it look as desirable as they can.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: No Confidence at Hunter

title: HALIFAX GROUP REPORTS PROFIT DECLINE
description: The Halifax Group indicated that second-half profit fell 10 percent as the company, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, increased spending to revamp computer systems and as the profitability of home loans declined. Net income fell to 541 million ($781 million), from 602 million in the second half of 1999. Full-year profit rose 9.8 percent. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News forecast a 14 percent second-half decline and a full-year gain of 8 percent. Halifax's retail banking net interest margin, which measures lending profitability, fell to 2.12 percent from 2.25 percent and will fall about 10 percent, or about 22 basis points, in 2001, and less than 3 percent in 2002, its chief executive, James Crosby, left, said in an interview. Halifax's overall net interest margin fell to 1.76 percent and is likely to decline more because the company has cut its home loan rate. From March, Halifax will sell mortgages at 100 basis points more than Britain's base rate, now at 5.75 percent. That will shave about 34 a month off a 60,000 mortgage at Halifax's current 7.5 percent standard variable rate, said Ian Beggs, a spokesman. The new mortgage rate is also expected to lure customers who are now paying a higher rate -- the standard variable rate -- to transfer about 10 billion in mortgage balances, Mr. Crosby said. The bank has 19 percent of the overall British mortgage market. The lender, based in West Yorkshire, last year bought the insurer St. James's Place Capital and Bank One's British credit card unit to diversify away from mortgages.

title: Ex-Aide Tells of Plot to Kill bin Laden

title: Nigeria's Press Bounces Back From Military Rule
description: Freshly hired reporters were typing away on a recent morning, sitting before shiny blue-and-red computers, as editors huddled nearby. At the end of the day, they would put out another issue of The Anchor, one of several new newspapers in the newly democratic Nigeria.

title: The Steak Awakened
description: STEAK is the simplest of meals to begin with, and the best seasonings for it are just as elemental. Salt and pepper go only so far, though, and so I was happy to discover steak in Tokyo flavored with nothing more than wasabi and garlic. This powerfully flavored paste takes plain beef to another level.

title: TV Notes: Reality Producer Sought by CBS
