title: Gaps in C.I.A.'s Ames Case May Be Filled by F.B.I.'s Own Spy Case
description: When a Central Intelligence Agency officer, Aldrich H. Ames, was arrested as a spy for Moscow in 1994, critics questioned how the agency could have allowed his espionage to go undetected for nine years. Officials at the Federal Bureau of Investigation helped fuel the criticism with complaints that the C.I.A. had failed to share sensitive information, stifling the investigation.

title: Study Finds Teenage Drug Use Higher in U.S. Than in Europe
description: American teenagers are far more likely than their European peers to use marijuana and other illicit drugs, but European teenagers are more likely to smoke cigarettes and drink alcohol, according to a study of 31 nations.

title: Where to Taste, and Learn, in New York
description: WINE classes in New York cater to the whole range of the curious, from connoisseurs to dilettantes. Here is a selection:

title: TAX EFFECTS AID DRESDNER NET PROFIT
description: Dresdner Bank, Germany's third-largest bank, said yesterday that net profit rose 60 percent, to 1.7 billion euros ($1.5 billion), in 2000 on the back of favorable tax effects. Analysts had forecast full-year net profit of 1.5 billion to 1.9 billion euros. Provisional income before taxes fell 24 percent last year, to 1.61 billion euros. A Dresdner Bank spokeswoman said the positive tax effect was related to deferred taxes after Germany's tax reform in 2001, which reduced corporate tax to 25 percent from 40 percent. Dresdner Bank confirmed that its failed merger with Deutsche Bank last year cost 550 million euros.

title: Getting Real Before Anyone Else; MTV's 'World' Rolls On With Voyeurs on Its Coattails
description: Years before the gimmickry of ''Survivor,'' ''Temptation Island,'' ''The Mole'' and the other reality shows now swamping television, there was ''The Real World.''

title: F.B.I. AGENT CHARGED AS SPY WHO AIDED RUSSIA 15 YEARS | Grave Harm Seen | Suspect Tied to Deaths of Counteragents -- Inquiry on Lapses
description: A senior F.B.I. agent who worked as a counterintelligence supervisor at the agency's headquarters was charged today as a spy who passed highly classified information to Russia for 15 years without being detected. Law enforcement officials described the case as an extremely grave breach of national security.

title: Indian Point Plant at Half Power After Water Leak Is Discovered
description: A tiny leak in a water pipe at Indian Point 2 has forced Consolidated Edison to operate the nuclear reactor at half power temporarily and has renewed safety concerns among some Westchester residents.

title: Rutgers Senior Shot to Death on Street Near Camden Campus
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 20  A 22- year-old Rutgers senior was fatally shot in the street near the state university's Camden campus Monday night, apparently by someone he knew, the Camden County prosecutor's office said today.

title: Hearst May Finish Tower Started in 1926
description: With the help of one of the world's most renowned architects, the Hearst Corporation may finally finish something it started 75 years ago: a headquarters tower near Columbus Circle.

title: 141 Varieties Of Sake to Savor, Page by Page (Or Take a Cab)
description: The term ''sake connoisseur'' cannot be applied to many Americans as yet, but John Gauntner bets that that will change, as more and better brands of sake come onto the market. His book ''The Sake Companion'' (Running Press, $24.95) is a handsome alphabetical directory of 137 sakes, most made in Japan and a few in the United States. Each gets its own page, with a description of its type and flavor, a picture of its label and its rating by the author. The book gives the history of sake, explains what to expect when you taste it, tells how to read a label and describes the main producers.

title: Countersuit Filed Against TV Contestant
description: CBS and the producer of its hit show ''Survivor'' filed a countersuit yesterday against Stacey E. Stillman, the former contestant on the show who sued two weeks ago contending that the show was rigged.

title: My Debt to Cousin Louis's Cornet
description: While viewing Ken Burns's recent television documentary series on jazz, I was interested to see that Louis Armstrong had been hired as a teenage delivery boy by immigrant New Orleans coal merchants called Karnofsky. They took him under their wing, fed him a hot meal every evening, lent him five dollars to buy his first cornet. And because they were Jewish, as a gesture of gratitude for their generosity Armstrong wore a Star of David around his neck for the rest of his life. Thus they inadvertently contributed to American culture -- and earned at least a measure of immortality.

title: Antiques, Foie Gras, a Bistro and 3 Ducks to Go
description: Organic chickens turn on a rotisserie, surrounded by French country antiques. Nearby, foie gras club sandwiches and salads with three kinds of duck are available to go. When D'Artagnan, the Newark purveyor of foie gras, game, truffles and mushrooms, decided to open its first Manhattan store, at 152 East 46th Street, a mere meat market was clearly never a possibility. The two-story store, called D'Artagnan, the Rotisserie, has a retail shop, prepared food to take out and a bistro. Through March 1, food in the bistro is half price.

title: Technology Shares Lead Market Lower
description: Technology stocks fell sharply yesterday, leading the market lower, as investors tried to adjust to the economic slowdown.

title: Back to Basics
description: Early in the fourth quarter, Stan Van Gundy, the Miami Heat assistant coach and Jeff Van Gundy's brother, approached Pat Riley and suggested that the Heat try to ride Anthony Mason to victory. Van Gundy thought the burly All-Star would be able to use his combination of finesse and muscle to overwhelm the Knicks.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Stuff column on Feb. 7 about the lighting fixtures at the Rock Center Cafe in Manhattan misidentified the company that sells them. It is Stephen McKay Lighting Inc., a manufacturer that deals only with the trade. Standard Lighting, at 14 East 38th Street, sells variations.

title: Article 2001022190357417082 -- No Title
description: Teenagers Try Online Learning

title: Pope Installs 44 New Cardinals
description: ROME, Feb. 21  Pope John Paul II today installed 44 new cardinals, the largest number at one time in history, in a ceremony that mingled rich pageantry with the solemn purpose of molding the institution that will someday pick his successor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, MARTHA PAULA RUPPANER KNOWN AS POPPI.
description: THOMAS-Martha Paula Ruppaner known as Poppi. Died suddenly on February 18, 2001 at her vacation home at Tryall, Jamaica. She was 85. The widow of Joseph A. Thomas, she was the beloved stepmother of Michael M. Thomas of Brooklyn, N.Y. and Jeffrey F. Thomas of San Francisco, CA. She is survived by her stepsons and their families, by her cousin, Dr. Pedrin Tondury of Switzerland and by numerous loving friends. Among the latter must be counted the denizens of the Animal Kingdom, whose interests she tirelessly served as a longtime Board member of the Wildlife Conservation Society (formerly the New York Zoological Society) and the Animal Medical Center (of which she was Board Chair Emerita and recipient of its ''Top Dog'' and Brook Astor awards). Interment will be private. Memorial services will be scheduled in Old Brookville, L.I. and Jamaica at later dates. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Wildlife Conservation Society or the Animal Medical Center.

title: Dreamland Creatures, Pastel and Jewel-Like
description: The family programs that the New York Theater Ballet offers at Gould Hall may be choreographically tailored for children, but they are not childish. That's why these ballets can be enjoyed by audiences young and old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOZLIN, EMMA KAMINSKY
description: MOZLIN-Emma Kaminsky. On February 19th, 2001. Wife of the late Robert, mother of Roseanne and Paul Klein and Michael and Cynthia Mozlin, grandmother of Hannah Lipman and Ryan and Kyle Mozlin, sister of Louis Kaminsky, Mary Cohen, Mildred Rosenblatt and Meyer Kaminsky. Resident of Pembroke Pines, FL, formerly of Cranbury, NJ and the Bronx, NY. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at Wien & Wien Funeral Home, Hackensack, NJ. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Napster Planning Fees Starting in Summer
description: Outlining plans to transform itself into a fee-based service, Napster said today that it intends to start charging users this summer to exchange music files online. And the company said it has proposed giving $1 billion over five years to record companies, including the major record labels that sued Napster after accusing it of abetting copyright infringement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABRIEL, RYAN
description: GABRIEL-Ryan. We mourn the tragic loss of beloved Ryan. We grieve with our dear friends Barbara, Barry and Spencer and the rest of the family. Randee, Michael, Ilana, and Ross

title: A Worthwhile Substitute For the Regents Exams
description: A NUMBER of New York City alternative schools want to substitute their student projects, known as portfolios, for Regents exams as graduation requirements in math, social studies and science. The New York State education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, who has already said that all students must take the English Regents, promises a decision on these other subjects soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LEO HARRY
description: BERMAN-Leo Harry. Died February 16, 2001 in his 85th year in Westport, CT. A memorial service will be held at 7 PM on Friday, February 23rd, at the Unitarian Church in Westport, 10 Lyons Plain Road, Westport, CT. Calling hours will be held the folowing day, Saturday, February 24th at 19 Otter Trail, Westport, CT.

title: Business Travel; Passengers Face Delays, As Well As Labor Woes
description: As if last summer's record delays and cancellations weren't bad enough for business travelers, there's apocalyptic talk these days that the air-transportion system is now flying into what Aviation Week magazine last month described as the potential ''Perfect Storm.''

title: A Tempest Over Photo of Shackled Boy
description: On a Sunday afternoon last October, Ingeborg Coffman was working in the photo lab of the Wal-Mart store in Plant City, Fla., when two fellow technicians asked her to look at a disturbing print that one of them had developed. It showed a boy of maybe 8 or 10 sitting on what looked like a toilet, Ms. Coffman recalled, his arms and legs bound together with silver duct tape.

title: Man Killed in Central Park Robbery; 2 Are Held
description: In the first homicide inside Central Park since July 1999, a 25-year-old man sitting on a bench near the Harlem Meer was shot to death in a botched robbery attempt early yesterday, the police said. Two men were arrested last night in the case.

title: Is It Time to Abolish the SAT?
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill's Final Tour? Don't Mention It
description: The Aviators were a bunch of energetic second-graders in a recreation league in Cincinnati who made more turnovers than baskets and who kicked the ball as often as they dribbled it. These 8-year olds were trying to learn the game while playing against a league stacked with third-graders, which is more daunting than it sounds. One year can make a sizable difference when the ball is almost as big as you.

title: Hard Realities On the Rio Grande
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Intel Plans Broad Measures to Cut Costs
description: Intel today announced a wide range of cost-saving measures, including delayed raises for employees, but not layoffs, intended to counter a slowing economy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LYON, ANDY LOGAN
description: LYON-Andy Logan. A memorial tribute to New Yorker writer Andy Logan will be held on Sunday, February 25, 2 PM, at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park So.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALKER, JOHN H.
description: WALKER-John H. On February 19, 2001. U.S. Army World War II Veteran. Beloved husband of Rosalyn. Devoted father of Barbara. Graveside services will be held Thursday, February 22, 11:00AM at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENEBAUM, BETTY
description: GREENEBAUM-Betty. Scarsdale, NY resident, died February 16. Dearest mother of Madeline Paulson (Chad) and beloved grandmother of J.T. Funeral Friday, 12:30PM, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Contributions to Betty Greenebaum Fund at the Scarsdale Historical Society, P.O. Box 431, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISENBERG, FRIEDA (NEE EPSTEIN)
description: ISENBERG-Frieda (nee Epstein). Of Forest Hills, NY on February 19, 2001. Beloved wife of Morris for over 55 years, devoted mother of Edward, Elliott and Howard, loving grandmother of Karen Clements and Paula Zuckerman, great-grandmother of Lauren and Brian Clements. She served as a teacher for 25 years in the public school system of NY. Services Wed, 1 PM, at Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Rash of Gaffes And Scandals Shakes Party's Grip on Japan
description: When Yoshiro Mori was chosen by a secretive conclave of governing party leaders 10 months ago to become prime minister after Keizo Obuchi's death, Mr. Mori was thought to be a safe interim choice to lead the government.

title: The Neediest Cases; Conquering Isolation of Deafness and Mental Illness
description: On the day in 1986 when the police in Flushing, Queens, received a call that a homeless man was sleeping in their neighborhood's sidewalks, they did not have to go far to find him. The man, Michael Smith, then 43, slept behind the police station. The police picked him up and had him taken to the Bellevue Hospital Center psychiatric ward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANKER, SARA
description: ANKER-Sara. Beloved teacher, guidance counselor, friend. Wife of the late Irving Anker. Mother of Laura, Deborah and Philip David. Grandmother of Shanna, Rebecca, Joshua, Alyssa, Kimberly, Philip Samuel and Jessie. Great grandmother of Mizel Isaiah. Sister of Harry Rudman. Services Thursday, 12 Noon at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expy, Fresh Meadows, N.Y. Contributions may be made to the SUNY/Old Westbury College Foundation for the Irving and Sara Anker Public Education Scholarship, Old Westbury, NY 11568-0210.

title: Many Candidates for Next Rangers Save
description: The Rangers are in desperate need of a top-flight goaltender now that Mike Richter is lost for the season because of a knee injury. Nikolai Khabibulin, in a contract dispute with Phoenix, is just that.

title: A Cheesecake, Part Cloud, That Borders on the Perfect
description: AFTER two hours at a table, ending with cheesecake has always seemed to me an efficient way to kill dining's euphoria. You take a bite, and what lands on your palate is a dull brick that obliterates all that came before it.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; 'Private' Group Is Ruled a Public Entity
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a nominally private association regulating interscholastic sports in Tennessee's public and private high schools should be treated, like any other arm of government, as a public agency that is bound by the Constitution.

title: Opening The Book Of Wine
description: WHEN Kevin Zraly, the instructor at the Windows on the World Wine School, started his program 24 years ago, he was among a small group of eccentrics teaching wine in a city content with martinis and beer.

title: 24/7 MEDIA DEFERS PROFIT REPORT
description: The interactive marketing company 24/7 Media Inc. said yesterday that it would postpone its fourth-quarter earnings announcement because the company was ''actively evaluating strategic alternatives to improve its cash position.'' The shares of 24/7 Media fell 12.5 cents, or 10.53 percent, to $1.06, yesterday. A year ago, 24/7 was trading at more than $60 a share. A spokesman for 24/7, Mitchell Simmons, said the company would complete the evaluation to improve the cash position so that results can be released on March 21. The fourth-quarter earnings announcement had been scheduled for Monday. Wall Street analysts expect 24/7 to report a loss of 49 cents a share. Allison Fass

title: An Editor's Lament
description: To the Editor:

title: Goliath Shrimp (Gigantic Flavor, Too)
description: THEY stare up from the plate at Esca, a seafood restaurant in the theater district, like baleful prehistoric monsters, long feelers projecting forward under eyes the size of gray capers, their legs gathered and curled around their fleshy bodies, braised fennel strewn across the top. Their size is striking, as big as the arc made by the thumb and middle finger and as thick as a fat carrot.

title: New Optimism Buoys Efforts To End War In Congo
description: Rwanda's decision to begin pulling back troops from positions in Congo, and the new Congolese president's go-ahead for talks on his country's political future, are creating optimism as ministers from Africa prepare to open two days of talks in the Security Council Wednesday on ending the Congolese war.

title: Corrections
description: Charts of holiday travel schedules last Friday through Monday for Washington's Birthday included an erroneous summary of New York City parking rules supplied by the Department of Transportation. Alternate-side regulations were suspended, but other normal regulations -- not Sunday rules -- remained in effect.

title: Finding Site, Not Cash, Slows Schools
description: At Public School 112 in Long Island City, half a class of fifth graders, about 15 students, regularly meets in what used to be the boys' locker room. Their coats hang from hooks for the showers, still covered in industrial yellow tile.

title: Puts and Calls: Mixed Signals On Direction Of the Market
description: The pros are confident, but the amateurs are scared. Unfortunately, this is one area where the amateurs seem to have a better forecasting record.

title: Study Suggests New Option for Women With Abnormal Pap Tests
description: For the two million American women a year who have ambiguous or borderline abnormal results on the Pap test, which is used to screen for cervical cancer, a new study by the National Cancer Institute may ease the confusion about what to do next.

title: From Dour 'Mortician' of F.B.I. To Suspected Russian Superspy
description: The Russians apparently never knew the name of their prized American spy.

title: Ramallah Journal; Bitter, Stark Souvenirs: Sneakers and Slingshots
description: In one translucent plastic box, there is a single sock, recovered by the widow of 25-year-old Bilal Affaneh after he was shot dead by Israeli forces outside the Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem last September.

title: EL PASO SELECTS CISCO EQUIPMENT
description: Cisco Systems has won an order to sell as much as $1 billion in data-networking and optical equipment to the El Paso Corporation, which is building a fiber optic network, the companies said. The order comes two weeks after Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., missed quarterly financial goals and cut its sales forecast.

title: Fight for Grammys
description: Over the years the Grammy Awards broadcast has performed very well in the ratings for CBS. It has generally held an audience of much more than 20 million during its three decades on television. Last year it was watched by nearly 28 million people.

title: Colorado Children's Deaths Rekindle Debate on Religion
description: The deaths over the last two years of three Colorado children whose parents denied them medical treatment on religious grounds has fueled support for state legislation that would prevent parents from using their religion as a defense against prosecution.

title: McGreevey Issues Tax Returns, Saying His Assets Are 'Meager'
description: Moving to distinguish himself as the candidate most committed to fully disclosing personal finances, James E. McGreevey, the likely Democratic nominee for governor, released tax returns for the last eight years today.

title: Knicks Trying To Land Mutombo
description: The Knicks have offered Marcus Camby, perhaps their most energetic, crowd-pleasing player, and Glen Rice, their most accurate 3-point shooter, to the Atlanta Hawks for Dikembe Mutombo, three Eastern Conference officials said yesterday.

title: Chinese Fiber-Optic Work Linked to Raided Iraqi Sites
description: Chinese workers were helping the Iraqi military build a fiber-optic network linked to radar stations and other targets attacked by American and British warplanes last week, defense and intelligence officials said today, raising a new challenge for the Bush administration just as it is communicating for the first time with the Chinese leadership.

title: Putin Invites West to Work On a Defense For Missiles
description: President Vladimir V. Putin called on Europe and the NATO alliance today to work with Russia on developing a common defense against missile attacks and presented a set of proposals to the NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, who is visiting Moscow.

title: Is It Time to Abolish the SAT?
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Kellogg Consolidates Cereal Work at Burnett
description: Kellogg USA is consolidating its United States general market cereal advertising at Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, which had handled most of that assignment, by shifting duties previously at the New York office of J. Walter Thompson. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The trusted insider

title: Heated Letter To an Official Leads to Arrest
description: A 40-year-old city employee who wrote a letter to the Staten Island borough president criticizing him for closing a youth center in a largely black neighborhood was arrested last month and held overnight.

title: Management: Discarded Dreams Of Dot-Com Rejects; Growing Indignation Results From Recent Brusque Dismissals
description: They are young, smart and bitter. They are the victims of the recent wave of layoffs in the high-technology industry, and many of them cannot believe how clumsy their former employers were in delivering the bad news.

title: 'Facing History' Online
description: On the Crayola Crayons Web site you can pick up some fascinating trivia:

title: The Cappuccino Buzz That Runs on Batteries
description: Craving a cup of cappuccino or latte with a tall, frothy head of warm milk -- but not another large machine in your kitchen? Make one serving of espresso in a tiny stove-top pot, and bring out the Aerolatte, a little hand-held mixer that operates with two AA batteries. It can whip up foam for your coffee directly in a mug or cup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONKMEYER, HILDE RUTH
description: MONKMEYER-Hilde Ruth. On February 19, 2001 at age 94. Bold and independent beyond compare. Beloved wife of the late Paul Monkmeyer. Loving mother of Peter Monkmeyer and Peggy Mastroianni. Devoted grandmother of Susan, Jim, Bob, Christina and Antonio and great-grandmother of four. After earning her doctorate from the University of Berlin, she worked as a journalist in Germany and, in 1937, emigrated to America with her husband and young son. A pioneer in the field of photojournalism, she founded Monkmeyer Press Photo Service where she and her husband worked side by side for many joyful years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMERMAN, ELAINE Z.
description: SOMMERMAN-Elaine Z. On February 18, 2001. Loving mother of Ellen Buckwald and the late son Dr. Neil Sommerman, wife of the late Dr. Aaron Sommerman, grandmother of Brett and Linda Buckwald, Rebecca and Mark Masercola and Dr. Emily Sommerman and Doug Croft, great grandmother of Mallory, Abby, Miles and Alex. Mother-in-law of loving Marty Buckwald. Loving sister of Florence Eisenberg and late brother-in-law Bernard, and most devoted nieces & nephews.

title: Article 2001022193712946465 -- No Title
description: By MARGARET W. GOLDSBOROUGH

title: Lindros Saga Completes a Circle
description: Twenty-five years ago, as a rookie on the hockey beat, I wrote about Bobby Orr and Gordie Howe. Before that season, Orr left the Boston Bruins as a 28-year-old free agent. Despite several knee injuries of increasing severity, teams vied for his prestigious name. Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League, called the bidding ''a dog's breakfast.'' The winning team was Chicago. Plagued with knee pain, Orr played only 20 games for the 1976-77 Blackhawks and soon retired.

title: INSIDE
description: High-Tech Searches at Issue

title: U.N. Board Says Legal Drug Use Increases in Rich Countries
description: An international narcotics monitoring board is warning that legal drugs like Viagra, steroids and diet pills are being consumed in worrying excess in richer countries, particularly in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLER, JOYCE DEVRIES
description: LAWLER-Joyce DeVries, on February 16, 2001. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Loving mother of Anna. Sadly missed by the Eccarius family of Abbington, PA and the DeVries family of the Netherlands. She was a home care physical therapist in the Brooklyn and Pocono areas. Relatives and friends are invited to attend her memorial service Saturday, February 24, 1 PM, at the Craft-Givnish Funeral Home, 1801 Old York Rd. at Old Welsh Rd; Abbington, PA, 215-659-2000. Memorial contributions may be made to your local Humane Society or SPCA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAXE, THELMA
description: DAXE-Thelma. At age 88, on Feb. 18th, 2001, in Miami. Longtime resident of Great Neck, New York. Beloved wife of the late Arnold, adored mother of Brenda Feldman, Arnold Jr., and Chester. Cherished grandmother of Peter, Steven, Jeffrey, and Shelly. Dear sister of Murray Laurence. Private memorial services at Riverside-Gordon, Miami FL., February 25. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimer's Assn in her name would be appreciated.

title: Hunting bin Laden's Allies, U.S. Extends Net to Europe
description: Spurred by growing international alarm about Osama bin Laden's militant networks, the police in Britain and Germany have recently arrested more than a dozen Islamic radicals. American officials say some of those arrested were plotting terrorist attacks in Europe and elsewhere.

title: Lines That Divide, Ties That Bind
description: One hundred preachers are on 100 Harlem corners, and Michelle Ramirez is on hers: Fifth Avenue and West 129th Street. She positions her microphone, aims her voice at the tenement opposite, and opens fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAVES, MAE ANNA, DR.
description: GRAVES-Mae Anna, Dr. entered into eternal life February 16, 2001. Beloved sister of Kathleen Richardson, Virginia Walker, Ellis Robinson of Pittsburgh, PA., and Curtis Lee Robinson of Tucson, AZ. Loving grandmother of Marilyn Ford-Vessels of Denver, CO and James Lane of Brooklyn, NY. Services Thursday, February 22, 2001 7PM at the Goodwill Baptist Church, 642-44 Crotona Park South, Bronx, New York. Viewing, 4PM-7PM. For information Roy L. Gilmore's Funeral Home, Inc. St. Albans, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A letter on Saturday about Head Start misidentified a person involved in discussions about the program in 1978. It was Lady Bird Johnson, the former first lady, not former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who died in 1973.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBACH, MARIA
description: MARBACH-Maria. Congregation Kol Ami records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and conveys sincere condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Thomas K. Weiner Rabbi Shira Milgrom Ken Simon, President

title: Corrections
description: Charts of holiday travel schedules last Friday through Monday for Washington's Birthday included an erroneous summary of New York City parking rules supplied by the Department of Transportation. Alternate-side regulations were suspended, but other normal regulations -- not Sunday rules -- remained in effect.

title: Bloomberg Close to Deal to Move Into Tower on Alexander's Site
description: After more than 26 months of often tortuous negotiations with a developer, Bloomberg L.P., the giant financial information and media company, said yesterday that it was close to signing a deal for a proposed 70-story tower on the site of the old Alexander's department store at Lexington Avenue and 59th Street.

title: Bridgestone in New Recall of 98,000 Firestones
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said today that it was recalling about 98,000 Firestone-brand tires mounted mostly on Altima SE sedans because surface cracks on the edge of the tires could spread.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about a recommendation that the University of California stop requiring applicants to take the SAT misspelled the surname and misstated the title of an executive of FairTest, an organization that opposes the SAT. He is Bob Schaeffer, not Schaefer -- the group's public education director, not its president.

title: Russian Dash, in an Evening of Firebirds and Nightingales
description: Hearing the New York Philharmonic's all-Russian program Thursday night was a bit like reading an entire book of fairy tales at one sitting. The stories ranged from ''Romeo and Juliet'' (Tchaikovsky) to ''The Song of the Nightingale'' and the ''Firebird'' Suite (Stravinsky), with Rachmaninoff's ''Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini'' as an essayistic exegesis.

title: Protocol Wars; A Standard Emerges, but Watch Out for Those Microwave Ovens
description: THE protocol called I.E.E.E. 802.11b has been put in place by so many companies offering wireless short-range networks that it is emerging as the standard for the field.

title: Ordering Up a Bit of Starck or Ritz
description: STANTON ORELOVE travels 120,000 miles a year, allowing him to road-test a lot of beds. Recently, he found nirvana while staying at the W hotel in San Francisco: a queen-size mattress and box spring with a feather bed on top. His purchase of a set just like it, plus two changes of linens and two square European-style pillows, set him back $1,400 -- a bit more than the tab for a three-night stay at the hotel.

title: Michigan Plans a High-Tech Lure
description: Here in Michigan, it may soon be possible for a lawyer to argue a court case while sitting in New York at a kitchen table, wearing pajamas, sipping coffee and eating a sticky bun for breakfast.

title: Metro Business Briefing; OLD RESORT HOPES FOR REVIVAL
description: The City Council of Long Beach, N.Y., has chosen the development company Philips International to build a 100-room hotel and two residential condominiums on a vacant six-acre beachfront site. The city intends to acquire the 13 lots through eminent domain, with the owners of the lots expected to challenge the city's valuations in court. There are no longer any hotels in Long Beach, once a popular Long Island resort. Bruce Nyman, the city manager, said officials hoped construction on the $100 million project could begin early next year. In 1998 the city contracted with another developer for a project on the site, but it could not obtain financing. Joseph P. Fried

title: Life Without Parole for Wendy's Killer
description: A Queens man who pleaded guilty to taking part in the massacre of five workers at a Wendy's restaurant in Flushing was sentenced to life in prison yesterday, but not before four of the victims' relatives addressed him in court and told him how the shootings had ripped apart their families and their lives.

title: Guy Rodgers, an N.B.A. All-Star, Dies at 65
description: Guy Rodgers, a four-time National Basketball Association All-Star, a two-time all-American at Temple University and one of the most talented guards and playmakers of his era, died Monday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 65.

title: Teenagers and Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Web, Without Wires, Wherever
description: IT'S coming soon to an espresso bar near you.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Wearing Your Vital Signs on Your Wrist
description: FOR decades, electronic devices have helped people who have fallen and can't get up.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Vital Signs column of Science Times on Tuesday about possible links between a vaccine and autism misstated the scope of the General Practitioners Research Database, on which a new study was based. It comprises detailed information on some four million children and adults, not almost all children born in the United Kingdom.

title: U.N. War Crimes Court Convicts Bosnian Serbs in Rape Case
description: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 22  In a groundbreaking prosecution of sexual slavery, a United Nations war crimes tribunal in the Hague convicted three Bosnian Serbs for taking part in the systematic rape of Muslim women during the Bosnian war and sentenced the men to long prison terms.

title: TRADE DEFICIT IN JAPAN
description: Japan's trade balance in January dipped into negative territory for the first time in four years, registering a deficit of 95.3 billion yen ($824 million) for the month. Goods imported into Japan exceeded exports as the slumping economies in the United States and the rest of Asia, Japan's two biggest export markets, slowed Japan's export growth while the increasing price of oil bloated the value of imports. Miki Tanikawa

title: Microsoft Outlook Add-On For Wireless Keeps You Posted
description: Microsoft recently took the wraps off a free Microsoft Outlook e-mail add-on called Outlook Mobile Manager, a program that automatically forwards urgent e-mail messages to any wireless gadget, like a Palm VII, a BlackBerry pager or a text-message-capable cell phone. Once you have taught the program which messages to forward, Mobile Manager uses artificial intelligence to decide which future messages are worth sending on to you. The program is available in prototype form at www.microsoft.com

title: GENERAL MOTORS PLANS TEMPORARY CLOSINGS OF PLANTS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it planned intermittent closings of 14 plants through mid-June. The temporary closings will affect almost half of the automaker's 29 plants in North America. G.M. said it also planned to slow assembly at four plants. G.M. and other automakers have been idling factories and laying off workers to reduce inventories as demand drops after record sales in 2000. The 14 factories are being idled for one to five weeks.

title: Wolfinger to Transfer From St. John's
description: Jack Wolfinger's nomadic basketball life took another turn yesterday when St. John's announced that he was transferring. St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis described the parting as mutual, but he also expressed disappointment that Wolfinger, a redshirt freshman, would again face a disruption in his life.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: CREDIT RATING UPGRADED

title: Soft Colors and Simple Lines: Rooms to Tame the Daily Grind
description: Modnature, another favorite decorating shop for Parisians, is at 3, rue Jacob, just across the street from Blanc d'Ivoire. Its creator, Henry Becq, an interior designer, loves simple lines and natural colors (ecru, straw, brown, white). Clients are encouraged to embrace the total Modnature look, as seen in the current collection, left, upholstered in soft white leather, but most individualists are likely to mix things from here and places like Blanc d'Ivoire. Modnature's furniture, goatskin rugs and the three white Bottle vases shown ($140, $175 and $200) are in New York at Intrieurs, 149 Franklin Street (Varick Street); (212) 343-0800.

title: A Better Intifada
description: The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians grows increasingly violent, and Israel seems to be heading toward a unity government that may strengthen Ariel Sharon's political hand.

title: Microsoft Settles Suit With Bristol Technology
description: Ending a bitter three-year-old private lawsuit, Microsoft and Bristol Technology Inc. today agreed to a confidential settlement of a dispute over antitrust and unfair trade practices.

title: A Honeymooner's Gamble Sneaks a Game Contract By
description: Freezing temperatures and seven hours of daylight might not seem attractive for a honeymoon, but with bridge players you never know. Suellen Beres and John Solodar, who met as Gimbels trainees 38 years ago, were married in Manhattan this month and immediately set off for Iceland and its annual tournament.

title: Dot-Com, Esq.: Legal Guidance, Lawyer Optional
description: AS a small talent agency in the swaggering Hollywood entertainment world, CMB was struggling for a foothold.

title: Bound by the Spirit World as They Drifted Apart
description: FAMILIAR SPIRITS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELBY, JEROME
description: SHELBY-Jerome. Died on February 21, 2001 at the age of 70 after a long bout with leukemia, which he endured with characteristic courage, grace and humor. A business man's lawyer, he earned his Bachelor's Degree from New York University in 1950 and graduated Cum Laude from Harvard Law School with an LL.B. degree in 1953. Immediately thereafter, he joined Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, where he became a protege of H. Lee White, a successful ship finance lawyer and shipping businessman. Mr. Shelby was a Partner of the Firm from 1963 through 1992. During his tenure as Partner, Mr. Shelby served as Cochairman of the Firm for more than nine years and was a member of Cadwalader's Management Committee for close to two decades. After stepping down as a Partner in 1992, he remained Counsel to the Firm. He is survived by his wife, Adrian, son P. Austin Shelby and daughter-in-law Heath Shelby of West Orange, NJ, daughter Dr. Karen Shelby Anderson and sonin-law Tim Anderson of Bedford, NH, granddaughters Meredith Shelby, Melissa Shelby, Emily Anderson and Shelby Anderson, a grandson Maxwell Anderson and brother Judge Stuart Shelby of Santa Monica, CA. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 23, at 11:30AM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Donations may be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Patience Is a Virtue, Accorsi Is Finding
description: The Giants' Ernie Accorsi, at the grand old age of 59, is now the most experienced general manager in the National Football League. He has always been considered a smart football man, but in his contract talks with two key potential free agents, cornerback Jason Sehorn and running back Tiki Barber, he must rely on something else, and that is patience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, EVA H.
description: MEYER-Eva H. Beloved wife of Manfred. Loving mother of David and Paulette. Grandmother of Rachel and sister of Benjamin Hoffman of Tel Aviv. Service Thursday, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Loft With a Bridge Over Untroubled Waters
description: DAVID LING lives in what is quite likely the only loft in New York with an office, two bodies of water, a wood bridge and a waterfall. ''I commute along a stone-lined moat, live on a metallic lily pad surrounded by water, shower in a silver cone, sit on a floating throne and sleep on a king-size diving board,'' he said dryly.

title: No Man's an Island, All Are Islanders
description: ''Vieques,'' the play, is not about what you might think it would be. No warships tearing up the turf with target practice. No civilian protesters against the Navy being forcibly removed from the little island just east of Puerto Rico. No noble poor islanders being dispossessed by a brutal superpower.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, DOUGLASS
description: CAMPBELL-Douglass. The Board of Directors and shareholders of 5 East 71st Street, Inc. express their deepest sympathy to the Campbell family at the sudden passing of its longtime friend, neighbor and member of the Board of Directors. 5 East 71st Street, Inc. Michael Jesselson, President

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: State Workers Ruled Unable To Sue Under Disability Act

title: A CLINTON IN-LAW RECEIVED $400,000 IN 2 PARDON CASES
description: Former President Bill Clinton's brother-in-law Hugh Rodham received nearly $400,000 in fees for lobbying for a presidential pardon and a prison commutation for two wealthy felons, Mr. Rodham's lawyer and other officials said today.

title: Metro Business Briefing; BANK'S LICENSE SUSPENDED
description: The State Banking Department has suspended the license of a Massapequa, N.Y., mortgage bank for failing to comply with regulations and for submitting misleading documents that misrepresented its financial condition, officials said yesterday. In its statement of charges, the department said the bank, Morning Star Real Estate and Mortgage Financing Corporation, submitted statements in July and December that purported to have been certified by an accountant who later denied ever having had any contact with the bank. A hearing will be held within 30 days to determine if the bank should lose its license permanently, said Bethany Blankley, a spokeswoman for the Banking Department. Angela Daidone-Sutphen, the president of Morning Star, denied wrongdoing and said she would seek to get the suspension overturned in court. Terry Pristin

title: Aiming for the Pin
description: Less than two months into the PGA Tour season, scoring records have been falling faster than the price of some Internet stocks.

title: New York's New Cardinal
description: The cardinal of New York's sprawling archdiocese has historically been one of the most important non-elected officials in a city that Pope John Paul II has called ''the capital of the world.'' Yesterday, in a sunlit ceremony before thousands of believers in Rome's St. Peter's Square, the pope presented scarlet caps or birettas to 44 new cardinals, including Edward Egan, the successor to Cardinal John O'Connor as New York City's premier Catholic leader. Cardinal Egan brings to this crucial job many powerful assets.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Legal Aid Online; Web's Law Library: A Partial Catalog
description: WEB sites offering legal information, advice, documents and referrals to consumers and small business owners have proliferated in the last five years and are expected to grow sharply over the next decade.

title: Vox Populi Aside, Power to the City Council
description: The New York City Council has the power to repeal the term-limits law, several legal experts agree. But if those pushing to overturn the law are successful, some of the lawyers caution, the Council will wind up facing formidable legal challenges.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell after Japan posted its first trade deficit in four years, a sign the global slowdown is hurting growth. In New York, the dollar settled at 116.62 yen, up from 115.66 yen on Tuesday.

title: A Technology Magazine Is Reducing Its Staff by 17%
description: In a move that signals the ever-deepening crisis in the sector of magazines that focus on technology and the Internet economy, Standard Media International, the parent company of The Industry Standard magazine, announced yesterday that the company would cut its staff by about 17 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a call on NATO by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to develop a joint missile defense system misstated NATO's membership in some editions. It is 19 countries, not 16.

title: Absolut customizes a campaign to salute the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.
description: THE long-running marketing efforts for Absolut vodka have been focused on print advertisements and posters that salute artists, liquor ingredients, cities, states and even states of mind. Now the campaign is breaking another path by promoting a cause.

title: Jackson Comes Home in Trade for Childs
description: He began his pro career making dazzling passes in the arena of his childhood dreams, wowing the Madison Square Garden crowd with feeds that often defied description. Eventually, Mark Jackson's flashy-to-a-fault play and defensive liabilities turned the hometown fans against him, and he was jettisoned from New York and became a Knicks antagonist.

title: Benefits of Deregulated Energy Elude Business
description: A new study by a leading consulting firm has found that many American businesses are ''wholly unprepared'' to deal with electricity deregulation and that few have switched electricity providers to take advantage of deregulation.

title: A Convict in the Storm's Eye Had Plenty of Other Help
description: Hugh Rodham, Bill Clinton's brother-in-law, was far from the only advocate for Carlos Vignali, a convicted Los Angeles cocaine dealer whose 15-year prison sentence Mr. Clinton commuted on his last day as president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGENSTEIN, LUDWIG
description: REGENSTEIN - Ludwig. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member, Renee Pepper, and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck Yaacov Lerner, Rabbi Michael Frank, President

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Neither Hillary nor I had any knowledge of such payments. We are deeply disturbed by these reports and have insisted that Hugh return any monies received.''

title: Fans of Modernism Criticize Cigna's Plan to Raze Offices
description: To the people with an eye on the bottom line, they are expensive dinosaurs that should be bulldozed for a golf course. But to the architects who gathered at a symposium in New Haven two weekends ago to discuss corporate Modernism, two buildings on the Bloomfield, Conn., campus of Cigna Corporation are icons of the International style that merit praise and preservation.

title: Stocks End Mostly Lower on Fears of Weakening Economy
description: The stock market struggled unsuccessfully today to recover from recent setbacks that eliminated any remainder of this year's early gains.

title: In America; Rising Tides
description: The easiest approach for the time being is to pretend it's not happening. It's better for the nerves in the short run to remain riveted by the Clinton follies or the latest shenanigans on ''Temptation Island'' than to acknowledge that the majestic ice cap atop Mount Kilimanjaro, which seemed for so long to be an almost permanent feature of the planet, will vanish in less than 15 years.

title: Polka Dots: Grown Up, Everywhere To Go
description: POLKA dots took their name from the polka, which stormed the dance floors of Vienna and other European cities in the mid-1800's. For the next 150 years, polka dots appeared on everything from tablecloths to little girls' dresses. Today, polka dots have finally grown up: designers are now using larger, irregularly spaced dots and spots to create sophisticated patterns. Candy hues have given way to purple, chartreuse and taupe. This season, polka dots have popped up on everything from rugs and pillows to paperweights. And don't be fooled by a dinner plate bearing one big dot on its center; a table set for 12 will look absolutely dotty.

title: They Can Feel the Pain Of a Dissociated World
description: Bebe Miller's new ''Verge'' opens with a man reaching into another man's mouth and telling him to ''just relax, O.K.?'' The heart sinks, and continues to settle as Ms. Miller's four dancers speak at one another in desultory encounters. There will be no room for the audience here, it seems.

title: In Switzerland, Stagecraft From a Cast of Parisians
description: To stage ''Lucio Silla'' by Mozart, the Opera of Lausanne, Switzerland, has imported Paris-based talent. The dcor is by Mattia Bonetti of the design team Garouste & Bonetti, known for its stylized, cartoonish, baroque designs, among them perfume bottles for Nina Ricci, shops for Christian Lacroix and the Palace nightclub. Mr. Bonetti upholstered a metal throne in red velour (above) for the opera, which is directed by the actor Jean-Marc Bory with costumes by the couturier Adeline Andr. Sunday through March 7, Opra de Lausanne, 011-41.21.310.16.00; www.regart.ch/opera-lausanne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, RUTH
description: HELLER-Ruth. Wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Susan Carden, Carole Heller and Richard Heller. Dear grandmother. Services Friday, 12 Noon, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the acquittal of six protesters charged with having disrupted Congress in a demonstration for Congressional voting rights in the District of Columbia, and an article on Nov. 1 about a mistrial in the same case, misspelled the names of two defendants. They were Debby Hanrahan, not Hebby Hannahan, and Queen Mother Shema Yah, not Queen Mother Sheme Yah. (Ms. Hanrahan's husband telephoned about the errors after the second article was published.)

title: Courses Don't Add Up
description: To the Editor:

title: NO DISSENT ON BRITISH RATE CUT
description: The Bank of England said its decision to reduce interest rates by one-quarter of a percentage point this month was unanimous, with two of the nine members of its Monetary Policy Committee urging a bigger reduction of one-half point. Voicing concern about the slowdown in the United States economy, the committee voted two weeks ago to bring the benchmark interest rate down to 5.75 percent, the first cut in 20 months. Alan Cowell

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Rock On
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 9 about layoffs and other cutbacks at technology companies in the New York region referred incorrectly to one step taken by the RCN Corporation, a cable television, telephone and Internet service provider. It is writing off its investment in JuniorNet, a children's Web site that is seeking a buyer; the company is not trying to sell its Internet unit.

title: 'Thank You For the 50,000'
description: The letters and phone calls between Russia's spymasters and the American turncoat they called B reveal a man as intent on concealing his identity as he was on helping Moscow. Excerpts, Page A14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARL, BELLA
description: PEARL-Bella. Survived by her loving daughters Fern Pearl and Shereen Posner. cherished grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Funeral services Thursday, 12:45PM at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Should We Watch McVeigh Die?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Chief Executive as Chief Cheerleader
description: Chief executives of publicly traded companies know that in addition to managing their companies, they must manage their stock's price. And with so much executive pay riding on a rising stock price, they have great incentive to be especially skilled spin doctors in today's dreary stock market.

title: Barak's Party Reels After His Swift Exit
description: Ehud Barak's sudden resignation from political life appears to have cleared the way for a unity government under Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon. But there are still bitter opponents in the now leaderless Labor Party.

title: Disease, The Clock And the Will Not to Fail
description: The easiest way to choose a play title is simply to name the characters or surface subject matter (''Art,'' ''The Lion King,'' ''Vampire Lesbians of Sodom''). It's harder and rarer to express the work's larger meaning (though ''Proof'' actually does both). So Deb Margolin might have called her new play ''How Professional Basketball Got Me Through Hodgkin's Disease.''

title: In Defense of Dr. Freud
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke and Procter & Gamble In Joint Marketing Venture
description: Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola announced yesterday that they would form a company to manufacture and market Pringles chips and the two companies' juice and fruit-flavored drinks, splitting the profits.

title: Article 2001022290077778111 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: How to Teach Tragedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001022291745094386 -- No Title
description: By MARGARET W. GOLDSBOROUGH

title: The Bedspread That So Cozily and Prettily Blanketed Provence
description: Blanc d'Ivoire (literally, White of Ivory, or off-white) is the name Monic Fischer chose for her home collection in 1995. ''Because it evokes linens, and sounds good in lots of languages,'' Ms. Fischer said. The shop itself (above), 4, rue Jacob, is a charming French country interior stocked with flea market finds. Thanks in part to Blanc d'Ivoire, the boutis, the traditional quilted bedspread of Provence, (on chair) is making a comeback. Produced in India, the boutis is precisely copied from 18th- and 19th-century originals. Blanc d'Ivoire has opened a wholesale showroom in Dallas; American shops and catalog retailers can order the boutis, as well as lamps, curtains, tablecloths and furniture, from (817) 222-2140. A boutis retails from $250 to $525.

title: Once Snubbed, World Trade Center Is Snapped Up
description: The World Trade Center, which was derided as a 110-story, 10 million-square-foot example of government excess when it opened in the 1970's, is being handed over to a giant company in the largest real estate deal ever involving a single office complex.

title: Poll Watch: Some People Just Can't Like Clinton
description: People have tried to like Bill Clinton. And many people do like Bill Clinton. But there is that constant 40 percent or so of Americans who just can't like Bill Clinton.

title: Can Women Trust Men?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRTENSTEIN, DANIEL
description: HIRTENSTEIN-Daniel. The Board of Directors of the Hebrew Hospital Home wish to express their condolences to the family of Daniel Hirtenstein on their profound loss. We were privileged to have Dan serve as a member of our Board of Directors for over 10 years and we were inspired by his courage during his final illness. Our thoughts are with his beloved wife Audrey, his son Andrew and daughter Traci at this difficult time. Arnold Goldstein, Chairman David A. Spector, Chairman Emeritus Mary Frances Barrett, Chief Executive Officer Hebrew Hospital Home, Inc.

title: Should We Watch McVeigh Die?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Fighter Jet Attacks Iraqi Defenses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  An American fighter jet attacked a missile defense battery in Northern Iraq today, Pentagon officials said, resuming low-level skirmishes with Iraqi air-defense forces six days after American and British jets launched the first military strike authorized by President Bush.

title: PROFITS UP AT SWISS CHEMICAL MAKER
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals, Switzerland's second-biggest chemical maker, reported a 76 percent rise in its net profits for 2000, and predicted low double-digit earnings growth again this year. Net profits from continuing operations rose to $249 million last year on sales that were up 9 percent. The company said favorable exchange rates, improved operating margins and a sharp drop in debt helped profits last year. Elizabeth Olson

title: U.S. Coach Silent On His Strategy
description: Bruce Arena, coach of the United States men's national team, will not say which formation he will use or which players he will start in the World Cup qualifying game against Mexico next Wednesday in Columbus, Ohio.

title: The Court Usurps Congressional Power
description: A sharply divided Supreme Court decided yesterday to limit the reach of the Americans With Disabilities Act, and in so doing stripped a vulnerable minority of Americans of important protections against job discrimination. The decision also represented the latest in a series of lamentable judicial assaults on the legitimate authority of the federal government to identify and address serious national problems by enforcing constitutional guarantees of equal protection.

title: Fairness in Tax Audits
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgeon Sues Health Dept., Saying It Slandered Him
description: A New York neurosurgeon who was accused by the state of operating on the wrong side of a patient's brain -- the second such accusation against the doctor in a decade -- is suing the New York State Department of Health and its commissioner for libel, slander and a violation of his civil rights.

title: New York City, Ready for Its Close-Up
description: To the Editor:

title: World Wrestling Decorators
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruiz Plans to Attack Against Holyfield
description: John Ruiz said yesterday that he would not tiptoe around with Evander Holyfield when the two heavyweights meet March 3 in a rematch for the World Boxing Association title.

title: Rapper Accused of Trying to Bribe 4 Potential Witnesses
description: The hip-hop mogul Sean Combs tried to buy the silence of four potential witnesses against him in his gun possession and bribery trial, a Manhattan prosecutor alleged in a private court proceeding and in a letter to a judge, both of which were made public yesterday.

title: Safety Commission Recalls Three Children's Products
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission issued recalls today for three children's products, including 860,000 highchairs because the legs of the chairs separate from the seat, collapsing the chairs, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAMBURY, JOSEPH A., JR.
description: BAMBURY-Joseph A., Jr. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Joseph A. Bambury Jr., a Life Member of the Society and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Animated Rap Music Video Takes Leap to Interactivity
description: IMAGINE a music video that borrows the otherworldly look and interactive feel of some of the best computer games, that can rumble with digital sound and splash onto a computer screen with just a few clicks of a mouse.

title: Shaping a Legacy, Pope Installs 44 Cardinals
description: Pope John Paul II elevated 44 men today to the rank of cardinal, the largest number in history, in a ceremony that mingled ancient pageantry with the more immediate aim of molding the institution that will someday choose his successor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEKOFF, CHARLES, MD.
description: PEKOFF-Charles, MD. The Department of Pediatrics at North Shore University Hospital/Manhasset mourns the death of Charles Pekoff, MD. Charlie was a former resident and dear colleague of ours. Sincere condolences go out to his family. Harvey Aiges, MD, Vice Chairman, Department of Pediatrics, North Shore University Hospital/ Manhasset

title: New Electronic Book Software Makes Lending Out Impossible
description: A new name, if not an entirely new format, has entered the field of reader software for electronic books. The former Glassbook reader, after a small upgrade and a corporate takeover, has re-emerged as the Adobe Acrobat eBook Reader.

title: Mayor Says Arrest Over Letter Was Apparently a Mistake
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the police apparently made a mistake when they arrested a man for writing a letter to the Staten Island borough president criticizing him for closing a community center in a largely black neighborhood.

title: But Bern Rejects Charges That It Fails to Act Against Money-Laundering : French Assail Swiss on Financial Crime
description: PARIS  Leftist members of the French Parliament attacked Switzerland on Wednesday over money-laundering, accusing the Swiss authorities of paying only lip service to banking standards intended to fight organized crime.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: EONE GLOBAL, Napa, Calif., named Raj Kushwaha managing director, senior strategy officer and chief technology officer. He had been head of technology strategy at Dell Online.

title: Inflation Index Jumps, Thanks To Energy Costs
description: Americans paid sharply higher prices for energy in January, causing inflation at the consumer level to rise at its quickest pace in 10 months, the government reported yesterday.

title: Conoco in a Buyback
description: Conoco Inc. said today that it planned to repurchase $1 billion of its shares over three years. The integrated energy company said that at current prices, it would repurchase about 5.7 percent of its 624 million shares outstanding. Shares of Conoco rose 20 cents today, to $28.30. The new buyback plan replaces an existing program, which was intended to offset the dilution of shares associated with the company's employee-compensation plans. The company reported $1.9 billion of earnings on $39.3 billion of revenue for the last 12 months.

title: Eminem Grabs Spotlight, but Steely Dan Wins Best Album
description: The top winner when the 43rd annual Grammy Awards were presented tonight at the Staples Center here was an album about incest, statutory rape, threesomes and drugs. But it was not by the rapper Eminem. It was a very different sort of album: ''Two Against Nature,'' a marriage of funk, rock, jazz and lecherous lyrics by Steely Dan, a veteran rock group that had never won a Grammy.

title: Playing Their Way In
description: It's almost March, a month of games and meets that decide college winter sports championships. Soon afterward comes another kind of final -- the weeks in April when many 17-year-olds who applied to selective colleges will open thin envelopes containing the disappointing news that they are not being offered places at schools like Bowdoin, the University of Michigan or Columbia. These two emotionally charged events of spring are far more closely connected than most of us probably suspect -- even at the most selective colleges.

title: Metro Matters; At City Hall, Chicken Little Is Lame Duck
description: IF you have ever wondered what our elected officials do on our time, you should have been at City Hall yesterday, at a hearing of a City Council committee.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a call on NATO by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to develop a joint missile defense system misstated NATO's membership in some editions. It is 19 countries, not 16.

title: In Stamford Court, Skakel Is Arraigned as Adult in '75 Killing
description: Michael C. Skakel, the Kennedy relative charged with murder in the 1975 death of Martha Moxley, was arraigned today as an adult in State Superior Court here and was told by a judge that he faces a potential sentence of life imprisonment if convicted.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET NAPSTER COURT DATE The date has been set for the next legal proceeding in the matter of the record companies versus Napster . On March 2, at 10 a.m., all sides are scheduled to appear at a hearing that may determine when Napster, which permits users to exchange music free over the Internet, will cease to exist in its current incarnation. The hearing is before Chief Judge Marilyn Patel of the United States District Court in San Francisco. Judge Patel issued a preliminary injunction in July ordering Napster to stop permitting the exchange of works whose copyrights are held by the major record labels. Last week, a federal appeals court affirmed much of Judge Patel's ruling but ordered her to narrow its scope. Napster has said that depending on the scope of the injunction it may be forced to close. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, EDWARD B.
description: GREENSTEIN-Edward B. Age 62 of Tuxedo Park, NY. Husband of Edie. Father of Karen, David, and Jessica. Musician and teacher for 30 years. Services are 1:45PM today, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W. 150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: Dual Controls
description: To the Editor:

title: A Laptop Design Thinks Outside the Clamshell
description: A CONCEPT car, as any car nut can tell you, is a prototype designed to shake up dusty, entrenched notions of car design. To show that they're trying to ''think outside the box,'' automakers create these futuristic, radical-looking models for display in car magazines and auto shows. In the laptop world, I.B.M. has been promoting its own efforts to shatter preconceived ideas.

title: NO DEAL YET TO PROP UP CHIYODA
description: The Chiyoda Mutual Life Insurance Company of Japan, which collapsed in October, canceled a planned announcement and said it failed to reach agreement with a prospective buyer on conditions for remaining in business. American International Group, the world's largest insurer by market value, is in final talks with administrators to buy Chiyoda, an insurance executive involved in the negotiations said. The administrators were to announce the transaction yesterday, but they put off any statement until tomorrow because the two sides could not agree on terms, a Chiyoda Life spokesman, Seiichiro Muramatsu, said.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Robot, Self-Contained and Untethered
description: THE latest vehicle Dr. Doug Adkins helped build does not turn on a dime so much as it can climb one. Dr. Adkins is part of a Sandia National Laboratories team that has created what the researchers believe is the world's smallest untethered robot.

title: Tank Warfare on Jerusalem's Outskirts
description: Not much is left of the apartment where Osama Kurabi was killed by an Israeli tank shell on Tuesday night.

title: Boy Charged As Adult In Killing At Park Bench
description: A 15-year-old boy was arrested and charged yesterday in the killing of Ismael Marzan, an East Harlem man who was sitting on a bench in Central Park, shortly after midnight on Tuesday, Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik said.

title: Blending Ballet Bravura With a Disco Drive
description: Twyla Tharp Dance, the new company Ms. Tharp formed last summer, made its New York debut at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with two very different pieces.

title: Witness in Bombing Case Describes Scouting Mission by 3 Men Near Embassy
description: Almost four years before a terrorist bomb demolished the American Embassy in Kenya, three men paid a visit to an old acquaintance in Nairobi.

title: Red Bank Catholic Rolls Over Marlboro
description: Red Bank Catholic, New Jersey's top-ranked girls basketball team, overwhelmed fourth-seeded Marlboro, 59-28, last night in the semifinals of the Shore Conference tournament at Lakewood High School.

title: A Lyrical Fire (No 'Seasons' In Sight)
description: Cecilia Bartoli's 1999 Decca recording ''The Vivaldi Album'' was a musicological as well as vocal landmark. By searching through manuscripts in the National Library of Turin, Ms. Bartoli found some astonishing arias from Vivaldi's little-known operas (of which there are nearly 40). Six of the 13 arias she recorded were world premieres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARNOFF, LUCILLE
description: SARNOFF-Lucille. Beloved wife of the late Paul, devoted mother of Nancy and the late Alan, Mitchell and Denise, Steven and Tracy. Loving grandmother of Mark, Valerie, Matthew, Emily, Zachary and Leah. Dear sister of Deborah and Morris Shane, Irving and Suzanne Sarnoff, Norman and Ruth Sarnoff. Services Friday at 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'' 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday about the artist Paul McCarthy, whose performances and videos have included simulated acts of self-mutilation and excretion, referred incorrectly to an exhibition of his work opening Saturday at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo. It will indeed carry warning labels about its content.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Organic Wildflowers?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIU, F.T.
description: LIU-F.T. Died peacefully at home on Friday, February 16, 2001. description: There's a Bible story about the prophet Elijah's seeking reassurance from Jehovah. He stands on a mountain, waiting. A wind comes, then an earthquake, then a fire. But only a still, small voice that follows such violence reveals the divine.

title: A Well-Connected Cog in Harlem's Revival
description: OF all the many roles played by Darren Walker, chief operating officer for the Abyssinian Development Corporation in Harlem, one that catches the eye is his self-styled role as a kind of Sherpa for the rich and powerful, people curious but wary about trekking to the unfamiliar terrain of Harlem alone.

description: The Mets won't swap Mike Piazza or Edgardo Alfonzo for Gary Sheffield and, as it turns out, they won't give up a package including Armando Benitez and Jay Payton either.

title: Dazzling Dresses and Fabrics Of the Light-Catching Sort
description: Jouer la Lumire -- ''Play the Light'' -- is the theme of a stunning textile show at the Museum of Decorative Arts here. The exhibition's curator, Jean-Paul Leclercq, says that only with light can a fabric's true qualities be investigated, and light is what makes this show shine. The exhibition features textiles from the 16th century to today, including dresses by Madeleine Vionnet, 1924 (below left), and Jeanne Lanvin, 1910 (below right). Among the contemporary designers are Jean Paul Gaultier. Union Centrale des Arts Dcoratifs, 107, rue de Rivoli; 011.33.1.44.55.57.50; www.ucad.fr; through January.

description: Under the first-year tandem of General Manager Terry Bradway and Coach Herman Edwards, the Jets began a makeover yesterday by releasing five 30-something veterans, including the starting linebackers Bryan Cox and Roman Phifer.

description: JERUSALEM  The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians grows increasingly violent, and Israel seems to be heading toward a unity government that may strengthen Ariel Sharon's political hand.

title: AIB GROUP POSTS PROFIT RISE
description: The AIB Group, Ireland's largest bank, reported a 10.5 percent increase in annual pretax profits, to 1.25 billion euros ($1.14 billion). More than half that came from the bank's operations in the United States and in Poland, where profit increased 40 percent. After seven years as chief executive, Tom Mulcahy, above, will step down in April; Michael Buckley, a former official in the government's finance department, will succeed him. Brian Lavery

title: Bush Concerned About China Aid to Iraqi Defenses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  President Bush said today that he was troubled by evidence that China was aiding Iraq in attempts to build a radar system more capable of attacking American and British pilots, and said the problem had now "risen to the level where we are going to send a message to the Chinese."

title: Google Extends Search Engine's Reach to a Popular File Format
description: IN a move that may prove particularly popular among academics and researchers, Google, an Internet search engine, has started indexing millions of Portable Document Format files.

title: MetroStars Trade for Backup Goalie
description: The MetroStars traded the rights of the free-agent defender Ramiro Corrales to San Jose yesterday for Paul Grafer, a goalkeeper who was selected earlier yesterday by San Jose in a special draft that was held because he had signed with Major League Soccer after the league's SuperDraft on Feb. 5.

title: New York's U.S. Attorneys Suddenly Lack Job Security
description: To the Justice Department, New York is different from other states: its four United States attorneys, who direct some of the nation's most visible federal cases, have been protected from changes of power in Washington. But now, for the first time since the Ford administration, they are working without job security.

title: Deepening Political Crisis Rocks Markets in Turkey
description: The impact from a political dispute involving Turkey's prime minister and its president reverberated through the country's skittish financial markets today, sending the stock market plunging 18 percent and driving up overnight interest rates to 6,100 percent.

title: Classicism Meets Jazz, And Style-Hopping Ensues
description: Crossover projects are generally viewed with a justifiable disdain, mainly because they cheapen music for the sake of what seem purely commercial interests. And that applies to both sides of the equation: applying classical techniques and sensibilities to pop can be as destructive to that music as applying a layer of commercial glitz to a classical score. Hardly anything good comes of these endeavors, but Kristjan Jarvi and his Absolute Ensemble have been proving in recent seasons that under the right conditions it can work.

title: Greer Sparks Rutgers's Rout of Hall
description: They moved senior night at Rutgers up two weeks for Jeff Greer because his older sister, Jesse, couldn't be in two places at once. See, Jeff's brother Ricardo is closing out a fine Big East career of his own at Pittsburgh at home on March 3 against Virginia Tech, the same day Rutgers plays its home finale.

title: Bush Keeps Clinton Policy on Poor Lands' Need for AIDS Drugs
description: The office of the United States trade representative said today that the Bush administration would not change the Clinton administration's generous but contentious policy concerning AIDS drugs for impoverished countries.

title: U.N. Council Agrees to Plan To Get Troops Out of Congo
description: Moving with remarkable speed and unanimity to respond to a cooperative new government in Congo, the Security Council agreed today on a step by step plan for the withdrawal of all foreign troops from the country, the scene of Africa's largest war.

description: Dikembe Mutombo was awaiting an update yesterday afternoon. From his agent, David Falk. From the Hawks' general manager, Pete Babcock. From anyone who could unlock the secret to his future over the next 24 hours.

title: BALTIMORE TECHNOLOGIES REPORTS SALES SURGE
description: An Irish developer of security software, Baltimore Technologies P.L.C., reported preliminary annual sales of 74.2 million, or $110.9 million, for the year ended Dec. 31, an increase of 219 percent over 1999. License revenue for Baltimore's security products, which manage digital certificates and secure online transactions, rose 347 percent, to 40.3 million. Its latest deal, announced on Tuesday, embeds digital certificates into mobile phones for the Japanese wireless carrier NTT DoCoMo. For the year, Baltimore said its loss before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization rose to 25.4 million from 20 million. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, Baltimore reported a loss of 8.7 million on sales of 28.4 million. Brian Lavery

title: Civilians Were Distraction, Sailor Tells Submarine-Accident Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The U.S. ambassador to Japan, Thomas Foley, offered an apology to the emperor of Japan on Wednesday for the accidental sinking of a Japanese trawler by a U.S. Navy submarine, a day after a sonar operator testified that he had been momentarily distracted by civilian guests in the submarine's control room.

title: East Coast Coupon Book
description: Coupon booklets are not to be dismissed as bargain sources, modest as they might be -- especially when all it takes is a telephone call to get one. Anyone thinking of visiting the Mystic Seaport Museum in Mystic, Conn., for example, may want to carry along the 2001 Coast Card, which contains over 70 coupons good for discounts at hotels, attractions, restaurants and shopping along the eastern coast of Connecticut. Discounts include $3 off a ticket to the Eugene O'Neill Theatre Center in Waterford, Conn.; $2 off a ticket to the Essex Steam Train and Riverboat; and 10 percent off a one-night stay at the Comfort Inn and Days Inn in Mystic and the Ramada and Courtyard by Marriott in Norwich, Conn., among other hotels. The Coast Card is available by calling (800) 692-6278; for information, call up www.mycoast.com .

description: HORN-Max. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Darling, loving companion of Dolores Bartolotta. Loving father of Stewart and Lawrence and father-in-law of Adela and Deborah. Services today, 10 AM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave. (Ave. J), Brooklyn.
