description: In a motorcade of eight police cars, Robert W. Tulloch was brought to this quiet New Hampshire town today and arraigned in the killings of two Dartmouth College professors.

title: MOSCOW SIGNALING A CHANGE IN TONE ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: After months of protesting the American plan to develop an antimissile system, Russia has begun to talk more seriously about the possibility of missile defenses.

title: Social Studies Class Finds How Far E-Mail Travels
description: MAYBE it was the innocence of the e- mail message that caught the eye: "Hi! We are 50 sixth-grade students at Taylorsville Elementary." Maybe it was their ambitious project: "We are curious to see where in the world our e-mail will travel." Or maybe it was the simple plea at the end of that message that compelled all the responses: "PLEASE help us."

title: Lindros Deal Stalls; Recriminations Don't
description: When Bob Clarke played in the National Hockey League, he was a smart and tough center who used his quick stick for both playmaking and punishment. When Pat Quinn played, he was a big defenseman who threw hard bodychecks and backed down from no foe.

title: All Eyes Are on Jeter After His Big New Contract
description: The first full-squad workout of spring training always feels like the first day of school, Paul O'Neill said this morning. You look around and see who all your new classmates are.

title: Communist Victory Predicted in Moldova
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21  The Communist Party seems poised to win a working majority in elections this weekend in Moldova, political experts say, giving the party effective control of the government.

title: So Many Knots, Inspector, And Time Is Running Out
description: Why it that Chief Inspector Morse never seems to smile?

title: APPLE ADDING FEATURES
description: Trying to entice consumers with wild patterns referred to as Blue Dalmatian and Flower Power molded directly into the plastic of the popular iMac home computer, the chief executive of Apple Computer, Steven P. Jobs announced several new consumer-oriented products in Tokyo yesterday. The new multihued iMacs, which will have faster processors and the ability to both read and write CD's, will be priced at $899 and $1,499. Apple also introduced a faster version of its G4 Cube computer, which will also come with the ability to write directly to blank CD's and will be priced at $1,599. John Markoff

title: Get Movie Popcorn, Then Check the Mail
description: DURING a recent PowerPoint presentation that I had prepared in the hope of teaching my husband the value of a dollar, he pointed to a big green wedge of the pie chart.

title: Big Chinese Oil Company Testing Equity Markets Again
description: Seventeen months after an unforgiving stock market spoiled its foreign debut, China's flagship offshore oil company is again preparing to list its shares in New York and Hong Kong.

title: Bob Buhl, 72, Braves Pitcher Who Was Hapless as a Hitter
description: Bob Buhl, who teamed with Warren Spahn and Lew Burdette as the pitching stars of the Milwaukee Braves' 1957 World Series champions, died Friday in Titusville, Fla. He was 72.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Another Pardon Disgrace
description: The disclosure that Bill Clinton's brother-in-law received large fees from two beneficiaries of Mr. Clinton's last-minute pardons and commutations can only deepen the public revulsion over the former president's decisions. It adds to the disturbing impression that Mr. Clinton's actions may have been influenced by friendships, politics and financial contributions.

title: Article 2001022293547520854 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Closings at 35 Lechters Stores
description: Lechters, the national housewares retailer, will close 35 underperforming stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, company officials said yesterday. Closing sales are under way. The affected stores will remain open until the inventory is sold, which could take three months, said David Hisbrook, a senior vice president for marketing. Earlier this month, the company, which is based in Harrison, N.J., said it would close 166 of its 490 stores.

title: JUDGE REFUSES TO DELAY BIDDING FOR T.W.A.
description: A federal bankruptcy judge in Delaware denied a motion yesterday by Continental Airlines to delay the bidding for Trans World Airlines, pending its appeal. Continental had argued that the bidding process favored the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, which has offered $500 million in cash for most of the T.W.A. assets. It asked the court to issue a stay while it appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. But the bankruptcy judge, Peter Walsh, ruled that Continental's proposal was unrealistic and that a delay would cause irreparable harm to T.W.A. American, which lent T.W.A. $200 million to keep it flying, has said that it will retain most of T.W.A.'s 20,000 employees and has agreed to assume $3 billion of its debt. Yesterday's decision means that the deadline for bidders to qualify remains Feb. 28. Laurence Zuckerman

title: Metro Business Briefing; CHEAPER HEALTH INSURANCE
description: Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey said yesterday that it was cutting its monthly premiums by up to 15 percent for 45,000 elderly and disabled people, as a result of additional reimbursements approved by Congress. The reduction, which began in the middle of the month, involves policies available to people eligible for Medicare who are at least 65 years old or disabled. The reduction comes to $8.33 a month, with resulting monthly premiums of $46.67 for the basic Medicare Blue plan and $81.67 for Medicare Blue Plus, which includes a prescription plan. Horizon, based in Newark, is New Jersey's largest health insurer, with 2.4 million people enrolled.

title: Devils Are Able to Compensate In Replacing Injured Players
description: All four injured Devils players reported progress with their ailments today, but none will play against visiting Buffalo on Thursday night, and perhaps not on Friday night at Carolina either.

title: Amid Trade Talks, Knicks Take a Fall in Detroit
description: Yet another superstar, Detroit's Jerry Stackhouse, was dominating the Knicks. The Philadelphia 76ers were weighing a deal for Dikembe Mutombo. And Scott Layden, the Knicks' general manager, was standing pat.

title: VERIZON BID RAISES QUESTIONS
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that significant questions remained about whether Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, had proved that its dominant local network was open to competitors that provide high-speed data service in Massachusetts. Verizon is seeking clearance to begin selling long-distance voice and data service to its local customers in the state -- a $2 billion market. The Justice Department voiced its concern in a filing to the Federal Communications Commission, which will have final say on Verizon's bid for long-distance service. Department officials urged the F.C.C. to be cautious in resolving the application, which it must decide by April 16.

title: Rare Study Finds Brain-Chilling Is No Help in Head Injuries
description: Dashing the hopes of many doctors, a large national study has found that contrary to some preliminary research, a simple step -- lowering the temperature of the brain -- did not help patients with severe head injuries.

title: Jerome Shelby -- Lawyer, 70
description: Jerome Shelby, the former co-chairman of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, one of America's oldest law firms, died yesterday. He was 70.

title: WOODSIDE REPORTS BIG EARNINGS GAIN
description: Net earnings at Woodside Petroleum, Australia's second-biggest oil company, benefited from a weaker Australian dollar and higher oil prices last year, rising 192 percent, to 967 million Australian dollars ($522 million). Production was higher than analysts expected, and revenue increased to a record 2.4 billion Australian dollars. Woodside is the target of a $9.9 billion Australian dollar ($5.3 billion) takeover by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which now holds just over 34 percent of the company. Becky Gaylord

title: American Cardinals Handle Reporters and Flying Birettas
description: In his first remarks to reporters after receiving the red silk hat that symbolizes his new status as a ''prince of the church,'' Cardinal Edward M. Egan mentioned New York four times, and God once.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TISCHLER, DAVE C.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER DROPS. Copper fell after a report signaled slow economic growth in Germany that may reduce demand. In New York, copper for March delivery fell 2 cents, or 2.4 percent, to 80.05 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, SALLY Z.
description: JACOBS-Sally Z. On February 8, 2001 in her 87th year. Beloved wife of the late David, loving mother of Barbara (Ed) Gross, Ivan, and Glenn. Devoted grandmother of Scott, Cindy-jo, Ronne, Robert, Karann, and Michael. Dear sister of Jean (Murray) Kirschenbaum and Diane Hilliard. Cherished greatgrandmother of six. To know her was to love her. She will always be missed and never forgotten.

title: KELLOGG CONCEDES TOP SPOT TO GENERAL MILLS
description: The Kellogg Company is relinquishing its spot as the biggest American cereal company after decades of holding off General Mills, Kellogg's chairman and chief executive, Carlos Gutierrez, said yesterday. Until recently, Kellogg had focused on volume rather than revenue, offering coupons and other discounts to retain its top spot based on pounds sold. Mr. Gutierrez said he was willing to fall behind General Mills if it would help bolster Kellogg's profit. Profit from operations will increase less than Kellogg's previous goal of 8 percent to 10 percent a year because of higher advertising costs, he said. Kellogg shares fell 25 cents, to $27.10. Shares of General Mills, the maker of Cheerios and Chex, fell 32 cents, to $44.29.

title: Rodriguez Is Humble On Day 1 With Texas
description: Alex Rodriguez performed agility drills on a barren back field at Charlotte County Stadium toward the end of his first workout with the Texas Rangers today, the mundane tapping of his feet witnessed by one fan, two photographers and two reporters. This is Rodriguez's new world, the biggest star in baseball sweltering in anonymity for a couple of minutes.

title: Spartans Remain at No. 1
description: Michigan State split its games last weekend against top 15 teams, Western Michigan and the University of Michigan, but the Spartans retained the top spot in the national polls.

title: Moving House, With 2,000 Chinese Parts
description: IN the village of Huang Chun, in the south-central province of Anhui, a wealthy Chinese pawnbroker named Huang commissioned an elaborate house of wood and stone more than a century ago. He called it Yin Yu Tang, or Hall of Plentiful Shelter. The house had 5 bays, 16 rooms and 2 fishponds. Complicated feng shui calculations dictated that the house face north, instead of south, where it would have received the most sunlight.

title: Sports of The Times; The League Of Dreamers Is No More
description: A PUGNACIOUS basketball league that persevered in the manner of a large gypsy family for 55 years appears to have expired, leaving its scattered roster with only vivid memories and the satisfaction of having played for love of the game.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LYON, ANDY LOGAN
description: LYON-Andy Logan. A memorial tribute to New Yorker writer Andy Logan will be held on Sunday, February 25, 2 PM, at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park So.

title: Ruling on Disability Rights Called a Blow by Advocates
description: Advocates for the disabled said today that the direct effect of the Supreme Court's ruling on disability rights might be limited but that the decision was a serious blow because it suggested the court might not allow disabled people to sue states over blatant discrimination in schools, hospitals and other government institutions.

title: HONDA LEAVES XFL
description: Honda has pulled out of the XFL, which will begin to give advertisers additional spots in the games to make up for the drop in ratings.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the re-emergence of break-dancing as a suburban phenomenon misspelled the name of a store at a mall in Middletown, N.Y., where a competition was held. It is T. J. Maxx, not T. J. Max.

title: Boston Globe Prints Apology On Article on Murder Inquiry
description: The Boston Globe printed a front-page apology yesterday retracting a report that investigators believed the murder of two Dartmouth College professors was likely to have been ''a crime of passion, most likely resulting from an adulterous love affair'' involving one of the victims, Half Zantop.

title: Finding Help Online For Message Boards
description: Q. I am developing a Web site and would like to include a message board, but I have no idea how to do it. What is the best way for a novice to approach this? Do I need to have my own server?

title: A Laptop Design Thinks Outside the Clamshell
description: A CONCEPT car, as any car nut can tell you, is a prototype designed to shake up dusty, entrenched notions of car design. To show that they're trying to "think outside the box," automakers create these futuristic, radical-looking models for display in car magazines and auto shows. In the laptop world, I.B.M. has been promoting its own efforts to shatter preconceived ideas.

title: MOTOROLA CUTTING 300 JOBS
description: One of the world's biggest makers of cell phones and semiconductors, Motorola Inc., said yesterday that it would eliminate another 300 jobs from the division that makes cell phones and other communications devices. The company said the move was part of an effort to cut expenses at a time when demand for its products had weakened. A few weeks ago, the company said that it would eliminate 4,000 jobs in its semiconductor division and a month ago it said that it would close its only remaining domestic cell phone manufacturing plant, cutting 2,500 jobs. David Barboza

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, TIFFANI
description: FELDMAN-Tiffani. 4/1/76-2/2/00. Still feel your love, still hear your laughter. Always with love, Grandmother, Grandfather & Family

title: POLY PREP STAR RECORDS 4TH DOUBLE
description: I-Perfection Harris recorded his fourth double of the season in the long and triple jumps and tacked on a victory in the 600 meters yesterday in leading Poly Prep of Brooklyn to the boys' team title in the Ivy League prep schools indoor championships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, BENJAMIN
description: MILLER-Benjamin. Died Saturday, February 17th, in Orlando, FL. Devoted husband of Diane (nee Schoenfeld) of 54 years. Proud father of Lois Miller of Winter Springs, FL., Susan Schwarz of New York City and Dr. Lee T. Miller of Los Angeles. Loving grandfather of Joanna Athwal of New York City. Bereaved family includes Nat and Ruth Miller, Frank Miller, Shirley Luchs and Stan and Doris Miller. Ben was a registered pharmacist representing Eli Lilly and Co. in Brooklyn, N.Y. for more than 36 years. He retired to Orlando, FL. in 1982. As an active member of Temple Israel in Orlando, Ben exemplified the ideals of integrity, loyalty and dignity that was central to his faith. In memory of Ben donations may be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund at Temple Israel in Orlando.

title: Bush Covers Broad Range in First News Conference
description: President Bush confronted the media today in his first official White House news conference, evading some questions but touching on a wide range of issues both domestic and international.

title: Web Site Shares Feats Of Engineers' Daring
description: The National Society of Professional Engineers wants to share some of the secrets behind the nation's buildings, bridges, dams, factories and monuments. ''A Sightseer's Guide to Engineering'' (www.engineeringsights.org) offers an interesting sampling of historic feats and oddities, with photographs, maps and links.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Courses Don't Add Up

title: Education Dept. Will Get Biggest Budget Increase, Bush Says
description: Using a rural elementary school as a backdrop, President Bush said today that the Department of Education would grow more than any other federal agency in the budget he would unveil next week, rising 11 percent to $44.5 billion.

title: Turkish Currency Falls 28% as Government Stops Defending It
description: ISTANBUL, Feb. 22 - Sixty-five million Turks found their national currency in a free fall today that stripped away about 28 percent of its value and sent a wave of concern through world financial markets.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column and a picture caption on Monday about Mayor Giuliani's proposal for a decency commission to oversee publicly financed museums misspelled the surname of the artist who painted ''Ia Orana Maria,'' on view at the Metropolitan. He was Paul Gauguin, not Gaugin.

title: Donella Meadows, 59, Author, And Advocate for Environment
description: Dr. Donella Hager Meadows, an author, educator and advocate for the environment, died Tuesday at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H. She was 59 and lived in Hartland Four Corners, N.H.

title: Justices Give the States Immunity From Suits by Disabled Workers
description: The Supreme Court today carved out a new area of immunity for the states from the reach of federal civil rights law, ruling that state employees cannot sue for damages for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act.

title: Article 2001022294046715198 -- No Title
description: The Web, Without Wires, Wherever

title: Sailor Killed on the Harlem Streets He Was Trying to Escape
description: After packing the trunk of his car on Tuesday night, Demetrius Haskins slammed it shut with the kind of resounding finality he hoped to bring to his life in Harlem. Ahead of Mr. Haskins, a 21-year-old Navy seaman recruit, lay a long drive south with his wife and newborn son to Norfolk, Va., and a six-month tour in the Mediterranean aboard an aircraft carrier. Behind him were nearly two decades growing up in a housing project, on a block plagued by drug dealers and gangs.

title: Real Estate Charges to Lower 2000 Deutsche Telekom Profit
description: Deutsche Telekom, the huge German phone company, said today that it would take a special charge for the cost of writing off real estate assets, and that the charge would reduce its profit for all of 2000 by one-fifth.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENERSTEIN, EZRA J.
description: DENERSTEIN-Ezra J. Sweet, gentle man remembered today and everyday with love by his children and grandchildren. Susan and Harris

title: For a Military Pay Raise
description: To the Editor:

title: Frenetic Fun, Sunup to Beyond Sundown
description: It must have been during the fourth or fifth rollicking slide down the tubing hill, which was after the ice skating and the night-time snowboarding lesson -- but before the visit to the indoor amusement center known as the Fun Zone and definitely before the fireworks following the trailside torchlight parade -- that we realized we would never do it all.

title: 76ers Hope Mutombo Will Deliver the Title
description: Already laying claim to the best little man in pro basketball, the Philadelphia 76ers yesterday reaffirmed their commitment to winning the National Basketball Association championship this season by acquiring the last great center still standing in the Eastern Conference.

title: Essay; The Molehill Mountain
description: ''Sorry about the handwriting,'' my linguistic source at the Allenwood Federal Penitentiary in White Deer, Pa., writes. ''The Bureau of Prisons has a dinosaurian paranoia about typewriters, word processors and just about any writing tools beyond pencils and ballpoints, universally called 'ink pins.' ''

title: Spy Chasers Feel Betrayed by One-Time Top Gun
description: When Robert Philip Hanssen went to work as a squad supervisor in F.B.I. counterintelligence in New York in 1985, the hundreds of agents in his division were consumed by what they saw as an all-out war against hostile targets, primarily the Soviet Union.

title: The Neediest Cases; Safe From Civil War but Still Struggling
description: Although it is crowded with 12 people and at night is usually illuminated only by the flickering television in the living room, Eddie Taylor's two-bedroom apartment in a Staten Island housing project seems like a palace compared with his former home in a Ghanaian refugee camp.

title: Nassau Lawmakers Oppose Jail Officers' Pact
description: Legislative leaders from both political parties in Nassau County say a proposed labor contract that the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, has negotiated with county correction officers is unacceptable.

title: MARKET FROWNS ON SYBASE DEAL
description: Shares of the database software maker, Sybase Inc., tumbled $4.56, or 18.6 percent, to $19.94, a day after the company announced that it would acquire New Era of Networks Inc. in a $373 million stock transaction. New Era, known as Neon, makes e-commerce applications, a rapidly growing category of business software. News of the deal lifted Neon shares by 5.4 percent, to $7.31. Some analysts and shareholders said Sybase overpaid for a software company that had been unable to reach profitability on its own, but David Chen, above, chief executive of Sybase, said he was not worried. ''I'm very comfortable that with our help, they'll get to profitability very soon,'' he said. Andrew Zipern

title: Should We Watch McVeigh Die?
description: To the Editor:

title: Composers In Their Flashes Of Youth
description: If the New York Chamber Symphony concert at Alice Tully Hall last weekend had been a museum show, it would have been titled ''Brahms and His Successors: A View of Central European Romanticism.'' And it was, at least, a fine piece of curating. It showed three composers, Brahms, Janacek and Ernst von Dohnanyi, early in their careers -- 26, 24 and 28 years old respectively -- all working in the same Romantic tradition, all looking fixedly at the past.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: On Energy Farms, Technology Milks the Wind
description: THE windmill is a centuries-old technology originally developed to pump water and grind grain, but it could play an important role in solving two serious problems facing the United States: generating an adequate supply of electricity and reducing the emission of greenhouse gases.

title: Hamilton Wants Out. Any Takers?
description: Darryl Hamilton arrived in the Mets' clubhouse today, the day position players reported to spring training. But before he began to change into his uniform, a dozen reporters had crowded around him. Hamilton does not want to court controversy, but he expected the scene. He is quiet but proud, and the only thing hurting worse than his toe is his pride.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CGI GROUP INC., Montreal, a company that installs and services computer networks, agreed to buy the rival IMRglobal Corp., Clearwater, Fla., for about $438 million to add customers in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVRUTIS, THERESA GWYN KELLAR
description: AVRUTIS-Theresa Gwyn Kellar. At home, on February 18, 2001. Widow of Newton. A graduate of Morris H.S. 1930 and NYU 1934. She practiced Clinical Psychology for over 45 years. Daughter of the late Louis Goldberg and Anna Freund. Sister of the late C.M. and I. Harold Kellar. She is survived by her daughter Andrea, her nephews Raymond, Alan and Jeffrey, her grandnephew Michael and her sister-in-law Charlotte. Services Thursday, 9:45AM at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Memorial contributions to Museum of Jewish Heritage, Battery Park City, New York.

title: New Cell Phones Put Whole Alphabet in Play
description: For many cell phone users, text messaging is a godsend. That is largely because divine intervention is needed to compose an intelligible message on the cell phone's tiny numeric keypad. Motorola has tried to make the task a little easier with two new products, the V100 and the Accompli. Both are GSM cell phones with hands-free headsets plugged into what are essentially the clamshell bodies of pagers with full qwerty keyboards.

title: A Quaker Greeting
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Depot's Co-Founder, in Surprise Move, Is Retiring
description: A day after Home Depot said fourth-quarter earnings were down 20 percent from the period a year earlier, the company's co-founder and co-chairman, Arthur M. Blank, surprised the financial community yesterday by announcing that he would retire from the company May 30.

title: Social Studies Class Finds How Far E-Mail Travels
description: MAYBE it was the innocence of the e-mail message that caught the eye: ''Hi! We are 50 sixth-grade students at Taylorsville Elementary.'' Maybe it was their ambitious project: ''We are curious to see where in the world our e-mail will travel.'' Or maybe it was the simple plea at the end of that message that compelled all the responses: ''PLEASE help us.''

title: APTIMUS SHIFTS WEB STRATEGY
description: Revealing a new business strategy in the hopes of staving off doom, Aptimus Inc. said yesterday that it had shifted its focus to providing companies with an online infrastructure for direct marketing and that it would close down its consumer Web sites, which include FreeShop.com, Desteo.com and CatalogSite.com, over the next few months. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Not for My Daughter
description: To the Editor:

title: Courses Don't Add Up
description: To the Editor:

title: ASTRAZENECA WINS U.S. APPROVAL FOR ULCER DRUG
description: The drug manufacturer AstraZeneca said yesterday that American regulators had agreed to allow the company to promote its new ulcer medicine Nexium as a better alternative to Losec. The company hopes Nexium can replace Losec, which made up 42 percent of its sales in 2000, before the drug, the world's best seller, loses its patent protection. Losec is sold as Prilosec in the United States. Nexium's label will say that it is faster than Losec, information that AstraZeneca hopes will persuade doctors to switch patients to Nexium before cheaper, generic versions of Losec are available.

title: Shine a Light on China
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, HORATIO NELSON, JR.
description: SLATER-Horatio Nelson, Jr. Died February 19, 2001. Husband of Brenda Luther Slater, father of Joy Salter Carrier of Unionville, PA., and Samuel Slater of Coatesville, PA, brother of Alexander Salter, Sr., uncle of Elizabeth Ann Luther, Laura Susan Luther both of Boston, MA., and John Clark Luther of Franklin, MA. Services to be held at St. John's church in Salisbury, CT at 11AM, Saturday, February 24th. Contributions may be made to Salisbury Visiting Nurse Association, 30 Salmon Kill Rd., Salisbury, CT 06068, Salisbury Volunteer Ambulance Service, Under Mountain Rd, Salisbury, CT 06068 and Hotchkiss School Slater Scholarship Fund, C/O Hotchkiss School at 11 Interlaken Road, Lakeville, CT. 06039.

title: TWO LARGE LAW FIRMS SAY THEY ARE CLOSE TO A MERGER
description: Sidley & Austin, the Chicago-based law firm, and Brown & Wood, a Wall Street firm, have announced that the two firms are close to a merger. The combined firm, which would be known as Sidley, Austin, Brown & Wood, would have more than 1,300 lawyers, with about 400 in New York. According to the two firms, the New York office of Sidley & Austin would be combined with that of Brown & Wood, which is in the World Trade Center. The merger, which is subject to approval by the partners in each firm, is expected to be completed this spring. It is the latest in a series of mergers in the legal industry as law firms try to establish themselves as one-stop shops for corporate clients. Jonathan D. Glater

title: Blink Offers to Transfer Bookmarks to Cell Phones
description: A novel solution for the lack of a proper keyboard on cell phones comes from Blink.com, a bookmark-organizer Web site. Blink.com has made it possible for users to use their desktop computer bookmarks on Web-enabled phones, hand-held computers and other wireless devices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ARLINE
description: COHEN-Arline. May 8, 1921 to February 20, 2001. Wonderful and devoted wife of Dr. Alex Cohen. Special, special mother to the late Ruth Barbara Sandler and Jeff Evans, Joan Sices Dichter, Judiie and Aurin Primack, Gerri and Phil Nizza. Adoring grandmother to Michael and Retha Sandler, Bobby and Susan Sandler, Kenny and Shoshana Dichter, Kathy and David Burg, David and Alan Primack, and Joey Nizza. ''Couldn't be prouder'' great grandmother to Michael and Caroline Sandler, Lily and Melanie Sandler, Kendra and Sam Burg, and Chloe Dichter. Each and every one of us felt a special connection with you. You were so easy to love.

title: Many Banks Tightening Up Business Loans
description: The challenges Lucent Technologies faced refinancing its debt the last week demonstrate just how wary bankers have suddenly become, according to several leading lenders. This caution comes despite attempts by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, backed up by two sharp rate cuts, to foster more vigorous lending.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the purchase and relocation of a 1928 house designed by Addison Mizner referred incorrectly to the seller, Richard DeVos. He is not the father of a girl who had a birthday party in the house; that was a previous owner. The article also misstated the sale price of the house. It was $200,000, not $3.5 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: For Ducasse, Settings Retooled With Respect and Playfulness
description: The assignment: design two markedly different Paris restaurants for the celebrated chef Alain Ducasse. The fellow who received the commission was Patrick Jouin, 33, who has worked with Philippe Starck. The interiors at both the Plaza Athne (above left) at 25, avenue Montaigne, and 59 Poincar (above right) at 59, avenue Raymond-Poincar), were landmarks, so Mr. Jouin injected contemporary notes with the furnishings. The chandeliers at the Plaza Athne were ''beautiful but banal,'' he said, ''so I had the idea to gently disturb them by wrapping them in a tube of sheer white.'' He brought stainless steel, glass and marble to the other restaurant. ''The seating is something between a bar stool and a chair, with metallic legs and white leather upholstery,'' he said. Patrick Jouin: 011.33.1.44.76.06.22.

title: Article 2001022292171578957 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Article 2001022291714520556 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, SIMON
description: SCHWARTZ-Simon. On behalf of the officers and members of the United Federation of Teachers, we mourn the passing of a vibrant leader who was active in building the UFT in a 35-year career as a teacher and trade unionist. He served as the UFT Manhattan representative and fought for the rights of all working people through the consumer assembly, the municipal credit union and for children in special education. We salute Si for his leadership and offer our deep sympathies to his wife Frances, his children and grandchildren. Randi Weingarten, Pres., UFT

title: NAPSTER COURT DATE
description: The date has been set for the next legal proceeding in the matter of the record companies versus Napster. On March 2, at 10 a.m., all sides are scheduled to appear at a hearing that may determine when Napster, which permits users to exchange music free over the Internet, will cease to exist in its current incarnation. The hearing is before Chief Judge Marilyn Patel of the United States District Court in San Francisco. Judge Patel issued a preliminary injunction in July ordering Napster to stop permitting the exchange of works whose copyrights are held by the major record labels. Last week, a federal appeals court affirmed much of Judge Patel's ruling but ordered her to narrow its scope. Napster has said that depending on the scope of the injunction it may be forced to close. Matt Richtel

title: They Call It Tobacco Road, Sing Sing-Style; Struggling to Make Ends Meet, Guards See Trailer Park as a Symbol
description: A trailer park sits so close to Sing Sing that the lodgers there could play handball against the prison wall if the man in the rifle tower allowed it.

title: Talks Are Under Way For SF Interactive
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is in negotiations to acquire SF Interactive in San Francisco, a leading interactive agency with revenue estimated at $13 million from clients that have included Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and Nike.

title: Foot-and-Mouth Outbreak Halts British Animal Exports
description: Faced with its first outbreak in 20 years of foot-and-mouth disease, a virulent illness that infects animals with relentless speed, Britain said today that it was suspending all exports of live animals as well as milk and meat, even though the disease poses small risk to humans.

title: Shifting Vantage Points And Plenty of New Angles
description: The audience could move along with the dancers in ''Auto.Publik,'' which Mark Jarecke presented on Friday night at St. Mark's Church in the East Village.

title: Brother-in-Law Used to Using Family Ties
description: The disclosure yesterday that Hugh Rodham took payments to help people win presidential pardons was not the first case of his being a political embarrassment for his older sister, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, and her husband.

title: SONY IN ONLINE GAME ALLIANCE
description: Sony Computer Entertainment, the unit of Sony that makes PlayStation game machines, disclosed an alliance with the Sega Corporation and Namco Ltd. to provide online game services via high-speed broadband networks to begin by the end of the year. The online game network includes a connection to arcade game centers operated by Sega and Namco. Sony has been working to expand the horizon of its PlayStation games, including a tie-up with NTT DoCoMo to link PlayStation with DoCoMo's popular i-mode mobile Internet service. Miki Tanikawa

title: A Dowager Queen in India Is Vengeful to the End
description: The body of the dowager queen of Gwalior was borne on a palanquin of sandalwood and silver in January, past the decaying palace that had once been among the grandest in India's now-defunct princely states, to the garden where she was to be cremated.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Feb. 12 about Dr. Marshall R. Urist, an orthopedic surgeon, omitted a survivor. He is a son, John Baxter Urist of Westport, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEE, COLEMAN F.
description: DEE-Coleman F. Age 87, of Sag Harbor, N.Y. and Jensen Beach, Florida, on February 18, 2001. Beloved husband of Mary E. Fitzgerald (nee) Somerville, and the late Patricia M. (nee) Sheridan. Loving father of Raymond C. of Pottsville, PA, and Mary D. Churchill of Sag Harbor. Dear brother of Marie Niemann of Bowie, MD. Also survived by eight grandchildren and four great grand-children. Reposing at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, Rte. 114, Sag Harbor, Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM Mass Saturday February 24, 10 AM, St. Andrews R.C. Church. Interment St. Andrews Cemetery, Sag Harbor.

title: Stocks Fall Broadly, With Major Indexes Around Year Lows
description: The pessimism gripping United States stock markets deepened yesterday, as investors nervous about weak corporate earnings and higher inflation sent stocks to new lows for the year.

title: Fronting Her Band While Being Inside It
description: Claudia Acua, a young singer who moved to New York from Chile six years ago, uses a semi-thick voice from the chest, and with it she can turn the standard American jazz ballad into into something like a bolero. She could probably start over as a cabaret singer tomorrow morning. But she is also committed to the idea of a jazz singer as an inseparable part of a band, and in a late set on Thursday night at Sweet Basil she worked closely with all the flux going on around her.

title: Getting Snow Off Runways: Alaska Beats New York
description: If snowflakes start to fall on the runways of New York airports on Thursday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will be ready with an army of more than 150 snow blowers, plows, melters and brooms. But air travelers might be better off in Anchorage.

title: Economic Scene; Smaller classes don't necessarily equal better education. Do the math!
description: PRESIDENT BUSH has been on the road this week, promoting the education package that is a centerpiece of his policy agenda. His plan, whose broad outlines enjoy bipartisan support, ties federal funds to minimum performance standards on regular tests. But it also gives states a lot of flexibility in how they set and achieve their educational goals.

title: A Museum Banishes Gloom From Its Halls of Asian Art
description: After five years of renovation, the Guimet Museum of Paris, below, has finally reopened. Long lines snaking daily from the entrance on the Place d'Ina, near the Trocadro, demonstrate how much Parisians missed the museum during its hiatus. With 45,000 sculptures, paintings and other objects spanning five centuries of the ceremonial, religious and ornamental arts of Asia, the Guimet had undergone no major changes since its founding in 1889 by the industrialist and collector mile Guimet.

title: Should We Watch McVeigh Die?
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Just a Rumor

title: Sailor Says Sub Tracked Ship But Guests Were Distraction
description: The Navy has told federal investigators that the submarine Greeneville detected a Japanese fishing trawler more than an hour before sinking it in a collision. Separately, investigators learned from interviews that a Greeneville crewman keeping track of surface vessels said he could not complete his job because there were so many civilian guests in the control room.

title: Home-Style Approach In Hardee's Campaign
description: Hardee's Food Systems in Rocky Mount, N.C., part of CKE Restaurants, is promoting itself in a humorous but homey way in a campaign that is the first from its new agency, Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Opinions on Limits of Disabilities Act
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that state workers cannot sue for damages for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act. The vote in Board of Trustees of the University of Alabama v. Garrett was 5 to 4. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote a concurring opinion, and Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote the dissent.

title: Spy Handler Bedeviled U.S. In Earlier Case
description: Viktor Cherkashin wears the Russian face of the cold war: A piercing stare, and the intimidating presence of a brilliant actor, which of course is a necessary tool of any successful spy. But it was his careful approach to clandestine operations that made him such a tough adversary to the Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, ELSE
description: SILBERMAN-Else. The Directors, officers and members of the American Federation of Jews from Central Europe are deeply saddened by the passing of Else Silberman, wife of our Chairman Dr. Curt C. Silberman. Their long road together through persecution and hardships, but also years of achievement, forged a bond whose breach is hard to bear. Our thoughts and prayers are with you. Fritz Weinschenk, President

title: Staten Island, C.C.N.Y. Reach CUNY Finals
description: On a night of stirring comebacks, the College of Staten Island and City College advanced to the men's final of the City University of New York Athletic Conference men's basketball tournament last night. The second-seeded Dolphins will square off against the eighth-seeded Beavers tomorrow night at the City College gym.

title: Council Panel Tries to Shield Finance Law From Giuliani
description: In the latest skirmish over the city's campaign finance system, a City Council committee adopted legislation yesterday to try to block a legal challenge to the system by the mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, HELENA (NEE EDEY)
description: JOHNSON-Helena (nee Edey). Age 89, of Far Hills, NJ, on Friday, February 16, 2001. Wife of the late Francis Edgar Johnson Jr. Mother of Dr. Cynthia Mackay of Brooklyn, NY, Helena Bienstock of Princeton, NJ, and Frank E. Johnson III of New York City. Grandmother of Robert L. Mackay, Jessica F. Koehler, Hope M. Crosier, Christina M. Johnson and the late Alison G. Fraker. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 3, at 11 AM, at Lamington Presbyterian Church, Lamington, NJ. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the Clarence Dillon Library, Lamington Rd, Bedminster, NJ 07921, or WNET Channel 13, 450 W 33rd St, NY, NY 10001.

title: F.B.I. Never Gave Lie Test To Agent Charged as Spy
description: Robert Philip Hanssen was never polygraphed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to determine whether he might be a security risk during the 15 years when, it is charged, he spied for the Soviet Union and then Russia, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLES, ERNEST
description: GELLES-Ernest. 86, died 2/20. Predeceased by his wife of 57 years, Charlotte Remenyi Gelles. Survived by 2 daughters, Sherry and Carol. A lieutenant in the Italian Army until 1939 when he came to the US, rising through the ranks to Captain of military intelligence eventually serving as Interim Governor of Calabrese during WWII. In 1946 he joined Molded Latex (currently Kaysam Corp of America). He became president, then chairman of the board and was director of the Paterson Chamber of Commerce. Forbes magazine referred to him as ''one smart cookie''. A pillar of strength to all who knew him. The after-life masters have a formidable champion join their celestial bridge tournament today. Services will be held today at Plaza Memorial (91st and Amsterdam) at 10 AM.

title: A Universe of Music
description: THE grandly amorphous term ''world music'' is now applied comprehensively to field recordings and big-budget studio pop, to deep-rooted traditionalism and cross-cultural experiments, to gimmicky one-shots and venerable non-Western classical styles. Yet amid the confusion, world music has never been less foreign to American ears. What immigrants haven't taken with them, musicians have tracked down and imported.

title: A Faustian Bargain Explains the Rock Stars' Gigs
description: If you thought rock 'n' roll evolved from merging strains of American blues, folk and country music, you're in for a shock. No less an authority than ''Haunted Castle,'' the first 3-D Imax horror movie, is here to tell us that rock 'n' roll is really what those much-ridiculed fire-and-brimstone-preaching guardians of 50's morality always claimed: the devil's music.

title: 76ers Hope Mutombo Will Deliver the Title
description: Already laying claim to the best little man in pro basketball, the Philadelphia 76ers yesterday reaffirmed their commitment to winning the National Basketball Association championship this season by acquiring the last great center still standing in the Eastern Conference.

title: Pardons, Morals and History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRABKIN, STEVEN WAYNE
description: DRABKIN-Steven Wayne. 10/19/61-2/23-81. Twenty years have gone by, but we who held him dear remember. He is enshrined within our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRASSO, THOMAS A.
description: GRASSO-Thomas A. Age 54. Died February 10, 2001. Teacher, actor, administrator. Director of Herbert Berghof Studio. Former associate at Actors Connection. Mr. Grasso taught multiply-handicapped children at the New York Institute for the Blind. He was a member/performer with the Village Light Opera Group, et al. Beloved son, brother and uncle; devoted partner; friend to animals. Survived by his life partner, David T. Jones; parents Anthony & Mary Grasso of N. Arlington, NJ; sister Judith McLaughlin and husband Thomas; sister Regina Purcell and children Angelica and Vincent; brother Anthony Grasso and wife Robin; and Oscar, his cat. A memorial service will be announced. Donations in Mr. Grasso's name may be made to: HB Playwrights Foundation, 122 Bank Street, NYC 10014.

title: Corrections
description: A film review of ''Down to Earth'' in Weekend last Friday referred incorrectly to the character played by Robert Montgomery in the 1941 film ''Here Comes Mr. Jordan,'' a version of the same story. He was a boxer, not a gangster. (In ''Down to Earth,'' the leading character is a comedian, played by Chris Rock.)

title: The Anguish of Souls Echoes Across an Era
description: MUSIC FOR THE THIRD EAR

title: A Symphony of Nations, Playing Live
description: A sampling of international music performances in the coming weeks in New York City. Many are sponsored by the World Music Institute. Major Manhattan locations and information numbers: Cooper Union, Seventh Street at Third Avenue, East Village, (212) 545-7536; Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, Flatiron district, (917) 606-8200; Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400; S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940; and Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, (212) 545-7536.

title: That Walk to High School Woke Me Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Suite Deal at the Rihga Royal Hotel
description: Cold weather has the power to drop the rates of Manhattan hotels. Through March 31, the Rihga Royal Hotel, 151 West 54th Street in Manhattan, is offering suites for $229 a night on weekends and $309 on weekdays. The usual price for these suites is $495. The rates do not include taxes, and a suite with a convertible sofa is $29 a night extra; the offer is subject to availability. The Rihga, a 500-suite hotel, is close to Broadway theaters, Rockefeller Center and the Museum of Modern Art. Call (800) 937-5454.

title: Article 2001022390458886615 -- No Title
description: The Web, Without Wires, Wherever

title: A Chief Exporter, and Not at All Pleased About It
description: Factories just like the Matsushita plant here made North Carolina an industrial colossus less than a decade ago, the state with the largest percentage of its workers in manufacturing jobs. Surrounded by fountains and landscaped nature trails, that pristine compressor factory seemed to embody the state's economic promise when it opened with fanfare in 1991.

title: A Tense Mideast Awaits Powell's Visit
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 23  On the eve of General Colin L. Powell's first visit to the region as secretary of state, officials in Israel today rebuffed his pleas for an easing of the blockade of Palestinian territories, while Palestinian militants burned him in effigy.

title: From Blaze to Ashes, as He Overpowers His Piano
description: The Finnish pianist Paavali Jumppanen, who gave a Young Concert Artists recital at the 92nd Street Y on Tuesday, is a quiet-looking young man full of intensity, strength and imagination the moment he puts his hands to the keyboard. His programming, too, suggests thoughtfulness and passion -- and independence.

title: Pardons, Morals and History
description: To the Editor:

title: Town Agrees To Restrain Police Force
description: After months of ignoring allegations that the police routinely harassed women and tried to intimidate critics, the Wallkill Town Board approved an agreement tonight with the state attorney general's office providing for strict guidelines on police conduct and oversight by a federal monitor.

title: Quiet on the Lobbying Front; Sudden Halt to Coalition's Bid for Corporate Tax Breaks
description: With a determined tax cutter moving into the White House and Republicans still in charge on Capitol Hill, the stage seemed set early this year for Charls E. Walker to help lower the taxes paid by corporate America once again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, LAWRENCE J.
description: GOLD-Lawrence J. On February 21, 2001. Husband of Vivian. Devoted father of Robin, Bonnie, and Scott. Cherished grandfather to Griffin, Max, Taylor, Jake, and Sydney. Services Friday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: ABN AMRO'S PROFIT FALLS
description: ABN Amro Holding N.V., the largest Dutch bank, said its second-half net income fell 23 percent as costs increased and it took a charge to restructure. The bank will cut another 5,750 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, and close 200 Dutch branches as it aims to meet profit targets. Net income fell to 873 million euros ($790 million).

title: 2 Retailers Report Disappointing Fourth Quarter
description: Weak holiday sales led to a second consecutive quarterly loss at the J. C. Penney Company and a 59 percent decline in profit at Nordstrom Inc., the companies said yesterday.

title: Foreign Affairs; Hype and Anti-Hype
description: The Gartner Group consultants have developed a useful concept to describe the hype around new technologies, which they call the ''hype cycle.'' As a new technology -- like the Internet -- is triggered, the hype curve soars upward until it reaches a peak of inflated expectations. Then it sinks almost straight down into a trough of disillusionment, as the less successful players drop out. And finally it climbs steadily upward again to a new stable plateau, as clear winners emerge and the new technology is absorbed, integrated and made profitable by people and industries that understand it.

title: National Enquirer Is Out Front on Two Major Reports
description: For the second time in a month, The National Enquirer, a tabloid newspaper reviled by celebrities and politicians for its gossip-laden and sometimes unsubstantiated articles, has been out front in reporting a story that the mainstream news media found more than worthy of their attention.

title: Oracle defies wisdom by using itself to pitch its software products.
description: THEY are hardly an advertising novelty, but whether they are offered by movie celebrities, sports stars or plain citizens, testimonials are usually about products that are made by third-party companies and not by the person who is delivering the pitch.

title: Kutlug Ataman
description: Lehmann Maupin

title: Desperate Farmers Imperil Peru's Fight on Coca
description: Not long ago, American officials considered Peru a model of success in their fight against the illegal drug trade, one they are seeking even now to replicate in neighboring Colombia.

title: Spy Drama Survivor Watches as Story Unfolds
description: Boris Yuzhin could be called the third man in the unfolding F.B.I. spy drama, the only survivor of a trio of named Russian agents for the United States who the government says were exposed by Robert Philip Hanssen.

title: New Clues From the Greeneville
description: It has not yet been clearly established whether the distracting presence of civilians in the control room of the U.S.S. Greeneville was responsible for the submarine's deadly collision with a Japanese fishing trawler earlier this month. But NBC News reported last night that investigators had now determined that the Greeneville's sonar detected the Japanese vessel just moments before the collision and that the crewman plotting the location of the fishing vessel failed to alert the captain. That may have been because of the crowding caused by civilian visitors in the control room.

title: Article 2001022393931088368 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Kozmo.com to Cut 4% of Workforce
description: Kozmo.com, the one-hour online delivery service, announced today that it would lay off about 60 employees in its corporate headquarters in Manhattan in an effort to cut costs, and it said it would begin doing more business that does not involve the Internet.

title: Transcript of President Bush's White House News Conference
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CONTINENTAL DROPS OBJECTIONS TO T.W.A. AUCTION
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it was dropping its objections to the auction of Trans World Airlines by a bankruptcy court and would withdraw its appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. On Wednesday, a bankruptcy court in Delaware refused to delay the auction, scheduled for March 5. The airline had contended that the bidding procedures unfairly favored American Airlines, which has offered $500 million in cash for most of T.W.A.'s assets. Continental had said that it was willing to pay as much as $400 million for some of T.W.A.'s assets as part of a rescue plan led by others that would keep the carrier independent. But yesterday, Continental said that T.W.A. might be forced to stop flying if a deal were not completed by March 12 and that American had firmed up its offer. Laurence Zuckerman (NYT)

title: HEINEKEN IN GERMAN VENTURE
description: Europe's biggest brewer, Heineken, pushed into Germany by creating a joint venture with the Schrghuber group to sell Paulaner Weiss beer. Heineken, a Dutch brewer, said it would buy a 49.9 percent stake in the venture to gain access to two German beer makers and a link to a brewer in Chile. Bayerische BrauHolding A.G., a Schrghuber unit, will own the rest. Financial details were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the effect of oil exploration on wildlife refuges misstated the measurement of the oil estimated to lie beneath the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. It is 5 billion to 19 billion barrels, not acres.

title: Clinton Fatigue in Democrats
description: Even some of the most devoted supporters of Bill and Hillary Clinton now refuse to defend their messy exit from the White House and some openly criticize them. Page A16.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PASTA-SAUCE CASE DECIDED
description: In the legal battle over Patsy's pasta sauces, Patsy's Restaurant in Midtown has prevailed over Patsy's Pizzeria of Harlem. In a ruling issued late Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Judge John S. Martin Jr. agreed to make permanent a preliminary injunction he issued in December 1999 preventing the pizzeria from selling mason jars of spaghetti sauce. Not only did the pizzeria's labels bear a suspicious resemblance to those of the Midtown restaurant's successful products, Judge Martin noted, but its owners had falsely claimed that they started selling sauce first. He scheduled an April hearing to determine whether the pizzeria's owners and lawyers should be sanctioned. But Judge Martin did not rule on the most emotionally fraught issue in the legal battle: which Patsy's was Frank Sinatra's true favorite.

title: Thrills, Spills And More Cries Of Sled Injuries; Non-Steer Plastic Replaces Flexible Flyer on the Hills
description: Gary Ryan watched anxiously on a recent day as her daughter Isabel plunged down a snowy hill on the Pelham Country Club golf course, perched precariously on an inflatable plastic pad called the Rally Sno Tube. Her anxiety turned to panic as Isabel headed straight for the trunk of a large tree with no ability to steer or brake.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Article 2001022391338812130 -- No Title
description: February 22, 2001

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Pearl Oyster Bar, the fish diner on Cornelia Street, is popular but small. Very small. But not too small to spawn. Mary Redding, a partner in Pearl, has left to open her own fish shack a few blocks away. It's called Mary's Fish Camp and is, if possible, even smaller than Pearl Oyster Bar.

title: Metro Business Briefing; COMPTROLLER'S ECONOMIC REPORT
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who has announced plans to run for governor, issued a report yesterday contending that New York's metropolitan areas are lagging economically. The report, which compared the state's cities with similar areas in other states, covered 1991 to 1999 and 1995 to 1999. ''The upstate economy is still not healthy,'' Mr. McCall said in a statement, ''and the state needs to make a strong commitment to a comprehensive economic development strategy if the region is going to be able to attract and keep good businesses and jobs.'' A spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki noted that the state was recently ranked fourth among all states in attracting new and expanding companies. ''Obviously, any report that goes back to the early 90's will be skewed by the massive hole that Carl McCall's partner, Mario Cuomo, dug for the New York State economy,'' said the spokesman, Joseph Conway.

title: Wolfinger Will Transfer From St. John's
description: Jack Wolfinger's nomadic basketball life took another turn yesterday when St. John's announced that he was transferring. St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis described the parting as mutual, but he also expressed disappointment that Wolfinger, a redshirt freshman, would again face a disruption in his life.

title: New Cardinal In a Clash Of Creeds
description: The gold ring that John Paul II placed on the finger of Cardinal Lubomyr Husar at a Mass for the 44 new cardinals today was too tight. After the ceremony in St. Peter's Square, the cardinal eased it off and slipped it into a pocket inside his flowing black robes.

title: Article 2001022393722152058 -- No Title
description: By MARGARET W. GOLDSBOROUGH

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a Supreme Court ruling that gives states immunity from lawsuits by disabled workers omitted the response of the University of Alabama Hospital, which was accused by a nurse of having demoted her when she returned to work after cancer treatment. The hospital contended that the nurse was not demoted but requested and received a transfer.

title: Sorting Out the Pardon Mess
description: The political class in Washington and around the nation seldom finds itself in the state of stunned, bipartisan unanimity produced by President Clinton's pardons. Former President Carter expressed the consensus view by denouncing the hasty, undisciplined granting of clemency to undeserving felons and fugitives as a signal mistake of the Clinton era. The announcement that Hugh Rodham, the brother of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, had returned $400,000 he got for supporting two of the most baffling grants of executive clemency will do nothing to stem the outrage or sweep away the civic, legal and political problems created by Mr. Clinton.

title: Yellow Brick Road as a One-Way Street to Misery
description: Even before she died in 1969, Judy Garland had begun a ghostly public existence, buried beneath layers of clichs. Now her legend is entrenched. She is the camp icon beloved by cross-dressers; the poster girl for tragic child stars and Hollywood drug abuse; the epitome of a comeback kid, staging triumphant concerts when her career seemed dead. And always she is Dorothy, whose innocence in ''The Wizard of Oz'' has a perpetual life of its own apart from the anguished off-screen image Garland came to inhabit.

title: Williams Pushing Himself As Honor to Ailing Father
description: Bernie Williams calls his father every other day, dialing his number in Puerto Rico while desperately hoping there will be some better news about Bernabe Sr.'s deteriorating condition. The conversations have become exasperating and short. Bernabe tries to speak, but he gasps for breath, struggling to say what he is thinking, and puts down the phone.

title: Storm Leaves 3 Dead and Traffic in Snarls
description: A surprisingly powerful snowstorm rolled across the Eastern Seaboard yesterday, causing hundreds of accidents and leaving at least three people dead.

title: Breezy Point Journal; Neighborly Place Hits a Sewer Line in the Sand
description: It might be too simple to blame the whole mess at Breezy Point on the toilet, but it wouldn't be far off.

title: Bush Meets With British Prime Minister
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23  President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain discussed a wide range of world issues today and vowed that their countries would continue to have, as Mr. Bush put it, "an alliance that has made a huge difference in the world."

title: U.S. Had Evidence of Espionage, But F.B.I. Failed to Inspect Itself
description: For a number of years, American intelligence officials have had evidence that Russia had a significant pipeline from the United States government, yet the F.B.I. failed to conduct a rigorous internal review of its own personnel, current and former government officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, RUTH
description: HELLER-Ruth. Loving and courageous sister-in-law, aunt, and great-aunt. Rest in peace. Renee, Vicki, Bud, Scott, Joanna, Eric

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHELBY, JEROME
description: SHELBY-Jerome. Died on February 21, 2001 at the age of 70 after a long bout with leukemia, which he endured with characteristic courage, grace and humor. A business man's lawyer, he earned his Bachelor's Degree from New York University in 1950 and graduated Cum Laude from Harvard Law School with an LL.B. degree in 1953. Immediately thereafter, he joined Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, where he became a protege of H. Lee White, a successful ship finance lawyer and shipping businessman. Mr. Shelby was a Partner of the Firm from 1963 through 1992. During his tenure as Partner, Mr. Shelby served as Cochairman of the Firm for more than nine years and was a member of Cadwalader's Management Committee for close to two decades. After stepping down as a Partner in 1992, he remained Counsel to the Firm. He is survived by his wife, Adrian, son P. Austin Shelby and daughter-in-law Heath Shelby of West Orange, NJ, daughter Dr. Karen Shelby Anderson and sonin-law Tim Anderson of Bedford, NH, granddaughters Meredith Shelby, Melissa Shelby, Emily Anderson and Shelby Anderson, a grandson Maxwell Anderson and brother Judge Stuart Shelby of Santa Monica, CA. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 23, at 11:30AM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Donations may be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: David Salle -- 'Pastorale'
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Trade Center, Once Sneered At, Lures Rich Suitor and $3.2 Billion
description: The World Trade Center, which was derided as a 110-story, 10 million-square-foot example of government excess when it opened in the 1970's, is set to be handed over to a giant company in the largest real estate deal ever involving a single office complex.

title: Clothes Make the Model
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC AGREES TO 2ND ACQUISITION IN A WEEK
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, a maker of products to clear heart arteries, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Embolic Protection Inc. for $75 million, its second acquisition in a week. Embolic Protection, which is closely held, makes a filter designed to catch material dislodged during artery-clearing procedures and keep it from traveling to the heart or brain, where it can cause a heart attack or stroke. Last week, Boston Scientific said it would pay $345 million for the closely held Interventional Technologies to acquire a new balloon catheter used to clear arteries.

title: Scientists Find Signs of Meteor Crash That Led to Extinctions in Era Before Dinosaurs
description: Extraterrestrial gases trapped within cagelike carbon molecules are providing the first compelling evidence that a meteor impact set off the most catastrophic of mass extinctions more than 250 million years ago, similar to the cataclysm that later killed off the dinosaurs.

title: Sun Revises Its Estimates Downward
description: Sun Microsystems said yesterday that many of its large customers had sharply cut back on investments in computer equipment, making it likely that it will fall well short of projected sales and earnings in the current quarter.

title: Pardons, Morals and History
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting Out Market Fear Elsewhere
description: Turkey's devaluation of its currency yesterday seemed to take some of the pressure out of the latest emerging-markets crisis. Most damage in other nations' financial markets came earlier in the week as the crisis grew.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, TIFFANI
description: FELDMAN-Tiffani. 4/1/76-2/22/00. Still feel your love, still hear your laughter. Always with love, Grandmother, Grandfather & Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMON, JOSEPH F.
description: HARMON-Joseph F. Of Eastchester. Died February 21, 2001 at the age of 68 yrs. Joseph is survived by his wife, Joan Pawlowski Harmon. He is also survived by Leslie Harmon-Jarsen, Laura Harmon, Margaret Holmes, Kathleen Emens, Karen Jarsen and Bruce Jarsen. Brother of Mary Ellen Gladir, Robert Harmon, James Harmon and the late Judith Pagnotto. Uncle of Nina Gladir. Grandfather of ten. Friends may gather Sunday, February 25 from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Westchester Funeral Home Inc., 190 Main St., Eastchester, NY. Funeral Mass Monday 10:45 at Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory: The American Cancer Society, Westchester Division, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, NY 10601.

title: Harmon Goldstone Dies at 89; Led New York Landmarks Commission
description: Harmon Hendricks Goldstone, an architect whose career ranged from creating the 1939 World of Tomorrow to preserving broad swaths of the world of yesterday, died Wednesday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 89.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after a report showed inventories plunged last week to their lowest level in 27 years. In New York, crude oil for April delivery rose 29 cents, or 1 percent, to $28.82 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, DOROTHY HURT
description: PRICE-Dorothy Hurt. Died on February 22nd after a long illness. She was a resident of Palm Beach, Southampton and New York City. Her three husbands, Malcolm Meacham, Edgar Eyre and Hickman Price, Jr. all predeceased her. She drove an ambulance in New York as a volunteer during World War II, and was president of the Village Improvement Society in Southampton. She was the last surviving founding member of the Bath and Tennis Club and a member of the Everglades Club. She had an identical twin, Margaret, whom she survived. She is survived by a daughter, Marjorie Meacham Meek, a granddaughter, Marina Dunn Nelson and four grandsons, Arvid, Eric and Malcolm Nelson and Jonathan Dunn. There will be a small private reception at her home in Palm Beach later in the spring.

title: Teenage Suspect in Park Slaying Is Not Violent, His Relatives Say
description: One day after three teenagers were charged in the shooting death of a man in Central Park, relatives insisted that the 15-year-old accused of being the gunman was not a violent person.

title: Colombia Massacre's Strange Fallout
description: He seemed to be the perfect officer for the beleaguered army.

title: Election Night Reports
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAYE, ROBBIE
description: KAYE - Robbie. 1/16/76 - 2/23/96. Five years ago we lost you from our lives but not our hearts and souls. Love, Mom, Dad, Andy

title: California Couple Sentenced for Helping Clients Evade Taxes
description: A California couple who helped their clients evade at least $13.8 million in federal income taxes were sentenced to long prison terms yesterday, sentences the judge extended after they said that the tax laws were invalid and did not apply to them.

title: ANALYST CUTS MICROSOFT FORECAST
description: Microsoft could post fiscal third-quarter revenue $100 million to $300 million below analysts' consensus estimate, a Merrill Lynch analyst, Henry Blodget, wrote in a research note yesterday. He cited ''continuing deterioration of fundamentals across the technology industry'' in the quarter ending March 31. Mr. Blodget wrote that he was sticking with his estimate that Microsoft would earn 43 cents a share.

title: Piercing Dadaist Anomie With the Call of Tradition
description: Salia Ni Seydou, a modern-dance company from Burkina Faso, shared a bill with two American choreographers on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater in a program that epitomized the theme of 651 Arts' rich festival ''Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation.''

title: PEMEX DIRECTORS OPPOSED
description: Mexican lawmakers opposed to President Vicente Fox want to remove four businessmen from the board of the state-owned oil company Petrleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, saying Mr. Fox's appointments violate the Constitution. ''Private citizens can't be members of Pemex's board as representatives of the state,'' said Carlos Aceves, a legislator from the centrist Institutional Revolutionary Party. Mr. Fox stunned the nation when he named the billionaire Carlos Slim Hel and three other top executives to the Pemex's board nine days ago.

title: Warner LeRoy, Restaurateur, Dies at 65
description: Warner LeRoy, a son of Hollywood pioneers who combined show business glamour with circus ballyhoo to create New York restaurants like Maxwell's Plum, Tavern on the Green and the Russian Tea Room, died Thursday night at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 65.

title: Navy Postpones Inquiry in Sinking Until March 5
description: The Navy has delayed until March 5 a public court of inquiry to investigate the sinking of a Japanese fishing trawler by the nuclear submarine Greeneville, Navy officials said today.

title: A Balkan Horror, And Our Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My guidance to them is behave yourself, and they will.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOK, IDA (NEE GRAFF)
description: KOOK-Ida (nee Graff), of Del Ray Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Newton Kook. For information ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-378-1892.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLLY, PATRICIA
description: BERLLY-Patricia. Dear Joel, Joan, Lillian, Michael and Lauren, we share your grief and will always remember with great respect and admiration Pat's valiant struggle against impossible odds. Her sense of humor and her daily cheerful emails will be missed. Susan and Fred Friedman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, JOHN (JACK) BRUTON HAYES, JR.
description: HAYES-John (Jack) Bruton Hayes, Jr., 59, of Fairfield, CT, husband of Susan S. Hayes, died February 22, 2001. Mr. Hayes was born in Bronx, New York, son of John B. Hayes Sr. and the late Muriel S. Hayes. He received his Bachelor's Degree from Manhattan College and was employed at Chapdelaine & Company, New York City. A member of the Brooklawn Country Club, a Trustee of the Wakeman's Boys and Girls Club, both Fairfield, the National Golf Links of America, and Metropolitan Club of NYC. In addition to his wife and father, he is survived by his children, John (Jay) B., III, Andrew (Drew) S., and Caitlin C., three brothers, Gerald, Kevin, and Brian, two sisters, Kathleen Hyer, and Joan Dwyer. A memorial Mass, Monday March 5, at 10:00 AM in St. Thomas Church, Fairfield. The family will receive friends, Sunday, March 4, from 4-8 PM at the Redgate-Hennessy Funeral Home, Main St. & Gorham Pl. Trumbull, CT. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 372 Danbury Rd., Wilton, CT 06897, the Wakeman's Boys and Girls Club, 385 Center Street, Southport, CT 06490, or the Wall Street Charity Fund, 99 Wall Street, 22nd Floor, New York, New York 10005.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: UBS Hires Key Executive Away From Morgan Stanley
description: UBS Warburg, a division of the Swiss banking giant UBS A.G., took another step toward raising the profile of its United States investment banking business yesterday, hiring a key executive from Morgan Stanley. The executive, Jeffrey A. Sine, has been global co-head of the media and communications investment banking group at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

title: Romancing Columbia: Lessons in Nostalgia And New Discoveries
description: Who is without those unsettling dreams about having failed a course at college, requiring an extended time back on campus to earn a degree? Sometimes I wake up and wonder what it would be like, only to find myself in recent months living the reality, but for a happier reason. I have returned to the subject of my master's thesis at Columbia University to write a book about a 13th-century Count of Champagne.

title: Bush Tells Blair He Doesn't Oppose New Europe Force
description: THURMONT, Md., Feb. 23  President Bush today endorsed a European rapid-reaction force for the first time, telling Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain that the United States had no objections to a separate military arm to help keep peace in Europe as long as that force was clearly secondary to NATO.

title: UBIQUITEL BUYING VIA WIRELESS
description: UbiquiTel Inc., which provides Sprint PCS wireless telephone services in the central and western United States, said it would acquire VIA Wireless for $119 million in stock and $25 million in assumed debt. The agreement will triple the number of UbiquiTel subscribers, to 56,000, and make it the second-largest Sprint PCS affiliate. UbiquiTel, based in Conshohocken, Pa., will exchange 16.4 million shares of its common stock, which fell 19 cents, to $7.25, after the announcement. VIA, a privately held company based in Fresno, Calif., has 40,000 customers in central California. Peter Lucas, UbiquiTel's acting chief financial officer, said the deal would be completed in July 2001, leaving the company with $50 million in cash. VIA Wireless shareholders will own 19.5 percent of the company, UbiquiTel said. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Amid Telecommunications Gloom, Optimism in France
description: While the financial markets remain pessimistic about the mobile telecommunications business, with stock sell-offs on both sides of the Atlantic, telecommunications suppliers are showing no signs of retreat at the 3GSM World Congress here, where more than 14,000 people have converged on this small city on the Cte d'Azur.

title: SIEMENS BUYING MODEM MAKER
description: Siemens A.G., the big German electronics concern, strengthened its position in the high-speed Internet business in the United States with its agreement yesterday to acquire Efficient Networks, a large maker of modems for fast Internet connections, for $1.5 billion in cash. Siemens will pay $23.50 a share for Efficient, which is based in Dallas, or 90 percent more than its closing price on Wednesday. The deal led investors to bid up Efficient's stock yesterday, with the share price climbing $10.69, to $23.06. The acquisition is part of the Siemens strategy of expanding in the United States ahead of its planned share offering next month on the New York Stock Exchange. Mark Floyd, above, Efficient's chairman, said, ''The combination with Siemens, with representation in over 160 countries, will allow us to further accelerate growth of our combined broadband business.'' Simon Romero (NYT)

title: ART REVIEW
description: BY way of introducing Paul McCarthy's show opening tomorrow at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, here's a mini-synopsis of ''Painter,'' one of his videos: Wearing a hospital gown, no pants, a bouncing bulbous rubber nose, blond wig, giant rubber ears and hands, and using paintbrushes the size of lances and paint tubes as big as sleeping bags, Mr. McCarthy plays the temperamental Action painter as a kind of psychotic Bozo.

title: How History Was Made In a Moment of Defiance
description: Rosa Parks sits on the bus and in a reverie sees a tire on a rope swinging from a tree; as it sways in and out of sight, the child's makeshift ride becomes the body of a lynched man. Then we glimpse her as she must feel: a black woman sitting completely alone in the front of the bus as a crowd of black people stand in the rear and stare. Instead of literally recreating that watershed moment in 1955, when Mrs. Parks defied the segregation law and refused to give her seat to a white man on a Montgomery, Ala., bus, the audacious ''Boycott'' sparingly uses moments of visual poetry to create an attachment to history.

title: 6 Agencies Compete For Mohegan Sun
description: Mohegan Sun, a casino and entertainment center in Uncasville, Conn., said yesterday that it was asking agencies to compete for its account, with billings estimated at $20 million.

title: Rich Get Richer; Knicks Get Older
description: The Sixers strengthened their stake as the best team in the Eastern Conference with the acquisition of Dikembe Mutombo, while their pursuers, the Knicks, hope that Mark Jackson can keep pace with Allen Iverson.

title: Drawing the Line on Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Want Sehorn And Barber to Return
description: The Giants announced yesterday that they would not use the franchise tag on either cornerback Jason Sehorn or running back Tiki Barber, two of the team's more valuable players.

title: McGreevey Joins Debate on Tax Rebates
description: Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, the lone Democratic candidate for governor, waded into the debate over New Jersey's perennially high property taxes today, setting the stage for a noisy partisan battle over the state's ballooning debt, with the possibility of a little class warfare as an added attraction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, VIVIAN
description: MARCUS-Vivian. On February 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Dear sister of Harold Hofflin and the late Norman Hofflin. Cherished and devoted aunt of Lois Hofflin, Jesse Hofflin and his wife, Phyllis, and loving great-aunt of Lauren Hofflin. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Sunday, 12 PM.

title: One Case May Hold Clues to Another
description: For nearly a dozen years, a former State Department official, Felix S. Bloch, has lived in limbo, dismissed from his senior diplomatic post and investigated on suspicion of being a Russian spy, yet never charged with any crime.

title: QANTAS TO CUT JOBS
description: Qantas Airways Ltd. said it would cut one-fourth of its Australian-based executives and middle managers within the next two weeks and would trim 5 percent of all staff over the next six months. The job cuts, totaling 1,470, come as the airline's earnings have been hurt by higher fuel costs, new regional competitors and a weak Australian dollar. The company's net profit for the first half-year, ending Dec. 31, slipped more than one-fifth from the same period a year earlier, despite a 13 percent rise in revenue. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Corrections
