description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about physicists' attraction to mountain climbing misidentified the make of plane that crashed on Dec. 19, 1997, killing Dr. David N. Schramm, an expert on the Big Bang. (The error first appeared in an article in the section on Feb. 10, 1998, about Dr. Schramm.) The craft was a Swearingen SW-3, not a Cessna.

title: SWEDISH BANKING MERGER
description: A bank co-founded by the Wallenberg family, SEB A.B., agreed to merge with Swedbank in a stock swap valued at roughly $7.4 billion to create the Nordic region's largest bank by assets. SEB shareholders will own 51.5 percent of the new entity, to be called SEB Swedbank, with investors in Swedbank holding the remainder. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Legal Expert Sees Napster Competitors Thriving
description: By now it's sunk in that, last week, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco branded a great many Napster users as direct copyright infringers. That was bad news for Napster fans, to say nothing of Napster itself, which was declared by the court to have likely violated federal copyright laws for contributing to the infringement activities of its fans.

title: Elvis Week Offers Cover (In Polyester) For a Holdup
description: Demian Lichtenstein's ''3,000 Miles to Graceland'' is a hybrid: it combines plot elements of ''Ocean's 11'' and ''Honeymoon in Vegas'' and lumps in the entertainment value of, oh, ''Roustabout'' or maybe ''Blue Hawaii.'' This bloated spectacle has all the get-up-and-go of one of the legendary late-era Elvis Presley concerts. The picture feels longer than Presley's career and as irrelevant as he was by the end.

title: The Moles Will Always Be With Us
description: There is nothing more painful for the men and women entrusted with the security of our country than learning that one of their own has betrayed them and their country. No part of our government is immune to such treachery, no matter how thorough an organization's security and vetting procedures.

title: Board Makes Minor Changes To Bilingual Education Plan
description: The Board of Education made minor amendments yesterday to Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy's plan to change bilingual education, beefing up his plan to give parents more say when their child is enrolled in the program.

title: For Daewoo's Founder, Pride Before the Fall
description: A decade ago, a Fortune magazine writer wrote in an introduction to Kim Woo Choong's book ''Every Street Is Paved With Gold'' that Mr. Kim, the founder of the Daewoo industrial empire, ''personifies the drive and imagination that makes East Asia a dynamic center of economic growth.''

title: Nasdaq Falls to Worst Close Since '99 as Dow Ends Even
description: Technology stocks were shaken by more signs of weak corporate profits yesterday, dragging the Nasdaq stock market to its lowest point in more than two years, and the broader market remained pessimistic despite some upbeat economic news.

title: Pardons, Morals and History
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Survivor With a Gun

title: Man Pleads Guilty to Pretending To Be a City Transit Employee
description: A 35-year-old man who has spent much of his life masquerading as a New York City Transit worker pleaded guilty yesterday to forgery and burglary charges relating to an incident last year involving an N train at the 57th Street station in Manhattan.

title: SPIRIT SALES HELP DIAGEO
description: The world's largest liquor company, Diageo P.L.C., said strong demand for spirits and beer offset a decline in fast food and contributed to an 11 percent rise in first-half operating profit. Demand for Smirnoff vodka and Guinness beer helped push group operating profit for the six months ended Dec. 31 to 1.23 million ($1.78 million) compared with 1.15 million a year earlier. During the same period, operating profit at the Burger King unit fell 6 million, to 99 million.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about payments to President Bill Clinton's brother-in-law Hugh Rodham for lobbying for a pardon and a prison commutation for two wealthy felons gave a misspelled name in some copies for the home city of G. B. Data Systems, a company owned by one of the felons. It is Marina del Rey, not Del Ray.

title: MALAYSIA EASES FINANCIAL RESTRICTIONS
description: Malaysia's Securities Commission announced a 10-year plan to liberalize the country's securities markets, easing restrictions to win back foreign investment and give companies alternatives to what economists say is an overreliance on bank lending. The commission's plan calls for lifting limits on foreign ownership of financial companies by 2003 and for folding two smaller Malaysian exchanges into the main stock exchange by next year. The plan, announced by the Securities Commission chairman, Ali Abdul Kadir, also proposes ending restrictions on selling borrowed stocks or bonds or short-selling. That practice was banned in 1998 during the Asian financial crisis. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Despite an Off Year, Ventura Is All Class
description: The World Series was over, the Mets had lost, and the numbness had set in. When the clubhouse opened to the news media, the reserve Mets sat in silence, their heads in their hands. Most of the veteran starters consoled themselves elsewhere.

title: TERRA NETWORKS EXECUTIVE QUITS
description: Abel Linares, chief operating officer of Terra Networks, resigned from Terra, the world's third-largest Internet company, less than a month after its chief executive, Bob Davis, stepped down. Terra, which is controlled by Telefnica, Spain's largest phone company, gave no reason for the departure of Mr. Linares, above, which comes at the end of the process of integrating Terra Networks with Lycos Inc., the United States Internet company it acquired in October for $6.5 billion, and six months after Telefnica's new chairman, Csar Alierta, named Joaquim Agut as Terra chairman. That appointment led to the resignation of Mr. Davis, a founder of Lycos, who stepped down as chief executive on Feb. 1, saying there was not room for the company to be run by two people.

title: Does the U.S. Trade Deficit Matter? This Year, It Will
description: ONLY a year ago, as the United States trade deficit set a record, there were warnings that something had to give. Surely the United States could not continue to buy $723 million a day more than it sold. The dollar would have to decline, it was said.

title: Turkey Floats Currency, and It Falls 25%
description: Sixty-five million Turks awakened this morning to find their national currency in a free fall that stripped away more than 25 percent of its value by the end of the day and sent a wave of concern -- but so far no panic -- through many foreign markets.

title: $4.5 Billion in Credit Lines for Lucent
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. has persuaded banks to provide $4.5 billion in new credit lines, avoiding a possible downgrading of its debt to junk status and allowing it to pursue a revamping, the company said yesterday.

title: Bush Holds His First White House News Conference
description: As the former president's pardons threatened to eclipse the current president's plans, George W. Bush held his first news conference in the White House today and sought to redirect public attention to, and amass public support for, his proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut.

title: Jacob Lawrence
description: D.C. Moore Gallery

title: Fast, English, Eccentric And Headed This Way
description: IF you are in the market for the fastest car in America, Peter Wheeler says he has just the thing. But he would advise you to wait, since the vehicle he has in mind isn't at dealerships yet. Actually, there aren't any dealerships, but he says they are coming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, JOHN RYAN, JR.
description: QUINN-John Ryan, Jr., New York advertising sales executive, was killed while riding as a passenger in a tour vehicle in Tanzania's Serengeti Wildlife Preserve on February 19th, 2001. A Manhattan resident, John grew up in Rumson, NJ, became a high school tennis star and National Champion in platform tennis. At Boston University, he was Captain of the tennis team and graduated magna cum laude. Actively involved with Marble Collegiate Church, he played an integral role in founding ''Future Possibilities,'' a life skills coaching program for kids. His mother, Phyllis Igoe of Manhattan, preceded him in death. He is survived by: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Quinn, Sr. of Sea Girt, NJ, sisters Sally Curci of Cranford, NJ and Margot Quinn of Portland, OR, five loving nieces and nephews, his girlfriend Donna Frischknecht, and Jarrell Bland, whom John mentored. John was in truth, his brother's keeper. Memorial services will be held on Monday, February 26th, at 6 PM at Marble Collegiate Church, 5th Ave. and 29th St. In lieu of flowers, please contribute in John's memory to Future Possibilities, 249 E. 32nd Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: Harassment and Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Art's Cold Welcome on the Web
description: In the whole foofaraw around Napster, what mostly got lost was the artists. They are the Belgians of this controversy, trampled by armies heading someplace else. Now the Information Wants to Be Free hipsters battle the mercantilists (AOL Time Warner), who feel their copyright extends to ''all media known and unknown throughout the universe,'' as the legal phrase goes. And no one is really that concerned about the actual creators of intellectual property.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: With Defense and Hasek, Sabres Dominate Devils Again
description: Dominik Hasek's goaltending is the biggest reason the Devils want to avoid playing the Sabres in the playoffs. But Buffalo's speed and defense have become huge factors as well. All three elements were in ample supply tonight as the Sabres held on for a 1-0 victory at Continental Arena before a sparse crowd of 6,203, reduced mostly because of the snowstorm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, LOIS TOBY
description: JACOBSON-Lois Toby. Passed away February 20, 2001. Loving mother of Jacob and Benjamin. Devoted sister and daughter. Her spirit and love will always be with us. The Zaro Family

title: Surrendering to Scenery and Snow
description: ''Want to go to the White Mountains?''

title: Art of the Id
description: In Henry Selick's exuberant ''Monkeybone,'' Brendan Fraser (left) plays a comic-book artist whose grotesque images, inspired by nightmares, have given way to cheerful cartoons, thanks to the efforts of a kindly sleep doctor (Bridget Fonda).

title: Top Strategist Is Leaving a Large Hedge Fund
description: After a brief union, Stanley Shopkorn and Stanley F. Druckenmiller, two top hedge fund managers, are splitting up.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MUFSON, JOANNA
description: MUFSON-Joanna. 8/16/69-2/23/83 ''Not wonder, worship, not even peace seemed in my heart to be: only the memory of one, of all most dead to me.'' Love, Mom and Abby

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: COMPTROLLER'S ECONOMIC REPORT

title: Democratic State Senator Switches Parties
description: Raymond J. Zane, the deputy minority leader of the New Jersey Senate, said today that he was leaving the Democratic Party and would run as a Republican when he seeks a ninth term in the Senate in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROCH, JOAN
description: MOROCH-Joan, 71. On February 22nd, 2001 of pancreatic cancer. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted mother of Karen and Henry Altszuler, Michael Moroch and Nancy Barrow, Robin and Ken Zaret. Loving grandmother of David, Amy, Seth, Scott, Dina and Evan. Funeral services Sunday 11AM at Louis Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: $20.01 All Year
description: If you missed restaurant week (Jan. 29 to Feb. 2), take heart. Certain restaurants, including the 12 below, have $20.01 lunch menus all year. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Corrections
description: The Business Day charts of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the Nasdaq composite index and the trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange omitted closing figures on Saturday for Friday's activity. The missing figures are reflected in today's charts, on Page C6.

title: Smithsonian May Lose Washington Portrait
description: The Gilbert Stuart painting of George Washington that has come down through the years as the enduring image everyone recognizes as the first president has been offered for sale to the Smithsonian Institution for $20 million.

title: Effort to Cut Expenditures Costly for bin Laden
description: Several years ago, the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden told his followers in Sudan that he had money problems, and was cutting back on salaries and travel budgets. But Mr. bin Laden was known as a man of great wealth, and one member of his group, L'Houssaine Kherchtou, asked one of his aides for $500 to cover the cost of a Caesarean section for his wife. He was refused.

title: A Plan to Send Prescriptions Electronically
description: Three companies that operate most of the nation's managed care drug plans agreed yesterday to establish a joint system to make it easier for doctors to send prescriptions to pharmacies electronically or over the Internet.

title: KOREAN TELEPHONE PROFIT SURGES
description: The Korea Telecom Corporation, the government-controlled telephone company, reported a net profit for last year of a trillion won ($811 million), up from 383 billion won a year earlier, helped by its Internet and wireless communications units. Sales totaled 10.3 trillion won, a gain of 7.6 percent from the prior year, the company said. That figure included 4.24 trillion won in domestic telephone service and 682 billion won for international services. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: UBS PROFIT IS UP
description: UBS of Switzerland, the world's largest money manager, reported a fourth-quarter net profit that was better than expected but the company failed to attract significant new assets to its wealth management business. The net profit totaled $861.5 million, which included, for the first time, PaineWebber, the brokerage house that it acquired last year. The profit was 8 percent lower than that of the third quarter but up from $670 million a year earlier. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Ming Smith -- 'In the Spirit of Jazz'
description: Tribes Gallery

title: Black and Blue
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Making the White House a Home
description: Among the first bits of the Clintons' decorating to go when the Bushes moved into the White House were the Victorian wallpaper and upholstery in the Lincoln sitting room and the boldly upholstered furniture in the president's office in the residential quarters.

title: Trash Haulers Present Plan for Higher Rates
description: Trash haulers presented a plan yesterday under which waste disposal rates for about 40,000 New York City businesses could increase by 150 percent or more. The proposal drew immediate opposition from the Giuliani administration.

title: Bridgestone Results Hurt by Firestone Recall
description: The Bridgestone Corporation said today that its fiscal year profit tumbled 80 percent as a result of its sweeping recall of Firestone tires in the United States.

title: Florida Panel to Recommend Statewide System for Voters
description: Florida is about to take another step to ensure that it will never endure another post-election period marked by hanging chads, butterfly ballots and debates over voter intent.

title: CHIP MAKERS OUTLINE WIRELESS PLANS
description: Texas Instruments Inc. will invest $100 million over the next 12 to 18 months to develop wireless phone applications that use the company's OMAP software architecture and processing chips. Nokia, Ericsson, Sony and Handspring have selected the company's technology for the new generation of wireless devices known as 3G. The announcement came just a day after Hewlett-Packard set up a separate division to focus on mobile technology.

title: Warner LeRoy, Restaurateur, Dies at 65
description: Warner LeRoy who combined show business glamour with circus ballyhoo to create New York restaurants like Maxwell's Plum, Tavern on the Green and the new Russian Tea Room, died Thursday night at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 65.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about die-hard typewriter users misspelled the name of the White Plains library where one such loyalist, Stewart R. Manville, is curator. It is the Percy Grainger, not Granger.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCH, BENJAMIN (TOMMY)
description: HIRSCH-Benjamin (Tommy). You are in our hearts and mind every day. Happy Birthday. We love you Dad. Audrey, Peter, Gary

title: Alternate Makes Leap To 4-Way Tie for Lead
description: On Tuesday morning, Brent Schwarzrock was about 2,500 miles from the Riviera Country Club and was not expecting to play in the Nissan Open.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDHOFF, ARNOLD J.
description: FRIEDHOFF-Arnold J., 77, died Wednesday. Son of the late Abraham and Stella Beerman Friedhoff. Beloved husband of 55 years to Frances Wolfe Friedhoff. Devoted father of Lawrence T. Friedhoff and his wife Beth, Nancy Friedhoff Walsh and her husband Dan and Richard M. Friedhoff. Loving brother of Hulda Friedhoff Edelstein and her husband Robert. Cherished grandfather of Emily, Jane and Sarah Friedhoff. Uncle of Michael Wolfe, Teri Edelstein and Andrew Blair. Memorial service Sunday, February 25, 4PM at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Family and friends may call from 3-4PM. Memorial contributions may be made to The Stella and Abraham Friedhoff Foundation.

title: 3 SERBS CONVICTED IN WARTIME RAPES
description: In its first trial dealing exclusively with sexual violence, the United Nations war crimes tribunal today found three former Bosnian Serb soldiers guilty of raping and torturing Muslim women and girls. It also convicted two of the three men of enslaving their captives, the first time that an international tribunal has prosecuted and condemned sexual slavery.

title: Pilot Pen Account To Kaplan Thaler
description: The Pilot Pen Corporation of America, part of the Pilot Corporation, said yesterday that it had named the Kaplan Thaler Group in New York, part of the Bcom3 Group, to handle advertising for pen brands that include Dr. Grip and G-2, which had been handled for three years by KGA Advertising in Middletown, Conn. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Prodigal Point Guard Comes Home
description: THEY never should have traded him in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RAFSKY, ROBERT ALAN
description: RAFSKY-Robert Alan. Lovingly remembered today and every day

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about payments to President Bill Clinton's brother-in-law Hugh Rodham for lobbying for a pardon and a prison commutation for two wealthy felons gave a misspelled name in some copies for the home city of G. B. Data Systems, a company owned by one of the felons. It is Marina del Rey, not Del Ray.

title: West Side: The Armory Show on the Piers Just Keeps Growing
description: There is a big, Las Vegas-style gold sign, festooned with light bulbs spelling ''Ye$,'' at a booth occupied by Modern Art, one of the scores of galleries participating in this year's supremely entertaining Armory Show. It may not win first prize, but it would be hard to find a piece that more aptly incarnates the spirit of this year's show than this sly sculpture by the English team of Tim Noble and Sue Webster.

title: IBP TO RESTATE EARNINGS AND TAKE $153 MILLION CHARGE
description: IBP Inc., a meatpacker being acquired by Tyson Foods, said yesterday that it would restate earnings for the last two years after the Securities and Exchange Commission questioned its accounting. IBP will take as much as $153 million in pretax charges for inventory and accounting errors at its DFG Foods unit. It did not give the total after-tax effect on earnings. IBP's stock dropped 14 percent when it revealed the S.E.C. review on Jan. 25, as investors questioned whether the $4.7 billion acquisition would go through. Tyson, the world's largest chicken producer, delayed the transaction four times while waiting for completion of the accounting review. IBP is the largest beef producer and the No. 2 pork producer in the nation.

title: North Korea Questions Test-Ban Accord
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 22  North Korea said today that it did not feel bound to agreements with the United States not to test fire missiles and not to work on producing nuclear warheads. Impatient with Washington's review of the relationship, North Korea cast doubt on an accord reached in 1994 under which it suspended its nuclear program in return for the promise of twin nuclear reactors to fulfill energy needs.

title: Ski Team Has Money, And a Long Way to Go
description: The hulkish Hermann Maier was planted like a silo just beyond the finish line today, casually watching each racer turn the snow into confetti as they sprayed to a stop, looking as if he could stuff most of the competition in the glove compartments of his biceps.

title: Article 2001022393228316957 -- No Title
description: My guidance to them is behave yourself, and they will.

title: Front-Office Skills Move to the Forefront
description: Conventional wisdom for a hockey team on the road is to play conservatively and methodically to take the home fans out of the game. A Buffalo-like snow did that for the Sabres last night before they played the Devils at Continental Arena.

title: Beijing Tries to Woo Olympics And Keep Dissidents in Check
description: Hoping to avert protests that might hurt China's chances of winning the 2008 Olympics, Chinese officials have placed known critics of the government and their families under more surveillance this week and warned them not to speak out while inspectors from the International Olympic Committee are visiting here.

title: Euro RSCG Buys Black Rocket Stake
description: Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York, part of Havas Advertising, said yesterday that it would acquire a majority stake in Black Rocket, an agency in San Francisco known for quirky creative work for advertisers like Yahoo. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Record for Money Flows to Mutual Funds
description: The market might be falling but investors have not given up. January was a record month for mutual fund flows, according to new reports from Lipper Inc. and Strategic Insight, two concerns that track the industry. Net inflows were $140 billion last month, far ahead of the record net inflow of $86.8 billion in January 1999, according to Lipper's report.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: System Is Planned to Send Prescriptions Electronically

title: A Salute to a Racing Legend, Who Had the Guts and the Glory
description: Once, back when Dale Earnhardt was banging fenders on short tracks, back when his sideburns were a little too long and his temper too short, his friends and family could have gathered in one of the little white wood churches so common here to say goodbye to him. But today, after so many victories, so much fame, it took a cathedral to hold all the people who wanted to say how much they will miss Earnhardt, the man stock car racing fans call the Intimidator.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: How Merrily We Roll Along

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLID, MARCELLE
description: DOLID-Marcelle, formerly of Great Neck on February 22 in Haverford, PA. Remembered with love and joy by husband Norman Dick and children Margaret Fichter and Peter and grandchildren Jonathan, Daniel, Anne, and Thomas and sister Charlotte and brother Frank. Gifted teacher and counselor, activist for peace, civil rights and women's equality. Memorial service will be held in Great Neck in the spring.

title: Pardons, Morals and History
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BERGEN BRUNSWIG, Orange, Calif., a drug wholesaler, said that it had agreed to provide $3.5 billion in brand-name drugs over three years to AdvancePCS, Irving, Tex., an online drug-benefits management company.

title: Subway Manners
description: To the Editor:

title: Unable to Find a Suitable Deal, Nets Stick With the Current Lineup
description: By lunchtime yesterday, the calls and the offers, no matter how outlandish, had stopped. Silence meant the status quo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, ROBERT S.
description: GOLUB-Robert S. Devoted husband of Thelma, loving father of Amy and Will, Richard and Caryn, Mark and Harly, and the late Stephen. Proud grandfather of Matthew, Ian, Rachel, Sydney and Brian and dear brother of Judy Singer. Services at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, 12:15PM, Friday, February 23. Donations to Juvenile Diabetes.

title: Mfon Essien -- Photographer, 34
description: Mfon Essien, a Nigerian-born American photographer, died on Feb. 13 in New York. She was 34.

title: Stripped of Hope but Not Her Humanity
description: In Pawel Pawlikowski's ''Last Resort,'' Dina Korzun plays a young Russian woman named Tanya, twice divorced and accompanied by her sullen preadolescent son, Artiom (Artiom Strelnikov), who goes to England in search of a fresh start. She explains to the impassive customs officials at the airport that her fianc will be meeting her shortly, but he seems to have made other plans. And so she and Artiom find themselves in the desolate seaside town of Stonehaven, whose crumbling high-rise hotels and shuttered amusements have been converted into a ''designated holding area'' for illegal immigrants. In desperation, Tanya decides to apply for political asylum.

title: This Time, Clintons Find Their Support Buckling From Weight of New Woes
description: Even the most devoted and vociferous backers of Bill and Hillary Clinton are now refusing to defend their messy exit from the White House and some are openly criticizing their conduct. Many of them said yesterday that the disclosure that Mrs. Clinton's brother Hugh Rodham received nearly $400,000 for helping secure a presidential pardon and a commutation of sentence was the last straw.

title: The Big City; Just Forgive, And Forget The Big Bucks
description: I'M disappointed, too.

title: F.T. Liu, 82; U.N. Official In Peace Roles
description: F. T. Liu, a Chinese-born United Nations official who worked closely with the American Nobel laureate Ralph J. Bunche during the Congo crisis of the 1960's and in many other trouble spots, died on Feb. 16 in his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 82.

title: KNIGHT RIDDER EXPECTS LOWER EARNINGS IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Knight Ridder, the newspaper publisher, said yesterday that it expected its first-quarter earnings to decline because of higher newsprint costs and a slowing advertising market. The company, publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Miami Herald and The San Jose Mercury News, had profit from operations of $68.9 million, or 74 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Knight Ridder is expected to earn 73 cents this quarter, the average of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Other companies, like Dow Jones and Gannett, have also forecast weak ad sales.

title: California's People Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Sub Accident Shakes Japan's Security Ties With U.S.
description: When George W. Bush won the White House, people on both sides of the Pacific predicted that the new administration's plans to give greater emphasis to relations with Japan would usher in an era of closer security ties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, RODMAN BOWNE, JR.
description: MONTGOMERY - Rodman Bowne, Jr., 71, of Manhattan. He is survived by a son, Rodman Bowne Montgomery, III; three daughters, Jennifer Montgomery Voorhees, Phoebe Montgomery Moeller and Justine Montgomery Ix; one sister, Justine Corbin, seven grandchildren and one greatgrandson. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the American Parkinson's Disease Association, 60 Bay Street, Suite 401, Staten Island, NY 10301.

description: An 'Annie,' Bereft, Is Suing

title: Honors
description: Association of Independent Commercial Producers, New York, named national officers for 2001. Alex Blum, partner at Headquarters, Santa Monica, Calif., was re-elected chairman and Alfred Califano, partner at OneSuch Films, New York, was re-elected vice chairman.

title: Mrs. Clinton Says Her Brother's Role Left Her 'Saddened'
description: Forced to confront yet another scandal arising from the Clinton presidency, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tried today to distance herself from the roles her husband and her brother played in a presidential pardon and a prison commutation granted to two wealthy felons.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about workers laid off in the high-technology industry misspelled the surname of a former employee of SpotLife.com. She is Lorraine Chew, not Cheu.

title: Port Authority Approves Budget, Putting Capital Plan in Motion
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved a $4.6 billion budget for 2001, from which it will begin spending on a $14 billion, five-year capital plan that is the largest in the agency's history.

title: Stocks End With a Late Rally
description: Technology stocks rebounded today from another round of heavy selling, as a suggestion of an imminent cut in interest rates gave hope to investors dismayed by the continuing drumbeat of profit warnings.

title: Tinseltown's TVR: Quite a Stunt
description: THE last John Travolta movie to feature an automobile prominently was ''Get Shorty,'' a 1995 film based on Elmore Leonard's best seller. The vehicle in question was an Oldsmobile Silhouette rented by Mr. Travolta's character, Chili Palmer, and humorously tagged ''the Cadillac of minivans.'' It wasn't enough to save Olds. Come June, filmgoers will have a chance to see Mr. Travolta and his co-star, Hugh Jackman, at the wheel of something more sporting, a TVR Tuscan, in ''Swordfish,'' a counterespionage action thriller. As you might imagine, that car's makers are hoping for a better long-term result.

description: Turkish Currency Plunges

description: To the Editor:

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Clinton's Brother Pursued Clemency Bids for Friends
description: The furor over President Bill Clinton's pardons intensified today as Congressional investigators focused on Roger Clinton and his efforts to win pardons for friends and associates from his half brother.

title: Leenane III, Bones Flying
description: Excuse me, but is that a piece of tibia that's just landed in my lap?

title: It's Time for Let's Make a Deal in the N.B.A.
description: He began his pro career making dazzling passes in the arena of his childhood dreams, wowing the Madison Square Garden crowd with feeds that often defied description. Eventually, Mark Jackson's flashy-to-a-fault play and defensive liabilities turned the hometown fans against him, and he was jettisoned from New York and became a Knicks antagonist.

title: Article 2001022391168484982 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: A Rider of the Storm Who Viewed It All With Curiosity, Passion and Panache
description: Throughout the memorial exhibition of work by Oskar Kokoschka at the Marlborough Gallery, we are reminded that in everything he did, Kokoschka gave his whole self, without evasion and without stint. The alphabet of his life was laid out from A to Z in his work, just as it was in his memorably anecdotal conversation. When he died at 93 in 1980, it was as an undefeated ancient, with his panache intact.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Politics and Families, Mixed: Presidential Relatives and Headaches They Caused
description: The list of relatives involved in presidential embarrassments could fill a tome in a presidential library. Following are some who became embroiled in full-fledged scandals and investigations:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, HELEN R.
description: KAUFMAN-Helen R. On February 21, 2001 at age 84. Beloved wife of the late Judge Irving R. Kaufman. Loving mother of James M. and the late Robert H. and Richard K. Kaufman. Also survived by grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Services at Park Avenue Synagogue, Madison Ave. at 87 St., Friday, February 23rd, 11:30 AM. Interment Mt. Pleasant Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Robert H. Kaufman Scholarship Fund established at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine.

title: Prime Time Without The Prime
description: ONE of the most bewildering aspects of the floundering XFL is its presence on NBC's prime-time schedule on Saturday nights.

title: Hartford Worst in National Study Of Births to Unmarried Mothers
description: The statistics tell the damning story of this city: nearly 80 percent of all babies born in 1998 had single mothers, double the national average and 10 times the state average. A quarter of all births were to teenage mothers, and a quarter of those teenagers had given birth before.

title: East Side: The Art Show in the Armory Explores Recent History
description: It's always possible to overdose on the galleries in and around Manhattan, but this weekend the art medics should be on special alert. New York's two premier fairs of modern and contemporary art are in joint session, coinciding as they have for the last eight Februarys. Call them big and bigger.

title: Technology Briefing
description: DEALS SIEMENS BUYING MODEM MAKER Siemens A.G., the big German electronics concern, strengthened its position in the high- speed Internet business in the United States with its agreement yesterday to acquire Efficient Networks , a large maker of modems for fast Internet connections, for $1.5 billion in cash. Siemens will pay $23.50 a share for Efficient, which is based in Dallas, or 90 percent more than its closing price on Wednesday. The deal led investors to bid up Efficient's stock yesterday, with the share price climbing $10.69, to $23.06. The acquisition is part of the Siemens strategy of expanding in the United States ahead of its planned share offering next month on the New York Stock Exchange. Mark Floyd, above, Efficient's chairman, said, "The combination with Siemens, with representation in over 160 countries, will allow us to further accelerate growth of our combined broadband business." Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Article 2001022391361638772 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Isles, Ignoring Their Standing, Rally to Upend the Flyers
description: They are at opposite ends of the Atlantic Division -- the leading Flyers, the last-place Islanders. Four previous meetings this season netted Philadelphia four victories.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The euro fell in part after Turkey abandoned its defense of the lira, raising speculation lenders will suffer losses on loans to Turkish banks. In New York, the euro settled at 90.57 cents, down from 90.82 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, DANIEL L., M.D.
description: HARTMAN-Daniel L., M.D. Died February 21st, 2001 at his home in Southampton, NY at age 86 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Joyce, devoted father of Gail and Alison, loving father-in-law of Peter Clark, cherished grandfather of Emily, Alex, Jake and Adam. Private memorial services to be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 2247, New York, New York 10116-2247.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAYMAN, CHAYA
description: NAYMAN-Chaya. We have lost a true Eishes Chayil of the generation who suffered the tremendous travails and sacrifices of all time. It is with deep sadness that we extend our sincerest condolences to Fayge Schwartz on the passing of her beloved mother. As a Silver Founder of the Medical Center, and as a devoted Vice President of the National Women's Division, Fayge, together with her husband Morton, personify the highest standards of tzedakah and chesed, which was passed on to them by this very special woman. May Fayge, Rabbi Jacob Nayman and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr. Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres. Sidney Adler, Treas. Lee Weinbach, Pres., Nat'l Women's Div. Michael S. Strauss, Chrmn. NY Bd.

title: Judge Approves Auction House Settlement
description: A federal judge gave final approval yesterday to a $512 million settlement of the lawsuit against the Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses by customers who said they were cheated in a price-fixing conspiracy that lasted several years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHANCER, LOLA J.
description: SCHANCER-Lola J. Died February 19th in Nashua, NH. Born in Brooklyn on October 12, 1926. She was married 34 years to Myron Schancer, who died in 1983. Family members include two sons, Douglas Schancer of Derry, NH and his wife Kathy; and Gary Schancer of Albuquerque, NM and his wife Kathy; three grandchildren; a sister; and nieces and nephews.

title: Art Fairs in Joint Session
description: Two big art fairs are in town this weekend. The 13th Art Show, with 70 American dealers, is at the Seventh Regiment Armory. The peripatetic Armory Show, with 170 dealers, domestic and foreign, is on Hudson River Piers 88 and 90, where Roni Horn's ''Fox'' (right) is one of the works.

title: In Galleries
description: Jorg Immendorff

title: A Comic-Book Artist's Descent Into Unconsciousness, as Freud Might Tell It
description: To declare Henry Selick's ''Monkeybone'' the best comedy of 2001 would be to smear it with the faintest of praise. Not only is the year a scant eight weeks old, but the movie's main competition also consists of ''Head Over Heels'' and ''Saving Silverman.'' To say that ''Monkeybone'' is funnier, smarter and more original than those pictures is like saying it's more pleasant than a kick in the groin followed by a trip to the dentist. Better to say that it's a welcome antidote to the epidemic of witless, frenetic, secondhand low comedies that gnaw at our brains like antibody-resistant spirochetes.

title: Apartheid Memories Find Their Audience
description: IT is pitch-black backstage at Playhouse 91, the cocoonish Upper East Side theater where the South African actress Pamela C. Gien nightly makes like a medium and channels the 28-character cast of her one-woman show, ''The Syringa Tree,'' through her frail frame before an increasingly appalled, but enthralled, audience.

title: Mind Games In a Sequel
description: Altogether it was a thankless task for a director. Sequels usually are relatively straightforward affairs, but how does one go about following ''The Blair Witch Project,'' the $150 million box office phenomenon that packed theaters in 1999?

title: Siblings Who Often Emerge In an Unflattering Spotlight
description: To Hillary Clinton's White House staff, they were known wryly as ''the Brothers Rodham'': Hughie and Tony, the first lady's bearish younger siblings, the president's occasional golfing partners, frequent visitors for family celebrations and holidays.

title: Minor Leak at Indian Point 2 Fixed but Full Power Delayed
description: A minor, nonradioactive leak at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant has been repaired, but the plant will not resume full power for at least another day while technicians complete what officials describe as unrelated preventive maintenance.

title: To Build a New Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Tinseltown's TVR: Quite a Stunt
description: The last John Travolta movie to feature an automobile prominently was "Get Shorty," a 1995 film based on Elmore Leonard's best seller. The vehicle in question was an Oldsmobile Silhouette rented by Mr. Travolta's character, Chili Palmer, and humorously tagged "the Cadillac of minivans." It wasn't enough to save Olds.

title: Daughters of Frazier and Ali Engage in a Role Reversal
description: They are the grown-up middleweight daughters of heavyweight champions, but in this match of the offspring of Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier, Laila Ali is the reserved voice, Jacqui Frazier-Lyde the motormouth.

title: METROSTARS TRADE FOR GOALIE
description: The MetroStars traded the rights of the free-agent defender Ramiro Corrales to San Jose yesterday for Paul Grafer, a goalkeeper who was selected earlier yesterday by San Jose in a special draft that was held because he had signed with Major League Soccer after the league's SuperDraft on Feb. 5.

title: Doing the Right Thing, in Kosovo's Heartland
description: The seven brothers of the Geci family were always at the forefront of the war against Serbia, and their home lies in the hilly central heartland of the Kosovo Albanians' fight for independence. Last weekend, they took a courageous step of a different kind, gathering the people of their village to denounce the bomb attack that killed at least 11 Serbian civilians last Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARP, ELI
description: CARP-Eli. Died on February 2. Cherished husband of Rea Carp. Beloved father of the late Jeffrey Carp. Loving brother of Selma Kaufman and husband Herbert Kaufman and sister-in-law Lee Margolin and beloved uncle of all his nieces, nephews, and cousins. You will be in our memory always.

title: Witnesses Called by Defense Say Rap Star Was Unarmed
description: Defense lawyers for the hip-hop mogul Sean Combs began presenting their case yesterday, calling witnesses who testified that Mr. Combs danced on a coffee table, arms aloft, in a packed Manhattan nightclub before a shooting occurred there, with no gun or bulge from a weapon visible in his waistband.

title: Michigan State Keeps Hold on the Top Spot
description: Michigan State split its games last weekend against top 15 teams, Western Michigan and the University of Michigan, but the Spartans retained the top spot in the national polls.

title: COVAD TO ACQUIRE FLASHCOM CUSTOMERS
description: The Internet service wholesaler Covad Communications Group agreed to buy about 24,500 customers from Flashcom Inc. in exchange for as much as $3.5 million in cash and debt forgiveness. Covad will exchange $750,000 in cash and debt forgiveness initially and as much as $2.75 million more depending on how many Internet users agree to be transferred. The offer was approved by a United States Bankruptcy Court in Santa Ana, Calif., where the closely held Flashcom filed for protection in December.

title: French Arrest a Basque Hours After Bombing
description: The French judicial police arrested a man on Wednesday who was described as the top military leader of the Basque separatist group E.T.A. The arrest was made six hours after a car bomb attributed to E.T.A. killed two workers in San Sebastin, Spain.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: INSIDE ART
description: A '71 Serra For the Capital

title: Album of the Week
description: JIM WHITE: -- ''No Such Place'' (Luaka Bop). Jim White's second album starts out with him handcuffed to a fence in Mississippi and ends with him contemplating a defunct Corvair full of birds. In between there are romances, breakups, murders, prayers and more than one breakdown on a lonesome highway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, FRANKLIN
description: JACOBY-Franklin, age 94, in Bridgeport, CT on February 21, 2001, formerly of Flushing and Floral Park, NY. Beloved father of Milton Jacoby of Fairfield, CT and Fran Lucio of New Rochelle, NY. Cherished grandfather of James, Janet, Jason and the late Joan Jacoby. Services Friday 12:30PM from Green Funeral Home, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT. Interment following at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. Donations may be made to the Joan Jacoby Fund or to a charity of your choice.

title: Sheffield Deal Still Just Talk
description: Despite additional trade talks between the teams, the Mets and the Los Angeles Dodgers have made little progress on a Gary Sheffield deal, baseball officials said today.

title: BUSH FAULTS CHINA ON ITS AID TO IRAQ FOR RADAR SYSTEM
description: President Bush said today that evidence of China's aid to Iraq in building radar systems to use against American and British warplanes had ''risen to the level where we are going to send a message to the Chinese,'' a statement that put Mr. Bush at odds with Beijing only four weeks into his presidency.

title: Rookie Starts For Rangers
description: The Rangers beat the snowstorm yesterday and made it to Pittsburgh, where they may or may not face Mario Lemieux for the first time since his comeback began.

title: Memories Chiseled in a Cathedral's Stone
description: Twenty-two years ago, the idea rang out like a clarion.

title: Larry Poons
description: Salander-O'Reilly

title: A New Tack: If the Bus Isn't on Time, It's on Boston
description: The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority has begun offering a guarantee usually reserved for pizza delivery or overnight packages: It's on time, or it's on them.

title: An Essential For Gardens: The Bench
description: On Sunday an old park bench took center stage in the television adaptation of ''Anna Karenina'' on PBS. It was on that bench that Vronsky and Anna declared their passion for each other. ''Gardens are places for looking, for contemplation, for reading, for reflection, for dreaming, for chatting, for philosophizing, for embracing -- but could we do any of these things satisfactorily without that indispensable item of garden furniture, the bench or seat?'' So asks Louis Benech in the introduction to ''Garden Seats and Benches,'' a book of precise drawings of fine antique European examples by Andrew Zega and Bernd H. Dams (Alain de Gourcuff diteur, 2000).

title: The Neediest Cases; Helping an Autistic Child Learn About the World by Playing With Dolls
description: As she plays with a dollhouse, Roza Reznikova, 5 1/2, takes a tiny pink hand-held mirror and places it in front of each member of a doll family: baby, child, mother and father. This way, each doll can see its face.

title: An Insensitive Play

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, T. EMMETT JR.
description: MURPHY-T. Emmett Jr. On February 16, 2001. Documentary, film and art writer. Author of Academy Award-winning film, ''Project Hope,'' and art book, ''Great Bordellos of the World.'' Yale graduate. Survived by daughters, Keven Murphy and Aidan Wilson; sister, Roslyn Kinne; brothers, Brian and Stephen, and four grandchildren. Services will be held February 24, 2001, at 1 PM, at 72 Tryon St., South Glastonbury, Connecticut, 860-633-7935.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIU, F.T.
description: LIU-F.T. Died peacefully at home on Friday, February 16, 2001. Beloved husband and father, he is survived by his wife Joan, his son Michael and wife Karen, and grandson John Michael, and his daughter Margaret Liu McConnell and husband Scott, and grandchildren Neil, Kristen and Anna. Services will be held at Christ Church, 17 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, New York at 2 PM on Saturday, February 24th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Children and Armed Conflict, United Nations, Room S-3161, New York, New York 10017.

title: Emily Vermeule, 72, a Scholar Of Bronze Age Archaeology
description: Emily Vermeule, an emeritus professor of classical philology and archaeology at Harvard University who started her career with the discovery of an ancient Mycenaean tomb and went on to conduct excavations in Greece, Turkey, Libya and Cyprus, died on Feb. 6 at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 72.

title: Jason Robards Memorial
description: A tribute to Jason Robards, who died on Dec. 26 at age 78, will be held at noon on Monday at the Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 44th Street.

title: Experts Back Privatizing Flight Control
description: Eight former top-ranking aviation and transportation officials, including three former administrators of the Federal Aviation Administration, said in a letter released today that the agency would never be able to cope with growing air traffic control problems and that the federal government should give the job to an independent nonprofit corporation.

title: Residential Real Estate; Work Finally Starts at 14th Street Armory Site
description: After nearly three years and changes in both the intended uses and the development team, construction is under way to turn the empty site of the 14th Street Armory into a mixed-use complex.

title: The Daimler Puzzle:Is Mitsubishi the Key?
description: FRANKFURT  As DaimlerChrysler prepared to approve Friday a sweeping overhaul of its complicated empire, suspicions grew that Germany's biggest industrial company had not fully learned from the mistakes of its trans-Atlantic takeover.

title: Europe Comes Calling
description: President Bush's expected meeting today with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain will be his first with a European leader since taking office. Though Mr. Bush has placed a healthy new emphasis on Western Hemisphere issues during his initial days as president, American military and economic security still depend heavily on the nation's enduring ties to Europe. Mr. Bush's presidency will be measured in part by whether he is able to maintain harmonious relations with Europe as America's allies seek a more independent role on security issues and try to encourage the consolidation of democracy and free markets in Russia. Mr. Blair, as the leader of Washington's most dependable ally, can play a critical role in resolving differences that may develop. He is currently favored to win re-election in a vote expected to take place in May.

title: Jones Expects an Easy Night
description: Roy Jones Jr. stepped in front of Derrick Harmon on the stage for today's weigh-in, glared at the members of Harmon's entourage who were heckling him, lifted his arms to flex his biceps and yelled, ''I'm still the best ever!'' Jones offered a scowl and then backed away, saving the rest of his energy for Saturday night's fight against Harmon at the Ice Palace.

title: National News Briefs
description: Jeb Bush Weeps, Saying Black Aides Are Scorned

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: To Receive Final Paycheck, Workers Cede Right to Sue

title: A Small Border War Turns, but Is Not Yet Won
description: A year ago, this small town on the border with Mexico was in chaos.

title: Screwdriver Scholars And Pencil Punditry
description: After decades of languishing in obscurity, the zipper finally got its lucky break in 1921. That year, an engineer at the B. F. Goodrich Rubber Company in Akron, Ohio, decided to attach the metal contraption to a pair of rubber galoshes. The result was the popular Goodrich Zipper Boot, and its so-called hookless fastener went on to trounce the button and the snap.

title: Most Colleges Are Expected To Continue to Use the SAT
description: As the University of California weighs a recommendation by its president to drop the SAT's as an admissions requirement, the vast majority of the nation's highly selective institutions, as well as other large public universities, are expected to rely on the tests for the foreseeable future.

title: For Parents, One Size Doesn't Fit All in Bilingual Education
description: Yuliya Kovardinskaya remembers being thrown into an 11th-grade classroom when she arrived from Ukraine 10 years ago and not understanding much of what she was taught. In this sink-or-swim environment, she swam. By 12th grade, she had moved from an English as a second language program, or E.S.L., to a regular classroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTONE, HARMON
description: GOLDSTONE - Harmon. We mourn the passing of Founding Trustee Harmon Goldstone and express our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Gomez Foundation for Mill House

title: Article 2001022492423227766 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Physicists Thrill to Finding of Superconductor
description: A readily available metallic compound has unexpectedly turned into the latest breakthrough superconductor.

title: Five Queries Can Forestall Those Ill-Advised Overcalls
description: A player who is considering an overcall must ask five questions. Is it likely to lead to a successful contract? Is it likely to lead to a desirable save against an opposing contract? Is it relatively safe at that level and vulnerability? Is it likely to create problems for the opponents? And is it likely to help partner find a good opening lead?

title: Corrections
description: Apicture of a North Korean hospital operating room on Tuesday, with an article about the collapse of the country's health care system, carried an erroneous credit. The photo was by Janet Durrans, not from Agence France-Presse.

title: LLOYDS SET BACK IN ABBEY BID
description: Britain's secretary of state for trade and industry, Stephen Byers, asked the country's antitrust regulators to investigate whether Lloyds TSB Group's proposed takeover of Abbey National would impede competition. The referral voids Lloyds most recent offer, which is valued at 17.5 billion ($25.3 billion) at current prices, and was conditional on clearance. The referral also prevents the bank from making another bid until regulators present their ruling no later than June 12. The decision paves the way for Abbey National to move forward with its preferred merger partner, the Bank of Scotland. Suzanne Kapner

title: Kozmo.com to Lay Off 60 And Focus on Offline Sales
description: The online delivery service Kozmo.com announced yesterday that it would lay off about 60 employees at its corporate headquarters in Manhattan to cut costs, and it said it would begin doing more business that does not involve the Internet.

title: Interest Groups Are Gearing Up For High-Stakes Tax Cut Fight
description: Calling President Bush's effort to pass his tax cut the defining early battle of his presidency, a broad swath of interest groups and business lobbyists are mounting full-scale national campaigns, including grass-roots organizing and television advertisements, for or against the $1.6 trillion, 10-year measure.

title: Motorola Says It May Post Quarterly Loss, First in 15 Years
description: Its shares already battered by a yearlong profit slide, Motorola Inc. said today that weakening demand for its products could result in the company's first quarterly loss in 15 years.

title: Gill Hopes to Return This Season
description: Kendall Gill, who was at the Nets' practice facility in East Rutherford, N.J., yesterday to begin rehabilitation from knee surgery, said he was hoping to return by the end of March. Gill had surgery Feb. 6 to remove a small piece of his right kneecap that was sticking into an inflamed tendon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARCELLA (NEE USDIN)
description: COHEN-Marcella (nee Usdin). Of Providence, RI, on February 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Mother of Sanford and Barbara. Grandmother of Hillary and William.

title: BAIN CAPITAL BUYS STAKE IN HUNTSMAN, CHEMICAL COMPANY
description: The Huntsman Corporation, a leading chemical company, said yesterday that Bain Capital Inc., the buyout firm that owns Domino's Pizza and Sealy Mattress, agreed to buy a $600 million stake in the closely held business. Huntsman said it would use part of the money to buy out Imperial Chemical Industries' 30 percent share of Huntsman. Huntsman, which is based in Salt Lake City, makes plastics, footwear, paints, coatings and construction materials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, JOHN B. III.
description: HAYES-John B. III. On February 22, 2001. All of us at Chapdelaine & Co. are saddened by the sudden death of Jack, our longtime friend and associate. Our sincere sympathies to his wife, Susan, and his children, John, Andrew and Caitlin.

title: Letter Writer Tripped Up by Unusual Security for Borough President
description: Four days after police officials acknowledged that a man was wrongly charged with a crime for writing a critical letter to the Staten Island borough president, police and city officials would not say how the letter got into the hands of the detectives who made the arrest, or who among their superiors authorized the man's arrest.

title: New Twists in the Pardon Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: A Life Beyond Being A President's Sibling
description: For Roger Clinton, Politics is not just his brother and sister-in-law's business: it is also the name of his band.

description: CAIRO, Feb. 24  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here today on the first leg of his first overseas trip as the United States' chief diplomat and immediately plunged into talks with the Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, on the two sides' widely differing plans for missile defenses.

title: Article 2001022490967944180 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Religious Sect Gains Victory In Moscow Trial
description: The Jehovah's Witnesses won a potentially far-reaching victory today in a Moscow court over prosecutors who had sought to ban the group under a 1997 law that prohibited religious sects that incite hatred or intolerance.

title: Beliefs; A 19th-century theologian whose questions remain pertinent to the Roman Catholic Church.
description: It went relatively unnoticed that Wednesday, the day Pope John Paul II created 44 new cardinals in the Roman Catholic Church, was also the 200th anniversary of the birth of a man many consider the greatest cardinal of modern times.

title: Jackson's a Hit, But Debut Lacks A Happy Ending
description: When Mark Jackson, the vintage point guard who had been booed out of New York nine years earlier, returned to Madison Square Garden as a Knick last night, he received a boisterous standing ovation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, HELAINE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Helaine. Supermom, wife, sister, daughter and, most of all, my Best Friend Forever. You'll be in my heart always. Patti

title: Love's Dominance Continues
description: Davis Love III has played so well recently that he has been reluctant to take time off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEROY, WARNER
description: LeROY-Warner. On February 22, 2001 at age 65. Entrepreneur, designer and noble friend. Beloved father of Bridget, Carolyn, Max and Jennifer. Cherished brother of Linda Janklow, Brian and Quentin Vidor. Devoted Grandpa to Georgia, Joelie and Bing. You will always be a star! Services Monday, February 26th at 10:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017, or New York Presbyterian Hospital, Department of Medicine, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Medicare Drug Costs Are Projected to Soar
description: The Congressional Budget Office has sharply increased its estimates of spending on prescription drugs for the elderly, a revision that will make it more difficult for Congress to pay for drug benefits under Medicare.

title: Colombian to Ask Bush for Trade Help
description: When President Andrs Pastrana travels to Washington this weekend for his first meeting with President Bush, he will ask for trade preferences to spur his country's economic growth, rather than pressing ahead with earlier plans to request $600 million a year in new aid.

title: Radiologist's Medical License Is Restored
description: New York State has restored the medical license of a radiologist whom the state health commissioner suspended from practicing medicine last June. This is the second time in a month that the state has overturned an emergency suspension of a license by the commissioner, Dr. Antonia C. Novello.

title: New Twists in the Pardon Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Friend Urged Pardon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, FRANCIS J., REV.
description: COLLINS-Francis J., Rev. CSsR. Suddenly on February 21, 2001. Beloved son of the late Margaret and Michael. Dear brother of Mary, Ann Ainley, Thomas, Sister Teresa Collins CSJ, Rita Lally and the Rev. Raymond Collins CSsR. Devoted uncle of nine nieces and nephews. Reposing M.V. Cosgrove & Son Chapels, 5723 Fifth Ave, Brooklyn until Sunday 6PM. Transferral to the Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help at 7PM. Wake service 8PM, Mass of the Resurrection 11AM Mon., OLPH. Interment St Alphonsus Cemetery, Esopus, NY. Donations to OLPH Elementary School or St Peter's Elementary, Philadelphia, Pa.

title: ROYAL BANK'S PROFIT IS UP
description: Canada's largest bank, Royal Bank of Canada, reported a 13 percent profit rise to 584 million Canadian dollars ($380 million) for the first quarter of its financial year, ending Oct. 31. Share profit of 91 Canadian cents, although a record, was a cent below analysts' forecasts. The bank said 70 million Canadian dollars had been added to the allowance for credit losses, up 40 percent from the previous quarter. Timothy Pritchard

title: Devils Unable To Beat Injuries Or Hurricanes
description: Devils Coach Larry Robinson bit hard on his words until he finally thought it best to say no more. Killing time until their injured players return is difficult enough these days for the Devils. Killing penalty after penalty made it impossible tonight for them to have a good chance to win.

title: MILITARY IN CURB ON CIVILIAN VISITS
description: The Pentagon struggled on two fronts today to counter mounting criticism of the accidental sinking of a Japanese fishing vessel by the American nuclear submarine Greeneville, as Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld ordered a temporary ban on civilians sitting at the controls of any military equipment and the Navy announced the dispatch of a senior admiral to Japan.

title: One Last Lap Around the Speedway
description: The Intimidator'' they called him, a man who could freeze the heart of any man who looked in the mirror to see the black Number 3 Chevy threatening to run up his tailpipe. Dale Earnhardt won seven championships and $41 million on the Nascar racing circuit to become, arguably, the greatest stock-car driver there ever was.

title: BUSH TELLS BLAIR HE DOESN'T OPPOSE NEW EUROPE FORCE
description: President Bush today endorsed a European rapid-reaction force, telling Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain that the United States had no objections to a separate military arm to help keep peace in Europe as long as that force was clearly secondary to NATO.

title: Good Guys vs. Bad Guys, With Earnest Orations
description: If the economy really is headed downward, as so many people say, Mary Stuart Masterson's new drama series, ''Kate Brasher,'' is ahead of the curve. From the looks of the first episode (tonight on CBS), the show is all about hard times.

title: Robert Weiskopf, 86, TV Comedy Writer
description: Robert Weiskopf, who wrote scripts for ''I Love Lucy,'' ''Maude,'' ''All in the Family'' and several other hit television comedies, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 86.

title: Rejection of Son's Eulogy Renews Dilemma of Mass
description: Joseph F. Lane Jr. was upset when a parish priest in Long Beach told him he could not give a eulogy at his father's funeral Mass this month in the church where his father grew up and served as an altar boy.

title: 57 Hurt in Chain-Reaction Pileup in Lincoln Tunnel During the Morning Rush Hour
description: Fifty-seven people were hurt inside the Lincoln Tunnel and rush-hour traffic was snarled this morning, after a chain reaction of collisions involving a commuter van and two New Jersey Transit buses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVOY, QUEEN MARIA JOSE
description: SAVOY-Queen Maria Jose of Italy. A Solemn Requiem Mass in memory of Italy's last Queen will be held Monday, February 26th, at 6:30 PM at the Church of Our Saviour, 38th St. and Park Ave., NYC.

title: Prague Journal; Stalin's Ghost Haunts a Czech Park
description: Marie Vikova, huddling with her daughter and her dog against a biting wind under the massive plinth where one of the world's largest statues of Stalin used to stand, pondered the city's latest idea for what to do with this echoing, haunted place: an aquarium, for tourists.

title: U.S. and Russians Meet on Defenses Against Missiles
description: CAIRO, Feb. 24  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here today on the first leg of his first overseas trip as the United States' chief diplomat and immediately plunged into talks with the Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, on the two sides' widely differing plans for missile defenses.

title: Hollywood Friend Had Clinton's Ear for 2 Late Pardons
description: Harry Thomason, a Hollywood producer and longtime friend of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, spoke privately with the president urging pardons for two Arkansas men convicted of tax evasion charges, a lawyer for Mr. Thomason said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, CAROLINE
description: GORDON-Caroline. On Feb. 22, 2001 in her 94th year. Beloved wife of the late Roy Gordon. Loving mother of Dr. Wayne Gordon and his wife Margaret Brown. Cherished grandmother of Hannah Brown Gordon. Star teacher of the New York City schools. Services Sunday, February 25, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: LIBERTY GAINS IN EUROPEAN CABLE
description: The Liberty Media Corporation increased its position in the European cable market through two separate transactions. In partnership with Klesch & Company, a private equity firm in London, Liberty Media, led by its chairman, John C. Malone, above, agreed to buy 55 percent of six cable television operators from Deutsche Telekom A.G. Deutsche Telekom is selling assets to appease European regulators and to pay down debt. Additionally, Liberty Media agreed to pay $1.4 billion to increase its stake to 30 percent in UnitedGlobalCom. Suzanne Kapner

title: Corrections
description: A picture of a North Korean hospital operating room on Tuesday, with an article about the collapse of the country's health care system, carried an erroneous credit. The photo was by Janet Durrans, not from Agence France-Presse.

title: CHAPTERS INC. WITHDRAWS OFFER FOR ITS ONLINE UNIT
description: Chapters Inc. said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer for shares in its online sales unit because bankers would not approve the debt-financed transaction by the bid's deadline yesterday. Chapters Online stock plunged 1.06 Canadian dollars (69 cents), or 41 percent, to 1.50 Canadian dollars in Toronto, its largest one-day percentage drop. Chapters shares were unchanged at 9.30 Canadian dollars. The move could spell the end of Chapters Online, one of Canada's biggest online retailers. Chapters Online threatened yesterday to go to court to force its parent to honor the bid of 3.40 dollars a share for the 30 percent of Chapters Online stock that Chapters does not already own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, ALICE ELIZABETH
description: MURPHY-Alice Elizabeth, a dance artist of the Vaudeville Stage, age 90 of Brigantine, NJ. Member of the dance troupe known as ''The Murphy Sisters''. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, February 26, 2001, 9am in the Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church, California and Atlantic Avenues, Atlantic City, NJ. Friends may call for viewing Sunday evening from 7 to 9 PM and Monday morning from 8 to 8:45 AM at the Funeral Home. Burial will be in Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NYC at approximately 1:30 PM. For information, call H.M. Gormley Funeral Home, Albany Avenue, Atlantic City at 609-344-3188.

title: Bronx Leaders Denounce Fliers Calling Dominicans Drug Sellers
description: Community leaders in the Bronx voiced concern yesterday about a flier that says that Dominicans are drug dealers and that livery cab drivers in the Bronx prey on young girls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAF, HAROLD
description: LEAF-Harold. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Harold Leaf. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Adele, and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Rose Schecter, President

title: New Twists in the Pardon Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: On Eve of a Visit by Powell, Rising Unrest in the Mideast
description: On the eve of Colin L. Powell's first visit to the region as secretary of state, officials in Israel today rebuffed his pleas for an easing of the blockade of Palestinian territories, while Palestinian militants burned him in effigy.

title: For Ex-Student Protester, a Pardon Without the Spotlight
description: AND then there was the pardon President Bill Clinton granted Howard L. Mechanic, whose return to good standing has, so far, been altogether routine, uncomplicated and anything but controversial.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: From Blocks of Cedar, Artifacts Worth Gold; Hunting Decoys Outlived Their Usefulness to Become Collectors' Items
description: At first the wooden decoys were simply a means to an end primitive carvings just convincing enough to lure Long Island's ducks and shorebirds into the sights of hunters. Over the years, though, the outdoorsmen who fashioned them from blocks of cedar and cork grew more sophisticated, learning to evoke the anatomy of the birds they carved and growing more adept at applying oil-paint plumage.

title: Police Seek Robber-Rapist In Upper West Side Attacks
description: A man who robbed two women and raped one of them Tuesday night on the Upper West Side may be responsible for six other robberies in the neighborhood in the last two months, the police said yesterday.

title: For Voters, A Lesson In Limits
description: POOR New Yorkers. How many unwanted civics lessons must they endure?

title: Britain Moves to Curtail Spread of Foot-and-Mouth Disease
description: Britain today imposed a seven-day ban on transporting livestock in an attempt to stem an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease that has led to a suspension of meat exports and an appeal to Britons to steer well clear of the countryside.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil prices rose amid a strong rebound in refined products caused by rising gasoline prices on the Gulf Coast. In New York, crude oil for April delivery rose 22 cents, to $29.04 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, DOROTHY M.
description: LEAHY-Dorothy M., 83, of West Palm Beach, Fla., passed away February 4, 2001. She was an interior decorator who graduated from Pratt University in Brooklyn, NY. She attended Bethesda by the Sea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach, Fla. Graveside services will be held Tuesday, February 27, 1 PM, at Hillcrest Memorial Park, West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Boldly Out of the West, Bent on Courting Youth
description: At a time when America's major orchestras are struggling to define their missions and maintain audiences, the San Francisco Symphony under Michael Tilson Thomas is an exception. Concertgoers there are younger and have embraced Mr. Thomas's adventurous programming. The orchestra is considered an artistic beacon not a cultural relic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLLMAN, DR. ABRAHAM A.
description: OLLMAN-Dr. Abraham A., 84, on February 22nd. He is survived by his son Robert, daughter-in-law Joanne, and granddaughters Jennifer and Leigh. His wife Beatrice and daughter Carolyn predeceased him. A loving father and grandfather. Captain in the U.S. Army. A dedicated dentist. ''Doc'' will be missed by all. Graveside services will be held Sunday, February 25th, 11 AM, at the Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. For further info, contact the I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 800-624-8282

title: New Twists in the Pardon Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixing Business and Family In Hong Kong Commerce
description: Richard Li may no longer have a hot hand in the fickle world of Hong Kong commerce. But he still holds one ace: a 72-year-old father who is extremely rich and unflaggingly loyal.

title: Lessons From a New Raleigh Hall
description: By seeing to its own needs, this city has built a symphonic hall whose scale and grace have universal applications. Meymandi Concert Hall opened on Wednesday night. Its shoe box design (the walls slightly asymmetric for acoustical purposes) and its modest capacity (1,700 seats, 1,550 if singers occupy the gallery behind the stage) reconfigure the intersection of public place and intimate exchange that was largely lost in the wave of gigantism that swept theater building a century ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELIG, KENNETH C.
description: SEELIG-Kenneth C. Cherished husband of Joyce. Adored and devoted father of Anne and Lisa. Loving son of Phyllis and Michael. Beloved brother of Patricia. Passed away suddenly on Friday, February 23, 2001. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', Hewlett, Long Island, 12 noon Sunday.

title: California Plans to Buy Utility's Wires
description: The state of California took another small step toward resolving its electricity problems yesterday, announcing that it had agreed to buy the transmission system of Southern California Edison, the state's second-largest utility, for $2.76 billion.

title: Sports of The Times; For Jackson, Dj Vu Of Sorts
description: WHEN Mark Jackson returned to the Knicks' lineup early in the second period last night, after a hiatus of 677 regular-season games since he was traded away in 1992, the sellout crowd of nearly 20,000 in Madison Square Garden stood and applauded.

title: A Jewish Canon, Yes, But Not Set in Stone
description: What did the Israelites hear at Mount Sinai? According to one rabbinic commentator, they were so overwhelmed by the divine voice that they could hear only the first two of the Ten Commandments. Another said they couldn't withstand even that much. All they could hear was the first letter of the First Commandment: the aleph.

title: Editorial Notebook; Green Winter in the Sonoran Desert
description: The Sonoran Desert is greener now than it has been in years. A winter like this can almost erase the impression created in other seasons, when the desert looks like a garden of striking specimens set out on a dull, barren plain. Autumn and winter rains have given the desert floor a presence it usually lacks. It is no longer the indiscernible gap, the thing that is deserted, between saguaros and ocotillos and chollas, but a level green abundance of its own, flecked with blossom. All its life is now becoming explicit.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a potential witness in the trial of the rap star Sean Combs misstated the given name of a felon and fugitive who is a potential witness for the prosecution. He is Matthew Allen, not Michael.

title: Eviction, Debt and Grief Test Slain Restaurateur's Kin
description: It has been nearly six months since her husband went to deliver two bags of Chinese food and never came back. His broken body was found later, pounded senselessly with fists and a brick on a street near the family's restaurant in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Judge Closes Proceedings in an Inquiry Into Torricelli Allegations
description: A federal judge here today approved a request by Senator Robert G. Torricelli to close hearings and seal documents concerning the senator's allegations of improper disclosures of evidence being considered by a grand jury investigating the financing of his 1996 Senate campaign.

title: Money Sought for Pilot Project To Improve Teacher Training
description: Harold O. Levy and Matthew Goldstein, the chancellors of the New York City schools and of the City University of New York, have turned to Washington for help in creating a ''Teacher Empowerment Zone'' to improve teacher training.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages on Feb. 14 about the paperback release of ''A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius,'' by Dave Eggers, included an erroneous reference, provided by a publicist at Vintage Books, to a city that figured in an anecdote about the author's fondness for elaborate surprises. The city -- where Mr. Eggers took a crowd to a bar after a trip by chartered bus from an East Village bookstore -- was Newark, not Trenton.

title: S.& P. Lowers Its Rating on Japanese Debt
description: Standard & Poor's, the credit rating agency, lowered its rating on Japan's debt today, citing the country's growing fiscal inflexibility as public spending rises while an economic overhaul remains stalled.

title: Bush Backs Turkish Efforts To Resolve Economic Crisis
description: Seeking to bolster a struggling ally, President Bush telephoned Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey today to offer his support for the country's efforts to cope with its second economic crisis in three months.

title: Eighth-Seeded C.C.N.Y. Wins Tournament
description: With members of the best team in school history in attendance, the City College men's basketball team finished the most improbable run in City University of New York Athletic Conference history, defeating Staten Island, 77-69, last night at the Nat Holman Gymnasium on the City College campus.

title: At End of Regular Season, Adelphi, 26-0, Stands Alone
description: Ryan McCormack gathered his Adelphi teammates before their game at New York Tech tonight and said: ''Don't worry about any streak or making history. Don't worry about any of that. We'll talk about that afterward.''

title: Guinea in Crisis as Area's Refugees Pour In
description: This country's border runs straight and true through the forest before dipping sharply inside Sierra Leone south of here. That spit of land, known by the lovely name of Parrot's Beak, has become the focus of a widening war in West Africa and home to what United Nations officials describe as the world's worst refugee crisis.

title: Disabilities Act Is Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; Philosophy Of the Worst
description: The French have a phrase for it: la philosophie du pire, the philosophy of the worst. It is the belief, in politics, that your side will gain in the end if the bad guys on the other side win now and do their worst.

title: Corrections
