description: A theater listing in the Spare Times for Children column in Weekend yesterday about ''Revenge of the Space Pandas,'' being presented today and next Saturday at the Atlantic Theater Company in Manhattan, misstated the telephone number. It is (212) 691-5919.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Access Proved Vital in Last-Minute Race for Clinton Pardons
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  In a speech before the Arkansas Legislature on Jan. 17 on his final trip as president, Bill Clinton described his amazement at the last-minute avalanche of applications for pardons and prison-sentence commutations.

title: Spy-Hunt Team Followed Trail To F.B.I. Agent
description: A secret investigative team established in 1994 to identify the source of a series of damaging intelligence losses played a crucial role in the counterespionage probe that led to the arrest on Sunday of an F.B.I. agent, Robert Philip Hanssen, officials said today.

title: Ticket Price For a Movie Goes to $10 At Loews
description: In a city where it is not unheard of to pay $35 for a bowl of soup or $65 to see an Off Broadway play, it probably should come as no surprise that yet another price barrier has been broken.

title: Judge Rejects Most Claims By Law Firms in Auction Suit
description: A federal judge yesterday threw out the claims of 43 of 46 law firms seeking fees for preliminary work on the class action lawsuit by buyers and sellers against the Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses.

title: New Twists in the Pardon Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: Security at the F.B.I.
description: Since the arrest of Robert Philip Hanssen on espionage charges, new disclosures in the case have shown that the Federal Bureau of Investigation badly fumbled the matter. Though the bureau was aware that sensitive American secrets were being compromised, it did not adequately explore the possibility that the betrayal had come from within its own ranks. A major overhaul of the bureau's internal security measures will be required to prevent a recurrence in the future.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE LIBERTY GAINS IN EUROPEAN CABLE The Liberty Media Corporation increased its position in the European cable market through two separate transactions. In partnership with Klesch & Company, a private equity firm in London, Liberty Media, led by its chairman, John C. Malone, above, agreed to buy 55 percent of six cable television operators from Deutsche Telekom A.G. Deutsche Telekom is selling assets to appease European regulators and to pay down debt. Additionally, Liberty Media agreed to pay $1.4 billion to increase its stake to 30 percent in UnitedGlobalCom . Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Bush, Upstaged and Losing a Crucial Moment
description: The conventional wisdom that President Bush is benefiting from bad news about Bill Clinton is on increasingly shaky ground as the controversies over Mr. Clinton's pardons grow rather than abate. If anything, as Mr. Bush finds himself vying with his predecessor for public attention, he is losing precious time to establish public support for his agenda.

title: Toll of Ethnic Violence in Indonesia Reaches 200
description: Ethnic violence continued today in the Indonesian section of Borneo, with the death toll rising to at least 200 in six days of fighting between indigenous Dayak tribesmen and Madurese migrants.

title: Michael Oksenberg, 62, China Expert in Washington
description: Michel Oksenberg, an American authority on China who as a member of President Jimmy Carter's National Security Council helped establish full diplomatic relations between Washington and Beijing, died on Thursday at his home in Atherton, Calif. He was 62.

title: Televising an Execution
description: To the Editor:

title: NESTL'S PROFIT GROWS
description: Nestl S.A. said its net profit jumped 22 percent to $3.6 billion last year, with a 9 percent increase in revenue to $50.9 billion. Based in Vevey, Switzerland, the company expects this year to top last. It is awaiting approval of its takeover of Ralston Purina. Elizabeth Olson

title: Disabilities Act Is Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: DaimlerChrysler Weighs Steps to End Losses; Truck Unit Is Focus
description: Chrysler is not the only problem at DaimlerChrysler A.G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDMAN, NATALIE DAMASK
description: BRANDMAN-Natalie Damask, 82, a former Manhattan resident died February 18, 2001 in Reno, Nevada. She was the wife of Arthur Brandman who died in 1997. She is survived by two sons, Richard Damask and Kenneth Damask, daughter-in-law Susan Damask, and two sisters, Lillian Baskin and Shirley Speiller. Her husband Harold Damask M.D. preceeded her in death in 1964. A graveside service is scheduled at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York at 11 AM, Sunday, February 25, 2001.

title: Fighting a Losing Battle; Russian Military Plants Struggle to Change With Times
description: For the last 10 years, ever since the breakup of the Soviet Union introduced a market economy to Russia, the Saratov Aviation Factory has been struggling to do what it does best: make airplanes. But as old dreams are eclipsed by new realities, it has become increasingly clear that it is a losing battle.

title: Submarine Joy Rides
description: To the Editor:

title: This Revolution Is Being Televised
description: The thick fog creeps into Lima in a B-movie kind of way. It's a Sunday afternoon, winter dark and already time for prime time. Though the multiplex across the street is full of movies, I know that the place to be is here: in my hotel, watching TV, a too-warm room-service ceviche by my side.

title: A Landmark Ruling on Rape
description: The conviction this week by the Hague war crimes court of three Bosnian Serbs for rape and sexual enslavement marks the first time an international tribunal has convicted defendants exclusively for sexual violence or prosecuted sexual slavery at all. The decision shows the progress that women's issues have made in international justice, which used to ignore mass rape, considering it a natural occurrence in war. The tribunal's verdict should also encourage individual nations to treat sexual violence more seriously.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPLIN, LILLIAN (AKA GLEN LINCOLN)
description: CAPLIN-Lillian (aka Glen Lincoln). On February 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Stuart. Loving mother of Wendy, David and Satya. Dear sister of Allen and Stanley. Adoring grandmother of Jonathan, Stephanie and Bobby. Service on Sunday, 2:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Arafat and Gandhi
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFA, MAE
description: JAFFA-Mae. A women of valor. Her strength, dignity, wisdom and lovingkindness will be greatly missed. Beloved wife of the late Ned E. Jaffa. Adored mother of Faith Jaffa Goldstein and Marcy Low. Devoted mother-in-law of Dr. J. Manfred Low. Loving sister of Ethel Wershaw and sister-inlaw of Albert Wershaw. Revered grandmother of Laura Mae Low, Suzanne Michel and Harris Goldstein, and their spouses, Gary Michel and Sara Goldstein. And cherished great-grandmother of Noah & Gabrielle Michel. Services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant, Passaic Street, Hackensack, NJ on Sunday, February 25, 2001, at 10 AM. Donations in her memory may be made to the Renal Care Center at The Valley Hospital, 223 North Van Dien Ave, Ridgewood, New Jersey 07450.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINREBE, ROBERT
description: WEINREBE - Robert. 1913 - 2000. We remember your appreciation of life's beauty, your zest for finding the answers to the ''important questions'', love and concern for friends and family-and the music. In loving memory, your famil

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Behind Trade Center Deal, the Toughest of the Tough in Real Estate
description: Steven Roth was known as a strip mall king from the suburbs when he swept into New York in the mid-1990's. Few of New York's real estate tycoons knew him or cared to know him.

title: The Neediest Cases; Now Helping Others Along a Road She Just Traveled
description: Twice a month in a communal room at a homeless shelter in Brooklyn, about a dozen women gather to listen to Margaret Duncan, a speaker they can relate to. Ms. Duncan was homeless herself for five years and used crack for eight.

title: Jackson Didn't Burn His Bridges
description: Mark Jackson wore a determined look last night while running the Knicks' offense in the first game of his second go-round in New York. But even as he concentrated on setting up his new teammates, his mind wandered. Five years of memories -- the good ones, not the bad -- raced through his head during the Knicks' 88-84 overtime loss to the Phoenix Suns at Madison Square Garden.

title: SCHOOL-DAY TRADER
description: Jonathan Lebed wanted to get rich. He wanted to tune out his school life. And neither the S.E.C. nor his parents were in a position to stop him. A report by Michael Lewis in The Times Magazine.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the film producer and director Stanley Kramer on Wednesday misidentified the studio that distributed his 1952 western ''High Noon.'' It was United Artists, not Columbia Pictures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASDON, LAWRENCE H.
description: LASDON-Lawrence H. Age 58 died February 16, 2001, of a heart attack at his home in Palm Desert, CA. A former resident of New York he was a graduate of Florida Southern University and a former member of the NYSE. He is survived by a brother, Rand M. of New York and two sons, Lance and Chad of Los Angeles, CA. Services will be at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue and 81st Street at 1 PM, Sunday.

title: Budget Office's Estimates For Drug Spending Grow
description: The Congressional Budget Office has sharply increased its estimates of spending on prescription drugs for the elderly, revisions that will make it more difficult for Congress to pay for drug benefits under Medicare.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, IRVING
description: ROSENTHAL-Irving. On Wednesday, February 21. Irving Rosenthal loving son of the late Nathan and Sylvia Rosenthal. Beloved brother of the late Ruth Marlowe, loving uncle of Penny and Manny Flecker, Ellen and Bernard (Marlowe) Wally and the late Michael Marlowe, loving great uncle of Dana and Adam Marlowe, Barbara Byers and Captain Alexander Flecker, and the late First Lt. Norman Flecker. Funeral services and interment will be held on Sunday, February 25, 2PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Please omit flowers, contributions in his memory may be directed to Congregation Ahavas Israel, 770 Howes Lane, Columbia, MD 21044. Following services, friends and relatives are invited to the home of Ellen and Bernard Wally, 7 Pecan Valley Drive, New City, NY 10956. For additional information, please contact Sol Levinson & Brothers, 800-338-1701.

title: Article 2001022491761784422 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: When Synonyms Were My Stock in Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Margins of Literature, Blasphemy Beckons
description: MARGINALIA

title: Young Yankees Are Trying to Make an Impression
description: Ryan Bradley has a pigeon-toed walk, and now he is back to pitching with a pigeon-toed motion and going through something of a rebirth at the Yankees' training camp. But Bradley is merely one symptom of a larger phenomenon occurring within the organization: the farm system, which had a troubled year in 2000, appears to be rebounding.

title: Another Minority Flexes Its Muscle in San Francisco
description: Some days, Theresa Sparks finds it an ordeal simply to walk out her door. How will she look? How will others see her? The same questions dog her everywhere. Entering a public restroom takes internal debate. Walking up to a makeup counter requires a stiff upper lip.

title: Team Concept May Be Adopted
description: Thoroughbred racing is tinkering with a team concept. On two Saturdays in March, 36 horses each from Gulfstream Park and Santa Anita will compete in a home-and-home series that is being billed as the debut of the Super Track Racing Series.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're interested in people's wastebaskets as much as anything else.''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Saturday about Andrew M. Cuomo's announcement that he was joining a New York law firm misspelled the name of the firm in which his father, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, is a partner. It is Willkie Farr & Gallagher, not Wilkie.

title: Broken Seat Belt Is Found in Earnhardt's Wreck at Daytona
description: Nascar officials said today that they found a broken seat belt, a flaw they consider to be a rarity, in the wreckage of Dale Earnhardt's black Chevrolet. The doctor who tended to Earnhardt after his fatal accident at the Daytona 500 on Sunday said that Earnhardt might have lived had the belt not broken.

title: The Perils of Sledding
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares Tumble, Then Regain Some Ground
description: The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rebounded slightly yesterday after a suggestion of an imminent cut in interest rates gave hope to investors who are dismayed by the continuation of corporate earnings warnings.

title: Disabilities Act Is Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001022493647777711 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Warner LeRoy, Restaurant Impresario, Is Dead at 65
description: Warner LeRoy, a son of Hollywood pioneers who combined show business glamour with circus ballyhoo to create New York restaurants like Maxwell's Plum, Tavern on the Green and the new Russian Tea Room, died Thursday night at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 65.

title: Storm Postpones Downhill in Utah
description: Heavy snowfall forced the cancellation of a makeup event on the World Cup circuit yesterday in Huntsville, Utah, leaving the men's United States ski team with yet another delay in its effort to turn the plunging Grizzly run at Snowbasin into a home-course advantage before the 2002 Winter Olympics.

title: Early Puberty in Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARES OF WILLIAMS-SONOMA CLIMB ON PROFIT FORECAST
description: Shares of Williams-Sonoma Inc. rose 15 percent yesterday after the company, a retailer of kitchen goods and home furnishings, said that its most recent quarterly profit beat forecasts and that profit this year might exceed estimates. The company said it would report profit of 78 cents to 79 cents a share in the period, which ended Jan. 28 and was the fourth quarter of its fiscal year, more than the 75-cent estimate of analysts. While most retailers had their worst holiday season in at least five years, Williams-Sonoma increased profit by controlling inventory costs. Slowing consumer spending may lead to losses in the first half, the first deficit since fiscal 1997, but the company expects to rebound as new management redesigns catalogs and improves customer service. Shares of Williams-Sonoma rose $3.40, to $26.40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBITT, SOLOMON
description: COBITT-Solomon. Of NYC and Weston, CT on February 11 at age 88. Beloved father, grandfather and devoted friend. An actor and print model, he is immortalized in movies, ads, greeting cards, and as the senior ''centerfold'' of a 1997 NY Times magazine. Service on Sunday, February 25, at the Community Church, 40 E. 35th St., at 1:30PM. Memorial contributions may be made to Earthjustice.org

title: A New Way to Have Children: The Adoption of Frozen Embryos
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  On the afternoon of Feb. 14, an express courier truck arrived at an Atlanta fertility clinic to make an unusual pickup. Waiting for the driver, frozen inside a thermos of liquid nitrogen, was the promise of human life: 12 fertilized embryos, the genetic offspring of Susanne and Bob Gray.

title: For Last Paycheck, More Workers Cede Their Rights to Sue
description: With layoffs on the rise again, many employees are facing an uncomfortable new choice as they walk out the door: agree never to sue their employer or walk away with less money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSEN, RANDI
description: DORSEN-Randi. A young lady who fought so very hard for so very long and whose body just couldn't keep up with her spirit. May she finally achieve the peace and rest that was denied her for so very long. She will be missed, she will be loved. Maxine, Tad, Jerry Belson

title: New Twists in the Pardon Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the background of Robert Philip Hanssen, a senior agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who has been accused of spying, misstated the year he joined a Chicago accounting firm. It was 1971, not 1973.

title: Article 2001022493117724817 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: Inquiry Focuses on Commuted Sentences for 4 New Yorkers
description: The federal authorities in Manhattan are investigating whether there were any violations of the law in President Bill Clinton's decision to commute the sentences of four Hasidic men who were convicted of defrauding the government of tens of millions of dollars, people familiar with the investigation said.

title: Sports of The Times; Parents' Trip From Russia To UConn Is Well Worth It
description: Lyudmila Abrosimov was dressed in a navy blue skirt and matching long jacket. Her husband, Oleg, wore a green suit. The daughter they sent here from Russia, with love, limped between them on crutches, in her red, white and blue uniform, and into the arms of the man who took her in and became her demanding father figure and coach.

title: Our Iraq Policy Is Not Working
description: America's policy to contain Iraq is rapidly unraveling. The package of coercive levers used in the 1990's -- economic sanctions, weapons inspections and the no-fly zones -- is coming unglued. Indeed, this containment policy has not succeeded in its goals of ridding Iraq of weapons of mass destruction or ousting Saddam Hussein. The policy only antagonizes our coalition allies, and it should be abandoned.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CROWN CASTLE INTERNATIONAL CORP., Houston, which owns communication towers used by wireless phone companies, agreed to lease space in Britain at a minimum of 5,500 sites to Hutchison 3G UK Ltd. and BT Cellnet for undisclosed financial terms.

title: General Motors Sues California Over Quota for Electric Car Sales
description: The General Motors Corporation filed suit today seeking to invalidate a new California rule that would require automobile manufacturers to sell thousands of electric cars in the state each year starting in 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANICK, ETHEL
description: GRANICK-Ethel. Deceased February 19th, 2001 at her home in East Hill Woods, Southbury, CT. Fierce and independent to her last breath. For memorial information, call: 203-789-1879 or E-mail: pbloom@connix.com

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with a music review of the Absolute Ensemble misidentified the bassist at the left. He was Mat Fieldes; Kristjan Jarvi is the conductor.

title: As Hopes Wither, Africans Turn on Leaders
description: VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe, Feb. 24  The rain burst from the heavens and drenched the faces of the jubilant supporters who serenaded the old man at his birthday bash here today. All across town, young women celebrated the leadership of their longtime president, singing, "South Africa will follow you, Mugabe, Namibia will follow you."

title: U.S. and Russians Meet on Defenses Against Missiles
description: CAIRO, Feb. 24  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here today on the first leg of his first overseas trip as the United States' chief diplomat and immediately plunged into talks with the Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, on the two sides' widely differing plans for missile defenses.

title: BUSINESSMAN IS ATTACKED
description: Three masked assailants wielding baseball bats attacked the managing director of Huntingdon Life Sciences, a British drug testing company that has been the target of animal rights protesters, the police said. The executive, Brian Cass, 53, was attacked outside his home in Cambridgeshire on Thursday night and was hospitalized briefly with head wounds. His company has said it was rescued by the United States investment company, the Stephens Group, of Little Rock, Ark., after the Royal Bank of Scotland came under pressure from protesters to call in a loan. Alan Cowell

title: Missile Defense Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Selfish Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Valentine and Hamilton Air Out Their Differences
description: Bobby Valentine and Darryl Hamilton had their meeting today, such as it was. Valentine has called this spring's Hamilton controversy the biggest nonstory of his managerial career. But to Hamilton, the Mets' outfielder, it has mattered more.

title: Article 2001022491437029601 -- No Title
description: By MARGARET W. GOLDSBOROUGH

title: Cuttings: An Acorn and What It Sprouted
description: JEFFREY MEYER is a nurseryman who has always loved trees. But it was not until his first son, Forest, toddled over to him with an acorn in his hand that he had an idea that would become his life's work. The acorn was from the 300-year-old Treaty Live Oak in Jacksonville, Fla., and when he and his wife, Anne, went home, they planted the acorn in their front yard.

title: New Twists in the Pardon Tangle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL
description: FRIEDMAN-Samuel. 1/12/20-2/24/ 85. Always in our thoughts. Arthur is getting married 8/11 this year. Love you, Eleanor and Arthur

title: For New York, Energy Lessons Flicker in California
description: The following article is based on reporting by Neela Banerjee, Alex Berenson and Richard Perez-Pena and was written by Mr. Berenson.

title: Kovalev Snaps Rangers' Streak With a 5-Point Night
description: Aleksei Kovalev still insists that the Rangers do not provide extra incentive for him. ''They're just another team,'' he said.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Subaru Outback H6-3.0 L. L. Bean Edition; A Melting Pot With All-Wheel Drive
description: WHEN Subaru introduced the Outback version of its midsize Legacy six years ago, the traditional station wagon seemed headed for oblivion, elbowed aside by the minivan and the sport utility. Who would have thought that all-wheel drive, an evocative Australian name and some rugged-looking trim could transform an innocuous Japanese wagon into a cult car for the Snow Belt?

title: Spring Packages For Baseball Fans
description: Baseball fans unable to wait for Opening Day can catch their favorite teams at spring training camps in Florida and Arizona. Several companies specializing in travel to sporting events offer both customized vacations and prepackaged tours to help fans attend preseason games, which start March 1. Prices below, which do not include air fare, vary according to choice of hotel, seats, teams etc.

title: When You're No. 3 (Maybe), It Pays to Take a Long View
description: Undaunted by a solid record of almost nonexistent election support, the Green Party has jumped back into state politics by recently nominating Jerry L. Coleman, a consultant, as its candidate for governor in this year's campaign.

title: Rangers Still Look to Fill Richter's Skates
description: It was as if Mark Messier were calling out to the team president and general manager, Glen Sather, for a little help.

title: Streetscapes/Rockefeller University, 62nd to 68th Streets Along the East River; From a Child's Death Came a Medical Institute's Birth
description: IN 1901 John D. Rockefeller's first grandchild, John Rockefeller McCormick, died of scarlet fever at age 3. Four months later, Rockefeller decided to found an institute devoted to research in medicine. With Rockefeller University in its centennial year, its campus near the East River from 62nd to 68th Streets shows evidence of three building campaigns, and it continues to grow. The 15-acre site is visible to passersby through its high iron fence, but it is open to the public only once a year, for a single day in May.

title: For Reggae Star, a Life Flavored by 2 Islands
description: AFTERNOON traffic chugged along East Merrick Road as Shaggy, the Grammy-winning reggae singer, walked down the street toward his office. There was a good chance, he mused, that some people in the passing cars might even be listening to his record ''It Wasn't Me'' as they drove by. After all, it was the No. 1 single from his No. 1 album ''Hot Shot.''

title: Shots in the Dark: Tunnel Photography
description: WATER TUNNEL NO. 3 is what it sounds like, a third water tunnel being built to increase water delivery to New York City. But despite its no-nonsense name, the tunnel, a decades-long project of the city's Department of Environmental Protection, has undeniable charisma. Four men enamored with the tunnel have spent years photographing its construction.

title: The Power to Choose Is Here, But Few Have Made a Move
description: JOEL N. GORDES of Colebrook still has a copy of a letter he wrote to a state newspaper in 1981 about the need to break up the electric utility monopoly in Connecticut. So last year, when the Connecticut Energy Cooperative began offering consumers their first choice in many decades about where to buy electricity, he signed up.

title: Come on in!; Fashions Of The Times
description: Make yourself comfortable as we take you Inside. First to San Simeon, where William Randolph Hearst and Marion Davies threw glamorous fetes. To Istanbul to meet the new power elite. To Palm Springs, and the modernist imaginings of Albert Frey. Then to Newport, to exchange clothes with Doris Duke. It's time to storm the velvet rope and see how the fashion half lives. It's a vicarious, voyeuristic ride. Welcome!

title: Sensibilities Expanded
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside Whiff; Mink Dew
description: In this baffling age, in which fortunes bubble and burst in the blink of a silicon chip, the clues that separate insiders from outsiders have become increasingly subtle. Forget Fendi furs and Gucci shoes; the most primal tribal mark is invisible -- smell. If you wanted to pass yourself off as a third-generation heiress just back from a stint of do-gooding in Ladakh, you might run into Barneys and douse yourself with Chanel No. 5. But while Chanel certainly has pedigree and price, with its face on every bus shelter in Manhattan, it takes no inside knowledge to find. A true American heiress would want to wear what her mother or grandmother wore, Norell.

title: Risks in Commercial Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: The Instincts of a Reformer
description: New York's great reformer, Jacob Riis, who died in 1914, often gave a lecture that ended with the words, ''The first, the all-important [task] is to find your neighbor.'' Riis's lifelong work was exposing and remedying the conditions in which New York's poorest, and often newest, residents lived, and he welcomed allies, both public and private. But Riis believed that neighboring was not just a matter of proximity -- the habit of helping people who live next door to you. It was also an ethical charge that extended well beyond the limits of local geography. That was what he meant when he instructed his well-to-do listeners to search out a poor neighbor -- ''Go, find him.''

title: A Wonder of the Pitching World
description: A pitcher wounds his arm every time he throws a baseball hard. There is microscopic tearing, fluid leaks, cells are damaged. Even if a pitcher avoids a traumatic injury -- a severe tear of the rotator cuff, for example -- there is physical erosion. Calcium slowly collects in the places where there is microscopic tearing, and it inevitably affects the muscle, as ice cracks a sidewalk.

title: Inside Pal; Right-Hand Man
description: Luis Nunez died where he lived: in the studio. For 16 of his 34 years he was the devoted right hand of the photographer David LaChapelle, a job he initially performed as if he were all thumbs. There was scarcely a task that Nunez could handle in the early days of their working relationship without being guided by LaChapelle. Even something as simple as speaking on the phone to a client proved difficult for Nunez. So, in the beginning, he was dependent on LaChapelle, just as he had been dependent until he left home at the age of 17 on his large and doting Cuban family in North Bergen, N.J. Yet, in time, LaChapelle says, their roles reversed, and it was he who sought Nunez's guidance, who depended on his opinion and unspoiled enthusiasm for the work they were doing. ''Basically, Luis became the teacher,'' says LaChapelle, who in honor of what Nunez had meant to him had ''Luis'' tattooed on the fingers of his right hand.

title: An Acorn And What It Sprouted
description: JEFFREY MEYER is a nurseryman who has always loved trees. But it was not until his first son, Forest, toddled over to him with an acorn in his hand that he had an idea that would become his life's work. The acorn was from the 300-year-old Treaty Live Oak in Jacksonville, Fla., and when he and his wife, Anne, went home, they planted the acorn in their front yard.

title: States Ask Bush to Revoke Clinton's Medicaid Rules
description: State health officials and governors from both parties are lobbying the White House to revoke rules issued in the final hours of the Clinton administration that would provide a vast array of new rights to Medicaid patients in health maintenance organizations.

title: Week in Review: Feb. 18-24
description: Russian Missile Offensive

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 11 about the rising influence of behavioral economists misspelled the surname of one and misstated the name of the university where he works. He is George Loewenstein, not Lowenstein, and he is at Carnegie Mellon University, not the Carnegie Mellon Institute.

title: Insect Patrol
description: Hunt for overwintering insects outdoors. Prune out galls on roses, willows, pines and junipers. Check deciduous trees for shiny bands of tent caterpillar eggs and junipers for bagworm's twiggy-looking cocoons; prune. Check hemlocks for waxy white egg masses of woolly adelgid; spray with horticultural oil when it will be above 40 degrees for several hours.

title: February 18-24; A Difference of Degrees
description: In a world where the temperature can change dozens of degrees on a single day, a rise of 1.3 degrees over 100 years might seem inconsequential. But an influential panel of earth scientists has concluded that exactly that change has measurably affected ecosystems and physical features of the planet, like alpine glaciers, most notably the vanishing ice cap atop Mt. Kilimanjaro.

title: A Borough of Collectors
description: We wanted to broaden Brooklyn's definition from a geographic place to a state of mind,'' said Arnold Lehman, director of the Brooklyn Art Museum. The museum's exhibition ''A Family Album: Brooklyn Collects'' features about 200 items -- from antiques to contemporary paintings -- owned by more than 80 collectors who feel a deep connection to the borough. One of them, Harvey Fierstein, the playwright and actor, is showing his collection of figurines (above) carved by the folk artist Lavern Kelley.

title: Man Dies in Fall Near Ex-Girlfriend's Home
description: A Brooklyn man who had threatened to kill his girlfriend after the couple separated recently, fell to his death trying to climb into her sixth-floor bedroom window from the roof while she slept, the police said yesterday.

title: SEX OFFENDERS' PRISON
description: A state appeals court has ruled that corrections officials can move sex offenders from a temporary facility at Kearny to one at East Jersey Prison in Woodbridge. Mayor James McGreevey, who fought the proposal, said he would not appeal because the chance of a reversal was unlikely. The facility, located in the Avenel section of the township, will house 135 sex offenders who have completed their sentences but are not considered safe to be released. Corrections officials said they would place sex offenders in the Woodbridge facility only after the one in Kearny was full. Abhi Raghunathan

title: SPECTACLE; Peking Acrobats: It's in the Spirit
description: IN China, children as young as 5 with acrobatic promise are recruited to train at special schools, where they follow a rigorous program of contortion, hand balancing, object manipulation, martial arts and character dance. Some of those children grow up to perform with the Peking Acrobats, China's elite troupe of gymnasts, jugglers, cyclists and tumblers.

title: Inside Inspiration; Get The Picture?
description: The last thing I expected when I telephoned Slim Aarons was to end up arrested.

title: Church, State And Nonbeliever
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; Reclaiming a Legacy, in Spirit
description: DON'T get him wrong. He is not planning a hostile takeover or trying to elbow his way back into the president's office. He is 86, after all, and well aware of it.

title: A Pairing of Maestros
description: To the Editor:

title: Because Virtual Isn't Always Good Enough
description: Some astute students of corporate organization say business will increasingly rely on joint ventures and transitory projects. Instead of trying to do everything themselves, businesses are focusing on their core expertise and allying with other specialists for everything else. So Hollywood's production techniques -- with squads of skilled artists assembling to make a movie and, once finished, going their own way -- are seen as a wave of the future. But Laurence Prusak and Don Cohen, authors of ''In Good Company,'' are skeptical that ''virtual'' companies formed along those lines can succeed. An excerpt from their book follows.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Subject to Debate

title: Lives; Ransom Notes
description: I went to Ghana to look for Kwasi and Kwame, two 19th-century Ashanti princes given as gifts to the Dutch king. I wanted to explore their lives for a novel I was writing about them. Wherever I went in my travels during those six weeks, people invited me into their homes and introduced me, a tall blond stranger, to their mothers and eldest sisters, the most important family members. My finest memories of Ghana are of this readily offered friendship, usually accompanied by a small white sandwich sprinkled with sugar. I felt so welcomed that I let down my guard.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MIDTOWN

title: A Newsstand Dies, and With It, a Neighborhood's Hub
description: At first they blamed winter vacation. Then they wondered whether another fire had struck. Some even believed that the Muslim holiday Ramadan had played a part. Finally, when no one could explain why the newsstand in the north corner of Grand Army Plaza was closed, neighbors began thinking conspiracy.

title: New President of State Theater
description: After a seven-month search, the State Theater in New Brunswick has selected Mark Hough as its new president and chief executive. Mr. Hough, vice president for capital and major gifts at the Museum of the City of New York, succeeds David W. Fleming next month. Mr. Fleming left the State Theater to become the president and chief executive of the Greater Austin Performing Arts Center in Texas. The State Theater, a renovated vaudeville palace, presents artistic, popular and educational programming.

title: Iron in the Blood, Misfortune on the Mind
description: At Smith's Bar on 44th Street and Eighth Avenue on Tuesday night, the ironworkers were talking of little else.

title: Inside Palm Springs; In The Frey
description: Albert Frey designed 200 buildings in the middle of the California desert. With their sharp edges and modern lines, they're a graphic metaphor for this season's hottest prints.

title: Inside Collectible; Save My Seat
description: It had to happen: postwar modernism is over. Brilliant as they are, the furniture designs of masters like Charles Eames and George Nelson have become so overexposed and overpriced that it was just a matter of time before the advance guard marched on to (or teetered toward, depending on footgear) the Next Big Thing: the startling forms, lush sensuality and futuristic glamour of the 1960's furniture of Pierre Paulin.

title: The Challenge of Reimagining the Holocaust on Stage
description: THE Holocaust should not be relegated to unfathomable mystery. It consists of concrete acts of mass murder. Yet anyone who writes about it, or seeks to recreate aspects of it artistically, quickly becomes aware of the formidable barriers it presents.

title: Forget Voting Them Off the Island. They're Just Shot.
description: TALK about timing. A smorgasbord of reality programs is being presented on the big 100-channel buffet, and the post-Super Bowl premiere of ''Survivor II'' racked up the season's highest rating for an entertainment show.

title: Samaritans: Just Add Milk
description: Team Cheerios boxes are often a billboard for athletes who work together successfully. A box unveiled last week at the ShopRite in Clark swaps sports heroes for grocery store clerks, cashiers and managers. About 70,000 special Team Cheerios boxes have been released for sale, available only at the 192 ShopRite stores, which are in New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Delaware. The boxes picture the 58 ShopRite employees and their family members (37 of them are from New Jersey) who have made exceptional efforts to help the hungry, particularly the working poor. The box is a collaboration among General Mills, Wakefern Executives (distributing arm for ShopRite) and ShopRite Partners in Caring, the company's hunger-fighting program, which this year is raising $2 million for food banks. Adrienne Bell

title: For These Book Lovers, A Happy Ending Ahead
description: The first book may not be checked out for a few years, but 578,000 library-card-carrying Bronx residents have something to look forward to: a new, more spacious central library, with a Latino cultural center to boot.

title: Inside Trading; How I Got That Scoop!
description: The Paris taxi driver was of the chatty kind that makes you cringe as you try not to shut your cream coat in the door. As we crawled down Avenue Montaigne, he waved expansively at the hulking house of Christian Dior.

title: Ann Egan, Christian Nugent
description: Ann Elizabeth Egan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Egan of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christian Collins Nugent, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Dennis M. Nugent of Yardley, Pa. The Rev. Mark A. Connolly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title: Sonia's Penance
description: Father of the Four Passages

title: Home Sweet Home, but Not Saccharine
description: POOR little ''Gilmore Girls.'' This witty, charming show about a 32-year-old single mother and her 16-year-old daughter is one of the best series on the air, and possibly the most underappreciated. When it arrived in the fall, WB scheduled it against ''Friends'' (Thrusdays at 8 p.m.). That was tough enough, and we all know what happened next: gunning for ''friends,'' CBS put the second ''Survivor'' on at the same time. Now ''it's the two Japanese monsters coming at each other,'' said Amy Sherman-Palladino, the ''Gilmore Girls'' creator, who can envision her own show being crushed underfoot. ''It's horrible.''

title: The Sportsman Can Go All Out Under One Roof
description: March is the month in the Northeast when anglers -- save those who enjoy huddling in an ice shanty on a frozen, windswept lake -- rejoice that escape from winter's embrace is imminent. Emboldened, they begin to sort out gear, tie flies, peruse tackle catalogs and attend sporting goods shows.

title: A Former Foe Knew Crash Was Serious
description: On his first day as a network analyst, Darrell Waltrip watched his friend Dale Earnhardt die last Sunday after he crashed into a wall on the final lap of the Daytona 500.

title: Church, State and Nonbeliever
description: To the Editor:

title: Handling Metal's Enemy: Rust
description: CORROSION is a complex electrochemical process that results in the degradation of the physical and aesthetic properties of a metal. Rust is a form of corrosion that affects ferrous metals like iron and steel. In the process, oxygen pulls electrons away from the metal, causing it to disintegrate. Some oxidation can occur when oxygen in the air comes in contact with the metal, but in most cases water vapor must be present before any appreciable deterioration can take place. With iron, for example, 40 percent humidity must be present before rust will occur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPLIN, LILLIAN (AKA GLEN LINCOLN)
description: CAPLIN-Lillian (aka Glen Lincoln). On February 22, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Stuart. Loving mother of Wendy, David and Satya. Dear sister of Allen and Stanley. Adoring grandmother of Jonathan, Stephanie and Bobby. Service on Sunday, 2:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: INSIDE
description: Serbs Arrest Ex-Police Chief

title: Harris and Pollock: A Decadelong Dance
description: IN the late 1980's, the actor Ed Harris received a book from his father as a birthday gift. It was a biography of the Abstract Expressionist painter Jackson Pollock. A year later, Mr. Harris recalled, he received another Pollock biography from his father. It seemed that Mr. Harris's father saw a physical resemblance between his son and the painter.

title: Corrections
description: The Dining Out column last Sunday misstated the opening hours for Fiddlers Seafood Restaurant in Chester. They are Tuesday through Saturday, 11:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.; Tuesday through Thursday, 5:30 to 9 p.m.; Friday, 5:30 to 9:30 p.m.; Saturday, 5:30 to 10 p.m.; Sunday 4 to 9 p.m.

title: Letters
description: Our article on cloning riveted readers, though some wanted more on the efforts of scientists and less on those of the U.F.O. sect. And the image in What They Were Thinking of the boy alone in his bedroom, missing his brothers in foster care, prompted others to contemplate those who would resort to cloning to replace a lost child.

title: Kimber Wilson, Matthew Blackburn
description: Kimber Leigh Wilson and Matthew Kemp Blackburn, both patent lawyers with Morgan & Finnegan, a New York law firm, were married yesterday. The Rev. Catherine A. Caimano, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Charting the Future Direction for Route 110
description: KEY issues like transportation, affordable housing for young employees and energy needs for high-technology companies are being raised by businesses and government officials concerned over the development of Route 110, a direct north-to-south route in the middle of Long Island. The 12-mile state road parallels the Nassau and Suffolk border and includes parts of the towns of Babylon, Huntington and Oyster Bay, with about eight miles in Huntington.

title: One Flue Over the Cuckoo's Nest
description: I DIDN'T invent fire. It just feels that way.

title: Pair of Views About Sudan: Help Rebels Or End War
description: The Bush administration is coming under pressure from Christian groups and members of Congress to help Christian rebels in southern Sudan, but a nonpartisan group that includes many diplomatic experts on Africa is recommending that the United States begin an international effort to end the 18-year-old war, the longest running in Africa.

title: The Neediest Cases; Grounded by Amnesia, but Still Grounded in Family
description: LaWandra Williamson, a flight attendant for Trans World Airlines, was making the standard landing announcement on a flight from San Juan, P.R., to Kennedy International Airport. She asked passengers to remain seated until the captain had turned off the fasten-seat-belt sign.

title: Building an Empire One Party Page at a Time
description: JASON BINN is pretty unabashed when it comes to showing his enthusiasm for celebrity, for clothes and for flashy restaurants. But he gets really excited when he talks about money.

title: Margaret Wilson, Thompson Godfrey
description: Margaret Kathryn Wilson, a daughter of Sharalee and Patrick J. Wilson of Traverse City, Mich., was married there on Friday to Thompson Christian Godfrey, the son of Nancy and Peter S. Godfrey of Redding, Conn. The Rev. William W. Lipscomb performed the ceremony at St. Francis of Assisi Catholic Church.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Vickie L. Milazzo, whose company trains nurses as consultants to lawyers, misstated the year in which the business was incorporated. It was 1989, not 1990.

title: Political Briefing; A Group's Advice: Run, Hillary. Run.
description: Hardly anyone noticed last March when American Women Presidents was formed. The goal of the small group, which has headquarters in Sacramento, was lofty enough -- to promote the election of a woman to the White House -- but in the hubbub of the nominating season, the announcement of its arrival on the political scene was almost totally lost.

title: The Gift of Good Record-Keeping
description: MANY years ago, my wife's grandfather gave us a $5,000 municipal bond, which earns us about $350 a year in interest. Thanks, Grandpa.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Getting a Fix On the Vastness Of the Cosmos
description: A HUGE celestial sphere shimmers in a light-filled cube at Columbus Avenue and 79th Street in Manhattan, the newest architectural addition to the American Museum of Natural History. Looking like a giant gyroscope, tilted as if it were about to spin off into space, the open ball of interlocking aluminum rings and stainless steel fittings is called an armillary, an astronomical instrument that has been used since antiquity to depict the universe. At the center of this version, which is based on the latest astrophysical data, is an S-shaped representation of our galaxy, the Milky Way.

title: A Tired Complaint
description: To the editor:

title: Learning to Celebrate Water-Cooler Gossip
description: LAURENCE PRUSAK and Don Cohen, two lifelong students of business learning, are champions of the chance encounter. They believe that people in business learn most effectively (and most often) from their colleagues, typically in unplanned exchanges that are as likely to occur on a staircase as in a conference room.

title: The Real-Life Legacy of an Architectural Visionary
description: THERE was a time when architects thought they had found the key to creating Oz. They would use modern design to transform cities from haphazard mlanges of buildings and streets into rational metropolises. Highways would be double-decked and high-rise residential towers would stand evenly as pickets, while industrial activity would be banished to the hinterlands.

title: Bow Your Head and Hide That Navel
description: SOON, winter will make way for spring's strolling weather, and tourists will be out in force, trying to see as much of New York as possible and as comfortably as possible. Many will head up to Harlem churches and show us how casual they can be with denim, sneakers and the accessory of choice, camera equipment.

title: Despite Worries, Joyful Sweet 16
description: IT was Jennifer Medina's sweet 16 party, but there was one bitter note in the apartment on Riverdale Avenue here. Jennifer's 38-year-old mother, Deborah, who is partially paralyzed from a stroke, was told recently that she may no longer be eligible for the monthly payments she has been receiving since her husband died of a heart attack eight years ago.

title: February 18-24; Ruling on Balkan Rapes
description: In a landmark case, the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague sentenced three Bosnian Serbs to between 12 and 28 years in prison for raping and torturing Muslim girls and women and using them as sex slaves. It was the first international tribunal to convict soldiers for wartime mass rape and sexual enslavement. Women's groups that had lobbied for prosecution were pleased with the ruling, which said that the offenses, committed in 1992, were crimes against humanity. Marlise Simons

title: Van Gogh and Friends In St. Louis Exhibit
description: A new exhibition at the Saint Louis Art Museum in St. Louis explores Vincent van Gogh's relationship with the French avant-garde in the late 1880's. ''Vincent van Gogh and the Painters of the Petit Boulevard,'' on display through May 13, features more than 70 works by van Gogh and his contemporaries, including Gauguin, Toulouse-Lautrec and Georges Seurat. Some of the works have never been seen in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, MARTHA (POPPI)
description: THOMAS-Martha (Poppi). It is with deep sorrow that the Board of Trustees and staff of The Animal Medical Center mark the passing of our devoted Chairman Emerita, Mrs. Joseph A. (Poppi) Thomas. Mrs. Thomas' passionate belief in the important role of animals in our lives led to her tireless work for 44 years as an active member of our board, serving for 12 years as Chairman. Her generosity of spirit, her integrity and her unwavering commitment to improving the care of animals served as an inspiration to us all. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and all those who were touched by her joy of living and the warmth of her friendship. Cynthia Phipps Chairman Guy Pidgeon, DVM, DACVIM President and CEO

title: Robert Enrico, 69, Award-Winning Film Director
description: Robert Enrico, a popular French movie director whose memorable 24-minute film, ''Incident at Owl Creek,'' won a Palme d'Or at the 1962 Cannes International Film Festival as well as an Oscar for best short film at the 1964 Academy Awards, died on Friday. He was 69.

title: Reversing Decades-Long Trend, Americans Retiring Later in Life
description: For nearly a century, Americans were able to retire at ever-younger ages and in greater prosperity. But over the last few years, they have begun staying on the job later into life.

title: He Pleased Himself
description: To the Editor:

title: Natchez
description: Mainly what I love about Natchez is its fairy-tale quality of having been suspended in time. And the fact that it's small enough to explore on foot, which gives you a chance, if you're nosy, to peer behind picket fences into private gardens, gaze through antique-glass windows into living rooms, and daydream about a slower, prettier and perhaps more romantic era.

title: February 18-24; Big, Bigger, Megavehicle
description: What weighs over six tons and scares mammals? Tyrannosaurus rex -- or a Freightliner Unimog, an $84,000 four-wheel-drive vehicle that can scale 80 percent inclines. Based on a German military truck, the Unimog is 9 feet 7 inches tall. Freightliner, part of DaimlerChrysler, will introduce it late this year and has already begun promoting it to American off-road driving enthusiasts who own smaller military surplus Unimogs from Europe. Freightliner said last week that it would emphasize selling its fire-engine and snow-plow versions, while still selling to individuals. The Sierra Club dubbed the diesel-guzzling Unimog, ''Daimlersaurus Wrecks.'' Keith Bradsher

title: Facing Facts: Aid to Colombia; America Gets Candid About What Colombia Needs
description: FOR nearly a year now, American officials have been trying to tell voters why they should care about Colombia. But this month, one architect of that campaign, the recently retired Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, dramatically changed the argument. He warned that the whole of Colombia was dying. If Americans stood idle, he said, they would be like the neighbors of Kitty Genovese, the 1964 murder victim in New York whose screams went unanswered.

title: A Photography Pioneer, Semi-Obscure No More
description: THE American photographer F. Holland Day (1864-1933) spent much of the last 15 years of his life in his family home in Norwood, Mass., not far from here. He had long since stopped making pictures. He was all but forgotten by the art world. After his mother's death, he took to his bed and had it surrounded by bookcases, their contents an arm's length away. They enclosed him like a protective box, a live-in camera lucida.

title: How Karaoke Conquered Broadway
description: Go ahead. Pick up the microphone. You know you want to. What difference does it make if you can't sing? Or dance? Or act? We're all friends here. Everybody loves you. Anyway, it's only Broadway.

title: Brenda Alosio, Benjamin Schoolsky
description: Brenda Jean Alosio, a daughter of Arlene Alosio of River Vale, N.J., and the late Donald T. Alosio, is to be married there today to Benjamin Schoolsky, a son of Judith and Allan Schoolsky of Lynbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Jerry Hahn, a Roman Catholic priest, will officiate at the Florentine Gardens, a catering business. Rabbi H. Philip Berkowitz is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Midway Airport Is Undergoing a Major Expansion
description: MIDWAY AIRPORT, the very distant -- No. 2 airport in the Chicago area behind O'Hare International, is getting a $761 million makeover that includes a new terminal and a number of other improvements aimed at both increasing capacity and smoothing out the congestion that has been a growing problem in recent years.

title: PRAISE FOR CLINTON'S WARDROBE
description: The Westchester Wag, the Larchmont-based monthly, has taken a shine to former President Bill Clinton. In the current issue, it includes him on its list of Westchester's best-dressed men, along with Ralph Lauren and others. The magazine says Mr. Clinton's ''well-cut, single-breasted suits are all the more flattering on his slimmed-down build.'' In the March issue, out next week, The Wag will run a fiction-writing contest with a theme of ''Bill and Hillary: The New York Years.'' The top three selections will be published. Mary Ann Liebert, the Wag's editor and publisher, joked that it could be difficult to come up with a winner because ''with the Clintons, truth is often stranger than fiction.'' The Wag has warmed toward the Clintons since last summer, when its editor, Diane Straus Tucker, left to become publisher of The Westchester County Times. Ms. Tucker's father, Peter Straus, is married to Monica Lewinsky's mother, Marsha Lewis. Corey Kilgannon

title: The Singing Did It
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; A Lot of Pluribus, Not Much Unum
description: ON the day allied warplanes launched their most recent strikes near Baghdad, an American-Iraqi encounter of a different kind was taking place in Washington.

title: Lexical Overdrive
description: DEMONOLOGY

title: Less Scoring Needed in N.B.A., Not More
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Cosmic Dispatches'
description: To the Editor:

title: Saxes and Piccolo In Bach's Elysium?
description: SAXOPHONES are wandering in the Elysian fields of Bach's music, and somehow a piccolo and a xylophone have crept past the vigilant gatekeepers, too, not to mention a twirling celesta. Indeed, the place is full of instruments that should not be there: full symphonic strings, massive brass sections, pounding timpani, a glockenspiel and a triangle.

title: At a French Factory, Culture is a Two-Way Street
description: FOR both Toyota and the workers at its new French plant, cross-cultural communication was a learning process.

title: Maryland Farmers Turn From Tobacco to Flowers
description: More than three centuries after Maryland took root as a lush English tobacco colony, the last tobacco farmers are renouncing ''the money crop,'' as it long reigned, to take a bittersweet state buyout that guarantees them an income for 10 years.

title: February 18-24; A Big Year in Bad
description: Eminem must have been relieved when the envelope containing the Grammy Awards' highest honor, best new album, was torn open at the Staples Center in Los Angeles and his name wasn't inside. Now, the protests, hand-wringing and nonstop media attention aimed at the offensive lyrics on his ''Marshall Mathers LP'' can finally subside. And he still walked away with three Grammys, making a clean sweep of the hip-hop categories. His mentor and producer, Dr. Dre, however, was disappointed. Cornered after the ceremony, he said, ''I was robbed.''

title: Thomas and Sheffield Showing Salary Envy
description: Payroll disparity, meet salary disparity.

title: In Panama, Sipping Coffee At Its Source
description: EVERY morning, whether I wake up in New York or New Zealand, I follow the same routine: wash, dress, and go look for coffee. Flight delays, bumpy bus rides, lizards on the bathroom floor -- these are mere annoyances, easily shrugged off. But a bad cup of brew in the morning (or even worse, no coffee at all), can throw a hotel, a restaurant, even an entire destination onto my blacklist.

title: Iraq Defiant as U.S. Lobbies Arabs on Shift in Sanctions
description: As the Bush administration tries to build international consensus around a new, perhaps less punitive sanctions regime against Iraq, the reaction in the Iraqi capital runs from the contempt of Saddam Hussein to something resembling a weary, believe-it-when-we-see-it shrug among the 23 million ordinary Iraqis who have endured a decade of incremental misery.

title: SPRING THEATER/EVOKING THE HOLOCAUST; Affirmations of Life In the Shadow of Death
description: FOR Elise Thoron, the creative process began with a loan from a playwright friend. In 1995, the friend gave her a book filled with the artwork of Charlotte Salomon -- deeply personal images of a German Jewish family haunted by suicides and splintered by Nazi persecution. Ms. Thoron, who is not Jewish, had no direct connection to the Holocaust, but Salomon's stories of depression, suicide and family secrets resonated with her.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about a shop connected to McSweeny's, a literary quarterly founded by the author Dave Eggers, reversed the adjectives in the title of his memoir. It is ''A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius.''

title: POSTINGS: 51 Apartments in the East Village; 'Soviet' for Recent Graduates
description: The eight-story building scheduled to rise at 222 East Third Street in the East Village will consist of 51 apartments, including three duplex penthouses, and its facade will be granite and glass. So why have the husband and wife team of Stephen B. Jacobs, the building's architect, and Andi Pepper, the designer, jokingly dubbed their design ''Soviet apartments''? Not because they will be shoddy, Mr. Jacobs explained, adding that with an open living room and common area on each floor, as well as an exercise room and party room in the building, the apartments will be anything but.

title: Ideas & Trends; Reality TV's Ultimate Death Trip
description: AT a moment when XFL football and ''Temptation Island'' are cited as portents of the coming apocalypse, the reality television trend took an unexpected turn last Sunday. Live and in living color, and then again in a ride-along instant replay, 32 million Americans watched as Dale Earnhardt Sr. was killed in a last-lap crash during Nascar racing's biggest event, the Daytona 500.

title: Who Cares Who Wrote It? What Does It Sound Like?
description: NOT long ago, I sold two chairs: a grim mid-19th-century Victorian pair with hints of the gothic revival style. I didn't remember them from my childhood, I found them ugly, and so I was happy to turn them over to my friend the antique dealer. Her questions were: Who owned them? Where did the owners live and when? How did they come to you?

title: Don Henley at NJPAC
description: Don Henley, singer and guitarist who was a member of the Eagles, has spent much of the last decade organizing benefit concerts and albums and writing about Walden Woods as part of his Thoreau Institute. He has released a new solo album, ''Inside Job'' on Warner Brothers Records, his first album of new material since 1989's ''The End of the Innocence.'' Mr. Henley will perform tonight at 8 in the New Jersey Performing Arts Center's Prudential Hall in Newark. Karen DeMasters

title: In Lieu of Manners
description: What started as an essay about the way in which the law has replaced manners (and I guess, according to your writer, this is a bad thing) turned into (sigh, another) legal critique of the Supreme Court's decision in the national election. Should George W. Bush and Al Gore have had the ''manners'' to settle things in Congress rather than take it to the Supreme Court? Or in a throwback to those shining examples of enlightened thought from the 18th and 19th centuries, should the conflict have been handled by a duel or by ''shunning''? Your writer seems to pine for an America that existed in the mythology of what we imagine the 19th century to have been. If manners have failed us, is it because we haven't tried hard enough? Or were they simply inadequate in the first place?

title: The Slopes Aren't Slippery For High School Ski Star
description: IF R. J. Best, the standout skier of the North Salem High combined team, were a train, he would be a runaway express.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLAU, PHILIP
description: SCHLAU-Philip. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother and respected by all who knew him professionally or personally. He'll be missed. We were lucky and blessed to have had him with us. Florence, Stacey and Beth Schlau Murray and Trudy Starr

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for PATRICK McGURN; The Shareholders at the Barricades
description: AS the proxy season heats up, shareholders are offering up a dizzying array of proposals. Many will not come to an actual vote, because some companies and investors will reach agreement on the issues, while others could end up the subject of spirited campaigns.

title: Putting Last Things First in a Puzzle About Memory
description: IN the summer of 1997, the film director Christopher Nolan and his younger brother, Jonathan, were driving westward together across America. The brothers are half-English and half-American and had grown up commuting between England and the United States. Christopher, who was 27 at the time, had just finished shooting his first film, ''Following,'' in England and was relocating to Los Angeles.

title: Powell Urges an End Violence and Pledges Support
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Feb 25v - U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell urged Israelis and Palestinians on Sunday to end violence that has taken more than 400 lives in five months, but fresh shootings immediately showed the distance left to go.

title: Sky Watch: Mir Comes Home
description: Mir, the 15-year-old Russian space station, is expected to decay in the Earths atmosphere roughly two to three weeks from now. A Progress cargo ship, commanded by ground controllers, is docked at Mir and is steadily lowering the low end of Mirs orbit.

title: TRACING YOUR ROOTS
description: Anyone interested in learning about African-American history or tracing their lineage can take advantage of the Westchester County Archives's online project, ''Our Roots Run Deep,'' www.westchestergov.com/wcarchives/. In addition to original documents, the project describes sources for historical information, like government archives and local historical societies. It also includes an educational project based on the life of Lewis Brady, an African-American who escaped from slavery and made his way to Ossining. Elsa Brenner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, ALICE ELIZABETH
description: MURPHY-Alice Elizabeth, a dance artist of the Vaudeville Stage, age 90 of Brigantine, NJ. Member of the dance troupe known as ''The Murphy Sisters''. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, February 26, 2001, 9am in the Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church, California and Atlantic Avenues, Atlantic City, NJ. Friends may call for viewing Sunday evening from 7 to 9 PM and Monday morning from 8 to 8:45 AM at the Funeral Home. Burial will be in Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NYC at approximately 1:30 PM. For information, call H.M. Gormley Funeral Home, Albany Avenue, Atlantic City at 609-344-3188.

title: Jackson Will Have to Be Quick Study in Knicks' System
description: In the crucial moments of his first game back in New York on Friday night, Mark Jackson was on the floor only because he could not resist standing for a better view any more than any other fan. He came off the bench and inched onto the court with a towel around his neck.

title: Debating the Sincerest Form of Architectural Flattery
description: Founded in 1865, the Harvard Club of New York sees itself as more than a landmark; it is a tradition, or so the its Web site says. Yet, club officials say they are looking to the future, and the needs of increasing membership, with a plan to demolish part of its landmark Georgian-style clubhouse to make way for an eight-story annex. The proposal has made some preservationists unhappy.

title: The Greener Grass Is, Well, Greener
description: Like many other high-powered people, Barry Schuler, the chief executive of America Online, loves his job. Forget the potential for hackers and systemwide computer problems. ''I feel I have the best job in the world,'' he said.

title: Creating a Pediatric Hospital Like No Other
description: WITH stars twinkling inside its domed ceiling and clowns and musicians performing near a bubbling brook that runs past an aquarium, a miniature golf course, a sports museum and a doll house, the Maria Fereri Children's Hospital at Westchester Medical Center will be like no other pediatric facility in the country, perhaps the world.

title: Medium Is the Message In Counterfeiting Battle
description: China is considered one of the worst offenders in counterfeiting foreign goods like CD's, videos, electronics and luxury watches, and the occasional crackdown is often publicized by showing a steamroller crushing the phony goods. But now, apparently even foreign-made steamrollers are threatened by counterfeiting.

title: White Flight, This Time Toward Harlem; Newcomers and Good Times Bring Hope, and Fears of Displacement
description: Few people doubted in recent decades that Harlem needed change. Now change has come -- and it is being met not simply with hope but with unease. Residents voice a complex tangle of aspirations and anxieties about class and culture and race that at least in some ways echoes fears expressed by whites during an earlier chapter of racial change in the neighborhood.

title: Through The Camera, A Closer Look at Age
description: COMMUTERS hurrying through the subway station at 42nd Street and Sixth Avenue are confronted by images of where they are headed -- not uptown or downtown but a biological destination, old age. The portraits publicize ''Elder Grace: the Nobility of Aging,'' an exhibition of photographs by Chester Higgins Jr. at the New-York Historical Society through next Sunday. It is at once a celebration of aging and a cautionary lesson. These handsome, dignified, larger-than-life images of senior citizens proclaim, in Mr. Higgins's words, ''This is what life can be like for those who live it wisely and well.''

title: Inside Epiphany; All Hams On Deck
description: On May 2, 1981, at 8 p.m., one network television program changed fashion forever. It wasn't the live assassination of a couturier. It didn't involve Jackie. Or Krystle and Alexis, or even Kelly, Sabrina and Kris. Nancy Reagan and Madonna had nothing to do with it.

title: The Persistent Charm Of 'Time and Again'
description: To the Editor:

title: N.J. TRANSIT BUDGET
description: The New Jersey Transit board of directors last week proposed a $1.13 billion capital budget for the fiscal year 2002, a 23 percent increase over the current fiscal year budget and the agency's largest capital proposal ever. The budget includes plans for work on the Newark International Airport Station, completion of the Montclair Connection and Secaucus Transfer Station, continued construction of the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail and the Southern New Jersey Light Rail Transit System, and the first phase of construction of the Newark-Elizabeth Rail Link.

title: Bayonne's Terminal Catches Hollywood's Eye
description: Can Opie help salvage the Military Ocean Terminal? Can the terminal be magically transformed into the land of Oz?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, VIVIAN
description: MARCUS-Vivian. On February 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Dear sister of Harold Hofflin and the late Norman Hofflin. Cherished and devoted aunt of Lois Hofflin, Jesse Hofflin and his wife, Phyllis, and loving great-aunt of Lauren Hofflin. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Sunday, 12 PM.

title: Singing Those Technology Blues, Again
description: The stock market was pounded last week, with two major indexes ending at or near their lowest levels since the market highs last March. But investors managed to limit the damage with a rally late Friday as rumors circulated that the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates even before its next policy meeting in late March.

title: Penelope Kemp, David Ross
description: Penelope Johnston Kemp and David Anthony Ross were married on Friday at Grace Episcopal Church in Manhattan. Canon John Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: In Gloom, a Beacon: Tax-Saving Funds
description: AS a teacher, the market does not spare the rod. Last year, investors decided that they had had enough of mutual funds intended to be tax-efficient. After a half-decade of growing interest in this nascent fund category, sales plummeted.

title: It's Time to Gather Around the Campfire, but Which One?
description: FOR Jill Lesage of Guilford, going to overnight camp was a life-altering experience. Growing up in Orange, she decided that she did not want to hang out on the beach in Woodmont with her brother, cousins and friends all summer. She wanted to develop her interests in drawing, painting and music.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page 3 of the Travel section today with a report about the restoration of a fresco at the Basilica of St. Francis in Assisi, Italy, misidentifies a saint in some copies. He is St. Vittorio, not St. Rufino.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about investing in the Best Buy Company, the retailer of consumer electronics and appliances, referred incorrectly to the financial condition of Musicland Stores, a company it acquired on Jan. 31. Musicland renegotiated agreements with creditors and suppliers in 1997; it was not bankrupt.

title: For Artists, Harlem Gets Too Hot to Handle
description: IN the Roaring Twenties, the brick and concrete building, hulking over the elevated subway at Broadway and 132nd Street, was built as a garage for Nash motorcars. Later, according to local lore, it became an assembly plant for wooden models of the A-bomb and a meeting place for Gen. Leslie Groves and Robert Oppenheimer, ground zero east of the Manhattan Project.

title: A Reluctant Grad Adds His 'I' to Alumni
description: WHEN I was in college (no names, please, but I assure you that the place is terribly top-drawer), alumni were as alien to me as coelacanths, those living fossil fish off Madagascar. I knew they existed, sure, and that if I managed to avoid being caught with my crib notes, one day I would join their ranks. Then I, too, would know the thrill of tacking my year of graduation on after my name,  la ''Esq.'' or ''Ph.D.,'' when introducing myself at rarefied social functions. Not to mention the joy of being regularly hit up for donations.

title: Article 2001022593966539100 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Imaginative Leaps Into the Real World
description: IN architecture, it is always the Thirties. Buildings can never be entirely divorced from social reality, since they make up a good chunk of it. Nor can they be isolated from the world of ideas. They make up a hefty slice of the intellectual sphere as well. With luck, there will always be openings for those who wish to debate whether architecture is best seen as a form of art or one of social service.

title: Jonathan Lebed's Extracurricular Activities
description: On Sept. 20, 2000, the Securities and Exchange Commission settled its case against a 15-year-old high-school student named Jonathan Lebed. The S.E.C.'s news release explained that Jonathan -- the first minor ever to face proceedings for stock-market fraud -- had used the Internet to promote stocks from his bedroom in the northern New Jersey suburb of Cedar Grove. Armed only with accounts at A.O.L. and E*Trade, the kid had bought stock and then, ''using multiple fictitious names,'' posted hundreds of messages on Yahoo Finance message boards recommending that stock to others. He had done this 11 times between September 1999 and February 2000, the S.E.C. said, each time triggering chaos in the stock market. The average daily trading volume of the small companies he dealt in was about 60,000 shares; on the days he posted his messages, volume soared to more than a million shares. More to the point, he had made money. Between September 1999 and February 2000, his smallest one-day gain was $12,000. His biggest was $74,000. Now the kid had agreed to hand over his illicit gains, plus interest, which came to $285,000.

title: Bones to Pick
description: Kids can see where the stars of ''Jurassic Park'' came from on a fossil dig in the South Dakota Badlands this summer. Steve Nicklas, a paleontologist, leads the weekend and one-week excursions from Bowman, S.D. The price for one week -- $1,500 a person, double; $800 under age 16 -- includes all meals, accommodations and ground transportation. Weekends are $600 a person, double; (866) 333-3466 or www.clubdinosaur .com.

title: More Girls On the Field, And More at The Doctor's
description: Amy Drinkwater, 14, won't be playing soccer again. Neither will her 22-year-old sister, Lesley. Both of them broke their ankles on the athletic field.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Gabriella's Book of Fire

title: Word for Word/Variety 'Slanguage'; Show-Biz Tubthumping: How to Tell The Socko From the Whammo
description: LET'S face it: ours is an entertainment-obsessed culture. The Grammys, the Oscars, Hugh Rodham -- we eat this stuff up.

title: Not About AIDS. It's About Moving On.
description: JUST off the Bowery in a studio warmed with portable heaters, the choreographer Neil Greenberg was mapping out dance phrases with Paige Martin and Antonio Ramos. As the taped voices of Ray Charles and Betty Carter sang ''Baby, It's Cold Outside,'' the dancers executed wavelike movements that gradually accelerated and spun outward, chasing space even as the music faded out. This new work, titled ''Construction With Varied Materials,'' will have its premiere on March 7 and will run through March 10 at the Kitchen in Chelsea.

title: Trading Talent Today For a Better Tomorrow
description: On the surface, the Atlanta Hawks, the Detroit Pistons and the Washington Wizards parted with much better players than they received at Thursday's trading deadline.

title: Titles for Farrell And St. Joseph's
description: Monsignor Farrell repeated as the boys' titleholder and St. Joseph's-by-the-Sea defended its girls' crown yesterday in the Staten Island high schools indoor championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.

title: Aboriginal Artist Faces Attitudes in Her Culture
description: Tracey Moffatt

title: The Nation: Tax Fight; Where George Bush Leads, Who Will Follow?
description: PRESIDENT BUSH was back on the campaign trail last week. This time, however, he was running not to win a job, but to show he could be effective in the job he had won. He wanted a sweeping tax cut -- $1.6 trillion over 10 years. And he strove to convince Americans, along with a critical mass in Congress, that his plan was both fair and prudent.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: 'The Grammy Award-Winning . . . '
description: On hold for the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's box office, ticket buyers hear a tape of Dvorak's New World Symphony, with a new voiceover about the Grammy-winning orchestra. Last week Dvorak was part of the orchestra's first Grammy Award, for its Delos recording of his Requiem, with the Westminster Symphonic Choir. The award, for best engineered classical recording, is the orchestra's first, and a tribute to the acoustics of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, where the CD was made. There were only two recordings in the orchestra's 71-year history before Zdenek Macal became music director, bringing an exclusive recording contract with Delos International. In the last six years, the orchestra has made five recordings, three of works by Dvorak, and more are planned. Leslie Kandell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, SAMUEL I.
description: LEWIS-Samuel I. Age 92, on February 23, of Wayne, NJ. Survived by his wife Lillian, his children John and his wife Florence, Marjorie, Steven and his wife Patti, 18 grandchildren and seven greatgrandchildren. Services on Monday, 11 AM, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt 4 (East), Parmamus, NJ.

title: DROPPING OUT WITH/Susan Cianciolo; Confronting Reality, Designer Packs It In
description: IN the late 1990's, Susan Cianciolo was living the dream of every starry-eyed fashion student who had ever been stuck three-deep in a Williamsburg apartment or waited in line in the rain for standing room tickets to Seventh on Sixth.

title: Also in St. Paul . . .
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Pataki Is Man Behind Curtain, Trying to Keep The Bills Down
description: As sharply higher electric bills have hit New Yorkers over the last year, Gov. George E. Pataki has taken a number of steps behind the scenes to address the problem. But he has largely avoided discussing the issue publicly.

title: Travel Advisory
description: GARDENS IN ALL VARIETIES

title: R. W. White, 96; Put Focus on Personality
description: Robert W. White, a Harvard psychologist who brought a historian's perspective to the study of personality, died on Feb. 6 at a nursing home in Weston, Mass. He was 96 and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: Funds Watch: With a Focus on Israel, It's Business as Usual
description: The combination of acute political tension in the Mideast and a meltdown of the Nasdaq composite index has not dissuaded the sponsors of a new mutual fund that invests in small Israeli technology companies that trade on Nasdaq.

title: 'Prince Igor': Who Cares Who Wrote It? What Does It Sound Like?
description: HOUSTON -- NOT long ago, I sold two chairs: a grim mid- 19th-century Victorian pair with hints of the gothic revival style. I didn't remember them from my childhood, I found them ugly, and so I was happy to turn them over to my friend the antique dealer. Her questions were: Who owned them? Where did the owners live and when? How did they come to you?

title: Min Okubo, 88, Dies; Art Chronicled Internment Camps
