description: Min Okubo, a Japanese-American artist who recorded in 2,000 drawings and a book what she saw and felt as an internee in American detention camps for Japanese and Japanese-Americans during World War II, died on Feb. 10 in Manhattan. She was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLSON, ERWIN ''NICK''
description: NICHOLSON-Erwin ''Nick''. On February 21, 2001. He was the Executive Producer of the daytime drama The Edge of Night for 20 years. He won an Emmy for the show in 1972, the second Emmy every given for a daytime drama. Before joining The Edge of Night, Mr. Nicholson directed the daytime dramas Brighter Day and The Secret Storm. In 1997, Mr. Nicholson brought his extensive experience in the television industry to the National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. In 1994 The New York Chapter of NATAS presented him with the Silver Circle, an award for distinguished television professionals. Donations in his memory can be made to the Actors Fund in Englewood, N. J.

title: A Desire To Duplicate
description: I read with great interest Margaret Talbot's article on cloning (Feb. 4). To those who would argue that human-cloning research should be halted, I must ask whether we consider ourselves so untrustworthy that we would avoid knowledge just to preclude the possibility of its misuse. What does this fear say about us?

title: Letters on Travel
description: AWAY TO TAHITI

title: When Articles on Hastings Prove to Be Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKELMAN, A. JOSEPH. RABBI
description: HECKELMAN-A. Joseph. Rabbi. 75. It is with deep sorrow that we mark the passing of our dear husband and father (may his memory be blessed). Yet we are comforted by the richness of his life and by the effect he had on the lives of others. He was the son of committed Jewish parents, Jack and Anna Heckelman, of Brooklyn, NY. Joe served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and earned a degree in electrical engineering from Columbia University. He put his radar expertise to use when he and his young bride, Tziporah, volunteered to serve in the Israeli Army during Israel's War of Independence in 1948-49. Upon returning to New York, he joined his father's business, the Olympic Glove Company, and took the helm following his father's death. At age 35, Joe decided to study for the rabbinate. He graduated from the Jewish Theological (Conservative) Seminary and was ordained in 1966, becoming Rabbi at Temple Beth El in Waterbury, CT. Ten years later, he and Tziporah made ''aliyah'' to Safed, Israel where they founded Kehillat Shalva, the first Conservative synagogue in Galilee. He was Kehillat Shalva's spiritual leader for 24 years until his death on February 1, 2001, Tet Shvat, 5761. His wife Tziporah, his brothers Sol and David, his son Yaqub (Joshua) and daughter Sara survive him. His children are both living in Jerusalem. Those wishing to make donations can contribute to a fund created in his memory to enable Kehillat Shalva to continue in its current location: Keren Yosef, C/O Kehillat Shalva, P.O. Box 1195, Safed, Israel. A memorial service will be held on March 4 at 11:00AM at B'nai Shalom Synagogue, 135 Roseland Avenue, Waterbury, Connecticut 06710.

title: The Persistent Charm Of 'Time and Again'
description: To the Editor:

title: Schedule Is Shuffled Again
description: For the second straight day, officials were forced to cancel a men's World Cup race at Snowbasin, where more than 18 inches of snow fell in the last 24 hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNN, ALBERT A., III.
description: DUNN-Albert A., III. Of Wilton, CT. Beloved husband of Michele Miles Dunn and son of Janet Dempsey Dunn. Loving father of Heather, Miles, Timothy and Caroline Dunn. Brother of Dr. William Dunn, Rosemary Haase and Irene Woodham, and Ellen Doyle. Mr. Dunn was a ship broker with Odin Marine in Stamford, CT. Calling hours will be held Sunday, February 25, from 3-5 and 7-9 PM, in the Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St, New Canaan, CT. Funeral will be held on Monday, in Wilton, 11 AM, at Our Lady of Fatima R.C. Church. Burial will be private. Contributions to Visiting Nurse and Hospice Care, 1029 E. Main St, Stamford, CT 06902.

title: Christina Maddi, Riaz Haidri
description: Christina Margaret Maddi, a daughter of Theresa and Peter Maddi of Chester, N.J., was married there yesterday to Riaz Haidri, the son of Shamima Haidri of Florham Park, N.J., and Dr. Nazar Haidri of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Lancelot Reis performed the ceremony at St. Lawrence Roman Catholic Church.

title: Naked Boys Auditioning
description: ON a recent chilly afternoon, in a basement theater on Seventh Avenue South, six nervous young men were stripping for nine fully clothed men and one fully clothed woman.

title: A 'Miracle,' But Maybe Not Always A Blessing
description: RISING productivity is a wonderful thing. Income and living standards improve when companies find ways for their workers to produce more in each hour they spend on the job. But sometimes surges in productivity backfire, and this may be one of those times.

title: If It's Big, It's Not a Big Deal
description: SOMETIMES, it seems as if the whole world has been shrunk to fit into a Fendi Baguette. And while the Baguette's popularity wanes, the taste for micro products continues. Even wholly portable objects have been minified: Altoids mints reduced to dots; Harper's Bazaar in a new diminutive Pocket Bazaar version of itself. Here is a look at what's big in extra-small.

title: A Very English Risk Taker in a Play-It-Safe World
description: ANY new movie directed by John Boorman has to be considered an event, in part because he makes so few -- ''The Tailor of Panama'' (opening March 30) is only his 14th feature in more than three-and-a-half decades of filmmaking -- but mostly because a picture with his signature on it is pretty much guaranteed to be different: different both from every other Boorman work and from whatever else is passing for cinematic entertainment at the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKMAN, LOUIS
description: DICKMAN-Louis. Passed away On February 5th, 2001. Beloved husband of Mollie Dickman. Father of Mark Dickman, Michael and Darlene Dickman, Richard and Kim Dickman and Howard and Martie Dickman. Grandfather of Ryan and Mindy Dickman, Chris Dickman and Stephen and Julie Dickman. Louis was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. He retired from The New York Times after forty-one years of dedicated service. You will always be forever in our hearts.

title: San Simeon, Circa 1943; The Castle Rocked
description: At the anniversary party for Sir Charles and Lady Mendl, Harry Crocker had given me an invitation on behalf of Mr. Hearst to visit San Simeon. I told Mother [Bemelmans's pet name for Lady Mendl, Elsie de Wolfe] that I had accepted, and was very interested to see the man and the establishment.

title: He's 'Mr. L.A. Theater' To Friend and Foe Alike
description: IN his small, cluttered office across the street from the Music Center, Gordon Davidson glanced at a fistful of pink telephone message slips that had piled up during lunch hour. The numerous calls from New York producers had to be returned soon because of the three-hour time difference. A board member of the Center Theater Group -- which includes two theaters, the Mark Taper Forum and the Ahmanson -- was en route for a meeting. Associates had questions about Peter Parnell's new play ''QED,'' in rehearsals at the Taper.

title: Children's Services Guide Compiled
description: LIKE most major cities, Yonkers has many organizations that deal with the needs of children. But there is no single agency that coordinates their activities.

title: Age: 38. Fastball: 96. How Does He Do It?
description: As a pitcher ages, all those thousands of fastballs take their toll. There is microscopic tearing. Fluid leaks. Cells are damaged. Calcium builds up. The legs weaken, the arm slows, and eventually, a 96-mile-an-hour weapon becomes an easy target for hitters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELIHER, AGATHE S.
description: KELIHER-Agathe S. Died in Meadowbrook, Pennsylvania on February 18 at the age of 102. Born in Kansas City, MO in 1898, she lived 95 years in Brooklyn, N.Y. before moving to Meadowbrook. Widow of Francis T. Keliher. She is survived by a daughter, Agathe Crouter of Philadelphia and a son, Frank of Washington, D.C., 3 step-grandchildren and 6 step-great-grandchildren. Funeral services and burial are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDHOFF, ARNOLD, J.
description: FRIEDHOFF-Arnold, J. The Silberstein Aging and Dementia Research and Treatment Center of the New York University School of Medicine mourns with profound sorrow the death of Professor Arnold Friedhoff. For more than a quarter of a century, Dr. Friedhoff was the Director of the Millhauser Laboratories at NYU Medical School. He was a wonderful inspiration for us. His vast knowledge and wisdom were always available to the many researchers who sought his assistance. He worked unstintingly to advance the understanding and treatment of mental illness. We send our deepest respects & sympathies to his family.

title: Confronting Their Darkness With Dance
description: THE dark-eyed, cinnamon-skinned woman, posture perfect, stood before the dancers gathered in a practice room at Trinity College in Hartford. In halting English, she told them of her country, Chile, and its national dance, the cueca. She told them of the cueca's history as a courting ritual, all passionate, sensual movement. And she told of when it changed -- when sons and daughters were taken from their homes by the Pinochet regime, tortured, killed, vanished -- and the cueca became a mother's dance of mourning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANITA
description: MILLER-Anita. 83, of Holmdel, on February 23, 2001. Born in NYC. Longtime resident of Brooklyn. A 1949 Hunter College Graduate. She was a Medical Librarian for the State University of NY Downstate Medical Center. Services private. For info contact the Holmdel Funeral Home, 26 South Holmdel Rd., Holmdel, NJ 07733.

title: Composing Digitally
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, HELMER
description: JOHNSON-Helmer. Died in Washington, D.C, February 23, 2001. Age 88. He was the husband of the late Ramona Louise Grattan, father of three sons, Grattan, William and Craig, and grandfather of Lindsey Elizabeth. He was Attorney at the Justice Department from 1939 to 1946. He later practiced in New York at the firm Willkie Farr Gallagher and Fitzgibbon until retirement in 1978. He will be missed. Private memorial plans.

title: Opening a Window on the Universe
description: AT 45 degrees, it was a chilly November evening in the hills above Oakland, Calif., yet I waited in line patiently with 300 others for nearly an hour to peer at a bunch of sparkly dots that resembled a tiny pile of granulated sugar. One by one, we filed into a silver-domed observatory and climbed a ladder to look into the lens of a 20-inch telescope named Rachel, one of the largest refractors in the western United States open to the public. Tonight's target was M-15, a group of about 250,000 stars almost 40,000 light-years away. To put it into mind-boggling perspective, one light-minute is equal to a little more than 11 million miles, and despite this almost unfathomable distance, M-15 is still within the Milky Way.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Bestfoods Baking Is Sold To Canadian Food Giant

title: Monica Schadlow, Keir Buckhurst
description: Dr. Monica Barbara Schadlow and Keir Buckhurst were married yesterday at the Colony Club in New York. Robert M. Levy, a magistrate judge of Federal District Court in Brooklyn , officiated.

title: Inside Ride; Love On Wheels
description: I always liked the look of those cars. ''Jaunty'' is the word I'd use, if I only had one -- the jauntiest car on the road. The car's alert, optimistic face reminded me of a dog's when you get home -- happy to see you, determined to go out. It became a game, spotting those cars, and wouldn't you know it, those cars turned up in the most promising places: squeezed into an illegal spot outside the diner in Newport, R.I.; parked, at a rakish tilt, beside a TriBeCa bar. They weren't hard to spot, those cars. They came in 70's browns and golds, true reds and navy blues and most famously, in the happy colors of some psychedelic joie de vivre -- the so-called safety colors: orange and fluorescent yellow and mint green -- as if to say, ''Don't take us too seriously.'' And how many cars can say that?

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: U.S. Charges Present a Paradox: the Pious Spy
description: For a man accused of betraying his country to the godless leadership of the Soviet Communist Party, Robert Philip Hanssen could not have seemed a more devout follower of the Roman Catholic Church -- or a more committed anti-Communist.

title: Away to Tahiti
description: To the Editor: We traveled on the very same cruise as Ann Costello, who wrote ''Running Away to Tahiti'' (Feb. 4) about her trip on the Paul Gauguin, operated by Radisson Seven Seas Cruises. We enjoyed many activities that she did not mention. Swimming in the lagoon of Bora-Bora, among the stingrays, is truly an exercise in splendor. Watching sharks eat through your snorkeling goggles is also something to relate to the world. We hung onto a rope within three yards of the sharks as they were fed by the guide.

title: Like Father, Like Son
description: Lamont Wilder knew there was trouble last September when his 5-year-old son, Sheemie, entered the Bronx barbershop alone, dragging a duffel bag. In the bag was a letter from the boy's mother, Kisha Reynolds. ''Show him how to be a good, responsible man,'' she had written.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Lives on the Line Dispatches From the U.S.-Mexico Border. By Miriam Davidson. University of Arizona, cloth, $35; paper, $17.95.

title: Deborah Goldfrank, Justin Wender
description: Dr. Deborah Jessica Goldfrank, a daughter of Jane Goldfrank and Dr. Jack C. Goldfrank of Columbus, Ga., was married last evening to Justin Bellows Wender, the son of Phyllis and Ira T. Wender of New York. Rabbi Mychal Springer officiated at the TriBeCa Rooftop in New York.

title: President on Board (But From Farther South)
description: As soon as the outcome of the election last fall was clear, speculation on the boardroom potential of departing administration officials began -- all the way up to Bill Clinton.

title: New York Faces Prospect Of Its Own Energy Troubles
description: For New Yorkers, the electricity crisis in California may seem a continent away.

title: Rental Season For Summer Stays Hot
description: APPROACH David Jones, a broker with Prudential Connecticut Realty in Old Lyme, Conn. and tell him you have $15,000 to spend on the rental of a summer house on the coastline of Long Island Sound, and he will respond ever so politely, ''That's nice, but I have nothing left.''

title: More Space for Children to Swing a Bat
description: Little Leaguers celebrated an early victory two weeks ago when the Battery Park City Authority agreed to build two green ball fields with stadium lighting along Warren Street on the north end of Battery Park City.

title: An Italian Crooner Of Restless Songs Is All Over the Map
description: WEATHERED and savage and festive all at once, Paolo Conte's face is a virtual Italian cultural caricature -- part Florentine fresco, part Venetian carnevale mask, with a nose straight out of Dante. When he opens his mouth to sing, though, Mr. Conte both embodies Italy and transcends it. His songs, redolent of vintage American jazz and South American tangos, German cabaret and French chanson, conjure voices from all over the map as channeled through the ancient soul of an Italian poet. Horace, Virgil and no doubt Dante himself probably had faces like Paolo Conte's. But Mr. Conte's music is his own.

title: A Strange Universe in 'Unhappy Woman'
description: THE advance publicity for ''An Unhappy Woman'' called it ''a dark, romantic comedy,'' but don't let that fool you; this hilarious new play at the New Jersey Repertory Company is no ''You've Got Mail'' with a murder thrown in. Probably the press-release writer just resorted to ''dark, romantic comedy'' out of desperation, because frankly, ''An Unhappy Woman'' is almost indescribably bizarre. And that's a good thing.

title: Do Cell Phones Belong in the Car?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dana Margalit, Saul Teplitsky
description: Dana Ester Margalit, a daughter of Sabina and Moshe Margalit of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married on Thursday evening to Saul Phillip Teplitsky, a son of Sylvia and Michael Teplitsky of Cedarhurst, N.Y. Rabbi David Sternberg officiated at Marina Del Rey, a catering business in the Bronx.

title: February 18-24; Veterans Win Medical Care
description: When the government needed men for World War II, it promised them free lifetime medical care if they stayed in the service and retired after 20 years. But in 1956, Congress cut back coverage, and in 1966, military retirees were told to rely on Medicare. A Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the government had broken a contractual obligation to the retirees. The government, it said, can change benefits for future retirees but cannot unilaterally amend contracts it entered into decades ago. The ruling applies to two men, but could help many more if the case is certified as a class action. Robert Pear

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: COMING TO BIRTH

title: Inside Insiders; Two For The Rolodex
description: Meet Alex and Magda Berliner. You've probably never heard of them. But Tom Hanks knows who they are. So does Tom Cruise. And Jeffrey Katzenberg. And every other studio head, publicist and star in Los Angeles who cares about image. The Berliners are Hollywood's ultimate inside couple. They get to see stars in their homes and in their underwear. And they get paid to do so.

title: Swiss Bristle at New Blast at Their Banks
description: GENEVA, Feb. 24  Swiss bankers and officials are bristling once again over accusations, this time from neighboring France, that the country is an international haven for dubious money dealings.

title: There's No Cure Like Travel
description: The 21st century may be an age of jet planes, bullet trains and automobiles that sense trouble, but one thing appears not to have changed from the days of the sailing ship and the covered wagon: Travel is still the stuff of adventure and a source of laughter and lessons.

title: Modern And Chinese: No Oxymoron
description: UNTIL the 1980's, modern dance was a mysterious art form in China, existing underground, if at all. The Guangdong Modern Dance Company, the first modern troupe in China, did not present its official debut concert until 1990, but its roots go back to 1986, when Chiang Ching, a choreographer, performer and former actress, was asked to judge a choreographic competition in Beijing. Ms. Chiang accepted the offer in the hope that the winners would gain scholarships to study at the prestigious American Dance Festival. The scheme worked.

title: Quick Lessons in the Fine Old Art of Unwinding
description: GOT stress?

title: Habitats/East 49th Street; In Penthouse, a Decorator Takes Out the Built-Ins
description: IT was a three-story penthouse with spectacular views, and yet when Steve Lyons first saw it, he felt closed in. Access to every window was blocked by built-in furniture and cabinets.

title: A Supermarket For Natural Shoppers
description: A new supermarket at 250 Seventh Avenue in Chelsea promises that everything it sells, from eggplant to dishwashing liquid, is produced naturally. ''You don't have to read labels here,'' said Otto Leuschel, general manager of Whole Foods Market, which is the first New York City outlet of the Austin-based Whole Foods Market national chain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCKER, JOAN (NEE SAPAN)
description: BLOCKER-Joan (nee Sapan). On February 23. Loving wife of Marvin. Beloved mother of Ellen (Leonard), and Robert (Christine); cherished grandmother of Gennifer and Bradley. description: GILBERT-Sue. Beloved wife of the late Vic. Loving mother of Judy Goldstein (Julian). Cherished grandmother of Terri and Wendi.

description: A recent incident exemplifies the attitude that Rosen describes. A couple recently started parking a new, very large recreational vehicle on the street in front of their house, much to the dismay of many who live in my neighborhood. As neighbors talked about solutions to the problem, the most frequently discussed options were appeals to institutions that might have some legal power.

description: Regards to Broadway, Heart in San Francisco

description: What if you held a terrorism trial and the main defendant never showed up?

title: Shakespeare in Michigan -- Big Time
description: THE living climb ropes and ladders, the dead dangle from them. A liver is cut out, a tongue thrown aside, a severed arm gloatingly waved at its owner by Joan of Arc.

title: If It's Big, It's Not a Big Deal
description: SOMETIMES, it seems as if the whole world has been shrunk to fit into a Fendi Baguette. And while the Baguette's popularity wanes, the taste for micro products continues. Even wholly portable objects have been minified: Altoids mints reduced to dots; Harper's Bazaar in a new diminutive Pocket Bazaar version of itself. Here is a look at what's big in extra-small.

description: The smell of incense permeates 9 Second Avenue, a dark brick structure nestled on Houston Street behind the Liz Christy Bowery-Houston Garden. The Ma Jou Miu Taoist Temple has been housed in the building since 1986, but its days there may be numbered.

description: THE six women hang from their heels on a trapeze, balance tree branches on their chins and flip backward through hoops held high, but what they do isn't exactly circus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, BERNARD M.
description: EPSTEIN-Bernard M. On Saturday, February 17, at age 82, residing at Evergreen Woods, North Brandford, CT. Beloved husband of Ada M. (Bernstein), brother of Inda Goldfarb of Marlboro, NJ. Devoted father of Drs. Adrian, Jay, Rochelle (Rogart), and Serle Epstein. Caring grandfather of eight splendid grandchildren. Services Tuesday, February 20, noon, at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Request no flowers. Donations may be rendered in his memory to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 W. 168th Street, NYC 10032-9982.

description: GUITON-Jacqueline. Age 51, of Bryn Mawr, PA, on Tuesday, February 20, 2001. Survived by her parents Jacques and Margaret Otis Guiton, her sister Nicolette, brother John, sister-in-law Linda and niece Sophie. Memorial service to be held at a later date.

title: Soap Opera Actor Arrested on Drug Charge
description: A 56-year-old veteran actor who has appeared on the ABC soap opera ''All My Children'' for many years was among two dozen men and women arrested early yesterday in a drug raid at an illegal social club in the East Village, the authorities said.

description: GABRIEL'S STORY

title: A Desire To Duplicate
description: Your article creates a frightening picture of genetic research and cloning by presenting these issues almost exclusively through the extremist views of a sect called the Ralians. Talbot quotes the sect's founder, a former race-car driver, who predicts that the cloning of infants is a first step toward the ultimate goal of eternal life: ''The next step will be to make it possible to clone directly an adult person and not a baby.'' No legitimate scientist believes such a feat is possible now or in the future. Relying on the Ralians instead of on scientists knowledgeable in genetics, for an article on cloning, is like basing an article about space exploration on conversations with U.F.O. cultists instead of on astronauts and engineers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIEGELBAUM, JERRY
description: ZIEGELBAUM-Jerry. At the age of 81, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Violet for 55 years. Devoted father of Ira and Philip and father-in-law of Joanne. Cherished grandfather of Sara and Josh. Services Sunday, 12:15 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIMMELL, VIVIAN FLAKS
description: HIMMELL-Vivian Flaks. Age 96, on February 23, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Samuel S. Himmell and devoted mother of Joanne Dann and Barbara Springer; son-in-law Nathaniel Springer, sister Evelyn Kossin, brother-in-law Benjamin Kaplan, grandchildren Jonathan Dann, Patty Dann, Priscilla DannCourtney, Katherine Eaton, Tom Springer and William Springer. Eight great-grandchildren. She was selfless person loved by all. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, 6-8 PM with services Monday, 11:30 AM. Interment Mt. Pleasant Cemetery.

title: The Harvard Godfather Who Lives to Provoke
description: ROBERT BRUSTEIN was convinced he had hit pay dirt. ''I think he's the real McCoy,'' he was saying as he sat in his office in the repertory theater he established more than 20 years ago on the campus of Harvard University. ''I couldn't pull myself out of the play: a deep lake. I was so absorbed. It reminded me of ' 'Night, Mother.' ''

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: A Night's Stay For $80 or Less
description: ALONG America's roads today, drivers seeking modestly priced places to stay can encounter a bewildering variety of chains. There are 120 different chain names in the economy and midscale categories, as ranked by Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn., which monitors the hospitality industry. The two categories combined have average rates under $80 a night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEROY, WARNER
description: LeROY-Warner. On February 22, 2001 at age 65. Entrepreneur, designer and noble friend. Beloved father of Bridget, Carolyn, Max and Jennifer. Cherished brother of Linda Janklow, Brian and Quentin Vidor. Devoted Grandpa to Georgia, Joelie and Bing. You will always be a star! Services Monday, February 26th at 10:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017, or New York Presbyterian Hospital, Department of Medicine, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Visitors Program Takes the Edge Off Loneliness of Later Years
description: TUESDAY afternoons Elisabeth Pohl, 84, spreads a flowery tablecloth over her coffee table, sets it with china, puts cookies on a plate and waits for Marianne Davis to come. They visit each week in Ms. Pohl's Scarsdale apartment, where the walls are covered with family photos, pressed flowers and paintings of faraway places.

title: February 18-24; Britain's New Meat Problem
description: Anxiety over the health of Britain's animal herds, heightened because of the battle with mad cow disease, surfaced anew when an outbreak of foot and-mouth disease spread from the southeast to the north, prompting bans on meat exports and on the transportation of livestock to markets. The authorities also urged Britain's ramblers and country-lovers to stay in town for fear they might inadvertently spread the viral disease, which can be fatal to animals but rarely affects humans. Hunting was also suspended. The outbreak came as a crushing financial blow to farmers and deepened the nation's malaise over meat products once seen as staples. Alan Cowell

title: Two Soaves, Anything but Simple
description: Mass-produced soave deservedly gets no respect. Like frascati and verdicchio, two other everyday Italian whites, soave is synonymous with simple, refreshing plonk. But not all soaves are born equal.

Even wholly portable objects have been minified: Altoids mints reduced to dots; Harper's Bazaar in a new diminutive Pocket Bazaar version of itself. Here is a look at what's big in extra-small.

title: Also in St. Paul . . .
description: To the Editor: The State Capitol rated only a passing mention in Neal Karlen's ''What's Doing in St. Paul'' (Jan. 7), but this is a magnificent Beaux-Arts palace designed by the noted architect Cass Gilbert. Free tours are offered daily on the hour, and it is easily reached from downtown.

title: Handling Metal's Archenemy: Rust
description: CORROSION is a complex electrochemical process that results in the degradation of the physical and aesthetic properties of a metal. Rust is a form of corrosion that affects ferrous metals like iron and steel. In the process, oxygen pulls electrons away from the metal, causing it to disintegrate. Some oxidation can occur when oxygen in the air comes in contact with the metal, but in most cases water vapor must be present before any appreciable deterioration can take place. With iron, for example, 40 percent humidity must be present before rust will occur.

title: Millions Eligible For Food Stamps Aren't Applying
description: CLEVELAND  As she weighs bunches of purple grapes or rings up fat chicken legs at the supermarket where she works, Fannie Payne cannot keep from daydreaming.

title: Wheels on This Bus Will Still Stop on 55th
description: Responding to an outcry from elderly Sutton Place residents, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has agreed to keep two M57 bus stops that it had planned to eliminate. Transit officials initially said the stops, on East 55th Street, were too far from the M-57's new layover site, on East 60th Street near the Queensboro Bridge.

title: A Desire To Duplicate
description: Among those most interested in cloning are people with severe infertility problems. The implications are interesting: one might assume that clones of people with infertility problems would perhaps be more likely to have infertility problems, too. The thought of being forever reduced to reproducing only oneself, generation after generation, seems to me a bit like Sisyphus, condemned to push the same rock up the mountain again and again. Who would want such a future?

title: Jones Aims to Make Most of a Second Chance
description: Bobby Jones heard the ribbing from his friends all winter: What was he doing in Class AAA? Wasn't he supposed to be a major league pitcher? What a lost season it must have been.

title: 10 Years Later, Hussein Is Firmly in Control
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 25  Ten years ago, Saddam Hussein looked  at least in the view of the American- led military alliance that defeated his forces in Kuwait  every inch a finished man, another discredited dictator heading for the ignominy of history's rubbish heap.

title: Martin Still Learning Though School Is Out
description: Kenyon Martin, like few of his contemporaries, played four years of college basketball. But once classes were out at the University of Cincinnati, school was just beginning for Martin, the Nets' No. 1 draft pick.

title: How Brooklyn Became New York's Tortilla Basket
description: THE shelves of the Plaza Buena Vista Grocery on Flushing Avenue in Brooklyn are full of imported Mexican goods like grapefruit soda, chili-covered lollipops and fresh prickly pear. The two-pound bags of corn tortillas, however, are local.

title: Anina Rossen, Jeremy Abbate
description: Anina Elly Rossen, a daughter of Karen Rossen of River Vale, N.J., and the late Dr. Stanley I. Rossen, was married last evening to Jeremy Aaron Abbate, a son of Rosemary and Fred J. Abbate of Moorestown, N.J. Cantor Jordan Franzel officiated at the Women's Club of Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: Assisi Restoration On View Through April
description: Every Saturday until April 28, visitors to the Basilica of St. Francis in Assisi can take a close look at a unique puzzle. Its pieces are thousands of fragments of the late 13th-century frescoes that fell from the basilica's vault during a 1997 earthquake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, MARIAN
description: FRIED-Marian. February 21, 2001. Exceptional and adored wife of Irving. Mother of Andrew, Ellenand Alex Helfand. Beloved sister of Helen and Louis Blau and sisterin-law of Betty and Zeke Brenner. Darling daughter of Ruth and the late Arthur Silverberg. Cherished grandmother of Emma and Benjamin. Marian touched all who knew her and will be forever missed by her extended family of cousins, nieces, nephews, students and colleagues at H. Frank Carey High School neighbors and friends. We loved her so.

description: Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik has replaced the official who oversees the Police Department's anti-narcotics efforts, which the commissioner has often called crucial to reducing incidents of reported crime, officials said yesterday.

description: IT was a 100-page lesson in tradecraft, as compelling as any novel by John Le Carr.

description: They called from Los Angeles and Miami. They called from Woodstock, N.Y., and Stamford, Conn. After reading last Sunday about Abraham the homeless dog who scrounged on the streets of Queens, they all wanted to help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLLMAN, DR. ABRAHAM A.
description: OLLMAN-Dr. Abraham A., 84, on February 22nd. He is survived by his son Robert, daughter-in-law Joanne, and granddaughters Jennifer and Leigh. His wife Beatrice and daughter Carolyn predeceased him. A loving father and grandfather. Captain in the U.S. Army. A dedicated dentist. ''Doc'' will be missed by all. Graveside services will be held Sunday, February 25th, 11 AM, at the Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. For further info, contact the I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 800-624-8282

title: Shatter-Proofing The Light Bulb
description: WORRIED about light bulbs that break and scatter their glass dangerously? A new line of shatter-resistant incandescent and fluorescent light bulbs, the Saf-T-Guard by General Electric, will be available in stores next month.

title: DROPPING IN WITH/Matthew Avedon; Showing 'Realness,' Model, 18, Rises
description: THE age of male vanity -- the era that has resulted in L'Oral hair color for men and magazine articles about C.E.O.'s who get oxygen facials -- seems to have wrought little for men who might have the greatest cause to preoccupy themselves with matters of appearance. Here we speak of the injustice that no social movement has arisen to eradicate: the gross disparity between the paychecks of professionally good-looking people belonging to one sex versus the paychecks of those belonging to the other. Female models still take home a lot more money than male models -- sometimes 10 times as much.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, DOROTHY HURT
description: PRICE-Dorothy Hurt. Died on February 22nd after a long illness. She was a resident of Palm Beach, Southampton and New York City. Her three husbands, Malcolm Meacham, Edgar Eyre and Hickman Price, Jr. all predeceased her. She drove an ambulance in New York as a volunteer during World War II, and was president of the Village Improvement Society in Southampton. She was the last surviving founding member of the Bath and Tennis Club and a member of the Everglades Club. She had an identical twin, Margaret, whom she survived. She is survived by a daughter, Marjorie Meacham Meek, a granddaughter, Marina Dunn Nelson, and four great-grandsons, Arvid, Eric and Malcolm Nelson and Jonathan Dunn. There will be a small private reception at her home in Palm Beach later in the spring.

description: CAUSE CELEB

title: Under the Dryers, a Community's Heart
description: GLORIA Nelson, a crossing guard at Public School 92 in Corona, had strolled past the Astoria Boulevard salon four or five times, intrigued by the possibilities but too shy to walk in the door. Then one Thursday afternoon, Ms. Nelson screwed up her courage and entered the world of J. C.'s Hair Extraordinaire East.

title: Parents and Daughter Make Music Together
description: THOSE who read The New York Times's review of Alisa Weilerstein's Weill Hall recital earlier this month -- the headline read ''Debut of a Young Cellist With Energy to Spare'' -- know that the 18-year-old winner of an Avery Fisher Career Grant and various other prizes is an artist to treasure.

title: The Peruvian Revolution Is Being Televised
description: The thick fog creeps into Lima in a B-movie kind of way. It's a Sunday afternoon, winter dark and already time for prime time. Though the multiplex across the street is full of movies, I know that the place to be is here: in my hotel, watching TV, a too-warm room-service ceviche by my side.

title: State Must Decide How to Use Kelda Land
description: TO protect the purity of drinking water, water companies usually try to keep the public off the land around their reservoirs. Now the state government has negotiated a deal with a water company to buy the rights to 15,300 acres and plans to encourage the public to get onto the land -- with their hiking shoes and fishing poles.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Where the Thorny Devil Dwells
description: There's a stunning clarity and vibrancy in Art Wolfe's wildlife portraits that help lift THE LIVING WILD (Wildlands Press, $55) well beyond the typical cuddly-critter and fangs-of-death coffee-table fare. Part of the book's extraordinary power comes from seeing the animals in their natural habitats, often in wide-angle shots, and part of it comes from Wolfe's careful, often haunting, compositions. More than 140 species from more than 40 countries are on display in seven sections arranged according to terrain, from polar and subpolar to tropical, from island and ocean to mountains. Among the more striking images are those of the thorny devil, an improbable-looking Australian lizard covered with spines; baby spectacled caimans floating in vegetation; arresting aerial views of a lone polar bear; and a pod of 34 beluga whales in the Arctic Ocean. There is plenty to linger over in the accompanying essays from eminent scientists and conservationists like Richard Dawkins, George B. Schaller and Jane Goodall, as well as the short text blocks that describe each animal and its prospects for survival. Wolfe also includes his field notes, which provide both technical details and testimony to his patience and brio: with an alarming close-up of an elephant seal, for example, he writes: ''As I cautiously approached this three-metric-ton seal, the bull bellowed out a warning. In the cold temperature, his moist, warm breath was recorded on film. Fortunately, the smell of his breath was not.'' Inevitably, there is an elegiac quality to Wolfe's images -- particularly those of mountain gorillas and other species hovering near extinction. Yet despite the call to arms issued by the book's sobering assessment of global habitat destruction, pollution and overhunting, Wolfe still says: ''This book is not about the species we are too late to save. It is about the species that we still have time to save.'' Scott Veale

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEELIG, KENNETH C.
description: SEELIG-Kenneth C. Cherished husband of Joyce. Adored and devoted father of Anne and Lisa. Loving son of Phyllis and Michael. Beloved brother of Patricia. Passed away suddenly on Friday, February 23, 2001. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', Hewlett, Long Island, 12 noon Sunday.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-25-01: The Ethicist; Taking Leave
description: My wife and I excitedly expect a child this year. Her employer provides paid maternity leave. But she is unsure whether she will want to return to work after the child arrives. Would it be proper for her to take the paid leave and then quit the job without returning? Should she, in that event, repay any of the money she received? anonymous, Atlanta

title: Egypt and the Nile
description: Tourism to Egypt has been in a slump lately, but Americans generally need not fear to go there. And there's not much to cause apprehension in the price of an 11-day trip that combines a stay in Paris, a Nile cruise and a stop in Luxor. Starting at $1,299 a person, based on double occupancy, the Sunny Land Tours package includes round-trip air fare from the United States to Paris, two nights' accommodations in Paris, with continuing air fare to Egypt, a four-night Nile cruise on the Nile Carnival, three nights in a deluxe hotel in Luxor and 18 meals. That rate is good on departures March 15 through 29; from April 5 through May 3, it is $1,499 a person. These rates are subject to a 10 percent service charge, and there is a $20 visa fee and $35 for cruise tips. Call (800) 783-7839; Web site www.sunnylandtours.com .

title: Arbitrating 'Decency'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMELL, ROSE
description: LAMELL-Rose. Beloved mother of Renee Ostroll. Mother-in-law of Scott and Walter. Grandmother of Jerry and Jamie, Alan and Karen, Gary, Ira, Debbie and Michael, and Melissa. Great-grandmother of Aidan, Abigail, Gabriel and Michael. Funeral services Monday, 11:30 AM, at ''Sinai Chapels.''

title: The Nation; It's Up, It's Down: Playing Games With the Economy
description: TALK about a role reversal. There was Alan Greenspan, the last line of defense against irrational exuberance, the dour chaperone ever ready to take away the punch bowl, reassuring Congress that the economy should pull quickly out of its downturn and resume its upward trajectory.

title: Serbia Arrests Fired Chief Of Feared Secret Police Unit
description: Signaling that Slobodan Milosevic and other members of his circle may be detained soon, Serbia's new government announced tonight that the police had arrested the former president's feared secret police chief, Rade Markovic, on suspicion of murder.

title: Peekaboo, I See You Own a Site
description: WHEN Gov. George W. Bush was said to be looking for a running mate last June, his campaign was characteristically mum about his short list. Karl Rove, a longtime Bush adviser, said the decision was being made above his level.

title: Their Notices? Great. Their Shows'? Don't Ask.
description: JANINE LaMANNA is not living in fantasy land. Marla Schaffel is not in denial. They may not have read the reviews, but these actresses are well aware of reality: both are blessed with the breakout roles of their careers in Broadway musicals that have taken a beating, critically and commercially -- Ms. LaManna as the bird Gertrude McFuzz in ''Seussical'' and Ms. Schaffel as the title character in ''Jane Eyre.''

title: Johnny W. Tjupurrula, Aboriginal Artist, Dies at 75
description: Johnny Warangkula Tjupurrula, a founding member of a thriving school of aboriginal painters whose work is increasingly prized in Australia and on the international art market, died on Feb. 12 at Papunya in the western Australian desert near Alice Springs. He was about 75.

title: Baseball Fan Union
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: Nascar Doesn't Linger, and Keeps Its Nerve
description: The Denning family of Springfield, N.J., watched the Daytona 500 together, but after the crushingly final result was announced, 13-year-old Jon went into his room to grieve alone. He sat on his Dale Earnhardt bedspread and stared at a Dale Earnhardt poster on his wall. The man he admired as mysterious and indestructible would have wanted to go out on top, Jon thought; he wouldn't have wanted to retire 10 years after he couldn't win anymore. As sad as he was, that gave Jon solace.

title: The Shrinking Life Span of the Black Sitcom
description: A RECENT episode of ''The P.J.'s,'' the foam-animated WB series set in the projects, ended with two boys reflecting on the duplicitous ways of their elders. ''Promise me we'll never grow old,'' implores the first. The other replies, ''The statistics are in our favor.''

title: Arrests of Youths in Dartmouth Case Leave a Town Searching for Answers
description: With the arrests of two of its own teenage boys in the murders of two Dartmouth professors, Chelsea has been portrayed in the national media as somewhere between an agrarian utopia and a hick logging town. In fact, like so much of this evolving state, Chelsea is so diverse, and so much a mix of the old and new Vermont, that it defies labels.

title: The World; Learning to Fear Putin's Gaze
description: CENTRAL and Eastern Europeans think they have a deeper understanding of Russia and the Russians than anyone else, and given their wretched history since World War II, they should. Now they are deeply concerned about Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, who seems not just to be talking the talk of renewed empire, but walking the walk despite his country's manifold weaknesses.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Just Off I-95, Vietnamese-Thai Food to Please
description: YEARS ago Saigon City was a popular hangout near the Yale campus in New Haven. Then it disappeared. We were pleased recently to find it in new digs, somewhat off the track in Old Saybrook.

title: A Desire To Duplicate
description: I have noticed that in discussions of human cloning, the primary ethical consideration is either ignored or glossed over as incidental. The focus is never on the actual clone. What would it be like to grow up knowing you were merely a duplicate, second best to someone else? Would such a replica be seen as less than a person by others? Would there be a new subgroup, less than human in society's eyes?

title: LIPA Bills Going Up; Supplies to Follow
description: FORCED by events to offset part of the 20 percent rate reduction it enacted when it took over electricity service to most Long Islanders two years ago, the Long Island Power Authority is entering a new phase of bolder actions that it says are necessary to secure the Island's energy future.

title: Church, State And Nonbeliever
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSEN, RANDI BETH
description: DORSEN-Randi Beth. On February 23, 2001. Beloved daughter of Audrey and Max. Devoted and loving sister of Marc, David and sister-in-law of Ellen. Dear aunt of Jennifer, Justin, Zachary, Amy and Carly. May her fighting spirit continue to be an inspiration for all whose lives she touched. She will always be in our memories and hearts. Service Sunday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: For Kosovars, Battle Moves To the Border Of Macedonia
description: Eight days ago, a local television reporter, Snezana Lupevski, and her two-member crew drove into a border village high in the mountains adjoining Kosovo, just 15 miles north of Macedonia's capital. They were acting on a hunch, which within minutes proved correct: they were surrounded by hostile armed men, some in uniform, some in civilian clothes, the first outsiders' glimpse of a new Albanian guerrilla force in Macedonia.

title: February 18-24; Report on Submarine
description: A confidential Navy report raised new, disturbing questions about just what went into the submarine Greeneville's deadly collision with a Japanese trawler. The civilians on board disrupted crew communication and may have blocked a TV linked to the periscope, the report says, and the periscope scan was too quick to pick up a vessel as close as 2,000 yards. One officer feared the surfacing was too rapid, but with guests at his elbow, balked at challenging the captain. Hubert B. Herring

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK BORDERS; A Rock in a Hard Place, Half Queens, Half Brooklyn
description: Ten thousand years ago, a glacier melted and dropped a large boulder in what is now Ridgewood, Queens. There are many such stones in the area, but this particular one would take on a special role and get a special name: Arbitration Rock. It became the centerpiece for a boundary war lasting more than a hundred years and was used to set the line between Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, EVA
description: MEYER-Eva. Young Israel of the West Side mourns the passing of Mrs. Eva Meyer, a distinguished founding member. She was the daughter of the late renowned Rabbi Dr. Jacob Hoffman and a descendant of Torah giants. We extend condolences to her husband Manfred and son David. May the Comforter of Zion console the entire family. Emanuel Gettinger, Rabbi Sheldon Fine, President

title: Ninian Smart, 73, Author and Scholar of Comparative Religion
description: Roderick Ninian Smart, a scholar of comparative religion whose copious writings on the essence of faith informed readers on both sides of the Atlantic, died unexpectedly on Jan. 29 in a hospital in Lancaster, England, apparently of a stroke. He was 73 and lived in Lancaster and Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHNEIDER, LORRAINE C.
description: SCHNEIDER-Lorraine C. February 17, 1955. In ever loving memory. Your sister, Marily

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: BLACKBERRY WINE

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-25-01: Five From Michael Graves; Best Buildings
description: He calls himself a general practitioner, and his wildly varied work -- from Disney's Burbank corporate headquarters to a Target toilet brush -- proves the claim. A week and a half ago, the 66-year-old Princeton architecture professor and president of Michael Graves & Associates received the highest individual honor bestowed by the American Institute of Architects, its 2001 Gold Medal. To mark the occasion, we asked Graves to pick his favorite buildings.

title: Seen in Its Entirety
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, DANIEL L., M.D.
description: HARTMAN-Daniel L., M.D. Died February 21, 2001 at his home in Southampton, NY at age 86 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Joyce, devoted father of Gail and Alison, loving father-in-law of Peter Clark, cherished grandfather of Emily, Alex, Jake and Adam. Private memorial services to be held at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 2247, New York, New York 10116-2247.

title: Torre's Plan Is Long-Term Involvement
description: Joe Torre and George Steinbrenner have had a few conversations about the parameters of Torre's imminent contract extension, but they have still not worked out the length or the amount of the contract. It seems logical that they would prefer to reach an agreement before the season starts to eliminate any distractions.

title: The Play's the Thing, Especially When It Isn't Too Long
description: TWO elementary school boys were teasing each other in the lobby of the Community Theater in Morristown last week about a topic that people their age often find amusing. Put delicately, it involves secretions from the nose. Half an hour later, they and more than 300 other children and adults were immersed in the lusher language and weightier musings of William Shakespeare, as they listened to Hamlet describe man as a ''quintessence of dust,'' death as an ''undiscovered country'' and the sky as a ''majestical roof fretted with golden fire.''

title: Palestinians, Hit by Curbs, Foiled in Use Of U.S. Aid
description: Israel's increasingly strict controls on the movement of Palestinian goods and people are paralyzing United States government economic development projects in the Palestinian territories, American officials here said as Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived in the region today.

title: In Cold Blood?
description: FATAL NORTH

title: Challenging Students to Become Entrepreneurs
description: EARLIER this month, William Barrett stood up in front of Joanne Pesce's ''Business Ownership and Marketing'' class at Half Hollow Hills High School East, in Dix Hills, and introduced Frank Imburgio, a local Web site developer.

title: Rewriting Bach, As Bach Rewrote Others
description: WHEN Gustav Mahler arrived in New York in the winter of 1907-8 to take up his post as principal conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, he came as the champion of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde,'' Richard Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra'' and other immense masterworks, and as the composer of equally monumental symphonies.

title: Rent Rules: Codification Or Stretch?
description: LAST December, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal adopted numerous amendments to the rules enforcing rent laws in New York City and the rest of the state, and some details in the changes it made are causing heated debate. Lawyers who represent landlords say the amendments accurately reflect changes in the law passed by the State Legislature; tenant advocates contend that in some cases the housing division may have overstepped its authority.

title: SOAPBOX; Illuminating the Past
description: IN the introduction to ''Lies My Teacher Told Me: Everything Your American History Textbook Got Wrong,'' the historian James W. Loewen writes, ''Those who don't remember the past are condemned to repeat the 11th grade.''

title: Emerging-Markets Worries Are Not Confined to Turkey
description: ANOTHER emerging-markets crisis erupted last week. But while it rattled many foreign markets a bit, by the time Turkey devalued its currency on Thursday by letting it float freely, it appeared that there would be little lasting fallout from this rocky episode.

title: QUICK BITE/Jersey City; Chicken, the Universal Language
description: I am not fluent in Spanish. I try to speak it with Estela at the office, and with Lzero and Alejandro at my local diner. But throw in an unfamiliar word or a verb not in present tense, and I am lost. So it was with a bit of trepidation that I entered Pollo Kokorico, where Spanish is the primary language of the staff and clientele. The comfortable dcor slightly reduced my apprehension: up front, spinning rotisserie chickens and a lunch counter; in back, tables and hanging plants. Mirrors along both walls give the narrow room a spacious feel. High atop the refrigerated beverage case, a chicken figurine watches over the proceedings. Duly inspired, I ordered filetilos de pollo salteados con pimienta ($5.95), or pepper steak chicken breast (the menu listed English translations of the many Colombian and Cuban dishes). With growing confidence, I requested sopa de ajo (garlic soup). Alas, they were out of it, and my dialogue with the waitress broke down completely. Undeterred, she found another English-speaking patron, who patiently consulted on my substitute soup selection. We picked the hearty and delicious caldo gallego ($2), loaded with white beans, ham and potato. My entree, sauted pieces of chicken, green peppers and onions, with white rice and a choice of red or black beans, was also quite good. There is a wide array of other chicken, beef, pork, and shrimp offerings. Every dish is under $10, and most are less than $6. I was so comfortable by meal's end that I stayed to watch the popular Colombian televison show ''Betty La Fea.'' If only Armando would realize that ugly Betty is, in reality, the ideal woman . . . Jack Silbert

title: MOUNT VERNON: ALTERNATIVE TO PRISON
description: A new Day Reporting Center in Mount Vernon has opened as an alternative to prison for nonviolent prisoners. Selected inmates, many of whom have a history of drug abuse, will report to the center for treatment and educational services. Participants will wear electronic bracelets so the Probation Department can monitor their whereabouts. In its first six months of operation, the program could divert 25 defendants from the Department of Correction. Elsa Brenner

title: Living like a Duke
description: Doris Duke. The Ultimate Heiress. Slim, tall, even without standing on her father's tobacco millions, she loved men, sex, clothes, jewels and intrigue. She loved the erotic and the exotic.

title: He's Rich and Has No Fear of Commitment
description: THE burning question in Nassau County's Republican circles these days is this: Is Bruce R. Bent, a multimillionaire financier who helped invent the first money-market mutual fund, a serious Republican candidate for county executive?

title: Turkey's Turmoil Exacts a Price in the Billions
description: ISTANBUL, Feb. 24  As political tantrums go, the one thrown by the Turkish prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, will go down as one of history's most expensive.

title: New Engine: Different Strokes
description: TRUE to its origins as a small, quirky company that followed its own path, Subaru is one of the few mass-market automakers to use engines of a horizontally opposed, or ''flat,'' design. Subaru's new six-cylinder, like its familiar fours, has this configuration.

title: Parcells-Era Free Agents Costly for Jets
description: Believe it or not, some general managers treat the salary cap as if it were radioactive, avoiding it, completely leaving the job to someone else. But Jets General Manager Terry Bradway has been extremely hands-on with all of the team's recent cap moves, working closely with the team's cap guru, Mike Tannenbaum, since replacing Bill Parcells.

title: Inside Nostalgia; Mudd Quake
description: The letters stenciled on the exterior of the army-green building on White Street read ''MCL: Mudd Club and Lounge.'' Steve Mass, the wannabe impresario, named this space, which he rented from the artist Ross Bleckner, after the physician Samuel Alexander Mudd, who became a pariah by honoring his Hippocratic oath and treating John Wilkes Booth, Lincoln's assassin.

title: Dual Focus: The Ball, the Nest Egg
description: ANGER can be a destructive force, but for Monica Seles, rage over an attempt on her life eight years ago had a hidden benefit. It brought home to her the value of money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, HELEN
description: SPECTOR-Helen. 89. Retired vice principal and executive board memeber of New York schools, died Thursday in Memphis, TN. Burial was Friday in Memphis. Survived by brother Irving Spector of Memphis and sister Bernice Wolman of Copake, NY and Boynton Beach, FL. Life member and past chapter President of B'nai Brith. Volunteer for New York Library, UJA, and Anti-Defamation League.

title: Damage Is Limited In Galpagos Fuel Spill
description: WHEN the oil tanker Jessica ran aground about 500 yards offshore here in mid-January and began leaking fuel, an environmental disaster in one of the world's most delicate habitats appeared imminent. This entire archipelago is a United Nations World Heritage Site and a favorite of eco-tourists because of the rare marine and bird species that have evolved here. Much of that animal life suddenly seemed in jeopardy.

title: PORT CHESTER: VERDICT APPEALED
description: The Village of Port Chester and Mayor Christine Korff are appealing a verdict that awarded $180,000 in damages to a man who said his civil rights had been violated when he was denied a job, said Frances Mary Maloney, the lawyer for the village. The plaintiff, Christopher Bisignano, charged that he was passed over for the $28,000 job of village recreation assistant because his stepfather had campaigned for the mayor's opponents in 1997 and 1999. The mayor and the village are seeking a new trial or the elimination or reduction of the award. Elsa Brenner

title: Tender Care for Sick Children's Siblings
description: EVERY Thursday afternoon, Natalie Manzo, 6, does her homework in the large, homey suite of rooms in the basement of a Hewlett office building. She has a snack, plays with dolls or on the computer and has supper. Later, she romps with the golden retriever and Australian herder dogs who visit each week. And sometimes she gets to watch a movie before it's time to return home.

title: Church, State And Nonbeliever
description: To the Editor:

title: From Bulgaria to New York, via the Army
description: WHEN Dimitri Kovachev was hired by the New York Life Insurance Company in 1999, one of the first people he met was his new boss, Val Ivanov, the managing partner in the Melville office and a fellow Bulgarian.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of addresses and telephone numbers on Feb. 4 with a directory of spring and summer cruises included an incomplete reference to P&O Cruises, supplied by Princess Cruises, a sister company. A spokeswoman says Princess has information about P&O world cruises only; details about all other P&O cruises must be requested from London, at (44-207) 800-2222.

title: Solomon Says
description: To the Editor:

title: Regis's Right-Hand Woman
description: FOR the last several decades, the Fourth of July Parade in Berlin in Camden County has marched stately by Joe and Esther Ripa's house on Broad Street. So every year, the Ripa lawn chairs come out, the beer and soda gets piled on ice in the trash cans and the neighborhood settles in for a parade-watching party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZZI, BENEDICT JAMES
description: RIZZI-Benedict James. Of Garden City, on February 23, 2001. Adored husband of Maxine. Dearest brother of Joseph. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Why to Expect the Best Of an Unexpected Maestro
description: SO, finally, it's over. Lorin Maazel will be the next music director of the New York Philharmonic.

title: Inside Wit; Kaiser on a Roll
description: It has been a subject of historical frustration that the world's greatest extemporaneous wits (Dorothy Parker, Fran Lebowitz, Truman Capote) are invariably surrounded by half-wits. Their best bon mots are too often delivered to the drink- and drug-addled, and lost in the vapid minds of the socialites rich enough to afford their company. Fortunately, Karl Lagerfeld is rich enough to hang out with anyone he likes, and often, the people he likes are journalists, who write his quips down. In the interest of fashion posterity, we've accumulated a few of our favorites, so when anyone is looking for proof of the designer's insight, intelligence and wry humor, they can save a little time. Keep in mind that Lagerfeld can be witty in six languages. -- Amy M. Spindler

title: Yorkville's Foreign Accents
description: LUCA +

title: Celebrating a Sea of Faith, Still at the Full
description: More than two centuries ago, when Brooklyn was a village surrounded by farmland and marshes, a group of Methodists began holding open-air services in what would one day be the heart of downtown. The group included whites, free blacks and former slaves, and for a couple of generations they shared the same church.

title: El Salvador Says Earthquake Aid From Abroad Is Lagging
description: VERAPAZ, El Salvador, Feb. 24  Six weeks after a disastrous earthquake and two weeks after a second major quake, Salvadoran officials say assistance from abroad, especially the United States, is lagging.

title: SOAPBOX; Legal Remedies
description: THE quirk of New Jersey law that allows Donald DiFrancesco to be both interim governor and Senate president might be good medicine for the state. A half a year before New Jersey's Senate president took on a second job -- acting governor -- from Christie Whitman, Mr. DiFrancesco announced that health insurance reform would be at the top of his agenda.

title: The Trials of Rewriting
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Side of Options
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Stojakovic Improving? He'll Prove It
description: When he first came to play basketball in America, Predrag Stojakovic was already aware of the label attached to Eastern European players: ''Soft. I heard this many times.''

title: Arms Control Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: The Persistent Charm Of 'Time and Again'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-25-01: The Machine Age; Cellular Metastasis
description: I'm terrified that some technological breakthrough is going to make cell-phone use possible during airplane flights, and I'll have to sit there, forced to be a voyeur during long, transcontinental journeys. Already when you board a plane there are usually a couple of guys on their phones cramming in a few last minutes of air time before takeoff. They're standing up in front of their seats with the little hands-free wires clipped to their shirts, and they're trying to shimmy out of their jackets without interrupting their conversations. As the plane fills up and the order to turn off the phones approaches, you can hear them talking faster and faster, like a drowning person trying frantically to get a few last gulps of air before being trapped underwater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, SYLVIA
description: GOLDNER-Sylvia. On February 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Jules Goldner. Former President of Goldner Press, a legal printing company in New York. Services Wednesday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: From Podium to Stage, It's Student Power
description: IN one of his folk songs, Tom Paxton posed the question ''What did you learn in school today?'' For J. D. Gersen, a Masuk High School junior from Monroe, the answer might be that he learned how to compose a symphonic piece and will conduct the first performance of it with the Greater Bridgeport Symphony.

title: Facing Police Problems In Nassau and Suffolk
description: Nassau County residents have long suffered with one of the highest tax burdens in the county, due in no small measure to the bloated budget of the county Police Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARP, ELI
description: CARP-Eli. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eli Carp, associated with The Times from 1958 until 1978.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Clive Davis; A Rock Angel Refuses to Fall
description: ''Have fun, Dad,'' called one of Clive Davis's sons, as his father approached the red carpet outside the Beverly Hills Hotel. Mr. Davis, who has been the host of this pre-Grammy gala since 1974, when he founded Arista Records, waved.

title: More Sunshine for Japan's Overworked Students
description: Daichi Zaitsu, a seventh grader, has so much studying to do that he has precious little time to devote to his favorite hobbies: researching passenger jets on the Internet and playing tennis. Still, the 13-year-old thinks that plans to reduce school hours are a horrible idea.

title: February 18-24; Russian Missile Offensive
description: Russia has long insisted that the West does not need new missile defenses. But now it has outlined its own plan to protect Europe from missile attack during meetings in Moscow with NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson. The Russian system, which would comply with the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, would be able to destroy incoming short- and medium-range missiles. Skeptics say the move is nothing more than an effort to draw European support away from the grander U.S. system. But Lord Robertson saw the proposal as an indication that the Russians may be ready for serious give and take. The real test will come this year, after the Americans flesh out their plans for anti-missile systems and arms cuts. Michael R. Gordon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMYTH, JOSEPH PERCY
description: SMYTH-Joseph Percy. On February 14, 2001. Joseph Percy Smyth was born May 24, 1907 in Brooklyn to Katharine Stoothoff Eldert Smyth and the Rev. Joseph Percy Smyth, an Espiscopal minister. He was graduated from St. Paul's School, Garden City; Columbia College, Columbia University, NY with an A.B. degree (1930); and Brooklyn Law School with an L.L.B. (1934). 1935-1937 he worked for Cullen and Dyckman, attorneys, Brooklyn. In 1944 he joined the legal department of Sacony Vacuum, now called Mobil Oil Company. He later went into private practice in Manhattan. He served for fifteen years on the Associate Vestry of St. Bartholomew's Church, where he was married to Virginia Gibbs, 1938. His marriage ended in divorce in 1967. He was a member of the St. Nicholas Society, President of the Society of Colonial Wars, and a member of the New York Social Register. He is survived by three children and five grandchildren. One grandchild predeceased him. A memorial service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, 50th St and Park Ave on Monday, February 26th at 4:30PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 East 50 St, New York, NY 10022.

title: Malta on Fifth
description: Walking around Manhattan is an exercise in serendipity. For instance, the Art Deco lobby of the Empire State Building is the place for a free exhibition on the islands of Malta until March 14. The main exhibit is a uniform of the Knights of Malta of the 16th to 18th centuries; also displayed are examples of the islands' traditional crafts such as model boats and fine lace.

title: Mr. Bush's First Battle
description: After an unusually self-assured first month at the White House, President Bush is certain to get a warm personal welcome Tuesday night when he addresses Congress for the first time. But when Mr. Bush unveils his first budget recommendations on Wednesday, the reception is not likely to be as positive. Until now, he has not had to detail how he intends to pay for his big tax cut while also financing increases for defense and education. He indicated last week that he will urge restraint and even cuts in other areas, something that was not emphasized in his presidential campaign. In other words, once the proposals hit hundreds of desks on Capitol Hill, Mr. Bush and his optimistic White House team, who have shown a sure touch on public relations, will find themselves tested in the legislative arena.

title: Customs Officials Spot Stolen Cars but Don't Try to Stop Them
description: As many as 2,000 stolen vehicles pass by the border station here on their way into Mexico each year, Customs officials say.

title: Asking Americans To Build Their Savings
description: There is no denying that the decade-long economic expansion has enriched many Americans. Yet huge numbers of people have little to show for those years of prosperity, other than the homes they own.

title: Support for Health Care Bill Divided Over Contraception
description: In the fight over legislation requiring insurers to cover contraceptives, the differences between the two sides are so sharp that a choice of words says it all.

title: The Timeless Dance Of Art and Money Takes Center Stage
description: THERE must be a cost!'' Benvenuto Cellini cries to his benefactor, the Duke of Florence, in John Patrick Shanley's new play, ''Cellini,'' about the 16th-century Florentine sculptor. A study of the creative temperament, ''Cellini'' resounds with thematically freighted artist-patron squabbles. In the interest of holding down expenses on a bronze statue of Perseus, the Duke -- a member of Florence's Medici family, noted for supporting the arts -- suggests eliminating one component: the body of the slain Medusa, on which Perseus stands.

title: Editors' Note
description: A music review in Arts & Leisure on Aug. 27, 2000, discussed a Deutsche Grammophon recording of the complete works of Anton Webern on six CD's, overseen and conducted by Pierre Boulez. The review praised the recording highly, although it also cited shortcomings in comparison with an earlier recording of these works by Mr. Boulez, for CBS, now Sony Classical.

title: Toyko Breakfast
description: To the Editor: To add to Elizabeth Andoh's fine article ''Tsukiji Market in Tokyo: Tuna Sold, Tuna Eaten'' (Jan. 14), the market makes the perfect ''first night-morning in Tokyo'' activity for North American visitors. Flights from the United States cross many time zones and usually arrive in the mid- to late afternoon. Many of us awaken between 2 and 5 a.m. with no hope of further sleep.

title: Hale House Opens Shop To Sell Donors' Gifts
description: Hale House, a Harlem charity that cares for babies born with drug- or alcohol-related problems, has opened a children's clothing store at 43 Avenue B in Alphabet City. Dr. Lorraine Hale, founder of Hale House, said the shop opened because the charity was receiving more donations of new and used items than it could use. The store sells only new items -- from booties to bicycles to books -- including some adult items. Prices range from $2 for an infant's sweater to $12 for a child's winter coat. Some clothing is donated by Old Navy and the Gap. Proceeds go to Hale House. ''We are not here to make a profit,'' said Toni McRae, assistant manager.

title: What Kind of Party for the Democrats?
description: The continuing controversy over President Clinton's pardons of Marc Rich and others has placed leaders of the Democratic Party in a quandary. In some ways, the last few weeks have been harder on Mr. Clinton's supporters than even the battle over impeachment. Some have strongly criticized his pardon decisions, and many were embarrassed by questions over gift-taking as he and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton left the White House.

title: Gardens in All Varieties
description: Indoors and out, with or without the groundhog's blessing, flower shows and garden tours arrive in bunches during March and April.

title: Milk, Eggs, Quality Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Melville J. Ulmer; Economist, 89
description: Melville J. Ulmer, a liberal-minded economist, died at a group home in his hometown of Potomac, Md., on Feb. 9. He was 89.

title: Ottoman Odyssey; The Empire Strikes Back
description: Read into it whatever you like, but travel shorthand for a fashion insider's pilgrimage goes something like this: If it's been a James Bond location, eventually the fashionable will go.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMONS, MARJORIE
description: SYMONS-Marjorie, age 92, on February 21. Beloved mother of Lawrence, Richard and Suzanne. Loving grandmother of Felicia, Steven, Kevin, Dana, Jill, Meredith and Matthew, and great-grandmother of Jordan, Aaron, Gaby, Raquel and Brianna. She will be missed by all.

title: Bubbles on the Waves
description: Carnival Cruise Lines has come up with a program to keep the fizz in its cruises. Its adult Fountain Fun Card, an expansion of a similar card for children, is good for unlimited soda. From $14.95 for a three-day cruise to $29.95 for a week; children's cards, $9 to $19.95; tips included. The regular price is $1 a glass. JOSEPH SIANO

title: Footlights
description: Violist Who Sculptures and Carves

title: Kasparov Wins a 3rd Corus
description: Garry Kasparov won the elite Corus International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands, for the third straight time on Jan. 28. This was the first time anyone had achieved such a thing in the 63-year running of this famous competition.

title: OPINION; More Energy, but With Caution
description: INCREASING demand for energy has resulted in a proliferation of proposals for new fossil-fuel power plants on Long Island. Although existing KeySpan generating plants were built decades ago, when nearby development wasn't an issue, all the current proposals are for new sites, and in several cases they are near homes, schools, hospitals, assisted-living residences and athletic fields. There's widespread community concern that these sites will cause a degradation in the health of nearby neighborhoods.

title: Talking Shop (Which Takes In the World)
description: ON a Saturday morning last month, four playwrights whose work is being seen in Off Broadway theaters this year gathered at the Joseph Papp Public Theater to talk about their plays and, as it turned out, other subjects: Kia Corthron, 39, the author of ''Force Continuum,'' which closes today at the Atlantic Theater Company, and ''Breath, Boom,'' at Playwrights Horizons in May; Rebecca Gilman, 36, whose ''Boy Gets Girl'' runs through April 8 at the Manhattan Theater Club; Suzan-Lori Parks, 37, whose ''Topdog/Underdog'' will be at the Public Theater in July (Ms. Parks and Ms. Corthron also each have plays in the current ''Urban Zulu Mambo'' at the Signature Theater Company); and Kenneth Lonergan, 38, whose play ''Lobby Hero'' opens March 13 at Playwrights Horizons (and whose screenplay for the movie ''You Can Count on Me,'' which he also directed, has been nominated for an Academy Award). The moderator was Pamela Renner, manager of editorial services at Variety in New York. Following are excerpts from the discussion.

title: The Challenge of Reimagining the Unimaginable
description: THE Holocaust should not be relegated to unfathomable mystery. It consists of concrete acts of mass murder. Yet anyone who writes about it, or seeks to recreate aspects of it artistically, quickly becomes aware of the formidable barriers it presents.

title: Historic Designation Sought for Staten Island Bungalow Community
description: A coalition of preservationists and historians, riled by the recent demolition of three bungalows in the Spanish Camp community on Staten Island, announced yesterday that it would seek to have a portion of the South Shore settlement designated as a historic district because of its association with Dorothy Day, a founder of the Catholic Worker movement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LARKIN, LEO
description: LARKIN-Leo. A memorial service will be held for Leo P. Larkin Jr. on Tuesday, Feb. 27, at 10AM at St. Vincent Ferrer, Lex Ave & 66 St.

title: Sports of The Times; The N.F.L. Meat Market Opens for Business
description: THE massive Leonard Davis was a striking departure from the norm on Friday afternoon. For starters, size alone made him seem like the largest person in Indianapolis, certainly the largest of the 400-plus players attending the National Football League's scouting combine. Fresh from a grueling battery of physical examinations, Davis, an offensive tackle from the University of Texas, was able to give his exact measurements. Height: 6-foot-5 3/4. Weight: 370 pounds. Shoe size: 18. ''In Nikes,'' he said. One reporter asked Davis if it was true that he weighed 300 pounds at age 13. David nodded in the affirmative. The reporter gasped:

title: The Spin Cycle Around the Globe
description: IN the five years we've been married, my husband, Richard, and I have seldom been home long enough for our place to get dirty, at least by the forgiving standards we've developed independently over many years of being single. He's retired, I can write anywhere, and we've both always wanted to see the world.

title: The Close Reader; The Romance of Real Estate
description: Certain subjects change the way we read fiction. Sex is one, which is why some authors are reluctant to write about it directly. Real estate is another, at least for anyone who has ever ridden the heart-stopping roller coaster of the contemporary housing market. The allure of both comes dangerously close to that of pornography or of books about people you know: your prurient interest in the subject matter threatens to overwhelm your attention to anything else.

title: Powell, Meeting Both Sides in Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Makes Little Headway
description: KUWAIT CITY, Feb. 25  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell stepped into the middle of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today, traveling in an armored van from the elegant King David Hotel in Jerusalem through a barbed-wire crossing into the economic bleakness of the West Bank.

title: The View From/Darien; Wanted: A Rink of Their Own Just a Stone's Throw Away
description: IN the Ardsley Curling Club's bright white rink, Anne Wiggins knelt behind a bull's-eye painted red, white and blue at one end of the ice while her teammate Jim Meinhold awaited instructions at the opposite end before attempting his next shot.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; In Jersey City, an Industrial Park by the Hudson
description: IT may seem that every inch of the Hudson River waterfront in this old industrial city is filling with new office towers or apartment buildings. But a 50-acre patch overlooking the river on the far southern reaches of the shoreline is being returned, after a sluggish start, to the city's roots as an industrial park with up to a million square feet of commercial space.
