title: Hartford Bursts With Color As Garden Clubs Show Off
description: JUST when Connecticut's winter seems endless, the annual flower show arrives to pick up spirits and remind New Englanders that spring is coming soon.

title: RCA BUILDING
description: The RCA Building, a Camden icon topped by an illuminated stained-glass image of Nipper, the RCA Victor dog, will be cleaned of asbestos and turned into 300 apartments under a plan approved last week by the Delaware River Port Authority, which voted to spend $6 million on the plan. The project is to be overseen by Dranoff Properties of Philadelphia, which specializes in reusing aging sites. Steve Strunsky

title: Bush Set to Offer Budget to Slow Costs and Cover Tax Cut
description: President Bush will present his first budget in the coming week, and administration officials say he will use it to show that he can restrain the growth in government spending, pay for his $1.6 trillion tax cut and make good on his promise to overhaul Social Security.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-25-01: Questions for Michael De Luca; Cast Away
description: Q: Except for a job making bagels when you were still living at home, you've never worked anywhere but New Line. What is it like to leave?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Student Survey's Unexpected Lessons
description: When the Village of Ridgewood school district gave an anonymous survey to 2,000 high-school and middle-school students in the fall of 1999, officials sought to peer into teenagers' lifestyles with intimate questions about sex, substance abuse, crime and self-esteem, among other things.

title: Inside Out; Inside Patty's Brain
description: In the interest of science, Patricia Marx, the noted New York thinker, offers a peek into the workings of one woman's cerebral matter.

title: Lisa Freiman, David Fishberg
description: Lisa Ann Freiman and David Benjamin Fishberg, associates at law firms in Washington, were married last evening by Rabbi Mara Zimmerman at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: In Lieu of Manners
description: Jeffrey Rosen's article (Feb. 4) about our increasing use of the courts to settle disputes was both enlightening and sadly true. And yet what has brought about the deplorable condition of the American justice system? Litigation-happy lawyers and a segment of the public that is eager to engage attorneys for the promise of an easy payoff.

title: New Director for Museum
description: THE Hudson River Museum in Yonkers has named Michael Botwinick to be its new director. He will succeed Philip Verre, who left the museum last September to become deputy director of the High Museum of Art in Atlanta.

title: Inside Track; A Star Is Born
description: Laugh if you will, but this is a story about a fashion moment. It happened shortly before Christmas at a party in a swell town house in Greenwich Village. Fashion moments don't happen very often these days -- too many women are too good at looking good too much of the time, or never quite good enough.

title: February 18-24; Behind Mass Extinctions
description: Two theories for past mass extinctions are meteor impacts and continent-size volcanoes. Now, it seems they may be two halves of one theory: the impacts set off the eruptions. Scientists have found chemical traces of a meteor that coincide with a mass extinction 250 million years ago, a pairing of unlikely events they also found at another extinction. Kenneth Chang

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Jane Austen

title: Finding Ways to Save Money on Energy
description: FOR many businesses, heat and electricity account for a large portion of expenses. But, traditionally, if they wanted to trim more than a few kilowatts, they had few ways to get the meters spinning slower that did not involve the risk of electrocution or a theft-of-service charge.

title: Tales of Institutionalization Where an Epileptics' 'Village' Stood
description: At the turn of the last century, the state of New Jersey decided to establish an institution designed for people with epilepsy, who at the time were placed in mental asylums. They chose Maplewood Farmse, a 187-acre plot in Montgomery Township with a 20-room mansion that eventually became the superintendent's home. The grounds, which grew to more than 1,000 acres with dozens of farm animals, was called the State Village for Epileptics. The house, ramshackle and ghostly, still stands, though it is to be demolished. The New Jersey Developmental Disabilities Council and the Epilepsy Foundation of New Jersey would like to renovate it and create a research center about the history of mental institutions in the United States. Norman Reim, communications director of the New Jersey Developmental Disabilities Council, spoke recently about the State Village for Epileptics.

title: Job-Search Site Focuses On Part-Time Openings
description: With more people out of work, job-search sites are becoming more popular. Eparttimejobs.com, based in Scarsdale, is offering a new approach by focusing on part-time job openings.

title: Beam Up My Info
description: THE BIT AND THE PENDULUM

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-25-01; Theme Park On a Hill
description: Once again, Florida has made history. Quite literally made it, in the way that Florida does best, out of fresh concrete and plywood and brightly painted plaster. In a stroke of divinely inspired good timing, a new Orlando theme park called the Holy Land Experience, which lets Disney-jaded tourists make a pilgrimage to ancient Jerusalem for $17 a ticket, opened its gates this month, just as things in the real Holy Land were going straight to hell.

title: In Lieu of Manners
description: Even if Rosen is right that Americans turn to law more frequently nowadays, why should we view that as a bad thing? As he acknowledges, the abstract principles of our evolving legal tradition provide a language to mediate disputes among people who no longer share a broad social consensus (if they ever did). Thus the law can be seen as a terrain of engagement for people from different backgrounds and worldviews to debate social and political mores. And debates framed in legal terms have the advantage of forcing us to acknowledge that there are multiple points of view on any issue.

title: 'Love, Etc.'
description: StuartHello!

title: Two Works That Scream, 'Pay Attention'
description: NO, we must wait here and see what our fate will be,'' wrote the former professor Victor Klemperer in Dresden on Nov. 1, 1941. For the next four years, recording ''the everyday life of tyranny,'' as he described it, became a mission for Klemperer, whom the Nazis stripped of all rights and kept under virtual house arrest. He wrote on loose sheets of paper that he and his wife carefully hid away.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: It is good to hear that Sahara Sunday Spain, who is being raised in artistic splendor, has been blessed with an ''authentic'' voice (''The 9-Year-Old Poet With the Big Advance,'' by Dwight Garner, Feb. 4). But one can only imagine the authenticity of the poems 12-year-old Albert Hubbard, whose brothers are in foster care and who says his mother doesn't know why, might write.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEL, ERIC KARL
description: TURKEL-Eric Karl, 49. Of Old Bridge, NJ, died February 23, 2001 at home after a brief illness. Musician, author, teacher and audio engineer. Survived by his grieving, much beloved wife Barbara, son Matthew, parents Dr. Herb and Dorothea, sister Judith and her partner Jennifer, father-in-law Abe Abukoff, as well as many friends and devoted students. Memorial services will be held next Saturday, March 3rd at 11AM at Trinity Evangelical Free Church, 390 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTONE, HARMON
description: GOLDSTONE-Harmon. The Directors, Officers, and members of the Wyckoff House and Association deeply mourn the passing of Harmon Goldstone, who not only saved the 1652 Wyckoff House from destruction, but also had it landmarked as the first landmark building in NYC. He was also a devoted Director of the Association for many years. We will miss you and thank you for your excellent counsel, advice and devotion.

title: Migrants Flee Borneo as Death Toll Rises
description: Thousands of Madurese refugees scrambled to board a navy ship in the Indonesian section of Borneo today, as the death toll from a week of ethnic clashes in the city of Sampit increased to at least 210, with officials predicting that the number would rise further.

title: Business Jets Light in the Air, but Too Heavy for Teterboro
description: The Boeing Corporation and the Port Authority are locked in a fight over the authority's refusal to allow Boeing's line of big, expensive business jets to land at Teterboro Airport.

title: Family Prayer Meetings Irritate a Town
description: THE Murphy family has been holding weekly prayer meetings in their New Milford home since 1994 with few complaints from their neighbors. Dozens of people often attend, and the street on those Sundays can fill with cars.

title: Illegal Employees
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sidekick Who Is Not Too Much Anything but Pleasant
description: TO those who are not soap opera watchers, Kelly Ripa is hardly the household name she will probably become as co-host of the renamed ''Live, With Regis and Kelly.''

title: A Question Mark at Janus
description: There is more read-between-the-lines news from Janus Capital and its parent, Stilwell Financial. Last week, Stilwell said that about a dozen key Janus executives and fund managers, who hold 197,000 shares of the closely held Janus, decided to exercise options to sell all of the shares to Stilwell for an estimated $200 million. Stilwell also said it would offer to buy as much as half the Janus shares held by a broader group of 150 Janus employees. After the news, Lehman Brothers downgraded Stilwell shares.

title: Attack Sparks Bias Inquiry
description: Two white men attacked a black man outside a restaurant in Queens early yesterday and robbed him after yelling racial slurs at him, the police said.

title: The Rise of the Robo-Ref
description: It's 1 o'clock on a crisp December afternoon, and in his San Antonio hotel room, Danny Crawford, an N.B.A. referee, has assembled his crew. Michael Smith, a seven-year vet, flew in a few hours earlier from Memphis; Jim Clark, a silver-haired veteran, has driven from his home in Austin. The Knicks and the Spurs will take the court in six and a half hours, but the refs are already on the job.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Harlem Journal; Dancer Tries to Save Site of First Hesitant Steps
description: Frankie Manning was 14 or so. He and his friend Herman Jackson were on their way to church in Harlem on a Sunday afternoon. They spotted a group of kids their age gathered outside an elegant building at Seventh Avenue and 126th Street and asked what they were up to. Inside, they were told, was the Alhambra Ballroom. The kids were waiting to go upstairs and dance.

title: Jo Dee Messina: Feisty Country
description: Jo Dee Messina is the country-music belter whose rise to fame has been a slow burn. She broke the mold coming from Massachusetts, and followed an independent path to become known as one of the most solid artists in the genre. You can always count on her for feisty country, with rock (never pop) powerdrive. Being the protg of Tim McGraw doesn't hurt either. While Mr. McGraw's wife, Faith Hill, smoothes out country's rough edges, Ms. Messina slogs her way through. From her first hit ''Heads Carolina, Tails California'' to her uplifting ''That's the Way It Is,'' she comes off as the real deal. She'll perform tonight at 7:30 p.m., at the Washington Township Performing Arts Center. Robbie Woliver

title: Do Cell Phones Belong in the Car?
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: A Forum on Wednesday; Finding Spaces For the Arts
description: The crisis in finding suitable and affordable space for performances, exhibitions and administration that faces cultural organizations will be the topic of a forum to be held by the Arts and Business Council on Wednesday. It will begin at 6:30 p.m. in the Proshansky Auditorium at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue at 34th Street.

title: Science Fiction
description: ''Myth is neither irresponsible fantasy, nor the object of weighty psychology. . . . It is wholly other, and requires to be looked at with open eyes.'' So Gene Wolfe informs his readers in the third volume of his third series of epic tales about faith and its consequences, RETURN TO THE WHORL (Tor/Tom Doherty, $25.95). Some science fiction writers have assumed the mantle of mythmakers to lend substance to what are essentially old adventure stories in new dress. While Wolfe underpins his far-future inventions with references to ancient legends and scriptures, he knows that myths, even at their most fantastic, are stories that once compelled belief. His great achievement is not the complex fictional universe he has shaped over the last two decades but the people who inhabit that universe, especially the reluctant believers like Patera Silk, an unorthodox priest whose faith grows more subtle with every shock to traditional dogma.

title: Big Splash in England For 150th America's Cup
description: On Aug. 22, 1851, a stealthy black schooner named America bested a fleet of Britain's finest ships in a race around England's Isle of Wight. For this mighty upset, America's crew earned a strange, ornate jug that, on looks alone, might have better been left forgotten.

title: Class in a Glass
description: Mass-produced soave deservedly gets no respect. Like frascati and verdicchio, two other everyday Italian whites, soave is synonymous with simple, refreshing plonk. But not all soaves are born equal.

title: This Revolution Is Being Televised
description: The thick fog creeps into Lima in a B-movie kind of way. It's a Sunday afternoon, winter dark and already time for prime time. Though the multiplex across the street is full of movies, I know that the place to be is here: in my hotel, watching TV, a too-warm room-service ceviche by my side.

title: If It's Big, It's Not a Big Deal
description: SOMETIMES, it seems as if the whole world has been shrunk to fit into a Fendi Baguette. And while the Baguette's popularity wanes, the taste for micro products continues. Even wholly portable objects have been minified: Altoids mints reduced to dots; Harper's Bazaar in a new diminutive Pocket Bazaar version of itself. Here is a look at what's big in extra-small.

title: February 18-24; A Chinese Connection
description: President Bush warned China that he was troubled by evidence that Chinese workers were building a fiber-optic network linked to Iraqi targets attacked by American and British warplanes on Feb. 9. The strikes, however, were launched at night on the Muslim sabbath to reduce the risk of killing civilians, including the Chinese. China responded by saying it would ''remedy the situation'' if the allegations were true, Mr. Bush said. Steven Lee Myers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROCH, JOAN
description: MOROCH-Joan, 71. On February 22nd, 2001 of pancreatic cancer. Beloved wife of Howard. Devoted mother of Karen and Henry Altszuler, Michael Moroch and Nancy Barrow, Robin and Ken Zaret. Loving grandmother of David, Amy, Seth, Scott, Dina and Evan. Funeral services Sunday 11AM at Louis Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Pyongyang Memo; North Koreans, Belts Tight, Cobble Up a Future
description: For most of a decade marked by shortages of food, fuel and other commodities North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, has exhorted his people to do more with less. And today, belt-tightening has even seeped into this capital city's fanciest hotel, the Koryo. Lights are kept dim, making it difficult to read. Well-furnished rooms hover just above freezing, warmed by space heaters.

title: Inside Vision; Hot Chicks, Cool Rooms
description: LIBERACE'S LIVING ROOM BY MONTGOMERY PERRY

title: Austria's Versatile Pumpkinseed Oil Never Requires Cooking
description: IN the hills of Styria in southeastern Austria where it is made, roasted pumpkinseed oil is as highly prized as white truffles in Italy. The seeds are harvested from pumpkins in the fall, dried and roasted on millstones and pressed. The result looks like crude oil, a thick, dark green with a mellow, nutty taste.

title: Article 2001022594103220822 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: National News Briefs
description: Florida Woman Indicted After Taking Son to Cuba

title: THE GUIDE
description: Humor in the Mechanics

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Biding Time
description: AS the days get longer, it is hard for gardeners to restrain themselves. The urge to get out and start planting is overwhelming, even if the ground is too wet and the nights are too chilly. Fortunately there are things to do while you wait.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASDON, LAWRENCE H.
description: LASDON-Lawrence H. Age 58 died February 16, 2001, of a heart attack at his home in Palm Desert, CA. A former resident of New York he was a graduate of Florida Southern University and a former member of the NYSE. He is survived by a brother, Rand M. of New York and two sons, Lance and Chad of Los Angeles, CA. Services will be at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue and 81st Street at 1 PM, Sunday.

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-25-01: On Language; Body Man
description: The political lexicon is suddenly being enriched. For years, the man has been the president, perhaps associated with main man, from black English. Now the man has a man of his own with an official job title.

title: Exhibition About Shango in Newark
description: Shango is an orisha, a deity of the Yoruba people in West Africa. The religion was brought to the Americas by West Africans sold into slavery. In the United States, Cuba and Brazil, the religion is called Santeria. Drum rhythms linked to the worship of each orisha have found their way into jazz, gospel and Latin music, including into the music of Desi Arnaz, who invoked the orisha Babalu. An exhibition about Shango, ''Faces of Worship: A Yoruba God in Two Worlds'' will open at the Newark Museum today. The museum will also offer two programs in conjunction with the show. There will also be an ''Honor Your Ancestors'' workshop at 1, 2 and 3 p.m., in which visitors can learn Yoruba traditions and make an object in memory of their ancestors. At 2:30 p.m. Baba Lorisha John Mason will conduct the opening prayers of good beginnings in the African Galleries. At 3 p.m., Dr. Robert Farris Thompson, a Yale professor, will give a lecture about Shango rituals. Afterward, the priestess Ziomara Rodriguez and the Omo'Nago (Children of the Anago) will perform ritual songs, dances and drumming. Margo Nash

title: Newcomer in the Heart of Kebab Country
description: PORT WASHINGTON has long been the kebab capital of Long Island. Ayhan's Shish Kebab is a mainstay there, and it was joined a few years ago by Ayhan's Fish Kebab. Now there's yet another Middle Eastern entry in town. The 60-seat Bamiyan Kebab House, at 82 Main Street (516-883-5056), is trying to stake a claim right in the heart of shish kebab-fish kebab country, which might seem a bit like opening a new neighborhood hardware store next to an established Home Depot. But Assad Rusta, the new spot's owner, is no newcomer to the world of skewers and spices. In the early 1990's he successfully operated the Afghan Samovar in Massapequa Park.

title: Laura Richards, James Naughton
description: Laura Hudson Richards and James Matthew Naughton were married yesterday by the Rev. Douglas Renegar, an Episcopal priest, at Christ Church, Frederica on St. Simons Island, Ga.

title: Not an Imitation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAYSON, ROSALIND S.
description: PAYSON-Rosalind S. Of Southport, CT, died February 21, 2001. She was a residential real estate agent with Nicholas H. Fingelly Real Estate. She is survived by her companion, Charles (Bud) Hamilton Sanford, three sons, Laurence, Blakeney and Eliot Payson, and five grandsons. A Memorial service will be held Friday, March 2, 2001 at 11:00AM at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport. Donations in her memory, Trinity Episcopal Church Restoration Fund, 651 Pequot Avenue, Southport, CT 06490.

title: Rising Trends
description: It's an old clich that when hems go up, so does the stock market. So Wall Street, rejoice: with a few adventuresome women sporting the refreshing look of a long stretch of exposed leg, the miniskirt shows signs of a revival. In the early 1970's, the mini saved the fashion world from the debacle of the mid-calf lengths championed by the press, designers and store buyers. Customers of all ages rejected that dowdy look for the youthful short skirts, as many women believe the legs are the last to go.

title: Waiting for the Numbers That Make a New Map
description: New Jersey will almost certainly not see a black or Hispanic governor for the next several years, but minority representation in the State Legislature may get a boost when district maps are redrawn this spring to reflect the latest population shifts.

title: Some See New Route to Adoption In Clinics Full of Frozen Embryos
description: On the afternoon of Feb. 14, an express courier truck arrived at an Atlanta fertility clinic to make an unusual pickup. Waiting for the driver, frozen inside a thermos of liquid nitrogen, was the promise of human life: 12 fertilized embryos, the genetic offspring of Susanne and Bob Gray.

title: Making a Risky Crossing Safer
description: The Department of Transportation has posted bright yellow signs along Queens Boulevard urging pedestrians to be more alert when crossing the thoroughfare, where two more people were injured in an accident on Thursday. The signs bear a grim reminder of the 73 people who have died on the multilane roadway since 1993. The 400 signs, which went up earlier this month, are at intersections between Eliot Avenue and Union Turnpike, where the boulevard is 10 lanes wide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENDER, THELMA (BELLAK)
description: SENDER-Thelma (Bellak). Devoted wife of the late Samuel. Beloved mother of Carol and Russell Ketcham, Michael and Debbie Sender, Barbara and Joel Metter. Cherished grandmother of Todd, Douglas, Danny and Max. Funeral 1 PM, Monday, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY.

title: For Oysters, Try Eastchester
description: OYSTERS are a meditative food. As they slip down, one is inclined to reflect on their briny origins. An assortment of these luscious mollusks may inspire wonder at the efficiency of natural selection: tiny shells deep and spiny, shells shallow and elongated, shells round and smooth -- all suited to their native waters.

title: Fasten Seat Belts, But Expect a Soft Impact
description: The slowdown in the economy isn't an abstraction for Oneil Taylor. A week and a half ago, it became very real. He was laid off, one of 10,000 employees -- 1,500 in New Jersey -- let go by Lucent Technologies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKS, RICHARD ASHBY FARRIER
description: JENKS-Richard Ashby Farrier, age 20 on February 15, 2001, Indianapolis. Survived by Kathleen Carlton Farrier, mother, Anne Riley Jenks, sister, both of NYC and Thomas Riley Jenks, father and Lucy Honor Edgarian Jenks, halfsister both of San Francisco. Memorial service Monday, February 26, 11am, Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Ave. at 91st St.

title: It's Never Too Late to Accessorize
description: Pauline Trigre, 92 and known for designing timeless clothes, has introduced a line aimed at people for whom time, while fleeting, has not run out.

title: Online Moving Service Settles in White Plains
description: Monstermoving.com, which offers online moving services including house searches, moving quotes and mortgage financing, is moving its corporate head quarters to White Plains. The company, owned by the job search site Monster.com, has already begun operations on the 15th floor of 50 Main Street, and plans to occupy all of the the 15th and 16th floors by August.

title: Is a Battered Dell Ready to Rebound?
description: AFTER years spent basking in the sun of booming sales, makers of personal computers are finding their industry to be a cold, cheerless place.

title: With a Focus on Israel, It's Business as Usual
description: The combination of acute political tension in the Mideast and a meltdown of the Nasdaq composite index has not dissuaded the sponsors of a new mutual fund that invests in small Israeli technology companies that trade on Nasdaq.

title: An About-Face on Domestic Violence
description: LAST November, Acting Judge Thomas A. Dickerson of Family Court here dismissed aggravated harassment charges against a man accused of threatening to kill his estranged wife and his 2-year-old daughter.

title: BEST SELLERS: February 25, 2001
description: Weeks

title: Musical Skills Put to the Test
description: INSTEAD of demonstrating prowess with a ball or puck, the challenge for the competitors is bringing Brahms to his knees, scoring on Purcell, working a power play on Beethoven or slam-dunking Scarlatti.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, JOHN B. III.
description: HAYES-John B. III. On February 22, 2001. All of us at Chapdelaine & Co. are saddened by the sudden death of Jack, our longtime friend and associate. Our sincere sympathies to his wife, Susan, and his children, John, Andrew and Caitlin.

title: Brotherly Love
description: A SPELL OF WINTER

title: F.Y.I.
description: Where Marksmen Met

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, ALBERT
description: BRAUN-Albert. Beloved and loving husband of Roselyn. Loving and cherished father of Willa and Jim Freiband and the late Dr. Eve Klipstein. Cherished grandfather of Linda, Bill, Mindy and Andrew. Loving great-grandfather of Isaac and Jonas. Loving brother of Viola Gotlop. Services Monday, 10 AM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue and Avenue J. Brooklyn.

title: Janis Ian, Beyond 17
description: It might be surprising to some that Janis Ian has been in the music business for longer than such veterans as Billy Joel and Elton John. Her first hit was in 1967, at the age of 15, with the groundbreaking ''Society's Child,'' which tackled the then-taboo subject of interracial dating. Mentored by Leonard Bernstein, the young folk singer was heralded as the female Bob Dylan. Her next enormous hit was as a woman, in 1975, when she released ''At 17,'' a seering look at life from the perspective of ''an ugly duckling girl like me.'' The record sold millions and won a Grammy Award. Since then she has released folk, rock and country albums, dealing with topics from politics to sexuality. She will be performing songs from ''God and the F.B.I.,'' her 17th record, when she appears Friday, at 8 p.m, at William Paterson College in Wayne. Robbie Woliver

title: Cumberland's Peaceable Kingdom
description: HERE'S the problem: in an otherwise congenial relationship my partner, Andrew, and I have vastly different vacation requirements.

title: Facing Police Problems In Nassau and Suffolk
description: The Suffolk County police chief, Philip Robilotto, says: ''I have complete faith in the men and women of this department. At worst there is a handful of rogue people.''

title: Flirting With Disaster
description: Rick Moody wrote ''Demonology,'' the title story of his new collection, in 1995, but he hasn't read it since. ''I don't read it aloud in public,'' he said. ''I can't even physically read one paragraph.'' At the heart of ''Demonology'' is the true story of the car accident that resulted in the death of Moody's older sister, Meredith, a photographer and the mother of two young children, who collapsed at home from a seizure hours after her car ran ''smack into a local deer,'' as the narrator tells us.

title: OSSINING: VULTURE ON THE MEND
description: Officials at Teatown Reservation in Ossining are trying to nurse an ailing vulture back to health. It is a young but fully mature vulture that has two infections and arthritis. Because there is only a 25 percent chance that it will be fully rehabilitated and released, reservation officials will apply to the federal Fish and Wildlife Service to keep him with their nine other birds of prey. The black vulture's presence in the region seems to be increasing -- as many as 30 have been seen around Cortlandt this year. Elsa Brenner

title: Georgetown Takes Step Toward Big East Bye
description: As the game clock wound down today and Georgetown's victory over Syracuse was nearly complete, Hoyas fans chanted, ''Overrated!'' The same could have once been said for Georgetown, but when the final horn sounded at the MCI Center, the Hoyas' players were joined by their mascot and cheerleaders at halfcourt, then by hundreds of students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAY, HARRIET MCLEAN
description: CLAY-Harriet McLean. Of East Hampton, New York, passed away at her home on February 13, 2001 after a long battle with cancer. Piddy, as she was known, was born in New York City on February 21, 1928, to Major Henry C. McLean, of Newburgh, N.Y., and Harriet Peckham McLean, of Albany, N.Y. Piddy will be remembered as an athletic, independent, fun-loving, and glamorous person loved by a strong circle of family and friends. She is survived by two children from her first marriage to Howland P. Rogers of Hobe Sound, Florida: Lisa Rogers Bornstein, of Oakland, CA, and Henry P. Rogers, of San Mateo, CA; five granddaughters, two nieces and two nephews. A private memorial celebration will be held in June. Donations in her memory may be made to the East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978-7048

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, EVA
description: FRIEDMAN-Eva. Of Forest Hills, NY. On February 23, 2001. Beloved widow after 52 years of marriage to Lou. Devoted mother to Adele Vivien Friedman Newman and cherished mother-in-law of Robert Newman. Loving sister of Yetta Banks and sister-in-law to Sol Banks, aunt and great-aunt to numerous nieces and nephews, both in the United States and in England. Respected leader of Jewish community groups and activities. You were our true ''Yiddishe Mama'', and we loved you more than we can say. Whether a button to sew, a meal to make, a mountain to climb. You did it all unselfishly. You were forever young and so we cannot believe that you are no longer here. With you goes a piece of our heart. Mama, no one could have loved a daughter more, and no daughter could have loved her mother more. Services will be held at Parkside Funeral Home, Queens Boulevard, at 2 PM on Sunday, February 25. Contributions can be made to the Senior Program at the Central Queens YM & YWHA, Forest Hills.

title: Access Proved Vital In Last-Minute Race For Clinton Pardons
description: In a speech before the Arkansas Legislature on Jan. 17 on his final trip as president, Bill Clinton described his amazement at the last-minute avalanche of applications for pardons and prison-sentence commutations.

title: An Irish Name, but the Cuisine Is Global
description: I HAVE been to the historic house (circa 1858) at 1441 Old Northern Boulevard in Roslyn so often I could lead tours. The restaurants come and go, but the elegant Art Deco mirrors are a constant. In the last decade, this lovely building has been home to at least six different establishments. (The most recent was Giorgio.)

title: The Nation; Personally Empowered
description: Thursday morning was the first time since Jan. 13 that California was no longer under any officially declared power emergency, but it may be too soon to resume leaving the lights on all day. California's Independent System Operator, which manages the state's power grid, cautioned that long-term supplies remain limited, and the Bush administration insists that a national energy crisis looms. At right, an outline of options for those hoping to avoid future blackouts. TOM ZELLER

title: Appearances; The Star Treatment
description: There is a time in your life when your mother is the most beautiful woman in the world. As you grow older, your beauty paradigm shifts. Looking like your mother is the last thing you want to do. Standards of beauty -- once the domain of goddesses, lovers of great men and your mother -- are now inspired by too many girls named Kate (Moss, Hudson, et al.).

title: Neighbor's Septic System
description: Q: I live in a neighborhood that is not yet served by the city sewer system, so we must rely on septic tanks. The adjoining property owner has neglected the upkeep and maintenance of his septic system for a number of years. The liquid emerging from their front lawn is odorous in the summer and in winter causes large sheets of ice to form on our lawn, driveway and sidewalk. Numerous pleas for them to correct this matter have gone unanswered. Is there any city agency that can be notified of this situation? . . . Rudolph Radic, Staten Island.

title: Political Briefing; Ventura Serves Up A Week of the Jackal
description: Like all politicians, Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota enjoys being in the limelight. But he has a limited tolerance for the people who shine it on him -- or so he professes.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article last week about donations to Planned Parenthood in President Bush's name misstated the surname of a White House spokesman who declined to comment. He is Scott McClellan, not McLennan.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Consideration for the Jury
description: For security reasons, the jury of six men, six women and six alternates is being kept anonymous. And it is not known after the first three weeks of testimony how much they know about one another.

title: GREAT FALLS
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli praised the Great Falls in Paterson as the birthplace of the Industrial Revolution, and Congressman Bill Pascrell called the site ''hallowed ground.'' They were at the falls last week to announce that Senators Torricelli and Jon S. Corzine and Representative Pascrell have introduced legislation that would require the federal Interior Department to study making the falls and the surrounding 118 acres a national park. Such a designation, they say, would bring millions of federal dollars to create museums, draw tourists, and hasten a spotty revival campaign that started after the Great Falls was named a national historic landmark in 1976. The politicians paid homage to Alexander Hamilton, Paterson's founder in 1792, who dreamed of harnessing the Great Falls' waterpower for the fledgling nation's first big manufacturing center. Robert Hanley

title: Rice Fields Cultivate Old Ways
description: FOR much of our childhoods, in Charleston, S.C., the coastal plain between our hometown and Savannah, 105 miles to the south, seemed like a rural backwater. Swamps, sandy logging trails and private hunting plantations were someone else's idea of heaven (we didn't own hunting rifles, nor did we have any desire to). But as we reached adulthood, we came to appreciate the area's hauntingly beautiful landscape, and now, we visit the region's broad marshes and estuaries for an annual late-November kayaking and bird-watching journey in what remains one of the largest swaths of undeveloped land on the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Left Behind in the Real Estate Boom
description: NORMAN JONES said his co-workers at a beer distributor have no idea he lives in the dark hallway of a three-story Hempstead walkup. ''I'm homeless,'' Mr. Jones, 49, said the other night as he clutched a brown bag with clean slacks for work, ''but I'm not dirty.''

title: California Dreaming Updated for the 21st Century
description: ERIC GOODE and Sean MacPherson sat in a Naugahyde clamshell-shaped banquette last week, like post-prom coffee-shop dates, in the main dining room of the Park -- their new 7,000-square-foot, $5 million Chelsea restaurant and lounge. The Park opened on Monday at 118 10th Avenue (18th Street).

title: Here Comes the Neighborhood
description: Everyday People

title: What They Were Thinking
description: What were you thinking? Perhaps your Ethicist ought to explore the exploitation of a 12-year-old's sad story. Ask a caseworker if such a photo op is a good idea for the child.

title: Sari Weinstein, Zachary Flug
description: Sari Heather Weinstein, a daughter of Paula Weinstein and Dr. Bernard Weinstein, of Austin, Tex., was married last evening to Zachary Orrin Flug, a son of Justice Phyllis Orlikoff Flug and Dr. Arthur Flug of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbi Brett Isserow officiated at the Crowne Plaza Powers Ferry Hotel in Atlanta.

title: In and Around Teatown, A Multitude of Choices
description: TEATOWN LAKE RESERVATION, the nature preserve in Ossining, is well known to Westchester residents. But Teatown Tea? It's produced locally, and its name, as well the preserve's, harks back to colonial times.

title: Introduction
description: Our article on cloning riveted readers, though some wanted more on the efforts of scientists and less on those of the U.F.O. sect. And the image in What They Were Thinking of the boy alone in his bedroom, missing his brothers in foster care, prompted others to contemplate those who would resort to cloning to replace a lost child.

title: Article 2001022593499318489 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Inside Stuff; When Ghouls Rush In
description: Mid-November on a Monday afternoon, Palm Springs, Calif., is a ghost town frozen in time, ''The Ice Storm'' set in the desert. Concert posters flapping on the windows of storefront strip malls boast not of ''Beck Live!'' but of an appearance by Buddy Greco performing in the Bogart Room of the Racquet Club. A figure wearing a dark suit strolling among the rare passers-by -- the majority dressed in desert-tan Dockers shorts -- may just as well be a vampire or the Man Who Fell to Earth.

title: Tip Them Over, Pour Them Out
description: TEA drinkers might weigh carefully whether to choose a smoky Lapsang Souchong or a delicate jasmine, whether they prefer a calming chamomile or a spicy apple cinnamon. But what about the teapot? Does anyone notice its shape or the way it pours? Do people wonder about its history and how it evolved?

title: Schools, Not Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our current system, just telling kids to study, study, study, has been a failure.''

title: Running With Hillary
description: HILLARY'S TURN

title: Amsterdam
description: To the Editor: I couldn't quite tell from Daisann McLane's article ''Amsterdam in Winter: Warmth in Unexpected Places'' (Jan. 7) whether she really enjoyed her stay in Amsterdam in December. I certainly did mine.

title: Race Was Not an Issue In East Orange Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 11 about sex surveys omitted credit for one source. Two facts -- a reference to a sociology professor who disparaged the 1976 ''Hite Report on Female Sexuality'' and a total of 50 for the number of sex surveys conducted in the United States from 1900 to 1950 -- were from the book ''Kiss and Tell: Surveying Sex in the Twentieth Century,'' by Julia A. Ericksen with Sally A. Steffen (Harvard University Press, 1999).

title: The View From Wilkes-Barre
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: STONED

title: Inside Dope; Absolutely Fatuous
description: Fashion fortunes yo-yoed like the Nasdaq last year, with winners including the model supe du jour Gisele Bundchen, the Guess girl turned millionaire widow Anna Nicole Smith and Donna Karan, who outraged investors but increased her personal wealth when she sold her trademark to LVMH at a marked-down price. Not so lucky was Petey, the Karan family pooch, mauled to death by a swan in Central Park. Tommy Hilfiger and Ralph Lauren took a beating of a different kind, being pummeled by plummeting stock prices. But life-affirming moments were just around the corner: Lauren donated $5 million to establish a cancer center in Harlem; Gucci's Tom Ford bankrolled Alexander McQueen's own label, offering him a way out of his messy relationship with LVMH; the new retail conglomerate Pegasus put its money on the designers Daryl Kerrigan and Miguel Adrover; and the organizers of the otherwise emetic Vogue/VH1 Fashion Awards at least had the sense to deny John Galliano permission to present an award naked (he settled instead for an atomic-yellow corset accessorized with an American Indian headdress). Some people love fashion for the frocks, but for us, the monumental egos, backstage back-stabbing and absolutely fatuous goings-on are what make the industry the unrivaled spectacle that it is.

title: February 18-24; 44 Cardinals Elevated
description: Putting a definitive stamp on the institution that will someday elect his successor, John Paul II elevated a record 44 men to the rank of cardinal in St. Peter's Square. The pageantry offered a glimpse of the pomp and privilege that envelopes ''princes of the church,'' which now include Edward M. Egan, 68, New York City's premier Catholic leader. But a few cardinals, too old to vote in a conclave but rewarded for loyal service, revealed the humanity behind the grandeur. Avery Dulles, 82, the first U.S. theologian to receive a red hat, was one. Another was Roberto Tucci, who has worked on all the pope's foreign trips and turns 80 in April. ''I tried not to think of my mother,'' he said when asked what ran through his mind as he received his red biretta. ''I was afraid it would make me cry.'' Alessandra Stanley

title: Melanie Fitzpatrick, Michael Arad
description: Melanie Ann Fitzpatrick, a daughter of Claire E. Connolly of Hingham, Mass., and the late Joseph Fitzpatrick, was married in Boston last evening to Michael Sahar Arad, the son of Rivka and Moshe Arad of Jerusalem. Rabbi Moshe Waldoks performed the ceremony at the Spiritual Life Center at Northeastern University.

title: Business; Putting 'Hostile' Back Into Takeover
description: ANNOYED by the biting questions hurled at him at an industrial technology conference last November, William D. Gehl cut his presentation short. He gathered his materials, stuffed them in his briefcase, bolted out the back door of the conference room and walked briskly toward the exit of the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.

title: Fighting AIDS in Africa
description: The recent announcement by the Indian drug company Cipla that it would sell AIDS therapy for $600 a year or less to African countries is a step toward commuting the death sentences now hanging over the 25 million Africans infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. A year and a half ago, few people even dreamed that the citizens of poor nations would be able to get the antiretroviral drugs that have turned AIDS into a manageable disease in rich countries. Now, each week brings new developments on fighting AIDS in poor nations, and a stronger international consensus that poor countries can provide treatment to those infected and improve their prevention campaigns to slow the spread of the virus. None of this will be possible, however, without leadership from the Bush administration, which must take a more aggressive role in combatting AIDS abroad than its predecessor.

title: An Affordable Home? Huntington Fills the Bill
description: EACH of the rooms in the model home was Susan P. Garcia's favorite, from the elongated living room to the small eat-in kitchen to the spacious square of a master bedroom.

title: In Comedies, Signs of a New Women's Movement
description: TEN years ago, when Terri Minsky started out as a comedy writer on such sitcoms as ''Doctor, Doctor'' and ''Flying Blind,'' most of her colleagues were men and the mood around the offices frequently resembled that of a locker room. ''I worked on so many series where I was the only woman,'' Ms. Minsky said. ''The jokes in the writers room were so misogynistic, so hateful, I thought if I go to the mat on this, I'll be doing that every 30 seconds.''

title: John Fahey, 61, Guitarist And an Iconoclast, Is Dead
description: John Fahey, a guitarist who carved out a private corner of Americana only to see it become a foundation of new age music, died on Thursday at Salem Hospital in Salem, Ore., after undergoing sextuple heart bypass surgery, said Mitch Greenhill, the president of Folklore Productions and Mr. Fahey's executor. Mr. Fahey was 61 and lived in Salem.

title: Auden's Shakespeare
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Westchester; Towns Debate Response to 'McMansion' Trend
description: OOOH, I hate that word! It's so derogatory,'' Sheila Stone, vice president of the Julia B. Fee real estate agency, said with a shudder.

title: Our Towns; A Late Return to Prominence for a Former Newark Mayor
description: KENNETH A. GIBSON was fading into history. His political clout was waning. His business was sputtering. A local civic group wanted to honor him as a ''living legend.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Love in TriBeCa
description: By turns bracing and breezy, Betsy Berne's first novel, BAD TIMING (Villard, $23.95), which is set in downtown Manhattan, charts an interracial, extramarital affair as seen through eyes of the single, 30-something ''other woman,'' a painter disillusioned by moderate success. One night in a bar, this unnamed narrator meets -- and later spends the night with -- Joseph Pendleton, the charming owner of a popular jazz club, who she knows is married and raising a son. Believing that both she and Joseph ''hailed from the dark side'' (though we also come to see her appetite for the lighter side -- she writes beauty articles to earn money, watches ''Beverly Hills 90210'' reruns and paints her loft entirely pink), the narrator becomes depressed after he gives her the brushoff. Many weeks later, however, she discovers she is pregnant, and after she informs Joseph that she is considering keeping the baby, ''Bad Timing'' hits just the right emotional tempo as the two circle and spar. The narrative suffers from a few stereotypes: the fact that Joseph is black inspires the white, Jewish narrator to make an exhausting number of flippant racial remarks; meanwhile, the narrator's overbearing mother and acerbic gay neighbor are uninspired versions of overly familiar characters. Though the plot proves to be as predictable as affairs with married men tend to be, Berne fully evokes every painful step in this one, as when the narrator first realizes that Joseph's favorite words to her are ''try, maybe and might'' -- and yet continues to hope their relationship will somehow work out. Megan Harlan

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 25, 2001
description: Weeks

title: BENEFITS
description: For Scholars and Mentors

title: Inside Paradise; San Simeon Revisited
description: Once upon a time, William Randolph Hearst and Marion Davies would amuse themselves throwing costume parties. And Hollywood's A-list would turn up in clothes remarkably similar to this spring's chic retro looks.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: BLUE ANGEL, by Francine Prose. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14.) Ted Swenson is a middle-aged college professor and blocked novelist who becomes blindly infatuated with his most talented student, a punkish nymphet who happens to be writing a novel about a love affair with a teacher. This novel of ''high comic despair'' portrays ''a fissile world where the sexes and generations are forgetting how to mix, becoming as remote and unintelligible to each other as creatures of separate species,'' Lorna Sage wrote in these pages in 2000.

title: Article 2001022592429098609 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: American Finds Fame Fleeting
description: At the sight of him, girls squealed out in volumes reserved for pop stars; in his presence, politicians threw an arm around his sprite-sized frame for the cameras; and when he entered a bar, patrons lifted pints in his honor.

title: Food; The Subterraneans
description: Roots are what's left of summer. Stalwart and sensible, they are the underside of beauty, the part that endures. No one begrudges the potato, the turnip or the yam its homely appearance. Yet more and more, weirder and weirder roots and tubers are surfacing -- in the culinary world, at least: brown, barky roots; shaggy, hairy roots; roots that are bulbous, swollen and as gnarled as fingers with unfriendly plans.

title: Aviation Museum Deserves Every Helping Hand
description: ''A Wing and a Prayer'' [Feb. 11] explored the pros and cons of Nassau County's financing the Cradle of Aviation Museum in the face of budgetary cutbacks. As the stewards of an institution whose roots in Nassau County extend back to 1874, we at the Garden City Hotel believe strongly that government, as well as the private sector, should continue to support the Cradle and the other museums at Mitchel Center.

title: If It's Big, It's Not a Big Deal
description: SOMETIMES, it seems as if the whole world has been shrunk to fit into a Fendi Baguette. And while the Baguette's popularity wanes, the taste for micro products continues. Even wholly portable objects have been minified: Altoids mints reduced to dots; Harper's Bazaar in a new diminutive Pocket Bazaar version of itself. Here is a look at what's big in extra-small.

title: What Brings A Bear Back to The Market
description: IN nature, bears hibernate in winter. But on Wall Street just now, it is hard to find many of them asleep.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday showing the New York City residences of Edgar Allan Poe misstated the address of Poe Cottage in the Bronx. It is at Kingsbridge Road and the Grand Concourse, not 3309 Bainbridge Avenue.

title: Winston Cup Drivers Get Back to the Business of Racing
description: Ken Schrader had a new yellow race car today. He seemed to be grateful. He said this weekend's race at North Carolina Speedway could not have come quickly enough, so he could strap himself into the car, push it to the edge, concentrate on his job and forget about the terrible way his last race ended.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONHEIM, PHILLIP
description: CONHEIM-Phillip. February 21, 1944. In ever loving memory. Your daughter, Marilyn

title: The Way We Live Now: 2-25-01; What They Were Thinking
description: Katherine Hopkins-Nicholas and Fayard Nicholas, The Derby, Hollywood, Calif., Sept. 6, 2000

title: McCarter Proves 'Scandal' Has Style
description: AT first sight, the ensemble at the McCarter Theater appears primed for a chamber opera. Fans are unfurled, walking sticks are in place, and new music composed for the occasion graces the air.

title: A Pleasing Perennial
description: Among the North Fork's minor wines, one of the more familiar, pleasing perennials has been Cygnet, Kip Bedell's gewrztraminer-riesling blend.

title: Will a Picture Palace Hero Finally Save the Day?
description: Loew's Paradise Theater on the Grand Concourse was once the cinematic jewel of the Bronx.

title: In Race for Governor, Charting the Course of Education
description: In their first side-by-side public appearance of the campaign, the three candidates for governor of New Jersey today courted the support of the state's largest teachers union in ways true to type.

title: Flight Path; A Pilot Took a Terrible Risk to Avoid Endangering Those Below
description: ON a hazy afternoon a few miles from beaches packed for the start of the Labor Day weekend last summer, Major David Haar buckled himself into his cockpit. He checked his safety harness, and snapped a salute to his crew chief.

title: A London Walking Tour That's Strictly Legal
description: YOU don't have to be a lawyer to appreciate the Inns of Court, the four ancient societies of English barristers that lie at the center of London. Little known to tourists, the inns offer easy access to the best of England -- beautiful vistas, superb architecture, colorful and vibrant traditions, fascinating literary and historical associations and, most remarkably, absolute serenity.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: NEVER mind what Anthony Minghella's script and direction do or don't do right in terms of Patricia Highsmith's homoerotic murder-mystery novel. THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY (1999) is breathtakingly beautiful. If this is what rich, Amerian and expatriated looked like in scenic 1950's Italy, bring back Eisenhower. And the film is faultlessly acted by everyone concerned: Matt Damon as the poor boy who gets a taste of the good life; Jude Law as the rich boy whose privileged life he decides to steal, in several senses; Gwyneth Paltrow as the rich boy's pampered girlfriend; Cate Blanchett as the rich girl who complicates the masquerade; and Philip Seymour Hoffman, stealing scenes left and right, as an equally rich and reckless young man who becomes justifiably suspicious -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: We were struck by the juxtaposition of the picture of 12-year-old Albert Hubbard (Feb. 4) and the sentiments expressed by some of the parents seeking cloned children in your cover article. We, too, have had a long-sought son die in infancy. Instead of saving a hair sample for an impossible hope, we have adopted.

title: Remembering Mama, More or Less, on Stage
description: EIGHT years ago, the actress Lynn Redgrave brought to the stage her memory play of sorts about life with father, the great actor, Sir Michael Redgrave. Now, it's mother's turn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, RADIE
description: HARRIS-Radie. The officers and Board of Directors of the American Theatre Wing note with sorrow the passing of Radie Harris who devoted much of her life to the Wing's activities. She was a board member emeritus. Her presence will long be remembered. Isabelle Stevenson, Chairman of the Board Roy A. Somlyo, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVOY, QUEEN MARIA JOSE
description: SAVOY-Queen Maria Jose of Italy. A Solemn Requiem Mass in memory of Italy's last Queen will be held Monday, February 26th, at 6:30 PM at the Church of Our Saviour, 38th St. and Park Ave., NYC.

title: Test Pilots Do Their Part for the Team
description: LAHTI, Finland, Feb. 24  The test pilots arrived in full combat gear, sporting boots, jackets, gloves, confidence and  now for the confusing part  ski poles. No, these test pilots, as they are known on the World Cup circuit, had not come to put planes through their paces; they had come to put cross-country skis through their paces, and with races scheduled to begin soon there was little time to spare for repartee.

title: A Chance for Pollard
description: To the Editor:

title: A Benefit For the Few Weighs On Many
description: SHAREHOLDERS of technology stocks have been battered by earnings shortfalls at their favorite companies and by day-late downgrades from brokerage analysts. But a third element is at work in the current devastation of tech stocks, one that's less obvious but every bit as powerful. It is the ill effect on shareholders of enormous stock-option grants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMAN, JANET S.
description: ULLMAN-Janet S. My wife, mother of our children, Susan, William & Lucy; mother-in-law to Kathy & to Jim; grandmother of Annalese, Leif, Jessica & Noah. She was loved and cherished by all who knew her. A very special person. Montague Ullman

title: Dancing Teapots as Practical Art
description: FOR artists, the teapot is like a puzzle,'' said Randy Au, a ceramic artist who has been creating teapots for eight years. ''You've got the body, the spout, the handle, the base and the lid, and they all have to fit together visually as well as functionally.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: CRAZY MELON AND CHINESE APPLE

title: February 18-24; Same Faith, Fewer M's
description: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has grown into the nation's sixth-largest religious body. But it still struggles with critics who claim its theology is not really Christian. So church leaders decided to step up efforts to discourage use of the term Mormon Church. Their preference: either the full title or simply the Church of Jesus Christ. Individuals can still be called Mormons. And, church leaders say, no one is thinking of renaming the Mormon Tabernacle Choir. Gustav Niebuhr

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 11 about Disney's California Adventure theme park misstated the literary source of the term ''feelies.'' It was used in Aldous Huxley's novel ''Brave New World,'' not in ''A Clockwork Orange'' by Anthony Burgess.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 11 about the town of Washington referred incorrectly to the Revolutionary War travels of its namesake, George Washington. He could not have visited the town by railroad; steam-powered locomotives came to the United States in the 1820's, some 30 years after his death.

title: No Belly Dancing
description: IF your idea of a Middle Eastern restaurant is a night of exotica under a tented ceiling, with soft pillows for dining while reclining, dancing women playing peekaboo with scarves, and hookah smoking afterward, the first clue that Cedar Restaurant won't be that is the directions to the place: Turn right at the Subway shop and it's just down the street.

title: Political Briefing; A State Reconsiders Its Independent Ways
description: One of the quadrennial conundrums about New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation presidential primaries is how independents will vote.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FLUHR, BENJAMIN S.
description: FLUHR-Benjamin S. January 26 1909-February 24 1976. Dad, gone 25 years and I'm still basking in the glow you left behind. Your smile and widsom are with me always. Love, Ellen.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS MEET ON DEFENSES AGAINST MISSILES
description: On his first overseas trip as America's chief diplomat, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell plunged into talks today with the Russian foreign minister over differences on plans for a missile defense. They agreed to hold an expert-level dialogue on both offensive and defensive weapons, officials on both sides said.

title: Style; California Preenin'
description: It all began with a ''Beverly Hills'' shampoo. In the 60's, hairdressers ruled the earth. Jay Sebring, an inspiration for Warren Beatty's character in ''Shampoo,'' worked his magic in tight, flare-bottomed jeans and a fitted shirt all purchased at a little shop on Melrose called Ron Herman/Fred Segal. In the time it would take for his adoring fans to be cut, shaped and blown out, they were already at the store buying guys' jeans.

title: As Hopes Wither, Africans Turn on Leaders
description: The rain burst from the heavens and drenched the faces of the jubilant supporters who serenaded the old man at his birthday bash here today. All across town, young women celebrated the leadership of their longtime president, singing, ''South Africa will follow you, Mugabe, Namibia will follow you.''

title: Now, in an Old Gatehouse, Art, Not Water, Will Flow
description: At one time, New Yorkers could climb to the highest point in Manhattan, enter a turreted castle through elegant iron gates and look down at millions of gallons of clean drinking water gushing toward the city through an opening in the Croton Aqueduct.

title: Police Commissioner Proves To Be a Poor Businessman
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, JOHN DAVID
description: SCOTT-John David. Of Franklin, MA, on February 21, 2001. Beloved son of the late Charles D. & Lorraine S. (Shear) Scott & brother of the late Judith S. Durner. Brother of James C. Scott of Feedings Hills, MA; Uncle of Kristin E. Durner of Bradford, MA, Amy Scott of Winchester, MA & Christopher Scott of Springfield, MA. A Memorial service will be held in NYC in late April 2001. Memorial may be made to the St. Camillus Hospice, 447 Hill St., Whitins., MA 01588. Thoughts and memories may be shared at: www.johnwentworth.com/jds/guestbook.htm

title: Aimee Dalton, John Roderick
description: Aimee Loren Dalton, the daughter of Lorraine and Guy Dalton of St. James, N.Y., is to be married today in Port Jefferson, N.Y., to John Christopher Roderick, the son of Rosann and John M. Roderick of Warren, R.I. The Rev. Susan Marlan, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the Port Jefferson Country Club at Harbor Hills.

title: Islanders Hang On to Win Second Straight
description: The last time the Islanders won two straight games, Al Groh was still coaching the Jets, Mike Hampton was still a Met and the Islanders were tied for first place.

title: Jimnez Is Finding Success in the U.S.
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Feb. 24  In unfamiliar surroundings, Miguel Angel Jimenez has found a way to look perfectly comfortable.

title: The Ring's the Thing for a Former Actress
description: Before Jill Emery took up boxing, she was an actress.

title: Opponent Puts Up a Fight, But Jones Retains His Title
description: Roy Jones Jr. promised he would put on a dazzling display against the little-known Derrick Harmon this morning. No one doubted Jones and no one expected him to sweat much in handling Harmon. Jones did sweat, but he was always in control in winning again.

title: Love Breaks From Pack on Wet Day
description: On a miserable weather day at the Nissan Open, it was hard to stay dry, it was hard to stay warm, and it was hard to catch Davis Love III.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, MAX
description: GOLDBERG-Max. Mr. Roumania Roumania. A legend in Jewish entertainment. The end of an era. We will never forget you. Harriet and Morty Werbel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, MELVILLE N.
description: LIBERMAN-Melville N., on December 3, 2000, in his 93rd year. Predeceased by his dear wife Hilda. He is survived by his loving son Stuart and his granddaughters Tracy and Cari-Anne. Loving brother of Adele Feingold, Marjorie Mottus, Frank Liberman and the late Bertram Liberman and several nieces and nephews. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Rally Round the Flag
description: The Imagined Civil War

title: A West Side Stepchild Seeks Respect for Its Roots
description: Manhattan Valley, the sloping neighborhood east of Broadway from 96th to 110th Streets, has long played stepsister to the Upper West Side. In the 1850's, its only residents, squatters, had to move to make room for Central Park. In the 1870's, the poor and infirm found homes there, in tenements and asylums. Later, they were joined by working-class people who settled into rows of three-story brick houses beside the country's first cancer treatment hospital, at 105th Street and Central Park West.

title: The Nation: Pardon Me. Please.; Lobbying for Forgiveness
description: LAWYERS familiar with the pardon process say there has always been a bit of ''back-dooring,'' with some petitioners trying to press their case at the White House through influential people. But no one had ever seen anything like the atmosphere of the last months of the Clinton administration, a period some have described as akin to a fire sale.

title: Reckonings; Will V Go To L?
description: It's a thin line between love and hate. This time last year all the talking heads were adamant that the new economy had abolished the business cycle. Now we're told, after only a few months of slowdown, that we can kiss prosperity goodbye. The economy isn't perfect? Then it must be hopeless.

title: Do Cell Phones Belong in the Car?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, FLORENCE DIANE
description: AUERBACH - Florence Diane, peacefully in Medford, Oregon, died February 10, age 83. Beloved wife of the late Jack Auerbach. Cherished mother of Lewis and Stephen. Loving grandmother to Joshua, Melina, Aaron and Peter. Private inurnment. In memoriam donations may be made to Amnesty International or Tamir Foundation in Ottawa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDORF, INA
description: LANDORF-Ina. Loving and courageous mother of Peter & Andy, mother-in-law of Joanie, grandmother of Ali & Greg-we love you and may you rest in peace.

title: Toward a Neater Garage, But at a Four-Figure Price
description: For those of you eager to get a jump-start on spring cleaning, why not begin with the garage? GarageTek Inc., a Long-Island-based company that manufactures garage organizing systems, has opened a franchise in White Plains.

title: Article 2001022593250506561 -- No Title
description: By MARGARET W. GOLDSBOROUGH

title: A Magical Mystery Tour That Comes to Take The Grief Away
description: HOW do children learn to cope with grief? With a bit of intervention, perhaps, and a crash course in learning to live again.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/West Harlem; Brownstones in Manhattan, at a Discount
description: FOR almost three years, Walter Biggs and his wife, Clara Rubio, searched in Manhattan for an apartment they could afford. After scouring scores of two-bedroom apartments packed into 650 square feet and priced at almost half a million dollars, they were ready to give up when a friend suggested they look in Harlem.

title: American Apartheid
description: BROWN V. BOARD OF EDUCATION A Civil Rights Milestone and Its Troubled Legacy. By James T. Patterson. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTS, DAVID
description: WATTS-David. On February 23, at home in Summit, NJ, quietly after a long illness at age 69. Beloved and devoted husband of Susan Armstrong, loving and adoring father of daughters Jennifer and Mary Saunders, son David, granddaughter Helen Watts Deverell, and son-in-law William Deverell, and brother of Ridley Watts. Graduate of St. Paul's School and Harvard; former naval officer and nationally ranked squash player. Retired partner and managing director of J. & W. Seligman & Co., Inc., New York. Memorial contributions may be made to Ridley Watts Professorship of Public Health Policy, Harvard Medical School, 25 Shattuck St., Cambridge, MA. Memorial Service arrangements to be announced. For information call Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit, NJ.

title: Gallery Hopping Under a Single Roof
description: THE membership of the Silvermine Guild in New Canaan keeps growing, and one of the benefits of membership is an exhibition. The problem then is how to present a coherent display of disparate work by a lot of artists.

title: Allure of the Woman Behind the Hydrangea
description: WHEN February, the longest short month, rolls around, I think longingly of flowers and soft spring air. I am more than ready to succumb to the charms of anything floral, especially the voluptuous specimens portrayed in botanical art.

title: Article 2001022590123405731 -- No Title
description: February 24, 2001

title: Island Adventure
description: To the Editor: Having visited Culebra, off Puerto Rico, several times, we enjoyed the article ''A Little Island Hard to Leave'' (Jan. 14) by Nina Siegal. A vacation on Culebra is indeed memorable. We had a potentially dangerous experience there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVRUTIS, THERESA GWYN KELLAR
description: AVRUTIS-Theresa Gwyn Kellar. At home, on February 18, 2001. Widow of Newton. A graduate of Morris H.S. 1930 and NYU 1934. She practiced Clinical Psychology for over 45 years. Daughter of the late Louis Goldberg and Anna Freund. Sister of the late C.M. and I. Harold Kellar. She is survived by her daughter Andrea, her nephews Raymond, Alan and Jeffrey, her grandnephew Michael and her sister-in-law Charlotte. Services were held Thursday, February 22nd. Memorial contributions to Museum of Jewish Heritage, Battery Park City, New York.

title: In This Corner, Your Lawyer. In That Corner, Your Broker.
description: THE SETTING -- Two flights down on Park Place on a rainy Friday night, in a space dominated by the faintly sweet smell of sweat and the clinking of Corona bottles. Here in the Church Street Boxing Gym, along with teenage kick-boxers and other gym rats, are office types boxing, often before a crowd for the first time, as part of an occasional event called White Collar Fights.

title: The World; Firm Foundations for Disaster
description: THE number of killings in this country's grinding civil conflict tops 5,000 a year. Paramilitary gunmen, once shadowy killers who operated in a few regions, have spread across the country. And rebels, despite agreeing to resume peace talks, continue to threaten the state.

title: It's a Living: Working 250 Nights a Year, Winning Fans One by One
description: WHILE some New Jersey musicians, like Bruce Springsteen or Jon Bon Jovi, attract tens of thousands to concerts, another New Jersey rocker, Billy Hector, is collecting fans 150 at a time.

title: Home-Cooked Sounds
description: To the Editor:

title: A False Division
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brooklyn Showcase For Local Designers
description: Brooklyn Sugar, a clothing and accessory shop at 322 Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, mixes new labels with vintage lines. The store, which also sells used clothing on consignment, sells reconstructed vintage jewelry ($15 to $90) by Viva Vintage, a local designer, and hand-painted ties ($40) from Brooklyn Strangler, another local label.

title: INVESTING WITH: Hobart C. Buppert II; Flag Investors Value Builder Fund
description: VALUE is in the eye of the beholder, says Hobart C. Buppert II, who runs the $954 million Flag Investors Value Builder fund, a portfolio in which the multimedia AOL Time Warner nestles comfortably against Allied Waste Industries, a trash hauler.

title: Inside Eats; Elite Meat
description: The T.H.F. (Trendy Hall of Fame) is littered not only with the carcasses of Air Jordans, Cabbage Patch Kids and just about every rock star who ever lived, but also with many foods and the occasional cuisine (anyone tried minceur recently?). So intensely exciting were some of these dishes that we binged our lifetime cravings away in minutes. I, for one, don't care if I ever see another blackened redfish in this lifetime, and they damned well better not serve any in hell either.

title: Article 2001022592646512149 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: Professor Marvel at the Atheneum
description: MAGICIAN OF THE MODERN

title: A Marble Tribute to Willard Scott
description: IT was only after moving out of the city that I discovered the existence of weather. Thanks to either window grime or smog, city days all take on a gray oneness. Once you learn to make the fine distinction between raindrops and air conditioner drippage, you've pretty much mastered urban meteorology.

title: Sarah Coyne and John Walker
description: WHENEVER Sarah Mary Coyne visited her mother's Tudor-style house in South Orange, N.J., she always found a bird's-nestlike mound of articles that had been clipped out for her.

title: The Nets Wait Too Long, Letting the Heat Hold On
description: The Nets reduced the 18-point deficit they faced entering the fourth quarter tonight against the Miami Heat to 6 midway through the period. Yet, after the late surge fell short, Nets Coach Byron Scott did not want his players to claim a moral victory.

title: From County Hospital To Regional Medical Center
description: BEFORE he left his last job in the fall, Dr. Laszlo Fuzesi, a 45-year-old surgeon, had the surreal experience of being surrounded by 200 people who might not have been alive without him. Yet there they were, giving him a goodbye party at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark, where Dr. Fuzesi had created the heart transplant program.

title: Talking It Over Some More
description: Love, Etc.

title: Only One Athlete Has Ever Inspired This Many Songs
description: JOE LOUIS was still relatively new on the national scene and would not be the world's heavyweight boxing champion for nearly two more years when Memphis Minnie sang of the man and his arms in August 1935. Louis's left and right, she belted out in her husky, lusty voice, were like ''a kick from a Texas mule'' and a ''jolt of dy-nee-mite.'' Films of a recent Louis fight were playing at the local theater, she sang, and she told everyone not to miss them. ''If you ain't got no money,'' she declared, ''honey, go tomorrow night.'' She then told of betting all her money, the ''ten hundred dollars'' she'd laid up on her shelf, that Louis's latest victim wouldn't last a round. And then she explained why.

title: Boom!
description: Fashion insiders have an almost mystical ability to hone in on The Look, The Subject, The Film, The Star, The Place. And even the most articulate insider isn't always able to say Why. There are explanations to be made for some insider obsessions, and we've made them in this issue -- for Slim Aarons's photography. Tuscan steak. The BMW 2002. But some obsessions defy decoding. For instance, why ''Boom!''? Why is ''Boom!'' suddenly in the forefront of fashion's consciousness?

title: E-MAIL PRESCRIPTIONS
description: The New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs has proposed allowing doctors to write and transmit prescriptions directly to pharmacists by E-mail, Mark Herr, division director, said last week. Nationally, 7,000 people die each year and $95 billion in additional medical care results from errors in prescriptions, much of it caused by illegible handwriting by doctors, Mr. Herr said. The change in regulations is expected to be adopted by the appropriate boards within the next few weeks and go into effect by summer.

title: 2 Doctors Suspended After Surgery on Wrong Side of Man's Brain
description: Two neurosurgeons said to have participated in an emergency operation on the wrong side of a patient's brain last week have been suspended by a Brooklyn hospital pending investigations by the hospital and the New York State Health Department, officials said yesterday.

title: National News Briefs
description: Tornado Kills 5 People in Mississippi City

title: Wealthiest Pay Declining Share of Their Incomes in Taxes
description: The richest Americans are paying a declining share of their incomes in taxes, even as their incomes grow more rapidly than everyone else's, according to data that the Internal Revenue Service gave a Republican member of Congress.

title: Slow Start Endangers St. John's Postseason
description: St. John's could have made things interesting for itself and the Big East this week. A victory on the road today would have nudged the Red Storm back into contention for an at-large bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament, which seemed unlikely a week ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEROY, WARNER
description: LeROY-Warner. On February 22, 2001 at age 65. Entrepreneur, designer and noble friend. Beloved father of Bridget, Carolyn, Max and Jennifer. Cherished brother of Linda Janklow, Brian and Quentin Vidor. Devoted Grandpa to Georgia, Joelie and Bing. You will always be a star! Services Monday, February 26th at 10:30AM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Meals on Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10017, or New York Presbyterian Hospital, Department of Medicine, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: He's Thinking, and Throwing, Straight
description: The second baseman was habitually recalling some of his positive baseball experiences, laying them out as immaculately as the uniforms in a Marine's closet. How his Uncle Eddie implored him to stifle teams with defense. How he went to spring training 10 years ago as a Class AA player and vowed that the Minnesota Twins would keep him. How he thinks that he will be remembered most for helping the Yankees win three World Series titles, not for throwing baseballs so haphazardly that he was benched and pondered retirement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTZER, FRANCES D.
description: WALTZER-Frances D. Beloved wife of the late Henry Waltzer and the late Moe Pruss. Devoted mother of Dorothy E. Gastman and stepmother of Elissa Flanders, JoEllen Schwarcz and Frank Waltzer. Cherished grandmother of eight. Dear sister of Jacqueline Edelman and the late Samuel Jacobsen. Loving aunt and greataunt. Daughter of the late Nathan and late Ray Jacobsen. A devoted and dear friend to many. Service today at 11:30 AM, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn (opposite Kings Plaza).

title: Dark and Darker: Balancing Heaven and Hell on Earth
description: Butoh was still a genre of avant-garde Japanese dance unfamiliar in the West when the Dairakudakan troupe introduced Akaji Maro's visionary dance theater to the United States at the 1982 American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C. The company, rarely seen in this country, appeared this evening at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here with ''The Sea-Dappled Horse,'' the nightmarish blend of the epic and the banal that stunned audiences nearly 20 years ago.

title: Disappointing Season Continues for Seton Hall
description: Seton Hall has attributed its crumbling season to complacency, defensive lapses and poor chemistry. Yesterday against West Virginia, the Pirates added a lack of self-assurance to that list.

title: The Neediest Cases; Finding Ways to Send Gifts, Large and Small
description: Despite the option of donating via the Web, the vast majority of gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund still come via the Postal Service.

title: Drug Developed From Gene Study Tested on People
description: A drug developed by a big pharmaceutical company from a pioneering genomics collaboration has entered clinical trials, says William A. Haseltine, the chief executive of Human Genome Sciences.

title: Article 2001022693173733295 -- No Title
description: The Web, Without Wires, Wherever

title: 10 Years Later, Hussein Is Firmly in Control
description: Ten years ago, Saddam Hussein looked at least in the view of the American-led military alliance that defeated his forces in Kuwait -- every inch a finished man, another discredited dictator heading for the ignominy of history's rubbish heap.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We stood alone, against an alliance of more than 30 armies, a third world country against the world's greatest superpower, and it is they who have been defeated, not us. We are very proud of ourselves.''

title: At Co-op City, Residents Wonder Whether Profit's Price Is Too High
description: Everything about Co-op City is supersized, including the quandary over its future.

title: High-Stakes Appeal Could Be Last Court Date for Microsoft
description: After years of bruising setbacks before a deeply skeptical federal district judge, Microsoft moves upstairs in the court house on Monday morning. There it will find an appeals forum that in the past has been receptive to its antitrust defenses, but that now could also present potentially fatal pitfalls.

title: Swiss Angry At Charges Of Laxness In Banking
description: Swiss bankers and officials are bristling once again over accusations, this time from neighboring France, that the country is an international haven for dubious money dealings.

title: McLean's Strong Play Can't Save Rangers
description: The Rangers' front office may be down on Kirk McLean. But McLean, a 34-year-old veteran, sure played like a No. 1 goaltender here tonight.

title: Family Ghosts Hoard Secrets That Bewitch The Living
description: In the last week of her life, my three half-sisters, my younger brother and I gathered around the easy chair in which our mother lay floating between this world and the next.

title: Facing Up to New York's Court Crisis
