description: For years, lawyers and judges have been warning of a growing problem in New York's justice system -- the dwindling number of competent attorneys willing to work for the low rates the state pays for representing poor people in New York City's criminal and family courts. Now, thanks to Albany's inattention, the problem has escalated into a crisis that Gov. George Pataki and legislative leaders can no longer ignore.

title: Russia to Investigate a Mass Grave in Chechnya
description: Russian military officials promised today to investigate a grave containing a number of bodies found near a Russian military base outside the Chechen capital, Grozny. But they made it clear that they believed that its inhabitants had been killed by Chechen rebels and not by Russian soldiers.

title: Pardon Me
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Urban Renewal For Tower of Babel; Bilingual Education in the City Is a Monument to Inconsistency
description: Last fall, Alicia Julian Campos was dismayed when administrators at a public school in Bushwick, Brooklyn, enrolled her 6-year-old daughter, Jennifer, who was born in New York City and speaks English, in an all-Spanish-speaking class for the second year in a row and kept her there against the mother's will for weeks. Mrs. Campos, a Mexican immigrant, later learned that the move was the result of a mistake in interpreting Jennifer's test score, but she believes such mistakes happen a lot at a school where administrators try hard to sustain bilingual education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, NANCY JANE
description: COLEMAN-Nancy Jane. 62, fifth generation Houstonian, passed away after a courageous and dignified battle with cancer in her home on Saturday, February 24, 2001, surrounded by her family and loved ones. Nancy was a graduate of Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Connecticut, and Hollins College. Nancy was a lifelong student and teacher of music, especially piano. She took great pride in bringing music to people's lives as a former Executive Director of Young Audiences of Houston, a member of the Cultural Arts Council of Houston, member of the Junior League Sustainer Musical Group, piano instructor, and various other musical volunteer groups. Nancy was a member of the Forest Club, Junior League of Houston, The Assembly, Bolero, Garden Club of Houston, St. Martin's Episcopal Church, Galveston Boat Club, and Rockaway Hunting Club of Lawrence, New York. Nancy Jane Coleman was preceded in death by her parents Stewart P. Coleman and Jane Cochran Coleman Peck, and her sister, Margaret Stewart Coleman. She is survived by her children, Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Cochran (Diane) Hirtz, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Theodore (Amy) Hirtz, and Mr. and Mrs. William August (Krissy) Hirtz, grandchildren, Ian Stewart Coleman Hirtz and Margaret Elizabeth Hirtz, special friend, Mr. H. John Strom, former husband and father of her children, Mr. Theodore S. Hirtz, Jr., relatives from the Shepherd, Cochran, and Coleman families, and numerous friends. Friends and family are invited for visitation from 6 to 9 o'clock in the evening on Wednesday, February 28, 2001, at Nancy's home. Funeral services will be held at 11 o'clock in the morning, Thursday, March 1, 2001, at St. Martin's Episcopal Church, 717 Sage Road, with the Rev. Dr. Peter G. Thomas officiating. Interment will follow at Glenwood Cemetery. A reception will follow at her home. For those desiring, memorial contributions may be directed to CanCare or St. Martin's Cancer Support Group. For information, contact Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, 1010 Bering Drive, Houston, TX 77057, 713-789-3005.

title: In a Switch, Too Much Snow Cancels Utah Games Preview
description: A veil of snow and fog cloaked Snowbasin for three days, never budging to open the curtain on a 2002 Winter Olympic preview.

title: Corrections
description: A television review last Monday about ''The Unfinished Civil War,'' a History Channel documentary on people who re-enact Civil War battles, misstated the publication year of Tony Horwitz's ''Confederates in the Attic,'' a book on the same subject. It was 1998, not 1988.

title: Olivier Awards for 'Stones' and Sondheim
description: ''Stones in His Pockets'' by Marie Jones was named best new comedy and the Donmar Warehouse's revival of Stephen Sondheim's 1981 ''Merrily We Roll Along'' was chosen best new musical when the 25th Laurence Olivier Awards were presented Friday night at the Lyceum Theater in London.

title: Compressed Data; Job Sites Are Thriving on Dot-Com Sector's Troubles
description: What with the constant reports of layoffs, bankruptcies and Nasdaq delistings, it may provide some comfort to know that at least someone is benefiting from the shakeout in Internet companies. Job-search sites are in demand right now, posting enormous gains in Web page views.

title: Accounts
description: Touchstone Energy, Arlington, Va., an alliance of local, consumer-owned electric cooperative utilities, to Masius, New York, part of the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles unit of the Bcom3 Group, to handle its account, which had been at Westhill Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $17 million to $20 million.

title: Compressed Data; Services Try to Link Reporters and Publicists
description: Journalists and public relations people have long endured a relationship of mutually unsatisfying symbiosis. Tenacious publicists harass editors and reporters, who ignore them for months only suddenly to demand immediate access and answers when news breaks.

title: China Hones Old Tool: 'Re-educating' Unruly
description: BEIJING, Feb. 26  He had been detained for six months in 1989 for helping to organize a strike, and later he tried to sue the police on behalf of an exiled labor leader, so Zhou Guoqiang, a lawyer and longtime human rights advocate, knew he was on thin ice. Still, he was surprised in 1994 at the pretext they used to jail him.

title: Breezy Modernist Gets His Due; Honor at Last for an Architect Who Made California His Muse
description: Rudolph M. Schindler came here in 1920 and never left. The Austrian-born architect made this city his muse, finding the vast open spaces and perfect climate liberating in his quest to build houses at modest cost on beaches and hills and in the desert. He designed Modernist houses, which sometimes eliminated conventional rooms, to allow sleeping outdoors as well as indoors, and he created a communal way of life that would remake not only buildings but society.

title: INSIDE
description: A Quixote for Ukraine

title: Unofficially Official: Clemens to Get Start
description: Roger Clemens is scheduled to pitch for the Yankees in Friday's exhibition game against the Toronto Blue Jays, and if you make the broad assumption that he does not suffer any injuries or setbacks during spring training, this place in the rotation would put him on track to pitch opening day, April 2, against the Kansas City Royals.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHNER, LEON
description: FLEISCHNER-Leon. On February 24, in Cheshire, CT, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Lillian (Goldberg) Fleischner. Cherished father to Susan Matos of New Rochelle, Burt Fleischner of Milford, CT, and the late Alice Fleischner. Devoted father-in-law to Dr. Jeffrey Matos. Adored grandfather to Amanda and Lindsey Matos. Accomplished violinist in the New Haven, CT, area, volunteer for many years at Hospice in Branford, CT, and St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury, CT. Funeral services at the Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, 543 George St., New Haven, CT, on Monday afternoon at 1 PM.

title: Mitsubishi Outlines Restructuring Plan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26  Mitsubishi Motors officials outlined a sweeping restructuring plan today that in some ways mirrors that of DaimlerChrysler, which owns about one-third of its stock.

title: Big Business, Ever Eager To Tap Into Teenage Wallets

A few minutes later, with even more passion as he discussed dangerous conditions, the former champion turned gifted broadcaster declared, ''We've got to do something.'' In NascarNation, those two sentiments are linked.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the partnership between the financier Marc Rich and Pincus Green, who were pardoned by President Bill Clinton, misstated the relationship between Philipp Brothers, a commodities firm where they met, and the Salomon Brothers brokerage firm. Salomon Brothers merged into Phibro, the parent of Philipp Brothers, although officials from Salomon wound up in control of the merged company, now a part of Citigroup. Salomon did not buy Philipp Brothers.

description: Breaking his silence, the commander of the nuclear submarine that accidentally sank a Japanese educational fishing trawler 16 days ago, leaving nine people missing and presumed dead, has sent an emotional letter of regret to the Japanese people.

title: In India and Africa, Women's Low Status Worsens Their Risk of AIDS

title: Wretched Barbarity as the Scar of Urban Poverty
description: The dialogue in ''Saved,'' Edward Bond's admonitory drama about the hopelessness of the poor working class, is clipped and unmusical. The characters are uneducated, unintuitive and largely inarticulate, and except when they're screaming at one another in oafish anger, they communicate in short, mundane bursts of want. They don't listen well; conversations have an elliptical skew. Isolated and entrapped by urban poverty, everyone is speaking out of a persistent base instinct to achieve an evanescent pleasure, a tiny, momentary victory. Sex, food, money, vengeance: these are the palliations that drive them. They're hedonists, but without a shred of imagination, and they are dangerous.

description: An article on Friday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's brothers, Hugh and Tony Rodham, misstated Tony Rodham's age in some copies. He is 46, not 44.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDHOFF, ARNOLD J., MD
description: FRIEDHOFF-Arnold J., MD. The National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD) mourns the loss of our esteemed Scientific Council member, Chairman of the Lieber Prize Committee for Schizophrenia Research and devoted supporter. Dr. Friedhoff's pioneering leadership in the field of biological psychiatry led to his role as a founding member of our distinguished Scientific Council. His wise guidance and supportive energies were typified by the Nobel Prizes awarded to scientists previously honored by the Lieber Prize Committee under his leadership. He was truly one of the important guides and mentors in the remarkable development of brain and behavior research. His work was profoundly humanitarian in lifetime focus and achievement, enhancing the science, medical education and patient care. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Frances and his family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President of the Scientific Council Constance E. Lieber President, Board of Directors

title: School Privatization Foes Say Chosen Company Unfairly Gets Board's Help With Vote

Levy to let a private company manage five low-performing public schools are accusing the Board of Education of unfairly skewing the process because the private company, Edison Schools Inc., is being given board resources to try to persuade parents to support the plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORNARI, DR. HARRY D.
description: FORNARI-Dr. Harry D. Of 2 Rivers Drive, Great Neck, NY, passed away on the morning of February 24, 2001, after a two year illness with cancer. He was born in Rome, Italy, on May 21, 1919, and emigrated to the US in June, 1939, to escape the Fascist regime prior to World War II. He served in the US Army from 1941 to 1945 in North Africa and Europe in the War Information Office. He returned to the US in 1947 with his wife Maria and son James and embarked on a distinguished business career that spanned over 50 years. Notable among his accomplishments, Dr. Fornari served as Vice President for Bunge Corp. from 1952 to 1984, and afterwards as the Director for Risk Management for TIE Communications. He completed his Doctor of Letters degree from the University of Bologna, BS and MA degrees from Columbia University, and received a Ph.D. in History from the City University of New York. He was the author of several books on history and the commodities industry, including: ''Mussolini's Gadfly,'' ''Bread Upon the Waters,'' and ''A Story of Peace and Other War Stories.'' Dr. Fornari also served as Executive Director of the American Fats and Oils Association, and for the past 40 years as an arbitrator for the American Arbitration Association and the National Association of Securities Dealers. Dr. Fornari also served as an Officer and Director of the Graduate Faculties Alumni of Columbia University for 30 years. He was also the principal of his own consulting firm, Risk Management Counsel. He is survived by his loving wife Maria and his sons James D. Fornari and Daniel J. Fornari and their families. His life was filled with rich experiences and challenges that he always met with resolve, skill and determination. His spirit and ever present will to help others will remain with us forever. Funeral services will be private.

title: A Global Warning to Mr. Bush
description: Scientists meeting in San Francisco a week ago heard a startling prediction: the seemingly indestructible snows of Kilimanjaro that inspired Ernest Hemingway's famous short story may well disappear in the next 15 years. To most mainstream scientists, the rapid erosion of Kilimanjaro's majestic ice cap, along with the steady retreat of mountaintop glaciers elsewhere, is further dramatic evidence of a relentless warming of the earth's atmosphere that cannot be explained by normal climate shifts and is at least partly traceable to the burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil.

title: Survivor
description: hat's when the fires started," Jared Kotz says nonchalantly, a few minutes into the story of his apartment. By this point, he's already mentioned the drug dealers, the thigh-high mounds of garbage, the broken windows and the lack of heat and hot water, all of which vividly describe the state of the sixth-floor Alphabet City walk-up he began renting 19 years ago. It's evident that Kotz (pronounced "coats") has told the story many times, because he seems numb to its sensationalist details. When I ask him if he has any "before" pictures, he says, "No. It was too dangerous to have a camera."

title: Race for Borough President Sharpens Rivalries in Bronx
description: The upheaval and wrangling produced by term limits has made for lively political theater in virtually every sector of New York City. But few dramas rival the one in the Bronx, where an open seat for borough president is already creating signs of political warfare and discord among Democrats.

title: Workers at Met Urge Opera to Intervene in Their Bid to Unionize
description: For eight months, a court injunction barred restaurant workers at the Metropolitan Opera from criticizing the opera, but yesterday, with the injunction overturned, they faulted the Met for not intervening to make it easier for them to unionize.

title: Sports of The Times; Combine for Stars and Sleepers, Not Modesty
description: MIKE McMAHON considered the question, then answered with an assuredness that belied a player with a relatively modest projection in the National Football League draft. McMahon, the 22-year-old quarterback from Rutgers, had been asked to comment on the idea that Michael Vick of Virginia Tech and Drew Brees of Purdue were considered the top quarterbacks in the draft and that he, McMahon, was the best of the rest.

title: Court Argues Property-Rights Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  The Supreme Court has struggled for years over how and when to apply the Fifth Amendment's injunction that private property shall not be "taken for public use without just compensation."

title: Editorial Observer; Truth Commissions Take On a Local Flavor
description: When a nation goes through a transition from war or dictatorship to democracy, the standard practice is to hold elections, free political prisoners -- and, nowadays, convene a truth commission. Considered exotic only a few years ago, truth commissions gained renown with South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Today they have become an integral part of overcoming a repressive past.

title: New Economy; Corporate credit managers have long warned about Internet companies' shaky math. Now, people are listening.
description: STOCK analysts like Henry Blodget of Merrill Lynch still wax enthusiastic about the prospects for many of the troubled Web companies they follow. But with the capital markets closed to cash-short Internet companies, bullish analysts no longer hold the key to a company's ability to raise money.

title: Daimler Says It Expects A Big Drop In 2001 Profit
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., which has been dragged down by huge losses at Chrysler in the United States, expects its revenue to fall by 13 percent this year and its operating profit to decline by as much as 75 percent, company officials said tonight.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a halt of all animal exports by Britain after 27 pigs were found to have foot-and-mouth disease misstated their classification among mammals. Pigs are ungulates -- a group having hoofs -- not ruminants, which are cud-chewing animals.

title: Arizona's Thunderbird Lodge
description: The Anasazis liked it there so much that they built cave dwellings on the red-rock cliff walls centuries ago. And now through March 31, Canyon de Chelly, on the Navajo reservation in northeastern Arizona, is going to look more attractive to visitors, too. The Thunderbird Lodge in Canyon de Chelly National Monument is offering a $65 a night package on Friday, Saturday and Sunday that includes a room in the modern lodge, a Continental breakfast (or $3 off a full breakfast in the cafeteria) and 10 percent discounts on gift items and motorized canyon tours. Call (800) 679-2473 or visit www.tbirdlodge.com .

description: Dr. Arnold Jerome Friedhoff, a psychiatric researcher at New York University who investigated the biological underpinnings of mental disorders, died Wednesday at a rehabilitation center in Manhattan. He was 77 and a resident of the Upper East Side.

title: MediaTalk; Some Familiar Touches For Sunday Mornings
description: Is ABC's Sunday morning news program, ''This Week,'' trying to catch up to NBC's ''Meet the Press'' by cloning it? People at NBC think so.

title: How Oscar Nominees Fare on Tape and Disc
description: Russell Crowe and Colosseum carnage (''Gladiator'') play equally well at the cinema and on the sofa. But among other films, home viewers prefer to watch Julia Roberts test polluted water (''Erin Brockovich''), while people going out to the movies would rather see George Clooney swamped by seawater (''The Perfect Storm''). Or so say the data comparing the home-rental and box-office receipts for this year's Oscar-nominated films.

title: Microsoft's Appeal Seems to Find Sympathetic Ears Among Judges
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Judges on a federal appeals court today pelted lawyers representing the Justice Department and 19 states with skeptical questions about the decision last year that found Microsoft had repeatedly violated antitrust law. The questioning suggested that many elements of the decision were vulnerable to reversal.

title: Labor Party Agrees to Join Sharon's Government
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 26  Despite warnings that they were selling their souls for a scrap of power, leaders of the Labor Party agreed today to join a unity government led by Ariel Sharon. The party said it would select its ministers later in the week.

Full of enthusiasm, he displayed a new set of duplicate whist trays donated by a Mr. Z. Hall, who was sent a warm letter of thanks. It would now be possible for bridge players to eliminate the luck of the deal, as whist players had been doing for six years, thanks to John T. Mitchell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSCOVITZ, HOWARD, M.D.
description: MOSCOVITZ-Howard, M.D. The staff of the Zena and Michael A. He performed pioneering research in cardiovascular physiology and was a superb clinician who provided compassionate and outstanding care to his patients. We are also grateful for his deep commitment to Mount Sinai. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife and family.

title: INTEL IS BUYING SEMICONDUCTOR MAKER VXTEL
description: The Intel Corporation said it had agreed to buy VxTel Inc., which makes microchips that bridge traditional networks with the increasingly popular optical networks, for $550 million in cash. VxTel, a privately held company based in Fremont, Calif., was founded in March 1999 and has no revenue yet. Intel said it expected to complete the acquisition in the second quarter and ship its first VxTel products in the second half of the year. VxTel's technology transforms voice and data services that transmit over circuit-switched networks, which now carry most voice telephone calls, into a format that can beam through optical networks. Chris Gaither

title: Russia Can Be Our Ally on Missile Defense

In his meeting last weekend with Igor Ivanov, Russia's foreign minister, Secretary of State Colin Powell agreed to open a dialogue on this issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEATON, EDWARD K.
description: LEATON-Edward K. A resident of The Hermitage at Cedarfield, Richmond, VA., died February 23, 2001 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 34 years, Janet K. Leaton. Also surviving are five sons and their wives: Edward M. Leaton, M.D. and Barbara of Midlothian, VA; Robert A. and Valerie Leaton of Horseheads, NY; Thomas W. Leaton and Janet Janes of Vienna, VA; Richard K. and Karen Leaton of Louisville, KY; and James M. Leaton of Oak Ridge, NJ. Two sons, William G. Leaton and Kenneth H. Leaton predeceased their father. Surviving also are 11 grandchildren: E, Timothy, Christina and Jonathan; Robert, Kathleen and William; Kenneth and Andrew; and Cynthia, Benjamin and Allyssa. Ed was a graduate of Lehigh University '49, B.S. Mechanical Engineering, and Yale University: M.S. Industrial Administration. He is a member of The Tau Beta Pi Association, the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, and Omicron Delta Kappa Foundation. He was well known and respected in the life insurance and pension plan industry and was listed in ''Who's Who in the World'' and ''Who's Who in America'' for twenty years. During his career, he was President of the General Agents and Management Association International, and was elected to its ''Hall of Fame;'' was President of the National Association of Pension Consultants and Administrators; Vice President of The American Society of Pension Actuaries; President of the Life Manager's Association of Greater New York; President of the New England Life General Agents Association; Chairman of the ERISA Coordinating Committee, and President of the Million Dollar Round Table Foundation that successfully enabled ''MADD'' and ''Make-aWish'' in becoming national organizations. He was a General Agent of New England Financial for 22 years. In his first year as a General Agent, his NY agency placed second but for the remainder of his 21 year career he was the Company leader. Ed also served as a Trustee for Trinity Episcopal School of Ministry in Ambridge, PA, Barrington College and Gordon College in Wenham MA, and the American College in Bryn Mawr, PA. He was Senior Warden at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Darien, CT for three years and served on its Vestry for nine years. A memorial service will be held at Cedarfield on Saturday, March 3 at 2:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Hermitage at Cedarfield Samaritan Fund, 2300 Cedarfield Parkway, Richmond, VA 23233; The American Parkinsons Association, Inc., 807 So. Alfred St #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, JOSEPH LOCKE
description: SLATER-Joseph Locke, a graduate of Colgate University who returned to his alma mater to head its Department of English and retire from its faculty in 1986 as Edgar W.B. Fairchild Professor of American Literature, died on February 22, in Norwich, New York, of respiratory failure. Professor Slater, a distinguished scholar of the work of Ralph Waldo Emerson and editor of The Correspondence of Emerson and Carlyle (1964), was married for 62 years to Vivien Harvey Slater, pianist-in-residence at Colgate. Class valedictorian in 1937, Prof. Slater received his Ph.D from Columbia University in 1956. From 1944 to 1948, he was a lieutenant in the United States Navy, serving aboard troop transport vessels in the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. Before returning to Colgate, he taught at Lafayette College and at Rutgers University. He wrote extensively for The Saturday Review of Literature, where he served as assistant poetry editor in 1956-57. In addition to publishing in European and American literacy journals, he is best known as editor of the Emerson Carlyle correspondence, and for his general editorship of the Harvard University Press Collected Works of Ralph Waldo Emerson. During his retirement, he devoted himself to indexing his extensive collection of The Masses. Joe is survived, in addition to Mrs. Slater, by his daughter, Lydia Slater, of Hubbardsville, New York, by his son John, of Needham, MA, and two grandchildren, Joseph Kennedy Slater and Thomas Kennedy Slater. A memorial service, to be held on the Colgate campus, is planned for the spring.

title: Burke Signs New Contract
description: Goaltender Sean Burke and the Phoenix Coyotes agreed yesterday on a three-year contract extension that will pay him an average annual base salary of nearly $3 million. Burke's new deal also includes a no-trade clause, which means the Coyotes will almost certainly trade 28-year-old goaltender Nikolai Khabibulin, who has sat out nearly two seasons in a contract dispute.

title: Trying to Tame the Roar of Deadly Lakes
description: On the evening of Aug. 21, 1986, a cloud of carbon dioxide erupted from Lake Nyos in the mountainous region of northwestern Cameroon. Heavy and deadly, the gas rolled down hills, into valleys and villages, suffocating everything in its path. By the next morning, 1,700 people were dead.

title: Pergament Home Centers, Now Bankrupt, Is Going Out of Business
description: Pergament Home Centers, a regional chain that once was the dominant home improvement firm on Long Island, is going out of business, a company lawyer said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLAND, SEYMOUR
description: BERLAND-Seymour. Age 87, died February 24, peacefully in Charlotte, NC. He was the son of the late Joseph and Anna Berland, husband of the late Jean Spector Berland. He is survived by sons Joseph and Richard Berland, daughters-in-law Sue and Joanne and ten loving grandchildren. Funeral and interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Comcast Reports a Profit
description: The Comcast Corporation, the big cable television provider, said today that it posted a fourth-quarter profit on a system swap with AT&T and an increase in customers for fast Internet service and digital TV. The company said net income was $778.5 million, or 80 cents a share, after the payment of preferred dividends, in contrast to a loss of $174.2 million, or 24 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 25 percent, to $2.41 billion, said Marlene Dooner, a spokeswoman. Fourth-quarter profit was increased by a pretax gain of $1.15 a share for swapping systems with AT&T, said Ms. Dooner, who would not provide profit excluding charges and gains. Comcast, which served 7.6 million homes at the end of the year, said the number of Internet and digital TV customers had more than doubled.

title: Asian-American Story
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When we built our house in '55, our taxes were less than $200. We expanded to raise five kids, and every room I added has a memory, a history. And I feel that all the new citizens moving in here are just confiscating our home to pay for their schools.''

title: Mormons Release Database For Blacks Searching Roots
description: The Mormon Church yesterday released a database of 72,000 bank accounts opened by former slaves and other blacks after the Civil War, records that could help millions of their descendants trace their roots.

title: SCI SYSTEMS TO CUT 3,800 JOBS AND CLOSE PLANTS
description: SCI Systems, an electronics contract manufacturer, said yesterday that it planned to cut about 3,800 jobs, or 10 percent of its staff, and close an unspecified number of plants because sales growth has weakened. SCI Systems, based in Huntsville, Ala., makes base stations for cell phones, and personal computers for other companies. The job cuts and plant closings will result in a charge of $40 million to $60 million for the present quarter, the chief financial officer, Jim Moylan said. The job cuts, will be made through attrition and layoffs, he said.

title: Sports of The Times; Frazier Assists Are With Words
description: THE high school principal, at 43, is old enough to recall when Walt Frazier was Clyde and Clyde epitomized cool.

title: Sir Donald Bradman, 92, Cricket Legend, Dies
description: Sir Donald Bradman, rated the greatest player in the history of cricket, died Sunday at age 92, sending his native Australia and the sport's followers around the world into mourning.

title: Metro Business Briefing; LONGER RUNWAY A PRIORITY
description: In a formal position paper, the authority that runs Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport has said its top priority is lengthening the airport's main runway to accommodate increased jet service to major travel hubs like Chicago and Atlanta. For regional jets to operate with full passenger loads, the main runway would have to be lengthened about 2,000 feet, to 7,600 feet. The current runway, the Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority said, ''is too short for most airlines to operate on a break-even basis.'' In its paper, released last week, the authority said it envisioned Tweed accommodating 30 flights a day by several major airlines. Now, only US Airways operates flights to and from New Haven, using turboprop aircraft and flying to Philadelphia and Washington. David Herszenhorn (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Leaving Asthma Behind, With the Car
description: When Atlanta put strict driving rules in effect for the 1996 summer Olympics, air pollution dropped. But something else went down, too: the number of children seeking treatment for acute asthma.

description: At the climax of one of the biggest undercover money-laundering investigation in United States history, federal agents seized $1.8 million in 1998 from Citibank accounts in New York that were held by a mysterious Cayman Islands bank that had no corporate offices anywhere in the world.

title: Mets Just Don't Know What Shinjo Can Do
description: Tsuyoshi Shinjo is the Mets' international man of mystery -- stylish, superstitious, shadowed by 30 Japanese reporters. Some of his skills are unknown, and he is only beginning to show them. To the Mets, his profile is like the message on his Web site: ''Under Construction.''

description: Yahoo Inc. said today that H&R Block Inc. had agreed to provide tax information and filing services for Yahoo's online tax center.

title: Fellow Actors Honor Jason Robards
description: Audiences may have been sad to lose Jason Robards, who died on Dec. 26 at age 78 after a long battle with cancer. But on Broadway yesterday afternoon at a memorial service at the Broadhurst Theater to honor Mr. Robards, the stage and film star, it was actors who seemed to feel most profoundly the loss of one of the greats, one of their own.

title: South Korea Sees Slowing Of Economy
description: South Korea's economic revival appears to have bogged down amid questions about the government's commitment to changing the way business is done here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLACK, DOROTHY SCHAFF
description: SLACK-Dorothy Schaff. Died on February 25 in her 99th year: beloved wife of the late Meyer H. Slack, dear mother of Leta J. Zoigt and Ellen C. Bayle, loving grandmother, great-grandmother, and sister. We shall miss you sorely. Rest in peace. Funeral private.

title: QWEST TO SEEK RIGHT TO EXPAND LONG-DISTANCE SERVICE
description: Qwest Communications International Inc. will ask regulators for permission to sell long-distance phone service in a state, perhaps Colorado or Arizona, this summer, its chief executive, Joseph Nacchio, said yesterday. After getting approval from the Federal Communications Commission in one state, Qwest will seek permission later this year and in early 2002 to sell long-distance in the other 13 Western states where it sells local phone services. When Qwest, the nation's No. 4 long-distance company, bought U S West Inc. last year, it was barred from selling long-distance service where U S West provided local services. Qwest must convince the F.C.C. that rivals have access to its local networks before it can provide long-distance services.

title: Microsoft's Appeal Seems to Find Sympathetic Ears Among Judges
description: Judges on a federal appeals court pelted lawyers representing the Justice Department and 19 states with skeptical questions today about the decision last year that found Microsoft had repeatedly violated antitrust law. The questioning suggested that many elements of the decision were vulnerable to reversal.

title: Fresh Air Follows Sosa Into Camp
description: His first spring-training workout behind him, Sammy Sosa quickly separated himself from the contractual whiners. ''Missed the plane a couple of times,'' he said, alluding to the six workouts he had missed, then smiled broadly and added, ''Just kidding.''

title: DRIVEWAY.COM ENDING WEB-STORAGE SERVICE
description: The Driveway.com online file-sharing and storage service told its customers yesterday that they had until next Monday to remove all files before it shuts down its consumer operations. Driveway, based in San Francisco, is also cutting its staff as it moves to focus on enterprise-level companies. A notice on the company's Web site suggests customers transfer files to a former rival, FreeDrive, which says it is the largest online storage provider, with 12 million customers who each get 50 megabytes of server space to share photos, music and other files. Phone calls to Driveway were not answered. ''The world's not quite ready to look at storage as a utility,'' said a Forrester Research analyst, Galen Schreck. ''Companies haven't yet tried to do this in-house, let alone take it outside.'' David J. Wallace

title: TERRA NETWORKS NAMES NEW U.S. PRESIDENT
description: The Internet services company Terra Networks S.A. said that it had named Stephen Killeen as president of United States operations as it reorganizes its management after the resignation of several top executives. Mr. Killeen, 38, replaces Ron Sege as head of Terra Lycos U.S. Mr. Sege and the unit's chief operating officer, Abel Linares, resigned earlier this month as the former Lycos Inc., purchased by Terra in October for $6.5 billion, was integrated into the company, based in Barcelona, Spain. Terra Networks will change its name to Terra Lycos S.A. Bob Davis, who ran Lycos, based in Waltham, Mass., since it started in 1995, resigned as chief executive of Terra Lycos on Feb. 1. Mr. Killeen, who led the financial information Web site Raging Bull, said he was hired for the job because of his focus on consumers and the ''bottom line.''

Recently, they have won some significant convictions and have brought some important charges in a mounting cleanup campaign that they hope will restore investor confidence.

title: Detecting Bombardment
description: By far the most interesting scientific news of the week was the application of an ingenious new method for detecting past bombardment of the earth by asteroids. The method, which depends on searching for trapped gases created in stars, now points to an asteroid as the probable cause of the great extinction of life that ended the Permian era some 250 million years ago.

title: A Passive Everywoman on an Embarrassing Precipice
description: Three weeks before turning 50, Leslie Ayvazian was on vacation in Greece with her family. The temperature was 112 degrees and the air-conditioner in their hotel room was broken, so they all went to the pool where, importuned by her 11-year-old son, she climbed to the high dive and became paralyzed with fear, unable to jump off. Evidently what went through her mind up there was her life.

title: SPANISH WIRELESS PROFIT IS UP
description: Telefnica Mviles, the wireless subsidiary of Telefnica, the Spanish telecommunications company, reported a 52 percent increase in subscribers and a 36.5 percent rise in operating profit, to 2.45 billion euros ($2.25 billion), despite a significant drop of average revenue per user in Spain. Consolidated revenue rose 47 percent in Latin America, thanks mainly to Brazil, which accounted for 2.57 billion euros ($2.36 billion). Spain contributed 68 percent of sales, a 28.2 percent increase at 4.80 billion euros ($4.41 billion). Mviles added nine million customers in Latin America, a gain of 40 percent. Emma Daily

description: For the last two months, the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant has been generating almost as much angst as electricity. A series of leaks, shutdowns and errors has alarmed elected officials and delayed Consolidated Edison's efforts to get the plant back into full operation.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PAIR ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: A retired physician and his son, the president of a computer company based in New York, were accused yesterday of defrauding 11 investors out of more than $1.8 million. An indictment unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan charged Dr. Joshua Gurin, 62, and his son Edward Gurin, 26, president of the Trinarc Corporation, with bilking victims by falsely offering them no-risk investments that would double or triple their money, according to the United States attorney's office in Manhattan. Their schemes, the office said, included soliciting investors to buy warrants in one company that had never issued warrants and in another that did not exist. The indictment said Joshua Gurin told people his son had successfully invested for well-known figures including former Vice President Al Gore. The prosecutor, David B. Anders, said he did not know whether the son had been involved in Mr. Gore's financial matters. The two men were in custody yesterday afternoon awaiting a bail hearing and their lawyer did not return a telephone call.

description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 27  On his first visit to NATO headquarters as secretary of state, Colin L. Powell said today that the United States agreed in principle to a "phased and conditioned" return of the Yugoslav Army to an area of southern Serbia that has been a buffer zone.

description: No one will ever know when someone first raised arms into the air, pivoted and took a few light steps this way and that -- and danced.

description: The United States Supreme Court dismissed an appeal today for a new hearing for a Tennessee man who has argued that recanted eyewitness testimony and new ballistics evidence is sufficient to overturn his conviction in the 1981 murder of a Memphis police officer.

title: Turkey's Precarious Success
description: Late last week in Turkey, the stock market declined by 18 percent and the lira lost a third of its value. Interest rates have soared to several thousand percent, and inflation is around 30 percent. What reportedly scared away investors was a publicized argument between President Ahmet Necdet Sezer and Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, whom the president had accused of being too lenient toward corrupt politicians. But that was merely the beginning of the crisis, not its underlying cause.

title: Metro Business Briefing; VORNADO DOWNGRADE CONSIDERED
description: Vornado Realty Trust's credit ratings could be lowered because of concern over its plans to take control of the World Trade Center in New York City. Moody's Investors Service said in a news release that it has placed the real estate investment trust's preferred stock ''under review for possible downgrade'' because of the plans to acquire a 99-year lease on the center. A downgrade would knock Vornado's preferred stock, which Moody's currently rates baa3, into noninvestment-grade status. The move by Moody's came after Standard & Poor's said Friday that it was considering downgrading $450 million of Vornado debt because of the World Trade Center plan. If the two rating services were to lower their ratings, it would raise the cost of borrowing for the company, which is based in Saddle Brook, N.J. Last week, Vornado was named the winning bidder to run the 10.6-million-square-foot complex. It bid $3.25 billion. Moody's said it was concerned that Vornado's ''extensive development and redevelopment pipeline in Manhattan,'' coupled with the size and scope of the trade center transaction, could hurt the company's credit profile and operating infrastructure.

title: DISNEY INTERNET GROUP TO CUT 135 MORE JOBS
description: The Walt Disney Internet Group said yesterday that it was eliminating 135 jobs, mostly at its ABC.com and ABCnews.com units. The news came a little more than a month after the online Disney subsidiary said that it was laying off 400 employees. The company said it needed to streamline. Michelle Bergman, a spokeswoman for the company, said the cuts did not reflect sagging revenue from online advertising, and that revenue in the first quarter of this year rose 36 percent over the quarter a year earlier. The cutbacks announced yesterday and in January, which included the planned closing of the Go.com Web portal, left Disney's Internet group with about 1,500 employees. Also, yesterday, Disney's ABC News unit said that it would trim $15 million to $20 million in costs and that some saving would be realized by ending some correspondents' contracts. Matt Richtel

title: Cloaked in Stealth Molecules, Drugs Sneak Past the Body's Defenses
description: A substance used to thicken shampoo and lipstick is now making its way into medicine, potentially improving the effectiveness of drugs to battle diseases like hepatitis C, diabetes and cancer.

title: Your Baby May Be Wailing Right on Key
description: Think your child is a natural-born musician? You may well be right.

title: Foreign Affairs; Glasnost In the Gulf
description: The leaders of the 22 Arab nations will gather in Jordan in a few weeks for a summit meeting to discuss the Arab-Israeli conflict. What's striking is that not one of these leaders has been chosen in a totally free and fair election. No other region of the world, including sub-Saharan Africa, is so democracy lite. The good news, though, is that there are democratic stirrings these days among Arab peoples, most notably in Syria, where ''discussion forums'' recently sprouted, calling for greater democracy, free speech and political parties. The forums were shut down last week by Syrian security services, but other flowers are not so easily crushed -- most notably Qatar's Al-Jazeera satellite TV station.

title: Burglars Assault Woman
description: A 34-year-old woman reported that she was tied up and sexually assaulted by three burglars in a house in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: Skating in Quicksand, Rangers Lose
description: There were a few no-shows among the crowd of 18,200 in Madison Square Garden last night when the weary Rangers lost by 3-2 to the Ottawa Senators. Perhaps the Detroit Red Wings could have filled those empty chairs by sending a few more scouts.

title: Judges Voice Doubt On Order Last Year To Split Microsoft
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The government suffered a second difficult day of questioning in its Microsoft antitrust case today when a Federal appeals court cast doubt about a judge's order last year to break the company in two.

title: New Rules in Sperm and Egg's Cat-and-Mouse Game
description: Heard the one about why it takes 100 million sperm to fertilize an egg? Because none of them will stop to ask for directions.

title: ESC MEDICAL AGREES TO PURCHASE UNIT OF COHERENT
description: ESC Medical Systems Ltd., an Israeli maker of medical lasers, said yesterday that it agreed to buy a unit of Coherent Inc. for $203 million in cash, shares and bonds, becoming the largest company in the market. The transaction will add 60 cents a share to net income in 2001, ESC said. Coherent, based in Santa Clara, Calif., will receive $100 million in cash and $12.9 million in bonds and become ESC's largest shareholder with 5.4 million shares, or 16 percent.

title: POWELL PROPOSES EASING SANCTIONS ON IRAQI CIVILIANS
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said on Monday that he had won agreement from Arab nations on a plan to modify sanctions on Iraq by letting in more civilian supplies but sharpening controls on strategic items sought by President Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRIGHT, ANNA LEONY
description: WRIGHT-Anna Leony. On February 24, 2001, Volunteered in New York City Schools assisting with remedial reading, also volunteered at New York Foundling Hospital assisting with abused handicapped children. Wife of Robert F., father to Winston F., grandfather to 4. Services on Tuesday with visitation on Monday at the Bartron Funeral Home, Montrose, PA. Contributions to New York Foundling Hospital, 590 Sixth Ave., NY, NY 10011.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Race of Her Own

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLBERT, ANN
description: COLBERT-Ann. Died peacefully on February 25, having recently reached the age of 95; mourned by her family, daughter Vera Chimene, son-in-law Lucian Chimene, grandson Claude Chimene and granddaughter Alyda Brunt and two great grandchildren, Steven and Allegra, all of Texas. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, February 28 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Metropolitan Opera for the Young Artist Development Program, Lincoln Center, New York City 10023.

title: Bayern To Visit MetroStars
description: The MetroStars agreed yesterday to host one of the top European teams, Bayern Munich, on May 26 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Campaign Finance Law Inspires A Gluttonous Mayoral Metaphor
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the cost of the city's generous campaign finance program was approaching the ''pig factor,'' and that it was feeding a rapacious industry of political consultants, advertising executives and pollsters.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Press for Clarity in a Property Rights Dispute
description: The Supreme Court has struggled for years over how and when to apply the Fifth Amendment's injunction that private property shall not be ''taken for public use without just compensation,'' and an argument today over whether an environmental regulation that barred development on 18 acres of oceanfront wetlands in Rhode Island amounted to a ''taking'' did not necessarily bring the justices any closer to a clear answer.

title: Brotherhood of Terror and Flight, Not Joy
description: Beethoven's Ninth Symphony was the unheard work hovering over the concert by Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic on Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall. The main offering was the Symphony No. 9 by Hans Werner Henze, composed in 1995-97 and receiving its American premiere in honor of Mr. Henze's 75th birthday this year.

title: Discoveries as Intricate As the Human Shape
description: As is usually the case with the work of a young writer, there are cavils to be leveled at ''Sitting Pretty,'' by a young British playwright, Amy Rosenthal, which is receiving its American premiere at the Sol Goldman Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of the Educational Alliance on East 14th Street.

title: In Performance: Harmonies Heavenly and Adventurous
description: CMUSIC

title: CMG RISES ON OUTLOOK
description: CMG P.L.C. shares rose 12 percent after the company, a British-Dutch computer services concern, said sales of mobile-text-message software more than doubled in the second half and would rise more than 50 percent this year. CMG also said second-half net profit fell 48 percent, to 16.5 million ($24 million), or 2.5 pence (4 cents) a share, from 31.8 million ($46.3 million), or 6.1 pence (9 cents), a year earlier, hurt by acquisition costs. Revenue rose to 460.6 million ($670.4 million) from 318.1 million ($462.9 million).

title: Israel Laborites Vote 2-1 to Join Sharon Cabinet
description: Despite warnings that they were selling their souls for a scrap of power, leaders of the Labor Party agreed today to join a unity government led by Ariel Sharon. The party is to select its ministers on Thursday.

title: Excerpts From Arguments in the Appeal of the Antitrust Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Following are excerpts from oral arguments today in the Microsoft antitrust case before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. Representing Microsoft was Richard J. Urowsky; John G. Roberts Jr. presented arguments for the 19 state attorneys general who have sued Microsoft along with the Justice Department.

title: Israel's Unity Government
description: Israel's Labor Party acted responsibly yesterday by voting to join a national unity government under the Likud Party leader, Ariel Sharon. Crucial details are yet to be worked out, including Labor's new leadership and the identity of its cabinet nominees. But the important portfolios Labor will hold, including the Defense and Foreign Ministries, should permit it to exert a moderating influence on the new government's policies.

title: Sour Economic Reports Send Nasdaq to 2-Year Low
description: Technology stocks fell sharply today, pulling the Nasdaq composite index down more than 4 percent to its lowest close since the end of 1998, after more sour economic reports failed to prompt the immediate cut in interest rates that much of Wall Street had come to expect.

title: Article 2001022791620966999 -- No Title
description: By MARGARET W. GOLDSBOROUGH

title: The Big City; How a Touch Of Success Found Harlem
description: IF you think of Democrats as the politicians dedicated to rebuilding cities, you might have noticed something odd about the recent series of articles about a block of West 129th Street.

title: Clues in an Inkblot
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Inventory Problem Leads To Profit Warning at Nike

title: G.O.P. Leader In New York Steps Down After Decade
description: William D. Powers, the iron-willed political boss who transformed New York's debt-ridden and dispirited Republican Party into an effective political operation, stepped down today after 10 years as the chairman.

title: A Pick-and-Choose Song Repertory
description: Everyone entering Carnegie Hall Saturday night for the first of three recitals in the Jessye Norman and James Levine Songbook Series received a large souvenir booklet containing a collection of texts from which the artists would select songs for that evening, a few notes about the repertory, and a couple of reproductions of artworks.

title: A Day Late, Team Earnhardt Wins Again
description: Steve Park had snapped a special black baseball cap around his gearshift handle before today's race. He would say later that he wanted to be prepared for the sweetest of racing moments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, FANNY (NEE LASHKEVITZ)
description: WOLF-Fanny (nee Lashkevitz). On February 26, 2001 of S. Orange, formerly of Brooklyn, New York. Beloved wife of the late Arnold. Devoted mother of Herbert and Maxine, Robert & Ronnie, Stephen and Alice Wolf, Joani and David Ascher. Loving sister of Sophie Friedenson. Adored grandmother of Ellen and Eric, Barbara and Kenny, Rachel, Melisande and John, Alex, Richard, Randi, Ethan, Ari, & Shonna. Great grandmother of Danielle, Cody, Samantha, Baird, and Amanda. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, N.J. on Wednesday February 28th, 2001 at 11:30 AM. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: As Taxes Rise, Suburbs Work to Keep Elderly
description: Suburbs have always had one big idea, to be comfortable and safe places for families with children. But local politicians here and around the country are working hard these days to cater to a new generation of suburban V.I.P.'s -- those retired couples in the three- or four-bedroom houses down the street. People like Fred and Mary Froehlich.

title: THAILAND SETS ECONOMIC PLAN
description: Thailand's new prime minister, the telecommunications tycoon Thaksin Shinawatra, outlined to Parliament his plans for helping both big commercial banks and small farmers. Over the weekend, Mr. Thaksin and top bankers agreed to create a national asset management company to buy about $28 billion in nonperforming loans from the banks at a discount. Supporters of the plan said it would help revive lending by relieving banks of the need to haggle with politically powerful debtors. Critics argued that it represented an inflationary, taxpayer-financed bailout of vested interests. Mr. Thaksin is also proposing state financing and a moratorium on debt payments for small villages. Wayne Arnold

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADDOCK, SANDY (NEE CAROL SANDRA JENKINS)
description: PADDOCK-Sandy (nee Carol Sandra Jenkins). Died February 10 at her home in Shoreham. A longtime Glen Cove resident, she was the wife of Bob and the mother of Bruce and Patricia. She was also godmother to thousands of pets, as the proprietor of the Animal Inn, a boarding kennel in Glen Cove. The Paddocks will celebrate Sandy's life on Sunday, March 4, at 2 PM, at Harrison House, Dosoris Lane, Glen Cove. Donations may be sent to the James A. Baker Institute for Animal Health, New York State College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, New York 14853.

title: Siegel Quits Rights Group to Run for City Office
description: Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, who has been a frequent critic of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, resigned from that position yesterday to run for public advocate.

title: LUCENT REVISES AGERE OFFERING AGAIN
description: Lucent Technologies lowered the value of the shares it plans to sell in a microelectronics operation for the second time in a week, underscoring the chilly reception expected for offerings of shares in communications companies. Lucent plans to sell the operation, recently named Agere Systems, for $12 to $14 a share, compared with an earlier range of $16 to $19. Lucent had originally hoped to sell shares in Agere (pronounced a-GEAR) for $15 to $20 apiece. The company still expects to raise up to $7 billion in the sale, after increasing the number of shares it hopes to sell in Agere, to 500 million from 370.3 million, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Simon Romero

title: A Role for Eyes in Ringing of the Ears
description: Tinnitus is well known as a disease that affects the ears, but researchers now suspect that the eyes may also play a role.

title: Stars in Tow, A Hollywood Talent Agent Jumps Ship
description: Talent agents have traditionally sought to lure away one another's high-priced clients. But times have changed, and talent agents now seek to lure rival agents, who bring their high-priced clients with them.

title: ALCAN PICKS A TOP EXECUTIVE
description: The board of Alcan Aluminium has named Travis Engen, 56, as president and chief executive, succeeding Jacques Bougie, who resigned unexpectedly last month. Mr. Engen, who was born in California and is a graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is currently chairman and chief executive of ITT Industries, which was spun off from the ITT Corporation in 1995. He has been on the board of Alcan, based in Montreal, since 1996. Mr. Bougie resigned on Jan 10; Mr. Engen will take over on March 12. Timothy Pritchard

title: Daimler Anticipates A Hard Year, Losing Perhaps $1.5 Billion
description: With his career and the fate of the world's biggest auto merger hanging in the balance, the chairman and chief executive of DaimlerChrysler A.G. announced his plans for a turnaround today but forecast a grim year ahead.

title: Marine in Charge of Troubled Osprey Program Is Being Replaced
description: The Marine Corps colonel who has managed the troubled V-22 Osprey program since 1997, a period when two Osprey crashes killed 23 marines, has been denied a promotion to brigadier general and will retire in June, service officials said today.

title: Nike 3rd-Quarter Profit To Fall Short of Forecast
description: Nike said yesterday that its third-quarter profit would fall short of forecasts because of problems with an inventory system that led to shortages and late deliveries.

title: Varied Portraits of bin Laden Emerge in Embassy Bomb Case
description: On a typical weekend, the witness said, Osama bin Laden liked to relax at his farm near the Blue Nile in Sudan, where he spent time riding horses. His followers would often accompany him, the witness went on, and they would picnic on the grounds of the farm or swim or amuse themselves by playing soccer.

title: Citizenship and Pardons
description: To the Editor:

title: Brother of Former Treasurer Is Sentenced in Bribery Case
description: A brother of the former Connecticut state treasurer was sentenced today to 21 months in prison for his role in a bribery scheme that spawned the largest corruption scandal in the modern history of the state.

title: Political Missteps by Organized Labor
description: With Republicans in control of the White House and Congress, organized labor is understandably worried about its loss of influence in Washington. That fear has led the A.F.L.-C.I.O. into a misguided effort to oppose several provisions of the McCain-Feingold bill, which seeks to reform campaign finance practices. The union move is bad for the country and ultimately for labor's Democratic political allies.

title: Rich, Yes, but Even More Different: Liberal and Fun
description: IT is fun to watch Agnes Gund, a multimillionaire, sorting through her mail. In her warmly appointed office at the Museum of Modern Art, where she is president, it is late afternoon, a long conversation is winding down, and her tongue is finally letting loose, providing a devilish hint of her fearless candor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBER, FLORENCE
description: EBER-Florence. Of Belle Harbor and Los Angeles. On February 24, 2001. Beloved mother of Dr. Leslie and Judith Eber and Robert and Susan Eber. Cherished grandmother of Gabriella and Daniella, Gabriel and Jordan, and adoring great grandmother of Alexandra.

title: White House Logs Said To Show Pre-Pardon Visits
description: Secret Service records show that Denise Rich and Beth Dozoretz visited the White House on the evening of Jan. 19, a few hours before Bill Clinton issued a pardon to Marc Rich, lawyers familiar with the case said today. But associates of the two women disputed the records and said neither was there.

title: Court Rules Cost Should Not Affect Action on Clean Air
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the way the federal government sets clean-air standards, rejecting an industry argument that regulators must balance the desire for clean air with the cost of having it.

title: Know Bones About It!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Jeter's Sore Shoulder Not Serious
description: Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter was scratched from the team's intrasquad game this afternoon because of a sore throwing shoulder, a condition that the club does not think is serious.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Hantavirus Found Near the Beaten Track
description: More health risks may be associated with off-road vehicles than just rolling over. A new study raises the possibility that off-road activities increase the spread of the deadly hantavirus in mice that live near such popular recreation areas.

title: REVLON REPORTS LOSS IS BIGGER THAN EXPECTED
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, said yesterday that it lost more than expected in the fourth quarter as sales of its namesake makeup and Almay skin-care products declined. Revlon's loss from operations narrowed to $29.6 million, or 58 cents a share, more than the 27 cents a share that analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected the company to lose. Sales fell 23 percent, to $321.1 million.

title: Strike Zone's Bar Is Raised; Umps Call It By the Book
description: Like a professor in class, Umpire Jerry Crawford stood in the Yankees' clubhouse here today and, in essence, taught Strike Zone 101. Crawford explained how Major League Baseball wants balls and strikes to be interpreted, and pupils like Roger Clemens, David Justice and Glenallen Hill asked questions.

title: Tunnel Vision; Remembering Broken Noses And Collars
description: It is not the most conventional method, but a great way to examine how far the New York City subway has come over the last three decades is to consider the medical records of a man named Brendan J. McGarry.

title: U.S. and NATO Back Serbian Access to Kosovo Buffer Zone
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 27  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States was prepared to allow Serbian soldiers back into a three-mile-wide buffer zone along the Kosovo border, where Albanian militants have been increasingly active.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, JORDAN
description: EDELMAN-Jordan. 76, on February 25, 2001 after a valiant struggle with lung cancer. Jordan Edelman was born in the Bronx on November 25, 1924. Beloved son of Abraham and Sylvia Edelman, devoted brother of Theo Heller, adored father of Abbe Hesketh and Marti Christianson and cherished grandfather of Joel, Leah, Beth and Samuel. Educated at the University of Pittsburgh and Harvard University, Jordan received his PhD in Psychology. A US army veteran of World War II, he was an administrator of mental health at Anna State Hospital in Anna, IL. He was blessed with a wonderful sense of humor, a warm and caring nature and will be missed by all of us who loved him.

title: Local Scouting Board, Calling Gay Ban 'Stupid,' Urges End to National Policy
description: Calling the ban on homosexual scouts and troop leaders by the Boy Scouts of America ''repugnant'' and ''stupid,'' members of the group's New York City board announced yesterday that they were trying to persuade the Texas-based national organization to renounce and repeal the policy.

title: Elizabeth Police Say Man Shot by Officers Wanted to Be Killed
description: A man who yelled that he was armed but was only holding a Bible -- was fatally shot here this weekend by a police officer, the authorities said. They said they believed he wanted the police to kill him.

description: BLUM-Seymour. On February 23, 2001. Loving father of Rochelle Winiker and her fiance Jim Kisatsky and Jeff Blum and his wife Leslie. title: Public Interests; A Man With A Plan
description: George W. Bush is making his big budget speech tonight. You remember. The president.

title: A New Script For Greenspan At House Panel
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, will offer revised testimony on the United States economy and monetary policy when he appears before the House Financial Services Committee on Wednesday, a Fed spokesman said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, PAULINE SHERMAN
description: WEINTRAUB-Pauline Sherman, 93. Died Feb. 25 at home surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of the late Morris Weintraub, cherished mother of Howard, Vivian, & Leonard. Loving grandmother of Robin, Alexander, Bonnie, Scott, Melissa, Randy, Sherry and Craig. Adoring great grandmother of Brandon, Griffin, Kayla, Taylor, Jake, Sidney, Max, and Natalie. Dear friend of Ida James. Services will be held at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett,, Long Island, on Tuesday, February 27, at 1 PM.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell on speculation that OPEC will back away from a second output cut this year when it meets next month. In New York, crude oil for April delivery fell 62 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $28.42 a barrel.

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPFERBERG, HERBERT
description: KUPFERBERG - Herbert. The staff of Parade Magazine mourns the loss of a beloved friend and colleague. In his 33 years of service, Herb Kupferberg helped shape Parade into the successful magazine it is today. His contributions were significant and farreaching; his talent immense. Many benefited from his wise counsel and guidance. We will miss his sense of humor, keen intellect and deep sense of commitment. We extend our deepest sympathies to his loving wife, Barbara, his children and grandchildren. Walter Anderson, Publisher

title: U.S. Finds Rights Abuses in China, Colombia and Israel
description: The State Department concluded today that despite seven years of deepening American economic engagement with China, the human rights situation there had worsened significantly, with ''intensified crackdowns'' on religious organizations, political dissenters and ''any person or group perceived to threaten the government.''

description: Music Before 1800

title: Claude Shannon, Mathematician, Dies at 84
description: Dr. Claude Elwood Shannon, the American mathematician and computer scientist whose theories laid the groundwork for the electronic communications networks that now lace the earth, died on Saturday in Medford, Mass., after a long fight with Alzheimer's disease. He was 84.

For almost forty years, his vision served our Association as a bright beacon, lighting its growth. He will be missed for his commitment to principle, the soundness of his judgment, and, most importantly, the warmth of his friendship. American Fats and Oils Assn., Inc David Italiaander, Pres. Walter J. Karpinski, Vice. Pres. Nicholas B. Sander, Vice Pres. Ralph Joel, Treasurer Eric H. Jackson, Secretary David E. Rothschild, Exec. Dir. Bardin Levavy, General Counsel

title: Police Say Shooting May Be Linked to Rap Feud
description: The police were investigating yesterday whether a shooting outside a Manhattan radio station on Sunday afternoon stemmed from a feud between the rap artists Lil' Kim and Foxy Brown, the authorities said.

title: Judges Scrutinize Microsoft Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Judges on a federal appeals court pelted lawyers representing the Justice Department and 19 states with skeptical questions today about the decision last year that found Microsoft had repeatedly violated antitrust law. The questioning suggested that many elements of the decision were vulnerable to reversal.

title: Drunken Riding: An Invitation for Injury
description: Researchers from Johns Hopkins University are reporting a strong link between alcohol consumption and bicycle injuries and deaths.

title: A Century of Service, Battlefield to Bedside
description: ''100 Years of American Nursing: Celebrating a Century of Caring,'' edited by Thelma M. Schorr and Maureen Shawn Kennedy, Lippincott, $38.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALBOT, ROBERT ''PETE''
description: TALBOT-Robert ''Pete'' 83. Of Bloomfield, CT and Fishers Island, NY died February 26, 2001 in CT. He was the son of the late Harold Richmond Talbot and Nannie Brown Talbot. He graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1935 and from Yale University in 1939. He was retired from Pratt and Whitney Aircraft. Survivors include his wife, Caroline Allen Talbot, three sons and a daughter and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Monday, March 5, 2001 at 2:00 P.M. at Asylum Hill Congregational Church, Hartford, CT. Donations may be made to the American Red Cross, 209 Farmington Ave., Farmington, CT 06032 or the Henry L. Ferguson Museum, Fishers Island, NY 06390.

title: At Last, Scientists Find Bones From a Tenontosaurus That Didn't Lose Its Head
description: The Tenontosaurus, a large plant-eating dinosaur, was to the predatory Deinonychus 110 million years ago what the wildebeest is to the lion: lunch.

description: The Seeds of Dance

description: To the Editor:

title: HSBC Reports Hobbled Profit For Last Year
description: HSBC Holdings reported a full-year profit today that was marred by weakened trading income and undercut by the muted recovery in Asia. The results, below many analysts' expectations, were more disheartening because of HSBC's near-term forecast.

title: The Tricky Business of Cross-Cultural Theater; The Challenge (Beyond the Anglos) Is Attracting Latinos of All Stripes
description: Dasha Epstein, the producer of ''4 Guys Named Jos . . . and una Mujer Named Mara!'' a musical revue playing off Broadway since September, says she never counts on advance sales to tell her how well her show is doing on any given week.

title: Russian Sub's Officer Wrote Of Torpedo Blast, Izvestia Says
description: A newspaper here reported today that a note scrawled by an officer aboard the submarine Kursk and found by divers last summer said the vessel sank because of an explosion caused by a torpedo that apparently misfired.

title: Yugoslav Parliament Passes Amnesty for Jailed Kosovars
description: The Yugoslav Parliament passed a long-awaited amnesty law today that will free several hundred Kosovo Albanians held in Serbian prisons since the war in Kosovo in 1999 and will clear thousands of draft dodgers and deserters in Yugoslavia from prosecution by the army.

title: Take Tradition, Add Modernity and Make Life
description: The 651 Arts ''Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation'' festival ended on Saturday night at the BAM Harvey Theater with the inspired combination of a tribute to Katherine Dunham with a performance by Ronald K. Brown. Among Ms. Dunham's major contributions to American dance were her reconstructions and transformations of traditional African, Caribbean and American dance forms in theatrical programs in the 1940's. Her evident respect for and delight in those forms make it hard to believe -- as one commentator suggested in an excerpt shown from ''Free to Dance,'' a new documentary produced by the American Dance Festival -- that Ms. Dunham saw her presentations as dignifying the original dances.

title: Trouble With 'The Bag' Is in the Head
description: The fog was lifting, and my wife's voice echoed thinly across the recovery room. ''The surgery was successful,'' she said. ''The operation lasted over six hours.''

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS AGAIN LOWERS PROJECTIONS
description: Citing ''the economic slowdown that is continuing to constrain demand for technology products,'' Texas Instruments lowered revenue projections for the second time in five weeks. The company, the No. 1 maker of computer chips for mobile phones, also lowered its capital spending plans to $2 billion, a 30 percent reduction from last year. Last week, Motorola, a major competitor, said it might report its first quarterly loss in 15 years because of weakening demand. Texas Instruments plans to reduce costs through voluntary retirements, temporarily idling plants and imposing a freeze on new hiring. The company's stock fell $1, a 3 percent drop, to $29.15 yesterday. Andrew Zipern

title: A Short, Speckled History Of a Transplanted Hand
description: From beginning to end, Clint Hallam's landmark hand transplant embarrassed nearly everyone involved.

The story was ''An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge,'' not ''Incident at Owl Creek,'' and the author was Ambrose Bierce, not Pierce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, EDWARD F. JR.
description: PIERCE-Edward F. Jr., on February 23, 2001. Former Editor & Director of Public Relations, IBM, NYC. Resident of Patterson, NY. Survived by several nieces & nephews and many friends. Memorial service Tuesday 11AM at the home of Thomas Kennedy and Edward Pierce, 382 Haviland Hollow Rd, Patterson, NY. title: China Hones Old Tool: 'Re-educating' Unruly
description: He had been detained for six months in 1989 for helping to organize a strike, and later he tried to sue the police on behalf of an exiled labor leader, so Zhou Guoqiang, a lawyer and longtime human rights advocate, knew he was on thin ice. Still, he was surprised in 1994 at the pretext they used to jail him.

title: PANAMSAT FORMS INTERNET JOINT VENTURE FOR MEXICO
description: The PanAmSat Corporation, a leading operator of commercial satellites, said yesterday that it had formed a joint venture with an affiliate of the Mexican cellular phone company Grupo Pegaso S.A. to provide Internet and satellite services in Mexico. Terms were not disclosed. The Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors owns 81 percent of PanAmSat, which is based in Greenwich, Conn. The joint venture is 49 percent owned by PanAmSat and 51 percent owned by Grupo Pegaso, Mr. Meyer said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLINGSWORTH, JEANNE DORFMAN
description: HOLLINGSWORTH-Jeanne Dorfman. On February 23 after four years of pulmonary fibrosis. Born in 1924 in Monroe, LA, she had a B.A. (1945) from Oberlin College. She worked for 16 years for the National Foundation as it led the fight against polio. In 1964, she earned a law degree (J.D.) from NYU Law School. She retired in 1985 as Chief of the Legal Management Division of the New York City Housing Authority. Survived by her husband Kirk, a sister, Ann Brundage of Ann Arbor, MI, two nieces, Ellen Persiko of Louisville CO., and Lisa Johnson of Fair Oaks, CA, and a stepson, Michael of Austin, TX. A Requiem Mass will be held at 11 AM on Saturday, March 10 at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields in Greenwich Village. Please omit flowers: memorial contributions should be made to the AIDS Project at St. Luke's, 487 Hudson St, New York City 10014.

title: ESPN campaign uses a 'hostile' Web site to send viewers its way.
description: ANXIOUS advertisers are studying a myriad of methods to encourage visits to their World Wide Web sites, but few have considered a multimedia campaign to urge computer users to not visit their Web sites. But one big media company is undertaking just such an exercise in reverse psychology, with apparent success so far.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITTINGHAM, JEAN
description: WHITTINGHAM-Jean. At home in Chappaqua, NY, on February 24, 2001. Beloved wife of Charles A. Devoted mother of Beth, Charles III, Philip and Leigh. Cherished sister of Nancy Brown. Kind and caring mother-in-law of Charles F., Jan, Susan and John. Fun-loving grandmother of Elizabeth, John III, Chase, Kate and Claire Victoria. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice Care in Westchester and Putnam, Inc., 100 South Bedford Rd., Mt. Kisco, NY 10549. Funeral services will be private. There will be a memorial mass and reception held at a later date. She was a very special person to so many.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL TO LAY OFF 1,100 SALARIED WORKERS
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, the world's largest maker of engine bearings and seals, said yesterday that it would lay off about 1,100, or 8.6 percent, of its salaried employees to reduce costs. The layoffs, which represent about 2.1 percent of the total work force, will be completed this year, the company said. Federal-Mogul, based in Southfield, Mich., will take an unspecified charge for severance packages, a spokeswoman, Kimberly Welch, said. About 12,750 of the company's 51,400 employees are salaried.

title: Justices in Trenton Hear Debate on Fate of Frozen Embryos
description: In a post-divorce tussle that is becoming all the more common around the country, the New Jersey Supreme Court was asked today to decide the fate of seven frozen human embryos left over from a failed marriage.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: PAIR ACCUSED OF FRAUD A retired physician and his son, the president of a computer company based in New York, were accused yesterday of defrauding 11 investors out of more than $1.8 million. An indictment unsealed in Federal District Court in Manhattan charged Dr. Joshua Gurin, 62, and his son Edward Gurin, 26, president of the Trinarc Corporation, with bilking victims by falsely offering them no-risk investments that would double or triple their money, according to the United States attorney's office in Manhattan. Their schemes, the office said, included soliciting investors to buy warrants in one company that had never issued warrants and in another that did not exist. The indictment said Joshua Gurin told people his son had successfully invested for well-known figures including former Vice President Al Gore. The prosecutor, David B. Anders, said he did not know whether the son had been involved in Mr. Gore's financial matters. The two men were in custody yesterday afternoon awaiting a bail hearing and their lawyer did not return a telephone call.

title: For Vote Battle, Bush Raised $6 Million
description: President Bush raised nearly $6 million in mostly small contributions to pay for the legal battle over Florida's contested vote, federal records show.

title: Review/Fashion; McQueen Nods to a Prince, but Genuflects Toward Milan
description: ''Give me the time,'' Alexander McQueen said, one day after closing the deal to sell his company to Gucci, ''and I'll give you revolutionary.''

title: Wolfinger's Vehicle Use Not Under Investigation
description: Jack Wolfinger, who left St. John's basketball team last week, drove a vehicle belonging to another former Red Storm player, but that will not prompt a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation, university officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISHOP, GEORGE FRANCIS
description: BISHOP-George Francis, age 84 of Burlington, NC died Friday February 23, 2001. A native of Brooklyn, N.Y. he was the son of the late George F. Bishop and Mary C. McCormick Bishop. Mr. Bishop was a member of Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church, retired employee of A.T.&T Telephone Pioneers of America, U.S. Army Air Corp Veteran of WW II, serving in Italy with the 460th Bombardment Group (H) of the 15th Air Force. He graduated from Villanova University, class of 1939 and Xaverian High School in Brooklyn in 1935. A funeral mass was held at 5 PM Monday at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church in Burlington, NC. A graveside service will be held at 2 PM Wednesday at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY by the Holy Ghost Fathers. Survivors include a niece, Mrs. Maureen McGillivray Griffin of Kirkland, WA and a nephew Gilbert B. McGillivray of Forest Hills, NY. Memorials may be made to Blessed Sacrament Catholic Church Building Fund, 328 W. Davis St., Burlington, NC 27215 or to St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, 352 42nd Street, Brooklyn, NY 11232.

title: Chiang Mai Journal; A Courageous Editor's Lonely Quest
description: It's not much of a newspaper office three little computers and an ailing 30-year-old printing press squeezed into a converted beauty salon. But it's a pretty good bunker.
