title: Mitsubishi Motors Charts an Austerity Plan of Its Own
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation outlined a sweeping restructuring plan today that in some ways mirrors that of DaimlerChrysler, which owns about one-third of its stock.

title: Getting Rid of the Itch
description: To the Editor:

title: E.D.S. Awarded Contracts
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corpopration, a leading computer-services provider, said yesterday that it had been awarded more than $700 million in contracts for data services to a government agency, a health care insuror and two other companies. Electronic Data signed agreements to provide computer services worth $475 million with Blue Shield of California, $138 million with the Ontario government and $40 million with clothing retailer J. Crew Group. Electronic Data Systems also won a $62 million contract to support the computer network of EBS, a foreign exchange brokerage system.

title: Nasdaq Plunges on Sour Economic Reports
description: Technology stocks fell sharply today, pulling the Nasdaq composite index down more than 4 percent to its lowest close since the end of 1998, after more sour economic reports failed to prompt the immediate cut in interest rates that much of Wall Street had come to expect.

title: Over Din of Fellow Inmates, Man Ran Investment Fraud, Officials Say
description: On Oct. 29, 1999, Ira Monas, a Long Island investment adviser who had been convicted of grand larceny and possession of forged documents in a securities fraud case, entered the Adirondack Correctional Facility at Ray Brook, N.Y., to begin serving a term of two to four years as New York State Inmate 98A5992.

title: 22 Guys in Shorts: Winter in Columbus
description: Whether in the steamy outback of Guatemala or the gilded suburbs of Los Angeles, the United States rarely feels like the home team in soccer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHANK, PATRICIA ANN SMITH
description: SCHANK-Patricia Ann Smith. Widow of Sherwood Schank, died of natural causes at her home in New York on February 22. Daughter of Anne and Vincent Smith, she is survived by her first cousin Constance Meaney. Mrs. Schank was active for many years on the Boards of Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' & Airmen's Club and Elder Craftsmen. Services at 4 PM, Saturday, March 3, St. George's Chapel, Stuyvesant Square. Donations in her memory may be made to these organizations.

title: Article 2001022790512404986 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: For Older Drivers, a Wealth of Alternatives
description: Alice Riddle, an 80-year-old retired Brooklynite, used to drive everywhere. But in her mid-70's, she realized that her reflexes were not as good as they once were, and she no longer felt comfortable behind the wheel of a car.

title: Judges Scrutinize Microsoft Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26  Judges on a federal appeals court pelted lawyers representing the Justice Department and 19 states with skeptical questions today about the decision last year that found Microsoft had repeatedly violated antitrust law. The questioning suggested that many elements of the decision were vulnerable to reversal.

title: Adjusting Drug Policy
description: It is rare for a Hollywood movie to stimulate meaningful debate about social policy, but that has been the case with ''Traffic,'' Steven Soderbergh's gritty depiction of the drug wars that has been nominated for an Academy Award as best picture. With its disturbing images of middle-class teenage addiction, outgunned American counter-narcotics agents and corrupt Mexican drug officials, the movie has touched a nerve at a time of flux in the nation's decades-long campaign against illicit drugs. With new leadership both in Washington and in Mexico, this is a good time to think anew about the most effective ways to deal with a social problem that has fueled widespread violence and corruption and destroyed countless lives.

title: Article 2001022791171505001 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: The Slow and Constant Leak of Electricity
description: The''off'' switch is lying to you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, LILA
description: FRIED-Lila. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Mordecai Waxman, Rabbi George N. Abrahams, President

title: Lee's 'Tiger,' Celebrated Everywhere But at Home
description: Ang Lee's romantic martial arts epic, ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' packed them in again last weekend at multiplexes across the United States. Already the most successful foreign-language film in history, ''Crouching Tiger'' has grossed $81 million and is expected to top $100 million.

title: Clues in an Inkblot
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERNOV, SAMUEL
description: SHERNOV-Samuel. Age 100, of Hallandale Beach, Florida, passed away on February 25, 2001. Loving father of Jan (Arthur) Leichtung, grandfather of Kathy Reichenbaum, Robert (Debbi) Leichtung, great-grandfather of Harris, Jamie, Stephanie and Aaron, brother of Edith Goldstein. He taught us to never give up trying to find the answer to any problem. He will be missed by all. Graveside services will be held at 1 PM today at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Hague Tribunal Convicts Bosnian Croat for War on Muslims
description: In its first trial of a senior Balkan political figure, the United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague today found a former Bosnian Croat leader guilty of playing an important role in a campaign against Muslim civilians.

title: 'Faith Based' Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: P.& G. Points to Crisis in Turkey in Warning of Lower Profits
description: Citing the economic crisis in Turkey, Procter & Gamble warned yesterday that its profits would fall as much as 4 percent in the third quarter and about 1.5 percent for the entire year.

title: Madden Pulls Devils Out of Their Rut
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 26  Trailing by a goal entering the third period tonight, the Devils were looking at the possibility of a third consecutive defeat. But a goal by Patrik Elias midway through the period and a short- handed goal by John Madden with 4 minutes 48 seconds remaining gave the Devils a 5-3 victory over the Florida Panthers at Continental Arena.

title: Bush, Spelling Out Agenda to Congress, Makes Tax Cut the Centerpiece of Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  President Bush turned full force to the difficult task of selling the Congress and the country on his legislative agenda tonight, using a nationally televised address from the House chamber to cast his proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut as reasonable and responsible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDHOFF, ARNOLD J.
description: FRIEDHOFF-Arnold J. We express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our mentor and friend. He was a great inspiration to all whose lives he touched and will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his family. Florence Diamond, Emanuel Meller, Jeannette Miller, Helen Rosengarten, Eric Stone

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS

title: Ewing Is Always Special To Jackson
description: More than 13 years ago, Mark Jackson entered his first Knicks training camp with an unfavorable opinion of Patrick Ewing. He respected Ewing's game but pictured the Knicks' then-franchise center as a hostile, brooding villain around whom a rookie point guard should tread lightly.

title: Spitzer and Other Riders Take a Frightful Bus Trip
description: When Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer headed for La Guardia Airport Sunday evening, he thought he was in for a quick flight to Washington. Instead, Mr. Spitzer soon found himself on a passenger bus, full of passengers from canceled flights, all on a harrowing adventure down the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Show Me the Paycheck
description: To the Editor:

title: Intellectualizing the Music Or Simply Experiencing It
description: Rock 'n' roll can rattle the most basic definitions. The show Saturday night at the Bowery Ballroom explored the question ''What is the meaning of simplicity?'' Three post-punk bands tackled the legacy of American roots music to assert their own versions of authenticity, that dreaded ideal. Each delivered inspiring performances that exposed how a stance can shape what an artist thinks is the truth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, BERNARD
description: GILBERT-Bernard, age 92, on February 24, 2001. Of Mt. Vernon, NY. Beloved husband of Shirley. Father of Marvin and Maxine. Loving grandfather of Cynthia and Jeffrey Pattison, Richard and Sharone Gilbert. Great grandfather of Alexander and Mara. Donations may be made to American Friends of Technion University of Israel.

title: New Meat-Testing Regulation Wins Backing of White House
description: In its first food-safety regulation, the Bush White House has approved a proposal, made in the waning days of the Clinton administration, that would require testing for potentially lethal Listeria bacteria in factories that process ready-to-eat meats.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Saturday about a legal charge brought against Bishop Pierre Pican of Bayeux, France, contending that he had failed to inform governmental authorities that a priest was sexually abusing young boys, misstated the source of the bishop's information. It was not gained in the confessional with the priest but from an administrative assistant who was told by a boy's mother. The bishop then had a private conversation with the priest, a lawyer for the bishop said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, NATHAN
description: GREENBERG-Nathan. 1912-2001. Died suddenly on Sunday, February 25 in Margate, Florida, at 88. Widower of Frances, he is survived by his devoted and loving wife of 20 years, Edith (Keit) Greenberg. Adored by daughters Lorraine Potecha, Risa Solomon, and son Emil Jay Greenberg, as well as by daughter-in-law Susan Greenberg and son-in-law Marc Potecha. He was the beloved grandfather to Michael and Joshua Weinberger, Elycia and Cynthia Solomon, and Flora and Peter Greenberg. Loved and admired by his stepchildren Gordon and Helen Keit, and Joanne Paltrowitz; his step grandchildren Lawrence, Justin, and Danielle Paltrowitz; Jerilynn and Ross Keit; and Michael Potecha. He will be sorely missed also by his surviving sister, Caroline Dale, of Tarzana, CA., and his many nieces and nephews. A man of strength and integrity, who continually inspired those around him, he was the founder of Nathan Greenberg Inc., an importer of diamonds. A former vice-president of the Diamond Manufacturers and Importers Association, he was also, in 1967, Master of the Paramount Lodge, F.&A.M. Services will be held at 2:00 PM on Tuesday at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Hillcrest Jewish Center in Jamaica Estates, or to Pride of Judea.

title: UAL IN TALKS TO SELL US AIRWAYS REGIONAL CARRIERS
description: Atlantic Coast Airlines Holdings Inc. confirmed yesterday that it was in talks to buy at least one of the US Airways Group's three regional carriers from the UAL Corporation, which wants to avoid paying higher wages to those carriers' flight attendants. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, confirmed it has had discussions about selling Piedmont Airlines, PSA Airlines and Allegheny Airlines, though it did not say whether it has talked with Atlantic Coast. UAL is seeking regulatory approval for an $11.6 billion purchase of US Airways. UAL would sell the East Coast commuter carriers if and when the US Airways purchase is completed. United's flight attendants' contract would require United to have the same pay scale for all US Airways attendants, including those at the regional carriers who are paid less than counterparts at the main airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITCOMB, DAVID
description: WHITCOMB-David. 76. Interior designer in NYC since 1950, died February 21 at Tailings, his home in Germantown, NY. Patron of the arts and music in Columbia County, he was a master gardener and champion of the environment. He is survived by Robert Montgomery, his companion of 20 years, and many loving friends. A memorial is planned in late spring. Donations Columbia-Greene Humane Society, Hudson, NY 12534.

title: EToys, Unable to Find Buyer, Plans to File for Bankruptcy
description: EToys Inc., which began last year as the largest Internet toy store, said today that it would file for bankruptcy protection in the next 5 to 10 days because it had been unable to find a buyer or more financing.

title: A. R. Ammons, 75, Poet of Eclectic Tastes
description: A. R. Ammons, an award-winning poet who could turn any topic, even a heap of garbage, into poetry, died on Sunday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Chicago Suburb's Polls Under Federal Watch
description: If there's anything this old town, muscled into submission by Al Capone and long wracked by accusations of extortion and corruption, doesn't need, it's another scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONKLIN, JOSEPH E.
description: CONKLIN-Joseph E. On February 24, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Ann Conklin. Survived by his sister Margaret Love, three nephews and five nieces. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Tuesday 5 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Eighth Church of Christ Scientist NY, NY, or the First Church of Christ Scientist, Boston, MA.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about a campaign for Oracle software, misstated the affiliation of Dave Tutin at the agency handling the account. He is executive vice president and executive creative director of Grey Worldwide, New York, which is part of the Grey Global Group -- not of Grey Worldwide's San Francisco office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEROY, WARNER
description: LeROY-Warner. The entire Citymeals-on-Wheels family mourns the loss of our cherished friend and generous benefactor, Warner LeRoy. For twenty years Warner graciously hosted our events, always as a gift, always in surroundings only he could have created. He gave out of loving concern for frail elderly shut-ins throughout New York's five boroughs. We will miss him terribly and send condolences to all who loved him. Gael Greene, Chairman Preston Robert Tisch, President Marcia Stein, Executive Director Citymeals-on-Wheels

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday in Fashions of The Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, about Zac Posen, a 20-year-old dress designer in London, misspelled the name of the Brooklyn Heights private school where he first met a number of prominent young women who became clients. The name was also misspelled in a front-page article in Sunday Styles about an 18-year-old male model, who transferred from the school at 16. The school is St. Ann's, not St. Anne's.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about criticism of efforts to privatize five New York City public schools misstated the name of an opposition group. It is Jews for Racial and Economic Justice, not Jews for Economic and Racial Justice.

title: South Korean President Sides With Russia on Missile Defense
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 27  Less than a week before he meets President Bush in Washington, the president of South Korea today publicly took Russia's side in the debate over Washington's plan for a national missile defense.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: KOREAN AIRPORT FEES RAISED
description: Airlines will have to pay 19.7 percent more for the use of Inchon International Airport after it opens on March 29 than they now pay at Kimpo Airport, the Inchon International Airport Corporation said. The announcement noted, however, that the new fees would be less than one-third those of Kansai International Airport, near Osaka, Japan, and about half those of Pudong International Airport in Shanghai. The airport corporation said the fee for a 747-400 with 312 passengers would be $2,800 for two hours on the ground; a similar-size cargo plane would pay $2,675. The corporation decided against even higher fees for fear of discouraging airlines from using Inchon as a regional hub. Inchon will replace Kimpo on international flights in and out of South Korea. Don Kirk

title: Nascar Awareness, but at a Price
description: In death, Nascar has never achieved greater awareness. No sport wants to achieve renown because its greatest star perished in a crash at its greatest race. But Dale Earnhardt's death at the Daytona 500 nine days ago pushed Nascar to the forefront of the news and sports pages, and televised news programs.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia Holds U.S. Student

title: People
description: * David J. Scholes, president and chief executive at the New York office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, was named president and chief executive at two agencies also owned by Omnicom, Targetbase and TBi, Dallas. He succeeds Jack Wolfe, who left. Mr. Scholes will be succeeded at Rapp Collins New York by Lesley Mair, who had been chairwoman of the WWAV Rapp Collins Group, London, and managing director of the WWAV Rapp Collins London office.

title: Russia Turns Drug Arrest Into Spy Case
description: The domestic intelligence agency unexpectedly said today that an American graduate student, arrested nearly a month ago on seemingly minor drug charges, was probably working for United States military intelligence.

title: Earthquake Shakes Pacific Northwest
description: Apowerful earthquake rumbled through the Northwest today, sending down a rain of masonry, cutting power to thousands of people and forcing Seattle's airport to close. At least 25 people were injured.

title: Bill Clinton, for Better or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGGIO, EUGENE
description: MAGGIO-Eugene. At age 72 of Nanuet, died Saturday, February 24, 2001 in the Good Samaritan Hospital Suffern, New York. Mr. Maggio was born on December 30, 1928 to the late Mariano and the late Jennie Loprest Maggio. He was a Photographer, employed by The New York Times for over 35 years. He loved his job and it was very important to him. He also worked with his father in the family business Maggio Studio's in West New York, New Jersey. He is survived by his wife, Josephine Maggio, his two daughters, Jo Ann and Elizabeth Maggio, his two sisters, Mary Sarsano and Ann Roma, and two brothers, Anthony and Joseph Maggio. A Mass of Christian Burial was held in St. Anthony's Church in Nanuet, New York, on Tuesday, February 27. Interment took place in St. Anthony's Cemetery in Nanuet. For information Joseph W. Sorce Funeral Home Inc., of West Nyack, New York. Donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: For Tech-Happy Gastronomes, Reviews Are Always Handy
description: FINDING a good restaurant can be one of life's great hit-or-miss propositions, akin to throwing a dart at the Yellow Pages. You might be foresighted enough to carry a guidebook with you, but a guidebook's listings can grow stale faster than a croissant. You might clip reviews out of newspapers, but unless you're far better organized than I am, you tuck them away in a folder and can never remember the names when you need them.

title: Old Rarities, New Respect: U.S. Works With Italy
description: In 1995, United States customs agents seized a fourth-century B.C. libation bowl from the New York apartment of an antiquities collector. They were acting on a request from Italian cultural officials, who said that the intricately patterned gold bowl had been smuggled out of Sicily and sold illegally.

title: Combs Will Take the Stand at Trial But Lopez Will Not, Statements Say
description: Sean Combs will testify this week at his trial on charges of gun possession and bribing a witness, he said in a statement last night. The statement added that Jennifer Lopez, his former girlfriend, would not testify.

title: Corrections
description: An article, a picture caption and a listing last Wednesday about wine classes in New York misstated the name of one organization that offers them. It is the Neighborhood Tasting Society, not the Neighborhood Wine Society.

title: KANGWON POSTS PROFIT
description: The Kangwon Land Corporation announced a net profit of $33 million in 2000 on sales of $73 million at a casino it opened in a mountainous region east of Seoul, South Korea, last October. The small casino, inside a hotel also owned by Kangwon Land, is the precursor of a large resort project featuring outdoor sports and a much larger casino. The casino is the first in the country that is completely open to Koreans. Casinos in Seoul and other cities cater to foreigners only. Don Kirk

title: Chosen Director Quits Boston Ballet
description: Maina Gielgud will step down as artistic director designate of the Boston Ballet, effective immediately. Ms. Gielgud assumed the designate's post in September and was to have become director in July. The announcement, made on Monday by Ms. Gielgud and the ballet board, described her departure as amicable but attributed it to ''clear differences of opinion and a mismatch of expectations.'' Ms. Gielgud, the former director of the Australian Ballet and Royal Danish Ballet and the niece of the actor John Gielgud, was to have succeeded Anna-Marie Holmes. Ms. Holmes will remain through June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRY, SYLVIA
description: LAWRY-Sylvia. A friend, a fighter and the epitome of courage. We salute you. The Dystel Family

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about Patrick Ewing's return to Madison Square Garden misstated the site of his final game as a Knick. It was in New York, not Indiana.

title: Article 2001022894059927300 -- No Title
description: The Web, Without Wires, Wherever

title: ALLSTATE PLANS ONLINE SALES
description: The No. 1 auto insurer, State Farm, tried it. Now, No. 2, Allstate, is having a go at selling policies through one of the first online markets for insurance, a California site called InsWeb. And this time, analysts say that they think the chances for success are good. ''State Farm couldn't make money with InsWeb,'' said Todd Eyler, a senior analyst at Forrester Research, ''but Allstate's agents are much more Internet friendly and enabled.'' InsWeb distinguishes itself by providing customers with comparative prices for insurance from several companies. But customers who wanted to buy from State Farm had to contact the insurer and then wait, often to no avail, for an agent to reply by telephone or an e-mail message. Allstate says that it will send a quote via an e-mail message within 30 seconds, along with a toll-free phone number to call to complete the purchase of a policy. Joseph B. Treaster

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGER, ROSE B.
description: TAGER-Rose B. Of Brooklyn, New York. Died on February 27. Loving wife of the late Harry L. Tager, M.D. Loving mother of Michael G. Tager, M.D. of Westport, CT and Charles W. Tager, D.D.S. of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. A graveside service will be held March 1 at 11AM at the Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Takeover Foes File Suit
description: A group of community organizations, school board members and politicians filed suit yesterday to block Edison Schools' bid to take over five failing New York City schools.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Israeli Labor Party's vote to join the government misstated the number of party members who voted to accept Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon's offer to share power. Fewer than half the 1,700 members of the party's governing body voted; and of those who did, about two-thirds -- not two-thirds of the entire governing body -- voted to accept.

title: Livingston and Inico Star at Armory
description: Stacey Livingston and Kedar Inico were among the standouts last night in the Eastern States High School Indoor Championships at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.

title: Housing Proposal Reflects Policy Shift
description: Seven years after directing his administration to unload the city's extensive and very much unwanted inventory of blighted apartment buildings, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is shifting his focus to try to prevent the city from ending up again as the landlord of last resort.

title: Irradiated Beef: In Markets, Quietly
description: IRRADIATED ground beef is now available in about 1,500 stores across the country, but retailers are apparently still nervous about consumer response. So nervous that Omaha Steaks, the large mail-order beef company, does not tell its customers in advance that all the ground beef it has been selling since January has been irradiated to kill potential bacteria.

title: Europe Sets Examination Of G.E. Deal
description: The European Commission confirmed today that it would open an extended investigation into the General Electric Company's planned $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International Inc., despite an 11th-hour effort by John F. Welch Jr., the G.E. chief executive, to secure a quick clearance by European regulators.

title: Board Fiddled; Bronx Science Is Burned
description: WITH time running out on him as acting principal, William J. Stark was delighted yesterday to talk about the Bronx High School of Science and his 33 years there as a teacher and administrator.

title: BUSH, SPELLING OUT AGENDA TO CONGRESS, MAKES TAX CUT CENTERPIECE OF THE BUDGET
description: President Bush turned full force to the difficult task of selling the Congress and the country on his legislative agenda tonight, using a nationally televised address from the House chamber to cast his proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut as reasonable and responsible.

title: Nighttime Is a Good Time to Save Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: Ordez Needs to Alter His Offensive Approach
description: Maybe there is technology that would allow Al Leiter to change the past. Maybe, Leiter said, smiling, he could superimpose Rey Ordez onto footage from the ninth inning of Game 5 of the World Series last fall.

title: Military Spending Priorities
description: President Bush's budget plan calls for more than $1 billion in new spending for research on national missile defense and calls for closing military bases around the country. Page A14.

title: Revving Up the Search Engines to Keep the E-Aisles Clear
description: IN the real world, the search for something like a red medium-size women's sweater hardly ranks as a shopping challenge. Just go to a clothing store, head for the women's section, scan the sweater aisles or ask for help.

title: European Tours
description: Book by March 31 and get $100 off the price of three Globus European tours that include river cruises. A 13-day Switzerland and Rhine cruise includes a four-day Rhine sailing from Basel to Dusseldorf, Germany. Before the discount, rates range from $1,479 to $1,529 a person, based on double occupancy. An 18-day tour of Switzerland and Austria includes a three-night Basel-to-Dusseldorf cruise; rates are $1,949 to $1,999 a person, double. And on a 14-day tour to Austria, there's a five-day Danube cruise from Vienna, through Hungary and Slovakia, ending in Germany; rates: $1,949 to $1,999 a person, double. Departures for all three itineraries are April through September, and prices given do not include air fare. For brochures, call (877) 325-0656; Web site, www.globusandcosmos.com . Reserve through a travel agent.

title: Taliban's New Role: Vandals of Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Burgundy's Big Guys Aren't the Bad Guys
description: YEARS ago, when I made my first tentative -- and largely unsuccessful -- efforts to understand Burgundy, I did learn one thing. There seemed to be an unbridgeable gulf between the small growers in the villages and the powerful ngociants, or shippers, and nothing would ever bring them together.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINREICH, ROBERT
description: WEINREICH-Robert. We have lost and mourn for a cherished friend from childhood. All of the Ravens including Bert, Gary, Morton, Sid, Don, Dan, Dan, Ed, Norman, Bill, Irwin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELLY, JOSEPHINE (MCGINNESS)
description: CONNELLY-Josephine (McGinness). On February 25, 2001 at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Harry S. Connelly. Loving sister of the late Arthur F. McGinness. Aunt of Eugenia Singer and stepmother of Patsy Holt, Colleen Moss, Pete, Mike, Denis and Bill Connelly and the late Tommy Connelly. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66 St., Thursday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Sexy Married Men
description: It is pilot season in Hollywood, the time of year when the networks begin to make test pilots of new programs that could wind up on their prime-time schedules this fall. So far, a common theme is emerging: a host of potential new comedies are being considered by the major broadcast networks that are basically male versions of HBO's popular ''Sex and the City'': shows about men and love and relationships and sex.

title: 60 Fire Chiefs Join to Protest Commissioner
description: In a signal of a widening rift in the leadership of the Fire Department, dozens of the city's high-ranking chiefs asked yesterday to be relieved of some of their duties to protest a variety of actions by Fire Commissioner Thomas Von Essen.

title: Reality Strikes
description: The prevailing story of the February sweep, which will end tomorrow, is reality television and how it affected every network.

title: 7-ELEVEN ENTERS DEAL TO OFFER WESTERN UNION SERVICES
description: 7-Eleven Inc. said yesterday that it signed a seven-year contract with Western Union Financial Services Inc. unit to offer Western Union money orders and transfers at its 7-Eleven convenience stores. 7-Eleven, with more than 21,000 stores, will offer Western Union money transfer services through its automated teller machines and continue selling Western Union money orders. 7-Eleven is installing kiosks where customers can buy money orders, cash checks or make other financial transactions.

title: Caught in the Swirl of an Electronic Eden
description: Thirty years ago Karlheinz Stockhausen was the most prominent composer in the world, sustained in place by spectacular performances he was giving internationally and by Deutsche Grammophon's prompt and opulent release of each new major work. That great river of success has thinned to a trickle, but Thursday's exciting concert at Miller Theater both caught the earlier force and suggested what went wrong.

title: CROWN CORK, A MAKER OF CANS, TO REALIGN ITS PRODUCTION
description: The Crown Cork and Seal Company, a leading maker of metal food cans, said yesterday that it would realign production at its plant in Weston, Ontario, to cut costs and meet changing industry demand. Crown Cork will convert two of its four aluminum beverage container production lines to make two-piece steel food cans. No job cuts are expected at the Weston plant, which employs about 200 people and is one of the company's largest aluminum can operations. The company, which is based in Philadelphia, said the change would allow it to meet demand for two-piece cans, and it would reduce aluminum can production, because beverage makers are turning to plastic containers.

title: As Antidote to Slowdown, Intel Will Spend, Not Cut
description: Intel, the world's leading maker of computer chips, said today that it would try to spend its way through the troubled economic times.

title: Bloody Marys With a Twist: Flavor Borrowed From a Martini
description: I'M a sucker for anything salty, which is why I had to try Dirty Olive vodka after spotting it among the wines in the window at Crossroads, on the Union Square-Greenwich Village border. Gimmicky as it seemed, a vodka without currants or orange or other cloying sweetness had potential. The salesman said it made a mean olive martini without olives, and certainly the sleek greenish-brown bottle looked worthy of a spot on any bar.

title: ROSEMOUNT WINERY PURCHASED
description: The Australian wine and water heater manufacturer Southcorp said it bought Rosemount Estates, creating one of the largest premium wine companies in the world. Southcorp paid 1.5 billion Australian dollars ($787 million), mainly in stock, for the family-owned Rosemount. After the purchase, more than 75 percent of Southcorp's profits will come from wines like Rosemount, Lindemans and Penfolds, according to Southcorp's chairman, Rick Allert; the company will produce more than 10 million cases of premium wine a year, with sales of about 1.1 billion Australian dollars. Becky Gaylord

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 2 Big Investors To Take Over Finova Group
description: Two investors with a reputation for buying troubled companies on the cheap have agreed to take control of the Finova Group, an ailing lender to companies.

title: LINUX DISTRIBUTOR BUYS A CONSULTANT
description: Red Hat Inc., the largest United States distributor of software based on the Linux operating system, said it had acquired a closely held network consultant, Planning Technologies Inc., for $47 million in stock. Planning Technologies, an Atlanta company that helps clients build and manage computer networks, has customers that include Home Depot, Delta Air Lines and AT&T. Red Hat issued about 7.2 million new shares for Planning Technologies and said it planned to use its stock as currency for more acquisitions. Yesterday, its shares slipped 13 cents, to $6.66. Red Hat works with other companies to develop operating systems for devices like hand-held computers and cellular phones and programmable appliances like videocassette recorders.

title: Article 2001022893628325732 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Bill Clinton, for Better or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey's Acting Governor Defends Loan From a Home Builder
description: TRENTON, Feb. 28  Five years ago, one of New Jersey's largest home builders provided $225,000 to Donald T. DiFrancesco, the State Senate president, to pay off an outstanding legal judgment, court records show. Mr. DiFrancesco, who also became acting governor of New Jersey a month ago, has never repaid the money and says he does not think it is his responsibility to do so.

title: Chanting and Rockin' to Appease the Elements
description: ''May all be kind to each other,'' said Nawang Khechog at Carnegie Hall on Monday, before using his Tibetan flute to summon a dream of his homeland. Mr. Khechog's blessing recalled the Buddhist meditation on compassion, the quality that inspires this annual benefit concert for Tibet House, an international organization that works to preserve Tibet and its culture.

title: THE CHEF
description: MY main job is eating, not cooking, because my restaurant is ultimately playing to one palate. When I think up a dish or a menu, I'm not trying to shock anyone, or reinvent the wheel. I'm thinking of what I want to eat.

title: Life at All Costs?
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Arrested in Brooklyn Housekeeper's Rape
description: Two brothers were arrested last night in connection with a four-hour attack on a housekeeper at a Brooklyn town house on Monday, the police said. One brother confessed to raping the woman and robbing the house, a law enforcement official said.

title: L.I. Village Uses Litter Law In Fighting Untidy Evictions
description: For years, housing advocates and civic leaders have argued that Nassau County's eviction practices add insult to injury: first, people are turned out of their homes, and then, all of their belongings are dumped onto the sidewalk, where they are exposed to the elements and picked through by scavengers.

title: CAMPBELL HIRES TWO EXECUTIVES TO SHORE UP SOUP SALES
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it had hired two consumer-products veterans to fill new positions to revive its soup sales. Larry McWilliams, 44, the former head of sales at Coca-Cola's Minute Maid unit, was named chief customer officer, and Patrick O'Malley, 51, who headed operations at Nabisco's foods division, will oversee the global supply chain. Both will report directly to the chief executive, Douglas Conant, who was hired last month.

title: Plaintiffs Agree to Arbitration Of Newark Plane Crash Claims
description: The city and 21 people affected when a small private plane crashed into a residential neighborhood have agreed to submit their claims against the estate of the dead pilot to binding arbitration.

title: Corrections
description: A review yesterday about the closing event of the festival ''Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation,'' by the community-based 651 Arts in Brooklyn, misstated the name of a composer whose music accompanied part of ''High Life,'' a suite of dances by Ronald K. Brown. The composer is Fela Anikulapo Kuti; ''and'' was inserted erroneously after the first part of the name.

title: Spencer Might Not Be Ready In April
description: Shane Spencer, feeling soreness in his surgically repaired right knee, asked to be excused from the Yankees' intrasquad game today. Hours later, Manager Joe Torre acknowledged that Spencer might not be ready to play when the season opens April 2. ''I'm not counting on him right now,'' he said.

title: Pack Your Portmanteau: Stews for the Road
description: AMONG the many delicious options these days at Grand Central Terminal, I've found few things as consistently satisfying as the stews at La Truffe du Prigord, a small takeout counter on the east side of Grand Central Market.

title: Accounts
description: * American Italian Pasta Co., Kansas City, Mo., to Barkley Evergreen & Partners, Kansas City, to handle the account of Mueller's pasta, which the company recently acquired. Billings have not been determined. Under the brand's previous owner, Bestfoods, now part of Unilever, the account had been at the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: New Juilliard Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIBOURG, SADIE
description: FRIBOURG-Sadie. Age 98. Of Southbury, CT. On February 26, 2001. Widow of Jean Fribourg. Mother of Richard C. Warner and Nancy R. Greenstone. Sister of Milton Lamden. Grandmother of five, great grandmother of 14.

title: Nighttime Is a Good Time to Save Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREEN, WILMA
description: GREEN-Wilma. February 28, 1989. Remembering MY GREAT LADY.

title: Court to Hear After-School Evangelism Case
description: To the Rev. Stephen D. Fournier, pastor of the Community Bible Church in this rural community of 3,000, the Milford Central School seemed the obvious place to hold meetings of the Good News Club, a church-run youth group. Up a hill from the town's only stoplight, the school serves as communal hub, a place where long after the last school bell, classrooms buzz with meetings of the 4-H Club, Rotarians and the Boy Scouts.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: YORKSHIRE POWER GROUP BOUGHT
description: Innogy Holdings P.L.C. said it agreed to pay two United States utility companies 508.6 million ($735 million) for 94.75 percent of the Yorkshire Power Group to expand its position as a gas and electric supplier in Britain. Innogy, which was created when National Power P.L.C. was split into two companies last year, also will assume 1.37 billion in debt. One of the United States businesses, the American Electric Power Company, said it was selling its stake to concentrate on wholesale energy in Britain and Europe. The other, Xcel Energy Inc., said it would sell all but a 5.25 percent stake in Yorkshire, as it turns its attention to its European subsidiary NRG Energy Inc. Suzanne Kapner

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANCTUARY OF ABRAHAM AND SARAH
description: Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah Above ground Jewish burial. Affordable indoor mausoleum spaces and prime family rooms. Free brochure, call 800-526-4600

title: Bill Clinton, for Better or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon Turns To Recruiting Some Partners From the Right
description: Bolstered by the Labor Party's agreement to join him in a unity government, Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon shifted his attention today to satisfying the demands of potential partners from religious and right-wing political factions.

title: KAO AND ARCHER-DANIELS TO COLLABORATE ON COOKING OIL
description: The Kao Corporation, Japan's biggest household products maker, said yesterday that it would form a joint venture with the Archer Daniels Midland Company to make and sell ingredients for Kao's popular cooking oil in the United States. Kao and Archer Daniels, one of the world's biggest grain processors, will jointly make diacylglycerol at a plant in Decatur, Ill., to come on line in November, Kao said. Kao says the oil, already popular in Japan, is less fattening than regular edible oils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACSON, H. HARDING
description: ISAACSON-H. Harding. On February 26, 2001. Beloved husband of Janet. Memorial services 2PM, Thursday, 8 March, Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Ave at 90 St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Soldiers', Sailors', Marines' and Airmen's Club, 283 Lexington Ave, NYC 10016.

title: All Femme And Fatale, With a Man At Her Feet
description: The New York City Ballet made room for a major debut in a minor work just before closing its season on Sunday. Tom Gold repeated his fine performance as the pitiful male figure in George Balanchine's ''Variations Pour une Porte et un Soupir'' on Friday night at the New York State Theater but Maria Kowroski was the new femme fatale who devoured him in both a passionate metaphor and a billowing cape.

title: An Account Review For Mail Boxes Etc.
description: Mail Boxes Etc., part of U.S. Office Products, has begun a review for its creative and media account, with billings estimated at $20 million.

title: Neither Barren Nor Remote
description: Oil or wilderness? This is the question at the center of the new energy bill that Senator Frank Murkowski of Alaska has just introduced, following through on President Bush's campaign promise to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to drilling.

title: PROMOTIONS CLOSE TO HOME
description: While online advertisements reached a record level of more than 172 billion impressions during the fourth quarter of 2000, on average 28 percent of the ads on the sites of Web media companies were nonpaid and were self-promotional, according to research that was released yesterday by AdRelevance in New York, which is part of Jupiter Media Metrix. The research found that Web media companies that had the highest percentage of house ads -- 30 percent -- fell into the category of entertainment and society Web sites. Also during the fourth quarter, 22 percent of ads on Web sites in the news and information category were house ads, compared with 19 percent in the portals and search engines category. Allison Fass

title: Afro-Asian Ensemble
description: Adapted from Caffe Addulis

title: The Roots Of 'Sopranos' Grew From Cagney Film
description: In the second half of Sunday night's two-hour opening of the new season of ''The Sopranos'' on HBO, Tony Soprano, caught up in conflicting emotions by the death of his mother, Livia, finds himself retreating to his den to watch a video of the classic gangster movie ''The Public Enemy.''

title: Surplus Feast: Will Tax-Cut Appetizer Leave Room for Debt-Slice Dessert?
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  During his run for the presidency, George W. Bush declared daily that Washington's budget surpluses should be returned to the people whose taxes created them. On Wednesday night, for the first time, Mr. Bush began discussing in detail the national debt that has to be repaid by the people who are saddled with it.

title: Brosius' Bat to Decide His Yankee Future
description: Scott Brosius lived through the frustration of his poor offensive performance last summer and had no desire to see the final numbers. Still, when his wife, Jennifer, mentioned in January that he batted .230 last season, he could not believe his average was that low.

title: Business Travel; Foreign currency, and the best way to get it, is a vital issue for those on the road abroad.
description: MONEY makes the world go around. And short of a debate about frequent-flier miles or deteriorating air service, there's nothing that will kick up as much reaction among international business travelers as a discussion about foreign currency.

title: NAPSTER FOES ENLIST LOBBYIST
description: The Recording Industry Association of America, turning its efforts against Napster from the courts to Capitol Hill, has retained former Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana, left, as a lobbyist. Mr. Racicot said yesterday that he planned to advocate protection of the record companies' intellectual property rights, saying the protection of such rights is a fundamental notion on which democracy is based. The recording industry group said the move was part of an overall education and lobbying effort on behalf of record companies that have sued Napster asserting the service aids copyright infringement. Mr. Racicot, a lawyer at the Washington offices of Bracewell & Patterson, is a Republican who helped represent the Bush campaign during the Florida recount. Matt Richtel

title: Medicaid's Inadequacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges Voice Doubt On Order Last Year To Split Microsoft
description: The government suffered a second difficult day of questioning in its Microsoft antitrust case today when a Federal appeals court cast doubt about a judge's order last year to break the company in two.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Article 2001022891850269571 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Greenspan's Testimony Sends Stocks Sharply Lower
description: Stocks fell sharply today after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, gave no indication that the Fed's policy makers were planning to cut interest rates before their next meeting.

title: Hawaiin Greenhouse
description: Hawaiian Greenhouse, in Pahoa, Hawaii, operated by Lynne and Alan Kuwahara, is a purveyor of lush tropical plants that has also moved into other products like coffee and Hawaiian crafts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMMONS, A.R.
description: AMMONS-A.R. The members of the American Academy of Arts & Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague, whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of literature.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES MAY REJECT PARTS OF T.W.A. UNION PACT
description: Donald J. Carty, the chief executive of American Airlines, said yesterday that American might decline to accept certain labor contracts as part of its final bid for Trans World Airlines, which is due today. American has offered to buy most of T.W.A.'s assets in bankruptcy for $500 million in cash. Mr. Carty said in a message to American employees that the airline was still committed to retaining all of T.W.A.'s 18,000 unionized workers but it needed the unions to waive certain provisions of their contracts. If those negotiations cannot be completed by today's deadline for bids, American would not accept the contracts, he added. Keith O'Leary, a spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association, said the union was confident it could resolve the issue in time. A spokesman for the International Association of Machinists, T.W.A.'s largest union, declined to comment. Mr. Carty also said that American was unlikely to accept certain T.W.A. leases at Kennedy Airport. American had previously committed to building a new $1.3 billion terminal at the airport. Laurence Zuckerman (NYT)

title: Clashing Arias for Berlin Opera
description: Rome, Amsterdam, Madrid and Washington have one opera house each, while New York, London, Vienna and Paris can boast two. Berlin, on the other hand, has three, which is a dream for operagoers but increasingly a nightmare for those charged with keeping them afloat. Put simply, Berliners love having three opera houses that they cannot afford. Who, then, is going to foot the bill?

title: South Korea Takes Russia's Side in Dispute Over American Plan for Missile Defense
description: Less than a week before he meets President Bush in Washington, the president of South Korea today publicly took Russia's side in the debate over Washington's plan for a national missile defense.

title: The Neediest Cases; Voices Are Heard and Help Is Given
description: Today marks the end of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's 2000-01 appeal for donations, the most financially successful in the fund's 89-year history by a margin of more than $1 million.

title: Borneo Backwater's Clashes Draw Little Notice
description: The ethnic violence that erupted 10 days ago in the Indonesian section of Borneo, where hundreds of people have been decapitated and thousands more left destitute, might seem a likely candidate for a major deployment of government troops or international peacekeepers.

title: Sidney Weinhouse, 91, Expert On the Metabolism of Cancer
description: Dr. Sidney Weinhouse, who received the first National Science Foundation grant half a century ago and distinguished himself as a teacher and researcher of the metabolism of cancer, died on Feb. 9 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 91.

title: Freedom of Press or Bulletproof Vests?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Kentucky Journal; Fighting Appalachia's Top Cash Crop, Marijuana
description: Winter is easing in the rolling hills and hamlet hollows, and all the prespring indications are that marijuana will have another big year and remain this state's No. 1 cash crop, just as it continues prime in West Virginia and Tennessee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMARK, FRITZ
description: NEUMARK-Fritz, died September 2, age 87. Served on staff of Radio Free Europe for 20 years, subsequently founding member of the Society of International Broadcasters, composed of RFE alumni.

title: Big Japanese Agency Plans to Sell Stock
description: Dentsu Inc. in Tokyo, Japan's largest agency, is planning to go public by the end of the year, it said yesterday.

title: Rwanda and Uganda Cut Back Troops in Congo
description: KIGALI, Rwanda, Feb. 28  Two armies in the sprawling conflict in Congo took what appeared to be a major step toward peace today, pulling back soldiers from front-line positions with the expectation that other combatants would do the same soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORNARI, DR. HARRY D.
description: FORNARI-Dr. Harry D. The American Fats and Oils Association mourns the death of Dr. Harry D. Fornari, its founding member, two-time President, and longserving Executive Director. For almost forty years, his vision served our Association as a bright beacon, lighting its growth. He will be missed for his commitment to principle, the soundness of his judgment, and, most importantly, the warmth of his friendship. American Fats and Oils Assn., Inc David Italiaander, Pres. Walter J. Karpinski, Vice. Pres. Nicholas B. Sander, Vice Pres. Ralph Joel, Treasurer Eric H. Jackson, Secretary David E. Rothschild, Exec. Dir. Bardin Levavy, General Counsel

title: What the Web Means In Tougher Times
description: LAST year, even before dot-coms started to splat all over Silicon Valley sidewalks, wise watchers of the Internet liked to say that the real action was elsewhere -- in the hundreds of millions of dollars that old-economy companies were spending to improve their efficiency. These transformations, while less than glamorous, would allow them to grow faster than ever.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a sentencing in a Connecticut corruption case attributed one defendant's political background to another in some copies. It was Ben F. Andrews Jr. -- not Paul J. Silvester, a former state treasurer -- who ran unsuccessfully for secretary of the state in 1998.

title: 'Scaffolding' Is Raised, and So Are Sights
description: PAUL ARREOLA, 15-year-old son of Mexican immigrants (his mother is a garment worker, his father a janitor), was not doing poorly at Southwest High School here. He expected eventually to graduate, then perhaps get a community college education leading to a job somewhat greater in status than his parents' work.

title: Article 2001022894187878159 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Appeals Court Questions Order to Split Up Microsoft

title: Sports of The Times; Far-Flung Yankees Answer Call
description: THEY are the national team of the United States, but their luggage tags are international. They are not a salaried fire brigade hanging around the station house (''Three bells! Mexico's in Columbus! Everybody down the pole!'') but more like volunteers, dashing out of the barber shop and the hardware store, wherever they can hear the siren -- in this case, all over Europe.

title: Cheers for Patrick, With Touch of Guilt
description: Allan Houston and some of his teammates embraced him, hugging Patrick Ewing as if they had never wanted him to leave. Many of the fans who still feel that Ewing failed to win a title for them arrived an hour early at Madison Square Garden last night to watch him pop in a baseline fallaway beneath the building's pinwheel ceiling.

title: Grab Your Injera: A Selection of Ethiopian Restaurants
description: ETHIOPIAN restaurants in New York are centered in Manhattan, particularly near Columbia University. Except for the stylish Caffe Adulis, most of these restaurants are small, modest and inexpensive. Almost all take credit cards, and reservations are always a good idea.

title: Article 2001022890536964596 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Greenspan Says Fed Is Ready if Rate Cuts Are Needed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told the country today that it must hunker down a while longer, until the current slowdown has run its course. And he made it clear that the Federal Reserve Board is watching the situation closely, no doubt ready to take action if necessary.

title: Against a Trend, U.S. Population Will Bloom, U.N. Says
description: Alone among major industrial countries, the United States will continue to grow markedly in population during the next half century, a result of the largest intake of immigrants anywhere and a higher fertility rate than that of other rich nations, says a United Nations analysis to be published Wednesday.

title: AT&T Raises $3.6 Billion To Cut Its Debt
description: Furthering its effort to reduce debt, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would sell some cable television systems in the United States and its stake in Japan Telecom for a total of $3.6 billion.

title: What, Son? He's Got A Picture of Bette Midler?
description: Let's get the obligatory condemnations out of the way right off the bat: ''Some of My Best Friends,'' a sitcom that arrives tonight on CBS, is shameless in its use of hoary stereotypes. It brazenly reduces gay people, Italian people, Asian people and aging married people to caricatures in the interests of good ratings and corporate profits.

title: Fassel's Latest Guarantee: Four More Years
description: Only three months ago, Jim Fassel's Giants were stumbling from consecutive lopsided losses at home, Fassel's future with the team was in jeopardy and his profile in the New York market and the pro football community could not have been more indistinct.

title: Article 2001022890174752917 -- No Title
description: February 28, 2001

title: Bush Promises Colombia Help on Trade but Refuses Peace Role
description: In his first meeting with President Andrs Pastrana of Colombia, President Bush agreed today to press for expanding trade preferences to Colombia, but refused a request to take part in peace talks with leftist guerrillas, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, ZELDA
description: HOROWITZ-Zelda. Loving, caring, beautiful friend will be greatly missed. Deepest sympathy to her family and to Fred. Selma and Marty Rosen

title: Execute Terrorists at Our Own Risk
description: As a nation, we have decided that terrorism that results in loss of life should face the possibility of the death penalty. But is this wise?

title: Verdict for Former Deputy Divides an Oregon County
description: The way Carl Bell told it to a federal jury, racial jokes -- and ''bizarre forms'' of racial profiling -- were common at the Clackamas County Sheriff's Department.

title: High School Dropout Rate Rises, and Levy Fears New Test Will Bring Huge Surge
description: New York City's high school dropout rate has risen by two percentage points for the second year in a row, prompting education officials to ask whether higher promotion and graduation standards are driving students out of the system.

title: In an Old Apothecary, a Cure for the Common Trattoria
description: WHEN I visit a restaurant for the first time, I almost always enter believing I'm going to enjoy my meal. But once in a while I sense that a place is going to be special, and that's how I felt about Locanda Vini & Olii, a mom-and-pop trattoria that opened a month ago in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

title: A Confused Mankind Converses With Angels
description: As part of his Sacred Music in a Sacred Space series at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Kent Tritle is undertaking an exploration of the French choral and organ literature that is planned to cover several seasons. He has edged into this overview by way of Belgium, through the music of Franck, who was born in Lige in 1822 but who did his greatest work in Paris, where he died in 1890, having taken French citizenship nearly 20 years earlier.

title: Corrections
description: An article, a picture caption and a listing last Wednesday about wine classes in New York misstated the name of one organization that offers them. It is the Neighborhood Tasting Society, not the Neighborhood Wine Society.

title: How Staunch Republicans Became a Dictator's Pals
description: NAPOLEON AND HIS COLLABORATORS

title: Russian's Tip in 1990's Failed to Lead to F.B.I. Spy, Officials Say
description: A Russian intelligence source warned the United States in the mid-1990's that Moscow had a spy inside the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but investigators were unable to track the lead to Robert Philip Hanssen, the F.B.I. agent who was arrested on Feb. 18 on espionage charges, intelligence and law enforcement officials said today.

title: Bill Clinton, for Better or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Earnings Decline 3.1% at Federated Stores
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 3.1 percent because of higher costs and a loss at the catalog and Internet division.

title: For One Church, Divine Intervention Isn't Enough
description: God, it is said, is in the details. But he is also in the bottom line. No one knows this better than those who have dedicated their lives to the business of faith.

title: Accord for Hyundai Engineering
description: Hyundai Engineering and Construction, the largest of South Korea's huge, debt-plagued construction companies, got a fresh reprieve today when its lead creditor, the Korea Exchange Bank, promised to guarantee $400 million in loans for overseas projects.

title: Nader and the 'Bad Guys'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLBERT, ANN
description: COLBERT-Ann. Died peacefully on February 25, having recently reached the age of 95; mourned by her family, daughter Vera Chimene, son-in-law Lucian Chimene, grandson Claude Chimene and granddaughter Alyda Brunt and two great grandchildren, Steven and Allegra, all of Texas. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, February 28 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Metropolitan Opera for the Young Artist Development Program, Lincoln Center, New York City 10023.

title: Bill Clinton, for Better or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Israel's strict controls on Palestinians on United States economic development projects misstated the surname of the spokesman for the American Embassay in Tel Aviv, who urged Israel to end its economic pressure. He is Larry Schwartz, not Shartz.

title: E-Business
description: Big companies that once invested heavily in the Internet to help keep up are now counting on its efficiencies to help weather the slowdown.

title: U.S. Admiral Delivers Apology to the Japanese in Sub Sinking
description: In the latest attempt to soothe Japanese feelings over the accidental sinking of a fishery school ship by an American submarine off Hawaii this month, the Navy's second-ranking officer delivered a letter of apology on Tuesday from President Bush to Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori. And today he met with family members of the nine people lost in the disaster.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GLOBAL PAYMENT TECHNOLOGIES INC., Hauppauge, N.Y., a leading manufacturer of currency acceptance systems, authorized the repurchase of up to 300,000 shares of common stock.

title: Why Purchasing Agents Turned Out to Be Hard to Herd
description: EARLY last year, when the consumer Internet companies started their death march, investors turned their attention to the business-to-business Internet sector, hoping to find the true promised land of the new economy.

title: Metro Business Briefing; AGENT ACCUSED IN FRAUD
description: The Hollywood agent Rick Yorn improperly received hundreds of thousands of dollars from Dana C. Giacchetto, who is now serving five years in prison for investment fraud, according to a lawsuit filed Thursday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. The lawsuit was filed by a court-appointed trustee, Robert L. Geltzer, who is trying to recover some of the millions of dollars lost by clients of Mr. Giacchetto's bankrupt investment firm, the Cassandra Group. Mr. Giacchetto was known as the investment adviser to the stars. The lawsuit complains that in September 1999 Mr. Yorn received a check for more than $737,000 from Mr. Giacchetto. Though the check indicated it was repayment for an investment, there is no evidence that Mr. Yorn made such an investment, the lawsuit says. A spokesman for Mr. Yorn said he could not be reached for comment. Leslie Eaton

title: Board of Education Votes, 7-0, To Revamp Bilingual Programs
description: The Board of Education voted unanimously yesterday to overhaul the system's 26-year-old bilingual education program, giving parents of children who speak little English the right to move them into a range of new classes that emphasize instruction in English rather than in native languages.

title: HUNT OIL PURCHASES NATURAL GAS PROSPECTS IN ALBERTA
description: The Hunt Oil Company agreed to buy natural gas-producing properties in Alberta from Canadian 88 Energy for 176 million Canadian dollars ($115.3 million) to increase production. Hunt, based in Dallas, gets the right to explore for gas on 460,000 acres in the Rocky Mountain foothills in southwestern Alberta. Hunt agreed to buy the 50 percent it did not own of a gas field near Caroline, Alberta, and a 90 percent stake in a field near Waterton, Alberta.

title: Block Is Ordered to Stop Advertising 'Rapid Refunds' of Taxes
description: A federal judge has ordered H&R Block, the nation's largest income-tax preparation company, to stop using the phrase ''rapid refund'' and other terms that he said were deliberately intended to disguise expensive loans that Block arranges for people anticipating refunds on their income taxes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the declining share of income paid in taxes by the wealthiest Americans misstated the share of all federal income taxes paid by the top 1 percent of taxpayers in 1998. It was 34.75 percent; 18.5 percent was their share of total individual income.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our new governing vision says that government should be active, but limited; engaged, but not overbearing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUPT, EDWARD JOSEPH
description: HAUPT-Edward Joseph. Died on February 21, 2001, in his sleep from complications related to pancreatic cancer. Born December 28, 1936, Bronx, NY, survived by three sons, Carl, Marcus, and Jeremy, and one grandson, Ryan, also born on December 28, 1999. New York State Regents Scholar, BA, aeronautical engineering, University of Minnesota, 1958, Ph.D., psychology, NYU, 1969, Professor of Psychology, Montclair State University, thirty years, Assistant Professor of Opthalmology, New Jersey School of Medicine and Dentistry, fifteen years. Author of numerous publications on experimental psychology, the history of psychology, and the psychology of vision. His latest work was on Georg Muller, one of the founders of experimental psychology. Always active in civil rights, he is remembered fondly by his family, friends, and colleagues, including those at The American Psychological Association, of which he was a member for thirty years. Services are on Saturday, March 3rd, at 11 AM at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, 158 Vreeland Ave., Nutley, New Jersey 07110. Flowers should be sent to the church. Donations should be made in his name to The American Cancer Society.

title: OBITUARY : Edwinston Robbins, 96, Airman
description: PARIS (IHT)  Edwinston Robbins, 96, who retired as a colonel from the U.S. Air Force in 1957 after World War II service in Europe, Panama and the Far East, died Friday in Coatesville, Pennsylvania. From 1957 to 1969, Mr. Robbins, based in Paris, was as deputy director of Lockheed's aircraft operations in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

title: U.S. AND NATO BACK ACCESS FOR SERBIA TO KOSOVO BUFFER
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States was prepared to allow Serbian soldiers back into a three-mile-wide buffer zone along the Kosovo border, where Albanian militants have been increasingly active.

title: G.M. in Partnership to Make Cars in Russia
description: After four years of talks, General Motors has struck an agreement to manufacture automobiles in Russia.

title: Mutt and Jeff
description: Pork-rind manufacturing is a second career for Timothy Schaff, 56, who until the early 1980's was a customer service manager and field engineer for Beckman Instruments, a maker of medical testing equipment in Fullerton, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAHL, REBECCA (NEE PASTEELNICK)
description: WAHL-Rebecca (nee Pasteelnick). Beloved mother of Sally Constain. Loving grandmother of Bill and Nicole Constain. Beloved mother-in-law of Edward Constain. Loved her family, music and life. Services Thursday 12noon at ''Parkside'' Chapel, Queens Blvd & 66 Ave, Forest Hills.

title: GALLAHER'S PROFIT IS FLAT
description: With British smokers turning to bootleg cigarettes to avoid ever higher government tobacco taxes, the Gallaher Group said its overseas earnings rose by a quarter while sales in Britain remained flat. Cigarettes in Britain cost smokers about twice Continental European prices and there is a brisk trade in smuggled goods while legal sales dwindle about 10 percent a year. Gallaher, which makes Silk Cut and Benson & Hedges cigarettes and which is expanding in Russia and Austria to offset the shrinking British market, said pretax profit in the year 2000 remained virtually unchanged at $491 million, in line with expectations. Alan Cowell

title: In Touch, in the Clouds: Boon, Bane and Business Opportunity
description: GAZING at the clouds from Seat 4F aboard an Air Canada Boeing 767 somewhere over Quebec, I confront the prime existential question for the modern air traveler -- if I can't be called, can't be paged and can't check my e-mail, do I really exist?

title: Making the Leap With Mops, Flowers and Pork Rinds
description: The challenges and opportunities of electronic commerce are beginning to reach even the smallest companies, which are now going online to sell everything from janitorial supplies to tropical flowers -- or at least contemplating their first tentative steps onto the Web.

title: Beneath the Budget Are the Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Buried in President Bush's budget are proposals to cut billions of dollars' worth of corporate subsidies and other activities of the Departments of Commerce, Agriculture, Energy and Transportation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZER, HENRY
description: SELTZER-Henry. Beloved husband of Esther. Devoted brother of Lee, Frank and Estelle. Brotherin-law of Pauline. Also survived by loving nephews, nieces and sisterin-law. Service 1 PM, Thursday, March 1st, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: Former Ambassador Going to WPP Group
description: Philip Lader, the departing United States ambassador to Britain, was named nonexecutive chairman at the WPP Group in London, succeeding Hamish Maxwell, 73, who is retiring.

title: The Compleat Web Guide To Planning a Wedding (Groom Not Included)
description: MY boyfriend, Marcus, touched off a tornado when he proposed on Christmas night. First came the congratulations from family and friends, followed by a storm of questions: Had we set a date? Where would the ceremony be? How about the reception? Who would cater it? Had I chosen a dress? Who would be in the wedding party? I had barely said yes, and my head was already spinning.

title: SHOPKO WILL OFFER PAYLESS SHOES IN ITS PAMIDA STORES
description: ShopKo Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would sell Payless ShoeSource products at its Pamida discount chain, expanding a relationship that has had better-than-expected results. Payless will provide almost all of the shoes sold at Pamida stores starting in July before the back-to-school season starts. Pamida's shoe sales totaled about $20 million last year. Payless ShoeSource, based in Topeka, Kan., currently runs the shoe departments in all ShopKo stores.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARX, BENZION
description: MARX-Benzion. Dear Vati/Opaat last your name appears in the Times. Time has passed-it has been 25 years -time does not heal -you left a void, our loss is indescribable. Ruth and Leo Strauss Marta and Frank Kohner Claudia, Eric and Carlyne

title: Devils Have a Feast On Isles' Turnovers
description: The Devils, who are having a miserable time lately, took advantage of only a couple of the many mishaps by the Islanders tonight, but it was enough for the Devils to skate away with a 4-1 triumph at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Sauce Wars: The Winning Patsy Savors a Victory
description: AND in this corner, weighing in at 220 pounds, his snowy chef's jacket a treacherously snug fit due to daily infusions of pasta from his family's famous kitchen, is Salvatore J. Scognamillo, the undisputed winner -- unless his beaten challenger drags its recently resolved federal trademark case into appellate court -- of the Patsy's sauce and Sinatra wars.

title: Nighttime Is a Good Time to Save Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, HELEN S.
description: STONE-Helen S. On February 26, 2001, in her 94th year. Beloved sister of the late Lucille Salomon. Devoted aunt of Ellen S. Gutenstein and Charles S. Salomon. Loving great aunt of Michael, Lisa and Howard. Adored great great aunt of Bess, Jenna, Emily, Laura, Emma, Sam, and Hannah. Services Wednesday, February 28, 11:30 AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIANPIANO, BANAITIS, ANGELA M.
description: PIANPIANO-BANAITIS-Angela M. on February 27, 2001. Beloved wife of Jerome, loving mother of KerryAnn, Christopher and Douglas Michael. Dear daughter of Rina Pianpiano and fond sister of Cherie Tokwaulu. Reposing Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Ave (corner Lefferts Blvd), Richmond Hill. Mass of Christian burial, Saturday 9:45AM, St. Joseph Labre R.C. Church. Interment to follow Fair Ridge Cemetery, Chappaqua, NY. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday, 2:30 to 5, and 7 to 9:30PM.

title: No. 2 Admiral Meets With Families of Sub Victims
description: TOKYO, Feb. 28 -- The United States Navy's second highest ranking officer met today with the relatives of nine missing victims of a submarine accident earlier this month that sunk a Japanese fishery school ship off Hawaii.

title: Easy-Drinking Young Riojas
description: IN the last two decades, half a dozen or so little-known Spanish wine regions have stepped confidently into the modern age, producing exciting wines that have captured worldwide attention. Meanwhile, Spain's most famous region, Rioja, has gotten short shrift, as if its wines were pass or no longer worthy of notice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  THALER, DANIELLE
description: THALER-Danielle. 1965-1999. My love for you has taught me to love life. Miss you. Peter, Hanna and Logan

title: Medical Research Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney to Take 50% Stake in US Weekly Magazine
description: Wenner Media's US Weekly, considered by many to have had a troubled transformation from a monthly magazine over the last year, is getting some much-needed help from the Walt Disney Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LEO H., M.D.
description: BERMAN-Leo H., M.D. Members of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis join in the expression of sorrow for the sudden death of a dear colleague and a ''psychoanalyst for all seasons''. Ian Alger, M.D. Myron L. Glucksman, M.D. George Nicklin, M.D. Samuel Slipp, M.D. Matthew A. Tolchin, M.D.

title: Reckonings; Debt and Taxes
description: You're a middle-aged couple, at the peak of your earning power. You are saving in preparation for your retirement, a little more than 10 years from now. You consider paying off your mortgage early. But the bank informs you that you would face prepayment penalties. Do you (a) stick with your plan to prepare for retirement, but buy stocks and bonds instead of paying off your mortgage, or (b) say, ''Oh, in that case let's forget about the future and take an expensive vacation''?

title: His Dubya and My R
description: I want to thank you, Dubya. I'm grateful to you for restoring respect for the middle initial. When the president holds up three fingers to form a W or refers to himself as ''George W.,'' he warms the hearts of those of us who insist on the use of our middle initials.

title: Our Towns; Town Wants To Pass Up This Honor
description: JAMES E. McGREEVEY nearly ousted Gov. Christie Whitman, a Republican, four years ago, and now he is aiming to replace her successor, Acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco, also a Republican.

title: New Administration Worries Some E-Rate Proponents
description: Advocates for the E-rate, a program that subsidizes Internet connections for the country's schools and libraries, are worried that President George W. Bush's proposal to consolidate federal education technology programs into a single block grant could stifle its success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEFF, LORD MARCUS JOSEPH
description: SIEFF-Lord Marcus Joseph. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourns the passing of Lord Marcus Joseph Sieff, Chancellor and Chairman Emeritus of the Weizmann Institute of Science Board of Governors. Throughout his life, Lord Sieff was deeply involved in Weizmann, promoting its mission of science research for the benefit of humanity. The Daniel Sieff Research Institute was established in Israel in 1934 by the Seiff family in memory of Lord Marcus's younger brother. The Sieff Institute grew into the Weizmann Institute. A constant source of inspiration, Lord Sieff believed passionately in strengthening Israel through science, technology and economic growth. He was a tireless philanthrophic leader, whose efforts touched the lives of countless individuals. We express our deepest sympathy to the Sieff family. Robert H. Asher, Chairman American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin Kraar, Exec. V.P. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President

title: Metro Business Briefing; MAYOR SEEKS TRADE CENTER TAX
description: Vornado Realty Trust must pay the World Trade Center's full $100 million tax bill to New York City should it succeed in leasing the complex, or face a court battle with the city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey tentatively agreed last week to lease the trade center for 99 years to Vornado for $3.25 billion. The authority now gives the city a payment in lieu of taxes -- $29 million last year. There is not a formal agreement with the city on any new tax rate. Under the lease, Vornado would become responsible for the existing payment in lieu of taxes and the authority would pay any increase resulting from a new arrangement with the city.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the resignation of William D. Powers as chairman of the New York State Republican Party misstated the performance of the party's candidate for governor, Pierre A. Rinfret, in 1990. He came in second, after the Democratic incumbent, Mario M. Cuomo; Mr. Rinfret did not also trail Herbert London, the Conservative Party candidate.

title: Ewing's Night, Ewing's Crowd
description: They rose with a roar last night when he jogged onto the court, his shoulders bobbing , his expression typically stoic. They interrupted the national anthem to let him know that they loved him, cheering boisterously and calling him ''the Man.'' And they continued to stand and applaud for three minutes after the Knicks offered a video montage to pay tribute to one of the greatest players ever to wear their colors.

title: THE BOSS; I Have the I.Q. for Retail
description: I've had two strange job interviews, the first with Charles Lazarus, founder of Toys ''R'' Us.

title: Seeking to Tie Conspiracy to Embassy Attacks
description: It was one week after the American Embassy in Kenya had been bombed. A suspect named Mohammed Saddiq Odeh was taken to Nairobi police headquarters, where he was interviewed by the Kenyan and American authorities.

title: Relying on the SAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Is the Love? It's at the Garden
description: From every corner of Madison Square Garden signs dangled from the rafters and unfurled from the hands of children and old-timers. There was none of the anticipated mixed reaction in the messages; each one lamented his departure or begged for his return.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar fell as a weaker-than-forecast consumer confidence report underscored slowing economic growth in the United States. In New York, the euro settled at 91.71 cents, up from 91.21 cents on Monday.

title: Bush's Plans for the Pentagon Include Base Closings and Money for Missile Defenses
description: President Bush's budget plan will include more than $1 billion in new spending for research on national missile defense, administration officials said today.

title: Jets' Presidency Going to Cross, Stadium Expert
description: The executive brought in to develop a new Jets stadium will be the team's new president.

title: Response From the Democrats
