description: Following are excerpts from the response to President Bush's first joint address to Congress last night as delivered by the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle, and the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt.

title: Fast, Faster, Fastest at N.F.L. Combine
description: They differed on the depth of this year's pool. Their concerns ranged from marginal to major over several players' decisions to postpone their workouts. But this was the common thread among National Football League executives who studied last weekend's scouting combine of 327 college players in Indianapolis none had never seen a faster group from top to bottom.

title: Flavors' Little Helpers
description: VERY few ingredients -- bacon, dried mushrooms and anchovies come to mind -- make everything they touch taste better. I'd like to add dried shrimp to this short list of natural flavor enhancers.

title: Guy Wood; Composer, 89
description: Guy Wood, a songwriter whose works include ''Till Then,'' ''My One and Only Love'' and ''Shoo-Fly Pie and Apple Pan Dowdy,'' died on Friday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 89.

title: A Classic French Partnership
description: BEURRE noisette, the nutty-tasting browned butter sauce, fell out of favor in all those years when butter was viewed as a heart attack in a saut pan. But there's a reason it has been indispensable in French kitchens for centuries. It couldn't be faster, simpler or more satisfying.

title: Trade Protesters Repelled
description: The police beat back protesters today as they tried to march on a meeting of the World Economic Forum here.

title: National News Briefs
description: Puerto Ricans Seek End to Bombing on Vieques

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZZI, BENEDICT
description: RIZZI-Benedict. The officers, board memebers and staff of the Institute for Music and Neurologic Function join in extending our deepest sympathy to Maxine Chrein upon the loss of her beloved husband Benedict Rizzi. As a founding member of the Institute's board in 1995 and its chairman until 2000, Ben was a generous champion of our music/brain research. Henriette M. Kole, President Institute for Music and Neurologic Function-The Beth Abraham Family of Health Services

title: Sylvia Lawry Is Dead at 85; Led Multiple Sclerosis Fight
description: Sylvia Lawry, whose brother's incurable multiple sclerosis prompted her to found national and international organizations to fight the disease, died on Saturday at Bird S. Coler Hospital on Roosevelt Island. She was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Thomas Tells White Sox He's Sorry
description: Eager to shed his new national image as ''a poster boy of greed'' as quickly as he earned it, Frank Thomas apologized profusely today for his public stance that painted him as a wealthy player complaining about not making enough money.

title: E.P.A.'s Right to Set Air Rules Wins Supreme Court Backing
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously and decisively rejected an industry attack on the Clean Air Act in one of the court's most important environmental rulings in years.

title: Copying the Best Schools, Verbatim
description: Alisa Berger was studying English as a senior at Barnard College the first time she set foot inside Mott Hall in West Harlem. She spent a year at the middle school as a student teacher, then three more as a full-time teacher, marveling as poor children from Hispanic immigrant families posted top reading and math scores and went off to selective places like Stuyvesant and Andover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, HELEN LOUISE ''SIS.''
description: HARRIS-Helen Louise ''Sis.'' Age 80, on February 26, 2001. Loving mother of Bette Ann and Walter, devoted grandmother of Kate and Jenny. Died after a long illness in Mamaroneck, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in Sis's memory to the Graduate Programs in Physical Therapy, MGH Institute of Health Professions, 101 Merrimac St., Boston, MA 02114. Services Wednesday 2:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSCOVITZ, HOWARD, MD.
description: MOSCOVITZ-Howard, MD. The Jewish Home and Hospital medical department and entire staff mourn the loss of Howard Moscovitz, MD, Chief of Cardiology for more than 35 years. ''Howie'' was a friend to many, an outstanding surgeon and clinician who shared his positiveness with all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEASON, CHARLES L., JR.
description: GLEASON-Charles L., Jr. 82. Of Vero Beach, FL, and Stinson Lake, NH. Died January 30, 2001, after a brief illness. He served in the U.S. Army as a Medical Administrative Officer in World War II, and during The Korean War. He graduated from The University of Massachusetts and received an MBA from Columbia University. After working at General Electric, he was employed by Time, Inc., for 33 years where he was Vice President and Director of Personnel. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Martha, and four children, Charles III, of Glen Cove, NY, David, of Vallejo, CA, Gail Beamer, of Boston, MA, and Scot, of NYC.

title: Judy, Judy, Judy
description: Just when it appeared that the network television movie might be an extinct species, ABC gave the genre new life this week with the first part of a two-part biography of Judy Garland.

title: Putting 401(k)'s Online: Add Choice, Save Trees
description: TO broaden retirement benefits for his 125 employees, John Maultsby Jr., the president of Florida Plywood Inc. in Greenwood, Fla., began offering a 401(k) plan in 1999. Employee payroll deductions were partly matched by the company, and employees could invest among eight mutual funds managed by First Union Bank of Charlotte, N.C.

title: Article 2001022890443199882 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: CBS Official Says Clinton Didn't Sway His Decision
description: The president of CBS Television, Leslie Moonves, said yesterday that he received a phone call about six months ago from President Clinton, who asked him to ''be nice'' to Mr. Clinton's friend, the Hollywood producer Harry Thomason, who was owed money by the network.

title: Odd Mix of Partisanship And Building of Bridges
description: From the moment he entered the House chamber, embracing Democratic Congresswomen as he made his way to the rostrum, to his pledge to end racial profiling, President Bush tailored much of his first major presidential address to please his Democratic Congressional adversaries.

title: Bush, Spelling Out Agenda to Congress, Makes Tax Cut the Centerpiece of Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  President Bush turned full force to the difficult task of selling the Congress and the country on his legislative agenda tonight, using a nationally televised address from the House chamber to cast his proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut as reasonable and responsible.

title: Impressed and Blessed With His Attorney Bernie
description: The songwriter Dave Frishberg is like a brilliant, sarcastic college professor who is loath to lower his intellectual guard. But when he relents and allows a hard-boiled sentimentality to peek through his misanthropic facade, you have a sense of diamond rays of sun leaking through the clouds on a steel-gray afternoon.

title: A Simple Equation for the Financial District
description: In its first bid for success, Bayard's took a gamble. That's what everyone else does in the financial district, after all. It hired a young Belgian chef, Luc Dendievel, who offered this restaurant-starved neighborhood some genuine excitement, with food that leapt far beyond chops and grilled fish.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Face-Off, or Cosmetic Boycott

title: FLOOD CLAIMS HURT INSURER
description: Britain's largest insurer, CGNU P.L.C., said claims from the country's worst floods in decades and earlier floods in France would cost it 285 million ($412 million), adding to online investment costs that pushed down profits. The British floods damaged at least 5,000 properties late last year, presenting insurers with a claims bill of about $750 million. Nevertheless, CGNU, formed from the 7.5 billion merger of CGU P.L.C. and Norwich Union P.L.C., beat analysts' forecasts for the full year 2000, reporting operating profit of 1.4 billion ($2.03 billion). Richard Harvey, above, will replace Bob Scott as chairman of CGNU in April. Alan Cowell

title: Bush Underlines Pledge About Social Security
description: President Bush made good tonight on his campaign promise to push for the creation of personal investment accounts within Social Security, telling Congress that encouraging workers to buy stocks and bonds is the best way to deal with the looming financial strains on the retirement system.

title: Metro Business Briefing; HIGH-TECH HELICOPTER
description: Executives at WPIX, New York's WB affiliate, said yesterday that they had the nation's first news helicopter fully equipped with digital technology that will allow them to transmit a clear and stable picture from remote locations, solving a problem that has bedeviled area stations. Executives at WPIX, which is owned by the Tribune Company, said the helicopter could send signals to the station from as far away as Montauk, Poughkeepsie, Atlantic City and the Poconos. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Commercial Real Estate; A Plaza Few Use But Everyone Wants
description: Apartment dwellers need open space. Investment banks need trading space. And in Lower Manhattan, where every inch is precious, the two needs are colliding over an elevated one-acre public plaza at 55 Water Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADITSA, LEO FERRERO
description: RADITSA-Leo Ferrero. Died unexpectedly on February 22nd. at the age of sixty-four, in Annapolis, Maryland. A devoted teacher at St. John's College, he was an ancient historian, and an essayist on contemporary politics, psychiatry, literature and art. He was an accomplished painter and poet, and short story writer. He will be deeply missed by his family and friends, and beloved students. He is survived by his son, Sebastian, and his sister, Bosiljka Raditsa. A Memorial Service will be held in his honor at St. John's College in Annapolis on Saturday, March 24th. at 2 P.M. A Second Memorial in New York City is being planned. In lieu of flowers, send contributions in the memory of Leo Raditsa to The St. John's Library, Attention: Jeff Bishop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, MARY L.
description: WERNER-Mary L. February 25, 2001. Of Buck Hill Falls, PA. and New York City. Beloved daughter of Lucille Werner. Memorial service Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Ave, 12N Tues., March 6. In lieu of flowers, donations to the church please.

title: Random House Sues Over Rights to Publishing E-Books
description: Opening a new battle over the ground rules of the nascent business of electronic books, the Random House division of the Bertelsmann media empire has sued a start-up, RosettaBooks, over who owns the rights to sell digital versions of previously published books.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TENBRINCK, MARGARET S., M.D.
description: TENBRINCK-Margaret S., M.D., F.A.A.P., Feb 28, 1911-Nov 16, 1998. The family of Dr. Tenbrinck wishes to pay loving tribute to her on the occasion of what would have been her 90th birthday. A graduate of Barnard with her M.S. in Chemistry and M.D. from New York University, and a Board Certified pediatrician, Dr. Tenbrinck had a lengthy and distinguished medical career in practice, teaching and industry. Among her numerous accomplishments, she became the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's first female officer, retiring in 1972 as Associate Medical Director. Relocating to Phoenix, Arizona, she became Director and pediatrician for the Child Evaluation Center, retaining her medical license up to the time of her death. Always generous with her medical skills, in 1942 Dr. Tenbrinck served as pediatrician on an expedition to Portugal to rescue European children. She devoted vacations to working at the Albert Schweitzer Hospital, Lambarene, Gabon; Hospital Amazonico A. Schweitzer, Pucallpa, Peru; U.S. Public Health Service, Whiteriver, Arizona (Apache Reservation); South Phoenix Community Center; and Spafford Children's Center, East Jerusalem. Dr. Tenbrinck lectured at international pediatric conferences and published over 22 medical papers for journals including Arizona Medicine, Journal of the American Medical Association and New York State Journal of Medicine on subjects ranging from allergy, nutrition, fetal alcohol syndrome, and statistical research to medical problems encountered at locations where she volunteered. Her many awards included the Esther Pohl Lovejoy Award for medical service abroad (1972) and the Medalie Award for distinguished alumna, Barnard College (1982). She held life memberships in the American Academy of Pediatrics, American Medical Women's Association, and International Health Society, and was Assistant Editor of the Journal of the American Medical Women's Association. Daughters Jean Daubenas and Elizabeth Dawsari, along with grandson Jamil Dawsari, son-inlaw Joseph Daubenas, and granddaughter-in-law Juliet Dawsari profoundly miss her and Eduard J. A. Tenbrinck, her husband of 65 years and our father/grandfather, who passed away October 8, 1999.

title: Court Finds Legal Restrictions on Welfare Recipients Unconstitutional
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The Supreme Court ruled today that Congress violated the First Amendment when it barred lawyers in the federally financed legal services program from going to court on behalf of their indigent clients to challenge the validity of welfare laws and regulations.

title: Theodore Lidz, Professor, 90; Studied Causes of Schizophrenia
description: Dr. Theodore Lidz, a Yale professor of psychiatry who explored the background causes of schizophrenia and specialized in the treatment of it, died Feb. 16 at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADASKO, BEULAH
description: ADASKO-Beulah. On February 26. Beloved wife for 52 years of Joseph; devoted mother of Lauren and Lee; mother-in-law of Carol and the late Fred Lercher; loving grandmother of Chase, Chelsea, Danny and Chandler. She was a devoted sister, friend and charitable person. Funeral service Wednesday, February 28, 12 noon at ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, COLETTE GAY
description: IRVING-Colette Gay. Age 80. On February 26, 2001 at home in Southampton, New York. Wife of Alexander Duer Irving II. Mother of Alexandra I. Rush, Evelyn I. Leonard and Michael D.G. Irving. Sister of Anne G. Sharretts and grandmother of six grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at noon on Saturday, March 3, 2001 at St. John's Church in Southampton, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Southampton Hospital.

title: Bill Clinton, for Better or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGANUCCI, PAUL DONNELLY
description: PAGANUCCI-Paul Donnelly. On February 26, at home in Hanover, New Hampshire, quietly after a long illness at age 69. Beloved and devoted husband of Marilyn and father to daughter Elizabeth and son Thomas. 1953 graduate of Dartmouth College, summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa, Tuck School of Business Administration (1954), and Harvard Law School (1957). Following Army service, long and illustrious business career including founder and president of Lombard, Vitalis & Paganucci, Inc., Members NYSE; executive vice president and vice chairman of W.R. Grace & Co.; founder and chairman of Ledyard National Bank; and member of numerous corporate boards. He served as chief financial officer of Dartmouth College under two Dartmouth presidents. Also served many years as trustee and chairman of investment committee of Colby College in his hometown of Waterville, ME. An exceptionally loyal, dedicated, generous and effective Dartmouth alumnus, he led and energized a broad array of existing alumni organizations and formed several others. Visiting hours are at RandWilson Funeral Home, School St., Hanover from 6:00 P.M. to 8 P.M., Thursday, March 1. Memorial services Friday, March 2 at 11 A.M. at Aquinas House on Dartmouth campus; reception following at Hopkins Center. Memorial donations may be made to Dartmouth Class of 1953 Charitable Trust, C/O Ledyard National Bank, P.O. Box 799, Hanover, N.H. 03755.

title: NBC Remains Optimistic on XFL
description: Top NBC officials yesterday supported its XFL co-venture with the World Wrestling Federation despite a free fall in its television ratings.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: LOSS WIDENS AT PRODIGY
description: The Prodigy Communications Corporation, an Internet service provider that is based in Austin, Tex., said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss more than doubled from a year earlier to $72.9 million, or $1.04 a share. The company, which revised strategic and marketing pacts with a major shareholder, SBC Communications, in January, will focus on digital subscriber line customers in the coming year. The company reported that it had 2.8 million total Internet subscribers as of the end of the quarter, 425,000 of whom receive D.S.L.-based services. Prodigy said it expected to have 3.1 million to 3.7 million subscribers by the end of the year. Andrew Zipern

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, THOMAS E.
description: CASEY-Thomas E. Of Deer Park, New York on February 24, 2001, 5 months shy of his 100th year. Born McHenry, North Dakota, July 23, 1901. Beloved husband of the late Katherine (nee Murray). Devoted father of Geraldine Kneafsey of Deer Park and John B. Casey of Stony Point, New York. Cherished grandfather of 5. Loving greatgrandfather of 11. Great great grandfather of Meghan Elaine. Visiting Mangano Funeral Home, Inc., 1701 Deer Park Ave. Deer Park, NY, today 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10:00AM, Sts. Cyril and Methodius RC Church. Interment Oakwood Cemetery, Bay Shore, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORN, RUTH
description: THORN-Ruth. Of Forest Hills, N.Y. On February 25, 2001. Age 98. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Mother of Jerry, Judith, Richard (deceased). Grandmother of Colin and Polly Samuels, Eric, Clifford and Tina Thorn. Great grandmother of Collin Thorn. Services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, N.Y. on Wednesday, February 28th. at 11:30 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNBAR, WILLIAM K. JR.
description: DUNBAR-William K. Jr., age 93, died Saturday, February 24 after a long illness. He was born in Pittsburgh, PA in 1907, moved to Plainfield, NJ in 1914 and Bay Head, NJ in 1971. He went to work for Phelps Dodge Corporation in 1930 and retired in 1967 as vice president of Phelps Dodge Industries. He is survived by his wife of 68 years Elizabeth Barlow Dunbar, a son William K. Dunbar III of Mantoloking, NJ, a daughter Anne Dunbar Yearley of Osterville, MA, seven grandchildren and 16 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 3rd at 10:30 AM at the Bay Head Chapel, Route 35, Bay Head, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to SAVE BARNEGAT BAY, 906-B Grand Central Avenue, Lavalette, New Jersey 08735.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDHOFF, ARNOLD J. M.D.
description: FRIEDHOFF-Arnold J. M.D. A dedicated pioneer in the field of biological psychiatry, prolific writer, internationally honored, the Director of The Jonas Center for the Study and Treatment of Children at Risk at NYU Medical School; but most of all, an empathic teacher and valued friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. He will be sorely missed. Barbara and Donald Jonas

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HART, JACK
description: HART-Jack. So we'll go no more a-roving. So late into the night, though the heart be still as loving, And the moon be still as bright. For the sword outwears its sheath and the soul wears out the breast, the heart must pause to breathe, and love itself must rest. Molly

title: Clinton Tells House Panel He Won't Block Aides' Testimony on Pardons
description: Former President Bill Clinton today informed the House panel investigating his last-minute pardons that he would not try to block the testimony of his top presidential aides by asserting executive privilege.

title: In 2 Pro Leagues, U.S.O.C. Drug Plan Draws Bafflement
description: The decision by the United States Olympic Committee to end the exemption that professional athletes had from random drug testing could threaten the participation of American Dream Teams in both Olympic hockey and basketball.

title: Hollywood Magic Allows Livia One Last Angry Whine
description: Livia Soprano, the malevolent and manipulative matriarch of the Soprano family, was fond of tearfully waving a wet tissue at her family and saying, in the tone of a martyr, ''I wish the Lord would take me now.'' Livia used other familiar bits of dialogue when she spoke to her gangster son, Tony, who, incidentally, she had tried to ice. She often said: ''Me? What did I do? I didn't do anything.'' Or ''Out of sight, out of mind.'' Or ''What do you care?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZABO, PAUL BEKEFFY
description: SZABO-Paul Bekeffy. Died February 24. Beloved husband of Edo Kisfaludy Szabo. Father of Peter, father-in-law of Debra and grandfather of Danielle, Christian and Katrina. Interment private. Memorial service Tuesday, March 6th, 11 AM at St. Steven of Hungary Church, 414 E. 82nd Street, betwn 1st and York Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Paul Bekeffy Szabo's name may be made to Capistran Youth Foundation Inc., P.O. Box 6050 Yorkville Station, New York, N.Y. 10128.

title: Bill Clinton, for Better or Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: A Short Shopping List
description: President Bush's budget speech, with its emphasis on his tax cut, education proposals and debt reduction plan, reflected both his campaign and his record as governor of Texas, but it was more narrowly focused than most presidents have chosen to be in their first nationally televised address to Congress.

title: FOR THE NETS, ROAD TRIPS ARE NO FUN
description: The Nets had two times as many home games as road games in February and they took advantage of such comforts. Because the team won six of its eight games at Continental Arena, including victories over the playoff-bound clubs Philadelphia, San Antonio and Toronto, the Nets (20-38) cannot finish any worse than .500 for this shortened month, the first time they accomplished that all season.

title: Aterkek Alecha
description: Adapted from Ghenet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSESS, STANLEY
description: POSESS-Stanley. Our dear friend for so many years, we will truly miss you. Our heartfelt condolences to Rose, David and Nina. Ana Maria, Mal and Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLIN, SEYMOUR
description: COLIN-Seymour. On February 25, 2001. Beloved husband of Sue, dear brother of Edna, step-father of Mark Shyman and uncle of Jim, Edward and Susan. Funeral Services Wed., 11:45 at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PROMOTIONS AT R.E.I.T.
description: S L Green Realty Corporation said yesterday that it had promoted Marc Holliday, chief investment officer, to the additional post of president, effective at the end of March, and named Michael Reid chief operating officer. Mr. Reid had been a managing director in the global real estate department at Lehman Brothers. Both Mr. Holliday and Mr. Reid succeed David J. Nettina, who resigned from the posts of president and chief operating officer. S L Green Realty, a real estate investment trust, owns and manages commercial office properties in Manhattan and has ownership interests in 25 buildings comprising more than 10 million square feet.

title: Bush Sends Congress Outline of Budget Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  President Bush today proposed a $1.96 trillion federal budget for next year that would cut taxes, reduce the national debt and make room for increased spending on education, medical research and the military by cutting road building, community health care, corporate subsidies and a host of other programs.

title: Democrats Cite Deficit Fears in Opposing Bush's Tax Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  The Democratic leaders of Congress signaled their determination today to wage a muscular battle against President Bush's centerpiece $1.6 trillion tax cut, charging that it could imperil the future health of Social Security and Medicare and lead the nation back to an era of deficits.

title: Former Cendant Executives Charged With Fraud
description: Walter A. Forbes, who built a small company into the giant Cendant Corporation, was an active participant in a fraud that resulted in the company reporting more than $500 million in phony profits, the government charged today. The case is the largest accounting fraud ever, with investors having lost $19 billion.

title: When California Lights Dim; Utilities' Turmoil Also Hits Program That Aids Concerns Owned by Women And Minorities
description: For years, the engineering company that Oscar Ocampo helped to found has benefited from a California program that pushed private utilities to increase contracts with minority- and women-owned businesses.

title: Mr. Bush's Budget Strategy
description: In his poised, focused and warmly received address to Congress last night, President Bush presented a vision of government as ''active but limited, engaged but not overbearing.'' It was a polished debut, with some eloquent flourishes that showcased Mr. Bush's likability, self-confidence and, above all, his determination to move beyond the Republicans' reflexive anti-government ideology. Especially noteworthy was Mr. Bush's call for an end to racial profiling by the police. He also spoke fervently of schools that reach ''every child in America,'' another of his many gestures to Democrats, minorities and others still skeptical of his mandate. He outlined a creative path between ''those who want more government regardless of the cost'' and ''those who want less government, regardless of the need.''

title: Now That We're Still Here, Where Do We Go? 7 Answers
description: HUNDREDS of millions of people surf the Web, hundreds of billions of dollars of stock market value have come and gone, and yet the burning questions posed by the Internet have cycled back to the same ones asked five years ago, when people first started to size up the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARPIN, GERARD ''TODD''
description: ARPIN-Gerard ''Todd''. Our magnificent, beloved friend died February 26, 2001, age 52, of Cancer. A great artist, Todd was extraordinarily skilled in many forms of painting, and his work enhanced and beautified many city and country homes. Many of his clients became his close friends. He loved life, laughed much and made the world a much better and more beautiful place. We extend our deepest sympathy to his dear friend and companion, Brando.

title: Solid Year for Spain's Top Phone Company
description: Telefnica, the dominant telephone company in Spain, said its profits rose 39 percent in 2000 because of a surge in wireless phone use in its home market and booming growth at its Brazilian units.

title: A lighthearted campaign for an Internet service gives data a wry, sometimes cheeky personality.
description: THE theme of a surprisingly wry campaign for an Internet services company could be summarized -- with apologies to Cole Porter -- by altering one of his song titles to declare ''My Heart Belongs to Data.''

title: I Know You, You Know Me, Let's Sell Goods Online Privately
description: A FEW years ago, Neil S. Novich, the chairman and chief executive of Ryerson Tull, was lamenting the torrents of paperwork in the offices of this Chicago company, a metals processor and distributor. There had to be a better way, Mr. Novich said. Faxes, order sheets and paper were everywhere.

title: Clinton Aides to Testify
description: Former President Bill Clinton told the House panel investigating his pardons that he would not block the testimony of his former aides by asserting executive privilege. The decision allows three advisers to testify at a hearing tomorrow.

title: Excerpts From Second Day of Arguments in Appeal of the Antitrust Case
description: Following are excerpts from oral arguments today in the Microsoft antitrust case before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House Inc. Representing Microsoft were Richard J. Urowsky and Steven L. Holley; John G. Roberts Jr. argued for the state attorneys general who have sued Microsoft along with the Justice Department.

description: HELLER-Anne Cohen. Died Saturday, February 24, 2001, at home in Manhattan. She was 81. A physician known professionaly as Dr. Anne C. Carter, she was a lifelong resident of the city and Bedford, NY, and was predeceased by her husband, William B. Heller. She is survived by her children, James A. and Susan K. Heller of New York City, a daughter-in-law, Pamela, and two grandchildren, William B. II and Susan C. Heller. Calling hours will be from 6-8 PM, Tuesday, February 27, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave. at 81st St. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Chapel at 11:30 AM on Wednesday, February 28. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Dana Hall School, 45 Dana Road, Wellesley, MA 02481 or Wellesley College, 106 Central Street, Wellesley, MA 02481.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVERITT, ANNE ELIZABETH
description: EVERITT-Anne Elizabeth. Of Heritage Hills, Somers, NY, formerly of New York City. Died on February 25, 2001. A graveside service will be held in Pine Grove Cemetery, Falmouth Foreside, Maine, on March 2. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Nature Conservancy or The Humane Society would be appreciated.

title: Poll Watch: Environment Ahead of Energy
description: Americans continue to put environmental concerns ahead of energy matters, even though California is in the midst of an energy crisis and most Americans have had to endure higher energy costs this winter. There is, however, some support for increasing energy production, according recent polls conducted nationally and in California.

title: Sports of The Times; Homecoming Raises Issue Of Next Year
description: HE was next-to-last out of the runway, onto the Madison Square Garden court, on what some people called Patrick Ewing's homecoming night. Yet for all the subsequent cheers, the powerful three-minute ovation to which he appreciatively raised his arms, there was no getting past the fact that the Garden wasn't home anymore.

title: After Ads That $houted, Dot-Com Survivors Try Quieter, Cheaper Spots
description: A YEAR ago, Internet companies flooded the airwaves with advertising messages that were often humorous and sometimes outrageous. But in a diminished technology market where many of those companies have closed or at least scaled back, the dot-com advertising landscape has taken on a new look.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, BOBBIE (BERTHA)
description: DAVIDSON-Bobbie (Bertha) on February 26, 2001. A woman of valor. Predeceased by her lifelong love and husband Harry and by their beloved daughter Penny Esther Spiegel. Bobbie blessed the lives of her grandchildren and great-grandchildren, her sister and brothers, and her friends with unconditional love. She will always be remembered for the wisdom, humor, dignity and humility, kindness and respect that she bestowed on all who knew her. Graveside services today at 11:15 at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Weinstein, Garlick, Kirschenbaum Directors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, DOROTHY
description: ROBBINS-Dorothy. On February 27, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Allan. Loving mother of Susan (Jacob) and Nancy (Michel). Devoted grandmother of Simon (Elizabeth) and Amy. Service Thursday, 11:30AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to The Alzheimers Association or a charity of your choice.

description: New in Midtown

title: Burundi City Sees 4th Day Of Fighting With Rebels
description: Fighting in Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi, flared for a fourth day today as the military worked to push rebel forces from suburbs of the city, which was blistered by the heaviest clashes in months.

title: Putting Younger Workers to Shame
description: HUBERT GREEN -- he'd like you to call him Hubie -- is 84 years old and has been an air-conditioning engineer since the end of World War II. That is longer than he ever thought he would work. It's certainly longer than anyone around him has worked, and although he has fleeting thoughts of retirement, he does not know how to make a decision that final.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil dropped on expectations that inventories have rebounded from their lowest level in 27 years. In New York, crude oil for April delivery fell 29 cents, or 1 percent, to $28.13 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRAIL, KEFELI, JEAN
description: McGRAIL - KEFELI - Jean. Died peacefully in her sleep February 23, 2001 in her Manhattan apartment. Her sister-in-law, cousins, nephews and nieces and their children survive her. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend visiting hours on Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, 10 AM, at St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 E. 55th St., NYC. Interment will be in a family plot in Strewsbury, MA, Saturday. In lieu of flowers, donations preferred to St. John the Evangelist Church. For further information, contact 212-744-3084.

title: Passenger Train Crash in Britain Kills 13
description: LONDON, Feb. 28  In another of the devastating incidents that have plagued Britain's railways, 13 people were killed and 70 injured early today when a high-speed London-bound passenger train hit a car stalled on the mainline track and then collided with a fully-loaded freight train coming from the opposite direction.

title: THE WEB IN TOUGHER TIMES; Life After Dot-Death For a Pair Of Content Providers
description: WRITERS are as plentiful in New York City as starlets are in Hollywood. Like a mass casting call, the dot-com boom offered writers unprecedented job opportunities, with the prospect of higher wages than print media, I.P.O. riches and endless demand for content.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend on Friday about world music misstated the site of the March 9 opening of a two-day ethnomusicology conference. It is to be at the Graduate Center, City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue (34th Street) -- not at New York University. (The March 10 session will be held at N.Y.U., in Room 703 of 33 Washington Place.)

title: Transcript of President Bush's Message to Congress on His Budget Proposal
description: Following is a transcript of President George W. Bush's message to Congress last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: From the Volcano, The Rarest Brew
description: AS you drive south along the west coast of the Big Island, you can't help smelling the coffee roasting. With that, and the slopes of Mauna Loa on your left, bathed in the sumptuous sunlight of a Hawaiian morning, and the whales cavorting in the blue Pacific on your right, who needs roses?

title: Iraqi, Ending U.N. Talks, Dismisses Powell Pledge as a Ploy
description: As the United States tries to revitalize a common front on Iraq in the Security Council, an Iraqi delegation ended two days of talks here today with little to show but their determination to stay in the game as events move around them.

title: Ovation Provides A Warm Welcome
description: The white Mercedes pulled up the ramp at 5:54 last night. On the Eighth Avenue side of the arena, Patrick Ewing left his keys with a team attendant and made his way toward the visiting locker room at Madison Square Garden for the first time in his professional career.

title: Michelin Demotes Ducasse, Again
description: FOR the second time, Alain Ducasse's restaurant in Monte Carlo, Louis XV, has lost one of its three Michelin stars. The latest downgrading is in the red Michelin guide for 2001, containing hotel and restaurant ratings, which goes on sale on Friday. But the guide retains the top rating of three stars for his Restaurant Alain Ducasse in Paris. It moved last fall from the Htel du Parc to the Plaza Athne.

title: Ann Colbert; Musicians' Manager, 95
description: Ann Colbert, the founder of Colbert Artists Management Inc., which manages the careers of classical musicians, died on Sunday. She was 95 and lived in Manhattan.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Technology Shares Tumble To Lowest Close Since '98
description: Technology stocks fell sharply yesterday, pulling the Nasdaq composite index down more than 4 percent to its lowest close since the end of 1998, after more sour economic reports failed to prompt the immediate cut in interest rates that much of Wall Street had come to expect.

title: BOND BUYER AND AMERICAN BANKER TO BE SOLD
description: The Thomson Corporation, the publisher of The Bond Buyer and American Banker, said yesterday that it was selling those newspapers and other publications to focus on delivering financial information electronically. The chief executive of Thomson Financial, Patrick Tierney, said all its publications and services in the banking, insurance and investment marketing group would be sold, except Wiesenberger, an electronic fund-tracking service based in Rockville, Md. The company is shifting to electronic delivery of financial, legal and educational material and is cutting its dependence on regional markets. American Banker has a circulation of 14,500 and The Bond Buyer has 40,000 readers daily, the company said. The businesses for sale have about $250 million in annual revenue, Mr. Tierney said. Analysts said the publications might bring $400 million to $700 million.

title: Nuclear Power Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Is Seeking a Few More Touches
description: Marcus Camby never quite comes out and says that he wants the ball. He just alludes to it subtly in comments concerning other matters.

title: Beijing, Turning Tables, Defends Its Repression of Sect
description: The Chinese government lashed out today in frustration against critics of its harsh crackdown on the Falun Gong spiritual movement, making strenuous new efforts to paint the group as evil and murderous, and accusing the United States and other critics of harboring ''ulterior motives.''

title: Westchester Wants Albany to Act on Drivers' Use of Hand-Held Phones
description: In joining a growing movement to bar the use of hand-held cell phones while driving, Westchester County legislators say they want to send a message not only to drivers, but also to the state: pass a statewide ban.

title: A Victory for Cleaner Air
description: To the delight of environmentalists and the dismay of several industries, the Supreme Court unanimously reaffirmed the bedrock principles of the Clean Air Act yesterday, as well as the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to enforce that act with detailed regulations. The decision vindicated the clean air strategy devised by the outgoing E.P.A. administrator, Carol Browner, and challenged her successor, Christie Whitman, to move forward with a program to achieve the clean air targets set by Ms. Browner.

title: NEW BIDDER FOR FLETCHER
description: A group led by the investment company Guinness Peat Group said it planned to offer cash and shares worth $1.7 billion to buy Fletcher Energy, New Zealand's biggest oil company. The bid would top one made by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and, if successful, would be a blow to the expansion plans of Shell, which is trying to build its natural gas business in the Asia-Pacific region. The Guinness group, which includes the Greymouth Petroleum Mining Company, would pay at least $3.70 a share in cash, compared with Shell's $3.34.

title: Allied Waste Profit Is Up
description: Allied Waste Industries, a leading trash hauler, said its fourth-quarter profit rose 22 percent because of price increases, the consolidation of its businesses and cost-cutting. Profit from operations rose to $41.7 million, or 22 cents a share, from $34.1 million, or 18 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales were little changed at $1.39 million. Analysts had expected the company to earn 21 cents a share. Allied Waste had a charge of $23.1 million, or 12 cents a share, from acquisition costs, resulting in net income of $18.6 million, or 10 cents a share, compared with $14.4 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: General Powell in the Middle East
description: Colin Powell made a deft diplomatic debut on his just-completed six-nation trip to the Mideast, his first overseas journey as secretary of state. He listened attentively to regional leaders, built Arab support for a plan to refine and reinvigorate sanctions against Iraq, and even won a promise from Syria's truculent president, Bashar al-Assad, to send revenues from a recently reopened oil pipeline to an internationally monitored account instead of letting them go to Saddam Hussein.

title: 3 New Reports Show Evidence Of Weakness In the Economy
description: As the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, prepared to testify before Congress today about the nation's economy, three reports offered new, if murky, evidence yesterday of economic weakness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDZ, THEODORE, M.D.
description: LIDZ-Theodore, M.D. The Western New England Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourn the death of our beloved colleague, teacher and friend, Dr. Theodore Lidz on Friday, February 16, 2001. Lynn Reiser, M.D., Pres., WNEIP E. Kirsten Dahl, Ph.D., President, WNEPS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, WILLIE
description: KLEIN-Willie. The Officers and Trustees of The New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a Member of The New Sports Hall of Fame on February 26, 2001, in Edison, NJ. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: Experiment in Assisted Living Exposes Regulatory Confusion
description: For a glimpse of where the assisted living industry in New York may be headed, take a look inside three upstate homes for the aged operated by the biggest company in the business.

description: Adapted from Caffe Adulis

title: National News Briefs; Federal Observers Watch Primary in Illinois Town
description: Voters who went to the polls under the supervision of federal observers chose the leading Democratic candidate for president of the Town Board in today's primary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, DOUGLAS
description: SHERMAN-Douglas. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Mordecai Waxman, Rabbi George N. Abrahams, President

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: AGENT ACCUSED IN FRAUD

title: Technology Briefing
description: E-COMMERCE ALLSTATE PLANS ONLINE SALES The No. 1 auto insurer, State Farm , tried it. Now, No. 2, Allstate , is having a go at selling policies through one of the first online markets for insurance, a California site called InsWeb . And this time, analysts say that they think the chances for success are good. "State Farm couldn't make money with InsWeb," said Todd Eyler, a senior analyst at Forrester Research , "but Allstate's agents are much more Internet friendly and enabled." InsWeb distinguishes itself by providing customers with comparative prices for insurance from several companies. But customers who wanted to buy from State Farm had to contact the insurer and then wait, often to no avail, for an agent to reply by telephone or an e-mail message. Allstate says that it will send a quote via an e-mail message within 30 seconds, along with a toll-free phone number to call to complete the purchase of a policy. Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: A Handyman Is Shot at Work, or Was He?
description: Early one Saturday morning nine years ago, Frank Rick was shot in an apartment building in the Crown Heights section of New York where he worked as a maintenance man. The bullet smashed the bone of his right arm and severed a nerve; his two teenage assailants also pistol-whipped him, breaking his nose, and shot a tenant who came out of his apartment to help. The attackers were never caught.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about the Israeli Labor Party's vote to join the government misstated the number of party members who voted to accept Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon's offer to share power. Fewer than half the 1,700 members of the party's governing body voted; and of those who did, about two-thirds  not two-thirds of the entire governing body  voted to accept.

title: CALENDAR
description: French Culinary History

title: Deal Reached to Acquire Land for The Times's Headquarters
description: The New York Times Company and a developer have negotiated the major terms of an agreement with city and state officials to acquire land for the newspaper's new headquarters in the Times Square area and to give the company millions of dollars in tax breaks.

title: At Long Last, New York Is Ready for Ethiopia
description: THE brick and ocher walls glowed softly in the low lights, the place was packed with a good-looking crowd, and the chef was making the rounds, kissing familiar faces and asking if everybody was happy. But nobody at this new restaurant was praising the foie gras or the tuna steak. Here at Queen of Sheba, which opened just a week ago in Clinton, the crowd had turned out for fine Ethiopian fare: beef and lamb stews flavored with a rousing dark-red hot sauce, and wonderful vegetarian dishes seasoned with complex spice blends, all eaten not with forks but with pieces of injera, a spongy flat bread with the enticing flavor of sourdough.
